column2: Two defense lawyers cross-examined John Lautner yesterday in the trial of sixteen secondary Communist party leaders, charged with conspiring to advocate and teach the overthrow of the Government of the United States by force and violence.

John F. Froehlich Jr., a 45-year-old potato farmer of Hicksville, L. I., who was sentenced on April 29 to a year and a day for income tax evasion, was released yesterday from the Federal Penitentiary at Danbury, Conn., after Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo in Brooklyn Federal Court granted an application for a reduction in sentence.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 12 -- Dean Wesley A. Sturges of the Yale Law School announced today the names of law school students who won prizes for outstanding work during the year. All of the prize winners received degrees at commencement exercises Monday.

BERLIN, June 12 -- Unless the Soviet Union agrees to truly free elections and the establishment of a real democracy in all Germany -- something Moscow is highly unlikely to agree to -- the situation in Berlin can only get worse.

RYE, N. Y., June 12 -- Mrs. Russell Holman of Innis Arden and Mrs. Allison Choate, the home-club champion, leaders yesterday with 78, posted a 38, 37 -- 75 at the Apawamis Club today to win the four-ball best-ball event of the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association with 153.

The National Displaced Persons program is not only an unqualified success, but an important factor in the mutual defense of a free world, welfare officials declared last night at a dinner to Louis L. Bennett, retiring executive director of the New York Association for New Americans.

Dresser Industries, Inc., oil, gas and chemical equipment manufacturer, lifted sales for the second quarter of its fiscal year to a new record and has an order backlog that will keep company plants busy for many months, H. N. Mallon, president, reported yesterday.

The Newark chapter of the American Red Cross reported yesterday that it had received 1,090 pints of blood including the seventh day of an eight-day mass donation said to be the largest in the history of the state organization. The donations were made at the Weston Electrical Instrument Corporation.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- An Administration plan for the Government to lease submerged oil lands in the Gulf of Mexico by having them declared "surplus property" has been abandoned, Oscar L. Chapman, Secretary of the Interior, told the Senate Judiciary Committee today. Mr. Chapman added that President Truman had agreed.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- The controversial St. Lawrence Seaway and Power bill reached the Senate floor today amid indications that it might he talked to death.

HANOVER, N. H., June 12 -- Charles J. Zimmerman of Hartford, Conn., has been elected an alumni trustee of Dartmouth College, it was announced tonight after the annual meeting of the Alumni Council. He was elected by the board of trustees to succeed Nelson A. Rockefeller of New York, who had served two terms and was not eligible for re-election.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 12 -- The first strike in the 66-year-old history of Johnson Johnson, surgical dressings manufacturer, ended today when 1,400 workers affiliated with Local 630, Textile Workers Union of America, C. I. O., voted to accept a wage increase of about 6 cents an hour. The strike began June 4.
Many neckties will be Bought today and tomorrow for Father's Day, but the harassed shopper may be grateful for more imaginative suggestions.

The notion that "the minister is a man in a white robe who is ready to marry any and all who come to him" should be a thing of the past, the Rev. Worcester Perkins, rector of the Church of the Holy Communion, 47 West Twentieth Street, asserts.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The Department of Defense prepared today to organize an inquiry by neutral nations into the United Nations handling of Communist prisoners on Koje Island.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The Government and the Dollar interests settled their seven-year fight today for control of the shipping empire established by the late Capt. Robert Dollar.

Reversing a seven-week downtrend, business loans from New York banks rose $36,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday. The rise, according to data issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, brought the reduction in business loans since the first of this year to $423,000,000, against an expansion of $390,000,000 in the similar period a year ago.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- Glenn McCarthy, Inc., a new corporation headed by the Texas oil man and builder of the Shamrock Hotel at Houston, proposed to the Securities and Exchange Commission today a 20 million dollar stock issue to finance oil prospecting, development and operations.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (UP) -- An advisory committee of seven was named today in a Senate investigation of government news policies. The appointments were by Senator Blair Moody, Democrat of Michigan, chairman of the Senate anti-censorship subcommittee.

KOJE ISLAND, Korea, Friday, June 13 -- Two tough prisoner stockades holding an important group of Communist captives on this prison island offered no resistance today when Brig. Gen. Haydon L. Boatner, island commander, gave them his latest ultimatums to pack up and shift quarters.

Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., manager of the Eisenhower-for-President campaign, accused those backing Senator Robert A. Taft yesterday of employing "shyster methods" in an effort to turn the Republican National Convention into a "kangaroo court."
Baltimore County, Md., borrowed $11,500,000 yesterday in the market on an issue of bonds due from 1955 to 1992 at an interest cost of 2.2789 per cent.

The New York Association of Day Nurseries, Inc., a federation of thirty voluntary agencies caring for 1,500 children, will cease operations on Sunday. The nurseries themselves will continue without the association, which is a standards-setting advisory group.

The Uniformed Firemen's Association, A. F. L., has collected the signatures of 10,000 citizens so far in its campaign against the proposed elimination of fifty-two fire companies. James F. Chambers, business secretary of the union, said yesterday that the association had been circulating the petitions for two months and would keep at it probably for another three months.

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, June 13 (AP) -- United States Forty-fifth Division troops inflicted heavy casualties last night and early today in a raging see-saw battle with Chinese Communist troops for a hill position on the western front. The battle has become one of the most hard fought since last November.

SINGAPORE, June 11 -- The feeling here against the United States over this year's sharp decline in rubber prices is showing signs of receding. The fact that supply and demand factors, rather than United States Government policies, were mainly responsible for Malaya's huge drop in earnings from rubber, appears to be getting somewhat wider recognition.

HONG KONG, June 12 -- Millions of peasants have been mobilized throughout China proper for the "central task" of combating a widespread locust plague. According to domestic Communist reports, peasants in parts of Honan Province have been hauling in locusts by the ton while others in rice-rich Hunan have pronounced the pestilence the worst in thirty years.

Directors of the Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago approved yesterday the initial step in the utility's projected $300,000,000 financing program for expansion. The company, one of the largest independent operating electric and gas utilities in the United States, plans to file next week with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $40,000,000 of first mortgage bonds.

THE fly fishermen should find most of the Catskill and many of the Adirondack streams in better condition this weekend than they have been all season, and as the weather man can find no "fronts" moving this way the outlook is bright.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., June 12 (UP) -- Military prisoners at the Camp Pendleton Marine Corps training base staged an hour-long free-for-all riot last Tuesday, a military spokesman said today:
The conflict between the increased cost of hotel operation and the higher cost of living for hotel workers was recorded yesterday at a hearing before the state Hotel Minimum Wage Board.
NEW DELHI, India, June 12 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru said today he wished all Asian nations would openly declare that they would not enter a war whatever happened.

POCOMOKE CITY, Md., June 12 (AP) -- Mrs. Ernest Schultz, librarian at the Bordentown Military Institute in New Jersey, won the chicken cooking championship here yesterday with an "old fashioned roast chicken."

It was to be expected that Gilbert Miller would not forgo the opportunity of buying something for Broadway during his European sojourn. What he purchased was a provocative play by Marcel Ayme called "Head of the Others" ("La Tete des Autres'), a robust success that has been running in Paris since February.

Deadlocked for five-hours last night in contesting the sixth game of their match at the Manhattan Chess Club, Samuel Reshevsky of New York and Svetozar Gligoric of Belgrade took another adjournment in an even position after forty-five moves had been recorded.

JACKSON, Miss., June 12 (UP) -- The names of leaders of the States' Rights-dominated Mississippi Democratic party have been stricken from the roster of officials for the national convention, Mrs. John Clark, national committeewoman announced here today.
MANCHESTER, N. H., June 12 (AP) -- Roger L. Putnam, Economic Stabilizer, said last night that New Englanders should stop moaning about their losses to Southern mills.

A complaint charging violation of regulations of the Office of Price Stabilization in over-ceiling sales of used machine tools was filed yesterday by United States Attorney Myles J. Lane against the Universal Brass Turning Company, 912 Courtland Avenue, Bronx.

LAKE MAHOPAC, N. Y., June 12 -- Arrangements were made today for the funeral tomorrow of Betty June Arnold, 9 years old, who was fatally stabbed yesterday by an escaped convict trying to evade capture here.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The basic economic controls sought by the Truman Administration to run the defense effort were granted by the Senate today as it approved an extension of the Defense Production Act by a 58-to-18 vote.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson summoned the British and French Ambassadors to his office today for an urgent unity meeting of the Western Big Three on ways to answer last month's note from the Soviet Union on German unification.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The Government of South Korea suspended broadcasts of the Voice of America over the Government radio today. The action drew an immediate protest from the State Department.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., June 12 -- New York City took its case for increased state financial assistance today to the State Conference of Mayors, introducing a "package" of five resolutions calling for more state aid and broadened local taxing powers.

Sugar futures on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange firmed up yesterday following reports from Cuba that President Batista intended to keep almost 20 per cent of the island's sugar crop off' the market this year and cut production next year nearly one-third. Cuba's sugar crop for this year is estimated at 6,900,000 Spanish long tons. The Spanish long ton is 2,271 pounds.

ANNISTON, Ala., June 12 -- Ralph J. Cordiner, president of the General Electric Company, announced tonight that within the next two years the Southeastern area will become a major center of the company's operations, with more than 13,000 employes and a $50,000,000 annual payroll.

Local 11 of the Hotel and Restaurant Employes International Union, A. F. L., threatened yesterday to strike, beginning possibly today, against thirty-four Schrafft restaurants and the company commissary.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The slate of thirty-eight Texas Republican delegates predominantly favoring General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower as Presidential nominee has filed with the Republican National Committee notice of contest of the validity of a rival slate favoring Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio.

Millions of victims of Hansen's disease (leprosy) are receiving no care or medical treatment although the cheapest of the new sulfone drugs can effect a cure or major improvement for most of them at a cost of only $2.50 a patient year, Bishop Fulton J. Sheen said yesterday.

BERLIN, June 12 -- West Berlin's second Annual Film Festival opened tonight with the showing of United Artists' "The Well" and the awarding of the David O. Selznick prize for the best German film of the year to a film story of an abortive European peace movement sponsored by Bertha Suttner just before the first World War.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- The House approved today the decision of its Armed Services Committee in selecting the old Plattsburg, N. Y., barracks as the site of a $36,261,000 Air Force bomber base.

PARIS, June 12 -- A semi-official statement today, twenty-for hours after the French Cabinet's decision to propose a four-power conference on Germany, said that the decision referred to a meeting not of the foreign ministers but of their deputies.

PUSAN, Friday, June 13 (AP) -- The Voice of America's three daily broadcasts over the ten-station Korean Government network have carried excerpts from United States and foreign newspapers attacking President Rhee.

LOS ANGELES, June 12 -- The Government reactivated today its "airlift" deportation system in an effort to reduce the tide of Mexican "wetback" workers. These border-jumpers pour into the Southwest at an estimated rate of more than 1,000,000 a year.

A humorous little old lady, contentedly knitting a hideous yellow scarf, was depicted yesterday as one of the thousands of persons served by the 423 agencies that receive support from the Greater New York Fund.

Borough President James A. Lundy of Queens jolted his colleagues on the Board of Estimate yesterday when he "served notice" that he was making an inquiry into the allegedly "excessive" $11,523,034 cost of the recently completed Kissena Corridor sewer in Queens.

PUSAN, Friday, June 13 (AP) -- The Voice of America's three daily broadcasts over the ten-station Korean Government network have carried excerpts from United States and foreign newspapers attacking President Rhee.

LOS ANGELES, June 12 -- The Government reactivated today its "airlift" deportation system in an effort to reduce the tide of Mexican "wetback" workers. These border-jumpers pour into the Southwest at an estimated rate of more than 1,000,000 a year.

A humorous little old lady, contentedly knitting a hideous yellow scarf, was depicted yesterday as one of the thousands of persons served by the 423 agencies that receive support from the Greater New York Fund.

Borough President James A. Lundy of Queens jolted his colleagues on the Board of Estimate yesterday when he "served notice" that he was making an inquiry into the allegedly "excessive" $11,523,034 cost of the recently completed Kissena Corridor sewer in Queens.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- If the "keynote" at the Republican National Convention in Chicago next month pursues the theme of those now in control of the party machinery -- that everything must be done to discourage Democrats who are ready for political conversion -- Shakespeare furnishes a pattern for parody in the speech of Henry V to his vastly outnumbered force before Agincourt on St. Crispin's Day, Oct. 24, 1415. For instance:

Shortages of skilled factory workers, technicians and professional employes in New York companies and those within 300 miles of the city have increased considerably in the last year. This was reported yesterday by the New York Classified Advertising Managers Association, which predicted that the situation probably would grow more acute in the next six months.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 12 -- G. Albert Hill, State Highway Commissioner, announced today the five-mile route of the proposed Fairfield County Thruway through the town of Fairfield. The section will cost $12,300,000 and will displace 309 families and some commercial establishments.

New Jersey delegates and alternates to the Republican National Convention met yesterday with Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio and General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, the chief contenders for the Presidential nomination, but it was regarded as unlikely that the visits had changed the delegates' strong pro-Eisenhower sympathies.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (UP) -- John Gates former editor of The Daily Worker, said today that the Communist party in this country would "never go underground of its own accord" but was being driven there by the Government.

Gerard W. Purcell, who pleaded guilty Wednesday to theft of funds of the Uniformed Firemen's Association, was granted permission to go anywhere he wishes so long as he informs the District Attorney's office, it was decided yesterday after a conference in the chambers of Judge Jonah J. Goldstein.

LONDON, June 12 -- The British Labor Party, in a statement on foreign policy issued today, called for delay in the ratification of the Bonn and Paris agreements on West Germany and pledged itself to strive for the admission of Communist China to the United Nations if the Laborites return to power.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (UP) -- The Federal Maritime Board agreed today to consider "new evidence" in a squabble over subsidies for two American Export Line passenger ships.
Following is the text of questions and Senator Taft's replies after his address at the National Republican Club:

BUFFALO, June 12 -- Dr. Maurice Eisendrath, president of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, the parent body embracing some 450 reform synagogues in this country and Canada, in a speech here tonight criticized the charge that "America is grossly materialistic and that ours is a cynical and irreligious generation."

PARIS, June 12 -- Rene Pleven, French Minister of Defense, told the National Assembly today he hoped the North Atlantic Treaty Organization would establish a three-year balanced program for rearmament so that it would no longer be necessary to negotiate every year for United States aid and to make short-term plans in consequence.

The stock market attempted yesterday to extend its gains made on Wednesday, but profit taking prevented, and prices closed at about the previous day's final levels. Changes in quotations covered a fairly wide range during the day, but at the finish there were few of an exaggerated nature and the composite average was up 0.05 point.

BECKENHAM, England, June 12 -- While Dorothy Head of Alameda, Calif., and Don Candy of Australia were reaching the semi-finals of the Kent championships in the only singles matches played today, the Wightman Cup teams of British and American women were going through their last workouts for tomorrow's opening of the international match at Wimbledon.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- President Truman said today that he would not exercise his authority as Commander in Chief to compel General of the Army Douglas MacArthur to retire before he served as keynoter of the Republican National Convention July 7.

TOKYO, Friday, June 13 -- Maj. Gen. William K. Harrison Jr., senior United Nations representative at the Korean truce talks, told the Communists at Panmunjom yesterday to look for no more concessions from the Allied command.

STANTON, Del., June 12 (AP) -- E. B. Schley's Fracas and John M. Schiff's Montadet, an entry trained by Oleg T. Dubassoff, today finished one, two in the $13,450 Tom Roby Steeplechase Stakes, first jumping contest of the Delaware Park meeting.

WALTHAM, Mass., June 12 -- Brandeis University, which will have its first graduation ceremony next Monday, is youthful enough to think big. To signalize its first commencement it is presenting a festival of the creative arts here on its campus.

With June 15 upon us, thoughts of householders turn to income-tax installments, and then inevitably one is once again trying to balance the domestic budget. Though many of us may have a sneaking suspicion it just cannot be done, we would rather be hopeful than not.

A show of paintings, sculpture, designs for fabric and costume and various crafts by junior and senior high school students over the country opened here yesterday with a party preview for the young artists, their friends and families.

BOERNE, Tex., June 12 (UP) -- A Mexican diplomat to whom service was refused in a cafe here said today he would protest "a direct insult to the Mexican Government" to Washington, Mexico City and the Governor of Texas. Consul General Cosme Hinojosa said he and two companions were refused service by the cafe owner, Charles O. Grimsley, yesterday because of their race.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- The Indians blasted Frank Shea for six runs today in a third inning that featured Pete Reiser's three-run pinch homer and went on to defeat the Senators 7 -- 4.
TOKYO, Friday, June 13 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,279, for Thursday's operations:

BOSTON, June 12 (UP) -- Marty Marion was indefinitely suspended as manager of the Browns for having pushed an umpire last night and Bill Veeck, president of the club, said that he would protest today's 7-5 loss to the Red Sox.

WORTHING, England, June 13 (UP) -- Antonio Cerda of Argentina and Harry Weetman, British match play champion, tied for first place in the 1,350 ($3,780) Spalding golf tournament today with 271's for the seventy-two holes.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 13 (AP) -- The twenty-two-vote Arkansas delegation to the Democratic National Convention was instructed today to back Senator J. William Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas, for the party's Presidential nomination.

The city completed yesterday the purchase of the uptown campus of Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart by paying $8,800,620 for the eighteen-and-a-half-acre plant. The property, which extends from 130th to 135th Street and from Convent Avenue to St. Nicholas Terrace, adjoins the City College campus, and will be used to expand the facilities of that institution.
TOKYO, Saturday, June 14 (AP) -United Nations Command communique 1,280, for Friday:

Representatives of forty East and Gulf steamship operators and three maritime unions agreed yesterday to submit the salary demands of the unions to arbitration. Maurice J. Tobin, Secretary of Labor, will be asked to name the arbitrator, an employer spokesman said last night.

The election of Elton W. Clark as a director and a member of the executive committee of the Hanover Fire Insurance Company was announced yesterday. He is vice president, treasurer and a director of Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation.

JACKSON, Miss., June 13 (UP) -- Plans for a possible States' Rights protest convention in Chicago immediately after the Democratic National Convention if the national nominee and platform were not acceptable to the group were reported here today.
MOSCOW, June 13 -- Dr. Albert Einstein's theory of relativity was attacked today by a leading Soviet scientific spokesman as the "cul de sac" of contemporary physics.

PITTSBURGH, June 13 -- The leaders of 600,000 striking steel workers vowed tonight that they would "never surrender" in their fight for a contract based on the recommendations of the Wage Stabilization Board.
Six thousand drivers for eleven major metropolitan bakeries will receive wage increases of $6 a week under the terms of an arbitration award made public yesterday.

BECKENHAM, England, June 13 (AP) -- Ham Richardson, the traveling tennis youngster from Baton Rouge, La., scored the upset of the English grass court season today by defeating Eric Sturgess, the South African No. 1, in the semi-final round of the Kent championships.
Military civic and patriotic organizations will participate in Flag Day ceremonies today in observance of the 175th anniversary of the adoption of the Stars and Stripes by the Continental Congress.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., June 13 (AP) -- Notre Dame today attacked the National Collegiate A. A. 1952 controlled football television program as illegal and unfair. In a letter to Walter Byers, N. C. A. A. executive director, the Rev. John J. Cavanaugh, C. S. C., president of the football-famed school, listed seven reasons why Notre Dame voted against the TV gridiron plan for next fall.

An underwriting syndicate with "good spirit and the will to do" is likely to end successfully while a similar syndicate with more knowledge and resources but with a "lackadaisical" spirit may be unsuccessful, Harold L. Stuart, president of Halsey Stuart Co., Inc., said in Federal Court yesterday.

VIENNA, June 13 -- A report of the Austrian Audit Office charged today that Austria's two big nationalized banks, the Creditanstalt and the Laenderbank, had diverted dollar exchange to their foreign affiliates instead of using it to increase Austria's hard currency holdings.

Retailers will be permitted by the Office of Price Stabilization on Monday to increase prices of a wide variety of consumer items, Leo J. Heer, vice president of the National Retail Furniture Association, revealed yesterday. But, he said, increases to the consumer from stores which take advantage of the new price relief will be negligible.

SEOUL, Korea, June 13 -- Every major problem of war and peace in Korea was under discussion here tonight at a secret meeting of the top Allied military and armistice officials, called for the benefit of a British group headed by Field Marshal Earl Alexander of Tunis, Minister of Defense.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Average primary market prices advanced 0.2 per cent in the week ended on Tuesday to 111.7 per cent of the 1947-49 average, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index was 2.9 per cent below the average for January, 1951.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- President Truman, stepping into a second fight in the House of Representatives -- due Monday -- over proposed increases by at least $5 monthly in Social Security payments to about 4,500,000 old-age and survivor beneficiaries, put the blame publicly tonight on Republicans for the defeat of the program on its first test.

The death of Michael Cardinal von Faulhaber, Archbishop of Munich and Freising, carries the memory back to the darkest days of nazism. When most German voices were stilled Cardinal von Faulhaber spoke his opposition to Hitler from the pulpit of St. Michael's in Munich, denouncing the atrocities committed against the Jews and upholding the doctrine that "not blood but faith is the foundation of religion."

An important railroad merger may be in the offing. According to reports in the financial community, an official of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway has discussed informally with some large holders of preferred and common stock of the Central of Georgia Railway the possibility of acquiring their shares.

Record sales of $5 and $10 automobile use tax stamps at City Collector's offices throughout the city yesterday increased to an indicated $6,321,380 the total funds taken in from this source since June 2. The city's minimum advance estimate of the annual yield of this tax was $6,000,000.

LONDON, June 13 (AP) -- Andrei A. Gromyko, a thick-set man trained since his youth for his career in the iron-willed Soviet school of diplomacy has been No. 2 man in the Soviet Foreign Office for just a little more than three years.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- High United States military authorities appealed today for quick Senate ratification of the Bonn peace contract with the Western Allies and the change in the North Atlantic Treaty to bring West Germany into its orbit.
The Third Marine Division that recaptured Guam and fought through to victory at Bougainville in the South Pacific in World War II has begun the reactivation of the Third Marine Division Association.
LONDON, June 13 -- Weakness of sterling, coupled with the Government's warnings on long and hard tasks facing Britain, put the stock markets in a dull mood today.

The Zionist Organization of America opened its fifty-fifth annual convention yesterday at the Statler Hotel, the 2,000 delegates facing several complex issues including the organization's role in the American Jewish community and its relationship to Israel.

Discretionary spending power of nonagricultural consumers is $79,600,000,000 a year, according to a study issued yesterday by Macfadden Publications, Inc. With the figure for 1939 equaling 100, the company's index for such spending power stood at 355 for wage earner families and at 187 for all nonagricultural families in the first quarter of this year.

Some months ago many of us looked upon Senator Taft as a candidate who if not necessarily our first choice for President we would certainly have no objection to voting for if nominated by the Republican party.

The responsibility for the physical soundness of longshoremen and harbor workers should be placed at the door of the unions which "insist upon deciding who may work and who shall stay idle," George W. Morgan, president of the Association of American Ship Owners, declared yesterday.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J., June 13 -- The women's New Jersey team retained the Golf Illustrated Trophy by defeating Westchester, 24 to 6, and Long Island, 20 1/2 to 9 1/2, for a grand total of 44 1/2 points, over the Upper Montclair course today.
The Southern California Composite Squad captured the women's team crown as the eight-day national championships opened at the Fencers Club yesterday with a record entry.
MONTREAL, June 13 (AP) -- The International Civil Aviation Organization has rejected a proposal that its headquarters be moved from this city.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Roman E. Shvetz of New York has united a rocking chair and a music box in an arrangement protected by Patent 2,599,948, issued this week. "The use of music boxes on rocking chairs and the like has soothing and/or entertainment values," he comments, "but requires a simple, effective and durable clutch connection for general use.
WASHINGTON, June 13 (UP) -- The Government moved today to end the practice of private promoters who have been selling Federal oil and gas leases on land where there isn't any oil or gas.

Commodity futures on the local exchanges were mixed yesterday in generally slow trading. Hides, tin, cottonseed oil and cocoa were higher, while wool and wool tops and coffee were lower. The soybean oil, sugar and rubber markets were mixed.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 13 -- Connecticut Democrats opened their two-day state convention tonight by listening to a plea from Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota to join in a liberal coalition against "conservative or reactionary opposition, whether it be of the Dixiecrat or the Republican variety."

A first-grade fireman, Louis Teitelbaum, was dismissed from the Fire Department yesterday by Commissioner Jacob Grumet for "shaking down" merchants on East Fifty-seventh Street. Teitelbaum was charged with having falsely represented that he was collecting money for the Firemen's Welfare Fund and for a non-existent Firemen's Christmas Fund.
Young and old citizen's of the lower East Side joined forces yesterday in marking the fiftieth anniversary of Hamilton House at 72 Market Street.
NEWARK, June 13 -- The largest slum clearance and redevelopment project in New Jersey, costing an estimated $40,000,000, is scheduled for final consideration by the City Commission here on June 25.

President Truman was not in a fighting mood during his speech at the Howard University commencement yesterday. He repeated his belief that some sort of federal legislation is necessary to guarantee equal rights to all our people in all our states. But he could and did report some encouraging developments that have taken place without such legislation.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- The Office of Price Stabilization has decided on a 3.84 cents-a-pound increase for copper and brass products, because of the higher cost of foreign copper. An O. P. S. spokesman, reporting this today, said the new regulation probably will be issued early next week, to become effective July 1.

WALTHAM, Mass., June 13 -- Leonard Bernstein , describes "Trouble in Tahiti," which had its premiere at Brandeis Unversity here last night, as "a little opera in seven scenes." The piece takes a shade over thirty-five minutes to perform and has enough wit and charm to make for pleasant listening.
A seemingly simple question on cookery, posed recently by a reader in Dover, Del., required rather extensive checking with home economists before a satisfactory answer could be found.
DALLAS, June 13 -- A 69 that enabled him to tie the thirty-six-hole record of 138 in the tourney was Ben Hogan's contribution today in his quest for his fourth United States open golf crown.

Mrs. Dorothy Smith Reidy, widow of Assemblyman William N. Reidy, who died on May 30 at his home, 34 Mada Avenue, West Brighton, S. I., was designated by the Democratic County Committee of Richmond last night to succeed him in the State Legislature.

TOKYO, Saturday, June 14 -- United Nations delegates at Panmunjom told the Communists today that they would "never" make a substantial change in their formal proposals for settlement of the remaining issues in the path of a Korean armistice, but stood ready to "explain and clarify" the Allied plan.

NEWARK, June 13 -- Ferdinand Eberstadt, a New York investment banker and an alumnus of the class of 1912, received a gold medal and a citation scroll from Newark Academy at a dinner in the Essex House tonight. The award initiated an annual presentation for distinguished service in the recipient's field of endeavor.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 13 -- The United States Government's Information and Education Section in Belgrade was attacked bitterly today on the front page of the newspaper Politika for having distributed booklets containing information hostile to the Yugoslav Government and its leaders.

BOSTON, June 13 (AP) -- Bob Rush totaled 11 strikeouts tonight while pitching his ninth victory for the Cubs with a 5-0 shutout of the Braves and a three-hit performance. Chicago wrapped up the game in the opening inning, tallying four times against Vern Bickford by bunching three hits with two bases on balls.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (UP) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, said today that officials of the General Electric Company would be called before his Senate Labor subcommittee to answer charges that a "small group of profit-blinded business executives" encouraged a Communist-dominated union.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., June 13 -- The William Henry Beers Memorial Trophy, named for the late editor of Golf Illustrated, was captured by Joseph Comber of Clearview at the Ardsley Country Club today. First to tee off in the field of ninety and first to post his score, the Long Island player won the twenty-fourth staging of the Metropolitan Golf Association event with a low net of 92 -- 22 -- 70.
George R. Barlow has purchased a new ranch dwelling at 14 Reynal Crossing, Scarsdale, from Manuel deSilva, builder, through Prince Ripley, Inc., brokers.

DETROIT, June 13 (AP) -- Senator James H. Duff, Republican of Pennsylvania, today accused backers of Senator Taft of using "corrupt methods" in seeking the Republican Presidential nomination in an attack heralding General Eisenhower's Flag Day visit here tomorrow.

Jaun Lautner, a Communist party member for twenty years, completed his fourth week of testimony yesterday in the trial of sixteen secondary Communist party officials accused of conspiring to advocate and teach the overthrow of the Government of the United States by force and violence.

CALGARY, June 13 (Canadian Press) -- A wildcat well in the Williston Basin area of south-central Saskatchewan has struck oil in the Mississippian formation. Indications are that it may prove to be Saskatchewan's first commercial light crude oil well.

NEW DELHI, India,June 13 -- Governments may change but people rarely do. In its suspicion and distrust of foreigners, including Russians and fellow Asians, the China of Mao Tse-tung is little different from the China of Chiang Kai-shek.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 13 -The Hayes Fair Acres Stable's Dudley Hanover, a 5-year-old chestnut horse by Billy Direct-Vivian Hanover from Du Quoin, Ill., with Benny Schue in the sulky, scored a length victory over Prince Jay in the third renewal of the Benjamin W. Downing Memorial mile-and-a-half pacing stake in 3:06.1 at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

THERE are bigger fish in the sea, and some of them will be grabbing up baits and lures during the coming season, so the International Game Fish Association was thoughtful in publishing its 1952 Yearbook in time to give salt-water anglers some marks at which to shoot.

The one-story industrial building occupied by the R. Hoe Co., manufacturer of printing presses and heavy industrial equipment, at 173 Locust Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the Cranley Realty Corporation, Edward Schwartz, president, to the Summit Holding Company.

WASHlNGTON, June 13 -- The United States Lines will not renegotiate its contract to purchase the new passenger liner United States and will expect the ship to be delivered next Friday for the agreed price of $28,087,000, officials of the line declared at a news conference here today.
FRANKFORT, Germany, June 13 (AP) -- A Finnish attempt to bring East and West German sports leaders together for the formation of an all-German team for the Olympics at Helsinki failed today.

The scheduled airlines that made scores of daily flighs out of Newark Airport befort it was closed by the Port of New York Authority reported yesterday that they had not yet made plans to resume operations at the field, although it will be available for limited commercial flights on Monday.

Permit me to add heartiest congTatulations for your editorial protesting the roughshod tactics of the Taft group. Appointing General -VIacArthur keynoter of tile Republican convention is a cynicism hardly to be iguored brought about as it was by carryovers who are in temporary authority by no' popular choice---lame ducks whose wings have not been properly clipped.

NEWARK, June 13 -- Wallace S. DePuy, former first assistant prosecutor in Bergen County, who pleaded guilty May 19 to three counts of failing to file income-tax returns, was sentenced today to serve one year in prison.

NEW CASTLE, Del., June l3 -Conflicting claims of the strength of Senator Robert A. Taft and General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower in Delaware's twelve-vote delegation to the Republican National Convention were voiced this afternoon by leaders of the state's rival factions.

The New York chapter of the Red Cross reported yesterday that it collected 1,287 pints of blood on Thursday through its main centers and nine bloodmobiles. The largest donation, 185 pints, was made at the Manhattan center, 70 West Fortieth Street.

From New York to Oregon, final report cards have been coming in this month at almost every home where school-age children live. Some of them are plain and simple, bearing marks such as 65 or 80 or C or B or F: others are more complex with comments on attitudes, work habits, social graces and the like.

The Normro Realty Corporation has sold the four-story building containing six stores and twenty-eight apartments at 95-13 to 95-19 Northern Boulevard, Jackson Heights, Queens, to the Regal Realty Company. Hamerschlag Realty was the broker. The property, on a plot 80 by 100 feet, was sold for cash above mortgages of $70,000.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 13 -- By moving faster and making a higher bid, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has cornered the film rights to Louise Baker's new novel, "Snips and Snails." Metro reportedly submitted a check for $35,000 and worked out a deal with the author to write the screen version as well, which will increase the value of the sale for Miss Baker.

CHICAGO, June 13 (UP) -- Mrs. Camille de Rose, former owner of a suburban Cicero apartment building where a race riot occurred last summer, was disarmed in court today and sentenced to two years for contempt.

Albert Selden, who together with Baldwin Bergersen provided the music for "Small Wonder," the revue that made a favorable impression hereabouts in 1948, has acquired an option on a new comedy called "The Grey Eyed People,'' written by John Hess.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- Grains had a strong price trend today except for early setbacks in rye. The basis for buying of wheat, corn and oats apparently was the dry weather and high temperatures that have prevailed for several days in the Great Plains Belt from the Canadian line into western Kansas and northern Texas.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Proponents of the St. Lawrence Seaway and Power Project spent four hours today urging the Senate to approve the United States-Canadian agreement for its- joint construction. They found few members staying on the floor to hear their arguments.
WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- Following is the text of a Commencement Day address by President Truman today at Howard University :

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 13 -- Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky, it was disclosed today, told the three Western powers last December that the United States did not have "supremacy" in the atomic field, and neither did the Soviet Union hold "superiority" in armed forces and in (other) armaments over the Atlantic powers.

An opinion that most controls will be cut down to the status of stand-by powers was expressed yesterday by Robert D. L'Heureux, counsel to the Senate Banking and Currency Committee and the Joint Congressional Committee on Defense Production.

Westing Industries, Inc., bought the four-story house at 433 West Thirty-third Street for cash over a purchase money mortgage of $10,000 in a deal negotiated by Jacob J. Tabolt, broker. The tax valuation is $20,000.

Mr. Taft has repudiated the help of Democrats, independents and "mugwumps" in general. He evidently feels that he does not need such support because "he has never lost an election," apparently forgetting that neither party has enough "straight ticket" voters to elect any man President of the United States and that Ohio is not the entire country.

HOMER CROY is a Chaucerian gatherer of stories about the rambunctious nineteenth century on America's Southwestern frontier. He gave Will Rogers words to use in a photoplay and wrote a memoir of Jesse James. The dreary artificiality of the folklorist never clouds Mr. Croy's pages. His scholarship is breezy, with the morning winds of the West blowing through it.

LONDON, June 13 -- Representatives of the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company and a legal expert from the Admiralty are awaiting at Aden the arrival of the 632-ton tanker Rose Mary, the first ship to try to carry oil sold by Iran in defiance of the British ban.
ROME, June 13 -- Fire broke out yesterday in the famous Basilica of St. Francis in Assisi and caused serious damage to the sacristy of the so called Middle Church.
The following is a round-up of Household hints, derived from various sources, which may be of interest to homemakers:

This is the time of year when the frankfurter begins to emerge -- at full speed -- from the partial eclipse into which it went late last fall. The frankfurter is eaten in large quantities during the winter, season, to be sure, but from now until cold weather returns the volume consumed will be tremendous.

Reflecting curtailed operation because of a strike at its Marrero, La., plant, net earnings of the Celotex Corporation in the six months ended on April 30 declined to $119,766 after taxes, O. S. Mansell, president, reported to stockholders yesterday.

George Araujo, lightweight battler from Providence, received the decision over Arthur King of Toronto in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night. The verdict in favor of the New England boxer was not popular, drawing jeers from most of the 2,576 fans present.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today reproved Colonial Airlines for having placed itself "on the auction block" and reminded its president that the board would decide if any sale was in the public interest.

The police were checking last night the alibi of "a leading suspect'' in the murder of Mrs. Marion Robbins, 54-year-old widow and divorcee, who was found-strangled last Tuesday in her apartment at 34 West Eighth Street.

A Republican of many years standing, I switched to THE NEW YORK TIMES at the time of the MacArthur hearings because of your reputation for fairness and because the avowedly "Republican" daily I had previously read came out in favor of the present Administration on that matter.
AMMAN, Jordan, June 13 (Reuters) -- The Jordan Government announced today it had received a telegram from King Talal in Switzerland approving its actions since he left his country.

PRINCETON, N. J., June l3 -- More than 5,000 of Princeton University's returning alumni will hold their annual "P-rade" from Nassau Hall to University Field to witness the 212th Princeton-Yale baseball game tomorrow in the climax of the reunion week-end.

The three-day Spanish Trade Fair in the Astor Gallery of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel closed last night with firm sales exceeding $1,000,000 of gloves, leather goods, laces, dolls, toys and other specialties to nearly 400 buyers from the United States and Canada.

CLEVELAND, June 13 -- Sometimes a streak can be detrimental, as the Yankees, who dropped a 7-1 decision to the Indians and forfeited first place to the Red Sox, learned tonight. Perhaps the New Yorkers would have lost to Mike Garcia regardless, but it appeared that Casey Stengel's reluctance to snap Allie Reynolds' string of completed games cost the Yankees whatever chance they might have had to win.

Camden, N. J., will accept bids on June 26 on $8,000,000 of sewer bonds dated Aug. 1, 1952, and due from Aug. 1, 1953 to 1987. These bonds are the final offering of issues authorized by the city in the aggregate of $12,000,000.

A horse from France and a rider from France combined their talents for a five-length triumph in the Aqueduct National Maiden Hurdle Stakes at the Queens County Jockey Club's cavalry post yesterday. Daniel Saint's 5-year-old Byng, with George Foot in the saddle, did the job in the role of 3-to-2 favorite.

More than 65,000 commuters on the New York Central and New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroads were delayed from twenty minutes to two and three-quarter hours last night when fire broke out in the motor of one New Haven train and another train of the same line had a motor power failure.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, June 13 -- Britain introduced her case against Iran in the international Court of Justice today.

It is a tribute to the effectiveness of Soviet propaganda that so well-informed and learned a man as Prime Minister Nehru of India has apparently swallowed the Kremlin-inspired stereo-type about Soviet minority policy. In a recent speech he praised the Soviet Union as the "only country" that had adopted a "wise and successful policy in winning over the people living in outlying areas."

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., June 13 -- The State Conference of Mayors lined up unanimously today behind New York in its effort to obtain more money from the state and added a few requests of its own for more financial assistance from Albany for upstate localities.

ST. ANDREW'S-BY-THE-SEA, N. B., June 13 (AP) -- Graham Towers, Governor of the Bank of Canada, said today that countries with import and currency restrictions were perpetuating inflation, hindering defense of free nations and generally contributing to a "serious weakening of the economic structure of the free world."

OMAHA, June 13 (AP) -- Missouri tonight beat Holy Cross, 1 -- 0, in the second round of the National Collegiate A. A. baseball tournament although the Tigers were held hitless for seven and a third innings by Jackie Lonergan and their seventh-inning run was unearned.

LONDON, June 13 -- A London report published abroad to the effect that Britain, France and the United States were prepared to invite the Soviet Union to four-power talks on Germany was dismissed here today as showing a lack of appreciation of the situation that exists.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 13 -- United Nations circles interpret the appointment of Andrei A. Gromyko as Soviet Ambassador to London as a probable indication that the Kremlin has decided to step up its campaign to exploit the neutralist sentiment in Britain.

LONDON, June 13 -- The Moscow radio announced tonight the appointment of Mr. Gromyko. The broadcast, which quoted Tass, official Soviet news agency, said the Supreme Soviet had appointed Mr. Gromyko to the London post and had relieved him of his duties as Deputy Foreign Minister.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- "Atomic cocktails" of radioactive iodine, artificial element created in the ovens of the Atomic Energy Commission, have successfully treated 384 patients suffering from over-activity of the thyroid gland, a group of University of Chicago surgeons reported today at the closing sessions of the annual meeting of the American Medical Association.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 13 -- The United States women won all three matches in today's opening session of the international tennis series for the Wightman Cup and seem virtually certain of defeating their British rivals for the sixteenth successive time.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Householders in the New York area along with others in the Northeastern section of the country will pay eight-tenths of a cent a gallon more for next winter's fuel oil as the result of Government action today.

CARMEL, N. Y., June 13 -Shortly after a murdered 9-year-old girl, Betty June Arnold, was laid to rest in Raymond Hill Cemetery here late this afternoon, Donald Hugh Snyder, 25, of Canastota, N. Y., was indicted by a Putnam County Grand Jury. Snyder, who escaped on Tuesday from the Greenhaven Prison, was charged with first-degree murder and seven counts of felony.

" Music in Mexico," by Robert Stevenson of the University of California, a study that covers Mexican music from the time of the Aztecs to the present, will be issued in the fall by Crowell. The author in his travel in Spain this year discovered several previously unknown documents bearing on the history of music in Mexico in the colonial period.

KOJE ISLAND, Korea, June 13 -- The last Communist strongholds on this prison island collapsed today as four Red compounds suddenly capitulated to the latest crackdown orders issued by Brig. Gen. Haydon L. Boatner, commander of Koje.

BERKELEY, Calif., June 13 (AP) -- America's collegiate track stars broke three national meet records and tied a fourth today with only two final events completed in the thirty-first annual National Collegiate A. A. championships.

The unanimous vote of the Commissioners of the Port of New York Authority to reopen Newark Airport next Monday is a sensible action. Closed four months to commercial aviation because of an almost incredible concentration of accidents, the field will now be used on a greatly restricted basis until November, when a new runway is to be ready.

In the interest of fair play I would like to tell the other side of the alleged "steal" of Texas delegates to the Republican convention. There is, of course, tremendous enthusiasm among Texans for General Eisenhower, who could probably carry the state, whereas Senator Taft, except against Truman, probably could not, as things are today.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Admiral Arthur W. Radford, United States Pacific naval chief who was recently charged with responsibility for the Formosa area, appealed today for increased arms shipments to the Nationalist forces stationed on the critical island off the China coast.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 13 -Maj. Gen. Daniel H. Hudelson, Fortiet Infantry Division commander whose remarks about Communist manpower in Korea brought denials from the Pentagon, received an "administrative reprimand" today from Lieut. Gen. Joseph M. Swing, Sixth Army commander.

Some ground was gained yesterday by the stock market without the benefit of expansion in business. The general course throughout the session was upward with some of the rails, papers, rubbers and liquors leading the way.

Dr. Buell Gordon Gallagher, United States Assistant Commissioner of Education, is slated to be elected as president of City College when the Board of Higher Education meets at its regular meeting on Monday evening.
LONDON, June 13 -- Prime Minister Robert Menzies of Australia will discuss the development of his country's new uranium fields next week when he visits Washington on his way home, he said here today.

June, the month, especially associated with weddings and the showering of gifts in celebration, also adds anniversaries for the weddings that have taken place in earlier years. Tradition dictates the media with which to say "happy anniversary."

Two of the oldest and most provocative questions in human cultural history were dug up here yesterday by eighty-two distinguished scholars at the Wenner-Gren Foundation International Symposium on Anthropology.

Samuel Reshevsky of New York and Svetozar Gligoric of Belgrade, having adjourned the sixth game of their match after five hours of play Thursday night, fought it out in another session, lasting five and a half hours at the Manhattan Chess Club, yesterday.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 1 to 10 points yesterday in a moderate volume of business.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 13 -- The wives of two service men in Korea won a promise today from the Sailors Union of the Pacific, A. F. L., that it would furnish a deck crew for the liner President Cleveland so that the ship might leave on a scheduled trip to the Orient instead of being tied up here by a seafarers' strike.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- Walter S. Hallanan, who has been named temporary chairman of the Republican National Convention, opening July 7 in Chicago, today termed Senator Henry Cabot Lodge of Massachusetts, campaign manager for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, a "completely spoiled political child," who was "obviously having a political nightmare."

Sales of leading mail order and chain stores for May showed an aggregate increase of 9.3 per cent above the volume for the 1951 month, according to a compilation of figures for forty-five companies made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

LONDON, June 13 -- The theory that the pock-marked surface of the moon was due to a series of violent internal explosions akin to the volcanic blowout in the East Indies island of Krakatoa in 1883, the most catastrophic ever recorded, was put forward at the Royal Society yesterday by the Cambridge astronomer and natural philosopher Prof. Harold Jeffreys. He was speaking about the origin of the solar system.

The Interstate Conference on Reciprocal Non-Support Legislation, ending a two-day session at the Roosevelt Hotel, called on the Federal Security Administrator yesterday to aid the states in forcing deserting parents to provide support for children on the public assistance rolls.

Out of the fog of uncertainty that beclouds the quest for a Republican Presidential nominee -- other than Bob Taft -- one certainty rings out with the clarity of a lighthouse bell -- that the loudly proclaimed nationwide, upsurging draft predicted by General Eisenhower's followers simply does not exist.

New Jersey's annual sneak attack by mosquitos will carry a Sunday punch this year. All this week a small army of bug specialists from four counties have been smiting hip and thigh at masses of larvae hatching happily in marsh, backyard and basement.

On leaving his post at the United Nations to become executive director of the Chicago Council of Foreign Relations, Porter McKeever told the U. N. correspondents that he was deeply concerned at the diminishing public support of the organization. For six years Mr. McKeever has rendered able and devoted service as chief information officer of the United States delegation.

It is a historical fact that on June 14, 1777, the Continental Congress resolved: "That the flag of the United States shall be of thirteen stripes of alternate red and white, with a union of thirteen stars in a blue field, representing the new constellation." The Flag has so remained, except for the addition of new stars for new states.

Three tall hoodlums charged into the offices of the Home Window Cleaning Corporation, 161 Livingston Street, Brooklyn, at 2:15 P. M. yesterday, slugged a policeman and a 70-year-old messenger and escaped with a $7,500 payroll and about $500 in cash and jewelry from nine employes.

Flatbush residents who have been demonstrating with traffic-blocks their demand for a new traffic-control light are to get their wish -- in quadruplicate. David R. Post, Deputy Commissioner of Traffic, announced yesterday that lights would be placed on the corners of the intersection of Rogers Avenue and Beverly Road, Brooklyn, within the next two or three weeks.

My friends and family are more alarmed and troubled over the theft of delegates in Texas than over any political matter since the days of 1933 in Germany. We cannot forget Precinct 176 of Harris County, Texas, with its vote of 265 to 4, calmly declared to be a victory for the four voters.

Miss Jeane Ansell, who controls one of the largest foreign-language movie chains in the city, and her accountant were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury, charged in 210 counts with attempted evasion of $203,677 in admission taxes.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., June 13 -General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower made a direct bid today for the support of Pennsylvania's seventy delegates to the Republican National Convention, which starts July 7.

Summer schedules will begin at some churches here tomorrow. The Rev. Dr. David A. MacLennann of the faculty of Yale University Divinity School will be the first of five guest preachers to be heard this summer at Riverside Church. Riverside Drive and 122d Street.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 13 -- Dr. Charles Malik, chairman of the United Nations Human Rights Commission, said today that blame for the unfinished labors of the commission -- which ended a nine-week session here this afternoon -- must be put both on Western and Soviet bloc members.

PUSAN, Korea, Saturday, June 14 (UP) -- President Syngman Rhee of South Korea clamped a tight Government censorship on all news, newspapers and magazines today to muzzle all criticism of his regime and refused to lift his ban on broadcasts of the Voice of America.

PARIS, June 13 -- Jacques Duclos, acting secretary general of the French Communist party, today accused the Paris police who arrested him late in May of robbing him, and the French Government of staging an action similar to the Nazi Reichstag fire trial in its offensive against the French Communists.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, June 13 -- The arrival of the Forty-ninth United States Air Division in Britain a few days ago marks a significant rise in the defensive air strength available to Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, and his air chiefs.
WASHINGTON, June 13 (UP) -The Senate approved and sent to the House today a compromise bill to keep the government in the synthetic rubber business until March 31, 1954.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 13 -- A gift of acreage here valued at $150,000 to the Washington Irving Council of the Boy Scouts of America was announced today. The council, serving three-quarters of Westchester County and all of Putnam County, intends to develop a headquarters, training center and property.
HARRISBURG, Pa., June 13 -The Rev. Dr. Frederick B. Newell of New York was elected a Bishop of the Methodist Church today over a field of thirty-four candidates.

In the first change of ownership in thirty-seven years, the six-story factory and several small buildings containing 40,000 square feet at 93 Underhill Avenue and 324 St. Marks Avenue, Brooklyn, have been sold by Colomon Fromm to the Flow Realty Corporation.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- President Truman today reaffirmed his civil rights program without compromise, asserting the rights of individuals could not be left to state protection alone but required the full power of the Federal Government.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, June 14 (AP) -- American troops of the Forty-fifth Infantry Division stormed and won a second height last night on a hotly contested hill mass west of Chorwon, on the western front and hurled back early today an attack by a Chinese battalion aimed at cutting off their forward position.

SALT LAKE CITY, June 13 -Warning that "any political figure who says this nation can have both a reduction of taxes and any real security is not telling the truth," a Presidential aspirant, W. Averell Harriman, expressed the belief today that planned defense expenditures in the United States and Europe during the next two or three years would deter any major warlike moves on the part of the free world's enemies.

When the Chinese Communists invited an Indian "cultural" mission to visit Peiping the motive was obvious. The Indians were to get a big dose of window dressing and buy the Communist bill of goods. Somebody along the line slipped up and the Indian delegation included Frank Moraes, editor of The Times of India, the second of whose reports on what he saw and heard appears in this newspaper today.
RANGOON, Burma, June 13 (AP) -- Torrential rains in Yunnan Province have slowed the "monsoon offensive" of Nationalist Chinese irregulars against the Chinese Communists, reliable sources said today.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., June 13 -- Senator Estes Kefauver returned to his "home folks" today and assured them that he was "more confident now than ever before that I will win the Democratic Presidential nomination at the National Convention in Chicago next month."

BERLIN, June 13 -- Otto Grotewohl, East German Premier, declared tonight that his Government was preparing a program for "armed defense" as a result of the West German Government's policies of political and military integration with the Western Allies.

HANOVER, N. H., June 13 -- Orton H. Hicks of Great Neck, L. I., director of research and development for Loew's International Corporation, was elected president of the Dartmouth College Alumni Council today. A member of the Class of '21, Mr. Hicks was also graduated from the college's Amos Tuck School of Business Administration and has long been active in alumni affairs.
LONDON, June 13 (Reuters) -Nations making British type tweeds must stamp them with the name of the country of manufacure, the International Wool Conference agreed here today at its final session.

OCEANPORT, N. J., June 13 (AP) -- Monmouth Park saddles up for its seventh modern racing season tomorrow with the $15,000 added Oceanport Handicap as the feature. The mile-long race course -- located on the North Jersey shore -- has attracted some of turfdom's brightest stars for the forty-nine-day meeting.

Western Germany is the only country among the nations of Western Europe where the trend toward nationalization has been effectively halted, it was reported here yesterday by Herbert Barchoff, executive vice president of the Eastern Brass and Copper Company, who has just returned from a two-month study of business conditions on the Continent.

TOKYO, Saturday, June, 14 (AP) -- The Foreign Office warned Japanese business men yesterday that recent trade offers by Communist China were "motivated by political and military aims rather than from any genuine desire to expand trade."

With the announcement of Andrei A. Gromyko's new appointment, Western diplomats are clearly faced with the possibility that a major new Soviet diplomatic move is in the offing, one comprehensive enough to cover both the Asian and European fronts of the current international struggle.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The Republican National Committee certified contests for nineteen delegates in four states today. It sent eleven of the contests, those involving district delegates, back to state central committees. The other eight contests, involving delegates at large, will be heard by the National Committee, the decisions of which may be appealed to the Credentials Committee of the National Convention, with final appeal to the convention floor possible.

The Simmons Machine Tool Corporation completed this week the rehabilitation of its 400th government-owned machine tool. In announcing this yesterday in Albany, Charles A. Simmons Sr., president, said that the company, a major machine tool rebuilder, had reached the halfway mark in its program of restoring the armed forces' stand-by metal-working equipment.

In a move designed to muster additional pitching support for their hard-pressed Big Three of Sal Maglie, Larry Jansen and Jim Hearn, the Giants yesterday purchased Hal Gregg from Oakland of the Pacific Coast League.

BONN, Germany, June 13 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer seeks free, democratic all-German elections as the first step toward reunification of Germany and considers agreement by the Soviet Union to the holding of such elections to be the test of success for any projected four-power conference.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The shut-down of steel production resulting from the strike of the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., led officials of the National Production Authority today to predict a cancellation of moves taken last month to ease building restrictions.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 14 -- Hampered by fog and generally poor visibility, the Swedish Navy and Air Force have been engaged all day in a fruitless search for the Air Force C-54 missing from a navigational training flight with a crew of eight over international waters in the Baltic in the vicinity of the Isle of Gotland since noon yesterday.

Prices of cotton futures moved narrowly last week and most changes were small. At the close of trading on Friday, the near-by July delivery on the New York Cotton Exchange was up 36 points, but other futures ended mixed, 8 points higher to 7 points lower than a week earlier.

TWO young people, deeply satisfied with one another mentally, emotionally and sexually, wake one morning to find the joy of their unusually happy and successful marriage taken from them. The core of their pattern of life is crushed, their future as they had always planned it together, ended, through no fault or responsibility of either and there is nothing they can do to escape their tragedy.

RANGING from anagrams and archery, through chess, eating, housekeeping, Seeing-Eye dogs, and sewing, up to and including wrestling and various forms of writing, this book is one of the most comprehensive and interesting guidebooks for the blind that this reviewer has ever seen.

IS man himself the unknown in the equation which relates him to his environment? Then, knowledge of self is much wanted in these dizzy times and information proffered is eagerly welcome. This volume makes friends pleasantly. Type and paper texture attract the reader to the page.
Following is the text of last night's address in Detroit by General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, as transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Dr. Jack Masur, of the U. S. Public Health Service, told the American Surgical Trade Association in Chicago last week that hospitals of the future will be havens of comfort for the patient, that hospital service will be radically changed by the increasing need for complete rehabilitation, and that hospital-provided home care will grow.

With railroad passenger travel having declined steadily since the end of World War II, reflecting the greater use of the highways and airplanes, the railroads are making renewed efforts to recover some of the business lost to put passenger train operations back on a more solid basis.

About 14,000 physicians turned up at Chicago last week to attend the annual meeting of the American Medical Association. Some 400 papers were read, most of them of only passing interest. The striking advances in medicine are usually reported in the leading medical journals.

" A GUSTIN DE ITURBIDE, the Liberator of Mexico, sprang from a noble family which was seated in the onetime kingdom of Navarre." This is the opening sentence of a monolithic and exhaustive biography by William Spence Robertson, and it gives a pretty good idea of its style.

THE Irish writer Patricia Lynch is best known in this country for such fantasies as "The Turf-Cutter's Donkey" and "The Grey Goose of Kilnevin." But even when she writes what must be called, in contrast, a realistic story, like "Grania of Castle O'Hara," she infuses it with an eerie, half-dreamlike mood, very Celtic indeed.

CHARLESTON, S. C., June 14 (AP) -- Gen. J. Lawton Collins, Chief of Staff of the Army, said today in a commencement speech at The Citadel that Russia has a powerful army, possibly the largest air force and a strong navy.

The 175th anniversary of the adoption of the Stars and Stripes by the Continental Congress was marked yesterday as civic and patriotic organizations celebrated Flag Day in ceremonies throughout the city. The flag was prominently displayed from homes, apartment houses and business places.

The summer months herald an eagerly awaited vacation for most college students, but to the forty-five mothers and grandmothers studying at Hunter College, summertime will mean only a brief return to household chores and childrearing.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 14 -- A long controversy over water resources development in the Pacific Northwest, pictured by some partisans as a phase of a nationwide conflict between rival philosophies of hydroelectric power generation, is scheduled for a further hearing next week.

THE story of this year's international contest for pianists at Brussels and of the way in which a young American, Leon Fleisher, won first prize was told on these pages last Sunday by Olin Downes from his unique vantage point as reporter and member of the jury.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- On May 12 last a bill was introduced in the House that, among other provisions, would have increased disability benefits under the Social Security Act.

THERE is nothing like a few statistics to wipe out that blase feeling. Only last week in these columns there was a casual back-handed aspersion upon the creativity of the season just past, and nothing could more clearly testify to just how spoiled we have become in the dance world.

The Communist-led Hukbalahap insurrection in the Philippines is rapidly being terminated, Ramon Magsaysay, Secretary of Defense of the Philippines, said yesterday as he arrived in New York from Washington for a four-day visit.

Virginia, Rensselaer Polytech, Army, Maryland and Duke, outstanding college teams of the country, dominate the 1952 All-America selections announced yesterday by Frederic A. Fitch, chairman of the All-America Committee of the United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association.

BONN, June 14 -- The French proposal for four-power talks with the Soviet Union on the bases for German reunification has strengthened and encouraged the opposition to Chancellor Adenauer in Germany's most important postwar political debate to the detriment of the immediate aims of United States policy.

ROGERS HORNSBY is having trouble enough these days. Yet it is impossible to leave unchallenged one ridiculous statement he made in a magazine rebuttal to Ty Cobb's original blast against the modern ball players. The Rajah destroyed the efficacy of his arguments by the malicious way he omitted the Georgia Peach from his All-Star team.

JACKSON, Miss., June 14 (UP) -- Gov. Hugh White, who started the 1948 "Dixiecrat" walkout, announced today that he would "fight it out" this year in the Democratic party, reports of plans for a new bolt notwithstanding.

MOSCOW, June 14 -- The appointment of Andrei A. Gromyko as Ambassador to London was believed by diplomats in Moscow today to indicate that British-Soviet relations now stood on the threshold of a new and significant period.

VERY few music lovers outside of Russia have ever heard Mussorgsky's Boris Godunoff as originally written. All-Russian casts are a novelty in the West, and for the most part any "Boris" that is heard is likely to be in Italian.
The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's forty-ninth annual championship will start tomorrow over the Upper Montclair Golf and Country Club course, Upper Montclair, N. J.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 14 -- Harvard University will confer degrees on some 3,000 seniors and graduate students at the 302d commencement exercises of the college next Thursday. The college, still the undergraduate division of the institution, is the nation's oldest, with its beginnings dating back to 1636.
HONOLULU, June 14 -- An 18-year-old Hawaiian, Evelyn Kawamoto, emerged from Waikiki natatorium's pool last night with a new unofficial American record for the 400-meter women's free-style.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (UP) -- Senator Taft said today that the Republican National Committee was following a rule written by his present party opponents in referring disputes over delegates to the national convention back to the states for settlement.

KOJE ISLAND, Korea, June 14 -- The death toll among the Communist prisoners of war who thought before dawn last Tuesday morning that the United States was still afraid to crack down on "kangaroo" tyranny is gradually mounting from the bayonet wounds the fanatic Communists invited when they defied orders to move into more manageable compounds.

Trade observers estimated that department store sales in the week ended yesterday were about 16 per cent below the 1951 week. It was remarked that the chief reason for the unfavorable showing was the fact that a year ago the price war was raging in this district.

Two of Great Britain's top soccer teams will be seen for the first time as rivals on American soil today when Manchester United opposes Tottenham Hotspur at the Yankee Stadium, starting at 3:45 P. M. The preliminary will pit the Philadelphia Nationals against the New York Americans in the final of the Lewis Cup competition at 2 P. M.

In the five years since the Taft-Hartley Act went into the books over his veto President Truman has used it six times to stop national emergency strikes. Only two of the injunctions came after the 1948 cam paign in which he made the act a prime political target -- and one of those was against his old antagonist, John L. Lewis of the coal miners.

ONE of the most dramatic experiments in the colonization of Canada was that of Lord Selkirk, the Scottish nobleman and landowner, who spent half a million dollars establishing a doughty band of Scots in mid-continent, at the confluence of the Red and Assiniboine rivers.
Liquor production is slated to be cut sharply during the next few months. Distillery executives admitted here yesterday that swollen inventories make current production schedules seem foolish.

The boom which for some time has been on borrowed time, is giving evidence of its weariness in the first-quarter corporate income of the nation's manufacturing enterprises. Industral pro duction, employment, personal and national income continue at top levels under the support of governmental expenditures for defense.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Mr. Morison said he had wanted to resign for the last year in order to re-enter private law practice. Before entering the Government service he had been a member of the late Wendell L. Willkie's law firm in New York, but he said today that he would likely practice here in Washington.
CHICAGO, June 24 (AP) -- Today's livestock ture follow:

General Boatner's prompt and firm actions on Koje appear now to be paying dividends. The worst of the unruly Communist prisoner concentrations have been broken up and United Nations control, which never should have been vitiated, has been re-established. The clean-up is being carried through.
Wes Westrum's ninth home run of the campaign provided the margin of victory yesterday as the Giants turned back the Cardinals, 4 -- 3, for their sixth straight victory at the Polo Grounds.

BEGINNING during the depression, one New York gallery which has since devoted itself exclusively to contemporary American art is now celebrating its twentieth anniversary with an exhibition which illustrates that its faith in the field has paid off.

VALLEY FORGE symbolizes the physical suffering that the winning of independence evoked. Americans who were long on supplies but short on faith caused more grief by failing to provision their soldiers in the field that winter -- which, contrary to common belief, was unusually mild -- than did the British, busy debauching themselves in Philadelphia.
A FEW days ago there came to our desk an unpublished report of research conducted on emotional factors in the home lives of youngsters who, although normally intelligent, were failing in school.

LONDON, June 14 -- Accused of passing on valuable secret information to the second secretary of the Soviet Embassy here, a 24-year-old, 8 ($22.40)-a-week British Foreign Office radio operator was sent to prison today for a week to await trial.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., June 14 -- For the first time in years, the racing fleet out on Long Island Sound had a reaching start instead of a windward tangle. It was in the initial championship series regatta of the summer season held by the Larchmont Yacht Club.
DETROIT, June 14 (UP) -- Vic Wertz, pinch-hitter, exploded a two-run eighth-linning homer to give Detroit a 7-to-6 victory over Washington today and snap a seven-game Tiger losing streak.
WASHINGTON, June 14 (UP) -- General of the Army Omar N. Bradley, chairman of the United States Joint Chiefs of Staff, has advised Congress that Russia "could overrun Europe today."

SYLLOGISM -- Major premise: taxi drivers talk more to more people than any other group. Minor premise: word of mouth advertising sells books. Conclusion: books read by taxi drivers will be talked about. Using this logic; Prentice-Hall has distributed 100 copies of Cecil St.-Laurent's "Caroline Cherie" to New York hackies free of charge. If the scheme works, it will be tried elsewhere.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The Republican party, it now seems certain, will convene at Chicago next month in wild political weather, and how much damage the storm will do to its Presidential election chances cannot be forecast. But the winds of controversy over candidates will blow harder and more bitterly than they have for forty years.

PSYCHOANALYSTS undoubtedly have their own opinions of people who like comedy along with their murders; but ever since the porter opened the gates of Inverness to MacDuff, and probably long before, the combination has been an appealing one.

THE tritoma, once widely known as the red hot poker, has now achieved dependable winter hardiness here in the Northeast. What is more, a wider range of colors, perhaps less spectacular than the original orange red, makes it a more harmonious candidate for the garden. In fact, the new versions of this perennial have stately spikes that merit a place in any garden.

A nation-wide program of cooperation with the schools to assure an adequate supply of chemists and chemical engineers to meet future civilian and military needs has been launched by the American Chemical Society.

ACCORDING to publishers' reports, there has been a marked falling off in fiction sales in recent years. Even when other books are selling fairly well, novels fail to reach as large audiences as might once have been expected for them -- a new novel can sell as little as 10,000 copied and make the fiction best-seller lists.
