NEW YORK will have a new symphony orchestra next season. Columbia University is expanding its chamber orchestra to an ensemble of major symphonic size. Emanuel Balaban is the conductor who has been appointed to direct the expansion and to lead the orchestra in its public concerts.
The strength of United States air power continued to be a political issue as well as a military problem last week.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- United States authorities on the Soviet Union, who have learned the wisdom of restraint in interpreting Soviet policy in public, cautioned today against "overspeculation" on the recent series of shifts in the Soviet diplomatic service.

MONTAUK, L. I., June 14 -- Better marine protection for the eastern end of Long Island is forecast by the Coast Guard as a result of the arrival at Lake Montauk of an eighty-three-foot patrol boat and the setting up of a Coast Guard life-saving headquarters on Star Island, near the entrance to the lake.

The vanguard of 25,000 store executives and buyers will descend upon Chicago tomorrow. They will comb the American Furniture and Merchandise Marts for new fall merchandise at the opening of the summer home furnishings market and many will stay to the bitter end of the event on June 27.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., June 14 -- The Southern Regional Education Board announced today that a committee of twelve men prominent in the fields of education and public service had agreed to undertake a long-range study of how to improve the political science and public administration programs in Southern colleges and universities.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 14 (AP) -- Two American scientists, arriving last night from Japan, said that it would be "at least two generations before we know the full effects of the Hiroshima atom bomb burst on human beings."

You can sit on a lawn or under a tree now and almost see the way time flows past. It doesn't hurry or dawdle; it simply flows, much as a great cumulous cloud moves across the summer sky. You can feel it, somehow, too, if you don't try too hard. In growing things, mostly.

THE HAGUE -- model of a Dutch town, complete and perfect in every detail, is rising in Scheveningen Wood on the outskirts of this city. Its first building, a castle of the year 1100, already dominates more modern structures and will stand in sharp contrast to an airport, railway with safety devices and marshalling yards, ferry boats, a fast motor highway with tunnels, and other evidences of machine-age urban cizilization.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 14 -- Senator Brien McMahon urged today the stockpiling of thousands of hydrogen bombs, which are far more lethal than atomic weapons, as a war prevention measure. His proposal was made in a speech to the Democratic State Convention, which pledged him Connecticut's twenty-two national convention votes as a "favorite son" candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination.
CHICAGO, June 14 (AP) -- Major grains dipped slightly while rye advanced a couple of cents at times on the Board of Trade today.

PITTSBURGH, June 14 -- David J. McDonald, the secretary-treasurer of the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., is normally as faultless a reader as one can find outside a Shakesperean company. But he made a significant slip when he read the resolution adopted by steel strike leaders here yesterday, committing the union to a "no surrender" fight for higher wages and the union shop.
HELSINKI, Finland, June 14 -- The second annual Sibelius Festival ended here tonight in the great exhibition hall.

Charley Moore Jr., perhaps the best of all United States bets for an Olympic title at Helsinki this summer, yesterday shaved two-tenths of a second from the American record for the 440-yard hurdles, set ten years ago by the 1948 Olympic winner of the distance test over the three-foot barriers.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Supporters of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Republican Presidential nomination assailed today "steamroller tactics" they ascribed to campaign strategists in the camp of his chief rival, Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio.

The reform of our civil service is so important to the ethics of government in our nation that it should have the fullest possible discussion in the press. I refer to the excellent letter written by Joseph H. Harris of Barkeley, Calif., published in THE NEW YORK TIMES on June 1.

WOODLAND paths are always a delight. Developing one in your own woodland is an adventure that takes patience and skill, but is well worth the effort. The summer months are the best time to start such a project.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 14 (AP) -- Calumet Farm's famed racing stable grabbed everything in sight at Hollywood Park today, including both ends of the double-header stakes program.

Cain Hoy Stable's Hushaby Baby, with blinkers added to her equipment, kept her attention firmly on the chief bit of business before the house at the Aqueduct Race Track yesterday and ran off with first money of $19,325 in the $28,600 Gazelle Stakes for 3-year-old fillies. It was something of a surprise. The Cain Hoy filly was the $24.30-for-$2 seventh choice.

ONE sign of a healthy resort season in the offing is that the New York State Employment Service's resort placement section is getting more job orders from summer hotels than last year. Unfortunately for youngsters in and out of college who dream vaguely of vacations with pay, this does not mean that jobs are to be had for the asking by the inexperienced.

The automotive and speed boat city of Detroit, which has been envious of Seattle since Stanley Sayres' fleet of speed boats named Slo-Mo-Shun took the famous Gold Cup out to the Northwest and established a world record of 160.323 miles an hour, has been campaigning for two years to recapture Michigan's lost glory.

I sincerely beg your letter writer in the June 1 issue who deplored the "malevolent" face on the May 18 cover to think a little more deeply. She represents the state of mind which never progresses beyond expectation of either beloved hero or hated villain.

PARIS, June 14 -- Speaking at Bayeux in Normandy today, eight years after he visited that town when it was part of a week-old Allied beachhead, Gen. Charles de Gaulle said that on that day "the national power" appeared in France.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 10 -- An insight to the mentality of the ultra-nationalism that is the source of Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan's political strength in the Union of South Africa is given in an article in Inspan, Afrikaans business magazine, by Dr. D. N. Diederichs, prominent Nationalist member of Parliament and big business representative.

NESTLED under snowcapped Mount Lamborn are three greenhouses from which have come in the last five years a succession of fine petunias that have enriched gardens all over the country. And on the outskirts of town are fields with sturdy petunia plants, set out for study and comparison.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., June 14 (AP) -- Beating his nearest opponent by more than two minutes, Frank Havens of the Washington Canoe Club virtually clinched a berth on the United States Olympic canoe team today by winning the 10,000-meter (0.2 miles) one-man single-blade event at the final trials on Lake Sebago.

Who were the people known as Scythians, Russian historians were asking last week -- a question that also interested the Greeks for whom Herodotus wrote an elaborate answer. A growing school of Russian scholars, THE TIMES correspondent reports, suspects that the Scythians, who for several centuries held the southern part of Russia, were Slavs.

HOME gardeners who have a few fruit trees are often distressed to see little green plums, peaches, apples and pears dropping to the soil. This is particularly discouraging -- and most apt to occur -- in June, when the fruits are about as large as the thumbnail.
DETROIT, June 14 (AP) -- Four allowance races, only one of which was won by a favorite, drew 17,738 to the Michigan Racing Association track today and resulted in a $1,059,098 mutuel handle.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 14 -- America's tenure of the Wightman Cup, held continuously since 1931, was extended for another year today. Leading by 3 to 0 after yesterday's opening program, the United States won the four remaining matches for a sweep of the seven contests in the international women's tennis fixture with Great Britain.

Before the month ends, 385,000 young men and women will have left the nation's colleges and universities, ready to enter the world of 1952 in either a civilian or a military capacity. Although the number receiving degrees this year is still considerably above the pre-World War II level, it is beginning to show a substantial drop over recent years.

DETROIT, June 14 (AP) -- Following is the text of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's diclosure today that he had thrown his prepared speeches "out of the window" and would speak his own mind on what he believed to be the basic issues of the day:

BERLIN, June 14 -- In formulating a policy for the year 1952 the European statesman must always reckon with two major influences, both of which, unfortunately for the man who predicates his decisions upon logic, are in essence neither calculable nor predictable. The first of these is the utterly unknown reaction of the Moscow Politburo to any foreseeable circumstance. The second is the equally unfathomable aspiration of that eclectic being, the American voter.

LOS ANGELES, June 14 -- Economic security cannot be gained by avoiding risk, according to a commencement address at the University of Southern California today by Alden G. Roach, president of Columbia-Geneva and Consolidated Western Steel Division of the United States Steel Company.

ARLENE FRANCIS has virtually abandoned the hope of becoming a great actress and settled down to the career of television panelist on quiz programs, a fast growing business that new college graduates ought not to overlook. The work is effortless, she says, the hours short and the job educational. Putting it another way, Miss Francis knows a good living when she sees one.

PARIS, June 14 -- The purpose of the visit to Washington this week of Jean Letourneau, French Minister for the Associated States of Indo-China, was to bring nearer the day when the French might hand over a substantial part of the task of defending Indo-China to the native armies -- mainly the Vietnamese now being formed.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 14 -- A series of calculations designed to throw light on the impact of the nation's defense program on the economy will be started next week by scientists and economists using the new high-speed electronic computer at the Institute for Advanced study here.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 14 -- Princeton completed its first sweep since 1942 of the traditional home-and-home baseball series with Yale by defeating the Elis, 4 to 2, before an alumni reunion crowd of 10,000 at University Field today.

THE dead horse of our pre-Korean China policy gets another whipping in "Spies, Dupes and Diplomats." Congressional committees have belabored the carcass again and again and now the writers of books are continuing the process.

THESE stories are as Gallic as the French shrug, as American as the tall tale, and as wisely humorous as the folk tales of any people. Mrs. Carlson heard them from her mother, who in turn heard them from a French-Canadian great-uncle who "talked as if a house had no walls" and acted out every story.

ONE of the more obvious sights and surely the most mobile scenic wonder of America is the automobile bumper strip, a 100 per cent American advertising gimmick which annually introduces millions of motorists to thousands of "natural wonders," "historic sights," "amazing attractions" and firemen's bazaars.

THE Saga of the late Mark Hellinger, recently completed by James Bishop and now in the hands of his agents and publishers, also has aroused the interest of Hollywood buyers. According to Al Horwits, who is representing the author on film deals for the book, "three major studios are definitely interested and Burr Lancaster and Humphrey Bogart, who have independent production set-ups, are anxious to discuss it with Bishop."

CHICAGO, June 14 -- Will Harridge, American League president, today lifted the suspension of Marty Marion, but fined the St. Louis Browns' manager $100 for his argument with Umpire Bill McGowan during last Wednesdty night's game with the Red Sox in Boston.

PITTSBURGH, June 14 -- With steel production cut off by a national strike, coal operators are wondering how long it will be before they have to grapple with the threat of a similar shutdown in the coal mines.

THE subtitle "The Practical Man's Guide to a Well-Planned Cruise" could hardly be used for Tom Crichton's book. It is a record of one of the most unlikely, courageous, haphazard, resourceful and -- as the author admits here and there -- fool-hardy adventures in sail that has been set down in many a year. Maybe he should have entitled it "Where Angels Fear to Sail."
I read with considerable interest Malcolm Ross' "The Need -- and the Chance -- for Equality" (May 25).

ROME, June 14 (AP) -- An Italian concern disclosed today that -- in defiance of Briitsh attempts at boycott -- it had made a ten-year contract for the purchase of 2,000,000 tons of Iranian crude oil a year

" HAVE you noticed." the editor remarked the other day, "the upsurge in the number of recordings featuring Russian soloists and orchestras: Oistrakh, Ghilels, the Moscow Symphony, the Bolshoi Orchestra?"

Three hundred and seventy-four Queens College students, comprising the college's largest graduating class, will receive their degrees at 4 P. M. on Wednesday on the Flushing quadrangle. Dr. John J. Theobald, president, will confer 279 Bachelor of Arts degrees, sixty-five Bachelor of Science degrees and thirty Master of Arts degrees.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 14 -- Nancy Jane Imboden of Bronxville, N. Y., today captured the horsemanship championship in the saddle seat competition at the thirty-sixth annual Greenwich horse show and also earned the right to compete in the good hands event at the 1932 National Horse show.

LAWN grasses, like starched collars, often wilt in 90-degree temperatures and humidity. The attempt to have the summer lawn retain its present lush greenness may prove vexatious. Still, reasonable observance of sound management practices will obviate most of the common causes of summer lawn failure.

BOSTON, June 14 -- A retired violinist, who became a member of the Boston Symphony Orchestra in its first season in 1881 and remained with it until 1914, returned to the stage of Symphony Hall here last night for a surprise sentimental reunion at one of the concerts of the informal Boston "Pops."

BONN, Germany, June 14 -- The appointment of Mr. Gromyko as Ambassador to London encourages the belief that the rulers of the Soviet Union are extremely uneasy over the development of Western policy and power and are eager to place a trusted spokesman in one of the centers of Allied activity.
In an article in THE TIMES of May 31 Harry Schwartz discussed Gen. Emil Botnaras as a likely candidate to replace Ann Pauker in Rumania's Politburo.
PHILADELPHIA, June 14 (UP) -- The Phillies broke a four-game losing streak with their fourth victory in fourteen games today as they defeated the Pirates, 4 -- 2, on Russ Meyer's five-hit pitching.

A MODERN movie studio incongruously planted in tropical jungles was the base of operations for "The Jungle," first motion picture to be made in India with United States stars and the first such venture ever consummated in a single exchange of letters over 13,000 miles.

IT does his family credit that John Fante felt free to publish this book. A family of thin-blooded, thin-skinned Anglo-Saxons would have put him in the deep freeze and hammered down the lid. Mr. Fante has written about Italian families before but this time the family happens to be his own.

Twelve men and women who have achieved prominence in their respective professions received "Youth Oscars" last night at the annual inspirational dinner of Youth United in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Youth United is a social agency that gives financial aid and other assistance to eight Brooklyn settlement houses.

RYE, N. Y., June 14 -- Taxpayers will go to the polls here on Tuesday in a special referendum to decide whether $75,000 in public money should be spent for the purchase and improvement of parking areas of the railroad station or whether the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad should be allowed to sell the land to commercial developers.
ITHACA, N. Y., June 14 -- The appointment of Mrs. Dorothy V. N. Brooks as Dean of Women at Cornell University, effective Sept. 1, was announced today by Deane W. Malott, university president.

BECKENHAM, England, June 14 (AP) -- Hamilton Richardson, the 18-year-old boy from Baton Rouge, La., regained his form after a shaky few minutes today and went on to capture the Kent lawn tennis singles championship.

WOODS HOLE, Mass. -- This sea-going Cape Cod village scarcely requires explanation, either for its pursuit of scientific research or as the lively port of embarkation for summer visitors to Martha's Vineyard and Nantucket.

If the Reds ever beat the Dodgers it will be a redletter day. Last night at Ebbets Field before 29,619 highly partisan witnesses the Brooks downed the Cincinnatians twice, 6 -- 2, and 4 -- 3, and again took a four-game lead over the second-place Giants.

CAIRO, June 14 (AP) -- The Jordan Government has ordered the Associated Press correspondent at Amman, the capital, to submit for censorship any dispatches quoting sources opposed to the Jordan Government.
LONG BEACH, Calif., June 14 (AP) -- Two American records were shattered today in a track and field meet staged between an all-Armed Forces team and the Los Angeles A. C.

BAY SHORE, L. I., June 14 -- Dr. George Suttie King celebrated his fiftieth anniversary of practice in this village by giving a lawn party at the South Bay Golf Club here today for all the babies he has delivered. Of the 4,000 persons he has brought into the world, 800 signed the register or had it signed for them.

As some 14,000 physicians from all parts of the United States met here this week at the 101st annual session of the American Medical Association, the scientific achievements of medicine were temporarily crowded out of the headlines by the highly publicized controversy between the association and the President's Commission on the Health Needs of the Nation.
DETROIT, June 14 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower did today what every Presidential candidate since John P. Wintergreen has wanted to do.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, June 14 -- The chances of the establishment of a veritable "capital of Europe" have been greatly improved as a result of discussions concluded here today among the six countries participating in the Schuman plan for integrating West European steel and coal output -- France, West Germany, Italy, Luxembourg, Belgium, and the Netherlands.
The term "alien" has become synonymous with "citizen" in the dictionary of the Immigration and Naturalization Service.

AUGUSTA, Me., June 14 -- As Maine prepares to hold its state primary Monday there is confusion among Republican voters as to the effects an investigation into the state's $20,000,000 liquor monopoly will have on the Senatorial contest between Senator Owen Brewster and Gov. Frederick G. Payne.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 14 -- The currency reform and compulsory loan by individuals to the Government that were instituted in Israel this week are the latest but probably not the last in the series of harsh measures that have been made necessary by the basic peculiarity of Israel's economic situation.

STANTON, Del., June 14 (AP) -- High Scud, in the King Ranch silks of Robert J. Kleberg, took on added stature in the 3-year-old division today when he set a new mile-and-a-sixteenth track record of 1:42 1/5 in the Kent Stakes at Delaware Park. In the race preceding the feature Bayard Sharp's Hannibal had smashed the six-furlong mark.

JERSEY CITY, June 14 -- Employes at the Claremont Terminal waterfront installation, from which construction material and supplies are shipped to North African air bases, learned this week that they must abide by a strict set of conduct rules if they expect to hold their jobs.

MIKHAIL PRISHVIN is described as a Russian naturalist and sportsman born in 1873 but still writing under the Soviet regime. The present volume of very brief sketches follows the seasons in a primitive rural region not very far from Moscow and it has for American readers a very special flavor, due in part to the curious mixture of the familiar with the strange.

DES MOINES, June 14 -- Representatives of Republican farm groups in eleven Midwestern states recommended a farm program today "aimed at actual parity prices for all farm products in the market places so as to provide such production as is needed."

CONSUMER incomes in industrial areas have been affected to some extent by wage losses resulting from labor-management disputes and some reduction in the number of hours worked. So far the developments have not been reflected in any sharp reduction in retail sales.

TOKYO, Sunday, June 15 -- United Nations offices admitted yesterday that one Korean civilian was wounded by shell fragments inside the neutral zone at Panmunjom June 5 when Allied artillery opened up on Communist troops sheltering in or near the area of the Korean truce conferences.
THE list of summer replacements -- still showing little in the way of originality or freshness -- continues to grow. Here are some of the new attractions to grace the summer screen:

The domestic machine tool industry, soon facing the prospect of some idle productive capacity and already confronted with stiff competition from Europe's tool builders, wants fast relief -- permission from the Government to ship tools to customers, in this country and abroad, who do not hold rated orders.
LONDON. June 14 -- Jim Peters, Britain's main hope for the Olympic title next month at Helsinki, today ran the fastest marathon ever recorded when he was clocked in 2 hours 20 minutes 42.2 seconds.

PUSAN, Korea, Sunday, June 15 (UP) -- President Syngman Rhee threatened today to tighten the screws of his personal control of the Korean Republic Government by dissolving the National Assembly and calling for a new general election.
LONDON, June 14 (AP) -- A gilt and silver sea trophy that nobody has bothered much about for years may soon be back in the international limelight.

GROTON, Conn., June 14 -- President Truman today dedicated the Nautilus, the world's first atomic submarine, a deadly instrument of war, hailing it as the forerunner of nuclear power for everyday use in an ultimate golden age.
PHILADELPHIA, June 14 -- Attorney General James P. McGranery announced here today that he had accepted the resignations of three of his top assistants, all Presidential appointees.

THERE are various ways of seeing the Grand Canyon. The most usual is to stop at the observation points along the rim for panoramic glimpses of the chasm. There are many such lookouts on the motor highway that follows the South Rim as well as several points on the North Rim.

TOKYO, Sunday, June 15 (UP) -- Allied fighter-bombers wiped out a Communist airfield near the north Korean capital of Pyongyang yesterday to prevent its use by the enemy in a possible summer offensive.

FOR the last five years or so there have been rumors about a "definitive" encyclopedia of records compiled by two Englishmen, F. F. Clough and G. J. Cuming. Clough and Cuming, it was reported, spent a major part of their lives on the project. When it was finished, nobody would publish it.

ENGLEWOOD, N. J., June 14 -- Sidney B. Wood Jr. of New York, the defender, led the seeded players into the third round of the annual invitation tournament at the Englewood Field Club today. The top-seeded former Wimbledon champion defeated H. R. DeVries, Brooklyn, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 1, in the first round, then set back Lester Hirschfield of Kew Gardens, 6 -- 8, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 3.

KOJE ISLAND, June 14 -- Three Communist women leaders who were inside Compound 76 when the stockade fell in a bitter battle last Tuesday said today with pride that during their thirty-four days stay there they had been treated "as well as women are treated in the United States."

Louis de Broglie has been awarded the annual Kalinga Prize of one million francs ($2,800) for his popular writing on science. He is the first winner of the prize. He is honorary president of the French Association of Science Writers. Kalinga was an empire that covered part of India and Indonesia more than 2,000 years ago and that was created by the famous Emperor Asoka.

PLANE dress is not necessarily plain dress, although it avoids many of the customary fripperies because its purpose is to make the hours a passenger spends in an airplane as comfortable as possible. Plane dress, as it is understood by veteran travelers, is not the same kind of thing one is likely to find in the fashion sections.

The unexpected collapse of steel wage negotiations and President Truman's request for legislation enabling the Government to seize and operate the steel industry ruffled financial markets last week. Except for a sell-off on Tuesday, however, the stock market took the news stoically and prices improved after midweek.
ST. LOUIS, June 14 (UP) -- Bob by Shantz whipped the Browns for his eleventh victory as the Athletics gained a 9-2 triumph.

AS co-producer, co-author, director and dance director working with collaborators who, as he says, "have such confidence in me that they give me my head and let me try anything," Joshua Logan has tackled his multiple jobs on the forthcoming musical comedy "Wish You Were Here" with the avidity of a child opening its Christmas packages.

In the grey, half-light of dawn one day last week, a battalion of American G. I.'s stood with fixed bayonets outside the barbed wire of a Koje Island stockade, tensely awaiting the order to enter. One of them said, "I'd rather hit the beach in a first wave amphibious than go in there."

LAZARO CARDENAS del RIO is Mexico's best-known modern President. In the United States he is remembered above all for his expropriation of the foreign petroleum industry in 1938. In Mexico he is still discussed, pro and anti, in terms as ardent as though he were still President, the most striking national executive since Juarez.

OCEANPORT, N. J., June 14 -- General Staff, owned by Larry MacPhail and ridden by Willie Passmore, took command at the proper time and sped to victory in the $15,000 added Oceanport Handicap, the opening-day feature race at Monmouth Park today.

IN these days when Hollywood film-makers are gnawing pencils down to stubs in their frenzy to figure out patterns whereby movies may be made to hold some ground against the onrush of television, so that their old Brentwood homesteads may be saved, it must be maddening to them to have a picture such as Ben Hecht's "Actors and Sin" come swaggering along in a mockingly impudent manner with a thumb cocked rudely to its nose.

In a small stone building near Arco, Idaho, a little over a year ago, atomic scientists succeeded in lighting an electric bulb by means of atomic energy. The power came from a controlled chain reaction in an atomic reactor -- a large, concrete box in which aluminum rods containing uranium were placed between layers of graphite.

HALF a century ago, Indiana bade fair to displace Boston and New York as the literary center of the United States. The brighter stars in the rising Indiana galaxy included James Whitcomb Riley, George Ade, Booth Tarkington, and Theodore Dreiser; of these, Riley and Ade were among the first to applaud Abe Martin when his sayings began to appear, late in 1904, in The Indianapolis News.

A NATIVE of South Africa, where she still lives, Nadine Gordimer has published several of her stories in American magazines (The New Yorker, Harper's, The Virginia Quarterly). This is her first published volume, and her debut is an exciting one.
Julius Boros, with 281, won the U. S. open by four strokes at Dallas yesterday. Ed Oliver was next while Ben Hogan, the defending champion, finished third with 286.

THE motion picture industry has a special interest in the contract entered into last week by Columbia Pictures to turn out a group of thirty-nine half-hour-length television movies for the Ford Motor Company. The deal puts Columbia into the television field in a big way because the pictures will be owned by the film company and ultimately it will be in a position to sell them to other sponsors.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified today 252 Korean war casualties, including 27 dead, 218 wounded and 7 injured. The following were from New York and New Jersey (none from Connecticut):

OF making many books on recent American foreign policy there seems to be no end. Those who helped formulate it, dead and living, give us their memoirs, diaries and papers. President Truman authorizes disclosures which lead ex-Secretary of State Byrnes to charge him with terminological inexactitudes.

BERKELEY, Calif., June 14 -- Seven meet records were set and two were tied today as the powerful University of Southern California captured its fourth consecutive team title in the thirty-first National Collegate Athletic Association's track and field championships.
PRINTED recipes, of which there is such a disconcerting number nowadays, sometimes give the impression there is just one way to cook. Not so; differences in method persist.

TUNIS, Tunisia, June 14 (AP) -- Rioting between Moslems and Jews erupted in Tunis today. The disorders came amid tension over reports that an attempt had been made to poison members of the family of the Bey of Tunis, but the incidents appeared to have no connection. An 18-year-old Jewish boy was killed by a stray bullet.

EVEN a city slicker like me feels the apartment walls closing in at this time of year. The Scotty has a chance to take the air in Central Park, but my wax begonias that have been flowering nobly all winter and a couple of amaryllis that dwarfed my window not long ago are beginning to look a bit drab -- not to mention dissipated.

Three Holland-America liners have been scheduled for ten voyages next winter to southern waters in the Western Hemisphere. This was announced here yesterday by Frederick R. Wierdsma, general manager of the company in North America.

THREE days after the Fourth of July, television will set off its biggest fireworks to date. The Republican national convention opens July 7 at Convention Hall (International Amphitheatre) and will he followed by the Democratic convention at the same place on July 21.

LIMA, Peru, June 14 -- Regulations for applying Peru's new law on petroleum exploitation, officially approved here on Tuesday by President Manuel Odria and published, have produced a generally good impression in foreign circles interested in the oil business.

THE familiar practice of queuing up for dining-room and deck-chair reservations on board ship may soon become a thing of the past. Nowadays more and more of the larger steamship lines operating between this country and Europe are encouraging passengers to mail in their requests for such accommodations so that when they get aboard they won't be faced with the confusion and tiresome waiting in line that usually fills the first hours of a voyage.

IN the window of a real estate office on Bellevue Avenue here there are thirty or forty cards setting out the virtues of various properties for sale. The properties are of all kinds, but there is a certain pointed significance in the juxtaposition of two cards. One says: "BRICK RANCH TYPE." The other says: "250-YEAR-OLD COTTAGE."
Following is the text of President Truman's address yesterday at the keel-laying of the atomic submarine Nautilus, at Groton, Conn., as transcribe by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

If music had no effect on the emotions not a cent would be spent on concerts and operas. Sentimentalists have been known to weep when love songs and dirges have been played. Though all this has been known for centuries it is only in recent years that psychiatrists have seriously considered the possibilities of making use of music in the treatment of abnormal mental states.
TOKYO, Sunday, June 15 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1281, for Saturday's operations:

YOUR reviewer of "Rome and a Villa," speaks of "Piranesi's opium-dream reconstruction of the ancient city." The reference is to the celebrated passage in "Confessions of an English Opium Eater." which begins:

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Cut back the dead flower heads on alyssum, candytuft and other early-flowering perennials, leaving only a neat mound of foliage. When violas start to look leggy, they may be sheared back to half their height for renewed bloom in summer. Cut off three or four inches of the top growth on the perennial asters and 'mums for bushy plants.

SIXTEEN-YEAR OLD Gwen, only child of an indulgent father and an over-efficient mother, suddenly has to share her world with orphaned cousins. Disconcerted when old friends are monopolized by the charming newcomers, she refuses to share with them her interests outside the home.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 14 -- Nearly 6,000 marchers poured through Ferris Thompson Gateway in Princeton University's annual "P-rade" to the 212th Princeton-Yale baseball game today, traditional climax of the alumni weekend.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Harold V. Stirling, assistant administrator for insurance of the Veterans Administration, was today appointed deputy administrator of the agency.

For years emphasis on the use of lights during night driving has been put on keeping the brights from blinding people driving in the opposite lane. Momentary blindness caused by bright lights has been responsible for many of the accidents which have occurred at night.

SATURDAY will be the first day of summer. Reports have been coming in all this month from garden clubs stating that "this is the final meeting of the season!" Most groups will wait for the cooler, less busy days of September and October to renew their projects.

NAPLES, Italy, June 14 -- While the United States command ship Adirondack, anchored in this port, fired two seventeen-gun salutes, Admiral Robert B. Carney relinquished to Vice Admiral Jerauld Wright his responsibilities as Commander in Chief of United States Naval Forces in the aEstern Atlantic and the Mediterranean.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 14 -- Herbert F. Sturdy of Los Angeles has been elected chairman of the Yale Alumni Board, A. Whitney Griswold, president of the university, announced today following a meeting of the organization.

A letter in your June 1 issue expressed the hope that in the future you would grace the magazine cover with the faces of men of extraordinary character, not those of "unfortunates exposed to atheistic communism."

RAHWAY, N. J., June 14 (AP) -- Milt Campbell, Plainfield High's 18-year-old Olympic hopeful, set two hurdles records while winning three events in the New Jersey A. A. U. track and field championships today.

HERE is a quiet, unassuming novel that has moments of true lyric charm and infectious humor. The writer has such a real feeling for people that his characters transcend national barriers and a Western reader soon feels comfortable with the unusual cast -- including the passionate and romantic snake charmer, the lovely girl whom none will marry because her horoscope is accursed, and the matriarch whose worship of tradition leads her to amorality.

A program of seventeen serenades, to be held Wednesday at 8:15 P. M., will mark the close of a series of monthly recorded concerts at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. Philip L. Miller, acting chief of the Music Division, will be the commentator. The concerts will be resumed in October.

THAT colossal musical "exposition" entitled "Masterpieces of the Twentieth Century," of which much has been said in these columns, has finally come to an end after running most of us ragged with the number and brilliancy of its performances.

THIS is the third novel in the sprawling trilogy begun with "The Sun Is My Undoing" in 1941 and continued with "Twilight on the Floods" eight years later. Like them, it abounds in color and violence, tumbles with incident and leaves the reader with matter to ponder.

FRECKLES have probably been around since the first strong sunbeam struck the first freckle-susceptible nose, but they have never been popular. People have tried to bleach them out, peel them off, cover them up; but the freckle, as persistent as its pursuers has usually won, hands down.

IN spite of general opinion to the contrary, I have found primulas easy to grow from seed. Here in New Jersey the plants flourish for years, and there is no reason why they should not behave the same in any section of the Northeast. Of course, the soil has to be right.

THE present prominence of the English novelists Graham Greene and Evelyn Waugh has focused popular attention on the Roman Catholic writer -- or, as Mr. Greene recently decribed himself, on the "writer who happens to be a Catholic." During his recent visit to New York, Mr. Greene went out of his way to make the distinction.

AMONG the giant states of the modern world, a nation of less than ten million inhabitants stands a fair chance of being overlooked. The risk is all the greater if the country does not appear, at first glance, to lie in a very exposed or strategically decisive area. Size and geography thus conspire against Australia's claim to play an active and effective part in the free world.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The Subversive Activities Control Board passed a theoretical midway mark this week in its first and most crucial proceeding under the Internal Security (McCarran) Act of 1950. It began hearing the Communist party of the United States tell why it should not be compelled to register as part of a world-wide Communist revolutionary movement.

NEW DELHI, India, June 14 -- At the request of the Indian Government, a mission of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, headed by George D. Woods, chairman of the board of the First Boston Corporation, arrived here today to explore the possibilitiies of the bank's advancing a loan for expansion of India's iron and steel industry.
Shirt manufacturers are happy for the first time in a year and a half as they discuss next season's prospects. Even the die-hard pessimists no longer talk of getting out of the business.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 14 -- The vanguard of 10,000 delegates representing 175,000 of this country's nurses were arriving here this week-end for a session on Monday at Convention Hall.

ALBANY, June 14 (AP) -- In a split decision that may lead eventually to a revision of the state's censorship law, the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court upheld yesterday the New York ban against the French film, "La Ronde."

ON THE BANK OF NEAL'S CREEK, N. C. -- Envious husbands, sitting on the bank of Neal's Creek watching their wives fight stubborn trout, probably think things have come to a pretty pass for fishermen in North Carolina.

VIENNA, June 14 -- Recent events in Rumania, Czechoslovakia and Hungary have demonstrated that, next to coal mining, agriculture has become the most formidable problem for the Communist regimes of the East block. From an ideological viewpoint it is even more formidable.
WASHINGTON, June 14 (UP) -- The United States will have more than enough tin to meet all its essential needs this year, Government officials said today.
CHICAGO, June 14 (UP) -- The White Sox defeated the Red Sox today, scoring twice in the eighth inning for a 4-to-2 decision before 12,742 fans.

Americans were urged by Rabbi Israel Goldstein, president of the American Jewish Congress, in his sermon yesterday morning at Temple B'nai Jeshurun. Eighty-eighth Street, west of Broadway, "to live dangerously and be alert to crises."

A broadened welfare benefit plan land a new system of weekly disability payments has been instituted by the Seafarers International Union, A. F. L., under the terms of its agreement with its contracted companies.

The stealthy tread of a burglary suspect proved his undoing when the occupant of the apartment beneath the one he was allegedly robbing at 591 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, became alarmed by the unfamiliar footsteps and phoned the police.

IGOR STRAVINSKY, clad in a sport shirt and tennis trousers, came back to his dressing room from the stage of the Champs-Elysees Theatre, where he had been conducting the dress rehearsal of his opera-oratorio, "Oedipus Rex," before a packed house. He flung off the shirt, wringing wet with perspiration and remarked, in Russian.

A pair of young hoodlums who entered Patsy's Pizzeria at 2287 First Avenue, near East 117th Street, early yesterday morning with the idea of kidnapping the owner were very sorry about ten minutes later that they hadn't settled for a pizza pie instead.
Wesley D. Osborne's letter of June 1 sounds like double talk rather than a sure bet.
MILWAUKEE, June 14 -- Senator Joseph McCarthy and Gov. Walter Kohler today had unanimous reelection endorsements of the Republican State Convention.

ARDMORE, Pa., June 14 -- Champion Bang Away of Sirrah Crest, record breaking boxer owned by Dr. and Mrs. R. C. Harris of Santa Ana, Calif., and handled by Nate Levine, scored his sixty-third best in show victory today at the Bryn Mawr Kennel Club's annual all breed event.

MILWAUKEE, June 14 (UP) -- The 1952 American Bowling Congress tournament ended today with new champions crowned in all divisions and a new record for doubles set during the eighty-five days of shooting.

ATOGO chief with wife trouble, a Somali farmer robbed of a cow, a Ruanda schoolboy who failed his exams, these and hundreds of other folk with complaints are getting personal consideration these days as the United Nations Trusteeship Council carries on its sessions here this month and next.

OMAHA, June 14 (AP) -- Missouri nipped Penn State, 3 -- 2, for its third straight victory and the commanding role in the National Collegiate Athletic Association baseball tournament as Junior Wren, normally an outfielder, hurled a two-hit game for the Tigers.

SALT LAKE CITY, June 14 -- W. Averell Harriman announced tonight that ten of Utah's twelve-vote Democratic delegation, heretofore uncommitted and uninstructed, had been pledged in his behalf for the National Convention opening in Chicago July 21.

AS in several previous books Mr. Lane successfully combines information with a well written story. Far from their native state of Maine, Len, Am, and Ted of the sloop Altair, now tangle with oil pirates in the Gulf of Mexico.

More than 38,000 opportunities are offered this year to students for study in countries other than their own, according to the new edition of "Study Abroad," an international handbook of fellowships, scholarships and study grants, prepared by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization. The United States is the largest donor of fellowships, with 14,000 study opportunities listed.

SINCE 1945, when he renounced communism, Louis F. Budenz has been one of the most articulate of anti-Communists. Yet, as managing editor of The Daily Worker, he was so enmeshed in the Communist conspiracy that even now he seems able to view the world only through his old conspiratorial glasses.
DALLAS, June 14 -- Ben Hogan received an ovation as he walked off the eighteenth green of the Northwood Club today, but he was no longer the United States open golf champion.

MR. SALTER states on page 4 of his book that the following "are [among] the fundamental principles that guide the psychoanalyst in the treatment of EVERY man who comes into his office" (capitals Mr. Salter's):
CHICAGO, June 14 (AP) -- Hasty House Farm's Seaward won the twenty-fifth running of the Lincoln Handicap before 22,036 at Hawthorne Park today as Lincoln Fields closed its meeting there.

SOME research student might profitably undertake an Investigation into the Reasons for Dullness in Books About Rainer Maria Rilke. It is a literary irony that this great poet, so restlessly and insistently alive in every turn of his verse and prose, should act like a kind of Medusa-head upon his admiring critics.
The last of the 1952 Presidential primaries has been held; practically all of the delegates have been chosen; and just three weeks from tomorrow the Republican National Convention will begin.

ANYONE who could "make ten or twenty millions out of nothing" interested that smoothest of Fleet Street editors, David Wensley. Especially when the multimillionaire happened to be the man he hated most, his boss, the Baron. But what really fascinated Wensley was how such lords of creation got their first start.

Eugene Holman was bound to be an oil man, although he fought the thought while in school. Texas-born and raised in the first excitement of the oil boom in the Southwest, he now heads up the giant of the oil industry, Standard Oil Company (New Jersey).

THERE is no spectacle in the realm of animate nature which for sheer beauty, exquisite color and unbelievable grandeur quite approaches that of a large flock of scarlet flamingos taking to the air en masse in their native haunts.

MOTORISTS driving up the Maine coast to the fishing and game country of New Brunswick or the scenic Gaspe area encounter a unique manifestation of international goodwill on arriving at the twin border cities of Calais, Me., and St. Stephen, N. B., which face each other across the St. Croix River.

The recruitment of athletic talent, believed by many officers to have been a factor in the cheating scandal at West Point last year, has long been an unofficial, but approved, policy at the United States Naval Academy at Annapolis, which has just concluded another academic year.

Gertrude Samuels' "The Child's Name Is Today" (June 1) is as clear a presentation as I have seen on the work of the International Children's Emergency Fund (UNICEF), and I am writing to congratulate both you and Miss Samuels.

Thousands of persons who go abroad this summer and return here clutching antique "treasures" are in for a shock when Uncle Sam thrusts out an imperious hand and demands the payment of duty, Harvey J. Penson said yesterday.

ANOTHER chapter in the history of Newark Airport was written last week when the Port of New York Authority voted to reopen the big field on a limited basis as of midnight tonight. Closed since Feb. 11, when the third of the Elizabeth, N. J., crashes occurred, the field has been handling only military traffic in the last few weeks.

Jockey Stephen Anthony DiMauro, a recent star graduate from the apprentice ranks, suffered a broken right leg in a two-horse spill that occurred as the field started around the second turn in the eighth race at Aqueduct yesterday.

WALTHAM, Mass., June 14 -- Brandeis University, begun four years ago as an experiment in Jewish sponsorship of non-sectarian education, will conduct its first commencement exercises here Monday with the granting of degrees to 101 seniors. Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt, a trustee, will be the principal speaker.

THE peculiar feature of Indian Ocean history is that for centuries Europeans did not know the way into it, save by land across the isthmus of Suez and the long caravan route by Constantinople to the Persian Gulf. Hence the fantastic legends about "Prester John" and "The Grand Khan."

A 19-year-old Army private was held in $1,000 bail for a hearing June 20 on a vehicular homicide charge by Magistrate Samuel Orr in Bronx Magistrates Court yesterday in connection with the death earlier of a friend. He was killed when a door opened and he fell from the car while it was reportedly traveling at least seventy miles an hour.

TOKYO, Sunday, June 15 (AP) -- The Far East Air Forces today announced that wreckage tentatively identified as that of a missing B-29 Superfort with twelve persons aboard, has been sighted in the Sea of Japan.

CLEVELAND, June 14 -- Starting with Yogi Berra's three-run homer in the first and concluding with a five-run outburst in the ninth, the Yankees made things easy for Vic Raschi today at Municipal Stadium. And, with the big right-hander blanking the Indians, 11 -- 0, with four hits, Casey Stengel's club skipped back into the league-lead.

VENICE, Italy, June 14 (UP) -- The twenty-sixth International Art Show was inaugurated here today by President Luigi Einaudi who announced that the international jury had awarded the first prize for the best foreign sculptor to an American.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 14 -- Pronto Don, 7-year-old chestnut gelding owned by the Hayes Fair Acres Stable of Du Quoin, Ill., tonight became the third trotter ever to go over the $200,000 mark in earnings by taking the Adelphi free-for-all mile test at Roosevelt Raceway in 2:04 3/5.
WITH solstice time less than a week away, the has come to set forth the prospects for the theatre season in the barns, tents, Odd Fellows halls and other structures that comprise the summer circuit.

THE issue between the dam-builders and the sportsmen-conservationists, on the relative values of recreation and power, may become a Congressional problem in the very near future as a result of the failure of Army Engineers to consider the wildlife aspect in planning dams in the White River Basin of Arkansas and Missouri.

Many buyers were in the wholesale markets here last week, shopping fall lines and placing initial orders, resident buying offices reported. Substantial orders were placed as buyers crowded showrooms, but all are leaving a reasonable amount for future open-to-buy.

A BOON to families traveling by railway this summer is the economy group plan offered by fourteen Eastern railroads. Under the plan, small groups of three or more adults traveling together will obtain a flat 25 per cent discount on round-trip coach tickets.

President Truman's address at Groton yesterday at the keel-laying of the atom-powered submarine Nautilus ranged from the sublime to the political. Politics, we think, will be soon forgotten. Behind the politics was the still astounding fact of the planned production of the first full-scale, work-performing atomic power plant.

THE author of "The Kings of the Road" didn't come tooling up in a Hispano Suiza or a Lancia or a Stutz 8 or a Duesenberg. As a matter of fact, he strolled in and he had obviously been strolling along the street, too. It didn't make him look any better for the wear.
Women representing the New England Lawn Tennis Association defeated an Eastern lawn tennis association team, 6 -- 3, to retain the Sears Cup at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills yesterday.

THE light novels of Miss Doner generally unfold against a factual background which informs the reader about some industry or specialized activity. After reading "Host Rock" it's easy to envisage a procession of her pert little heroines and manly heroes pursuing one another through the mazes of the beet industry and the Great Lakes shipping industry.

NAHMA, Mich. -- Along with the sturgeon, whose Indian name it bears, this former sawmill town on Michigan's Upper Peninsula is staging a comeback. At least the sturgeon, which has dwindled alarmingly both in size and numbers in past years, appears to be making a comeback in this area.

ROME -- One of Rome's biggest sight-seeing bargains, virtually unknown to tourists and seldom if ever mentioned by travel agencies, is a streetcar named Esterna Destra -- or Sinistra, depending upon whether one travels clockwise or counter-clockwise around the Eternal City.

THE tax-burdened citizen who elects to buy (for 18 shillings) or borrow a new and handsome 300-page volume entitled "The British Film Industry" will be rewarded with the encouraging conclusion that if he wants to continue to have a native film industry he had better be prepared to go on paying for it.

DANBURY, Conn., June 14 -- Transient motorists passing through Danbury will have to continue contending with traffic bottlenecks here until the State Highway Department goes ahead with its long-awaited plan to reroute United States Routes 6 and 7 around the city, Mayor John P. Previdi has informed State Highway Commissioner G. Albert Hill.

A national fencing team title was taken from the Eastern Seaboard for the first time since 1906 when Northern Ohio Composite quartet topped a field of eleven rivals in epee team competition at the Fencers Club last night.

TWO projects, dissimilar in intent, spirit and auspices, currently in the art news, are related, however, because each is concerned with architecture and each is admirable in its own way. One is the plan for the new sculpture court to be built in the garden on the Fifty-fourth Street side of the Museum of Modern Art.

AT present I rise every day early, a practice which contributes much to the preservation of health, for its knits up the nerves and gives hardiness and vigour to the entire constitution. There are many people who have made themselves weak and sickly simply by sleeping too much, or rather by a vile habit of wasting the precious morning hours in lazy slumber.

IN her passionately felt first novel, Jeanne Wylie touches upon an impressive and bewildering array of themes. Whether dealing with segregation of the Negro, subversive elements on a university campus, the troubles of a crusading newspaper in the hands of two fiery young war veterans, or the romantic tangles of principal characters, "Face to Face" rings with conviction and sympathy.

THE Kodak Retinette 35mm. miniature camera, which is a small version of the Kodak Retina, was announced last week. Principal features are the new camera's pocket size, shutter speeds to 1/300th, built-in flash synchronization, Schneider Reomar 50mm f/4.5 three-element lens and automatic film wind, exposure counter and double-exposure prevention.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Not since the old, old days of 1945, when so many were so fond of speaking of Harry S. Truman's "humility," have his relations with Congress been anything more cordial than tentatively warm.

IN the days before the white man, two Indian boys, one the only son of a chief and the other a slave, following the tribal custom, set out upon a search for a Spirit Helper for Eagle, the chief's son. The hazardous voyage in a canoe among the islands off the northwest coast of America tests to the utmost the skill, courage and loyalty of the 14-year-old slave.

THE historical novels of Bruce Lancaster have always managed to ring a refreshing variation on familiar material. Dealing, for the most part, with some aspect of our home-grown wars, they have never failed to enlarge the reader's perspective on those conflicts.

THE legal niceties of the internment of 110,000 Japanese-Americans during World War II have been debated at length. Many authorities learned in the law have said that General De Witt's famous order, placing the Nisei behind barbed wire, was of dubious constitutionality.

SOME of the finest gardens I have ever seen were planted along the sea. Perhaps this is because the flowers thrive on the tangy salt air as much as the sojourner busily acquiring a healthy tan. Then, again, it may be that the simple background of an uncluttered Cape Cod cottage shows them off to better advantage.

In the Presidential battle the first week of June was all Eisenhower. The general returned from Europe, shed his uniform and established a beach-head by a series of public speeches, press conferences and private interviews. The consensus at the end of the week was: "Ike has a firm beach-head; now all he has to do is exploit it."

Auction sales here, all at once, have become events of some uncommonness. Some galleries have suspended activity for the season, but others will be functioning throughout the summer, although on a reduced schedule.

THE first 2 1/4x2 1/4 twin-lens reflex camera with interchangeable lenses to reach the market was introduced here last week at a reception by the commercial attache to the French Embassy. The camera is the Rex Reflex, which will be sold at $298.50 for the camera and two pairs of interchangeable lenses, with taking lenses of 75mm (3-inch) and 150mm (6-inch) focal length.
BOSTON, June 14 (UP) -- Hal Jeffcoat tripled home two runs in the fifteenth inning today to break up a 1-1 tie and give the Cubs a 3-1 triumph over the Braves before 4,922 at Braves Field.

There is good news both for city dwellers and for farm people in the latest Department of Agriculture report. The wheat crop this year promises to top 1,300,000,000 bushels and come close to the record of 1947. The prospects for other major crops are above average over most of the country and the outlook for the 1952-53 citrus crop is good.

THE American suspicion of backroom politicking goes back a long way. Almost two centuries ago a young Bostonian named John Adams confided to his diary that he had just learned that some local politicians were holding secret meetings in Tom Dawes' garret.
MADISON, Wis., June 14 -- An underdog Wisconsin crew defeated California by two and one-quarter lengths on placid Lake Mendota today.

THE importance of high school driver education as a factor in reducing highway accidents has been recognized by the Governors of the forty-eight states, and they are unanimous in urging its extension. In a symposium compiled by the American Automobile Association the chief executives of the states call training for young people one of the best long-range answers to road accidents and fatalities.

The total revenue from the sale of $5 and $10 auto use tax stamps since June 2 was estimated yesterday at $6,879,720 by City Collector Alexander E. Frontera as his offices in the five boroughs closed their doors at 5 P. M.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Republicans launched new attacks today on what they call "socialized medicine" provisions of a bill to increase Social Security insurance benefits, but party leaders passed the word that they would not seek to block the measure again when it comes up in the House of Representatives next week.
The Long Island Rail Road announced yesterday that it would meet two of the demands made by the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, independent, representing 309 engineers.

LONDON, June 14 -- While diplomats here guessed today about the inner meaning of Mr. Gromyko's assignment to London, his prececessor, George N. Zarubin, departed unobtrusively for the Soviet Union on a little white ship of only 2,900 tons.

IT is almost unfair to say that this sincere and partly successful attempt to write meaningfully about pleasant everyday people is as pedestrian as its characters. One should, perhaps, care very much about the fate of Paul Saxton, a young New Yorker like any other and even more so.

TO many, this book will come as a startling documentation of Emma Bovary, Marguerite Gauthier and other dark heroines of nineteenth-century French literature. For Marie Lafarge was a real person, center of a cause celebre of the Eighteen Forties, but so like the fictitious ladies as to be astonishing.

ANNE FRANK'S diary is too tenderly intimate a book to be frozen with the label "classic," and yet no lesser designation serves. For little Anne Frank, spirited, moody, witty, self-doubting, succeeded in communicating in virtually perfect, or classic, form the drama of puberty.

SINGAPORE, June 14 -- The large-scale resettlement of rural inhabitants has dealt a heavy blow to the Communist rebels in Malaya, but at the same time it has caused many difficulties for the Government, an official survey of the resettlement program, released here from Kuala Lumpur, reveals.

Studies made in the University of California's division of civil engineering and irrigation under the supervision of William J. Oswald and Harold B. Gottas, by Harvey F. Ludwig, now an officer of the U. S. Public Health Service, show that it is possible to produce high-protein food from sewage. If the idea is repulsive let it be remembered that we think nothing of eating vegetables grown on farms that have been fertilized with manure.

Investigation Commissioner James H. Sheils confirmed yesterday reports that he had been investigating for the last three months the financial status of "selected" city employes, with special attention to those engaged in inspectional services in several city departments.

TELEVISION'S coverage of General Eisenhower's press conference in Abilene, Kan., may rank as one of the milestones in the developing maturity of the medium. For the first time, in Abilene, the video industry stood up for its rights as a new arm of journalism and refused to be locked out of an important news event. And it won!

BERLIN, June 14 -- The military training of East German youth was boasted about by Soviet zone youth officials today. Pictures were published in the Communist-controlled Free German Youth newspaper of young boys and girls marching with rifles and carbines.

INTEREST in the Civil War shows no sign of abating, with at least ten new books on the subject published in 1951. All such books, if based on serious research, must tap the memoirs of U. S. Grant, the victorious general -- a character more spectacular than Abraham Lincoln.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- For an old soldier who was going to "fade away" General of the Army Douglas MacArthur remains very close to the center of the political spotlight.

Back in 1922 a young dancing instructor called at the office of the late Wilbur Ruthrauff, co-founder of the advertising agency known as Ruthrauff Ryan. He introduced himself as Arthur Murray, said that he had been in business eight years and that he was seek-to expand the mail order instruction activities of his small dance studio at 100 Fifth Avenue.

THE reviewer of "Is Anybody Listening?" states that he has been puzzled for years by the failure of the American business man to impress the American public with the virtues of free enterprise, despite his success in business and garrulousness in everyday life. May I offer an explanation?

SUMMER is iris planting time. In addition to the familiar tall, bearded aristocrats, there are many other kinds that are both delightful to look at and fascinating to grow. Some of them may need winter protection in the vicinity of New York City. but they add considerable variety to a lengthened iris season.

In deciding to help offset an operating deficit by borrowing $3,500,000,000 of new money on an issue of unrestricted bonds of intermediate term, the Treasury has taken a step in debt management that carries a host of striking meanings to the financial marketplace.

HARRISBURG, Pa., June 14 -- Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam, Methodist Resident Bishop of New York since 1944, was assigned to the influential Washington area of the church today at the denomination's twelve-state Northeastern Jurisdictional Conference.
A man in Billings, Mont., who was trying to sell the city a radar device for catching speeders was arrested for speeding by a policeman whose only scientific aid was a speedometer.

THE annual Mobilgas Economy Run, which measures the gasoline mileage capabilities of standard cars, produces a lot of records for the automobile companies and a healthy amount of skepticism on the part of average motorists. The average motorist cannot come very close to duplicating the mileage records piled up in the test -- and he would look and feel pretty silly while doing it, if he could.

Four hundred men, women and children, many of them wearing kilts and tartans of Scottish clans, joined yesterday in the twenty-sixth annual parade and commemoration exercises for Robert Burns, Scottish poet. The ceremonies were conducted under the auspices of the Robert Burns Memorial Association of America.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, June 1 -- The impending establishment of an Imperial Ethiopian College of Agriculture and Mechanical Arts, linked to Oklahoma A. and M., will mark the effective beginning of the Point Four Program in Ethiopia and, it is expected, will hasten the emergence of this country as a modern state.

HY LAVINTHAL complains that his latest bidding formula -- one of several that he has devised and that have been adapted for incorporation into the Culbertson bidding system -- was misrepresented in this column last week.

Six hundred patients at Goldwater Memorial Hospital on Welfare Island all but forgot their wheelchairs and stretchers yesterday when they took a mythical trip through fairyland and hobnobbed with Mother Goose's children.

POMPANO BEACH, Fla. -- All along Florida's east coast it is an open secret among deep-sea fishermen that, when you can't get a nibble elsewhere, you can nearly always pick up a couple of kingfish or an amberjack or two if you troll off the mouth of Hillsborough Inlet.

THE greetings and gifts and affections that are (theoretically) being lavished on male parents today -- it being Father's Day -- are all very nice in their way, but a certain few facts have to be faced. All the evidence indicates that Father's Day is not so much a positive thing as a negative.

DETROIT, June 14 -- Presenting himself to a crowd of 6,000 in Olympia Stadium here as "strictly a no-deal man," General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower tonight answered nine major questions in a personal bid for Michigan's forty-six delegates to the Republican National Convention.
KOJE ISLAND, Korea, Sunday, June 15 -- United States guards hurled tear-gas grenades into three new prison stockades yesterday when fanatical Communists defied orders.

THE major-party conventions in July officially open the main show in this year's edition of our national campaign circus. Meanwhile, the minor parties and their candidates -- traditional sideshows on the political midway -- are also setting up their time - honored concessions, proving once again that almost anybody can run for President.

The dominant position of the Federal Reserve System when exercising its orthodox powers is being demonstrated in the money market. Federal funds, the money which banks borrow to meet their reserve requirements, have been quoted ten weeks at 1 1/2 per cent or higher. This has been the longest tight period in the money market since just prior to the banking holiday in 1933.
Well over $1,000,000,000 a year is being siphoned from American industry through the thievery of employes.

WITH THE FIRST BRITISH COMMONWEALTH DIVISION, in Korea, June 14 (AP) -- Field Marshall Earl Alexander, British Minister of Defense, said today a new Communist offensive in Korea "would take a terrific loss and would not break through."

AT the rate unfamiliar compositions are being recorded, restitution will soon be made for all the injustices of neglect the great composers have suffered. One of the latest bodies of little-considered music that is now beginning to receive its due, for instance, is the chamber music of Handel.

Brandeis University, at Waltham, Mass., founded in 1948, will complete its full undergraduate cycle this month and graduate its first senior class. From its inception, the university has aimed at the development of an undergraduate liberal arts college of not more than 800 students, with a low student-faculty ratio of nine to one.

Israel's high-ranking leaders, headed by Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion, emphasized last night that the Zionist movement must taken the lead in forging a "partnership" between American Jews and Israel. Such a partnership, it was stressed, would involve the mustering of economic and financial assistance for the fledgling state as well as intensifying Zionist education among Jewish people.

A 6-year-old Greek orphan who has been adopted by a retired restaurant owner of Battle Creek, Mich., arrived at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, from Athens yesterday. His surname is unknown to Greek authorities; his first name is Stavros.

IF there proves to be factual basis for a claim which emanates from Austria regarding "the world's first postage stamp," philatelic history as set down in textbooks and encyclopedias across the past century will have to be rewritten.

The Giants made their first Sabbath home appearance of the year at the Polo Grounds yesterday under a blazing sun and before a sweltering crowd of 41,899, the season's largest National League gathering. But, all things considered, it might have been better had it rained just once more.

With the aid of underwater television the British Admiralty has succeeded in finding the submarine Affray, which sank off the Alderney Islands in the Channel. Echo-sounding had located a score of hulks in the area, but it took television to identify the Affray. In another demonstration a tempting bed of clams came into view, whereupon a diver was sent down to dig up enough for the wardroom mess.

Brooklyn College conferred 2,077 degrees and diplomas last night on the second largest graduating class in its history. Six thousand guests watched the college's twenty-seventh commencement exercises held on the grass-covered campus quadrangle.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (UP) -- Americans can expect "fairly stable" prices during the coming year, an American University report said today.
A number of diverse exhibitions and the opening of one new gallery are among the art events this week.

The present world crisis offers organized religion a great opportunity to increase its adherents, the Rev. Anson Phelps Stokes Jr., rector of St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street, declared in a sermon yesterday.

Sure, it's a great day for the Irish, for hams and bacons are again arriving from the land of the Murphys, McCarthys and McCraes. These have been off the American market for a year, much to the disquiet of our Irish-American citizenry, who consider them to be almost as precious as the Blarney Stone, and unquestionably more delicious.

BOSTON, June 15 -- (UP) -- Max Surkont twirled a two-hit shut-out today as the Braves beat the Cubs, 4 -- 1 and 2 -- 0, to capture their first doubleheader of the year and move into sixth place in the National League.

CLEVELAND, June 15 (AP) -- New and expanded plants in the steel industry should be able to turn out enough steel this year to make up for production losses due to strikes, the Magazine Steel reported today.

CHICAGO, June 15 -- With increased buying activity in corn and oats and a continued broad trade in soybean futures, last week business on the Board of Trade was slightly more active than in the previous week and considerably larger than a year ago.

Asserting that discrimination against Jewish applicants to medical schools in New York State had been found to be continuing, the American Jewish Congress and the New York State Committee on Equality in Education expressed "concern" yesterday over enforcement of the state's 1948 Fair Educational Practices Law.
The 140th anniversary of the founding of The National City Bank of New York will be celebrated today.

The summer series of half-hour dramatic incidents to be presented by Worthington Miner will begin Friday at 8 P. M. over the N. B. C. television network with an original story by Mildred Cram, "The Promise," with Robert Preston and Carol Bruce in leading roles.

The American Government has embarked on a program which could do much to increase Europe's military and economic strength without increasing our expenditures, and even achieve a saving for ourselves. That program, known as "offshore procurement," calls for placing military orders in Europe both for American requirements abroad and for the equipment of the European forces accorded Mutual Security aid.
Four new films and one that will resume an interrupted premiere engagement are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

PORTLAND, Me., June 15 -- Maine's bitterest primary campaign in twenty years closed tonight on a note of tension with both Senator Owen Brewster and Gov. Frederick G. Payne expressing confidence of being nominated for the Senate by Republicans in balloting tomorrow.

LE MANS, France, June 15 (AP) -- German Mercedes-Benz autos placed first and second in the Le Mans 24-hour sports car endurance race today with a British Nash-Healey third and an American Cunningham fourth.

Stephen Anthony DiMauro, 19-year-old jockey from Camden, N. J., who was injured in a two-horse spill at the Aqueduct race track on Saturday, was reported to be in good condition yesterday at Physicians Hospital in Jackson Heights.

CARLSTADT, N. J., June 15 -- Amateur pilots of speeding outboards had their big regatta afternoon of the early season today on the smooth flowing Hackensack River. The race meet was postponed from May 25 when a deluge of rain stopped even these intrepid pancake drivers.
LONDON, June 15 -- Although the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II, officially set for June 2, 1953, is still almost a year away, London is already suffering from anticipatory jitters.
DETROIT, June 15 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower told reporters today that he favored giving 18-year-olds the right to vote.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 15 -- Reno Bounce, from the Sunnyside Riding Club of Westwood, N. J., took the working hunter championship at the Greenwich horse show today. Why Not of the W. J. Brewster Stables, Southern Pines, N. C., set back on a protest in the preliminary event, won the reserve award after a tie on points with Miss Diana from Mrs. John J. Farrell's Darien stable.

Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., national chairman of the Harriman for President Committee, declared yesterday that W. Averell Harriman, Director for Mutual Security, now had more than one hundred delegates to the Democratic National Convention pledged to support him for the nomination for President.

PITTSBURGH, June 15 -- Steel production last week was estimated at about 13 per cent of rated capacity. This was a drop of 24 points from a revised rate of 37 per cent in the previous week. Compared to pre-strike levels the rate last week was off 89 1/2 points.
BOSTON, June 15 -- Anti-Communist forces have won the cold war, but much more remains to be done in order to insure peace, Erwin D. Canham, editor of the Christian Science Monitor, said tonight.

The Tottenham Hotspurs and Manchester United, England's top league soccer teams, played their heralded match at the Yankee Stadium yesterday but the game failed to live up to its billing. Rated as a battle that would be a close one all the way, the contest proved anything but that as the Hotspurs romped to a 7-to-1 triumph.
DENVER, June 15 -- How's Ike doing?
An audience of 6,300 assembled in the amphitheatre of Flushing Meadow Park last night for the third annual Queens Music Festival sponsored by the American Fund for Israel Institutions.

That Dodger mastery over the Reds, which had held for ten games and six innings of the eleventh, ended suddenly at Ebbets Field yesterday when the Reds came up with six runs in the seventh for a 7-4 triumph.
Engineers and motormen of the Long Island Rail Road were ordered late last night to go on strike at 4 A. M. today.

The latest parlor game seems to be trying to figure out why the Russians are shifting Ambassadors around, and especially why they are sending Gromyko to London. The senior Deputy Foreign Minister and ex-Ambassador to Washington would now rank in the diplomatic hierarchy as in third place after Molotov and Vishinsky.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 15 (UP) -- The King of Cambodia dismissed today the Democratic party's dictatorial government, which had been flirting with Communist rebels in this war-torn Indo-China state.

Checked yesterday by members of the Sailing Committee, headed by Ernest Ratsey, there appeared to be fifty-eight blue water yachts being made ready for the Cruising Club of America's race from Newport, R. I., to Bermuda which will start on Saturday.

LONDON, June 15 (UP) -- The Soviet Embassy denied today that its Second Secretary had fled from Britain after the arrest of a man charged with having given the Soviet aide British secrets. The embassy said the diplomat had spent the day in the country.

The production and distribution of a nation's output involves innumerable transactions, ranging from buying and selling goods and services and hiring labor to investing capital and paying taxes. The volume, rate and character of these transactions over any given period reflect in their aggregate the general state of the economy.

There are two or three times in a young man's life when the smoking of tobacco is likely to become an acute problem. One may fall somewhere between the tender ages of 8 and 12, when the urge to experiment grows stronger than the will to do at all times what one has been told is proper.

PARIS, June 15 -- The alarm voiced last Wednesday by Winston Churchill, Prime Minister of Britain, has just found striking justification in the figures published yesterday by the European Payments Union. The total deficit recorded by Great Britain (and through her by the sterling area) reached a record level of $1,096,000,000.

WENTWORTH - BY - THE-SEA, N. H., June 14 -- A glowing picture of Canada's progress during the past decade and its even brighter prospects for the immediate future was painted for members of the Savings Bank Association of New Hampshire here today by J. Allan Ross, chairman of the executive committee of the Dominion Bank of Toronto, Canada.
" A Pin to See the Peep Show," a drama based on a much-discussed English murder case of the early Nineteen Twenties, has been scheduled for presentation on Broadway in late October.

Characterized by a feeling of elegance and space, a newly decorated apartment, the home of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Maslow at 20 Plaza Street, Brooklyn, embodies some storage and open-floor plan features that might, in some degree, be adopted in other homes.

LONDON, June 15 -- With a feeling of tense and anxious expectancy not only the city but the business community throughout the country last week awaited the statement of R. A. Butler, Chancellor of the Exchequer, on Britain's gold and dollar reserves.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Even 10-year-old Linda, confined to her bedroom with the mumps, got into the act today as the public received a television view of the home life of Senator Estes Kefauver.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., June 15 -- The ninth scheduled regatta of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound, under the sponsorship of the New Rochelle Yacht Club, drew seventy-six starters today for the second largest turnout of the year. Sailed under ideal conditions in a moderate south-southwesterly, the regatta was marked by five repeat class winners over the week-end.

The possibility of repeal of the city's tax of 25 per cent on retail liquor license fees was shattered yesterday when it was found that the anticipated annual yield of $8,000,000 from the $5 and $10 auto use tax conformed with the estimates of the city's financial experts instead of exceeding them by $2,000,000.
BERLIN, June 15 (AP) -- Under Communist police spurring, East Germany's Christian Democratic Union confessed today that "American imperialist agents have forced their way into our ranks."

The Jewish Theological Seminary of America ordained twenty-three students, a record number, as rabbis yesterday at its fifty-eighth annual commencement exercises. Twelve hundred persons attended the ceremonies, held in the seminary quadrangle at the school, Broadway and 122d Street.
