MEXICO CITY, June 14 (UP) -Foreign Minister Manuel Tello said today he would protest to the United States State Department if reports of "discrimination" against a Mexican diplomat in Texas were true.

The National Industrial Conference Board yesterday issued a survey indicating that the current production of military aircraft is at a rate of only 1,250 planes a month and that attainment of the recommended 143-wing Air Force must be postponed until the end of 1954.

MOSCOW, June 15 -- Pravda informed its millions of readers today that the Presidential candidacy of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower stemmed from a plot by the Democratic party to insure continuance of the Truman policies regardless of whether the Republicans or the Democrats won the November elections.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (UP) -- The United States will have given away or lent an estimated $40,000,000,000 or more in post-war foreign aid by the end of this month, a survey disclosed today.

BOSTON, June 15 -- A former convict was reported by the police here today to have confessed that he strangled Mrs. Marion Robbins, 52-year-old widow, in her Greenwich Village apartment in New York after having picked her up in a bar last Monday.

PHILADELPHIA, June 15 (UP) -- The Phillies, shut out by Howie Pollet, 6 -- 0, in the first game, rallied with five runs in the seventh inning to win the second, 6 -- 3, today and split a double header with the Pirates.

DENVER, June 15 (UP) -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, who came here as a second lieutenant thirty-seven years ago to seek the hand of Mamie Geneva Doud, was welcomed back by 100,000 persons today and told his wife's home town folks that come what will in this year's Presidential campaign, they were not "going to worry."

This is Diamond Jubilee year for the good work carried on by our neighbor, The Herald Tribune. For seventy-five years The Fresh Air Fund has been sending underprivileged New York children to the country for vacations. In that time 774,333 vacations have been provided, in camps and friendly towns, at a cost of $7,000,000, given by more than 16,000 individuals and organizations.

If the gods first aim to make mad those whom they would destroy they seem to have been at it for some time with Mr. Truman about the Taft-Hartley Act. He has seemed on most other matters to be a well-intentioned, effective and law-abiding officer. But from the outset, as to the Taft-Hartley labor statute, he has ignored the Constitution's requirement that the President shall see that the laws be faithfully executed.

The first meeting in history of all Western Hemisphere presidents was advocated here last night by President Anastasio Somoza of Nicaragua, to set up a military organization to "unify tactics and weapons" against "the common danger" of communism.

CHICAGO, June 15 -- Trade in lard was moderately active with a reactionary price tendency at times, the market on the Board of Trade being influenced by the action in vegetable oils as well as by price changes in the hog market. Commission buying was fairly broad on the setbacks, and on the whole hedge pressure was easily absorbed.

Meet this morning one of the unique individuals in television: H. Dunbrack of Everett, Mass., just outside of Boston. He is the owner, operator, chief engineer and producer of his own video station, W-1BHD-TV, and he is the only TV broadcaster alive who doesn't care a bit about program ratings.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The nation's educators have been urged by Paul A. Walker, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, to act promptly lest they lose the benefits of proposed educational television by default.

Although the recruiting of athletes for the United States Naval Academy at Annapolis is carried out without official endorsement, the program is carefully regularized and its sponsors are frank in explaining and defending it.

John York, 32 years old, an electrical engineer who is also a refrigerator sales manager, was held in $1,500 bail on Sullivan Law charges yesterday after an arsenal of war souvenirs was uncovered in his home at 64-53 223d Place, Bayside, Queens.
CHICAGO, June 15 -- Coarse grains showed a definitely stronger trend last week, except in wheat which finished generally lower because of the bearish news on the winter crop.

A formula designed to cut the national debt by 3 per cent each year for four years is offered by Henry H. Heimann, executive vice president of the National Association of Credit Men, in his monthly business review. Mr. Heimann's plan also envisages a similar reduction each year in the Federal tax levy.

ORONO, Me., June 15 -- The key to peace is understanding among the peoples of the world, Dr. Milton E. Eisenhower, President of Pennsylvania State College, said today at the University of Maine's ninety-fifth commencement.

LONDON, June 5 -- The fact that the temperature of the earth's crust fluctuates like the fever chart of a sick man is to be investigated at first hand next month by a series of temperature readings on the floor of the Atlantic by Dr. Edward C. Bullard, director of Britain's National Physical Laboratory at Teddington-on-Thames.

WALTHAM, Mass., June 15 -- Marc Blitzstein has done a truly creative job in preparing his new English adaptation of "The Threepenny Opera," which was performed here last night at Brandeis University's Festival of the Creative Arts.
TOKYO, Monday, June 16 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,282 for Sunday's activities:

ST. LOUIS, June 15 (AP) -- The Browns scored their first doubleheader triumph of the season today, fighting for 11 innings before George Schmees drive in the winning run to give them a 7-6 decision over the Athletics in the finale. The Browns captured the first contest, 6 to 3.

PURCHASE, N. Y., June 15 -- A plane crash from which the pilot walked away unhurt today gave Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the Port of New York Authority, a taste of the conditions against which residents of the areas near Newark Airport have been protesting.

Summer fashions that are as cool to wear as they are to look at are the subject of today's Patterns of The Times. There are two styles, made from Advance patterns, designed to flatter as well as to afford the wearer a maximum amount of comfort on warm sunny days.

With the delivery of thirty-five forty-passenger Martins and four-teen eighty-eight-passenger Lockheed Super Constellations, Eastern Air Lines this summer will have increased its seating capacity in twin-engined and four-engined planes by 55 per cent over last year.

Amid a turbulent setting of sharp debate on complex Zionist problems, Rabbi Irving Miller, spiritual leader of the Sons of Israel Congregation, Woodmere, L. I., was elected president of the Zionist Organization of America last night at Manhattan Center as the organization continued its fifty-fifth annual convention.
A portable, standardized doll-play kit has been developed for use in the study of children's behavior. This was announced last week at Teachers College, Columbia University.

Proposals for improving the grants-in-aid program of the Federal Government to states and local Governmental units, as well as difficulties and objections involved, are discussed rather comprehensively in "Federal Grants and the Business Cycle"* by Dr. James A. Maxwell.

Miss Ruth Coates, a former senior cadet nurse who has been preparing to become a medical missionary in the Belgian Congo, was ordained in the ministry yesterday morning at the Park Avenue Christian Church at Eighty-fifth Street.

TOKYO, Monday, June 16 (AP) -- The newspaper Yomiuri said today Mrs. Tomi Kora had denied sending a message from Hong Kong that said the Soviet Union would repatriate 180,000 Japanese prisoners of World War II if and when Japan concluded a separate peace treaty with the Soviet.

President Truman and the members of his Cabinet have been urged by the National Maritime Union, C. I. O., to support Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer in his controversy with Controller General C. Lindsey Warren over the Government's share in the cost of the superliner United States.

LIMA, Peru, June 16 -- Peru has a big contribution to make to the great defense program of the West as a huge storehouse of vitally important strategic minerals. Her output in at least eleven such metals was stepped up notably last year, and activity is increasing in the whole mineral field.

RUMSON, N. J., June 15 -- Ch. Bang Away of Sirrah Crest, the boxer owned by Dr. and Mrs. R. C. Harris of Santa Ana, Calif., completed a week-end "double" at the Rumson Country Club today. He added best in show in the twenty-second event of the Monmouth County Kennel Club to the one he had taken yesterday at Ardmore, Pa.

ROME, June 15 -- The largest concentration of police forces ever seen in Rome has been quietly moved into the city during the last few days to deal with any disturbances or riots that the Com munists may attempt to stage on the arrival of Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway tomorrow on his first official visit since his appointment as commander of North Atlantic Treaty Organization forces.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 15 -- Western civilization has the capacity for progress, and faith in God will help it travel over "the rocky road to a richer and better life," Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, told the 670 members of the senior class today at the baccalaureate service in the university chapel.

ELIZABETH, N. J., June 15 -- The Mosquito Front, a huge stretch of meadowland here, buzzed tonight as a vanguard of the season's invasion of infamous Jersey pests took wing in what George E. Powers, superintendent of the Union County Mosquito Extermination Commission, predicted would be the worst in several years.

ROME, June 15 -- The tanker Rose Mary, en route to the Mediterranean with 1.000 tons of Iranian oil, was approaching Suez today, according to Dr. Hans Prager, Austrian-born member of the board of directors of the Italian company that has contracted for the purchase of a reported 2,000,000 tons of Iranian oil in the next ten years.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 15 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, former commander of American Occupation Forces in Germany, declared today that America "must be prepared to tell people behind the Iron Curtain when and how they can regain their freedom."

NEWARK, Monday, June 16 -- Newark Airport reopened officially today at 1:01 A. M., Eastern daylight time, with a full staff but for some time thereafter no planes took off or landed. The reopening consisted mainly of turning on additional ground lights.

The National Association of Manufacturers has completed plans for setting up a clearing house to assist small manufacturers to obtain defense work. In announcing this for publication today William J. Grede, president, said the service would enable small concerns "to learn where to go for contracts and assist prime contractors in increasing their lists of potential subcontractors."

MEXICO CITY, June 15 -- United States and Mexican officials joined today in a ceremony to mark the tenth anniversary of the founding of the Benjamin Franklin Library and paid tribute to the library's value in helping to promote better understanding between the two countries.

James Thomas Flexner, who is working on a combined life of Arnold and Andre, reveals that history books, and even the tomb in Westminster Abbey, have made Maj. John Andre a year younger than he actually was when he was hanged for his part in the treason of Benedict Arnold.
A major change in the organization of Soviet economic planning has been revealed in the magazine Bolshevik, organ of the Communist party's Central Committee.

OMAHA, June 15 (AP) -- The slugging Crusaders from Holy Cross smashed their way into the last round of the National Collegiate A. A. baseball tournament with a 15-4 victory tonight over Penn State. Once-beaten Holy Cross will meet unbeaten Missouri tomorrow at 10:30 P. M. (New York time). If Holy Cross wins, another game will be necessary.

Four off-duty policemen were stabbed, one seriously, early yesterday in a street row that the police said resulted from insults hurled at the passing patrolmen by a group outside a tavern at 821 Amsterdam Avenue. In a second incident, two other policemen and a civilian they were trying to save from being attacked were beaten late Saturday night near 807 Amsterdam Avenue.

The alternate-side-of-the-street parking program will go into effect today on the upper West Side and about 2,500 motorists will be deprived of curb space daily in the car-congested section. The curb, from 8 A. M. to 1 P. M., will enable the Department of Sanitation to clean the streets with high-speed mechanized equipment.

PARIS, June 15 -- Debate on France's policy in Tunisia will be resumed this week in the National Assembly to define the nature and scope of a program of home-rule reforms to be put into effect by decree in the strife-torn North African protectorate.

The conflict between the United States and the Iron Curtain nations is a spiritual struggle, Dr. John F. Brosnan, a member of the State Board of Regents, told 1,359 graduates yesterday at the eighty-second annual commencement of St. John's University.

Choosing a trustworthy goal for our lives that meets four specifications was emphasized as "the way to avoid fear and anxiety" in a sermon yesterday morning by Dean James A. Pike at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., June 15 -- The New Jersey delegates to the Democratic National Convention at Chicago on July 21 voted today to insist on a strong civil rights plank for the platform and declared they would oppose the nomination of any Presidential candidate whose views were not in accord with such a plank.

GUATEMALA, June 15 -- Congress passed and sent to President Jacobo Arbenz Guzman today a Communist-backed land reform bill. It becomes the law of the land fifteen days after its publication in The Official Gazette.

CHICAGO, June 15 -- The Jewish Labor Committee, representing more than 500,000 Jewish trade unionists in the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations and members of the Workmen's Circle, world's largest Jewish fraternal order, closed its first annual mid-western conference here today and requested a Presidential veto of the McCarran - Walters immigration bill.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 15 -- The revelation of the traitorous activities of a few fanatics aided the enemies of reform, but the reformer will again became a respected figure in American life. Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, declared today in the baccalaureate sermon opening the Harvard College commencement week.

BUFFALO N. Y., June 15 -- Rabbi Joseph L. Fink of Temple Beth Zion in this city was elected president of the Central Conference of American Rabbis at the close of its sixty-third annual convention here today. He succeeds Rabbi Philip S. Bernstein of Rochester, who had served two years.

TOKYO, Monday, June 16 -- The United Nations truce delegation charged the Communists yesterday with endangering the lives of Allied prisoners of the Korean war by failing to mark camps north of the Thirty-eighth Parallel in which American, British Commonwealth, South Korean and other captured soldiers were interned.

NEW HAVEN, June 15 -- Dr. A. Whitney Griswold, president of Yale University, announced at the annual alumni luncheon here today that the university had signed a contract with the Atomic Energy Commission to step up its atom-smasher to 20,000,000 volts.

President Truman sent a message to the Baltic States Freedom Rally at Town Hall last night condemning the "lawless invasion" of the Baltic States by the Soviet Union twelve years ago. He voiced the hope that the peoples of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania would survive the "grinding tyranny" to which they were now subjected and regain their independence.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio declared today that he would have 150 to 200 more votes than General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower on the first ballot at the Republican National Convention, opening in Chicago July 7.

HEADQUARTERS, Eighth Army, in Korea, June 15 -- Field Marshal Earl Alexander, the British Defense Minister, declared tonight that he was in complete accord with the United Nations conduct of the armistice negotiations. He added that after touring the battlefront he now realized that the Allied position was much stronger than he had thought while in London.

The wool industry plans to undertake a campaign at once aimed at misrepresentation in advertising. Specifically, the Wool Bureau, Inc., the trade group which represents the industry, charges that advertisers are using such terms as "tweed", "flannel", and "cheviot'' to describe synthetic fibers.

The men who govern nations and decide the questions of war and peace should be, if possible, selected in such a way that they are mentally healthy individuals, Dr. William Borberg, permanent delegate of Denmark to the United Nations, declared yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 15 -- There's no longer any need for conjecture about Marlon Brando playing Mark Antony in Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's "Julius Caesar." The studio confirmed the casting over the week-end and simultaneously revealed that John Gielgud had been engaged to play the part of Cassius. This is a role that Mr. Gielgud, one of the contemporary theatre's notable Shakespearean interpreters, played for 1,950 performances at Stratford-on-Avon.

This newspaper's music critic, Olin Downes, reporting from Helsinki on the second annual Sibelius Festival, raises in one's mind some penetrating questions. Finland is a nation of 4,000,000 people, scattered over a considerable area of forests and lakes. For centuries it was ruled either by Sweden or by Russia.

Like fine-spun sugar blowing up a cake of small dimensions and the same old ingredients, clouds of airy speculation are inflating the Kremlin's change of diplomatic guard into a move of world-wide significance. Much is made of the appointment of Andrei Gromyko, Deputy Foreign Minister, to head the Soviet Embassy in London.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (UP) -- Some $3,500,000,000 worth of new Government bonds go on sale tomorrow as the Treasury makes its first bid to borrow a large amount of cash from business since the early days of World War II.

British sterling was severely affected last week by many pressure factors, which included poor British dollar reserves, Prime Minister Churchill's "alarm," low credits in the European Payments Union, and continued rumors of broadening of official trading limits and more convertibility leeway for various types of sterling.

HARRISBURG, Pa., June 15 -- The Rev. Dr. Frederick B. Newell of New York was consecrated a bishop of the Methodist Church here today. Bishop Newell will serve the New York Area of the denomination, replacing Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam who yesterday was assigned to Washington.

New York is having the pleasure of playing host to Ramon Magsaysay, Defense Secretary of the Philippines. Mr. Magsaysay is the sort of person we are happy to meet. He had a hard job thrown at him in the Philippines. He has done that job with rare competence, complete devotion, good humor and inexhaustible energy.

OSSINING, N. Y., June 15 -- Forty-two young Maryknoll missioners, thirty-nine priests and three brothers, started late this afternoon for lifetime posts in Africa, Asia and South and Central America after the thirty-fifth annual departure ceremony in the quadrangle at Maryknoll, major seminary of the Maryknoll Fathers.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., June 15 -- The New York Athletic Club senior eight defeated the Nereid Boat Club of Belleville, N. J., by three lengths in the feature race of the open rowing regatta conducted by the Winged Foot Club in Pelham Bay Lagoon today.

A masked hold-up man was shot and killed at dawn yesterday in a pistol battle in which two policemen were wounded. The dead man's weapon subsequently was linked by the police ballistics bureau to a slaying here last month.

FRESNO, Calif., June 15 -- California's delegation to the Democratic National Convention, with its sixty-eight votes pledged to Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee called today for a "full civil rights plank," including a stand for a compulsory Fair Employment Practices Act, in the party's national platform.

PARIS, June 15 -- Washington dispatches the last few days reported that officials there were puzzled that the French Cabinet had announced its desire for a conference with the Soviet Union without specifying that it must be subject to the conditions laid down in the last Western note -- which required that an impartial commission on German elections should meet and report first.

Few things that General Eisenhower could have done would have won him more respect and esteem (except from ghost writers) than his announcement that he is through with ghost-written speeches. From now on, he declares, he will do his own speech-planning and his own talking as he deems best.

HAMBURG, Germany, June 15 (AP) -- Members of the United States Olympic equestrian team won two major events at the Hamburg international horse show today for the best showing in three pre-Olympic meets.

SINGAPORE, June 15 -- Gen. Sir Gerald Templer, High Commissioner for the Federation of Malaya, left by air today for London as Malaya hailed last week as the most successful so far in the territory's four-year war against the Communist insurgents.

CLEVELAND, June 15 -- The season's largest baseball crowd, 69,468 fans, found out today why the Yankees are leading the American League. It takes pitching, power, defense and determination, and Casey Stengel's men had all of them as they downed the Indians twice, 8 -- 2 and 4 -- 3, in Municipal Stadium.

Clergymen who advocate that children be released from school for supervised religious study were criticized yesterday by the Rev. Laurance I. Neale in his sermon at All Souls Unitarian Church, Lexington Avenue and Eightieth Street.

DETROIT, June 15 (AP) -- The Tigers crushed the Senators, 6-3, with homers by Vic Wertz, Jerry Priddy, Fred Hatfield and Pat Mullin in the first game of a double-header today. But the Senators scored three times in the first inning of the second game, with the help of Mel Hoderlein's two-run single, and won, 4-2.

CHICAGO, June 15 (UP) -- Rookie Dick Gernert's first major league home run with Vern Stephens on base gave the Red Sox a 3-to-2 decision over the White Sox and a double-header split today before 40,905 fans.
FRANKFURT, Germany, June 15 -- Soviet efforts to create a satellite army in East Germany are proceeding methodically, but do not yet appear to have advanced to any threatening degree.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The National Civil Service League urged the Senate today to reject the recommendation of one of its committees that postmasters, United States marshals and Federal customs collectors be kept out of Civil Service.

CHICAGO, June 15 -- Active buying of home furnishings at the summer market opening in Chicago tomorrow was predicted today by market officials. Lawrence H. Whiting, president of the American Furniture Mart, said he expects merchandisers to purchase vigorously, though selectively.

HEWLETT, L. I., June 15 -- An art show that, for most residents of Hewlett and four adjoining communities, is proud evidence of accomplishment, will continue through Tuesday at Lawrence School on Meadowview Avenue, Hewlett Bay Park.

Production of men's clothing continued considerably below 1951 and 1950 levels in April. according to the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U. S. A. Department of Commerce figures using men's suits as an index, show that the industry operated at 56 per

Internationally we still are living according to the law of the jungle. Our high hopes of being out of it were dashed by aggressive attacks which finally involved us by the torpedoing of our ships in 1917 and the sneak bombing of Pearl Harbor in 1941; and now, under threat of atomic destruction of our cities, it is up to us to keep the jungle from closing in.

A variety of new items, including a textured paper suitable for lampshades, Narui pottery and some decorative carved figures, are in the new collection of Japanese imports at Kogei, 23 East Sixty-seventh Street.
Two famous trains, the New York Central's Twentieth Century Limited and the Pennsylvania's Broadway Limited, observed yesterday the fiftieth anniversary of their runs between New York and Chicago.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 15 -- The Israeli Foreign Ministry published today the text of a note it addressed to the Czechoslovak Foreign Ministry June 11 drawing attention to the "atmosphere of mystery" surrounding the arrest of Mardechai Oren, an Israeli citizen.

Completion of the Hunts Point sewage treatment plant in the Bronx will speed the city's plans for new bathing beaches in the Bronx and Queens, Park Commissioner Robert Moses announced yesterday. The new plant, which began operation June 6, is treating about 100,000,000 gallons of sewage a day that formerly flowed through twelve outlets from the Bronx into the upper East River.
New Yorkers got their first real taste of this year's summer heat yesterday as the temperature in the city soared to a record high for 1952 -- a sizzling 90.6 degrees at 7:05 P. M.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., June 15 (AP) -- Frank Havens of the Washington Canoe Club won his second race of the U. S. Olympic trials today when he came home first in the 1,000-meter single blade event for canoes.

GUATEMALA, June 16 -- Congress today discussed the agrarian reform bill by sections, a process that is expected to be completed within the next two days. Since the bill was approved on its third reading by forty-one votes Saturday night, slight if any modifications are anticipated, especially since Opposition Congressmen walked out today protesting over the "arbitrary and undemocratic manner in which Congress approved the bill while one Opposition Congressman was still talking."

DENVER, June 16 (AP) -- General Eisenhower said tonight that if this county deserved her heritage of freedom, there was no more reason to fear the Russians "than there is to fear polywogs swimming down a muddy creek."

Add to the list of films opening this week, "Scarlet Angel," a Universal-International period romantic adventure in Technicolor, with Yvonne De Carlo, Rock Hudson and Richard Denning, which will arrive at the Globe on Friday. Sidney Salkow directed and Leonard Goldstein produced from a story and screen play by Oscar Brodney.

A Brooklyn state Senator, a housewife and a spokesman for a consumers' group urged yesterday at a Public Service Commission hearing that a "top to bottom investigation of natural gas conversion" be undertaken. The hearing was held in the commission's offices at 233 Broadway.

HAVANA, June 16 -- The International Yacht Club today was named the winner of the Hemingway Trophy after the judges disqualified some of the Havana Yacht Club boats in the international marlin fishing tournament which ended last night.

DURING the London blitz of 1940 Maj. Gavin Maxwell dreamed of a peaceful island haven where he could relax after the war. He got out a map of Scotland and, lying full-length upon the floor, drew a circle around the island of Soay in the Hebrides. In 1944 he bought Soay, lock, stock and "feu-duties" from the few crofters who inhabited it.

A preliminary report of a Board of Regents survey of admission policies of the state's nine medical schools, including a cheek on possible discrimination against Jewish applicants, is expected early in the fall, Roger W. Straus, a regent, said yesterday.

Federal efforts to settle a predawn strike of 309 Long Island Rail Road engineers broke down last night, confronting 175,000 riders on the country's busiest commuter line with the certainty of a second day of trouble getting into and out of New York.

Planning to aid American Indians in the United States has long been confused by arguments as to whether the Navahos, Hopis, Sioux and other tribes should be taught to be good Indians or good Americans, it was sug gested here yesterday.
Cotton futures were steady on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and final prices were 18 to 26 points net higher than Friday on active months.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 16 -- Harry J. Anslinger, Commissioner of Narcotics, Washington, said here today that while the narcotic situation in this country was serious and should not be minimized, "we are by no means in a helpless situation."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 16 -- An exposition by Eugene Black, president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, of the proposed International Finance Corporation touched off debate today in the economic and social council of the potentialities of the project which would, it is anticipated, greatly accelerate investment of private capital in under-developed countries.

The New York Philharmonic-Symphony will expand its young people's concerts next season to give three Wednesday afternoon concerts for students living on Long Island's North Shore. Great Neck, Roslyn and Huntington are the communities in which the orchestra will play.

CHICAGO, June 16 -- Heavy receipts of winter wheat at Southwest markets and enough rain in the Northwest to allay apprehension resulted in further price recession in wheat futures, and this had the effect of curtailing buying of other grains.

A plan of financial assistance for all who may require it as a result of enemy attack was announced yesterday by the New York State Civil Defense Commission. It augments the welfare program for free mass care in any post-attack period.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 16 -- Lucille Ball and her husband, Desi Arnaz, stars of the television comedy series, "I Love Lucy," are on the verge of signing contracts wtih Alex Gottlieb, independent producer, to star in one of the four stories he plans to offer as a film feature in "Billy Rose's Broadway Tales."

THOSE who raced for the northern lakes of Maine as soon as the ice went out, and blew on their fingers between casts, will be unhappy to learn that the past week-end provided some of the most exciting landlocked salmon fishing in the memory of the oldest guide on East Grand Lake, and downeasters are noted for longevity.

ROME, June 16 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, commander of North Atlantic Treaty Organization forces, arrived by air from Paris shortly before noon today and stepped into a Rome that was heavily guarded but completely peaceful. The Communists, possibly overawed by the overwhelming concentrations of police, made no serious effort to stir up any trouble.

The Free University of Berlin, which last July received a Ford Foundation grant of $1,309,500, will soon break ground for a large, modern library building of a design that was described yesterday as one "that might well set the pace for a new type of architecture in Western Europe."
ALEXANDRIA, Va., June 16 (AP) -- The Government went to court today to try to get back the tanker Meacham. The vessel figured in the Senate investigation of fast profits in surplus ships.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 16 -- Two Russian jet fighter planes intercepted an unarmed Swedish Air Force Catalina flying boat over international waters in the Baltic at 4 A. M. today, and the Swedish plane was shot down.
WALTHAM, Mass., June 16 -- Brandeis University graduated its first class today, bestowing degrees on 101 young men and women who started with the institution four years ago.

That letter to the editor not long ago from two readers protesting the exploding of firecrackers around town, said our man with the unlikely name of Balboa Prawn as he settled into a chair, had interested him very much.
TOKYO, Tuesday, June 17 -- The United Nations delegates walked out of the armistice negotiations at Panmunjom again today, forcing a new three-day recess in the deadlocked talks.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- The Government today authorized retail price increases on more than 75 per cent of all department store goods, to offset recent freight rate and parcel post increases. But many stores may not take advantage of the authority.

BONN, Germany, June 16 -- After a week-end of intense political activity both Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and officials of the Office of the United States High Commissioner are convinced that the fight for ratification of the treaty system aligning West Germany with the Western powers, although long and hard, will be won.

Present Government regulations on renegotiation of defense contract costs were criticized yesterday as being based on profit-limitation policies suitable to a full wartime emergency, but holding dangers of unfair treatment of business earnings in a time of limited emergency.

The visit of General Ridgway to Italy appears to be taking place without any violent Communist eruptions such as we saw in France when he first arrived there a few weeks ago. This is interesting, but not unexpected. It would seem as if Moscow does not want the Italian Communist party to face the same sort of crackdown as the French Government visited on the Reds in France.

Fischer-Landis, operators, have resold the five-and-a-half-story apartment building for sixty-two families at 1520 Crotona Park East, the Bronx, which they bought recently. Uhe house occupies a plot 125 by 107 feet and was sold for cash over mortgages amounting to $130,000 to an investing client of George Green.

CHICAGO, June 16 -- Stocks of home furnishings goods have been reduced from recent high levels but are still heavy in some lines and areas, comments of industry officials indicated today. Inventories were a major question as the summer furnishings market opened in the American Furniture Mart and the Merchandise Mart.

Joseph Kramm's drama, "The Shrike," which received this year's Pulitzer Prize, and "Pal Joey," designated by the New York Drama 'Critics' Circle as the best musical of the past season, have won the Donaldson Awards as the best play and musical of the 1951-52 season.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 16 -- A repetition of shooting into Brazilian territory by Argentine police has brought to Congress a request that a commission of inquiry be appointed to investigate the situation before the incidents create a critical situation between Argentina and Brazil.

Trading in commodity futures on the local exchanges was comparatively quiet yesterday. Price changes were narrow. Rubber futures on the Commodity Exchange eased 40 to 55 points on trade and commission house selling, but the turnover was light, totaling only 40 contracts.

BUENOS AIRES, June 16 -- Confronted with peronista strikes, the Mayors and the new governments of two large municipalities in the Province of Buenos Aires tonight headed for political oblivion, as state intervention by Carlos Aloe, the hard-fisted peronista Governor, appeared imminent.
DETROIT, June 16 -- Probably the most relaxed of all the Yankees today, as they awaited tomorrow night's after-dark contest with the Tigers, was Joe Collins.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., June 16 -- Maj. Gen. Charles G. Helmick, commander of the New England Subarea of the First Army, will arrive here late this month for the final assignment of his thirty-nine-year Army career.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 16 -- A forty-hour week for nurses, with time and one-half for overtime and two consecutive days off, was endorsed today by the four main sections of the American Nurses Association. These improvements in working conditions would induce women to return to the profession and students to enter it, according to a resolution which will be presented to the house of delegates tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (UP) -- Senator Warren Magnuson, Democrat of Washington, said today that he would introduce a resolution tomorrow calling for an investigation by the Federal Power Commission into spending by private utilities for "political and other" purposes.

Rabbi Irving Miller, newly elected president of the Zionist Organization of America, pledged himself yesterday to help "create a climate of public opinion favorable to Israel's legitimate political and economic needs" and called on the organization's members to enhance Jewish educational opportunities in the United States.

The American Locomotive Company, which also manufactures tanks for the Army, told an eight-man panel of the Wage Stabilization Board here yesterday that its 6,000 employes at the Schenectady, N. Y., plant were receiving more than workers in comparable industries.
Nine investment banking syndicates competed yesterday for the purchase of $20,000,000 of new public utility securities. The awards were:...

BETHLEHEM, Pa., June 16 (UP) -- Frank W. Abrams, chairman of the board of directors of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, called today on business groups and labor organizations to act with a "sense of responsibility" to insure the lessening of legal restraints and the enlargement of liberty.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Top diplomatic and military officials today discussed with Jean Letourneau, French Cabinet Minister for the Associated States, what this country could best do to beat back Communist guerrillas in Indo-China.
CHICAGO, June 16 (AP) -- Betsy Rawls today posted a medal-winning 74 -- one under par -- to lead the qualifiers in the twenty-third women's Western open golf tourney.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 16 -- Dr. Jan Papanek, former chief of the Czechoslovak delegation to the United Nations, testified today that since the Communists took power his country had been turned into "one huge forced labor camp."

LONDON, June 16 -- Christine Granville, a Polish countess who won high British decorations as a British underground agent in Poland, Hungary, France and Italy during World War II, was stabbed to death last night in the lobby of her London hotel.
A gathering of 7,468 cash customers at the Polo Grounds yesterday saw a re-take of last year's play-off excitement with but slight variation.

TRENTON, June 16 -- Lieut. Jacob Harris of the state police was exonerated today at a special court-martial of a charge of keeping secret a Christmas gift of $100, received while he was commanding the Ramsey Station in Bergen County. The money allegedly was distributed among the men at the station, and the lieutenant was charged with failing to report it to his superiors.

That summer problem -- unattractively clouded iced tea -- has been the subject of recent research by a leading food company. Contrary to earlier findings, the cause is now traced in large part to the refrigerator.

Supreme Court Justice Henry Clay Greenberg upheld yesterday the constitutionality of the city's recently enacted tax on retail liquor licenses, which has been set at 25 per cent of the $1,200 yearly fee now paid the state. The court also refused to grant an injunction to halt the new law's operation, effective next Monday.

OMAHA, June 16 (AP) -- The Crusaders from Holy Cross got five runs off a weakening Missouri pitcher in the sixth inning and beat the Tigers tonight, 7 -- 3, forcing the National Collegiate A. A. baseball tournament into another game.
ELMONT, L. I., June 16 -- Fire of undetermined origin took the lives of one man and twenty-one horses early today as half of a big barn on the grounds of the Belmont Park Race Track was destroyed.

LONDON, June 16 (AP) -- Vic Seixas, America's top-ranking tennis ace, gained a hard-fought first round victory in the London grass courts lawn tennis tournament today as the world's best players tuned up their games for next week's major show at Wimbledon.

David Freingoid and Joseph Kielman have sold the eightfamily apartment house at 464: Pulaski Street, Brooklyn, to Embling W. IDacin. Celia 1. Vice was the broker in the transaction, in which title was insured by the City Title! Insurance Company.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Only a late demand for a record vote prevented passage today by the House of Representatives of a bill increasing Social Security benefits for the aged by at least $5 a month.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., June 16 -- The first of the debutante parties of the "little season" on Long Island took place here tonight when Mr. and Mrs. Sherman Pratt and Mr. and Mrs. Henry D. Babcock gave a costume dance at Still Pond, the Pratt estate, to introduce to society Miss Joan Babcock, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Babcock, and Miss Maria-Helene Manville, Mrs. Pratt's daughter.

CHICAGO, June 16 -- The ever-increasing emphasis on fashion in the home furnishings industry was pointed up both by what was said and by what was to be seen in this city today. The occasion was the opening day of the semi-annual wholesale Home Furnishing Market, at which buyers from stores across the country inspect offerings and place orders for merchandise to be sold in the fall.

GLEN HEAD, L. I., June 16 -- The Cold Spring team of Ira Greenblatt and Jack Mallon shaved eight strokes from par to win the weekly amateur-pro of the Long Island P. G. A. with a 32, 31 -- 63 at the Glen Head Country Club today.
LONDON, June 16 -- The approaching end of the fortnightly bookkeeping account brought further contraction in volume of stock market trading here today, and in many sections prices were barely tested.

LONDON, June 16 -- Among the worshipers and sightseers in Westminster Abbey nowadays men can be seen from time to time working with steel measuring tapes and blueprints prepared by the architects of the coronation.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 16 -- Officers of five Weschester branches of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People deplored in a resolution today the acquittal here last week of Stanley S. La Benskey of Yonkers as "a gross miscarriage of justice."
BERLLIN, June 16 -- On the ground of an alleged threat of attack from the West, the unified bloc of East German political parties will announce tomorrow its decision to form an East German Army.

Midtown hotels on both the east and west sides of the city reported yesterday that they were "quite solidly" booked for rooms, but they declined to say whether the large number of reservations could be attributed to Long Islanders seeking rooms as the result of the railroad strike.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 16 -- The Harvard Crimson, university daily newspaper, reported in a copyrighted supplement to today's edition that at least fifty-three cases involving violations of academic freedom had occurred in twenty-five of the country's colleges. Last year The Crimson reported thirty-five such cases.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, June 16 -- A healing of the split between Protestants and Roman Catholics in the Western World would be a contribution of "first magnitude" to world peace and understanding, Dr. Emory Ross of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A., declared here today.

TROON, Scotland, June 16 -- Dorothy Kirby, the national titleholder from Atlanta, and five other of the ten competing Americans were eliminated from the British women's amateur golf championship by the end of the first two rounds of play today.

Although primarily a fall show, a good deal of buying of summer dresses was reported at the third semi-annual New York Dress Week at the Hotel New Yorker sponsored by the Garment Salesmen's Guild of New York. Initial orders were placed on fall lines yesterday by many buyers, but fill-ins and new ideas were still wanted on light-weight dresses for immediate delivery.

Faced with the continued deadlock in negotiations between labor and management in the steel industry, and the employment of funds for the new $3,500,000,000 Treasury 2 3/8 per cent bond issue, the stock market followed an uneven course yesterday.

The Board of Transportation announced yesterday that it was putting on extra buses and subway trains during the morning and evening rush hours to help Long Island Rail Road commuters stranded by the strike.

Findings of a research study that indicate the value to expectant mothers of even the briefest instruction on proper diet have just been released by the Milbank Memorial Fund in a pamphlet "An Experiment in Diet Education During Pregnancy," by Katharine Berry and Dorothy G. Wiehl.

Manufacturers of chocolate in Europe have made important advances in exports since the war, it was reported yesterday by Stephen Klein, president of Barton's Bonbonniere, returned from a two-month tour of Europe.

" General of the Army" should be replaced as the title for five-star rank in the Army. Experience has proved that it is so confusing and inadequate an indication of the importance of the rank that after some seven years of existence five-star generals are today popularly indistinguishable from four-star generals.

Long Island Rail Road terminals in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Jamaica, Queens, presented a dolefully peaceful aspect yesterday. Countermen and girls who usually work feverishly to supply commuters with newspapers, cocktails, snacks and other comforts were standing about with arms folded and gazing on emptiness.

Jacob L. Behrman, who is in charge of the sale of the city's new auto-use tax stickers in Queens, found last night that his own $10 sticker had been stolen from the windshield of his car. Two other motorists who keep their cars in the same garage as Mr. Behrman at 77-15 113th Street, Forest Hills, Queens, also discovered their stickers were gone.
Naval authorities defend with argument and statistics the recruiting of athletes for the United States Naval Academy and the emphasis at Annapolis on football and other intercollegiate sports.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J., June 16 -- Mrs. Catherine Fox Park of Glen Ridge won the qualifying medal in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship over the Upper Montclair course today with a one-over-par 39, 36 -- 75.

More than 30,000 Protestants in Colombia, South America, are being deprived of their constitutional rights of freedom of religion, press and assembly, the Rev. Dr. Luis A. Quiroga, secretary of the Confederation of Evangelical Churches of Colombia, said yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 16 -- An adjourned annual meeting of stockholders of the American President Lines was adjourned further today, for lack of a quorum, pending the sale of 92 per cent of the company's voting stock, which had been in litigation for seven years.

PHILADELPHIA, June 16 (AP) -- A triple by Richie Ashburn followed by Granny Hamner's long fly broke a 4-4 tie in the seventh inning and enabled the Phillies to beat the Priates 5 -- 4 today, despite homers by Ralph, Kiner and George Strickland.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, June 16 -- Averell Harriman's fruitless efforts last summer to settle the Iranian oil conflict became an issue today in the proceedings in the International Court of Justice to determine whether the tribunal had jurisdiction over the British-Iranian dispute.

Theoretically one thinks of Government employes as servants of the public and bound to do the latter's will. Yet the bigger Government gets the less are the voters able to control their servants. And, indeed, the latter often end by directing the voters. The tail wags the dog.

PARIS, June 16 -- The French Government is expected to announce soon a plan for stimulating exports by subsidies in the form of tax exemptions, which probably will be extended to the majority of exporters. French exports are regarded as stagnating at a level far below where they should be if recent restrictions on imports are to be lifted and if the franc is to be stabilized.

AUSTIN, Tex., June 16 (AP) -- Wealth never dreamed of a quarter century ago is flowing into the University of Texas treasury from oil and gas development of the school's 2,000,000 acres in West Texas.

Special graduation ceremonies for ninety-five students who have completed courses in the City College School of Business and Civic Administration cooperative retailing training program, were held yesterday at the Plaza Hotel.

During the vacation months there may be opportunity for parents as well as young persons to do some quiet reading and a little serious thinking in preparation for the new school term. Two new booklets, dealing with home and school, have just been published by Science Research Associates and might recommend themselves for attention.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- President Truman offered a word of advice today to some of the first United States soldiers to fight in Korea: Don't try to be President.

With the Holy Bible as their weapon, sixty young men and women cadets of the Salvation Army were commissioned probationary lieutenants last night and sent out into the world to battle in behalf of the poor, the hungry, and the friendless.

When a judge has made an extraordinarily good record on the bench he ought to be reappointed. It happens that this can be said for all three City Magistrates whose terms are ending June 30. They are Magistrates Benjamin Brenner of Brooklyn, Samuel Orr of the Bronx and Frederick L. Strong of Manhattan.

PARIS, June 16 -- Jacques Duclos, imprisoned acting secretary general of the French Communist party and president of its delegation in the National Assembly, tonight took action designed to force his fellow deputies to vote on the legality of his arrest.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 16 -- If a trustee at a privately endowed university is to perform successfully his function as a liaison officer between graduates and faculty, it is essential that he "rid his mind of lingering doubts about the honesty and decency of the American scholar," Wilmarth S. Lewis, member of the corporation of Yale University, said today.

A contemporary American setting has been arranged as a background for some furniture, Mexican in theme, in one of the two new model apartments now on view in the newly constructed building at 200 East End Avenue. The apartments were decorated by Wanamaker's.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 16 -- Jacob A. Malik, Soviet representative on the United Nations Security Council, used today his powers as President of the Council for June to call a meeting to discuss Communist charges that the United States had waged germ warfare in Korea.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The Soviet Union offered today to return 186 of the vessels the United States turned over to it for use in World War II. Moscow said it wanted to buy 167 other ships, but the United States once more insisted that all the vessels be returned.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (UP) -- The Council of State Chambers of Commerce accused the Department of Defense today of exaggerating the effects of a $46,000,000,000 limit on military spending in fiscal 1953, approved by the House of Representatives.

W. Averell Harriman, candidate for the Democratic nomination for President, would prefer to be known simply as Averell Harriman, it was reported yesterday at the national headquarters of the Harriman-for-President Committee, 111 East Fifty-sixth Street. The W stands for William.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (UP) -- A special House investigating committee that includes two women opened today an investigation of "immoral, obscene or otherwise offensive matter" in books and magazines by examining some samples.

Cardinal Spellman returned here yesterday with 500 other Roman Catholic pilgrims who attended the Thirty-fifth International Eucharistic Congress at Barcelona, Spain, and who later went to Rome to be received by Pope Pius XII and to witness the beatification of Maria Bertilla Boscardin.

Nineteen officers and crewmen of the Navy transport General A. W. Greely were honored yesterday for their rescue last winter of thirty-seven passengers and seamen from the ill-fated cargo ship Flying Enterprise.

A 27-year-old man, with a criminal record involving automobile larcenies, eleven aliases and both state and Federal prison terms, was described yesterday as "Traffic Enemy No. 1" by Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh.

New York's automobilists received yesterday an eleventh-hour reprieve of one week from enforcement of the new law requiring display of $5 and $10 auto use tax stickers. On orders of Mayor Impellitteri, a new effective date for the law was set for next Monday at 12:01 A. M. The law had been scheduled to become effective at 12:01 A. M. today.

LIMA, Peru, June 16 -- The smoldering resentment against recent United States policy, widespread now in South America, is well illustrated by a signed editorial in one of Lima's two leading newspapers today declaring it is gross fraud to speak of Pan-Americanism in current circumstances.

Approximately 34,500,000 tons of steel have been lost because of major strikes in the United States since the end of World War II, according to a survey released yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute. This total, the institute said, includes nearly 5,500,000 tons of steel lost in late April, early May and the first two weeks of June this year.

NEW DELHI, India, June 16 -- Sardar K. M. Panikkar, India's ambassador to Communist China who will shortly relinquish his post, was the honor guest at a farewell banquet in Peiping last Saturday at which Chinese leaders spoke in highly appreciative terms of the Indian envoy.

PORTLAND, Me., Tuesday, June 17 -- Gov. Frederick G. Payne, a comparative newcomer to Maine politics, came from behind early today to close out Senator Owen Brewster's eighteen-year career in Congress. This was shown in mounting returns from the state's cities in yesterday's primary. The vote:

In your issue of June 10 you carried a story reporting portions of a Senate speech by Senator Wayne Morse on June 9, in which he charged that the Chinese Government had instructed its officers in the United States to spy on the atomic bomb. Your story bore the headline "Atomic Espionage Is Laid to Chinese."

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 16 -- Westchester filed suit in Supreme Court here today to smash an alleged boycott by union leaders against the delivery of materials to county construction jobs to "blackjack" the county into accepting unions as exclusive bargaining agents.
ROME, June 16 -- Ratification of the Schuman plan by the Parliaments of all six member nations was completed tonight.

ALBANY, June 16 -- Republican legislative leaders today appointed four opponents of the legalization of yellow oleomargarine to a new joint legislative committee that will study the use and possible adulteration of "milk products."

Thousands of extra automobiles were thrown into the daily turtle race from Long Island to Manhattan and the Bronx yesterday as the bulk of the strike-beset 175,000 Long Island Rail Road commuters jammed main highways in morning and evening rush hours. Acting Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley and the Automobile Club of New York urged that car pools be formed for the duration.

Upholstery and drapery fabric manufacturers are confident that their second-half sales will exceed those in the first half by a wide margin. Results of a survey of the Upholstery and Drapery Fabric Manufacturers Association released yesterday show that most members of the group are planning for increased volume beginning in July.

President Syngman Rhee has done himself and his country a disservice in the methods he has used in his controversy with the Korean Parliament. He has taken one retracing step in the right direction in calling off the Parliamentary boycott of his followers. There are other and more important steps that should be taken immediately.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The Treasury Department closed the books today on its offering of about $3,500,000,000 of 2 3/8 per cent Treasury bonds Of 1958. The books were closed as of the close of business this afternoon but a brief Treasury announcement said:

Home-Made, owned by Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, was away ahead of the others at the finish of the $13,600 Astoria stakes at Aqueduct yesterday. A surprisingly large crowd of 19,574 saw the five-and-a-half furlong sprint, in which the winner was timed in 1:05 3-5 under 119 pounds.

JERUSALEM, June 16 -- The election of Rabbi Irving Miller of New York as president of the Zionist Organization of America and the resolution by its convention expressing "ideological and moral kinship" with the General Zionist party in Israel were regarded by most observers here as a slight to Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion.

The trouble with the high school students and graduates employed by local concerns is, according to the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, that their spelling is bad, their handwriting mostly illegible, their arithmetic unreliable, they can't compose a business letter and they expect too much pay and too rapid advancement.

For the first time in years streets on the upper West Side received a thorough cleaning yesterday. The Sanitation Department's alternate-side-of-the-street parking program was extended to the car-congested sector between Ninety-first and 109th Streets, inclusive, from Central Park West to, but not including, Riverside Drive.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 16 -- Yale tallied two runs in the seventh inning to shatter a 2-2 tie and defeat Harvard, 4 -- 2, before an alumni reunion crowd of 8,000 at Yale Field today.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (UP) -- The House passed and sent to the White House today a bill approving a compact among New York, Pennsylvania and New Jersey providing for "mutual military aid" in an emergency.
SEOUL, Tuesday, June 17 (AP) -- Withering Allied firepower blasted attacking Chinese Communists off western front hillsides four times in today's pre-dawn darkness.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 16 -- Woodrow Wilson Hall at Princeton University was dedicated to "the advancement of knowledge and the education of young men in the service of the nation and of the world" in a simple ceremony here this afternoon.

Ira M. Pink, president of the Englander Company, Inc., manufacturer of sleep equipment, reports that an aggressive selling and merchandising campaign, spearheaded by an intensive local newspaper program, resulted in a 40 per cent increase in sales for his company in May over the similar month of last year.
The sun was shining and no pilots complained of poor visibility, but almost all of the flying at Newark Airport yesterday was done by starlings and English sparrows.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (UP) -- Speaker Sam Rayburn of the House of Representatives said today after the regular weekly legislative conference with President Truman that he doubted Congress would pass any seizure legislation in the steel dispute "that would amount to anything."
TOKYO, Tuesday, June 17 (AP) -- United Nations headquarters communique 1,283, for twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M. Tuesday (5 P. M. Monday, Eastern daylight time):
PUSAN, Korea, June 16 (AP) -- The Republic of Korea told the United States today why it had banned Voice of America broadcasts over the ten-station South Korean Government radio network.

The two-story building containing sixteen small apartments at 111-48 Seventy-sixth Drive in Forest Hills, Queens, has been sold by Gordon Ash to clients of Sidney l R. B:,nn attorney, l:IamerschlagZ Realty and Ydloff Realty were co-i Orokers in the transaction.

WATERVILLE, Me., June 16 (AP) -- Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, director of the Trusteeship Department of the United Nations, charged today that much current criticism aimed at the United Nations "is deliberately dishonest, reckless and irresponsible."

WASHINGTON, June 16 (UP) -- John Gates, convicted Communist leader, testified today that he did not know the whereabouts of three Communist fugitives and would not tell if he did, not "in a million years."
DENVER, June 16 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower stopped answering questions for a short while today and began asking them.

The St. Joseph Lead Company is going into the oil business. At the special meeting of stockholders here yesterday an amendment to the mining company's certificate of incorporation was approved extending the purposes and power Of the company to include oil, natural gas and mining operations of all kinds.
A. R. Carr has been appointed manager of passenger tire sales of the General Tire and Rubber Company and J. A. Beckett has been named manager of kraft system sales.

DARWIN, Australia, June 16 (UP) -- The worst drought in history is burning North Australian cattle lands into a desert, killing off cattle by the minute, and threatening calamitous losses to Australia's and the world's beef supply.

A strike is expected to be called tonight against thirty-four Schrafft restaurants and a company commissary after the refusal of the Frank G. Shattuck Company, operators of the chain, to meet with the union yesterday before the State Mediation Board.

A new novel by William Carlos Williams, his first since "In the Money" was issued in 1940, is scheduled for October publication by Random House. "The Build-Up" is a story about an immigrant family's battle to make a place for itself in small-town society. Dr.

/.' two separate transactions, .one involving a purchase and the other a lease, Webb Knapp, Inc., has added to its holdings on West hirty - third and Thirty - fourth .,treets, west of Hera/d Square, ] here it p]n. to construct ail ar'cade building.

First Lieut. John K. Daly of Jersey City, a veteran of World War II and Korea, received the Silver Star medal for gallantry in action yesterday from Lieut. Gen. Willis D. Crittenberger, First Army commander, at a ceremony on Governors Island.

SINGAPORE, June 16 -- The monarchial coup in Cambodia over the week-end provides that little Buddhist kingdom with an authoritarian regime the aim of which will be to direct the country in a more effective resistance to the Communist-led Vietminh and other insurgent elements. The new regime is expected to cooperate more closely than its predecessor with the French.

Plans.for a new shopping center in Levittown, L. I, have been announced by Irving erger and Gilbert Tilles. The site, an irregular plot about 780 by 150 feet at the southast corner of Wantagh Avenue and Miller Place, was purchased from th Miller Dairy Company. Iax Gruber Associates were the brokers.

BOSTON, June 16 (AP) -- Swift Co., one of the world's largest meat-packing houses, was charged today with 440 violations of the Defense Production Act in criminal informations filed in Federal courts in Boston, Sioux Falls, S. D.; Concord, N. H., and New Haven, Conn.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The two top officers of the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions are on their way to the United States to try to effect a reconciliation with the American Federation of Labor.

LONDON, June 16 -- Archbishop Stefan Wyszynski, Roman Catholic Primate of Poland, has installed a permanent chapter in the Archdiocese of Wroclaw (Breslau), with special permission of the Vatican. The chapter will govern pending the appointment of an archbishop.
An investment banking syndicate headed by Shields Co. is offering a new issue of $2,900,000 of natural gas system revenue bonds of the Clinton Newberry Natural Gas Authority in South Carolina.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Convinced by Air Force officials of the threat of a sneak Soviet air attack, state civil defense directors today pledged to put into effect on July 14 a twenty-four-hour plane spotting service by civilian volunteers. They will undertake this, they said, despite a critical shortage of volunteers for the Ground Observer Corps.

The strike of engineers and motormen on the Long Island Rail Road which is inconveniencing 300,000 passengers daily is inexcusable. It violates both the letter and the spirit of the Railway Labor Act.

ATLANTA, June 16 -- The Georgia State Democratic Executive Committee formally instructed today this state's delegates to the Democratic National Convention to vote for Senator Richard B. Russell at Chicago "so long as his name remains before the convention or until they are released by him from this commitment."

One hundred of the Police Department's 1,148 sergeants were shifted in the city's eighty-four police precincts yesterday in the widest shake-up of its kind since Richard Enright was Commissioner almost thirty years ago.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- The General Accounting Office has cleared four Texas and Oklahoma companies accused of grain shortages in the handling of Government-owned wheat.
TUNIS, Tunisia, June 16 (AP) -- Jews and Arabs clashed anew today in the winding, cobblestone streets of old Tunis for the third straight day. Ten persons were wounded.

THE Professional Golfers Association championship tournament will begin in Louisville tomorrow, and up until late yesterday it appeared that the divot-diggers would stumble once again over their own peculiar and archaic rules. Julius Boros, the newly-crowned Nations Open king and therefore the hottest attraction in the game, was ineligible to compete because, under the rules, he hasn't been in the lodge long enough.
Twenty years ago this month the United States Industrial Chemicals Company began reporting on the progress, new products and research developments of the chemical industry as a whole.

DES MOINES, June 16 -- Senator Robert S. Kerr of Oklahoma claimed today "somewhat more than 100 delegates" to the Democratic National Convention in Chicago July 21 and foresaw 175 to 200 delegates favorable to his nomination for the Presidency by convention time.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 16 -- The Yugoslav Government has lifted some controls on industrial raw materials and semi-manufactured goods in its search for methods that would enable it to create a non-bureaucratic socialist economic system within the framework of the single-party state.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The cost of West Germany's rearmament for the next three years has been officially estimated at more than $7,000,000,000, with the United States contribution yet to be determined.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation raised to 5 per cent today its interest rate on disaster loans granted to restore profit-making business facilities and inventories. Interest charges on the loans -- available to victims of floods, storms, fires and earthquakes -- formerly were a uniform 3 per cent.

HAEUNDE, Korea, June 16 (AP) -- A spectacular series of explosions today destroyed part of the biggest ammunition dump in South Korea. It left one United States soldier dead, two missing and twenty-eight injured. More than 20,000 South Korean civilians were forced to flee their homes.

FORT WORTH, Tex., June 16 (UP) -- Henry Zweifel, Republican National Committeeman, telegraphed General Eisenhower today that Eisenhower delegates thrown out of the party's Texas convention were "Democrats and intended to remain Democrats."

Pleased by the fact that revenues from the new auto-use stamp tax were coming in at a pretty good rate, City Councilman Edward A. Cunningham, Bronx Democrat, was ready last week to start a movement to repeal the $3,500,000 tax on retail liquor license fees.

The "hidden qualities" of manmade fibers, never mentioned in the advertising, often make them an unsuitable substitute for wool, Giles E. Hopkins, New York technical director of the Wool Bureau, Inc., told the Lowell Technical Institute at Lowell, Mass., yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (UP -- Averell Harriman drew warm praise from President Truman today for his "uncompromising" campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination.
The nineteen newspapers in the Scripps-Howard chain endorsed yesterday the Presidential candidacy of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and urged the Republican party to nominate him.

Mayor Impellitteri placed his stamp of approval yesterday on Pier 86, Hudson River -- the West Forty-sixth Street terminal the city and the United States Lines have renovated and redecorated at a cost of $1,350,000 to berth the superliner United States.

I was both amused and irked by the news item in THE NEW YORK TIMES on June 7 wherein Commissioner McCarthy of the New York City Department of Welfare indicated that a group of forty relief recipients, tuberculosis patients receiving the new hunger-inducing anti-T. B. drugs, will be given a $4-a-month additional food allowance.

A five-way tie for top honors took place last night in the epee final of the national championships at the Fencers Club. The The defeat of Edward Vebell Lewis, Salle Santelli, in the last Vebell, 4 -- 3.

LOUISVILLE, June 16 (AP) -- The Professional Golfers Association executive committee today issued a special invitation to Julius Boros, newly crowned National Open golf champion, to compete in the thirty-fourth P. G. A. championship, which starts here Wednesday.

It will be inexcusable if the individual members of the Senate allow their vote on offshore oil legislation to be determined by mere party politics. The temptation will, however, be strong; for the President's veto of the Holland bill affords every anti-Administration Senator a perfect opportunity to take a crack at Mr. Truman on a question that probably only a small proportion of the voting public understands.
Record sales and earnings of the Solar Aircraft Company were achieved in the fiscal year ended with April 30, Edmund T. Price, president and general manager, reported yesterday.
DETROIT, June 16 (AP) -- The nation's auto industry built the year's 2,000,000th passenger car today, but the best production rate reached in many months appears doomed to a sharp slowing down.

When we put money in a savings bank or buy bonds or stocks or set up a business we usually ask ourselves two questions: How safe is this investment? What will be the rate of return? It might be interesting to apply this process to the $40 billions which the United States will have given away or lent in post-war foreign aid by the end of the present month.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- President Truman today asked Congress to appropriate $168,360,000 for administrative expenses of the Defense Production and Economic Stabilization agencies during the fiscal year 1953, beginning July 1. He also requested $5,000,000 for a revolving fund for the Small Defense Plants Administration.

Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, United States Assistant Commissioner of Education, was unanimously elected the seventh president of City College at last night's meeting of the Board of Higher Education at 695 Park Avenue. He will also have the rank of Professor of Education.

James A. Linen, publisher of Time magazine, disclosed yesterday that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin had begun to send letters to Time advertisers asking them to withdraw their advertising from the publication. Mr. McCarthy had threatened to take this action in January because, he said, the magazine was conducting a "smear" campaign against him.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (UP) -- Ashton H. Williams was nominated today by President Truman to succeed J. Waties Waring as Federal district judge for Eastern South Carolina. The Senate must confirm the nomination.
DENVER, June 17 -- Here's the way General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower is feeling about his campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination three weeks before the start of the convention:

A record field of fifty-four was reduced to twelve yesterday as the preliminary and semi-final rounds in the individual foil were completed in the national fencing championships on the New York A. C. strips.
MONTREAL, June 17 (AP) -- Canada's Superior Court upheld today the resistance of Montreal's retail stores to compulsory closing on Roman Catholic Holy Days.
TOKYO, June 17 (AP) -- United Nations headquarters communique 1,283, for twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M. Tuesday (5 P. M. Monday, Eastern daylight time):

PORTLAND, Me., June 17 -- Gov. Frederick G. Payne, who defeated Senator Owen Brewster in yesterday's Republican primary in Maine, is popularly identified with the progressive wing of his party in Down East politics. This is the same group that was responsible for the nomination and election of Mrs. Margaret Chase Smith to Maine's other Senate seat four years ago. Senator Brewster headed the Old Guard faction.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee completed today its hearings on agreements of state that would bring West Germany into the common defense of the West from any Soviet assault.

Shareholders of the Pacific Mercury Television Manufacturing Corporation at their annual meeting on June 26 in Van Nuys, Calif., will vote on amendments that would allow Sears, Roebuck Co. to buy 200,000 shares of Pacific's new 50-cent par value Class B common stock.
SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, June 17 -- Church and Government sponsored education in a majority of African territories was charged here today with failing to equip Africans for more than continued slavery.

THIS will be a festive week-end for the only sport in the world in which the contestants compete while sitting down and going backward. That sport, of course, is rowing. The Yales and the Harvards will celebrate their centennial race on the Thames at New London on Friday. A day later the Intercollegiate Rowing Association will have a golden anniversary party for its Poughkeepsie Regatta which will be held, naturally, at Syracuse.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (UP) -- John Foster Dulles received a key role in drafting the 1952 Republican platform today in what was depicted as an attempt to make sure that the Taft-Eisenhower fight did not hurt the party's chances in the November election.

" One of the Fifteen Million," by Nicholas Prychodko, a first-hand account of three years' ordeal in a Soviet slave labor camp, will be published by Little, Brown on July 10. The author, a Ukrainian by birth, is now working as an engineer with a Canadian industrial concern.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 17 -- Dore Schary, Metro's production chief, has found new inspiration in the exploits of the United States Army for another personal production undertaking. This time Mr. Schary is planning a pictorial salute to the Rangers of World War II -- the hit and disappear forces specially trained by the Army to carry out swift destructive raids into enemy territory -- in "Take the High Ground."

DENVER, June 17 -- The chairman of Utah's fourteen-member delegation to the Republican National Convention -- previously listed as a Taft supporter -- indicated today that he and at least six other Utah delegates might switch their support to General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower after the first ballot at the convention, which opens July 7 in Chicago.

In an unusual good-will gesture to a fellow advertiser, theatre owners and operators of "spectacular" signs turned the Great White Way dark for three minutes last night to mark the lighting for the first time of a huge neon sign at the north end of Times Square advertising Canadian Club whisky.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The House Education and Labor Committee voted tonight to recommend the abolition of the Wage Stabilization Board after sharply censuring it on several counts. One member said that the vote to abolish the board was 16 to 5.

WASHINGTON, Wednesday, June 18 -- Averell Harriman, Mutual Security Director, held a lead of better than 3 to 1 over Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee early today in mounting returns in the contest for the District of Columbia's six votes at the Democratic National Convention.

A strengthening of the moral and spiritual fiber of the people of this country is necessary to preserve world peace, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt declared yesterday. She addressed 1,500 parents, graduates and alumni at the twenty-first annual commencement of Yeshiva University at Amsterdam Avenue and 187th Street.

A fashion show featuring sheer silk evening dresses will provide the climax of a benefit to be given tonight at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by the Philippine Medical Association. The drive is to raise funds for scholarships enabling Filipino doctors to study in American hospitals.
Mayor Impellitteri accused Governor Dewey yesterday of false economy in vetoing a bill to postpone the retirement of John C. Riedel, 79-year-old chief engineer of the Board of Estimate.

FREEPORT, L. I., June 17 -- There is a popular belief that the chicken farmer and the boat livery operator merely loll around and watch the money pour in from the sale of eggs and the rental of boats. We "lolled around" this morning with Ed Buckley at his Freeport boat and bait emporium, and it took little lolling to convince us that this business also has its problems.

As total receipts from the sale of automobile use tax stamps rose to $7,835,745 at 3 P. M. yesterday, the first day of the one-week "grace" period ordered by Mayor Impellitteri, the City Council renewed its demand upon Governor Dewey for a special session of the Legislature to give the city more state aid and other fiscal benefits.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (UP) -- The Government authorized a 43 per cent increase in copper allotments for civilian goods today to spur hesitant manufacturers to buy up the United States share of the scarce metal on the free world market.

TROON, Scotland, June 17 -- Mae Murray, daughter of the Carnoustie-born golf professional of the Rutland (Vt.) Country Club, stood as the sole American still in the running for the British women's amateur golf championship today.

Awards of two medals, twenty-five certificates of merit and three trophies were announced yesterday at the thirty-third annual international cost conference of the National Association of Cost Accountants. The five-day meeting began on Sunday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel with attendance exceeding 2,500.

CHICAGO, June 17 (AP) -- All favorites, paced by the defending champion, Patty Berg, successfully sloshed through the opening round of the twenty-third Women's Western Open golf tourney at flooded Skokie Country Club today. An overnight downpour turned Skokie's 6,520-yard-par-75 layout into a chain of miniature lakes.

DETROIT, June 17 -- At an hour when most athletes are asleep, the Tigers and Yankees still were struggling to reach a decision tonight at Briggs Stadium. Finally, three minutes before 1 A. M., New York time, the marathon ended with the Tigers taking a hotly disputed 7-6 verdict in eleven innings.

Members and employes of the Stock Exchange donated 279 pints of blood in the last two days. This amount was far below the 700 pints pledged for a three-day period. Red Cross officials laid the lack to the brief strike on the Long Island Rail Road.

HONG KONG, June 17 -- Large groups of Communist party cadres in China have been shifted to government factories, mines, trading companies and financial offices for the announced purposes of strenghthening the party's political leadership in state enterprises and "making preparations for large-scale economic reconstruction."

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 17 (UP) -- Robert L. Knetzer, speculator who went $3,000,000 in debt selling postwar autos below cost, escaped from the city jail today with the aid of a man who posed as a United States marshal.

CHICAGO, June 17 -- A "space container" in the form of a huge plastic bubble, fitted inside with brightly colored small sleeping pavilions somewhat resembling pup tents, may replace the modern house, according to George Nelson, the architect.

Robert Montgomery's dramatic program, which during the year has offered some excellent television productions, had an off night this week. Its presentation on Monday evening of an adaptation of Marcia Davenport's novel, "Of Lena Geyer," was composed of about equal parts of grand opera and soap opera. The arias and the suds didn't mix too well.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Lindsay C.
