Warren, Controller General of the United States, told a House Merchant Marine subcommittee today that the renegotiated contract for the sale to American Export Lines of the liners Independence and Constitution was the only legal agreement under which the ships could be sold.

The latest type of ultracentrifuge, a powerful apparatus that spins samples of blood serum at 60,000 revolutions a minute, 300,000 times the force of gravity, will be put into use officially at the new research laboratory for the study of blood vessel and heart disease at Beth-El Hospital, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (UP) -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations said today that rank-and-file members of Communist-dominated unions would break with their leaders during a crisis in any political strike against the interests of their country.

The stock market made a slight but unenthusiastic shift to the higher side yesterday. Price changes at the close proved of little value in an appraisal of a trend. In fact, the difference between the number of issues to rise or fall proved small.

GUATEMALA, June 17 -- The revolutionary group of Congressmen that supports President Jacobo Arbenz Guzman unanimously approved at 1 A. M. today his land reform law to liquidate "feudal property" holdings and distribute the land to the Indians. The President approved the act, and it will become effective tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The first voting test on the pending Senate resolution to authorize the $818,000,000 international St. Lawrence Seaway and power project, which has been disputed in Congress for a generation, was scheduled today to take place tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The House of Representatives overwhelmingly approved today a bill increasing by at least $5 a month Social Security payments to 4,500,000 Americans now drawing benefits.

Earnings of the Allied Stores Corporation for the second quarter should be more favorable, B. Earl Puckett, board chairman, told stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday. He said a substantial improvement was expected in the third quarter, adding: "I can say with reasonable confidence that earnings for the year will be better than 1951."

PARIS, June 17 -- The next steps to create the single free market for Western Europe's coal and steel provided in the Schuman plan, now ratified by the six participating nations, will be taken at a meeting of their foreign ministers later this month.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 17 -- An agreement was reached today ending, at least temporarily, a long and bitter jurisdictional battle over galley workers on West Coast ships.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- The House Agriculture Committee approved a bill today to peg farm price supports at 90 per cent of parity for cotton, wheat, corn, peanuts, rice and tobacco. The bill fixes a floor under price support on these basic commodities through 1955.

A deal is about to be concluded whereby the American stage rights to Patrick Hamilton's latest thriller, "The Man Upstairs," will become the property of Alexander H. Cohen, it was learned yesterday. Investigation disclosed that contracts bearing the signatures of the interested parties are to be exchanged this week with the cooperation of Kay Brown, who represents the author as well as the London producing firm of Linnit Dunfee.

Since the members of the armed services represent "the greatest educational institution" in the country, entertainment of cultural value is important for those on leave, Capt. Joshua L. Goldberg, chaplain, Third Naval District, declared yesterday.

PARIS, June 17 -- Clashes between Arab and Jew in Tunisia, where their relations have been notably good when they were notably bad elsewhere in the Moslem world, have provoked mutual recriminations here between spokesmen for Tunisian nationalists and French administrators of the country.

Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, president-elect of City College, said yesterday that, while any loyal citizen should not hesitate to take a voluntary loyalty oath, such oaths were "not the most effective devices" for preventing disloyalty.

The Long Island Rail Road strike ended last night, just a little too late to permit restoration of service for thousands of home-bound commuters. The first train started running at 7:30 P. M., and officials promised that everything would be normal this morning on the country's most heavily traveled commuting line.

Samuel Reshevsky retained his 1-point lead in his match with Svetozar Gligoric of Belgrade last night at the Manhattan Chess Club when he played the eighth game of the series to a draw in thirty-three moves. Both moved with extreme caution.

After fourteen months of deliberation the Parliaments of the six nations involved have now completed ratification of the Schuman Plan for a European Coal and Steel Community. This marks the beginning of Europe's economic integration and constitutes the first of the three essential pillars on which is to rest a future United States of Europe.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 17 -- Without benefit of an act of Congress, the United States this week acquired, if only temporarily, a forty-ninth state -- but it was mostly a state of mind. The new acquisition is the Jersey Boys State, under the sponsorship of the American Legion, which came into existence Sunday for the seventh year here on the campus of the New Jersey College for Women, Rutgers University.
ASCOT, England, June 17 (AP) -- Queen Elizabeth II presided over her first Royal Ascot race meeting today but her horse finished tenth in a field of twelve.
WILMINGTON, Del., June 17 (AP) -- The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad pleaded innocent in United States District Court today to fifteen charges of violation of the Federal Elkins Act.

CHICAGO, June 17 -- Lieut. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer, retired, said today that the Korean war might have been averted if vital military information had not been withheld from members of Congress on the ground that "there would be a leak which might embarass some foreign power."

ALBANY, June 17 -- The State Labor Department's proposed legislation setting up a state-wide minimum wage of 75 cents an hour was reviewed by representatives of labor and industry today. Nobody thought too much of it.

Japan, despite its present close economic tie-up with production in support of the Korean war and mutual security in Southeast Asia, offers encouraging prospects as a market for United States goods, the Export Managers Club was told yesterday at a meeting in the Statler Hotel.
The practice here of dropping coins into cups carried by blind beggars was deplored yesterday afternoon at a meeting in the New York Association for the Blind, 111 East Fifty-ninth Street.

I was shocked to read the letter of Thomas A. Terry, executive vice president of the Fifth Avenue Association, published on June 9, in which he expressed the hope "that the proposed Thirtieth Street overpass will never be constructed."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 17 -- The United Nations plans to dismiss more than thirty additional United States members of the staff who are suspected of having taken part in illegal Communist activities. Highly reliable sources said that about fifteen United States secretariat members already have been dismissed or have been asked to resign.

A piece of strategy that went slightly awry spoiled the Giants' debut of the former Dodger, Hal Gregg, at the Polo Grounds last night and made a futile thrust of Bobby Thomson's tenth home run of the campaign.
A helicopter engaged in mosquito control, a twin-engined military plane and a few small private planes landed at Newark Airport yesterday, comprising the day's activity at the big field.

This is a good day, rain or shine, to begin thinking about Saturday's breakfast. It is not too soon to look ahead to that meal, which should be something special, because Saturday morning is one time that affords leisure in which to approach breakfast with the seriousness the day's first meal deserves but so rarely receives.

HELSINKI, June 17 (AP) -- Sigfrid Edstrom, president of the International Olympic Committee, said today that neither Nationalist nor Red China could, under present rules, participate in the Olympic Games here this summer.

Reacting violently to recurrent insinuations that they grow faint of heart when matched with first-division opposition, the league-leading Dodgers last night routed the third-place Cubs, 9 -- 1, to the vociferous delight of a Ladies' Night crowd of 28,080 at Ebbets Field.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 17 -- Robert A. Lovett, Secretary of Defense, and Charles Habib Malik, chairman of the Commission on Human Rights of the United Nations and Minister of the Republic of Lebanon to the United States, were among those who received honorary degrees today at Princeton's 205th commencement exercises. Bachelor and advanced degrees were conferred upon 921 persons, one of the largest groups ever to receive Princeton degrees at a single commencement exercise.

An aircraft parts and equipment show opened yesterday in the Park Sheraton Hotel with forty makers of everything from screws to engines represented. Eugene P. Connolly, president of Aircraft Trade Shows, Inc., sponsors, said he was satisfied with the first day's attendance of 500 persons from the aircrafts and kindred industries.
About 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon Teddy Atkinson bethought himself of the fact that it was his birthday, and determined to do something about it.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (UP) -- A Senate Labor subcommittee today approved a "nonpunitive" Fair Employment Practices Act but leaders said it had little chance of reaching the floor this session.

A widening of the qualifications for the Commissioner and Deputy Commissioner of the proposed new Department of Air Pollution Control, approved yesterday by the City Council's committee on general welfare, would make possible the appointment of William G. Christy and William S. Maxwell to these positions.

Knife-pleating, jet and passementerie embroidered details, sleeves with fullness dropped from the shoulders into the elbows, skirts with side fullness and hand - embroidered silk linings were important style notes in the fur fashions presented yesterday by Bernham-Stein, 660 Fifth Avenue.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board says transportation is a problem in New England but "it does not follow that the creation of an uneconomic air service is the answer."
MILAN, Italy, June 17 (AP) -- Ildefonso Cardinal Schuster, Archbishop of Milan, said today that the Moral Rearmament Movement endangered both Catholics and non-Catholics.

BOSTON, June 17 (AP) -- A heavy electrical rainstorm washed out the second game of tonight's Braves-Reds twilight-night doubleheader after right-hander Vern Bickford held the Reds to seven hits while winning the opener, 5 -- 1.

Hide, lead and rubber futures showed a firm tendency on the Commodity Exchange here yesterday. Tin futures, traded nominally, were unchanged. Coffee and cocoa futures were under pressure from trade and commission house selling.

Spending by tourists is considered among the three most important sources of income in one-third of the states, according to Ray A. Robinson, research director of the Crowell-Collier Publishing Company.

BERLIN, June 17 -- East Germany's National Democratic party, composed primarily of Communist-trained former Nazi soldiers, issued a dramatic appeal to all German veterans of World War II today to support national unity and a pro-Soviet policy.
Amateur golfers from the United States, Canada and Mexico will play a series of matches at the Seattle Golf Club on Aug. 14 and 15, the United States Golf Association announced yesterday.
LONDON, June 17 (AP) -- Frank Sedgman of Australia, who has never won the All-England lawn tennis championship at Wimbledon, was seeded No. 1 today in the men's singles for the third straight year.
BERLIN, June 17 -- East German authorities yesterday released two West Berlin news men who had been held for a week after their arrest on the boundary of the British sector June 10.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 17 -- The merger of four national nursing groups into two was assured today when the American Nurses Association rejected a motion to reconsider the approval of the reorganization plans voted by the House of Delegates late last night.

North and South America have had for at least 22,000 years a relationship to Asian peoples much closer than previously recognized, it was suggested here yesterday at the Wenner - Gren Foundation International Symposium on Anthropology at the foundation's office, 14 East Seventy-first Street.

CHICAGO, June 17 -- Sufficient aluminum soon will be available to permit its use on a broad scale in mass-production markets for the first time, John E. Menz, general sales manager of Kaiser Aluminum and Chemicals Sales, Inc., said today.
A telegram urging President Truman to veto the McCarran Immigration Bill was sent to the White House yesterday by twenty editors and publishers of foreign language newspapers in New York.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 17 -- Four major motion - picture companies are about to enter into a contract with the Screen Actors Guild recognizing the principle of additional payment to performers for repeat showings on television of films made specially for that medium, it was established tonight.

CLEVELAND, June 17 (AP) -- Earl Rapp and Jackie Jensen, with five hits between them, scored all the Senators' runs tonight as Washington defeated the Indians, 4 -- 3, in the opener of a three-game series. Bob Porterfield received credit for the victory in a duel with Bob Feller, but he was relieved in the eighth by Sandy Consuegra.
LONDON, June 17 (AP) -- The Moscow radio broadcast tonight this North Korean communique:

A registration statement covering a proposed public offering of 1,350,000 shares of capital stock has been filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission by Canada General Fund, Inc., a new investment company. Incorporated in Delaware, the company's purpose is investment in selected Canadian corporations.

STOCKHOLM, June 17 -- Gen. Nils Svedlund, Commander in Chief of Sweden's defense forces, called on the nation tonight to sharpen its military watchfulness. But to alleviate apprehension over Swedish-Soviet tension in the Baltic, he added that this caution did not amount to mobilization.

American strategy in Asia, especially in the "war of ideas," has failed because of our handling of the Koje Island prisoners and our support of Syngman Rhee, Chiang Kai-shek and the French in Indo-China, Norman Thomas, veteran Socialist party leader, said last night.
OMAHA, June 17 (AP) -- Jim O'Neill pitched Holy Cross to an 8-4 victory over Missouri and the championship of college baseball in a blazing finish to the National Collegiate A. A. tournament tonight.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange eased slightly yesterday and closed 15 to 25 points net lower than on Monday.

Borrowings totaling $37,500,000 by Maine and West Virginia and the Chicago Sanitary District, occupied the center of interest in the market for tax-exempt-interest local government bonds yesterday. The banking syndicates which bought the bonds reoffered them to investors yesterday and by the time the market closed here had placed $20,800,000 of the total.

BONN, Germany, June 17 -- The Cabinet approved today a formal offer by the West German Government to pay restitutions to Israel in the amount of $715,000,000 in goods to cover the costs incurred by the Israeli Government in resettling Jewish refugees.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Jean Letourneau, the French Cabinet Minister for the Associated States of Indo-China, said today that more United States aid would be necessary to strengthen the native anti-Communist Vietnamese forces from the present four divisions to the eight divisions sought by mid-1954.

A new sewing machine cabinet in the form of a knee-hole desk with drawers on either side, will be available by July 1 at the Necchi Sewing Circle, 135 West Fourteenth Street. A handle in the back of the desk-cabinet releases a removable panel in the top to disclose the sewing machine.

Young men in their twenties and thirties who are in the securities business today are "fortunate," according to a veteran West Coast investment broker. The young men now getting a start in New York's Wall Street, Chicago's La Salle Street and San Francisco's Market Street will be assuming the responsibilities that go with leadership in their field some ten or fifteen years before men of the same age reach corresponding positions in other business.

A reassuring first report has been made by Field Marshal Alexander, the British Defense Minister, who went to Korea at the head of a mission of diplomats and soldiers to provide the British Government and people with first-hand information on what is happening in that Far Eastern trouble spot.

CHICAGO, June 17 -- Bears had a field day in the grain market today, with further liquidation by longs, the predominant factor being the huge receipts of winter wheat, with the big producing sections just beginning to move the grain.

ROME, June 17 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway returned to Naples today for the first time since 1943, when he commanded the Eighty-second Airborne Division that liberated the city. He was received with far warmer signs of welcome and approbation than marked his arrival in Rome yesterday.

TOKYO, Wednesday, June 18 -- Peiping today denounced the United Nations action in withdrawing its delegates from the Korean armistice conferences at Panmunjom and for the second time forcing a three-day adjournment of negotiations.

SEOUL, Wednesday, June 18 (AP) -- Allied troops held a western Korean height yesterday under some of the heaviest Communist shelling of the war, and smashed Chinese assaults with heavy Red casualties.

When the great Soviet "peace appeal" was launched last year it seemed obvious that the name "Stockholm" was tagged on to bolster up the pretense that it originated in the capital of Sweden. The reason for this ruse was that Stockholm is the capital of the largest neutral state in Western Europe; it was a tribute to neutrality, for if Russia had her way all the countries beyond her orbit would be neutral.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., June 17 -- Three upsets and two extra hole matches marked the first round of the forty-ninth annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship at the Upper Montclair Club course today.

ST. LOUIS, June 17 (AP) -- Held hitless for five innings, the Browns fashioned three hits good for three runs in the sixth inning tonight to defeat the Red Sox, 3 -- 1, as Bobby Cain pitched a four-hitter for his fifth victory of the season.

The re-election of Arthur Garfield Hays, general counsel of the American Civil Liberties Union, as honorary chairman of the New York chapter of the American Council for Judaism was announced yesterday. Maxwell Steinhardt, also a lawyer, has been named chairman.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The Senate Preparedness subcommittee said today that President Truman ignored "the solemn warning" of the Joint Chiefs of Staff in deciding "to postpone, beyond the date of our gravest danger, the attainment of our necessary modern air power."

DENVER, June 17 -- Ike had a bad day today but it wasn't his fault. All he did was go to lunch with some reporters on his campaign tour and not with some others. Result: confusion, not to mention consternation.
MEXICO CITY, June 16 -- The big question of the Mexican Presidential campaign is not who will win but what, if anything, Gen. Lazaro Cardenas will do.

PORTLAND, Me., June 17 -- Senator Owen Brewster accepted philosophically today an abrupt retirement to private life by expressing his gratitude "to the people of Maine" for giving him a thirty-five year career in politics. He was defeated for the Republican nomination to a third term by Gov. Frederick G. Payne a comparative political neophyte in yesterday's state primary.

Carmine G. DeSapio, leader of Tammany Hall, announced yesterday that all local candidates for public office must subscribe to a pledge not to seek or accept American Labor party support before they can receive the endorsement of the New York County Democratic organization.

BUFFALO, June I7 (AP) -- Federal officials informed the United States Attorney's office here today that there was no Federal ruling or opinion available for guidance in the LoDolce extradition case. The information was sought by the United States Attorney at the request of Federal District Judge John Knight.

THE TIMES doesn't like what Taft stands for. THE TIMES doesn't like what MacArthur stands for. In those antipathies THE TIMES pretends that it speaks for a majority of the American people. How it can know that it so speaks remains a deep, dark mystery, but, regardless, it writes an editorial disparaging the selection of General MacArthur as keynote speaker at the Republican National Convention, practically calling him a reactionary.
The city sweltered yesterday. At 4:35 P. M. the thermometer went to 91 degrees, highest reading for the year.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., June 17 (AP) -- An agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation testified today in the Government's suit to recover the tanker Meacham that alien Chinese co-signed more than three-fourths of the checks of the United Tanker Corporation.

BOSTON, June 17 (AP) -- The White Oaks Stable's sophomore star, Blue Man, moved a step closer to 1952 honors in the 3-year-old division today as he came from behind to score a two-and-one-half-length victory in the $50,000 added Yankee Handicap at Suffolk Downs.

Table tops of unusual materials provide a design interest in the large group of tables displayed in the new collection of furniture at Reilly-Wolff Associates, 50 East Thirty-fourth Street. The furniture may be ordered now through decorators, and next month will be available in stores.

Department of Sanitation tow trucks hauled away eighty automobiles yesterday from the upper West Side on the second day of the alternate - side - of - the - street parking program there. Sixty-one were impounded the first day.

ST. ANSGAR, Iowa, June 17 -- Harold L. McKinley, Iowa farmer, protested today that the farm program that General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower credited him with drafting had been the "work of a tremendous number of people over a long period."

SINGAPORE, June 17 -- Peace with Communists of Malaya on any other basis than their unconditional surrender to the Government was described as an impossibility today by W. L. Blythe, the Singapore Colonial Secretary, in a statement before the Legislative Council.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 17 -- Spokesmen for seven underdeveloped nations brought debate in the Economic and Social Council to a crucial stage today with a move designed to expedite action on the proposed large-scale program of grants-in-aid of their respective countries.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- "Considerable progress" toward getting some steel mills back into operation to meet critical defense needs was reported today by the White House.

LONDON, June 17 -- The British Government has promised to give Australian orders for military materials placed in Britain the same priority as Britain's own defense orders, Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies announced today before flying to New York and Washington.

The city's traditional poorhouse set-up will undergo a drastic reform next month when the Department of Hospitals begins shutting down its oldest institution, the bleak group of buildings known as the City Home for Dependents, and opens the modern Bird S. Coler Memorial Hospital and Home.

ROANOKE, Va., June 17 (AP) -- National convention delegates elected by the "Regulars" in Virginia's Third Congressional District, were recognized as the official delegates tonight, by the Virginia Republican State Central Committee, after a stormy six-hour meeting.

BONN, Germany, June 11 -- Failure by West Germany or the other proposed members of the European Defense Community to ratify the treaty establishing that six - nation supranational army would represent a distinct victory for Soviet policy, according to Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 17 -- In the land associated with racing thoroughbreds, 144 players terminated practice today for the Professional Golfers Association Tournament, the first major golf event to be held in this area.

The cornerstone of a huge incinerator plant that will serve a Manhattan area of 548,000 population was laid yesterday at ceremonies attended by Mayor Impellitteri. City Construction Coordinator Robert Moses, Manhattan Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. and other officials.
VIENNA, June 17 -- Soviet conduct in Austria during the last ten days has puzzled the Austrian Government.
CHICAGO, June 17 (AP) -- Appliance makers whose products depend on the formation of new families for their first sales are in for a diminishing market, a plastics manufacturer said today.

The battle of Long Island to get to work and home again was being fought far more efficiently yesterday, as 175,000 Long Island Rail Road commuters -- forced off their iron steeds for the second and final day of an engineers' strike -- came up prepared with new tactical plans.

KOJE ISLAND, Korea, Wednesday, June 18 (UP) -- More than 300 non-Communist prisoners fought through ranks of die-hard Communist prisoners to safety today after Brig. Gen. Haydon L. Boatner said he has found the suspected "Czar" of Koje, a fanatical Communist who masterminded the Koje riots and murders.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- The Department of Justice said today that it had filed a civil anti-trust suit against eight corporations and six individuals, charging that they had tried to monopolize the rendering materials industry. The action was filed in the Federal District Court at Detroit.

LONDON, June 17 -- The Soviet Union, in a note to the Swedish Ambassador in Moscow, charged tonight that the Swedish plane shot down yesterday in the Baltic had fired on Russian fighters and ignored their signal to land. The Russians then fired on the plane and it fell into the sea, the note said.
DETROIT, June 17 -- The steel strike confronted military planners today with imminent shutdowns of defense plants now producing tanks, Army trucks, bazooka rockets and mortar shells.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The Rules Committee of the House of Representatives approved a bill today to give Congress a firmer grip on the Government's purse strings through a joint committee with a sizable staff of experts to make year-around investigations and analyses of the President's annual budgets.

TO the best of my knowledge and belief no man alive has read as many novels as Edward Wagenknecht, Professor of English at Boston University, an industrious literary critic, indefatigable anthologist and fellow classmate of Ernest Hemingway in the Oak Park High School graduating class of 1917. One-tenth of Mr. Wagenknecht's literary consumption would be enough to give most of us the blind staggers and the screaming meemies.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, June 16 -- Britain concluded today a three day presentation of her argument that the International Court of Justice had jurisdiction over the Iranian oil nationalization dispute. It was announced that Premier Mohammed Mossadegh, recovered from recent indisposition, would introduce Iran's rebuttal tomorrow and attend the remaining hearings expected to continue until the end of the week.
LONDON, June 17 -- Business was extremely quiet in the stock markets here today and price movements were determined largely by the technical leveling of the books.

A $19,000 jewel robbery last Wednesday from the apartment of Mrs. Shirley Carmel at 1161 York Avenue was considered solved by the police yesterday with the arrest of a 29-year-old man-about-town who is alleged to have admitted he committed the burglary with an accomplice he met at a bar.

Eikichi Araki, first Japanese Ambassador to the United States since World War II, appealed here last night for more foreign trade and industrialization for the new Japan. He was supported in this plea by John D. Rockefeller 3d, president of the Japan Society, who urged the United States and other industrialized countries to aid Japan by modifying tariffs, quotas and exchange restrictions.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The Army today in effect pronounced General of the Army Douglas A. MacArthur retired and ruled that as such he could engage in political activities without fear of violating Army regulations.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The Army announced today new steps in its continuing program to deploy anti-aircraft units for the protection of strategic industrial, metropolitan and Air Force centers.

SEWANEE, Tenn., June 17 -- Members of the faculty of the third annual Cumberland Forest Music Festival, scheduled to be held here from next Monday until Aug. 23, have canceled their teaching and concert contract because the trustees of the University of the South have denied Negro divinity students admittance to the university's School of Theology.

Owners of places of public accommodation throughout the state have been informed that beginning July 1 they will violate the state anti-discrimination law if they deny service to any person because of race, creed, color or national origin.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The student body of William Chrisman High School of Independence, Mo., today gave President Truman a medal saying he was an "outstanding orator." They received a promise from the President that "if I ever get into a contest on oratory, I shall wear it."

The last of a series of seven pamphlets, intended to strengthen future families by helping to educate youngsters wholesomely about sex and adolescents about dating and marriage considerations, was published yesterday by the social hygiene division of the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (UP) -- The House of Representatives approved legislation today to exempt radio and television stations from libel suits stemming from slanderous or defamatory remarks by political candidates.

MANILA, Wednesday, June 18 -- William J. Pomeroy, former United States Air Force soldier who spent four years as a ranking Hukbalahap guerrilla leader, pleaded guilty to a charge of rebellion upon his arraignment today and was sentenced to life imprisonment.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (UP) -- An Administration subcommittee of the House of Representatives recommended $415,000 for various House investigations today, includnig $25,000 to check into indecent books and magazines.
CHICAGO, June 17 (AP) -- The White Sox tonight swept a doubleheader from the Athletics, 13 -- 1, and 2 -- 1, the second game in ten innings before 38,948, largest night crowd of the season here.

The defeat of Senator Owen Brewster of Maine in his attempt for re-nomination is further evidence that the voters this year want new names, new faces to represent them on the national scene, and that they are fed up with the old-style run-of-the-mill politicians, irrespective of party.

On June 9, in the principal letter to the editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, David Simon, a former employe of the State Department's Publications Branch New York field office, opposed the transfer of the work of that office to International Press Service headquarters in Washington.

A power failure that puts a home freezer out of the running for some time may cause a loss of investment if much food is stored in the appliance. We recall how a hurricane in Florida left homes without electricity for almost a week, and how freezer owners stood in line for hours at milk plants waiting to buy dry ice.

CARACAS, Venezuela, July 16 -- Venezuelan authorities are rounding up hundreds of persons here suspected of Communist affiliation, as the aftermath of the rupture with Soviet Russia. Many of these have been detained while others were released after questioning.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 17 -- Members of the United States delegation to the United Nations spent today conferring with other members of the Security Council on tactics to be followed at tomorrow's meeting of the Council.

Seventy thousand persons -- members of District 65 of the Distributive, Processing and Office Workers of America, unaffiliated, and their dependents -- are about to be enrolled in the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York.

Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, a contender for the Republican Presidential nomination, will speak tomorrow night from 7 to 7:30 P. M. over the combined television facilities of the National Broadcasting Company, American Broadcasting Company and the Columbia Broadcasting System, his campaign headquarters announced here last night.

New issues of public utility and industrial securities valued at more than $77,000,000 will be offered to investors today. The offerings include debentures, mortgage bonds, common stock and preferred stock. They are as follows:

The largest operating electric utility in the State of Ohio, the Ohio Edison Company, reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $14,682,839 for the twelve months to May 31. This was equal to $2.74 a share on the utility's outstanding common stock, and compares with a net of $14,359,926, or $2.70 a common share, in the comparable period a year ago.

LONDON, June l7 -- With still nearly a year to go before Queen Elizabeth II is crowned on June 2, 1953, there is already a fierce competitive scramble for the traditional robes that the 1,200 peers and peeresses in their own right must wear to the ceremony at Westminster Abbey.

The New York State Insurance Department is now considering the question of higher rates for automobile liability insurance and of some form of merit-rating to reward the good driver or penalize the reckless. With costs of car operation already high, nobody is happy to see any element of these costs go higher.
TOKYO, June 17 (UP) -- Japan announced today it will open negotiations with American, British and French holders of its pre-war government bonds in New York next month.

The American Thread Company had net earnings last year of $2,253,049 after all charges, including $2,571,000 provision for taxes, according to Percival S. Howe Jr., president, in the annual report for 1951.

PARIS, June 17 -- Jacques Duclos, acting Secretary General of the French Communist party, failed today in an effort to force a debate in the National Assembly on his recent arrest and imprisonment on a charge of an attempt against the internal security of the state.

LONDON, June 17 (AP) -- Vic Seixas led a three-man United States delegation into the third round of the London dawn tennis championships today, but faced a strong challenge from the seven-deep Australian contingent.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- Following is the 360-to-22 roll-call vote by which the House of Representatives today passed and sent to the Senate a bill increasing Social Security benefits:

BONN, Germany, June 17 -- Baltic representatives charged here today that 25 per cent of the population of the three captive Baltic countries -- 1,500,000 persons -- have been sent into slave labor by the Russians.

The museum of medieval art, the Cloisters, the Metropolitan Museum's beautiful "branch" high above the Hudson River in Fort Tryon Park, has just received a gift of $10,000,000 from John D. Rockefeller Jr.

The upstate farmers and hotel owners who filed damage suits against New York City for its rainmaking efforts in the 1950 drought and whose claims were dismissed last spring because of a technicality in the court papers won the right yesterday to sue the city again for approximately $1,250,000 under an Appellate Division decision.

For more than a quarter of a century John D. Rockefeller Jr. has taken a devoted interest in The Cloisters. In 1925 he gave to the Metropolitan Museum of Art money to buy and maintain the collection of medieval sculpture and architectural materials gathered by George Grey Barnard.

Nearly 15,000 passengers on twenty-nine New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad and New York Central System inbound commuter trains were delayed from three to thirty-five minutes yesterday in the morning rush hour because of the breakdown of a New Haven engine at the 125th Street station.

PHILADELPHIA, June 17 (AP) Alf Brazle and Relief Pitcher Tom Yuhas held the Phillies to four scattered hits as the Cardinals won the second game of a twilight-night twin bill tonight, 4 to 0, after the Phillies had captured the opener, 2 to 1, on a ninth-inning pinch-single by Bill Nicholson with the bases loaded.

Suggestions by retailers regarding the uniform sizing of sports shirts were approved yesterday by the directors of the National Association of Shirt, Pajama and Sportswear Manufacturers. They met at the Prince George Hotel.

Two new films will arrive in first-run theatres this morning. At the Capitol, the attraction is "Pat and Mike," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer romantic comedy, starring Katharine Hepburn, Spencer Tracy and Aldo Ray. George Cukor directed and Lawrence Weingarten produced from a screen play by Ruth Gordon and Garson Kanin.
LAKEHURST, N. J., June 17 (AP) -- A huge non-rigid airship, described as the largest of its type ever built, arrived early today at the naval air station here.

LONDON, June 18 -- Renewed selling of British Government securities and some sharp rises in Japanese bonds were main features in the stock markets here today. Business generally remained on a small scale.

Without a radical improvement in health conditions all plans to raise agricultural and industrial productivity in undeveloped countries will be dangerously handicapped, if not doomed to failure, Dr. Pierre M. Dorolle, deputy director general of the World Health Organization, declared yesterday.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 18 -- Sweden today categorically rejected the Soviet charge that the Swedish Air Force Catalina which was shot down by Soviet MIG's last Monday had violated Soviet territory at Cape Ristna on the isle of Dagoe and had opened fire first on the Red craft.

A bank thief, working as quietly and unobtrusively as an embezzler, stole $2,400 yesterday afternoon from the Manufacturers Trust Company branch at 711 Lexington Avenue, a half-block north of Fifty-seventh Street.
AMERICUS, Ga., June 18 (AP) -A Federal District Court jury today freed Sheriff John B. Fokes of Dooly County and two other white men of charges of illegal arrest and peonage.
LONDON, June 18 (AP) -- Two Americans advanced today with easy victories to the London grass courts tennis championship quarter-final round, where they will run into a potent crew of six Australians.

I am one of the opponents of the Metcalf-Hatch Animal Seizure Bill referred to by Dr. Walter Alvarez in "Letters to THE TIMES." I am neither crazy nor badly in need of psychiatric assistance. Like many others, I am opposed to this bill on principle. I believe it is unconstitutional because it permits seizure of private property for purposes not paid for by public money or for the general use of the public.

Mechanical defects in motor vehicles constitute hazards that can cause fires at the most unexpected times, according to Robert J. Allen, chief traffic engineer of the Association of Casualty and Surety Companies, 60 John Street. Moreover, he said yesterday, high speeds in hot weather will cause worn tires to ignite and this often results in fatal accidents.
Although it is not a habit with me to comment on pending legislation, I am obliged to make an exception in the case of the McCarran Immigration Bill which is now before President Truman for approval.

IOWA CITY, Iowa, June 18 -- Experiences in all creative arts have great value for children, provided there is a chance for emotional release through self-expression and enriching appreciation of beauty in the child's daily surroundings.

TOKYO, June 18 (AP) -- Japan announced today that she had recognized Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek's Nationalist regime as the Government of China, thus ending speculation that she might sign a separate pact with Red China.

Nation-wide reserves for state unemployment insurance at the end of 1951 reached a high of $7,800,000,000, according to a report issued yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board. It said this was enough to meet annual average post-war benefit payments for five and a half years.

LONDON, June 18 -- In a speech to the Pilgrims, the society devoted to the furtherance of Anglo-American relations, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden pronounced a warning tonight that there was "an enemy at our doors ever vigilant to divide us."

CHICAGO, June 18 -- Mrs. Pasqualina Manca Judd, 32 years old, a Vassar College language teacher and former wife of an Elmwood Park (Ill.) physician, was sentenced to two years in Cook County jail today for having taken her 6-year-old daughter to her home in Poughkeepsie, N. Y., without consent of the court.
The Government of Haiti has asked the United States Bureau of Customs for assistance in the planned revision of its entire customs administration.

The Tudor City Hotel at 304 East Forty-second Street won from the Board of Assessors yesterday an award of $100,535 on its claim for damages of $165,352 allegedly caused by a grade change on Forty-second Street between First and Second Avenues.

WE live between the lost Atlantis and the unvisited geography of the stars. Having spent several thousand years trying to find the fabled El Dorados of the earth, man is now getting ready to go rocketing into space in search of Shangri-Las beyond the last horizon. The days of the argonauts are over; the age of astronautic travel lies ahead. Or so they say.

ASCOT, England, June 18 (Reuters) -- Queen Elizabeth II today saw her second hope of this year's Royal Ascot, the 3-year-old Stream of Light, finish third in the one and a half mile Ribblesdale Stakes.

CLEVELAND, June 18 -- Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee, a leading candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, attacked the Taft-Hartley Act today at the sixth convention of the Communication Workers of America, C. I. O.

The invention and use of the first implement may have been the most important single factor in the biological evolution of man, it was suggested yesterday at the Wenner-Gren Foundation international symposium on anthropology at the foundation's headquarters, 14 East Seventy-first Street.

BOSTON, June 18 (AP) -- The Reds overcame Lefty Warren Spahn's eleven-strikeout pitching to take the second game from the Braves by 3 -- 1 tonight after winning the opener of a twilight-night double-header, 7 -- 6. Spahn now leads Chicago's Bob Rush, 79 -- 70, for top honors in the league's fanning department.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 18 -- Yale capitalized on ten bases on balls and seven errors to defeat Harvard by 8 -- 7 today for the third time in their four-game series this season.

Efforts of the Pinay Government to stabilize France's economy can lead eventually to free convertibility of the franc and consequent improvement in Franco-American trade, members of the international trade section of the New York Board of Trade were told yesterday.
PORTSMOUTH, England, June 18 -- An eight-day "battle" to test the ability of the Western Allies to defend the North Atlantic sea lanes against enemy attack began today.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- The Government today exempted roughly 80 per cent of all copper and aluminum users from direct allocation control, starting July 1. Only large users of the two metals will be required to apply for allotments of the two metals in the third quarter, under a series of orders issued by the National Production Authority.

The "Celanese Theatre," one of television's outstanding dramatic programs, is losing its sponsor after next week's performance. There have been no developments to indicate whether the program will or will not return to the air next fall with a new sponsor.

DETROIT, June 18 -- Right up to game-time today, the Yankees still were indignant over the hit-by-pitcher incident that had cost them an eleven-inning ball game last night. However, once squared off for their second meeting with the Tigers they got down to business with a barrage of long-range hits, including three homers, and evened the set with a 10-6 victory over the cellar club.

PUSAN, Korea, June 19 (AP) -Fourteen South Koreans, seven of them members of the Republic's National Assembly, were put on trial before a ten-man civil-military court today upon orders of President Syngman Rhee.

The tail-end Pirates, who so unceremoniously up-ended the Giants Tuesday night, were back at their normal pace at the Polo Grounds yesterday with the result that Leo Durocher's champions experienced no difficulty making off with a much needed 5-2 victory that enabled them to maintain their four-game distance behind the Dodgers.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 18 -With banners, bunting and balloons flying, more than 6,000 Harvard alumni paraded today to the Harvard-Yale baseball game, the last event of a series of reunion activities.

Dr. William S. Carlson, president of the University of the State of New York, warned last night against the creation of an educated "elite," urging American educators to make "our culture as nearly as possible universal rather than elite."

RICHMOND, Va., June 18 (AP) -- Stockholders of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway approved today a plan to make 300,000 shares of authorized but unissued common stock available for purchase by employes through payroll deduction.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 18 -- Walter T. Candler's Duke of Lullwater from Decatur, Ga., winter book favorite for the Hambletonian, scored in his first stake appearance impressively, with Johnny Simpson driving, at Roosevelt Raceway tonight, when he defeated Hit Song by three-quarters of a length in the $11,650 Old Westbury 3-year-old trot.

PARIS, June 18 -- The Government won the votes of the de Gaullists for its defense budget tonight by assuring the Assembly that United States strategy was to defend Europe and by adopting some of Gen. Charles de Gaulle's strategic ideas.
CHICAGO, June 18 -- Better support developed in the grain market today but not before wheat futures on the Board of Trade had registered another set of new lows for the crop year.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 18 -- The deflationary effect of the forced loan of 10 per cent of currency holdings and of bank accounts, which the Government imposed eight days ago, has been so sharp that Government officials are uncertain whether to be jubilant or worried.

Lieut. Gov. Frank C. Moore paid Queens College seniors the compliment, in his commencement address yesterday, of assuming that they had enough interest in the welfare of New York City to listen to some serious talk about city financial problems. This was a deserved assumption: the students in our municipal colleges are, we believe, alert politically, and they have an obligation for various reasons, including self-interest, to be good citizens.

Five scholarships have been awarded to young musicians for summer study by the National Federation of Music Clubs. The announcement was made yesterday by Mrs. Ada Holding Miller of Providence, R. I., national president of the federation.
TOKYO, Thursday, June 19 (AP) -United Nations Command communique 1,285, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Thursday, Korea time:

With the arrival here yesterday of Robert Nathan from his Truro (Cape Cod), Mass., summer home, things have started to shape up for the author's dramatic work, "Jezebel's Husband." After a conference involving Mr. Nathan, Claude Rains, who will portray the Biblical prophet Jonah, and Sherman Marks, who will be handling the directorial assignment, rehearsals were scheduled to start on July 14.

Staten Islanders who work in Manhattan have always insisted that their daily half-hour ferry trip across the harbor to the Battery is "the best nickel ride in the world." But the man who does more than any other individual to make this trip a cheerful one is not on the payroll of the Board of Transportation.

FOR the longest while the large Hank Sauer of the Cubs has been the hottest slugger in baseball. But the leader in homers and runs-batted-in for both leagues was discovered shivering in the heat at Ebbets Field yesterday. He hadn't made even a teeny-weeny single in his previous twenty-four times at bat.

Shareholders of Middle South Utilities, Inc., have just registered a vigorous dissent from the proposal of one of their number to make pre-emptive shareholders' rights mandatory in future issues of common stock or other financing convertible into common stock.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 18 (UP) -- The United States Olympic boxing team took bloody shape tonight in a furry of stiff rights and jolting lefts that produced seven knockouts in the final ten champonship tryout bouts.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Senator Robert A. Taft said today that if elected to the Presidency he would consult his Republican rival for the nomination, General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, on military matters. He also declared that, as President, he would be "willing to pledge a straight 15 per cent cut in taxes."
Banking syndicates competed yesterday for the underwriting of more than $43,000,000 of new equity and debt securities of public utility holding companies. The awards were:

I have been a stanch Republican since 1892. I should like to know why Governor Dewey should be allowed to hand pick each of the ninety-six delegates to the Republican convention and direct each one of them as to how he should vote.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (UP) -- Drew Pearson, columnist, who was floored by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, eighteen months ago, was punched in a hotel lobby today by Charles Patrick Clark, Washington attorney.
ALBANY, June 18 -- The State Education Department announced today the names of 1,654 high school and parochial school students who won Regents' scholarships for the next four years.

PARIS, June 18 -- It was hinted in official circles here today that the French might delay application of the Schuman plan for a coal and steel merger of Western Europe until the break-up of the German coal-selling combine was completed.

The rearmament of Eastern Germany, long an open secret, has now been proclaimed official Soviet policy. In line with recent Soviet proposals for a national army for all Germany, Premier Grotewohl of the East German puppet regime has announced that such an army will be formed in the Soviet zone, and that all who fought under Hitler's flag, including out-and-out Nazis, will be welcomed to its ranks.

Jackie Robinson's fleetness on the base paths and the unpredictable behavior of a knuckle ball pulled the Dodgers through to a 6-5 ten-inning decision over the Cubs at Ebbets Field yesterday. The victory kept the league-leading Brooks four games in front of the second-place Giants.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -President Truman said today that the discovery of historical papers in a dust-covered bookcase in the Senate library the other day furnished an example of why new safeguards should be taken with official documents.
WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- Announced United States battle casualties in Korea reached 109,971 today, an increase of 259 since last week.

Joseph E. Seagram Sons, Inc., a subsidiary of Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., and its subsidiaries had a net profit of $20,876,974 in the nine months ended with April, after providing $25,100,000 for income and excess profits taxes, the report disclosed yesterday.

Newsprint, recently raised to near-record price levels by Canadian producers, was the subject yesterday of record production reports. The price advance has brought Canadian newsprint delivered in New York to $126 a ton. Reports of consumption in this country showed slight gains.

We wish to extend a sincere invitation to readers of THE NEW YORK TIMES to join in the deep satisfaction of making it possible for blind and crippled girls and women to have seashore and country vacations through our agency this summer.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- In agreeing today to hear and decide seventy-two of the ninety-five contests over delegates at large and district delegates to the national convention, including all thirty-eight from Texas, the Republican National Committee conformed to its own rules, but also it followed sound counsel as to Texas from Senator Taft several hours before.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- John L. Lewis offered today to advance $10,000,000 to the striking United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., to fight "the rapacious and predatory interests that oppose you."

Every photography manual and instruction booklet tells the photographer to hold the camera steady when taking a picture and release the shutter gently, just as marksmen and hunters are warned to squeeze the trigger and not to jerk it.

Future prices on the local commodity exchanges were generally firm yesterday. Hides, lead, sugar, coffee, cottonseed oil and soybean oil futures gained ground. Rubber and cocoa eased in comparatively light trading. Wool also declined.

PHILADELPHIA, June 18 (UP) -- Stan Musial passed the 1,900 mark in major league base hits tonight when he collected a two-run homer and a single to bat in three runs as the Cardinals defeated the Phillies, 7 -- 1, before 9,937 at Shibe Park.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 18 -- At least 1,000,000 men, women and some children are "slaving away" under forced labor systems patterned after the Soviet model in Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Poland and Rumania, according to testimony heard today by the United Nations Committee on Forced Labor.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (UP) -Dean Acheson, Secretary of State, answered critics of the State Department's passport policy today by asserting it was the "best we have been able to develop" under the circumstances. He said the department had to consider the best interests of the nation as well as the rights of the individual.

Normal operation -- with an unfortunate twenty-five-minute locking of brakes that delayed four morning trains in Brooklyn -- returned to the Long Island Rail Road yesterday after a two-day engineers' strike. All trains were running; 175,000 riders were working out arithmetic on commutation tickets, and subways had slightly more air space.
DENVER, June 18 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's careful strategy of avoiding direct controversy with Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio just about collapsed today.

LONDON, June 18 -- The Government published today a White Paper embodying plans for a Central African Federation, decided upon at an April conference in London with representatives of the white settlers in Northern and Southern Rhodesia and Nyasaland.

The decision made by Republican headquarters yesterday that the National Committee would handle most of the contests over delegates to the national convention (with possibility of ultimate appeal to the floor of the convention itself) is a tacit recognition of the fundamental issue here involved.

BONN, Germany, June 18 -- A vigorous protest against the "terror" launched by the East German Communist regime against thousands of persons living along the eastern side of the frontier between the two Germanys was approved by the Bundestag today.

Charles de Foucald, the French cavalry officer who became a monk in the Sahara and died a martyr while a captive of the mysterious veiled Touaregs, is the subject of a biography by R. V. C. Bodley. Mr. Bodley, author of "Wind in the Sahara" and "The Messenger," spent seven years in the Sahara, living among the nomads as an Arab.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., June 18 (UP) -- Stockholders in Eastman Kodak Company were notified today that the photographic equipment concern will pay its 200th consecutive cash dividend on July 1. Not since the company declared its first dividend on Aug. 30, 1902, has it failed to pay a dividend.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Donald C. Cook, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, today announced proposals of the commission for the adoption of new rules under Section 16 of the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934, with respect to the holdings of and dealings by insiders" (officers, directors and 10 per cent owners) in the equity securities of companies listed on a national securities exchange.

A 42-year-old Portuguese ship officer was held in $15,000 bail yesterday by United States Commissioner Edward McDonald after Customs guards found he was carrying $8,000 in fine gold in a specially constructed money belt as he boarded his vessel docked at East River and Clinton Street.

Fireman First Grade Charles G. Boesch lay burned and bandaged on a bed in Roosevelt Hospital yesterday as Mayor Impellitteri pinned on the lapels of his pajamas two medals for heroism -- the Franklin Delano Roosevelt and Fire Department medals.

Extension of the alternate-side-of-the-street parking program to include an additional ninety blocks on the car-congested upper West Side was called for yesterday by Andrew W. Mulrain, Commissioner of Sanitation.

New life was injected into the stock market yesterday under the sponsorship of the railroads, aircrafts and rubber issues. Buying interest rotated from one division to another throughout the session but there was no concentration in any particular section.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- President Truman was beaten in the Senate today on proposals to strip Congress of its political patronage in the appointment of postmasters, United States marshals and top customs officials.

Governor Dewey flatly rejected yesterday the City Council's request that he call a special summer session of the Legislature to consider more financial aid for the city. In a statement made public at Albany, Mr. Dewey declared that "calling a special session of the Legislature to consider 'get-rich-quick' schemes is not a sound substitute for sound fiscal planning and a carefully thought out program."

ROME, June 18 -- The Communists once again proved Florence to be one of their principal strongholds when they tied up all streetcars and buses for a quarter of an hour today and called a one-hour general strike to protest against Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway's visit to the city.

TOKYO, Thursday, June 19 -- The United Nations Command yesterday called on the Communists to verify the locations of the camps in which Allied prisoners are detained in North Korea. The lives of the captives are held to be endangered by enemy failure to post proper markings visible from the air.

Announcement has been made that the so-called "cut-rate fare of 15 cents for a combined ride on city subways and the municipal and private surface lines" will be discontinued July 1. The objectives of this fare increase are stated as an attempt to assist in returning the municipal bus lines to private ownership and to alleviate the deplorable financial situation of the Board of Transportation.
Dallas, Tex., announced yesterday that it will receive bids on July 1 on $15,000,000 of general obligation bonds dated July 1, 1952, and due July 1, 1953 to 1972.

The British White Paper giving a draft scheme for a "Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland" in Central Africa is obviously an important document. A settlement of this problem would have profound effects on the whole question of the readjustment of the white settlers to the irresistible upsurge of the native races.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended June 11:

BERLIN, June 18 -- In reply to a new Soviet charge that a United States plane had committed a "gross violation" of East German territory, the United States announced today that one of its hospital planes had strayed from an air corridor to Berlin.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The Republican National Committee decided today to pass on the validity of seventy-two out of ninety-five delegates whose right to sit in the national convention has been contested. The remaining twenty-three contests will be sent back to state committees for decision.
Four hundred and forty-nine brokers, executives and employes of the New York Stock Exchange and member firms donated blood to the Red Cross in the last three days, it was reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- A cautious analysis of recent Soviet prose and diplomacy appears to demolish the hopes of those who search for signs of peace or cooperation from Moscow.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -The International Labor Relations Committee of the American Federation of Labor reached an understanding tonight on many points of difference with top officers of the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions.

BALTIMORE, June 18 (AP) -- The Chesapeake Bay Bridge, first continuous link between Maryland's Eastern Shore and the rest of the state, is expected to open July 30. The Governor's office today announced the tentative date. The $43,000,000 bridge will be dedicated at 11 A. M. and then opened for public inspection.

Economical, east - to - prepare canned meats and meat products (corned beef hash, beef stew and so forth) always reach their popularity peak in the summer. They are available in especially large quantity this year. Supplies are 50 per cent above the recent average.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- A delegation representing the Utility Workers Union of America, C. I. O., urged President Truman today to change his decision not to seek reelection, and at least one member came away believing "there is an outside chance" that he might reconsider.

The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange at the close of business on June 13, amounted to 1,753,466 shares, according to information obtained by the Exchange from its members and member firms. This represents a decline of 91,110 shares from the 1,844,576 reported on May 15.

The Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation identified itself yesterday as the prospective purchaser of the 286-acre James Butler estate near Elmsford in Westchester County, where the company plans to relocate its New York office staff.

Bowaters Southern Paper Corporation, a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Bowaters Paper Corporation, Ltd. of England, announced yesterday that it has arranged to borrow $37 500,000 from twelve United States insurance companies on 4 3/4 per cent sinking fund first mortgage bonds due on March 1, 1973. Morgan Stanley Co. arranged the financing.

SEATTLE, June 18 (UP) -- The commander of United States forces in Alaska said today he believed the Russians could invade Alaska with large numbers of troops, but that United States air power would strike back immediately if such an attack were launched.

A new collection of Swedish stoneware, the first American showing of Mari Simmulson, 30-year-old designer, is on view at Bonnier's, 605 Madison Avenue. All the pieces were made in the Upsala Ededy factory.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 18 -The executive board of the Screen Actors Guild has informed the Motion Picture Industry Council that it will vote to support the proposed establishment by the council of a special committee to assist industry personalities whose loyalty as Americans may be questioned by public groups.

The growing popularity of the king-size cigarette has not gone unnoticed by the old line producers of the standard-size product. In an effort to capitalize on the trend, Liggett Myers Tobacco Company announced yesterday that it will introduce king - size Chesterfields to the New York and Boston markets next Monday to be available with its big selling, standard size cigarette.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 18 to 23 points net higher yesterday than on Tuesday.

BONN, Germany, June 18 -- The Bundesrat, or upper house of the federal legislature, will insist on debating and voting on all sections of the Bonn convention and the European Defense Community treaty, Hans Ehard, Bavarian Minister-President, said tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The Senate rejected a last-hour plea from President Truman today and again disapproved the St. Lawrence Seaway and Power Project, which has been in contro versy for a generation. Mr. Truman had declared that it would be "one of the worst economic mistakes the country has ever made to allow that great project to go by default."

MONTCLAIR, N. J., June 18 -Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of Century defeated Peggy Mackie of Inwood, the defending champion, 1 up, in the second round of the forty-ninth annual Women's Metropoltian Golf Association tourney over the Upper Montclair course today.

The American Fair Trade Council gave up yesterday its fight to bring mail order price cutters under the scope of "fair trade" legislation pending in Congress: There are strong indications, however, that the retreat on the mail order issue is temporary.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (UP) -Vice Admiral E. L. Cochrane said today the Federal Maritime Board had given American Export Lines an additional thirty days to decide whether to accept reduced subsidies for the liners Independence and Constitution or return them to the Government.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Averell Harriman, Mutual Security Director, was highly elated today by his 4-to-1 victory over Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee in yesterday's District of Columbia primary, but he refused to say whether he thought the result had stopped the Tennessean in the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

TRENTON, June 18 -- Angered by belief that Guy G. Gabrielson, chairman of the Republican National Committee, has used his position to help the candidacy of Senator Robert A. Taft for the Republican nomination for President, supporters of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower are considering the possibility of dropping him as Republican National Committeeman from New Jersey.
ALBANY, June 18 (AP) -- The Public Service Commission today refused to permit the New York Water Service Corporation to raise its water rates without a commission hearing.

The prospect of many vacant shipways toward the end of next year and of almost complete vacancy early in 1954 has aroused the American shipbuilding industry, which is now calling for an easing of Government restrictions on ship construction for foreign account.

ADEN, June 18 -- The British-owned Anglo-Iranian Oil Company won a major first-round victory today in its fight to blockade Iranian oil from overseas markets. A British court here granted a temporary injunction holding the tiny tanker Rose Mary and her cargo fast in this Arabian port under an armed British police guard.

Seven persons perished yesterday in an early-morning two-alarm fire in a Brooklyn tenement that had been classed as a firetrap in 1948. The four-story building at 1101 Bedford Avenue had no fire escape.

Preparations for construction by the Port of New York Authority of a new $90,000,000 third tube for the Lincoln Tunnel were expedited yesterday when the City Planning Commission, in a special meeting in its Municipal Building headquarters, approved plans for street improvements at the tunnel's Manhattan end.

The United Nations Korean Reconstruction Agency has announced another important step in aiding Korean rebuilding. More than 1,500 tons of good quality paper has been obtained in the United States, Canada and Japan and is en route to Korea for the offset printing of textbooks. This shipment should provide the means of supplying about 7,500,000 books.

The Queens Chamber of Commerce has studied the 1950 census figures and found that Queens now has undisputed title to being the "fastest growing home-owner borough in New York City." The chamber's own study of the statistics carves Queens into forty-four separate communities, many of which were once independent towns and villages, with a total population of 1,550,849.

CLEVELAND, June 18 (AP) -- The Senators toppled the Indians into fourth place tonight with a 3-to-2 defeat. The Tribe, which had not been lower than third this season, suffered its fifth straight defeat and fell behind the White Sox on percentage points, .544 to .542.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 18 -- Ernest A. Gross, the United States representative, today asked the United Nations Security Council to refer to the Disarmament Commission a Soviet proposal calling on all states to become parties to the Geneva Protocol of 1925, which prohibits the use of germ warfare.

Wilson W. Condict and William W. Martin have been elected directors of the Domestic Finance Corporation, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Condict is advertising director of The St. Louis Globe-Democrat and Mr. Martin is chairman of the Farm Credit Administration of St. Louis.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 18 -- An assistant professional, Bob Gajda pronounced "Gator") of the Oakland Hills Country Club, Birmingham, Mich., made his first appearance today in the Professional Golfers Association championship and showed the way to the field of 137 starters with a 6-under-par 66.

BONN, Germany, June 18 -- The West German Government has requested employer associations and trade unions to present proposals for the creation of a federal economic council. Such a council would have a semi-official status and would pass informally on all economic legislation in the Bundestag. In effect it would be an economic parliament ex-officio.
Lieut. Gov. Frank C. Moore ascribed the city's financial difficulties yesterday to the timidity of its elected officials and stressed that any sound solution would require a bold facing of the facts.

MILWAUKEE, June 18 -- Both business conditions and Federal policy indicate a downward trend in bond interest rates despite the recent increase in rates on Government savings bonds, a New York University economist said here today.
Mayor Impellitteri announced last night that the next chairman of the Civil Service Commission would be a Negro. He did not say who the chairman would be, nor when the appointment would be made.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (UP) -- A House-Senate conference committee agreed today on compromise legislation to enlarge the Marine Corps and make its commandant a part-time member of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -The Bureau of the Census reported today that cotton consumption from May 4 to May 31 averaged 35,215 bales for each working day. This compared with an average of 42,695 bales for the corresponding period a year ago, and with 33,898 for April of this year.

PARIS, June 18 -- The French Cabinet today revealed plans to move France's atomic energy program out of the field of research and experiment into the production of power for industrial use with the expenditure of $107,000,000 over the next five years.
The following book, of interest to parents, was published recently:

MADRID, June 18 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco ended today a three weeks tour of Catalonia which he made, Spaniards say, for two main reasons: To urge the Catalans to abandon whatever separatist or autonomist aims they have and support the Central Government as the symbol of national unity, and to encourage private initiative to collaborate in the present official policy designed to attain self-sufficiency in many fields of production.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The Senate Agriculture Committee was told today that the "plugging" of shipments of flaxseed bought by the Government under its farm price support program had added more than $3,000,000 to the cost, and that the Agriculture Department had taken no action against admitted perpetrators of the frauds.

Increased efforts by business to reduce rising clerical and other administrative costs were urged yesterday at a final technical session of the National Association of Cost Accountants' thirty-third annual international costs conference.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The Woman's Bureau issued today a study, "Maternity Protection of Employed Women," that said the United States was lagging far behind other industrial countries in providing maternity leave, cash benefits and medical care for working mothers.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- President Truman said today that relations between the United States and Czechoslovakia cannot be improved as long as that Government holds William N. Oatis, an American newspaper man, in prison.

THOSE planning to get in on the early school tuna run will have to make their reservations without too much delay if they expect to get a charter for the week-end, for the demand is threatening the supply of available craft.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., June 18 (AP) -- Twenty-four men, including the president of the concern, have been indicted by a Morris County grand jury in an investigation of the April 7 rioting at the strike-bound Whippany Paperboard Company, it was announced today.

SPRING LAKE, N. J., June 18 -- The capital needs of the commercial banks, savings bank competition, defalcations, and the scarcity of suitable personnel are among the major problems slated for consideration by members of the New York State Bankers Association, now gathering here for its fifty-sixth annual convention.

GLEN COVE, L. I., June 18 -Two former champions, John J. Humm of Rockville and Tom Strafaci of the Plandome Club, fired identical 37, 35 -- 72's to tie for the medal today in the Long Island Golf Association amateur championship for the Elmer E. Smathers Cup at the Nassau Country Club.
The two-day officially sanctioned wildcat strike of engineers on the Long Island Rail Road is over, but its casualties go beyond the inconvenience to some 300,000 passengers, bad as that was.

CINCINNATI, June 18 -- Adoption immediately of a vigorous policy of selective decontrol of prices and wages, permitting an orderly return to free markets, was urged here today by Fred Lazarus Jr., president of Federated Department Stores, Inc., one of the nation's largest retailing groups.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 18 -- Dr. Hernan Santa Cruz of Chile, former president of the United Nations Economic and Social Council, presented to that body today an analysis of the proposed grants-in-aid program to finance non-self-liquidating projects in underdeveloped countries.
WASHINGTON, June 18 (UP) -Conferees of the Senate and the House of Representatives agreed today to permit construction of 35,000 public housing units in the twelve months to start July 1.

Hitting like a heavyweight in the final sixteenth, the Belair Stud's Golden Gloves won the Shevlin in Aqueduct yesterday. Doughty Nick Wall, one of the oldest jockeys now campaigning, rated the son of Isolater expertly to bring him home in 1.44 1-5, a neck ahead of Quiet Step of the Apheim Stable in the mile-and-a-sixteenth fixture that had its twenty-fifth running.
MOSCOW, June 18 (AP) -- Tass, the Soviet news agency, has issued a formal denial of a report that Premier Stalin had made a new statement on the Polish boundary question.
LONDON, June 18 -- Despite British diplomatic recognition of the Chinese People's Republic Mao Tse-tung's Communist regime continues to treat the British with disrespect.

CLINTON, N. Y., June 18 (AP) -The New York State Presbyterian Synod offered its support today to legislation that would make habitual drunkenness a ground for divorce, and require a "waiting period'' in divorce suits.

CHICAGO, June 18 (AP) -- The defending champion, Patty Berg, turned on the pressure for a 2-up victory today to join four other pros in advancing to the third round of the women's Western open golf tourney. Miss Berg, seeking her fifth Western crown, beat an amateur, Carol Diringer of Tiffin, Ohio.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 18 -Nurses must give more vigorous backing to the collective-bargaining methods that are open to them if they wish to raise their "perennially substandard" salaries, the American Nurses Association was told today.
James Edward Barnes, who will be 14 years old next Wednesday, was graduated yesterday from Public School 85 in the Bronx.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, June 18 -- British tutelage in its African colonial possessions is rapidly coming to an end, according to Dr. Robert K. A. Gardiner, head of the department of extra-mural activities of University College at Ibadan, Nigeria.
The Washington conference on Indo-China ended yesterday on an optimistic note.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- Following is the 56-to-29 roll-call vote by which the Senate today adopted a resolution disapproving, and thus killing, President Truman's reorganization plan to eliminate Senate confirmation of 21,438 postmasters:

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The United States agreed today to undertake stepping up aid to French and nationalist forces trying to drive Communist-led rebels out of Indo-China. A communique concluding three days of talks between American military and diplomatic officials and Jean Letourneau, French Cabinet Minister for the Associated States, expressed the two countries' joint determination to bring six years of attempted conquest and subversion on the part of the Communists to an end.

The country's gasoline stocks declined 1,463,000 barrels last week, according to the weekly figures of the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, they totaled 121,993,000 barrels, compared with 123,456,000 a week earlier and 137,905,000 a year ago.

The Goldman Band last evening opened its thirty-fifth season of Guggenheim Memorial Concerts on the Mall at Central Park before an audience of 20,000 listeners. The concert was the 1,947th played by the Goldman Band, and was under the direction of Dr. Edwin Franko Goldman, who has led all or part of every concert in the series.

VIENNA, June 18 -- Karl Waldbrunner, Austrian Minister for Communications and Nationalized Enterprises, complained in a speech here today that the Soviet occupation authorities in Austria were censoring not only international telephone traffic to and from Vienna but telephone traffic from their zone to other parts of Austria.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 18 -Government efforts to settle the twenty-five-day strike of the Sailors Union of the Pacific, A. F. L., which has tied up more than seventy vessels of the West Coast, bogged down today.

GENEVA, June 18 (AP) -- A high official of the American Federation of Labor charged today that a certain section of management in the United States is seeking to discredit the International Labor Organization and prevent United States participation in it.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- Following is the 56-to-29 roll-call vote by which the Senate today adopted a resolution disapproving, and thus killing, President Truman's reorganization plan to eliminate Senate confirmation of 21,438 postmasters:

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The United States agreed today to undertake stepping up aid to French and nationalist forces trying to drive Communist-led rebels out of Indo-China. A communique concluding three days of talks between American military and diplomatic officials and Jean Letourneau, French Cabinet Minister for the Associated States, expressed the two countries' joint determination to bring six years of attempted conquest and subversion on the part of the Communists to an end.
CHICAGO, June 18 (AP) -- Rocky Castellani, a middleweight from Luzerne, Pa., tonight won a split decision over Chicago's Johnny Bratton in their ten-round battle in the Chicago Stadium.

Four fuzzy-memoried hotel thieves, three of whom disrobed twenty-four male tenants in a three-hour robbery in a West Side hotel lobby last Thursday, were arrested between 11:30 P. M. Tuesday and dawn yesterday.

PARIS, June 18 -- The French Government will continue to prosecute individual violations of the law by Communists and to root Red sympathizers out of the services affecting national defense, but it has no current plans for the outright suppression of the party itself.
