SAN FRANCISCO, June 18 -Government efforts to settle the twenty-five-day strike of the Sailors Union of the Pacific, A. F. L., which has tied up more than seventy vessels of the West Coast, bogged down today.

GENEVA, June 18 (AP) -- A high official of the American Federation of Labor charged today that a certain section of management in the United States is seeking to discredit the International Labor Organization and prevent United States participation in it.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The national cost-of-living level, as measured by the index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, rose, by May 15, to within one-tenth of a point of the record high level registered around the first of the year.

A new Lincoln biography by Stefan Lorant has been scheduled for September publication by Harper, entitled "Lincoln: A Picture Story of His Life." The book will contain 500 Lincoln photographs, including some newly discovered, Lincoln's important letters and political speeches in facsimile and a 100,000 - word biographical text.
OKLAHOMA CITY, June 19 (AP) -- William H. Cordell, administrator of the Red Cross blood center who charged that contaminated blood was being sent overseas from Oklahoma, was discharged today.

Fifteen young women, entrants in the "Miss Universe" beauty contest at Long Beach, Calif., starting next Monday, presented gifts from their native lands to Mrs. Vincent R. Impellitteri at Gracie Mansion yesterday, but a 5-week-old female lion stole the show at the Mayor's official residence.

THE Dodgers were going nowhere with great rapidity during the 1943 season and Branch Rickey was experimenting with one untried youngster after another in desperate efforts to halt the downhill slide. Nothing seemed to work. Then one day Leo Durecher breezed into the Mahatma's office.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 19 -- With the sun streaming down on the relatively placid waters of the Thames lending hope of pleasant weather for the classic tomorrow, crews from Harvard and Yale went through their final workouts today.

Herbert Bayard Swope, who headed the State Racing Commission for eleven years, proposed yesterday that the state set up kiosks or booths in Times Square, the financial district and other centers where anyone desiring to bet on a horse race could do so legally.

CHICAGO, June 19 -- A broadening concept of "good design" seems indicated by the selections added today to the display that goes by that name. Added to this continuing exhibit were 220 objects sponsored jointly by the Merchandise Mart of this city and the Museum of Modern Art of New York.
India's 80,000,000 cases of malaria can be cleaned up in three years with the cost of a single bomber, Chester Bowles, United States Ambassador to India, declared yesterday.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 19 -- Major Kerr, 7-year-old bay horse owned by Michael D. Sherman of Freehold, N. J., returned $209.90 to his backers at the Roosevelt Raceway tonight as he won the Class CC pace. Handled by Joseph Oliver, also recording his first victory of the meeting, Major Kerr finished in 2:09 4-5 in scoring by three lengths over Harkaday.
LONDON, June 19 (AP) -- The Moscow radio broadcast tonight this North Korean communique:

ROME, June 19 -- A valuable contribution to the history of the events that preceded the outbreak of World War II has been made by the publication, under the auspices of the Italian Government, of secret Foreign Ministry files covering the period from May 23 to Aug. 11, 1939.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The National Labor Relations Board announced today a decision rejecting a union's petition to merge its bargaining rights with one employer in sixty cities into one consolidated unit. The decision bears significantly on collective bargaining representation affecting any company that has plants in more than one area.
CHICAGO, June 19 (UP) -- Bobby Shantz hurled his eleventh consecutive victory today as the Athletics split a double-header with the White Sox.

HOUSTON, Tex., June 19 (UP) -- The leader of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's Texas delegation to the Republican National Convention disclosed today that the Republican National Committee had reserved hotel rooms for him and the members of his delegation thirty-two miles from downtown Chicago and had not sent convention tickets.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- Chairman Emanuel Celler, Democrat of New York, of the House Judiciary Committee urged President Truman today to approve the purchase of large quantities of aluminum from Canada to save 14,000 independent aluminum fabricators in this country he said "are gradually facing extinction."

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, June 20 (AP) -- ese Commufiist troops, mauled in the west, switched their heavy attacks to 'the eastern Korean front and were thrown back yesterday, leaving an estimated total of 200 dead.
CLEVELAND, June 19 (AP) -- The Senators scored three runs in the ninth inning today to sweep three-game series from Cleveland, 6 -- 3, and hand the Indians their sixth straight defeat.

PITTSBURGH, June 19 (AP) -- A Pennsylvania Supreme Court justice today condemned Whittaker Chambers' best seller "Witness" as a "monstrous book" and called on Congress to take action against the author.

In a prelude to summer, which begins officially tomorrow at 7:13 A. M. Daylight Saving Time, a short but fierce storm early yesterday afternoon broke the city's early heat wave, sending the temperature down eighteen degrees in ten minutes.
BOSTON, June 19 (UP) -- Hank Edwards broke up a tie game with a three-run, ninth-inning homer tonight to lead the Reds to a 7-4 victory over the Braves for their third victory in a four-game series.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The United States has assured Canada that Ottawa will be consulted, if the military situation permits, before Canadian troops are separated from their own command.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 19 -- Members of the Economic and Social Council today approved, 14 to 0, with three abstentions, the annual report of the World Health Organization, submitted by the Deputy Director General, Dr. Pierre Derolle. The Soviet, Polish and Czechoslovak delegations abstained.

GLEN COVE, L. I., June 19 -- Frank Strafaci of the Garden City Country Club, the defending champion led the way into the quarter-final round of the Long Island Golf Association's amateur championship with a pair of victories at the Nassau Club today.

BONN, Germany, June 19 -- Ratification by the Bundestag of the European Defense Community Treaty and the Bonn peace contract with the Western Allies before autumn appears unlikely because of the opposition of deputies in the Government parties, the press service of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's Christian Democratic Union declared today.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J., June 19 -- Mrs. Joseph C. Frelinghuysen Jr. of Somerset Hills sprang the biggest upset of the forty-ninth annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship by defeating Mrs. Catherine Fox Park of Glen Ridge, 1 up, over the Upper Montclair course today.

American industry should take a position of strong leadership in the development of international industrial, engineering, commercial and safety standards, Robert E. Gay, president of the American Standards Association, said last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel at the second general assembly dinner of the International Organization for Standardization.
Following is the text of Senator Taft's address and the questions and answers during his television appearance last night as transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Three new films will arrive at first-run theatres this morning. "The Winning Team," a Warner Brothers dramatization of the career of Grover Cleveland Alexander, with Ronald Reagan playing the famous pitcher, Doris Day and Frank Lovejoy, is at the Mayfair.

Senator Robert A. Taft declared last night that General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, his principal opponent for the Republican nomination for President, had shifted his position on certain issues, particularly on reduction of Government expenditures.

Five runs by the Pirates in a seventy-four-minute third inning marked by a storm of rain and a shower of words helped to send the Giants down to an 8-1 defeat before a Ladies' Day crowd of 6,369 at the Polo Grounds yesterday. The Giants completed the game under protest.

The Chilean Line (Compania Sud Americana de Vapores) has signed a contract with Chantiers de la Loire of Paris, for the construction of two 10,000-ton cargo vessels in the latter's yards at St. Nazaire. Augmenting a growing fleet, the ships are scheduled to be delivered in 1955.

Representatives of the city's five county medical societies appeared before the City Council's city affairs committee yesterday in an effort to break the virtual the monopoly maintained by the Health Insurance Plan among city employes.

Active interest in the study of governmental management on which more than $2,000,000 has been spent by the city in the last two years was urged yesterday by speakers at the seventy-fourth annual meeting of the Civil Service Reform Association in the Town Hall Club, 123 West Forty-third Street.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The master plan of "cannibalistic American imperialism" calls for eliminating 700,000,000 persons in Europe and Asia by means of war, starvation and disease, the Moscow newspaper Pravda has told its readers in a major article setting a new peak in the "hate America" campaign.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 19 -- Pleas for refining the process of government at the national and municipal levels were voiced today by John Foster Dulles, negotiator of the Japanese peace treaty, and by Mayor Joseph S. Clark Jr. of Philadelphia in addresses at Harvard University's 301st commencement. Both received honorary degrees.
TOKYO, Friday, June 20 (AP) -- Eight Army tactical summary 93, for Thursday:
LONDON, June 19 -- An imposing agenda for an important series of diplomatic conferences has been prepared for the London visit next week of Dean Acheson, United States Secretary of State.

Cardinal Spellman presented diplomas and pins to eighty-nine graduates of St. Vincent's Hospital School of Nursing yesterday at the sixtieth anniversary commencement exercises held in St. Patrick's Cathedral. More than 1,500 persons attended.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (UP) -- President Truman told a group of youngsters today that "in all probability" he would not be in the White House next year.

VIENNA, June 19 -- In a note to Soviet Occupation Authorities in Austria published today, the Acting United States High Commissioner, Walter Dowling, rejected a Soviet proposal that they should be notified of intended flights by American planes to avoid such incidents as the buzzing of Ambassador Walter J. Donnelly's plane by Soviet fighters a fortnight ago.

A legal move to stay the execution of Lewis Wolfe, self-styled Messiah, failed yesterday in Kings County Court when Judge Louis Goldstein denied the prisoner's application for a writ of error to set aside his conviction of murder in the first degree.

The long-debated and controversial question of whether the 2-year-old child is ready for nursery school has been answered favorably both by parents and teachers with the publication of a recent analysis of first-day and first-week records of thirty unselected 2year-olds in the Bellflower, Calif., public schools.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 19 -- Since the State Department, like all foreign ministries, never wants to admit that it has changed its mind, it is easy to understand why it has remained silent on the origins of the Geneva Protocol of 1925, which the United States now considers a mere "paper prohibition" of bacteriological warfare.

OTTAWA, June 19 -- With all the authority and respect that he commands throughout the British Commonwealth and among the Allied peoples who fought under his command in Africa and Italy during World War II, Field Marshal Earl Alexander, British Defense Minister, has backed the United Nations in Korea.
PHILADELPHIA, June 19 (UP) -- The Cardinals scored five runs on four hits in the sixth inning tonight to beat the Phillies, 6 to 4.

BONN, Germany, June 19 -- Authoritative sources here believe that France is raising difficulties over the Schuman plan for a coal-steel merger not because of anything specifically attached to the plan but chiefly out of a desire to slow down German resumption of influence in Europe.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (UP) -- House investigators today ordered public hearings next week on complaints that the Justice Department "stifled" 1948 anti-trust laws against the "Big Four" liquor companies.
BERLIN, June 19 -- The Soviet Union charged today that Britain, France and the United States had converted West Berlin into a "breeding ground" of espionage.

In France from now on it may not be necessary to ask questions to determine whether a person is an active Communist sympathizer or not. If he is speckled with blue dye he is a sympathizer and an active one. This will be because the police have been ordered to spray such a dye on the participants in future street demonstrations.

CINCINNATI, June 19 -- Documents and other records of Jews who came in 1654 from Brazil to New Amsterdam, now New York City, believed to be the first Jews ever to live in what now is the United States, will be sought during a five-week expedition in the West Indies and South America.
Prices of most commodity futures advanced yesterday in comparatively active trading. Gains were registered by hides, lead, rubber, cocoa, world sugar and coffee.

PHILADELPHIA, June 19 -- Some of Pennsylvania's leading Taft and Eisenhower supporters temporarily laid aside their differences tonight and sat down at a dinner in the interest of unity within Republican party ranks.

The American Lyric Theatre, William Whiting and Robert Lenner, co-producers, will present nine weeks of one-act operas, ballets and plays in repertory at the Provincetown Playhouse, beginning Tuesday, July 1, it was announced yesterday.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., June 19 (AP) -- The defense in the Government's suit for forfeiture of the tanker Meacham produced today an opinion by a Maritime Commission lawyer that the United Tanker Corporation qualified as an American citizen under the 1916 Shipping Act.
Monroe Meyers has been appointed general sales manager of the suit and coat division of Henry Rosenfeld, Inc.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 19 -- The liner President Cleveland of American President Lines sailed for the Orient today after seven postponements to permit the settlement of a union dispute.

DENVER, June 19 (AP) -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower prepared today for a flying week-end trip to Texas and Nevada, where he is expected to speak out on the contested Texas Republican delegates and on Western reclamation.

PARIS, June 19 -- A five-point program of home-rule reforms for France's troubled North African protectorate of Tunisia was described to the French National Assembly today by Foreign Minister Robert Schuman.

TROON, Scotland, June 19 -- A Scottish lassie won the British women's amateur golf championship today, the first to do so since 1938, and 3,000 of her overjoyed countrymen acclaimed a stirring comeback that ended in triumph on the thirty-eighth green.

DETROIT, June 19 -- Yogi Berra, who likes Tiger pitching even more than he likes home cooking, slammed his eleventh and twelfth homers of the season today, leading the Yankees to an 8-0 victory over the Bengals. With Hank Bauer also hitting for the circuit, Allie Reynolds easily registered his eighth triumph and his twelfth straight complete game.

Mrs. G. H. (Pete) Bostwick's Hyvania, winner of the eighth running of Aqueduct's Amagansett Hurdle Handicap a year ago, took the ninth edition yesterday. He outran and outjumped four others over a mile-and-three-quarter course that had been hit by a brief but extremely business-like early-afternoon thunderstorm.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (UP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan ruled out acreage allotments or marketing quotas on the 1953 wheat crop today because of the "national emergency."

ALBANY, N. Y., June 19 (AP) -- Effective July 1, the State Motor Vehicle Bureau will not reregister or transfer the ownership of trucks subject to the state's weight-distance tax unless the application is accompanied by a "certificate of tax clearance."

PARIS, June 19 -- Etienne Fajon, a member of the Central Committee of the French Communist party and generally considered to be its Moscow doctrinaire, scolded the party today for its recent failures, particularly its loss of mass support through what he termed opportunism and sectarianism.

DENVER, June 19 -- On the theory that the delegates to the Republican nominating convention are entitled to all the facts about General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower before deciding whether they wish to nominate him for the Presidency, the following report is submitted and certified correct by the above-signed after careful first-hand observation:
Faraway lands and times have inspired a number of the new fabrics available through decorators at Howard Schaffer, Inc., 509 Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The European Payments Union was saved from threatened collapse today when the International Monetary Fund established a $50,000,000 line of credit here for the Belgian Government to facilitate the liquidation of that country's staggering surplus with the clearing agency.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- During the week ended June 18, member bank reserves increased $1,254,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

DETROIT, June 19 -- Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee, front-running contender for the Democratic Presidential nomination, resumed today his courtship of Michigan's forty delegates to the Chicago convention. It was the Senator's third visit to Michigan in his campaign for the nomination.

MOSCOW, June 19 -- Two more republican plenums (full assemblies) of the Communist party organizations chiefly devoted to sharp criticism of the party's work in agriculture and in ideological fields have been reported by the Soviet press.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended June 14 totaled 631,043 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 53,200 cars or 7.8 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 195,840 cars or 23.7 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year and 174,833 cars or 21.7 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.
A new lower level platform of the IND subway at Eighth Avenue and Forty-second Street will open in mid-summer to provide rush hour travelers from Queens with faster and smoother service.

The degree of Associate in Applied Science was conferred last night upon 160 men and women at commencement exercises at the Fashion Institute of Technology, 225 West Twenty-fourth Street. It was the first time a college degree had been granted by an institution devoted to training for careers in garment manufacturing and allied industries.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., June 19 -- Vice Admiral Charles Turner Joy, former chief of the United Nations truce negotiators in Korea, returned home today to advise continued "talking" with the Communist negotiators as long as there was "even the slightest chance" for an armistice.

A commuter request for a gubernatorial review of the Public Service Commission's recent grant of a fare increase to the New York Central Railroad has been rejected by George M. Shapiro, counsel to Governor Dewey, Philip W. Lowry, attorney, who had sent to the Governor last week a petition endorsed by 700 Westchester commuters, made public a letter from Mr. Shapiro saying that the Governor "has no power to review the determination of the commission."
BONN, Germany, June 19 -- The United States Government's influence as a promoter of European economic cooperation has suffered a marked decline lately among top-level Western European officials.

Former Police Inspector Herbert Golden was adjudged in contempt yesterday by Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz in Kings County Court for refusing to answer questions about his financial affairs before the Brooklyn rackets grand jury.

It has come to my attention that a very kind and useful service is being performed by public-minded citizens who visit Bellevue Hospital on Sunday mornings to assist the medical personnel and to permit patients to attend worship services.

The doughnut business is not "peanuts" -- last year sales of the product amounted to $276,500,000, according to J. I. Sugerman advertising and sales promotion director of the Doughnut Corporation of America. This is an increase of more than 7 per cent over the volume in 1950.

If we review our experience in the last quarter century can we say our leaders have shown evidence of great foresight? I fear the only answer is a resounding no. They appear to have been surprised by crisis after crisis and forced to improvise, rather than to have acted with any long-term policy in view.

FORKED RIVER, N. J., June 19 -- The resort community of Barnegat Pines, three miles northwest of Forked River, was threatened this afternoon by a rekindled forest fire, raging out of control over 4,000 acres of pine woodlands.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The Commonwealth Edison Company, of Chicago, today applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission for permission to market $40,000,000 of first mortgage bonds, series 0, due July 1, 1982. The securities will be offered for public sale at competitive bidding.

Ever since the Defense Production Act was extended for the first time, a year ago, the Administration has been busily cultivating and propagating a political myth about price-wage control. This is the myth that the original price-control provisions had been soundly conceived and highly successful in operation.

ST. LOUIS, June 19 (AP) -- A young right-hand pitcher who previously had started only one game this season and failed to last five innings, baffled the Browns today as the Red Sox won the series final, 2 to 0.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 19 -Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion expressed satisfaction today that the Zionist Organization of America at its convention in New York this week had cleared up the misunderstanding about the right of foreign Zionists to participate in the shaping of Israel's policies.

LIMA, Peru, June 19 -- Ten Peruvian students were en route today to start a course at the University of Texas under the Point Four program. This project adds one more point to a large score that can be totaled against the charge that the United States is failing in a good-neighborly attitude toward Latin America, at least as far as Peru is concerned.

VIENNA, June 19 -- Austria's two big nationalized commercial banks whose transactions with Marshall Plan funds have been subject to so much recent comment here and in the United States, will have rid themselves of worthless German assets by the end of this year and will ask to be denationalized.

ABINGDON, Ill., June 19 -- Larry Stopher, 16 years old, said today he was "scared to death" when his companion, 17, took him up in a stolen airplane and then announced that he did not know how to get it down.

Arthur V. Sheridan, 64 years old, who planned to retire on July 1 as Commissioner of Borough Works in the Bronx, was killed at 2:20 P. M. yesterday when the automobile he was driving collided with an oil truck at Broadway and 256th Street, the Bronx.

NOW that other forms of angling have opened up, the trout fisherman can move up his favorite stream for at least 100 yards without falling over competitors, and according to reports from a score of streams in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Pennsylvania this is scheduled to be an interesting weekend for the fly fisherman.

New fashion trends that will be important this fall were presented by the ready-to-wear committee of The Fashion Group at a luncheon meeting yesterday at the Astor Hotel. Interesting changes in fabrics and silhouettes were indicated in the coats, suits, dresses and sportswear shown.

CINCINNATI, June 19 (AP) -- Production of jet engines for the nation's fighter planes was cut virtually in half today when a full-force strike stopped work at the General Electric Company's plant here.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 19 -- An avalanche of letters concerning candidates for the Republican nomination for President is descending upon Westchester County's eight delegates and alternates to the Republican national convention. The total reached 6,000 today.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The highest Republican foreign policy spokesman in Congress, Senator Alexander Wiley of Wisconsin, proposed today an impartial and outside investigation of Communist charges that the United States had used germ warfare in Korea.

Miss Gisela Ratzeburg of Bremen, Germany, a one-time member of the Hitler Youth who now is a junior at Long Island University, has been chosen to represent the university at the annual student leadership conference sponsored by the New York region of the National Conference of Christians and Jews at Vassar College next week.

More than $43,000,000 of new securities of public utility holding companies will be offered to investors today. The offerings include debentures and common stock of American Gas and Electric Company, which will be distributed direct to the public by underwriting syndicates, and a preferential offer of common stock to shareholders of the Southern Company, a standby transaction which will end on July 10.
ADEN, June 19 (Reuters) -- The Supreme Court of this British colony today ordered the Italian tanker Rose Mary, carrying a cargo of Iranian crude oil, to stay tied up here until July 15.
Grants totaling $200,000 were made yesterday by The Greater New York Fund to six welfare agencies to find ways of placing more homeless children in suitable homes with less waiting time.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (UP) -- The Government announced tonight that the United Steelworkers, C. I. O., had agreed to ship finished steel for military use from 132 plants and warehouses affected by its strike.

Two jittery robbers, well versed in the vocabulary of hold-up men but in need of soothing words from their frightened victim, pushed into a West Side apartment yesterday morning, tied up two of the occupants, barricaded a third in her room and escaped with $10,000 in cash and jewelry.

City department heads and others who ignored a "cordial invitation" from the Mayor's office to attend safety award ceremonies in the Board of Estimate chamber yesterday morning received a public tongue-lashing from Mayor Impellitteri for passing up the event.

Senator William Benton, Democrat of Connecticut, received last night a silver plaque for his "distinguished service in behalf of democratic rights." The presentation was made by the advertising, radio, television and graphic arts division of the Joint Defense Appeal at a dinner at the Pierre Hotel.

CHICAGO, June 19 -- James C. Thompson, Chicago business man, disclosed today that President Truman had said at a private dinner party Tuesday in the White House that he was not available for a draft nomination and that he wanted only to serve out his present term.

WHITEVILLE, N. C., June 19 (AP) --Thomas L. Hamilton, Imperial i Wizard of the Ku Klux Klan, andI twenty-three alleged Klansmen! were indicted today on charges in-i v01ving terrorism that swept this1 area last year.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- President Truman pleaded again today that nearly 1,000,000 service men and women would be unable to vote this year unless Congress acted before adjournment.

Sunglasses bought haphazardly with an eye to cheapness rather than visual requirements are likely to prove one of the most costly purchases a motorist can make, according to the New York State Optometric Association, 55 West Forty-second Street. Improper sunglasses were described as high accident sources yesterday by Dr. William Roth, chairman of the public information committee.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- President Truman declared today that the use of a Taft-Hartley Act injunction in the steel strike was under consideration but that the ultimate decision would not be forced by Congress.

Carl Erskine of the Dodgers pitched a no-hit, no-run game against the Cubs yesterday. Only a walk to Willard Ramsdell, the Bruins' second hurler, in the third inning, marred an otherwise perfect performance as the Brooks won, 5 to 0, at Ebbets Field.

MOSCOW, Friday, June 20 -- The Soviet Government, in a note delivered to the Swedish Ambassador to Moscow last night, rejected Swedish protests regarding the shooting down of a Swedish plane over the Baltic this week and demanded that Sweden take action to prevent future violations of Soviet frontiers by Swedish aircraft.

LONDON, June 19 -- Interest in the stock markets today was centered mainly on British funds and foreign bonds. Selling of British funds was on smaller scale, though wider in scope, and losses at the close were confined to a maximum of 10 shillings ($1.40).

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The Chinese Nationalist garrison on Formosa was authoritatively described today as not competent to defend the island itself against Communist assault, much less take offensive action against the China mainland.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission today authorized Tennessee Gas Transmission Company, Houston, Tex., to increase its capacity 205,000,000 cubic feet daily, to a total of 1,515,000,000.

Twice in the past three months President Truman has urged Congressional action to make it possible for about two and a half million men and women in the armed forces to vote in the coming elections. The "soldier vote," of course, includes personnel in all the services.

TOKYO, Friday, June 20 -- Peiping turned its propaganda guns today on the visit to Japan and Korea of British Defense Minister Earl Alexander and Minister of State Selwyn Lloyd. It warned that inclusion of a Commonwealth representative in the United Nations delegation seeking a Korean armistice would make "no tangible improvement" in the deadlocked negotiations.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (UP) -- The House voted 105 to 25 today to reject Administration drive to repeal import restrictions on cheese, other dairy products, rice and fats and oils.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 19 -- E. J. (Dutch) Harrison, who registers from Ardmore, Okla., blazed the way for the qualifiers in the thirty-fourth Professional Golfers Association championship today with a thirty-six-hole score of 136.

At a special meeting yesterday, the Board of Education appointed ten men and five women as elementary school principals, effective next September. The posts have a starting annual salary of $6,500 and reach a maximum of $9,100 after eight years.

An ancilliary to the atomic age has produced a new fluorocarbon, the properties of which are such that they may abolish dishwashing, permit airplanes to function comfortably in the stratosphere and provide a permanent lubricant for automobiles. Manufacture of the product will begin soon.

Shortly after 4 o'clock yesterday, Pee Wee Reese scooped up a grounder from Eddie Miksis, arched the ball to Gil Hodges, and this simple play set off a celebration at Ebbets Field that usually is reserved for the winning of a world series game.

The air of tension that has held the rest of Europe in its grip ever since Soviet Russia precipitated the "cold war" has now spread to Scandinavia, following the shooting down by Soviet jet fighters of a Swedish sea rescue plane searching the Baltic for survivors of another Swedish plane, assumed to have met the same fate.
CLEVELAND, June 19 -- Creation of a $12,000,000 strike fund was authorized by delegates to the sixth annual convention of the Communication Workers of America, C. I. O., today.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The State Department, effective immediately, is eliminating the weekly political round-up from its wireless bulletin distributed to United States envoys overseas.

The basic real estate tax rate for the fiscal year beginning July 1 probably will be $3.22 for each $100 of assessed valuation, according to calculations made yesterday by City Hall fiscal experts. In no event, according to these sources, will the rate be less than $3.21.

The human species no longer has the privilege of deciding whether it will or will not live in one world, scientists agreed here yesterday at the Wenner-Gren Foundation International Symposium on Anthropology.

LAKE GEORGE, N. Y., June 19 (AP) -- Workmen's compensation costs in New York State are the highest in the nation and are driving some business concerns out of the state, a spokesman for industry asserted today.

Trans World Airlines announced yesterday it would resume operations at Newark Airport on July 1. It was the second major airline to reveal its plans to return to the airport, which was closed to commercial operations on Feb. 11 after three crashes in near-by Elizabeth, N. J. United Air Lines will resume operations Wednesday.

Except in the vegetable department, fresh foods have shown no significant price changes since last Friday. All meats are being offered at the same prices as a week ago, although the city Department of Markets reports the demand has fallen off sharply, especially for roasts and stews.

SOMEWHERE on the high plateau of northeastern Tibet at 12,000 feet above sea level lies the isolated community of Taktsang Lhamo, "Goddess of the Tiger's Den." It consists of the twin and rival lamasaries of Gurdu and Sechu and several tiny near-by hamlets. In the surrounding mountains and on the vast steppes live some of the most primitive of Tibetan tribes, amateur robbers all, some of them professionals.
Most of the D. A. Schulte chain's 160 cigar stores in ninety-five cities were closed yesterday by what management called a strike and what the union termed a lockout.

The rat problem in Harlem, where two-thirds of the city's rat attacks on infants occur, was discussed yesterday by two dozen civic leaders, social workers and representatives of city departments at a meeting of the People's Civic and Welfare Association at the Harlem Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The contest in Texas between the supporters of Senator Taft and General Eisenhower over the make-up of the state delegation to the Republican National Convention arose when a majority of the delegates to the state convention, elected in precinct and county conventions in thirty-one counties and instructed for Eisenhower, were disqualified by the State Executive Committee and the Credentials Committee of the convention, both controlled by backers of Mr. Taft.

A spectacular fire threatened the industrial Brooklyn waterfront for two hours yesterday afternoon. A brief, heavy rain squall helped firemen to keep the flames from spreading far in the congested area of docks, barges, warehouses and factories.

CLAREMONT, Calif., June 19 -- A proposal to suspend negotiations for a merger of the nation's Congregational Churches with the Evangelical and Reformed Church was rejected by a narrow margin today in its first submission to the eleventh biennial Congregational General Council meeting.

Braintree, Mass., sold $1,435,000 of school and sewer bonds due from 1953 to 1972 to J. P. Morgan Co., Inc., and associates yesterday at a bid of 100.21 for interest of 1.9 per cent. The reoffering was made at yields ranging from 1.1 per cent to 2 per cent.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Another Senate economy drive collapsed this evening when that body, after fighting off all attempts to cut to the bone the coming fiscal year's appropriations for flood control and rivers and harbors improvements, passed a $666,700,000 funds bill.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 19 -- Contractual relations between Hollywood stars and movie studios are due for a going over by Treasury and Justice Department investigators, it was announced today by Bernard B. Laven, Assistant United States Attorney in charge of income tax evasion prosecution for the Southern District of California.

LONDON, June 19 (AP) -- Irvin Dorfman, a black-haired, hard-hitting New Yorker, and the top three men of the Australian Davis Cup squad advanced to the semifinals of the London grass courts tennis championships at the Queen's Club today.

Seven alleged hotel bandits, including the three who invaded the Emerson Hotel last week, were arraigned yesterday before Magistrate Louis A. Pagnucco in Felony Court on charges ranging from assault and violation of the Sullivan Law to robbery.

ASCOT, England, June 19 -- An Indian princess, the Maharanee Seeta Dewi Gaekwar of Baroda, today won the Ascot Gold Cup and the rich racing stake of more than 10,000 ($28,000) added money before Queen Elizabeth and her royal party that included the Duke of Edinburgh and Princess Margaret.

Four children under 10 years old and three adults have lost their lives in a Brooklyn tenement house fire. The four-story frame building with brick veneer had apparently been known to the city administration as a firetrap since 1948. Ownership changed, but nobody did anything toward providing a fire escape or other safeguards.
Welcome to potatoes; they are back.

The stock market made it three gains in a row yesterday but progress still remained small. Strength spread over a wide variety of issues with the leadership supplied by several of the key units in the list, mainly the railroads, motors and steels.

PARIS, June 19 (UP) -- Italy's troops in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization were praised today by the Supreme Commander, Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, as "among the best" of the many fine soldiers he had seen.

REGINA, June 19 (Canadian Press) -- The uraninum mine and mill of the federal government's Eldorado Mining and Refining Company in far-northwestern Saskatchewan are expected to be in operation next year.

Those Shubert Alley savants were correct last month in predicting the arrival of "The Deep Blue Sea," starring Margaret Sullavan, at the Morosco. That's where the Alfred de Liagre Jr-John C. Wilson reproduction of Terence Rattigan's London success will open on Nov. 5, with Alan Webb in the supporting cast, according to Mr. de Liagre.
PITTSBURGH, June 19 (UP) -- A surgeon admitted today that a brain operation had failed to cure a thief of his urge to steal.

Of 363 concerns responding to a questionnaire from the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., the majority indicate a distinct downward trend in their business volume for the first six months of the year, compared with that of the same period of 1951.

A rare family portrait entitled "The Music Party," by Pieter De Hooch, that came to this country in recent weeks from a famous collection in Bath, England, has just been acquired by the Cleveland Art Museum.

Cash requirements of business for quarterly income tax payments swelled loans in the New York area during the past week by $152,000,000. It was the largest increase shown by member banks in New York City since mid-September, 1940, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
Business and industrial organizations of the New York area will assume sponsorship of six of this summer's concerts at Lewisohn Stadium, it was announced yesterday by Stadium Concerts.

Directors of American Car and Foundry Company voted four cash dividends of 75 cents each on the common stock yesterday, a ten per cent stock dividend on the common and also reported a net profit of $7,202,164 for the year ended April 30, last.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Congress completed action today on a compromise bill to give the Marine Corps part-time representation on the Joint Chiefs of Staff and to maintain its strength at a minimum of three divisions and three air wings.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- More than 700 small companies in New York State will have open production capacity available for defense orders during the third quarter of this year, the National Production Authority announced today. On a national scale, according to a report compiled by the mall business division of the Defense agency, some 3,500 small producers will be available for handling defense contracts after July 1.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 19 -- The number of the mentally ill, who now comprise 52 per cent of all hospitalized patients, would be reduced if more psychiatric training were given to nurses, according to a statement made today at a forum during the biennial nursing convention here.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- Higher prices and smaller supplies of pork for next fall and winter were indicated today in a report of the Department of Agriculture.

Most of the news about bridges lately has been about big spans, like the one linking Maryland's eastern and western shores of Chesapeake Bay and into which the other day was raised the last of one hundred and twenty-three sections.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that department store sales in the week ended June 14 were 9 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1951:

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia; June 19 -- The Austrian Foreign Minister, Dr. Karl Gruber, arrived tonight in Belgrade on a four-day mission to establish close cooperation between Austria and Yugoslavia, two countries having a common frontier and a common problem of resisting Soviet pressure.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (UP) -- Sal B. Hoffman, president of the Upholsterers Union, A. F. L., today chided the C. I. O. for its past toleration of Communists, but conceded that it had mended its ways.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 19 -- The struggle between the state and the Roman Catholic clergy has developed to a point of unusual violence in recent weeks. On the basis of the tenor and quantity of the daily attacks appearing in the Yugoslav press it would appear that the Yugoslav Government is determined to bring the issue of state-church relations to a climax.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- The House Public Works Committee approved today a compromise plan for a multimillion-dollar development of the Delaware River port at Philadelphia and Camden, N. J.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 19 -- Walt Disney has outlined a production program extending through 1955 that will involve the expenditure of more than $20,000,000, the producer announced today to company representatives attending a sales convention at the Disney Studio in near-by Burbank.

CHICAGO, June 18 -- Wheat futures were strong today, continuing the recovery that started yesterday, with buying based on the unfavorable weather conditions in the Northwest. No precipitation was reported in the Dakotas, and Montana had only a few light local showers.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Lester Luther, United States Attorney for Kansas, was removed from office today by President Truman, who acted at the request of Attorney General James P. McGranery.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Friday, June 20 -- Foreign Minister Osten Unden returned late yesterday from an interrupted vacation in Italy to take charge personally of Sweden's relations with the Soviet Union, strained by the Baltic plane incidents and the part attributed to Soviet diplomats here in the activities of the seven Swedish Communists now on trial as Soviet spies.

" My Little Margie," a situation comedy intended as a summer replacement for "I Love Lucy," is the sort of tired and trite film that should make television think several times before moving its base of operations to Hollywood. Surely, there must be some better use for celluloid.

LONDON, June 19 -- Gen. Sir Gerald Templer, who was sent to Malaya four months ago as high commissioner to suppress Communist terrorism, reported progress in London today. He predicted success, provided the British colony could get a satisfactory price for its natural rubber.

Decca Records, Inc., has acquired 134,375 shares of common stock of Universal Pictures Company, Inc., from General Cinema Finance Corporation, Ltd., according to Milton R. Rackmil, president of Decca. The stock changing hands was the holdings of General Cinema, which is controlled by J. Arthur Rank, British motion picture producer.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (UP) -- The House Judiciary Committee today rejected a Senate-approved bill providing the death penalty for peacetime espionage.
Active cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 9 to 18 points yesterday.

Mrs. Bessie Honig of 817 Willoughby Avenue, Brooklyn, the owner of a ramshackle dwelling in which seven persons perished in a fire on Wednesday morning, was booked on manslaughter charges in the Gates Avenue precinct in Brooklyn last night.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 19 -- For the fourth successive day, a United Nations committee listened in closed session today to charges that the Soviet Union had forced the peoples of surrounding smaller states into slave labor camps.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- President Truman said today that increasing defense precautions were in line with this country's efforts to prevent a third World War.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- President Truman said today that taxes should be increased rather than reduced, and that any President, whether Democrat or Republican, would put the country further in the hole by attempting such a reduction.

Mayor Impellitteri, who was honored by the citizens of Genoa while on a tour of Italy last fall, returned the goodwill gesture for New York's citizens yesterday by presenting to Genoa's mayor, Vittorio Pertusio, the city's Medal of Honor.

Fairfield Osborn, president of the New York Zoological Society, announced yesterday a $329,000 program of improvements at the Bronx Zoo. He spoke at the spring meeting of the society's board of trustees.

I would ask the courtesy of your columns to reply to the moving letter of May 30 signed by a group, some of whom have personally suffered the impact of Nazi brutality. They do not approve the proposed erection on Riverside Drive of a memorial to the six million Jews done to death by the Nazis.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The Treasury announced today that its recent offering of $3,500,000,000 of 2% per cent bonds of 1958 was oversubscribed more than three times, with subscriptions from all sources totaling about $11,695,000,000.

Thirty-six thousand New York hotel workers will now be covered by an employer-paid pension plan as the result of an agreement reached yesterday between the New York Hotel Trades Council and the Hotel Association of New York City.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., June 20 -- Roslyn (Cookie) Swift of Glen Oaks and Mrs. Joseph Mason of Ridgewood will meet tomorrow in the final of the forty-ninth annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship over the Upper Montclair Country Club course.

MANY anglers planning a summer vacation trip seem interested in the Maritime Provinces of Canada. Most of those who have written this department seem to have the illusion that all the good fishing waters, especially the salmon rivers, are closed to those unable to afford a large daily fee.

Wearing his victim's suit and tie, a murderer returned to the scene of his crime to commit another crime early yesterday, with the second attempt leading to his arrest, detectives of the Grand Avenue Precinct reported.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 20 -- The United States today introduced a resolution under which the Security Council would ask the International Committee of the Red Cross to investigate Communist charges that United Nations forces defending South Korea had used bacteriological warfare.

ROME, June 20 -- Alarmed by reports that deep internal dissensions in Colombia may bring about bloodshed and even civil war, Pope Pius XII addressed the Colombian people by radio today "in a grave moment of your history" urging them to "find the way of peace in prayer and in penitence intensifying your Christian life with devotion to the Celestial Mother and with faithfulness to your pastors."

A second fiddle fared better than a first trombone yesterday at auditions for a "job" with the Student Symphony Society, which starts its third season in September. Desperate for violinists to replace members who will enter college in the fall Frederique Petrides, conductor of the student group, told 14-year-old Robert Gutter: "The orchestra isn't big enough right now for trombones."

ZURICH, Switzerland, June 20 -- Tonight saw the premiere at the Zurich State Theatre -- and in the composer's presence -- of Paul Hindemith's new version of his opera, "Cardillac," originally composed twenty-five years ago to a libretto of Ferdinand Lion, after E. T. A. Hoffmann's tale of "Madame de Scuderi."

One of the more important travel developments which came out of the gasoline shortage during the Second World War was the car pool. That was an arrangement whereby owners of cars agreed to carry other car owners as riders in return for reciprocity on other days.

LONDON, June 20 -- Complaints about the optical effect of discoloration caused by fluorescent lighting on many substances from human skin to banknotes has led to an investigation of the problem by the National Physical Laboratory.
BONN, Germany, June 20 -- A restaurant owner in Hamburg, this country's biggest port, has introduced a novel practice.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, asserted today that the Federal authorities had taken nearly twenty years to collect about $25,000 in income taxes from Frank Costello and over a fifteen-year period had "marked off" $315,156 due from Philip F. Kastel.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The United States let it be known officially today that it would help European countries build their own war planes provided they put up part of the money themselves and could meet operational requirements.

Criticizing the Government for not having prosecuted promptly, Federal Judge Sylvester Ryan placed Oscar John Vago, 54-year-old, Hungarian-born structural engineer, on three years' probation yesterday for committing perjury in 1950 before a Federal grand jury investigating a Russian atom spy ring.

VIENNA, June 20 -- A Pan-European plan to concentrate Roman Catholic priests from all countries at the most important points of this Continent to counteract the decline in the over-all strength of the priesthood was described tonight by Archbishop Coadjuster Franz Jachym of Vienna at a meeting in preparation for Catholic Day, to be held in Vienna in September.

Etienne Fajon of the French Communist party's Central Committee has administered a brisk scolding to his brethren. The party and its influence have been declining, he says, because the Communists have been too "sectarian." They have not put enough emphasis on winning non-Communist allies in the fight for "peace" and for ending the "American occupation."
Attempts to resume direct negotiations between the striking United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., and steel producers were made here yesterday, but were broken off last night.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 20 -- Last night's Moscow note declining responsibility for the shooting down of a Swedish Air Force Catalina plane over the Baltic last Monday and insisting that the incident happened over Russian waters and that the plane had fired first, contrary to all available evidence here, today caused despair among the Swedes of obtaining any sort of redress from the Soviet Union.

COPENHAGEN, June 20 -- Capt. Henrik Kurt Carlsen, Danish-born master of the Flying Enterprise, was received by King Frederik today on board the royal yacht Dannebrog. The yacht was at the Danish island of Bornholm in the Baltic, where the King is deerstalking while Queen Ingrid and the three small princesses are visiting England.

ROCK ISLAND, Ill., June 20 (AP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee asserted tonight that America's military spending could be cut four or five billion dollars annually "without reducing fire power."
There has been much debate and speculation during the last few years as to whether the Marshall Plan and our whole general aid pattern to Western Europe were showing any tangible results.

In spite of comparison with high volume produced by the "price war" at this time last year, combined dollar sales volume of major New York department stores is estimated to be only 12 per cent below that for the corresponding week of 1951.

Overcoming innumerable obstacles, not the least of these being another signal failure on the part of Sal Maglie to finish a Starting assignment, the Giants rallied to top the Cubs in ten innings, 4 to 3, before 24,117 fans last night at the Polo Grounds.
A strike yesterday by 300 airport bus drivers caused some inconvenience to plane passengers and provided taxi drivers with an unexpected bounty of fares.

CINCINNATI, June 20 (AP) -- In Common Pleas Court today Judge Carson Hoy ordered striking A. F. L. machinists back to work turning out jet engines for fighter planes at the General Electric plant near here. His ruling upheld the company's contention that the strike, which started Wednesday, violated agreements contained in a work contract signed March 13, 1951.

Title has been taken by Bronxanne, Inc., to the six-story apartment house containing sixty-eight suites at 2504 Bronx Park East, the Bronx. The property was acquired from the 2504 Realty Corporation subject to mortgages of $207,000.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation asked the public today to help trace Robert L. Knetzer, accused of using the postwar shortage of automobiles as the basis for a million-dollar illegal business.
WILMINGTON, Calif., June 20 (UP) -- The police said today a dying youth had told them he was lashed to the bumper of a driverless car which was pushed down a hill into a six-foot-high embankment.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 (AP) -- Robin Roberts held the Reds in check tonight as the Phillies triumphed, 3 to 1. Roberts, who fanned five, including three in the fifth inning, and allowed only three hits, weakened once when he tossed a home-run ball to Hank Edwards in the seventh.

BERLIN, June 20 -- Lothar Bolz, Deputy Premier of East Germany, told members of the National Democratic party yesterday that the Soviet Union was Germany's powerful ally in the struggle against the United States.

GLEN COVE, L. I., June 20 -- Frank Strafaci of the Garden City Country Club, the defending champion, and John J. Humm, winner of the title in 1948, today earned the right to meet in tomorrow's 36-hole final of the Long Island Golf Association amateur championship at the Nassau Country Club.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- Pessimistic crop reports covering spring wheat in the American Northwest balanced the glowing reports on winter wheat and made for a rather strong undertone, although it was still a hard job to hold the rallies.
Columbus, Ohio, City School District announced yesterday that it would receive bids July 15 on $4,000,000 of bonds dated July 15, 1952 and due July 15, 1954 to 1974.

A grand jury investigation into the responsibility of the Department of Housing and Buildings in the Brooklyn tenement fire last Wednesday in which seven persons died was ordered yesterday by District Attorney Miles F. McDonald.
In a new effort to pacify turbulent Tunisia, Foreign Minister Schuman has outlined before the French National Assembly a five-point program for home-rule reforms in the protectorate.

Red Cross bloodmobiles yesterday collected whole blood from airline personnel at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, from the Nyack Chapter at Nyack, N. Y., and a Consolidated Edison shop at 20 West Sixty-sixth Street. On Thursday donors contributed 671 pints to five bloodmobiles and the borough centers.

TAIPEI, Formosa, June 20 -- Arthur Hays Sulzberger, publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, conferred with President Chiang Kai-shek for twenty minutes this morning. Mr. Sulzberger received a detailed briefing from Maj. Gen. William C. Chase, chief of the United States military assistance advisory group, after which he called on top-rank- ing Chinese officials.

MIDDLETOWN, Ohio, June 20 (UP) -- Officials of the independent union at the Middletown plant of Armco Steel Corporation said today a new wage agreement signed with the company called for an average 25-cent-an-hour increase.

PARIS, June 20 -- The National Assembly rejected tonight a de Gaullist motion to declare Robert Schuman, the Foreign Minister, incompetent to solve the Tunisian question. But it did so by only a nominal majority, and in circumstances that caused increased doubts that the requisite Parliamentary backing would be forthcoming for the general foreign policy personified by M. Schuman, including the peace agreement with the Bonn Republic and the European Defense Community Treaty.

FORT ORD, Calif., June 20 -- Sgt. C. Dean Chase, who criticized Gen. Mark W. Clark for repudiating concessions granted Koje Island Communist prisoners of war while they held Brig. Gen. (Colonel) Francis T. Dodd a hostage, received a light court-martial sentence today.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 20 -- Sir Ernest Oppenheimer who, as head of the giant De Beers combine virtually controls the world sale of diamonds through the single channel Diamond Corporation announced today an agreement between the Diamond Corporation and Dr. John Thorburn Williamson, Canadian born Tanganyika diamond magnate, who broke with the Diamond Corporation last September and later held a private showing of $18,000,000 worth of diamonds in London.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 20 -- The United Nations today reported the "summary dismissal" of Eugene Wallach, a United States member of the secretariat who had appeared three times before the Federal Grand Jury in New York investigating subversive activities and espionage.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.4 per cent over the week ended on June 17 to 111.2 per cent of the 1947-49 average, according to the United States Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics.

A plot of 13,000 square feet on Beechwood Avenue at the Columbus Avenue railroad station in Mount Vernon, N. Y., has been purchased by Harrington, Wilson Brown, machine tool distributors, from the estate of Martin Jenter.

DETROIT, June 20 (AP) -- Rookie Right-hander Harry Byrd of the Athletics scattered eight Tiger hits tonight to record a 3-1 victory before 13,944 chilled fans -- smallest night crowd here since lights were installed in 1948. It was Byrd's third triumph against six defeats.

Several years of study of the law while serving a twenty-years-to-life sentence in state prison returned a "bonus" yesterday to Daniel Francis Ahearn, 51-year-old veteran thief who once wrote a book entitled "How to Commit Murder and Get Away With It."
WASHINGTON, June 20 (UP) -- The Kremlin is steadily strangling distribution of the State Department's Russian-language magazine Amerika in the Soviet Union.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 20 -- Turning in its best exhibition of the season, Yale's varsity crew defeated Harvard today as the 100th anniversary of the famous regatta was celebrated on the Thames. The margin at the finish was a scant length, no open water showing as the two shells skimmed across the finish.

LONDON, June 20 -- A party of twelve geologists led by Prof. William Quarrier Kennedy of the University of Leeds is flying to Africa on Monday where it plans to explore the Ruwenzori range of West Uganda, the so-called Mountains of the Moon.
Civil defense workers who have been engaged in mandatory training projects for the last six months will mark the halfway point in their program next week with special drills in all five boroughs.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- A majority of the National Security Training Commission, a five-member group established by Congress to plan details for compulsory military training, challenged Congress today either to dissolve the commission or give it enough funds to carry on properly.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The tenth annual achievement award of the American Association of University Women was presented tonight to Dr. Lily Ross Taylor, retiring dean of the Bryn Mawr College Graduate School.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 20 -- Forty educators, research workers and home extension service aides from fifteen states will wind up their three-day conference tomorrow on how to help families to make use of available resources.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- President Truman nominated today Angus Ward, a career diplomat, to be Ambassador to Afghanistan and Phelps Phelps of New York to be Ambassador to the Dominican Republic.
PUSAN, Korea, June 20 (AP) -- About fifty young Koreans today broke up a meeting of educators and civic leaders, called to protest "dictatorial measures" of President Syngman Rhee.

LONDON, June 20 -- A quiet session ended on the stock markets here today with the week-long decline in British Government securities still in progress although at a slower pace. Renewal of small selling on an unwilling market carried the gilt edge issues as much as 5 shillings (70 cents) lower.

BOSTON, June 20 (AP) -- The Braves, thanks to a furious ten-run rally in the sixth inning, tonight gained a 12-7 victory over the Cardinals. The visitors rebounded from that nightmare to score all of their runs in the seventh, during which Solly Hemus connected for a grandslam homer. Lefty Warren Spahn, called in to check St. Louis, homered in the eighth for the final Boston marker:
LOUISVILLE, June 20 -- After two eighteen-hole match play rounds in the Professional Golfers Association championship today, top-ranking money winners were conspicuous by their absence.

George Shuba yesterday foiled a Pirate bid to scuttle the Dodgers for the first time this season. A two-run homer by the reserve outfielder, up as a pinch-hitter with two out in the ninth inning, salvaged Brooklyn's foundering ship. This clout transformed an impending 4-3 defeat into a 5-4 victory.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (UP) -- Farmers are making more money but their expenses also are rising, the Agriculture Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The State Department said this evening that it had issued an order barring Prof. Owen Lattimore from leaving the United States. It said it acted on the basis of an "allegation" that he was planning to visit the Soviet Union or its satellite countries.

DENVER, June 20 -- Between 3,000,000 and 4,000,000 young Americans will vote the Republican ticket if General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower is nominated for President but will not if Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio is the nominee, Paul G. Hoffman, chairman of the advisory committee of the Citizens for Eisenhower organization, said today.
BALTIMORE, June 20 (AP) -- Professor Lattimore said tonight that charges that he had planned such a trip were "nonsense." He said he had no idea "whatsoever" as to why the allegation was made.

MOSCOW, June 20 -- United States Ambassador George F. Kennan is concerned over the current anti-United States campaign in the Soviet Union based on charges of American mistreatment of prisoners of war in Korea, diplomatic circles indicated today.

CLEVELAND, June 20 (AP) -- With fourteen hits, including homers by Bob Lemon, Jim Fridley and Larry Doby, the Indians checked their six-game losing streak tonight by beating the Red Sox, 9 -- 2. Lemon held the Red Sox to five hits and blanked them on one single for the first six frames.

ERIE, Pa., June 20 -- Samuel R. Rosenbaum, trustee of the Music Performance Trust Fund, called today for amendments to the Federal copyright law that would create and protect a performer's right as well as rights of the composer and publisher.

CAMDEN, N. J., June 20 -- Mrs. Sylvia Neff, 42-year-old secretary of Local 80, United Packinghouse Workers, C. I. O., was sentenced today to ten years in Federal prison on three counts of perjury in her testimony before a Federal grand jury concerning her alleged Communist affiliations.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- Reduced shipments to all continents except North America caused a fall in United States exports from $1,417,700,000 in March to $1,332,000,000 in April, the Bureau of the Census said today. Imports declined from $963,300,000 to $931,800,000.
TOKYO, Saturday, June 21 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,287, to 6 A. M., Saturday, Korea time:

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today approved a plan for the recapitalization of the Central Public Utility Corporation, St. Louis holding company, and for the merger into control of its holding company subsidiary, the Consolidated Electric and Gas Company of New York.

ROME, June 20 -- The Italian Government expelled today Miss Olga Tchetchetkina, correspondent of Pravda, whose dispatches from Italy were considered so polemically biased and factually inaccurate that they were felt to exceed permissible limits even in a democracy.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., June 20 -- The weather forecast was a major point of interest today for twenty-seven crews, their coaches and followers waiting for tomorrow's Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta on Onondaga Lake.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (UP) -- The Senate by unanimous voice vote passed and sent to the White House today a bill approving a compact between New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania for "mutual military aid" in an emergency.

The proper use of words, which are powerful weapons, can help us Americans overcome the difficulty we have in making ourselves understood in the rest of the world, Lieut. Gov. Frank C. Moore declared last night.

Three company presidents agreed yesterday that the time had come for business executives to speak up and disclose, to the public in general and their own employes in particular, their views on current political and social issues.

Dan Shapiro and Milton Pascal, who supplied some of the tunes for "Follow the Girls," the Broadway musical hit of 1944, have signed contracts to write the lyrics for "Saddle and Go," the musical comedy with a Wyoming locale, due on Broadway in the fall. They will arrive from Hollywood on Monday to confer with Harry Revel, who is doing the music.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- An invention patented this week by Nathaniel B. Wales Jr. of New York makes it possible to air-condition a bed both summer and winter.

NEWPORT, R. I., June 20 -- With time allowances figured for the yachts to start from off here tomorrow in the race to Bermuda, it was ascertained today that John Hertz Jr.'s seventy-three-foot ketch Ticonderoga would be on scratch and allow more than a day's time to the two smallest boats over the 635 miles.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 20 -- George B. Begole's Silver Riddle from Oakfield, N. Y., and the Hayes Fair Acres Stable's Pronto Don from Du Quoin, Ill., won the two qualifying heats of the $20,000 David H. McConnell Memorial trot at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

Although sales of Armour Co. and its domestic subsidiaries were reasonably well maintained in the twenty-six weeks ended with April, net income after taxes and all charges decined to $3,144,446 from $10,415,658 earned in the corresponding period of the previous year.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, June 21 (AP) -- United Nations troops threw back today a heavy Chinese Communist assault west of Chorwon on the western front, killing or wounding more than 600 Reds in close-quarter fighting.

The New York State Athletic Commission held yesterday that Ray Robinson must give up his middleweight title if he defeats Joey Maxim for the latter's light-heavyweight championship of the world at the Yankee Stadium on Monday night.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 20 -- At exactly three minutes to noon today, the eleven delegates to the United Nations Security Council were listening to an interpreter drone out a French translation of a Brazilian's speech about germ warfare.

CAPE MAY, N. J., June 20 -- More than 2,000 members of the Religious Society of Friends from all parts of the United States met here today for the opening of the Biennial Friends General Conference. Sessions began tonight and will continue through next Friday.

As the $51,965 collected up to 3 P. M. yesterday brought to $7,982,005 the sale to date of the $5 and $10 automobile use tax stamps, City Treasurer Spencer C. Young reminded motorists that today -- from 9 A. M. to noon -- would be the final opportunity for them to make unrestricted over-the-counter purchases of the stickers.

Twenty-four men and women, including five alternates, were named to the 1952 United States Olympic fencing team last night at the Hotel Roosevelt. Following the week-long competition in the national championships, the selection committee picked three women and, in the foil, saber and epee events, six men each, besides alternates.

"Morality in American Politics," by George A. Graham, Professor of Politics at Princeton University, is planned for Aug. 25 publication by Random House. It is an analysis of corruption and integrity in government and of right and wrong in politics.

The "March of Time" will make its reappearance on television beginning the first week in October with its original format -- a half-hour documentary film presentation covering the events of the week all over the world. Westbrook Van Voorhis again will be the narrator.

PARIS, June 20 -- In announcing today an agreement that the United States would finance production of military aircraft in Europe on the basis of recommendations by the staff of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization here, Ambassador Fred L. Anderson, acting United States special representative in Europe, said this same procedure would be extended to other defense contracts in Europe financed by the United States.

THE planet-touring space ships of the future may not be exactly Tennysonian argosies with purple sails. Instead of anything so graceful, they'll probably look more like big rockets with threshing machines impaled on their noses. But there will be a connection between them and the bark that carried Jason's crew in search of the Golden Fleece.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of interest to the homemaker.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 20 -- Agreement was reached today on a revised plan looking toward the establishment of an international development fund to give financal help to the world's needy nations.

Secretary of State Acheson will fly to England next week to receive an honorary degree from the University of Oxford. Originally this was to have been simply an academic occasion, an exchange of compliments in the pleasant atmosphere of Oxford, with some casual political talk on the side with British statesmen.

Vince Martinez of Paterson, N. J., boxed his way to victory over Sammy Giuliani of Stamford in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night. The battle was fiercely waged, but Martinez enjoyed a clear edge and the decision was unanimous.

Robert Moses, City Construction Coordinator and chairman of the State Council of Parks, was described yesterday as not only favoring the legalizing of off-track betting on horse races but of the belief that lotteries will have to be sanctioned for the support of public and private hospitals and bingo for churches.

LONDON, June 20 -- The Steering Committee of German Debt Conference gave its approval today to a preliminary settlement of the "standstill" debts negotiated directly between the West German delegation and the creditors.
The board of managers of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals will not seek a court test of the controversial Metcalf-Hatch Law, it became known yesterday.

There was no explosion yesterday when President Truman signed the Mutual Security Act of 1952, under which nearly $1.5 billions is subtracted from the $7.9 billion authorization which he requested last March for foreign aid. Sometimes Mr. Truman operates on a long fuse.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 (AP) -- Harold E. Stassen said today the views of both Senator Robert A. Taft and General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower were too conservative and that only such a "liberal program" as he supported would win for the Republicans in November.
BERLIN, June 20 -- A 26-year- old American girl landed in a sailboat across Berlin's "little iron curtain" last night and was held overnight by the Soviet and East German authorities.

Arrangements for obtaining license agreements from two American manufacturers of turbo-jet engines have been made by the Fiat Company of Italy. This was announced yesterday by Vittorio Valletta, president of the major European industrial organization.

NORTH ARLINGTON, N. J., June 20 -- Four young boys who robbed a dozen industrial plants and shops in this area in the last two months were in custody today after a subterranean hideaway constructed by them was discovered, complete with loot, in the Hackensack Meadows.

Controller Lazarus Joseph submitted yesterday to the City Council a financial report making it mandatory upon that body to fix a basic real estate tax of $3.22 for each $100 of assessed valuation for the fiscal year beginning July 1.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- George Washington, trying to get the struggling Republic on its feet, was one to practice economy. When he called a special session of the Senate in 1791, his third year in office, he was still using paper bearing the watermark of George III, the tyrannous monarch from whom he had wrested freedom.

One of the city's biggest summer businesses -- "exporting" children -- will hit its peak next week. Some 40,000 youngsters will scramble aboard trains and buses and other thousands will quit the hot streets for summer camps in special cars and automobiles of parents, social agencies and private camps.

ST. LOUIS, Saturday, June 21 (AP) -- Satchel Paige pitched ten scoreless innings in relief for the Browns tonight as St. Louis and the Senators battled eighteen innings to a 5-5 tie in the longest game this year in the major leagues.

SPOKANE, Wash., June 20 -- Congress was criticized by public and private utility spokesmen today for failure to appropriate sufficient funds to keep up with the need, in terms of Federal power projects, in "the tightest power shortage area in the nation," the Pacific Northwest.
A two-day stoppage that had closed cigar stores of the D. A. Schulte chain in ninety-five cities will end today and the stores will reopen.

The one that collected first money of $6,535 in the $10,000 added Fairy Chant Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday was a 5-year-old mare that hadn't won in ten previous tries this year. Joe W. Brown's Thelma Berger, with Keith Douglas Stuart in the saddle, did the job and accounted for the flashing of a $7.60 mutuel.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, said tonight that a Republican President's first task would be to cut Government spending and taxation "to a point where a free economy can begin to operate again."

Junior Building, Inc., has sold for cash to the 226 Realty Corporation, Leonard S. Kandell, secretary, the six-story commercial building at 8 to 14 East Forty-seventh Street which is occupied under lease by the real estate firm of Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc.

The passing of John L. Foley, for more than a quarter of a century one of the outstanding teachers of English at the George Washington High School in New York City, reminds us again that one of the great sources of strength of America is in her schools.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The House of Representatives voted today to require the removal of price controls from a wide range of necessities, including food, and to replace the Wage Stabilization Board with a new one lacking the authority to intervene in labor disputes.

Chance and a delayed attack of the fidgets cut into a bank robber's return yesterday. The same considerations saved several thousand dollars for the Public National Bank and Trust Company of New York branch at 550 Seventh Avenue, on the northwest corner of Thirty-ninth Street.
Five hundred years of effort by scholars of the humanities have failed to reveal a real set of values for the conduct of life, a meeting of the world's leading anthropologists charged here yesterday.

Promulgation of a new code by the Federal Trade Commission covering radio and television should help the industry to avoid misleading practices, even inadvertent ones, according to Glen McDaniel, president of the Radio-Television Manufacturers.

The stock market marked time yesterday, but gains outnumbered losses. In less spirited trading, possibly because of the shutdown over the week-end, the list ran a ragged course and fell under moderate profit-taking near the close.

SPRING LAKE, N. J., June 20 -- Creation of employe welfare funds by industry is a demonstration of "enlightened self interest" which advances the whole economy, the president of J. P. Morgan Co., Inc., declared today.

Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan at 4 P. M. yesterday ordered the suspension of twenty policemen, formerly detailed to the plainclothes division, who in the morning had been picked out of a line-up of twenty-four by bookmaker Harry Gross in a dramatic confrontation in the Criminal Courts Building.

BALTIMORE, June 20 (AP) -- The Pennsylvania Water and Power Company, which makes electricity along the Susquehanna River, started $19,280,000 in damage suits today against one of its main wholesale customers, the Consolidated Gas and Electric Company of Baltimore.

A $500 fine and a six-month suspended sentence were imposed yesterday in Special Sessions on Thomas Eboli, known in boxing circles as Tommy Ryan, on his guilty plea to a third degree assault in an attack on Al Weill, matchmaker of the International Boxing Club, in Madison Square Garden Jan. 11.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 20 -- Thirteen Asian and Arab countries submitted today a formal request that the sixty-member General Assembly of the United Nations be called into special session to take up the dispute between France and the Tunisian Nationalists.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- The Air Force announced today the reassignment of six generals. It said that the changes were routine.

AS a daily reader of your reputable newspaper for over thirty years I have read with some amazement and no little concern two letters from Robert J. Alexander which have appeared in your columns relative to Venezuela. I have specific reference to his letter published May 17.

It must have been only a little while ago, and during the rains. At that time, when it was dismal and raw as well as wet, the sun came out very infrequently. It must have been then that the inner voice spoke up and in wistful words begged for the brilliant sun.

LONG BEACH, Calif., June 20 (AP) -- Parry O'Brien of Southern California broke the National Amateur Athletic Union shot-put record tonight on his second throw of the championships with a mark of 57 feet 4 3/8 inches.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- Senator Guy Corden, Republican of Oregon, said today a Senate Appropriations subcommittee has approved appropriations totaling $73,123,400 for construction and operation of Bonneville Power Administration facilities in the Pacific Northwest.

The alternate-side-of-the-street parking plan, now in effect in two Manhattan areas, is not only easing street cleaning operations for the Sanitation Department but is proving to be a windfall for the city's treasury.

A sharp rise in rubber futures on active trading featured the local commodity exchanges yesterday. Hide contracts also sold at higher levels, but coffee, sugar and cottonseed oil futures were lower. Wool and wool tops were mixed as were cocoa, lead and soybean oil.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The Army announced without explanation today that the number of Communist prisoners in Allied hands in Korea had declined by 554 in the last month.
