TRENTON, June 20 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll accused Senator Robert A. Taft today of being as much a "New Deal" Republican as any of the Republican Presidential candidates the Senator had criticized.

CHICAGO, Saturday, June 21 -- In the fourth hour and sixth minute of an eleven-inning thriller before 39,444 fans at Comiskey Park early this morning, Sam Mele slammed a three-run homer that gave the White Sox an 8-5 victory over the Yankees.
TOKYO, June 20 (UP) -- The chief of the Soviet Union's military- political mission in Japan, Maj. Gen. Andrei P. Kislenko, has been recalled to Moscow.

In Edmonton, on his way home from Korea, Field Marshal Earl Alexander reiterated that he was greatly, impressed by the fine teamwork of the U. N. forces. In several press conferences following his visit to the Korean battlefields the British Defense Minister has declared that criticism either of military operations or the conduct of the truce talks is entirely unjustified.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- A movement to nominate Mrs. India Edwards as Democratic Vice Presidential candidate was begun here today with the formation of the Democratic Women for India Edwards for Vice President.

An airy accent might be given the summer home, indoors or out, by objects made of straw, bamboo or other fibers. Not only useful but handsome, many of the items being offered have simple lines, relyng on their textural appearance for design interest.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, June 20 -- Dr. Maurice L. Perlzweig of the World Jewish Congress, who arrived yesterday to investigate reports of an anti-Semitic terrorist campaign here, said today that he had been agreeably impressed by the Government's attitude in the matter.

FONTANA, N. C., June 20 -- Local community leaders will have the primary responsibility for promoting aims of the Save the Children Federation in rural areas, it was decided during a two-week conference of the federation that ended here today.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 20 -- A selective service for nurses in the event of a national emergency was approved by the House of Delegates of the American Nurses Association at its closing convention session here today.

TOKYO, Saturday, June 21 -- The Government-controlled Peiping radio charged today that Allied planes had dropped projectiles filled with germ-laden insects over the camps in North Korea where United Nations prisoners are held, infecting one American soldier, who is now under medical care in a prison hospital.

I read the letter written by Ernest T. Nash, "For a Free China," which appeared in your issue of Sunday, June 8. I note the editorial department's preface to the letter, which states that Mr. Nash served in the Shanghai Municipal Council for many years, which undoubtedly qualifies Mr. Nash as an expert on Chinese affairs.

CLAREMONT, Calif., June 20 -- The United States is now experiencing "the most critical shortage of churches in its history," the Eleventh Biennial General Council Meeting of the Congregational and Christian Churches was told today. About 3,000 delegates were at the third days of sessions in a four-day convention at Pomona College.
GENEVA, June 20 (UP) -- The United States Secretary of Labor, Maurice J. Tobin, said today that the free world had proved it could produce both guns and butter.

GENEVA, N. Y., June 20 -- Three hundred Young Democrats attending the Sixth Annual Political Institute under the auspices of the Democratic State Committee's Youth Division got a preview today of their party's tactics and strategy for the fall election campaign.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- President Truman signed the $6,447,730,750 Mutual Security authorization bill without comment today. He had indicated that he would mark the occasion with some sharp remarks about those responsible for cutting the measure by 18.6 per cent under his request.

The appeal of M. Fajon for less militancy and greater efforts to woo the non-proletariant was caused in the first instance by recent French Communist party defeats. From a longer range point of view, however, it falls into a "united front from below" policy that has been increasingly evident in the world Communist movement this last year.

Aaron Horvitz, arbitration specialist and lawyer, has been selected to decide wage disputes between East and Gulf Coast steamship operators and three maritime affiliates of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

The House of Representatives has delivered another slap in the face to the American consumer by refusing to abolish the famous "cheese" amendment to the Defense Production Act and also by encouraging a "go it alone" attitude in the world-wide competition for scarce and strategic raw materials.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The nomination of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for President at the Chicago National Republican Convention is now assured, Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., national campaign manager for General Eisenhower, said today.

A factory containing 15,000 square feet on a tract of two and one-half acres on Landing Avenue in Smithtown, L. I., has been purchased by Rosenberg Brothers, novelty manufacturers, from the Hafner Corporation. Inter-Boro Industrial Company was the broker.

LONDON, June 20 -- Following his victory over Victor Seixas, Mervyn Rose of Australia scored another major conquest today to reach the final of the London grass court tennis championships at the Queens Club. The young left-hander from Down Under defeated the champion of his country, Kenneth McGregor, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4.

BONN, Germany, June 20 -- By unanimous vote the Federal Bundesrat decided today it had the right to debate and vote upon complete texts of the Bonn peace contract with the Western Allies and the European Defense Community Treaty.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, June 16 -- Believers in a free economy can chalk up one for their side on the basis of Dutch economic developments of the last six months.

ROME, June 20 -- Documents in secret files of the Italian Foreign Ministry for the period immediately preceding World War II, which have just been published by the Italian Government, indicate that only the early outbreak of the war prevented Spain from becoming a full member of the Rome-Berlin Axis.

Paprika, the fourth most popular spice m this country, is apropos because it does so much to enhance the now-plentiful chicken. The American Spice Trade Association, which represents leading importers and distributors, reports that only pepper, mustard and cinnamon are used in larger quantities.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The Senate Finance Committee approved today increases of at least $5 a month or 12 1/2 per cent, whichever is greater, in payments to old-age insurance pensioners and survivors under the Social Security Program. The House of Representatives recently voted the same increases.
LOS ANGELES, June 20 (AP) -- Roberto Rossellini today was shut out of the custody battle over Pia Lindstrom, daughter of Ingrid Bergman and Dr. Peter Lindstrom.

Two four-story store and apartment buildings at 187 Sutter Avenue and 152 Amboy Street, Brooklyn, have been sold by Mrs. Mollie Kellman to the Estate Securities Company, operators. Advance Realty Company was the broker and the attorneys were Murray Neitlich for the seller and Jacobs, Leibowitz Kahn for the buying group.

The cotton futures market closed steady yesterday, 19 points higher than on Thursday on the July and 1 point higher to 4 points lower on other months, as trading on the New York Cotton Exchange continued fairly active.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 20 -- Averell Harriman, Director of the Mutual Security Agency and a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, charged today that anyone who said "you can reduce taxes and still have security is either ignorant or dishonest."

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The construction industry seemed destined for another setback today as the National Production Authority put aside promises made earlier that it would relax restrictions on the use of steel for home construction and commercial building.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The Government delivered today to the United States Lines the superliner United States for the contract price of $28,087,000. President Truman said that the liner cost the Government "almost $78,000,000."

SAN FRANCISCO, June 20 -- The strike of the Sailors Union of the Pacific, A. F. L., against members of the Pacific Maritime Association may force closing of the California and Hawaiian Company's sugar refinig plant at Crocker, near here. officials said today.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 20 -- One marked improvement in the Soviet standard of living during the last four years was noted here today by Schmuel Elyashiv, Israel Minister to Moscow, who is visiting here.

HOF, Germany, June 20 -- Field Marshal General Friedrich von Paulus, captured with his German Sixth Army at Stalingrad in 1943, is wearing a Russian uniform and teaching at the Moscow Military Academy, a former German war prisoner reported on his return from the Soviet Union today.

Liquor wholesalers, caught by freight rate increases, are asking suppliers who sell f. o. b. to share some of this additional cost of doing business. Morris O. Alprin, counsel for the Greater New York Wholesale Liquor Dealers Association, Inc., explained yesterday that because of their poor business it would be economically unwise to pass the increases along to retailers.

The Rev. Dr. Charles B. Foelsch, pastor of Holy Trinity Lutheran Church, Central Park West and Sixty-fifth Street, who resigned recently to accept a post as the first president of the new Pacific Lutheran Theological Seminary in Berkeley, Calif., will preach his farewell sermon at the 11 A. M. service tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Democratic sources said tonight that Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois had decided to make himself available for the Democratic Presidential nomination and would make his decision known soon.

DEERFIELD, Mass., June 20 -- Leo F. Morrissey, Town Clerk of this historic Massachusetts community, which was incorporated in 1673, appealed through the newspapers today for clues to the whereabouts of the town's records for the 258-year-period from 1673 to 1931.

An oral agreement between an American and a British toy producer, believed to be one of the first of its kind, has increased sales of both companies and reduced expenses. The pact permits members of Ideal Toy Corporation and Lines Brothers, Ltd. of London, to visit each other's plants and borrow blueprints of any item for production in the other country.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- Makers of round steel goods used in the oil industry here were told today they must increase their production by nearly 50 per cent in the next three years if the nation is to get the petroleum needed for its defense efforts.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 -- Clements Davies, Liberal party leader in the British House of Commons, said here tonight that lasting world peace could be achieved only through the creation of an international commonwealth composed of all nations.

More than 3,000,000 man-hours of open time will be available on critical machine tools for sub-contract defense work in New York State during the July-September quarter, it was reported yesterday by the New York State Department of Commerce.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., June 20 (AP) -- Executives of Speidel Newspapers, Inc., and of eight affiliated newspapers will obtain voting control of the corporation under a reorganization and recapitalization plan made public today by John Ben Snow, chairman of the board.

PARIS, June 20 -- Members of the Central Committee of the French Communist party have trampled figuratively at each other's heels to get in line to confess the past errors called to their attention by their fellow member, Etienne Fajon, and to declare their allegiance to the course of action be counseled.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, June 20 (AP) -- Dr. Jose Nunes de Oliveira, former Governor General of Mozambique, said today there was racial discrimination in two Portuguese African territories even though the Portuguese Constitution called for the equality of citizens before the law and especially scorned racial distinction.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., June 20 -- Mr. and Mrs. Winston H. Hagen gave a dance tonight at Fox Brae, their home here, to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Christine Helen Hagen, and Miss Wendy Whitaker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Stanley Whitaker of San Francisco.

For many of the city's handicapped school children yesterday was a big day. In three ceremonies sixty-eight youngsters who did not let physical or other handicaps stand in their way received high school diplomas or special awards for achievement.

TOKYO, Saturday, June 21 -- United Nations truce negotiators informed the Communists today that the Soviet Union had introduced the principle of "no forced repatriation" of war prisoners in World War II.

A new British-built Ford four-door sedan, designated the Zephyr, was announced yesterday by Ralph T. Horgan, president of Ralph Horgan Inc., 1842 Broadway, Ford dealers and distributors of English Ford units. The cars, now on display at the Horgan showrooms, will sell here for $1,925 exclusive of city sales tax.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- Representatives of two companies controlling large acreages in Western Canada's Peace River natural gas field testified today they are willing to negotiate with West-coast Transmission Company, Inc., for the sale of gas.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Responding to President Truman's appeal yesterday for prompt action to provide absentee voting rights to an estimated 1,000,000 members of the armed forces not having them now, the Senate passed such a measure by a voice vote today.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 20 (AP) -- The Kansas City Star Company today was served with a subpoena to produce all of its records of every category for the last 25 years before a Federal Grand Jury here next month.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- The Marine Corps announced today award of the Medal of Honor to eight marines who lost their lives on battlefields of Korea.
BOSTON, June 20 -- The 100-foot Gloucester fishing trowler Albatross and the 10,000-ton tanker Esso Chattanooga collided early today off Provincetown, Mass. The captain of the trawler was lost.

Gen. Anastasio Somoza, president of Nicaragua, received New York City's medal of honor and a scroll for distinguished public service in ceremonies yesterday at City Hall. The presentation was made by Mayor Impellitteri before a noon-time crowd in City Hall Park.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today refused to permit railroads in the Eastern part of the country to cancel free service in the pick-up and delivery of less-carload railroad freight.

Judge Leo F. Rayfiel in Brooklyn Federal Court reserved decision yesterday on the question of the constitutionality of the Cedarhurst, L. I., ordinance prohibiting flights over that community of less than 1,000 feet.
THE ways of government are often strange but the behavior of the Federal Communications Commission with regard to the future of the American Broadcasting Company is in a class by itself.

A thousand gymnasts from various communities of Czechoslovak-Americans in the eastern United States will take part next Sunday in a Sokol Festival at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island, the Czechoslovak Federation of America announced yesterday.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 21 21 (Reuters) -- The Government announced tonight that tests showed that a DC-3 plane missing over the Baltic since June 13 had been shot at, and said the Soviet Union had been asked whether its fighting forces were responsible."

IT is probably a statement of fact that most men like dogs but do not care for cats. Cats have always left me a little cold: to me, they have seemed sly, lazy, too independent, too self-sufficient. Sometimes I have thought cats acted a trifle condescendingly toward homo sapiens; the fact they have reason adds kindling to the fire of resentment.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, displaying complete confidence that he would receive the Republican Presidential nomination on an early ballot, said today his own count gave him "about 603 or 604 delegates" at the party's national convention next month in Chicago.

CHICAGO, June 21 -- Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee predicted here today that he would win the Democratic nomination for President on the "fifth or sixth ballot" at the national convention opening here July 21.

THIS is undoubtedly the season to bring along movies about sports -- about golf and baseball and tennis and, if you like, bowling on the green. In the winter and other seasons, such subjects do have their straight appeal, uncomplicated and objective, depending on how well they're put on.

SALEM, Mass. -- For many years this city has been one of the foremost tourist attractions for visitors to the Bay State. Salem boasts many things of tourist interest -- the House of Seven Gables used by Nathaniel Hawthorne; fine examples of old sea captains' homes on Chestnut Street; 275-year-old buildings associated with the days of the witchcraft trials and many other aspects of historical importance.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, June 21 -- The police fought a gun battle today with groups of the nearly 300 heavily armed convicts who escaped from a prison island yesterday after having killed seventeen guards and civilian employes. Twenty-two convicts were recaptured in the battle.

The 32,200 customers at Aqueduct yesterday studied the past performances, checked the handicappers' selections, cast a horoscope or two and voted the Lazy F Ranch's 4-year-old colt, Out Point, the one least likely to succeed in the $28,175 Edgemere Handicap.
LONDON, June 21 (AP) -- The Soviet Union tonight mobilized her satellites in a new diplomatic offensive, apparently with high hopes of yet defeating a link-up of West German and West European arms.

How mutable is life; how fleeting the news. Even a crossword puzzle can't keep up, it seems, judging by THE TIMES Magazine's puzzle of June 15, definition 110 Across, dealing with "Hornsby's job." This is obviously Rogers Hornsby, and the answer, an abbreviation, was obviously "Mgr." for manager.

SOME of the finest modern ballets, particularly those of Tudor and de Mille, have been based upon murder themes (Miss de Mille is, indeed, a noted connoisseur of historical murders); so it's hardly surprising that mystery-writers have returned the compliment by occasionally basing their murders on the ballet.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The Army Medical Service reported further gains today in the treatment of wounded soldiers. Reporting the latest figures on treatment of wounded in Korea, the service asserted that fewer wounded were dying if they were reached for treatment than ever before in United States military history.

CHICAGO, June 21 (AP) -Calumet Farm's speedy filly, Bubbley, today became a contender for the national juvenile filly championship with a sparkling two-length victory in the $17,925 Pollyanna Stakes at Arlington Park.

A week ago yesterday President Truman officiated at the keel-laying of the Nautilus, the first of two submarines to be driven by atomic energy. The power plant of the Nautilus will be supplied by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation. The contract for a second submarine has been let; the atomic power plant of this one will come from the General Electric Company.

AS the perennial garden steps into stride, glowing with early summer color, many gardeners are looking ahead. They are thinking of that midsummer lag when so many early perennials are through blooming and before the late flowers are really at their best.

VARIOUS gardening groups are placing emphasis on specific kinds of plants this week. Two stately border plants -- the lily and delphinium -- share the spotlight with the less spectacular, yet equally interesting, ferns.

PARIS. ON Feb. 26, 1802, a boy baby was born to an officer of Napoleon's legions in the Alpine town of Besancon and named Victor-Marie Hugo. In the next eighty-three years Victor Hugo, a one-man fountain of words and ideas, was to dominate his century of French letters as no man has ever dominated it before, sampling with amazing brilliance and fickleness every one of the political myths and passions of his turbulent age.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Administration forces, caught by surprise yesterday when the House of Representatives crippled its price control bill, began marshaling forces today in an endeavor to salvage a workable controls measure from Congress.

THOSE two sterling exponents of the fisticuffs art, Walker Smith and Guiseppe Antonio Berardinelli, will trade rude punches in the Yankee Stadium tomorrow night in a match that has the Busted Beak industry intrigued and excited. They'll battle for the light-heavyweight championship of the world and -- what's that? Oh. Didn't you know?

When ACTH, cortisone and other compounds were introduced for the treatment of arthritis the pharmaceutical houses began to ask questions. The most important was: How many sufferers from arthritis are there in this country? The pharmaceutical houses would like to know because they make the drugs that physicians prescribe for diseases of the joints.

Of the $4,249,000,000 just borrowed by the Treasury to help finance the 1952-53 operating deficit, how much represents bona fide savings likely to remain invested for an indefinite period of time? And how much of the total borrowing will come -- if not directly, then indirectly -- from the commercial banking system?

IF John Guthrie's other five novels are as amusing as this one, it is surprising that they haven't been published here. "Merry-Go-Round," the sixth, is a post-war story of Peter Smith, who is assistant to the director of the Society for British Culture.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., June 21 -Three Navy crews wore a look of greatness today. In the fiftieth anniversary regatta of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association, held on Onondaga Lake, the Academy's varsity slammed to a three-length triumph. Its junior varsity won by a similar margin and its plebes by a length.

UNTIL the end of the month an admirable group exhibition of European and American modern painting and sculpture is current at the Curt Valentin Gallery. It includes a life-size bronze of Rodin's "Eve," that majestic brooding figure originally designed in larger form for the unfinished "Porte de l'Enfer" and certainly one of the master's finest achievements.

WEST POINT, N. Y., June 21 -- Gilmore Rothrock, power-hitting Cornell Junior, won the thirtieth Eastern Intercollegiate tennis championship today defeating top-seeded Tom Boys of William and Mary, 1 -- 6, 3 -- 6, 8 -- 6, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 1.

MEXICO CITY, June 21 -- A new organization called the Committee for the Liberation of Guatemala began its propaganda activity today with newspaper advertisements calling for support "to save Guatemala from the grip of the Soviets."

Last week was one of the busiest periods in the wholesale market since the opening of the new fall lines, Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office, reported. Coats, suits, dresses, furs and accessories were ordered in quantity as offices and showrooms were crowded with buyers.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 21 -- The Yugoslav delegation to the sixth session of the Danube Commission, which will open Monday in Galati, Rumania, will attempt to break the Soviet Union's control of the Danube River.

THE herb garden at the Cloisters is a small but important part of this famous museum of medieval art which last week received a gift of $10,000,000 from John D. Rockefeller Jr. It certainly merits attention from anyone who is planning to start an herb garden.

USING an ordinary movie projector and a tape recorder, any 8mm moviemaker may now add synchronized sound to his color or black-and-white silent films by a simplified low-cost method demonstrated here last week by the Revere Camera Company.
LONDON, June 21 (AP) -- Britain's Olympic hopefuls competed today before Queen Eligzabeth and a tall high school teacher gave the best performance, in the two-mile steeplechase.

Federal Reserve Board figures showed a gain in sales by department stores for the week ending June 14 of 9 per cent above the corresponding week a year ago, against a gain of only 2 per cent in the previous week. All districts but New York and Minneapolis showed gains of 5 to 23 per cent. Minneapolis sales were unchanged and New York's were off 8 per cent.

MRS. KELLY says that she has attempted to write "the probable life of Geoffrey Chaucer, Gentleman," and to place him in a social and historical background of his time. She succeeds. The personality of young Geoffrey emerges clearly, and fourteenth-century English life is graphically presented.

Hunter College will confer degrees on 871 day and evening session students at its 102d commencement at 5:30 P. M. tomorrow on the Bronx campus, Bedford Park Boulevard and Goulden Avenue. It will be the second time in Hunter's history that the exercises will be held outdoors.

I am rather surprised at the way your erudite writers get stuck at mere elementary points. Theodore H. White in "France Holds On to the Indo-China Tiger" (June 8) writes: "There is an Oriental expression which is almost untranslatable in French.

Cardinal Spellman distributed medals of honor yesterday afternoon at the chancery of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, 451 Madison Avenue, to twenty eighth grade winners in two educational contests.

A charter has been granted to the Interamericana de Financieamento e Investimentos, S. A., (Interamerican Finance and Investment Company), a new investment banking enterprise in which Brazilian and North American financial interests have joined hands, according to information received here from Rio de Janeiro.

OCEANPORT, N. J., June 21 -The Regret Handicap occupied the feature spot on the program at Monmouth Park today, and the popular fixture attracted so many candidates that it had to be run in two divisions. Sharing the victory in the competition for fillies and mares were Jouett B. Shouse's Cinda and Dixie Flyer of the Duntreath Farm.

SINGAPORE, June 21 -- British official sources here have welcomed the decisions on Indo-China reached in Washington as a result of the visit there of Jean Letourneau, French Minister for the Associated States of Indo-China.

The near-record wheat crop that is being harvested in the United States may require the Federal Government to advance $1,000,000,000 to support prices. While it is bit too early to tell just how much of this year's crop will go into the loan, the trade expects that impoundings will be the largest since 1942, when 408,000,000 bushels were placed in the loan.

Members of the National Security Training Commission have made a desperate appeal to Congress that deserves prompt and sympathetic attention. The Commission of five distinguished citizens was established by Congress itself to present working plans for universal military training.

Moderate net gains in cotton prices on the domestic market marked the close of the week. Prices had advanced steadily during the early part of the week until active future contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 28 to 62 points from the previous week.

Five children were overcome by smoke yesterday in an early-morning fire in a three-story tenement at 2405 Pitkin Avenue, in the East New York district of Brooklyn. Three of the victims were removed to Kings County Hospital, where their condition was said to be critical.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., June 21 -- In one of the keenest finals in the history of the competition, Mrs. Joseph Mason of Ridgewood captured the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association title today by beating Roslyn (Cookie) Swift of Glen Oaks, 1 up, at the Upper Montclair Country Club. This thrilling final of the fortyninth annual tournament carried to the thirty-sixth green.

LONG BEACH, Calif., June 20 (AP) -- The athletes who have qualified from the National A. A. U., the National Collegiate A. A. and All-Service track and field meets for the United States Olympic team final trials at Los Angeles next Friday and Saturday are:

For many years educators, and students, too, have debated the question of what makes a good classroom teacher. Besides such essential elements as scholarship, there are many intangible factors. How much freedom should the teacher permit students to have? Should she permit them to participate in the teaching program? What happens if you leave the pupils alone entirely, giving them little or no direction?

PROBABLY no one in London, aside from Katharine Hepburn herself, is waiting with more anxiety for the opening on Friday of Shaw's "The Millionairess" at the New Theatre than Fifty-third Street's Theatre Guild.
PITTSBURGH, June 21 -- The Pittsburgh Steeler football club accented its switch from ground power to the air attack today by signing Gus Dorais, "father of the forward pass," as backfield coach.
A 22-year-old ne'er-do-well with an excellent memory found yesterday in Brooklyn Felony Court that as far as he was concerned history was repeating itself with remarkable accuracy.

IN "The Boy's Workshop Companion" there are over 300 illustrations of tools for working in wood and metal and of the way tools are used. The illustrations are accompanied by explanations that will help young craftsmen use their tools economically and efficiently.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The Senate passed and sent to the House today a resolution directing the Administration to investigate discriminatory practices in foreign countries against American flag vessels.
Two young hold-up men entered an apartment house in Forest Hills, Queens, about dawn yesterday, tied up the doorman and a tenant, and made off with clothing, jewelry, cash, a radio and an automobile.

PROFESSOR HOOK'S * * * loud disclaimers regarding the "deeper opposition of genuine American liberals * * * to the Kremlin" are nowhere supported by factual examples. * * * But above all the reason why to me, an Asiatic, Chambers is right and Hook is wrong, that (speaking very, very broadly) "man worships God or Stalin" is found writ large in modern history and experience.

PARIS, June 21 -- The Schuman plan for creating a wider coal and steel market in Western Europe has now run the gantlet of ratifications and the Foreign Ministers of the six participating countries are expected to meet soon to choose the "high authority" of nine members to supervise the market and the court that is to sit in judgment.

Harry Gross spent two hours yesterday in City Prison with Assistant Corporation Counsel Victor J. Herwitz, going over evidence to be introduced at the departmental trial of the twenty policemen he picked out of a line-up on Friday.
TOKYO, Sunday, June 22 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,288, for Saturday's operations:

JERUSALEM, June 21 -- Israeli military police armed with sub-machine guns were in occupation of offices of the United Nations Mixed Armistice Commission here tonight to prevent officials from opening a fifty-gallon metal drum seized from an Israeli convoy seventeen days ago.

The caption of a photograph illustrating Penn Kimball's article, "The 'Terribly Normal' Class of '52" (June 8) reads, "The job market is strong for this year's crop of college graduates." According to my experience, if this were not so ironic, it would be laughable.

GARDEN roses are a pleasure to arrange, either by themselves or in combination with the many other flowers that bloom at the same time. This month climbers, ramblers, hybrid perpetuals, hybrid teas and floribundas all provide an abundance of bloom for cutting.

THE first thing that strikes you while talking to A. J. Liebling, the author of "Chicago: The Second City" (see page 3), is that there is nothing wayward or backward about his thinking. It is thinking that is direct and lively not in the obvious sense of brilliant pyrotechnics, but rather in the scrupulous shadings of its concerns.

SOME months ago I was browsing through some old sheet music and came upon Irving Berlin's "My Walking Stick." Reading it through, I found the line: "I'd go insane without my cane." And it struck me that there, in six words, was the thing we are in danger of losing in our musical theatre.
" Anyone can kill a Communist, given a weapon, but the harder way offers more solid success," Ramon Magsaysay, Secretary of Defense of the Philippines, declared yesterday.

OF the listing of twenty-seven films which follows, a selection of representative 16-millimeter offerings to be had for a reasonable fee and, as indicated, the mere asking, at least three may be said to typify a crossing of custom-made boundaries, in subject as well as treatment.

Business leaders were told last week to "slow down and live longer." They were admonished against behaving like opera singers or baseball stars, and a scholarly Britisher told them that it is difficult to teach new tricks to an aging corporation executive.

READERS took their first trip to the moon 1,800 years ago -- via two stories by the satirist Lukian (or Lucian) of Samosata, who may, therefore, properly be called the "father of science fiction." In one of his tales, titled "True History," the trip was accidental: a ship sailing in mysterious waters west of the Pillars of Hercules was blown to the moon by a sudden storm.

Plantdom's pot of gold again is gleaming at the foot of the floral rainbow now approaching the high arch of its annual brilliance. The golden dust that is pollen virtually covers the earth made verdant by its previous visitations.

Absolute control of the famed Howaldtswerke shipbuilding enterprises will pass from German hands for the first time as soon as an outside group completes the details involved in the purchase of a half interest in the concern's Kiel shipyard.

TAKING his three articles that appeared in The New Yorker, A. J. Liebling has added an introduction, some footnotes (comprising letters from irate readers and his comments on them), illustrations by Steinberg, and wrapped them into a book published apparently for the tourist trade that will converge on Chicago for the political conventions in July.

The 1951 edition of The New York Times Index, containing the summaries of more than a half million news items, arranged alphabetically by subjects, persons and organizations, was published yesterday. The volume, compiled under the direction of Joseph C. Gephart, editor, contains 1,220 pages, three columns wide, and is printed on rag paper.

ANYBODY who has dug some of those delicious saloons on West Third Street, got his kicks in the San Remo or passed some charge around with a mixed grill of teaheads, hollow men, female baritones and uptown slummers in a cold-water flat over near West Street will recognize at once the fine, crummy verisimilitude Chandler Brossard has brought to his first novel.

The award for the best stockholder report prepared by a Junior Achievement Company in the New York area was presented by the New York Financial Writers Association yesterday to the Anti-Crime Laboratories group of twelve New York high school students.

PARIS, June 21 -- Helen Keller, the American woman who has been deaf and blind all her seventy years, paid tribute today to Louis Braille, French inventor of the systen of printing for the blind that opened for them the world of silent, unassisted reading.

CLEVELAND, June 21 (UP) -- Sid Hudson proved a valuable stop-gap in the flood of pitching troubles deluging the Red Sox by stopping the Indians today, 3 to 1, before 12,987. Second-place Boston thus cut the Yankee's lead to a game and a half.

CHICAGO, June 21 (AP) -- Major grains eased throughout the session on the Board of Trade today, wheat and corn slipping about a cent. Rye again showed independent firmness, although not matching the previous session's upturn, and a few soybean contracts showed flashes of strength.

DALLAS, June 21 -- Southwestern business maintained a steady tone during the last week. Agricultural production outlook improved with hot, dry weather and good moisture. Construction activity mounted and department store sales were as good or better than last year.
DETROIT, June 21 (AP) -- The nation's auto industry still is depending upon its civilian operations for the greater part of its income and employment.

Every Soviet move and policy modification inevitably raises the problem for the West of what light it throws on the Kremlin's over-all strategy and intentions. In recent weeks there have been several such developments which have raised a number of questions in the minds of western diplomats.

The absence of constructive developments in the steel controversy and further complications in the international picture had a depressing effect on financial sentiment last week. Many stock traders marked time as the steel strike continued through its third week.
A CHICKEN barbecue sounds as American as Fourth of July. Indeed, it is well suited to that approaching holiday when friends and families gather together and a fresh-air feast is indicated.

About 3,000 of the nation's leading engineers and technical experts on materials are expected to attend the fiftieth-anniversary meeting of the American Society for Testing Materials this week at the Statler and New Yorker Hotels.

If the views expressed by another newspaper man 119 years ago had been accepted, the need for Herbert L. Matthews' informative article on fifty years of corruption in "The Republic With No Citizens" (May 18) might not have arisen.

BERLIN, June 21 -- The completion of a twenty-one-mile canal that, the East Germans say, was built to free them from the waterway stranglehold now held by the Western powers in West Berlin, was announced today.

BOTH Chambers and Hook make the mistake of assuming belief in God and belief in man are opposed to each other. True, belief in man does not imply belief in God. But belief in God is belief in man, belief in one's self as indestructible.
JOSEF VON STERNBERG, the director whose last film made outside of the United States was "The Blue Angel," an item released here in 1930, will journey to Japan to make his next picture.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 21 -- A dose of Long Island Sound's weird weather played a big part in the results of today's L. I. S. Yacht Racing Association championship regatta, staged by the Indian Harbor Yacht Club. But the fleet of sixty-eight, competing in ten classes, managed to get home on the strength of a fresh southerly, although arriving somewhat later than in recent regattas.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- A high Administration official predicted today that some steel production for essential defense needs would be resumed within a week.

Some 3,075 Europe-bound travelers are expected to set a postwar record for the Holland-America Line for a single week as four of the company's vessels depart during the period June 26 to July 3, Elliot I. Liman, passenger traffic manager of the company in New York, said yesterday.

The New York Daily News yesterday endorsed Senator Robert A. Taft as the man it would like to see elected President and said General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower would make "as good a Vice Presidential candidate as any."

ROBERT HERMES, Buffalo commercial artist, won the $300 Special Press Award in the 1952 Graflex Photo Contest, in which sixty-two winners shared a total of $5,000 in cash prizes. New York State led the twenty - one states represented among the winners, receiving nineteen awards to California's eleven and Pennsylvania's nine.

TORONTO -- By projecting the findings of a seventy-question survey of tourists in the Province of Ontario last year, officials can predict that the average United States motoring vacationist in Eastern Canada this summer will travel this way:

Irving Geist, New York business man, received last night a gold medal for his philanthropic services to veterans from the Fourth Armored Division Association at a dinner at the Statler Hotel. The dinner was part of the sixth annual convention of the organization.

Hanson W. Baldwin's article in THE TIMES of June 15 points out that Russia has more planes in operation than we have, and a greater productive capacity, giving the impression that Russia is stronger and that we are trying to catch up. He qualifies this impression to some extent by noting that ours are better.

CHICAGO, June 21 -- Happy birthday? Eddie Lopat, who was 34 today, did not mind working on this occasion. And the only present he hoped for was a victory over the White Sox. However, the celebration was held by Paul Richards' go-go guys, who capitalized on the Yankee errors that led to a 5-1 triumph for the Chicagoans.

A survey yesterday revealed that the electronics industry had gone far to meet the almost impossible needs of a modern air arm. There still are bottlenecks as ever more efficient controls and other devices are worked out for modern fighters, bombers and commercial aircraft.
ENGLEWOOD, N. J., June 21 -- George Ball of New York and Cal MacCracken of Tenafly, N. J., reached the final of the invitation tennis tournament at the Englewood Field Club today.

BADEN-BADEN, Germany, June 21 -- Since the era when Queen Victoria summered here, this pleasant Black Forest town has been accustomed to foreign visitors. But the majority of those on hand these days are not exceptionally welcome. They are French, they wear uniforms, and they are members of an occupation army.

OURS is a critical age, and books about books, writers about other writers, abound. Yet, amid all the hubbub of critics and criticasters, there is still room for the genuine article of criticism, and Yale University has shown much editorial wisdom in launching this series of studies of some of our great modern classics.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (UP) -The House Ways and Means Committee has all but written the death notice for a bill designed to correct some of the flagrant tax law abuses exposed in the last year.

THE Reverend Mr. Reissig seems to agree that theology is not a sufficient basis for liberal social policy. The history of western thought from the Stoics to Emerson and John Dewey indicates that it is not a necessary basis.

A FLEET of fifteen trucks tomorrow goes into its third week of ragweed spraying in New York City's five boroughs. This program continues until Sept. 15. In other Eastern cities and small towns, similar campaigns are under way.

LOUISVILLE, June 21 -- A thunder and lightning storm forced a postponement of the third round of play in the Professional Golfers Association championship today. By 10 A. M. so much water had accumulated on the fairways and in the low areas of the Big Spring Club course that officials decided to put off the matches.

" SUMMER is icumen in," chants the cuckoo on the very first page of "The Oxford Book of English Verse," and in many offices and shops and factories, stenographers and clerks and workers, and their employers, are frantically making plans for their vacation.

The greatest unified campaign in the history of the liquor industry has entered the operational phase, it was learned here last week. The campaign is aimed at getting legislation through the next session of Congress to reduce the Federal excise tax rate from $10.50 a gallon to $6.

Textile exports from this country have slumped badly in the last two and one-half months, Harold N. Pratt, outgoing president of the Textile Export Association of the United States, reported last week. There is little likelihood of an early recovery, he added.
CLEVELAND, June 22 (AP) -- With steel stockpiles big enough in most cases to last another two weeks, the magazine Steel said today any real shortage might be felt after the strike is settled.
Recognized as one of the great fighters of the era, Ray Robinson, world middleweight champion, tomorrow night will attempt to write a brilliant page in ring history.

The Cubs, who were burning up the National League a week ago, were functioning cooler than the weather at the Polo Grounds yesterday as the Giants flattened them, 6 to 2, for their second triumph of the four-game series, which ends with a twin bill today.

ATLANTA, June 21 -- A sharp upturn in demand by Southeastern retailers for fall apparel was reported here this week. More than 250 sales representatives of wholesalers at the annual showing in Atlanta of the Southeastern Travelers Exhibitors estimated that sales to retailers of fall merchandise were 35 per cent ahead of last year.
CHICAGO, June 21 (AP) -- Department of Agriculture report of livestock trading here today

CHICAGO, June 21 -- Betsy Rawls staged a rally on the last nine holes today to beat Betty Jameson, 1 up, in the thirty-six- hole final of the twenty-third annual women's Western open golf championship.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 21 -- Connecticut Republicans nominated five candidates for Representatives in Congress in district conventions today. Three incumbents were renominated without opposition. Two were named after contests in districts now represented by Democrats.

ELIZABETH, N. J., June 21 -- An unidentified aircraft, described only as "a four-engine airliner," droned over this city at low level at 8:40 A. M. today and touched off the first angry charge of violation of the new Civil Aeronautics Administration regulations for flights into and out of recently reopened Newark Airport.

There is a double satisfaction in the announcement that Angus Ward has been named Ambassador to Afghanistan. In the first place this is a promotion and Mr. Ward deserves it. In addition he is being sent to a sensitive area where his well-known skills can be of more service to this country than they could be in Kenya, where he has been a consul general.

The first post-war building to increase voluntary hospital facilities in Queens will be dedicated on Thursday at Jamaica Hospital, Eighty-ninth Avenue and Van Wyck Expressway. Patients will be moved into the new five-story wing on July 1.
BOSTON, June 21 (UP) -- Wilmer Mizell hurled a four-hit shut-out today and his mates shelled three pitchers as the Cardinals beat the Braves, 9 to 0, before 5,658 Ladies' Day fans.

SINGAPORE, June 21 -- The visit to Washington this week of Jean Letourneau, French Minister for the Associated States of Indo-China, has produced a re-examination of the Indo-China situation and fresh decisions by the French and United States authorities at an opportune stage in the development of the Indo-China war.

ROME, June 21 -- The Italian Foreign Ministry has received "positive assurances" from Austrian Foreign Minister Karl Gruber that he will not raise the question of Trieste in his conversations in Yugoslavia and that he will refuse to discuss it if it is broached by the Yugoslavs.

THE Automobile Manufacturers Association, a group having a due regard for the importance of its industry, has completed one more survey designed to show the essential nature of the automobile in American life.

This is a week of two anniversaries. It is two years since the Communist army of North Korea invaded the Republic of Korea, with obvious Kremlin sanction, and sought to exterminate the United Nations-sponsored experiment in freedom and democracy in that part of Asia.

Gian-Carlo Menotti, Arturo Toscanini, Kirsten Flagstad, the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Jascha Heifetz and Artur Rubinstein are among those cited for honors in the ninth annual radio poll of music critics and editors of daily newspapers in this country and Canada sponsored by Musical America.

EVERYONE cannot escape from the city for a full-length vacation this summer. Thousands of families will be chained to the head of the household who, in turn, will be tied to his job and waiting impatiently for a delayed holiday in the fall or winter.

CONSISTENCY of quality and line rather than period and place of origin are the elements to consider when blending unrelated objects into a harmonious whole. How happily several miscellaneous styles can be integrated into a single setting may be seen in the rooms of the apartment pictured here.

THE historian George Bancroft said of the Society of Friends, "The rise of the people called Quakers is one of the memorable events in the history of man. It marks the moment when intellectual freedom was claimed unconditionally by the people as an inalienable birthright."

GLEN COVE, L. I., June 21 -- John J. Humm of the Rockville Club defeated the defending title-holder, Frank Strafaci of the Garden City Country Club, 1 up, in the thirty-six hole final of the Long Island Golf Association's amateur championship at the Nassau Country Club today.

Maj. Sammy Lee of the Army Medical Corps, who won the platform title at London in 1948, and Miller Anderson, runner-up to Bruce Harlan for springboard honors, are among the early entries in the final Olympic diving tryouts.
Improvement in men's clothing sales in the last two weeks on both the retail and wholesale levels has inspired confidence among manufacturers, it was noted last week.

An exemption clause in the Federal manufacturers' excise tax on automotive parts is not being observed, according to a canvass of purchasing agents representing various local governments. The clause specifically exempts state and local governments from paying the tax, which varies according to the type or class of the material involved.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 21 -- The first anniversary of Jacob A. Malik's famous broadcast on Korea will find the Soviet Union still doing business at the old stand. Now as before the aim is to sow distrust and suspicion among the allies and potential allies of the United States, but the technique has changed considerably.
With two weeks to go, the Taft-Eisenhower struggle for the Republican Presidential nomination last week came down to this central question:
LONDON, June 21 -- Frank Sedgman of Australia won the London tennis championship today on the turf of the Queens Club.

The New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, will give its final indoor concert of the season on Wednesday between noon and 2 P. M. The library soon will announce the opening date of its summer concerts in Bryant Park.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The State Department's study of an "allegation" that Prof. Owen Lattimore was "making arrangements for a possible visit" to the Soviet Union or other Iron Curtain countries may be completed within a week or two, it was indicated here today.

HARASSED by low budgets and slow procedures, a small group of earnest men with headquarters in Albany is directing a year-round state-wide fight against pollution of New York State's lakes, streams and ocean waters.

When the Eisenhower family left Denison, Tex., some sixty-odd years ago, David Dwight Eisenhower, as he was then called, was only a few months old and the family in fairly poor circumstances. It did not seem likely that the little boy whom Mrs. Eisenhower carried in her arms would ever come back a conquering hero.

ROME, June 21 -- A Vatican organ has charged that both the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization and World Health Organization are dominated by a "materialistic spirit" that makes them a potential menace, or hindrance, to the work of Catholic missions in many parts of the world.

TRIESTE -- The special charm of Austria lies in its villages. Salzburg, Innsbruck, Graz -- these medium-sized cities have charm aplenty, and even beleaguered Vienna retains some of the carefree enjoyment of each passing hour for which it was famed before two great wars stripped it of power and glory and freedom.

Undaunted by the intermittent drizzle and slippery footing, 600 youngsters (mainly girls but here and there a boy) took over Central Park's Sheep Meadow yesterday afternoon and for ninety minutes demonstrated that part of the nation's culture is the dance. The occasion was the twenty-fifth annual children's dance festival, arranged by the Department of Parks, and virtually every playground in Manhattan was represented on the program.
The new superliner United States will be greeted on her arrival here tomorrow morning with the greatest harbor welcome ever accorded a vessel in the history of the Port.

A PUP and a balloon, as anyone who has tried the combination will testify, can provide entertainment for just as long as the latter survives. For Susie, a vivacious spaniel fresh from the country, the city was a dull and alien place until one rainy day the family brought her a big red balloon.
Rain-defying dragon dances and shadow boxing conducted without benefit of shadows were notable at the twelfth annual baby contest held yesterday at Columbus Park by the Chinese Community Club.

THE marriage of poetry and the academies in our time has produced a family of critics with certain distinct common features. The new critic is a meticulous bibliographer, a careful though sometimes ingenious reader, and a master of cross-reference.

FLOWERS are lovely in the garden. But flowers in the house as well as those we give to friends bring equal pleasure -- and so we cut them. However they are used, the blooms have only a few days to live, and, once cut, their demise is hastened.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (UP) -- President Truman is suppressing publication of a secret Federal Trade Commission report on a "giant international oil cartel" but is willing for Congressional committees to see it on a confidential basis, Senator Thomas C. Hennings Jr., Democrat of Missouri, revealed today.

IT has become fashionable to poke gentle fun at the light reading of our grandmothers. The "handkerchiefly" novels by such popular purveyors of domestic sentiment as Maria Cummins. Susan Warner, and Augusta Evans Wilson now evoke only amused condescension or ironic appreciation.

Santha Rama Rau's "The Wind That Means Life to India" (June 8) gave a striking picture of the behavior of that great invisible and logical force, bringing its annual relief and aid to the land of India.

ONCE again the year is divisible by four and that ubiquitous election adjunct -- the campaign slogan -- is heard in the land. The present batch ranges from a musical comedy contribution, "I like Ike," to the drab but direct "Win with Taft."

STOCKHOLM, June 21 -- The shooting down of an unarmed Swedish plane by Russia and the ensuing diplomatic feud between Stockholm and Moscow has stirred speculation as to whether Sweden is ready to abandon her century-old policy of neutrality.

FOR the camper who really wants to get far away from paved surfaces and the internal combustion engine, and who nevertheless is not enamored of hiking, there is no better solution than a canoe or foldboat trip.
HARRISBURG, Pa., June 21 -- The Harrisburg Senators of the Interstate League today signed a 24-year-old woman to a player's contract.

LONDON, June 21 -- A blueprint of the Labor party policy on the domestic economic front is coming before the party leaders for approval next week before being submitted to the party conference at Morecambe next September.
FORKED RIVER, N. J., June 21 -- The United States Power Squadrons held its annual interdistrict rendezvous today near the newly enlarged New Jersey State Yacht Basin at the famous old Eno's hostelry.
Critical shortages in food supplies in Alaska and the Hawaiian Islands were reported yesterday as a result of a shipping strike that has cut vital supply lines.

Within a few days Congress will vote on the question as to whether to sustain or override President Truman's veto of S. J. Res. 20, the joint resolution sought by California, Louisiana and Texas to give these states all the oil deposits and other mineral resources of the adjacent marginal sea belonging to all the people of the United States.

EARLY last Monday morning Newark Airport, closed to all but a few military planes since Feb. 11, reopened on a limited basis. Up to today not one scheduled or nonscheduled airliner has put into or taken off from the field that used to be known as "The World's Busiest Airport."

WALTHAM, MASS. BRANDEIS UNIVERSITY is so new that the class of '52 is its first graduating group. Founded four years ago as an experiment in Jewish sponsorship of non-sectarian education, the school, its faculty and students seem too occupied with the problems of swift growth to worry about such homely details as ruts in primitive roads on the grounds.

ALTHOUGH Adlai E. Stevenson has declared that he "could not accept" the Democratic nomination for President, Noel F. Busch evidently feels the 52-year-old Illinois Governor still will get the call at Chicago, and even be elected in November.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- President Truman is not at present seeking to bring about the nomination of anyone as Democratic Presidential candidate, it was announced today in a brief statement from the White House.

Martin Gilbert Olsen, the mild-mannered 37-year-old bank teller who went to lunch from a Brooklyn bank last Jan. 29 with $38,224 of the bank's funds, was picked up yesterday in Los Angeles, the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced here last night.

BUFFALO, N. Y., June 21 (AP) -- John Foster Dulles said tonight that "freedom on the defensive is not defensible." He urged a return to what he called creative democracy in the fight against "the moral monstrosity" of communism.

IF baseball terminology may be applied to the nation's summer musical events, it can be said the country has both its major and minor leagues. In the big league are the outdoor symphonic concerts, in the small one the chamber music festivals.

MOSCOW has given its seal of approval in recent weeks to Poland's infant film industry. A "Festival of Polish Films" was arranged and moviegoers in Moscow, Leningrad and other major Soviet cities received the opportunity of seeing ten of the eighteen feature films produced in Poland since 1945.

BONN, Germany, June 21 (AP) -- West Germany's Government reported with satisfaction today that its booming economy has made the mark worth nearly as much as Europe's hardest currency -- the Swiss franc.

THE oldest summer dance festival extant in these parts will get under way this week for a season of fifty performances divided over ten weeks. This is the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, near Lee, Mass., under the direction of Ted Shawn, which will go into its eleventh season with a matinee on Friday at 4, followed by an evening performance at 9 and two performances on Saturday.

ONE of the most popular radio programs in Western Germany, according to the officials of the Northwest German Radio Station, the biggest in this country, is a round table discussion among foreign correspondents broadcast a half hour every Sunday at noon.

LOMPOC -- SANTA MARIA, Calif. GARDENERS buy packets of flower seeds from a retail garden center, select them from racks in the hardware or feed and grain store or order them by mail from a catalogue. Whatever the source, it is a fairly good guess that the seeds were grown in a valley along the coast of Southern California.

PARIS, June 21 -- Approximately thirty German officers in civilian clothes will begin to participate in defense planning for Western Europe next week in the Palais de Chaillot overlooking the Seine River here. They will work alongside their French, Italian, Belgian, Dutch and Luxembourg colleagues in an interim subcommittee of the European Defense Community.

ELIZABETH, N. J., June 21 -- Virtually neglected in a "no man's land" created by the Elizabeth interchange of the New Jersey Turnpike, the bascule bridge that has spanned the Elizabeth River at Baltic Street since 1916 rusts while the Union County Board of Free-holders ponders its fate.
Letters in your recent columns about automaton chess players interested me. My experience when playing Ajeeb in the Eden Musee many years ago was not a pleasant one.

AN innovation in summer programming will be undertaken by Robert Montgomery and the N. B. C. television network beginning Monday, July 14, from 9:30 to 10:30 P. M. when the producer introduces a six-week dramatic series featuring a summer stock company of four principals -- two men and two women yet to be selected.
Following is the text of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's address at Dallas last night, as transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

AMONG the most persistent of our national traits is the quest for labor-saving devices. Dennis W. Brogan, a sympathetic commentator upon the American scene, has observed that this is not so much the result of a desire to get something for nothing as a holdover of frontier psychology, when every settlement was short handed and every pair of hands had to do the work of three.

Harold B. Hinton's article, "Rep. Barleycorn" (May 18), makes mention of "Joe Byrnes of Tennessee," calling him Speaker of the House "during the closing days of the Hoover administration." Further reference to him is made that "he and a few cronies * * * kept steel filing cases full of good liquor in an obscure room on the ground floor of the Capitol."
Two years ago this week in Korea the opening shots were fired which were to embroil this nation in some of the hardest and most frustrating fighting in which American troops ever have engaged.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, June 21 -- President Otilio Ulate Blanco today reaffirmed the foreign minister's assurance that the government would strictly protect the rights and freedom of the Jewish community here. He told Dr. Maurice Perlzweig of the Jewish World Council he stood behind Foreign Minister Fernando Lara who yesterday denounced the anti-Jewish campaign that has been promoted in recent weeks by a small anonymous body styling itself the Junta Patriotica.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (UP) -- The Senate today passed by unanimous voice vote legislation intended to lift the threat of a prosecution for bigamy from over millions of Americans divorced and since remarried.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- James W. Wadsworth, former United States Senator and Representative from New York, died tonight in Emergency Hospital at the age of 74. He headed the commission that drew up plans for universal military training.
ONCE upon a time when men thought of far-off lands they did not think of them as isles of escape -- and safety. In those days men thought of "civilized" countries as safe, and feared the unknown.

PUSAN, Korea, Sunday, June 22 (AP) -- The South Korean National Assembly took an indefinite recess today -- virtually ruling out the possibility of a Presidential election tomorrow as demanded by opponents of President Syngman Rhee.

THE surprise appearance by Nicholas M. Schenck, president of Loew's, Inc., at the meeting last Monday of the Hollywood A. F. L. Film Council in the company of Richard F. Walsh, international president of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes, provides food for thought concerning the financial state of the movie industry.

SHREVEPORT, La., June 21 -- Contests involving seven district delegates to the Republican National Convention were decided in favor of Senator Robert A. Taft's supporters by the Republican State Central Committee today.

THE meteoric rise -- social and fiduciary -- of an ex-Army Medical Corps colonel named Thomas Owen is narrated by Horace McCoy with some remarkably sharp dialogue, a large number of precipitously tense scenes, several clinically persuasive surgical feats, and a firm, if familiar, surety of purpose.

SPRING LAKE, N. J., June 21 -- The $300,000,000 which New York banks pay out annually in wages and salaries provide an "untapped reservoir" for increasing bank capital, banking executives were told here today.
SEOUL, Sunday, June 22 (AP) -- United States and Filipino infantrymen braced early today for expected new Chinese Red assaults on "T-Bone" and "Pork Chop" hills of the Korean west-central front.
BALTIMORE, Md., June 21 -- Professor Lattimore expressed mystification today at the State Department's ban on travel abroad by him, and called the order "absurd."

SHELTER ISLAND, L. I. -- The ferries from the mainland are already bringing the first summer visitors to this water-locked little resort town, which will celebrate its 300th anniversary this summer with events including a historical pageant on July 25.

WITHOUT doubt the most damaging charge made against the United States in recent years is that we cannot afford real peace. The argument, which any reasonably perceptive visitor to Western Europe has almost certainly heard, runs something as follows: The American economy is notoriously unstable and accordingly must be propped up by sizable Government expenditures.
DALLAS, Tex., June 21 -- The battle for Texas is really on.

EVERY editor of a large project has at times been tempted to put aside his principal task temporarily, in order to describe some of the amusing but obscure characters that have crossed his path. Warren Hunting Smith has not been able to resist the temptation.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 21 (UP) -- The two greatest thoroughbreds racing in the West, Intent and A Gleam, came through with clean-cut victories today on a twin stakes program at Hollywood Park.
PEEKSKILL, N. Y., June 21 -Thirteen insurgent district leaders this week renewed their demand that Raymond T. Moniz resign as Republican city chairman for the good of the party.

ELLSWORTH, Me. -- Many tourists following U. S. 1 along the Maine coast with Mount Desert Island or the Maritime Provinces as their objective miss one of the stateliest mansions in New England, the Black House in Ellsworth.

The captain and crew of a Liberty ship, who sought a salvage award from the Government for helping to save lend-lease cargo bound for Russia in World War II, simultaneously won and lost their case in Federal Court last week.

THE public still sometimes encourages airplane pilots to think of themselves as a breed apart, possessed of almost magic powers. This adulation may be a factor in making some pilots into windy philosophers like the narrator of this novel.

SHORTLY after Rufus W Griswold published his devastating memoir of Poe, a Southern physician, Dr. Thomas Holley Chivers, set himself to answer it with a critical biography of the poet whom he believed to be "one of the greatest men that ever lived.

SCIENCE fiction (as Mr. Ley points out on Page 1 of this issue) has a long if somewhat thready lineage. It is only recently, however, that stories of this genre have been written especially for young people and the supply has not equaled the post-war demand.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 21 -- The Middlesex County Sewerage Authority is going ahead with plans to build a trunk sewer to end pollution of the Raritan River despite the decision of two of the largest potential users not to participate in the program.

SINGAPORE, June 21 -- Responsible Americans are fully aware of Malaya's part in natural rubber production and the United States' stockpile and fight against communism, H. C. Bugbee, vice president of the United States Natural Rubber Bureau, said tonight.

Malcolm Ross, author of "The Need -- and the Chance -- for Equality" (May 25) is justifiably proud that the University of Miami offers the only full undergraduate curricula in human relations in the country.

PSYCHIC bids stopped being fashionable about 1935 or 1936. Technically, their value (or lack of value) had not changed at all, because nothing in bridge ever does. The best players had simply discovered that they cost more in the long run than they gain.

LONDON, June 21 -- Opposing bail for the young Foreign Office radio operator accused of acting as a spy for a Soviet diplomat here, the prosecution said today that although "a document containing highly secret and confidential information" found upon him had been taken away, it was possible that he still retained the substance of it in his head.

An outstanding example of both decentralization and expansion of industry is to be found in upstate Michigan. The nation's industrial giants are spending millions of dollars for the construction of new plant and equipment designed, immediately, for defense production.

Arkadyev of the Soviet Union quoted from American newspapers hostile to the Truman Administration in support of his allegation that this is a nation of "war-mongers" and at the same time that our press is in the hands of a "monopoly."

FIFTY years ago, as Mr. Eliot points out in his foreword, Arthur Symons in "The Symbolist Movement in French Literature" had a more unified body of French poetry to study than Joseph Chiari has now. The subject-matter that this book attempts to clarify is extensive and complex.

MAPLEWOOD, N. J., June 21 -- Edgar Roll of Suburban and D. F. McDonald took a two-stroke lead in the seventeenth annual John F. Roche memorial member-guest golf tournament today with a 35, 34 -- 69, Roll's personal score over the Maplewood Country Club course.

BERLIN, June 21 (Reuters) -- Soviet troops were reported to have gone to the aid of hard-pressed East German security forces this week to crush a peasant revolt against Communist moves to seal off the East-West German frontier.

The mass sale of $5 and $10 auto use-tax stamps, which began June 2 and ended at 12:30 P. M. yesterday, brought in $8,030,010, according to City Collector Alexander E. Frontera. This was $30,010 more than was estimated by the city's fiscal experts last winter, when imposition of the tax by local law was authorized by the 1952 Legislature.

The Giants defeated the Cubs, 3-2, at the Polo Grounds yesterday, but remained five games beyond the first-place Dodgers, who at the Pirates, 14 -- 4, under the fights at Ebbets Field. The Yankees' lead was cut to a game-and-a-half by a 5-1 loss to the White Sox in Chicago.

WE have tried to follow the approved pattern for motor travel: jump briskly into the car before sunrise, drive a hundred miles before breakfast, choose a good motel by 4:30 P. M., sleep soundly and repeat from the beginning. It didn't work.

Various bushes and shrubs belonging to the honeysuckle family have already come to bloom; but the one which country folk know as the true honey-suckle, the sweetest flower that blooms, waits for mid-June. Now its white trumpets are open, and you can smell its fragrance a quarter of a mile away, if the wind is right and the evening damp with dew.

DOWN from the attic or the topmost closet shelves have come the family suitcases; out of the children's toy chests carefully chosen treasures have been dug; new shoes sit in tissue paper in their boxes; haircuts have been scheduled.
