MR. CONRAD'S heroine, a Negress held in peonage until the age of 12, escapes from a Mississippi plantation to begin an odyssey that lasts for thirty years. Her destination is the North. But the winds of fate blow Leeha off her course; clouds of passion obscure her guiding star, and storms of ignorance founder her on reefs.
The 13,335 Flatbush citizens who abandoned their customary Saturday night pursuits to root for the Dodgers in person last night sat in on quite a show.

RETAIL trade in many sections of the country is making a more favorable showing. The latest report of the Federal Reserve Board, covering country-wide department store sales during the week ended June 14, revealed a rise of 9 per cent over the corresponding week of last year. Buying for Father's Day was a major factor.
CHICAGO, June 21 (AP) -- Dom DiMaggio, centerfielder for the Red Sox, is the new leader in the All-Star baseball ballot race.

When the Security Council of the United Nations met last Wednesday to take up Communist charges that the United States had resorted to germ warfare in Korea there were more than 2,000 requests for the 200 seats available to spectators.

STANTON, Del., June 21 (AP) -Big Mo, in the Circle M. Farm silks of Mrs. Edward S. Moore, outran thirteen other classy 3year-old fillies at Delaware Park today to win the fourteenth Delaware Oaks over a mile and a furlong of muddy going.

Pyrochlore, a mineral containing uranium and niobium (a rare metal used in alloys for jet engines), is found in certain types of granite in Kano Province, Nigeria, Africa. Now a large quantity of pyrochlore-bearing granite has been discovered. There are many millions of tons of ore-bearing rock in the deposit.

LONDON. In what promises to be one of the biggest summer tourist seasons in Britain's history, London, as ever, will be the focal point. As if rejoicing in the first year of the new reign, London gilds the summer evenings with a mellow glow of light, the touch of a prodigal hand dramatically illuminating its historic buildings and monuments.

An appeal by Gov. Earl Warren of California for public contributions of $555,555 marked the beginning last night of a video marathon for the benefit of United States teams participating in the 1952 Olympic Games. Bing Crosby, the radio and movie crooner, made his television debut on the program, which started at 11 P. M., E. D. T.

The first six awards to outstanding retired professors who will continue teaching at small selected liberal arts colleges for the 1952-53 academic year were announced yesterday by the John Hay Whitney Foundation, 30 Rockefeller Plaza.

Howard Bennett, who hitchhiked by car, jeep, truck and plane to Alaska and back in seventeen days elapsed time last August, visited THE NEW YORK TIMES news room yesterday to tell about his latest exploit.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 21 -- K. D. Owen's Hal Senator from Houston, Tex., turned in a 2:04 mile with Harry Fitzpatrick up to score a one-length victory over Floating Dream in the Flushing Junior Free-for-All Pace for $4,500 at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- One of the inevitable consequences of an election year is absenteeism on Capitol Hill, and 1952 is following the form closely. In the expiring Eighty-second Congress Representatives and Senators are becoming more and more conspicuous for their absence.

THERE are to be two United Nations stamps, instead of one as originally announced, in commemoration of "Human Rights Day," Dec. 10, when the issue will be released. In addition to the promised 5-cent item in "United Nations blue" there will be a 3c in a color yet to be chosen.

SUSAN MORRIS, just out of a small-town high school, comes to Chicago to job-hunt -- although her real goal is marriage. Work in a bookstore and later in the testing laboratory of a famous biscuit-mix factory brings her into contact with charming Michael Chase and forthright Andy Hortland, each of whom seems for a time to be the right man.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., June 21 -- Middlebury College today announced the award of four fellowships for study at the twenty-seventh session of its Bread Loaf Writers Conference, Aug. 13 to 27 at the college's mountain campus.

TO live seventy-one years without coming to Europe, as the Boston Symphony Orchestra has done, could be taken either as a compliment to Europe or as an affront. We in Europe prefer to take it as a compliment.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Democratic chieftains around the country are doing a not-so-slow burn these days over the failure of their party to produce a strong and likely Presidential contender with a bandwagon that all or most of them can comfortably board.

EDMONTON, June 21 (Canadian Press) -- Far-reaching decisions affecting the Alberta Government's right to collect royalties on oil, natural gas and coal will be handed down by the Privy Council in London this summer. Some observvers say there are more than $200,000,000 in petroleum rights alone involved.

Three more alleged members of teen-age mugging gang that for two months has terrorized strollers in the Rambles, a wooded section of Central Park near Seventy-fifth Street, were arrested Friday night and early yesterday, bringing to six the number arrested since Thursday. One youth had in his home a foreign submachine gun, four rifles and a target pistol, the police said.
Widespread changes in the training of the nation's premedical students are proposed in one of the most comprehensive surveys of the medical profession undertaken in the last forty years.
Widespread changes in the training of the nation's premedical students are proposed in one of the most comprehensive surveys of the medical profession undertaken in the last forty years.

NEW DELHI, June 21 -- India is willing to help in early settlement of the Korean truce talks without in any way appearing in the role of mediator, Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru declared today. But he said that any solution of the deadlock on the problem of exchanging war prisoners should be such as to be acceptable to all parties and "if we can help in that matter we shall eagerly do so."
" Calling Dr. Michaels, calling Dr. Michaels," bellow the loudspeakers of a hospital. The system has its points, but it also rasps the nerves of patients who need rest and quiet.

The Senate has sent back to its Foreign Relations Committee the bill that would authorize our participation with Canada in the development of the St. Lawrence seaway and power project. Last April the President said that the bill gave us our "last chance" to join Canada in carrying out the enterprise, inasmuch as Canada had announced her intention to build the seaway alone if need be.

The methods of preparing teachers for the nation's schools are scheduled for a thorough examination by 600 educators at the seventh annual national conference sponsored by the Commission on Teacher Education and Professional Standards at Western Michigan College of Education this week.

ROME, June 21 --There is no doubt that the Communist attempt to promote large-scale riots during Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway's visit in Italy failed completely. Only in the Communist stronghold of Florence did anything resembling a strike occur against the SHAPE commander.

SEVENTY MILLION Americans are expected to be in the nationwide audience when our greatest recurring drama -- the nomination and election of a President -- opens this year in Chicago. In two weeks one out of every two persons in the country will pull up a chair in front of a TV set and personally witness the first of the sessions that will pick standard-bearers for the Republican and Democratic parties.

THE United States Court of Claims has ruled that Kathleen Winsor wrote "Forever Amber" for her own amusement and is therefore entitled to a refund of $26,358 in taxes on the sale of movie rights. The intrusion of the courts into the realm of literature is an interesting one, since the ruling, in this case, coincides with the stated opinion of a great many critics at the time the novel was published.

WE think we have a heavy musical season in New York. Heaven knows it is heavy, as much as a well-manned musical staff can find time and space to report adequately in the fall, winter and early spring.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 21 -- About 175 junior high school girls from all over New Jersey will arrive at New Jersey College for Women here on Monday for the sixth annual Citizenship Institute for Girls, sponsored by the state Federation of Women's Clubs.

I am happy to be able to report that within a week after the appearance in your columns of a letter from "Virginian" offering $1,000 to send CARE packages to the Madras famine area if your readers would match the amount, contributions totaling $1,118 reached our offices.
The Taft-Hartley Act, five years old tomorrow, is being pushed into the front rank of campaign issues by the steel strike.
WHAT is a sportsman?
DARIEN, Conn., June 21 -Heavy competition among 940 entries marked the opening of the twenty-third annual Ox Ridge Hunt Club Horse Show. Five championships will be decided tomorrow afternoon.

DOWN at the southern tip of New Jersey, Cape May County is making a bid for summer visitors next weekend with its Antique Auto Derby. More than 100 automobiles of ancient vintage will assemble there from all parts of the East for a parade on Cape May's Beach Drive, where Henry Ford, Louis Chevrolet and other motor pioneers raced their cars nearly fifty years ago.

BOSTON -- Construction of an east-west toll road from Boston to the New York State line has been assured by bipartisan support in the Masachusetts Legislature this year. The 130-mile project, costing between $150,000,000 and $200,000,00, will be financed by bonds to be sold by a special state authority.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The Eighty-second Congress approaches its end in a mood compounded of languor about the present, of excitement over the coming political conventions and of detached wonder as to how and when all the work will be done.
ST. LOUIS, June 21 (UP) -- The Browns exploded for six runs in the sixth inning today against the Senators, and Ned Garver went on to post his third straight victory, 7 -- 3.

" IT'S A PROBLEM," a television program wherein various experts in their fields examine and discuss problems inherent in daily living, is produced by a young woman who says she is just beginning to "grow up." She is Phyllis Adams, 27, who began maturing suddenly last fall when assigned a job that, in effect, made her an entrepreneuse of human understanding.

TOKYO, Sunday, June 22 -- United Nations Command headquarters announced today that 27,000 civilian internees, South Koreans who had served with the Communist armies or who had been rounded up during the Communist invasion south of the Thirty-eighth Parallel, would be released from custody during the next few weeks and turned over to the jurisdiction of the Korean Republic.

CHICAGO, June 21 -- There is nothing so rare as a day in Chicago without a convention. As many as two dozen gatherings of butchers, bakers and candlestick-makers are listed by the Chicago Convention Bureau on an off-day of a slow week any time from New Year's Day to Christmas Eve.

WITHIN a five-day period Brandeis University has just awarded degrees to its first graduating class and stood sponsor to what it describes optimistically as its first annual festival of the creative arts.
PHILADELPHIA, June 21 -Norman Cousins, editor of The Saturday Review, said tonight that more than one billion of the world's people "are shopping for a revolution."
PRINCETON, N. J., June 21 -- A half-century of marriage was celebrated here today by Senator and Mrs. H. Alexander Smith in a family gathering at which six of their seven grandchildren were present.

Thirty-two speedboat performances by Americans have been accepted as world records by the Union Internationale Motonautique which from its Ghent. Belgium, headquarters is regarded as the ruling international body of the sport. George W. Sutton Jr. of New York, co-chairman of the joint American Power Boat Association's international committee, said yesterday, "This is the biggest record news since the birth of the sport in the United States."

Both for the collector and for those with not quite such special aims as the collector, the final sale of the season at the Coleman Auction Galleries, 160 East Fifty-sixth Street, will offer on Thursday and Friday a large variety of furniture, paintings, decorative items and Oriental and broadloom rugs.

THE author likes Eugenio Pacelli, but dislikes the Pope. Though John McKnight bills himself as a Protestant, his real credo is liberal democratic humanism cum internationalism. Any religion, or aspect of a religious system, that furthers world union and democracy is, pro tanto, good; any that hinders it is bad.

MOSCOW, June 21 -- United States Ambassador George F. Kennan left Moscow by air today for a week's trip to Western Europe that will include discussions of importance with Secretary of State Dean Acheson on questions of Soviet-American relations.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Little headway will be made by weeds in plantings that are mulched or, if that is not practical, cultivated regularly. Loosening soil with hoe or tractor once a week is frequent enough even in the rapidly growing flower or vegetable plot. Shallow-rooted weeds will die in the sun; large ones should be thrown onto the compost heap.

The Committee for Better Education of Rockville Centre, L. I., is expanding its membership to include all the citizens of the community. The committee is sponsoring a drive for new members who may be interested in improving education there. Plans are under way to make 1952-53 an "education year."

ONE of the major record companies alive to the responsibilities entailed by its position is Columbia, which boasts a resplendent catalogue of important modern works. Its most recent addition is Arnold Schoenberg's Erwartung, the monodrama for soprano and orchestra that was presented in concert form last season by Dorothy Dow and the New York Philharmonic-Symphony conducted by Dimitri Mitropoulos.

CAPE MAY, N. J., June 21 -Americans must fight education by decree and legislative mandate and foster true fredom of education if they are to preserve their other fredoms, Earl G. Harrison, former dean of the Law School of the University of Pennsylvania, told the second session of the Friends General Conference here this morning.

Prospects for early action to put the long-considered Schuman Plan into operation revived concern of business leaders last week over features of the plan regarded as potentially damaging to free enterprise.

HONG KONG, June 21 -- After two and a half years of complete Communist control of China's mainland, the methods, accomplishments and future plans of the Chinese Communist regime may now be assessed in proper perspective. What the Peiping dictatorship has done and is doing to 460 million Chinese is apparent.

ATLANTA, June 21 -- The Southern Association of Science and Industry will hold its twelfth annual meeting in Winston-Salem, N. C., next Thursday and Friday, according to Dr. M. P. Etheredge, president of the association and dean of science at Mississippi State College.

ATLANTA, June 21 -- The Southern Association of Science and Industry will hold its twelfth annual meeting in Winston-Salem, N. C., next Thursday and Friday, according to Dr. M. P. Etheredge, president of the association and dean of science at Mississippi State College.

YONKERS, June 21 -- Champion Bang Away of Sirrah Crest, owned by Dr. and Mrs. R. C. Harris of Santa Ana, Calif., added another victory to his list today when he was named best in show at the Yonkers Kennel Club all-breed event.

One of the most popular and best-read subway car cards is not an advertisement but a cartoon-type editorial published monthly by the New York City Board of Transportation and known as "The Subway Sun."

The increase in the newsstand price of THE NEW YORK TIMES' Sunday edition from 15 to 20 cents a copy was met last night by a refusal on the part of some dealers in the Times Square area and in some other sections to accept delivery of the newspaper.
LORDSHIP, Conn., June 21 (AP) -- Two juniors stole the show on the second day of the Great Eastern skeet shoot at the Lordship range today by turning in perfect scores of 100 in separate events.

OMAHA, Neb., June 21 -- Averell Harriman suggested today the establishment of the office of Inspector General as a "Presidential arm" to weed out corruption in government and set up a standard of ethics for government workers.
GENEVA, N. Y., June 21 -- Senator Warren G. Magnuson, Democrat of Washington, told the Young Democrats tonight that he was "afraid to trust the Republican leadership with the atom bomb."

WHO is Paul J. C. Friedlander's clothier, if he has one? Judging from his article "Plain Dress for Plane Comfort," it is doubtful whether he has bought any new men's apparel in the last ten years. The sartorial picture he conjures of what it takes to be comfortable on an air trip is enough to send tourists back to traveling by horse and buggy.

IF Newport were merely another summer resort preferred by the millionaires of the Age of McKinley, it would mean no more to the American people than a cigar band dating from Bryan's first campaign. But Newport, as anyone knows who has motored across the Mount Hope Bridge, can't be dismissed so easily as that.

Religious leaders were called upon yesterday by Rabbi David B. Kahane of the East Fifty-first Street Synagogue, 221 East Fifty-first Street, to "close their ranks" against the forces of "the new isolationism" that are seeking to destroy the United Nations.

BECAUSE Bach composed mainly to German texts, and because many of the greatest composers were Roman Catholics, English-speaking Protestantism has trailed behind other denominations in representation in the record catalogues.
NEWPORT, R. I., June 21 -Close hauled, or with their sails winced in taut, fifty-eight yachts, ship-shape in every way, today started their race to Bermuda.

AT SEA ABOARD THE UNITED STATES, June 22 -- The super-liner United States knifed through the Gulf Stream 200 miles off the Virginia Capes at more than 34 knots today to give the passenger complement of 1,200 members of Congress, Government officials, shipping officials and newspaper representatives a brief sample of her capabilities as an ocean greyhound.

Responding to an appeal that reached them while cruising in the Persian Gulf, crew members of the Maury, now docked in the New York Naval Shipyard, Brooklyn, became "foster fathers" of ten underprivileged boys yesterday.

BONN, Germany, June 22 -- This is a story the Germans tell in addition to the warmed over one about the July 20, 1944, plot on Hitler's life. It is the story of the riot of the Munich students against Nazism.

A wardrobe of summer fashions for the mature figure is brought to you today by Patterns of The Times. There are three pattern numbers in all, but by varying them and making them in different materials you can get as many as six different garments.
Two hundred representatives of the Finnish community in New York braved misty weather yesterday afternoon to attend the eighteenth annual Midsummer Festival on the Mall in Central Park

A demand that Government-owned freighters operating under charter to private companies be withdrawn from service to give privately owned vessels more business has been sent to the Federal Maritime Board by a group of tramp ship owners.

If any doubt remained in the minds of advertising executives over public interest in selling America to the rest of the world, the Bing Crosby-Bob Hope fundraising telethon for the Olympic Games, which began Saturday night and ended yesterday afternoon, should have dispelled it.

FALLS VILLAGE, Conn., June 22 -- Popular music has been the chief concern of Broadcast Music, Inc., since its founding twelve years ago. However, the corporation also has an interest in concert music, and this week-end it took a new step in the serious field, launching its first festival of chamber music by contemporary composers.

ERIE, Pa., June 22 -- Cecil Smith, editor of Musical America, speaking last night at a dinner closing the seventh annual three-day convention of the American Symphony Orchestra League, said "name" soloists were an expensive luxury and produce artificial box-office appeal.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 22 -- United Nations diplomats were told today that the Soviet Union had decided to give priority in the Security Council to a United States demand for debate on a proposed inquiry into Communist germ warfare charges.

CHICAGO, June 22 -- Lard futures were heavy most of the week following the general trend of vegetable oils and grain futures. A softer tone in the hog market also was a depressing influence. Commission buying was more active following the Government's pig report showing a 9 per cent decrease in the 1952 crop, compared with a year ago.

The Civil Aeronautics Board has granted Seaboard Western Airlines, Inc., trans-Atlantic all-freight carrier, authority to expand its operating schedules by seventy-two trips a month on a world-wide basis. This will make available for the first time a scheduled air-freight service for Government agencies, since most of the line's flights will be made for the Government:

The City Center of Music and Drama will open an art gallery in the fall to promote the works of contemporary painters and sculptors and to facilitate the sale of these works to a wide public at reasonable prices.
The mystery of the missing grain is giving New York shipping and allied port interests much concern these days.

A program to eliminate firetraps like the one at 1101 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, where seven persons perished by fire last week, was urged upon Mayor Impellitteri yesterday by the Citizens Housing and Planning Council of New York.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 22 (UP) -- A fire that raged for five hours last night destroyed the stage section of the nineteenth-century Budapest Opera House. The blaze broke out at 11 P. M., just after the audience had left the building after it had witnessed a Verdi opera.
TOKYO, Monday, June 23 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1.289, to 6 A. M., Monday, Korea time:

Whatever one may think of the action taken by the House at the end of last week in the field of price control, that body performed a long overdue public service in voting to abolish the Wage Stabilization Board in the intolerable form in which it has existed since April 21, 1951.

Talk of presenting a musical variation of "My Sister Eileen" again is in the air and all signs point to Robert Fryer bringing it to the stage this time. Previously associated with George Abbott in the song and dance version of "A Tree Grows in Brooklyn," Mr. Fryer aims to do the production on his own.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Charles Sawyer, the Secretary of Commerce, said in effect today that he would welcome an investigation of the contract by which the United States Lines had obtained the $78,000,000 superliner United States for $28,087,000.

ZURICH, June 22 -- Answering a question by a Zurich banker about the legality of the practice of the United States Treasury in arbitrarily blocking Swiss dollar balances in the United States, Swiss Foreign Minister Max Petitpierre declared in Parliament last week that "the American measures were based on American war legislation."

In his address at Dallas night before last General Eisenhower set forth his concept of what the Republican party ought to be. The concept is challenging. Whether the party, as a party, has sufficient integrity and vitality to accept the challenge may well determine November's outcome.

Additional office space made available to municipal departments by transferring their inactive records to a central storage facility has saved the city about $1,200,000 in rent since 1942, according to a report made public yesterday by Rebecca B. Rankin, chairman of the Mayor's Municipal Archives Committee.

A generation that is "not only sick but dangerously evil" may seek God's protection at a "price," the Rev. Dr. John Heuss, rector of Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway and Wall Street, said in his sermon yesterday.

DALLAS, June 22 -- Leo Durocher of the New York Giants and Casey Stengel of the New York Yankees may not know it, but they are involved in the fight over Texas' thirty-eight votes at the Republican National Convention.

CHICAGO, June 22 -- Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee, aspirant for the Democratic Presidential nomination, said tonight that the American public was "witnessing a barroom slugfest" among the Republicans seeking the rival Presidential nomination.
J. Victor Herd has been reelected chairman of the executive committee of the National Board of Fire Underwriters.
TEL AVIV, Israel, June 22 -- A small home-made bomb exploded just after 1:30 A. M. today on the doorstep of the apartment here of Minister of Communications David Z. Pinkas.
Everything is set for tonight's light heavyweight championship battle in the Yankee Stadium between Joey Maxim, the titleholder, and Ray Robinson, world middleweight champion -- except the weather.

LONDON, June 22 -- Herbert Morrison, former Foreign Secretary and a leader of the Opposition, expressed the hope today that the arrival of Andrei A. Gromyko, newly appointed Soviet Ambassador to Britain, would usher in a new and brighter chapter in British-Soviet relations.

LONDON, June 22 -- Andrew L. Gomory, chairman of the American Committee for Standstill Creditors of Germany, said today that for the first time since the outbreak of World War II there was a likelihood that normal relationships might be resumed between German banks and the financial centers of the United States, Britain and Switzerland.

ROME, June 22 -- The remains of a third century Christian oratory, or chapel, one of the very few extant within the limits of the ancient city of Rome, have been discovered in the grounds of the United States Embassy on the Via Vittorio Veneto.
American business is standing in line to hire technically trained college graduates. Probably never before has there been such a demand for trained but inexperienced youth in America.

The two years since the start of the Korean war have seen a 17 per cent drop in the number of New Yorkers on relief rolls, and a 9 per cent saving in relief costs.
LONDON, June 22 (Reuters) -- Rousing war songs and martial music poured from the Moscow radio today as the Communists marked the eleventh anniversary of the German invasion of the Soviet Union.

A 42-year-old seminary student was injured seriously yesterday after a pilot light in his apartment at 303 East Twenty-seventh Street ignited naphtha fumes and caused an explosion. Twenty-one families in the building were driven to the street.
MAPLEWOOD, N. J., June 22 -- Charlie Whitehead, six-times state amateur champion, teamed with Ray F. Peeney to win the John F. Roche Memorial golf tournament today.

BONN, Germany, June 22 -- The great German debate on unity of the country against integration with the West took a startling turn today when Jakob Kaiser, Minister for All-German Affairs in Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's Cabinet, strongly supported calling a conference between the Western Allies and the Soviet Union on reunification.

ONE way of not severing the fragile bonds of memory and emotional understanding which link us with our youth is to appreciate the romantic outlook. This is not always easy. With maturity and disillusionment, with increased understanding of the complexities of human character and the stern realities of life, many persons lose their ability to enjoy the less subtle pleaserature.
GARY, Ind., June 22 -- Philip Murray told 8,000 striking steel workers here today that "the Taft-Hartley law does not manufacture steel."

A second book this year by T. H. White is scheduled for publication in August by Putnam. In March the concern issued 'The Goshawk," an account of the author's experiences training a short-winged hawk for hunting. His new book, "The Scandalmonger," continues his re-creation of "The Age of Scandal," with excerpts from eighteenth and nineteenth century diaries, gossip columns and letters, which he weaves together with his own comments.

PITTSBURGH, June 22 -- Nonchalance among steel users in recent weeks over adequacy of supplies was dissipated last week. Proof of unbalanced inventories is now clear-cut throughout the industry. Automobile makers and other types of manufacturing foresee shutdowns by the end of June unless the steel strike is terminated.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., June 22 -- For some years past rough weather has been the rule for the Riverside Yacht Club's annual regatta for the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound. Today was no different.

DARIEN, Conn., June 22 -- Peg's Pride, a grey gelding of the Hutchinson Stables, Closter, N. J., won the Ox Ridge Hunt Club jumper championship today with three blues and two reds for twenty-one points.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The National Citizens for Taft Committee charged today that supporters of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, in challenging Texas delegate elections, were seeking to "smear" Senator Robert A. Taft and "destroy our American two-party system."

The time is ripe for establishing a genuine liberal Jewish religious movement in Israel, Rabbi Maurice N. Eisendrath, president of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, said yesterday in his semi-annual report to the executive board of the union, parent body of Reform Judaism in America.

SINGAPORE, June 22 -- The Government has announced the release of the Indian labor leader, Peter M. Williams, who was jailed last week after he had begun to advocate publicly peace with the Malayan Communist rebels on the basis of recognizing the Malayan Communist party as a legal party if it would agree to operate legally.

The celestial committee charged with providing week-end weather for the metropolitan area continued in a sullen and unreasonable mood yesterday. For the fifth week-end in the last seven, the weather was bad. Skies were gray and occasional rains fell.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, June 22 (AP) -- Ninety-four of the nearly 300 prisoners who escaped from Anchieta Island Friday after a bloody rebellion were still at large tonight, Elpidio Reali, State Secretary for Security, announced.

LONDON, June 22 -- slightly more confident tone given to the stock markets by Chancellor of the Exchequer R. A. Butler's statement on Britain's gold and dollar reserves position has proved short-lived. A trifling rally in sterling also has not been held.

A syndicate represented by Irving T. Wolfson, attorney, has purchased the sixteen-story building at 290 Broadway from Louis J. Glickman, realty operator, who recently took title. It is the former home of Dun Bradstreet and is under lease to the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

SUGAR RAY ROBINSON is a prideful man. He's also a rich one. It will be a big pay day for the middleweight champion when he fights Joey Maxim, the light-heavyweight champion, for the 175-pound title in the Yankee Stadium tonight. Yet the money he will get, win or lose, will not interest him a fraction so much as the prestige he will acquire should he win.
BONN, Germany, June 22 -- Russian troops and East German police darted into disputed territory along the frontier between East and West Germany today and kidnapped forty West German workers.

HELENA, Mont., June 22 -- Mr. Harriman in a campaign speech that was pointed tonight to the western United States, called for expansion of production in food, minerals and all raw materials in which the West's potential was termed great.

LOUISVILLE, June 22 -- The possibility that the Professional Golfers Association championship title might go to a player from a foreign land disappeared today when Roberto De Vicenzo, the Argentine champion, bowed in the third round.

Representatives of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., and the New York City Omnibus Corporation will confer this morning with the Board of Transportation in an effort to iron out difficulties that threaten to upset the city's plan to sell its five Manhattan bus lines to the private operator.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- President Truman gave Secretary of State Dean Acheson a personal send-off tonight as the Secretary left by Presidential plane at 8:14 o'clock, Eastern daylight...
An off-duty patrolman was shot at midnight yesterday when a bullet fired by one of several policemen trying to halt a wild autoist ricocheted.
LONDON, June 22 -- The prospect of sponsored television competing with the British Broadcasting Corporation has emerged as a favorite subject for political speechmakers.

The Bob Hope-Bing Crosby "telethon" to raise funds for the United States Olympic Fund, which probably kept a good part of the nation up for most of Saturday night and Sunday morning, was quite a financial feat. A total ofof $1,000,020 was contributed or pledged over a fourteen and one half hour period, which is a formidable achievment now that these marathon performances occur so frequently on TV.

Out of the forty or more cook books published this spring emerge a few that are sound, interesting and worthy to have and to hold. "Coast to Coast Cookery," which was published last week (Indiana University Press, 318 pp., $3.95) is one.
The Rev. John Walter Houck called on the churches yesterday to take a stand on controversial issues. He spoke at the Pilgrim Congregational Church of New York, 1880 Grand Concourse, the Bronx.

Next Friday at the age of 70 and with fifty-two years of public school teaching to her credit, Florence Earll Clarke will teach her last class at Public School 130 at Hester and Baxter Streets. But she is not retiring -- she's being retired, she declares.

DETROIT, June 22 (AP) -- Hal Newhouser of the Tigers -- highest paid relief pitcher in baseball with a $32,500 pay check -- hurled seven scoreless innings today and tallied the winning run on pinch-hitter Vic Wertz' bases-loaded single in the twelfth inning as the Tigers defeated the Athletics, 4 -- 3, but Philadelphia won the second game. 10 -- 0, on Carl Scheib's seven-hit pitching.

PARIS, Monday, June 23 -- In a by-election held yesterday in the Second District of Paris to fill the seat of Pasteur Valery Radot in the National Assembly, the de Gaullists suffered a striking setback, while Premier Antoine Pinay's Independent Republican party made an equally notable gain.
The following booklet, of interest to parents and other adults working with children, is published today:

From next Monday through Aug. 29 the Police Athletic League will conduct recreation programs on sixty-six playstreets and playgrounds in the five boroughs of this city, Deputy Police Commissioner James B. Nolan, president of the league, announced yesterday.

BOSTON, June 22 (AP) -- The Cardinals, who haven't lost a double-header this season, won both games of a twin bill from the Braves today by identical 7 -- 2 scores. Southpaws Al Brazle and Harry (The Cat) Brecheen limited the Tribesmen to ten hits, five in each game.

CHICAGO, June 22 -- Trade in grain futures on the Chicago Board of Trade last week was slightly less than the week before, but was considerably larger than a year ago, the daily average of purchases of grains and soybeans being about 37,000,000 bushels compared to 39,000,000 the week previous and 30,000,000 a year ago.
BERLIN, June 22 -- The Soviet Union blamed the United States today for three more incidents in East Germany, all of which were alleged to have taken place last Thursday.

LONG BEACH, Calif., June 22 (UP) -- The United States appeared on the threshold of its greatest Olympic track and field victory today after disclosing unexpected strength in the distance events -- long dominated by Europeans.

Your editorial of June 3 on the pacts recently signed at Bonn and Paris states that quick ratification by the United States Senate is necessary "because an adequate defense of Western Europe is impossible without Germany.''

Perverse weather, which has been making life miserable for the Giants ever since the start of the season, hit the National League champions another blow yesterday when rain wiped out the scheduled double-header with the Cubs at the Polo Grounds.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 22 -- Immigrants from the United States arriving here after July 14 when the Israeli Nationality Act becomes a law will lose their American citizenship immediately they land unless they previously have opted against Israeli nationality.

There are occasions when it is good to be alone. This does not mean that twenty-four hours each day should be spent alone, for that not only would be overdoing a good thing but would be a direct result of misanthropy, which is unpardonable.

Unless the world consecrates itself to the Sacred Heart of Jesus, "never shall we have peace in the individual heart and never shall we have peace on the face of the earth," Auxiliary Bishop Joseph F. Flannelly said yesterday in a sermon at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

DALLAS, June 22 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower said today that he would not accept a Democratic nomination for the Presidency or cooperate with any third party movement if he were defeated for the Republican nomination at Chicago next month.

Champion Rancho Dobe's Storm, the black and tan Doberman pinscher who carried off top honors at Westminster this year and who has continued to show impressively, was named best in the thirteenth annual all-breed event of the Staten Island Kennel Club yesterday.

LORDSHIP, Conn., June 22 -- Two marksmen were repeaters in the twentieth annual Great Eastern skeet shoot at the Lordship recreation center range today as more than 275 gunners aimed at targets. Rain and wind provided severe handicaps.

Union teamsters employed by the Railway Express Agency took a secret strike vote yesterday afternoon at Beethoven Hall, 310 East Fifth Street, as both union and management prepared to resume mediation sessions tomorrow.

CLEVELAND, June 22 (UP) -- Steve Gromek and Mickey Harris combined to pitch a shutout in the opener and Mike Garcia notched his tenth victory of the season in the afterpiece today as the Indians defeated the Red Sox, 7 -- 0 and 5 -- 4, before a crowd of 38,947.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Administration supporters held out scant hope today that the House of Representatives would reverse its decision to force the removal of price controls from a wide range of necessities, including food.

What was intended as a star-studded grand finale to New York's "boating week" yesterday at City Island became one of the worst weather-beaten speedboat regattas since the 1948 holocaust at Detroit when Guy Lombardo broke an arm.
British sterling was moderately active last week on a downward scale, despite the encouraging report issued by R. A. Butler, Chancellor of the Exchequer, on Great Britain's gold and dollar reserves.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 22 -- Lana Turner will make her third romantic picture this year for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer when she stars in "Why Should I Cry" as a Broadway musical comedy star who falls in love with a blind pianist.

Averell Harriman, candidate for the Democratic nomination for President, was praised yesterday by Prof. Raphael Lemkin as the first Presidential candidate to come out for prompt ratification of the United Nations Genocide Convention by Congress.

TOKYO, June 22 -- Political circles here believe that the first of the major war criminals to complete a sentence imposed by the International Military Tribunal, Mamoru Shigemitsu, Foreign Minister in the Tojo Cabinet and signer of the Japanese surrender aboard the battleship Missouri, has become a leading candidate to be the next Premier of Japan.

Effectiveness of recent Brazilian measures to restrict imports in the interest of holding down dollar, obligations was reflected in a decline in the value of new drafts drawn on Brazilian importers during May to $26,100,000 from the April level of $35,300.000, according to the latest report by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

PURCHASE, N. Y., June 22 -- The thirty-three-man drill team of the New Jersey Wing of the Civil Air Patrol defeated teams of the New York and Rhode Island wings in competition today on the apron of the Westchester County Airport.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (UP) -- Field Marshal Earl Alexander, British Defense Minister, arrived here today to confer with United States officials and told them the Americans in Korea were 'Tunning a good show."

A new model house that combines modern equipment with interiors furnished in traditional style is now on view in Greenwich, Conn. The first in a development known as Perryridge Knolls, the six-room house was built by the Hvass Construction Company and decorated by Altman's.
Six new films will arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

Christianity has been damaged and weakened by attempts to broaden and dilute it, the Rev. Dr. John F. Fraser declared yesterday in a sermon at the Madison Avenue Baptist Church, at Thirty-first Street.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 22 -- Prospects for an early settlement of the Pacific Coast maritime strike appeared dim today as union leaders said they were prepared to hold out for six months or more, if necessary.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) Representative Hugh B. Mitchell, Democrat of Washington, said today the Idaho Power Company was the most powerful single interest that wanted to kill the Hells Canyon dam project on the Snake River in the Columbia Basin.

Until about 5:30 A. M. yesterday, Charles E. Murphy, a 25-year-old veteran, was kindly disposed toward hitchhikers. His own thumb had served him well. When he was discharged after six years in the Navy he had hitchhiked home to New York all the way from Los Angeles.

The first clash at the Republican National Convention between General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Robert A. Taft, rival candidates for the nomination for President, is expected to come on a motion for a rule to prevent delegates whose credentials are challenged from voting on any of the contests.
HARRISBURG, Pa., June 22 (AP) -- Eleanor Engle officially joined an organized baseball team as a player today, but practically all she did was watch the game.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 (UP) -- Karl Drews' three-hit pitching earned the Phillies a 3-0 "protested" victory over the Reds today after Andy Seminick's two-run ninth-inning double gave Cincinnati a 5-3 triumph in the first game of a double-header.

DALLAS, June 22 -- The Taft-Eisenhower fight over Texas' thirty-eight delegates to the Republican National Convention in Chicago almost certainly will be influenced and may well be decided by a Texas Supreme Court ruling handed down in 1930.

Svetozar Gligoric of Belgrade, due to fly back to his home tomorrow, endeavored vainly to break down the defense of Samuel Reshevsky in a five-hour session of the tenth and last game of their match at the Manhattan Chess Club last night.

With about 40,000 military airplanes in operation, the Soviet Union exceeds American air strength in numbers and is approaching it in quality, Gen. Curtis E. LeMay, commander of the Strategic Air Command, declared last night.

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, June 23 (AP) -- A strong United Nations tank and infantry force pushed deep into the Chinese Communist positions on the western front in Korea yesterday and returned after having killed or wounded an estimated 570 of the enemy.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Plans are being made at "the highest policy levels" to develop guided atomic missiles that would be able to destroy 95 per cent of an attacking bomber force, Air Force Magazine reported today.

Headed by Rusty Callow's unbeaten Navy varsity, which completed the middies' first Intercollegiate Rowing Association Regatta sweep at Syracuse on Saturday, nine college eights and one club crew are listed thus far for the United States Olympic trials to be held July 3 to 5 on Lake Quinsigamond in Worcester, Mass.

A strange, heroic procession wound its way yesterday through the streets of Paris. The coffin of Louis Braille, who died a century ago after inventing a system by which the blind can read, was being taken to the Pantheon, there to rest with the dead whom France most desires to honor.

New Yorkers will gain fresh appreciation of the role of the architect in society this week as the American Institute of Architects, with more than 1,500 members, representing chapters in all forty-eight states, holds its annual convention here. In honor of the event Mayor Impellitteri has proclaimed this as Architects' Week.

OMAHA, Neb., June 22 -- Averell Harriman flew westward today in his quest for the Democratic Presidential nomination but left behind for Midwesterners to mull over a firm conviction that "the Democratic party is in danger of being captured by compromisers."

The new $4,000,000 Marine Stadium, one of the most important projects in the post-war expansion of Jones Beach, L. I., will be dedicated by Governor Dewey at 8 P. M. on Thursday. After the official ceremonies the stadium season will open with a performance of the Johann Strauss musical comedy, "A Night in Venice."

A continued lack of skilled seamen was cited yesterday Hoyt S. Haddock, executive secretary of the Congress of Industrial Organizations Maritime Committee, in a criticism of the decision of Selective Service headquarters to stop seeking deferments for draft-age merchant sailors.

ASHEVILLE, N. C., June 22 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Robert L. Eichelberger, once General of the Army Douglas MacArhhur's right-hand man in the occupation of Japan, announced today his support of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Republican Presidential nomination.

NEW DELHI, India, June 22 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru announced today a plan designed to channel the vast manpower resources of the nation into constructive activities on a strictly "voluntary" basis.

Mayor Impellitteri and his special committee on buses have been urged by acting Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley to remove the obstacles to expansion of the one-way-avenue program in Manhattan by compelling modification of franchises held by private bus lines.
In reading your editorial of June 15 entitled "Bright Lights" I was again reminded of the rather puzzling reluctance of motor car operators to offer a protest in their own behalf.

Carver Houses, the state-aided Harlem city housing project for which a pilot medical center plan is being worked out was disclosed yesterday to be under study for a pioneer embellishment with sculpture and paintings, tentatively scheduled at $25,000.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 22 -- Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion is expected to announce tomorrow a Cabinet reshuffle involving the replacement of Finance Minister Eliezer Kaplan by Levi Eshkol, who is now Minister of Agriculture and Development.
CINCINNATI, June 22 (UP) -- Efforts to settle a strike that has stopped production at one of the biggest jet plane engine plants in the country failed today.

PONCE, Puerto Rico, June 22 (AP) -- Puerto Rican Republicans selected two rival slates of delegates to the National Convention opening in Chicago July 7 after an intraparty quarrel today that saw the police called out to restore order.

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, June 23 -- The United Nations Command announced today that screening of Communist prisoners of war and interned civilians was resumed on Koje Island today. The screening will determine whether prisoners wish to return voluntarily to Communist control or remain with the United Nations Command.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 22 -- The premier tournament in lawn tennis from the standpoint of box-office appeal and prestige accruing to the winner starts tomorrow on Wimbledon's treasured turf with more than thirty nations represented.

There is such a thing as "too average," the Temporary State Housing Rent Commission admitted yesterday after looking into tenant complaints about recent rent increases. The increases, to include electric current formerly submetered, were based on "average" electric bills that included the neighbors' toasters, television, toy trains, ovens, shavers and other appliances

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 -- The United World Federalists today called on the platform committees of the Republican and Democratic parties to offer a "constructive solution to the foreign policy problem" when they draft their planks at the national conventions in Chicago next month.

CHICAGO, June 22 -- A split in the double-header with the White Sox was the best the pace-setting Yankees could achieve today before 47,970 fans, the season's high at Comiskey Park. Yogi Berra's fourteenth homer and Bob Kuzava's superb two-hit pitching gave the New Yorkers a 3-0 triumph in the opener, but they could do little against Marv Grissom and bowed, 2 -- 1, in the afterpiece.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Senator Robert S. Kerr of Oklahoma said today that his nomination as the Democratic candidate for President would give to both his party and to the country the best opportunity for unity.

" Keys" to the city, heretofore reserved exclusively for visiting foreign potentates, aviators and channel swimmers, from now on will be presented symbolically to all first tenants of new apartment houses, Mayor Impellitteri announced yesterday.

SINGAPORE, June 22 -- The recovery in rubber prices during the last month has counteracted the earlier pessimism felt here concerning the future of Malaya's key rubber producing industry. Rubber prices climbed recently from a low of around 23 cents a pound to more than 30 cents.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., June 22-,-. and Mrs. David A. Lowry Iof the Lattingtown colony gave a reception thi afternoon at CottsWold, their home, to present to society Mr. Lowry's daughter, Miss Corelia E. Lowry. Later there was 'a buffet supper, with dancing in a mnrquee, for debutantes of the season and their escorts.

Two six-story apartment houses occupying a plot 100 by 100 feet and containing five stores and fifty-five suites at 910 and 914 Longwood Avenue, corner of Hewitt Place, the Bronx, have been purchased by the Estate Securities Company, operators, for all cash over mortgages from the 33-11 Eighty-ninth Street Corporation in a deal negotiated by the Advance Realty Company, brokers.

ST. LOUIS, June 22 (UP) -- Gene Bearden and the amazing Leroy (Satchel) Paige teamed to gain a 3-2 victory for the Browns over the Senators in the second game of a double-header today after four errors paved the way for five unearned runs in Washington's 8-to-5 first-game triumph.

Claims for unemployment insurance are expected to rise by 15 per cent in July over those filed in June, Stephen Mayo, metropolitan director of unemployment security of the State Division of Placement and Unemployment Insurance, said yesterday.

PORTLAND, Ore., June 22 -- A program of indirect conservation in the Pacific Northwest, whereby leftovers from sawmills and plywood plants are turned into chips for use in making heavy duty paper and cardboard boxes, was declared today to be on the way to saving 9,000 acres or more of old-growth timber a year.

FLINT, Mich., June 22 -- Michigan's forty-six-vote delegation to the Republican National Convention, while avoiding a showdown between partisans of Senator Taft and General Eisenhower, today selected a delegate friendly to the Eisenhower camp for membership in the Credentials Committee of the convention.

CHICAGO, June 22 -- The grain market was depressed last week. In wheat the major factor was the flood of winter wheat, which is currently pouring into the terminals. The bear factors in corn were the favorable crop prospects and steady pressure of Commodity Credit Corporation stock, which show no sign of ending immediately.

The growing acceptance by governments of direct responsibility for the welfare of children is perhaps the outstanding development in that field in the last decade, according to Miss Christina Ellwyn, social affairs officer in the United Nations secretariat.

TOKYO, Monday, June 23 -- Communist armistice negotiators at Panmunjom made a formal protest today against the decision of the United Nations Command to free 27,000 interned civilians from stockades in South Korea and turn them over to the jurisdiction of Korean Republican authorities.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 22 -- General Eisenhower toured Hoover Dam today and visited with members of the Republican convention delegation from Nevada.

A thousand compositions by school children from second graders to high school seniors on "What Makes a Happy Family" have given ample proof that children do a great deal of thinking about relationships at home, according to a report just issued by the Guidance Center of New Rochelle, N. Y.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- Americans have more education than ever before, the Census Bureau said today on the basis of data compiled in taking the 1950 census.

The grisly story of slave labor in satellite Eastern Europe and in the captive Baltic States is being unfolded before a United Nations committee these days. One witness has testified that there are at least 1,000,000 such unfortunates in Eastern Europe. Another has put the number in Czechoslovakia alone at 350,000, confined in 247 labor camps.

Automobile owners who should have bought their $5 and $10 auto use tax stamps by last Saturday's deadline but failed to do so will be allowed to purchase them until Aug. 1 without incurring the prescribed penalty of five times the amount of tax, City Treasurer Spencer C. Young announced yesterday.

Taxicab fares in New York City are the same today as they were nineteen years ago. The City Council has voted 21 to 1 to raise the fares an average of 27 per cent, and the Board of Estimate will consider the matter this week.

Greater savings of critical materials used in the production of radio and television equipment will be made later this year without reducing quality of the output, Lewis M. Clement of the Crosley division, Avco Manufacturing Company, predicted in a week-end report.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 22 -- Weather conditions forecast by the Bermuda meteorological station indicate that the fleet of fifty-eight ocean yachts should make good time in the 637-nautical-mile race from Newport to Bermuda.

It is by now an old story that the American quadrennial orgy of Presidential campaigning does things to world politics as well as to the domestic scene. Aside from the normal effect on Congressmen, who start cutting expenditures with suspicious and sometimes excessive fervor, or favoring this or that influential voting interest, there are the international repercussions.

MEXICO CITY, June 22 -- An unusual campaign to inaugurate a trust fund for the poor, to be supported equally by the Government and by private contribution, has been launched by Mario Moreno, beloved Mexican comedian who is to the people of this country a sort of combination of Charlie Chaplin, Will Rogers, Bob Hope and Milton Berle.

The dominance of the convention machinery of the Republican party by the Taft forces, illustrated by the selection of the temporary chairman and keynoter, calls for a sober analysis of the facts. It would appear that the Taft leaders have put the self-interest of obtaining the nomination of their candidate above the avowed purpose of the party to win in November.

Lew Hahn's "Stores, Merchants and Customers: A Philosophy of Retailing"* is aptly named. It is just that -- the retailing philosophy of an authority with long experience in the field, presented clearly and interestingly.

As seventy-five married couples, young and old, held hands yesterday in the pews of the Fort Washington Presbyterian Church, Broadway at 174th Street, the Rev. Dr. Wesley Megaw renewed their nuptial vows in a traditional service held annually since 1937.

BRIDGEHAMPTON, L. I., June 22 -- The "separate but equal" policy followed by the Supreme Court of the United States in "condoning" separate schools for Negroes and whites in the South was attacked as "basically undemocratic" at the final session of the fifth annual Minden Institute today.

In a dress rehearsal for disaster, the emergency welfare division of the Department of Welfare will stage a series of theoretical "atomic incidents" over the city this week to demonstrate how homeless persons will be cared for in the event of enemy attack.

BUFFALO, N. Y., June 22 (AP) -- The National Editorial Association demanded today that President Truman withdraw his executive order permitting classification of documents in all Government departments.

Lillian S. Ossa bought the two-story dwelling on the east side of Larchmont Avenue, 132 feet south of Cherry Avenue, Mamaroneck, Westchester County, from William C. Hardesty through Thomas B. Sutton, broker, and insured title with the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.
May I, as a student guest from India in the United States of America, seek the hospitality of your Letters columns to express something that is of concern both to Indians and Americans ?

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., June 23 -- Barney Lobel of Willow Brook and Ferdie Catropa of Peninsula combined for a 31, 32 -- 63 score, nine strokes under course figures, to win first prize in the Long Island P. G. A. amateur-pro tourney at the Hempstead Club today.

BERLIN, June 23 -- In identical notes to the Soviet commander in Germany, the Western High Commissioners insisted today on the right of the Western Allies to patrol the Autobahn between West Berlin and West Germany.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (UP) -- A House Appropriations subcommittee has asked the Air Force for an immediate report on the reported use of about $28,000 in military construction funds for work on a golf course at McClellan Air Force Base near Sacramento, Calif.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 23 (AP) -Indiana Democrats tonight elected twenty-two uninstructed national convention delegates described by party chiefs as "generally favorable" to Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois for the Presidential nomination.

LONDON, June 23 -- Scientific fishermen who have completed the deepest trawl ever made came up with no sea serpents but with bacteria that may shed new light on the way mineral oil deposits are formed, according to their leader, Dr. Anton Bruun of Copenhagen University.

Two races for fillies marked the card at Aqueduct yesterday, and Ray York, 19-year-old freckle-faced jockey recently arrived from California, not only was astride the winner of each but also registered a consecutive triple. Two of his scores were gained with long shots at the expense of odds-on choices.

Last Dec. 29, James Perkins of 358 Fourteenth Street, Brooklyn, the father of four children, was the victim of gunfire that caused the loss of his right leg. Yesterday in Kings County Court Mr. Perkins made a successful plea for leniency in behalf of his assailant, Vincent DiRubbio, 31 years old, of Bay Shore, L. I., the father of two children.

TUNIS, Tunisia, June 23 (AP) -- Tunisian Nationalists rejected today French offers of reforms in the protectorate's administration and called instead for an international conference to settle this North African dispute.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- The value of land along military highway No. 13 in Princess Anne County, Va., has increased as much as $7,300 an acre since 1948, Patrick B. McGinnis, chairman of the board of the Norfolk Southern Railway, said today.

Directors of Baldwin Rubber Company have authorized payment of an extra cash dividend, a stock dividend and a regular quarterly dividend, it was announced yesterday. The stock dividend, amounting to 10 per cent, will be paid on July 31, while an extra cash dividend of 10 cents and the quarterly dividend of 15 cents a share will be distributed on July 25.

LLOYD HARBOR, L. I., June 23 -- The valuable jade collection of Oliver Burr Jennings was stolen from his Lloyd Harbor mansion over the week-end. The police believe it was taken by youngsters who did not know its value.

THE job done by Bing Crosby and Bob Hope on the Olympic Telethon over the past week-end was a stunner. The world of sports never has had anything quite like it. These two flippant charmers, as durable as a couple of Marathon runners, stayed up all night in order to raise funds for the United States Olympic team.

Senator Taft has repeatedly made the statement that the presentation of what happened in Texas was not accurate or true. As I was a visitor in Houston at the time of the Republican precinct caucus, I should like to state briefly what I saw and heard.

The weather forced the Giants to remain idle yesterday, and also gave the Dodgers last night off. In the case of the Giants, the rain washed out the opener in their three-game series with the Reds at the Polo Grounds.

A banking syndicate headed by First Boston Corporation submitted the best bid yesterday for $2,940,000 of public works bonds of Hartford, Conn., due on Nov. 1 from 1952 to 1971 and callable out of earnings in 1956. The bid was 100.169 for interest of 1.6 per cent.

Full union support of a strike to achieve a forty-hour week by July 1 on nine privately owned bus lines operating in three boroughs was voted last night by 600 stewards and section officers of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., at a televised "meeting."

Hospitals throughout the country are handicapped by a serious shortage of nurses and other trained personnel. In this city the Board of Education and nine hospitals have been working together in a new program that is helping to overcome the shortage and may serve as a model for other cities confronted by the same problem.

HARRISBURG, Pa., June 23 (AP) -- Mrs. Eleanor Engle moaned today that George M. Trautman, head of the minor leagues, "threw me a curve and I struck out," when he ordered her out of organized baseball.

PURCHASE, N. Y., June 23 -- The Westchester County Airport, owned by the county, was virtually assured today of a new $1,900,000 hangar and the hangar's first tenant when the county's Board of Acquisition and Contract approved contracts to cover the deals.

CAPE MAY, N. J., June 23 -- This nation's foreign policy in India and Pakistan, stressing material benefits, is losing out to communism, whih is appealing to the imagination of the masses, Willis D. Weatherford, Assistant Professor of Economics at Swarthmore College, told the Friends General Conference here today.
Early gains in the stock market were not maintained yesterday and increases ranging beyond a point were reduced or eliminated in the late trading.
CHICAGO, June 23 (AP) -- A social program tailored to a brief Republican National Convention was announced today for Republican women.

Because the United States economy is relatively free, it is flexible enough to grapple with menacing instability, according to several participants in the American Round Table Forum, held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday under the auspices of Advertising Council, Inc. Dr. Henry M. Wriston, president of Brown University, acted as moderator.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- Field Marshal Earl Alexander, Britain's Defense Minister, talked with United States military leaders today about the stepped-up war and the stalled search for a truce in Korea.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 23 -- Richard Savitt opened the sixty-sixth All-England lawn tennis championships on Wimbledon's center court with a crushing victory today, but the two other Americans who followed the defending titleholders on the world's most famous carpet of turf were knocked out of the running.

Last week Foreign Minister Schuman placed a new program for Tunisia before the French National Assembly. It offered more Cabinet posts to Tunisians, priority in civil service jobs and greater Tunisian participation in the courts, the legislature and the municipal councils.

Eight air-raid drills involving more than 3,000 civil defense volunteers and covering the eight defense divisions in Manhattan were held last night, marking the half-way point for workers enrolled in the year-long series of mandatory training exercises.

At the half-way mark in the yacht race from Newport to Bermuda, John Nicholas Brown's yawl Bolero was leading by a scant mile over Wendell W. Anderson's yawl Escapade of Detroit. Bolero is the flagship of the New York Yacht Club, of which her owner-skipper is commodore. She has to give an hour time allowance to Escapade, which is a foot shorter on deck.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -With all of the Republican National Convention's 1,206 delegates now selected and with 604 votes needed for nomination, The Associated Press' tabulation based on pledges, instructions, delegates willing to express a first ballot choice and on candidate concessions stands as follows:

Moscow's observance last Sunday of the eleventh anniversary of the invasion of the Soviet Union by Germany in World War II again stressed the familiar party line that Russia defeated Germany (and, for good measure, Japan) single-handed.

RIVER EDGE, N. J., June 23 -- Speed violators will convict themselves automatically through the recordings of an electric watch system that goes into operation officially here tomorrow. As this mechanical detective is portable, its locations will remain a police secret so motorists will not know the routes under surveillance.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 23 -- California's seventy delegates to the Republican National Convention, pledged to Gov. Earl Warren, lean heavily toward General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower as a second choice, a reliable source said today.

FRANKFORT, Ky., June 23 (UP) -- Edward F. Prichard Jr., former national treasurer of the Democratic party, who went to prison for stuffing election ballot boxes and whose sentence was reduced by President Truman, has been restored to citizenship and may seek reinstatement as an attorney.

A concern for contemporary storage problems is apparent in a small collection of night tables and chests, all walnut and all executed in French Provincial style, now on view at Mittman, 316 East Fifty-third Street. The furniture is available through decorators.

At the end of the current week about 9,100,000 tons of steel will have been lost in the steel strike in late April, early May and June, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The loss up to the week starting June 23 was about 7,253,000 tons of ingots and steel for castings.

The chemical industry should not "hide its light under a bushel," Charles S. Munson, newly elected president, told the Manufacturing Chemists Association's annual meeting in White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., yesterday. He was succeeded as chairman of the association by William H. Ward, vice president of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc.

BRIGHAM CITY, Utah, June 23 -- Representatives of Western Indian tribes, concluding the first of three "self-help community development workshops" today called upon the Bureau of Indian Affairs and their own tribal councils to look to development of small on-the-reservation industries.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 23 -- The Soviet Union succeeded today in temporarily blocking discussion in the United Nations Security Council of a United States resolution calling for a Red Cross investigation of Communist charges that United Nations forces in Korea had used bacteriological warfare.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The President's Materials Policy Commission reported today that developing shortages and mounting costs of raw materials had raised grave questions for the nation's security and living standards and called for coordinated development and use of resources by all free nations.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 23 --Japan's application for membership in the United Nations was submitted today by Hisanaga Shimadzu, Japanese Consul General in New York, and Toshio Yamanaka, Consul.
New York Harbor pulled out all the stops yesterday in greeting to the new ocean queen, the superliner United States.

Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer described the trim new superliner United States as the "fastest and most perfect" in the world when he arrived here on the ship yesterday and added that the "United States can't expect to get a ship so magnificent without paying a substantial premium for it."

THE completion of the last link in the Hatteras highway should open that long, thin island to thousands of anglers and gunners who were not equipped to "run the beach." According to a letter from Aycock Brown, chronicler of the Outer Banks, the rush of sportsmen started the day the road was opened.

An officer of the Fire Patrol and two firemen were taken to hospitals and seven other firemen received medical attention for smoke poisoning and minor injuries at a stubborn blaze that started shortly after 7 o'clock last night in a large three-story brick factory building at 925 Bergen Street, between Franklin and Classon Avenues, Brooklyn.
Eleven banking syndicates competed yesterday for the award of three issues of public utility securities totaling $24,000,000 that were put up for sale at public bidding. The awards were as follows:

Admiral Alan G. Kirk, former United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union, has succeeded in unifying ten organizations of Soviet exile for joint propaganda action against the Stalinist regime, it became known yesterday.

There could be no more unkempt or more foul-looking spot in New York City's residential area than the vital park at East Forty-ninth Street facing the river. An overhead pass has been completed there, enabling a few adults to cross the East River Drive safely and to enjoy a closer view of the river.

There doesn't seem to be too much disagreement about the basic facts in the Taft-Eisenhower battle for the thirty-eight delegates from Texas to the Republican National Convention. Early this year the State Executive Committee decided that voters who wanted to take active part in the G. O. P. had to sign this pledge: "I am a Republican and desire to participate in the Republican party activities in 1952."
WIMBLEDON, England, June 23 (AP) -- Results in today's matches in the first round of men's singles in the Wimbledon lawn tennis championships:...

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The Administration was reported today to be ready to reject the application of a small airline to fly regular certificated trans - Atlantic cargo routes on a nonsubsidized basis. The ruling, expected soon, would leave cargo traffic to the regularly scheduled airlines and the nonscheduled, or irregular, carriers.
Eastern Air Lines announced yesterday plans to resume operations at Newark Airport on July 1.
WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- The Petroleum Administration for defense announced today that the steel strike had forced it to quit giving priority aid to wildcat oil well drillers.

The trial of sixteen secondary Communist party leaders in the United States District Court here was adjourned yesterday for another week because of the illness of one of the defendants, a judicial conference and a proceeding before a Federal board.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art gave a press preview yesterday of its first suburban art exhibition, which will open on Sunday at Hofstra College, Hempstead, L. I.
WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- Mr. Hamilton accused Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey today of "dangling" state appointments before delegates in an effort to woo them away from the Senator.
PHILADELPHIA, June 23 -- The American Psysical Therapy Association elected Lieut Col. Harriet S. Lee as its president here today.
DENVER, June 23 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower said tonight that "peace may well be at stake" in the present Presidential election campaign.

Glenn Stanton, president of the American Institute of Architects, yesterday came to the defense of the construction industry and answered recent criticism concerning its alleged failure to keep pace with general technological progress.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Defense and diplomatic officials recognized today the big air raid on power installations in North Korea as a major operation. But they shied from any official comment on speculation that this action grew out of the stalemate in peace talks in Panmunjom.

LONDON, June 23 -- Tokyo reports that the Japanese might hedge on dollar clauses at the debt settlement conference brought declines of around seven points in Japanese bonds here today. In other sections of the stock market business was small but prices were a little steadier than last week.

After the chilly week-end, the problem of preparing party dinners that do not overheat a small city apartment hardly seems pressing. But hot summer nights are bound to come -- and soon. Hence this department has asked two experts, Miss Kathleen Dunning and Russel Wright, to suggest menus that are festive yet do not require much last-minute cooking.
TROY, N. Y., June 23 -- Senator Irving M. Ives attacked the St. Lawrence Seaway today as "a defense liability" to this nation and a costly luxury that might better be built by Canada.

Passenger travel between New York and the east coast of South America is heavier than at any time in the last twenty-five years. Discussing the unprecedented movement yesterday, the two major ocean carriers in this run admitted that bookings for the next two months have already passed their most optimistic expectations.

BAD OEYNHAUSEN, Germany, June 23 (UP) -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway watched maneuvers of his Atlantic Pact troops for the first time today as he began a three-day inspection tour of the half-million Allied frontline soldiers under his command in Germany.

The City Council now has before it, in position for action, a revised bill for establishing a new Department of Air Pollution Control. The measure has been approved by the Committee on General Welfare, which feels that "more efficiency in air pollution control" will result.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, sent to Congress today a student-aid bill to provide direct aid to needy talented students, and a loan system for others.

The House of Representatives has not yet completed action on the extension of the Defense Production Act, but tentatively it has passed a number of amendments which indicate a deplorably irresponsible state of mind.

Jed Harris has signed contracts to direct as well as adapt for the Broadway stage the French comedy, "Si Je Voulais" (to be called "If I Wanted You"). Written by Paul Geraldy and Robert Spitzer, the comedy has been on the production schedule of Arthur Lesser since last December.

Another book about Joseph Stalin is planned for publication a month before Putnam issues Budu Svanidze "My Uncle Joe." It is Lotus Fischer's "The Life and Death of Stalin," which Harper will publish in August. Mr. Fischer has based his work on his fourteen years residence in Soviet Russia and on hitherto suppressed Stalin material, articles, secret speeches and personal letters dating from the Nineteen Twenties.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- The Bureau of Mines is working on new cost estimates for making liquid fuels from coal with more emphasis than ever before on the production of chemicals, a top official said today.

TOKYO, Tuesday, June 24 -More than 500 planes, flying from Korean bases and from the decks of four Navy carriers, yesterday smashed five of North Korea's largest hydroelectric power plants. Spared from attack during the two years of warfare on the peninsula, these plants are the main source of energy for the Manchurian industrial complex near Mukden.

GENEVA, June 20 -- Leon Jouhaux, veteran French labor leader and Nobel Prize winner, has launched a movement designed to break the Communists' monopoly on "peace" as a rallying cry for the discontent in the non-Communist world.

The Home Lines cruise ship Nassau, which has operated between here and the Bahamas since last December, will be removed from this run temporarily in the fall when she is scheduled to make a special round-trip voyage to Israel.

KALIMPONG, India, June 23 -The 15-year-old Panchen Lama, accompanied by officials and a Chinese military escort, reached his spiritual home at Shigatse today after a fifteen-day journey from Lhasa, which included a five-day halt at Gyantse, reports reaching here from Tibet said.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 23 -- Because of America's rapidly increasing population, the nation may face in the foreseeable future a critical food situation unless science can step up food production by preventing some of the waste and loss now being incurred.

As the Korean conflict enters its third year the United Nations Command appears to have embarked on a new initiative intended to demonstrate to the Communists that they have nothing to gain and much to lose by prolonging the present deadlock. Acting on advice from the truce negotiators that firmness and applied military power are necessary to impress the Communists, the United Nations Command is increasing its military pressure.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 23 -The Republican party of Illinois at its state convention today chose ten Taft supporters as delegates at large to the G. O. P. national presidential nominating convention in Chicago next month.

It is well to review the advances of recent years on civil rights, as President Truman did at Howard University on June 13 and as THE TIMES did in its editorial the following day. There has, indeed, been substantial progress. Nevertheless, if the whole picture is examined, it is clear that there is yet no cause for complacency.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- The nation's airlines today modified their ruling that passengers must confirm plane reservations at least six hours before flight time. They listed three exceptions to the ruling and one of them would affect most air passengers.
James E. Day, president of the Midwest Stock Exchange, will confer here next month with officials of the New York Stock Exchange on mutual problems of the two big securities markets.

Joey Maxim, world light-heavyweight champion, and Ray Robinson, holder of the world welterweight title, hit the scales "right on the button" when they weighed yesterday noon for their scheduled light-heavyweight title match at the Yankee Stadium, but the traditional ceremony became an empty gesture when rain forced a postponement of their meeting until tomorrow night.

A children's theatre workshop for 9-to-12-year-old youngsters will open next Monday at the Village Presbyterian Church House, 139 West Thirteenth Street. The program will be conducted in the manner of a day camp Mondays through Fridays from 9 A. M. to 5 P. M. and will include a variety of activities toward actual theatre productions the children will create for themselves.

BOSTON, June 23 -- Sinclair Weeks, chairman of the Republican National Finance Committee, today urged Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio to "save this country" by stepping aside in favor of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Presidential nomination.

The United States Children's Bureau is considering the feasibility of arranging small, intensive conferences among research workers in the child development field as part of the activities of its research clearing house, according to an article in the latest issue of The Child, the bureau's official publication.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 23 -- A former Rumanian diplomat today told a United Nations committee, meeting in closed session, that increasing "economic sabotage" pointed to growing resistance by the Rumanian population against Communist domination.
