GENEVA, June 23 -- In an effort to placate mounting antagonism in free trade union circles to labor legislation proposed by Tokyo, a Japanese Government delegation met here today with officials of the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions to explain "misunderstandings" it says have arisen.
Junior fashions for cruise wear were presented at Franklin Simon last evening, in conjunction with the arrival of the new luxury liner, the United States.
CHICAGO, June 23 (AP) -- Cicero's police chief and two policemen were fined a total of $2,500 today as a result of race riots in the all white suburb last summer.

CLEVELAND, June 23 -- Rabbi Max D. Davidson of Perth Amboy, N. J., president of the Rabbinical Assembly of America, asserted here tonight that American Jews had a twofold task, to advance the cause of freedom, with particular emphasis on our democratic ideals and principles, and "to assure a creative future for their millenial tradition."

A bare line of type in a Pentagon release out of Washington yesterday, expanded to good purpose by the First Army Information Bureau here, finally blossomed into importance and promise under the hopeful research of Brig. Gen. Frank L. Howley, vice chancellor of New York University, in charge of development.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee unanimously approved today the Allied peace contract with West Germany that is designed to bring the Federal Republic into the company of the free world.

MADRID, June 23 -- The Roman Catholic Episcopacy of Spain and the regime of Generalissimo Francisco Franco, after more than six months of intense negotiations, have reached a compromise solution on the question of high school education, which for a time had seriously strained church and state relations here.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 23 -- A tense situation arose in the South African Parliament today when Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan proposed a motion for a sweeping limitation of debates.

KARLSRUHE, Germany, June 23 (Reuters) -- Maria Knuth, 42-year-old dark-haired German actress accused of trying to obtain secret plans of projected West German military units, is to be charged with espionage, the Federal prosecutor said today.

MANILA, June 23 -- President Elpidio Quirino called the Philippine Congress into special session today to complete the unfinished work of its regular session. This included approval of next year's budget, of a $16,000,000 counterpart fund linked to United States financial assistance, several important tax extension measures and Senate ratification of the Japanese peace treaty.

The 250-year-old Ackerman homestead in Hackensack, N. J., is to, give way to a super-market. The property, which fronts 325 feet on the north side of Essex Street, has been purchased by Safeway Stores, Inc., from Edward A. and Frances P. MacDonald in a transaction negotiated by J. I. Kislak, Inc., as broker.

A demand for a $200,000 award against the General Cable Corporation made by the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, independent, based on an alleged lockout by the company has been turned down in an arbitration decision by James J. Healy, Professor of Law at Harvard University.

Maj. Gen. Courtney Whitney, spokesman for General of the Army Douglas MacArthur, denied yesterday that General MacArthur had ever considered supporting General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Presidency in 1952.
MIAMI, Fla., June 23 (AP) -- Independent stores handle almost two-thirds of the nation's grocery business, Gerard Klomp, president, of the National Association of Retail Grocers, said today.

SPOKANE, Wash., June 23 -Joseph Stalin was depicted tonight by Averell Harriman, Director for Mutual Security, as "looking at the American election of 1952 with the hope that the policies of the Republican Old Guard will regain control of the country."

NEWARK, June 23 -- Five Essex County breweries were forced to halt operations today when personnel refused to cross picket lines of Lodge 340, International Association of Machinists, A. F. L. The machinists quit Saturday in a wage dispute with the New Jersey Brewers Association. The stoppage, it was estimated, affected 7,500 workers.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 23 -- A go-ahead signal was given in the United Nations today for the preparation of detailed plans for an international development fund to supply financial help to economically retarded countries.
SINGAPORE, June 23 -- Malcolm MacDonald, top British diplomat in South Asia, said today it was time to break the tyranny of the dinner jacket in this sweltering climate.
DETROIT, June 23 (AP) -- Auto manufacturers are likely to have to revise much of their forward planning because of the steel tie up.

WASHIINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- Banks insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation will get back more than $70,000,000 of the $120,000,000 they paid as assessments for insurance in 1951, the corporation announced today.

LONDON, June 23 -- The Government hopes that in the next decade the British Broadcasting Corporation will introduce color television and international television transmission and largely replace medium wave with very high frequency sound broadcasts, L. D. Gammans, assistant postmaster general, said in the House of Commons today.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -President Truman warned today that a "terrible disaster" would result if funds for the Air Force's program of globe-circling air bases were slashed by 50 per cent, as rumored in Congressional quarters.

Stylists in leading hair salons have just issued their forecasts for fall, with longer hair underscored for coiffures in the autumn. With lengths varying from four to eight inches from the crown of the head, the new hair styles present a refreshing change from the popular poodle cut with its ducktail back.

CHICAGO, June 23 -- Paul V. Galvin, president of Motorola, Inc., predicted today that 40,000,000 television sets will be in use in this country by 1957. Nothing will have a greater influence on the minds and actions of the American public than television from now on, he said.

Awards of $10,000 each will be offered by the Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation to the first ten universities or other organizations to set up educational, noncommercial television stations, Benjamin Abrams, president of the corporation, announced yesterday.

The first announced break in the New York State delegation to the Republican National Convention since the primary came yesterday with a statement by Richard Neville, one of two delegates from the Nineteenth Congressional District, that he planned to support Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio for the Presidential nomination.
The Montague Hotel, a Brooklyn Heights relic of the mauve decade, was ordered vacated last night as a fire hazard by Fire Commissioner Jacob Grumet.

I have just returned from French Equatorial Africa, and have had my attention drawn to the article by your correspondent Michael Clark which appeared on June 1 under the headline, "Schweitzer's Role in Africa Passing." The implication of the article followed the headline and concluded that the famous Lambarene Hospital was really becoming superfluous and would vanish, and quite properly so, upon the death of Dr. Albert Schweitzer.

Three detectives of the Narcotics Squad, including a woman disguised as a flashily dressed showgirl with two others posing as junk collectors, yesterday brought about the arrest or six persons in Harlem. The prisoners were charged with the possession of illicit drugs.

It was learned yesterday that Dr. Harry N. Wright, president of City College, had relieved three key members of the Hygiene Department of their duties "in line with our policy of revamping and modifying our athletic program."

Five graduates of city high schools, whose scores in college entrance examinations placed them in the top 1 per cent of the country's secondary school graduates, were awarded yesterday Grand Street Boys Foundation Maintenance Scholarships of $1,200 a year for four years.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, June 23 -- With a warning to Britain to abandon hope that oil nationalization would "disappear with me," Premier Mohammed Mossadegh left for home today aboard a Dutch airliner at the close of the two-week hearing by the International Court of Justice on whether it had jurisdiction in the British-Iranian dispute.

The new one-story building containing 11,000 square feet of space at 58-15 Fifty-seventh Road, Maspeth, Queens, has been leased by the Eastern Container Corporation of Springfield, Mass., from the Rust Realty Company. The Cross Brown Company was the broker.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- A House Judiciary subcommittee began hearings today on whether the Department of Justice had been diligent or superficial in investigating charges that the major liquor distillers had violated the anti-trust laws.

CLEVELAND, June 23 -- Red Cross chapters that have merged with federated fund-raising groups in their communities heard a cease-and-desist warning today from E. Roland Harriman, national president of the American Red Cross.
ALBANY, June 23 (UP) -- Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein joined Governor Dewey today in rejecting proposals to establish a dental group-insurance policy similar to group-health policies.
LONDON, June 23 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson arrived here today for talks with the British and French foreign ministers on what he called "the great common task" of their three countries.

The nation's mutual savings bank depositors increased their holdings by $137,000,000 last month to a total of $21,572,000,000. Almost doubling the gain of $72,000,000 registered in May, 1951, the expansion was the largest on record.
TOKYO, June 23 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,289, to 6 A. M., Monday, Korea time:

Opinion in advertising circles was divided yesterday as to who would get the $4,000,000 portion of the Kellogg Company account now handled by Kenyon Eckhardt, Inc., which the agency has resigned effective Oct. 1. K. E. handled domestically such products as All-Bran, Raisin Bran Flakes, Shredded Wheat and Gro-Pup Dog Food as well as Kellogg products in Canada.
The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned easier yesterday, with emphasis on the old July delivery.

Some of the major difficulties that have disturbed harmonious relations between the American Federation of Labor and the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions are reported to have yielded in face-to-face conversations between leaders of both organizations in Washington.

HELMSTEDT, Germany, June 23 -- British soldiers backed up reinforced West German policemen at a disputed frontier point near here today in defiance of Communist orders to keep away following the kidnapping of forty-three West German workmen.

Congress, Army and Navy procurement services and a major business organization were accused last night of inaction in the matter of aiding small business concerns to obtain a fair share of defense contracts.

A hint that the luxury liner, the United States, will seek to wrest the trans-Atlantic speed title from the Cunard liner Queen Mary was voiced last night by Commodore Harry Manning, skipper of the new ocean grayhound.
Following is the text of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's radio and television fireside chat last night as transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES.
Technical know-how being developed in mobile power units for military purposes may make economically possible the building of plants primarily for the production of electric power from atomic energy.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 23 -United States Ambassador Edward J. Sparks called on President Victor Paz Estenssoro today and, according to a United States mining source here, asked guarantees of personal safety for United States citizens working at the Bolivian mines.

ST. LOUIS, June 23 -- Hits, runs and errors -- with pitchers to match -- were cheap at Sportsman's Park tonight as the Yankees, after any number of unusual twists, put an end to the nonsense and registered a 14-10 victory over the Browns. Everyone, including the losers, was relieved at the finish of a three-hour twenty-two-minute comedy that just was not funny.

Central Soya Company, Inc., one of the three largest domestic processors of soybeans and the leading producer of concentrates for livestock and poultry feeding, increased sales by 13 per cent in the nine months ended with May, but earnings declined under the pressure of higher operating costs.

BOSTON, June 23 (AP) -- The Braves broke up a close ball game in the eighth inning tonight when, aided by three Pittsburgh errors, they scored five times and emerged with a 9-3 victory over the last-place Pirates.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The Senate adopted by voice vote late today the resolution to give Puerto Rico its own constitution and commonwealth status, but with more reservations than the House of Representatives voted last month. The measure now goes to conference for adjustment of differences between the two houses.

Judge Harold R. Medina, who is presiding over the investment banking anti-trust trial at the United States District Courthouse, here, ruled yesterday against the contention of Government counsel that hearsay is admissible as evidence if used by a complaining witness to explain his reasons for believing trade restrains were used against him.

Erna F. Sievers of Cincinnati, Ohio, has sold the six-story apartment house at 222 East Sixty-seventh Street to the 41 Fulton Street Corporation, represented by William J. McNulty, attorney. The Cruikshank Company was the broker and the Title Guarantee and Title Company insured title.

BALTIMORE, June 23 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio asserted tonight that he would have the votes of nine to sixteen of Maryland's twenty-four delegates in the Republican National Convention after they were released by Gov. Theodore R. McKeldin, a favorite son candidate.

The lively and handsome decor of the sleek new flagship of the United States Lines posed a problem for the decorators that has required the utmost skill of both artist and technician. For the rigid requirements of the naval architects' plan for a fireproof superliner extend to the murals and sculpture, the pictures, the fabrics, floor coverings, and even to the filling of chairs, sofas, and beds.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 23 -- Stanley S. La Benskey of Yonkers, who was acquitted here June 11 on charges of first-degree murder for the slaying of two Negroes outside a Yonkers tavern on March 19, pleaded not guilty in County Court today to a new indictment charging illegal possession of firearms. He had pleaded self-defense in the slayings.

The National Broadcasting Company announced yesterday the sale of radio station KOA, Denver, to a group of Denver citizens and Bob Hope and his associates. The price was quoted at $2,250,000. The sale is subject to approval by the Federal Communications Commission.

LONDON, June 23 (Reuters) -- A record innings of 184 by Vinoo Mankad helped India avert an innings defeat on the fourth day of the second international cricket test. But at close of play today England, with one second innings wicket down, needed only thirty-seven runs to win.

Now that the school year is over, there again has ended one of the more disturbing, ever-present incidents of the modern educational system. This is not, as might be supposed, the request for aid in finishing the home work no parent possibly can comprehend, let alone solve.

The amateur camera fan need not worry over supplies for his hobby. Despite a 200 per cent increase in defense orders, Robert E. Lewis, yesterday elected president of the National Association of Photographic Manufacturers, predicted ample photographic and optical equipment for civilians unless the world situation worsens.

PUSAN, Korea, Tuesday, June 24 (AP) -- A hunger strike against the Korean National Assembly was begun yesterday by 500 Provincial Council members. They squatted on straw mats in front of President Syngman Rhee's hillside residence for more than twenty-one hours.

At least 70,000 volunteer aircraft spotters are needed immediately to man observation posts throughout the state in response to an Air Force request for a twenty-four-hour plane-spotting service beginning July 14, Lieut. Gen. Clarence R. Huebner, state civil defense director, declared yesterday.

CATSKILL, N. Y., June 23 -- A warning that a prolonged steel strike would materially delay completion of the main 435-mile route of the New York State Thruway, slated for completion late in 1954, was sounded today by Bertram D. Tallamy, chairman of the Authority in charge of the project.

The Foreign Bondholders Protective Council has withdrawn its representatives from London discussions aimed at settling Germany's external indebtedness under the Dawes and Young Plans because of disagreement involving a basis for settlement reached by the German negotiators and those of European creditors.

Formation of a new committee, headed by Walter L. Fleisher, consulting engineer of 475 Fifth Avenue, to advise the Board of Smoke Control on technical questions involved in the city's war on smoke was announced yesterday by William G. Christy, director of the Smoke Control Bureau.

In his first address as president-elect of City College, Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, Assistant United States Commissioner for Higher Education, last evening compared the long tension between Sparta and Athens in the fifth century B. C. with the strain between totalitarianism and democracy today.

The Suntide Refining Company, in which the Sunray Oil Corporation has an interest, announced yesterday plans for the construction of a modern refinery with a capacity of 25,000 barrels a day at Corpus Christi, Tex. When completed late in the summer of 1953, the refinery will represent an investment of $15,000,000.
DETROIT, June 23 (AP) -- The Red Sox scored eleven runs in a wild fourth inning to crush the Tigers, 12 -- 6, today and slip into second place in the American League race.

Leopold Groenhut has purchased the one-story factory at 898 Kent Avenue, Brooklyn, from the Irving Hosier Mills and will occupy it for the manufacture of novelty chocolate candies after alterations have been completed. Queens Industrials was the broker and the attorneys were Lowenbraun Lowell for the seller and Julius Kaplan for the buyer.

Trading in zinc futures was resumed on the New York Commodity Exchange yesterday after a lapse of nearly eleven months. Transactions were suspended last July 27 because of Government controls and restrictions on the metal.

A determined bid by Svetozar Gligoric of Belgrade failed in the tenth and final game of his match with Samuel Reshevsky of New York at the Manhatan Chess Club yesterday. The contest, adjourned Sunday night, ended in a draw after seventy-six moves. As a result Reshevsky maintained his one-point margin and took the match by a score of 5 1/2 -- 4 1/2.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., June 23 -- The Westchester Professional Golfers Association tournament at the Quaker Ridge G. C. today drew 111 teams, a record for its pro-amateur events, and two of them tied for best-ball honors with five-under-par cards of 65.

THE great campaigns of the last war were fought by millions of men using astronomical quantities of technical equipment. But no matter how total the nature of war becomes or how great the masses involved there will always be fringe activities, little sideshows a long way from the main tent where a few men face death on an individual basis.

Charles E. Wilson, former president of the General Electric Company, and Alan S. Rupley, a vice president and treasurer of W. R. Grace Co., were elected yesterday directors of the international industrial and trading concern.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Mrs. Oscar A. Ahlgren, president of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, today said that she had just one big legislative objective for her two-year term -- making American history a required subject in high schools and colleges in states not now having such a law.
WASHINGTON, June 23 (UP) -Allan R. Rosenberg, a former Government official, refused today to admit or deny that he was ever a member of a wartime Communist spy ring here.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 23 -- Twelve United States newspaper men were named today for a year of study at Harvard University as Nieman Fellows. Three British Commonwealth newspaper men also were named for Associate Nieman Fellowships.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 23 -- Rain fell today, but none of the fifty-nine players trying for places in the twenty-second annual Women's Long Island Golf Association championship over the Meadow Brook course seemed bothered by it as Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson of Cherry Valley won the medal with an even-par 35, 36 -- 71.

For motorists the task of applying for $5 and $10 automobile use tax stamps became more complicated yesterday, but in spite of that the city had collected $41,815 from sales of these stickers up to 3 P. M. The day's proceeds from 6,882 stickers brought the total since June 2 to $8,071,825.

NEW DELHI, India, June 23 -- G. V. Mavalankar, Speaker of the House of the People, the lower house of Parliament, today ordered an inquiry by a Parliamentary committee on privileges into the authenticity of allegations made by a Congress party member that the Indian Communist party was acting under direct instructions from the Cominform.

LOUISVILLE, June 23 -- Ted Kroll of New Hartford, N. Y., who has been rebuilding his game the last seven years following his discharge from the Army, today gained the semi-final round of the Professional Golfers Association championship by defeating Cary Middlecoff, 1 up, at the thirty-eighth hole.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., June 23--An upstate newspaper, defending itself against a $500,000 libel suit by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, brought out today that major American periodicals had criticized him for his tactics in anti-Communist campaigns -- and heard the Senator denounce most of them for "left-wing smears."

TOKYO, Tuesday, June 24 -- Communist armistice negotiators at Panmunjom assumed a threatening attitude today, warning the United Nations Command that a "dangerous step" had been taken with the Allied action in again polling war prisoners on Koje Island to determine how many wished to return after a truce to Communist territory.

ELIZABETH, N. J., June 23 -- Joseph V. Casino Jr., 28-year-old Army Air Force veteran of 16 West Morris Avenue, Linden, whose troublesome appendix was frozen with drugs to permit him to leave the Alexian Brothers Hospital here for several hours to be married Saturday, underwent an appendectomy this afternoon.

CHICAGO, June 23 (UP) -- Frank (Spec) Shea lasted only six and one-third innings against the White Sox, but he gained his fifth victory as the Senators belted three Chicago hurlers for eleven hits and a 6-to-4 triumph today.

Fifteen persons were injured yesterday when a city-owned Gates Avenue bus and a private car collided at 2:15 P. M. at Quincy Street and Nostrand Avenue, Brooklyn. Only one of the injured persons remained at a hospital after treatment.

Macdonald Goodwin has been appointed manager of government land export sales of the Bogue Electric Manufacturing Company and Sylvain Garnett has been named a staff assistant to the vice president in charge of engineering.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 23 -- Box-office receipts at motion-picture theatres in Los Angeles and surrounding areas stood up better than anticipated in the face of television's all-out invasion Saturday night, with Bob Hope and Bing Crosby leading a parade of stars in raising funds to send American athletes to the Olympic Games at Helsinki.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Senate's leaders moved decisively today to assure ratification of the Allied peace and defensive agreements with West Germany before the adjournment of this election-year Congress.

BONN, Germany, June 24 -- The ultimate objective of Russian policy toward Germany indicated by the pattern of recent events in Berlin, East Germany and Moscow appears to be the creation in a divided Germany of a situation similar to that prevailing in Korea before the North Korean attack two years ago tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- "Rescue Street," built to resemble an atom bomb ruins, is 85 per cent complete at the Civil Defense Staff College at near-by Olney, Md.

LOUISVILLE, June 24 -- Jim Turnesa of the famed golfing family gained the final of the Professional Golfers Association tournament for the second time today. We will meet Melvin (Chick) Harbert of Northville, Mich., for the title tomorrow.

BRIELLE, N. J., June 24 -- When we hit the beach this morning, just as a thin ribbon of light became visible in the east, we were confronted with an omen that was both encouraging and discouraging -- another surfcaster leaving for home with two striped bass.

EVANSTON, Ill., June 24 (AP) -- Top - seeded Hugh Stewart of Southern California advanced to the third round without competition and three seeded stars were eliminated in today's first and second-round play of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tennis tourney.

Holland's election campaign, which ends at the polls today, has been as phlegmatic and unexciting as ours is effervescent and exciting. It is not only a case of Dutch phlegm and orderliness; it so happens that little change is expected.

A 2-year-old girl was fatally injured and her sister, brother and a 'teen-age relative were critically hurt when they accidentally plunged out of a fifth-floor window in a lower East Side tenement to the bottom of an air-shaft at 5 P. M. yesterday.

The one-story taxpayer building at 319-29 Kings Highway, Brooklyn has been sold by the L. L. F. Realty Company to an investing client of Daniel D. Cantor, broker in the transaction. Constructed twelve years ago, the building occupies a plot 100 by 100 feet and contains an A. P. supermarket and three other stores.

A dozen little girls in rolling carts or lying straight in their beds recited the Girl Scout promise yesterday and thus activated the Girl Scout troop of Bellevue Hospital, the first of its kind in recent years here.

Joseph M. Mahoney stared from his thirty-third floor office in the New York Central Railroad Building at 230 Park Avenue yesterday on a scene that has changed tremendously since he came with the road fifty-two years ago.
DENVER, June 24 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower launched a campaign today for an internationalist Republican foreign policy plank.

As a vital step in stabilizing metropolitan property values and providing better environment for city residents, the American Institute of Architects yesterday called on the Federal Government to take the leadership in a long-range program to create more open space in the nation's population centers.

PUSAN, Wednesday, June 25 (AP) -- Yesterday Dr. Rhee said in an interview that he would defy his enemies, friends and Korea's Constitution in order to build a "firmer base of democracy" in South Korea.

ST. LOUIS, June 24 -- Bill Veeck, the front-office guiding genius of the Browns, had only one consolation tonight as he watched his athletes drop an 8-3 decision to the Yankee. There were 12,575 customers at Sportsman's Park and, with forty home games still to go, his Brownies have played before an aggregate of 296,596 fans. In all of 1951, only 293,790 saw the club play at home.
Pressure on wholesale beef prices in the New York market was renewed yesterday after a week in which cattle prices in the Chicago livestock market declined to the lowest levels since late 1950.

Mostest got there first under the direction of Willie Boland in the Gravesend Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. Catching the pacesetting Standee at the sixteenth pole, the T. G. Benson 5-year-old scored by two lengths in the mile- and-a-sixteenth event.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Attorney General James P. McGranery said today he would begin his investigation of the subsidy dispute over the liner United States in a conference next Tuesday with Lindsay C. Warren, the Controller General.

A year-long stretch of picking "also-rans" that resulted in a loss of $85,000 was described yesterday as the cause of grand larceny and forgery charges against a 34-year- old managing rental agent who is accused of stealing the money from his employers.

The Dow Chemical Company plans a public offering of $100,000,000 of convertible debentures, it was announced yesterday. Dated July 1, 1952, and maturing July 1, 1982, the debentures will be convertible into common stock of the company at prices to be named by amendment to the registration statement filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Withdrawal of the representative of the Foreign Bondholders Protective Council from London negotiations for settlement of Germany's external indebtedness under the Dawes and Young Plans drew an expression of regret today from Warren Lee Pierson, the United States delegate to the conference.

The strike in the steel-making industry is beginning to be felt by the railroads in virtually every section of the country. Of course, the railroads in the East are most heavily hit, but, as general industrial activity is curtailed because of the lack of steel, roads in every section are being affected indirectly.

Sumptuously produced by two masters of the craft, Leland Hayward and Joshua Logan, "Wish You Were Here" will seek to fulfill the obligtaions of an inviting title, starting at 8 o'clock this evening at the Imperial. To make the occasion a gala one, the Shuberts have redecorated the house inside and out.
INDIANAPOLIS, June 24 (AP) -- Indiana Democrats lined up almost solidly behind Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois today for the party's Presidential nomination.

HERSHEY, Pa., June 24 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio charged today that General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower chose to do battle with "a straw man in the form of an isolationist, presumably a Republican," rather than attack the "complete failure" of the Administration on foreign policy.

Looking southward along Park Avenue from one of those islands in the traffic, planted in green things between the cross streets and covering up the railway tracks below, provides a spectacular sample of New York architecture reaching back for half a century -- period pieces of each decade, including survivals of the days before the tracks were decked over and the railway ran in an open cut, slicing the two sides apart.

RYE, N. Y., June 24 -- When the filet round of the forty-eighth annual United States Seniors' Golf Association championship was concluded today, Thomas C Robbins of Winged Foot and the Rev. Francis Ryan of Wheatley Hills, were tied for the lead with a one-over-par 73 on the Apawamis club course.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Imported copper, copper refined from foreign ores and scrap copper from abroad were exempted from price controls today, by the Office of Price Stabilization, on condition that proper records subject to inspection by the agency are maintained.

OSAKA, Japan, Wednesday, June 25 -- Rioting Communist demonstrators hurling flaming Molotov cocktails, attacked a compound housing American women and children here today and threw acid in the face of a United States General.

CARLSTADT, N. J., June 24 -- High-ranking pilots and engineers of twelve international and domestic airlines gathered here today to study a new flight-crew training device which, it was said, would increase the safety factor of regular airline operations.

The United States Radiator Corporation has announced the election of Roland P. Place and W. C. McCord as chairman and president, respectively. Both offices were previously held by Wesley J. Peoples, who will continue as a director and as advisor and as consultant.

PHOENIX, Ariz., June 24 (AP) -- Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia angrily denied today a charge that he had aided a conspiracy to keep the Democratic nomination for President from Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee.

Mayor Impellitteri named six members of his official family yesterday as a committee headed by City Construction Coordinator Robert Moses to solve the problem presented by the existence of 54,155 old-law tenements in the city.

BOSTON, June 24 -- Former Gov. Robert F. Bradford was listed today as the second of Massachusetts' six uncommitted convention delegates to declare himself in favor of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower as the Republican nominee for President.

The International Ladies Garment Workers Union, which has made trade union history on many occasions, continues to add to its laurels. Its annual financial report, just published, is not only a model which could well be emulated by large corporations with greater resources but is unique in trade union annals.

Underwriting syndicates will make public offering today of corporate securities valued at more than 54,000,000. Included are mortgage bonds of public utility companies, debentures of a telephone company, and convertible preferred stock of a food distribution enterprise.

If the Taft forces in Texas can prove what they claim (and they seem to have the evidence) General Eisenhower's first test vote in the convention will be on his support of the proposition that avowed Democrats have the moral right to take physical possession of Republican caucuses, name delegates to Republican conventions, and then return to the Democratic ranks and resume their party duties as Democrats.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- Substantial price upturns in wheat and corn featured the trading in grain on the Board of Trade today. Corn led the upward procession, rye and oats also joining. The corn buying was due to rumors that the Government might stop selling corn because of a shortage of box cars, which are needed badly for handling wheat.

The stock market was caught yesterday between opposing forces which resulted in a highly irregular pattern but prices were moderately improved at the end. The closing level was only slightly above that of the previous day, when late realizing cut the gains, and the combined averages of THE NEW YORK TIMES index rose 0.29 point. Few stocks did better.

BOSTON, June 24 (AP) -- Pitcher Jim Wilson scored the deciding run in the ninth inning tonight while hurling the Braves to a 4-3 victory over the Pirates. Gus Bell's eighth-inning homer accounted for all of the Pirates' tallies.

PUSAN, Korea, Wednesday, June 25 -- South Korean President Syngman Rhee narrowly escaped death today when he was attacked by a would-be assassin wielding an automatic pistol before the eyes of United States Ambassador John J. Muccio and 50,000 Koreans.

CHICAGO, June 24 (AP) -- The Senators tonight clubbed five White Sox pitchers for a 6-2 victory and toppled Chicago from a third-place tie to fourth in the league race. Julio Moreno, Cuban right-hander, holding Chicago to five hits, allowed only one safe blow after the third inning.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 24 -- France came forward today with a "middle of the road" timetable for disarmament aimed at reducing the major differences between the Soviet Union and the West.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Following is the text of a June 10 letter from Joe Ingraham, chairman of the Harris County, Tex., Republican Committee, to William H. Worrilow of Lebanon, Pa., a Pensylvania delegate, as released by the Eisenhower headquarters here:

LONDON, June 24 (Reuters) -- Britain is exporting more cars and commercial vehicles than any other country in the world -- including the United States -- the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders said today.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Faced by new restrictive laws, the Communist party continued to go further underground during the fiscal year ending June 30, 1951, J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today. Estimated party membership dropped from 51,785 in the previous fiscal year to 37,000 in the period for which he reported.

Another shopping center on Long Island is planned by Irving Berger and Gilbert Tilles, builders, who have purchased a plot 250 by 600 feet at the northeast corner of Hicksville and Merrick Roads in Massapequa from Ben Okum. Thanhauser Brown were the brokers.

Worthington Miner, the producer, director and adapter, who founded "Studio One" during his association with the Columbia Broadcasting System, has switched his allegiance to the National Broadcasting Company. In the fall, he is scheduled to have his own one-hour drama program, but pending that event, he is keeping his hand in with a new series called "Curtain Call" (8 P. M. Fridays over Channel 4).

LONDON, June 24 (Reuters) -- The Soviet Union protested today to the United States and Britain against the new arrangements in the British-American zone A of Trieste that give Italy a greater share in running the former Italian territory.

TOKYO, Wednesday, June 25 (AP) -- Seven hundred Korean laborers rolled into the big Japanese city of Osaka today on a commandeered passenger train and fought a pitched battle with police on the second anniversary of the Korean war.
TOKYO, Wednesday, June 25 (AP) -- Eighth Army tactical summary 98, for Tuesday:

On Michael Myerberg's memo pad for tomorrow are two appointments -- luncheon with Faye Emerson and dinner with Ilka Chase. In each instance, the conversation will center around Mr. Myer-I berg's next presentation of Andrew Rosenthal's play, "Third Person," containing roles suitable for the two actresses.
CHICAGO, June 24 (AP) -- Eddie Arcaro, 36-year-old veteran of twenty-one riding seasons, today became the first American-born jockey to boot home 3,000 thoroughbred winners.

A mass departmental trial of thirty - four policemen, ranking from patrolmen to captains, was set yesterday for July 22, to ascertain whether they had accepted graft from Harry Gross to protect his $20,000,000-a-year bookmaking business.

An attack on the Federal Trade Commission as a "political propaganda agency building up prejudice against business and particularly what it calls big business" was made here yesterday by Dr. Robert E. Wilson of Chicago, chairman of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana), before a luncheon meeting of the United States Trade-Mark Association at the Hotel Pierre.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- The Defense Department today identified 96 Korea battle casualties in a list that reported 23 killed, 67 wounded and 6 injured. The following casualties were listed from New York and New Jersey (none from Connecticut):
Most commodity futures on the exchanges here followed a mixed and comparatively narrow course yesterday in moderate trading.

TOKYO, Wednesday, June 25 -- Planes from four big Navy carriers off the Korean coast struck again yesterday at the important hydroelectric power plants in northeast Korea that were battered in Monday's massive bombing attack.

As Congress engaged in its pre-convention clean-up, foreign traders looked yesterday for at least a modification of the import quota restrictions proposed for continuance in the new Defense Production Act. These concern chiefly the curbs placed last August on foreign cheese as a result of a last-minute "rider" attached to the old defense measure, which expires on Monday.

TACOMA, Wash., June 24 -- Isolationism exists as much as ever in this country and is more dangerous than ever despite Republican talk that there is "no such thing any more" as isolationism, Averell Harriman told a Jefferson-Jackson Day dinner audience here tonight as he ended a day of campaigning in the Puget Sound area for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

Six cooperatives of dairy farmers in the New York milkshed have been suspended from the benefits of the Federal-state price-fixing pool for various infractions of the rules, Charles J. Blanford, administrator of the New York Metropolitan Milk Market, announced yesterday.
The new Japanese motor freighter Awobasan Maru will dock here today, doubling the frequency of Mitsui Lines sailings between New York and the Far East.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 24 -- All immediate plans for construction of a natural gas pipeline across Westchester County by the Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation and the development of a $1,000,000 compressor station in a residential area of Rye were canceled today.

LONDON, June 24 -- In launching a series of conference here today, Secretary of State Dean Acheson and Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden readily agreed that the Western Allies should be on guard against Soviet maneuvers in Berlin and should act with firmness and unanimity in the face of provocation.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 24 (AP) -- The United States Naval Academy yacht Royono was reported leading the Newport-to-Bermuda yacht race at 5 P. M. tonight.
I trust that you will call to the attention of your readers the bold-faced inaccuracy of the page ad in your June 23 issue supporting the claims of the Taft faction in the Texas primary contest.

In his Denver address on Monday evening General Eisenhower outlined a foreign policy which takes full account of the scope and the character of the Communist menace. This policy, given firm and courageous leadership, can be made a vital, living, driving force, capable of enlisting in its support all free nations.

Ten persons were injured at noon yesterday when a taxicab swerved onto the sidewalk at the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Fiftieth Street. The busy corner is a bus stop outside the Saks Fifth Avenue department store, across the street from St. Patrick's Cathedral and across the avenue from Rockefeller Center.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 24 -- Lord Alexander paid a courtesy call at United Nations headquarters this afternoon before leaving by air for London. Both Lord Alexander and Selwyn Lloyd, British Minister of State, who accompanied him, confined themselves to formal statements for newsreel cameras.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Robert A. Lovett, Secretary of Defense, disclosed today that the Joint Chiefs of Staff, his principal advisers, had given Gen. Mark W. Clark, United Nations Supreme Commander, special permission to order yesterday's air attack on North Korean power installations on the Yalu River.

Confusion over dimensions of the world's largest liners spurred the transfer of many a dollar yesterday, not to mention many a telephone call to newspaper and steamship company offices for accurate information.
LAUSANNE, Switzerland, June 24 -- Communist China has been invited to the Helsinki Olympic Games by mistake, Otto Mayer, chancellor of the International Olympic Committee, disclosed today.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 24 -- The consumer himself, not the Government, is neglecting the consumer, Government experts told the forty-third annual meeting of the American Home Economics Association today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 24 -- Billy Rose, the bantam Broadway showman, is about to take the plunge and become a movie producer. For his initial film effort Mr. Rose has acquired from Oscar Hammerstein 2d the right to "Carmen Jones," the transplanted adaptation of Prosper Merimee's "Carmen," set to the music of Bizet and played with a Negro cast in a Southern locale in this country instead of in Spain.

A jury before Judge Robert A. Inch in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday returned a verdict of $65,000 for Robert H. Rawlins, a 43-year-old seaman, whose right hand was bitten off by a hippopotamus aboard the freighter African Star, owned by the Farrell Lines, Inc., of 26 Beaver Street.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 24 -- A quartet of former Metropolitan champions, Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson of Cherry Valley, Mrs. Mortimer May of Willow Brook, Mrs. Harry McNaughton of Seawane Harbor and Margaret (Peggy) Mackie of Inwood, triumphed in their first round of the twenty-second annual Women's Long Island Golf Association match-play championship at the Meadow Brook Club today.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., June 24 -- Taking office today as City Manager, Aaron Simmons joined with Mayor Stanley W. Church in trying to save the city from nasty charges of reneging on a 1688 promise to give a fat calf every June 24 to the heirs of Sir John Pell.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- A United States spokesman rejected tonight the Soviet Union's protest against the May 9 agreement giving Italy a bigger voice in the administration of the Western zone of Trieste, and retorted that Moscow was trying to make "political and propaganda" capital from the Italian-Yugoslav dispute over the territory.
CLEVELAND, June 24 (AP) -- Al Rosen's 2-run homer snapped Bobby Shantz' victory streak tonight at eleven straight as the Indians, defeated the Athletics, 2 -- 1. A1 Clark homered for the A's.
A good deal of excitement about the Republican National Convention is just plain nonsense.
A preview of fall jewelry and scarf fashions was presented yesterday by the makers of Coro jewelry and Glentex scarfs at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Why Staten Island is sometimes called "the poor man's Bermuda" was seen yesterday by members of the Park Association of New York Ctiy.
HOLLYWOOD, June 24 (UP) -- Ingrid Bergman, Swedish film star, lost her plea today for a court order permitting her 13-year-old daughter to visit her in Italy this summer.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- United States-Russian talks to settle the $11,000,000,000 lend-lease account broke down again today, with the negotiators having failed to reach an agreement on the 186 ships that Moscow tentatively offered to return on June 16.

Members of the Pakistani community and other Moslems marked the end of the holy month of Ramadan yesterday with prayers and a feast conducted by the Pakistan League of America at 82 Clinton Street. The I'd-ul-Fitr observance ended a month of fasting to commemo rate the revelation of the Koran to Mohammed.
CLEVELAND, June 24 -- An Army spokesman today invited the American Red Cross to step up their relief and assistance program in Korea.

LAKENHEATH, England, June 24 (UP) -- A United States B-50 bomber crashed and burned in an open field near Lakenheath today, killing all eleven crew members who had flown here on a training mission from New Mexico.

TEHERAN, Iran, June 24 (AP) -- Wildly cheering Iranians hailed Premier Mohammed Mossadegh as the "savior" of Iran today on his return from debating the British in the International Court of Justice at The Hague for control of the nation's vast oil resources.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Senate Appropriations Committee eliminated from a House-approved bill today a prohibition against the appointment of a diplomatic representative to the Vatican without Senate confirmation.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- A shy baby sitter who saved seven children in a fire, a diminutive Boy Scout who saved a girl from the jaws of an alligator, and a zealous youth who promoted civil defense were honored today.

CLEVELAND, June 24 -- The establishment of "organic Jewish communities" to serve the spiritual, cultural and social needs of American Jews was urged here tonight in a paper submitted to more than 350 spiritual leaders of the Conservative branch of Judaism attending the fifty-second annual convention of the Rabbinical Assembly of America.

William W. Howard, vice presi-t dent of HKO Theatres, announeedI yesterday Mfs. Julian Olney's 1952-1 53 series of outstanding stage at-/ tractions wil! be presentea at theI RKO Keith's Theatre in WhiteI Iplains, srfi, tg in Oetober.

The Interstate Commerce Commission began public hearings yesterday at 641 Washington Street on the petition of seven bus companies operating lines between New York and New Jersey for an increase of 3 to 5 cents over their present fares.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Bethlehem Steel Company and the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., reached an understanding last week that would have ended the steel strike, but the deal was subject to the approval of other major steel companies and they, or a majority of them, refused to go along.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was active yesterday as evening up in the old July position continued on a fairly large scale.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 24 -- Bela Varga, former President of the Hungarian Parliament, today accused Hungarian Communist leaders of committing genocide by sending hundreds of thousands of civilians to slave labor camps, where many, he said, died from inhuman treatment.

ROME, June 24 -- Less than a month after the provincial and municipal elections in central and southern Italy, which revealed a strong resurgence of Fascist sentiment, the Christian Democratic party has undertaken to defend the Italian democratic regime against totalitarianism, both of the right and left.

LONDON, June 24 -- The massed United States air strikes against enemy power plants near the Yalu River frontier between Korea and Manchuria started a noisy and, at times, disorderly dispute in the House of Commons today. During this wrangle the Labor opposition forced Prime Minister Churchill to concede that the action had been taken without prior notice to or consultation with the British Government.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Senate Committee on Labor and Public Welfare approved by a 9 to 3 vote today a new civil rights measure designed to prevent or stop discriminations in employment because of race, color, religion, national origin or ancestry.

The first twilight-night double-header in Polo Grounds history saw the Giants win their first twin victory of the season last night and pick up a full length on the league-leading Dodgers, whom they now trail by four games.

Msgr. John O'Grady, general secretary of the National Conference of Catholic Charities, expressed the fervent hope yesterday that the McCarran Immigration Bill, now awaiting the signature of President Truman, would not become law.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 24 -- A new budget director and two new park commissioners for Westchester were appointed today by County Executive Herbert C. Gerlach. All the appointments are subject to confirmation July 14 by he Board of Supervisors.

BONN, Germany, June 24 -- Many United States officials here have recently expressed privately their concern over what they regard as a possibly dangerous belligerence in political attitude in large sectors of German public opinion.

Is there a milk shortage ahead? We raised this question the other day when we learned that the cow population has been declining while the human population has been increasing. Last year the number of milk cows was the smallest since 1929.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce reported today that retail sales reached a 1952 high in May. It said the rise was caused in part by the May 7 order dropping controls on installment buying.

LONDON, June 24 -- The main body of prices continued to slip on the stock markets today as the volume of business shrank further. Only Japanese bonds and shares with a commodity backing resisted the lower trend.

Engineers can be a potent force for international peace, Truman S. Fuller, retiring president of the American Society for Testing Materials, said yesterday at the second-day sessions of its fiftieth anniversary meeting at the Statler and New Yorker Hotels.

BRIONI ISLAND, Yugoslavia, June 24 -- Dr. Karl Gruber, Austrian Foreign Minister, said today on the completion of his five-day conversations with Premier Marshal Tito and Yugoslav Foreign Office officials that the aim of his visit had been achieved.

Queens will experience the sharpest rise among the boroughs -- 17 cents -- in its tax rate of $3.44 for each $100 of assessed valuation in the fiscal year beginning July 1. The borough rates became known yesterday when they were set by the City Council along with the basic city tax of $3.22 as recommended by Controller Lazarus Joseph.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Representative Kenneth B. Keating of New York passed out "I Am a Republican" buttons to fellow-Republican members of the House of Representatives today in an effort to heal the Taft-Eisenhower dispute.

JERSEY CITY, June 24 -- The wildcat strike of 125 employes of Dade Brothers at the Claremont Terminal Pier operated by the Atlantic District. United States Army Engineers, was ended late this afternoon with the employes, members of Marine Warehousemen's Local 1478, International Longshoremen's Association, scheduled to report at the 7:50 o'clock shape-up tomorrow morning.

The superliner United States, every bulkhead, cabin and public space of which was designed for easy convertibility as a troop carrier, became a member of the Naval Reserve yesterday in a ceremony atop the vessel's massive bridge.

The Museum of Modern Art will open to the public today an exhibition made up of paintings from the personal collection of Captain Molyneux, who long has been identified with world of fashion. The show will run through Sept. 7.

A half-hour dramatic series on film, entitled "Four Star Playhouse," will have its premiere on the C.B.S. television network on Thursday, Sept. 11 at 8:30 P.M. The program will alternate in the time period with "Amos 'n' Andy," under the sponsorship of the Singer Sewing Machine Company Tentatively scheduled to appear in leading roles are Charles Boyer, Rosalind Russell, Joel McCrea and Dick Powell.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Col. Francis S. Gabreski, one of this country's foremost air aces, warned that an "Asiatic Battle of Britain" would develop if the Communists threw all their airpower into the Korean conflict. He said this country would have to win that battle to maintain its position in Korea.

Lucky Strikes are not going to war -- at least in the battle for the king-size cigarette trade, despite the action of Chesterfields in entering the fray. This was revealed yesterday by Paul M. Hahn, president of the American Tobacco Company, maker of Luckies.

City commissioners and agency heads who were publicly upbraided by Mayor Impellitteri last Thursday when they remained away from an "invitation" function at City Hall were on hand in large numbers yesterday at a City Hall affair to which they again had been bidden. The occasion was the Mayor's awarding of certificates of merit to thirty-three record officers in thirty-one city departments.
The Amerian section of the Society of Chemical Industry announced yesterday that Crawford H. Greenewalt, president of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., would receive the Chemical Industry Medal for 1952.
The Brown-Isaacs bill, barring public funds to child-care institutions that discriminate because of race, color or religion, was signed into law yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri.

Two third-grade detectives accused of unlawfully taking $20 from a tavern owner on June 10 were cleared yesterday in Felony Court. Magistrate Thomas H. Cullen Jr. dismissed the charges after Assistant District Attorney Peter D. Andreoli said a grand jury had failed to return an indictment.
The second of five borough-wide Civil Defense drills was held in the Bronx last night, with 1,000 workers taking part in the ninety-minute rehearsal of an atomic bombing.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., June 24 -- The annual convention of the National Association of Secretaries of State opened with a controversy here today over a proposal that the group favor the abolition of the Electoral College system of electing Presidents and Vice Presidents of the United States.

LOS ANGELES, June 24 (AP) -- Negotiators for North American Aviation, Inc., and the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., conferred tonight on a Government request that the union call off a strike due at midnight tomorrow at four plants producing sabre jet fighter planes for Korea.
HAVANA, June 24 -- A Communist attempt to create disorder in Havana streets tonight resulted in the police chief, Gen. Rafael Salas Canizares, throwing out a net to pick up all Communist leaders.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt deplored the "great fear of communism'' in this country in an address yesterday at the opening session of the Board of the International Federation of Business and Professional Women at the Savoy-Plaza Hotel.

On the eve of his departure for France, after a twelve-day visit in New York, Maurice Worth, president of the famed house of Worth in Paris, expressed his admiration for New York and its great dress market.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The National Production Authority today modified its ban on the production of home-type color television sets. The agency warned, however, that defense requirements were still too heavy to allow more than a trickle of color sets.

Sales of the Firestone Tire Rubber Company and its subsidiaries in the six months ended on April 30 increased 3.7 per cent to $465,187,866 from the $448,307,918 volume for the corresponding period of the previous year, but earnings declined.

Twenty-three members of the Lord Taylor department store staff who have completed twenty-five years' service in the last year received gold watches from the store's president, Miss Dorothy Shaver, at a dinner given in their honor last night at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel.

Two former employes of the Bureau of Internal Revenue were indicted yesterday by the special Federal rackets grand jury for making false statements to investigating agents of the Intelligence Unit of the Treasury Department, United States Attorney Myles J. Lane announced.

TOKYO, Wednesday, June 25 -- The United Nations commander, Gen. Mark W. Clark, today warned the Communists that if an armistice failed to result from the long negotiations in Korea and full-scale hostilities were resumed, "we are ready."

LONDON, June 24 -- In a report to the Royal Commission on Marriage and Divorce published today the Modern Churchmen's Union, a body speaking for the liberal wing of the Church of England, took issue with "official" church insistence on the indissolubility of Christian marriage.
SINGAPORE, June 24 -- Observers here believe the creation over last week-end of the first Malaya-wide Chinese political party may have a far reaching effect on political developments in Malaya.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- National headquarters for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower today issued a letter in which an avowed supporter of Senator Robert A. Tan of Ohio said he believed the Eisenhower forces had won "fairly and squarely" a majority of the thirty-eight Texas delegates to the Republican National Convention.
The city of Philadelphia borrowed $10,000,000 in the public market yesterday through an issue of school district serial bonds maturing from 1954 to 1977. The interest cost was 2.2986 per cent.

FARGO, N. D., June 24 (AP) -- Showing strength in early reporting precincts, Senator William Langer moved into a slight lead over Representative Fred Aandahl tonight in their North Dakota primary election contest for the Republican nomination for Mr. Langer's Senate seat. Mr. Aandahl, serving his first term in Congress, had led from the first tabulations.

The American Music Library Association will meet next Monday and Tuesday as part of the week-long national convention of the American Library Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel Dr. Harold Spivacke, music librarian of the Library of Congress, who is president of the Music Library Association, will preside.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- An authoritative Justice Department official today described as "highly unfounded" a report that Prof. Owen Lattimore was planning to visit the Soviet Union or its satellites.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24 (UP) -- Robin Roberts pitched a two-hitter and Russ Meyer and Jim Konstanty combined for a six-hitter as the Phillies swept a twilight-night bill, 6 -- 0 and 2 -- 1, tonight from the Cubs for Chicago's eighth and ninth losses in a row.
Joseph Pulvermacher, president of the Sterling National Bank and Trust Company of New York, will complete fifty years in banking today.

DETROIT, June 24 (AP) -- Virgil Trucks, sweltering in near-record 86-degree temperature, pitched the last-place Tigers to a 7-to-1 victory over the Red Sox and toppled Boston from second to third place tonight before 38,698 fans.

A split was the best the Dodgers could do in their day-and-night battles with the Cardinals at Ebbets Field yesterday. They won the day encounter, 6 -- 0, but the Cards took the night game, 7 -- 4, enabling the twice-victorious Giants to pare the Brooks' first-place lead to four games.
BERLIN, June 24 -- The flow of East German refugees into West Berlin this month may come close to a record, according to figures issued today by the city's refugee office.
LONDON, June 24 (Reuters) -- England today gained a 2-0 lead in the four-match cricket series against India, winning the second game by eight wickets.

Barbara Friedberg, a Beaver College student from Baltimore, and Mrs. Kathryn Moore of New York swept one bracket ahead of the field to gain the quarter-finals of the women's Eastern clay court tennis championship tournament yesterday at the Bayside Tennis and Racquet Club.

The Senate has thrown another monkey wrench into the process of turning Puerto Rico from a dependency into a commonwealth. This was done on Monday when the upper house by a voice vote modified the Puerto Rican resolution to bar amendment of the proposed commonwealth constitution except with previous approval by the United States Congress.

ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., June 24 -- New Mexico's twelve-vote delegation to the Democratic National Convention will go to Chicago uninstructed, despite intensive efforts by supporters of Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee to arrange an advance commitment, it was indicated tonight.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 24 -- On the No. 1 court, with every seat and bit of standing room filled, Maureen Connolly made her bow today as a contender for the All-England lawn tennis championship at Wimbledon. It was a completely successful debut despite rather alarming reports that have circulated the past two days about the condition of Miss Connolly's shoulder.

The Transport Workers Union has a contract with privately owned bus lines which says: "During the terms of this agreement neither the union nor the operating employes shall participate in any stoppage or interruption or interference in the normal operations of the companies, nor in any strike against the companies, nor in any sympathetic or general strike, whether within or outside the property of the companies * * *."

CARMEL, N. Y., June 24 -- Assemblyman D. Mallory Stephens, chairman of the powerful Ways and Means Committee and a veteran of twenty-seven years in the State Legislature, said tonight that he would not seek another Assembly term.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 24 -- Henry E. Brown, a United States mining engineer who was beaten by rioting miners Saturday and was refused permission to leave the mining town of Huanuni, has arrived safely in the city of Oruro en route to La Paz and the Minister of Mines has promised protection to other North Americans there, an official of Brown's company stated today.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 24 -- Overcast skies and crowded positions of yachts marked the Newport-to-Bermuda ocean yacht race tonight.

PARIS, June 24 -- Jean de Hautecloque, French Resident General in Tunisia, will return to the North African protectorate in a few days to face the difficult task of rallying hostile French and Tunisian opinion there to a reform program on which even the French Parliament could not agree.

The Boston Road Theatre, 1472 Boston Road, the Bronx, formerly operated by the Loew's chain, has been sold by Edgar T. Appleby to the Emerald Retail Grocers Association, an affiliate of Emerald Food Stores. The building, erected in 1923 by the Benenson interests, is one story high and also contains stores and lofts. It will be altered by the new owners and used as a wholesale grocery warehouse and retail outlet.

While prices of ferrous scrap, a key ingredient in steel, were breaking sharply below ceiling levels in several markets yesterday, steel company representatives asked the National Production Authority at a meeting in Washington not to dismantle allocation machinery on scrap.

Today's new film is "I Dream of Jeanie," a period romantic musical in Trucolor, produced by Republic and featuring Ray Middleton, Bill Shirley, Muriel Lawrence, Eileen Christy and Lynn Bari, at Loew's State. Allan Dwan directed the offering, which was Written by Alan LeMay.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 24 -- Irving Wexler, alias Waxey Gordon, the New York gangster and racketeer, died t 5 P. M. today in the hospital in the Alcatraz Island Federal Prison here.

In a brief ceremony yesterday at City Hall, Mayor Impellitteri administered the oath of office to Robert Moses for a new six-year term as chairman of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority. Commissioner Moses originally was appointed to the non-salaried post in 1934 by the late Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia and subsequently reappointed by former Mayor William O'Dwyer.

Racial discrimination was charged by a white lessee and a Negro occupant to prevent their eviction from an apartment in Knickerbocker Village, East Side housing development, in a suit filed in Supreme Court yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- President Truman reported to Congress today that he would not terminate military or economic assistance to Italy because that country permitted the shipment of a "centerless grinding machine" to Rumania.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- A House Appropriations subcommittee has decided to recommend further substantial reductions in the $6,447,730,750 Mutual Security authorization despite a warning from Robert A. Lovett, Sercetary of Defense, that such action would "seriously endanger our national security."

The New York Red Cross Regional Blood Program appealed yesterday to healthy men and women to give blood before July 4 as a means of offsetting an acute slump in donations expected prior to the holiday.
WASHINGTON, June 24 (UP) -- Frank E. McKinney, Democratic National Chairman, today accepted the credentials of State Attorney General J. P. Coleman as national committeeman from Mississippi.

Samuel J. Tilden High of Brooklyn won its first city P. S. A. L. baseball championship yesterday by overtaking Bryant High of Queens, 11 -- 10, at Dexter Park, Woodhaven. It was the first city championship game held since 1949.

BONN, Germany, June 24 -- Federal Chancellor Konrad Adenauer agreed with Bundestag deputies of his Christian Democratic Union today that decisive action on ratification of the Bonn peace contract and the European Defense Community treaty must be postponed until September.

Scholarships, cash awards and medals were awarded yesterday by the School Art League of New York City to 232 art students in the city's high schools at a ceremony in the auditorium of the New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Brig. Gen. Francis G. Brink was found shot today in an office in the Pentagon Building and died in an ambulance en route to Walter Reed Hospital.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Julian P. Van Winkle, president of the Stitzel Weller Distillery Company of Louisville, Ky., told a House of Representatives Judiciary subcommittee today that Schenley Distillers, Inc., had carried a half million dollars of insurance on twelve warehouses Schenley did not own and in which it never had stored a drop of whisky.

The American Federation of Musicians is trying to curtail the making of records abroad by American musicians, especially conductors. How far the union's campaign is likely to go is not yet known, but already Artur Rodzinski has placed his membership in jeopardy by disregarding the ban of James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Labor union.

Joey Maxim, holder of the world light-heavyweight title, and Ray Robinson, world middleweight champion, marked time yesterday awaiting the call to their postponed battle of fifteen rounds in the Yankee Stadium tonight. And, with good weather, officials of the International Boxing Club were optimistic that this clash for Maxim's title, postponed from Monday because of rain would go through as scheduled.

Because of the postponement of the opening night program at Lewisohn Stadium, Dmitri Mitropoulos has changed the program which he will present tonight with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony. The revised program includes Bach's Fantasia and Fugue in G Minor, arranged by Mr. Mitropoulos, Respighi's Toccata for Piano and Orchestra, and Mr. Mitropoulos as conductor and soloist and Beethoven's "Eroica" Symphony.

WASSENAAR, the Netherlands, June 24 -- West Germany offered Israel today $715,000,000 -- mainly in goods and partly in the proceeds of a possible United States loan -- to help compensate for the resettlement of 500,000 of Hitler's victims in the young state.
The Crosley division of Avco Manufacturing Corporation introduced yesterday what it asserts is a "foolproof" appliance to eliminate post-mealtime exasperation.
The 1952 edition of Elliott Murphy's Aquashow, comprising stage and aquatic entertainment, opened last night at the amphitheatre in Flushing Meadow Park, Queens.

In June, 1949, the House passed the National Housing Act by a vote of 228 to 185. The Senate passed it by 57 to 13. Although this authorization of policy contemplated the erection of 135,000 low-rent housing dwelling units a year, the dictates of economy and the shortages of construction materials have kept the program well below authorized level.

On this second anniversary of the Korean war, weapons are rolling off American production lines at seven times the pre-Korean rate. We have climbed two-thirds of the way toward our planned peak of arms output, but we are still at least three years away from numerical superiority over Soviet Russia in the air.

OKLAHOMA CITY, June 24 -- President Truman told the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People today that the ten-point program he sent to the Congress in 1948 was "still my civil rights program for the American people."

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- A House Appropriations subcommittee approved today a $1,450,000,000 atomic expansion program, designed to make nuclear weapons available for all the United States armed forces.

Senator Estes Kefauver, asserting that he has never felt more confident of the Democratic nomination for President, struck out yesterday against Democratic leaders who, he charged, were flouting the will of the people.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 24 -- Jacob A. Malik, the Soviet representative, resorted today to another procedural maneuver to delay Security Council consideration of a United States resolution. This resolution proposes a Red Cross investigation of Communist charges that United Nations forces defending South Korea had employed bacteriological warfare.
Jacob A. Livingston, who served as Republican leader of Kings County for eighteen years, announced yesterday his preference for Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio as the party's nominee for President.

Dr. Harry N. Wright, president of City College, announced yesterday that a year's leave of absence had been granted to Dr. Ruth Caldwell Wright, dean of students at the City College School of Business and Civic Administration, so that she might become a cultural attache at the United States Embassy at New Delhi, India.

ELIZABETH, H. J., June 24 -- After a five-month study of this city's three air disasters, the January Union County Grand Jury today found no cause for indictments on the basis of negligence, but submitted numerous recommendations for air safety.

TROY, N. Y., June 24 -- The State Department of the Veterans of Foreign Wars went on record unanimously today in favor of denying tax exemptions to all "educational institutions" that employed persons who were members of "subversive organizations."

ATLANTIC CITY, June 25 -- Sex hormones have been used successfully to make virgin heifers give milk without having had calves, a group of research veterinarians from Michigan State College reported here today.

Michael Todd's outdoor contribution of the week, the new version of Johann Strauss' opera, "A Night in Venice," will open tonight at 8 o'clock at the new 8,206-seat Marine Stadium in Jones Beach, L. I.

The highest price ever recorded at an American philatelic auction for a block of four United States stamps was paid here yesterday when part of the collection of the late Henry B. Close, a food corporation executive, was sold publicly at the Commodore Hotel through Eugene N. Costeles of 93 Nassau Street.

ST. LOUIS, June 25 -- It was advertised as big league baseball but any resemblance to such was merely coincidental today at Sportsman's Park, where the Browns, despite five errors, outlasted the Yankees, 10 -- 9. Bill Veeck, the St. Louis owner who suffered along with all the others, almost was tempted to return the admission price to the 4,600 fans.
NEWARK, N. J., June 25 (AP) -- Five big breweries in this area, shut down since Monday by a strike of A. F. L. machinists, resumed full-scale operations today.

It is not surprising that Mr. Acheson and Mr. Eden started their talks in London with a discussion of the situation in Berlin. Although the current Big Three conference is more or less accidental, the by-product of the conferring of an Oxford degree on the American Secretary of State, it promises to be one of the most important meetings of the Western Foreign Ministers.

ALBANY, June 25 (AP) -- The procedure by which an estimated 350,000 New York service men may obtain military ballots for the November election was outlined today by the State Division of Veterans Affairs.

Hat silhouettes that reflect the Renaissance were previewed for the press yesterday by Irene of New York, 16 East Fifty-second Street. Softly draped berets worn back of the hair line were molded toward the back giving greater width at the sides.
The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active and somewhat steadier yesterday, closing unchanged to 49 points higher than on Tuesday, with July showing the most strength.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 25 -- The United States Naval Academy's yawl, Royono, became the first finisher, and the Class A winner in the Newport-to-Bermuda yacht race by gliding across the finish line off St. David's Head at 3:16 P. M. today.

Removal of numerous Government-imposed and unnecessary restrictions on private international trade is essential to expansion of a world-wide interchange of goods and services, the National Foreign Trade Council declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Some Republican politicians in the capital who strongly support General Eisenhower for their party's Presidential nomination gloomily share the shift in opinion of fifty newspaper correspondents here who in May, 35 to 11, guessed in a Newsweek poll that Eisenhower would be chosen, and in June, 25 to 24, guessed that the nominee will be Senator Taft.

A convicted colleague of the late Irving (Waxey Gordon) Wexler in a narcotics deal last Aug. 2 suffered a setback yesterday when General Sessions Judge Francis L. Valente refused to grant a new trial to Arthur (Fat Sam) Repola on the basis of "newly discovered evidence."

MADISON, Wis., June 25 -- The most serious challenge so far to develop to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's bid for the Republican Senatorial nomination in the Wisconsin September primary came in the announcement today by Leonard F. Schmitt, 50-year-old attorney and leader of Wisconsin's Republican insurgents, that he was a candidate for the nomination.

LONDON, June 25 -- Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, called today for an end of the Korean War which he described as "the prime obstacle to a renewed effort toward global settlements."

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The White House said today that President Truman "had asked for and got" a report on the "allegation" that Prof. Owen Lattimore was planning to visit the Soviet Union or its satellites.

ALBANY, June 25 -- With less than one week before the sale of yellow oleomargarine becomes legal in New York, only 775 eating places of the estimated 50,000 in the state have applied for oleo licenses, the State Department of Agriculture and Markets reported today.

GLEN COVE, L. I., June 25 -- The J. P. Morgan mansion, built by the late banker about 1900 on East Island and his legal residence until the time of his death, is scheduled for the auction block for the second time in four years.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The House of Representatives joined the Senate today in requesting President Truman to use the Taft-Hartley Law to stop the twenty-four-day steel strike.
HARRISBURG, June 25 -- Governor Fine said today that there was a possibility he might announce whom he would support before he left for Chicago next week.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- David K. E. Bruce. Acting Secretary of State, expressed today his own and the State Department's "deep sense of loss" at the death of Brig. Gen. Francis G. Brink, who died from gun wounds inflicted in an office at the Pentagon yesterday afternoon.
WASHINGTON, June 25 (UP) -- The Government reported today that cash dividend payments by corporations issuing public reports totaled $234,000,000 in May, 10 per cent more than in May a year ago.

ASPEN, Colo., June 25 -- In the opening address yesterday of the Aspen Conference, Buckminister Fuller, well known engineer, predicted that the entire world would be industrialized by the year 2,000 and that 100 per cent of the "human family" would enjoy at that time the highest technical advantages available to anyone.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Plans to repel an invasion of "wetbacks" from Mexico probably will be dropped as a result of cuts made by Congress in budget requests for border patrol activities, immigration officials said today.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (UP) -- President Truman signed a bill to-I day extending from Sept. 1, 1952,I to July 1, 1953, the cutoff date forI payment of a $100-a-month bonus1 to physicians and dentists who vol-J unteer for service in the armedI forces. The premium was voted in] 1949 to stimulate their enlistments.'
CARSON CITY, Nev., June 25 (AP) -- Mrs. Jeanne d'Arc Michaud, 36 years old, was convicted by a Federal Court jury today of complicity in the $1,500,000 Redfield burglary of last February.

Our news columns report that Mayor Impellitteri, in a note of greeting to all first tenants of new apartment houses, will proffer a "key" to the city which will help unravel one of the most baffling mysteries known to man -- where to expect to find a given house number on a north-south avenue in Manhattan.

WESTHAMPTON, L. I., June 15 -- A proposed revision of Protestant Episcopal Church law that would limit the powers of a bishop in filling vacant pulpits in parishes was overwhelmingly opposed here today at the closing session of the annual three-day clergy conference of the Diocese of Long Island.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 25 -- Charges that Communist China is using at least 1,000,000 and up to 2,000,000 persons as slave laborers were made today before a United Nations committee of inquiry by Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor.

LOUISVILLE, June 25 -- Jim Turnesa, sixth son of the noted golfing family, won the Professional Golfers Association championship today by defeating Melvin (Chick) Harbert of Northville, Mich., 1 up, on the last hole of their thirty-six-hole final.
CHICAGO, June 25 -- Strength in July corn was the feature of the market today, the near month again going to a premium over the September.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- A $200,000,000 credit to France was approved today by the Export-Import Bank to provide that country immediately with the dollar proceeds of contracts for military supplies and materials under the Mutual Security Program.
