" Relax," says Harold Rome in the title of a song for "Wish You Were Here," which opened at the Imperial last evening. Without lacking appreciation for a lavish production, a theatregoer could wish that Mr. Rome and his associates had taken their own advice.

TAIPEI, Formosa, June 25 -An agreement designed to encourage private investments in Formosa through United States Government guarantees was signed at the Chinese Foreign Office this afternoon by representatives of the United States and Chinese Governments.

The late Michael Cardinal von Faulhaber of Munich, whose life and career are reviewed in THE NEW YORK TIMES of June 13, said and did many things which lent aid and comfort to the Nazi regime of Adolf Hitler. Although your account leaves quite a different impression, it ignores a substantial part of the Cardinal's record.

Ray Robinson, world middleweight champion, had the world light-heavyweight title within his grasp in his battle with the defending champion, Joey Maxim, last night at the Yankee Stadium, but he didn't have the strength to carry through.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., June 25 -- Mr. and Mrs. Fred E. Wright of Leewood captured the Westchester County Golf Association's mixed foursomes championship by carding 40, 38 -- 78 over an alternate-stroke route at the Sunningdale Country Club today.

BOSTON, June 25 (AP) -- The combination of Max Surkont's five-hit, pitching and Sid Gordon's slugging today enabled the Braves to complete a three-game series sweep over the last-place Pirates, 5 -- 2.

OKLAHOMA CITY, June 25 -- A step-up in the campaign to end segregation in public recreation facilities and in transportation was disclosed today by Thurgood Marshall, head of the legal department of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (UP) -- A House Judiciary subcommittee approved today a Senate bill to permit sellers to match lower prices of competitors unless they knew the prices were fixed illegally. It also would allow sellers to absorb freight charges so their products could be sold at the lower prices to buyers in different areas.
Longshoremen refused yesterday for the second day to unload 9,323 cases of Polish hams from the Swedish American Line freighter Krageholm.

New York has been playing host this week to board members and delegates of the International Federation of Business and Professional Women. Some 300 representatives from nineteen countries, with a total membership of 300,000, have been meeting to discuss problems concerning the economic, legal, educational and social status of women here and abroad.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 25 -- Mrs. R. M. Torgerson of Cherry Valley, Roslyn Swift of Glen Oaks, Mrs. Mortimer May of Willow Brook and Margaret Mackie of Inwood reached the semi-final round of the Women's Long Island Golf Association match-play championship at the Meadow Brook Club today.

VICTORIA, B. C., June 25 -- Two gigantic stars, thirty-three and thirty-seven times as massive as the sun, revolving around each other at a relative speed of 450 miles a second, or 1,620,000 miles an hour, have been discovered by Dr. Joseph A. Pearce, director emeritus of the Dominion Astrophysical Observatory here.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 25 -- Designation of the Speaker of the South African Assembly as President of the new High Court of Parliament was announced today. The court was established to enable Parliament by a straight majority to override the Appeal Court on constitutional questions.

After completing an extensive tour yesterday of the remodeled Riverside Hospital on North Brother Island, which will receive its first teen-age narcotics users next Tuesday, city and state officials seemed to be agreed that the right approach to stamping out youthful narcotics addiction as a local problem finally had been started.

GENEVA, June 25 -- Over the strenuous objections of employer delegations from most of the member countries, particularly the United States, the International Labor Organization conference adopted today the text of a convention on minimum standards of social security.

Artur Rodzinski, who, as conductor, has made some records abroad with an Austrian orchestra, has placed his membership in the American Federation of Musicians in jeopardy by defying the union regulations which apparently compel him to work only with A. F. of M. members.

HANOVER, N. H., June 25 -- S. C. Hollister, dean of the Cornell University Engineering College, said today that a complete reorganization of the profession of engineering was imperative if demands of the national economic system were to be met.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -John Foster Dulles, a former special adviser to the Secretary of State and now foreign policy expert for the Republican party, called today for "steadfast, resolute and resourceful" support of the United Nations as an instrument of peace.

CLEVELAND, June 25 (AP) -- The Athletics rallied with a six-run burst in the eighth inning to whip the Indians, 11 -- 9, today before a heat-wilted crowd of 6,261. The setback toppled Cleveland from second place to third.

DETROIT, June 25 (AP) -- Chuck Davey, fast-moving scholar of pro boxing, knocked out Chico Vejar in the fifth round of their scheduled ten-round welterweight bout at Olympia Stadium tonight with a barrage of body blows. Davey, 147 1/2 pounds, flattened Vejar, 149 1/4, at 1:58 of the round.

Favas, the beans with a venerable history, are mentioned in current market reports by Mrs. Frances Foley Gannon of the City Department of Markets. Explaining that the fresh legumes are now abundant, reasonable in cost and very good eating, she advises housewives to "put them on the shopping list and inquire about them."

A decline of 380,000 barrels in the country's gasoline stocks last week was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, they totaled 121,613,000 barrels, compared with 121,993,000 a week earlier and 137,036,000 a year ago.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 25 -- A bronze plaque in memory of the members of the United Nations forces who died in Korea was presented to the world organization by the Government and people of South Korea at a brief ceremony today on the second anniversary of the Korean war.

LOS ANGELES, June 25 (AP) -Leaders of the United Auto Workers, C. I. O., today called off strike plans for this week and agreed to Federal conciliation in Washington on contracts covering 25,000 jet-producing workers at North American Aircraft Corporation's four plants.

Important elements in the textile, chemical, electrical and medical fields joined forces yesterday to begin an all-out drive to minimize the generation of static electricity in nylon, orlon, dynel, dacron and other synthetic "wonder" fibers.

CLEVELAND, June 25 -- Dr. Arthur H. Compton, chancellor of Washington University in St. Louis, told the National Red Cross convention here tonight that a third world war was by no means inevitable and that the free world could overcome the Communist challenge without the force of arms.

Unmindful of the blistering heat that must have singed their flannels in the sweltering dugouts, the Giants ended their second home stand of the year against the west at the Polo Grounds by deftly polishing off Luke Sewell's Reds yesterday in the series finale, 3 to 2.
Election of William J. Keary as president of the Empire State Building Corporation, was announced yesterday by Col. Henry Crown, chairman of the board.
Eugene Anschel has been appointed export manager of the Nepera Chemical Company, Inc.
LAFAYETTE, Ind., June 25 (AP) -- Six of the top eight qualifiers, including Medalist Paul Harney, were eliminated today in the National Collegiate Athletic Association title golf tournament.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 25 -- Acting on the application of State's Attorney Lorin W. Willis, Superior Court Judge John A. Cornell today ordered a one-man grand jury investigation into reported violations of gambling laws in Stamford and Norwalk.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Thursday, June 26 -- In a striking upset, the Labor party stepped into the position of the Netherlands plurality group for the first time in yesterday's quadrennial parliamentary elections, according to semi-official final results early today.

Price changes continued mixed in most commodity futures on the exchanges here yesterday. Hides, rubber, tin, coffee, cocoa, wool and vegetable oils moved into higher territory. Lead, zinc and sugar futures declined. Trading was moderately active.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 25 -- The economic responsibilities borne by the American family appear to be so great that, without state help, they may become too heavy to bear, Dr. Hazel Kyrk of the University of Chicago said today at the forty-third annual conference of the American Home Economics Association.

New life was injected into the stock market yesterday when late buying appeared in some of the key units, notably the steels, rails, oils and electronics. The list was affected price-wise by the concurrence of the House in the Senate's request that the White House invoke a Taft-Hartley Act injunction to get the steel mills back in production.

A dual role for scientists and technologists in the period of international stress was urged last night by Detlev W. Bronk, president of the National Academy of Sciences and president of Johns Hopkins University.

Intrigued by Charles C. Platt's suggestion, noted in this corner a little while ago, a gentleman curious in such matters has called attention to a recent article in the Architectural Forum which gives an account of the Philadelphia way of dealing with "blighted" urban areas assigned to "redevelopment."

WIMBLEDON, England, June 25 -- Maureen Connolly had her introduction to Wimbledon's court today, and it was an ordeal that brought out her splendid fighting qualities as she defeated Angela Mortimer, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 3, in the All-England lawn tennis championship.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (UP) -- Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada, recommended recently that Conrad E. Snow be dismissed as head of the State Department's Loyalty-Security Board for attacking Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.

THE HAGUE, June 25 -- The International Tin Study Group, in its monthly survey issued today, was unable for the first time since the war to give the figure for April world mine production because of the absence of statistics from Bolivia.

" Unless we get women equal education, we can't get them equal pay and opportunity," Dame Caroline Haslett, president of the International Association of Business and Professional Women, said yesterday at its three-day board meeting at the Savoy-Plaza Hotel.

PARIS, June 25 -- Marshal Alphonse-Pierre Juin, Atlantic pact ground commander in Central Europe, severely criticized today the United States performance in Korea and Washington's attitude toward the French in North Africa and Indo-China.

At the investment banking antitrust trial, Judge Harold R. Medina expressed the view yesterday that an investment banker who served as a director of a company for which his firm was underwriting was "in a theoretically inconsistent position, no matter how much he goes to church on Sundays."
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- With Washington engulfed in a record-breaking heat wave, a giant water main burst today, cutting off water to the White House and much of downtown Washington.

Governor Dewey's account of his tour of the Orient, titled "Journey to the Far Pacific," will be published July 14 by Doubleday. The book describes his trip covering 41,000 miles, which he undertook to inform himself about the peoples and nations who stand between communism and our Pacific Coast. It is the midsummer selection of the Book-of-the-Month Club.
LONDON, June 25 -- A redistribution of duties without any major change of posts is taking place in Prime Minister Churchill's Government but not in line with advance predictions.

Present methods of obtaining dogs and cats vital to medical teaching and research are so costly and uncertain that "hundreds" of projects are being held up or abandoned. And the animals that do arrive are in such poor condition that it may cost more to rehabilitate a dog than to buy it, while as many as half the cats in one shipment may die of disease contracted before reaching a medical institution.

WHAT is termed a "liberalized framework of opening dates" for the waterfowl season will be initiated this year, according to the Department of the Interior. The earliest opening date is moved forward to Oct. 1 and the latest closing day back to Jan. 10.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 25 -- Mayor Stanley W. Church of New Rochelle, N. Y., arrived here tonight at the estate of Gene Tunney with a husky Holstein calf he had bought at Wingdale, N. Y., to use in payment of New Rochelle's annual "debt" to descendants of Sir John Pell.

BONN, Germany, June 25 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer asked the three Western Allies today to strengthen their patrol forces along the explosive frontier between the Federal Republic and Communist East Germany.
The McCarran anti-immigration bill, full of hatreds, fears and prejudices that have no proper place in American legislation, richly deserves the veto that President Truman courageously has given it.
Two women were injured, one seriously, in a fire that routed eight families from the five-story brick building at 128 Degraw Street, Brooklyn, at 9:40 A. M., yesterday.

FRANCE, June 25 -- In his first month since assuming the Supreme Command of Allied Forces in Europe, General Matthew B. Ridgway set a personal example of hard work and drive that has amazed many long term observers at this headquarters.
Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., issued another strike threat yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- President Truman today nominated Walter L. Greene to be- Federal Housing Commissioner, succeeding Franklin D. Richards, who resigned recently.

The preliminary annual report of the Kimberly-Clark Corporation, manufacturer of paper and cellulose products, issued yesterday, showed a net profit for the fiscal year ended on April 30, of $11,257,976. This is equal, after preferred dividend payments, to $5.29 a share on 2,044,951 common shares.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Riss Co., New York trucking concern, has been ordered by the Interstate Commerce Commission to cease hauling dangerous explosives over many of the routes it has been using.

Ellsworth B. Buck, former chairman of the Richmond County Republican organization, was assured yesterday of his designation as a delegate to the National Convention in Chicago as the result of a ruling by Supreme Court Justice James C. Brown Jr.
OLYMPIA, Greece, June 25 -- The Olympic torch, symbol of the world games, was kindled by the rays of the sun here today in the grey ruins of the Temple of Zeus.

Ray Robinson was a prostration case in his dressing room after the fight. The defeated middleweight champion was kept in partial seclusion, sharing a dressing room with Ruby Goldstein, who was recovered completely from the condition that forced him to leave the ring when he did.
WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department is urging wheat farmers to hold some of their grain off the market during the current harvest season to keep prices from falling.

AMARILLO, Tex., June 25-- Gene Howe, 66 years old, well known Texas editor and publisher, wa found dead in his car near here foday. A bullet had pierced his right temple, and an inquest vgrdict of suicide was returned. Friends said that he had been despondent over his health.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 25 -- Dr. Jaime Torres Bodet, director general of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, replied today to an attack on UNESCO policy made yesterday in Washington in the Senate Appropriations Committee, which acted to cut off United States funds to the United Nations agency.
GENEVA, June 25 -- Pope Pius XII has pledged the "continued support of the Holy See" for the United Nations efforts to alleviate the plight of refugees.

The Department of Sanitation, which periodically finds itself in the used car business, will hold a public auction Monday of thirty-five autos recently impounded for illegal parking but not reclaimed by their owners.

LACONIA, N. H., June 25 -- Television set owners here saw the snowy veil of fringe area reception swept aside today with the completion of a community antenna on top of near-by Mount Belknap. Some of them immediately made arrangements to have their individual, top-heavy antennas removed from rooftops.
Hilarious, from a mare named Laughter, had what amounted to a chortling, chucklesome romp in the sixtieth running of the Tremont Stakes for 2-year-olds at the Aqueduct track yesterday.

Joey Maxim never did catch up with Ray Robinson in the Yankee Stadium last night. But the heat did. The flashy Sugar Ray burned himself out while pitching "shutout ball" in a ring perched over the baseball diamond. He lost his "no-hitter" in the ninth when Pal Joey tagged him for the first time, and after that only deft fielding saved him.

A new phase of the war has opened in Korea. This is the only possible meaning of this week's intensive bombing attacks against the Yalu River and other North Korean power plants. These generators, which have supplied North Korea and parts of Manchuria as far as Mukden and Port Arthur with power, have been, hitherto, immune from attack.

Carl Erskine, who pitched a no-hit shut-out against the Cubs in his last previous start, was raked for eight hits by the Cardinals yesterday, while Jerry Staley was holding the Dodgers to four safeties.

An incident recalled in a dispatch sent to this newspaper by Jack Raymond from Bonn may help some of us to improve our historical perspective. United States High Commissioner John J. McCloy has just transferred to Frau Inge Aicher-Scholl about a quarter of a million dollars for her vocational training school in Ulm.

A plan, designed to promote public service advertising on a cooperative basis in daily newspapers, has been developed jointly by the Advertising Council and the public service committee of the Newspaper Advertising Executives Association.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 25 -- Four specialists in anti-monopoly policy reported today the results of a critical examination of statistical findings by Prof. M. A. Adelman of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology that there is little evidence of a trend toward greater concentration in American industry since the turn of the century.
PUSAN, Korea, Thursday, June 26 (UP) -- Two National Assemblymen were arrested today and another was being sought for alleged conspiracy to assassinate President Syngman Rhee yesterday.

PORTLAND, Ore., June 25 -- Seeking second choice votes among Oregon delegates to the Democratic National Convention, Averell Harriman carried a campaign for equal treatment of minorities into three areas today. The Oregon delegation, with twelve votes, is pledged by the primary vote to Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 25 -- Jacob A. Malik, Soviet representative in the United Nations Security Council, announced today that he would veto a United States resolution to refer the question of the Geneva protocol of 1925, which prohibits bacteriological warfare, to the Disarmament Commission.

CHICAGO, June 25 -- The 1952 summer home furnishings market enters its final day tomorrow at the American Furniture and Merchandise Marts. Industry leaders reported today that sales of individual exhibitors had varied widely, although buyer attendance has run well ahead of the furnishings show a year ago.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25 (AP) -- A new Associated Press poll of Pennsylvania's highly important seventy-vote delegation to the Republican National Convention showed today that almost half the delegates either backed General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for the nomination or said they preferred him for the nomination.
Underwriting syndicates will place on the market today issues of corporate securities valued at more than $57,000,000: Most of the total is in public utilities. The offerings are:
TOKYO, Thursday, June 26 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,292, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Thursday, Korea time:
A quiet campaign by members of the riverboat fraternity will come to a successful close Saturday afternoon, when the new shrine of Our Lady of the Hudson will be dedicated at Port Ewen, N. Y.

Methodists of the New York area honored Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam and his wife last night at a farewell dinner in the Commodore Hotel, attended by 700 persons. Bishop Oxnam will depart soon for Washington to head his denomination in the capital after eight years as Bishop of New York.

Imaginative play equipment for youngsters who like to run, jump, swing, slide and climb can be provided without too much effort or cost by parents where backyard space or even a small play area is available. Some ideas for simple but out-of-the-ordinary play constructions are described and illustrated in the latest issue of Recreation, monthly magazine published by the National Recreation Association.
Four hundred students from forty-one states and sixteen countries will arrive at Tanglewood, Mass., this week-end for the opening of the tenth annual session of the Berkshire Music Center.

JERSEY CITY, June 25 -- The Exeter, American Export Line ship, docked at Pier D at 7:15 o'clock tonight with 106 regular passengers and one special one -- a 50-year-old man who had been plucked off a channel buoy in Buzzards Bay, Mass., after a night tied to the rocking signal.

JERUSALEM, June 25 -- The reorganization of the Israeli Government, involving a switch in Finance Ministers and the addition of a fourteenth Cabinet member as Minister of Justice, received the approval of the Knesset (Parliament) in Jerusalem today.

The decision of the United States Supreme Court in "The Miracle" case, extending to motion pictures the constitutional guarantees of free speech and a free press, was hailed yesterday as a momentous victory by speakers at a luncheon in the north ballroom of the Hotel Astor.
WASHINGTON, June 25 (UP) -- Thomas K. Finletter, the Secretary of the Air Force, presented the Distinguished Service Medal today to America's greatest living ace, Col. Francis S. Gabreski.
BONN, Germany, June 25 -- The presentation of his credentials to the French Government by the Saar's envoy to France has produced a new outburst of indignation in West Germany.
City pavements melted and blistered yesterday, the hottest June 25 on record.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- By a teller vote of 118 to 87, the House of Representatives tentatively approved today scrapping all price and wage controls on July 31.

Your editorial of June 21 entitled "The Consumer Loses" misrepresented the purpose of my amendment dealing with the International Materials Conference. This amendment was passed by the House of Representatives June 19 by a teller vote of 169 to 102.

THE curtain rises on the Book-of-the-Month Club's judgment room. It has been redecorated to represent part of the bull ring at Seville. Somewhere offstage a band led by Thomas Scherman is playing selections from "Carmen."

TOKYO, Thursday, June 26 (AP) -- Japanese police smashed a Communist riot in Tokyo Wednesday following an earlier outbreak at Osaka. The incidents were a violent climax of Red demonstrations against the Korean war.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 25 -- A drastic reduction in military tank output within the next three weeks was forecast here today as result of the steel strike. Even should the strike be settled immediately, production for the armed forces was expected to be materially affected.

PARIS, June 25 -- A proposal to take a concrete step this year toward creating a European legislature with real powers was discussed by the French Cabinet today, and probably will be put before the foreign ministers of the six Schuman plan nations when they meet next month.

THE balloting will end tomorrow for the starting teams in the annual-all-star game at Philadelphia's Shibe Park on July 8. The fans will have done the voting and their selections will have to be accepted by the rival managerial master-minds, Casey Stengel and Leo Durocher, whether they like them or not.
The new interdenominational chapel of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center was dedicated here yesterday afternoon for meditation and prayer by patients, their relatives and the hospital staff.
WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- President Truman originated a program of assigning State Department officials to state Governors on a temporary basis, the department has advised Senators.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 25 (AP) -- Results of matches today in the Wimbledon lawn tennis championships:

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- Announced United States battle casualties in Korea reached 110,611 today, an increase of 640 since last week. This was the biggest increase for any week since last Dec. 12.

New York City has borrowed $23,500,000 on tax anticipation notes due over a year at 1 1/2 per cent interest, Controller Lazarus Joseph announced yesterday. The notes are dated June 26, 1952, and will come due as follows: $4,000,000 on Aug. 4, 1952; $2,000,000 on Oct. 1, 1952; $2,000,000 on Dec. 3, 1952; $2,000,000 on Feb, 18, 1953; and $13,500,000 on June 26, 1953.

With sales in the neighborhood of $50,000,000, the Bulova Watch Company attained the highest dollar volume of business in its history in the fiscal year ended with March. The company earned $4.07 a share and paid stockholders $3.50 a share in dividends.
WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's message today vetoing the McCarran-Walter Immigration bill:

A poster showing a boy playing ball in Central Park under the slogan "Parks are yours -- Enjoy them; Don't destroy them," won first prize yesterday in a contest for the best poster combating vandalism in the city parks. The contest sponsors are the Park Association of New York City, the Board of Education and the New York Junior League.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- A Senate subcommittee decided today to urge Congress to eliminate the proposed ceiling of $46,000,000,000 on Defense Department spending in the fiscal year beginning July 1.

Three new films will arrive at first-run theatres this morning. "Where's Charley?" Warner Brothers' Technicolor version of the Broadway musical adaptation of "Charely's Aunt," which was filmed in England with Ray Bolger repeating his stage assignment in the title role, is at the Radio City Music Hall. David Butler directed from a script by John Monks Jr. Allyn McLerie, Robert Shackleton and Mary Germaine are among the principals.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in twenty-four leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended June 18:

PHILADELPHIA, June 25 (AP) -- Manager Phil Cavarretta inserted himself into the Chicago line-up at first base in desperation tonight and the strategy paid off as the Cubs downed the Phillies, 4 to 1, to end a nine-game losing streak.

So far ahead in points that the world light-heavyweight title was virtually within his grasp, Ray Robinson lost by a technical knockout to Joey Maxim in the fourteenth round at the Yankee Stadium last night after collapsing from exhaustion in 104-degree heat.
DENVER, June 25 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower definitely will go to Chicago early next month in his bid for the Republican Presidential nomination.

NEWARK, June 25 -- The City Commission approved today two resolutions that gave the final stamp of approval, on the local level, to a $40,000,000 Newark Housing Authority slum-clearance and redevelopment project. The resolutions were adopted on recommendations of the Newark Planning Board that two tracts be declared blighted.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The ranking Republican foreign affairs spokesman in Congress, Senator Alexander Wiley of Wisconsin, called on his party today to endorse in its coming platform the Truman Administration policies in Europe.

CLEVELAND, June 25 -- The Rabbinical Assembly of America, composed of more than 500 leaders of the conservative branch of Judaism, unanimously went on record today in asserting that the "greatest threat facing our democracy is from within in suppressing honest criticism of ideas and institutions."

RYE, N. Y., June 25 -- Thomas C. Robbins of Winged Foot carded a 74 today for a thirty-six-hole total of 147 and a three-stroke lead over the field as the second day's play in the forty-eighth annual United States seniors championship was concluded over the Apawamis Club course.
WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- A revival of consumer buying, already started, will restore 1952 retail business to last year's level or better, credit men agreed today.

The first step toward construction of a new $22,000,000 state-aided low-rent housing development in the west midtown was taken yesterday when the City Planning Commission voted to include the project on the city's master plan.

The great confidence which the public reposes in Robert Moses is well illustrated once more by the fact that Mayor Impellitteri has named him to head a six-man inquiry into cause and prevention of tenement house hazards. No other choice could so well convey determination to get at the bottom of a problem, or to inject common sense and know-how into search and solution.

The Federal Communications Commission has refused to grant to the Radio Corporation of America permission at this time to make field test broadcasts of its color system during regular broadcast hours.

Wholesale food prices dropped in the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Dun Bradstreet index, to the lowest average level in six weeks. At $6.39 the index was 3 cents lower than a week earlier and was down about 9 per cent from the average for the corresponding week a year ago which was $7.02.
Ten of the twelve teams in the National Football League will launch their circuit seasons on Sept. 28, with Dallas, the newest member, playing host to the New York Giants in its opener.

Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, predicted yesterday that Averell Harriman, Director for Mutual Security, would be among the three leading candidates on the first ballot at the Democratic National Convention, would be nominated for President on a later ballot and would be elected to the Presidency in November.

Acting to equalize competition between commercial and savings banks in the soliciation of thrift accounts, the Federal Reserve Board has amended Regulation Q affecting member banks, it was announced yesterday.

The records and procedures of the Department of Housing and Buildings will be thoroughly checked to determine whether there has been serious laxity in the enforcement of building regulations, Commissioner Bernard J. Gillroy declared yesterday.

Funds for the establishment of nine new arthritis clinics were presented to hospital chiefs of staff here last night by the New York City chapter of the Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation at a dinner at the Academy of Medicine, 2 East 103d Street.

CHICAGO, June 25 (AP) -- The Senators strolled to a tenth inning, 9 -- 6, victory over Chicago today, taking their third straight and rising to fourth-place in the American League race while dropping the White Sox to fifth.

FLORENCE, Italy, June 25 -- One remains, even the morning after, under the spell of the noble opera "Didone," by Francesco Cavalli, produced in Venice in 1641 and revived here three centuries later as one of the crowning events of the Florence May festival.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The Senate Committee on Rules and Administration approved a bill today to encourage wider use of Presidential primaries in the future by making Federal funds available to finance the costs.

BOSTON, June 25 -- Mrs. Katherine G. Howard, secretary of the Republican National Committee, became today the third of six uncommitted Massachusetts delegates at large to the Republican National Convention to announce support of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower.

American conductors, singers and instrumentalists who now are making recordings with European organizations are "taking a big chance," a spokesman for the American Federation of Musicians warned yesterday.

The unfamiliar work on last night's symphony concert at Lewisohn Stadium was Respighi's Toccata for Piano and Orchestra, with Dimitri Mitropoulos making strenuous gestures both at the keyboard and at his orchestra.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 25 -- The United Nations Technical Mission to Bolivia in its first general report to the Bolivian Government has said that more efficient tax collecting and budgeting and a better application of the labor laws are urgently needed.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio conceded today that a vital struggle for control of the forthcoming Republican National Convention was under way.
LONDON, June 25 -- The Stock Exchange showed a-flicker of renewed interest today. This took the form of professional bear covering, which sent prices higher in a market short of stock.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., June 25 -- The advantages of censorship of advertising by newspapers were reviewed here yesterday by Monroe Green, advertising director of THE NEW YORK TIMES. He spoke at the summer meeting of the Newspaper Advertising Executives Association.

FARGO, N. D., June 25 (AP) -- Senator William Langer, who usually supports the Democratic Administration, won renomination in Tuesday's North Dakota primary election by defeating Representative Fred G. Aandahl.

TOKYO, Thursday, June 26 -- "Is it your proposition that a nation should provide itself with an adjustable scale of decency -- that it is wholly justified in being humane at one time and bar barous at another?" was the challenge on the war-prisoners' issue uttered by Maj. Gen. William K. Harrison Jr. for the Allies to the Communist truce delegates at Panmunjom, Korea, today.

BONN, Germany, June 25 -- Mutual recommendations have been made by United States and German historians for the teaching of history in their respective countries. These recommendations stress the feeling on the part of the Americans that their cultural attributes have been neglected whereas the Germans have indicated they feel their democratic leanings are neglected.

Feltman's, the sprawling Coney Island landmark that is older than the Boardwalk -- and cooler -- was put up at auction yesterday, but none of the 300 persons attending would bid enough to persuade the owner to sell.

Delfin Paez, consul general of Venezuela in New York, declared here yesterday that commerce between his country and the United States had reached a record high and that relations between the two nations "were never more cordial."

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- President Truman accepted today the resignations of two Assistant Attorneys General, H. Graham Morison and Harold I. Baynton. Mr. Truman praised the services of the men, who were two of the three officials whose resignations were announced when James P. McGranery took office as Attorney General.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 25 -- Woodbury College in Los Angeles has come up with some figures, based upon the survey of more than 5,000 television-set owners, which cast a dark shadow over the silver lining theatre owners expect to see when large-screen theatre television advances from its present experimental stage.
Congress is planning to slow down our industrial preparedness program at a time when most top military planners feel we are already arming too slowly against the Soviet threat.

OXFORD, England, June 25 -- Four Americans -- George Steiner, Donald Hall, Gisela Richter and Dean Acheson -- were honored at Oxford University today. Mr. Acheson received the honorary degree of Doctor of Civil Law.

A group of 486 veterans of the Korean battlefields received United Nations Service Medals at a ceremony yesterday morning on Governors Island commemorating the second anniversary of entry of United States troops into the Korean war.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- President Truman today vetoed the McCarran-Walter Immigration and Nationality Bill with some of the strongest language he has used in recent messages to Congress.

NEWARK, June 25 -- The largest Federal income tax lien against an individual in New Jersey -- a total of $728,956 -- was filed with the Essex County Register's Office today against Abner (Longie) Zwillman, who was one of the major figures in bootlegging during prohibition.

BERLIN, June 25 -- The East German Government plugged the few remaining holes in its wall around West Berlin today by forbidding those who worked outside the city or owned property there to commute back and forth.

Hats will be literally "in the ring" today when the New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, opens to the public an exhibition of Presidential campaign material that goes back to the nation's infancy.

Elizabeth Gurley Flynn told the Subversive Activities Control Board yesterday that the Communist party of the United States had never received directives, instructions or financial aid from the Soviet Union or any international Communist group since she became a member of its national board in 1938.
Scott George, United States Vice Consul in Tel Aviv, as reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES for June 23, undoubtedly set forth an accurate legal interpretation of the new Israeli citizenship law.

LONDON, June 25 -- Facing bitter Opposition attacks on United States policy in the Far East generally, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden tried to calm the storm today by justifying the heavy bombing attacks on Korean power plants on military grounds but conceding doubts on the political wisdom of the United States in ordering them carried out without informing or consulting the British Government.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 25 -- Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Green Terbell gave a dance here tonight at the Round Hill Club for their respective debutante daughters, Miss Joan Louise Terbell and Miss Margaret Adeline Gerli. Several dinner parties were held in advance of the dance.

DETROIT, June 25 (UP) -- Two former Tigers, George Kell and Hoot Evers, turned on their ex-team-mates with a home run apiece today to lead the Red Sox to a 10-3 victory over Detroit. The triumph raised Boston from third to second place.

The Atlantic Refining Company is planning a public sale of 1,000,000 new shares of common stock, Henderson Supplee Jr., president of the company, said yesterday. An underwriting syndicate headed by Smith, Barney Co. is to manage the distribution.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (UP) -- An Appropriations subcommittee of the House of Representatives cut $250,000,000 more from the Mutual Security Program today as Congress worked to clear away a backlog of appropriation bills in time to adjourn next week.
WASHINGTON, June 25 (UP) -- The Senate Commerce Committee pigeonholed today President Truman's controversial reappointment of Thomas C. Buchanan to the Federal Power Commission.

Eidophore, Twentieth Century-Fox's new method of televising live entertainment in color on large size motion picture screens, received its first official demonstration yesterday afternoon before an invited audience at the film company's home offices, 444 West Fifty-sixth Street.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 26 -- The non-white campaign to defy South Africa's "unjust laws" began today in Johannesburg and Port Elizabeth. Hundreds of police were mobilized throughout the country to act against the demonstrators.

HARRISBURG, Pa., June 26 -- Pennsylvania's Gov. John S. Fine said tonight he was "getting closer and closer" to the views of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower but refused to say he was for General Eisenhower for the Republican Presidential nomination.

Unseeded Carmen Lampe, 20-year-old Rollins College sophomore from Forest Hills, kept pace with the top three seeded-players to reach the semi-final round of the women's Eastern clay court tennis championships at the Bayside Tennis and Racquet Club yesterday.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 26 -- Miss Janet Brooks of Haddonfield, representing the National party, was elected Girl Governor of the 1952 Jersey Girls State at New Jersey College for Women campus today. She defeated Miss Barbara Brunton of Teaneck, the Federal party's candidate, 137 to 90.
PARIS, June 26 (AP) -- The North Atlantic Treaty Organization charged today that war prisoners in Soviet hands were being systematically killed off by forced labor in Russia and northern Siberia.

Having a wide and watery lagoon to contend with, Mike Todd, the enterprising pitch-man, has staged a huge, spectacular extravaganza at the New Marine Stadium at Jones Beach, which was dedicated last evening. The show is Johann Strauss' "A Night in Venice," full of familiar music which is good, and familiar operetta situations, which are not quite so comforting.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 26 -- Fifteen jet and rocket propulsion fellowships, the largest number in the five-year history of the Daniel and Florence Guggenheim awards, were announced today by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, in conjunction with the Guggenheim Foundation and the California Institute of Technology.

AUTHORSHIP, according to Frank Swinnerton, is a gloomy pastime. Publishing in "his era of dogmas, bigotries and scheming self-advertisement" is even more "parlous" than it has always been. As the author of more than thirty books and as a publisher of more than fifty years' standing, Mr. Swinnerton speaks with feeling on these and related matters.

The City of Camden, N. J., yesterday borrowed $7,953,000 in the public market on sewage disposal works bonds due serially from 1953 to 1987 at an interest cost of 2.568 per cent. The bonds were sold at public bidding to a syndicate headed by National City Bank.

Two new films will arrive at first-run houses today. "Wait Till the Sun Shines, Nellie," a Twentieth Century-Fox romantic drama in Technicolor, with David Wayne, Jean Peters, Hugh Marlowe, Albert Dekker and Helene Stanley, is at the Roxy.

BONN, Germany, June 26 --Following eight months of investigation, a parliamentary committee has filed a report expressing dissatisfaction with the choice of some West German diplomatic representatives on the ground that their previous association with a pre-war or wartime Foreign Ministry might damage the reputation of the Federal Republic.

What should a lawyer do when he is asked to represent unpopular clients? The New York Bar Association's Committee on Civil Rights wrestled with this question and last night came up with an answer, for presentation at the Association's annual summer meeting at Saranac Lake.

SPRINGFIELD, N. J., June 26 -- With this town virtually sitting on a powder keg as the result of the theft in the last few days of 211 sticks of dynamite from a storage shed of the Commonwealth Quarry here, Police Chief William J. Thompson today called on residents to search their premises to make sure they are not being used to hide the stolen explosives.
JONES BEACH, L. I., June 26 -- Governor Dewey dedicated tonight the new $4,000,000 Marine Stadium to "the good health, wholesome entertainment and the future enjoyment of the people of all states."

TRENTON, June 26 -- The State Supreme Court sustained today the Weehawken Board of Health in penalizing the New York Central Railroad for violations of the township's smoke-abatement ordinance. There were seventeen charges of emission from engines of dense smoke or negligent emission of smoke.

JACKSON, Miss., June 26 -- The groundwork for another possible revolt of Southern States' Rights Democrats, such as took place in 1948, was laid in the Mississippi Democratic State Convention here today.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 26 -- Representatives of the Sailors Union of the Pacific, A. F. L., and of the Pacific Maritime Association, bargaining agent for twenty- five West Coast shipping concerns, met at the call of Federal Conciliator Omar Hoskins here today but made no progress toward settlement of the strike that has tied up eighty-six ships for the last month. No further joint meetings are scheduled.

Clean-cut markings somewhat primitive in appearance characterize a large collection of hand-thrown and hand-incised ceramic pieces by David Holleman, a young Boston craftsman. This collection, composed of bowls, vases and plates, goes on display today at Pottery of All Nations, 108 Seventh Avenue South.

Some horse players do have sense. Several thousand decided it was too hot for winner-hunting, and stayed away from the Aqueduct session yesterday. The attendance -- 13,916 -- was the smallest of the New York campaign.
TORONTO, June 26 (AP) -- The Ontario Government today by order-in-council legalized the use of Ontario highways by United States trucks carrying freight in bond.

Time was when house organs were considered necessary evils by management and were read with suspicion by employes. All this has been changed, however, according to the Gebbie Press, publishers of "The Nation's Leading House Magazines."

HACKENSACK, N. J., June 26 -- Judge J. Wallace Leyden in Superior Court today sentenced Leo Link, who last week pleaded no defense to charges of violating the gambling laws of New Jersey, to one-and-a-half to two years in state prison.

Directors of the Standard Gas and Electric Company have approved a plan requiring the liquidation of the company and allocation of portfolio securities to all classes of stock, C. A. Johnson, acting chairman, announced yesterday.

MOSCOW, June 26 -- Minister of Cotton Production Usman Y. Ssupov in a press article said today that the 1952 target for cotton deliveries to the state had been set at 24 per cent above last year's deliveries or in the neighborhood of 4,750,000 metric tons.

A class in automobile damage appraisal was graduated last night at the Brooklyn High School of Automotive Trades, 50 Bedford Avenue. Twelve women were among the fifty-two students who received certificates. Unofficially they are classified as "doctors of damages."
Following is the text of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's radio address in Denver last night as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

The undemocratic acts by which a small minority controlled the majority in the Texas Republican primary is shocking and points up the very deep split in the party. If this were true in Texas and other Solid South states only, the cause for alarm as to the future of the Republican party might not be so great.

A nineteen-story and penthouse apartment building with 126 suites to replace the two-story garage at 442-444 East Fifty-sixth Street and 22-28 Sutton Place South was among plans filed yesterday witlT the Department of Housing and Buildings.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 26 -- George Jessel, after nearly ten years as a producer of musical shows for Twentieth Century-Fox, will terminate his association with the studio in September. Mr. Jessel said today that he is making plans to move into the field of independent movie making and that he also contemplates entering television on a "guest shot" performer basis.

RYE, N. Y., June 26 -- Only three in a field of 105 were able to break 80 in the intense heat today as the third day of play in the forty-eighth United States Seniors golf championship was completed over the famous Apawamis Club course.

Every day I delight in reading your very objective and moderate in tone editorials. As a refugee from a country beyond the Iron Curtain, accustomed to the Communist type of propaganda THE NEW YORK TIMES became for me the symbol of the American democracy and integrity.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- David L. Behncke, founder of the Airline Pilots Association, A. F. L., and president until ousted by the board of directors in July, 1951, was ordered reinstated by Judge Walter J. LaBuy in Federal District Court today.
TOKYO, Friday, June 27 (AP) -- United Nation Command communique 1,293, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Friday, Korea time:

The Public Service Commission has increased by 50 per cent the number of its gas meter testers in response to complaints from consumers that natural gas has resulted in excessive charging by the utility companies, which have been warned that they must cooperate or face penalties.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (UP) -- A high State Department official said today that the Central Intelligence Agency had represented a false report that Prof. Owen Lattimore had planned to visit Moscow as a confirmed fact.

JERSEY CITY, June 26 -- The second wildcat strike of marine warehousemen in three days today delayed shipments of material for the construction of Air Force bases overseas from the Army Corps of Engineers pier at the Claremont Terminal here.
A syndicate of investment banking houses headed by Goldman, Sachs Co. will place on the market today 500,000 shares of common stock of the Blockson Chemical Company of Joliet, Ill.

The stock market yesterday pushed into the best ground since January, but the absence of any real buying interest failed to prove the advance to be a major move. It was a highly selective market marked by a rotation of interest, although the heavy industrials, such as the steels and motors attracted scant attention.

AFTER glancing through reports from scattered salt-water ports up and down the coast. Montauk appears to be the best bet for the week-end, at least when it comes to volume as well as variety of fish. However, there is every chance that school tuna may show up in numbers from Brielle to Shinnecock.

Six vacant parcels in the Bronx, Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island were sold at auction by the Board of Estimate of the City of New York for a total of $32,450. The sale was conducted in the Municipal Building by Henry G. Waltemade, auctioneer.
The Girl Scouts of the United States had a membership of 1,770,000 between the ages of 7 and 17 in 1951, according to the organization's annual report to Congress.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Senator Robert A. Taft in an aroused mood today assailed what he termed a "Dewey-inspired" propaganda campaign minimizing his chance of carrying New York State should he gain the Republican Presidential nomination. He gave no indication, however, that he felt the "Dewey" campaign was hurting his chance for the nomination.

Mayor Impellitteri has five important appointments to make on the Board of Higher Education, which, under the chairmanship of Ordway Tead, administers our municipal colleges -- City, Hunter, Brooklyn and Queens. Terms expire on June 30 and, save for appointments to fill vacancies, run for nine years or until a successor is appointed.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 26 -- Jacob A. Malik, the Soviet representative and President of the Security Council for June, protested today against the fact that "thousands" of women demonstrators were not allowed inside the United Nations headquarters yesterday.

Four Ohio youngsters who were to have left here Wednesday for a camp of the Children's International Summer Villages, Inc., in Ste. Colombe, France, departed yesterday afternoon on an Air France plane for Paris.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art announced yesterday that two sets of regional juries would judge its forthcoming national art competition -- the last of three covering various fields. One jury will be composed of artists of the "modern" school and the other of artists of the conservative.

A syndicate headed by Ed R. Wolfe has purchased two five-story apartment buildings, each with twenty-five suites, at 1348 and 1352 Clinton Avenue, the Bronx, from the Mansco Realty Corporation. The property is assessed at $97,000.

LONDON, June 26 (AP) -- The British Press Association said tonight Emmanuel Shinwell, Minister of Defense in the former Labor Government, denied that Britain brought pressure on President Truman to remove General of the Army Douglas MacArthur.

The market behavior of the Treasury's new issue of 2 3 8's in the face of liquidation sales by "free riders" is so impressive as to suggest that the "nonbank-investment" character of the big borrowing may have a longer tenure than the fortnight first predicted.

In your editorial "St. Lawrence Quietus" you appear to overlook the fact that Canada has now, and has for many years had a so-called seaway. Therefore, she needs no international consent to go it alone.

PARIS, June 26 -- The special anti-inflation loan of the French Government, its capital value based on gold, which will soon be closed, is now expected by official experts to bring in about 150,000,000,000 francs in new money -- that is apart from the portion of the loan that will be merely conversion of old bonds into new.

The question of who owns -- or who will own -- Colonial Airlines got little closer to settlement yesterday, despite the fact that bids were made for the line by Eastern Air Lines, National Airlines and Northeast Airlines.

Although it has long been known that iron is abundant on the floors of the world's oceans, the fact never stirred much interest because development of such deposits seemed remote and difficult. At least one such mine has been worked in recent years, however.

ROME, June 26 -- In a spectacular dash to freedom today three men armed with revolvers took charge of a Yugoslav commercial airliner on a flight from Belgrade to Pola and landed it safely on a disused airstrip at Foligno near Perugia.

ROME, June 26 -- Myron C. Taylor, who was personal representative to the Vatican of the late President Roosevelt and President Truman until he resigned in December, 1949, was received in a private audience by Pope Pius XII this morning and remained in conversation with him for thirty-five minutes.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -Thirty thousand policemen went back to school today in classrooms from Milwaukee to Boston to study up on what to do if an atomic bomb should strike.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 26 -- A gift of United States school children to the United Nations, a nine-spray fountain set in a huge circular pool, was dedicated today and added its touch of coolness to a sweltering First Avenue.

BERLIN, June 26 -- A United States Army General Court Martial today sentenced to five years imprisonment and dishonorable discharge an American soldier who had been convicted of robbing a German taxicab driver and subsequently escaping from the Army stockade and into East Berlin.

When the final signal is given at 3 P. M. today, a huge army, tested and primed, will storm forth and take over the city's streets, parks and playgrounds or leave for camps. Citizens nervously chewing their fingernails may make defensive plans, but resistance will be useless.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The House of Representatives voted, 278 to 113, tonight to pass again the McCarran-Walter bill to overhaul and codify the immigration, naturalization and nationality laws, in the face of President Truman's veto message yesterday.

As a site for eighty new homes in the ranch and split-level styles, a tract of sixteen acres on Hicksville Road, south of Southern State Parkway, Wantagh, L. I., has been purchased by Benjamin Walker, builder, from Nathan Levine. Paul R. Gale of Freeport was the broker.
Paul G. Hoffman, chairman of the Advisory Committee of Citizens for Eisenhower, announced yesterday that the following fourteen persons had been added to membership of the committee:

The Greater New York Fund campaign this year has raised $6,215,212, more by $322,290 than the best of its previous fourteen campaigns. Additional thousands of dollars are expected to push the record mark even higher by the end of the year, after the clean-up part of the campaign.

Robert E. Dwyer was elected president of the Anaconda Copper Mining Company and its subsidiaries to succeed the late William H. Hoover, it was announced by Cornelius F. Kelley, board chairman, following the meeting of the board of directors yesterday.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 11 -- A new machine with which letters are sorted much faster than is possible by the orthodox hand method is being demonstrated here in conjunction with the Universal Postal Union Congress.

ST. LOUIS, June 26 (AP) -- Vic Wertz' three-run homer in the first inning, one of the longest balls hit at Sportsman's Park, started the Tigers off on a 6-to-0 triumph over Ned Garver and the Browns tonight.

A three-alarm fire that started shortly after 6:30 A. M. yesterday in a hold of the Norwegian motor freighter Samuel A. Bakke, moored at a Brooklyn pier, was still smoldering early this morning. Fireboats and fire equipment were standing by.
OCEANPORT, N. J., June 26 (AP) -- The Craigwood Stable's Palatial Appetite, won the banquet purse over the infield turf course at Monmouth Park today.

VICTORIA, B. C., June 26 -- Two unusual multiple stars, one a spectroscopic triple and the other a system of four stars revolving with different periods around a common center of gravity, were described here today before the joint meeting of the American Astronomical Society and the Astronomical Society of the Pacific.

GENEVA, June 26 -- The organization established by the Moscow trade conference to promote trade across the Iron Curtain, or at least talk about trade across the Iron Curtain, has changed its name and is seeking a permanent home in Geneva.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The Office of Price Stabilization today denied price relief to manufacturers of power and hand lawn mowers on the ground that the industry's earnings did not merit special consideration from the agency. The decision requires producers to continue determining their selling prices under the manufacturers' general ceiling price regulation.

A forty-eight-inch water main at the intersection of Jerome Avenue and 176th Street, the Bronx, burst at 2:05 o'clock yesterday morning, forcing fifty-two families from two apartment buildings, lifting paving blocks and parked cars and flooding a four-block area with two feet of water.

Examination of records showing the qualifications of 137 exempt city employes, including eight key members of Mayor Impellitteri's official staff, whose jobs are not dependent on Civil Service tests, will be started soon by the Citizens Budget Commission.

LOS ANGELES, June 26 -- Mrs. Oleta O'Connor Yates, one of fourteen California Communist leaders on trial in Federal Court, was sentenced to jail here today for an indeterminate term when she refused to answer five questions asked by the prosecution.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The Defense Production Administration reported today that military airplane production in May was right on the reduced schedule set after January's stretch-out -- 800 planes a month.

Implementing one of the recommendations of the recent education management study of the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey, the Board of Education yesterday appointed Dr. Frederic Ernst to the $25,000-a-year post of Deputy Superintendent of Schools.

BOISE, Ida., June 26 -- Abandonment of economic controls at this time would drive the cost of the defense program substantially upward and deprive the country of butter as well as guns, Averell Harriman declared today as he carried his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination from the coast of Oregon to southwestern Idaho.

BONN, Germany, June 26 -- The first reading of the two bills containing the Bonn Peace Contract and the European Defense Community treaty will be held in the Bundestag (Parliament) July 9 and 10, according to an announcement by the Bundestag's Council of Elders.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (UP) -- The Government told a newspaper advisory committee today that the program for a 50 per cent increase in domestic newsprint production by 1955 has bogged down at the three-quarter mark.

A few days ago, when it became known that the Soviet Government had suddenly and unexpectedly requested new talks on the long-standing problem of its wartime Lend-Lease account with the United States, hope flickered that here at last there might be a real effort to end that seven-year-old dispute.

The Germans like to spread lard on their bread, lard sometimes flavored with rose petals and sometimes sprinkled with sugar; they call it schmalz. But we shy away front a bread spread that is white. To suit our eye, as important in eating as our palate, the spread must be yellow.

Even if all retail sales clerks were walking enclycopedias, they could do little to make up for the failure of many manufacturers to provide sales-producing information on labels, members of the National Retail Dry Goods Association were told yesterday.

THERE was an air of unreality to the entire business. Joey Maxim did nothing and won the fight. Sugar Ray Robinson did everything and lost it. Perhaps Robinson, a proud and vain man, became too enamoured by his own magnificence. The artistry of the Harlem millionaire, especially over the first seven rounds, was positively breathtaking.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 26 -- Richard S. Nye's Class C yawl, Carina, today was declared the winner of the Newport-to-Bermuda ocean yacht race with most of the fifty-eight competing craft officially checked in at the finish line. Roderick Stephens Jr.'s Mustang took second place on corrected time and G. W. B. White's White Mist third.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The House of Representatives affirmed today its decision of yesterday requesting President Truman to use the Taft-Hartley Law to try to stop the steel strike. The vote was 228 to 164.
TOKYO, Friday, June 27 -- Allied truce negotiators walked out of the conference tent at Panmunjom today, forcing a third three-day recess in the Korean armistice talks.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Department store sales in the week{ fended June 21 were 6 per cent labove sales in the corresponding iweek' of last year. This was reIported today by the Federal Re}serve Board which listed the fol{lowing ehange from like periods of 1951:
The police moved into action on two fronts yesterday in connection with violations of the auto-use tax stamp law.
The investigation of violations of safety and fire laws in tenements in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens proceeded along several fronts yesterday.

ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., June 26 (AP) -- New Mexico Democrats today picked twenty-four delegates with twelve votes in the national convention, which opens July 21 in Chicago. Supporters of Senator Robert S. Kerr of Oklahoma promptly claimed at least eight votes on the first ballot.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- It may or may not be true, as charged by the Republican supporters of General Eisenhower in Louisiana, that the pro-Taft state organization has had valuable guidance from henchmen of the late Senator Huey P. Long in throwing out pro-Eisenhower delegates.
The cotton futures markets on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday, and final prices were 42 to 61 points net lower than on Wednesday.

Elizabeth Gurley Flynn, a leader of the Communist party of the United States, spent her second full day on the witness stand in the Federal Court House yesterday as the Subversive Activities Control Board continued its hearings into whether the party was engaged in Communist action.

PARIS, June 25 -- A troublesome and embarrassing problem is now being discussed by those Czechoslovak Communist leaders responsible for educating the nation's youth -- should the standard textbooks used in primary and secondary schools be revised for the third time in three years to assure that boys and girls now growing up are taught according to current Stalinist doctrine?

The charter of the Grand Lodge of the Knights of Pythias of the State of New York was suspended yesterday by the Supreme Lodge for nonpayment of per capita taxes. The state organization has 80,000 members in 358 lodges.

ROME, June 26 -- A battle of words over United States actions in Korea between John Steinbeck, United States author, and Ezio Taddei, a Communist writer, has been raging for almost two weeks now in newspapers here.

Robert W. White has been elect-I ed a director of the American Lacomotive Company. Formerly a vice president and treasurer of{ Union Carbide and Carbon Corpo-I ration, Mr. White is a member ofi Robert White Associates, business consultsm.

TRENTON, June 26 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll and former Gov. Walter E. Edge separately urged tonight that New Jersey's thirty-eight delegates to the Republican National Convention regard the recent state primary as a "mandate" to cast their votes for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower.

In the face of inflated prices, defense needs and actual or threatened shortages of some vital supplies, architects must cooperate to the fullest extent possible with the building industry in efficient, economical plans and conservation of materials.

What makes us so reluctant to change traditional -- and often unproductive -- teaching techniques in the secondary schools, anyway? Dr. Frederick L. Redefer's exhaustive survey of the million - dollar "Eight - Year Study" shows that a promising educational experiment begun twenty years ago has virtually withered away.

The salaries of all judges and official referees paid in full or in part by the city were increased yesterday by the Board of Estimate. Under the board's action 264 judges and seventeen official referees will receive pay rises totaling $460,167 a year.

Sally Victor is off with a head start to a new and what looks like a successful season. She may use hifalutin names, like those of Leonardo da Vinci, Piero della Francesco and Andrea del Sarto to tag her millinery inventions for fall and winter, but when you get down to plain facts, she has made a lot of wearable and attractive hats.

BERLIN, June 26 -- The three Western High Commissioners asked Gen. Vassily I. Chuikov, chairman of the Soviet Control Commission, today to hasten his reply to the Allied protest of April 29 concerning the Soviet jet fighter plane attack that day on a French airliner.

LOS ANGELES, June 26 (AP) -- The first half of the powerful 1952 United States Olympic track team will be chosen tomorrow in final tryouts in Memorial Coliseum that promise to be as spirited as the games themselves.

John Golden, one of Broadway's elder statesmen, sang a Chinese ditty he wrote many years ago, recalled some of his past theatrical experiences and received the nomination for President of the United States from an admiring colleague at a birthday luncheon given in the showman's honor yesterday at Sardi's Restaurant, although the anniversary actually is today.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended June 21, 1952, totaled 643,860 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 12,817 cars, or 2 per cent more than for the preceding week, 189,082 cars, or 22.7 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year and 166,111 cars, or 20.5 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., June 26 -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, told the nineteenth session of the University of Virginia's Institute of Public Affairs tonight that the overriding problem of the present time, and the overriding responsibility of the National Administration, was to preserve the fiscal and moral integrity of the United States.

Five men were indicted yesterday by a Brooklyn Federal grand jury on a charge of conspiring to steal 28,000 pounds of high grade beef en route from Sioux City, Iowa, to this city last March. The men are out on bail and have been ordered to appear for pleading in Brooklyn Federal Court on July 8.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 26 -- Government, a form of "public housewifery," should be of particular interest to women who in the past have "failed to translate their educated faculties into public action," Miss Mary Donlon, chairman of the New York State Workmen's Compensation Board, said today at the forty-third annual convention of the American Home Economics Association.

Five men, including a suspended New York City policeman, were indicted yesterday in the burglary of the Brevoort Post Office Station, 1205 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, on April 29, 1951. A large-size safe was broken open arid $15,083 in cash and $14,000 in travelers' checks were taken.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 26 -- Solution of the problem of economic production of electric power from atomic energy, with simultaneous manufacture of vitally needed plutonium, is "believed to have been found," Edwin J. Putzell Jr., secretary of the Monsanto Chemical Company of St. Louis, said here today.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- During the week ended June 25, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, member bank reserves decreased $1,226,000,000. The principal changes reducing reserves were a decrease of $1,075,000,000 in Reserve Bank credit, and increases of $125,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve banks, $50,000,000 in other deposits with Federal Reserve banks, and $27,000,000 in money in circulation.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, said today that a big brokerage concern had settled a $38,000,000 tax claim for $850,000 soon after discharging its other lawyers and hiring William M. Boyle Jr., former Democratic National Chairman.

CLEVELAND, June 26 -- An appeal to religious leaders of all faiths to make "the power of ethical religion felt again in the world by striving for world peace and human brotherhood" was made by Rabbi Ira Eisenstein of New York after he had been elected today president of the Rabbinical Assembly of America.

DENVER, June 26 -- In his sharpest attack on the Truman Administration since he entered the Presidential campaign, General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower tonight condemned it as too easy on corruption at home and on communism abroad. He called for a "good old-fashioned clean-up and clean-out" in Washington.

Ships putting out to sea tooted in salute yesterday as they passed the Floating Hospital of St. John's Guild, aboard which 1,000 aged persons were towed around New York harbor for their annual outing. "I didn't get a picture of the Liberte," Mrs. Mary Watts, 64 years old, said sadly. "It went by too fast."

HAVANA, June 26 -- President Fulgencio Batista today denied widespread and persistent reports of conflict between himself and the young army officers who spearheaded the swift military coup of March 10 which ousted President Carlos Prio Socarras.

Judge Harold R. Medina told lawyers in the investment banking anti-trust trial yesterday that he is beginning to "go along" with the Government view that investment bankers represent their banking business when they serve as directors of companies issuing securities.

The Lone Star Mariner, first of the five Mariner class vessels under construction by the Ingalls Shipbuilding Corporation at Pascagoula, Miss., will be launched on July 8, with Mrs. Albert W. Gatov, wife of a member of the Federal Maritime Board, as her sponsor.
Mortgage financing totaling $754,600 has been arranged by J. Halperin Co., brokers, for three new housing developments on Long Island.

Forty-two United States carriers yesterday were named winners of the National Safety Council's 1951 aviation safety awards. The annual awards go only to domestic, territorial and overseas scheduled carriers.

LONDON, June 26 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson told members of the British Parliament today that it was only because of an administrative mistake that British Ministers had not been informed of the United States Air Forces' intention to bomb the North Korean power plants on the Yalu River.

BOLTON LANDING, N. Y., June 26 (AP) -- A Rochester banker today told the New York State Association of Real Estate Boards "to keep a finger on the pulse of demand" because, he said, demand will exert a major influence on real estate activity in the next few years.

TRENTON, June 26 -- The State Supreme Court, on a technicality of procedure, declined today to approve increases in intrastate commutation fares on the New Jersey Central and New York and Long Branch Railroads.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 26 -- The Soviet Union failed today to win a majority in the United Nations Security Council for its resolution calling on all states that have not ratified or acceded to the Geneva protocol of 1925, which prohibits bacteriological warfare, to do so.

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, June 27 (AP) -- Allied warplanes hit Communist North Korea's electric power stations Thursday, with about 150 jet fighter-bombers and other planes showering destruction on the already battered hydro-electric system.
Fish that inhabit the waters of the Scotland Lightship area are enjoying a diet of Spanish potatoes today, thanks to an almost invisible worm known as the golden nematode.

Minimum wages of $1.15 an hour for restaurant workers who do not receive tips and 95 cents an hour for those who do were recommended to the New York State Restaurant Minimum Wage Board by union spokesmen yesterday. At the same time, spokesmen for restaurant owners warned that excessive minimum wages would jeopardize the continued existence of eating places throughout the state, particularly the smaller ones.

In the name of expediency we are creating a dangerous situation in emphasizing in the conduct of our domestic and foreign affairs what we abhor in the Communist ideology, without reaffirming concretely our positive positions. It is not enough to be anti. That is only a partial position.

OKLAHOMA CITY, June 26 -- The moral issue in the 1952 Presidential campaign must be the "mobilization of every decent American in an all-out crusade to square American democracy's day-to-day practice with its noble promises in the field of civil rights," Walter Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., declared tonight.

HANOVER, N. H., June 26 -- S. C. Hollister, dean of the Cornell University College of Engineering, received tonight the Lamme Medal of the American Society for Engineering Education, which is holding its sixtieth annual meeting at Dartmouth College.

LONDON, June 26 -- United States officials, who have been bitterly attacked for failing to tell the British Government of the plan to attack Korean power stations, were accused tonight by Herbert Morrison, Foreign Secretary in the former Labor Government, of talking too much -- and inaccurately -- about agreements to which he was a party.
The Interstate Commerce Commission in Washington ordered yesterday public hearings on a plan of reorganization of the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road as proposed by the Pennsylvania Railroad.

The harm done to international relations by uninformed or misinformed public opinion has seldom been so conspicuously exemplified as in the furor raised in the House of Commons by the bombing of the power plants in North Korea. American actions or attitudes often evoke expressions of exasperation in allied countries, just as they do at home.

The city was flooded yesterday with reports that Ray Robinson was in a hospital following his fourteenth round collapse against Joey Maxim in their world light-heavyweight title bout at Yankee Stadium Wednesday night.

SINGAPORE, June 26 -- Steady progress is being made in the struggle to defeat communism in Southeast Asia, Malcolmn MacDonald told a press conference here today. The British Commissioner General for the area reviewed conditions in the region before leaving tomorrow for a week's visit in Japan where he is scheduled to discuss problems effecting Japanese relationships with British and other Southeast Asian territories.
BALTIMORE, June 26 (AP) -- Archie Moore, the light-heavy-weight contender, stepped up and defeated one of the ranking heavy-weights, Clarence Henry, by a unanimous decision tonight.

The first appearance of Rise Stevens, Metropolitan Opera mezzo-soprano, on Saturday, July 5, and the twenty-first annual Gershwin Night, on Thursday, July 3, will be highlights of next week's programs at Lewisohn Stadium.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 26 (AP) -- A man and his dog stand equal chances of surviving or dying in an atomic bombing, a research veterinarian reposed today. For both men and dogs, the average deadly dose of radiation is about 400 to 450 units, Dr. Arthur H. Wolff of Washington, a Federal Security Agency veterinarian, said.

LONDON, June 26 -- Today's program at Wimbledon in the all-England lawn tennis championships offered no particular pairing to excite interest but more than 26,000 turned out for the fourth day of competition in warm, sunny weather.

Perle Mesta, United States Minister to Luxembourg, asserted yesterday that women knew more about what was going on in the world than men did. Appropriately, Mrs. Mesta was speaking at the annual board meeting of the International Federation of Business and Professional Women.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- A bill to provide $45,734,750,912, or $5,186,271,858 less than President Truman had requested, was recommended to the Senate today by its Appropriations Committee to operate the Department of Defense through the fiscal year starting next Tuesday.

BERLIN, June 26 -- The International Confederation of Free Trade Unions said today that French and United States authorities had blocked or impeded the travel to Berlin of two members of its eighteen-man executive board.

OTTAWA, Ont., June 26 -- Canadian exports in May totaled a record $390,800,000, it was announced today. Figures compiled by the Dominion Bureau of Statistics showed that the increase last month was in volume, while export prices were slightly less than a year ago.

Prime Minister Churchill's suggestion that Britain should have stronger high-level representation in the United Nations Korean command has been favorably received by the United States. Secretary of State Acheson yesterday proposed the appointment of a British officer to be Deputy Chief of Staff to General Clark, and the British are studying his proposal.

The shift in the Dutch political balance after Wednesday's general election was slight, but it had some significance and it caught everyone by surprise. In the previous Second Chamber, elected in 1948, there were thirty-two Catholic People's party members and twenty-seven from the Labor party, out of a total of 100 seats.

TOLEDO, Ohio, June 26 (AP) -- Ed (Porky) Oliver and Doug Ford were hotter than the 100-degree temperature today as they took the lead in the opening round of the $18,000 Inverness invitation round-robin best-ball golf tournament.
The bizarre circumstances surrounding the Joey Maxim-Ray Robinson fight were not confined to the ring. There were some bewildering doings in the world of radio, too.

NEW DELHI, India, June 26 -- Mrs. Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit, leader of the Indian Cultural delegation to Communist China, declared today that the over-all impression gained by members during their five-week tour of that country was one of "admiration" for the enthusiasm and disciplined energy with which the Chinese people were solving their difficult problems and for the measure of success achieved by them.

Five graduates of city high schools, whose scores in college entrance examinations placed them in the top 1 per cent of the country's secondary school graduates, were awarded yesterday Grand Street Boys Foundation Maintenance Scholarships of $1,200 a year for four years.
CHICAGO, June 26 -- Selling pressure increased moderately in grains today, but the outstanding feature appeared to be the absence of any aggressive demand.

LONDON, June 26 -- A slightly improved investment demand brought widespread small price rises on the stock market here today. Nearly all leading industrials finished at the day's best with many gains of one shilling (14 cents) or better.
