THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, June 26 -- Queen Juliana began consulting her political advisers today preliminary to selecting some one to form a new Cabinet. Willem Drees, 65-year-old caretaker Premier whose Labor party won an unexpected plurality in yesterday's elections, was expected to be her choice.
DENVER, June 26 -- The Taft-Eisenhower race has now reached the phase of psychological warfare and this is conducted in a political campaign very much as it is carried on in a military campaign.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Held in line by a plea that something better might come out of conference, Fair Dealers in the House of Representatives supplied the votes late today to pass a controls bill that had been riddled in earlier voting by a Republican-Southern Democratic coalition.
Advancing for the third successive time, loans to business by New York banks rose $8,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 26 -- Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson of the Cherry Valley Club moved a step closer to her fifth title in the Women's Long Island Golf Association match play championship at the Meadowbrook Club today with a 4-and-3 victory over Roslyn (Cookie) Swift of Glen Oaks.

It seems easier to get or keep warm than it does to get or keep cool. Hence hot weather induces a feeling of helplessness that cold weather does not. It promotes gloom, which is only partially relieved by the information, sometimes relayed to New Yorkers by the Weather Bureau from its local station on a breezy roof-top thirty stories above the street, that a record has been broken.

Bizet's "Carmen," with Mildred Miller singing the title role, was performed last evening in concert form at Lewisohn Stadium. Richard Tucker was the Don Jose, Elaine Malbin the Micaela, and Frank Guarrera the Escamillo. The chorus was that of the Schola Cantorum.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 26 (AP) -- Results of matches today in the Wimbledon lawn tennis championships:
WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- The Senate sent to conference with the House tonight a bill to raise old age and survivors insurance benefits by an estimated $300,000,000 a year.
New York was one big concrete and asphalt baking oven yesterday. For the second consecutive day it had record June temperatures.

Four-year college scholarships for five high school graduates whose parents are members of Local 32-B, Building Service Employes International Union, A. F. L., were presented here yesterday at tile Roosevelt Hotel by Governor Dewey.

The Department of Health announced yesterday that it had completed preparations for the administration of the new Metcalf-Hatch Act, which requires the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals and other publicly aided pounds to turn over stray dogs and cats for approved medical research projects.
ROME, June 26 -- Giuseppe Paratore was elected President of the Italian Senate today to succeed Enrico de Nicola, who resigned last week.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26 (UP) -- Patty Berg, beating the 98-degree heat with ice applications, posted a 69 today to take the opening-round lead in the women's national open golf championship and tie the tournament record for a one-round score.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Mrs. Katherine G. Howard, Secretary of the Republican National Committee said today that she, on her sole responsibility, had certified to the Republican National Committee thirty-eight Texas delegate contests.

SARANAC, N. Y., June 26 -- On the eve of the two-day summer meeting of the New York State Bar Association here, its Committee on Civil Rights presented a report tonight reaffirming the rights and duties of lawyers to represent any client, regardless of the unpopularity of either the client or his cause.
Navy's undefeated varsity eight will row against Princeton and Harvard in a preliminary heat in the Olympic trials at Lake Quinsigamond, Worcester, Mass., next Thursday.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- Production of military electronic and communications equipment, combined with the civilian output of radio-TV receivers and replacement parts exceed the peak output of the industry during World War II, Glen McDanile, president of the Radio-Television Manufacturers Association, said today in a report to the association's twenty-eighth annual convention.

Between 1950 and 1953 the rate of production of the newer synthetic fibers will increase 300 per cent, and the total production capacity next year will be more than 400,000,000 pounds, according to C. W. Bendigo of the new product development department of the American Cyanamid Company.

A much sought after actor, Arthur Kennedy, absent from this vicinity since "Death of A Salesman," has been signed for the stellar role in "See the Jaguar." The announcement was made yesterday by Lemuel Ayers, producer of the N. Richard Nash play in association with Whitfield Cook.

Thank you for your editorial of June 20 about the city's firetraps. As a public health nurse, I am astonished by the number of so-called dwelling houses where people live, crowded into two rooms or less, certainly insufficient for satisfactory family life. I find these people on the whole anxious for better lives and desirous of doing something about it.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 26 (AP) -The order of finish in the 75-mile Ncwport=to-lcnnuda race, giving name of yacht, class, elapsed time and corrected time (days, hours, minutes and seconds):
LAFAYETTE, Ind., June 26 (AP) -- An all-new field was set up today for quarter-finals of the fifty-fifth National Collegiate A. A. golf tournament.

Air-cooled Madison Square Garden tonight rings down the curtain on its indoor boxing season with a middleweight feature on a balanced card. Ernie (The Rock) Durando, Bayonne, N. J. contender for Ray Robinson's 160-pound crown, is to box Norman Hayes of Boston in a struggle scheduled for ten rounds.

Retail meat prices have begun to reflect the previous week's slump at wholesale. Two cuts each of pork and lamb and one of beef are 2 to 4 cents a pound cheaper, the city Department of Markets reported yesterday. No appreciable declines occurred this week, however, in wholesale meat prices, the department said.

For outstanding help in promoting closer relations between the United States and Ecuador, THE NEW YORK TIMES received last night one of ten Garcia Moreno Medal awards from the Ecuadorian-American Chamber of Commerce of 2 Broadway at the chamber's twelfth annual dinner, which was held in the Downtown Athletic Club, 18 West Street. Fifty persons attended.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Word that ice prices no longer would be controlled by the Office of Price Stabilization went out today to consumers sweltering in one of the nation's severest heat waves. The agency's action was accompanied by assurance that there was little likelihood that a sharp rise in ice prices would result from the ruling.
Directors of the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway increased the dividend on the common stock with the declaration yesterday of $1.25 a share, for payment on Sept. 2.

Eric Sevareid, director of the Washington News Bureau of the Columbia Broadcasting System [and author of "Not So ,,Vild a Dream," has brought together under tlle title "In One Ear" some of his radio news commentaries about Washington and its inhabitants.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The name of Eisenhower, next to that of Stalin, is the best known name in Russia and the election of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower to the Presidency would cause such pressure within Russia that the Kremlin chieftains would be forced to sit down and talk peace eventually, Paul G. Hoffman, chairman of the Citizens for Eisenhower Advisory Committee, said tonight.

LOS ANGELES, June 26 -- James C. Petrillo, the peppery leader of the American Federation of Musicians, A. F. L., threatened today to "fire" Artur Rodzinski from the union and thereby prevent his conducting in the United States, for having made foreign phonograph recordings without union permission.

EDDYVILLE, Ky., June 26 (AP) -- About 300 mutinous convicts in the Kentucky State Prison surrendered at 7:15 o'clock tonight after eight hours of rioting in which eight convicts were wounded and a guard was injured.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The House Appropriations Committee slashed $3,467,554,500 today from a supplemental appropriation bill in which President Truman had requested $13,750,688,280 for the armed forces, the Mutual Security Program, atomic energy expansion and other purposes.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- President Truman today called for a "more orderly" system of deferring skilled industrial and farm workers and told the Armed Forces to stop recruiting farm workers who are deferred from the draft.

With coffee futures leading the way, there were more price gains than losses in commodity futures prices on local exchanges yesterday. Advances were also scored by rubber, cocoa, wool tops, cottonseed oil, and most sugar deliveries. Hides declined and lead and soybean oil were mixed, as tin closed unchanged, with zinc unchanged to slightly lower.

Coffee production in South America is being stepped up to a rate that will meet all the needs of the American people in the foreseeable future, Edward Aborn, president of the National Coffee Association, said yesterday. He has just returned from Brazil.

DENVER, June 26 (AP) -- Four Western Republican governors said today Republican tickets in their states could get more votes in November if the party's nominee for President was General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower instead of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio.

That the present urge for simplicity in decoration does not spell the doom of elegance was expressed yesterday by William Pahlmann, a decorator, in a speech to the wives of architects attending the eighty - fourth convention of the American Institute of Architects at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- A top executive of the Seagram Distillers Corporation acknowledged today that he and other officials of the company had contributed $50,000 to the Democratic and Republican campaign chests in 1948.
The Murray Corporation of America, automotive parts makers, suffered a sharp decline in sales and earnings in the nine months ended with May, according to the report issued yesterday.

The five-story apartment house on lot 26.8 by 109 feet at 12 Gramercy Park has been sold by the Bahn Realty Corporation to Joseph L. Ennis Co., operators, in a deal negotiated by Frances Spencer, Inc., and H. Stanley Hillyer, Inc., brokers. It is assessed at $70,000.

The Board of Estimate unanimously approved yesterday the local law passed by the City Council on May 27 to increase taxicab rates by 27 per cent. The measure is expected to become effective in mid-July. Mayor Impellitteri is scheduled to sign it within ten days, after a public hearing in his office at City Hall.

William White, president of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad, was elected yesterday president and chief executive officer of the New York Central Railroad Company, effective Aug. 1, the railroad announced yesterday.

New lags in military production are worrying defense officials. On many key weapons we are falling behind the shaved-down schedules that were adopted in the first quarter of this year, and production planners are seeking ways to check the slippage before it becomes a habit.

LONDON, June 26 -- At a preliminary hearing, from part of which the public was excluded, William M. Marshall, a young Foreign Office radio operator, was held without bail today for trial on a charge of communicating official secrets to Pavel Kuznetsov, second secretary of the Soviet Embassy.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 26 -- Dr. Vannevar Bush and about 30,000 American scientists under his leadership who comprised the Office of Scientific Research and Development in World War II received high praise here tonight from Gilbert H. Montague, New York lawyer.
Apparently all Sal Maglie ever needed was another good look at a Brooklyn uniform.

NEW DELHI, India, June 26 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru told Parliament today it would be a bad move to take the Indian-Pakistan dispute over Kashmir out of the hands of the United Nations.
PUSAN, Korea, Friday, June 27 (UP) -- President' Syngman Rhee today ordered all censorship in Korea "abolished immediately" except on subjects of military security.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (UP) -The Senate overwhelmingly rejected tonight a House plan for reducing the taxes of members of Congress by permitting them to deduct their living expenses while they are in Washington.

DETROIT, June 27 -- The Ford Motor Company announced today that its assembly lines would be at a standstill at the end of the working day Monday, although manufacturing would continue through Wednesday or possibly Thursday at a diminishing rate.

HOUSTON, Tex., June 27 (UP) -- H. J. Porter, General Eisenhower's campaign leader in Texas, said today that he doubted the Taft forces could get enough documentation in the "hold of the Queen Mary to justify the brazen steal of delegates" in this state.

It had been hoped that after a day's consideration the House of Representatives might think better of the action it took on Wednesday, when, sitting as a committee of the whole, it voted to end all price-wage controls. It did, in fact, reverse itself on the most extreme single amendment contained in its bill extending the Defense Production Act.

HAGERSTOWN, Md., June 27 -- A "Flying Van," a transport that is a larger cousin to the "Flying Boxcars" being used in Korea as troop and cargo carriers, was put through fighter plane maneuvers in a demonstration from the Hagerstown Municipal Airport today.

Despite substantially larger taxes, Deere Co. and its subsidiaries, manufacturers of farm machinery, increased earnings over the corresponding period last year, reflecting the sharp gain in sales during the six months ended on April 30.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, June 27 -- Acknowledging the victory of the Dutch Labor party at the polls. Queen Juliana asked her caretaker Premier, Willem Drees, today to form a new Cabinet. She acted after the customary consultations with the leaders of all parties.

BANGKOK, Thailand, June 18 -- Already the world's largest exporter of rice, Thailand is initiating projects whereby the Government hopes to double the present annual export of 1,500,000 tons, in from three to five years. A rice-improvement program being financed by the United States Mutual Security Agency and conducted by United States experts, figures prominently in Thailand's plans.
Remedial action to remove the causes of criticism of advertising was urged yesterday at the mid-year sales promotion convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

CHICAGO, June 28 -- Long liquidation was heavy in July wheat today on the Board of Trade and the market dropped to a new low for that delivery, hedge pressure being a factor, with the bearish winter wheat statistics discouraging any active buying.

Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. requires special permission from the New York County Democratic Committee to seek renomination as a Democrat in the August primary because he failed to register or enroll last year, it became known yesterday.

The terms of two members of the Board of Transportation were shuffled yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri to make possible the appointment of Chairman Sidney H. Bingham for a full six-year tenure, expiring June 30, 1958, and the extension of the term of Commissioner James F. Dulligan for two years beyond next Monday's expiration date.

BONN, Germany, June 27 -Whatever the Western Big Three foreign ministers agreed in drafting a note to the Soviet Union on the German question, authoritative sources here made it clear that Chancellor Konrad Adenauer would have a very important say in the phraseology of the note before it was dispatched to Moscow.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Four more executives of big liquor companies testified today that they had made substantial campaign contributions to the Democratic and Republican parties.
PADUCAH, Ky., June 27 (UP) -- A strike of 4,500 laborers made almost 20,000 other workers idle today and stopped construction work on the huge $500,000,000 atomic energy project near here.

Some eighteen months ago the President called on his Materials Policy Commission, headed by William S. Paley, chairman of the board of the Columbia Broadcasting System, to make a study of the long-term aspects of the materials problem. The commission's report has now been completed and published in five volumes aggregating some 800 pages.

The stock market made a determined effort yesterday to further the advance of the week, but the absence of buying power held price increases to a narrow range. Gains were selective under the sponsorship of the pivotal issues such as the rails, steels, motors, oils and rubbers.

PITTSBURGH, June 27 (AP) -- Enos Slaughter drove in five runs tonight with four consecutive singles as the Cardinals beat the Pirates, 6 -- 4. Stan Musial helped the Card cause by doubling and singling to run his consecutive hitting streak to twenty-three games.

Top convention officials of the American Legion offered some insight yesterday into the programs that are being prepared for the 100,000 veterans expected at the five-day Legion convention that will open here Aug. 24. Thomas E. Paradine, national vice commander, and Spencer C. Young, entertainment chairman; Samuel E. Dribben, contest committee chairman, and James W. Irving, parade committee chairman, outlined their plans at a meeting in the Essex House.

Commodity futures prices on the local exchanges were pretty well mixed in rather slow trading yesterday. Coffee, wool tops and hides were higher while lead and zinc moved lower. Rubber, wool, sugar, cocoa and vetgetable oils were mixed.

Judge Harold M. Kennedy yesterday directed William Wyer, trustee of the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road, to buy twenty new multiple-unit two-motor passenger cars immediately. The jurist said the convenience of the riding public was the "paramount objective."

TOLEDO, Ohio, June 27 (AP) -- Two former P. G. A. champions, Sam Snead and Jim Ferrier, today moved to the front in quest of the $5,000 first prize in the Inverness four-ball best-ball matches as they scored a 4-up victory over Byron Nelson and Skee Riegel, a former national amateur titleholder.

BOSTON, June 27 (AP) -- Eddie Yost hit a homer and Pete Runnels clouted a pair of three-baggers tonight as the Senators supported Conrado Marrero with a nine-hit attack that defeated the Red Sox, 5 -- 3. Billy Goodman drove a homer for the third Boston run, in the eighth inning.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 27 (AP) -- The West Coast waterfront picture tightened today with the announcement that striking American Federation of Labor sailors will sign only on military ships carrying military cargoes.

Hull Down, the 4-year-old son of Count Fleet and Dark Discovery who has been campaigning with indifferent success, gained his second victory of the year yesterday when he captured the $7,535 Manhattan Beach Classified Handicap at Aqueduct. The color-bearer of Mrs. Edward Lasker was a five- length winner over the Rhantom Farm's Nullify.

Ernie Durando of Bayonne defeated Norman Hayes, Boston middleweight, in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night. The result was rather a surprise, but there was no denying Durando's right to the decision, which was unanimous.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 27 -Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of Century scored 38, 39 -- 77 at the Greenwich Country Club today to win gross honors in the opening tournament of the Women's Tri-County Golf Association season. The Tri-County group limits handicaps to 12, and forty-four of the low-handicap players turned out.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- Without discussion or opposition, the House today passed a bill designed to build up the American merchant marine through a system of subsidies.

Another month in which the Soviets have misused the presidency of the Security Council of the United Nations as a strategic outpost in their "cold war" has come to an end, amid indications that this policy has reached the point of diminishing returns.

Scheduled airline operations out of Newark Airport, now functioning on a limited basis, are being studied by the carriers that formerly used the big field to determine whether adequate, dependable service for the New Jersey area is possible under the current rules for flights into and out of the airport.

The Civil Aeronautics Board ordered and President Truman approved yesterday the reopening of the cases of Seaboard and Western Airlines and Transocean Airlines for certificates of convenience and necessity to operate all-freight schedules between the United States and Western Europe and the Middle East.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -What's the proper modern way to crack a nut? Why, blow it up from the inside with high-frequency electricity, of course. Otto Thaning of Eikenhof, Transvaal, Union of South Africa, shows how in United States Patent 2,601,421, granted to him this week.
The city will switch from butter to colored oleomargarine next week, saving about $240,000 a year on its food bill, Purchase Commissioner John Splain disclosed yesterday.

GENEVA, June 27 -- The passage of a strong resolution proclaiming the rights of trade unions to develop free of political interference completed today all the major work of the thirty-fifth International Labor Conference.

DUBLIN, June 27 (AP) -- Prime Minister Eamon de Valera's Fianna Fail party tonight maintained its slim majority in the Irish Dail (Parliament) in three special elections. It won one new seat, lost one previously held, and hung on to a third.

By unanimous action of the Board of Estimate, following a 21-to-1 vote in the City Council, taxicab fares will be raised an average of 27 per cent when the Mayor approves the bill. This is the first such increase in nineteen years.

There are two schools of thought about dessert. By this particular dessert is not meant the just one which is given out in righteousness, and widely, for breaches of decorum or criminal practice, but that which comes with the end of a meal.
KARACHI, Pakistan, June 27 -- Pakistan is to get $22,500,000 and India $77,000,000 of United States aid for the fiscal year beginning July 1, authoritative economic circles said today.

One of the country's top Communist leaders told the Subversive Activities Control Board yesterday that, in the event of a war between the United States and the Soviet Union, she would support neither side.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Postmaster General Jesse M. Donaldson filed a petition with the Interstate Commerce Commission today for "consent" to increase parcel-post rates. However, any higher rates could not become effective until some time next year because of the circumstances under which the petition was offered.
PUSAN, Korea, Saturday, June 28 (AP) -- The South Korean Government has agreed to an immediate resumption of Voice of America broadcasts.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 27 -- Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson of the Cherry Valley Club beat Margaret (Peggy) Mackie of Inwood, 3 and 2, to win the Women's Long Island Golf Association match play championship for the fifth time at the Meadow Brook Club today.
Both line and fabric provided interest in the press preview of fall shoes by I. Miller Co. yesterday.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 27 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan's Nationalist party has won the Wakkerstroom parliamentary by-election, the first balloting in the Union since the Constitutional crisis began March 30. The Nationalist candidate had a plurality of 2,083 votes, 850 more than the winning margin in 1948.

SPRING LAKE, N. J., June 27 -William A. Lyon, Superintendent of Banks in New York, addressing a conference of New Jersey Savings Bankers here, recommended that New Jersey should follow New York and allow addition of common and preferred stocks to the banks' investment portfolios.

Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., said yesterday that members of the union's Local 100 would meet next Tuesday to consider recommendations for a strike on eight private bus lines.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., June 27 (AP) -- Jim Vickers of Oklahoma putted six inches for a birdie 3 on the twentieth hole to beat Marion Hiskey of North Texas State in today's semi-finals of the National Collegiate A. A. golf tournament.

HOUSTON, Tex., June 27 -- A mass experiment seeking to determine whether gamma globulin, a blood derivative, can prevent paralysis in poliomyelitis will begin here next Wednesday. The $500,000 project, financed by the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, is expected to involve about 35,000 children living in the Houston area, which is the scene of one of the nation's heaviest outbreaks of the disease this year.

The Hotel Bar Butter Company has redesigned its packages and has come up with one containing a half-pound of butter, broken down into two one-quarter packages. Incidentally, in January of this year, Albert Lowenfels, head of the company, came out for repeal of the state's ban on the manufacture and sale of yellow margarine.

The Frigidaire division of General Motors Corporation reported yesterday it was pulling out of the appliance slump at a more than satisfactory pace. Mason Roberts, general manager of the division, said large numbers of employes laid off recently were being rehired.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., June 27 -- Action taken by the Federal Trade Commission against Pillsbury Mills, Inc., was labeled "without basis" and "unrealistic" by a Pillsbury spokesman here yesterday.

TOKYO, Saturday, June 28 -- The Communists for the first time guardedly made reference yesterday to the United Nations mass attack Monday on the previously immune Supung (Suiho) power plant on the Yalu River frontier between Manchuria and North Korea.

It is my belief that we are currently watching the political suicide of the Republican party -- a needless and disastrous suicide presided over by Senator Robert A. Taft. He is now in a position to steamroller his way to the nomination -- a nomination which will not truly represent the wishes of the majority of the Republicans in this country.

A 20-year-old student at Roanoke College, Salem, Va., who thought she would have to postpone her ambition to become a teacher because of lack of funds to complete her college education, received yesterday the $1,200 President's Scholarship Award of the National Association of Manufacturers.

The State Department reveals that serious consideration is being given to ending the publication of the magazine Amerika, the Russian-language periodical which it prepares for distribution in the Soviet Union. In large part, apparently, this consideration is born of the fact that the Soviet authorities have cut the circulation of the journal from the original 50,000 copies to about 15,000 at present.

Ancient antagonists parted yesterday as friends, at least for the next ten weeks, when nearly 900,000 public school children and 36,000 teachers forgot the smell of chalk dust and the memories of unfulfilled homework assignments to start their summer vacations.
Among the loud and varied welcomes accorded the new superliner United States since her arrival here Monday is one that represents a new departure, a definite upsetting of tradition.

THE latest report from Ducks Unlimited indicates that the waterfowl production on the vast Canadian breeding grounds will be the highest in several years as larger breeding stocks returned to most areas and there was an excellent early hatch of ducklings.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson, acknowledging to the British yesterday that the United States should have notified them before the air blow fell on the Yalu River power plants in Korea, at the same time denied that Britain had an absolute right to know.
Today's housewife with such conveniences as prepared cake mixes, automatic dishwashers and frozen foods is likely to pity, not envy, her pioneer forebears.

The present political situation in Korea is being presented as a classic example of usurpation of power by a dictatorial President trying to overcome parliamentary opposition by arresting members of the National Assembly in order to assure his own re-election as President.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 27 (AP) -Heirs of an inventor were told by a Federal Court today that the way was clear for them to file a judgment against Remington Rand, Inc., for more than $1,300,000 for use of his invention.
Consolidated net income of Avco Manufacturing Corporation for the six months ended May 31 amounted to $3,542,928, equal to 38 cents a common share.
An occasional loss to the Giants isn't going to hurt too much, if the Dodgers can continue their reign of terror over second-division rivals.

After having floundered around a bit in the face of swift technological, social and economic changes, building designers and planners at last are accepting a new approach to design in keeping with the new era, according to Hugh Ferriss, president of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects.
SINGAPORE, June 27 -- An All-Malayan Labor party, the second new political party to be created in Malaya within a week, came into being yesterday in the Federation capital of Kuala Lumpur.
Most of the heat at the Stadium last night was generated by Lefty Ed Lopat and Mickey Mantle as the Yankees gathered twelve hits to crush the Athletics, 10 -- 0, before 26,749 fans.

SUFFERN, N. Y., June 27 -- Anticipating an influx of transients in connection with the construction of the New York State Thruway, the Suffern board of trustees has adopted a resolution to prohibit the establishment of trailer camps, tourist cabins and tourist camps within the village.
The first serious heat wave of this summer was broken last night.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., June 27 -- The Florida Supreme Court yesterday dismissed the petition of the last remaining intervenor in the Florida Power Corporation rate case.

The Atlas Corporation has contracted to buy all the preferred and common stocks of the Italian Superpower Corporation owned by the Institute per la Ricostruzione Industriale, it was announced yesterday by Floyd B. Odlum, president of Atlas.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The danger of the Republican party's election chances "breaking up on the rocks of personal bitterness" was pointed up here today by Gov. Earl Warren, a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination.
PITTSBURGH, June 27 -- The Pittsburgh Steel Company, a basic steel producer employing 10,500 workers, agreed today on a new contract substantially following Wage Stabilization Board recommendations.

CINCINNATI, June 27 (AP) -- Lefty Paul Minner scored his seventh victory for the Cubs tonight by shutting out the Reds, 6 to 0, on six hits while smacking two doubles and a single himself. Roy Smalley clinched the game when he walloped a three-run homer in the ninth.

An indictment containing four charges of second-degree forgery was returned yesterday in General Sessions against two exporters who had been arrested April 14 for the alleged misappropriation of $780,000 deposited in a bank here by Japanese publishers seeking newsprint.

LONDON, June 27 -- Without much trouble the foreign ministers of France, Britain and the United States reached agreement today on the next reply that they would make to Soviet proposals for a four-power meeting on the unification of East and West Germany.
TOKYO, Saturday, June 28 (AP) -- Eighth Army tactical summary 101, for Friday's activities:
PHILADELPHIA, June 27 -- History repeated itself with painful effect tonight as the Giants crashed head-on into a stunning 6-to-0 defeat at the hands of the sixth-place Phillies.

LONDON, June 27 -- Britain will get this year about $400,000,000 -almost as much as she earned last year from exports to the United States -- for providing the United States with thirty bases in this country, and from what the 50,000 United States airmen who are manning them spend privately, according to Picture Post, a leading illustrated weekly.

Negotiations over the settlement of Germany's pre-war external corporate debt are moving rapidly toward an agreement calling for no reduction of principal, a funding of two-thirds of the interest arrears, and the resumption of interest payments at rates approximating 75 per cent of those of the original contracts.

Clarence R. Krigbaum, the recently appointed District Commissioner of Internal Revenue here, announced yesterday the names of three revenue service career men who, as Directors of Internal Revenue, will replace the politically appointed Collectors of Internal Revenue.
Congratulations on your brilliant editorials on the McCarran "anti-immigration" bill.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- President Truman today conferred the Medal of Honor on two infantrymen for heroic exploits in Korea. They were Corp. Jerry K. Crump, 19 years old, of Forest City, N. C., and Corp. Ronald E. Rosser, 22, of Crooksville, Ohio.

ALBANY, June 27 -- The Board of Regents today approved plans to set up a nine-member advisory committee to help the State Education Department to develop ten television channels for educational programs.
LONDON, June 27 -- The stock markets ended the week today on a firm note. There was no major increase in business, but even a limited number of buyers short of stock caused prices to rise.
OKLAHOMA CITY, June 27 -- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has called upon General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower to clarify his position on the issue of civil rights.
Broadway plans for two forth- coming stage offerings, "Devil's Hornpipe" and "Casey Jones," have been delayed because of production problems.
SEATTLE, June 27 -- A specially called Federal grand jury today indicted a travel agency executive of this city on a charge of falsely reporting that Prof. Owen Lattimore planned a trip to Russia.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 27 -Speculation here on the ouster of Robert Grant centered on whether it was in any way connected with the case of the missing Robert L. Knetzer, whom Mr. Grant accompanied in an official capacity on many of Knetzer's jaunts to raise funds to pay creditors.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (UP) -- The Federal Trade Commission tonight charged Pillsbury Mills, Inc., with illegally acquiring assets of two competitors.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. of Massachusetts, campaign manager for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, told a press conference today that the general could win the Republican Presidential nomination "without the contested delegations."

Five thousand librarians from over the country will attend the seventy-first annual conference of the American Library Association opening here tomorrow evening and continuing through Friday. Its theme is "Books Are Basic."
LONDON, June 27 -- Katharine Hepburn made a dazzling debut tonight in "The Millionairess," one of George Bernard Shaw's later plays.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 27 -- Doris Hart, the defending title-holder from Coral Gables, Fla., and Maureen Connolly, winner of the American crown, each lost a set today in gaining the quarter-finals of the All-England lawn tennis championships at Wimbledon.

Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday 10 to 22 points net higher than on Thursday. Starting 11 points lower to 2 points higher, the market held steady all day despite favorable weather reports from the South.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- Following is the 57-to-26 roll-call vote by which the Senate today overrode President Truman's veto of the McCarran-Walter Immigration Bill, with a two-thirds majority required:

DENVER, June 27 -- Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia, a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, in a radio speech here tonight, criticized both leading Republican contenders, General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, and also President Truman.
PHILADELPHIA, June 27 (AP) -- The Phillies announced tonight that Manager Eddie Sawyer had been replaced by Steve O'Neill.

RYE, N. Y., June 27 -- Col. C. D. McAllister of Orlando, Fla., faltered in his quest for the forty-eighth annual United States seniors' championship today as he added a 77 to his first-round 75 for a 36-hole total of 152 over the Apawamis Club course. The competition was spread over four days.
LANSFORD, Pa., June 27 (UP) -- Four men were killed today and six others injured, two critically, in an explosion 1,200 feet underground in an anthracite mine.
Directors of the Westmoreland Coal Company, at their meeting yesterday in Philadelphia, took no action on the dividend usually declared at this time and payable in September.
PHILADELPHIA, June 27 -- Record-breaking golf rather than the anticipated record - smashing hot weather marked the second round of the women's national open golf championship today.
OTTAWA, Ont., June 27 -- The arrest of a prominent Canadian writer has been ordered by the Justice Department.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Senate decided tonight that women in the armed services reserves might become mothers without being ousted involuntarily. The chamber also agreed that some mothers who are reservists in the Wacs, Waves and other female branches of the armed forces might even be called to active duty, though they had dependent children.

The International Missionary Council, which coordinates the Christian world mission activities of non-Roman Catholic churches, will hold its next conference July 5-17 in Willingen, Germany. It will bring together representatives of mission boards and societies and of churches in fifty countries.

Orders booked by furniture manufacturers in May were about equal in dollar volume to the corresponding month last year, according to the monthly report issued yesterday by Seidman Seidman, accountants for many leading factories.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (UP) -A Congressional committee reported today that it blocked Air Force plans to spend $80,000,000 to house troops who would never be where the barracks were.

WASHINGTON, Saturday, June 28 -Senate-House conferees completed action at 2 o'clock this morning on an extension of the Defense Production Act, preserving most of the price, wage and other economic controls in substantially their present form.

Net income of the Philadelphia Electric Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended April 30 amounted to $26,536,160, equal to $2.13 a common share, according to the report released yesterday by H. P. Liversidge, chairman. This compares with a net income of $27,531,264, or $2.22 a share for the twelve months ended April 30, 1951.

More news of trouble comes from the unhappy Union of South Africa. This time it concerns the "non-white" movement against the laws enforcing "apartheid" or racial separation. Since there are approximately 10,000,000 non-whites, of whom about 8,500,000 are Negroes, the movement could be formidable.

R. E. Jacobson, who writes in THE TIMES, is justifiably much disturbed by the new parking regulations, which reduce parking facilities on the involved streets by 50 per cent. But here is a situation which allows for eating the cake and having it too: If the Traffic Department would adopt the tried and feasible plan of requiring parking at an angle, instead of parallel to the sidewalk.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The House of Representatives tentatively cut $65,000,000 today from an appropriation for additional power generating capacity for the atomic energy program. However, only the surface had been scratched after seven hours devoted to the $10,283,133,780 Supplemental Appropriation Bill.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -The American Association of Railroads today slapped a partial embargo on the movement of grain for storage to all points in Kansas and at Kansas City and St. Joseph in Missouri.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The McCarran-Walter bill to overhaul the country's immigration and naturalization laws, which Congress has written into law despite President Truman's veto of Wednesday, puts the permissable annual immigration at 154,658.

Grinning and crying by turns, a 27-year-old porter confessed yesterday that he set the fire in the four-story tenement at 1101 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, early on the morning of June 18 that took a toll of seven lives.
CHICAGO, June 27 (AP) -- The White Sox moved into a fourth-place tie with Cleveland by defeating the Indians, 5 to 1, tonight behind the four-hit pitching of Billy Pierce before a crowd of 39,968.

The sudden heavy consumer demand for frozen juice concentrates that came with the heat wave has virtually wiped out stocks of lemonade concentrate in the metropolitan area, trade sources reported yesterday. The product, which is comparatively new on the local market, has proved to be the most popular hot weather drink of all concentrates.

In my estimation there is only one candidate for President of the United States, and that is Senator Robert A. Taft, who always stands behind his word of honor and integrity. He is a man of experience and able enough to take care of the foreign and domestic problems and will be no yes man or "Me-tooer" for any special group.

The Board of Transportation announced yesterday that it had sold a piece of property in downtown Brooklyn for $100,000 and another piece in the Bronx for $55,000. Both sales were made at public auction.

BONN, Germany, June 27 -- The Western Allies are making arrangements for tightened military patrolling in support of the increased West German border guards along the undulating interzonal border with Russian-occupied East Germany.

Undistributed issues of corporate securities were estimated at $60,000,000 yesterday as the under-writing community faced away from an unusually busy spring season and began to head into the summer. Most of the unsold securities represent the tag ends of a half-dozen issues of public utility bonds which moved slowly after sale at competitive bidding.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 27 -- The United States said today that a special session of the United Nations General Assembly on Tunisia, requested by the Arab-Asian group, was not warranted.

Lumber production for the week ended June 21 was 2 per cent above the comparable week last year, according to reports wired yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES by regional associations. Shipments were up 5.5 per cent and orders 20 per cent.
WASHINGTON, June 27--There were hints of major undisclosed developments in atomic energy today with a visit to the White House by two leaders in the field.

In a showing which comprised a wide range of styles, held on Thursday night in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, a wide variety of garments, for which prices ranged from $18 to $150 retail, was presented. Aptly calling their showing the "Style-Wise Series," the exhibiting New York manufacturers demonstrated their ability to interpret all the newest fall and winter trends.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- Business prospects have brightened for the men's clothing industry, a survey of Chicago manufacturers indicated today. Fall orders have been much better than those for the generally slack spring season and employment is returning to a relatively high level.

A .22-caliber rifle bullet, fired mysteriously shortly before midnight Thursday, took the life of a young graduate rabbinical student as he strolled in McCarren Park in the Greenpoint district of Brooklyn after having said prayers in memory of his mother.

RANGOON, Burma, June 16 -- The Burmese Government continues to reject peace overtures from Burma's rebel Communists. Red peace feelers are described in Government quarters as merely tactical maneuver on the part of the Communists designed to gain a breathing spell and weaken the anti-Communist resistance front.

LOS ANGELES, June 27 (AP) -- Art Bragg of Morgan State won the 100-meter dash of the final United Sates Olympic team tryouts today in 10.5 seconds as a powerful American squad shaped up for the games in Helsinki amid a series of record-breaking performances.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 27 -- President Victor Paz Estenssoro stated today that his Government still hoped to settle the nationalization of the big Bolivian mining companies on the basis of friendly agreement with the companies. He said nationalization would include the payment of a fair indemnity to the companies concerned.

BAYONNE, N. J., June 27 -- Employes of the Navy's $125,000,000 "department store," the huge Navy Supply Corps depot, here, spent this afternoon and this evening celebrating the tenth anniversary of the commissioning of the 160-acre installation.

Platform pledges to relieve emergencies due to thousands of miles of deteriorated and unsafe roads throughout the United States were urged yesterday upon the Republican and Democratic national conventions. Commitments to improve highways to save time, lives and money were sought by the National P. A. R. Committee, sponsored by the National Highway Users Conference.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -The Federal Reserve Board reported today that industrial output, sliding since February, dipped in May and then-dropped sharply this month as strikes in steel and some other lines cut heavily into production.

That old bellwether of the stock market, United States Steel common, gave the boardrooms something other than the heat wave to think about yesterday. Near noon in a dragging market, a block of 25,000 shares of the stock appeared on the tape at 39, off 1/4-point.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -Latest available figures on the popular vote in the Republican Presidential primaries show Senator Robert A. Taft polled an aggregate of 2,785,990 votes in twelve states against 2,115,430 for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower in nine states.
IPSWICH, Mass., June 27 -- The first American performance of a Gluck opera opened the second season of the Castle Hill concerts this evening, on the Crane Memorial Reservation.

Ukuleles and fishing rods were clutched with great care yesterday by many of the 300 Boy Scouts who dragged an assortment of gear aboard eight buses waiting to drive them 100 miles to Camp Manhattan, one of the five camps of the Ten Mile River Scout Reservation near Narrowsburg, N. Y.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Senate today joined the House of Representatives in overriding President Truman's veto of the McCarran-Walter immigration bill, and thus wrote the measure into law. The Senate's vote was 57 to 26.

Did John Chirieleison, 25 years old, grow a mustache in defense of his twin brother, Anthony? A jury in Kings County Court decided yesterday that he did and convicted Anthony of robbery in the first degree.

Two men accused of attempted robbery and felonious assault charges in connection with two East Side hold-ups a week ago were dismissed yesterday in Felony Court for lack of evidence. A similar charge against a third youth was reduced to simple assault by Magistrate Thomas H. Cullen Jr.
A woman lawyer who transferred ownership of her automobile after receiving forty-one parking summonses was fined $590 yesterday. She also faces 125 days in jail if the fine is not paid by Sept. 2.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- President Truman told a delegation of sixty-three business and professional women from nineteen countries today that he would continue to work for peace after he left the White House.

CHEYENNE, June 27 -- Averell Harriman, seeking support in Wyoming today for his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination, warned national convention delegates and alternates that "you can't have a piece of the New Deal and win."
LONDON, June 27 -- A mild motion, devoid of any Bevanite flavor, has been offered by the Labor Opposition as the basis for next Tuesday's debate on British policy in the Korean war.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of interest to the homemaker:

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- President Truman summarily dismissed today Robert Grant, United States Marshal for the Southern District of Illinois, at the request of Attorney General James P. McGranery. The Attorney General accused Mr. Grant of "irregularities."

SARANAC LAKE, N. Y., June 27 -- District Attorney Miles F. McDonald of Brooklyn called for new legal weapons to fight the underworld when he told the New York State Bar Association here today that prosecutors were hamstrung by existing law.

PARIS, June 27 -- Two 19-year-old French youths motivated, they said, by love of art, not avarice, were caught redhanded early this morning in an attempt to steal three internationally famous paintings from the Paris Museum of Modern Art.

ESSEX FELLS, N. J., June 27 -Mrs. Philip Cudone of Montclair, leading from the start, won the women's New Jersey Golf Association's 54-hole medal play championship today with a record 227 at the Essex Fells Country Club.

Because the meter is the sole arbiter of the cost of the ride, taxicab passengers here can look forward to paying current fares despite the legally higher rate that would become effective with Mayor Impellitteri's signature to a local law increasing rates by 27 per cent.

WESTBURY, L. I. June 27 -- The Hayes Fair Acres Stable's Pronto Don, a 7-year-old chestnut gelding by Donald Truax, from Duquoin, Ill., scored a two-length victory over Roy S in the final dash of the mile and one-half David H. McConnell Memorial Trot for a purse of $10,000 in 3:11 1-5 at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., June 27 -- Senator Robert A. Taft tonight told an audience of 2,500 persons at the University of Virginia's Institute of Public Affairs that the United States should repudiate the Yalta agreements and endeavor to free the satellite countries from the yoke of Russian communism.

An early evening radio program for children minus spacemen, fast-shooting cowboys and all the other elements of violence and disaster their elders so often deplore may seem an unlikely dream to parents in the New York area but it is a reality for youngsters in and around Boston.

ALBANY, June 27 (AP) -- The State University of New York said today that it would start construction on about $10,042,500 worth of new buildings on six of its thirty-three campuses in the 1952-53 fiscal year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 27 -- Darryl Zanuck, production chief of Twentieth Century-Fox, is negotiating with George Jessel to produce a film about the latter's life. Jessel, who spent thirty-five years on the musical-comedy stage and in vaudeville and radio, has worked as a producer for Mr. Zanuck for ten years, and announced only yesterday that he would resign his position at the studio in September.

ST. LOUIS, June 27 (AP) -- Hal Newhouser of the Tigers held the Browns to three hits tonight, but two throwing errors gave St. Louis a 2-to-1 victory. Bob Cain and Satchel Paige allowed Detroit only five hits, all singles.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- A Senate committee said today that the Army had developed a radar eye that tracked enemy mortar shells to their sources while permitting friendly mortars to deliver fire to their targets.

In a world half slave and half free we have today an enhanced appreciation of the courts -- in guarding our democratic way of life, in dispensing impartial justice, in protecting the weak against the strong, in upholding the rights of the individual against governmental or political invasions of privacy and freedoms.

VICTORIA, B. C., June 27 -- The moon, which for countless ages has been the traveler's chief guide at night, has again come to the aid of navigators, for it has been used in a special series of observations by Northwestern University astronomers to check on the value of refraction by the earth's atmosphere.
EDDYVILLE, Ky., June 27 (UP) -- Guards quelled the second riot in two days at the Kentucky State Prison today, and Warden Jess Buchanan warned "anything might happen."
WESTPORT, Conn., June 27 -Competition for eight championships opened today in the three-day horse show of the Fairfield County Hunt Club.

The Poetry Society of Virginia annouced recently the winners of its 1951-52 contests. Gertrude Ryder Bennet of Brooklyn won the $50 Norfolk Prize for a sequence of two sonnets related in theme. The second prize of $25 went to Sarah M. Howard of Washington.

KARACHI, Pakistan, June 27 -- The Finance Ministry of the Government of Pakistan issued today a statement reassuring foreign business men that corporation and private profits earned here would be "freely" convertible into foreign currency.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 27 -- The home economist was urged today to give up specializing for a broader approach to her field. This advice was contained in a report on the results of week-long meetings of discussion groups participating here in the annual conference of the American Home Economics Association.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (UP) -- The Senate Appropriations Committee said today that it had approved the elimination of military aides for five-star generals such as Dwight D. Eisenhower and Douglas MacArthur unless they were assigned to specific duties.

NOTRE DAME, Ind., June 27 -- The Rev. Theodore J. Mehling, C. S. C., provincial of the Indiana Province of the Congregation of the Holy Cross, announced today that the Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, C. S. C., 35-year-old native of Syracuse, N. Y., was to be the fifteenth president of the University of Notre Dame.

Paul T. Biesser, family and children's consultant, Dr. Roscoe P. Kandle, field director of the American Health Association, and Harry O. Page, deputy commissioner of the State of New York Department of Social Welfare, will join the staff of Community Research Associates, Inc., in September.

TORONTO, June 27 (Canadian Press) -- George S. Messersmith, chairman of Mexican Light and Power Company, Ltd., said today the company has cash and labor problems. Adequate solutions must be found for both.

VIENNA, June 27 -- Soviet preparations to demonstrate against Secretary of State Dean Acheson's visit to Vienna on Sunday took the form today of banning from Vienna's Second District, which is part of the Russian sector of the capital, the American-sponsored German-language newspaper Wiener Kurier.

JERSEY CITY, June 27 -- The wildcat strike of 140 marine warehousemen at the Claremont Terminal where the Army Corps of Army Engineers ships material to air bases in North Africa grew today as checkers and hoisting engineers refused to cross picket lines.
SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, June 28 (AP) -- Allied warplanes roared down yesterday in their fourth attack of the week on hydro-electric power plants in North Korea.

Yesterday Foreign Minister Schuman of France joined Mr. Acheson and Mr. Eden in a frank and anxious discussion of joint policy. When they met last, in May, they were in a jubilant mood because one stage of the work they had carried on together was finished -- and finished, contrary to all predictions, on schedule.
Cook County, Ill., announced yesterday that it will receive bids July 15 on $15,000,000 of superhighway bonds dated July 1, 1952, due July 1, 1972 and callable from 1953 to 1971.

Two groups of Queens bus drivers refused yesterday to drive their vehicles past picket lines at La Guardia Airport set up by striking employes of the Carey Transportation Company, which operates airport coaches.
The production of military aircraft will no longer be impeded by the need of a tiny lamp bulb with a glass globe slightly larger than the head of a kitchen match.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: If the first Japanese beetle hasn't appeared yet, it will any day. They are iridescent, hard shelled and about three-eighths of an inch long. Cover plants on which they feast with DDT, lead arsenate or some repellent spray. Handpicking daily and dropping them into a can holding water and a little oil is only sure way to have perfect roses.

THE Kentucky coffeetree has just about everything except a good publicity agent to make it a most useful specimen for the home grounds. It attains the ideal size for a shade tree (forty to fifty feet), has delicate foliage, late bloom in June, interesting seed pods, beautiful fall color and can be grown easily in this area.
The great objective on both sides of the Taft-Eisenhower struggle is to convince the convention delegates that their man is the one who can win the election.

DENVER, June 28 -- When General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower was campaigning in Texas at the beginning of this week, a big former sergeant pushed through the crowd and said to him: "You'd better win, General, or we'll both be back in the Army for life."

WITH a cast of characters drawn not far above the Plimsoll line of popular fiction, Win Brooks has told a heart-warming and consistently interesting story of a group of people who live on, or visit seasonally, Cape Cod.

RACKETEERS of the road who ambush unsuspecting motorists are of varied types, but most vicious of all is the seemingly guileless hitch-hiker who robs and even murders for favors received. Statistics indicate that these modern footpads -- men, women, boys and girls -- are increasing in number along the highways, and summer motor tourists, particularly big-hearted vacationists, are warned to be wary of the extended thumb.
The month's vacation in Paris my wife and I had planned allowed no more than $10 a day for the two of us, but we were able to stay within the bounds of our budget.

The normal seasonal decline in department store sales was accelerated last week by the heat wave. As a result, it was estimated that volume for the week was 16 per cent less than a year ago. This drop was due partly to comparison with a year ago when over-all volume was affected by the "price war."

Although a backlog of traffic is being built up because of the steel strike, the railroads and other transportation agencies are expected to experience no difficulty in handling the additional load once the strike is ended.

Crosby Littlejohn, with a record of thirteen arrests and five convictions, all for burglary, and an accomplice picked the wrong apartment to rob late Friday night. It belonged to husky-looking, fast-stepping Patrolman John P. Kenney, 28 years old. The result: a two-block chase in which Patrolman Kenney, clad only in pajamas, fired four shots, and the capture of Littlejohn. The accomplice escaped.

CHATTANOOGA, June 28 -- General Eisenhower has made only one appearance in the South since he became a citizen Republican candidate -- his visit to Texas. Yet there are thousands of Democrats willing to support him this year because they believe he has a better chance to defeat a "Fair Deal" Democratic candidate and program than Senator Robert A. Taft has.

PORT EWEN, N. Y., June 28 -- The Shrine of Our Lady of the Hudson, with a six-foot blue stone statue of the Virgin Mary holding a tugboat in her arms as the central figure, was unveiled and dedicated this afternoon on the grounds of the Roman Catholic Church of the Presentation.

An increasing number of self-appointed censors are threatening the traditional independence of the nation's libraries, according to speakers yesterday at the opening of the American Library Association's Conference on Intellectual Freedom.

PERHAPS the only tiresome thing about being an American is that one is continually being told by foreigners what is wrong with this country. Fortunately, most Americans seem rather to enjoy this type of criticism, and wisely so, because, after all, criticism is a form of homage. One criticizes only that which seems potentially perfect.

The auction field, narrowed down these days to a few sales and restricted to a few galleries, will offer this week modern paintings and prints at the Kende Galleries, 119 West Fifty-seventh Street, and varied furniture, decorations and home appointments at Tobias, Fischer Co., 71 West Forty-fifth Street.

ONTARIO, Calif. "BUCCANEER won the gold medal at Geneva" The yellow cablegram which John A. Armstrong pulled out of his pocket was a pallid reflection of the golden hybrid tea roses, aptly named Buccaneer, on the luncheon table.

THE property around a new home -- just built, bought or rented -- may seem discouragingly barren at this time of year. But it need not stay that way. With a bit of ingenuity and determination, a good garden for midsummer and fall may still be achieved.

There was a 1,870-yard stakes race at the Aqueduct track yesterday that was decided in the 1,870th yard. There it was that Woodvale Farm's Marta, the $7.90-for-$2 favorite, shoved her nose ahead of the King Ranch's Renew, the second choice, to collect $19,200 of the $28,250 gross. The race was the mile-and-a-sixteenth Vagrancy Handicap, a filly-and-mare number with eight in the line-up.
New Yorkers, luxuriating in the first full day of comfortable, seasonable summer temperatures yesterday, were promised fair and pleasant weather for today.

The swift action taken by the House of Representatives on Friday in approving the so-called Long-Range Shipping Bill has given the maritime industry renewed hope that enactment of the measure finally may be in sight.

IN 1729 an Anglican priest, John Wesley, was leader of a small "Holy Club" of Oxford students that met regularly for prayer and study. Now, over two centuries later, the little club has become the world-wide Methodist group of churches, with "a constituency of eighty or ninety million" in seventy-five countries.
IN 1856, the Democrats characterized the Republican party, newly risen from the ashes of the Whig organization, as an unsavory band of schemers who supported free love and a dole for drunkards.

In your issue of June 15 there appeared a letter from representatives of six organizations under the heading "Subversive Education." This letter makes certain charges with respect to Teachers College which are so far removed from any relation to the actual facts that a correction seems in order.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 28 -- Keen competition in the working hunter division, in which thirty-four are listed marked the program today in the twenty-ninth annual horse show of the Fairfield County Hunt Club.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 28 (AP) --Four newspapers of the San Francisco Bay metropolitan area announced today price increases for single copies, effective July 1, because of increased newsprint and production costs.

The re-election of Vincent G. Barnett as president of the New York Shipping Association was announced yesterday. The organization's annual meeting was held on Friday at its offices in 80 Broad Street. Mr. Barnett is president of Barber Steamship Lines, Inc.
PHILADELPHIA, June 28 -- Residents in this area are all keyed up over the Taft-Eisenhower race for the G. O. P. Presidential nomination.

THE struggles of a totally incompetent British mission -- the Fruit and Vegetables Processing Mission -- with the various weird institutions, customs and personalities its members were bound to encounter during their wartime campaign in the United States is the subject of this first novel.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 28 -- Sweden has suffered a fresh rebuff from the Kremlin. Premier Tage Erlander's note to Moscow in mid-June making serious representations against members of the Soviet embassy staff implicated in the espionage trial here of seven Swedish Communists has been rejected as unfounded in a note delivered today by Soviet Ambassador Constantin Rodionov to Foreign Minister Oesten Unden.

PARIS, June 28 (UP) -- Guy Mollet, French Socialist leader, sharply protested today against the latest United States military moves in Korea and talked of a return to a policy "already condemned in the time of MacArthur."

WITH reference to Prof. Irwin Edman's article. "Literary Ambassadors From America," on the tourist's mission to help dispel the traditional European skepticism regarding American culture, may I point out how possibly, a more effective impact may be made.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- Philip Murray's striking United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., fighting a divide-and-conquer war with the nation's steel industry, was reported today sounding out some of the smaller basic steel companies in a desperate effort to win new contract settlements.

ROGER PRICE is a 180-pound, six-foot, 32-year-old refutation of a canard, popular in personnel offices, that a man must know his politics before he can even be considered for a job as a commentator. Price, who does frequent turns on radio and television as a humorist, satirist, caricaturist, actor and philosopher but not as an oracle, admits he has no political knowledge to speak of.

IPSWICH, Mass., June 28 -- Last night's performance at Castle Hill of Gluck's "The Passionate Pasha," in its first American presentation, was given as scheduled in the Italian Garden of the Crane Memorial Reservation. The one-act opera enchanted its audience and also shed some light on an aspect of Gluck that is not generally appreciated.

The Fund for the Advancement of Education, established by the Ford Foundation, has made a grant of $50,000 to Kenyon College (Ohio) to support work of the Committee on Admission with Advanced Standings. The twelve colleges participating in the work of the committee have agreed to devise means to permit students to enter college with some advanced credit toward the bachelor's degree.

Five ferries and two interstate bridges, clearly pointed out by signs on trunk lines passing them, enable motorists to cross the 107-mile obstacle of Lake Champlain, on both sides of which run the two shortest and quickest all-paved highways from New York City to Montreal, with many feeders westward to Adirondack resorts and eastward to those of the Green Mountains of Vermont and White Mountains of New Hampshire.

Teachers, administrators and other personnel in elementary and secondary schools and in colleges and universities throughout the United States will attend the 1952 summer session at Teachers College, Columbia University, which starts July 7. Leaders in nursing, marriage and family life, adult education, school administration, curriculum development and business education will participate in fifteen workshops and conferences to discuss current problems and trends in these fields.
DES MOINES, June 28 -- Farm problems, usually the No. 1 topic in the Midwest Farm Belt at any time, have given way before a variety of issues in the race between Senator Taft and Genera Eisenhower.

HAVANA, June 28 (AP) -- Marcos Hirigoyen, one of Cuba's most powerful labor leaders, was arrested today on a 1947 murder charge, and the Government-owned bus company, in which his union had been dominant, was placed under military guard.

PARIS, June 28 -- Summer is a favorite season in Europe for both tourists and generals. Once again the Continent accustoms itself to the enthusiastic influx of the former, while the latter, a more select group, carries on its ponderous maneuvers.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- After half a century in building the greatest industrial appetite and the highest standard of living the world ever has known, the nation was told this week that it was running out of the raw materials which it must have to survive.

BUENOS AIRES, June 28 -- Favored by an unusual political climate, German farm equipment manufacturers have outsold their American competitors almost two to one, a survey of import licenses issued by the Argentine Central Bank disclosed today. Of $41,500,000 worth of permits issued, German companies have received allocations worth more than $21,250,000, according to reliable sources.

FOR some reason stories about famous artists (and biographies, too) are rather rare in juvenile literature. It is seldom, indeed, that we have as full-bodied a story of this kind as Isabelle Lawrence's story of Rembrandt and his household.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., June 27 -- The first of 13,000 New Jersey National Guardsmen and organized reservists arrived here today for a two-week summer training period. An estimated 60,000 citizen-soldiers will be trained here this summer.

Jamie Coffman is flying to Europe on Friday to demonstrate at several big international conferences how she teaches paraplegics to walk on crutches and to live as nearly as possible like other people.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., June 28 (AP) -- Jim Vickers of Oklahoma, twice two holes down, rallied in the afternoon round to defeat 19-year-old Eddie Merrins of Louisiana State, 1 up, in the final of the National Collegiate A. A. golf tournament today.

THE first speedlight unit to employ the new National Carbon Company dry battery, which yields enough power to flash a lamp 1,000 times before it has to be replaced, was demonstrated here last week by the Hershey Manufacturing Company of Chicago, the makers. It is the Sun-Lite Portable Speed Flash and is priced at $79.50. The price includes a battery, lamp and camera bracket. A replacement battery costs $7.95.

PURCHASE, N. Y., June 28 -- The fabulous old Ophir Hall estate here of the late Whitelaw Reid has been converted into a modern college campus in little more than a year. In addition to setting records for speed and the use of new materials, the conversion has given to an established college a $14,000,000 dream campus" planned systematically from scratch.

Andrew S. Roscoe, chairman of the Brooklyn Chapter of the American Red Cross, reported last night that nearly 100,000 residents of the borough had participated in the chapter's civil defense program since the outbreak of the Korean war.

NOW that the season for lawn, terrace and beach living is upon us there may be some who find that furnishings planned during the cooler, early spring days do not suffice. For them, and for those tardy shoppers who have postponed their purchases until now, some new additions to summer furniture designs, not available before, are pictured here.

CHICAGO, June 28 (UP) -- The Yankees and the Indians dominated the American League with three men each, while the Giants, Dodgers and Cardinals landed two each on the National League team when starting line-ups for the All-Star game were announced today.

A COLLECTION of short stories, her first, by the author of "The Locusts Have No King" is likely to be something of a reading event. And so it is, it must be wryly noted, for these unusual stories, some of them no more than vignettes, reveal in Miss Powell the kind of demure and deceitful authority that, for example, Jane Austen knew a thing or two about.

STANTON, Del., June 28 (AP) -- Max Kahlbaum's Jampol, soundly trounced in the Kent Stakes two weeks ago, regained top form at Delaware Park today and survived a three-way photo finish to win the fifteenth Leonard Richards Stakes.

Possible disbandment of a "world community" shattered the annual celebration yesterday of Parkway Village, Queens, where 585 United Nations families from fifty countries have lived in a friendly atmosphere since 1946.

The rapid growth in employe benefit programs in recent years, which has resulted in more varied and complicated plans, has brought a request to Congress that it undertake a study of such plans in general with the idea of clarifying this important phase in labor-management relations.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 28 -- Brushing to the top in a third quarter of 29 3/5 seconds, Cleo A. Young's Ferman Hanover, a 5-year-old brown gelding from Timmonsville, S. C., with Johnny Simpson driving, scored a three-quarter length victory over Hal Senator in 2:02 2/5 in the $4,500 Jericho junior free-for-all pacing feature at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

TOKYO, Sunday, June 29 -- The United Nations and Communist delegations traded notes yesterday, while the negotiations for an armistice in Korea remained in adjournment after the Allied walkout for a new three-day recess until Tuesday.

Irving Greene, a 27-year-old porter, was held without bail yesterday in Brooklyn Felony Court for a hearing Tuesday in the same court on a charge of homicide by arson in connection with the fire he confessed setting early on the morning of June 18 at 1101 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn.
Pressures against the free flow of world news increased in the first six months of this year, but there were some heartening victories over the foes of a free press.

The New York Public Library's summer season of outdoor recorded concerts will open in Bryant Park on Tuesday at noon. Benny Goodman and the New Music Quartet will open the series with Mozart's "Quintet for Clarinet."
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Congress passed a compromise economic controls bill tonight and sent it to President Truman for his signature.

A significant advance in transistor research, which for the first time points the way to very high-frequency applications in television, FM radio and point-to-point radio communication, is announced by the Radio Corporation of America. The transistor, still in the developmental stage, consists of a speck of germanium crystal and fine contact wires.

THERE is no doubt of it whatsoever: Washington is the capital of the world and we are the nation on whom the future largely depends. So people everywhere believe, including, one suspects, the men of Moscow.

THE family background of Jocelyn Melisande Julie Scott, whose childhood and adolescence are the subject of Monica Stirling's "fictitious autobiography," is so like the author's own that the average reader will prefer to ignore the introductory protest that "all the characters, situations and institutions in it are imaginary."
Traveling on a budget of $5 a day is perhaps more work than just flinging dollars about, but for those who decide to go as I did, on a tourist wing and a prayer, Europe can still be fun.
WASHINGTON, June 28 (UP) -- The Federal Power Commission has rejected a request of the Texas Gas Transmission Corporation for an $11,000,000 a year rate increase.

As longevity and good health are among the basic objectives for which each of us strives, it is not surprising that medical research has traditionally attracted financial support from prosperous individuals and groups. Modern medical research had its beginning in the Renaissance, when both the ecclesiastic and merchant princes of the seventeenth century became the patrons of men of science.

THE great striped bass war, which has been flaring up and dying out on a shifting front for many years, is now entering another phase, and now that the sportsmen have abandoned "conservation" slogans for "economic" arguments, those opposing the proposals to make the striper a game fish have resorted to some rather odd devices.

A BRITISHER who visited the United States in 1875 commented: "Boats navigating the rivers and bays of the United States are constructed on a scale of magnificence quite unknown to European waters. * * * The grand saloon is not unlike a hall in a palace." Modern travelers

THE time is up-to-date: Lissa Miller cannot accept the loss of her eldest son, Noel, killed in World War II, and now her second son. Dair, is about to be drafted for the Korean war. The problem is this: should Dair marry at 18, despite the draft?

MOSCOW, June 28 -- There has been in progress in the Soviet Union an intensive campaign of public meetings, radio addresses, newspaper editorials and special articles directed at one, and only one, general target -- the United States' conduct of the war in Korea.

There has been a further decline in industrial orders and production during June, the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents reports in its monthly survey, issued for publication today.

The protection of the democratic rights of trade union members is a perennial source of discussion. It is not necessary to charge that individual rights are abused wholesale to recognize that even occasional lapses impair public confidence in the labor movement.
The guarantees contrived by the Young and Dawes loans to revive investment in Germany before the Great Depression are now rising like ghosts from World War I to haunt the survivors of World War II.

FOR more reasons, because they are contrasting, than those responsible for the eminence of his colleagues, William Randolph Hearst belongs among the titans of journalism. No one else was so strong an inspiration to newspaper publishers of his time.

The Lutheran World Federation, successor to the Lutheran World Convention, will meet July 25 to Aug. 3 in Hanover, Germany. In addition to 250 delegates and as many alternates from fifty-one Lutheran bodies representing 51,000,000 communicants in twenty-four countries, some 500 official visitors are expected.

FOUR figures dominate the bull ring of this century -- the Spaniards Belmonte, Joselito, Manolete, and the Mexican Gaona, Belmonte and Gaona are long retired, wealthy and respected. Joselito and Manolete are dead, killed in their twenties by fighting bulls.
It is too bad that Bertrand Russell in "The American Way (A Briton Says) Is Dour" (June 15) did not go deeper into the reasons for the American's trend to enjoy himself unhappily and feverishly.

ASBURY PARK, N J., June 28 -- Charles Oldfield of Ocean City, N. J., was elected today state commander of the New Jersey Department, Veterans of Foreign Wars, at the closing session of the thirty-second annual encampment here. He succeeded Charles Becker of Newark.
WINDSOR, Ont., June 28 (AP) -- Miss Pepsi, a Detroit-owned multi-engined hydroplane, swept all three fifteen-mile heats to win the Windsor Yacht Club's fourth annual Maple Leaf Regatta today.

NEW DELHI, India, June 28 -- Any possible "extension" of the military operations in Korea might "imperil" world peace, Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru declared in Parliament today. Mr. Nehru was replying to a short-notice question, asked by a Congress party member, as to the Government's attitude toward the United Nations forces' bombing of the power plants on the Yalu River.

A FEW days ago I spent a week-end in a house where the only readable matter was a dictionary of quotations and a volume entitled "So You Are Going to Have a Baby." Since I wasn't, I chose the quotations, but soon discovered that the purple patch is hard on the eyes.
We have long taken for granted the good things that constitute THE TIMES Magazine, but sometimes we are impelled to say thank you.
COPENHAGEN, June 28 -- The Olympic flame, brought to Denmark by air from Greece, was carried through Jutland by runners, riders and cyclists today on its way to Helsinki.

Members of the Eighty-second Congress have spent a great deal of time in recent months hurrying between Capitol Hill and Washington's Union Station or National Airport. In an election year there were fences to mend, gardens to cultivate, and here and there an ear put to the ground.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The State Department ended its travel ban against Prof. Owen Lattimore today and apologized for the "embarrassment" the widely publicized order had caused him.
CABINET ministers, including the primest ones, have occupied equally prominent positions in bridge from time to time.
Eric Mann, in his fervent desire to standardize geographical names in his recent letter, overlooks two extremely important points: pronunciation and transliteration.

REPORTS from Italy indicate that the world will see a new Ingrid Bergman in "Europe '51" -- a Bergman without the glossy make-up of her Hollywood films, a Bergman who is more gaunt, more mature, more intense in the fiery, realistic tradition of postwar Italian movies.
PUSAN, Korea, Sunday, June 29 -- A mob of 500 shouting supporters of President Syngman Rhee held 103 members of the National Assembly prisoner for five hours yesterday with a human barricade.
