Unanimously elected commander of the Kings County American Legion at its thirty-fourth annual convention yesterday, Francis M. Verrilli criticized the complacent attitude of the nation's citizens toward the sacrifices of those fighting in Korea.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 28 -- Transportation was nearly paralyzed in Israel this weekend as a result of the Government's new gasoline-saving transportation restrictions and the taxicab drivers' attempts to combat the restrictions.

When slim, 6-foot, 36-year-old Hugh R. Jackson assumed the presidency of the Better Business Bureau of New York City three years ago some people thought he was too young for the job. They didn't know that Hugh had made a habit of taking on big jobs, ordinarily entrusted to men of more advanced years.

FRANKLIN D. ROOSEVELT was 30 and Josephus Daniels 50 when they first met as stanch Wilson supporters at Baltimore in 1912. This meeting marked the beginning of a friendship which, with vicissitudes and modulations, lasted until Roosevelt's death.

THOSE popular triplets, Abercrombie, Benjamin and Christopher, whose lighthouse adventures made such good reading, are back again -- resourceful as ever, and just as hard to tell apart. This time they are living on their grandmother's farm, faced with the exciting prospect of the County Fair coming to the field next door.

SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, June 29 (AP) -- Allied and Chinese Communist artillery duelled on the western Korean front last night after United Nations infantrymen smashed three attempts to take a bald-topped hill.

Insects may be chemically killed by blocking involuntary motions on which their lives depend, according to Dr. J. Harold Burn of Oxford University, England. He told of his work at a symposium recently held at the University of Virginia by the American Chemical Society.

For the past four years Texas and, to a lesser degree, Southern California have experienced outbreaks of polio. There is always some polio in both areas -- even in winter. Every spring and summer the number of cases increases sharply. In the first twenty-four weeks of 1952 Texas and California accounted for 49 per cent of the nation's reported cases.

OF all the museums in New York, The Cloisters, the Metropolitan's "branch" on the summit of Fort Tryon Park, is the least like a museum. It is instead a harmonious entity in which precious objects of the Middle Ages can be seen in a setting appropriate to their intention and can be understood in an atmosphere which re-creates the spirit, if not the archaeological actuality, of their time.

PHILADELPHIA, June 28 -- Steve O'Neill's debut as manager of the Phillies was proclaimed a howling success by a gathering of 17,182 eye-witnesses as the Phils tripped the Giants for the second successive time tonight, 7 to 2.

IT was thirty-eight years ago, in 1914, that the United States Children's Bureau brought out its first publication for parents -- that well-known best seller (more than 28,000,000 copies of all editions distributed to date) titled "Infant Care." Today the bureau is releasing another pamphlet, the first new booklet of Zeneral interest it has brought out in some time.
WATERBURY, Conn., June 28 (UP) -- Four records were set today during the national A. A. U. women's junior outdoor track and field championships at the Municipal Stadium.

Americans attracted to Europe by low-cost air and steamship transportation need not abandon the idea of an economical tour upon arrival Public transportation affords an opportunity to see Rome as the Romans do and is materially cheaper than guided tours and taxi fares.

A daredevil stunt flier, piloting a Piper Cub-type single-engine plane, paid two visits to the thickly populated Bellerose section of Queens yesterday afternoon, swooping down to within 1,000 feet of the roofs of private homes in the area for a total of forty-five minutes. Both times he eluded the police, who took to the air in pursuit.
MINNEAPOLIS, June 28 -- The smallest star ever seen by man has been discovered in the Milky Way, two astronomers announced today.

BOSTON, June 28 -- Discussions of the relative merits of Eisenhower and Taft have reached the point of individual partisanship in New England, where old friends are beginning to pass each other on the street without speaking.

THE subject of this engaging and important little book by Columbia University's dean of political philosophers is the ancient problem of power and the means to its control Economic power arises from the private ownership of property and political power from the existence of government Robert MacIver trusts no man to exercise too much such power with restraint.

THIS delightful first novel is a pastoral tale of a year in a Bavarian highland parish composed of three villages. The central figure is idealistic 26-year-old Father Christopher Muller, newly appointed to the parish.

LOUD and long have been the cries for programs of taste and charm for young television viewers. Well, such a program, if only for a single performance, came along in the form of the Children's Ballet Theatre and behind its presentation lies one of those stories which should inspire any lagging creative spirits in TV.

The American Bar Association has included in a broad Americanization program a proposal to establish a uniform naturalization ceremony when applicants are admitted to citizenship. It is my profound conviction that this proposal should receive favorable consideration.

TOM YAWKEY is a fast man with a dollar bill and he fortunately has a lot of dollar bills to be fast with. For more than nineteen seasons he has been the No. 1 Red Sox fan. So passionate is his devotion to the Bosox that he has demonstrated his ardor in the loftiest and most expressive fashion known to mankind -- with money.

NEIL STACK of the Eire Philatelic Association has received word that Erskine Childers, Ireland's Minister of Posts and Telegraph, has announced a stamp will be issued "within a few months" for the centenary of the death of Thomas Moore (1779-1852), Irish poet, lyrist and historian.

LONDON, June 28 -- Emanuel Shinwell, who was Minister of De fense in the Labor Government, said today that Britain should insist that the United Nations approach the Chinese Communist Government to negotiate a settlement of the Korean war and of all outstanding issues in the Far East.

FEW wild flowers are more delicate than the trailing vine known as the twinflower (Linnaea borealis americana). Whether we chance upon it for the first time or see it often in near-by woods, it evokes admiration.

Flanders, Republican of Vermont, asserted tonight in an address to the University of Virginia's Institute of Public Affairs that the policies of Senator Robert A. Taft, aspirant for the Republican Presidential nomination, gave no indications "of new vision or new hope" and that his nomination might bring ruin to the Republican party.

Alfred University last week became the 400th educational institution to join the roster of The Tuition Plan. About equally divided among schools and colleges, the associates of The Tuition Plan now include the leading private secondary schools as well as many distinguished liberal arts institutions.

Y.

THE newly organized ballet company headed by Mia Slavenska, Frederic Franklin and Alexandra Danilova will give the first of its scheduled summer engagements on Tuesday at Olney, Md. The program will consist of the Franck "Symphonic Variations" choreographed by Miss Slavenska, a group of divertissements from the last act of "The Nutcracker," the "Don Quixote" pas de deux, "Blue Danube Waltz" danced by Miss Danilova and Nicholas Orloff, and Miss Slavenaka's "Spirituals" and "Settlers' Sunday."
The transport Washington, on military dependent service for the Navy since last November between this country and Germany, will be out of service until early August for her annual overhaul.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, preparing to leave tomorrow for Chicago to put the final touches on his Republican Presidential nomination campaign, asserted today that the only remaining hurdle to his convention victory was the argument that he could not win in November.

THE ten new titles in the Real Book Series continue to supply easy factual reading matter on a variety of subjects popular with children today. As in the first set, the information ranges as widely as do the modern child's interests -- including such diverse topics as cowboys and airplanes.

HOUSTON, June 28 -- With health officials declaring that this metropolitan area was in the midst of a poliomyelitis epidemic, other parts of the state of Texas were preparing today for possible heavier inroads by the disease.

Proving again the truism of the old adage that you can't keep a good man down, the United States Power Squadrons, pleasure boating's largest body of yatchsmen, with a new high count of members as of May 31 of 17,523, has approved four more unit squadrons.

NO authors could have had a pleasanter assignment than the American gourmet, James Beard, and the wise Scotsman, Alexander Watts, who seems to prefer a French gigot to Scotch haigis. Together they roamed the restaurants of Paris for seven months, looking from bistro to restaurant-de-luxe for the best that could be had in food and drink.

The Grand Lodge, Knights of Pythias, State of New York, has challenged the right of the organization's national council, the Supreme Lodge, to revoke its charter. It announced last night that it would hold its annual convention as planned from July 27 to Aug. 2 at Saratoga Springs.

WEST BERLIN'S second annual international film festival (June 12 to 25) was most notable for the way in which it showed up the rather poor quality of the pictures turned out by Western Germany's post-war film industry. The festival itself, although well organized, has a great deal to achieve before it can attain the popularity level of the Cannes and Venice fetes.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- One thing is certain amid all the uncertainty about whom the great political parties will nominate and who will be elected President. That is that the 1952 campaign will be the most expensive in history, topping the record of $40 million spent by the two parties in 1940.

At this stage of the Republican preconvention campaign it is clear that the issue goes beyond the mere counting of delegates already pledged. It seems unlikely that either Senator Taft or General Eisenhower will have enough of those formally pledged to take a nomination on the first ballot.

Major problems confronting the nation's librarians will be considered this week at the seventy-first annual conference of the American Library Association, opening today at the Waldorf-Astoria. More than 5,000 librarians from all parts of the country, representing public as well as college and university libraries, will participate.

PHOTOGRAPHS of birds need not be simple records of species, but can be interesting pictures in themselves. Ample proof to this effect will go on view tomorrow and continue through July 20 in the National Audubon Society's show of birds and wild life at the Kodak Photographic Information Center behind the Kodak Colorama on the east balcony of Grand Central Terminal. The gallery is open from 10 A. M. to 10 P. M. daily.

Even though the vegetable garden is packed solid right now, space will be available for succession sowings when the early crops of lettuce, peas, spinach, radishes and scallions are harvested and plants removed.

But at the party's national convention in Cleveland the week-end of May 30 it was Samuel H. Friedman of New York who was nominated for second spot on the ticket.

NEWARK, June 28 -- Detectives today questioned a dozen persons in a search for clues to the murder yesterday of Harry Olshan, 52 years old, a dealer in precious metals and gems. His body was found on the floor of his seventh floor office and workshop in the Wiss Building, 671 Broad Street.

Within recent months bitter opposition has developed to the teaching of information about the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) or the United Nations in the schools and colleges of this country.

The conservation-minded squirrels are the two-legged variety who hold little blue cards proclaiming them members of the Ancient and Honorable Order of Squirrels.
Samuel Antek, conductor of the New Jersey Symphony, yesterday afternoon made an appearance as guest conductor of the N. B. C. Summer Symphony at the Belasco Theatre.

Cullman, chairman of the board of commissioners of the Port of New York Authority, has expressed the Authority's "great regrets" at low-flying airplanes, which have disturbed performers and audiences at the opening concerts of the thirty-fifth Lewisohn Stadium season.

Seven divisional champions and two alternates were named to the United States Olympic weightlifting team yesterday as the National Amateur Athletic Union title event concluded a two-day run at the 69th Regiment Armory.

PITTSBURGH, June 28 (AP) -- Stan Musial blasted a triple to run his consecutive hitting streak to twenty - four games and Solly Hemus got his eighth home run as the Cardinals whipped the last-place Pirates, 4 -- 3 today.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Democratic leaders here and in Illinois are anxiously telling Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson that the hour is a lot later than he seems to think, and that if he has any intention of trying to get the Presidential nomination, or even of being in a position of receptivity to its offer, he had better do something about it.

NORWALK, Conn., June 28 -- Five persons were admitted to the Norwalk Hospital after a four car crash at 11:45 A. M. today on the Merritt Parkway, 400 yards east of Comstock Hill Avenue. Six persons received first aid.

This summer Greece is offering foreign college students low-cost accommodations and generous reductions on boat and train fares. Seven steamship lines are reducing their prices to students from 30 to 50 per cent. The I Togia Line connects Piraeus with Brindisi in the heel of Italy.

WITH a great tooting of whistles, the S. S. United States will sail Thursday noon from Pier 86 at the foot of West Forty-sixth Street, and the United States of America and the United States Lines will enter their joint venture -- the world's newest, fastest and most modern vessel -- in North Atlantic passenger service.

Failure to settle the steel strike and a heat wave in New York as the summer opened had a stultifying effect on financial markets last week. The pending adjournment of Congress also slowed action in the markets. Stock prices kept within a narrow range in moderately active trading and on balance were slightly higher.

BOSTON, June 28 (UP) -- Walter Masterson pitched the Senators into second place in the American League, three games behind the Yanks, by routing his former Red Sox team-mates, 5 -- 1, today before 11,040 fans. Boston dropped from second to fourth.

DETROIT, June 28 -- The Taft-Eisenhower contest has captured and held wide public attention throughout the Central States, though in the last few days the weather may have received more front-page prominence. At Supung (Suiho) on the Korean side of the Yalu River, which marks the boundary between North Korea and Manchuria, a forest of steel towers rises above squat, brick buildings. High-tension cables fan out from the towers southward into North Korea, northward across the Yalu into the great industrial complex in the Mukden area of Manchuria, and westward to Soviet-controlled Dairen and Port Arthur.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, June 28 -- The ethnarchy, highly political governing body of the Cypriot Greek Orthodox Church, which is under the partly-United States educated young Archbishop Makarios, has adopted a definite policy of trying to use the United States against Britain.

OCEANPORT, N. J., June 28 -- One Hitter took a single swing at the opposition in the Monmouth Handicap today, and it was all over. The Greentree Stable 6-year-old, installed the favorite by the crowd of 21,569 fans at the Monmouth Park race track, had only four others to beat in the mile-and-a-quarter feature event.

Cochrane, chairman of the Federal Maritime Board, said today that the United States should have at least a dozen new high-speed passenger ships for its world-wide trade routes. But he saw little hope of getting them built until the longstanding dispute over ship construction subsidies was settled.

WITH July Fourth coming on Friday, another long week-end will carry what may prove to be a record crowd of holidayers out of the city. The exodus will start Wednesday, when airlines begin to put on extra sections, especially to Cape Cod, Nantucket and Maine.

CHICAGO, June 28 (AP) -- Wheat tumbled under heavy selling into new low ground for this year's crop on the Board of Trade today. The break in wheat created selling in other grains, all of which headed lower.

BALTIMORE, June 28 -- A South Jersey housewife and mother of a couple of children, Mrs. Ruby Scull of Ventnor, who spends most of her summer week-ends on regatta courses, took two heats today for a perfect point score of 800 points in the 48-cubic-inch class of runabouts, the feature of the annual Wilson Point Men's Club race meet on Middle River, an arm of Chesapeake Bay.

THE major news in best sellerdom this month is political. Herbert Hoover, who was in twelfth place last week, is now in ninth and two points over Truman: the President, however, is four points ahead of Roosevelt.

BRIDGEPORT, W. Va. -- The clear mountain streams, quiet rivers and lakes of this conveniently located state make a good excuse for fishermen bound south and west to stop driving and start casting. WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Both houses of Congress, foregoing today the usual Saturday recess, pressed an earnest drive to complete essential business by the end of next week and leave Washington for the rest of the year.
CHICAGO, June 28 (UP) -- Larry Doby and Luke Easter backed up some good pitching by Mike Garcia with home runs today as the Indians is scored a 5-to-1 victory over the White Sox.

LOS ANGELES, June 28 -- Mal Whitfield, the defending Olympic champion at 800 meters, won the 400-meter final tryout today in the fast time of 46.9 seconds to spark a powerful American team in its quest for world honors in the games next month in Helsinki.
TOLEDO, Ohio, June 28 -- The Inverness best-ball $18,600 invitation golf tourney settled down to a two-way battle today between the Sam Snead-Jim Ferrier and Lloyd Mangrum-Cary Middlecoff duos.

SWITZERLAND is a concentrated little country, and it has a highly concentrated musical life. In terms of the number, quality and variety of musical events in proportion to the national population, its musical life is probably one of the richest in the world. And despite the conservative flavor of the Swiss way of life, it is by no means the least adventurous.

LONDON, June 28 -- Refugees from behind the Iron Curtain revealed today that the Soviet Embassy in London was carrying on a widespread campaign to get them to return home.

SINGAPORE, June 28 -- The buffeting that traditional colonial conventions in Malaya have been receiving lately reached a climax today when members of the committee of Kuala Lumpur's exclusive British-run Lake Club offered their resignations as a result of the public outcry over the club's policy of excluding Asians.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 28 (UP) -- F. Norman Phelps' Sturdy One, winner of the Inglewood Handicap last year, came back today to score a repeat victory by a length at Hollywood Park as the highly favored Calumet entry of Two Lea and Wistful was shut out of the money.

Earnings of New York City banks at the mid-year are showing substantial improvement over the results in 1951. The beneficial influence of the Federal Government's deficit financing program during the second half of this year is yet to be determined, but based on actual operating figures indications are that the banks will earn $156,000,000 during 1952, a gain of 11 1/2 per cent over 1951.

Yesterday's news is today's history and will eventually be commented on in tomorrow's history books. But before news can find its way into history it must be documented and checked back against the original papers for accuracy. CHICAGO, June 28 -- Eddie Arcaro, America's premier jockey, topped a celebration in his honor today by piloting Woodchuck to a nose victory in the $34,650 Equipoise Mile at Arlington Park.

OLD WESTBURY, L. I., June 28 -- The graceful, forty-five-room country home of Harold E. Talbott, New York financier, was badly damaged by fire this afternoon. THE rest of the world may have been in a topsy-turvy state last week, but everything was normal in Hollywood, for the motion picture industry is about to be subjected to another investigation. This time the Government will look into capital gain deals made between stars and studios to determine whether grounds exist for possible prosecution of income tax irregularities.

GOLDEN, Colo., June 28 -- Averell Harriman, Director for Mutual Security, warned his old friend, General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, in effect here today that the general would be a captive of the Old Guard Republicans if he became the party nominee.
RALEIGH, N. C., June 28 (AP) -- North Carolina Democrats nominated candidates for Representative in three of twelve districts today.

Financial worries having been relieved, if not entirely eliminated, by the apparently smashing success of the Bing Crosby-Bob Hope telethon, Olympic officials now buckle down to the monumental task of processing and equipping the full United States team of the 300 athletes that will wear the Stars and Stripes in the international games at Helsinski.

TOGETHER with all the "firsts" and esoterica that long - play has spawned, there has been a determined effort by the record companies to build up the bread-and-butter items of their catalogues. These efforts do not entirely involve duplication, for the large companies have had certain staples only on shellac disks or on long-play repressings of shellacs.

LEONARD SILLMAN, having given the critics something to cheer about as a result of his successful revue, "New Faces," at the Royale, is beginning to bear a striking resemblance to that fellow whose head teemed with endless schemes for the good of Titipu.

CHICAGO, June 28 -- The steel strike is beginning to have an adverse effect on heavy industries in the Chicago area, as some machinery manufacturers have announced layoffs because of shortages of components. The area's large electronic industry, however, is continuing to expand as new facilities go into production.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson left here today for Berlin well satisfied with the results of his London talks with Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden and French Foreign Minister Robert Schuman.

BERLIN, June 28 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson, aboard President Truman's personal plane, the Independence, flew today from London across the Soviet zone of Germany -- the scene of half a dozen air incidents in recent weeks -- and landed for an overnight visit to Berlin.
PRINCETON, N. J., June 28 -- "Everybody is conceding victory in the Olympic trials to Navy, but I've got a hunch they could be wrong," says Princeton crew coach Delos C. (Dutch) Schoch.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- News of a gold, oil or any other type of strike is a stirring event at any time. When word of an enormous "find" in the form of a gusher of oil and natural gas arrives in the midst of a droning, technical hearing on pipeline distribution of natural gas its dramatic effect is considerably heightened.

In some cases of arthritis, hydrocortisone (known also as Compound F) is more effective than cortisone when injected directly into inflamed joints. The action of cortisone, well-known anti-arthritis drug, may be the consequence of its similarity to hydrocortisone.

Those of us who lived through the physical end of the Mussolini era are naturally concerned with any manifestations of its spiritual revival, such as were outlined by Giorgio Borsa in "Again the Mussolini Way in Italy" (June 8).

THE gentleman by the name of Fred Lounsberry, who wrote in the column across the page last week, gave voice to a personal objection which seemed a bit on the audacious side. With respect to musical comedies as presented these days on the stage, Mr. Lounsberry took strong exception to what he termed "a sense of responsibility on the part of the leading practitioners of the musical-drama art."
Berkeley Bell, the former University of Texas star who turned professional in 1936, returned to the amateur ranks yesterday in the seventeenth annual New York State men's tennis singles championship.

SINCE the 1952-53 season does not open until next October, not all the orchestras have distributed their prospectuses. But from those that have come in a new trend is strikingly clear. There will be a marked in crease in concert versions of operas.

PROBABLY no section of the Union Army was more poorly prepared for the disastrous series of engagements that marked the first year of the Civil War than its medical department. No provision had been made to care for convalescing patients or the thousands of soldiers stricken with "civilian" diseases like pneumonia, dysentery and typhus.

IF you like your tales tall and slap-happy; if you like your heroine wacky, "Teacher Lady" is for you. Miss Brue Sheehan, who tells the story in the first person and admits she was named for an ailing cow, is a Character.

MANY Americans know Katharine Lee Bates as the author of "America the Beautiful." New Englanders know her as a local poet who spoke of their condition in measured verse steeped in the tradition of the great English and American writers.
CINCINNATI, June 28 (UP) -- Andy Seminick's single off the left-field fence with two out in the last of the ninth inning drove in the run that gave the Reds a 3-2 victory over the Cubs today.

Foreign aid for the coming fiscal year has just started its second run through the Congressional rolling mill. Its first run was in the form of an authorization bill which trimmed President Truman's request from $7.9 billions to a little less than $6.5 billions. This figure is a maximum, which may not be exceeded but which need not be attained.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, June 28 -- The University of Pennsylvania crew, here to defend the Thames Challenge Cup which it won last year, will be opposed first in the Henley Royal Regatta begining Wednesday by Britain's Bedford Rowing Club.

NORTHEAST OF HAIDUONG, Indo-China, June 28 (AP) -- French forces launched a new mop-up drive today against the Vietminh in the Red River delta. Planes parachuted about 1,000 soldiers into enemy positions fifteen miles northeast of Haiduong.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 28-- Fifty-four nonwhites wearing on one shoulder the black, green and yellow colors of the African National Congress, were charged with conspiring to commit public violence under the Riotous Assemblies Act in Johannesburg Magistrate's Court today.

ELIZABETH, N. J., June 28 -- The completion of a two-year landscaping project at the rear of Boxwood Hall, a pre-Revolutionary landmark here, was announced this week by Henry C. Paulsen, chairman of a committee of garden club representatives responsible for the work.
The seaman has a new enemy -- butterflies.

Kingsley Martin in his letter in your issue of June 22 is disturbed by our "new American orthodoxy." This is encouraging. Hitherto his New Statesman and Nation has been worried primarily about our lack of orthodoxy. For example: "Marshall Aid is a device for widening overseas markets for American business."

Little Bobby Shantz, baseball's biggest winner of 1952, pitched a gaudy two-hit shut-out against the Yankees yesterday and to compound the humiliation of the world champions, the Athletics pounded Johnny Sain and Tom Morgan for fourteen ringing blows, including a pair of home runs by Gus Zernial.

HENRY ENOCH KAGAN is a rabbi and psychologist of Mount Vernon, N. Y. He has taught at Columbia University and is active in interfaith activities in his home town. Like many other Americans, he is keenly aware of the dangers, to both Christian and Jew, of anti-Semitism.
The Third Naval District headquarters announced yesterday that four captains stationed here, each with more than thirty years of service, would retire tomorrow. They are:

DALLAS, Tex., June 28 -- A big airliner and a small, two-passenger plane were in collision in the air today at Love Field. The liner landed fifty-five passengers safely but the small plane was wrecked, killing its two occupants. Their plane, a Swift, landed in the middle of a street, completely demolished. The collision had sheared off one wing.

Folklore and fable hold up the ant and the bee as classic examples of industry; but if the insects should ever take over, the wasps will certainly be among those high in command. Particularly the thread-waisted wasps or Sphecidae. Their industry, ingenuity and ruthlessness are something to behold.

SARANAC INN, N. Y., June 28 -- United States military and economic aid to Europe must continue indefinitely unless present world conditions change substantially, Harlan Cleveland, Assistant Director for Europe of the Mutual Security Agency, told members of the New York State Bar Association here today.

MOST price controls would be extended for ten months or until April 30, 1953, in the compromise agreement reached by the Senate-House conference committee and later approved by the Senate. This reverses the previous action of the House in scuttling all price controls on items not rationed or allocated.

Many buyers were in the wholesale market here last week placing initial fall commitments for fur-trimmed and untrimmed coats suits, dresses, sportswear and furs, according to McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office.

OSSINING, N. Y., June 29 -- The Rev. Robert William Greene, 41-year-old Roman Catholic missionary, sat in the cool cloister of Maryknoll Seminary today and recalled the long nightmare of imprisonment and torture that preceded his release on April 20 from Communist China.

OKLAHOMA CITY, June 29 -- Walter White of New York, executive secretary of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, charged here today that delegates to the Republican National Convention from five Southern states had been "bought at a going rate of $2,500 each."

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Appropriations remain the principal obstacle before Congress, still bent on winding up its necessary affairs this week, so that the members may be free not only for the political conventions but also for campaigns in the fall.

The 100th anniversary of the founding of St. Ann's Roman Catholic Church, 110 East Twelfth Street, was commemorated at a pontifical mass yesterday morning. Auxiliary Bishop Stephen J. Donahue of the New York Archdiocese officiated. Cardinal Spellman presided.

PHILADELPHIA, June 29 -- The Greater Philadelphia-South Jersey Council urged Congress today to insure the industrial development program now under way on both sides of the Dealware River by authorizing a project to deepen the channel of this busy waterway to a depth of forty feet for the thirty-seven and a half miles from the Philadelphia Naval Base to the Trenton Marine Terminal.

Oil overflowing into a pit from a furnace that supplies heat and hot water to tenants of the sixteen-story apartment building at 269 West Seventy-second Street, near West End Avenue, ignited in a flash fire as firemen were fighting a blaze in the fire box yesterday afternoon.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 29 -Fernando Lamas and Metro-Gold-wyn-Mayer have buried the hatchet and the actor will play the lead opposite Elizabeth Taylor in "The Girl Who Had Everything." Lamas was suspended from salary after he had objected to going to Mexico to appear in "Sombrero," most of which is being filmed on location.

ST. LOUIS, June 29 (AP) -- Dick Kryhoski ended a pitchers' duel in 106-degree temperature today by smacking a three-run homer in the ninth with two out to gain a 3-2 victory for the Browns over the Tigers.

The country's librarians were urged yesterday to resist all efforts to curb free expression and to withstand especially any attempt to curtail the circulation of books and periodicals reflecting unorthodox views.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (UP) -- James V. Bennett, Director of the Bureau of Prisons, called today for revision of laws carrying mandatory prison sentences for certain offenses, including Post Office robbery and violations of the new Narcotics Act.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -United States, Australian and New Zealand Cabinet members will meet in Honolulu during the first week in August to draft long-range defense strategy in the Pacific-Asian region and review the Korean deadlock.

TOKYO, Monday, June 30 -- The United Nations charged yesterday that a 37-mm. high-velocity shell made in the Soviet Union landed Friday inside the neutral zone at Panmunjom. The Allied delegation on the same day walked out of the conferences for an armistice in Korea, forcing a recess until tomorrow.

Emphasizing that the Metcalf-Hatch Act, effective tomorrow, concerned only unlicensed, unwanted or unclaimed animals, the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals said yesterday that animals so classified could he requisitioned by the Commissioner of Health for research forty-eight hours after they had entered an A. S. P. C. A. shelter.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 29 -- The United States delegation made public today stacks of official records, reports, and other papers to back its charges in the United Nations that the Soviet Union had enslaved thousands of persons as forced laborers.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- There's wide disagreement among airplane pilots these days over a new international phonetic alphabet system. It was devised to replace the familiar AbleBaker-Charlie routine used during and since World War II to lessen the chances for misunderstanding in the pronunciation of letters that sound alike.

Twenty-four hours worked a Grifith change in the Yankees. Onlike the stumbling, impotent outfit that succumbed to the Athletics, 12 -- 0, the day before, Manager Casey Stengel's men regained their winning ways at the Stadium yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 29 -- A boom for the nomination of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur appeared under way here tonight. Gov. John S. Fine of Pennsylvania, a strong admirer of the general, has decided to delay the caucus of his seventy-member delegation until after the Republican convention keynote speech by the former Far East commander on the night of July 7.

In anticipation of the long and heavily trafficked Fourth of July week-end, when vacation time will begin for many families traveling by automobile, the National Safety Council has issued some pointers to encourage safer driving.

A new volume of Lincolniana by J. G. Randall has been scheduled for October publication by Dodd, Mead, entitled "Midstream -- Lincoln the President." The 700-page volume will deal with 1863, discussing not only the great war victories, but also Lincoln's personal life.

Service on the B. M. T. line was interrupted for several hours last night between Fifty-seventh Street, Manhattan, and Astoria, Queens, after a cable feeding power to the third rail caught fire in the north tube under the East River, about 250 feet from the Queens entrance.

CINCINNATI, June 29 (AP) -Brooklyn and New York, running one-two in the National League pennant race, will provide twelve of the twenty-five players on the league's squad that will clash with an American League team in the annual major league All-Star game at Philadelphia on July 8.

CAIRO, June 29 -- The Government announced tonight that Premier Ahmed Naguib El Hilaly Pasha had resigned, but that his resignation had not been officially accepted. Former Premier Hussein Sirry Pasha has been asked to form a new Cabinet.

Four thousand Americans of Irish descent kicked up their heels and lifted their voices yesterday in Gaelic competitions at the twentieth annual Irish Feis on the campus of Fordham University in the Bronx.

A strong demand for the Canadian dollar last week lifted it to a premium of 2 5/8 cent, highest since November, 1934. Week's lowest was 2 7/32 cent, and the close of 2 19/32 cent, represented a gain of 3/8 cent over the previous week.

LONDON, June 29 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden was confined to his room today by an attack of jaundice and has canceled his engagements for the present. His illness was disclosed in a Foreign Office announcement.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The national labor-management manpower policy committee said today in a set of employment principles that it was "opposed unequivocally" to drafting labor to meet mobilization needs.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- A Senate subcommittee has asserted that corruption and weakness dominated the District of Columbia Police Department under Chief Robert J. Barrett, now retired.

If you are planning a lazy relaxing vacation, you can still take up something constructive with a minimum amount of activity -- namely knitting. The fact that hand-knits were never more important in the fashion world is all the more reason you may wish to take along a knitting bag filled with some of the lovely new yarns and a few good patterns.

If present indications mean anything, the bulk of television programing ultimately is going to be done on film. Already the investment in "telepix" runs into the tens of millions of dollars and before too long it may constitute the major source of employment in Hollywood.

The Board of Estimate, at a special meeting today, called primarily to deal with problems in the field of private bus operation, is scheduled to vote an extension of at least three months -- and perhaps six -- for the interim fares now in force on all private bus lines operating under city franchises. All such lines now charge 10 cents except the Fifth Avenue Coach Company, which charges 12.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Senator Richard B. Russell, Democrat of Georgia, declared today his thirty-two years in government, twenty of them in the United States Senate, qualified him for the Presidency.

The present system of compiling statistics on production and sales of dress and sports shirts makes the figures useless to manufacturers and retailers because of the great variation in the classification of border-line garments. The problem has been accentuated recently because of the great increase in sports sales from less than 30 per cent of output in 1947 to more than 70 per cent in May, manufacturers said last week.

DENVER, June 29 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower heard two pieces or cheerful news today. Visiting members of the North Dakota delegation to the Republican National Convention told him that his chances of winning the Presidential nomination were improving, for the these reasons:

One cannot let pass without answer the recent attack made in these columns on Prof. Robert J. Alexander, the distinguished teacher who has worked so generously in the cause of a real Good Neighbor Policy, denouncing the dictatorships of Latin America in the name of the same principles for which the founders of this great nation stood.

Advertising which is not quite false but not entirely true will receive major attention of the Better Business Bureaus throughout the country. This was the result of a new program adopted last week by the Association of Better Business Bureaus at its thirty-eighth annual conference in Swampscott, Mass.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art and its officials were taken to task yesterday by a group of American artists who called them irresponsible in their handling of artists whose medium is modern abstraction.

More than 60 per cent of last year's record-breaking volume of private placement financing was supplied by life insurance companies and other institutions in the Greater New York area, according to the 1952 Yearbook of Private Placement Financing, published today by E. V. Hale Co. of Chicago.

In a period when books have come in for more than their share of censorship it is reassuring to see a large group of people come together in convention under the theme "Books Are Basic." That is the theme of the American Library Association, meeting in New York City this week to discuss the problems of librarianship, to seek ways of effectively spreading the culture of books and allied materials, and to renew acquaintances.
Allen H. Freeman has been appointed sales representative for the metropolitan area for Bartmann Bixer, Inc.
I should like to inject a hitherto unrecognized viewpoint in the steel crisis, that of the independent public stockholder.
PHILADELPHIA, June 29 -- Indignities no end were piling themselves on the Giants today as they engaged the Phillies in the series finale before 12,034 steaming fans.

CHICAGO, June 29 (AP) -- The White Sox cashed in for two unearned runs through Cleveland's leaky infield to take a 4-2 double-header opener today and then battled the Indians to a 7-7 stalemate in a 10-inning nightcap called by darkness.
Six new films will arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
Eight hundred American students from all parts of the country will depart this afternoon for European holidays of study and travel aboard the Netherlands Government vessel Groote Beer.

LONDON, June 29 (Reuters) -- America's steel industry is more productive than Britain's because of natural advantages and larger-scale operations, according to a British steel report to be issued tomorrow.

CINCINNATI, June 29 (AP) -- The Reds, enraged by a humiliating 9-8 loss to the Cubs in the opener of today's double-header, came winging back to a 9-1 victory in the finale behind Harry Perkowski's four-hit pitching.

HAMILTON, Ont., June 29 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian Olympic Association today named sixteen men and seven women to Canada's track team going to the Helsinki games next month. The full team of 113 and 20 officials also received final approval.

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, June 30 (AP) -- Front-line officers reported yesterday that the Allied infantrymen who stopped heavy Chinese Communist assaults on "Baldy" Hill, on the Western Korean front, had virtually wiped out the attacking force of 750 men.
BONN, Germany, June 29 -- The reply the Western Allies are preparing to send to Moscow may prove to be a "showdown note" on German unification, according to authoritative sources here.
With or without glasses, Herbert Feldman, 19 years old, of 853 Tiffany Street, the Bronx, encountered difficulties yesterday in driving an automobile in Brooklyn, the police reported.

BALTIMORE, June 29 -- Champions and favorites may have had their fun and thrills today but unheralded dark horses got the checkered flags in the second half of the regatta in Middle River of the Wilson Point Men's Club.

Assemblyman D. Maliory Stephens' decision to retire from the Legislature at the end of this year will deprive New York City of a powerful friend at Albany. Although he likes to describe himself as only "a country boy," Mr. Stephens has a keen grasp of the problems that face those who live in the state's largest municipality.

PHILADELPHIA, June 29 -- A 28-year-old Georgian, Louise Suggs, set a record in winning the women's national open golf championship today when she completed the seventy-two holes of play with a total of 284 for a margin of seven strokes.

ZURICH, June 29 -- Arrangements for the dismemberment of I. G. Farben Industrie A. G. -- Germany's largest industrial undertaking -- having at last been completed, the exchange of the old reichsmark stock of the vast German chemical trust for the stock of its twelve successor concerns can now begin.

The Christian Church is based "not on St. Peter as a person, nor his successors in office, the Bishops of Rome, but on St. Peter's confession to Jesus that 'Thou art Christ, the Son of the living God'," Canon Thomas A. Sparks, pastor of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, declared in his sermon yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (UP) -- The United States Chamber of Commerce said today the general outlook for business was good for the rest of this year and predicted that the strength would carry over into 1953.
BERLIN, June 29 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson indicated today that the United States would consider military measures if the East Germans attempted to occupy or blockade West Berlin.

BOSTON, June 29 -- The problem of drafting women for the armed services and a demand that the Democratic and Republican parties support the equal rights amendment are among the proposed resolutions to be put to the membership of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women here this week.

LONDON, June 29 -- The stock markets in the past few days managed to throw off to some extent the pessimism which has been affecting them with such persistency for the past few weeks. There have been periodical rallies in this period but nothing of a lasting nature and consequently there is skepticism concerning the durability of the present rather better trend.

MUNICH, Germany, June 20 -The number of army deserters or other Soviet citizens fleeing to the West for asylum has recently dwindled to almost nothing. One reason for this is that Moscow's security police have managed to tighten barriers and erect new obstacles to escape.

Reports of the speed attained by the trim, destroyer-like, superliner United States on her recent trials, coupled with announcement from Europe that the Cunarder Queen Elizabeth suddenly had been revved up to 34 knots on her latest eastbound crossing, have stirred up lively speculation in shipping circles.

NEW SALEM, Ill., June 29 -When Lincoln was tending store and studying in New Salem in his twenties, no one imagined that only thirty years later he would be leader of the nation. He hardly seemed like a man of destiny then. And naturally no one foresaw then, that in 1952, his six years in New Salem would be recreated in a chronicle play acted on the same hill.

Half a million dollars was donated to the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York yesterday by representatives of Jewish fraternal and benevolent organizations at a special luncheon-meeting at the Commodore Hotel. At the same time, Moshe Sharett, Israel's Foreign Minister, appealed for aid to build his nation's economic structure and consolidate Israel's "political and military successes."

The visit of Secretary Acheson to London, Berlin and Vienna, with French participation in the talks, helps to emphasize again the crucial importance of Western Europe to American policy. This has been a cardinal tenet of Dean Acheson's as Under Secretary and Secretary of State and it is one of the factors in his career which future historians will stress.

The Rev. Dr. Adam Clayton Powell Sr., pastor emeritus of the Abyssinian Baptist Church, 132 West 138th Street, laid a new cornerstone for the Negro church and community house building yesterday in a ceremony that closely paralleled the original one thirty years ago.

Hoodlums and law breakers in general probably will shed no tears at the news that Walter P. Murphy is to retire today from his job assistant special agent in charge of the intelligence unit of the New York District of the Internal Revenue Bureau.

CHICAGO, June 29 -- Heavy rains in the Northwest, with North Dakota having the heaviest precipitation of the season, combined with continued heavy marketings of winter wheat, including increased receipts of red winter wheat, to make a saggy market last week in wheat.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -The National Production Authority has announced its expanded allotments of copper for July -- a total of 133,333 tons of domestic and foreign copper for brass and copper wire mills and foundries.

HONG KONG, June 29 -- An Alice-in-Wonderland touch has been introduced into the daily lives of Chinese on the mainland by the Peiping regime's campaign against "bacteriological warfare." While Communist propagandists continue to denounce "American germ warfare criminals" for both domestic and foreign propaganda, hygienists have gone on a sanitation binge inside Red China.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio predicted today that if he won the Republican Presidential nomination he would carry thirty states and would be elected by a 5,000,000-vote margin.

SEOUL, Korea, June 29 -- Lieut. Gen. Glenn O. Barcus, United States Fifth Air Force commander, said today that Communist anti-aircraft guns in Manchuria fired across the Yalu River at American planes bombing the Supung (Suiho) power plant on the Korean side last Monday.

DETROIT, June 29 -- Leading American educators, here for the opening of the ninetieth annual summer convention of the National Education Association, expressed deep concern today at the growing attacks against schools and colleges that taught about the United Nations or the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO).

DANBURY, Conn., June 29 -- From a modest beginning fifteen years ago, when the small fry of Danbury had little to do but idle on street comers, this community of 30,000 has built a varied youth program. Today 5,000 Danbury youngsters 5 to l8 years old participate in some phase of the program.
TEHERAN, Iran, June 29 (AP) -Supporters of Premier Mohammed Mossadegh walked out of the Majlis (Parliament) today when it appeared that an anti-Government candidate was about to be elected speaker.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -The Senate Small Business Committee criticized the Department of Defense and other Government agencies today for a machine tool shortage, which, it said, "seriously retarded building our armed strength."

Eight hundred young and old Americans of Czechoslovak descent performed mass gymnastic exercises yesterday at Randalls Island in the annual rally of American Sokol teams, a festival that preserves in America the national sport now taken over by the Communist-regime in Czechoslovakia.

The lamprey, Tom Marvel said seriously, is delicious because it is so well-nourished. It eats other fish by attaching its snoutlike mouth to them and rasping off the flesh with its horny teeth. Such nourishment imparts to its own meat an excellent quality.

The fifty-seventh annual commencement of the Webb Institute of Naval Architecture, at Glen Cove, L. I., will be held this afternoon, with Walter L. Green, chairman of the board and president of the American Bureau of Shipping, delivering the principal address. Mr. Green is also a trustee of the school.

Instead of lessening the need for whole blood and plasma, production of dextran plasma expanders on a commercial scale will increase the need for whole blood and natural plasma by saving more of the wounded from shock for subsequent treatment.

LONDON, June 29 -- This week, in the wake of Secretary of State Dean Acheson's visit to London, the British Parliament expects to hear of some new arrangements for closer liaison and consultation between the United Nations Command for Korea and the countries participating in the war.

There is no balm in Brooklyn for the Braves. At Ebbets Field yesterday the Bostonians knocked out Preacher Roe with three home runs in one inning, but the Dodgers won, 6 -- 5, to hold a five-game first-place lead.

THE design for living in John Bell Clayton's new novel, "Six Angels at My Back,"* is starkly elemental. The three main characters all live in one cabin. The boy who tells the story is Ed Greaver. He is the sort of person things happen to; the others cause things to happen. They are Robert E. Lee (Turkey) Sims, and Mae, who is Turkey's wife.

When a Government spokesman was asked ten days ago why the State Department had barred Prof. Owen Lattimore from leaving the United States he said, in part: "We do not take action on fantasies or inanities." The Department has now made an apology -- which shows that in this case it did take action on fantasies and inanities.

General Eisenhower, expressing confidence that he would win the nomination, said in a televised program yesterday that he was attending the national convention next week in obedience to the "orders" and "recommendations" of his political associates.

WOODSTOCK, Va., June 29 (AP) -- Warren B. French of Woodstock, Seventh District delegate to the Republican National Convention, said today that he preferred to be listed as uncommitted. The Associated Press had carried Mr. French as a supporter of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio in its delegate table. Mr. French said he was "undecided whom I shall support."

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 25 -- South Africa's Nationalist Government, which has already been at loggerheads with the United Nations over the treatment of Indians in the Union and the status of the former German South-West Africa, seems to be heading for conflict over a wider front with the outside world.

SALT LAKE CITY, June 29 (UP) -- Senator Robert Kerr today told representatives of seventeen Western states that he would win the Democratic Presidential nomination on the fifth or sixth ballot at the convention opening July 21 in Chicago.

OKLAHOMA CITY, June 29 -A bumper wheat crop approaching the 1947 record dominates the country's midyear agricultural situation. Under ideal weather conditions, harvesting is proceeding at a rapid rate. Kansas, the country's No. 1 wheat state, may surpass its 1947 peak and the Oklahoma crop may also set a record.

YONGCHON, Korea, June 29 -About 1,800 South Koreans, most of them singing and all of them jubilant, marched away tonight from their barbed-wire prisons here to go home again to their families as free citizens. The happy, grinning men were the first of 27,000 who have been ordered released as non-Communists.

The leasehold on the eighteen-story office and showroom building at 1 Park Avenue has been sold by Webb Knapp, Inc.; to an investing client of Herrick, Feinstein Rossman, attorneys, in a deal negotiated by Herbert Papock and Maurice A. Pearson, brokers.

PITTSBURGH, June 29 (AP) -- A violent thunderstorm ended the Pirates' losing streak by cutting short a game with the Cards after five innings while the Bucs were leading, 2 -- 1. The triumph came after seven consecutive Pirate losses.

Two new political parties have announced their organization in Malaya during the past week. One, predominantly Chinese, is a conversion of what was formerly merely a benevolent society. The other adds a third to the two predominantly Malay parties that have already appeared in the field.
TOLEDO, Ohio, June 29 (UP) -Sam Snead and Jim Ferrier defeated Lloyd Mangrum and Dr. Cary Middlecoff today to win the $18,000 Inverness all-star golf tournament.

Executives of the major steel companies will meet this week to decide whether to make a new attempt to settle the four-week-old steel strike or to force President Truman's hand on use of the Taft-Hartley Act to end the tie-up, which enters its fifth week today.

HOUSTON, June 29 -- Western Republicans who favor General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for President launched a psychological offensive against Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio on the eve of the forty-fourth annual Governors Conference that opens here tomorrow.

BARNSTABLE, Mass., June 29 -- "Year-around" folk and city visitors in this quiet Cape Cod community joined today with representatives of the Massachusetts Bar Association in honoring the memory of James Otis, orator and patriot -- Barnstable's most distinguished citizen in the days of the American Resolution.
The Defense Production Act of 1950, extended for a year in 1951, was again renewed on Saturday almost on the eve of its expiration by statutory limitation.

Jule Styne, composer and producer, will leave tonight by air for the West Coast, where he will seek a male lead for "Hazel Flagg," the musical that he and Anthony B. Farrell have scheduled for production the end of this year.

The trustees of Columbia University have appointed fourteen business and professional leaders to a new council on medical affairs to advise them on the development of the university's medical program.

JERUSALEM, June 29 -- The highest ranking representative of Pope Pius in Israel, Msgr. Anthony Virgani, and the Rev. Leo A. Rudloff of the Church of Dormition on Mount Zion have jointly brought suit in Haifa district court against the Israeli Government's custodian of German property.

Your correspondent in Spain, referring to the attitude of the Spanish Government in Catalonia, wrote on June 8: "All Spanish newspapers were instructed never to use the word 'Catalonia' or 'Catalan.' About this and other similar statements, THE NEW YORK TIMES published an article on June 9.
CINCINNATI, June 29 (AP) -- The Kroger Company today reported sales totaling $482,319,869 in its semi-annual report.

The action of the Senate Committee in attaching a rider to an appropriations bill which would ban the use of funds by "any international agency that directly or indirectly promoted one-world government or world citizenship" brings into the open a series of scattered and variously sponsored attacks on the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

The annual memorial service for the 12,000 colonial patriots who died on British prison ships in Wallabout Bay, Brooklyn, was held yesterday at Emmanuel Baptist Church, Lafayette Avenue and St. James Place, Brooklyn.
PITTSBURGH, June 29 (AP) -- Coal miners started annual paid vacations today -- sure of $100 a man and hopeful that contract uncertainties may clear up during their ten days of rest.

PERHAPS this isn't exactly the right kind of weather for it, but football persists in sneaking onto the sports pages with ever increasing frequency these days. There was one recent item which caught the eye and sent memory churning. It was the announcement that Gus Dorais had signed as backfield coach of the Pittsburgh Steelers.

PARIS, June 29 -- A new commercial agreement between France and Yugoslavia will become effective on July 1, according to French officials. Conceived as part of the effort of the Western countries to reinforce the economic links with Yugoslavia, it will be in effect for a year.
Churchgoers were urged yesterday by the Rev. L. Humphrey Walz to include newspaper men and writers in their daily prayers.
A new heat wave, which had threatened to hit the city before it had much of a chance to recover from its recent spell of sizzling weather apparently has been averted.
Two special hour-long "Meet the Press" convention programs will be carried next Sunday and on July 20, 7 to 8 P. M., by the N. B. C.-TV network, from Chicago.

GENEVA, Switzerland, June 29 (UP) -- The Swiss Federation of Watch Manufacturers today called an emergency session for Wednesday to discuss a threatened increase in the United States tariff on watches.
CLEVELAND, June 29 (AP) -"Obviously, we have passed the peak of demand for machinery to make war equipment," an executive of a leading machine tool manufacturer said the other day.

New York housewives may buy yellow-colored margarine across grocery counters tomorrow for the first time in sixty-six years. Repeal of the ban on sales of colored margarine in this state becomes effective on July 1.

Mr. John has tied up his fall and winter collection with "romance," actually dedicating it to Dan Cupid, for he feels that he is doing his best service for the artful lad if he sends ladies forth in hats designed to set off their charms.

Two more seeded players got into action yesterday as the New York state tennis championships entered their second day of competition. They were Jack Tuero, defending champion, and Charles Masterson of Brooklyn. Both came through two matches with little trouble.

PARIS, June 29 (UP) -- Premier Antoine Pinay disclosed today that he intended to press for European unity because he was convinced that it was "an even more certain way of saving peace than the formation of any army, however strong that army may be."
Alistair Forbes of Aberdeen, 23-year-old Scotsman wearing borrowed kilts and tam o'shanter, flew into New York yesterday to cheer for the Dodgers.

Influenced by Washington developments and reports of favorable progress by the crop, cotton prices in the domestic market moved lower last week. At the close on Friday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were down 40 to 83 points from the level of a week previous. The sharpest net decline was in the near-by July delivery.
BOGOTA, Colombia, June 29 (UP) -- The all-Conservative Congress has voted to extend indefinitely Roberto Urdaneta Arbelaez term as Acting President of Colombia, it was announced today.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- They have canned everything else. Now the air force is canning clothing.
Louis Martin bought a one-family home at 73-55 195th Street, Flushing, from Sylvia Rubin and insured title with the City Title Insurance Company.

a transaction that requirexl eight months to complete, a property in the downtown Manhattan insurance districhas passed to new control with' the -ale by he heirs of John, Rathbone of the fourstory.store and loft building at 62 Fulton Street

The excess profits tax falls most severely on banks in growing communities where expanded services are required and the banks must build up capital protection to accompany added risks. This is the conclusion of a special committee of the American Bankers Association which has just completed an analysis of the recent Federal Reserve tax survey.
TOKYO, Monday, June 30 (AP) -United Nations Command communique 1,296, for Sunday:
PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., June 29 -- Knickerbocker one of the oldest yacht clubs, had a new idea today for the summer championship regatta out on Long Island Sound.

Lily Pons, coloratura soprano, was soloist and her husband, Andre Kostelanetz, conductor, when the Stadium Symphony Orchestra appeared at Lewisohn Stadium Saturday evening before an audience of 15,000. It was the coloratura's first appearance in five years at a Stadium concert.

In an address which he delivered at Ann Arbor, Edwin Putzell Jr. stated on the strength of a survey made by the Monsanto Chemical Company, of which he is secretary, and the Union Electric Company that atomic power for industrial use is "perhaps four or five years away, measured in terms of full-scale units."
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period June 21 to 27 are given in the appended tabulation:

CHICAGO, June 29 -- Guy George Gabrielson, chairman of the Republican National Committee, today threw the weight of his official position against a rules change demanded by backers of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower.

WATERBURY, Conn., June 29 (UP) -- Catherine Hardy, 22-year-old Fort Valley State College senior, tied the American women's track record for the 50-meter event today while winning the individual title in the women's outdoor National Amateur Athletic Union senior track and field championships.
Would not governmental departments, including the Department of State, better serve the country and avoid embarrassment by adhering to a few basic principles?

The New York branch of the Women's International Association of Aeronautics, founded in 1931, yesterday awarded the Lady Drummond Hay Trophy for 1952 to Mrs. Walter Beech, president of the Beech Aircraft Company of Wichita, Kan., as the woman who had done most for aviation in the year.

BERLIN, June 29 -- The dangers of venturing too close to West Berlin outer borders were forcefully, brought home to a group of non-German labor leaders today when one of them was almost bodily carried off a bridge between Berlin and Potsdam.

Occupying Cardinal Spellman's episcopal throne, Norman Cardinal Gilroy, Archbishop of Sydney, Australia, presided at the solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday. He gave his blessing to the congregation at the close of the ceremony.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 29 -- The second and final week of the All-England lawn tennis championships begins tomorrow after a day of rest for the players, with three Americans remaining in the quarter-finals of the men's singles and five in the women's tournament.

LOS ANGELES, June 29 (UP) -Eight men were named today for the marathon and walking events of the Olympic Games, leaving only the decathlon team to be selected for the United States 1952 Olympic track team.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 29 -Peg's Pride, 10-year-old gray gelding jumper, won another championship today. He headed a large field in the twenty-ninth annual Fairfield County Horse Show, compiling 18 points, including second money in the $500 open jumper stake.

BUTLER, Pa., June 29 (UP) -- A habitual burglar who underwent a rare brain operation to cure an uncontrollable urge to steal only to resume his life of crime five years later, imposed his own final sentence today -- death by suicide.

MANILA, June 23 -- Handicraft industries that have changed neither tools nor techniques since Magellan discovered the Philippines in 1520 are getting a Point Four lift in preparation for serving new markets abroad and tapping a large idle reservoir of native labor.
CHICAGO, Monday, June 30 -Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio arrived from Washington at Municipal Airport at 1:35 o'clock this morning, Central daylight saving time (2:35 o'clock New York time).

School is over now, and a new class of worker is greeting the dismal dawn with a morbid eye. This is the class of those who sought, and by now it seems lucklessly, found, what the economic system refers to as summer jobs.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- A Congressional committee today criticized military planners for what it termed a failure to press for discovery and production of uranium, the basic raw material of atomic bombs.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- A total of 1,574 delegates will go to the Democratic National Convention in Chicago on July 7 to cast 1,230 votes. Another ninety may wind up as spectators instead of accredited delegates.

Averell Harriman, New York "favorite son" candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, returned here yesterday from a nation-wide tour convinced that "the people, as usual, are away ahead of the politicians."

PUSAN, Korea, Monday, June 30 (AP) -- President Syngman Rhee handed the South Korean National Assembly today an ultimatum -- it must accept his proposed constitutional changes or he will dissolve the body.
ROME, June 29 (AP) -- Communists fired the opening blast today in a threatened parliamentary cold war against Premier Alcide De Gasperi's Government.

Max A. Geller's "Advertising at the Crossroads: Federal Regulation vs Voluntary Vontrols"* is a scholarly yet very readable work on the "motive force which keeps the economic merry-go-round in perpetual motion." This is how Dr. Geller describes advertising.

Determined to reaffirm the concept that books are basic to American democracy and international understanding, 4,000 members of the American Library Association began their seventy-first annual conference here yesterday.

BERLIN, June 30 -- Two organizations, each purporting to represent scores of millions of persons in many lands, one pro-Communist and the other anti-Communist, will begin five-day sessions here tomorrow.

Bobby Brown hit his first home run of the campaign into the seats of the lower right field stand at the Stadium yesterday and for a time it appeared that this might prove the payoff wallop in the scuffle with the Red Sox.

Strong leadership by pivotal issues paced the stock market to higher levels yesterday. The fresh power behind the current rally carried quotations to within a fraction of the best of the year and raised the composite rate of THE NEW YORK TIMES index further by 0.78 point.

This letter is written in reference to the article which appeared in THE TIMES of June 8, "Nehru Denounces Missionary Role." In the only direct quotation which you make of any length Mr. Nehru states, "The missionaries have done a very good work there (the hill area of northeastern India) and I am all praise for them.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- Wheat price supports for the 1952 crop were set at a national average of $2.20 a bushel to farmers.

More persons in this country were protected through voluntary plans against sickness and accident in 1951 than ever before, according to the results of a survey released yesterday by the Health Insurance Council of the Institute of Life Insurance in its annual report on accident and health coverage in the United States.

New York housewives can buy yellow margarine at their food stores for the first time today, as this state becomes the forty-first to make the sale legal. They become free of a discrimination against them more than against margarine, for they were the victims of the enforced chore of coloring the white margarine at home in a mixing bowl.

VIENNA, June 30 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson said at a press conference here today that the United States Government would continue to press the Soviet Union for a response to the Western notes urging a short form of treaty for Austria.

" Washington Story," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer drama of politics, opens today at Loew's State, Van Johnson, Patricia Neal, Louis Calhern and Sidney Blackmer are starred in a cast that includes Philip Oper, Patricia Collinge, Moroni Olsen, Elizabeth Patterson and Reinhold Schunzel. Robert Pirosh wrote and directed the Dore Schary production.

TOKYO, Tuesday, July 1 -- United Nations delegates at Panmunjom told the Communists today that an armistice in Korea was within arm's reach if the Chinese and North Koreans would drop their uncompromising demand that all war prisoners must be returned under the exact terms dictated by the enemy delegation.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The men's wear industry is in the middle of the biggest year in its history, M. J. Lovell, director-counsel of the National Association of Shirt. Pajama and Sportswear Manufacturers, said here today at a meeting of the Washington-Maryland Men's Apparel Club at the Willard Hotel.

RYE, N. Y., June 30 -- A field of 137 pro-amateur teams, only six less than the Westchester County Golf Association's record that was set here a year ago, toured Westchester Country Club's par-72 championship West course from early morning until dusk today. Four of the units carded best-ball 67's to share honors.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The United States joined with Canada today in seeking formal approval of a St. Lawrence River power project that would serve also as the first step in the Dominion's construction of a seaway to the Great Lakes.

After pledging defensive guarantees to West Berlin, which lies beyond the areas covered by either the North Atlantic or the European Defense Community treaties, Secretary Acheson has pledged similar guarantees to Austria, which is also outside the scope of these pacts.

A sharp increase in equity flotations and a contraction in bond offerings featured new financing in June. Stock offered to the public was the largest for any month since June, 1946. Flotations of bonds were down sharply from the two preceding months but were the largest for any June in twenty-six years.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics today estimated that by 1975 a man might look forward to nine years in retirement as compared to three years in 1900.

Lovers of dogs were out in force yesterday to protest with a picket line against the Metcalf-Hatch Law, which goes into effect today and which provides for the use of stray dogs and cats by state-licensed research organizations.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Wood screw manufacturers appealed to the Tariff Commission today to fix a quota on imports of wood screws. Spokesmen said orders received by United States manufacturers in the first four months of 1952 declined 53 per cent under the same period in 1951.
The problem of what to do with the city's estimated 50,000 old-law tenements was attacked on two fronts yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- A joint Congressional committee recommended expansion of the United States aluminum industry in preference to the proposed purchase of the metal from Canada.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The Senate passed tonight an appropriation bill carrying $46,403,000,000 in funds and contract authority to run the Department of the Defense through the fiscal year that starts tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (UP) -The National Production Authority acted today to cushion the impact of the steel strike on canners of perishable foodstuffs.
Inflation and television have combined to change the hobby picture among the nation's children, 8 to 16 years of age -- but not in the way most adults woulld guess.
Another provincial frontier vanished at 12:01 A. M. today when the sale of yellow margarine became legal in New York State.

LONDON, June 30 -- Parliament received from the British Government tonight a detailed chronological report on the Korean armistice negotiations and incidents in United Nations prisoner-of-war camps, both of which have caused acute concern and criticism in this country.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Issuing its long-awaited ruling on the dispute over transatlantic routes to be flown by Pan American Airways and Trans World Airlines, the Civil Aeronautics Board today enunciated a policy of competition in the international air travel field.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 30 -- Interior Minister Alexander Rankovic announced several days ago plans to transform the militarized state security police (U. D. B. A.) into a plainclothes civilian agency. He said that the change reflected the democratization of the Yugoslav political and economic system that is under way at present.

ONE of the better managerial jobs to be fashioned this season is that turned in by Lou Boudreau, current master mind of the Boston Red Sox. He inherited a team that looked to be a solid second division candidate. Not only did he lose Bobby Doerr through voluntary retirement and Ted Williams through involuntary retirement, but he had a squad which appeared to be eaten away by dry rot, apathy and old age.

Bank representatives said yesterday that the United Nations had declined to take over operating responsibility for the Parkway Village housing project in Jamaica, Queens, on a proposal that would give the bank owners a net annual return of $600,000. So they said they were going ahead with rent increases averaging 24 per cent to put the project "on a sound economic basis."

Business failures rose to 163 for the week ended June 26, compared with 151 in the previous week, according to the weekly report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet. In the like period a year ago, there were 188 failures. Failures with liabilities of $5,000 and over numbered 138, against 130 in the preceding week and 150 a year ago.

PITTSBURGH, June 30 -- Rabbi Samuel Berliant opened the sixteenth annual convention of the Rabbinical Council of America here today with an appeal to the orthodox body to support the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and to combat totalitarianism.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (UP) -- The Government ended today all import controls on natural rubber, effective at midnight.

Increased attempts at Federal tax evasion are being met with even more efficient tax collection enforcement and prosecutions, John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, said here yesterday in an address at induction ceremonies for new officers of the Bureau of Internal Revenue in this city.

An extensive group of lamps and a variety of accessories make up the new collection of useful and decorative objects for the home now on view at Richards-Morganthau, 225 Fifth Avenue. Available through decorators now and in stores by July 15, the collection is displayed in a new showroom designed by Edward Wormley.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The statement made to the press by Governor Stevenson of Illinois at Houston today is the most affirmative one that has come from him with respect to the Democratic Presidential nomination this year. Though it contains four words of negative color -- two "nots," a "nor" and "unlikely" -- it is affirmative because:

" The Newspaper Lights the Way of Freedom," the basic slogan for National Newspaper Week, Oct. 1-8, has been converted into a new emblem that will be made available to newspapers everywhere. This was announced yesterday by Theodore A. Serrill, Telegraph Building, Harrisburgh, Pa.

Although trading on the New York Stock Exchange in June expanded slightly over the May volume, sales were the smallest for a corresponding month since 1949. The turnover of 171,913,501 shares for the first six months this year also was the smallest in three years for a similar half-year period.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 30 -- A cultural revolution involving basic changes in legal and economic concepts has afforded minority groups in this country their first real opportunity for "incorporation into the national mentality as well as the political state," the ninth annual Race Relations Institute at Fisk University was told today.
" Listen, children. I want you all to come back. It's not going to rain. Those things in the sky mean nothing."
PARIS, June 30 (AP) -- Charles Humez of France scored a technical knockout over Tony Janiro of Youngstown, Ohio, tonight as Janiro's handlers threw in the towel at the start of the fifth round.
TRENTON, June 30 -- Important labor legislation and a new system of clamping down on reckless automobile drivers become effective tomorrow.
Albert Gallatin, artist, author and art collector, bequeathed many objects of art to museums and societies under the terms of his will, which was filed for probate yesterday in Surrogate's Court.

The landlords and tenants of a group of Harlem tenements came forward yesterday with an answer to the problem of what to do with back yards that seem to be always filling up with garbage. They have turned one big rear area into a neat play space, with swings and seesaws, and plenty of room for safe, carefree fun.
Although the fire in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, yesterday brought men and equipment equivalent to eight alarms, technically there is no alarm higher than five in the New York City Fire Department.
Both the weather and the Phils put the chill on the Dodgers at Ebbets Field last night, the onetime Whiz Kids beating the league leaders, 4 -- 0, before 21,377 disappointed fans.
William W. Remington, former Commerce Department employe facing a second trial for perjury, lost yesterday a motion to have his original perjury indictment dismissed.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- A House-approved provision to eliminate military aides for inactive generals and admirals was dropped in the Senate today on the ground it was not fair to all.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- Manufacturers sold $22,400,000,000 in goods during May, cutting down their inventories from $42,700,000,000 to $42,500,000,000, the Department of Commerce reported today.

JERUSALEM, June 30 -- The Israeli Government will invite foreign interests to prospect for, and perhaps exploit, the country's oil resources, by introducing an oil bill in Parliament tomorrow. Government officials expect it to be approved without delay, so that foreign companies could move in in a few months.

BOSTON, June 30 -- Judge Sarah T. Hughes of Dallas, Tex., accepted the support today of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women as a candidate for the Vice-Presidency of the United States.
