DENVER, June 30 -- Eisenhower headquarters here today began to release evidence intended to convince the Republican National Convention that contests on seventy-five delegates should be decided in favor of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower against Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio.

The weakest link in selling men's wear is the retail salesman, speakers at the youth conference sponsored by the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers said yesterday at the New Yorker Hotel.

HARRISBURG, June 30 -- Gov. John S. Fine said today that the seventy-vote Pennsylvania delegation to the Republican National Convention might hold a caucus before the convention opened to determine its stand on the seating of rival Southern delegations.

DETROIT, June 30 -- "Pocketbook prohibition" is cutting all alcoholic beverage tax revenues, John W. Woelfle of the legal department of Schenley Industries, Inc., said here today. Speaking at a tax protest meeting called by the Detroit Metropolitan Tavern Association at Cass Technical High School, he said that Federal, state and local taxes were pricing the American consumer out of the whisky market.

The warfare between Mayor Impellitteri and Carmine G. DeSapio, leader of Tammany Hall, was on in full vigor yesterday. The resumption of the political controversy that has existed since Mr. DeSapio refused to back the Mayor for election in 1950 came after friends of both parties had failed in efforts to bring about a truce, and it now seems certain to be carried into the mayoralty campaign of 1953.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 30 -- Richard Savitt was beaten by Mervyn Rose today, leaving Herbert Flam as the United States' last hope in the All-England lawn tennis championship.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., June 30 -- The Father and Son Golf Association held its thirty-second annual tournament at the Garden City Club course today, with over a 103 fathers and sons hitting alternate shots.
CHICAGO, June 30 (AP) -- Seven Indians and six Yankees bulwarked the twenty-five-player American League squad designated today by Manager Casey Stengel for the July 8 All-Star game at Philadelphia.

SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, July 1 (AP) -- A reinforced North Korean battalion of more than 750 troops attacked Allied positions last night along the Heartbreak Ridge sector in eastern Korea. United Nations forces fought off the Communist assault.

BOSTON, June 30 (AP) -- Tommy Collins of Boston took a boxing lesson from Willie Pep for three rounds and then gained a six-round technical knockout verdict over that former featherweight champion in their scheduled ten-round bout tonight at the Boston Garden.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 30 (AP) -- Grace Carlson, a leader in the Socialist Workers party and its candidate for Vice President of the United States, disclosed today that she had renounced the party and returned to the Roman Catholic Church.

Operations of the steel mills continue at a low ebb with the indicated rate this week scheduled at 12.3 per cent of rated capacity, according to yesterday's report of the American Iron Steel Institute.

A spectacular fire yesterday morning in the Greenpoint district of Brooklyn resulted in one death, injury to forty-six firemen and civilians and property loss estimated at $1,000,000. Four of the firemen were taken to Greenpoint Hospital suffering from smoke poisoning and minor hurts.

In the East River, just off 135th Street, there are three islands. The best known is Rikers Island, which served the city for many years as a garbage dump and is said to have supported, at the time, over a hundred million rats.

Is it not a pity that so many Americans prefer the glory of the uniform, giving little thought to the important fact that it is the man, and not the clothes, that makes a good or bad President? I could compare it to a military parade -- how wonderful and inspiring it is -- but how grim and tragic the aftermath, which inevitably is war.

LONDON, June 30 -- A pay rise of 65,000 ($182,000) a year was recommended today for the Queen of England, who, like everyone else, is having trouble with the cost of living. An annuity of 40,000 ($112,000) for life was suggested for Queen Elizabeth's consort, the Duke of Edinburgh, who now receives 10,000.

Judge Harold M. Kennedy, who has been a member of the United States Court in the Eastern District for the last eight years, announced yesterday that he had submitted his resignation to President Truman, to become effective on Sept. 30.

The experimental cookery laboratory at Purdue University has found a way of preparing jam without cooking it. The method has meaning for housewives on two counts: (1) it saves time and does away with the discomfort of standing over a hot stove; (2) it results in a product with the fine flavor of fresh, not cooked, fruit.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, June 30 (Reuters) -- Sirry Pasha is expected to recast both internal and foreign policy -- there is increasing talk that Egypt is more willing to associate itself with the Western defense plan for the Middle East. Previous Governments said they would not join until the British pulled out of the Suez Canal zone.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The Government authorized immediate retail ceiling price increases today for East Coast fuel oil ranging from half a cent to eight-tenths of a cent a gallon.

CHERBOURG, France, June 30 -- (Reuters) -- Passengers aboard the New York-bound Queen Mary watched the 7,547-ton Belgian freighter Mahenge sink after she collided with a French ship in the foggy English Channel today.

Heavier demand for textiles in recent weeks indicates an upward and long-over-due swing that should result in sound trade conditions for the last half of the year, W. Ray Bell, president of the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York, reported yesterday.
Led by Billy Talbert of New York, the United States new Davis Cup captain, the seeded players advanced easily in the New York State tennis championships at the Seminole Club, Forest Hills, yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Peter Kadenoff have' purchased the four-story apartment house accommodating thirty-six families at 1711 New Haven Avenue, Far Rockaway, Queens, from New Haven Avenue Properties, Ltd., of which Jerome Bassman is president.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Labor leaders may refuse to accept appointment to the new Wage Stabilization Board, and they are even considering withdrawal of support of the stabilization program.

The Brooklyn rackets grand jury returned two indictments yesterday in connection with its investigation into the theft from a borough dock of thirteen revolvers, one of which was used in the slaying last March of Arnold Schuster.
LA PLATA, Argentina, June 30 (AP) -- The newspaper El Argentino reappeared today under a new editor after a strike by Government-controlled unions prevented publication of its Sunday edition.

More home rule for the city's Hospitals Department and its individual institutions to let them "take definitive action in matters affecting patient care" was urged yesterday by the Hospital Council of Greater New York. Present "antiquated and cumbersome" policies imposed by the city "cause delay, excessive expense and inefficiency," the council said.

SINGAPORE, June 30 -- Serious discontent among 300,000 workers on rubber estates in Malaya loomed today as negotiations broke down between employers and laborers over revision of wage scales. An arbitration court will attempt to settle the dispute.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The State Department, noting "conflicting reports" in the matter, made public today the text of Secretary of State Dean Acheson's remarks to members of the British Parliament last week on the recent bombing of power plants in North Korea.
If June's weather seemed unusual, here's why:

Shoe production in May was estimated at 41,500,000 pairs, an increase of 8.3 per cent over the corresponding month in 1951 despite the decline in military orders, the Tanners Council of America announced yesterday. The increase for civilian shoes alone probably is about 15 per cent with all major segments of the industry showing rises.

LONDON, June 30 -- A rise of about four points in German bonds because of optimism over the progress of the German debt negotiations was a feature of stock market trading here today. Japanese and some Latin-American bonds were better too.
CHICAGO, June 30 (UP) -- Roy Smalley drove in five runs with a double and a homer today as the Cubs rallied to beat the Pirates 5 to 4, before 59,843 fans.

BOSTON, June 30 -- With exiled Leo Durocher looking on from a perch on the roof of Braves Field, the Giants tonight executed an appreciable gain in the National League flag race by taking both ends of a twilight-night double-header from Charlie Grimm's Braves.

GRIFFIN, Ga., June 30 (AP) -- A Georgia Superior Court judge ruled today that a pro-Taft faction was the state's legal Republican party. Judge Chester A. Byars agreed with attorneys for both factions, however, that his decision would not bind the Republican national committee.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 30 -- A resident of Mount Kisco, N. Y., John E. Dula, became executive director of the Westchester County Council of Social Agencies here today. Mr. Dula succeeded Miss Lillian A. Quinn as head of the council, which is composed of seventy-two agencies.

CHICAGO, June 30 -- Closer coordination between a company's advertised program and its actual direct sales efforts will be necessary to meet the more competitive market ahead, J. L. Singleton, vice president in charge of the general machinery division of Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company, Milwaukee, said today.

Forty-two persons were made homeless and 400 badly frightened neighbors were evacuated yesterday when windblown flames from a warehouse fire in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn threatened the entire area.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture said today production prospects indicate wheat supplies for the 1952-53 marketing year probably will exceed slightly the record of 1,601,000,000 bushels of ten years ago.

Having served for many years as a theatrical center for thespians wishing to study and improve their acting techniques, the Actors Studio now is contemplating broadening its activities. The policy change is said to stem from the desire of studio officials "to help the theatre as a whole."

The political crisis in Egypt is disturbing. It is evidence that the delicate balance which has been kept for five months is in jeopardy and that nothing has been settled or solved. This was obvious, to be sure, but it was hoped and believed that Hilaly Pasha could go on for some time.

Bound for New York, the Norwegian sailing training vessel Statsraad Lehmkuhl is now halfway across the Atlantic and is moving steadily toward her destination, at an average of six knots, according to latest reports. The 1,701-ton auxiliary bark is due here within the next two weeks, her exact arrival depending on favorable winds and following seas.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- President Truman signed the economic controls bill at 5:30 P. M. today, six and a half hours before virtually all wage, price and rent controls would have expired if he had not approved the measure.

PARIS, June 30 -- In a report just made by seven experts of the European Marshall Plan council on the internal financial situations of European nations and the United States, the prediction is made that the level of economic activity in the United States will remain high in the coming months. The report adds that, while the general inflation there has been checked, "there remain inflationary factors with which the Government must deal."

OSLO, Norway, June 30 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway arrived from Paris at noon today and was told at his initial conference with Norwegian defense officials this afternoon that Norway's military forces are expected to number nearly 250,000 fully trained and equipped men upon completion of the current military program two years hence.

Eslie Asbury's Dalal gave a bright performance in winning the Reina at Aqueduct yesterday. Competing in the seven-furlong test for 3-year-old-fillies, Dalal, under a competent ride by Jim Hardinbrook, beat six others with little trouble. A crowd of 21,364 saw the program.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- United States officials said today that a new extradition agreement with Canada would discourage the operations of confidence men who have been swindling American investors out of millions of dollars a year.

The appointment of the Rev. Thomas E. Henneberry as the first rector of Bellarmine College, Plattsburg, N. Y., was announced yesterday. The college is a new house of studies for the philosophical and scientific training of members of the Society of Jesus of the New York and Maryland Provinces, who are preparing for the Roman Catholic priesthood.

The New York Philharmonic-Symphony has set a goal of $150,000 in its second "Friends" Fund Campaign, which will be launched at a luncheon in the autumn. David M. Kaiser again will be the general chairman.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- About 6,500,000 individuals own publicly held stocks in this country, the Brookings Institution said today.
The 10-cent bus fare for all private lines that are now getting it under city franchises was extended yesterday by the Board of Estimate for a nine-month period ending March 31, 1953.

Stockholders of the American Superpower Corporation, at a special meeting yesterday in Dover, Del., approved the merger of Webb Knapp, Inc., into American Superpower. B. A. Tompkins, board chairman of American Superpower said the plan would be put into effect today.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., June 30 -- Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee brought his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination to Virginia tonight on the wings of a tempestuous storm and offered an audience of 2,000 assembled in the University of Virginia's amphitheatre a seven-point program for the economic and social development of the country.
AT midyear 1952 the state of books in America is spectacularly normal. In other words, it is all at sixes and sevens. When, in all its immensely improbable history, has it been otherwise?

The Park Department has quietly abolished the use of dim lights on its parkways and has amended its regulations to conform with the Traffic Department ordinance adopted last Feb. 3 that compels motorists to use low-beam headlights at night on city streets.

A new "Rocket to the Moon" show that will whisk passengers an imaginary quarter of a million miles through space in ten minutes will open today at the Hayden Planetarium, Central Park West and Eightieth Street.

ALBANY, June 30 (AP) -- The New York Telephone Company was authorized today by the Public Service Commission to issue 1,400,000 shares of common stock with a par value of $140,000,000 to aid its construction program.

JERSEY CITY, June 30 -- The wild-cat strike among warehousemen employed at the Army's Claremont Terminal here continued today as officials of Dade Brothers, Inc., the contractor at the pier, presented a new hiring plan to the men.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 30 -- Susan Hayward today was notified officially by Twentieth Century-Fox that she has been selected to play the co-starring role as Rachel Jackson in "The President's Lady." Adapted by John Patrick from the Irving Stone novel of the same title, the film will be a love story and will terminate with the election of Andrew Jackson as the seventh President of the United States.
Summer came to the roof-top "camp" of the Madison Square Boys Club yesterday. It arrived with a whoop and a holler, and the cooling sound of water splashing in a wading pool.

A sad and disturbing story comes to this newspaper from C. L. Sulzberger in Munich. This is that the stream of refugees escaping from Communist tyranny into Western Europe has "recently dwindled to almost nothing." One reason is that Moscow's police have become more effective.

While America's Olympic track and field team was flying to New York on the first leg of its journey to Helsinki, and while the divers, water polo players and swimmers were getting ready for their final tryouts, Olympic officials yesterday still were concerned about the collection of sufficient funds to finance the overseas expedition for the games that will be held in Finland from July 19 to Aug. 3.

June bond redemptions of $31,508,000 were the smallest since April and the lowest amount for any June in eighteen years. The total compared with $44,123,000 in the preceding month and $37,905,000 in June, 1951. Not since 1934, when the total was $12,562,000, were bond refundings smaller for a June.
Keith P. Rindfleisch has been appointed sales vice president of the supply division of the United States Steel Corporation.

A transportation consultant retained by the Manhattan Transit Company testified yesterday in a hearing before the Interstate Commerce Commission at 641 Washington Street that if the company's application for increased fares was granted, the total revenue derived would be about $814,000.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., June 30 -- The tobacco industry of America was informed today that its export business -- accounting for 20 to 30 per cent. of domestic production -- is in danger, because of the unbalance between imports and exports.

ROSELLE, N. J., June 30 -- Gustave Bosler of 119 Floral Street, a veteran employe of the National Broadcasting Company -- probably best known in radio circles as the man who devised the familiar N. B. C. chimes denoting station breaks -- retired today after forty years of service in the radio and "wireless" field.

BONN, Germany, June 30 -- Soviet actions in Germany belie Soviet professions in favor of German unity, the United States, Britain and France charged today in similar notes signed by the Allied High Commissioners and sent to the chairman of the Soviet Control Commission in East Germany.

WEST POINT, N. Y., June 30 -- Averell Harriman sharply criticized the House of Representatives tonight for cuts made last week in the foreign aid program and warned that any hesitation now in fulfilling the country's role of world leadership "would lead us to inevitable disaster."
Importers were mildly cheered yesterday by the final disposition of three legislative measures aimed at placing drastic restrictions on imports through the new Defense Production Act.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (UP) -- The General Accounting Office reported today that there was "no evidence" that W. Stuart Symington, former Secretary of the Air Force, or other officials had improper motives in awarding a research contract in Tennessee.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was somewhat quieter yesterday and closing prices were 3 points higher to 4 points lower than on last Friday.
DETROIT, June 30 (AP) -- The nation's auto plants built 2,200,000 passenger automobiles and 640,000 trucks in the six months ended today.

HONG KONG,, June 30 -- An American lawyer, Robert T. Bryan, who had been suddenly released from a Shanghai jail after sixteen months imprisonment, arrived here last night. His release reduced the number of imprisoned Americans in China to fifty, thirty-seven in jail and thirteen under house arrest.
A bespectacled bank manager who didn't quite realize what he was doing went out and caught himself an honest-to-goodness bank robber yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission said today that it had blocked temporarily a railroad proposal to establish special service charges for checking travelers' personal baggage.
Commodity futures showed a sagging tendency on the local markets yesterday. Coffee, hides, rubber and cocoa moved lower. Other futures contracts were barely steady.

Faced with a Supreme Court action, the Bail Fund of the Civil Rights Congress, whose 6,442 contributors have furnished bail for arrested Communist party leaders, consented yesterday to a permanent injunction and to the liquidation of remaining assets totaling $717,000.

Sigmund Bozymowski, a 37-year-old porter, was arrested on arson charges after a fire broke out at 12:05 A. M. yesterday in the three-story brick tenement in which he lived at 78 North Third Street in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn.

ELIZABETH, N. J., June 30 -- Another milestone in woman's long fight for equal status with men will be reached tomorrow, when the equal-pay-for-equal-work law goes into effect in New Jersey. The legislation. endorsed by most of the state's women's organizations, was written by the New Jersey Federation of Business and Professional Women with the cooperation of the Women's Bureau of the United States Department of Labor.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 30 -- An implication by Georgi F. Saksin, Soviet spokesman in the United Nations Economic and Social Council, that the United States habitually imposed military and political concessions as the price of its aid to other nations drew a sharp rebuke today from Dr. Isador Lubin of the United States delegation.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that prices received by farmers for their products fell one-third of 1 per cent in the month ended June 15.

The bugles that summoned 7,905 campers aboard trains in Grand Central Terminal yesterday sounded like the call of the wild to the children, like taps to their tearful parents and like just more noise to commuters caught in the annual pilgrimage to wide open spaces.
Fulminations, exhortations, criticism and advice are still flowing across the Atlantic from Britain following last week's bombing of the Yalu River and other North Korean power plants.

BERLIN, June 30 -- The Socialist Unity (Communist) party of Greater Berlin in a message to Premier Stalin published today, pledged to mobilize the populace in the Western sectors of the city against the municipal regime headed by Mayor Ernst Reuter.

In two brief ceremonies here, Vice Admiral Walter S. Delany turned over his command of the Third Naval District yesterday to Rear Admiral Roscoe H. Hillenkoetter and accepted command of the Eastern Sea Frontier from Vice Admiral Oscar C. Badger after receiving a promotion from rear admiral.

It is expected that the automobile tax on residents of New York City will be a constant source of hardship to persons who park their cars in the city but reside outside of its limits. While charges against such persons for tax evasion will readily be dismissed by the magistrate, nevertheless great inconvenience will be sustained and an appearance in court necessitated.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (UP) -- President Truman proclaimed today new immigration quotas that would permit natives of eight Asiatic countries to emigrate to the United States for the first time in history.

Senate-House conferees who worked out the final version of the measure extending the life of the Defense Production Act are genuinely deserving of the nation's gratitude. On Friday morning this group took over the two bills passed by the two chambers of the Legislature.
TOKYO, Tuesday, July 1 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,297 for twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M. Tuesday (5 P. M. Monday, Eastern daylight time):

The first union contract granting a forty-hour work week on a privately owned bus system in this city went into effect at 12:01 A. M. today, but it was not Michael J. Quill, blustery president of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., who won it.
GENEVA, June 30 -- European industrial circles are beginning to be disturbed by the creeping growth of agrarian protectionism in Europe.
CHICAGO, June 30 -- A bitter party-splitting fight over seventy-five contested delegates to the Republican National Convention appeared inevitable tonight.

The underworld of narcotics is the subject of a work by Will Oursler and Laurence Dwight Smith entitled "Narcotics: America's Peril," which Doubleday will issue July 10. The book discusses the ramifications of an international syndicate, the adventures of Bureau of Narcotics agents in several parts of the world and of the rehabilitation work being carried on among addicts at the United States Public Health Service Hospital in Lexington, Ky.

Paintings, drawings and sculpture by French impressionist and post-impressionist artist, in the collection of the late Maurice Wertheim, will go on view today in a special exhibition that will continue through the summer at the Metropolitan Museum.

LONDON, June 30 -- A debate in the House of Commons on the cost of food today found Maj. Gwilym Lloyd-George, Minister of Food, and Emanuel Shinwell of the Laborite opposition agreeing on one point: That there was little prospect that prices ever would fall to the level of the pre-war years.

CHICAGO, June 30 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, taking personal charge of his campaign for the Republican nomination, said today that he was of "a very forgiving nature" and, if nominated, would try to heal the breach in the party by asking those who had supported his opponents to come in and cooperate in the campaign for his election.

CAIRO, June 30 -- Hussein Sirry Pasha, Egyptian Premier-designate since yesterday, did not complete the formation of his Cabinet tonight despite a day of almost uninterrupted consultations in Alexandria, the summer capital.

CHICAGO, June 30 -- Winter wheat is being rushed to terminal markets in ever increasing volume, but the actual hedge sales appear to be surprisingly light, as the recent decline has made it more than likely that the growers will take advantage of loans. Today there were fractional early declines in wheat, followed by a rather brisk rally, which indicated both short profit taking and possibly some investment buying.
AMMAN, Jordan, June 30 (Reuters) -- James Bell, Middle East correspondent of Time Magazine, has been excluded from Jordan, the Foreign Affairs Ministry here said today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 30 -- The Canadian delegation to the United Nations issued today a statement by three Canadian scientists to disprove charges by the Chinese Communists that the United States Air Force had dropped poisonous insects.

Ninety drivers and other employes of six magazine distributing companies serving all of the city's boroughs except Richmond went on strike at 12:01 A. M. today. Picketing began then at the storage plants of the concerns involved.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Oliver S. Power resigned today as a member of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System to assume the presidency of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis.

One hundred persons looked on yesterday as Mayor Impellitteri, in brief ceremonies in his City Hall reception room, administered the oath of office to Sidney H. Bingham, chairman of the Board of Transportation, for a full six-year term, and to three magistrates for terms of ten years each.
DETROIT, June 30 -- The growing tendency toward censorship of textbooks and other instructional materials was denounced here today by America's key educators.
HOUSTON, Tex., June 30 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois made it plain today that he would consider accepting a genuine draft as the Democratic Presidential nominee.
Settlement yesterday of a nine-year-old dispute between the city and 5,000 laborers in forty departments will result in the payment to the workers of $4,000,000 in place of $13,000,000 claimed.

CHICAGO, June 30 (UP) -- The American and National Broadcasting Companies settled a labor dispute tonight that had threatened to cause picketing of the Republican and Democratic National Conventions, which open here July 7 and 21.
Settlement yesterday of a nine-year-old dispute between the city and 5,000 laborers in forty departments will result in the payment to the workers of $4,000,000 in place of $13,000,000 claimed.

CHICAGO, June 30 (UP) -- The American and National Broadcasting Companies settled a labor dispute tonight that had threatened to cause picketing of the Republican and Democratic National Conventions, which open here July 7 and 21.
Thirty-nine zebras from the Northern Tanganyika Territory were unloaded yesterday from a freighter berthed in Brooklyn Erie Basin.

CAMBRIDGE, N. Y., June 30 -- Black bass will be in peril through most of New York State beginning tomorrow. With the traditional July 1 season opener falling on a working day, the danger will be trifling at the start, but the respite will last only until the week-end brings its additional thousands of fishermen.

CHICAGO, June 30 -- Merger of the Central Barge Company of Chicago, and the Mississippi Valley Barge Line Company of St. Louis tomorrow will produce an inland waterway transportation system extending from Pittsburgh to New Orleans, north to the Twin Cities and, by way of the Illinois River, to the Chicago area.

Columbia University announced yesterday the appointment of Thomas I. Parkinson, president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, as chairman of the advisory board of the Institute of Urban Land Use and Housing Studies. He will serve for a three-year term ending June 30, 1955.

The National Lead Company announced yesterday that it had acquired the outstanding stock of Titangesellschaft M. B. H. of Leverkusen, Germany, which operates a plant producing titanium dioxide pigments for European consumption.

The International Labor Organization's annual conference in Geneva has closed on an important note, adoption of a strong resolution proclaiming the rights of trade unions to develop free of political influence.
New accoutrements for that favored type of al fresco dining at this season, the picnic, are available now in time for the holiday week-end.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- President Truman asked Congress today to study conclusions of the Materials Policy Board that the United States was running out of raw materials needed for security and prosperity and it should be ready for later legislative recommendations to help solve the problem.

BUFFALO, July 1 -- Federal Judge John Knight reserved decision today on the international question of whether the Italian Government could claim legal jurisdiction over a former American service man accused of murdering his commanding officer behind the German lines in Italy in 1944.
A three-day Christmas basketball tournament has been added to the Madison Square Garden program. Eight teams will compete, with the 1952 field already filled.

In the face of a sharp slump in blood donations because of the heat and vacations, the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross issued yesterday an urgent appeal for donors to meet a special shipment of whole blood from this area to Korea.

BONN, Germany, July 1 -- French, German and United States experts have worked out an agreement on the dissolution of the West German Central Coal Sales Agency which is expected to remove the last major barrier to the establishment of the Schuman plan for a coal-steel merger on a working basis.

BOSTON, July 1 -- Six major Presidential possibilities were asked today by the National Federation of Business and Professional Women to submit their stands on the proposed equal-rights amendment to the 3,000 delegates assembled here in their eleventh biennial conference.

BEFORE getting on to activities of lesser moment in the saltwater field, the excitement engendered by two fish, one a record-breaker and the other nearly a record, will be dealt with here. The near-record one, being more recent, will be treated first.
A West German Government mission arrived here yesterday on the Holland America liner Noordam to study United States operations in the control of exports.

LONDON, July 1 -- In Magistrate's Court today Dennis George Muldowney, a porter at the Reform Club, confessed that he stabbed Mrs. Christine Granville, former Polish Countess Skarbeck and wartime resistance heroine, at her London hotel on the night of June 15. The court committed him for trial at Old Bailey for murder.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- Controller General Lindsay Warren accused Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer tonight of "billingsgate and vituperation * * * far beneath the dignity of a high Cabinet officer."

CHICAGO, July 1 -- The rivalry between General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Robert A. Taft, opposing candidates for the Republican nomination for President, went into an increasingly bitter stage today.

A new major wave of deportations has been under way for the last two weeks in the Hungarian border areas adjoining Yugoslavia, Austria and Czechoslovakia, diplomatic sources in the United States reported yesterday.

DENVER, July 1 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower today plunged deeper into political warfare. He decided on a real old-fashioned, barnstorming, whistle-stop tour of ten Nebraska and Iowa cities and towns late this week on his way to the Republican National Convention, which opens July 7 in Chicago.

Another enterprising, young two-piano opera company tried its luck last night in launching a summer opera season in Greenwich Village. It was the Punch Opera, which is booked for a nine-week stand in the combination gymnasium and auditorium of the Metropolitan-Duane Methodist Church at the corner of Seventh Avenue and Thirteenth Street.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson told the people of Illinois tonight that he was flattered by talk of his possible Presidential candidacy on the Democratic ticket but he thought he had 'made it clear that I want to stay right here in Illinois -- as Governor, I hope."

A record throng of motor travelers is forecast over the three-day Fourth of July week-end when an estimated 900,000 motor vehicles will roll out of and back to this city. Motorists are urged to curb their holiday spirit and drive carefully to keep the casualty rate from rising.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- The Resolutions Committee of the Republican National Convention was organized today with the election of Senator Eugene D. Millikin of Colorado as chairman and was divided into eleven subcommittees that began public hearings in as many rooms in the Conrad Hilton Hotel.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- A committee representing seventeen non-operating railroad unions rejected a union security offer of Eastern and Western railroads and countered today with a demand for the union shop as recommended by an emergency board last February.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 1 -- Ernest A. Gross, the United States representative, declared today that Communist germ warfare charges against United Nations forces in Korea constituted a threat to international peace and security.

Determined to maintain its internationally recognized standing as "the safest railroad in the world," the New York City Transit System opened yesterday a new consolidated training school where everything from "kindergarten to post-graduate courses" will be offered to 2,500 maintenance workers.

LONDON, July 1 (Reuters) -- A Government commission charged today that Britain's insulated electric wire and cable industry is a monopoly. It recommended that price-fixing arrangements and bidding agreements should be ended since they restrict competition.

LONDON, July 1 -- The Medical Research Council here has ordered an investigation into the clinical effects of INH (Isonicotinic acid hydrazide) one of the new anti-tuberculosis drugs. Because it has not yet been listed as a poison this durg can be bought in any British drug store.

IT almost has become axiomatic that each American Olympic team is bigger and better than the one immediately preceding it. We won eleven of twenty-four events in the first post-war Olympic Games at London four years ago and yet the experts would have you believe that we figure to do at least that well again in Helsinki some three weeks hence.
Nine hundred house wreckers went on strike yesterday, halting demolition at six New York City Housing Authority projects and at a number of commercial building sites.

In observance of Independence Day, all financial and commodity markets throughout the United States will be closed on Friday, July 4. Canadian and European exchanges, however, will function as usual. The grain market in Winnipeg was closed yesterday for Dominion Day.

Already moderately plentiful in local markets, peaches will be at the peak of their season between July 10 and Aug. 2. The United States Department of Agriculture, which makes this prediction, adds that supplies this year will be unusually heavy, as the Georgia crop, about two weeks late, overlaps shipments from the Carolinas, Arkansas and California.
NEWARK, July 1 -- Commercial airline operations into and out of Newark Airport were stepped up today as Eastern Air Lines and Trans World Airlines resumed operations on a limited basis.

The time is ripe for a revival of religion, Dr. O. P. Kretzmann, president of Valparaiso University told the closing session of the thirty-fifth annual convention of the Lutheran Laymen's League last night at a dinner in the Commodore Hotel.

CLEVELAND, Wednesday, July 2 (AP) -- The Indians scored two runs in the nineteenth inning early today off Satch Paige, relief pitcher, for a 4-3 victory over the Browns. The contest equaled the record for the longest night game in major-league history.

The deathless Spanish Prisoner who has bobbed up every few years since Sir Francis Drake's time 350 years ago is at it again. This time he bobbed up at yesterday's session of the American Library Association.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Opponents of a bill to legalize, provisions of state "fair trade" laws that were invalidated by the Supreme Court last year were able to muster only seven votes against it in the Senate tonight.

CAIRO, Wednesday, July 2 (UP) Hussein Sirry Pasha, influential veteran independent statesman, has been appointed Premier and has formed a new all-independent Egyptian Government, it was officially announced today.

Fading optimism over the business outlook is evident in nearly half of the twenty-eight manufacturing industries represented in a survey of business opinion made public yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

BLOOMFIELD, Conn., July 1 -- Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce, a member of the Connecticut delegation to the Republican National Convention, declared tonight that the nomination of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio would be a "real political victory" for Premier Stalin, the only such victory "he has had in Europe since the formation of SHAPE under Eisenhower."

Yellow oleomargarine went on sale throughout the state yesterday for the first time in sixty-six years. But in the face of the stronger competition from the ready-colored spread, butter stood its ground. Instead of dropping to the support price of 67.75 cents, Grade A butter rose fractionally at wholesale this week and is now selling at 70.75 cents, Alfred Rich, manager of the Butter and Egg Merchants Association, Inc., reported.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- One of the largest ballrooms in the world, the Grand Ballroom of the Conrad Hilton Hotel, will be transformed into "Taft Town," a meeting place and entertainment center during the Republican National Convention. This will be open headquarters for delegates, alternates and their families.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (UP) -- President Truman's controversial $1,500,000,000 national flood insurance plan received a brief Congressional hearing today.
TRENTON, July 1 -- Dr. Frederick M. Raubinger of Ridgewood was named today as State Commissioner of Education, succeeding Dr. John H. Bosshart of Maplewood, who retired today.

NEW DELHI, India, July 1 -- The accomplishment of a peaceful land revolution, in which 60,000,000 acres are being transferred from landlords to peasants, was celebrated with festivals today in all 10,000 villages of the state of Uttar Pradesh.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 1 -- A United Nations committee that is investigating charges of forced labor announced today that it would ask accused governments to answer the complaints against them.
DETROIT, July 1 (AP) -- Amid reports that Manager Red Rolfe was about to be ousted, the Tigers reared up with three-run homers by Vic Wertz and Joe Ginsberg today to down the White Sox, 6 -- 4.

The subtle strains of Mozart's Quintet for Clarinet and Strings in A Major usually have the effect of quietly pleasing an audience. Yesterday, in Bryant Park, despite a confusion of back ground sounds from noisy sparrows, the wind in the trees and the off-key tooting of horns in the streets, the piece came as close to "sending" about 2,000 music lovers as anything off the hot jazz griddle.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., July 1 -- Mrs. John H. Bartol of Greenwich, Conn., today won her first Westchester Class A one-day tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association by touring the hilly Ardsley Country Club course in 41, 42 -- 83.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- The Government fixed today, as its mobilization goal for nylon and acrilan expansion, a three-fold increase in the country's producing capacity by the end of 1955.

The stock market finally pierced the year's high yesterday in the heaviest trading in almost a month. The sixth consecutive advance in prices carried the list back to the levels of last October and produced a gain of 0.93 point in the composite rate.

The television industry pursued the proper course yesterday in vigorously fighting to gain the right to cover the pre-convention meetings of the Republican National Committee. That video suffered a temporary setback when the committee voted, 60 to 40, to bar TV should not deter the broadcasters from continuing their drive for equality of opportunity with other journalistic media.

A 23-year-old burglary suspect leaped twenty feet from a window of the Bronx Magistrate's Court yesterday, was shot three times by three policemen firing from a courtroom window ledge and was captured a block and a half away by an off-duty probationary patrolman. Two women in near-by buildings were injured by stray bullets.

Billy Talbert, top-seeded entrant and captain of the 1952 United States Davis Cup team, led the way into the quarter-final bracket of the seventeenth annual New York State men's tennis singles championship yesterday at the Seminole Club, Forest Hills, Queens.

The American Lyric Theatre last evening began an ambitious repertory season at the Provincetown Playhouse. The Lyric Theatre plans to offer a full and varied schedule of one-act operas, ballets and plays, some of them familiar works, others being heard for the first time.

Federal Judge Leo F. Rayfiel yesterday held that the low-flying ordinance of Cedarhurst, L. I., was unconstitutional and invalid and signed a preliminary injunction restraining the community from enforcing the local law until a trial in the fall on an application for a declaratory judgment.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (UP) -- The Judiciary Committee of the House of Representatives today shelved President Truman's request for special legislation to admit 300,000 refugees to the United States during the next three years.

NEW DELHI, July 1 -- Loans for the immediate expansion of India's iron and steel production as a cardinal feature of the country's economic betterment program will be recommended to the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development by a mission sent by the bank to survey the industry here.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- The Defense Department today identified 206 battle casualties in Korea in a new list that reported 25 killed, 160 wounded, 8 missing and 13 injured. The following casualties were listed for New York and New Jersey (none were reported lot Connecticut):
The Radio Writers Guild, an independent union, just after midnight this morning called a strike in New York against the three major networks.

The New York State Board of Regents filed formal applications yesterday to operate ten educational television stations within the state. The applications were filed with the Federal Communications Commission in Washington.

" Secret Flight," a J. Arthur Rank drama from Britain, starring Ralph Richardson, and "Katy's Love Affair," a romantic drama starring Anna Neagle and Michael Wilding and presented by Sir Alexander Korda, will have local premieres today on a double-bill program at both the uptown Beacon and Midtown Theatres.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There is a bill before the New York City Council at the present time which all citizens should join in supporting. It is the Vogel bill, which increases the pension allowances of civil service and teaching personnel to a maximim of $12,000 a year, no person receiving more than a $300 increase.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The Senate ratified today, by a vote of 77 to 5, the Bonn peace contract with the Western Allies. The United States thus became the first of the four signatories to complete parliamentary action on the agreement, which gives restricted sovereignty to West Germany.

A home run by Gil Hodges off Jim Konstanty in the seventh and a pinch single by Capt. Pee Wee Reese in the ninth brought the Dodgers a 4-3 victory over the Phils at Ebbets Field yesterday. The rally lifted the gloom from a Ladies Day crowd of 17,121 fans, who had watched their heroes go into the seventh inning trailing by 3 --0.

NEWPORT, Ark., July 1 -- President Truman apparently undertook his role in the Democratic Presidential campaigns tonight. He made his first whistle-stop speech to a crowd of several hundred persons, telling them his public power policy address at Bull Shoals Dam tomorrow would be incorporated in the Democratic party's platform.
The combined dollar sales volume in June of major department stores here was 20 per cent below that of the comparable month of 1951, according to a survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- Wheat futures displayed an oversold pit condition today for the first time in a long while. The lack of any heavy hedge pressure against large wheat arrivals, more active flour buying, a moderate export trade, and considerable short profit-taking, all helped to create a stronger undertone.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On June 19 THE TIMES told the story of Jimmie Barnes' graduation from P. S. 85 in the Bronx, after five years' illness from muscular dystrophy. "Jimmie will be at home all summer," the story ended, "because he lives on the fourth floor of a walk-up apartment and it's not easy for him to get down."

A new court rule, allowing pre-trial examination of all parties in all civil cases throughout the state, took effect yesterday. Presiding Justice David W. Peck of the Appellate Division in New York and Bronx Counties urged lawyers to invoke it as "an epochal event in court administration."

PANMUNJOM, Korea, July 1 -- Two North Korean soldiers were happily behind barred wire deep in South Korea today after having beaten their armed Communist pursuers in a 1,000-yard dash through this narrow neutral corridor, where the generals are thrashing out the principal of free choice.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (UP) -- President Truman signed into law today a bill requiring the armed forces to do their buying from one catalogue instead of the fifteen or more now in use. Sponsors of the bill said it should cut defense spending by up to $5,000,000,000 a year.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 1 (Reuters) -- Sweden suggested to the Soviet Union tonight that the International Court of Justice at The Hague be called in to investigate the destruction of two Swedish aircraft over the Baltic Sea last month by Soviet fighters.

LONDON, July 1 -- Speaking from his vast experience as a military commander, Field Marshal Earl Alexander, British Minister of Defense, voiced his belief today that under present conditions a full scale Communist offensive in Korea could be "held" and that the Communists would suffer "terrific casualties."

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The Brooklyn fire on June 18 that cost seven lives led to a demand today for a Congressional study of how Federal housing assistance could be used to cut down the number of fire-trap tenements.

DETROIT, July 1 -- The academic freedom of the American public school teacher is threatened to a greater extent than at any time in the last 100 years, Dr. Martin Essex, chairman of the National Education Association's Committee on Tenure and Academic Freedom, asserted here today.

That was a good show the Yankees and Red Sox put on at the Stadium last night. Nicely cast, beautifully staged, dramatic and thrilling down to the final curtain, it was a 3-2 winning performance by the New Yorkers, who left only one question unanswered.

The third of his major ambitions was achieved yesterday by 29-year-old Dr. William L. Kraus, who a few years ago was a slave laborer for the Nazis. He began yesterday his duties as an interne at Roosevelt Hospital, Ninth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street.

A "complaint center" to which persons living near the three big commercial airports of the New York metropolitan area can phone to report "low-flying, non-military planes" was opened yesterday by the National Air Transport Coordinating Committee.
REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 1 (Reuters) -- Asgeir Asgeirsson today was declared elected President of Iceland with 32,925 votes.

LONDON, July 1 -- The stock markets kept reasonably firm today despite a fall in the volume of business. Foreign bonds, oils, notably German and Japanese issues, and selected mining shares made good gains. Leading industrials wilted a little at first before a trickle of sales, but rallied in the afternoon and by the close had recovered virtually all of their early losses.
The rate at which business men are being paid for what they sell is improving.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- Credit given on the installment plan shot up $447,000,000 in May after the consumer credit controls were lifted May 7.

Dr. Harold Lenz announced yesterday that he had written to the Board of Higher Education on Monday asking to be heard on his reassignment from the post of dean of students at Queens College to that of a Professor of German.

Guard of Honor maintained a firm hold on first place all the way around the track to capture the mile and a sixteenth race that held the feature spot at Aqueduct yesterday. The Samuel A. Peck colt found things to his complete liking as he strode to a three- length victory over the favored Vain Puritan.
The remodeled Riverside Hospital on North Brother Island, the new rehabilitation center arranged by city and state officials for youthful users of narcotics, was opened officially yesterday.

Eighty diabetic boys and girls were among the many city children departing for vacations as the mass exodus to summer camps continued yesterday. The group will spend a month at the New York Diabetes Association's Camp Nyda at Burlington, N. Y.

NEWARK, Del., July 1 -- The nation's newest and most advanced tank, named the Patton 48 after the late Gen. George S. Patton Jr., had its first showing here today at the Chrysler Corporation's Delaware tank plant.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., July 1 -- The Rutgers University board of trustees has received and approved funds totaling $26,069 for the establishment of the Mabel Smith Douglass Memorial Room at New Jersey College for Women, Dean Albert E. Meder Jr., secretary of the board announced today.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 1 -- Roslyn (Cookie) Swift of the Glen Oaks Club finished 1 over par with 38, 34 -- 72 to win the gross prize during the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association Class A one-day tournament at the Meadow Brook Club today.

PARIS, July 1 -- Proposals to speed the construction of a real European political authority around existing international institutions won endorsement today from spokesmen for the French Government and the fourteen-nation Council of Europe.
MEXICO CITY, July 1 -- Mexico will choose her new President Sunday from among a longtime civil servant, a retired Army general, a leftist labor leader and a corporation lawyer.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 1 -- The women's titleholder followed the men's out of the All-England lawn tennis championships today at Wimbledon. Doris Hart of Coral Gables, Fla., who finally fulfilled her ambition last year by winning the crown here, made her exit from the singles after a two-hour match in sweltering heat that reached the high 80's.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- Advertising should be used to overcome the idea that success in business means moral failure, Fairfax M. Cone, president of Foote, Cone Belding, said today. He spoke at a luncheon of the thirtieth annual conference of the National Industrial Advertisers Association here.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 1 -- Mark Ethridge, publisher of The Louisville Courier-Journal, strongly defended the basic foreign policies of President Truman in an address tonight to the University of Virginia's Institute of Public Affairs.

MINEOLA, L. I., July 1 -- The first 1952 official rating of the fifty-nine beaches in Nassau County where bathing permits have been issued showed that one had a better rating than last year and that none had declined.

LONDON, July 1 -- Assuming his familiar bulldog stance, Prime Minister Churchill took up a firm stand beside the United States today on the issue of the bombing of the North Korean power plants along the Yalu River and warned his people not to try American patience too far, especially in an election year.

The Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks of the United States presented yesterday to Bernard F. Gimbel, president and chairman of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, Inc., an original cover painting from the June issue of The Elks Magazine.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- With supporters of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio in solid control, the Republican National Committee voted 60 to 40 late today to prohibit television and radio broadcasting of its hearings on delegate contests.

Halliburton Oil Well Cementing During the first five months of the year, revenues Of Halliburton Oil Well Cementing Company increased ,$9,000,000, operating profits rose $1,300,000 and net income was $400,000 higher than in the corresponding period last year, Erle P. Halliburton, chairman, said yesterday at the annual meeting in Dallas. Earnings per share were $2.51, an advance of 29 cents over the five months of 1951.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 1 -- The Screen Writers Guild currently is juggling another film credits dispute, but this time no political issues are involved.

The greater New York Fund announced yesterday the formation of a labor committee to acquaint 1,500,000 members of the Congress of Industrial Organizations and the American Federation of Labor with the health and welfare facilities open to them in the city.
TOKYO, Wednesday, July 2 (AP) -- United Nations Command Headquarters communique 1,298, for twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M. Wednesday (5 P. M. Tuesday, Eastern daylight time):

In an act of wise statesmanship enhanced by its promptness the Senate yesterday endorsed by an overwhelming bipartisan majority the new network of pacts designed to initiate an era of European cooperation and to fortify American security. The two key documents thus approved are the "peace contract" with Germany, which ends the occupation regime and restores virtually complete German sovereignty, and an amendment to the North Atlantic treaty extending its guarantees to that country.

LONDON, July 1 -- In a move to increase its exports, Ford Motor Company, Ltd., of Britain announced today a reduction of 10 per cent in the price of its automobiles, 7 1/2 per cent for trucks and 5 per cent for tractors. Prices in the domestic market will be reduced 5 per cent.

HOUSTON, Tex., July 1 -- Three Republican Governors who are backing General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Presidential nomination appealed by telegram today to the Republican National Committee in Chicago to seat the pro-Eisenhower delegation from Texas.
The United States will not have a field hockey team in the Olympic games at Helsinki this month.

A youthful mugger, used as a decoy to pay $26 in marked bills for the purchase of an unregistered .22 caliber Italian-made automatic pistol, brought about the arrest of a Fulton Street sporting goods store owner on a charge of violating the Sullivan Law, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan announced yesterday.
An eleven-man honor committee of West Point graduates, organized in March to inquire into the cribbing scandal of 1951, was sharply divided into two camps yesterday.

PRINCETON, N. J., July 1 (AP) -- Most of the United States track and field athletes arrived today for a week of workouts before taking off Monday for Helsinki and the Olympic games, July 19 to Aug. 3.
Under this heading yesterday we examined Senator Taft's strength in delegates to the Republican National Convention, and found --

CONCORD, Mass., July 1 -- Thirty-four prisoners at the Concord State Reformatory barricaded themselves in a storeroom, with four guards and instructors as hostages, for three hours today but surrendered without a struggle.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Plans to establish "ready" and "standby" armed forces reserve organizations, as urged by Department of Defense officials, were revived today when conferees of the Senate and House of Representatives restored this basic concept to reserve components legislation.

BOSTON, July 1 -- In a spirited battle, punctuated by a one-blow fist fight, the Giants defeated the Braves tonight; 6 to 3, to gain their third-straight triumph in the four-game series and retain their position of trailing the league- leading Dodgers by three-and-a-half games.

Firemen poked vainly yesterday among bricks and smoldering timber for the body of a watchman who perished Monday in a $1,000,000 fire that destroyed a paper box warehouse and wrecked fourteen additional buildings in the Green-point district of Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (UP) -- A joint Senate-House conference committee threw out today a proposal to exempt radio and television stations from libel suits stemming from slanderous or defamatory remarks by political candidates.

Rubber trading was back in private hands for the first time yesterday since the Government took control over the nation's stockpile sixteen months ago. The cash price was 6 cents a pound below the Government's last price of 38 cents a pound.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- President Truman today charged Congress had opened "a dangerous gap in the mobilization program" by passing a new economic controls law with weaker wage, price, credit and rent controls. The President signed the act yesterday and it took effect today.

Hopes for a quick settlement of the month-old steel strike were set back last night when the head of the country's third largest steel producer notified the White House that he expected the strike to be "a long, drawn-out one."

GENEVA, July 1 -- European countries have agreed on the distribution of 9,700,009 tons of coal and 3,000,000 tons of coke for the third quarter of 1952, the United Nation's Economic Commission for Europe announced today.
More animated displays are being exhibited than in former years at the market week arranged by the National Association of Display Industries at the New Yorker Hotel, buyers said yesterday.

Ways in which small libraries can work out their own salvation in the face of modern trends toward centralized units were stressed at yesterday's sessions of the American Library Association, holding its seventy-first annual conference at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 1 -- Dr. Inez Adams, lecturer in sociology and anthropology at Fisk University, said today that Americans must show a greater interest in the leaders and achievements of cultures other than their own if this country was to play a decisive role in building a harmonious world society.

OTTAWA, July 1 -- Canada's will and ability to enlarge the existing canal system that by-passes the International Rapids section of the St. Lawrence River into a deep waterway accommodating seagoing ships was strongly affirmed by the leaders of all four political parties in the House of Commons today.

PARIS, July 1 -- The French Government's counter-attack against the powerful French Communist party sustained a severe setback tonight when a Paris Appeals Court ordered the release of Jacques Duclos, the party's acting chief, after he had been in prison nearly five weeks on a charge of plotting against the State.

Basil O'Connor, president of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, announced yesterday that it had granted recently $2,395,039 in March of Dimes funds for poliomyelitis research and professional education.

Humidity's Good Side These are the days of the high humidity, Often by mid-morning, and almost always by the mid-afternoon of these days, the shirt is clinging to the back like a barnacle to a waterlogged hull. The collar has been wilted since breakfast.

TRAVERS ISLAND, N. Y., July 1 -- The traditional baseball game between New York City Hall newspaper reporters and Councilmen at their twenty-fifth annual outing here today was won by the city officials' team for the first time in ten years with a score of 8 to 7. The upset was accompanied, according to impartial observers, by perhaps the best weather conditions for the game in that ten-year period.

CHICAGO, July 1 (AP) -- Thirty-seven-year-old Ted Wilks, making his twenty-ninth relief appearance, pitched the Pirates to a 3-2 victory over Chicago today, stopping the Cubs on two hits during the final two innings.
Prices of cotton futures rose 16 to 25 points yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange, with a moderate volume of business.

Harry Oransky, 54-year-old father-in-law of Harry Gross, convicted bookmaker, was stabbed and critically wounded yesterday afternoon. Last night the police booked on a felonious assault charge a 17-year-old Puerto Rican youth identified as Pablo Mendez of 346 West Twenty-third Street.
WIMBLEDON, England, July 1 (AP) -- Results of matches in the All-England tennis championships today:

SAN FRANCISCO, July 1 -- Under a pension plan negotiated a year ago by the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, unaffiliated, and the Pacific Maritime Association, 1,125 longshoremen, ships' clerks and walking bosses retired today on West Coast waterfronts and drew their first monthly pension checks.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Congress, through the Senate, gave its final approval today to the elevating of Puerto Rico to commonwealth status in charge of her internal affairs under her own constitution. The House of Representatives voted affirmatively yesterday.
The Florida Power Corporation is offering to holders of its common stock rights to subscribe for 309,360 shares of new common stock at $20 each until July 16.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The Government closed the 1952 fiscal year last midnight with a deficit of $4,016,640,378.10.
RANGOON, Burma, July 1 (Reuters) -- Burmese currency switched from the Indian system to Amercan-style decimalizatlon today with the introduction of "kyats" in place of the old rupees.

Mayor Impellitteri ought to travel up to East Harlem (or drive over there on his way down from Gracie Mansion) some Monday morning and inspect the garbage. Great piles of it stood on streets and sidewalks Monday, and had diminished little yesterday morning. We have seldom if ever seen conditions worse.
Negotiations between East and Gulf Coast shipowners and 8,000 deck officers took a serious turn yesterday as both sides exchanged formal rejections.
CHICAGO, July 1 -- John Foster Dulles arrived here today with a draft of what he called the most critical foreign policy platform written for the Republican party since before the war.

Margaret Mary Moore, 21-year-old Irish girl who was a friend of bank robber Willie Sutton, pressed her claim yesterday against the city for $300,000 as compensation for the loss of sight in her right eye.

Hearings on the special service charges on passengers' baggage, proposed by the eastern railroads, have been scheduled by the Interstate Commerce Commission beginning Aug 1, in Atlanta, Ga. The railroads' proposal calls for a charge of 50 cents for each trunk handled in passenger train baggage cars and 25 cents for each piece of hand baggage.

Taking of testimony by the Subversive Activities Control board to determine whether the Communist party should be required to register as an agent of the Soviet Union ended yesterday after more than fourteen months of hearings here and in Washington.

ST. LOUIS, July 1 (UP) -- Enos Slaughter, 36-year-old outfielder, passed the 1,000 mark in runs batted in during his major league career tonight as he smashed two home runs to drive in five markers while the Cardinals whipped the Reds, 8 -- 3.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 1 -- Members of the United Nations Economic and Social Council approved today, by a vote of 15 to 0, a joint resolution sponsored by Cuba, Iran and the Philippines, for an expanded study of the possibility of stimulating private foreign investments in underdeveloped countries through elimination of double taxation on the resultant earnings. The Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia and Poland abstained.

PARIS, June 27 -- Zibeline, which is French for sable, the softest of furs, is the term given the newest of surface treatments being featured here in woolens. Zibeline finish, a flattened nap of long silky mohair, creates an irresistible desire to stroke the fleeces, wool velours and broadcloths for the coming winter.

BERLIN, July 1 -- Prof. Frederic Joliot-Curie, French atomic physicist, told the Moscow-sponsored World Peace Council today that in view of the deteriorated international situation a full-scale session of the World Peace Congress should be called for the end of this year.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Employers were put on notice today that the exemption from salary controls granted by Congress to professional engineers employed in a professional capacity was "not a key to unlock stabilization."
CHICAGO, July 1 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: We were shocked by the photograph that appeared in the June 27 TIMES showing what appeared to be civilized Europeans bringing batons down on the heads of unarmed women who were left sprawling in the streets of Johannesburg, South Africa.

OSLO, Norway, July 1 -- Many problems of great magnitude are facing the Norwegians over their rearmament program, and the most urgent one is the creation of a corps of officers and noncommissioned ranks, Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Commannder of North Atlantic Treaty Organization forces, said here today.

Through sale of all the stock of Syndicate 57, Inc., headed by Leonard Rubinger, ownership of the sixteen-story building at 305-11 West Fifty - seventh Street has passed to a group headed by Lawrence A. Wien. Assessed at $735,000, the property is 75 by 100 feet and is west of Eighth Avenue.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission was asked today to deny six applications involving the import of natural gas from Canada into the United States.

The stork has developed into a bird of fashion. What with designers in the maternity field becoming increasingly style conscious each season, the whole concept of clothes of this type has changed. Women no longer look upon them as something to endure but rather to enjoy.
GOSHEN, N, Y., July 1 (AP) -- Saunders Mills' Worthy Coburn won the $11,500 E. H. Harriman Challenge Trophy, feature of the Grand Circuit program at Historic track today.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's statement today on controls:

An account of the discovery of gold in the Bulolo Valley, New Guinea, has been written by Frank Clune, Australian historian and explorer, and will be published July 22 by Philosophical Library under the title "Somewhere in New Guinea."

The Vulcan Copper and Supply Company of Cincinnati, engineers and manufacturers of equipment and plants for the chemical and petro-chemical industries, has opened a New York office at 161 East Forty-second Street to represent its engineering, manufacturing and construction divisions. V. D. Drummond is the manager.

David (Skippy) Browning, University of Texas junior, Bob Clotworthy, Ohio State junior from Westfield, N. J., and Miller Anderson, former Buckeye star who placed second at London in 1948, yesterday won the right to represent the United States in the three-meter springboard dive at the Olympic Games.

TOKYO, Wednesday, July 2 -- The Communist delegates at Panmunjom this morning suddenly requested a twenty-four-hour recess in the Korean armistice negotiations. Indications were that the Chinese and North Koreans were prepared to give further consideration to the face-saving device suggested for them yesterday by the United Nations on the crucial prisoner-exchange issue.

HONG KONG, July 1 -- The Chinese Communist party, which boasts a membership of 5,800,000, celebrated its thirty-first anniversary today in the midst of a "ranks overhauling" movement aimed at injecting new young blood into the party.

Total resources of the Manufacturers Trust Company on June 30, this year, amounted to $2,732,503,686, compared with $2,675,901,010 on March 31, according to the bank's quarterly statement of condition published today. Deposits were listed at $2,521,084,890, against $2,475,853,596 on the earlier date.
TULARE, Calif., July 1 (AP) -- Bob Mathias, Olympic decathlon champion, opened his bid as the No. 1 candidate for the 1952 United States Olympic team tonight.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your editorial of June 26 entitled "A Manhattan Reform" you make some sound suggestions for improving the numbering of buildings on Manhattan avenues. You are in error, however, in stating "that no relation exists between house numbers and cross-street numbers." Also your quotation from the World Almanac of a code method without locating avenue numbers is not entirely correct.

A group of Texas pipeliners has completed one of the longest deepwater pipe crossings ever attempted in this country -- a 6,600-foot natural gas line under The Narrows of New York Harbor. The city will welcome this second gas source to backstop the Hudson River line which has been its sole link with the Rio Grande gas fields. The pipe men, however, will go back knowing they were in a tussle.

Joseph Heidt will receive today the script of "The Unclean," a drama about Alger Hiss and his accuser, Whittaker Chambers, written by Robert O'Byrne and Edward Gilmore and scheduled for Broadway this season under Mr. Heidt's sponsorship.
State Supreme Court Justice Edgar J. Nathan Jr. upheld yesterday the constitutionality of the Metcalf-Hatch Law, which went into effect at 12:01 A. M.
SANTA CATALINA ISLAND, Calif., July 1 -- A collision with a porpoise stopped Roy Sutters' two attempts to swim the choppy twenty-one-mile Catalina-to-mainland channel today.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- A House Subcommittee of the Interior today approved a resolution authorizing the rehabilitation and preservation of Federal Hall in New York, where George Washington took the oath of office as President.

Staff news writers at three major networks went on strike yesterday after a breakdown in negotiations on a contract. The chains involved were the National Broadcasting Company, the Columbia Broadcasting System and the American Broadcasting Company.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 2 -- Syria complained officially today that Israel was flouting the United Nations by transferring Government offices from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.
NORFOLK, Va., July 2 -- Bernard M. Baruch spoke out today against the critics of "militarism" in this country, declaring that "our real peril is not 'militarism' but civilian indecision."
The Government will buy 30,000 tons of lead by Dec. 31 to make sure the metal is available for defense uses.

The gradual transformation of the United States from a "have" to a "have-not" nation is a fundamental factor, which the platform architects at the Republican National Convention in Chicago would do well to stress in the formulation of American military strategy and foreign policy.

PHILADELPHIA, July 2 -- Dr. A. S. W. Rosenbach, one of the world's foremost collectors of rare books, manuscripts and letters, died last night in University Hospital after a year's illness. He was 75 years old.

If motorists would avoid the avoidable accident, their week-end toll could be more than halved, according to an analysis of the three-day Memorial Day week-end. Accidents during that period killed 363 persons on highways throughout the country, including twenty-two in New York. At least 60 per cent of these were avoidable -- caused by speed, carelessness and violations of traffic regulations.
A 48-year-old Greenwich Village undertaker with a police record was arrested in Brooklyn yesterday, charged with the murder of Willie Moretti, New Jersey gambler.

Good Days for Anglers The past couple of weeks have been full of good days for the fisherman. Especially it was a good time for the trout fisherman; toward the end of the season most of the opening-day optimists take up some other form of recreation or pursue a less intelligent fish than the trout, leaving the trout streams to the perennially faithful and the hopelessly incurable members of the angling fraternity.

OSLO, Norway, July 2 -- General Matthew B. Ridgway, commander of North Atlantic Treaty Organization forces expressed criticism today of Norwegian preparedness in the air when he landed at Vaernes, near Trondheim, to which he had flown from Oslo this morning. "The Norwegian Air Force is below the critical minimum and you have too few airfields," he told newspaper men upon his arrival.

In the story in THE TIMES of June 28 about the reconversion of New York's taxicab meters, Col. Robert L. Huebler of the Rockwell Register Corporation is quoted as saying that "the earliest known taxi meter was a device used in China in the eleventh century" and that "it was used to clock the man-drawn vehicle, the rickshaw." Both statements are incorrect.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (UP) -- The Senate approved and sent to the White House today a compromise bill restricting the President's power to call reserve forces to active duty.

HOBOKEN, N. J., July 2 -- A new "pay-as-you-go" plan for financing a college education, patterned somewhat after the installment purchase of automobiles, washing machines and similar items, was announced today by Dr. Jess H. Davis, president of Stevens Institute of Technology here.
BULL SHOALS, Ark., July 2 -- President Truman stepped up his 1952 political campaigning today, making an outright appeal for a continuation of the New Deal and Fair Deal programs. He

CHICAGO, July 2 -- Governor Dewey arrived tonight, ready to do his best as titular leader of the party to help in bringing the Republican nomination for President to General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (UP) -- The Senate Appropriations Committee recommended tonight an appropriation of about $6,000,000,000 for military, economic and Point Four aid to Europe, the Near East, Asia, Africa and the Pacific for the next twelve months.

The validity of the city's use tax on passenger automobiles was upheld yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Henry Clay Greenberg in an opinion extensively critical of the administration for its "ineptness" in handling its fiscal problems.
HOUSTON, Tex., July 2 -- Twenty-three of the twenty-five Republican Governors of the United States struck a blow today at the Presidential aspirations of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio.

OSLO, Norway, July 2 -- A Government-sponsored plan to introduce legislation vesting in the state far-reaching permanent powers to regulate prices and control business and industry "for the good of the little man" has started a violent political controversy here and has threatened to become a major domestic issue.

In THE TIMES of July 1 you state you are going to run a series of editorials showing why Senator Taft cannot be elected. I ask that you, as a fair American news journal, print the following figures showing why Taft or any other Republican will be elected this year because of the back-breaking individual family debts alone.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Prof. Owen Lattimore, specialist in Far Eastern affairs and formerly an occasional consultant to the State Department, was accused by a Senate investigating subcommittee today of having been "a conscious articulate instrument of the Soviet conspiracy."

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The aluminum production industry was advised today that it must earmark 31,000,000 pounds of aluminum for replenishment of the nation's stockpile of that metal in the fourth quarter of this year. The information was furnished to an industry advisory committee by Samuel W. Anderson, deputy administrator of the Defense Production Administration, who is in charge of aluminum supplies for the defense effort.

M. Jacques Duclos must be thanking his lucky stars today that he is a citizen of France instead of a comrade in the Soviet fatherland. If he were arrested and tried in Moscow, Budapest or Bucharest on the charges preferred against him in Paris -- an impossible supposition, because in a Communist state he would not have a chance to direct an anti-Government demonstration -- he would never be heard of again.

In two previous editorials on this subject we have pointed out that Senator Taft's delegate strength at the Republican National Convention rests to an important degree on states that cannot help the Republicans in the election, because these states are overwhelmingly or traditionally Democratic; and that in other states which the Republicans have a chance to win, and need to win, General Eisenhower has greater appeal than Senator Taft.

SANTIAGO, Chile, July 2 (UP) -- Large police forces armed with rifles, machineguns and tear-gas bombs guarded strategic spots in Santiago today to prevent further disorders against the United States as the Senate continued debate on the United States-Chilean Mutual Military Aid Pact.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 2 -- The United States Secretary of State, Dean Acheson, landed at Rio de Janeiro at 10 o'clock tonight on an official visit to Brazil that has created general enthusiasm as an evidence of North American friendship for this country, which is proud of its record as a stanch ally of the United States.

This season's production schedule for the Playwrights' Company will be inaugurated, in all probability, soon after Labor Day with Stanley Young's play, "Mr. Pickwick," which is based on Charles Dickens' "Pickwick Papers."

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- One of Soviet Russia's best long-range bombers capable of bombing the United States is missing -- missing, that is, from the Air Force's guide that civilian volunteer spotters are supposed to depend on for identifying attacking planes.

TRENTON, July 2 -- The State Institutions Department announced today plans to reorganize Skillman Village for epileptics as a research center for treatment and cure of epileptics, alcoholics, juvenile psychotics, narcotic addicts and victims of cerebral palsy.
Marshall S. Mundheim has been admitted to general partnership in the New York Stock Exchange firm of Hirsch Co., it was announced yesterday. Robert Lee Kohns has retired as a general partner.
Officers of Local 100, Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., were empowered last night to call a strike against nine private bus lines in the union's campaign for a forty-hour week.
It will be the New York Athletic Club against the El Segundo Swim Club today in the final of the Olympic water polo trials at Astoria Park Pool.
