CHICAGO, July 2 -- The Eisenhower managers have about given up hope of stopping the Taft steamroller in the Republican National Committee, but they think they see a real chance to stop it in the Credentials Committee and on the convention floor.

Improved business conditions for the final half of this year were forecast by the National City Bank yesterday in its monthly letter. The hopeful view, and probably the correct one, the bank said, is that the rising urgency of the need for steel and a growing desire of strikers to get back on payrolls may bring about a settlement before industrial operations are disrupted.
TRENTON, July 2 -- New Jersey's plan to acquire the ten-mile beachfront property of the Phipps Estate in Ocean County encountered a legal obstacle today.

MOSCOW, July 2 -- Soviet political analyst, it was made plain today, believe that the British public no longer supports British foreign policy based upon the closest relations with the United States and now demands a "new approach to Anglo-Soviet relations."

TOKYO, Thursday, July 3 -- The Communist armistice negotiators at Panmunjom made a new proposal today on the vexed question of exchange of prisoners in the Korean war and asked that the truce conferences go into secret session for its discussion.

CAIRO, July 2 -- Egypt's ministerial crisis, which was precipitated Saturday with the resignation of Premier Ahmed Neguib el-Hilaly Pasha, was resolve dtoday when the new Premier, Hussein Sirry Pasha and his ministers were sworn in at Montazah Palace, King Farouk's summer residence in Alexandria.

Jacodema of the Apheim Stable scored decisively in the Bridal Flower Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. The event, a $10,000-added test for fillies and mares 3 years old and upward, attracted thirteen contestants, but when the six furlongs were run, there was Jacodema practically by herself, a length and a half in front of Sunshine Nell.

Stockholders of Lehman Corporation will receive a dividend of $2.81 a share on July 24 as the final distribution for the fiscal year ended on June 30. Of the total, $2.03 represents profit on the sale of securities and the rest is the distribution of net ordinary income for the year. Declarations for the fiscal year total $4.41 a share, compared with $5.84 in the previous fiscal year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 2 -- Paramount is preparing as one of its big historical spectacles for next year a new version of William Makepeace Thackeray's novel of the early Napoleonic era, "Vanity Fair." Pat Duggan has been assigned as producer of the projected film, which will be in Technicolor.

Synthetic materials have been used in nearly every corner of Mrs. Beulah Charlat's recently redecorated penthouse apartment at 309 West Eighty-sixth Street. Mrs. Chariat, whose small apartment has been decorated to make it easy and convenient for her to be at the same time career woman, mother and hostess, is delighted with the easy maintenance of such fabrics.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- With the adjournment drive in full swing, the House and Senate sent today more than half a dozen major bills to the President for signature.

The management of Radio City Music Hall has announced that the theatre's doors will be opened at 8:30 tomorrow morning and that extra performances of "Where's Charley?" the current film attraction, and the gala stage spectacle will be scheduled to accommodate the anticipated July 4 crowds.

Japan's Davis Cup players, Jiro Kumamaru and Atsushi Miyagi, entered the quarter-final round of the New York State tennis champiionships at the Seminole Club, Forest Hills, yesterday along with Tony Vincent of Miami, Fla., seeded fourth, and Richard Gaines of Edgartown, Mass., seeded fifth. Billy Talbert, Sidney Schwartz, Jack Tuero, the defending champion, and Dr. Jack Geller reached the round of eight Tuesday.
Prices of active cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 29 to 40 points net yesterday.
BONN, Germany, July 2 (AP) -- "I certainly deny allegations of perjury," Mr. Davies said.

NEW ORLEANS, July 2 (AP) -- The Times-Picayune Publishing Company is under United States District Court orders to stop requiring advertisers to buy space in both its papers in order to use one of them.

WASHINGTON July 2 -- The Senate passed and sent to the White House today the so-called "fair trade" bill previously approved by the House. The measure would legalize retail price fixing on trademark articles by their manufacturers in states where such practices are lawful.

Extreme rightists, superpatriots, the ignorant and the prejudiced constitute a real Fifth Column in America today on which communism relies to do its "dirty work," Norman Cousins told a meeting of the American Library Association yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 2 (AP) -- H. C. Fruehauf's Irish importation, Crocodile, overcame bad breaks at the start and the first and last turns to run over his eight rivals in the stretch and annex the $10,000 added Longfellow Handicap by two lengths at Monmouth Park today.

Purchasers here of British-built Ford passenger cars will benefit by about 2.7 to 4.3 per cent through the 10 per cent retail price reduction announced on Tuesday in London. This difference is the result of costs of export charges, including ocean freight, import duty and excise tax.

Adoption of the "Baltimore Plan" for the rehabilitation of unsafe and insanitary housing was recommended yesterday to Mayor Impellitteri by George L. Bliss, president of the Century Federal Savings Association. Condemning housing conditions in New York as "inexcusable" from the standpoint of safety and sanitation, Mr. Bliss declared that the "Baltimore Plan" was the proper remedy because it was based upon "honest and conscientious enforcement."
WASHINGTON, July 2 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today it had identified one of the causes of "X-disease" in cattle, which has cost farmers $2,000,000 a year in livestock losses.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The Army issued a call today for a 30,000 draft quota for September and announced quotas would be sharply increased during the last three months of 1952. The service said that about 54,000 men each month would be called in October, November and December.
BALTIMORE, July 2 -- Professor Lattimore said the Senate subcommittee's charge was "untrue and is supported by no creditable evidence."
A halt in the advance by the stock market was accomplished yesterday by profit taking sufficient to pull prices slightly below the new highs of the year set on Tuesday.

An account of the struggle between the German generals and the Nazis for control of the Third Reich, entitled "Sword and Swastika," has been scheduled for October publication by Simon Schuster. Written by Telford Taylor, chief prosecutor in the Nuremburg trials, the book traces the alternating phases of conflict and collaboration between the professional soldiers of the Prussian military tradition and the opportunists, charlatans and thugs who came into power with Hitler.

LONDON, July 2 -- A new bookkeeping account opened quietly in all parts of the stock exchange today. The exception was foreign bonds, which became active again on reports that terms were believed to have been tentatively agreed at the German debt conference.

Used and reconditioned machinery has long been a standard item for export from this country. Now an Australian concern is reversing the operation with the shipment of reconditioned earth-moving equipment to this country, according to a report by the Australian News and Information Bureau.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in twenty-four leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board reported today shows the following principal changes for the week ended June 25:
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The Air Force asked its general counsel today if bingo games in officers' and enlisted men's clubs were legal in states where bingo had been banned.
ALBANY, July 2 -- Frederick C. Bothwell Jr. of Glen Cove, L. I., was appointed today the State Liquor Authority's chief executive officer, effective Sept. 1. The post pays $9,599 a year.

BOSTON, July 2 -- Helen G. Irwin of Des Moines, Iowa, first business woman in seventeen years to be elected president of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women, urged women today to enter "critical short-age fields" in business and industry.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 2 -- Contrary to reports that public opinion in the United States is becoming increasingly opposed to the United Nations, the National Opinion Research Center of the University of Chicago has forwarded to Benjamin A. Cohen, Assistant Secretary General in charge of information, the findings of a recent poll indicating a steady advance in popular sentiment for support of the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- Legislation to crack down on influence peddlers was introduced today by Senator Clyde R. Hoey, Democrat of North Carolina and chairman of a Senate investigations subcommittee. The measure calls for $5,000 fines and up to two years' imprisonment for all persons invoved in an influence deal.

Supplying the larder for the Fourth of July week-end should pose no great problem for home cooks who insist upon such usual holiday fare as frying chickens, smoked hams, corn on the cob and watermelon. Even those who hail from New England should have little to grumble about, for the salmon steaks, green peas and new potatoes, traditional Independence Day fare in that section, are all readily available.

Anne O'Hare McCormick, in her column of June 18, writes that the Swedes "are naturally afraid of Russia," and, a little later, that "Sweden refused to join the Atlantic Pact Organization for fear of provoking Russia." This is not the case at all.

Magistrate Joseph A. Martinis, in whose courtroom a burglary suspect tried to escape Tuesday morning by leaping twenty feet from a window, ordered yesterday a change in the handling of prisoners in Bronx Magistrates Court.
Although its volume of loans increased, deposits and total resources of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York were cut in the quarter ended on June 30, the bank reported yesterday.
The semi-annual report of the Shamrock Oil and Gas Corporation showed yesterday a net profit of $2,419,780, equal to $1.80 a share, for the six months ended on May 31.

CHICAGO, July 2 -- The Americans for Democratic Action, through Prof. Kenneth W. Thompson of the University of Chicago, told Republican platform drafters today that countless independent voters were pledged "to resist any revival of isolationism under whatever guise."

A bartender who had been a witness to a tavern murder on Feb. 26 was found strangled yesterday morning on an East Harlem street. There was an unknotted rope around his neck and his head and face were lacerated.

AS anticipated, the black bass season that opened in New York State on Tuesday has been inconclusive so far, partly because fishermen are also workmen and relatively few have had a chance to test the waters. The big onslaught will begin tomorrow with the start of the long week-end.

A double setback was not what the Dodgers expected from the fifth-place Phillies yesterday at Ebbets Field. But Robin Roberts, notching his eleventh triumph, downed them in the opener by 4 -- 3 and Russ Meyer and Andy Hansen combined for a 2-1 victory in the second game, which Bill Nicholson wrapped up with a two-run pinch homer in the eighth.

A promise of good weather and a chilling prediction of deaths on the highways set the scene yesterday for the United States' celebration of the 176th anniversary of the United Colonies' Declaration of Independence.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 2 -- Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson of Cherry Valley, the new match play champion of the Women's Long Island Golf Association, carded a steady 39, 40 -- 79 for the low gross honors in the association's one-day tournament at the Sands Point Club today.

BUENOS AIRES, July 2 -- The receptive minds of Argentine school children are being overstuffed with Grimm's fairy tales, Mark Twain's stories about life on the Mississippi and Benjamin Franklin's exhortations to thrift, the Governor of Buenos Aires Province, Maj. Carlos V. Aloe, declared last night.

Bernard and Celia Thav have terminated a short ownership in the resale of the four-story garden apartment house with stores on Northern Boulevard, Roosevelt Avenue and 155th Street in Flushing, Queens. Paul Boyewski, the buyer, paid cash above mortgages of $123,000 for the property, which was held at $175,000.

The hearing on proposed bus fare increases between Manhattan and five New Jersey communities before an examiner at the Interstate Commerce Commission office, 641 Washington Street, ended yesterday after Kenneth J. McAuliffe, attorney for four protesting towns, testified.

CHICAGO, July 2 -- Financing arrangements were completed today by the Chicago Transit _uthority for the purchase of 300 elevated-subway cars and 100 additional motor buses at an estimated cost of $15,000,000. The authority, a public agency, owns and operates the city's elevated and troUey systems.

WORCESTER, Mass., July 2 (AP) -- The Naval Academy's great eight-oared crew and sixty other shells will compete for seven United States Olympic rowing assignments during the three-day final trials that will get under way tomorrow on Lake Quisigamond's placid 2,000-meter course.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 2 -- Recognizing the eminent domain rights of a natural gas company, Supreme Court Justice Elbert T. Gallagher granted motions here today by the Algonquin Gas Transmission Company to acquire pipeline easements across thirteen properties in northern Westchester County.

PIERMONT, N. Y., July 2 -- Here, where Henry Hudson first set foot on this country's mainland, a program has started for restoring some cleanliness to the waters from which the friendly Tappan Indians took fish and oysters for their first foreign visitors.

The Arabian American Oil Company last year imported materials, supplies and other items into Saudi Arabia with a value of $67,000,000 in carrying out its petroleum operations in that country, according to the company's 1951 report of operations to the Saudi Arabian Government.

CHICAGO, July 2 -- The banging of scores of hammers, installing everything from MacArthur posters on the eighteenth floor of the Conrad Hilton Hotel to water coolers for correspondents in the basement press room, signalized the mounting momentum of the Republican National Convention today.
CHICAGO, July 2 -- Former President Herbert Hoover today asked the Republican National Committee to announce he was not the author of a mysterious telegram bearing his name.

DENVER, July 2 (AP) -- Franklin Victor Reno, 41 years old, a scientist who helped to build the atomic bomb for the United States, was sentenced to a three-year Federal prison term today for once concealing that he had been a Communist party member.
Prices of most commodity futures on the local markets yesterday presented an irregular pattern in comparatively light trading.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- David K. E. Bruce, acting Secretary of State, today attributed the failure of the United States to inform the British that United Nations aircraft intended to attack the vital North Korean power installations to a "lack of coordination" between the State and Defense Departments.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- The Government today authorized higher ceilings on strip-mined sulphur to encourage a bigger output of the strategic material for world use.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The news dispatches from Atlanta under date of May 31 related that a Republican State Convention had chosen four delegates at large to the national gathering on the day appointed by the state committee; that it had ratified the choice of thirteen delegates in the Congressional districts a month before; and that fourteen of the total of seventeen delegates were for Eisenhower.

A special train, the "Empire State Victory Special," will be provided by the New York Central System to take members of the New York State delegation to the Republican National Convention in Chicago. Special arrangements also are being made by the Pennsylvania Railroad for the New Jersey, Connecticut and Pennsylvania delegations.

BUENOS AIRES, July 2 (Reuters) -- The Senate last night passed a bill providing for the liquidation of the Bemberg group of companies, which includes most of the important breweries in Argentina as well as large ranches and financial concerns.

BARCELONA, Spain, July 2 (Reuters) -- The military prosecutor demanded stiff prison sentences today for twenty-seven Spaniards charged with attempting to reorganize secretly a clandestine, anti-national group -- the Catalan Unified Socialist party.

BALLSTON SPA. N. Y., July 2 (UP) -- A special grand jury charged Michael E. Sweeney, a law partner of the Saratoga Republican leader, James a Leary, today with criminal contempt of court. It held that he refused to answer "material and relevant" questions in its investigation of gambling and corruption in Saratoga County.

HARRISBURG, Pa., July 2 (AP) -- Stella Walsh, the 41-year-old "grandma of women athletes," today was barred from trying out for the United States Olympic team because she competed twice before for Poland.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 2 -- The fourth annual five-day Barnum Festival, honoring P. T. Barnum, this industrial community's former Mayor and the "world's greatest showman," opened here today.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (UP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan has called for marketing quotas on the 1953 flue-cured tobacco crop that would cut acreage allotments by 12 1/2 per cent in six states.

PARIS, July 2 -- The court order releasing Jacques Duclos, the French Communist leader, from prison will not end the French Government's investigation and prosecution of an alleged Communist plot against the security of the state, a Cabinet spokesman said today.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- Glen Flanagan of St. Paul toppled Gene Smith of Washington to his first defeat in thirty-two professional fights -- by winning a unanimous decision tonight after ten rounds of rough slugging.

TULARE, Calif., July 2 (AP) -- Bob Mathias of Tulare, Olympic champion, late tonight appeared to be a virtual cinch to win the national decathlon champioship for the fourth time and lead the three-man decathlon team to Finland.

Baron Michiels van Kessnich, Mayor of Maastricht in the Netherlands, declared yesterday that the populace there "never forgets to teach its children that their freedom was paid for by American mothers and fathers who lost their sons and husbands."

Pier 86, North River, from which the superliner United States sails at noon today on her maiden voyage to Havre and Southampton with 1,700 passengers, was the center of activity yesterday as crew members, stevedores, truckers and company personnel joined hands to stock the 53,000-ton ship.

STANTON, Del., July 2 (AP) -- Walter M. Jeffords Tahiti today earend his second victory in as many starts when he blazed to a two-and-a-half-length triumph in the $15,450 Dover Stakes at Delaware park.

PHILADELPHIA, July 2 (AP) -- Bobby Shantz chalked up his fourteenth victory of the campaign as he turned in a four-hitter tonight to give the Athletics a 4-1 triumph over the Senators. Jackie Jensen hit a sixth-inning homer for Washington.

OAXACA, Mexico, July 2 -- An uneasy peace reigns over this city, the scene of bloody tax riots against the State Governor in March, and an aroused populace is only awaiting the finish of Sunday's Presidential election before renewing its campaign to force the resignation or dismissal of Gov. Manuel Mayoral, Heredia.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 2 -- The Communist party has forced the Roman Catholic bishops of Slovenia to make the first important concession in the church-state struggle that has been developing with increasing bitterness in the Republic of Slovenia in recent months.

The City of Providence, R. I., borrowed $3,500,000 in the public market yesterday on an issue of bonds sold at competitive bidding to a syndicate headed by Bankers Trust Company at a bid of 100.09 for interest of 2.3 per cent. The bonds were priced on reoffering to yield 1.6 per cent to 2.4 per cent. At the close of the market, bonds in syndicate account were estimated at $2,109,000.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 2 -- The Pacific Maritime Association late today, through its president, J. Paul St. Sure, filed an unfair labor practices charge with the National Labor Relations Board against two maritime unions growing out of the strike of the Sailors Union of the Pacific, A. F. L., now in its thirty-eighth day.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 2 -- Seven members of the Security Council today announced their support of a United States resolution calling for an investigation by the International Committee of the Red Cross of Communist charges that United Nations forces in Korea had waged bacteriological warfare.
CHICAGO, July 2 (UP) -- The Cubs swept their third doubleheader of the season by beating the Pirates, 8 -- 3 and 3 -- 0, before, 16,453 fans today.

Judge Edward J. Dimock ordered yesterday in United States District Court here a severance of the trial of Marion Bachrach, one of sixteen secondary Communist party leaders, because of Miss Bachrach's continued illness.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company received the right yesterday from Supreme Court Justice Ernest E. L. Hammer to increase rents at Stuyvesant Town an average of $2.55 a room monthly for the next three years and by $3 a room monthly the fourth year.

With more than 40,000,000 vehicles expected to take to the road over the Fourth of July week-end there are bound to be accidents, many of them fatal. In an effort to cut the death toll, at least two organizations are taking action.
DETROIT, July 2 (AP) -- Minnie Minoso's ninth homer of the season with no one on base in the sixth inning helped the White Sox to a 3-2 victory today over the Tigers.

For the first time since it became a nation four years ago, Israel will place on display in this city several hundred manufactured products, ranging from an automobile and scientific glass instruments to canned foodstuffs and baby carriages.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (UP) -- Congress approved and sent to the White House today a compromise bill to streamline the Federal Communications Commission and bar radio and television stations from charging premium rates for political candidates.

A decline last week of 711,000 barrels in the country's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end total supplies were 120,902,000 barrels, compared with 121,613,000 a week earlier and 135,356,000 a year ago.

The Long Island Transit Authority, through its chairman, George E. Roosevelt, said yesterday that the resignation of Judge Harold M. Kennedy from the Federal bench "will be seriously felt" by all parties interested in the reorganization of the Long Island Rail Road.

A six-story addition to the three- story Appellate Division Court house at 27-33 iadison Avenue was among plans filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings. The cost is estimated at $1,184,761. Rogers Butler are the architects.
GENEVA, July 2 -- Switzerland is seething with indignation over the threat of a rise in United States tariff duties on watch movements recommended by the Tariff Commission to President Truman.

PATERSON, N. J., July 2 -- The first mobile logging unit designed for use in the search for radioactive material was delivered to the Atomic Energy Commission today by the Bogue Electric Manufacturing Company of this city, according to an announcement made by Edward P. Schinman, president.

Attacked as a "ripper bill," designed to get rid of Rear Admiral William S. Maxwell, retired, deputy director of the Bureau of Smoke Control, a measure setting up a new independent city Department of Air Pollution Control was passed by the City Council yesterday by a vote of 20 to 2.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 2 -- Georgi P. Arkadyev, Soviet representative on the United Nations Economic and Social Council, today offered to provide jobs for 200,000 unemployed Britons, as many French and Italians, at least 100,000 Japanese and the same number of West Germans, and "some ten thousands" of jobless Dutch.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Averell Harriman, candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, declared today that he favored a program of health insurance at the national level.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- The Defense Department today reported the biggest weekly increase in United States casualties in the Korean war since last Nov. 14. The department listed 965 casualties in the week ended last Friday.

Soon some of the city's more fortunate youngsters will take off for the seashore, the mountains, the lakes and the farmlands. Many of them will be vacation guests in free or part-pay camps maintained by a number of social agencies. For at least a few weeks these children from the tenements will benefit from fresh air, sunshine and clean play.
ST. LOUIS, July 2 (AP) -- Harry (The Cat) Brecheen pitched and Enos Slaughter batted the Cardinals to a 3-0 victory over the Reds and Herm Wehmeier tonight, as the Cards swept a three-game series.
DETROIT, July 2 -- The rift between the American Legion and the National Education Association, kept under wraps here, appeared ready to break wide open today.

THE casualty rate has been rather high among major league managers this season and the axe-falling hasn't stopped yet. Rogers Hornsby and Tommy Holmes got it in the neck within a few days of each other. Then came Eddie Sawyer, with Red Rolfe due to be next -- or so the rumors say. That will add up to a quarter of the managerial ranks.

Total resources of the National City Bank of New York on June 30 amounted to $6,025,683,556, according to the bank's quarterly statement of condition. The figure compared with $5,883,765,872 on March 31 and $5,579,877,777 on the June date last year.

A PROFILE of the year's books shows peaks of talk and action, developments and trends. One is the renewed dominance of the storyteller. Another is the immense place that paperbound books are assuming in the landscape of popular reading. And a third is a rather weary but still vehement revival of the antique argument that the modern novel is going to hell in a hand basket.

Rather than pay about $188,000 in taxes to the city and to the state for the privilege of doing business in New York City, companies managing four diversified investment funds with assets of $230,000,000 have moved out of a Wall Street skyscraper into two private dwellings at Elizabeth, N. J. The move will mean a tax saving of about 85 per cent for 60,000 stockholders of the investment companies.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo, president of New Brunswick Theological Seminary, the oldest theological seminary in the United States, has been named Professor of Religion a George Washington University here.

Of all recent developments in Latin America the sudden burst of progress in United States-Brazilian relations is probably the most important. It is the sort of thing that might not have been noticed except for the fact that Secretary Acheson arrived in Brazil yesterday for a visit of goodwill.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (UP) -- Factories hired workers in May at a rate almost 15 per cent below that of the same month last year, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
The Consumers League of New York has taken action to correct what were described as "unfair and abusive practices" upon thousands of migrant workers employed in this state.

LONDON, July 2 -- Thanks to $202,000,000 in timely aid from the United States, the drain on the sterling area's gold and dollar reserves was reduced to a nominal figure during the second quarter of this year.

The Chase National Bank's quarterly condition statement shows deposits of $5,236,752,682 on June 30, against $4,988,540,257 on March 31 and $4,793,337,782 at the end of June, 1951. Total resources on the respective dates were $5,697,633,277, $5,446,879,594 and $5,227,895,685.
One big inning sufficed to give the Red Sox a 5-4 triumph over the Yankees yesterday in a clash of flipping ancients before 20,514 fans at the Stadium.

The development of fatal complications following the use of one of the antibiotics, named chloramphenicol, is reported in the current issue of The Journal of the American Medical Association by three groups of physicians from different sections of the country.

BERLIN, July 2 -- Three United States priests and their German woman guide were seized at gunpoint by the East Berlin police today when they apparently crossed the border into the Eastern zone. United States authorities immediately asked for their return but Soviet headquarters said it had no word of their arrest.

Long, white, feathery streaks high in the clear, blue sky, with some crosses, circles and curlicues -- something like Arabic skywriting, one imaginative observer said -- attracted the atten tion of thousands in the metropolitan area yesterday morning.
Employes of fifty-one Whelan Drug Stores in the New York area continued their strike for the second day yesterday as management and union differed concerning the effectiveness of the walkout.
The outlook for settlement of the national steel strike grew bleaker yesterday as industrial lay-offs skyrocketed and reserves of defense steel melted toward the vanishing point.

TOKYO, July 2 (AP) -- The United States Air Force said tonight hydroelectric plants in Communist North Korea were bombed last week because "they were supplying electricity" to the Reds' war plants producing weapons being used against United Nations troops.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Congress approved and sent to the White House today the final drafts of four appropriations bills carrying a total of $8,799,919,323 for operation of various agencies in the 1953 fiscal year, which began yesterday.

LONDON, July 2 -The Policy Committee of the Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany met today and authorized its representatives to conclude a settlement of indemnification and restitution claims against Germany on the basis of the terms worked out with a Bonn Governmerit delegation during negotiations in The Hague.

SALISBURY, England, July 2 (UP) -- A Royal Air Force dive bomber on a test-flight from a secret experimental airfield plunged out of control into a housing development near here today, killing two persons and injuring nine others.
The Federal Maritime Board was asked yesterday to prohibit attempts by certain freight forwarders to control the stevedoring contracts of steamship cargoes that these forwarders handle.
New issues of railroad-equipment trust certificates totaling $11,230,000 were sold yesterday at public sealed bidding to banking syndicates.
BOSTON, July 2 -- The Giants, reduced to one catcher who himself had been reduced to the use of one good eye, lost the final encounter of their four-game series with the Braves today, 2 to 1.
HARRISON, N. J., July 2 -- Strikers at the Crucible Steel Company's plant here cheerfully left their picket lines beginning at 1:05 P. M. today to collect vacation pay.

Pierre Monteux on the podium, facing the Stadium Symphony, is becoming a guarantee of a superb concert. The orchestra plays brilliantly under him; there are no bobbles or lackadaisical moments; and the strings sound with a sheen that only these virtuoso players can achieve when stimulated.

CHICAGO, July 2 -- By a vote of 62 to 39 the Republican National Committee seated today an insurgent Georgia delegation pledged to cast seventeen votes for the nomination of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio and refused credentials to a "regular" delegation that had favored General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower by a 14-to-3 margin.

FLORENCE, Italy, July 2 (UP) -- Artur Rodzinski, the conductor, said today that James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, was "absolutely misinformed" about his recording activities in Europe.

The effort of the Bevan faction of the British Labor party to exploit the bombing of the Korean power plants for its own ends has met with a double defeat. First the Labor party itself greatly watered down a Bevanite motion of censure. Then that motion was defeated in the House of Commons by a solid Conservative and Liberal majority.

VIENNA, July 2 -- A white-painted United Nations airplane descended at Schwechat airfield this evening to bring Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations to Vienna for the first official visit of a representative of that organization to this country, which is not a member of it.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- A Congressional subcommittee split three to two today in suggesting that the President has "the right and duty" to intervene in disputes arising out of monetary policy decisions of the Federal Reserve Board.
CHICAGO, July 2 -- A word of mouth campaign to get the public to feel that it is a part of business was outlined today at a meeting of the National Industrial Advertisers Association.

Harry Mopsick, president of the National Tenants Council, announced yesterday that he had asked President Truman to move for a stronger rent-control measures than those embodied in the law that the President reluctantly signed Monday.
BULL SHOALS, Ark., July 2 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's speech dedicating the Bull Shoals and Norfork Dams today:...

The "typical" department store had a net profit of only 2.4 cents on each dollar of sales last year, compared with 3.7 cents in 1950, it was reported yesterday by the Controllers Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association. Department store sales volume was up 1 per cent for the year.
JERSEY CITY, July 2 -- Members of the Marine Warehousemen's Local 1478, International Longshoremen's Association, voted today to end their week-old wildcat strike here at the Claremont Terminal.
DENVER, July 2 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower declared here tonight: "I'm going to roar out across the country for a clean, decent operation. The American people deserve it."

CHICAGO, July 2 -- Wheat futures on the Board of Trade displayed considerable strength today, reflecting the opinion of many traders that the big winter wheat movement has had about its maximum effect on the market, and that declines from this level will insure further large impoundings of wheat under the loan, which might leave available supplies comparatively small despite the large total wheat crop now indicated.

LONDON, July 2 -- A deafening row was caused in the House of Commons today by the disclosure that Field Marshal Earl Alexander, the Minister of Defense, had publicly voiced concern in a speech here about the reserves available to the United Nations command in Korea.

BERLIN, July 2 -- To save the world both from communism and war, bold aid must be given to the colonial areas of the world to satisfy their nationalist and economic ambitions, the General Council of the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions was told today.

The Queens County grand jury handed up a presentment yesterday in which it recommended legislation by Congress to allow criminal prosecution of violators of air safety regulations and in which it outlined measures to reduce the nuisance and hazard of planes operating from La Guardia Airport and New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- A special committee of the House of Representatives announced today its finding that "the Soviet N. K. V. D. [People's Commissariat of Internal Affairs] committed the massacre of thousands of Polish Army officers in the Katyn Forest near Smolensk, Russia, not later than the spring of 1940."

TOKYO, July 2 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida told the Diet today that the bloody May Day riots in Imperial Palace plaza had been carried out "at the instigation of foreign Communist nations" and warned that newly independent Japan must take steps against becoming "a colony of a foreign Communist power."
TOKYO, Thursday, July 3 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,299 for the twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M., Thursday, Korea time:

WASHINGTON, July 2 (UP) -- Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, said today the Bureau of Internal Revenue "compromised" at least forty-eight tax cases of more than $250,000 each over the last ten years and once settled a $888,021 claim for a mere $1,000.

PALMDALE, Calif., Juply 2 (UP) -- The military took some of the wraps off one of its most important shoreline defenses today, a high-flying supersonic jet warplane that automatically seeks out attacking enemy bombers in any kind of weather.

PUSAN, Korea, Thursday, July 3 (UP) -- The Korean National Assembly, seating 120 members provided by a police dragnet that hauled in hiding Assemblymen out of beds, went into secret session today to discuss a constitutional amendment demanded by President Syngman Rhee.

The first major indication that Ukrainian exile organizations may join with other exile groups for a common fight against the Stalin regime became evident yesterday with the announcement that Admiral Alan G. Kirk, former United States Ambassador to Moscow, had been invited to be one of the principal speakers Saturday night at the Fifth Congress of Americans of Ukrainian Descent at the Hotel Statler.

Modified import quota regulations on foreign cheeses may be more liberal than had been expected by importers, it was indicated yesterday in a study of the Senate-House conference committee report on the new Defense Production Act.

GOSHEN, N. Y., July 2 (AP) -- The outlook for next month's Hambletonian for 3-year-old trotters took a startling turn today when Hit Song won the Historic-Dickerson Cup in two straight heats. The favored Duke of Lullwater ran out of the money both times.
A five-alarm fire destroyed two four-story loft buildings yesterday afternoon on Howard Avenue between Monroe and Madison Streets in Brooklyn's Bushwick district.
Before it is too late Congress should stem the trend to limit imports from friendly nations.

A device full of magnetic and electronic magic and completely free from error was put into service in New York yesterday by American Airlines to sell airplane tickets. At day's end its record was above reproach.
ROME, July 2 -- The Pontifical Hungarian Ecclesiastical Institute in Rome announced today that it intended to resist the eviction order served on it by the Hungarian Government.

General Sessions Judge Saul S. Streit sent eleven fixers of college basketball games to prison yesterday for terms varying from six months to seven years. The judge, a caustic critic of high-pressure intercollegiate athletics, again denounced the present sports system. He urged that each state enact a law making it a criminal offense for anyone to subsidize college athletes.

CLEVELAND, July 2 (AP) -- Barney McCosky's pinch single with the bases loaded and one out in the tenth inning today settled another overtime battle between the Indians and the Browns, Cleveland winning, 3 -- 2.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- An Army Officer told the Court of Military Appeals today that Pfc. Warren G. McConnell of Alloway, N. J., endangered United States forces when he fell asleep while on guard on the Korean front last November.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- A union may legally charge a larger fee for reinstating a former member than it charges those applying for membership the first time, the National Labor Relations Board ruled today by a 3-to-2 vote.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- A proposed increase in the tariff on Swiss watches is being studied by several agencies of the Government concerned with carrying out the Trade Agreements Act. The increase was recommended by the United States Tariff Commission to President Truman under the "escape clause" of the act, which provides that tariffs may be increased to relieve United States producers from undue hardship.
HOUSTON, Tex., July 2 -- Hundreds of children, accompanied by their parents, jammed improvised clinics here today to get injections of gamma globulin, a blood derivative, in what was

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., July 2 -- Teen-age girl are more likely to discuss their dates with their mothers than with their fathers but they are more likely to argue with their mothers as well, a survey of 135 high school juniors shows. The research study, conducted by Miss Phoebe Forrest, home economist at Pennsylvania State College, investigated youngsters' "dating patterns" and how these affected, or were affected by, parent-child relations.

Judge Edward J. Dimock ruled yesterday in United States District Court in the trial of fifteen secondary Communist party leaders against introduction of excerpts from Marxist-Leninist "classics" during the cross-examination of the Government's second witness.

BOSTON, July 3 -- Two women Vice Presidential candidates threw their hats into the ring today and delegates to the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's convention here promptly filled them with $1,026.50.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Military procurement and construction totaled $8,000,000,000 in the second quarter of this year, a gain of 20 per cent over the first three months, Dr. John R. Steelman, acting head of the Office of Defense Mobilization, reported today.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- Congress tonight completed action on a compromise bill to build up the American merchant marine. The compromise omits controversial changes in tax deferment provisions of existing law.

Senator Taft may have been calculating the full meaning of his words when he commented in Chicago yesterday on the statement issued by twenty-three Republican Governors at Houston the day before. For his sake we hope he was not. We hope he did not really believe that the issue of the contested delegations was "not a moral issue" but "purely parliamentary."

It is long past time that the United States restore its diplomatic relations with the Nationalist Government of China to the proper level. Since the departure of Ambassador John Leighton Stuart from mainland China we have been represented in Formosa by a Minister. We have been fortunate in having, in the person of John Rankin, a competent and distinguished representative, but he has not had the Ambassadorial rank that the post deserves and requires.
LONDON, July 3 (Reuters) -- The British Government was urged today to press for an international agreement on cotton prices.

The four-man board named by Mayor Impellitteri to administer the employes' suggestion plan recently approved by the Board of Estimate held an organization meeting yesterday in the office of Deputy Mayor Charles Horowitz at City Hall.
Miss Frances Simmons and Milton Bogen have been appointed vice presidents of Alexander's Department Stores in the Bronx and White Plains.
WASHINGTON, July 3 - President Truman said positively again today that he would not accept the nomination of the Democratic party even if it were tendered to him.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 3 -- The movie colony today was trying to gauge the significance of the markedly poor attendance of the special general membership meeting last night of the Screen Writers Guild. The meeting was held to study the proposed establishment by the Motion Picture Industry Council of a "services committee" to assist free lance artists, who may be listed with allegedly subversive organizations, and activities by the American Legion and other groups.

Crude rubber futures on the New York Commodity Exchange continued to decline yesterday after Government decontrol and supervision over imports of this important commodity. Final prices were down 25 to 70 points as traders exchanged 1,456,000 pounds.

TULARE, Calif., July 3 (AP) -- The Bob Mathias story held another stirring chapter today. The next pages will be added this month in the Olympic games at Helsinki, where 21-year-old Bob will compete again with the best of other lands.

CHICAGO, July 3 -- The pro-Eisenhower Texas delegation, challenged to a television debate, called instead today for lifting of the ban on TV, radio and newsreel coverage of its dispute with the pro-Taft delegation before official bodies.

New York City plays host today to the 1,200 delegates attending the Fifth Congress of Americans of Ukrainian descent. The men and women at this meeting will come from all parts of America and from many occupations, for those of Ukrainian origin in this country have long played a proud and useful role among the many peoples whose blending has made our country great.

Reorganization and expansion of the executive set-up of the L. E. Waterman Company, and consolidation of its manufacturing and administrative operations in its Seymour, Conn., plant, were announced yesterday by F. D. Waterman, president of the fountain pen and ink manufacturing enterprise.
CINCINNATI, July 3 (AP) -- Bubba Church won his first game of the season by holding the Pirates to four hits today while the Reds pounded out a 5-1 victory over Howie Pollet.

LONDON, July 3 -- The statement of Chancellor of the Exchequer R. A. Butler that the drain on gold and dollar reserves had slowed down caused further improvement in sentiment on the Stock Exchange today. This produced stronger buying of British Government securities and leading industrials.

Jim Hearn pitched the Giants to a 4-3 victory over the Dodgers yesterday at Ebbets Field, cutting Brooklyn's league lead over them to two games. With last-inning relief from Hoyt Wilhelm, the big right-hander gained his ninth triumph of the year before 16,922 fans.
CHICAGO, July 3 -- The national convention of the Progressive party will open here tomorrow.

The Federal Court of Appeals upheld yesterday the conviction of Frank Costello for contempt of the Senate Crime Investigating Committee, but because seven of the ten counts of conviction were reversed the fines totaling $5,000 were reduced to $2,000. The gambler still faces eighteen months in jail.

CHICAGO, July 3 -- Chicago is teeming with oratorical timber of the familiar vertical variety, but the palm for horizontal forensics undoubtedly goes to Perry Howard: he makes a whale of a stump speech lying down.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 3 -- California's large delegation to the Republican National Convention headed for Chicago this afternoon after being warned by Gov. Earl Warren, its favorite son for the Presidential nomination, that "the most fundamental things in political life are being submerged by personalities" in advance of the nominating sessions.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- The Senate Public Works Committee approved unanimously today two bills that would permit a $100,000,000 development of the Delaware River port at Philadelphia and Camden, N. J.

A new high-performance torque converter for use in six-cylinder engine cars, was announced yesterday by the Chrysler division, Chrysler Corporation. The appliance, said to conserve oil, combines the torque converter oil system with that of the engine oil system, according to J. A. O'Malley, vice president and general sales manager of the division.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 3 -- An attempt by Czechoslovakia, backed by the Soviet Union and Poland, to obtain quick approval in the Economic and Social Council of a measure designed to halt the court-martial in Spain of leaders of the Barcelona strike in March of 1951 was blocked today by a counter-proposal by the United Kingdom.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., July 3 -- Bob Crowley, assistant pro at the Upper Montclair Country Club, teamed with Chet Sanok for a six-under-par 32, 34 -- 66 today to win the New Jersey Golf Association's pro-amateur championship at the Plainfield Country Club.
WASHINGTON, July 3 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture said today that American farmers an produce about 18 per cent more in the next four or five years than they did in 1951.

The combination of a mild, balmy evening and the annual all-Gershwin program lured 18,500 people, largest attendance of the season, to Lewisohn Stadium last night. Program and participants were familiar. Oscar Levant, who is by way of being a Gershwin specialist, played -- guess what? -- the Concerto in F and the "Rhapsody in Blue."

As an educator I favor Adlai Stevenson, the only liberally educated man I can detect among the possible nominees, and, on his record, the best qualified for the Presidency. Though Governor Stevenson is not actively seeking the nomination, I think the Democrats should draft him.

FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., July 3 -- Military regulations call for a forty-eight-gun salute to the Union on Independence Day, but of the four major military installations near the New Jersey shore only this fort appeared ready to meet the requirements tomorrow.
HENLEY - ON - THAMES, England, July 3 (UP) -- The university of Pennsylvania's unbeaten 150-pound crew and Tabor Academy of Marion, Mass., won their heats today at the Royal Henley regatta.

ON EISENHOWER TRAIN, En Route to Chicago, July 3 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower today opened his three-day barnstorming tour across Colorado, Nebraska, Iowa and Illinois to the Republican National Convention with a series of hard-hitting attacks on Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, his chief opponent for the Presidential nomination.

The thirty-four-story Williamsburgh Savings Bank Building at 1 Hanson Place, Brooklyn, was surrounded and searched by a large police detail yesterday after a nervous young thief took $170 from one of its many offices.

New York's Chinese community will begin a month's drive on Monday for funds to help an estimated 10,000 refugee Chinese intellectuals in Hong Kong to emigrate to other countries to continue their work while waiting for the liberation of their homeland.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 18 points higher to 5 points lower than on Wednesday.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 3 -- A capacity audience of 2,100 gave an ovation tonight to the new ballet "The Cage," whose performance by the New York City Ballet Company had been the subject of the first morals controversy in the six-year history of the Holland Festival.

A sizable part of the nation started the long Fourth of July week-end celebration yesterday, with hundreds of thousands jamming automobiles and similar crowds filling trains, buses and air and sea craft to spend a busy and gay three-day holiday.

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, July 4 (AP) -- Allied defenders atop Old Baldy and a near-by hill on the western front fought off three waves of Chinese attackers early today as United States Independence Day brought renewed fighting in Korea.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- President Truman hurriedly signed today a Congressional resolution approving a new Constitution for Puerto Rico so that its people could make an Independence Day celebration of it tomorrow.

CHICAGO, July 3 -- Following is the text of a statement by Guy G. Gabrielson, chairman of the Republican National Committee, in reply to the twenty-three G. O. P. Governors, who, in a telegraphed manifesto, called on the party's national convention to deny votes to disputed delegates on all contests over seats.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (UP) -- The House Appropriations Committee charged today that $262,000,000 spent by the Army Engineers on the Missouri River between St Louis and Sioux City, Iowa, actually had increased floods.

Three new films arrive at first-run theatres today. "The Lady in the Iron Mask," a period adventure starring Louis Hayward and Patricia Medina, opens at the Globe. The Twentieth Century-Fox production, based on the Alexander Dumas story, "The Three Musketeers," was produced by Walter Wanger and Eugene Frenke.

VIENNA, July 3 -- Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, was greeted with thunderous applause in the Austrian Parliament today when he said that he had long held that Austria should be a member of the United Nations and that "no regime should be arbitrarily imposed on any country."

BERLIN, July 3 -- The three Roman Catholic priests from Chicago who were arrested by East German policement on the outskirts of West Berlin yesterday were released this afternoon. They told United States officials they had believed they were in the United States sector of the city when seized.

Krich-New Jersey, Inc., has notified all its New Jersey dealers that it would exert every effort to see that trans-shippers of television receivers and appliances in the state were prosecuted, Max H. Krich, president, disclosed yesterday. His organization distributes in New Jersey a good number of the top brands in both fields.

WHEN Johnny Weissmuller was in his prime, he held virtually every world swimming record in the book. The record of which he was most proud was his 220-yard mark of 2:09, far prouder than of his 100-yard figures of 51 seconds flat.

IT'S getting so you can scarcely find a stretch of water that doesn't harbor a fishing contest. Today will bring the contest to full flower because it starts one of the year's biggest week-ends and the vacation season to boot.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- President Truman declared today he would not invoke the Taft-Hartley Labor Act in the steel strike because some steel companies were engaged in "a conspiracy against the public interest." Soon afterward, the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., invoked the act against six major steel companies, charging unfair labor practices.
LONDON, July 3 (AP) -- Officially, Britons are coolly aloof toward American passes at the transatlantic speed record by ship: Unofficially, they're red hot for the home team.
ST. LOUIS, July 3 (AP) -- Joe Presko, with the help of a fumbling opposition, marked up his fifth triumph of the season today, a 4-1 victory for the Cards over the Cubs in their series opener.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 3 (AP) -- Iran has formally rejected Russian charges that Premier Mohammed Mossadegh's Government violated the 1921 Iranian-Soviet friendship treaty by accepting renewed United States military aid.

Seven thousand Police Athletic League youngsters got a double-barreled treat yesterday simply by showing up at the P. A. L. play street or playground nearest their homes. First, they got the jump on their elders by celebrating the Fourth of July a day ahead of time with patriotic parades, skits and games on the sixty-six league play areas.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 3 -- The Soviet Union cast its forty-ninth veto today, blocking an International Red Cross investigation of Communist charges that United Nations forces in Korea had used bacteriological warfare. The United States replied by introducing a new resolution under which the Security Council would condemn "the practice of fabricating and disseminating such false charges."

PHILADELPHIA, July 3 (AP) -- Carl Scheib gained his fourth victory as Billy Hitchcock banged out a bases-filled ninth-inning single today to give the Athletics a 4-3 victory over the Red Sox. Boston dropped from third place to fifth.

The old-fashioned ice cream freezer with its wooden bucket and hand-turner was, in days gone by, as symbolic of the Fourth of July as "The Star Spangled Banner." Though the hand-turned dessert has for years been on the wane, Americans still lead the world in ice cream consumption.

SINGAPORE, July 3 -- The mobilization to combat the Communist rebellion in Malaya reached a climax in Kuala Lumpur today when the Federation of Malaya's Legislative Council approved unanimously a bill authorizing the conscription for national service of all inhabitants between the ages of 18 and 55.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- The Senate passed without discussion today a measure authorizing President Truman to appoint a special investigator to root out any corruption in government. The bill now goes to the House.

BERLIN, July 3 -- Yves Farge, former French Minister of Food Supply and leader of the French delegation to the World Peace Council, presented to that body today a long report on his observations in the Far East in which he sought to convince his listeners that the United States was engaged in bacteriological warfare.

Sidney Schwartz, second-seeded player from Long Beach, L. I., and Jack Tuero of Roslyn, L. I., advanced to the semi-final round of the New York State men's singles tennis championship at the Seminole Club, Forest Hills, Queens, yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The Office of Education, in its annual circular on expenditure per pupil in city school systems, covering the year 1950-51, found a $6 drop in "actual educational investment in each boy and girl" from the year before.

The Parole Board of this state requires that a prisoner who is eligible for parole, by reason of good behavior and having served two-thirds of his minimum sentence, must while in prison secure employment approved by the board before he is discharged.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Department store sales in the week ended June 28 were 1 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year. This was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board whose listing of sales in terms of percentage changes from like periods of 1951 follows:

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 3 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan said today his Nationalist Government would not call an election this year despite its sweeping victory in the Wakkerstroom parliamentary by-election. Elections will take place in May or June next year, he said.

For many years a campaign has been carried on to protect our children against severe, often crippling, injury from fireworks and firecrackers. During those years progressive legislation and education in our schools have limited the indiscriminate sale of these items, resulting in almost complete elimination of injuries to our children.

CHICAGO, July 3 -- Active commission absorption was evident in the wheat market today after prcies had eased on bearish crop estimates. While receipts continue close to record-breaking volume hedge selling is still comparatively light, and it is taken for granted that growers will place much of the crop under Government loan.

WORCESTER, Mass., July 3 -- Navy's big crew that swept Eastern sprint honors and won the intercollegiate championship during the season passed one more test today as the United States Olympic rowing trials opened at Lake Quinsigamond.

VIENNA, July 3 (UP) -- Bucharest newspapers received here today reported that the Rumanian Communist regime had adopted a "New Economic Policy," similar to the one to which Russia took recourse during the Bolshevik economic crisis in the Nineteen Twenties.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- Postmaster General Jesse M. Donaldson told Congress today that it would have to raise postal rates if it did not want the department to lose $670,000,000 this next fiscal year.

LIMA, Peru, June 28 -- Victor Raul Haya de la Torre, a Peruvian politician, has for roughly three and a hail years been in "exile" under foreign sovereignty in the heart of the capital of his native country.

LONDON, July 3 (Reuters) -- The "coronation bug" has bitten Britain's fashion designers and with the crowning of Queen Elizabeth II next June foremost in their minds, the effects are being felt in the fashions they now are busy preparing for the fall and winter months, still far -- and many hot weeks -- away.

ABOARD THE LINER UNITED STATES, At Sea, July 3 -- America's entry in the competition for Atlantic speed laurels is at sea on her maiden voyage, steadily building up revolutions of her four mighty engines for what 1,660 passengers aboard expect to be an attempt on a first crossing to lower the record held by the British liner Queen Mary.

For the last sixteen years department store executives have been receiving a lively little publication known as "Grey Matter," published by the Grey Advertising Agency. Many executives have been disturbed by some of the suggestions made for obtaining new business.

Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer swore in Vice Admiral E. L. Cochrane yesterday morning for a new four-year term as chairman of the Federal Maritime Board and Maritime Administrator. Admiral Cochrane, whose first term of two years expired Monday, was reappointed June 26 by President Truman.
SAN MARINO, July 3 -- Government workers in this small, 1,600-year-old Republic have not been paid for the past fifteen weeks and the State is facing bankruptcy, it was disclosed today.

Security markets in the United States will have an extended weekend as business shuts down today in observance of Independence Day and the various stock and bond exchanges conform to the Saturday closing for the summer months. European and Canadian markets will operate as usual.

TOKYO, Friday, July 4 -- The upper house of the Japanese Diet late yesterday adopted the controversial "subversive activities prevention bill" giving the Government power to suppress all organizations that use or instigate internal violence.

CHICAGO, July 3 -- Senator Robert A. Taft's backers gave him sixteen more votes, against three for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, as the Republican National Committee ruled today on nineteen delegate contests from Louisiana, Mississippi and Missouri.

I was shocked to learn from Benjamin Fine's article in your issue of June 29 that there are growing attacks against schools and colleges which teach about the U. N. and particularly about UNESCO. It is hard to imagine how people can be so shortsighted as to oppose the very organizations that are doing their utmost to bring peace into the world.

A "mechanical brain," the operation of which is expected to relieve the city's budget of $142,551 in annual salaries and release several hundred uniformed firemen from permit delivery and fee collection duties, has gone to work for the Fire Department.

Executing with matchless grace the identical ten-dive repertoire that was the vehicle of his 1948 Olympic triumph at London, Maj. Sammy Lee of the Army Medical Corps yesterday convincingly bagged the No. 1 United States berth in the ten-meter platform dive at the 1952 Olympics.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Both chambers of Congress labored through today and into this evening in an effort to pass all essential legislation in time to adjourn Saturday night. Both the Senate and the House will meet tomorrow, with the same goal in view, although the Fourth of July is normally a sacrosanct Congressional holiday.
COPENHAGEN, July 3 -- Denmark, as part of the important northern flank, is very much kept in mind at Atlantic pact headquarters, Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway assured the Danes at a press conference today.

Much evil is spoken about rainy week-ends, especially by persons planning to go to the country, but the true countryman knows that rainy days have many uses and he is not put out when dawn comes wet and cool.

Benjamin Fine's report in THE TIMES of June 29 on the growing opposition to UNESCO and the U. N. in general deals with a problem which is more comprehensive than the issue on which the article centers its attention. Of course, all kinds of illegitimate pressure, tending to restrict freedom of information and discussion, should be protested and opposed.

Weather permitting, a group of young people accompanied by some mothers and dads will spend a good part of tomorrow evening at the Mosholu golf course in the Bronx sharing a mutual interest -- observing the skies. Members of the Junior Astronomy Club of New York hold meetings regularly on Saturday evenings at the golf course when fair weather prevails, and a number of enthusiastic mothers and dads are usually on hand.

PUSAN, Korea, Friday, July 4 (UP) -- Presdient Syngman Rhee's Government agreed today to a compromise settlement of Korea's political quarrel after a non-stop forty-eight-hour conference of opposing factions.
PARIS, July 3 -- The French National Assembly today approved expenditure of the equivalent of $108,000,000 over the next six years for the development of peacetime uses of atomic energy.

Underwriters headed by Blyth Co., Inc., announced yesterday private placement of 51,000 shares of new common stock of the Pacific Gas and Electric Company, concluding the largest offering of equity shares of an American public utility operating company.

BONN, Germany, July 3 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer made today a series of suggestions for changes in the draft of the new note the Allies are preparing to send to Moscow in the diplomatic exchange over German unity. These included recommendations for changes of substance as well as phraseology.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- During the week ended July 2, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, member bank reserves increased $147,000,000. The principal changes supplying reserves were an increase of $402,000,000 in Reserve Bank credit and decreases of $44,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve banks, $34,000,000 in other deposits with Federal Reserve banks, $19,000,000 in foreign deposits with Federal Reserve banks, and $13,000,000 in Treasury cash holdings.

We commemorate today the signing, on July 4, 1776, of our national Declaration of Independence. In this Declaration members of the Continental Congress proclaimed that the American Colonies were and of right ought to be free and independent states. The Declaration itself set a special stamp upon our independence and it became the symbol of a bigger thing, our freedom.
Second-line steel producers closed ranks yesterday behind the industry's "Big Six" in resistance to any compromise on the union shop, pivotal issue in the thirty-two-day-old steel strike.

WASHINGTON, July 3 diP)North American Aviation, Inc., p,opoed tonight arbitt, ation of its wage dispute with the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O. The union promptly called a meeting in Detroit lv[ond/y to consider it.

VIENNA, July 3 (Reuters) -- Imre Nagy, Hungarian Cabinet Minister handling compulsory purchases of farm products, has criticized local councils in Communist Hungary for cheating peasants out of their rights.
Paul de Heresy in a letter to THE TIMES urges the establishment of a customs and currency union between the entire British Commonwealth of Nations and the United States of America.

HONG KONG, July 3 -- A campaign to "create extra wealth" to the extent of 400,000,000,000 people's dollars (about $177,800,000) has been started in North China under the name of "patriotic production-increase and economy emulation drive."

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, today termed Senator William Benton, Democrat of Connecticut, "a clever propagandist worth millions a year" to the Communist party. Mr. Benton in reply called Mr. McCarthy "a hit-and-run propagandist of the Soviet type."

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- The House today defeated a Senate-originated proposal to create a super budget committee in Congress. The action was by roll call vote of 173 to 155 and was on a resolution to consider the proposal. With only two days remaining in the present session, it was equivalent to killing the plan.

CHICAGO, July 3 -- Governor Dewey declared today that the "Taft steam roller" which he said had been operating on contests before the Republican National Committee would stop Monday, the day the convention opens. He predicted that General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower would be nominated for President on an early ballot at the Republican National Convention.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- The Defense Department today identified 284 battle casualties in Korea in a new list that reported 42 killed, 187 wounded, 33 missing, 21 injured and 1 death from injuries. The following were from New York and New Jersey (none from Connecticut):

MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., July 3 -- Barbara Bruning of Whippoorwill, New York State women's champion, playing in her first tournament of the year in the metropolitan area following a two-month illness, won both major phases of today's Women's Westchester-and-Fairfield Golf Association event at the Mount Kisco Country Club.
LONDON, July 3 (Reuters) -- Lord Swinton, Cabinet Minister in charge of raw materials policy, said tonight Britain might well have to "tighten up still further" on imports from non-sterling areas.

Some of the recent attacks on the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization originate with people who "are just as confused as it is possible to be," Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said yesterday. She told a general session of the American Library Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel that her recent mail on this international agency had been "extraordinary."

A suspended employe of the Flushing (Queens) Post Office, who had been out on $2,500 bail for allegedly forging and cashing a stolen postal money order, was arrested again yesterday on a similar charge. The first transaction took place in Brooklyn and the second one in Bethlehem, Pa.

Bank clearings of the twenty-five leading cities of the nation for the week ended on Wednesday amounted to a record $21,384,417,000, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. This represents an increase of 45.1 per cent over the $14,738,150,000 cleared in the holiday week last year and a gain of 13.6 per cent above the $18,828,493,000 a week earlier.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Loadings of revenue freight in the week ended June 28 totaled 649,172 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 15,312 cars or .8 per cent more than in the preceding week, 172,443 cars or 21 per cent less than in the corresponding week last year, and 134,348 cars or 17.1 per cent less than in the corresponding week two years ago.

ONE of the established pastimes of the European intellectual is taking the dim view of America. Even though our political democracy has been, like the achievements of Private Willis in "Iolanthe," "generally admired," the manners and morals that characterized us as a people have provided our critics with plenty of game for sport. This custom of honoring our hospitality by dishonoring our institutions goes back to the nineteenth century.

New York bank loans to business dropped $162,000,000 last week, marking the largest reduction this year. Repayments by public utilities were the major influence in the decline which reversed the increases of the three previous weeks.

TOKYO, July 3 -- Gen. James A. Van Fleet, Eighth Army commander in Korea, said today he fully agreed with the statement of the British Defense Minister, Field Marshal Earl Alexander, that greater military reserves were needed in Korea.

BERNARDSVILLE, N. J., July 3 -- Charlotte De Cozen of Montclair won low gross honors in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's one-day tournament over the Somerset Hills course today with a three-over-par 38, 38 -- 76.

After a gallant effort to keep running, marked by voluntary salary reductions and price-scale slashes, "Of Thee I Sing" has decided to call it a career after tomorrow night's performance, the seventy-second, at the Ziegfeld Theatre.
The Department of Parks Marionette Theatre will tour fourteen playgrounds in Queens beginning next Thursday with its summer production of "Jack and the Beanstalk."

PRINCETON, N. J., July 3 -- The earliest known painting of the Battle of Princeton, a decisive engagement won by the Americans on the outskirts of this community 175 years ago, has been presented to the Princeton University Library.

TRENTON, July 3 -- Forty-eight wholesale distributors of cigarettes in New Jersey were permitted today by Superior Court to join as complainants in a suit attacking constitutionality of the New Jersey cigarette fair trade law.

The Carter Handicap will occupy the top spot on the racing program at Aqueduct today. This traditional Independence Day fixture, for 3-year-olds and upward at seven furlongs, has attracted a field of eleven, and if all go, the race will have a gross value of $29,550, with the winner's net share amounting to $20,500.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The Senate passed tonight a supplemental appropriations bill limiting new Mutual Security outlays to $6,001,947,750. But it granted in full President Truman's requests for expanding the atomic energy program.

BOSTON, July 3 (AP) -- Curt Simmons pitched a neat four-hitter for his seventh victory against two defeats and Del Ennis walloped his eighth homer today as the Phillies blanked the Braves, 2 -- 0, for their fifth victory in seven starts since Steve O'Neill became their manager.

TOKYO, Friday, July 4 -- The United Nations delegation today agreed to re-enter secret negotiations with the Communists for an armistice in the Korean war following the presentation by the Chinese and North Koreans of a new proposal that might provide an outlet from the two-month deadlock over the disputed question of prisoner exchange.

CHICAGO, July 3 -- The fireworks started a day ahead of time at the Republican National Convention today when Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio demanded that to the disputed delegates from Texas, Louisiana, Georgia, Mississippi, Virginia and Puerto Rico there be given the power to vote on one another's rights to be seated at next week's sessions.

The appeal of the Mayor and the Water Commissioner for care in the use of city water during this summer's hot weather points up again the dismal fact that our present water system is so inadequate that it cannot cope with any abnormal situation.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 3 -- The Good Time Stables' Good Time, from Goshen, N. Y., scored a two and one-half length victory in 2:31 3/5 over Direct Rhythm tonight in the seventh $25,000 invitation National Pacing Derby at Roosevelt Raceway.

All but the most adventuresome vacationists may decide to call the whole thing off after pondering some of the hazards that might beset them as discussed in several safety reports. One means of insuring fun on a vacation, however, is to be prepared if emergencies come, the experts emphasize.

The Statue of Liberty is only six miles from Newtown Creek in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn. But it might just as well be sixty miles away, or even 600, as far as four teen-age boys who live near the creek are concerned, despite an attempt to visit it last night.
WIMBLEDON, England, July 3 -- For the first time in a quarter of a century an entire program of play was canceled by rain in the All-England lawn tennis championships at Wimbledon today.

DETROIT, July 3 -- The National Education Association interrupted its general business session today to deplore unanimously attacks on the public school and the N. E. A. in the June issue of the American Legion magazine.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- For only part of nearly six hours of baseball today did Casey Stengel have the hitting to overcome feeble pitching. His Yankees thus had to be content with a split of a twin bill with the Senators before 13,471 highly critical observers.

After stagnating for two months at dead center over the last remaining issue -- the exchange of prisoners of war -- the Korean armistice negotiations seem to have gained a fresh lease on life. New proposals and counter-proposals are being exchanged without the previous automatic rejection, and for the first time in weeks the Communists begin to indicate willingness to "compromise" this issue.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- President Truman said today that he had ordered an inquiry into "injustice" done to Prof. Owen Lattimore of the Johns Hopkins University and he hoped such an incident would never occur again. He also said that if he had anything to do with it there would be no recurrence.
TOKYO, Friday, July 4 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,300, for the twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M., Friday, Korea time:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 3 -- Following is the text of a resolution introduced by the United States in the United Nations Security Council today after the Soviet Union had vetoed a United States proposal for a Red Cross inquiry into Communist germ warfare charges:

LONDON, July 3 -- The subtle horror of "The Innocents," which opened here tonight at Her Majesty's Theatre, chilled the spines of the drama critics and warmed their hearts to it as a first rate, well-acted thriller.

TOKYO, Friday, July 4 (AP) -- The Communists no longer throw hundreds of swift MIG-15 jets into the North Korean skies and apparently are hoarding their air armada of 1,800 to 1,900 planes, the Far East Air Force said yesterday.

KANSAS CITY, July 3 (AP) -- President Truman is going to have a tried and true Democratic voice sing out his Presidential choice at the Democratic National Convention. The voice belong to Thomas J. Gavin, a little Irishman who has been following the Truman lead for a long time in Kansas City politics.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 3 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson answered critics of United States conduct toward Latin America with a statement here today that the Good Neighbor policy continued to be fundamental in United States foreign relations.

People in glass houses shouldn't throw parties, a wit remarked at the opening of the Lever House test kitchens. We're glad they did. For the gathering not only gave us a look at that handsome multi-windowed building, but afforded us a taste of a delicious product developed in the Lever kitchens.

The action of the New York State Board of Regents in formally applying this week for ten educational television stations within the state should not be construed as meaning that the uphill fight for these outlets is over. There still is a hard road ahead before educational TV becomes a reality.

DETROIT, July 3 (AP) -- Ted Kroll, an unattached pro who thrives on rain, fired a 7-under-par 32, 33 -- 65 in intermittent showers today to take the first-round lead in the $15,000 Motor City open golf tournament.

TEHUANTEPEC, Mexico, July 3 -- From all indications Mexico will have the second truly peaceful national election in her history when she chooses a new President and Congress Sunday. According to historians, the voting for President Miguel Aleman six years ago marked the first time Mexicans had gone to the polls free of the threat of revolution.

WINNIPEG, Man., July 3 (UP) -- A Greyhound bus bound from Minneapolis, Minn., to Winnipeg smashed into a parked trailer-truck near here early today. The crash killed eight persons and injured twenty, at least seven of them from the United States.
WASHINGTON, July 3 (UP) -- The Senate Small Business Committee has accused the Army and Navy of flouting the will of Congress in their procedures for awarding contracts to small companies.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (UP) -- Federal Judge Henry A. Schweinhaut today took under advisement the first court test of whether witnesses before Congressional committees could be forced to testify in the presence of television cameras and radio microphones.

BUFFALO, N. Y., July 3 (AP) -- A Jamestown couple has filed a damage suit for $236,376 against the Federal Government, charging that a Government agency furnished them incorrect information that caused them to sell more than 70,000 shares of stock at a loss.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Apparently, the pro-Taft leaders in the Republican National Committee entirely banned television, radio and motion-picture machines from the hearings on contested delegates because they were resolved in advance to assign to Mr. Taft most of those in dispute, if they could hold a committee majority in line to do so.

CHICAGO, July 3 (UP) -- Eddie Robinson banged two homers and drove in seven runs as the White Sox won two games today from the Browns, 6 -- 3 and 12 -- 3, and climbed to second place, two and one-half games behind the Yankees.
