WASHINGTON, July 3 -- President Truman said today at his news conference that the United Nations "is vital to our future as a free nation" and "the mainstay of our work to build a peaceful and decent world."

Pre-holiday factors dominated operations yesterday on the stock market and prices slipped back slowly. On balance, quotations ended with generally mixed changes, with a few of the oils up, while the chemicals weakened. Minor price changes showed in the steels and motors.
CHICAGO, July 3 -- The Republican party platform will declare that the Korean war could have been prevented with foresight, a member of the party's Resolutions Committee said tonight.

WELLESLEY, Mass., July 3 -- A 20-year-old college girl explained tonight that she was quoting former President Herbert Hoover and not impersonating him when she sent a telegram to the Republican National Committee signed with his name.

One of the largest contracts awarded here yesterday to small business concerns was that of the Eastern Air Procurement District of the Air Materiel Command for $1,450,000 for 5,403 amplifiers to Olympic Radio and Television, Inc., of Long Island City, Queens.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The United States has warned Denmark that the imminent delivery of a 13,000-ton, ocean-going tanker to the Soviet Union may force the Washington Government to cut off all economic and military aid to the friendly ally in the North Atlantic defense pact.
Fireman Thomas M. Farley of Engine Company 62 at 3431-33 White Plains Road, the Bronx, was fined fifteen days' pay yesterday by Fire Commissioner Jacob Grumet for violation of departmental rules.

CHICAGO, July 3 -- Two delegates from the New York Twenty-second Congressional District in Harlem, Harold C. Burton and Charles S. Hill, announced today that they would support Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio instead of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Republican nomination for President.

LONDON, July 3 -- A challenge to Aneurin Bevan's influence among the intellectuals of the British Labor party appeared last week with the publication of a pamphlet condemning class warfare and the slogan "Soak the Rich" as old-fashioned.

Marcus S. Siegel, 53 - year - old Brooklyn lawyer who was charged with heading a $500,000 black market ring in babies, was found guilty early today of illegally placing a child for adoption and inducing others to commit perjury. Under the verdict -- conviction on two counts of an eighteen-count indictment -- he could receive six years in prison.
As museums and galleries suffer from a chronic lack of wall space, summer's breathing spell gives them a welcome opportunity to show works of art in their possession that are not usually on view.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 3 -- Salary increases totaling $254,914 a year for Westchester's 3,000 employes, amounting to 2 1/2 per cent of present annual pay, were advocated today by Barrington Associates of New York, a business management concern retained by the county to make the first comprehensive survey of salary schedules since 1946.

Net profit of the Grand Union Company for the three months ended May 31 amounted to $375,370, equal to 50 cents a share on 621,045 common shares, according to the report released yesterday. This compares with $446,574 or 66 cents each on 578,108 shares a year earlier.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 3 -- The Republic of Lebanon, which enjoys the greatest degree of freedom of opinion of any of the Arab states and has no censorship, is going through a freedom of the press crisis that has caused within a fortnight a one-day strike of possibly half the business establishments in this city and two official newspaper strikes authorized by the press syndicate.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (UP) -- The Senate today completed Congressional action on a bill aimed at helping to prevent dock explosions such as those that occurred at South Amboy, N. J., in 1950 and Texas City, Tex., in 1947.
WASHINGTON, July 3 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture has forecast a slightly smaller non-citrus fruit crop this year but has predicted a decline in grower prices despite the drop in production.

A program with emphasis on expansion of low-cost public housing projects was offered yesterday by Manhattan Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. as a way to eliminate hazardous and insanitary living conditions.

SARANAC INN, N. Y., July 3 (AP) -- Business men must find markets for a record output of consumer goods by mid-1953, when defense spending is due to slacken, electrical contractors and dealers were advised today.
The following book, of special interest to the Catholic parent, was published recently:

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- The Commodity Credit Corporation suffered a net realized loss of $59,300,000 on its price support loans and inventories program on farm crops for the first eleven months of the fiscal year which ended on Monday.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 3 -- Yugoslav leaders have decided that the time has come to abandon direct operational control of the national economy as the next step in the process of transforming Yugoslavia from a bureaucratically controlled state capitalistic system into a decentralized Socialist society.
A caravan of singing Girl Scouts rumbled out of the Port Authority Bus Terminal yesterday toward two weeks of country life.

A subcommittee of the Joint Committee on the Economic Report, under the chairmanship of Representative Wright Patman, has been conducting an inquiry for more than a year into the question of monetary policy and public debt management. More informally it may be described as an effort to determine the causes of the recent clashes between the Treasury and the Federal Reserve System, and to propose means of reducing the friction.

The Department of Health, which has been conducting intensive studies in the last few summers on the relationship between protracted heat waves and death rates, released data yesterday showing that fatalities rose sharply in the city during the hot spell at the end of June.
WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's letter of transmittal sent to Congress today along with the annual report on United States relations with the United Nations:

The only book published today is "George Washington in American Literature, 1775-1865," a study by William Alfred Bryan. It is an evaluation of the treatment Washington received from American poets, dramatists and writers of fiction, but the author also includes Thackeray's portrait of Washington in "The Virginians."

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- A cloudburst marred the Independence Day celebration of the nation's No. 1 baseball fan at Griffith Stadium where the Yankees beat the Senators, 9 -- 4 and 4 -- 3, and held their two-and-a-half-game lead in the pennant race.

Plans for the deepening of the Gowanus Creek Channel in Brooklyn, from twenty-six to thirty feet, advanced yesterday with the passage of a bill by the United States Senate authorizing the expenditure of $428,000.

The Fifth Congress of Americans of Ukrainian Descent representing more than 1,500,000 persons in this country opened a three-day conference yesterday at the Statler Hotel with pleas for the freedom of their Soviet-dominated country and ratification of the Genocide convention.

Yesterday being Independence Day, Baby Dear, a rare South African talking bird, decided to declare its own independence. At 11 A. M. it flew out of the eighth-floor apartment of its owner, Mrs. Edna Bradley, at 155 East Forty-ninth Street.

Capt. Charles F. Blair Jr., a Pan American World Airways pilot who took a few days off from his airline chores in 1951 to fly a single-engine fighter plane non-stop over the North Pole from Norway to Alaska, was named yesterday the winner of the 1952 Harmon International Aviation Award as the "world's outstanding aviator."

TOKYO, Saturday, July 5 -- The Government - controlled Peiping radio this morning called on the United Nations armistice negotiators, meeting with the Communists in a new series of secret talks at Panmunjom, to "demonstrate American sincerity without further delay by letting the war prisoners of both sides return home."

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Traveling equipment for babies, calculated to relieve them and their mothers of worry and strain on holiday week-ends, was patented this week by Elsie A. Irvine of Philadelphia. The invention is a traveling bag big enough to pack away personal items for both parent and child and quickly convertible the inventor says "into a chair, swing, jumper, potty chair or commode, hammock, cradle and carriage."

The latest of a series of films treating more or less honestly the cruel injustices visited upon those original American, the Indians, opened with the vaudeville bill yesterday at the Palace under the title of "The Half-Breed." Jack Buetel plays the title role of the young Apache whose father was white and who is supposed to be torn asunder by conflicting loyalties.

BUCKSPORT, Me., July 4 -- Nearly everyone in this town of 3,120 turned out today for the climax of a retired school teacher's campaign to erect a monument honoring Admiral Robert E. Peary. discoverer of the North Pole, and his ship, the Roosevelt.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of use to the homemaker.

STANTON, Del., July 4 (AP) -- Sun Bahram, a 6-year-old offspring of Bahram headed for retirement after this season of racing, scored his most important victory today as he came off the pace with a sizzling stretch drive to win the $30,500 Sussex Handicap at Delaware Park.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 4 (AP) -- Long shots set off a 1-2 exposion under the favorites at Hollywood Park today, with Admiral Drake making the biggest noise in winning the $50,000 American Handicap and sending Intent, the heavy favorite, reeling into third place.
TOKYO, Saturday, July 5 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,301, for the twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M., Saturday, Korea time:

DETROIT, July 4 (AP) -- Dick Mayer and Ted Kroll, two rising young golfers on the pro circuit, took over joint leadership of the $15,000 Motor City open tournament at the halfway mark today with 11-under-par 133's.

Men's wear retailers who show a little enterprise can overcome adverse factors, Charles Hilton, president of Browning King men's shops asserted last week. His company, he said, realized early this year that the "sleigh ride" in retailing was over. It immediately began to reduce inventories and buyers in all departments were cautioned to buy only the right merchandise at the right time.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 4 -- The annual open race for all cruising and racing boats of the Riverside Yacht Club fleet for the Fierce Trophy was won today by Teddy Sheldon's Lightning Coquette. The sloop, handled by Judy Webb, the women's Long Island Sound sailing champion, triumphed on corrected time after an eight and one-half mile Gold Cup course contest.
HARRISBURG, Pa., July 4 (AP) -Youth dominated a nine-woman track and field team chosen tonight to represent the United States at the Olympic Games in Helsinki later this month.
WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Congress celebrated Independence Day by working today from noon into the evening toward adjournment for 1952 by tomorrow night.

LONDON, July 4 -- Neither warnings of the possibility of new import cuts nor a fresh decline by sterling had any noticeable effect on the stock markets today. They ended the week on a firm note with prices responding to a slight broadening of buying.

Beginning next Monday one of the biggest and best teams ever to represent the United States in the Olympic Games will take off for Helsinki. Over the week-end the last qualifications were made -- the swimmers competing in Astoria, the rowers at Worcester, Mass., the decathloners in Tulare, Calif.
LONDON, July 4 (Canadian Press) -- Britain's attempt to build the world's fastest automobile apparently has ended in embarrassing and costly failure.

ST. LOUIS, July 4 (UP) -- The Cardinals took over third place in the National League today as they swept both ends of a double-header with the Cubs, 13 -- 7 and 4 -- 1, extending their winning streak to six straight games.
MAYS LANDING, N. J., July 4 -- A Norfolk automobile dealer, Nick Allen Jr., made some champions look bad this afternoon on Lake Lenape as speed boat drivers competed for New Jersey titles.

WASHINGTON, July 4 (UP) -- The Food and Drug Administration disclosed today that its entire staff had begun a nation-wide survey to find out whether the anti-biotic drug, chloromycetin, was harmful and caused blood disorders.
CHICAGO, July 4 -- The Progressive party opened its national Presidential nominating convention today in Ashland Auditorium on Chicago's West Side.
NEWARK, July 4 -- Six adults and a child are d.ead as a result of automobile accidents on the New Jersey Turnpike today. Three persons are in hospitals.

PHILADELPHIA, July 4 (UP) -- The Red Sox blasted the Athletics for eleven hits and a 10-5 triumph in the first game of a double-header today, but dropped the second, 4 -- 3, when Elmer Valo scored from third in the sixth inning on a passed ball.
DETROIT, July 4 (AP) -- Miss Pepsi, the Dossin brothers' sleek speedster, won her second straight Detroit Memorial Trophy race today on the Detroit River.

CINCINNATI, July 4 (UP) -- The Pirates won a double-header for the first time this season today when Dick Groat's two-run single beat the Reds in the ninth inning of the first game, 4 -- 2, and the Pirates came from behind to win the second, 5 -- 2.
A quiet but serious struggle to halve the rate that nations pay to other nations to have their airmail hauled is now going on at the meeting of the Universal Postal Union in Brussels.

The significance of the Soviet Union's veto of the resolution calling for a Red Cross investigation of the charges of bacterial warfare should not be lost sight of merely because Mr. Malik's action was expected. The Security Council will be well advised to follow through, as the United States delegation has urged, with consideration of the further resolution that condemns the Soviet accusations as false.

In increasing quantity and variety, frozen pre-cooked fish is competing for the limited space in the grocery store's refrigerated case for frozen foods. The rate of expansion has not been so phenomenal as that for frozen concentrated citrus juices.
The National Shipping Authority, which handles Government-owned merchant shipping, announced yesterday that three more of the fast, new Mariner-type vessels had been assigned to steamship companies.

Plans for converting the five-Story private house at 16 East ninety-fourth Street into studio apartments and doctor's offices have been announced in connection with the resale of property by Fred H. Hill, operator, to Stanley Maggs, a contractor.
The Radio Writers Guild moved yesterday to extend to Chicago its three-day-old strike against the major networks.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, July 5 -- United States warplanes shot down twelve Communist MIG's and left a huge Red military headquarters near the Yalu River a flaming ruin in a Fourth of July raid, the Air Force announced today. F-86 Sabre jets destroyed twelve of the 115 Red planes that tried to break up the attack by F-84 Thunderjet fighter-bombers.

NEW DELHI, July 4 -- Rebutting Communist allegations that India, by accepting United States aid under the Mutual Security Act. had become an "American stooge," Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru implied to Parliament today that the New Delhi and Washington administrations were together on the relation of individual liberty and free institutions to sound economic conditions throughout the world.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, July 4 -- Danish circles, commenting on Washington's protest against the sale of strategic materials to the Soviet Union, said today that the keel of a second tanker contracted for by the Russians had been laid recently at shipbuilding yards in Copenhagen.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- The United States, which now has 47,000,000 children under 18 years of age and last year produced the largest number of babies in its history, is lagging in its efforts to give these youngsters the best start in life, according to a report just issued by the Public Affairs Institute.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, Eng., July 4 (UP) -- The University of Pennsylvania's undefeated 150-pound crew gained the semi-finals of the Thames Challenge Cup competition today in the Royal Henley regatta. Tabor Academy of Marion, Mass., was eliminated by the University of London -- Britain's top hope for the Olympic eight-oared rowing events.

ABOARD THE LINER UNITED STATES, At Sea, July 4 -- A world's record for liner speed fell to the American merchant marine today as the new superliner United States steamed eastward along the Atlantic sea lanes so long dominated by other maritime powers.

It is reported that the foreign policy plank of the Republican platform contains a declaration favoring the unification of Europe. Whether the plank as a whole will obtain the expected agreement of the opposing candidates depends on many factors besides the wording of the statement.

CHICAGO, July 4 -- The Dewey Republican organization in New York State is at work trying to whittle down some of the pro-Taft strength in the New York State delegation, which will arrive in force here tomorrow and early Sunday.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 4 -- Despite thunder showers early in the evening a crowd of 18,497 turned out tonight to watch the opening of the Nassau Trotting Association's thirty-six-day meeting at Roosevelt Raceway. The highlight was the $3,500 Class A Independence Pace and it was featured by a thrilling finish in which Express Hal staved off last-second charges by Paige Direct and the favored Prince Adios.

A concert devoted to the music of Kern and Hammerstein will be one of the features of the forth-coming week of concerts at Lewisohn Stadium. It will be given on Saturday evening, July 12, and will be the first such event in Stadium history.
PARIS, June 30 (by Airmail) -- Wicker, for furnishing suburban homes, has caught the imagination of French decorators now displaying at the Salon des Artistes Decorateurs.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 4 -- Filming will get under way Monday in Mexico on two versions of "Robinson Crusoe" in the Spanish and English languages. Luis Bunuel, who last year won first prize for direction at the film festival in Cannes with "Los Olvidados," has been working for two years in conjunction with Phillip Ansel Roll, the scenarist, in preparing the classic for the screen.
Librarians were urged last night to offer leadership in the field of liberal adult education and to protect America's heritage against enemies of free communication.

CHICAGO, July 4 -- Following are the texts of the messages exchanged by Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., campaign manager for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, and former President Herbert Hoover, and Mr. Hoover's telegram to Guy George Gabrielson, chairman of the Republican National Committee:

RALEIGH, N. C., July 4 (AP) -- Troy Ruttman of Lynwood, Calif., winner of the Memorial Day Indianapolis classic, won the 200-mile Southern Speedway A. A. A. championship race by two laps today. Jack McGrath of Los Angeles was second.

LONDON, July 4 -- About a hundred volunteers are undergoing "noise tests" each week here at the National Physical Laboratory, where physicists are trying to evaluate new units of noisiness based on the relationship between the loudness of different sounds and their energy and frequency content.

Mayor Impellitteri has let July 1 pass without a general increase in the transit fare, which by law can only be changed on that date. This chosen course of inaction will cause serious fiscal damage to the city.

BONN, Germany, July 4 -- West German Government leaders and the Allied High Commissioners are hoping the Saar issue will not explode again before next Wednesday when the first reading of ratification legislation of the Bonn peace contract with the Western Allies and the European Defense Community Treaty will take place in the Bundestag.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 4 (AP) -Seventeen-year-old Jody Alderson of the Chicago Town Club won the women's 100-meter free-style swimming tryouts for the Olympics today in a finish so close it took officials twenty minutes to say the winner.

CALGARY, July 4 (Canadian Press) -- Oil editor C. V. Myers of the Calgary Albertan said last night that Canadian Gulf Oil Company may have found the fourth major oil field in Alberta by making the province's thirteenth oil discovery so far this year.
CHICAGO, July 4 --The Glorious Fourth passed at convention headquarters without pyrotechnical incident, except of the ideological variety.

BUENOS AIRES, July 4 -- The entire Argentine nation went on a half-day holiday this afternoon as an act of homage to the seriously ill wife of the President, Senora Eva Peron, as the Senate passed a bill authorizing the erection of a huge marble and bronze monument to her in this city and replicas of it in each provincial state and territorial capital.

The Society of St. Vincent de Paul in the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York will begin its annual appeal a week from tomorrow for funds to support its free summer camp for children of poor families and its free all-year convalescent home for women.

Officials of the Liberian Government have opened negotiations with representatives of the Liberian Mining Company, Ltd., whose majority stockholder is the Republic Steel Corporation, for increased payments on iron ore mined in the large and rich Bomi Hills concession opened last year forty-five miles northeast of Monrovia, the seaport capital of the West African country.
SARANAC INN, N. Y., July 4 (AP) -- Three electrical concerns received safety awards today from the New York State Association of Electrical Contractors and Dealers.

A group of five eight-family houses on plot 130 by 80 feet at 567 to 579 St. John's Place, Brooklyn, has been sold by Milton Spitz to Helen Schwan and Daisy Hirsch for investment in a deal negotiated by the Lane Realty Company, brokers. The property is assessed at $104,000 and was sold subject to ten mortgages amounting to $83,600.
LONDON, July 4 (Reuters) -- The Canadian dollar took another upward leap today, the most spectacular one of any day since it started its rise last December, bringing the currency to a new high.
CHICAGO, July 4 (AP) -- Paul Bailey rode long shots to surprising victories today in stake races before a crowd of 34,330 at Arlington Park.

No one can quarrel with the the sentiment expressed on Thursday by Chairman Gabrielson of the Republican National Committee when he said: "As Republicans we must go to the American people with clean hands." But just how clean are the hands of those who have been manipulating the Republican National Committee to produce unearned convention votes for Senator Taft?

In his last Presidential report on the United Nations Mr. Truman warns against the "voices of despair" which would seize on the shortcomings of that organization to scuttle it and "go it alone." The United Nations, he declares, is the best means available to our generation to achieve peace despite the dangers posed by the Kremlin's policies of subversion, intimidation and conquest.

May I add several comments to the recent report of the hearing before the city affairs committee of the City Council concerning Councilman Edward Vogel's resolution to provide free choice of a non-profit medical prepayment insurance plan for all city employes.

WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) -- Senate-House conferees on the legislative budget bill reached an agreement today to exempt from income taxes the first $3,000 of the Washington living expenses of members of Congress.

The International Association of Machinists (A. F. L.) and the United Automobile Workers Union (C. I. O.) have set a good example to their labor brethren by renewing their no-raiding pact which was first signed in 1949. Under this arrangement each union agreed to respect the other's contracts and, what is equally important, formulated standards of fair competition for organizing campaigns in which both seek to gain members.
LONDON, July 4 (UP) -- Independence Day was celebrated by American colonies in many parts of Europe.

Eleven students from the University of California in Los Angeles, four women and seven men, celebrated Independence Day here yesterday by being briefed at International House, 500 Riverside Drive, on an eight-week tour of India to contribute to world peace.

CHICAGO, July 4 (UP) -- The White Sox tripped the Browns twice today, 3 -- 1 and 2 -- 0, with standout pitching before 30,118 fans to ring up a five-game winning streak and hold second place in the American League.

DETROIT, July 4 -- American schools were called upon today to teach about communism and all forms of totalitarianism. By a unanimous vote, the National Education Association approved an association platform that urged teachers to instruct their students about the practices of the Soviet Union and the Communist party in this country.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson's trip to Brazil. his first to Latin America, has been billed as an exhibition of the United States Government's continued interest in and friendship for its southern neighbors.
BOSTON, July 4 (UP) -- Good pitching went down the drain for the Phillies today as they lost their first double-header under Manager Steve O'Neill to the Braves, 2 to 1 and 3 to 2.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 4 (AP) -- Cary C. Boshamer's Late Model, racing as though she were right off the assembly line, drove to a hard-hitting victory today in the $15,000 Colleen Stakes feature at Monmouth Park.

PARIS, July 4 -- Speaking for the French steel industry, Pierre Ricard, vice president of the Steel Federation, said in an address here today that steel producers would cooperate with the Schuman plan but that it would be necessary to defend the French steel and coal industries as the treaty for merging their production with that of five other countries took shape.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 4 -There was a wind of remarkable sailing quality today for the annual regatta of the 77-year-old Larchmont Yacht Club. Strange in direction as it was, it came from due south and held steady while two squalls made up and went on their way out over Connecticut.

NEWARK, July 4 -- Somewhat incredulously four physicians -- two husbands and their wives -- went about their routine today as internes and staff members of Beth Israel Hospital here, 4,000 miles from the German concentration camps in which all had been prisoners.

OTTAWA, July 4 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian Government appears to be using a huge and expanding foreign-exchange fund to put the brakes on any spectacular climb by the Canadian dollar above its current high perch.

CHICAGO, July 4 -- Saying that he had come to Chicago as a peacemaker, Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr. of Massachusetts today warned supporters of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio and General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, the leading contenders for the Republican nomination for President, that if they permitted the fight for the nomination to become too bitter, it would endanger the election of the candidate chosen by the national convention.

BERLIN, July 4 -- A keynote speech today by Ilya Ehrenburg, Soviet author and propagandist, before the World Peace Council confirmed the belief that an all-out campaign is being prepared to turn public opinion in the United States against rearmament.

A special dispatch in yesterday' edition 0f THE NEW YORK TIMEg. listing 'Irs. Eugene Meyer as one of the speakers before the National Education Association at its Thursday session in E)etroit, in-. advertently referred to her a chairman of the board of Th9 Washington Post. Mrs. Meyer iz not an officer of that newspaper, but is the wife of the chairman of the board.

PARIS, July 4 --Managers of Gen. Charles de Gaulle's Reunion of the French People (R. P. F.) threatened today the continued existence of the Cabinet of Premier Antoine Pinay in a move to reimpose party discipline on Gaullist Deputies whose votes have kept the Pinay Government afloat.

Jamie Coffman, a 28-year-old paraplegic woman who teaches crutch-walking and "activities of daily living" to disabled patients at the Institute of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation of the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center, left for Paris last night from the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.
CHICAGO, July 4 -- Following is the tentative program of the Republican National Convention opening Monday, all times given being Central daylight time. New York time is one hour later.

This week's upsurge in the stock market contrasts with one of the worst periods of depression in market history two decades ago. Next Tuesday will be the anniversary of the date when the low-point of the last big bear market was reached. The long downturn in prices that set in after the collapse of the market in 1929 ended on July 8, 1932.

Clinical studies with the new anti-TB drug called marsilid have led to the finding that, in addition to serving as one of the most effective agents discovered so far for combating tuberculosis of all types, it also promises to become a powerful weapon in the relief of pain.

BERLIN, July 4 -- The General Council of the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions adopted today a strongly worded resolution condemning the "brutal repression" of the labor movement in Tunisia.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- The Senate Labor Committee -- with Senator Robert A. Taft objecting -- urged the upper chamber to approve a modified fair employment practices commission bill today but its passage was promptly blocked.

Baseball's Glorious Fourth at the Polo Grounds ended on a soggy note as rain split the long awaited Giant-Dodger holiday twin bill squarely in the middle and washed the second half right down the drain to the bitter disappointment of 49,443, the National League's largest crowd of the year.

Westchester County Publishers, Inc., sold to Mildred and Rose Harnik the three-story office building on the south side of Main Street, 106 feet east of Spring Street, Ossining, N. Y., in a deal in which title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

Atsushi Miyagi, Japan's 20-year-old newcomer to international tennis, and Billy Talbert, captain of the United States Davis Cup team, moved into the semi-final round of the New York State clay court championships yesterday.

New Yorkers who wish to enjoy vacation pleasure at no cost, or at most for a nominal fee, can take advantage of the many facilities offered by the New York City public park system during the summer months. An enlarged staff of 1,476 employes supervises and conducts the daily activities and special events that mark the comprehensive program arranged for young and old.

Dorothy Sarnoff, who won the favor of the local theatre appraisers with her portrayal of Lady Thiang in "The King and I," is set for the important part of Jessica in the forthcoming production of "My Darlin' Aida," the Charles Friedman version of Verdi's opera, due on Broadway this fall.

MEXICO CITY, June 27 -- A new "city" to house the 400-year-old National University of Mexico is rising on the outskirts of Mexico City on a vast bed of lava rock spewed from the Ajusco volcano 2,000 years ago.

CHICAGO, July 4 (AP) -- The Government yesterday filed a motion in Federal District Court naming 115 members of the du Pont family as individual defendants in an anti-trust suit against E. I. du Pont de Nemours Company and two corporations.

OAKLAND, Calif., July 4 -- The Giants wanted Hal Gregg, a no-hit hurler, so badly that they recently gave Oakland's Pacific Coast League club $35,000 and three players for him. Last night, Roger Bowman, one of those three players, pitched a no-hitter.

An American lawyer, Robert T. Bryan, has just reached Hong Kong after his release from sixteen months in a Red Chinese jail in Shanghai. He was held incommunicado and no charges against him were ever made public. He went through the usual "interrogation."

In a recent editorial you expressed disappointment over the results of the latest municipal elections in Italy. In fact, while the Communists have held their positions, the neo-Fascists have grown considerably stronger at the expense of the democratic center.

A new edition of "Shakespeare: The Complete Works," prepared for the general reader by G. B. Harrison, will b published on Aug. 7 by Harcourt, Brace. The volume contains a separate introduction to each play and poem, a general introduction with factual records of the playwright's life and a description of the England of his day.
CHICAGO, July 4 -- Women's role in the nation's politics -- as far as the Republicans go -- is stronger than ever before.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio asserted here today he had been told that General of the Army Douglas MacArthur would not reject the Republican Vice Presidential nomination if Mr. Taft headed the ticket.

CHICAGO, July 4 -- A bid for the farm vote through an attack on crop controls rather than an attempt to outbid the Democrats on high price supports was decided upon today by Republican farm leaders seeking to write an agricultural plank for the G. O. P. platform.

A vacant plot of land measuring 126 by 100 feet on the east side of Queens Boulevard, 120 feet south of Seventy-sixth Road, Forest Hills, Queens, was sold by Seven Santini Brothers, Inc., warehousemen, to the Jacelain Realty Corporation, which insured title with the City Title Insurance Company.

LONDON, July 4 -- Oliver Lyttelton, Colonial Secretary, delighted the American Society's Fourth of July dinner tonight with a story illustrating the difficulties affecting United States and British relations.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 4 -- Frank Sedgman won the All-England lawn tennis championship today, the first Australian to do so since 1933, and Maureen Connolly and Louise Brough will meet in an All-California women's final tomorrow.

Ever since August of 1950, the Greentree Stable trainer, John Gaver, has shuddered just a bit every time mention was made of the fact that Greentree paid $75,000 for Northern Star. Well, sir, it's time for Gaver to shake himself of the habit.

GOSHEN, N. Y., July 4 (AP) -Star's Pride, owned by L. B. Sheppard of Hanover, Pa., and E. Roland Harriman of Goshen, won the first heat of the $10,000 Titan free-for-all trot today before rain postponed the finish of the Grand Circuit program at Historic Track.

An electrical storm that rushed across the metropolitan area late yesterday afternoon drenched Fourth of July visitors here and at near-by resorts, ended their holiday celebrations early and created congestion on numerous roads as they started home.

BOSTON, July 4 -- Business and professional women of the country refused today for the second day to endorse measures concerning women in the armed services. They voted down support of legislation to keep mothers of minor children on reserve status in the armed services.
WASHINGTON, July 4 -- The House of Representatives approved tonight the final draft of a $46,610,938,912 military appropriations bill, biggest money measure of the session.

BLOOMINGDALE, N. J., July 4 -- Edward E. Leach, 63 years old,I head of the Leach Storage Ware-[ ihouses, Montclair, died of a cere-] ibral hemorrha,e and Mrs. Erminia] ,Gigante, 25, of Brooklyn drowned at 2:20 P. M. today as they at-' tempted to rescue a 5-year-old boy from Glen Wilde Lake.

ON WARREN TRAIN, En Route to Chicago, July 4 -- Gov. Earl Warren, without mentioning personalities, today took the side of the Dwight D. Eisenhower forces in the fight over whether disputed delegations from Texas, Louisiana and other states should vote on the floor of the Republican National Convention on the seating of one another.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 4 -- The Netherlands Navy announced today that it had contracted for four submarines of a revolutionary three-cylinder design claimed to be lighter, faster and deadlier than all existing models.

ON EISENHOWER TRAIN, En Route to Chicago, July 4 -- Traveling through Iowa today, General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower stepped up the attack on "corruption" in the camp of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio that he began yesterday in Colorado and Nebraska.

CHICAGO, July 4 -- A domestic platform adhering generally to the political philosophy of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio appears likely to be presented to the Republican National Convention on Monday by its Resolutions Committee.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- President Truman last night signed the Celler Bill, making it possible for child actors under the age of 14 to appear professionally in this city. His signature opens the way for the National and Gayety Theatres here to book such current New York hits as "The King and I," "Mrs. McThing" and "South Pacific."

SAN JUAN, P. R., July 4 -- Gov. Luis Munoz Marin, after reviewing a two-and-a-half-hour military and civic parade today, told a crowd that police estimated at 35,000, and hundreds of thousands of others listening to the radio, that President Truman's signature yesterday of the Congressional act creating the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico signaled the emergence of this island from colonial status.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 4 (UP) -- California's $300,000,000 fruit crop is threatened by the forty-day-old West Coast shipping tie-up and processing plants may be forced to shut down altogether if the strike continues, an industry spokesman said today.
CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, July 4 -- Just before his train stopped here tonight, General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower issued this statement:

With performances that augur well for the United States' chances at Helsinki, Clarke Scholes of Michigan State and Wayne Moore of the New Haven Swim Club yesterday won the first two events of the final men's Olympic swimming tryouts in the 50-meter pool of Flushing Meadow Amphitheatre.

MEXICO CITY, July 4 -- Mexico's long and comparatively tranquil election campaign closed today with the usual expressions of confidence by the four candidates from whom a new President will be chosen Sunday along with a Congress of fifty-eight Senators and 166 Deputies.

WASHINGTON, July 4 (UP) -- Senator Guy M. Gillette, Democrat of Iowa, said today his Senate Elections subcommittee would make a further study of the charges Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin and William Benton, Democrat of Connecticut, have made against each other.
Your editorial "Mr. Taft Can't Win -- I" is well reasoned, but since it takes no account of the real political forces at work the argument is vitiated throughout.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, July 4 -- Sir Gerald Templer, High Commissioner and supreme commander of the armed forces in the Federation of Malaya, announced today that June had been a record month of successes in Malaya's fight against Communist insurgents.
In theory, every man, woman and child in the United States drank 17.1 gallons of beer last year. This statistic was presented yesterady in the eleventh annual editio of The Brewing Industry Survey.

VINCENT SHEEAN'S "Rage of the Soul" is an uncommonly stimulating novel of ideas and the splendor that Scott Fitzgerald said happens in the heart. Your reviewer approached "Rage of the Soul" warily. It bleakly seemed to promise another somber tussle between India's sacred faiths and the West's wicked rowdiness.

Anxieties over world economic and political problems, together with spiritual approaches to them, will be discussed in a series of ten Sunday morning addresses at the Rensselaerville (N. Y.) Presbyterian Church, starting tomorrow.

One of those rare occasions when banks want to give money away to the right people is near. They are anxious to do so and are now preparing lists of persons they will pay it to if they can locate them.

A record 76,753,000 tons of cargo, 4,144,000 tons more than in 1950, moved through the Suez Canal last year on 11,694 ships. Yet net profits of the Suez Canal Company fell from $46,000,000 in 1950 to $39,000,000 in 1951, according to statistics made public at the company's annual meeting in Paris.

Only "fair to average" holiday business was reported in Broadway movie houses yesterday. It was notable that, for the first holiday in a long time, the Radio City Music Hall had no morning street- line outside, but attendance there began to pick up in the early afternoon.
Restaurant chains and independents here and throughout the rest of the country are building up new departments which sell meals for home consumption.
Mrs. Morris Hammer, 74 years old and five feet tall, was in critical condition at Bellevue Hospital last night after a beating by a six-foot burglar who invaded her apartment at 24 Avenue C.

A free Czechoslovak Parliament in exile, to speak for "the enslaved peoples at home," was set up yesterday by the reorganized Council of Free Czechoslovakia at a constituent meeting at the Pierre Hotel, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-first Street.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- President Truman signed into law today a measure enabling the Government to spend about $2,000,000 over the next five years for the development of a process for purifying, on a large-scale, salt or brackish water.
DETROIT, July 4 (UP) -- Early Wynn pitched a two-hitter and Bob Lemon a five-hitter as the Indians swept to a double victory over the Tigers, 11 -- 0 and 10 -- l, today before 40,035.

LONDON, July 4 -- London newspapers discovered a little belatedly today that there was no point to all the fuss in the Commons Wednesday about the alleged indiscretion of Field Marshal Earl Alexander's remarks about the United Nations reserves in Korea.
PUSAN, Korea, Saturday, July 5 -- President Syngman Rhee won principal points of his long battle with the National Assembly yesterday, apparently ending the grave political crisis in South Korea.

ALTHOUGH the matter has received little thought and no research by the writer, he believes that the literature on frogs is on the meager side. Since such a large portion of the population is within hearing disstance of frogs this week-end, some observations by Clayt Seagears of the New York State Conservation Department on the bullfiddles of the ponds are passed along.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 4 -- In speeches to both houses of the Brazilian Congress today, Secretary of State Dean Acheson again proclaimed the United States desire for unity of all the American peoples on a footing of equality for mutual defense against communism.

These are the days when summer brings a fortnight's holiday from the daily stint, when sons, prodigal or otherwise, often return to the old homestead with their sons, to spend a week or so fattening up on mother's cooking and being filled in on such local news as has not found its way into letters exchanged since the last meeting.

WORCESTER, Mass., July 4 -- Navy's eight-oared crew withstood a stirring challenge from California in winning a semi-final heat of the Olympic rowing trials on Lake Quinsigamond today. Both qualified for tomorrow's final. The margin between the two crews as they beat Wisconsin was a scant three feet.

A one-story taxpayer building at 909-13 East Tremont Avenue in the Bronx was sold by the estate of William Sandler to 911 Associates, Inc., for investment in a deal negotiated by George R. Read Co., brokers. It is assessed at $60,000 and had been owned by the sellers for many years.

CHICAGO, July 4 -- Supporters of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower today claimed at least 650 delegates who would vote for the amendment of the rules of the Republican National Convention to prevent any delegate on the temporary roll, whose seat was contested, to vote for the seating of any contested delegate or delegation.

CHICAGO, July 4 -- The Republican National Committee voted 60 to 41 tonight to split the contested Texas delegation to give Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio twenty-two delegates and General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower sixteen in the contest for the Republican Presidential nomination.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 4 -- Encouraged by United States pressure for anti-Communist labor unity, the International Federation of Christian Trade Unions at its eleventh triennial congress, renewed today its appeal to the much larger International Confederation of Free Trade Unions for an alliance without a merger.

THE Smoky Mountain country begins at the Virginia-Kentucky state line and stretches through eastern Tennessee and western North Carolina to the north border of Georgia. It has such place names as Dirty John Creek, Burnt Shirt Mountain, Mammy and Daddy Creeks, Loafers Glory Village, Broken Leg, Raw Dough, Happy Hollow, Greasy Branch, Little Bullet and Gouge Eye.
LATEST available count of the number of books about General Eisenhower -- 8.

The Arctic Institute of North America, Washington, D. C., announces the publication of "Science in Alaska," a collection of papers edited by Henry B. Collins of the Smithsonian Institution. Among the subjects covered are agriculture, anthropology, zoology, public health and medicine, botany, geology and geography. "Science in Alaska" surveys in one volume the accomplishments of science in a part of the world not usually associated with research.

PHILADELPHIA, July 5 (AP) -- Kid Gavilan, iron-jawed veteran of ninety-eight pro fights, will risk his world welterweight title Monday night against unbeaten Gil Turner, 21-year-old Philadelphian, in a fifteen-round bout at Municipal Stadium.

FOR the first quarter of this century, fictional murder occurred almost exclusively among the glamorous and ostentatiously overwealthy upper classes Then, in a healthy reaction, the pulp writers of the "Black Mask" school tried to bring murder, in Raymond Chandler's words, "back to the people who are really good at it," and abandoned the penthouse for the gutter.

WELLAND, Ont., July 5 (UP) -- Miss Betty Haas crossed the finish line in the All-Women's International Air Race championship three minutes ahead of her nearest rival today in her all-out effort to recapture the title she won two years ago.

CHICAGO, July 5 -- Calumet Farm's sensational 3-year-old filly, Real Delight, today added the $52.550 Arlington Matron Stakes to her string of major victories with a two-and-one- half-length victory over Bella Figura, owned by Brownell Combs of Lexington, Ky.

A SNAPSHOT of his friend at the helm of their sailboat won a total of $600 in cash for Alvin McMillin in the 1952 National High School Photographic Awards of the National Scholastic Press Association. Young McMillin, a senior at the Junction City High School in Junction City, Kan., took the $400 grand prize with this picture plus a $200 first prize in one of the classifications.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (UP) -- The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that the Taft-Hartley Act prohibited an employer from locking out his workers to force them to accept his terms in contract bargaining.

The political storm clouds that have hovered over the Government of the Republic of Korea for the past six weeks have lifted. President Syngman Rhee and his opponents have agreed on a compromise in their bitter clash, and it has already cleared the atmosphere.

PRESTWICK, Scotland, July 5 -- Scotland's leading Brooklyn Dodger fan, Alastair (Butch) Forbes, got back from a week's stay with the National League leaders today sporting a blue baseball cap and a new ambition.

CHICAGO, July 5 -- The Republican National Committee adopted several changes in the party rules today and formalized procedures for handling delegate contests at future conventions. The changes are subject to approval by the convention, which opens on Monday.

IN recent years Horatio, Lord Hornblower, has superseded Horatio, Lord Nelson, in the public consciousness. Truth, however, continues to be stranger than fiction, and also more dramatic. C. S. Forester's creations, measured against Nelson and his Emma, seem no more than pallid outlines. No writer would dare to offer them as invented characters.

FRANKFURT, Germany, July 5 (Reuters) -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, who brought Nazi Germany to its knees, now has become the favorite son of West Germans watching the race for the Republican Presidential nomination.

FOR more than fifty years Americans have been singing a ballad about the heroism of Casey Jones. So it is fitting that this superb collection of true railroad stories should start with the account of Casey Jones' courage in one of the most historic railroad wrecks of all time. We learn, incidentally, that the renowned Mr. Jones' real name was John; but he hailed from Cayce, Ky. -- hence his nickname.

TRENTON, July 5 -- The New Jersey Highway Authority, newly created to construct and operate the Garden State Parkway, has plans for immediate completion of a fifty-one-mile stretch designed to yield an annual average of $8,000,000 in tolls.
TOKYO, Sunday, July 6 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,302 for the twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M., Sunday, Korea time:
DETROIT, July 5 (UP) -- Southpaw Bill Wight made Fred Hutchinson's managerial debut a success tonight by pitching the Tigers to a 5-0 victory over the Browns.

MOVIE audiences will have an opportunity within a few months to witness the first feature-length three-dimensional motion picture, "Bwana Devil," an African adventure story written, directed and produced by Arch Oboler in association with the Natural Vision Corporation, developers of a refined stereoscopic photographic process.
CHICAGO, July 5 (AP) -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower disclosed today that he was going to ignore some pointers in the art of public speaking by Prime Minister Winston Churchill.
CHICAGO, July 5 -- Never before has the world been so fascinated by an American political convention as it is by the meeting of the Republican party that starts here on Monday.

MEXICO CITY. ALTHOUGH the Good Neighbor policy has been in effect since 1933, Mexico has never developed any warmth of feeling for the United States. To an extent startling to the newcomer. Mexicans do not like Americans. Mexican Government policy is certainly not unfriendly to the United States.
Two patrolmen went hunting on the "tar beaches" of the Bronx yesterday and in the line of duty captured a twenty-fire-pound opossum.

CHICAGO, July 5 -- John Bugas, vice president of the Ford Motor Co. in charge of personnel, sent a telegram today to all members of the important forty-six-vote Michigan delegation to the Republican National Convention urging them to vote for the nomination of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower.
The adjournment of the Eighty-second Congress, which failed even to debate, let alone enact, a single civil rights measure, emphasizes the miserable record of the Congress in this area.

MONTREAL, July 5 -- A seven-year struggle to rid the Canadian labor movement of a powerful, militant Communist bloc in the 15,000-member United Textile Workers of America, A. F. L., came to a dramatic end last night in a vote that virtually wiped out one of the last trade union bastions of the Communist movement in Canada.

THE worst mosquito invasion in three decades is about to beset the metropolitan area, according to expert intelligence. It is based, as usual, on New Jersey. Defending forces, which in the course of the thirty years' war have progressed from the use of "punk" to DDT and from flivvers to helicopters, were betrayed by the heavy spring rains.

DETROIT, July 5 (AP) -- Dr. Cary Middlecoff fired three straight birdies on the back nine today to take a one-stroke lead over Ted Kroll at the three-quarter mark of the $15,000 Motor City open golf tournament.

THE chances are that few working newspaper men in New York have trained around Broadway and the East Side with the impassioned intensity or the splendid aloofness of Robert Sylvester, who works for the drama department of one of the tabs on the other side of town and turns his night experiences into novels instead of frittering them away over the match game.

NEW MILFORD, N. J., July 5 -- The New Jersey Audubon Society's center at 796 River Road here, which has shown thousands of persons how to attract birds to their homes and served as a haven for scores of injured birds, may have to close for lack of funds.

AS the first of the intelligent quiz shows on radio, "Information Please" always has enjoyed a special niche in the affections of that section of the listening audience which somehow had been dimly aware that Washington's first name was George. Since it left the air some years ago a great many of the program's friends have repeatedly asked when the show would turn up on television.

SIX years, eight leading concert artists, the life of Sol Hurok and $2,500,000 have just been sewn up in a big musical production called "Tonight We Sing," which its producer, George Jessel, admits will appeal only to specialized audiences. "Movies as mass entertainment don't exist any more," he says, "so we're finally allowed to make a picture for adults -- even for music lovers!"

WALTER BARYLLI has frequently turned up recently on the Westminster label, both as violin soloist and as the leader of a string quartet that bears his name. He has never appeared personally in this country, but when he does he will almost be an old friend.

Plans are almost complete for a testimonial luncheon to be given by the members of the International Longshoremen s Association, A. F. L., to Joseph P. Ryan in honor of his twenty-five years of service as their president.

CHICAGO, July 5 -- Industrial expansion in the Chicago area continued to taper off as June commitments of $7,662,000 reached the lowest monthly mark for the year. However, the total compared with $7,555,000 for the same month last year and with $21,120,000 in June, 1950.

The increasing popularity of golf hereabouts is reflected in the Metropolitan Golf Association's disclosure yesterday that nearly 4,500 members -- a record figure -- have been given handicaps. A year ago, the handicap list contained 2,862 names. When the tabulation was revised last September, the number jumped to 3,498.

SAN FRANCISCO -- Being members of the genus tourist, transcontinental motorists arriving in California from the Eastern Seaboard usually find their wanderlust unsatisfied. Whether they land in Los Angeles and make a dutiful tour of the adjacent film capital or buck traffic from the Donner Pass down to San Francisco for a stroll through Chinatown and a ride on the cable cars, their usual question is, "What next?"

PHILADELPHIA, July 5 -- Vic Raschi continued his mastery over the Athletics today when, before a ladies' day gathering of 12,015, the big Yankee right-hander spun his tenth straight vic tory against Jimmy Dykes' crew. The count was 3 to 1. In the seven seasons he has been with the Yankees Raschi has lost to the Athletics twice.

The nation's attention last week was fixed on the fight over contested delegates and the bitterness it aroused. The hard mathematics of the contest on the eve of the convention explains both the fight and the bitterness. There are 1,206 delegates. According to the final Associated Press count, here's where they stand no:

CONCORD, N. H. -- New Hampshire's official Recreation Division estimates that this year the state's parks will attract at least 2,000,000 visitors, which is nearly four times the total of the state's permanent population. While this figure includes wintertime skiers at Cannon Mountain and Mount Sunapee, by far the greater percentage of vacationists visits the parks, historical sites and wayside areas during the summer.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 5 (AP) -- Gail Peters, 22-year-old Washington swimmer, bettered the American women's record for the 200-meter breast-stroke today in final tryouts for the United States Olympic swimming team.

WASHINGTON, Sunday, July 6 -- The Eighty-second Congress was still in session at 4 o'clock this morning, having been thwarted in its efforts to adjourn sine die by unexpected complications involving the nation's expanded atomic energy program.

CHICAGO, July 5 -- Gov. Earl Warren of California arrived here tonight with a warning to party colleagues that the November Presidential election could be won or lost by the way the Republican National Convention was conducted next week.

IN 1943, Simone Weil, who was possibly a saint and certainly a genius, offered her services to her compatriots of the Free French Committee in London. Momentarily embarrassed (what can a committee do with a saintly genius?), they finally had the happy idea of asking her to write a report on why France collapsed in 1940 and how French society might be reconstructed after the war.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 5 -- Sitting became the only thing to do for the most part in the regatta of the New York Yacht Club today out on Long Island Sound. And sitting on hot decks for hours in a broiling sun and no breeze is no fun for any one.
BUENOS AIRES, July 5 (AP) -- The Diligenti quintuplets, now in their eighth year, have been sent to five English boarding schools -- separated for disciplinary reasons.

PROGRESS in American rail transportation having been postally noted with a stamp issued a few months ago for the 125th anniversary of the granting of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad's charter in 1827, the over-the-highways freight haulers now are seeking a similar honor.

CLEVELAND, July 5 -- Unemployment in Cleveland industrial plants as a result of strikes and vacations is now estimated at more than 100,000 and another 50,000 will be added for vacation reasons next week. The City Relief Division and Soldiers Relief Commission report the heaviest demand for relief since the United Steelworkers of America strike in 1949.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 5 -- Returning to action after a one-month layoff, Clair Weaver's Rena Grattan from Harrisburg, Pa., set a new season's record for aged pacing mares when she covered the mile in 2:02 4/5 to gain a nose decision over Sycamore.

HEARING that the original portrait of what is probably the best known dog in the world was in America on a brief visit, we hot-footed it over to RCA-Victor to see the painting of that black-and-white canine who listens attentively to "His Master's Voice."

MEXICO CITY, July 5 -- Charges and counterchanges of attempted or impending fraud flew across the Mexican political scene today on the eve of balloting to elect a new President and Congress. The calm that had marked the wind-up of the long, bitter campaign appeared to be giving way to uneasy tension as the hour of voting tomorrow approached.

THERE has been a good deal of excitement over James C. Petrillo's latest foray into the headlines. On the surface the issue is whether Americans, members of the American Federation of Musicians, shall be permitted to make records abroad. Below the surface the problem is graver; it involves the economic status of the American musician, especially the symphonic instrumentalist.

The Republican National Convention opens tomorrow under conditions of storm and stress such as have not been experienced within the party in forty years. Beneath the contest for the nomination is a deeper struggle that goes to the roots of the Republican party.

MARTHA'S VINEYARD -- Now that the Fourth is past, the summer season is really under way here on this magical New England island. Not that the Vineyard is overcrowded. It would take a mass migration from the mainland to accomplish that. But it is clearly vacation time.

QUITE the most exhilarating announcement that has yet been made about next year's activities is that of a brief season of modern dance to be given in a Broadway theatre next spring under the auspices of the newly formed B. de Rothschild Foundation for the Arts and Sciences.
THE air route pattern for American-flag carriers on the North Atlantic between the United States and Europe was settled for at least another seven years last week by the Civil Aeronautics Board.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- A myth that is firmly held and deeply cherished in many Democratic breasts is that the Republicans, if given half a chance, will always see to it that a Democrat gets to be elected President.

PARIS, July 5 -- Frenchmen had a dramatic reminder this week that the real headquarters and "privileged sanctuary" of the powerful French Communist party was in France's Parliament -- the National Assembly.

TOKYO, Sunday, July 6 -- The United Nations yesterday introduced a new delegate to the long-drawn-out Korean armistice talks at Panmunjom, Brig. Gen. Joseph T. Morris of Punxsutawney, Pa. His credentials were presented in the armistice tent, where the United Nations and Communist delegations met for more than an hour in secret session without announcement of further progress.

CHICAGO, July 5 -- Beneath the surface of circus antics and juvenile horseplay that invests all political conventions in the United States there is a stratum of grim and possibly even lethal conflict here as the Republican party delegates are about to meet to write a platform and choose their nominees for President and Vice President.

CHICAGO, July 5 -- The nation has been hearing and reading for months -- possibly to a greater extent than ever before -- of the delegates who are now assembled in Chicago to make the Republican nomination for President. It has heard the rival claims of how these delegates will vote, and earlier it followed with interest the battles between the Presidential candidates to obtain delegates in the various states favorable to each particular cause.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, July 5 -- Weather conditions permitting, the United States Army Corps of Engineers will conclude a three-year series of underground explosion tests Tuesday with a huge blast of 320,000 pounds of T. N. T., deep in a sandstone cliff at isolated Buckhorn Wash, near Castle Dale, Utah.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (UP) -- The National Labor Relations Board today stepped up its investigation of charges that the "big six" steel companies formed an illegal conspiracy to block single company contract agreements with the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif. FUCHSIAS are truly one of the flowers which bloom here in a profusion almost unbelievable to a gardener from the East. An eight-foot hedge or shrub is quite likely to be some kind of fuchsia, and standards or tree types are common. Upright plants flower in pots and window boxes, in the open ground and lath houses; trailing kinds smother hanging pots with pendent bloom.

BOSTON, July 5 -- Victory for the Braves over the Dodgers this season is still to come. The Brooks made it twelve straight over their Back Bay "cousins" tonight, 5 -- 3, thus becoming the first club in the majors to clinch a season's series. The season's largest crowd here, 13,405, saw the game.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Foliage of spring-flowering bulbs, even narcissus, has turned yellow, and only a slight tug is needed to pull it out of the ground. Foliage may be added to the compost heap, bulbs left to bloom next year. Store bulbs forced indoors last winter in a cool, dry and dark place. Most of them will come up next spring if planted outdoors in the fall.
PRINCETON, N. J., July 5 --More than 300 clergymen and laymen will attend the Princeton Institute: of Theology opening here on Monday at the Princeton Theological Seminary.

CHICAGO, July 5 -- There has been a lot of noise at the Republican convention here this week, a lot of it distincly unpleasant. But in the last analysis it proves very little that everybody did not know last Monday, namely:

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, July 5 -- Trygve Lie, secretary general of the United Nations, who was here today en route from Vienna to his native Norway on a holiday, said at a press conference that he felt abused when asked about bacteriological warfare.

BIGGEST, or, anyway, most firmly entrenched institution out at Jones Beach, aside from the Atlantic Ocean and Robert Moses (not necessarily in that order), is the Thursday night square dance put on right through the summer and the first two Thursdays in September in the music shell from a quarter to 9 to a quarter to 12.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 5 -- The Schuman Plan for pooling the coal and steel resources of six West European countries is expected to begin functioning early in 1953, a competent authority said today on the conclusion of the meeting here of a commission of high-ranking officials of each country concerned.

ABOUT 1848 a Philadelphia gunmaker, Henry Deringer, well known for the excellence of his rifles and dueling pistols, produced the first real pocket-gun in firearms history. True, Samuel Colt's "Baby Paterson" appeared in 1839, and the "pepperbox," the multi-barrel handgun which is the subject of Lewis Winant's excellent study, was a pocket weapon of sorts which antedated the Colt by more than a century.

A majority of the delegates from eastern states were headed aboard special trains for Chicago last night to participate in what is expected to be the hottest Republican National Convention since Theodore Roosevelt and his Bull Moose followers bolted another Republican convention in the same city in 1912.
CHICAGO, July 5 -- This is the way ninety-six delegate disputes have been settled by the Republican National Committee:

CLEVELAND, July 5 (AP) -- Joe Tipton's single with one out in the eleventh inning scored Al Rosen from second base with the Indians' winning run in a 3-2 victory over the White Sex tonight. The blow settled a pitching duel between Bob Feller and Joe Dobson and sent Cleveland into second place, toppling the White Sex to third.

CHICAGO, July 5 -- The Republican National Committee is under challenge as it has not been for years as the pro-Taft Old Guard, which it largely represents, struggles with the Eisenhower forces for control of the Republican National Convention.
CHICAGO, July 5 (AP) -- Today's prices of livestock reported by the Department of Agriculture follows:

DETROIT, July 5 -- The American teaching profession is greatly disturbed by the many attacks that have been directed at it in recent months. Teachers are accused of being "subversive" in some communities because they introduce material dealing with the United Nations or UNESCO (the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization) in the classroom. Textbooks which they have used for years suddenly are challenged as un-American.

The Parker Pen Company has proved that a fleet of corporate airplanes is a profitable investment, according to word from its headquarters in Janesville, Wis., where it maintains a fleet of three, with two full-time pilots. There is even an air operations office in the middle of its executive and sales building.
GENEVA, July 5 -- The International Red Cross conference that will open in Toronto on July 23 may mark the end of the organization, in the considered opinion of Red Cross officials here.

RIO DE JANIERO, July 5 -- The communist newspaper Imprensa Popular charged today that Secretary of State Dean Acheson was making specific demands that Brazil send troops to Korea. Mr. Acheson made his final formal calls today on President Getulio Vargas and Foreign Minister Joab Neves da Fontoura and Finance Minister Horacio Lafer but as far as can be learned he did not ask for troops.

The first two Marine Corps Reserve units from this area to depart for summer training left Pennsylvania Station yesterday afternoon for two weeks of exercises at Camp Lejeune, N. C. Both of the units, totaling 141 men, were from Brooklyn.

WITH an increasing number of summer vacationists motoring into Mexico, there should be wide interest in the highway, now nearing completion, leading south from Nogales, Ariz., to Guadalajara, Mexico. Extending over 1,108 miles, the road is largely hard surfaced, and taps an area where there are excellent accommodations.
MOUNT HOLLY, N. J., July 5 -- Tomorrow opens a week-long celebration of the 200th anniversary of the Relief Fire Company.

As was noted in this column last week, the money that American people have invested in medical research through Government, industry, philanthropy and our medical schools and hospitals has paid enormous dividends in better health.
