WHY did Mr. Shaw write this book? In reading it, you are struck by the lonely plaint of the man, by a resigned display of wounds unhealed, by the author's frantic groping toward an indefinable goal.

EL PASO, Tex., July 5 (UP) -- A former winner of the "powder puff" air derby led the field of sixty-four women today as she roared into this border city after a 4-hour 45-minute flight from Santa Ana, Calif.
METUCHEN, N. J., July 5 -- A drive to combine this borough with Raritan Township, from which it seceded in 1900, was opened this week.

Despite the holiday the market here was very busy last week as buyers tried to place orders for hot-weather goods which were hard to find, according to Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying offices. Manufacturers have been concentrating on fall and holiday lines, creating a shortage of promotional merchandise such as white handbags, sheer shirts, washdresses and play clothes.

Prices of cotton in the domestic market moved narrowly last week and ended the period with only slight net changes. At the end of trading on Thursday -- the market was closed both Friday in observance of Independence Day, and on Saturday as usual -- active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were 2 points higher to 13 points lower than the final prices of the preceding week.

TRENTON, July 5 -- Hostesses in colonial dress will greet visitors on the annual old house tour of the Cape May Art League next Friday. More than twenty historic homes and buildings in Cape May County, some dating to the Seventeen-Seventies, will be featured.

BONN, July 5 -- While the latest reply of the Western powers to the Soviet Union in the diplomatic exchanges on German unity is designed to leave an opening for the convening of a four-power conference, it is essential to recognize that the opening does not mean immediate willingness to hold elections.

The New York Public Library's concerts, now daily events, Mondays through Fridays behind the Fifth Avenue building in Bryant Park, will feature tomorrow a recording of Schubert's Trio No. 1 in B flat with Artur Rubinstein, pianist, Jascha Heifetz, violinist and Gregor Piatigorsky, 'cellist.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 5 (AP) -- Virtually everyone from the top sports officials to the Finns selling programs expect the Olympic games to develop into a duel between the United States and the Soviet.

THE Republican National Convention, opening tomorrow in the International Amphitheatre in Chicago, and the Democratic National Convention, opening on July 21, will receive the most complete and exhaustive television and radio coverage ever accorded such events.

The New York Telephone Company's "navy" is due to be replaced in the next month. Of course, it has been only a one-vessel task force over the last thirty-eight years, but its performance in laying many miles of cable on the bottom of Long Island Sound has merited repeated "well done" signals from the company's headquarters.

Travers Island may sometime drift back to normalcy but it will never be the same again. This is the home of the Yachting Department of the New York Athletic Club, which, during the coming tense few days, will finish preparations for its annual Long Island Sound yachting excitement.

THERE can be no doubt that one of the crucial issues in this year's Presidential campaign will be our foreign policy, with special emphasis on the Far East. The war in Korea, the burdens of rearmament and mutual security, not to speak of Congressional investigations into alleged Communist influences on our policy, make this inevitable, and the issues themselves are so complex and so important that they cry for further clarification.

Wilfred Pelletier returned to the podium of the N. B. C. Summer Symphony yesterday evening in the Belasco Theatre for the first of three broadcast concerts. His program consisted of Schubert's Second Symphony, Elgar's Introduction and Allegro and Rossini's "Semiramide" Overture?

In view of the recent adverse criticism of radio programs it seems some extensive remedial steps should be contemplated. I believe one solution to the enigma would be a nation-wide educational AM network. While there is much discussion of educational TV, it appears that the long-established and far-reaching AM is all but forgotten as anything but a so-called entertainment medium and outlet for commercial hoopla.

THE widespread use of DDT and even more powerful insect-killers has raised some serious problems in the field of wildlife management and conservation. Increasingly since the war, the new insecticides are being used with great success on hundreds of millions of acres of forests and farm, marshland and orchard; and there isn't any doubt that they are a potent weapon in man's battle against the insects.

Ninety-eight years ago today, several hundred men assembled "under the oaks" on Morgan's Forty just outside the village of Jackson, Mich., and resolved -- "in view of the imminent danger that Kansas and Nebraska will be grasped by slavery" -- to "cooperate and be known as 'Republicans'."

The market for floating new issues of state and municipal bonds appears to be geared to accept a new supply of $5,000,000,000 of bonds each year, Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., said yesterday in its annual mid-year survey of the municipal bond market. Further, the survey said that the market "should give a good account of itself during this election year."
DETROIT, July 5 (AP) -- Despite steel strikes, lay - offs, model changeovers and controlled materials programs, the auto industry still may build 4,500,000 passenger cars this year.
ABOARD THE LINER UNITED STATES, At Sea, July 5 -- This new superliner added to her laurels again today and raced on eastward across the Atlantic in a bid for the blue ribbon.
THERE'S an old story about the cattle baron who was accused of landgrabbing. "It's a lie," he snarled. "I don't want all the land in Texas; jist that that jines my place."

Jack Tuero, a former national intercollegiate champion, continued to make a strong bid in defense of his New York State clay court tennis crown yesterday. Playing at the Seminole Club in Forest Hills, the one-time Tulane star defeated Sidney Schwartz of Long Beach, L. I., 6 -- 4, 6 -- 3, 1 -- 6, 7 -- 5, to gain the final round.
LONDON, July 5 (AP) -- Bobby Locke of South Africa is a firm 3-to-1 favorite to win the British open golf championship on the tough, narrow Royal Lytham and St. Annes links. Play begins Monday.

CHICAGO, July 5 -- The Republican National Convention's Platform Subcommittee on Civil Rights gave emphasis to the sharp differences within its ranks today by filing both a majority and a minority report to the full Committee on Resolutions.
ROBERT SHAW, a man with a flair for the unusual, made a strictly unconventional entrance on the Hawaiian scene during May and June.

The Army's tank production program is "well under way" and this country can now produce tanks in "sufficient numbers and variety to meet any requirements," Lieut. Gen. Willis D. Crittenberger, First Army commander, declared yesterday.

ONE of the largest expositions of the season is scheduled to open in Portland, Me., on Sept. 5 and continue through Sept. 14. It is ambitiously called the Maine Event, and will be a combination exhibition and fair with more than two hundred displays.

A FASCINATING but little-known chapter in the dissemination of foreign music during the past decade is the administration by the Office of Alien Property (OAP) of hundreds of thousands of copyright interests. Of nearly $4,500,000 collected on all copyright properties seized (vested), $3,200,000 came from music alone.

TOLEDO, Ohio -- The western Lake Erie vacationland from Cleveland around the lower end of the lake to Toledo offers dozens of pleasant stopping places for the Eastern motorist who may have an extra day or two.

CHICAGO, July 5 -- Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee, a contender for the Democratic Presidential nomination, stepped tonight into the enemy camp in the Conrad Hilton Hotel, headquarters of the leading Republican Presidential aspirants, and denounced Republican efforts to select a Presidential candidate.

CHICAGO, July 5 -- Accorded a tumultuous welcome on his arrival at the scene of the Republican National Convention today, General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower stepped quickly into the oratorical affray with a forceful delineation of his views on the major needs of foreign and domestic policy.

TOKYO, July 5 -- The possibility of a truce in the Korean war through new secret sessions on the vexed issue of repatriation of war prisoners -- the last remaining obstacle in the path of a ceasefire -- has again brought up here consideration of the eventual fate of the Ryukyu and Bonin Islands and their relation to the newly sovereign and independent Japan.

WRITERS differ on what should be done to improve Congressional procedure. Some advocate an adaptation of the British parliamentary system. Others yearn for increased party discipline or propose reforms which they hope may make Congress more business-like.

FROM London comes word that Iceland will release 1.25-krona, 2.20k, 5k and 10k stamps in October in memory of Sveinn Bjoernsson (1881-1952), who died last January while serving his second term as President. His portrait will be the design.

Supported by the fencing, gymnastic, cycling, soccer and weightlifting teams, the crack United States Olympic track and field squad will give a final home-soil demonstration of might in record-trial competition at Triborough Stadium today.

THE marathon demonstrations held in New York this past week of the new Eidophor system for transmitting large-screen color television to theatres have left this interested observer somewhat skeptical, not as to the working of the system but as to what it can possibly add in the way of novelty and inspiration to the present esthetics of the screen.

CHICAGO, July 5 -- Republican strategists studied the Republican National Committee's roll-call vote on the Texas "compromise" today in an effort to discover any clues to the votes of the 1,206 convention delegates on the issue when the Eisenhower-Taft dispute over seating thirty-eight delegates is appealed to the convention floor.

IT is indeed gratifying to see historic justice done to the Venezuelan patriot and Precursor of Independence in South America, Francisco de Miranda, in Father Joseph Thorning's book, "Miranda: World Citizen."
WIMBLEDON, England, July 5 -- Hail to a new Queen of Wimbledon, the youngest American to be crowned All-England champion since May Sutton won in 1905.

ROANOKE, Va. -- Motorists traveling the Blue Ridge Parkway this summer will find that they can drive from the parkway's entrance in Virginia all the way to Asheville, N. C., on paved surface, except for five short sections which require slight detours.
CHICAGO, July 5 -- The Republican party's 1952 foreign-policy platform was put in final shape today.
NEW DELHI, India, July 5 (AP) -- The leader of a Swiss expedition that reached within 900 feet of Mt. Everest's summit said today that the world's highest mountain was growing higher every year.

" Man is by nature a political animal," said Aristotle, clearly foreshadowing twenty - three centuries ago the excitement now emanating from Chicago. If a national political convention has some elements of a circus, as has been asserted frequently, the political animal theory would appear to be confirmed.

Olin Downes' timely article ("The Rites of Stravinsky: 'Order in Art,'" June 15) from Paris on the occasion of Igor Stravinsky's seventieth birthday and his commentary that with the passing of years Stravinsky's musical output shows decided tendencies toward conservatism and a general mellowing brings to mind some curious coincidences.

AS a matter of both theory and style, the leading players try to keep the bidding low when they have good hands. They open with one-bids instead of two-bids; they make minimum suit responses and re-bids instead of jump bids. They consider it wasteful and even amateurish to "jump all over the place."

Summer workshops in intergroup relations -- to train teachers and community workers in ways to deal with interracial and religious problems -- will be held during July and August at twenty-three leading American universities in cooperation with the National Conference of Christians and Jews.

ABOARD THE LINER UNITED STATES, July 5 (AP) -- Deck-chair experts are predicting that the American liner and her 1,700 passengers will pass Bishop's Rock off the English coast before dawn Monday to shatter the Queen Mary's record by six to ten hours.

TORONTO, July 5 -- Experts are convinced that the all-Canadian St. Lawrence Seaway will pay for itself and privately they will admit that American ships and shippers may foot more of the bill than they expect.

STANTON, Del., July 5 (AP) -- Kiss Me Kate, a long striding daughter of Count Fleet, finally returned to the form that won her 1951 3-year-old honors today when she soundly defeated nine others of her sex in the $61,600 New Castle Handicap, the richest race ever run at Delaware Park.
GOSHEN, N. Y., July 5 (AP) -- Gene Hayes' fast-stepping chestnut gelding, Pronto Don, captured the $5,800 Titan free-for-all trot today as Grand Circuit racing closed at Historic Track.

CARACAS, Venezuela, June 27 -- Venezuelan writers and magazine publishers have begun an intense campaign to impose a tax on United States and other foreign magazines entering the country. A special "Chamber of Magazines" has been formed with the express purpose of "defending the interests of the local magazines" against the competition of the North Americans.

I DO not wish to dispute Erik H. Huneker's pronunciation of James Gibbons Huneker's name, but Huneker himself told me it was Hun-eh-ker*. I knew him very well from 1914 and saw him a great deal in Philadelphia in 1919-20 when he was writing "Steeplejack" as a column for The Philadelphia Press.

OUR Olympic athletes will depart for Helsinki by airplane this week in five chartered planes instead of one chartered boat, the final capitulation to this modern age of the Olympic Games that began in 776 B. C. with victory by Coroebus of Elis. But before our heroes take off into the wild, blue yonder they will be on display today in Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island.

The slogan "Pay by Check" is proving too successful. For years, throughout the nation, banks have been advertising the slogan intensively. Now, swamped by hundreds of millions of checks, it appears that they are being hard-pressed to keep up with the results of their own merchandising efforts.

CAPETOWN, July 5 -- The incipient revolt of non-whites against apartheid (separation of races) is symptomatic of the rising clash in Africa, particularly in the Union of South Africa, where trouble has long been brewing. Now about 140 volunteers -- the vanguard of what is claimed to be a much larger force -- have gone into action after thorough preparation in a Gandhi-style resistance campaign.

WASSENAAR, the Netherlands, July 5 -- The midway point has arrived in the current phase of negotiations between West Germany and delegations of Israel and world Jewish organizations on compensation for Nazi anti-Semitic acts. The German delegation is headed by Prof. Franz Josef Boehm in Bonn for consultations, and when talks resume Monday progress is expected to be speeded up.

In all probability not even the works of such great artists as Rembrandt, Leonardo da Vinci, or Michelangelo have been seen by as many persons as those of a present-day craftsman, James Harley (Jim) Nash, the noted package designer.

One of the most difficult of all sounds to put down on paper is the song of a bird. The primary reason, of course, is that vocal music is essentially a matter of vowel sounds with the consonants giving a familiar form rather than a sound of their own. Try to translate bird songs into recognizable words and you run into all kinds of stumbling blocks, variations in words, pronunciations, even in accuracy of hearing.

CEDARHURST, L. I., July 5 -- Losing only one set all day the visiting Oxford-Cambridge tennis team of England swept the nine opening-day matches to insure victory in the Prince of Wales Trophy series with the Rockaway Hunt Club.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified 245 battle casualties in Korea in a new war list today. It included 35 killed, 169 wounded, 16 missing and 25 injured. The following were from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut:
A QUESTION frequently directed to this column is: "Where can I go fishing within fifty miles of this city?"

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 5 -- Hannibal moved a little later than is usual for him, but the 3-year-old son of Roman nevertheless picked the proper moment to go out in front and win the Select Handicap at Monmouth Park today. The colt, owned by Bayard Sharp and ridden by Willie Passmore, took the lead in the stretch and went on to score in the six-furlong fixture.

Mexico has been a teaser for the political student during these last eighteen or twenty years. The country really is a democracy -- but it does not have democratic elections. There is a Presidential election today (in Mexico it comes every six years) and there might just as well be one candidate instead of four.
CHICAGO, July 5 -- The Republican National Convention, beginning here on Monday, will be the twenty-fifth in the history of a party formed in 1854.

A NEW Kodachrome package and service, heralding Eastman Kodak Company's active participation in the stereo field, will be available this month, according to a trade announcement received by New York retailers.
CHICAGO, July 5 -- Two of the nation's potential "first ladies" arrived here today, one by land and the other by air.

AT 16, Millicent DeBole, as she calls herself, is successfully singing a risque number in a Victorian London music hall, and has her eye on a gentleman of title with matrimony in view. Minnie engineers her first marriage and regrets it.

Among the famous writers, artists and musicians shown in a poster of a Communist book festival in Poland, illustrating Theodore H. White's "Victor Hugo Again Is a Storm Center" (June 22), we can readily identify such names as Hugo, Leonardo and Chopin, and can identify "Kopernik" as Copernicus, but who is "Szekspir"?
PROSPECTS for better retail trade in the second half of this year remain the bright spot in the business picture.

Two attractive young women in bathing suits, escorted by a pair of well-dressed men, stepped from a green convertible car into Isidore Rosen's luncheonette at 2829 Surf Avenue in Coney Island at 7 A. M. yesterday.

Joseph F. Gregory retired yesterday as a Treasury Department agent after twenty-five years of Federal Government service. For the last eighteen years he has been assigned to the Alcohol Tax Unit of the Internal Revenue Bureau for Brooklyn and Long Island.

In what the police believed to be the outgrowth of a series of bitter family quarrels that had been going on for about a year, James Kirby, 28 years old, a laborer, of 172 Nagle Avenue, who had been separated from his wife, Mrs. Ellen Brannock Kirby, was fatally stabbed shortly after 10 o'clock last night in a bar and grill at 145 Nagle Avenue, in the Washington Heights district of Manhattan.
WASHINGTON, July 5 (UP) -- Senator Tom Connally came to the end of his thirty-five-year career in Congress today.
The liner Manchuria, built forty-eight years ago in Camden, will end her days in a scrapyard at Savona, Italy, the American Merchant Marine Institute disclosed here yesterday.

PARIS, July 5 -- Several steps were taken within the Council of Europe here today to give effect to the decision of the Assembly of the council to draw up a plan for a European parliament and to carry out the proposal of Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, for linking the council with the more concrete projects for uniting European nations.
LONG BEACH, Calif., July 5 (UP) The national Independence Day speed boat regatta at Marine Stadium produced a complete slate of new winners in seven classes.

ST. LOUIS, July 5 (AP) -- Al Brazle, 37-year-old relief ace of the Cardinals, made his third start of the season a five-hit shut-out tonight as the red-hot Redbirds scored their seventh straight victory, beating the Pirates, 5 to 0.

CELESTE HOLM, who, this past winter, had a fling at playing "Anna Christie," the Eugene O'Neill drama at the City Center, 'stepped into the musical, "The King and I," last Tuesday night amid smiles and nods of approbation from both the returning reviewers as well as the Messrs. Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d.

CHICAGO, July 5 ---A. Federal Reserve System "entirely free from either Treasury or White House domination" and the earliest possible return to a domestic and international gold standard were recommended today.by te monetary subcommittee for inclusion in the 1952 platform of the Republican party.
Newly freed by international treaty from the stigma of "a state of war," Japan is striving to extend her international rehabilitation from the field of politics to that of finance.
PUSAN, Korea, Sunday, July 6 (AP) -- The Republic of Korea's prolonged political crisis appeared virtually ended today with the National Assembly planning to meet tomorrow to enact an election law.

THIS newest book by Bishop Fulton Sheen is on Our Lady, the Blessed Virgin Mary, the Mother of God. It should appeal to many readers of all faiths, for not only Roman Catholics have come under her spell.

A TWENTIETH century Caesar -- some Americans consider him the "noblest Roman of them all" -- will rise in a great Chicago amphitheatre tomorrow night to sway the forum and the market place, the delegates, and the galleries and 100 million Americans in front of the nation's TV screens.

BOSTON, July 5 -- New England's 110 delegates to the Republican National Convention, who may cast as many as 101 of their ballots for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, left behind them some party rifts that will need patching before the election in November.
CHICAGO, July 5 (AP) -- Ted Kluszewski supplied the power and Ken Raffensberger the pitching as the Reds handed the Cubs their fourth straight lacing today. The score was 7 to 1.

I agree with Mr. Simonson in his letter commenting on Santha Rama Rau's "The Wind That Means Life to India" (June 8) that the monsoon is strikingly named, but the ominous shape and sound of the word appear to be only a happy accident.

Four hundred Olympic athletes will get a ticker-tape farewell at noon tomorrow as they parade up lower Broadway with an escort of 2,000 uniformed members of the armed forces and the city's Police, Fire and Sanitation departments and a motorcade of city and Olympics officials.

BERLIN, July 5 -- One of the Indian delegates to the Soviet-sponsored World Peace Council in East Berlin today proposed a world-wide economic boycott against American goods until the United States stops its "aggression" on various fronts.

PARIS, July 5 -- A group of Gaullist Deputies, who may number as many as twenty, decided tonight to quit Gen. Charles de Gaulle's party rather than submit to a decision that their votes in the National Assembly should be determined by the party's National Council.

PAWTUCKET, R. I., July 5 (AP) -- The Putnam Stable's Combat Boots -- a 9-10 favorite of the crowd of 25,706 -- came within two-fifths of a second of the Narragansett Park mile-and-a-sixteenth record today in winning the $8,800 King Philip Handicap.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) -- The National Civil Service League said today that the Internal Revenue Bureau, ordered reorganized after it was rocked by scandals, was being reshuffled in a manner which "must be held suspect."

Dogged detective work led to the arrest yesterday of the alleged hit-and-run driver of a truck that fatally injured Frank Di Bona, 18 years old, of 1172 Madison Street, Brooklyn, Thursday at 5:05 P. M. on Sunrise Highway, near White-law Street, Ozone Park, Queens.

To expand and develop their facilities to meet the increasing demand for petroleum products, American oil companies by the end of this year will have spent nearly $20,000,000,000 since the close of World War II. No other industry ever spent so much money for expansion in a like period.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., July 5 (AP) -- Harness racing's brightest stars move to Saratoga Raceway Monday for a two-week Grand Circuit stand. Four $10,000 races and eight $5,000 events are scheduled during the twelve nights.

NOW that the bulk of urgent garden work is completed, it's time for a judicious examination of all the trees and shrubs on the property. This is done with a view either to keeping them in good condition or getting them back into shape.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Britain has proposed to the United States that a civilian be named political adviser to Gen. Mark W. Clark to assure regular consideration of the diplomatic aspects of the military actions in Korea.

ROBERT SYLVESTER, drama columnist and critic for The New York Daily News, who already has sold two novels to the West Coast studios, revealed last week that bidding has commenced for the screen rights to his latest, "Indian Summer," which Random House will publish tomorrow.

A COUPLE of collectors and a catalogue are all that are needed to set off a long discussion about what and what not should be recorded or rerecorded (all, of course, according to the several tastes and dictates of said collectors).

LONDON, July 5 -- John Strachey, who was Minister of War in the former Labor Government, asserted today that not only British opinion profoundly disagreed with "the MacArthur school of though in America," which he said believed that the Chinese Nationalist could be put back into power.

Admiral Alan G. Kirk, former United States Ambassador to Moscow, last night made a bid to the Fifth Congress of Americans of Ukrainian Descent for their support in the campaign to "help all exiles rid their territories of the oppressor."

T. S. ELIOT'S current visit to this country marks the thirtieth anniversary of the publication of "The Waste Land," and the thirty-fifth since the first appearance of the "Prufrock" volume of 1917. The present time is accordingly as good an occasion as any to look back upon Eliot's youthful achievement, and in particular to his early skill in the art of verse satire.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- The Eighty-second Congress enacted the following major legislation at its second session (an asterisk after mention of legislation signifies that this bill is before President Truman but has not been signed or rejected by him):

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Senator Taft, before leaving here this afternoon, called reporters to his office on Capitol Hill and read them a statement answering the charges of fraud and deceit that had been leveled at his organization by General Eisenhower and his backers.

WORCESTER, Mass., July 5 -- Navy's eight-oared crew left no doubt about where it was going after today by winning the final heat of the Olympic trials on this sunny afternoon with a record-breaking performance. The boatload of midshipmen, who have been capturing races for an unbeaten string of eleven since early spring, skimmed over the 2,000-meter course on Lake Quinsigamond in 5:57.7.

IT took less than an hour to make all the atoms in the universe, a few hundred million years to make the stars and planets but three billion years to make man. Such is the conclusion reached by George Gamow, Professor of Theoretical Physics at George Washington University and author of "One Two Three . . . Infinity."
CAMDEN, N. J., July 5 -- Four preachers, who formerly worked as chemist, taxi driver, farmer and truck driver, are enrolled as fulltime students at Rutgers University's College of South Jersey here.

IT'S rather difficult to tell the reader right off about Barnaby Conrad. For a young chap -- he's just turned 30 -- he's done, and is doing, too much. Of course, he is a novelist, having with his second novel ("Matador") hit the jackpot.

A seventh-inning homer enabled the Phillies to defeat the Giants, 3 -- 2, yesterday. Vic Raschi of the Yanks beat the Athletics, 3 -- 1. The Dodgers halted the Braves, 5 -- 3, in a night game. The Tigers dismissed Red Rolfe and named Fred Hutchinson manager.

MY researches in T-Viewing have forced me to the firm opinion that one of the glaring faults of most programs is the close-up views of the program announcers. The camera men seem to insists on showing all the dental deficiencies, the swollen tonsils and even the palates of these unfortunates.

BABYLON, L. I., July 5 -- The fleet of more than 100 craft assembled for the annual three-day invitation regatta of the Babylon Yacht Club had a long day on Great South Bay today. Fluky wind at the start settled to almost a dead calm before springing up a bit from the northwest.
ROY CAMPBELL, the beat South African poet that ever sang in English, wrote in his "Rounding the Cape":

" MEN of all nations and all faiths have treasured the miracle of Joan and are holding it among the most precious heirlooms of the human race," says J. Christophe Herold, who may be said to know, for he was born in Czechoslovakia, has lived in four other European countries and is now a citizen of the United States. In this biography he makes clear why this is so.
The days of derring-do were relived for forty-three days aboard a fifty-seven-foot ketch that voyaged 4,400 miles from Hamburg, Germany, to the boat basin at Seventy-ninth Street in the Hudson River.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- The Democratic party's 1952 platform must be based on the New Deal principles of the late President Roosevelt and the Fair Deal program of President Truman, a committee of seven Democratic Senators said today.

CHICAGO, July 5 -- A forged White House telegram asserting President Truman's support for Averell Harriman of New York for the Democratic Presidential nomination arrived today in this city, teeming now with Republicans excited over their own race between Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio and General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower.

Chicago is the nation's premier convention city -- political and otherwise. For the Republicans its fame as the place to nominate candidates stretches back to 1860 when, in a wooden arena not far from the spot made famous by Mrs. O'Leary's cow a decade later, Lincoln was nominated.

I read Philip Yedinsky's letter referring to Penn Kimball's article, "The 'Terribly Normal' Class of '52" (June 8) and telling of his frustrating experiences as a B.A. and M.A. in English trying to get a job. I sympathize with him.

LONDON -- A red-headed chap in a blue T-shirt, his short crew cut standing out in the flow of tourists like an American flag, lounged on the low fence outside the main gate of Eton. He was tossing a hard rubber ball in leisurely fashion to a half-dozen similarly dressed compatriots.

THE gallery of characters for this excursion into the darker areas of symbolism and abnormal psychology include an idiot boy, his resigned father, a promiscuous nurse and a neurotically destructive individual named Forward, who gave up a career as a successful business man to become a nurse in a hospital for the mentally deficient.

Your report on the address of the president-elect of City College, Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, is a timely reminder of the disasters occasioned when ideological conflicts combine with power politics, thereby befogging the issues. Dr. Gallagher spoke of the tension between totalitarian Sparta and democratic Athens.

A high fly that drifted lazily toward left, barely cleared the scoreboard and caromed off the foul-screen for a homer gave the Phillies a 3-2 decision over the Giants yesterday at the Polo Grounds. Granny Hamner propelled the "mighty" blow with two out and none aboard in the seventh inning and that one cost Larry Jansen his fifth setback of the season.

Not many Americans have yet read the 302-page McCarran-Walter Omnibus Immigration Bill or noted its dozens of new and retroactive grounds for excluding new immigrants, deporting old immigrants and denaturalizing those who have already become citizens.

Early in 1948 after the Illinois Democratic organization picked Adlai Ewing Stevenson to run for Governor, a Chicago North Side precinct leader asked indignantly, "Where the hell did you dig up this guy Add-lay? Let alone not knowing him, the voters can't even pronounce his name.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- The Fair Deal, roaring in on all sixteen cylinders in 1948 with President Truman behind the wheel, limped to a halt this week, a good record in the Eighty-first Congress offset by breakdown after breakdown in the Eighty-second Congress, just concluded.

Economies with a total estimated money value of $6,736,000 were achieved in 1951 by twenty-eight city departments and agencies, according to a report submitted yesterday to Mayor Impellitteri by his Board of Management Improvement.
LONDON, July 5 -- To sensitive noses in London it seemed this week that something was rotten in the Kingdom of the Nile. For the third time in barely six months Egypt has changed Premiers.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) -- Floyd Baker's double with the bases filled in the seventh inning scored two runs and lifted the Senators to a 4-3 victory over the Red Sox tonight before a crowd of 13,006, including President and Mrs. Truman.

ATLANTA, July 5 -- Paced by a substantial rise in home furnishings and appliances, retail sales in the Southeast are continuing to improve. Abnormally hot weather touched off a vigorous buying spree of room air conditioners and many retailers reported supplies were exhausted.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 5 (UP) -- Twenty tight-lipped Russian sailing competitors arrived today and removed any doubt remaining as to the Soviet Union's full scale participation in the 1952 Olympic Games. They came with eight boats aboard the freighter Thosno from Tallin and intend to compete in all five Olympic sailing events.

The notion that the activities of the professional rainmakers resident in the West and Southwest are affecting the weather in the central and northeast regions of the country is, offhand, somewhat extreme, to say the least. However, the evidence is accumulating that their activities in constant cloud seeding are perpetuating the Midwest and upstate drought and increasing the frequency of rains on the eastern seaboard.

THE Metropolitan Museum is now mailing to artists throughout America announcements of its huge forthcoming water-color, drawing and print competition. The intricate machinery of this third big American annual consists of four dual regional juries and a dual jury of awards.
PITTSBURGH, July 5 (AP) -- Finished steel products like jet engine blades and seamless pipe soon may be squirted into final shape just as you squeeze toothpaste through a tube.

ONCE in a great while a popular scientific book opens a whole new field. "Plants, Man and Life" is such a book. The author calls himself a botanist (he is Engelmann Professor of Botany at Washington University, St. Louis), and he knows his plants, including those dried, pressed, embalmed corpses which his colleagues gloat over as if they were stamp collections.

NONE of the outdoor historical dramas I have seen has been more absorbing than Kermit Hunter's Lincoln play, "Forever This Land," acted, incidentally, on land that Lincoln trod 120 years ago. Like the outdoor plays Paul Green has been writing for the last twelve years, it is put together according to a working formula -- narration, dramatization of historical episodes, choral singing and dancing.

Lice killed more men than did bullets in wars of the past. In World War II the Army dusted nearly every man, woman and child in Naples with DDT and thus succeeded in virtually stamping out typhus.

DETROIT, July 5 -- Robert (Red) Rolfe, who piloted the Detroit Tigers to within a breath of the American League pennant in 1950, was fired today and relief pitcher Fred Hutchinson was named to succeed him.

JERSEY CITY, July 5 -- More waterfront violence was feared today as a result of the slugging of a former stevedore hiring boss who was a key figure in a recent strike of longshoremen on the Army Claremont Terminal here.

THE long Fourth of July week-end is drawing to its close and, if the experience of past holidays repeats itself, even now the statisticians are totting up the accidents that have plagued the public and are reporting them in baleful tones by way of warning to those still sound of wind and limb. Accent on safety is strong indeed at times like these.

IN spite of the lure of green fields, the migration from sod to pavement continues. Never has the trend been so persistent as during the past ten years. In a period of unprecedented agricultural prosperity the proportion of Americans carried on the census rolls as "rural farm" has steadily declined until today it is at its lowest ebb in the nation's history.

IN his article, "Of This Year's Books, These Have Impressed Me Most," Mr. Orville Prescott writes the following: "Erich Maria Remarque, probably only second in rank after Thomas Mann among modern German writers, had his sixth novel, 'Spark of Life' published this spring." * * *

VIENNA, July 5 -- The dismissal of Ana Pauker, formerly Rumania's No. 2 Communist, from her post as Foreign Minister, announced today by the official Rumanian news agency, means that Mme. Pauker, who was involved in the recent purgings of Vasile Luca, Minister of Finance, and Teohari Georgescu, Minister of the Interior, is now completely out of favor. She will probably be the defendant in a "show" trial.

THE most notable news to come out of the home furnishings markets held here and in Grand Rapids last month is the fact that fashion changes, of a type once confined to the garment and automobile industries, have permeated the entire furniture industry.

JACKSON, Miss., July 5 (AP) -- Mississippi's "loyal" Democratic faction, pledged to support the national party nominee, elected delegates today to challenge States' Righters at the national convention opening in Chicago on July 21.

This country's private electric power and light industry has provided an adequate supply of low-cost power to enable the nation to get into "high gear" on its mobilization program, Bayard L. England, president of the Edison Institute, declared yesterday. Mr. England, who also is president of the Atlantic City Electric Company, made the statement in answer to President Truman's speech dedicating the new public power Bull Shoals dam in Arkansas.

CHICAGO, July 5 -- Just as the prospective advent of guests throws the average family into a tizzy of jangled nerves, Chicago's house-straightening for the Republican National Convention has precipitated a flurry of municipal backbiting.

Last winter at Hialeah, Arthur W. Abbott of Rye, N. Y., had offers ranging up to $125,000 for his 3-year-old colt, Blue Man. Everyday Abbott gets just a bit happier that he didn't accept any of the offers.

When Ambassador George F. Kennan returned to Moscow last week he found the unprecedentedly violent "Hate America" campaign still in full swing. Through the press and radio the Kremlin was still telling its people that the United States is a "bloody imperialist monster" engaged in murdering defenseless prisoners and spreading germ warfare, and having longer-range plans for killing off hundreds of millions of "inferior" peoples throughout the world.

ON a certain spring evening, the audience at a family-type movie theatre in Huntington Park, Calif., was watching an unannounced "sneak preview" of a new Hollywood production. The picture was about two-thirds over when a large segment of the audience, at least 400 persons, rose and left the theatre en masse.
BERLIN, July 5 -- The General Council of the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions today wound up its session here with a blast against the Union of South Africa's racial policies.

Under New York State's recently enacted Metcalf-Hatch law, which went into effect last Tuesday, researchers who experiment with animals may buy from pounds unclaimed stray dogs and cats for state-approved medical work. A last-ditch effort to prevent the enforcement of the act was made by the New York State Voters League Against Vivisection.

CHICAGO, July 5 -- The Republican National Convention, first half of the political version of "The Greatest Show on Earth," opens here on Monday in a circus-like atmosphere certain to draw a standing-room-only crowd to the convention hall and millions to their television sets at home.

THE reader who is looking for thrills, hairbreadth escapes from disaster, and dangerous encounters with weird sea monsters, will get more than his money's worth from this sequel to "Amazon Adventure." To begin with our three young heroes embark on a secret mission which includes bringing back alive such creatures as a giant octopus with tentacles forty feet long and luminous eyes as big as automobile wheels.
WASHINGTON, July 5 -- The steel strike for five weeks failed to live up to its calamitous billing, but the turning point has been reached.

Holidaying Americans were rolling up as grim a Fourth of July week-end record yesterday as they did in this year's three-day Memorial Day observance. The middle day of the current three-day week-end saw deaths by accident soar toward the 500 mark.

CHICAGO, July 5 -- Governor Dewey and other top level New York Republican leaders started an all-out drive today to obtain unanimous support from the state's ninety-six delegates for proposed convention rules changes that could determine the outcome of next week's nominating sessions.

CHICAGO, July 5 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio returned to the Republican convention city tonight with his wife, Martha, and the magnitude and spirit of his reception was more like that of a conqueror than a candidate.
CHICAGO, July 5 -- Following is the text of the statement read by General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower today at his first press conference in Chicago:

The citizens of Puerto Rico had special reason to celebrate this year's Fourth of July and they did so. In San Juan Governor Munoz Marin reviewed a parade in honor of President Truman's signature of the Congressional act giving the island the political status of a commonwealth.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 5 (UP) -- Flags went up over the Olympic village of Kapyla today in the first official ceremony of the 1952 games. The simple inaugural lasted twenty minutes and was largely an oriental affair.

IN Parrington's estimation, William Gilmore Simms (1806-70) was "by far the most interesting and virile figure of the Old South * * * an American Fielding, with a dash of Smollett." Yet he is unknown to the general reader.

WHAT does it mean to be a Republican today? Or a Democrat? One certain thing is that what it means today is not quite the same as what it will mean a few weeks from now. For the conventions that are upon us are not only parliaments and revels and demonstrations but exercises in definition.

AN old water wheel that supplied the "cold blast" for Pennsylvania iron-makers through June, 1883, has been restored by the National Park Service and will turn again beginning this afternoon beside the 182-year-old stone smelting furnace in Hopewell Village National Historic Site, near Birdsboro, on the Schuylkill in Berks County.

CHICAGO, July 5 -- Vito Marcantonio, former representative in Congress from New York, drew prolonged cheers of approval today from the floor of the Progressive party's national convention here in a speech blasting all and sundry Presidential aspirants, Congress, some labor leaders, President Truman and the Korean war.

THE history of Arkansas has been colorful and sometimes horrible, with French and English settlers, Indian wars and real Wild West outlaws all mixed in kaleidoscopic action. Homer Croy, author of "West of the Water Tower" and "They Had to See Paris," has taken one of the most fascinating periods of that history -- the taming of the West -- and fashioned an intensely interesting and exciting book.

Comparison with high year-ago volume produced by the "price war" continued last week to give major New York City department stores a sizable minus on combined sales volume. The deficit last week was estimated at 15 per cent.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) -- The special "racket squads" of the Bureau of Internal Revenue, found evidence for $73,176,196 in additional tax claims against "known and suspected criminals" in their first year of operations.

There were miracles at Roosevelt Field, Mineola, L. I., when it was established in 1909 and men flew strange crates by a sixth sense generally believed to lie "in the seat of the pants." There are miracles there today -- though no flying.

Hats have a new big story to tell for fall and winter, 1952. Most important is that they are larger and deeper than they have been in some seasons. The variety of silhouettes makes them adaptable to the many necklines that designers of suits, coats and dresses are offering.

Action of the Department of Agriculture last week in modifying import quota restrictions on foreign cheeses, as a result of import controls in the new Defense Production Act, came as a surprise to importers.

ON the hottest night of the year, Katharine Hepburn hit London with such a crack that she might have been a thunderbolt generated by the sweltering weather. Nothing like it has been seen for years. Other actresses from America have had great triumphs, swept to success by some play which has hit the public taste.

Blood plasma, proteins, enzymes, vitamins, glands have been preserved for months, even years, by a process known as "freeze-drying." The Naval Medical School at Bethesda, Md., is now experimenting with freeze-dried bone. The purpose is to provide surgeons with bone from a bank to be used in grafts.

PHILIPPE of the Waldorf said one day that soup often bored Americans, that a cream soup especially had small excuse for being and that Americans, who eat less at table than the French, are happiest with a "light and amusing" first course. All of which started us thinking about first courses generally and particularly with reference to summer meals. We wondered:
The old adage: "Don't change horses in the middle of a stream," has worked out just in reverse for Harvard-educated Paul Tishman.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 5 -- Pennsylvania University's 150-pound crew, rowing over unusually rough waters, defeated Christ College of Cambridge today to retain the Thames Challenge Cup at the historic Henley regatta.

MISS Agnes de Mille, in her review of my book, "The Last Years of Nijinsky," says: "One suspects that it is not always exactly truthful." Later she adds: "Among other improbabilities, * * * dancers in America, fearing rivalry, organized deliberately to keep Nijinsky out of the country, which I as a dancer cannot credit."

HOPEWELL VILLAGE, Pa., July 5 -- The old water wheel that supplied the blast for Hopewell's furnace through June, 1883, when more than a century of iron-making ended in this pre-Revolutionary village, has been restored by the National Park Service and will turn again tomorrow afternoon.

MIAMI, Fla., July 5 (AP) -- The cream of America's week-end golfers found the tough Miami Country Club's par-70 an impossible goal today as they warmed up for the national public links tournament with an eighteen-hole battle for the Warren G. Harding team trophy.
HANNOVER, Germany, July 5 -- A rowing club today accused Dr. Martin Brustmann, official physician of the Western German Olympic crew, of dispensing pills which made rowers tired instead of peppy.

DALLAS, Tex., July 5 -- Relief from credit controls proved to be a big shot in the arm for Southwestern business, the Federal Reserve Bank's monthly business summary indicated this week. Suspension of Regulation W last May 7 caused May installment sales to rise 49 per cent over April and 90 per cent over May 1951.

WORCESTER, Mass., July 5 (AP) -- Tom Bolles, Harvard athletic director serving as manager of the United States Olympic rowing team, beat the deadline by only a half hour tonight in entering thirty-one oarsmen for the seven races at Helsinki.

One of Pravda's most cherished propaganda notions is the idea that the American economy is essentially owned and operated by a small group of "Wall Street capitalists." The fallacy of that idea has long been obvious to anyone familiar with this country, but precise and concrete data for demonstrating that fallacy have been lacking for the most part.

In a recent issue of Science, Linn F. Cooper and David W. Rodgin of Georgetown University describe experiments which showed that nonsense syllables were more easily learned during hypnosis than in the waking state. This confirms discoveries made by psychologists long ago.

If the present generation of college students lacks imagination, I feel it is largely due to an all-too-great acceptance of the Bertrand Russell formula of "calculated impulse" as voiced in his "The American Way (a Briton Says) Is Dour" (June 15).

OUTSTANDING nineteenth and twentieth century French paintings, drawings and sculpture in the collection of the late Maurice Wertheim, eventually to go to the Fogg Museum, have been lent by Mrs. Wertheim for the summer for display at the Metropolitan where they are installed in two of the special exhibition galleries.
WASHINGTON, July 5 -- President Truman returned briefly today to the place where he spent "ten of the happiest years of my life" -- the Senate.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 5 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh presented his resignation to the Shah of Iran today in accord with constitutional practice following the organization of the new Iranian Parliament.

ALLEGRO has issued no new records since April and with the suspension of its activities the rumor spread that the company had failed. There were many who felt keen regret that it should have gone under. Not only was the company enterprising in its repertoire, but it did most of its recording in this country, and it gave opportunities to many excellent young artists.

WHAT is it that ails the Republican party and has rendered it incapable of winning the Presidency since 1928? Roland N. Stromberg traces the G. O. P.'s basic weaknesses back to the 1920 Presidential election.
VIENNA, July 5 (AP) -- The dismissal of Ana Pauker as Rumanian Foreign Minister is part of the tightening of the Soviet stranglehold over the Black Sea nation.

SEED of many perennials may be sown in July and August. In fact, too early seeding may result in too large plants that don't go into the winter well. Right now some perennials are maturing the current crop of seed, which can be planted when ripe.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, July 5 -- The question whether or not to deliver the tanker Asperon, built here for the Soviet Union, to the Russians over United States protest that the vessel constitutes strategic material banned by United States law for export to the Soviet Union and its satellites, was left open by the Danish Cabinet at a special meeting this morning.
The United States has ample reserves of natural gas to supply all defense and civilian requirements for the next twenty years regardless of stepped-up demands.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 5 (UP) -- Calumet Farm's great filly, A Gleam, made it a clean sweep today for Mrs. Warren Wright's runners by racing to a brilliant eight-length victory in the $59,750 Westerner, top race of the meeting at Hollywood Park for 3-year-olds.

THE TV-Radio Workshop of the Ford Foundation plans to enter video programming in a big way next fall. A weekly ninety-minute program, under the title of "Omnibus," will be presented over the C. B. S. network at 4:30 on Sunday afternoons, starting Nov. 9.

Some 30,000 delegates and their wives are expected to attend the eighty-eighth Grand Lodge convention of the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks here July 13-17, Supreme Court Justice James T. Hallinan of Queens, past grand exalted ruler of the Elks and general chairman of the convention, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Conferees of the Senate and House of Representatives agreed today on the final version of a supplemental appropriations bill in which foreign aid funds were sharply limited and outlays for expansion of the atomic energy program were held to less than half of what President Truman had requested.
LONDON, July 5 (AP) -- The Jamaica 1,500-meter relay team set a new Empire record for the mile today as the British Olympic squad played host to Commonwealth athletes in a track and field meet.

Ohio State won two more places on the United States Olympic swimming team yesterday when Freshman Yoshi Oyakawa from Hawaii and Ensign Jack Taylor, an alumnus of four weeks standing, put across a one-two slam in the 100-meter back-stroke.
Television in this country, with all of its foibles, is still a product far superior to that being dished out in the nine-month experiment in Peron's Argentina.

PHILADELPHIA, July 5 (AP) -- The National League, riding the crest of a two-game winning streak, was established a 13-10 favorite today to vanquish the American League in the annual all-star game here on Tuesday.

CHICAGO, July 5 (AP) -- Major grains backed down under light selling pressurke on The Board of Trade today. Old crop soybean contracts held up quite well at times managing to eke out a small gain from the previous close.

JOURNALS and autobiographies are becoming more and more important in today's literature. They seem to satisfy a need for immediate knowledge of an intentionally hidden world. This hidden world is the characteristic of certain periods of history when wars, despotisms, revolutions and counter-revolutions act directly and intimately on men's lives.

CHICAGO, July 5 -- Cheered by an enthusiastic crowd on his arrival today at the Chicago and North Western Railway station here, General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, in fighting mood, carried his battle against Senator Robert A. Taft for the Republican Presidential nomination into the convention city.

The straw hat season is over at the wholesale level and manufacturers reported last week that sales were about 10 per cent ahead of last year's. The 1951 straw hat business was slightly better than in the previous year, but this season's increase marks the first major rise in five years and the best activity since 1947.

CHICAGO, July 6 -- Senator Robert A. Taft declared today that 510 delegates to the Republican National Convention had pledged in writing not simply to support him for the Presidential nomination but to "become working members of the Taft team."

TEHERAN, Iran, July 6 -- The Iranian Chamber of Deputies voted today to request the Shah to reinstall Dr. Mohammed Mossadegh as Premier following the resignation of his Government yesterday in accord with constitutional practice after the organization of the newly elected Chamber.
You can't beat the Dutch, so the saying goes. Certainly they knew what they were doing when they held a tasting of their cheeses last week.

CHICAGO, July 6 -- From well before the first gavel at 11:30 Central daylight time tomorrow morning until the end of the Republican National Convention, the nation's principal radio and television facilities will be focused on its activities.

Eighty-nine Negro youngsters, participating in a race relations project, left Grand Central Terminal yesterday for two-week vacations as guests of white families in Vermont. The project is under the sponsorship of the Abyssinian Baptist Church, 132 West 138th Street.

PARIS, July 6 -- The Reunion of the French People -- the party of Gen. Charles de Gaulle -- today ended a three-day session of its national council with a serious split in its ranks, the full extent of which may not be revealed until next fall.

CHICAGO, July 6 -- The National Presidential nominating convention of the Progressive party closed its three-day session today with the adoption of a platform calling for broad, extensions of civil rights fair employement practices and Negro representation in state and Federal legislatures.

CLEVELAND, July 6 (AP) -- A thirteenth-inning homer by Minnie Minoso lifted the White Sox back into second place today, for it beat the Indians, 3 -- 2, and ended Cleveland's five-game winning string.
CHICAGO, July 6 (AP) -- David S. Ingalls, chairman of the Taft campaign committee, today urged General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower to disown what he termed a smear campaign by his supporters.

CHICAGO, July 6 -- A sizzling Sunday survey of the Republican candidates' headquarters reveals sex raising its attractive head in the Taft camp. . . . Leggy drum majorettes in blue sateen costumes bedizened with Taft insignia charging hither and thither, objective uncertain but probably any operating television cameras. . . . Bevies of beautiful girls, more fully clad, but equally emphatic in their allegiance -- "Belles for Bob."

WESTPORT, Conn., July 6 -- The little White Barn Theatre tonight was the scene of the world premieres of two one-act operas -- "The Princess" and "The Maypole," composed by Arnold Franchetti. Each miniature was about twenty minutes long.
BOSTON, July 6 -- Since the outbreak of the Korean war New England factories have received an estimated $5,000,000,000 in defense contracts, the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston said yesterday.

DETROIT, July 6 (AP) -- Cary Middlecoff won a sudden death play-off from Ted Kroll on the first hole today to take the $2,400 top prize in the Motor City open golf tournament. The two had tied with 274 scores at the end of seventy-two holes of regulation play.

New Yorkers and residents of adjacent counties contributed 263,052 pints of blood to the regional American Red Cross blood program in the fiscal year that ended June 30. The total was nearly twice as large as that of the 1950-1951 year.

TETERBORO, N. J., July 6 -- A mother and a grandmother, pilot and co-pilot respectively of a Beechcraft Bonanza, were the first to land here today in the sixth annual all-women's transcontinental air race arranged by the Ninety-nines, the women-fliers' group founded by the late Amelia Earhart.

If any lingering doubts had persisted regarding the reality and large scale of Soviet slave labor, the mass of documentary evidence submitted to the United Nations Commission on Forced Labor by American representative Walter Kotschnig should prove conclusive. In this evidence there were included official Soviet documents and thousands of affidavits from former slave laborers, some of them former Soviet citizens, others Poles, Germans and Japanese who have suffered under the Kremlin lash.

American athletes on their way to the Olympic Games in Helsinki put on a carnival at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island yesterday. A crowd of 10,000 turned out for the proceedings and saw a program drawn along lines of a three-ring circus as members of the track, cycling, weight - lifting, fencing, gymnastic and soccer teams went through their paces.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, July 6 -- Foreign Minister Ole Bjoern Kraft said tonight he agreed with the American view that the free world should not send strategic goods to Russia. He indicated, nevertheless, that Denmark would go through with delivery of a 13,000-ton Danish-built tanker to the Soviet.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- A staff memorandum of the Senate-House Economic Committee said today the outlook was for prices to rise to a new peak in the next six to twelve months.

HELSINKI, JULY 6 (UP) -- Transport authorities braced today to handle the arrival of more than 300,000 athletes and spectators who will swarm into the city in the next fortnight for the 1952 Olympic Games, July 19 to Aug. 3.
BERLIN, July 6 -- The Soviet-sponsored World Peace Council tonight ended its week-long session here with a call for a huge "Congress of the People for Peace" to be held in Vienna Dec. 5.

Television offered quite an overture to the Republican convention. Over the week-end the network channels abounded with predictions, promises, parades, placards, pickets and press agentry. If this is a forerunner of what lies ahead, the wise viewer will stock up now on vitamins and boric acid.
CHICAGO, July 6 -- The Republican National Convention program for tomorrow (all times Central daylight, which is one hour behind New York time):

CHICAGO, July 6 -- Gov. Earl Warren's seventy-vote California delegation, its collective backbone stiffened by "Stick-With-Warren" talks from its leaders in caucus, began serious efforts today to line up second-choice votes for the Governor among the delegates in other states pledged to rival Presidential candidates.

MEXICO CITY, July 6 -- Even more orderly than the optimists had hoped, nearly 5,000,000 Mexicans went to the polls today in an election that seemed bound to continue the ruling Party of Revolutionary Institutions in power for another six years.

Too many Americans tend to "neutralize malodorous civic sins" by "saturating destructive criticism of others with the chlorophyll of self-righteousness," the Rev. Edward M. Connors of the staff of St. Patrick's Cathedral said yesterday in his sermon. The service was presided over by Cardinal Spellman.
DETROIT, July 5 (AP) -- The auto industry is revising its new model changeover plans; in virtually every instance the changeover will be made several weeks later than originally scheduled.

CHICAGO, July 6 -- Gov. Theodore R. McKeldin of Maryland, a favorite son candidate for President, asserted today he had received some offers from "intermediaries" of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, but the Senator promptly denied the story.

Billy Talbert of New York, the United States Davis Cup captain, was forced to five sets before defeating Jack Tuero of Roslyn, 4 -- 6, 6--0, 6--3, 2--6, 6--1, in the New York State tennis championship final yesterday at the Seminole Club, Forest Hills.

Business executives, penetrating students of finance and practical practitioners in that field are impressive in their massive dignity. Edward Dies should qualify for all three designations, judging from his record. He has one other qualification.

Commodore Harry Manning, commodore of the United States Lines fleet, has had a distinguished career in the American Merchant Marine. His seamanship and daring often have made newspaper headlines. In 1929 New York gave him a traditional ticker tape welcome after he had directed the lifeboat that negotiated gale-lashed Atlantic seas to rescue the entire thirty- two man crew of the stricken Italian freighter Florida.

The Ciampi Construction Corporation, builders, sold the new six-story apartment house at 314-18 East Mosholu Parkway South, the Bronx, to Norwalk Properties, Inc., an investing client of James J. Leibman, attorney, Ray Struble and Fred Perk were the brokers in the sale of the property, which is assessed at $385,000.
ST. LOUIS, July 6 (UP) -- The Cardinals swept both ends of a double-header with the Pirates today, 6 -- 5 and 6 -- 4, to stretch their winning streak to nine straight games.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Two top-level Defense Department officials indicated today that the navy planned to develop the submarine as a launching site for atomic guided missiles.

KINGSTON, N. Y., July 6 -- Vacationing yachtsmen and especially skippers of power cruisers on voyages to Lake Champlain, the St. Lawrence River or even westward to the Great Lakes have been making Rondout Creek a traditional port of call because of its quiet water.

Adventure and travel stimulate the young designer who is the subject of today's article and who created the patterns illustrated here. In fact, at present she is absent on a secret mission in search of new inspiration for her forthcoming resort and spring collections. The most adroit questioning by this reporter could not wangle the tiniest hint from her as to the direction she was going to take.
Traffic fatalities set a new national record for a three-day Fourth of July week-end. This year's toll reached 350, against the total of 306 established in 1948.

JACKSON, Mich., July 6 (AP) -- State troopers used gunfire tonight to quell an outbreak among tough convicts at Southern Michigan Prison. The only casualty was a convict who was shot and wounded through the shoulder.

In its first change of ownership since 1890, the building at 98 Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by the First Unitarian Congregational Society in Brooklyn to Joseph Miller for altering into apartments. The Cruikshank Company was the broker in the sale of the structure, a former parsonage.

CHICAGO, July 6 -- The Republican party, which will open its twenty-fifth national convention tomorrow, had a radical beginning, which was not surprising, but did not have an outstanding leader, which was.

LENOX, Mass., July 6 -- The 1952 Berkshire Music Festival opened at Tanglewood this week-end. Though the first two programs consisted of chamber orchestra works of rather austere character, they attracted 6,300 listeners.
CLEVELAND, July 6 (AP) -- One hundred years ago Monday the first recorded bulk shipment of iron ore -- six barrels -- started down the Great Lakes from Marquette, Mich.

LONDON, July 6 -- Just before midnight last night a faded red doubledecker streetcar swung along the Thames Embankment from Savoy Street to the Houses of Parliament and turned to cross Westminster. Bridge as cheering spectators and a swarm of high-spirited passengers joined in singing "Auld Lang Syne."

CHICAGO, July 6 -- Mention the "Taft people" or the "Eisenhower forces" to a person today and he thinks instinctively of the handful of professionals responsible for getting the Republican Presidential nomination for either candidate.

A union-directed campaign to stamp out racketeer influence in the women's coat and suit industry in this city will get under way July 23, Isadore Nagler, general manager of the Cloak Joint Board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A.F.L., announced yesterday.

ROME, July 6 -- The police have refused to renew the residence permit of Julian Stryjkowski, who represented the Polish Press Agency (P. A. P.) in Italy. Since Italian law requires all foreign nationals to have residence permits, the measure against M. Stryjkowski amounts in effect to his expulsion and he will be required to leave the country within a few days.

The first volume of a projected six-volume life of Franklin D. Roosevelt by Frank Freidel of the University of Illinois has been scheduled for Nov. 6 publication by Little, Brown. "Franklin D. Roosevelt: Vol. I, The Apprenticeship" will cover the period from the late President's birth through the first World War when he was Assistant Secretary of the Navy under Woodrow Wilson.

The annual report of the Fire Department for 1951 just submitted to Mayor Impellitteri by Fire Commissioner Grumet contains a refreshing note. In a letter of transmittal accompanying the document Mr. Grumet departs from the usual statistics and self-congratulation of such reports to say bluntly that he has made "progress" in "weeding out the small group of men whose actions have brought discredit on the department."
The Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken raised objection yesterday to the clause in the Declaration of Independence that affirms that all men are divinely endowed with the right to the pursuit of happiness.

CHICAGO, July 6 -- Despite the bearish statistical picture in wheat, prices showed considerable firmness last week, being influenced by the fact that only a comparatively small portion of the heavy marketings have been hedged. This foreshadows the possibility of a record amount being impounded under the loan.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, July 6 -- Although Denmark's military building program is still mostly in the blueprint stage, the question whether to permit forces of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization from outside to man some of her air and other bases tops the foreign policy debate here, and informed circles predict a concession will be forthcoming in due course.

Heavy buying of the Canadian dollar last week propelled it to another new high premium in terms of American, when it sold at 3 11/16 cent, unmatched since September, 1934. Week's lowest was 2 11/16 cent, made on Monday, and Thursday's final of 3 9/16 cent, reflected a gain of 31/32 cent over the previous week.
PALLASTUNTURI, Lapland, Monday, July 7 -- A torch was lighted by rays from Lapland's midnight sun and sped by relays of runners toward Helsinki's Olympic Stadium early today.

CHICAGO, July 6 -- For the first time in twenty years, Chicago's convention scene will shift tomorrow from the Chicago Stadium to the Chicago Convention Building and International Amphitheatre, the big auditorium on the edge of the stockyards, the traditional site of the International Livestock Show.

New solid pine dining room and bedroom furniture is available at Abraham $ Straus in Hempstead, L. I. The main stone in Brooklyn, which has only the bedroom group, will have the dining room pieces after July 15.

MUNSAN, Korea, Monday, July 7 -- Truce negotiators met secretly for forty-eight minutes today in another attempt to break the long deadlock over how to exchange prisoners of war. A United Nations spokesman said the meeting was on a "businesslike basis." Brig. Gen. William P. Nuckols, the official spokesman, refused to say whether the negotiators made progress during their fourth off-the-record session.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 6 -- Marshal Tito said today that his Government was prepared to collaborate with Greece, Turkey and Austria but that it would not enter into pacts, alliances or blocs with those countries.

The three London buses that left here in March to give Americans the idea of visiting Britain returned at 8 o'clock last night after a 10,200-mile tour to the Pacific Coast, via twentysix states and forty cities.

Pan American World Airways' interest in jet airliners for the North Atlantic route received an official stamp yesterday when Juan Terry Trippe, president of the line, left here for London, where, he said, he would discuss the British-built de Havilland Comet With its manufacturers.

CHICAGO, July 6 (UP) -- Henry Zweifel, leader of the pro-Taft Texas delegation to the Republican National Convention, said today that an Eisenhower leader had tried to make a "deal" for an equal division of the state's thirty-eight votes between Senator Robert A. Taft and General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower.

LONDON, July 6 -- The Moscow radio reported tonight that Sergei Kavtaradze, Soviet Ambassador to Rumania, had been relieved of his duties and that Anatoly Lavrentiev, previously Soviet Ambassador to Czechoslovakia, had been appointed in his place.

Reports from Tokyo describe a vigorously renewed drive to have the Kurile, Ryukyu and Bonin Islands returned to Japan. Hopes for this are contingent upon some very large, and problematical factors, and while it is true that the San Francisco treaty did not deny Japan's island claims, these other factors make their satisfaction at this time unlikely.

PHILADELPHIA, July 6 (AP) -- Kid Gavilan ruled a solid 8 1/2-to-5 favorite today to turn back the title bid of 21-year-old Gil Turner tomorrow night in the third defense of his world welterweight championship.

CHICAGO, July 6 -- The two successive defeats of Governor Dewey of New York as the Republican candidate for President have wrought a fundamental change in his status with the convention delegates of the party.

MOSCOW, July 6 -- Pravda reported today from Alma-Ata, the capital of Kazakhstan, a serious failure to meet the goals of livestock expansion program and continued violations of collective farm statutes in that important central Asiatic republic.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (UP) -- The Government has granted five more loans to small business companies to help them get into the defense production program, the Small Defense Plants Administration announced today.

Confronted with an outbreak of poliomyelitis which may reach epidemic proportions, Texas is making a momentous experiment. For lack of a suitable, safe vaccine 17,500 children in the Houston area are to receive injections of gamma globulin, a fraction of blood which has been effective in measles and which may be a temporary protection against poliomyelitis.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (UP) -- Julio Moreno continued his mastery of the Red Sox today as he pitched the Senators to an eight-hit, 5-to-2 victory.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 6 (AP) -- Evelyn Kawamoto, 18-year-old Hawaiian swimmer, smashed her own American record with a 5:14.6 in the 400-meter free-style today to win a berth on the United States Olympic team.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Monday, July 7 -- Delegates and staff members of the United Nations armistice team discovered last night that in travel through No Man's Land to talk with Communists since the Korean cease-fire talks began almost a year ago they covered more mileage than the distance twice around the world. And according to one disillusioned veteran "we're still running around in the same old circle."
TOKYO, July 6 (UP) -- The nationalization of land, keystone of the entire Communist program in China, has been virtually completed, Peiping radio reported today.

Bricks and more bricks are needed for defense and housing in the Netherlands. While that country counts brick production as one of its key industries, since brick clay is a major natural resource, new methods of producing building and paving bricks in greater quantities are needed.

A report to this newspaper a few days ago described the way in which help is being given to rehabilitate the cottage weaving industry in northern Luzon, in the Philippines. An impressive part of that report is the relatively small investment in proportion to the available return.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (UP) -- T. Peter Ansberry, chairman of the Colonial Airlines stockholders committee, today urged acceptance of Eastern Airlines' offer to absorb Colonial.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 6 -- Paramount has finally wrapped up all the loose ends in its two-year-old negotiations with Irving Berlin to make a big musical show titled "White Christmas." Over the week-end, the studio reported that Fred Astaire had been engaged to share starring honors with Bing Crosby, who had been mentioned for the film from the first, and a top-name actress still to be selected.

Final tryouts in all sports having been completed and with the bulk of the $850,000 needed to send a full complement of 300-odd athletes to Helsinki in hand, the 1952 United States Olympic team stands ready today to depart for the quadrennial international games, which will bring some 7,000 athletes from seventy-one countries to Finland's capital for competition in eighteen sports between July 19 and Aug. 3.

TRAVIS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., July 6 (AP) -- The United States Air Force's first mass movement of jet fighter planes across the Pacific got under way today with the take-off of a squadron of F-84G Thunderjets for Honolulu.

CHICAGO, July 6 -- A change in Republican convention rules designed to bar lame duck control of future national committees is being pushed by friends of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower. The proposal is a direct result of resentment over the way Senator Robert A. Taft's supporters have obtained and exercised control over the present convention machinery.

CHICAGO, July 6 -- Factions supporting General of the Army Douglas MacArthur for the Republican Presidential nomination stepped up their campaign efforts today with a round of press conferences, formal statements and public rallies.

News that General Electric Company engineers have constructed a glass house that will not break even when stoned suggested to this department a perusal of proverbs to discover how many of the once tried and true (such as the one pertaining to people who live in glass houses) have been tried by our modern age and now are found wanting.

BUENOS AIRES, July 6 -- A complete revamping of the judiciary of Buenos Aires Province is in the making following adoption by the Provincial Legislature of a resolution requesting Gov. Carlos Aloe to ask President Juan D. Peron for Federal intervention in that branch of provincial power.

PHILADELPHIA, July 6 -- The Yankees goth twenty-five assorted hits in their double-bill against the Athletics today before a crowd of 31,935, but they had to be content with a stand-off that kept them three games in front in the American League pennant fight, this time ahead of the White Sox.
CLEVELAND, July 6 (AP) -- Even though the steel strike has lasted five weeks, most steel users have been able to operate without difficulty.

An industry-wide drive to promote the use of men's and boys' suits as Christmas gifts has been started by the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U. S. A. under the auspices of the national convention committee. The slogan of the campaign is "A Suit Is a Suitable Gift for Xmas."
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Vice President Alben W. Barkley announced tonight that he would actively seek the Democratic Presidential nomination.
CHICAGO, July 6 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower made a personal bid tonight to win the support of the uncommitted delegates of Pennsylvania and Michigan.

DETROIT, July 6 (AP) -- Hal Newhouser's bat and tricky base running sparked a four-run Tigers' rally and his pitching helped them gain their second straight victory for their new manager, Fred Hutchinson, but the 8-6 decision over the Browns cost Detroit the services of Gerry Priddy, second baseman.

CHICAGO, July 6 -- One of the more important developments so far in the battle between General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Robert A. Taft for the Republican nomination for President has been the action of all twenty-five Republican Governors in calling for amendment of the temporary convention rules.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The Eighty-second Congress gave up its drive for adjournment at daybreak today, with the Senate and House of Representatives deadlocked over a proposed restriction on the Atomic Energy Commission's expansion program.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- The airlines carried 1,069,034,236 letters and cards during the year ended June 30, 1951, the Air Transport Association said today. This was a 26.8 per cent gain over the preceding year.

For 3,000 youngsters who will not have an opportunity to leave the hot city in the summer months, vacation in New York will start this morning with the opening of the all-day summer play school program under the joint auspices of the Play Schools Association and the Board of Education's Bureau of Community Education.
TOKYO, July 6 -- The United Nations authorities will open negotiations with the Japanese tomorrow on the terms under which non-American troops will remain based here during the Korean war.

Outspoken opposition by the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., to the work of the board of inquiry that investigated the wildcat dock strike here last fall is contained in a 113-page statement that was released yesterday by Joseph P. Ryan, union president.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 6 -- The mass prison break in Brazil last month has had the unexpected effect of producing a wave of sympathy here for the desperadoes who shot their way to freedom and held out against an army of pursuers for days.
LONDON, July 6 -- Arrangments have been made for an Israeli corporation to buy the British-owned potash works at the southern end of the Dead Sea, the Israeli Legation in London announced today.

In the opinion of David J.
