Mahoney, former vice president of Ruthrauff Ryan, Inc. and now one of the youthful leaders in the advertising world, the future of business depends on sound public relations and advertising promotions. Mr. Mahoney, who founded his own concern less than a year ago, is emphatic in stressing the constant need for an aggressive approach to building new outlets for trade.
BOSTON, July 6 -- A new company to invest American funds in Canadian industry has been formed by executives of ten investment companies with assets of $800,000,000, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period June 28 to July 4 are given in the appended tabulation:

Bowen Stassforth, with a smashing 2:36.1 clocking in the 200-meter breast-stroke, and Jimmy McLane, with a hairsbreadth triumph over Ford Konno, were the individual victors at Flushing Meadows Amphitheatre yesterday as the last twelve berths on the twenty-five man United States Olympic swimming team were filled.
LONDON, July 6 -- The stock markets last week maintained the modest improvement made in the previous week. In a few cases gains were enlarged slightly.

CHICAGO, July 6 -- Gov. John S. Fine of Pennsylvania made it clear today that he would support the nomination of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower on the floor of the Republican National Convention.

CHICAGO, July 6 -- What might be the final draft of the foreign policy plank for the Republican platform for 1952 was approved unanimously by the National Convention's subcommittee on foreign policy today.
CHICAGO, July 6 -- Foreign policy is the major issue of the coming presidential campaign, representatives of a number of the country's leading national nonpartisan women's organizations agreed today.

CHICAGO, July 6 -- The Connecticut delegation at a caucus tonight at its headquarters in Edgewater Beach Hotel voted 20 to 2 to support the Lodge "fair play" amendment that Eisenhower forces will bring before the convention tomorrow.
Michael Todd has made some changes in the program schedule for the summer at the Marine Stadium, Jones Beach, L. I.
CHICAGO, July 6 -- The 1952 Republican National Convention will open tomorrow with a major, and perhaps decisive, battle over the rules of the conclave.
TORONTO, July 6 -- One of the most important achaeological fields in Canada has been found near the Manitoulin Island village of Sheguindah on the northern reaches of Georgian Bay, Ontario.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 6 -- A Nazi-like publication appeared here this week-end as the party organ of the new Iranian National Socialist party, founded last spring by Davoud Mochi Zadek, who spent close to twenty years in Germany and returned some years after World War II.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The Senate Preparedness Committee recommended today that a group of "eminent Americans" be appointed to help the armed forces find means of using manpower more economically and efficiently.

ABOARD THE LINER UNITED STATES, At Sea, July 6 -- For a third straight day America's new speed queen chalked up a record, turning in the unprecedented performance of 814 miles in the 22 1/2 hours ended this noon.

CHICAGO, July 6 -- A "sudden death" elimination contest between Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio and General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower was indicated today by the arithmetic of the Republican National Convention.

RYE, N. Y., July 6 -- Without much assurance in the way of wind, the regatta of the American Yacht Club was started today on Long Island Sound. There was but a breath from east-southeast as Jim Mertz sent the sailors off on a course from the middle of the Sound, over to Matinicock Point, L. I., back to Scotch Caps, off here, and then out to where they filled away at the start.

CHICAGO, July 6 -- Trading was more active last week than in the preceding period on the Board of Trade, with hedging tending to swell the volume, although hedge sales were still small compared to the amount of wheat being shipped in.

Net assets of Natural Resources Fund, Inc., an open-end mutual fund investing company, totaled $4,370,766, at the end of June, Frank L. Valenta, president, announced yesterday. This represented an increase of 71 per cent over listed assets of $2,560,366 on Nov. 30, 1951.

There was no precedent for what happened to Sal Maglie in the second game of a double header between the Giants and Phillies yesterday at the Polo Grounds. For the first time in his career the Barber got clipped by the Phillies. The score was 4 to 1. Earlier Max Lanier, going all the way for the first time this season, had blanked the visitors, 2 -- 0, in the opener, beating Robin Roberts.

Christians were urged yesterday by the Rev. Albert L. Neibacher, pastor of St. Luke's Lutheran Church, 308 West Forty-sixth Street, to pray that a man "chosen of God" be elected the next President of the United States.

JERSEY CITY, July 6 -- Benjamin Di Venuto, a local truck driver who had been sought by the police in connection with the beating yesterday of Dominick Strollo, a dock foreman, surrendered tonight at Jersey City Police Headquarters. He was questioned in connection with an altercation he had with Strollo on the Army Claremont Terminal pier here.

CHICAGO, July 6 -- The Republican National Convention opens here tomorrow with less than a dozen leaders grappling quietly, if not actually in smoke-filled rooms, with the really vital business at hand.

PITTSBURGH, July 6 -- Up to yesterday the loss of steel due to the strike has been 11,500,000 tons. In addition to this loss the steel shutdown is costing coal mines 1,500,000 tons of coal a week. Far more serious for the steel industry has been the "sympathetic" strikes of iron ore miners.
TOKYO, Monday, July 7 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,303, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Monday, Korea time:

BOSTON, July 6 -- Ben Wade walloped two successive home runs off Warren Spahn and Gil Hodges belted another off Vern Bickford today as the Dodgers beat the Braves for the thirteenth straight time before 7,218 fans.

The Republican Party faces three stern questions today as the curtain rises on its twenty-fifth national convention. First, can it prevent the Taft-Eisenhower quarrel from splitting its ranks and ruining its chances for success? Second, can it convince the American public that its leaders really stand for fair play? Third -- and of course involved in the other two -- can it survive as a party, and so keep alive and vigorous the two-party system?

TOKYO, Monday, July 7 -- United Nations and Communist delegates prepared to hold today their fourth consecutive secret meeting without any indication that they were any closer to an agreement on an armistice in the Korean war than when they began executive sessions on July 4.

ZURICH, July 6 -- All last week Royal Dutch common stock changed hands in Amsterdam at rapidly rising prices because of brisk demand from abroad, above all New York and Zurich. Two weeks previously the price in Amsterdam was steady at 290 per cent but by June 30 rose to 318 per cent and on July 4, to 322.

A break in a large main in midtown Manhattan at 11:45 o'clock last night sent a cascade of water westward along Fifty-second Street from Eighth Avenue and caused an interruption of service on the IND subway lines in the vicinity.

A two-story taxpayer on plot 200 by 100 feet at Michigan and Stein Drive, North Bay Shore, L. I., was sold by Miss Henrietta Bruno to Herbert Moses for investment in a deal negotiated by the Grand Central Brokerage and Realty Company, broker, and George F. Ewald Jr., associate broker.
Four new films, including an importation from France, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

AMSTERDAM, July 6 -- Some improvement was seen in business on the stock market last week mainly because of American and Swiss buying of Royal Dutch shares, which rose to 322 guilders at the week-end. Interest in Royal Dutch issues was stimulated by the favorable annual report and not by negotiations for the listing of the shares on Wall Street.

Appearing before the Republican Resolutions Committee in Chicago last Tuesday, Harold E. Stassen, a candidate for the Presidential nomination, called for "amendment of the Taft-Hartley Act so it would have the respect of both labor and business."

Rapid advancement in air safety education has resulted from 700 meetings by pilots at which they discussed accident prevention and made recommendations for more flying safety. In the last year 20,000 airmen have attended this special type of panel discussion proposed by the Civil Aeronautics Administration.

LONDON, July 6 (Reuters) -- Big banner headlines and front-page spreads in the Sunday press today gave Britons an eleventh-hour look at the United States election scene before the Republican convention.

With the national steel strike entering its sixth week today and no settlement in sight, the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., asserted yesterday that it was considering anti-trust action against the "Big Six" steel companies.

HONOLULU, July 6 -- A squadron of twenty F-84 Thunderjet fighter bombers landed at Hickam Air Force Base near here today, completing the longest non-stop air-refueling jet flight ever attempted -- 2,400 miles from Travis Air Force Base, Calif.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 6 -- An outstanding feature of Secretary of State Dean Acheson's visit to Brazil has been the failure of the Brazilian Communists to stir up trouble despite all incitement from their organ, Imprensa Popular.
WHEN Jim Thorpe, the fabled Sac and Fox Indian, won both the decathlon and pentathlon championships at the 1912 Olympic Games in Stockholm, King Gustav of Sweden presented him with his trophies.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- The Citizens Committee for the Hoover Report shut down operation last night with an estimate that Government reorganization proposals it had helped push through eventually would save the American taxpayer $4,000,000,000 a year.
You are to be highly commended for your splendid editorial about slave labor in Eastern Europe and in the captive Baltic States.
CHICAGO, July 6 (AP) -- Combining power with superior pitching, the Cubs swept a double-header from the Reds before 22,525 today, 5 to 1 and 2 to 0.
CHICAGO, July 6 -- John Foster Dulles, Republican statesman and diplomatic expert, has confided to intimates that he privately favors the nomination of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower.

ABOARD THE LINER UNITED STATES, At Sea, Monday, July 7 -- The liner United States streaked past Bishop Rock at 5:16 A. M., Greenwich mean time (1:16 A. M., Monday, Eastern daylight time) today, setting a new record for a trans-Atlantic crossing.

BUENOS AIRES, July 6 -- In a move designed to attract as little publicity as possible to Argentina's bids for 200,000 tons of wheat from abroad the Government has asked private traders to obtain the sorely needed cereal through barter transactions, it was learned here today.
CHICAGO, July 6 -- Following is an exchange of letters today by Senator Henry Cabot Jodge Jr., Eisenhower campaign manager, and Guy George Gabrielson, Chairman of the Republican National Committee:

A nine-point program for the elimination of unsafe and insanitary slum housing conditions was submitted yesterday to Mayor Impellitteri by a six-man committee headed by City Construction Coordinator Robert Moses.

PARIS, July 6 -- As the "Pinay experience" develops -- it will be at the end of its fourth month in a few days -- economic and financial circles here complain more and more of the falling off of business.

Although there were 330 fewer fires here in 1951, fire losses last year increased $1,570,160 over 1950, Fire Commissioner Jacob Grumet reported yesterday in the annual report of the Fire De partment. The average loss a fire increased from $439 in 1950 to $478 in 1951 and the average loss per capita from $2.44 to $2.65, the report showed.
CHICAGO, July 6 -- Governor Dewey told the New York delegation to the Republican National Convention tonight that he would be "Governor for the next two and one-half years, and I mean that."

A large group of ceramic pieces handmade by Phyllis Blundell, including lamp bases, bowls, ash trays and covered jars, is now on view at Ernst Schwadron, 757 Madison Avenue. The display will continue until July 16.
LOCKPORT, N. Y., July 6 (AP) -- The harvesting of Niagara County's sweet cherry crop got under way this week, but growers predicted a poor year for both the sweet and the later tart varieties.

PHILADELPHIA, July 6 -- Seven playing members of the champion Yankees will be included on the American League's roster in the All-Star battle against the National League here Tuesday, according to an announcement from Casey Stengel, who will lead the junior circuit.
CHICAGO, July 6 -- Alexander Hamilton's accomplishments as a statesman and soldier were recalled today by speakers at the dedication of the Alexander Hamilton Memorial in Lincoln Park.

PARIS, July 4 -- Contrasting colors lend fascination to the novelty silks and rayons being shown here this season. A shimmer of diverse tones enlivens taffetas in plain or shantung weave as well as the heavier dark fabrics for cocktail suits.

Angered by a man who had committed the same offense five times, Magistrate Hyman Bushel, declared yesterday in Mid-Manhattan Court that turning in a false alarm should be punishable by a penitentiary sentence up to three years instead of the present maximum of sixty days in the workhouse.

Election of George E. Stringfellow as a director of Thomas A. Edison, Inc., to fill the vacancy on the board to be left by the impending retirement of Howard H. Eckert as vice president, treasurer and director, was announced yesterday by Henry G. Riter 3d, president.

An underwriting syndicate headed by Smith, Barney Co. and the First Boston Corporation will place on the market today a new issue of $12,000,000 of 3 1/4 per cent sinking fund debentures of A. E. Staley Manufacturing Company, processor of corn and soybean products and of chemical derivatives.

CHICAGO, July 7 -- The wheat market showed a strong undertone today notwithstanding extremely large primary receipts and rapidly accumulating stocks. The inference is that only a small percentage of the wheat is being marketed at present prices. Ordinarily, hedge pressure against marketings of the size of the last few weeks would have swamped the buying demand.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 7 (AP) -- Following is the state-by-state vote on a proposal by Representative Clarence Brown of Ohio, a campaign leader for Senator Robert A. Taft, to change an amendment offered for the Eisenhower faction by Gov. Arthur B. Langlie of Washington on the procedure for seating sixty-eight contested delegates. A vote "for" is in favor of the Taft-sponsored amendment; an "against" favors the Eisenhower position:

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Following is a tabulation of percentage changes from the year before in department store sales by cities for the weeks indicated. This list, ordinarily printed on Sunday, was delayed by the Federal Reserve Board because of the holiday last week:
The rough-hewn national defense and foreign policy planks of the Republican platform as drafted yesterday in Chicago commit the United States to continued cooperation with the rest of the world.

A garden apartment development accommodating fourteen families at 115-04 to 115-26 Francis Lewis Boulevard in St. Albans, Queens, has been sold Walmar by Apartments, Inc., to Stanpol Realty, Inc. Edward Watrobski was the broker in the transaction, in which title was insured by the Inter-County Title Guaranty and Mortgage Company. The property, assessed at $110,000, consists of seven two-story buildings, each containing two apartments.
MIAMI, Fla., July 7 (AP) -- Lofty scores predominated today as the best of America's weekend golfers hooked up in the first round of the national public links tournament.

After swinging upward last year, the city's birth rate has registered a slight decline for the first half of 1952 and is expected to remain at this level for the rest of the year, the Department of Health's semi-annual report on vital statistics indicated yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 7 -- Top executives of the nation's $2,000,000,000 housewares industry expressed optimism here today that American housewives would spend more for household gadgets and equipment in the second half of this year than in the same period last year.

A final reckoning showed yesterday that the seventy-eight-hour Fourth of July week-end had rolled up the worst record of accidental deaths for any similar period this year. The mark was 643 fatalities throughout the country, compared with 510 "in the Memorial. Day week-end.

CHICAGO, July 7 (AP) -- Texas' Eisenhower supporteds voted jubilantly with the winning side today in the Republican National Convention's first test of strength between General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Robert A. Taft.

Among the Republican delegates assembled in Chicago a few more than enough to nominate if they were all in agreement were chosen from states which have what are called Presidential primaries. A comparable situation, with different figures, will exist when the Democrats get together. Not all these delegates are committed to designated candidates. In fact, most of them, so far as the law goes, are as free as birds.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 7 -- Govs. Thomas E. Dewey of New York and Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey demonstrated today on the first test vote of the Republican National Convention their power to influence the decisions of the delegates from their states.
SEATTLE, July 7 (AP) -- Stanley Sayres drove Slo-Mo-Shun IV to a world hydroplane speed record of 178.497 miles an hour today, cracking the mark set two years ago by more than 18 M.P.H.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- The Government announced today a nation-wide program for buying carload lots of manganese ore and concentrates from small domestic producers for resale to industry. The buying will take place at various rail points across the country.

CHICAGO, July 7 -- Efforts of Republican platform drafters to keep the text of their proposed declaration of principles from leaking out prematurely have taken on some of the aspects of a "cloak-and-dagger" serial.

The New York and New Jersey Sandy Hook Pilots Association announced yesterday that it had accepted a bid of the Brigham Shipyard, Inc., of Greenport, L. I., for the construction of a ninety-foot, Diesel-powered boat to ferry pilots to and from the station ships anchored near Ambrose Lightship.

LONDON, July 7 -- Some Laborite members of Parliament expressed indignation today at the British Government's decision to lift its embargo on the sale of arms to Spain. One member declared the decision was "immoral."

PHILADELPHIA, July 7 -- The most interesting item to come out of the two major league meetings and the joint meeting, presided over by Ford Frick, baseball commissioner, today was the approval of a world tour next fall by the Dodgers and the Indians.

IT must be granted that when the writer fished Hedges Lake for bass and the Battenkill for trout Saturday and Sunday, devotion to duty was running a fairly distant second to personal pleasure. These were days to relax and Monday appeared far off.

The Advertising Council hung up one of its tools yesterday with great satisfaction. But it hung it up in the ready state. It got word from the National Production Authority that, largely due to the council's efforts in the trade and general press, the needs of the steel industry for scrap had been met for the present time.
TRENTON, July 7 -- Attorney General Theodore D. Parsons ruled today that collective bargaining was not a right of public employes.

Philip Murray, president of the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., told a mass meeting of his striking followers yesterday that the union would win its strike despite a "diabolical" conspiracy on the part of the big companies to defeat it.

Whither drew away after a tight stretch battle to win the feature attraction at Aqueduct yesterday. The 3-year-old colt owned by Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt had a margin of three lengths over D.J. Schneider's Elixir at the end of the seven-furlong event, a classified handicap named the Douglaston. To the 21,999 fans, however, this test was of secondary importance to a daily double that paid $1,024.70.

PHILADELPHIA, July 7 -- It will be Curt Simmons, crack southpaw of the Phillies and therefore certain to be a popular local choice, against the yankees' Big Vic Raschi as the nineteenth edition of the major league's All-Star game gets under way in Shibe Park at 1:30 tomorrow afternoon.

The value of the Canadian dollar as measured by American money rose to $1.04 1/16 yesterday, a gain of a full half cent over the close here last Thursday and the highest value in almost twenty years. Selling in the late afternoon pared the premium appreciably, however.
PHILADELPHIA, July 7 (AP) -- "I'm young. There's plenty of time for me to win the title. Maybe a licking is good for a guy before he becomes a champion."

The Department of Agriculture lifted import controls on some foreign cheeses last week, and as a welcome consequence Roquefort will be readily available here by the end of the month. Though a shipment that arrived yesterday on the Ile de France was very small, France expects to send 2,000,000 pounds of Roquefort between now and the end of next June. This amount will top substantially the 1948-50 imports, which averaged about 1,300,000 pounds a year.

FAIRMONT, W. Va., July 7 -- Active members of Fairmont Post, No. 17, American Legion, were excluded from service on a jury that started today to hear the $100,000 slander suit of Dr. Luella Raab Mundel, ousted chairman of the Art Department at Fairmont State College.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 7 -- General of the Army Douglas MacArthur stirred the Republican convention tonight to a roaring endorsement of his plea for a crusade to rid the nation of a leadership he accused of tragic blunders at home and abroad.
The following book, published recently, may be of interest to parents and other adults working with children:

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., July 7 (AP) -- A Roman Catholic bishop condemned mothers tonight for allowing "their inexperienced daughters to expose themselves to the public gaze in competitions which offer them the questionable covered laurels of a Miss Surf Maid, a Miss United States or a Miss Universe."

WASHINGTON, July 7 (UP) -- The United States Foreign Service Journal urged the State Department today to get rid of a massive mural hanging in the department's main lobby because its message might be misinterpreted.

An announcement by cable to the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange that Brazil would defend a minimum price of 52 cents a pound for coffee and would make financing available on 80 per cent of the minimum sent futures prices as much as 60 points higher yesterday.

ST. ANNE'S-ON-THE-SEA, England, July 7 -- Thirty years after he won the United States Open and Professional Golfers Association championships, Gene Sarazen turned in one of his most distinguished rounds of golf today.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- Air Force chiefs told President Truman today that a new speed-up plan for transporting jet fighter planes to Korea would immeasurably strengthen the United Nations forces there.

Smooth silhouettes that emphasized line and construction characterized the fall millinery collection presented to the press yesterday by Walter Florell, 29 East Fifty-third Street. Inspired by the simple casual clothes that are popular today, Mr. Florell designed hats for 1952 that depend on skillful manipulation rather than trimmings.

CONVENTION HALL, CHICAGO, July 7 -- The leaders of the Taft forces in the Republican National Convention today fought every step of the way to a shattering disclosure of their weakness, and they lost when the delegates decisively approved the new rule that excluded sixty-eight contested delegates -- mostly supporters of the Senator from Ohio in his drive for the Presidential nomination -- from, voting on any challenge of the credentials of any of them.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- A second call for bids for the outstanding stock of E. Leitz, Inc. of New York was issued today by the Department of Justice. The bids will be opened at 3 P. M. on July 23 at the Office of Alien Property, 346 Broadway, New York.

MOSCOW, July 7 -- George F. Kennan, United States Ambassador, announced today that the United States Embassy had been notified by Soviet authorities that it must vacate the embassy premises on Mokhovaya Street, across Manezhnaya Square from the Kremlin, effective Dec. 31.

Twenty thousand long-distance telephone operators and maintenance employes will receive wage increases ranging from $3 to $6 a week under the terms of an agreement between the Communications Workers of America, C. I. O., and the Long Lines Department of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- On the basis of intensive studies in three widely-separated areas, Mrs. Amber Arthun Warburton of near-by McLean, Va., executive secretary of the Alliance for Guidance of Rural Youth, charged today that scientific know-how in remote rural areas of this country was too often used only for crops and coal, not for children.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The Senate and House of Representatives composed their legislative disputes sufficiently today to agree on adjournment sine die of the Eighty-second Congress. The House adjourned at 6:28 P. M. and the Senate at 6:41 P. M.

If we may judge from advance reports, the Republicans have made a good start in writing a sound monetary plank for their platform. They have declared for a Federal Reserve System "entirely free of either Treasury or White House domination."
Ways of removing such seasonal stains as those caused by mud or tomato vines are outlined in some recent reports from various sources.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 7 -- The Republican National Convention, in its first ballot, refused today, 658 to 548, to permit any contested delegation here to have a voice as to whether any other disputed delegation should be recognized.

TOKYO, Tuesday, July 8 (UP) -- The Communist Peiping radio broke the silence today of the secret Panmunjom truce meetings to declare that the Reds had turned down the Allied-offered solution of the prisoner-exchange issue.

General MacArthur sounded a "keynote" for the Republican party last night, but it is not likely to be the same "keynote" that the Republican party itself will sound when it gets down seriously to the business of drafting a platform on which to appeal to the country. When that stage is reached the Republican party will have to begin thinking about winning votes.

CHICAGO, July 7 (UP) -- Following is the text of the proposed rules change for the Republican National Convention as presented on behalf of the Eisenhower forces by Gov. Arthur B. Langlie of Washington:

Only a few more than 12,000 persons can get into the International Amphitheatre, down by the stockyards in Chicago, but sixty millions or more can see and hear a good deal of what is going on there. Many of these millions not only can but do. They may consider themselves part of a historic process, because television, though it existed in 1948, was just a baby then. Now it is all over the place.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- United States diplomats who have worked or lived in the United States embassy in Moscow saw no ulterior motive in the termination of the lease by the Soviet Union today. They said some other diplomatic buildings of other countries had to be surrender for use on Moscow University.

CHICAGO, July 7 -- Senator Robert A. Taft said this evening that the vote on the "fair play" amendment to the temporary rules of the Republican National Convention, instead of being a defeat for him, "practically guarantees my nomination."

WESTBURY, L. I., July 7 -- The silencing of all police and fire department sirens in Nassau County and their use only in case of an air attack was proposed here when aerial bombs and flares proved ineffective in tests conducted by the county civil defense unit at the County Park here today.

CHICAGO, July 7 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower took his preliminary victory at the Republican convention today like a soldier who had just landed a couple of divisions on the enemy's shore without casualties.
TOKYO, Tuesday, July 8 (AP) -- United Nations Command Headquarters Communique 1,304, for twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M. Tuesday, Korea time:
I wish to correct an erroneous impression given in the June 24 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES reporting on my speech at the Friends General Conference.
The Bureau of Smoke Control took to the water for the first to issue violations against three time yesterday in pursuit of craft poisoning city air with noxious smoke.

A plea for more adaptable furnishings for children's rooms -- chairs that could expand, tables with "telescope" legs, chests with pull-out steps that later become drawers -- was made yesterday by Robert McKean, a member of the executive committee of the Industrial Designers Institute.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- The Navy today displayed a four-and-a-half-foot model of its atomic-powered submarine, the Nautilus -- but said it did not give away any secrets.
SAINT ANDREWS, Scotland, July 7 -- Danny Kaye, artful comedian of motion pictures, today failed to charm the exclusive Royal and Ancient Golf. Club.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 7 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower won a decisive victory today over Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio in their first test of strength among 1,206 Republican National Convention delegates, who are expected to nominate a Presidential candidate on Thursday.

CHICAGO, July 7 -- The Credentials Committee of the Republican National Convention elected a pro-Taft chairman late today as Ross Rizley of Oklahoma won over Warren Burger of Minnesota by a 25-to-20 vote. Several members were absent at the organization session in the Conrad Hilton Hotel.

LONDON, June 26 -- The Government is saying very little about a plan to increase the natural fish population of the great African lakes as a large-scale food source, but an initial survey has begun and Robert Ross, a Government botanist, has gone to the lake area. He is a specialist in the microscopic plant food of fish known as diatoms.

PHILADELPHIA, July 7 -- Somehow or other there is an air of unreality to the entire business. To begin with, the National League is favored over the American League in the annual All-Star game on the morrow. From force of habit the Americans always were the favorites -- almost always, anyway.

Public Service Commissioner Paul E. Lockwood made an inspection yesterday of three of the rail lines on Staten Island in preparation for the hearings, which start tomorrow, on the application of the Staten Island Railway Company to discontinue passenger service on those lines in September. The hearings will be held tomorrow and Thursday at the Public' Service Commission office, I 233 Broadway.
Passenger ship service from the ports of New York and Boston to the Windward and Leeward Islands, a popular and lucrative service before World War II, will soon come to an end.
Stanton Griffis, former ambassador to Spain, was elected yesterday a director of the Emerson Drug Company of Baltimore City and of the Maryland Glass Corporation.

OTTAWA, July 7 -- Canadian merchants and hotel keepers, who until now have been accepting United States dollars at par, are being forced to reconsider their position as the gap between the United States and the Canadian dollar continues to widen.

CHICAGO, July 7 -- Just after hearing the news of her husband's preliminary convention victory, Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower gave her first press conference here at 6:30 o'clock tonight at a reception where she had been scheduled to appear only socially.

The farm policy of the United States is basically unsound because its foundation is political expediency -- not economic stability. By means of federally financed price supports, marketing quotas and subsidies of various kinds it undertakes to guarantee every farmer a profitable income.

MEXICO CITY, July 7 -- At least four persons were killed and more than fifty injured tonight when police and supporters of the defeated Presidential candidate Gen. Miguel Henriquez Guzman clashed in vicious fighting on downtown Mexico City streets.

The heart of Manhattan has proved to be an unexpectedly rich source for tree-starved Army personnel stationed at Fort Jay on Governors Island. Yesterday two trucks from Fort Jay, which bore the somewhat odd label, "Preventive," carted two linden trees away from the garden of the Museum of Modern Art. 11 West Fifty-third Street.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 7 -- Despite objections from the world's major airlines, the Universal Postal Union is expected to approve tomorrow a cut of at least one-third in the payments to air companies for carrying mail internationally.

John Lautner, Government witness in the conspiracy trial of fifteen secondary Communist leaders, who was a Communist himself until expelled from the party two years ago, testified yesterday in Federal Court that he was taught that "the time could be selected" for taking control of the state.

MIAMI, Okla., July 7 (UP) -- The Ottawa County Selective Service Board today postponed consideration of a Suggestion from top draft officials that Mickey Mantle, Yankee outfielder, receive another physical examination.

LONDON, July 7 (Reuters) -- Selwyn Lloyd, Minister of State, said today that Britain had made contact with the United States and other "interested Governments" on the latest Communist proposals to solve the Korean truce talks deadlock over prisoner repatriation.

Ernest Hemingway, whose latest work of fiction, "The Old Man and the Sea," will be published by Scribners on Sept. 8 and which is part of a double selection by the Book-of-the-Month Club for that month, is the subject of a work by Carlos Baker.

CHICAGO, July 7 (AP) -- Harry Darby, Kansas National Committeeman, said today the Eisenhowever Republican Convention victory over Taft forces on the contested delegate issue "is the best evidence yet that the general will be nominated."

Charting in detail for the first time the $14,000,000,000 New York market, the most extensive analysis of retail trade here ever prepared is being issued jointly today by The New York Mirror, The New York News and THE NEW YORK TIMES.

THE NEW YORK TIMES is to be complimented on its deep interest in refugees as exemplified by frequent articles on this problem, the latest of which is C. L. Sulzberger's report in THE TIMES of June 30.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 7 (UP) -- Senator Richard B. Russell said today he would support Gov. Adlai Stevenson of Illinois or Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee if they received the Democratic Presidential nomination but added that he might bolt the party "in a drastic case."

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., July 7 (UP) -- Averell Harriman, candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, said today that international tensions probably would ease and perhaps taxes could be. reduced in two years if the country followed the Roosevelt-Truman principles.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 7 -- Gov. Theodore Roosevelt McKeldin, one-time "boy orator" of Maryland, was chosen today to place General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower in nomination for President at the Republican National Convention.

GENEVA, July 7 -- Dr. Margaret Clapp, president of Wellesly, a United States college for women, today was elected president of a forty-four nation conference that opened here to study the things that hinder -- or help -- education for women.

Following is the text of the speech by Guy George Gabrielson, Republican National Chairman, opening the Republican National Convention in Chicago yesterday afternoon, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, July 7 -- The Danish-built tanker Apsheron was today formally handed over to the Soviet Union in the face of a protest by the United States. Washington had protested that the transaction constituted the sale of strategic materials to an Iron Curtain country and hence came under the American ban that countries receiving United States aide were bound to observe.

EAST WILLISTON, L. I., July 7 -- Two late finishing teams tied for top honors at 64 in the Long Island P. G. A. amateur-pro tournament at the Wheatley Hills Golf Club today. The winners were Frank Strafaci, Garden City C. C., and Pat Cici, unattached, and the pair of Stanley Florea, Oceanside, and Sam Mussachio, Engineers.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 7 -- Senator Robert A. Taft got a ten-second edge over General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower in the applause sweepstakes that punctuated the first enumeration of the leading candidates' names.

Two gunmen, a "Mutt and Jeff," team, held up two service stations on the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive early yesterday morning -- one station for the third time in two months -- and escaped, the police reported.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- The Government reported today that food prices had gone up three-tenths of 1 per cent in June. This means the cost of living may have soared to its record high.

PARIS, July 7 -- France welcomed two stout-hearted ships to her shores today -- the record-breaking 53,000-ton liner United States and the nine-ton sloop Kurun, with her 31-year-old skipper, who sailed her single-handed around the globe.

Thousands of retailers braved intense heat yesterday to mill through crowded showrooms in search of new home furnishings for presentation to the public in thirty to ninety days. The stand-out attraction was the summer furniture market in the New York Furniture Exchange, most important of several wholesale trade shows that opened in the course of the day.

New York City has borrowed $70,000,000 on tax - anticipation notes due on Oct. 20 and 23 at interest of 1 1/2 per cent, Controller Lazarus Joseph announced yesterday. The notes were sold to twenty-three local banks and trust companies by allotment, as follows:

LONDON, July 7 -- A dispatch in The London Daily Express reported today without official confirmation that Ahmed Aboud Pasha, millionaire Egyptian industrialist and financier, was responsible for the downfall of the Government of Ahmed Naguib el Hilaly Pasha, who resigned nine days ago. The newspaper alleged that Aboud Pasha's campaign cost him 1,000,000 ($2,800,000).

A tip to the police from a member of the Police Athletic League about an impending gang fight in the Bronx resulted in the arrest last night of twelve youths, ranging in age from 13 to 20 years. Seven were charged with unlawful assembly.
CONVENTION BUILDING, in Chicago, July 7 -- The Republican National Convention program for tomorrow: (All times Central daylight, which is one hour behind New York time):

CONVENTION BUILDING, in Chicago, July 7 -- Efforts of peacemakers interested in election of the Republican national ticket in November failed today to allay the bitterness between supporters of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Robert A. Taft, rival candidates for the nomination for President.

Fees for regulatory inspectional services performed by city departments should be increased to yield $3,252,910 a year more than the $8,199,607 taken in from these sources in the fiscal year 1950-51, the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey was told yesterday.

TETERBORO, N. J., July 7 -- Thirty-three of the sixty-nine women who are participating as pilots or co-pilots in the sixth annual all-women's transcontinental air race from Santa Ana, Calif., to Teterboro Airport here, had landed safely by sundown today.

The State Mediation Board will make a new effort this morning to end the week-old strike of 700 Whelan drug store employes. Louis Yagoda, a member of the board staff, will meet at 11 A. M. with representatives of the drug chain and the Retail Drug Employes Union, Local 1199, unaffiliated.

Secretary of State Dean Acheson's current visit to Brazil is not expected to produce any new foreign aid grants to that country, key foreign trade sources here agreed yesterday. The visit, they added, is aimed almost entirely at re-establishing "good neighbor" relations.

Raymond A. Rich has been appointed vice president of the refrigeration division of Philco Corporation, Philadelphia, and Harold W. Schaefer has been named vice president in charge of engineering for the division.

Hiram Walker-Gooderham Worts, Ltd., and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the nine months ended on May 31 a net profit of $12,740,263 after all charges, including $15,222,416 taxes. The net compared with $18,561,426 earned in the prior year's period, when taxes were $18,196,047.

I should like to make a few remarks on the article about education in the column "Topics of The Times" of June 27. The first is in regard to the conclusion reached from a study of spelling that teaching methods have improved in the past few years.

CHICAGO, July 7 -- A Washington correspondent was walking up Michigan Avenue by the Blackstone Hotel this morning, recalling how he had done exactly the same thing the opening day of the 1920 Republican National Convention.
PHILADELPHIA, July 7 -- The thudding fists of the cyclonic Kid Gavilan shattered the championship dream of 21-year-old Gil Turner tonight in Municipal Stadium before a crowd of 39,025.
TORONTO, July 7 (AP) -- Canadians, long accustomed to seeing their dollar in second place, are understandably proud that today
CHICAGO, July 7 -- For the first time, it looks as if a woman will be placed in nomination for the Vice Presidency at a major political party's convention.

TOKYO, Tuesday, July 8 -- United Nations and Communist delegations ended their fifth day of executive sessions on the Korean armistice discussions early this afternoon, and the atmosphere at today's meeting was officially described as "objective."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 7 -- Dr. G. J. van Heuven Goedhart, United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, asked the Economic and Social Council today to demonstrate its sincere intention of solving the problem of the residual wards of the International Refugee Organization by advancing a plan for disposition of the cases of "those still rotting in the camps in Central Europe."

Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange quieted down yesterday to await the first Government acreage report to be announced today, and final prices were 9 points higher to 3 points lower than on last Friday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 7 -- Largely with a view to aiding in the western world's struggle against the spread of communism, Cathedral Films of Hollywood will make a $500,000 color film, "Day of Triumph," dramatizing the life of Jesus Christ, according to an announcement today by the Rev. James K. Friedrich, president of the company.

KOJE ISLAND, Korea July 7 (UP) -- Koje Island, whose Communist prisoners were brought under control late last month, was disturbed last week by new disorders in which two prisoners were killed, eight wounded and twenty-eight escaped in the biggest break in Koje's stormy history.

TEL AVIV, July 7 -- A district court judge here, acting on an application from the United States drug firm of Parke Davis Co., issued an injunction yesterday restraining a local company called Abic from marketing chloromycetin.

TORONTO, July 7 -- The conviction that Russia would never withdraw from the International Red Cross was expressed here today by Jean Duchosal, secretary-general of the organization's International Committee.

The Air Warden Service and Auxiliary Police in the civil defense area described as the First Division will hold a "mandatory" defense drill tonight between 7:30 and 9:30 o'clock. The intersection of Macdougal and King Streets between West Houston and Prince Streets will be the center of the drill to be held under Police Sgt. George McVetty, civil defense coordinator of the Eighth Precinct (Mercer Street).

HELSINKI, Finland, July 7 (AP) -- The American flag was raised over Olympic Village for the first time today. It flew for the Puerto Rican, twenty-three-man team which arrived over the week end. The games run from July 19 to Aug. 3.

NANCY MITFORD likes to say that her early novel, "Pigeon Pie,"* an exuberant fantasy of England in the phony-war days, was one of Armageddon Part II's first and least spectacular casualties. That is -- or, rather, was -- a pity. For the book is less lacquered, more spontaneous, than anything she has done since. And now that it has at last been dollar-exported to the

Traders found nothing yesterday to excite buying interest on the stock market and, as a result, prices followed the path of least resistance, which was to the lower side. Quotations were softest in the late business hours, but even then the erosion was on an easy scale without any major pressure.

JERSEY CITY, July 7 -- Benjamin Divenuto, 37-year-old truck driver accused of assaulting Dominik Strollo, a carpenter shop foreman at the Army's Claremont Terminal Pier here, was arraigned today before Judge Morris E. Barison in Municipal Court and held in $5,000 bail for a further hearing July 15.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Vice President Alben W. Barkley, now an active candidate for the Presidency, declared today that the Democrats had a "positive record of performance" that assured them of victory in November.

Happily exhausted after a hectic round of activities that included a parade up lower Broadway, a City Hall reception, a farewell luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria and swift passage through the processing mill, the first two contingents of United States Olympians departed yesterday for Helsinki.
A ten-week tour of fifty-five cities under the sponsorship of Paul Gregory will be undertaken by Elsa Lanchester and her "Private Music Hall" company, beginning Sept. 20 in Carmel, Calif.
Following is the text of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur's keynote address last night to the twenty - fifth Republican National Convention as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:
LONDON, July 7 -- "Well," the hat check man in one of London's big hotels said to an American visitor last night, "it looks as if we are going to lose the old blue ribbon."
FORT LEE, N. J., July 7 -- Seven thousand youngsters left I;[ospitals and orphanages today for ten wonderful sun-splashed hours in a 158-acre amusement park where all the rides were just; for them.

SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, July 8 (UP) -- Fourteen Russian-made tanks attacked a United Nations position last night in the biggest show of Red armored strength in the last twelve months of Korean fighting.

The Renegotiation Board in Washington acted yesterday to continue exemptions from renegotiation of contracts for fresh meats, poultry, fruit and other perishable foodstuffs. It adopted an amendment, among others, broadening the terms of the exemption, which had applied only to prime and subcontracts for perishable supplies entered into before July 1.
LE HAVRE, FRANCE, July 7 -- America's new mistress of the seas came to this French port tonight wearing her laurels like an aristocrat.

CHICAGO, July 7 -- The outcome of the first test vote taken by the Republican National Convention, resulting in a victory for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower on the issue of seating disputed delegates, was acclaimed by Gov. Earl Warren of California tonight as "in accord with the American way of doing things."

Claudio Arrau, Chilean pianist, has canceled one concert appearance in Lima, Peru, and five in Santiago, Chile, because the office of the New York Immigration and Naturalization District did not furnish a re-entry permit in time for him to fulfill the engagements, it was learned yesterday.
LONDON, July 7 -- The stock markets opened the week with all-around firmness here today.

BONN, Germany, July 7 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and his aides have indicated to the Western powers they fear "deal" among the four occupying powers on West Germany at the expense of the Bonn regime.

A monument which defied the assaults of time and conquest in its own land is rapidly succumbing to the ravages of our New York climate. I refer to the so-called Cleopatra's Needle, which since 1881 has thrust its shaft above the greenery of Central Park.

CHICAGO, July 7 -- The most interesting by-product of the victory of the Eisenhower forces in the first session of the Republican convention was the dampening effect it had on General of the Army Douglas MacArthur's performance.

The Three Arts Club, which for nearly half a century has served as a nonprofit residence for women students of the drama, music and fine arts, will close as of Sept. 1, and the board of managers will try to at sell the eight-story clubhouse 340 West Eighty-fifth Street.

Mounting school enrollments and the failure to provide adequate funds for education are seriously threatening the effectiveness of public education in this country, Dr. John K. Norton of Teachers College, Columbia University, warned yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 7 -- Notwithstanding the fact that a three-day holiday had just been completed, a large field of eighty teams turned out for the Westchester P. G. A. pro-amateur best-ball tournament at the Ridgeway Country Club today.
The steel strike, now in its sixth week, touched off a rising volume of offers by importers to supply foreign steel to American manufacturers.

The operating rate of the steel industry is scheduled this week at 14.8 per cent of capacity, equivalent to 307,000 tons of ingots and steel for castings, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

" Paula," a romantic drama, produced by Columbia with Loretta Young, Kent Smith and Alexander Knox heading the cast, has been booked into Loew's State, where it will have its premiere next Tuesday. Rudolph Mate directed and Buddy Adler produced from a script by James Poe and William Sackheim.

The Lewisohn Stadium concerts entered their third week last night with a program that throughout its length was of the highest quality. It was somewhat disheartening that it should draw one of the smallest audiences. The 4,500 present would have filled Carnegie Hall almost twice, but they were spread thin over the white steps of the columned bleachers.

The Pennsylvania Company for Banking and Trusts, Philadelphia, Pa., reported as of June 30, 1952, total deposits of $677,932,414 and total assets of $740,186,743, compared, respectively, with $684,817,240 and $746,273,470 on Dec. 31, 1951. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $209,833,732 against $224,616,489; holdings of United States Government securities to $185,529,162 against $182,842,487, and commercial and collateral loans to $280,214,526 against $275,770,624.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that the support price for the 1952 flue-cured tobacco crop will be at an average loan rate of 50.6 cents a pound.

ROME, July 7 -- Vigorously pursuing its new measures for getting tough with foreign Communists, the Government expelled William Gallacher, former member of the British Parliament and chairman of the British Communist party.

LONDON, July 7 -- Sir William Lawther, president of the National Union of Mineworkers, vigorously rebuked some fellow mineworkers today for having broken the agreement to work with Italians who had been recruited voluntarily to help meet the shortage of miners in Britain.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Government circles said today it was understood that this country would not refuse further military and economic aid to Denmark because that nation had decided to deliver the Apsheron to the Soviet Union.

Millions of television set owners had a front-row aisle seat yesterday afternoon at the opening session of the Republican National Convention. In fact, in one way they had a decided advantage over the delegates on the floor. They heard and saw as much, yet did not have to forego lunch.

CHICAGO, July 7 -- The foreign policy plank of the proposed platform of the Republican party for 1952 received endorsements from the two leading candidates for the Presidential nomination today. Both had been given copies of the texts of the proposed plank for study.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 7 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson warned the Brazilians tonight of the danger of letting mistrust among American states be created by malicious propaganda, a danger his visit has done much to offset here.
OCEANPORT, N. J., July 7 (AP) -- In one of the closest finishes of the Monmouth Park meeting, the Prisjoe Stable's Lone Shadow won the featured Harry Bassett Purse by a neck today.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 7 -- Sang Ryup Park, 43-year-old Korean journalist who has criticized the Syngman Rhee Government, will be deported Friday, Bruce Barber, immigration director, here announced today.
CHICAGO, July 7 (UP) -- Ebbie Goodfellow resigned today as coach of the Chicago Black Hawks after two consecutive finishes in last place in the National Hockey League.

New York bade godspeed to the nation's Olympic team in a shower of ticker tape and confetti on the march up Broadway from Bowling Green to City Hall at noon yesterday. Several hours later the first contingent of the 336 athletes chosen to represent the United States in the quadrennial international games left the New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, bound for Helsinki, Finland.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- James P. McGranery, Attorney General, said today that he would set up a new Justice Department division that would devote all its efforts to studying Communist techniques.

The Willoughby Furniture Refinishing Company has leased two-story factory at 346 Lorimer Street, Broklyn, from the 56 Maserole Corporation and will use it for the refinishing and decorating of furniture. The Kalmon Dolgin Company was the broker in the transaction.
CHICAGO, July 8 -- Norman Thomas, former leader of the Socialist party, denied tonight reports that he intended to quit the party, for which he was the Presidential nominee six times since 1928.

LONDON, July 8 -- The Very Rev. Dr. Hewlett Johnson, Dean of Canterbury Cathedral, who returned here last night from Peiping via Moscow, said that charges that the United States had been waging germ warfare against China were "conclusive and irrefutable."

CHICAGO, July 8 -- Even a keyhole glimpse into the labors of the platform makers in this convention would lead the innocent bystander to conclude that the party platform is as sacrosanct and binding on believers as the Nicene Creed. Such hair-splitting and pound-the-table argument go into the phrasing of each article that the authors might be drafting a constitution with the force of permanent law.

MIAMI, Fla., July 8 (AP) -- Dave Stanley, 21-year-old U. C. L. A. student, ground out a 4-and-2 victory over George Eluck of Windsor, Ont., today in his opening bid for a second straight national public links golf championship.
An air raid drill, in which 200 wardens and auxiliary police participated, was held last night on Macdougal Street between West Houston and King Streets. The public did not participate.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- The bill passed by Congress to raise social Security and public assistance payments by about $540,000,000 a year would make the increases effective for September if President Truman signs it.

MEXICO CITY, July 8 -- Determined to prevent a repetition of the street rioting that turned downtown Mexico City into a battlefield last night, the Government ordered all police and military forces to be held at the alert today and arrested General Candido Aguilar on charges of attempting to incite a rebellion.

Army Ferry Boat 84 went back into service between Governors Island and the Battery yesterday, but renamed the Sgt. Cornelius H. Charlton in honor of a Bronx infantryman killed in action. He was the second Negro to win the Congressional Medal of Honor in Korea.

GLEN HEAD, L. I., July 8 -- Mrs. Bernard Freeman and Mrs. Leon Weil of Inwood won the qualfying medal in the sixth annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association best-ball championship with an even par 34, 39 -- 73 over the hilly North Shore Country Club course today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 8 -- Dr. Isador Lubin of the United States delegation suggested today to the United Nations Economic and Social Council that various inexpensive techniques might be adopted by less advanced countries to stimulate output in both industry and agriculture.

FITCHBURG, Mass., July 8 -- The Fitchburg Youth Library, in some respects unique in the nation, approaches its second anniversary in September by having won national recognition from the American Library Association.

VIENNA, July 8 -- The Austrian Cabinet decided today to protest to the Soviet occupation authorities and the Allied Council against the kidnapping in broad daylight yesterday in Vienna's Square of Heroes of Maria Schindler, 56-year-old Viennese.

GENEVA, July 8 -- Swiss confidence that the voters of this determinedly neutral country will accept almost any sacrifice for adequate national defense has been rudely shaken by the final results of Sunday's referendum.

TOKYO, Wednesday, July 9 -- The United Nations delegates today concluded their sixth secret meeting with the Communists in an attempt to work out a solution for repatriating prisoners of the Korean war. This issue, according to both delegations, is the only remaining obstacle to an armistice in Korea.

A Springfield, Ohio, dispatch in THE NEW YORK TIMES of June 22 states that at the North American Assembly on African Affairs I asserted that there was racial discrimination in two Portuguese African territories, notwithstanding the fact that such discrimination is specially condemned by the Portuguese Political Constitution.

TRENTON, July 8 -- State school authorities said today that antenna difficulties had been overcome and they probably would locate New Jersey's first educational television station At Rutgers University, New Brunswick.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- The acreage of American-Egyptian cot ton in cultivation in the United states on July 1 was reported by the Department of Agriculture today at 102,200, compared with 64,400 last year and 104,600 two years ago.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- Thousands of Government workers throughout the country are being dismissed as a result of sharp cuts the Eighty-second Congress made in appropriations for Federal agencies.

Yesterday's weather was dull, dreary and uncomfortably humid -- up to 96 per cent. Shortly after the day's high temperature reading of 79.4 degrees was reached at 10:45 A. M., there came showers. The light rain started again in earnest at 3:15 P. M. and continued on into the night.

CHICAGO, July 8 -- The North and the South resolved their conflict today over methods of restricting Republican primaries to Republicans and minimizing the possibility of challenges like the one involving Texas delegates at this convention.
DULUTH, Minn., July 8 (UP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver accused General of the Army Douglas MacArthur today of making "a political football out of this nation's foreign policy."
SOUTHAMPTON, England, July 8 -- This home of great ships opened its heart today to a rival liner that had won from Britain the speed supremacy of the sea.

An additional grand jury of nineteen men and four women was impaneled yesterday in Kings County Court and charged with determining whether the present laws governing housing and buildings were being "adequately enforced."

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 8 -- Asserting that the dominant issue in this country was the freedom of men, Herbert Hoover declared tonight that, through the policies of the two last Democratic Administration, this freedom was being hampered in the United States and was in danger of being lost in much of the rest of the world.

BERLIN, July 8 -- An official of one of West Berlin's anti-Communist organizations was kidnapped early today and transported into the Soviet zone of Germany. The action brought a prompt protest from the United States commandant in Berlin, who called the kidnapping "intolerable" and accused Soviet zone authorities of collusion in the incident.
In a ceremony at City Hall, Mayor Impellitteri yesterday swore in Thomas B. Dyett as a member of the Municipal Civil Service Commission.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 8 -- A Republican victory based on Republican principles is vital to this nation's "very survival," Representative Marguerite S. Church of Illinois declared today as she addressed the Republican National Convention.
Lassitude ruled commodity futures markets yesterday. Sales were below normal and price movements small, except in coffee, which advanced again on Brazilian price support plans.
Clyde Lovellette and other members of the United States Olympic basketball squad whose amateur status had been challenged received a clean bill of health yesterday.

The stock market almost came to a dead stop yesterday both pricewise and in turnover. No section was particularly favored by traders, likewise no group suffered from selling except some of the railroads. Price changes of any magnitude were reserved for a comparatively few issues and these mainly in some of the oils recently under speculative attention.

The eighty-eight-acre Smith farm in Franklin Lakes, N. J., has been acquired by the L. S. Custom Home Builders, Inc., for improvement with 200 houses in ranch and split-level design. The property was purchased from the Church-Market Corporation of Paterson, headed by Warren Smith and his son, Warren, in a transaction negotiated by the C. B. Snyder Realty Company, which will act as sales agent for the development.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 8 -- The television audience received an unexpected opportunity tonight to eavesdrop on a private huddle of Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr. of Massachusetts, who will be permanent chairman; Guy George Gabrielson, National Committee chairman, and Walter S. Hallanan, the convention's temporary chairman, at the Republican National Convention.

The city will be able to start federally aided construction of not more than 4,880 low-rent apartments, costing $38,950,000 to build, in the year ending next June 30, instead of its original schedule of 10,581 with a construction cost of $85,000,000.

The cloche takes the lead over all other silhouettes in the fall millinery picture. This was indicated at the Millinery Stabilization Commission's annual fall show in the grand ballroom of the Astor Hotel last night.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (UP) -The nation's cotton farmers are raising 2,000,000 fewer acres of cotton this year than the Government deemed necessary to meet basic home and foreign needs, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

Four young barfly hotel robbers, who have admitted (to the best of their memory) ten West Side hotel hold-ups this year, including a three-hour larcenous management of the Emerson Hotel on June 12, were named yesterday in six grand jury indictments for first-degree robbery.

One evening recently while my family and I were taking the air on the Department of Sanitation pier at the end of East Twentieth Street it was my privilege to witness an act of humanity and efficiency by the New York police that I do not think should be allowed to go unchronicled.
Macy's price-cutting practices last summer, which precipitated a local price war, were upheld yesterday by the Appellate Division, Second Department.

ALBANY, July 8 -- Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein informed the State Department of Agriculture and Markets today that it could continue its present efforts to enforce a rigid quarantine against the importation of Canadian cattle into the state.

A formula for settlement of the eight-day strike in fifty-one Whelan drug stores in the metropolitan area was agreed upon last night by officials of the drug chain and the Retail Drug Employes Union, Local 1199, unaffiliated.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 8--"Kiss Me, Kate," Broadway musical comedy hit of 1949, will be brought to the screen in Technicolor late this year by M-G-M, which today reported that it had closed a deal for the film rights. The project is now being prepared as one of the studio's most important of 1952, with Jack Cummins in charge of its production.

CHICAGO, July 8 -- The Eisenhower strategy concentrated on California and Minnesota today in the conviction that the ninety-eight votes of these two states now held the power of decision in the Republican National Convention.

So close is the race between Taft and Eisenhower at the Republican National Convention that literally every delegate counts. The important battle over sixty-eight seriously contested seats -- the initial phase of which was won by the Eisenhower forces on the floor of the convention Monday -- has now shifted to the Credentials Committee.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development lent Australia $50,000,000 today to improve and expand its agricultural production and basic industries.

LONDON, July 8 -- As expected, the National Union of Railwaymen, an organization representing 400,000 workers, gave a strong endorsement today to the campaign of Aneurin Bevan, leader of the Labor party's left wing, against the present level of British rearmament.
LONDON, July 8 (Reuters) -- The newsprint-starved British press devoted column after column of thin editions today to reports and comments on the Republican National Convention in Chicago.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- Frank E. McKinney, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said today "the Democratic party will not inject racial prejudice or religious bigotry" into the 1952 political campaigns.

The three-day Fourth of July week-end has more than justified forecasts of a high rate of accidents -- it has killed more Americans by accidents than any similar period in 1952. During the seventy-eight carefree hours of the holiday 643 people across the nation met with fatal accidents, compared with 510 in the Memorial Day week-end.

The General Tire Rubber Company and its subsidiaries achieved a new high record in sales for the first half of its fiscal year, but earnings declined from the corresponding period a year ago under the pressure of higher operating costs.

Herbert Hoover's speech last night to the Republican convention, like General MacArthur's speech on the preceding evening, took the form of a vigorous and sustained attack on the policies and performance of the Democratic party during its past twenty consecutive years in office.
TERRE HAUTE, Ind., July 8 (AP) -The United Auto Workers, C. I. O., voted today to continue its nine-week strike against Allis-Chalmers and the Air Force began removing machine tools from the plant.

CHICAGO, July 8 -- The fact that planks have been devised by Republican convention subcommittees which are at least formally acceptable to both General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Robert A. Taft and which broadly underwrite current United States pledges in Europe and Asia must naturally be greeted with relief by the free governments of these continents.

India's great political changes are the subject of a new book by Sir George Dunbar that Philosophical Library will issue Aug. 5 under the title "India and The Passing of Empire." Sir George is the author of "History of India."

ST. ANNE'S-ON-SEA, England, July 8 -- A Scot today won the qualifying honors and the fifteen pounds cash reward with two of the finest rounds of golf that had been shot in a British Open championship. Five Americans passed muster for the seventy-two-hole tournament proper starting tomorrow.
Despite Monday's low collection of 138 pints of blood, the Red Cross announced yesterday that it hoped to recoup today. Bloodmobiles will visit locations where 750 pints have been pledged.

Miss Laura Paz, 21 years old, of 155 East Twenty-seventh Street, was crushed to death yesterday by an elevator set in motion by her 2-year-old niece in a six-story loft building at 369 Third Avenue, the police reported.
Fall fabrics, shown in preview yesterday by John Walther Fabrics, Inc., at Hampshire House, indicated a coming season of textured fabrics with defined surface dimensions.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway today gained tigher command control over United States military forces in Europe. Through White House-Defense Department action the Supreme Commander of Allied Forces in Europe also became Commander in Chief of the United States European Command and was made solely responsible for the military aspects of United States policies in Europe.

LONDON, Wednesday, July 9 -- British correspondents in Chicago told the London public today that General of the Army Douglas MacArthur's speech to the Republican National Convention had been "a great flop."

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Philip B. Perlman, Solicitor General of the United States, resigned today, the fourth high Department of Justice official to quit since James P. McGranery became Attorney General on May 27.

It is now a year since the first meeting at Kaesong of United Nations and Communist representatives to set the framework for truce "negotiation." It has been a year of unimaginable frustration, a year in which "negotiation" took on a meaning that it has not previously enjoyed.

LE HAVRE, France, July 8 -- A young American who owes a debt of gratitude to the citizens of the Channel Island of Jersey, will fly to Jersey in few days to see his wartime benefactors for the first time since they helped him escape from the Germans in World War II.

PHILADELPHIA, July 8 -- The National League All-Stars were feeling quite chipper as they hustled into their clubhouse after the game had been interrupted by rain. But it wasn't until thirteen minutes after 4 o'clock that they let loose any victory shouts -- and the noise was mild then.
LONDON, July 8 -- The first television link between national capitals brought Paris to London tonight after a thunderstorm over the English Channel delayed the opening ceremony by twenty minutes.

PHILADELPHIA, July 8 -- Riding to the fore on two home runs, one by Jackie Robinson, the other by Hank Sauer, and aided by a dripping sky, Leo Durocher's National League forces conquered Casey Stengel's American Leaguers today in an abbreviated All-Star struggle.

BEGINNING next Wednesday and continuing until Aug. 28, a fishing contest for youngsters under 16 will be in progress in Prospect Park Lake, Brooklyn. The event is sponsored by the Department of Parks and Abraham Straus.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 8 (AP) -- Gov. Sherman Adams of New Hampshire designated New Jersey today as a key and influential state in General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's bid for the Republican Presidential nomination.

ROME, July 8 -- The opening of the Republican Convention in Chicago was front page news today for all Italian newspapers with the single exception of the Neo-Fascist Il Secolo, which relegated it to the back page. Even the extreme left wing press dedicated much space to it under prominent headlines.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 8 -- This was Oratory Day at the Republican Convention, and the air was azure with those cherished phrases that have formed so much of the woof if not the warp of American political history.

British sterling momentarily displaced the Canadian dollar as a major interest in the foreign exchange market here yesterday. The American account pound rallied to $2.79 7/16, the highest point since May 23, a net gain of 11/16 cents over Monday.

YONKERS, July 8 -- Yonkers city officials were trying today to ascertain the probable fate of the Yonkers Railroad, the street car line that carries the bulk of the city's transit riders. On Monday the members of the local division of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., voted against reduction of their hourly wages despite the warning of their own leaders that the refusal might jeopardize their jobs.
SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, July 9 (AP) -- Two reinforced Chinese companies, in hand-to-hand fighting, drove Allied infantrymen off a newly won hill on the east-central Korean battlefront today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 8 -- They waited almost an hour before calling today's All-Star game at Shibe Park. When the decision came, the American Leaguers were the victims of their seventh reverse in nineteen of the mid-season special attractions, none under quite such conditions as obtained today.

Today's new film is "She's Working Her Way Through College," a Warner Brothers musical comedy in Technicolor, with Virginia Mayo, Ronald Reagan, Gene Nelson, Don DeFore, Phillis Thax ter and Patrice Wymore, at the Paramount.

COLUMBIA, S. C., July 8 (AP) -- Representative James P. Richards, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, won easy renomination in today's South Carolina Democratic primary. Nomination is equivalent to election.
HELSINKI, July 8 (AP) -- American Olympic athletes had their first encounter with the Russians today. It was a social flop.

Baker Street, London -- whose most famous chambers, habitat of the great Sherlock Holmes, have been bodily translated to New York and are currently to be visited at the Plaza Galleries -- is, in fact, not nearly as pleasant a thoroughfare as East Fifty-ninth Street which they now adorn.
CHICAGO, July 8 -- More active buying of wheat was in evidence today, with higher prices registered.

PORTLAND, Ore., July 8 (UP) -- The executive board of the American Newspaper Guild, C. I O., urged the organization's national convention tonight to commend President Truman for his defense of civil rights.

The defense continued its hammering yesterday at Government testimony in the trial in Federal Court of fifteen secondary Communist leaders for conspiracy, in an attempt to gain admissions that the "Marxist-Leninist classics" urged peaceful methods rather than violence for achieving the Socialist revolution.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 8 (AP) -- Oriole, claimed two starts back for $6,000 by J. L. McKnight, made good in handsome style for his new owner today in the mile-and-a-sixteenth allowance feature over the turf course at Monmouth Park.

Plans for the International Maritime Races, which will feature a lifeboat and a towboat speed contest on the Hudson River on Aug. 27, are virtually complete and a field of thirteen entrants for the lifeboat event is indicated.

CHICAGO, Wednesday, July 9 -- Backers of Senator Robert A. Taft reasserted yesterday their control of the machinery of the Republican National Convention, but the psychological advantage among the 1,206 convention delegates still remained with General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower.

At least $10,000,000,000 will have to be spent on new school buildings in the next ten years to meet the "tremendous influx" of children into the public schools, Dr. Henry H. Linn of Teachers College, Columbia University, said yesterday.

The Municipal Art Society, ever thoughtful of the rapid demolition of the city's architectural monuments and hopeful that some day they may be protected by law, is gratified by certain announcements within the past year of the preservation of certain architecturally or sentimentally historic buildings or groups of buildings.

PHILADELPHIA, July 8 -- The National Leaguers have been so hungry for victory in the All-Star game over so long a period of time that they've reached a point where they'll grab anything without asking questions. So, they willingly accepted a 3-2 triumph in the moist and abbreviated struggle at Shibe Park today. It was a rather tense affair despite the wretched conditions surrounding it and the victory was well enough earned.

PARIS, July 8 -- Twenty-eight dissident Deputies of General Charles de Gaulle's Reunion of the French People formed a new splinter group in the National Assembly today and helped Conservative Premier Antoine Pinay win a vote of confidence on the sliding wage scale issue.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., July 8 -- Four quarter-final brackets were filled today in the New York State women's tennis championship singles flight before heavy showers halted play at the New Rochelle Tennis Club.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., July 8 (AP) -- A Chinese shipping man told a Federal court today that although Chinese citizens had made donations to Newbold Morris's China International Foundation, Americans ran the agency.
CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 8 -- The tentative program of the Republican National Convention for tomorrow (all times Central daylight, which is one hour behind New York time):

MADRID, July 8 -- General MacArthur's criticism of the Democratic Administration received the whole-hearted endorsement today of the Spanish press, which showed a decided preference for the nomination of Senator Taft.

MONTREAL, July 8 -- This metropolis, giving Canada in general the lead, moved today to prevent ill-will from developing among tourists, following a decision by Canadian merchants to charge a discount on United States currency.

The Philippine Medical Association in America recently celebrated its second anniversary. This is a private organization whose purpose is to raise funds for the advanced training of Filipino doctors in American hospitals.

Pigs is pigs, but pigtails is much cuter. This was the consensus of 200 guests, old and young, of the Children's Aid Society at the society's ninth annual pigtail contest yesterday at the Lower West Side Center, 219 Sullivan Street.
Following is the text of the address by former President Herbert Hoover delivered last night to the Republican National Convention in Chicago as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES.
The city of Seattle, Wash., announced yesterday that it would receive bids Aug. 5 on $25,000,000 of municipal light and revenue bonds

LONDON, July 8 (Reuters) -- Two Communists walked into the United States Embassy library here today, climbed to the first floor and hung a "Ridgway -- Go Home" banner on the balcony overlooking the street.

CHICAGO, July 8 -- A showdown appeared imminent tonight on the strength of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Robert A. Taft in the key Michigan and Pennsylvania delegations to the Republican National Convention.

JERUSALEM, July 8 -- A bill defining conditions for oil prospecting in Israel was approved on its first reading in Parliament tonight by 53 to 6. The measure now goes to the Parliamentary Finance Committee for further drafting and is expected to come up for a final vote before the end of the Parliament session next month.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Employment last June reached a new record level for all Junes at 62,572,000, Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, announced today.

Handsome enough to bring indoors after the summer season are some of the new accoutrements for outdoor living and dining. Such materials as glass, raffia, wicker, canvas and wrought-iron, utilized in the construction of these contemporary furnishings, make them practical and durable for entertaining inside or out.

LONDON, July 8--Industrial shares responded with further sizable gains to news of an improving British coal situation and a fall in unemployment among textile workers. British Government securities also continued to make widespread gains up to 7s 6d ($1.05).
