BONN, Germany, July 8 -- Negotiations between the West German Trade Union Federation and a parliamentary committee over a new factory council bill to which the trade unions objected, have collapsed. Nevertheless, a Federal Government party leader said the Bundestag would rush through a final reading of the bill, which grants some privileges to labor in management but does not meet the trade union demands.
TOKYO, Wednesday, July 9 (AP) -- United Nations headquarters communiqe 1,305, covering operations for twenty-four hours up to 6 A. M Wednesday, Korea time:

The Radio Corporation of America is breaking one of the largest campaigns in the industry for its Magic Monitor television receivers in THE NEW YORK TIMES and other Sunday and daily papers and national magazines. Starting today with full newspaper pages, the copy will run to teasers until Sunday, when THE TIMES and other Sunday papers will carry special sections throughout the country.

QUEBEC, July 8 -- Large numbers of icebergs in the Strait of Belle Isle, which lies between Newfoundland and Greenland, are threatening Canadian shipping. Packs of ice, measuring as much as two miles in length, are said to be drifting down from Greenland.

CHICAGO, July 8 (AP) -- Following is the vote by which the Republican National Convention Committee on Credentials today rejected, 30 to 21, a motion to seat the pro-Eisenhower Tucker delegation from Georgia.

CHICAGO, July 8 -- The possibility that the Republican National Convention might be stampeded in nominating General of the Army Douglas MacArthur for President -- a subject of speculation ever since his selection as the keynoter -- grew more remote today in the light of his speech last night.

Howard R. Davis of Williamsport, Pa., Grand Exalted Ruler of the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks of the United States of America, will arrive in Pennsylvania Station at 10:25 A. M. today in preparation for the eighty-eighth national convention of the organization.
LONDON, July 8 (Reuters) -- Oxford today forced a draw against Cambridge in the annual cricket match between the English universities.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- The United Auto Workers, C. I. O., agreed today to submit to final and binding arbitration a wage dispute at the North American avation plants in California and Columbus, Ohio.

CHICAGO, July 8 -- When the report of the Credentials Committee of the Republican National Convention on the contests affecting the Florida, George and Texas delegations is reviewed by the convention itself, it will be possible to determine whether by the adoption of the Langlie resolution yesterday the party entered the straight and narrow path of political morality to stay the limit or only to go part of the route.
Thayer Hobson, who, with a group of associates, recently acquired the controlling interest in William Sloane Associates, Inc., book publishing concern, has been named president in a reorganization.

The First National Bank of Chicago, Ill., reported as of June 30, 1952, total deposits of $2,368,780,409 and total assets of $2,582,338,641, compared, respectively, with $2,477,371,530 and $2,683,238,600 on Dec. 31, 1951. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $611,742,627 against $703,403,996; holdings of United States Government securities to $768,898,186 against $694,896,394; and loans and discounts to $1,060,084,123 against $1,147,902,122.

CHICAGO, July 8 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio worked long and doggedly today to counteract the early psychological harm done to his Presidential aspirations at the Republican National Convention -- a harm that his headquarters insisted was more apparent than real.

ELIZABETH, N. J., July 8 -- Two platinum capsules, each containing 25 milligrams of radium, which disappeared a week ago from the James S. Green Memorial Tumor Clinic of the Elizabeth General Hospital, were recovered from the city dumps with the aid of a Geiger counter.

While "We the People" are derisive of all forms of dictatorship in other countries, we appear pathetically willing to permit almost any form of autocracy in the direction and control of our daily lives.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 8 -- Six members of the Security Council announced today their support of a United States resolution condemning the practice of fabricating false charges, such as the Communist charge that United Nations forces in Korea had used bacteriological warfare.

" I Am a Camera," the drama by John van Druten adapted from stories by Christopher Isherwood about life in Berlin before the second World War, will suspend for a vacation after Saturday night's performance at the Empire Theatre.

SPRING LAKE, N. J., July 8 -- Billy Talbert and Sidney Schwartz, both of New York, were the only seeded players to see action today in the opening round of the Bathing and Tennis Club invitation tournament and both won easily.

LONDON, July 8 -- Two British archaeologist, Dr. Ernest A. Rudge and his wife, who live in West Ham, near London, have unearthed the course of an early Stone Age trade route leading from a neolithic flint arsenal in East Anglia to a point southwest of the Thames and beyond, a distance of more than 130 miles.

Those who live for their weekends have felt, as rainy Sunday followed rainy Sunday, that the season has been a wet one. Actually, it has not been wet enough. Down in Burlington County, where most of New Jersey's table sweet corn is grown, no rain ha dfallen, until some light sprinkles yesterday, since June 21.
A Bronx detective was exonerated yesterday of charges by a robbery case defendant that he had been "shaken down" by the policeman.

Industry-wide inventory replacement, traditionally representing a major upturn in demand, is under way in the wool textile and apparel industries, according to an analysis issued yesterday by The Wool Bureau, Inc. The bureau also cited reports of increasing sales of summer clothing from all parts of the country and the expectation of retailers that consumer buying will be accelerated during the fall and winter.

RICHMOND, July 8 -- A package of cigarettes, of the quality made today, could be retailed for ten cents provided the cigarette industry was taxed on the same basis as most other consumer industries, O. Parker McComas, president of Philip Morris Co., Ltd., Inc. told shareholders at the annual meeting here today.
SINGAPORE, July 8 -- The question of admitting Japanese investments and residents into Malaya has become a delicate problem for the governments of Singapore and the Malayan Federation.

The Utility Division, Local 101, of the Transport Worker Union, C. I. O., called upon the State Public Service Commission yesterday to investigate union charges that proposed cuts in plant personnel by the Brooklyn Borough Gas Company would endanger the public in areas served by the company.

A survey of medical and other conditions in the Far East will be made soon by Miss Dorothy E. Snavely of New York and West Haven, Conn., assistant director of medical projects of the Unitarian Service Committee, Inc. She will leave here next Monday to learn what help the committee can render in various lands.
HELSINKI, July 8 (Canadian Press) -- A North Atlantic storm has practically washed out any chance Canada had in Olympic sculling and rowing.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- A General Electric Company official struck back today at testimony by James B. Carey, president of the International Union of Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, C. I. O., that the company had encouraged a Communist-dominated union in a divide-and-rule policy of labor relations.
MOLINE, Ill., July 8 (AP) -- Stockholders of Deere Co. voted today to build a new plant at Pryor, Okla., and go into the production and sale of agricultural fertilizer chemicals.

The outstanding performance of the superliner United States on her maiden crossing of the Atlantic may "mark the dawn of a new era in American shipping" in the opinion of Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce.

Sixteen banking syndicates competed yesterday for the purchase of offerings of securities totaling more than $23,800,000. The offerings included new mortgage bonds of a public utility company, new railroad equipment trust certificates, and a block of outstanding public utility common stock.
HELSINKI, July 8 (UP) -- The first contingent of one of the strongest United States teams in history arrived tonight for the Olympic Games, opening here July 19.

The Order of Merite Maritime in the rank of Commander was presented yesterday by the French Government to John E. Slater, president of the American Export Lines, for wartime assistance to France and outstanding achievement in the marine industry field.

CHICAGO, July 8 -- The selection of a Vice Presidential candidate for the Republican ticket this year remains politically fluid as the party's national convention machinery moves closer to the balloting for a Presidential nominee.

Television, to which only last week had been denied an opportunity to cover the pre-convention meetings of the Republican National Committee, was a welcome guest yesterday at the deliberations of the convention credentials committee, even to reporting fully the committee decisions which heretofore have been made only in private sessions.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed mixed yesterday 2 points lower to 8 points higher than on Monday.

Sunshine Nell held off the favored Jacodema in a thrilling stretch drive to win the six-furlong race that occupied the feature spot at Aqueduct yesterday. A half-dozen fillies and mares participated in the event, which was named the Tradition. The crowd of 18,663 yelled itself hoarse as Sunshine Nell and Jacodema battled it out to the wire.

CHICAGO, July 8 -- Two New York City delegates, who last week had declared themselves in favor of Senator Robert A. Taft, reversed their position today and said they would vote for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower. A Rochester delegate, heretofore uncommitted but counted for General Eisenhower, came out for Senator Taft.

The Aluminum Company of Canada, at the request of the United States Government, will supply a United States competitor with 8,700,000 pounds of aluminum during the next month. The emergency shipment is designed to help make up for the loss of production at the Aluminum Company of America's storm-damaged Massena, N. Y., plant.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- The Government today authorized meat distributors affiliated with packing houses to raise their ceiling prices.

CONVENTION HALL in Chicago, July 8 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York and John P. Conway of New Orleans, one of the contested delegates from Louisiana, exchanged sharp words on the Republican convention floor today.

It was a pity that Mexico's Presidential elections had to end in very real fireworks with dead and wounded. However, the election itself last Sunday had gone off peacefully, and the rioting in Mexico City was a delayed explosion. Technically speaking, one can still claim that Adolfo Ruiz Cortines, the victorious candidate of the Government's Party of Revolutionary Institutions (P. R. I.) won in a fair and orderly ballot.

Some 150 persons, many of them in nightclothes, were evacuated from two apartment houses in Washington Heights at 11:30 o'clock last night after rain had short-circuited a power line and caused three explosions in a nearby manhole.

The difficulties of making a multi-national alliance, such as the North Atlantic, work smoothly and successfully have been illustrated again by the dispute between the United States and Denmark over the latter's delivery of an ocean-going tanker to Soviet Russia.

CHICAGO, July 8 -- A new clash between the North and South of the Republican party developed tonight in a platform subcommittee on civil rights and threatened to take the 1952 platform issue to the floor of the national convention for a rough family quarrel.
ALBANY, July 8 (AP) -- Willie Turnesa, former United States amateur and British amateur champion, was eliminated today in the first round of the annual New York State golf tournament.

INWOOD, L. I., July 8 -- Gordon Stott and Robert Baird of Nassau captured the Long Island Golf Association's best-ball team championship today over the Inwood Country Club's 6,764-yard, par-73 course. They won after a sudden-death hole with Mal Galletta and James Cullen of North Hills.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 8 -- Dr. Mohammed Mossadegh has refused to form a new government, despite the vote favoring his reappointment as Premier by the new Iranian Chamber of Deputies, until the Senate also has requested that he form a new government, authoritative sources said today.

The nation's major steel producers decided yesterday to ask leaders of 600,000 striking steel workers to permit iron ore to move to the struck mills from the Mesabi Range and other mines in the West as a means of preventing a fresh shutdown of steel production next winter.

CHICAGO, July 8--Pressure was mounting today on California delegates--and it caused concern among some of them--to try to persuade Gov. Earl Warren to release his state's seventy-vote delegation with the advice to support General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Republican Presidential nomination.

BERLIN, July 9 -- Sweeping changes appeared to be in store for East Germany tonight as one of the area's top Communists presented a program looking toward the eventual remolding of the region into a full-fledged "people's democracy."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 9 (AP) -- The State Supreme Court today upheld constitutionality of Ohio's Turnpike Act and ordered the signing of $326,000,000 in revenue bonds for a 241-mile toll super highway across northern Ohio. The vote was 5 to 1, with the seventh judge abstaining.

CHICAGO, July 9 -- California's seventy-vote delegation split today in ratios highly favorable to General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower as against Senator Robert A. Taft over the seating of contested delegates in Georgia and Texas.

HE heard "Halt, halt!" and some shots. One of the Bullets seemed to have loped pretty close to him. He kept on running as fast as he could. Then, for an interval, while the most experienced man hunters in the world decided which way to search, which way to shoot, he didn't hear anything from the persons trying to kill him in the dark.

The legality of state censorship of motion-picture newsreels will be tested next week by five Ohio film exhibitors who plan to show newsreels not submitted in advance to the Ohio censor for approval, it was announced jointly by the theatres and the Motion Picture Association of America.

Federal Judge Edward J. Dimock ordered an investigation yesterday to determine if a contempt of court citation were warranted against a newspaper that reported secret court matters during the current Communist conspiracy trial here. The newspaper was not named.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 9 (UP) -- The Russian track and field team for the 1952 olympics was revealed tonight and the list surprised observers by not including the name of Heino Lipp, an Estonian regarded as the best shot-putter in Europe.

The deepening impact of the thirty-eight-day-old steel strike was evidenced yesterday in a decision by the Chrysler Corporation to shut down all its Michigan automobile and trucks assembly lines Monday night.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (UP) -- A three-judge Federal court ordered the Department of State today either to renew the passport of Miss Anne Bauer, freelance writer, or give her a full hearing on why it was revoked.

John Frederic's approach to the millinery he has designed for fall and winter is modernistic. He has evolved sculptured forms that rely on contour and color and not on trimming. The collection was previewed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- In a precautionary move to protect the nation's canned food pack, the National Production Authority today ordered the Weirton Steel Company of Weirton, W. Va., to channel its entire tinplate output to makers of cans for perishable foodstuffs.
CONVENTION BUILDING, in Chicago, July 9 (AP) -- Governor Dewey incurred yelling disapproval at the Republican National Convention tonight.

One person was injured seriously and passenger service on the North Shore division of the Staten Island Rapid Transit Railway was tied up for more than an hour yesterday afternoon when a five-ton truck plunged over a forty-foot embankment in front of 174 Richmond Terrace, New Brighton.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Dean Acheson, the Secretary of State, said this evening that relations between the United States and Brazil had never been closer. He made this comment as he was welcomed back to Washington by President Truman, other United States officials and foreign diplomats.

Two suspended patrolmen of the Flushing-Hillcrest precinct in Queens were named yesterday in a four-count indictment based on their alleged attempt to shake down a man they had threatened to arrest as a morals offender. The patrolmen, Frederick Schnepf and John Cooke, were continued in $2,500 bail by General Sessions Judge Saul S. Streit.
A couple of 2-year-old colts owned by Mrs. C. Oliver Iselin of Glen Head, L. I., provided the highlights of the proceedings at the Aqueduct track yesterday.
OCEANPORT, N. J., July 9 (AP) -- Mrs. J. M. Cudone's High Hatter, a recent purchase for $5,000, today won $11,795 first money in the New Jersey Futurity at Monmouth Park.

Debate has been begun in Bonn by the German Parliament on the political and military pacts with the West that are designed to restore Germany as an equal partner of the free world, reorganize the North Atlantic defense system and provide further steppingstones toward a United States of Europe.

BOSTON, July 9 -- A 122-day strike of drivers and mechanics of the Eastern Massachusetts Street Railway continued tonight after a disagreement between union and company officials over conditions attached to the acceptance of a 15-cent hourly wage increase.

One of the sights that met the eyes of passengers aboard the United States as that new ship made her formal entry into New York's harbor the other day was restored Battery Park -- the city's front yard made green again or well on the way to answer that description.
CHICAGO, July 9 (AP) -- Coffee Money, Irish-bred 5-year-old, today scored an upset victory in the $21,950 Myrtlewood Handicap at Arlington Park.
" Either-Or" was the theme of the fall millinery collection of Laddie Northridge of 104 East Fifty-second Street, which was presented yesterday at the Pierre Hotel.
CHICAGO, July 9 (AP) -- Dick Savitt of Orange, N. J., top seeded, today won two matches to pace the singles field into the third round of the national clay courts tennis tourney.
ALBANY, July 9 (AP) -- Pierce (Bud) Russell of Troy upset John Ward of Syracuse, former national amateur semi-finalist, today in the state amateur golf championship.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., July 9 -- The first of the Army's new M-47 medium tanks to be turned over to Reserve or National Guard units were assigned here this week for the training of tankmen of the Fiftieth Armored Division, New Jersey National Guard, which is in the final days of a two-week's period of summer exercises.

The United States Government has reached an out-of-court settlement of a suit by the Oceanic Steamship Company of San Francisco involving claims for the wartime use as troop ships of the liners Mariposa and Monterey, the local office of the Maritime Administration announced yesterday.
Mayor Impellitteri signed yesterday the local law increasing by 27 per cent the rates now charged by the city's 11,878 licensed taxicabs.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 9 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin, told a cheering Republican convention today he would not soften his blows on the Communist issues because "a rough fight is the only fight Communists can understand."

I call your attention to an error in the letter of Sylvia P. Turk, president of the Vocational High School Teachers Association of the City of New York, published July 2. My bill provides for an increase, by $300 per annum, to the pension of pensioners receiving less than $1,200 a year -- not $12,000 a year as published in her letter.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The Air Force will put the helicopter to a new test of versatility next week by dispatching two of the rotary-winged craft on a trans-Atlantic flight.

BONN, Germany, July 9 -- The Government's case for ratification of the treaty system that would bind West Germany to the Atlantic community and, in Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's impassioned words, end the country's status as a plaything of the power blocs of the East and the West, made dramatic headway in the Bundestag today.
CONVENTION BUILDING, in Chicago, July 9 (AP) -- Following are the texts of the majority and minority reports of the Credentials Committee presented tonight to the Republican National Convention:

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 9 -- Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr. of Massachusetts, gaveled his fourth Republican convention to order tonight in the role of permanent chairman-designate and called for the rout of an Administration that he said had lost faith in the future of America.

CHICAGO, July 9 (AP) -- Following is the state-by-state roll-call vote by which the Republican Credentials Committee accepted today a proposal by Representative Clarence Brown of Ohio, a Taft leader, to uphold a prior decision by the Republican National Committee to split the disputed Texas delegation to give twenty-two votes to Senator Taft and sixteen to General Eisenhower:

The International Longshoremen's Association has now formalized in a 113-page statement its objections to most of the recommendations and findings of the board of inquiry which investigated last fall's wildcat longshore strike. Union President Joseph P. Ryan condemns the report unsparingly, except that section which recommended that the contract he negotiated with the employers be recognized as in full force and effect.

Investment banking syndicates will offer to investors today more than $41,000,000 of new securities of public utility, railroad and finance companies. The offerings consist of mortgage bonds, preferred stock and equipment trust serials and represent for the most part new-money financing intended either to expand plant and equipment or support enlarged business.

A net increase in capital funds totaling $5,684,454 for improvements to schools in the city was approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission. The action brought to $75,960,280 the amount allocated to the Board of Education in the city's 1952 capital budget.

The threat of a strike that would have cut off 70 per cent of the city's supply of wrapped white bread was eliminated last night when union and management negotiators agreed on a contract providing higher wages and an employer-financed welfare fund for 2,500 bakers.

A collection of fall hats, outstanding for their easy wearability, was presented yesterday by Emme, designer, 347 Fifth Avenue, at a luncheon for the press and trade in the Sky Gardens at the St. Moritz Hotel.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The State Department was caught in an embarrassing diplomatic dilemma in its' relations with Argentina today.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- President Truman today signed the Interior Department money bill authorizing a start on building ten new reclamation projects.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 9 -- Before a star-studded mass meeting of 4,000 Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer studio employes, Nicholas M. Schenck of New York, president of Loew's, Inc., outlined today plans for the company's first sweeping economy move since the depression days of the early Nineteen Thirties.

One hundred and five scholarships at New York University formerly handed out through the athletic department were thrown yesterday into the general pool of financial benefits for which all students at the university may compete.

Operating a business in recent years has grown increasingly complex. For this reason, the Burroughs Adding Machine Company announced yesterday, its products henceforth will be sold through retail stores and local dealers in all parts of this country and Canada.
" BARRING unforeseen and widespread disaster from weather, prospects are bright that waterfowl production will be in excess of 1951's excellent record."

HELSINKI, Finland, July 9 (AP) -- The Russians here to compete in the Olympic games suddenly dropped their icy reserve today and displayed unusual friendliness in what appeared to be an official, high-level change of policy.

The indecisiveness of the last few sessions gave way yesterday to a substantial retreat on the stock market as evidence kept piling up as to the effect of the steel strike. While losses in the main kept within fractions, some sharp setbacks in a few of the key industrial units, such as Chrysler, produced a decline of 1.04 point in the composite rate of THE NEW YORK TIMES index.

BUENOS AIRES, July 9 -- The celebration of the one hundred and thirty-sixth anniversary of Argentina's independence started with a loud bang early today when a powerful bomb destroyed the entrance to the United States Information Service's Lincoln Library.

TETERBORO, N. J., July 9 -- Poor flying weather grounded seventeen planes in the "powder-puff" derby today and when the 5 P. M. deadline arrived in the all-woman transcontinental air race the field of possible winners was limited to the nineteen planes that already had landed, the remaining contestants, who had not reached Teterboro, were disqualified.

LONDON, July 9 -- Britain's Labor party indicated tonight that it would fight every step of the way, in Parliament and in public forums, against the Conservative Government's bill to restore the nationalized trucking industry to private ownership.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The United States moved today to stimulate the European production of combat aircraft for the collective defense forces with an agreement to pay for about $250,000,000 worth of planes if the funds were matched by North Atlantic Treaty nations.

TOKYO, Thursday, July 10 -- United Nations and Communist delegates met for forty minutes today at Panmunjom on the first anniversary of the Korean armistice negotiations. Their talk was secret and was adjourned until tomorrow.

Workers in fifty-one Whelan drug stores in the metropolitan area returned to work yesterday morning after an eight-day strike. A settlement, worked out with the assistance of the State Mediation Board, assured the 700 strikers a five-day, forty-hour week, effective next April 1.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 9 -- The Soviet Union today cast its fiftieth veto, thus defeating a United States resolution under which the Security Council would have condemned the practice of making false charges, such as the charge that United Nations forces in Korea had waged bacteriological warfare.

Mrs. Henry E. Abt, wife of the president of the Brand Names Foundation, is returning today on the French liner Liberte after four months as the Foundation's unofficial ambassador to European industry and advertising. Her preliminary reports have indicated a growing interest in Europe in the American practice of standardizing products under brand names and their mass sale through advertising.

Stephen Kelen D'Oxylion, president of the Corso Jewelry Corporation, 15 West Forty-seventh Street, who was arrested in March on a charge of receiving part of $30,000 in gems stolen from a neighboring jeweler, was freed from bail yesterday when a grand jury failed to name him in an indictment against three others in the case.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The United States is negotiating with its West European allies in Paris for an agreement to put new curbs on strategic trade with the Soviet Union and its satellites.

CHICAGO, July 9 -- This convention has moved fast, yet on the third day it is twenty-four hours behind schedule. The explanation of this paradox is that the slowdown of the program is the direct result of swift currents running counter to the plans of the group in control when the sessions opened.
Three German eighteenth century choir stall panels recently brought to this country were presented yesterday to the Metropolitan Museum of Art by Lauritz Melchior, Wagnerian tenor.

The new $1,300,000 sludge vessel Owls Head, fourth and largest of the sea-going "navy" operated by the Department of Public Works to dispose of the treated residue from the city's pollution control plants, will take to the ways today.

The Sanitation Department's campaign to outlaw defective garbage and ash cans has resulted in the condemnation of 24,400 such receptacles since May 19, when the current city-wide drive got under way. The cans are the kind that are regularly placed in front of buildings by superintendents and home owners for emptying by the Sanitation Department.
The use of life insurance benefits as income has increased materially in the last ten years, the Institute of Life Insurance reported yesterday.
GLEN HEAD, L. I., July 9 -- Two rounds of the sixth annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's best-ball championship were completed at the North Shore Country Club today.

After a three-day truce occasioned by the all-star game in Philadelphia, major league baseball activity will resume today. Eight games are listed, with the Yankees at home and the Dodgers and Giants both on the road.

MOSCOW, July 9 -- The witch of the Balashikhinsk region plies her craft no longer, the newspaper Moscow Pravda reported today, but only after repeated complaints by the villagers of Nikolsk had finally prodded local authorities into action.

BURBANK, Calif., July 9 (UP) -- A million dollar fire roared through the Warner Brothers movie studio outdoor plant today, demolishing row on row of standing sets, then raced into the parched Hollywood hills behind the film studio.

CONVENTION BUILDING, in Chicago, Thursday, July 10 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's Presidential stock zoomed to new heights early today as delegates to the Republican National Convention dealt Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio two stunning blows and stripped him of his delegate strength in Texas, Georgia and Louisiana.
CHICAGO, July 9 -- A 71-year-old grandmother whose Bible is Robert's Rules of Order held a key role today in what may be one of the biggest parliamentary tangles in Republican convention history.

From a semi-annual report of the Health Department we learn that the city's birth rate, after climbing upward to 82,240 in the first half of 1951, has declined to 81,696 for the first six months of this year and is expected to remain at this level for the rest of 1952.
NEW DELHI, India, July 9 (Reuters) -- Two United States steel experts today met C. D. Deshmukh, Finance Minister, to discuss India's plans for increasing steel production.

Gerry Estates, Inc., sold to the Eleven Fifteen Realty Corporation for investment the twelve - story and penthouse, loft and showroom building at 1115 Broadway, southwest corner of Twenty-fifth Street. The property was sold for cash in a deal negotiated by Adams Co. Real Estate, Inc., brokers.

On July 7 your paper carried an editorial, one of many, on the Taft-Eisenhower contest in the Republican pre-convention struggle which was of very real importance. You specifically stated that the Taft-controlling forces are very likely to endanger the party's success in the November election, even though General Eisenhower should win the nomination.

Miss E. Beatrice Peterman is a reader who likes to work out new recipes. She lives in Manhattan, but her most recent culinary accomplishment is a dish familiar only to those who grew up within the sound of cow bells. It is a whey pie, a dessert that farm women used to make as a means of using the thin liquid that is a by-product of sour milk.

CHICAGO, July 9 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower was assured by his political managers today that he had the votes to win the Republican Presidential nomination. For the first time since this convention started, the Eisenhower advisers began serious discussion of a Vice Presidential candidate.

With the summer driving season now in full swing we are indebted to the American Automobile Association for the information that if all of the pleasure cars, trucks, buses and taxicabs in New York State were lined up, bumper to bumper, they would stretch out for 14,676 miles. This is 1,790 miles longer than the state's 12,866 miles of state-maintained highways.
CHICAGO, July 9 -- Former President Herbert Hoover formally came out tonight for Senator Robert A. Taft for the Republican Presidential nomination.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended July 2:

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- Moscow says American Presidential candidates will be elected at the Chicago conventions by a "small circle of bosses" who hire rooters at $20 a head to cheer for their candidates so the public will believe it has a voice in the selections.

The Graham-Franklin Corporation has sold the Park Lake Apartments in Hempstead, L. I., to investing clients of Daniel D. Cantor, attorney. Halford Realty acted for the seller. The two-story buildings, constructed in 1949, contain 240 apartments and 150 garages.

LONDON, July 9 -- If some members of the British Parliament had had their way tonight, the visitors arriving in London next year for Queen Elizabeth's coronation might have found Buckingham Palace converted into an apartment house and the royal family living the simple life in cozier quarters.

The building with forty-six apartments at 111 Tudor Place, the Bronx, has been purchased by Roman Blum and Max Rothstein from the Montpier Realty Company, Joseph Levinson, president, for cash above mortgages of $85,000. Allan S. Feldman Co. were the brokers.
CHICAGO, July 9 -- A Republican platform for 1952 was approved after more than six hours of debate by the National convention's Committee on Resolutions today.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 9 -- Formation of a new Iranian Government was complicated further today when the Senate gave only a minority vote in favor of Dr. Mohammed Mossadegh, who is the only candidate for Premier seriously in the field since the Majlis, or Lower Chamber, voted for him Monday.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- Members of Congress got a tax exemption today on the first $3,000 of their yearly living expenses in Washington. The two-year exemption was contained in a bill signed by President Truman.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (UP) -The Defense Production Administration reported today that the !Orinoco IVfining Company, a subI sidiary of the United States Steel Corporation had received tax. benefits on a $154,600.000 iron ore !mining project at Bolivar, Venezuela.
SPRING LAKE, N. J., July 9 (UP) -- All four seeded players were among the survivors today as the Bathing and Tennis Club invitation tennis tournament moved into the quarter-final round.

Noel Anderson, a 47-year-old porter who was born appropriately on Christmas Day, had reason yesterday to consider his birth date a good omen. Police Property Clerk Frank Leuci presented to him $2,000 in unclaimed money he had found March 8, while cleaning a roof drainpipe.

Payments from Brazil on its commercial dollar debt backlog have failed to meet expectations of United States export creditors in recent months, it was observed yesterday at a round-table conference held by the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau at the Statler Hotel.

LONDON, July 9 -- After a rowdy argument, the annual conference of the National Union of Mineworkers, which has 600,000 members and is the fourth largest union in Britain, reaffirmed today its support of the moderate majority leadership of the Labor party.
LONDON, July 9 -- Modest but general price advances were recorded throughout the industrial list in the stock market here today. British Government securities also went ahead.

The Bureau of Education on Fair Trade acted yesterday to carry on its activities indefinitely and to become completely representative of all retail elements favoring and using "fair trade." The action was taken at a meeting of the group in the Statler Hotel.
CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 9 -- The Republican Convention turned into a vocal Donnybrook tonight.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, Thursday, July 10 -- Gov. John S. Fine of Pennsylvania announced this morning for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Republican Presidential nomination and carried fifty-one of Pennsylvania's seventy delegates with him.

For people who at least try to be thoughtful General MacArthur's keynote speech was a masterpiece of repelling oratory. As your editorial in THE TIMES of July 8 points out, it is the actual state of affairs in the twentieth century with which our elected representatives must be expected to deal.
CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 9 -- The tentative program for the Republican National Convention for tomorrow (time given is Central daylight, which is one hour behind New York time):

A giant "key to the city" and a proclamation of "Elks Week" were on the program of welcome extended yesterday to Howard R. Davis, Grand Exalted Ruler of the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks. Mayor Impellitteri, himself an Elk, read his proclamation in the Board of Estimate chamber in City Hall, and called on the city to give the Elks' approaching convention a "home town" welcome.
TOKYO, Thursday, July 10 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,306, for Wednesday's activities:
Price changes were limited and volume small in commodity trading yesterday.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 9 -- When the political history of 1952 is written one conclusion at least will be inevitable. It is that the tactics employed by Senator Taft's leaders in getting delegates for him in the Southern states represented as fundamental an error by professional politicians as they made in his father's interest forty years ago, and the same one.

A drop of 1,369,000 barrels last week in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end they amounted to 119,533,000 barrels, compared with 120,902,000 a week earlier and 136,118,000 a year ago.

Frank E. De Luca has been appointed sales manager of the new Long Island sales district of the American Can Company. The area includes Connecticut, all of Long Island, the metropolitan area except Manhattan, and Sullivan, Dutchess, Ulster, Orange, Rockland and Putnam counties.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 9 -- Joseph A. Kaplan of New York, president of the National Housewares Manufacturers Association, said here today the housewares industry faced considerably increased competition that would result in greater values for the consumer.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 9 -- The "victory psychology" of the Eisenhower drive, added to intense pressure from the state organization headed by Governor Dewey, today caused Frank J. Kenna, Queens County leader, and his entire delegation of eight to leave the Taft camp for that of the Eisenhower forces.

PARIS, July 9 -- France warned potential spies and Saboteurs today that action against any of her Atlantic Pact allies or their forces on French soil would reap the same punishment as action against purely French interests.

Protests against the plan of the Staten Island Rapid Transit Railway Company to discontinue passenger service were entered yesterday by Cornelius A. Hall, President of the Borough of Richmond, and representatives of various civic organizations at a hearing before the Public Service Commission at 233 Broadway.
EDMONTON, July 9 (Canadian Press) -- Crude oil production in Alberta during the first four months of 1952 was 42 per cent greater than in the corresponding period last year.
CHICAGO, July 9 (AP) -- Following are the texts of the platform planks on foreign policy and civil rights recommended to the Republican National Convention by its Resolutions Committee:
GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 9 -- Sidewalk recruiting for civil defense volunteers to man sky-watching posts will be held for the first time in Nassau County on Friday evening in Hicksville.

ST. ANNE'S-ON-SEA, England, July 9 -- A slight Irishman from Belfast with a rolling gait who whistles his way round the course led the field of ninety-six qualifiers with a record-breaking 67 today in the first round of the British open golf championship.

CHICAGO, July 9 -- Leading supporters of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower refused early today an offer from a member of Senator Robert A. Taft's board of strategy to seat the pro-Eisenhower delegation from Texas, provided the delegation would agree to re-elect Henry Zweifel, Taft leader in that state, as national committeeman.

BONN, Germany, July 9 -- The Bonn district court today ordered the confiscation of this week's issue of Der Spiegel, a news magazine that alleged that Chancellor Konrad Adenauer had made plans to flee in the event of a Russian invasion.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, July 9 -- The superliner United States, resting briefly on her laurels as the new speed queen of the North Atlantic, entertained at luncheon today civic dignitaries from the seaport that gave her such a hearty welcome and British shipping men who were quick to pay their tribute.

The statement issued last Sunday by the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., with respect to the report of the State Board of Inquiry on the wildcat pier strike here last fall was described yesterday as a "callous and shameful attempt to justify an untenable position repugnant to the public interest."

AUSTIN, Tex., July 9 (UP) -- A 39-year-old Negro postman who won a Supreme Court decision admitting him to the University of Texas Law School said today he had left the university because of failing grades.

CAMP KILMER, N. J., July 9 -- One of the processing detachments at this post is the Veterinarian Clinic, the only overseas pet staging area in this part of the country. Mexican Chihuahuas, toy terries, Great Danes, St. Bernards and just plain "mutts" arrive here monthly from cities throughout the country to be prepared for shipment to Europe.

BURLINGTON, Vt., July 9 (UP) -- Senator Robert S. Kerr of Oklahoma, candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, said today that the Republican Convention in Chicago was a "wonderful show for the Democrats."

Net profits from merchandising operations of department and specialty stores declined sharply in the first quarter of this year. High expense ratios and reduced gross margins were responsible for the poor showing, with indications that stores may have to take "revolutionary steps" to get expenses under control.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 9 -- The postal administrations of ninety-two nations decided here today that payment to airlines for mail on Atlantic and other long-distance routes would be reduced a third, from 6 to 4 gold francs a ton kilometer.

Net assets of the Commonwealth Investment Company reached a new high of $52,026,373 on June 30, the midyear report disclosed yesterday, representing an increase of 57 per cent over the $33,132,114 assets on June 30, last year. Net asset value a share amounted to $6.98, against $6.44 a year earlier.

LONDON, July 9 -- A pale-faced young man stood uneasily in the dock of the Old Bailey today listening with head bowed as the Crown prosecutor accused him of having betrayed highly confidential information to a Soviet diplomat.

The six-week lecture series of the Summer Session Institute at Columbia University will open tonight at 8:30 o'clock with an address by James P. Warburg, banker and author. He will speak on "A Five-Point Program for Constructive Peace."

The social and criminal evils of narcotics and how they are distributed here and abroad are the subject of two books. Published today by Doubleday is "Narcotics: America's Peril," by Will Oursler and Laurence Dwight Smith. Based on the files of the Federal Bureau of Narcotics and the authors' own investigations, the volume presents a report on the problem today and an account of the adventures of the bureau's agents.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday, and closing prices were 1 to 9 points net lower than on Tuesday.

Results of the Brookings Institution's shareholder census are under close study at the New York Stock Exchange and have heightened interest in the possibility that a longer trading day might be a public service that would pay off. The census revealed the Far West and Middle West as far more important shareholding areas than had been suspected.

We do not profess to know what Philip Murray and his associates in the United Steelworkers of America will do about the plea of the nation's major steel producers who are seeking permission for iron ore to move from the Great Lakes in order that a new steel shutdown may be avoided next winter.
GENEVA, July 9 -- Women have the legal right to equality of educational opportunity in many countries, but in practice they do not get it.

Increased fighting in Korea has created a need for whole blood that must be shipped out of this country no later than tomorrow, it was announced here yesterday by Dr. William M. Markel, administrator of the New York regional blood program of the American Red Cross.
Two Broadway stage productions scheduled to open in the autumn have resolved their major casting problems.

CHICAGO, July 9 -- Free selling of corn futures was the feature today in the grain trade, with pressure heaviest on the December and other deferred deliveries. The selling was based on glowing crop reports from the important commercial corn areas, with indications now that the 1952 crop will mature earlier than in recent years, thus averting frost dangers to a great extent.

According to our correspondent C. P. Trussell, writing on Monday, the Republican platform to be proposed at Chicago would call for "ending the Secretary of Agriculture's power to set price supports." The Resolutions Committee, notes this correspondent, had decided against writing specific parity figures into the platform, but "favors guarantee of fair profits for the farm producer."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 9 -- Dr. Isador Lubin of the United States today criticized the practice of the Soviet Union in submitting Government statistics to the United Nations in terms of percentages that reveal little or nothing of conditions within that country.
The Korean truce negotiations were following yesterday -- one year after they started -- a now familiar pattern of high hopes but no results.

As the Bureau of Smoke Control takes to the water in a launch borrowed from another city department and extends its smoke-abatement drive throughout New York Harbor more and more types of smoke offenders are becoming aware that there is an anti-smoke enforcement law on the statute books.

The eight "Ivy Group" colleges announced yesterday a new football agreement which, besides tightening eligibility requirements, puts on the college presidents additional responsibility for keeping intercollegiate sports clean and in proper perspective in the design for higher education.

PITTSBURGH, July 9 -- The Aluminum Company of America and the International Council of Aluminum Workers Unions, A. F. L., agreed today on a tentative five-year peace pact under which 9,500 workers in six Alcoa plants would get a wage increase averaging 20 cents an hour, with 16 cents of it retroactive to last March 15.

HOBOKEN, N. J., July 9 -- Anthony Piscopo, secretary-treasurer of Marine Warehousemen's Local 1478, International Longshoremen's Association, revealed today that the union's ledger, membership index cards, a quantity of membership books and sixteen dues stamps had been stolen from the union's office at 68 Hudson Street.

SCOTT AIR FORCE BASE, Ill., July 9 (AP) -- The Air Training Command Headquarters here disclosed today that eighty-six officers had been separated from the service in the last three months because of "their fear of flying."

A five-point program aimed at re-routing air traffic away from Lewisohn Stadium during concert hours has been worked out in cooperation with airlines officials and the Civil Aeronautics Administration, it was announced yesterday.

MOSCOW, July 9 -- Pravda and other Soviet newspapers reported in special dispatches from Soviet correspondents in Chicago that the Republican National Convention was primarily a fight between Rockefeller, du Pont, Mellon, Ford and Morgan interests supporting General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and a group of Chicago and Midwest financial interests supporting Senator Robert A. Taft.

Production, sales and earnings before taxes reached new records for the Crown Zellerbach Corporation in the fiscal year ended last April. Net income, however, was 6 per cent below that of the previous year because of taxes, the California paper company reported yesterday in its annual statement.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 9 -- The Hollywood Film Council of the American Federation of Labor has begun a campaign to halt what it calls the "runaway" production of films by Hollywood producers in foreign countries. Both theatre movies and films for television will be affected.
The touring Oxford-Cambridge tennis team yesterday defeated the International Club, 4 -- 0, at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, Queens.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., July 9 (AP) -- A Chinese shipping executive said today that Mrs. Olga Konow -- the "Oilboat Olga" of the Senate's surplus ship investigation -- set up the deal that reportedly led three American tankers into trade with the Chinese Communists.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- President Truman today created an emergency board to investigate a union-management dispute that threatens to tie up the operations of Trans World Airlines. The make-up of the board was not made known at once.

The purchase of the summer estate of the late President Franklin D. Roosevelt on Campobello Island, New Brunswick, just off the coast of Maine, was announced yesterday at Armand Hammer, president of United Distillers of America and of the Hammer Galleries, 51 East Fifty - seventh Street.

CHICAGO, July 9 -- The Taft-controlled Credentials Committee made General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower a peace offering today of the eleven contested Louisiana delegates that had favored Senator Robert A. Taft and then split the larger Texas delegation twenty-two for the Senator and sixteen for his chief rival for the Presidential nomination.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Congressional action on appropriations during the session just ended should result in a $4,500,000,000 reduction in President Truman's $85,400,000,000 budget for the 1953 fiscal year, according to the Council of State Chambers of Commerce

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Robert A. Lovett, Secretary of Defense, advised Congressional leaders today that he would set up an advisory committee on manpower and its most economic utilization within the Department of Defense.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The heads of the nation's stabilization agencies decided today to concentrate on fighting inflation despite what they termed the "kick in the teeth" given them by Congress' sharp cut in their operating funds.

There are many ways in which the American people can make their contribution to sound international relations in these unsettled times. One of the most effective ways is for American capital to move into underdeveloped areas and invest, in newly independent territories struggling for economic stability, some of the genius that has gone into this country's development.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- Announced United States battle casualties in Korea reached 112,128 today, an increase of 552 since last week.

LONDON, July 9 -- Ten Conservatives in the House of Commons proposed today that Parliament ask Queen Elizabeth II to dismiss the Dean of Canterbury, Dr. Hewlett Johnson, who came home from China Monday echoing Communist propaganda about germ warfare by the United States.

In your issue of June 25 appears a letter from German Arciniegas, attacking the Colombian Army Mission to the United States headed by the Minister of War. Mr. Arciniegas accuses the army and the Government of religious intolerance, and cites a note of protest by the American Embassy in Colombia.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The Republican National Convention has Mr. Truman worried, to hear him tell about it today.
Ga. De Kalb County, Ga., sold yesterday $2,800,000 of improvement bonds due from 1953 to 1982 to a banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at a bid of 102.388 for interest of 2 per cent.

A new record in auction sales of antiques, jewelry, art objects and the various categories of home furnishings and decorations was reported yesterday for its 1951-52 season by the Plaza Art Galleries, Inc., 9 East Fifty-ninth Street. William H. O'Reilly, president, announced that the season's total of sales was $1,936,441, a gain of about $10,000 above the preceding year.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today proposed changes in its regulations by which it hopes to improve the operation of the registration and prospectus requirements of the Securities Act of 1933.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, Thursday, July 10 -- Following is the state-by-state roll-call on the vote in the Republican National Convention on the minority report to the Credentials Committee's report on seating the 17-vote Georgia delegation.

Rain, which yesterday blanketed the East Coast from Maine to Florida, benefited many crop-growing areas, notably in southern New Jersey. The rain also visited this city, but the fall here was only about one tenth of that in Burlington County, N. J.

MIAMI, Fla., July 9 (AP) -- A new star rose from the ranks of America's amateur golfers today when Bob Scherer, a rangy Illinois laborer, blasted defending champion Dave Stanley of Los Angeles out of the national public links golf tournament.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, Thursday, July 10 -- The Republican Convention halted for five minutes of laughter last night when the Puerto Rican delegation was called upon to vote on the Georgia seating question.

When a suspended Flushing, Queens, post office employe appeared in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday to answer to a charge of forging and cashing a stolen postal money order, United States Commissioner Edward E. Fay looked up and said:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 9 -- The United Nations Security Council shelved today, for a couple of months, action on the Soviet Union's demand for the mass admission of fourteen countries to United Nations membership.

The vote last night by which the Republican National Convention overrode the earlier decisions of its own Credentials Committee was clearly another impressive victory for General Eisenhower. But it was also something more. It was a victory for political decency, fair play and the good name of the Republican party.

Willie Howard, comedian, whose humor was for many years rated high along Broadway and was exceeded only by his reputation for generosity died insolvent on Jan. 12, 1949, at the age of 62, leaving assets of $7,118 and debts of more than $78,000.

FAIRMONT, W. Va., July 9 -- Dr. Luella Raab Mundel, former Art Department chairman at Fairmont State College, denied today that she is or ever had been a Communist or an atheist as she took the witness stand in her $1,000,000 slander suit against Thelma Brand Houdin, vice president of the State Board of Education.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 9 (AP) -- The United States Department of Agriculture announced today that Plum Island, New York territory eight miles off the Connecticut shore at New London, had been chosen as a "preferred site" for a $10,000,000 laboratory to study the foot-and-mouth disease of cattle.

MEXICO CITY, July 9 -- Spokesmen for Gen. Miguel Henriquez Guzman, the defeated Presidential candidate in Sunday's election, asserted today that a "considerable number" of the general's supporters had been killed in Monday's street rioting and charged that the Government had "kidnapped" the bodies to avert public anger.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, Thursday, July 10 -- Three delegates from New Jersey and one from Connecticut changed sides last night as the convention voted on the question of seating the Eisenhower delegation from Georgia in preference to the one backing Senator Robert A. Taft.

PARIS, July 9 -- The French Government today ordered Mohammed Masmoudi, the Paris spokesman for the Nationalists in the French Protectorate of Tunisia, to leave the country within three days on the ground his presence here tended to "compromise public order."

Mrs. Walter J. Monaghan, wife of a former plainclothes man and the mother of four children, does not approve of strangers as baby sitters, even though they are recommended by such a reliable agency as the Kings County District Attorney's office.

A price ceiling order that takes into consideration the special nature of the products involved was issued yesterday by the Office of Price Stabilization. While no change is made in ceiling price levels, the order is considered of importance because of the agency's awareness that various industries have specific problems not covered by a general pricing order.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 9 (UP) -- Striking sailors tied up the huge American President Lines' ship, President Wilson, today because "she is not needed for any military necessities."

Only if outsiders invest substantially in a reorganized company can general creditors participate in a reorganization plan for Huyler's, confectionery concern, Wilfred Feinberg, trustee, declared in an introduction to a reorganization plan filed yesterday in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 10 -- A 6,000-word platform for 1952, leveling a drumfire of bitter accusations against long Democratic rule and pledging a general clean-up in domestic and foreign affairs, was adopted without a dissenting vote by the Republican National Convention today.

I thought that you might be interested in knowing that I am having your editorial "Right to Counsel," published in your issue of June 27, framed and propose to give it a place of prominence in my office.

A new seventeen-inch television receiver, described as the lowest priced set of its size ever produced by a leading manufacturer, was shown yesterday at the opening of the 1953 line of Emerson Radio and Phonograph products in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. It will retail at $179.95, including excise taxi and warranty, in accordance with the company's new policy of inboard pricing on all models.
COLORADO SPRINGS, July 10 (UP) -- Judy Bell, 15-year-old star from Wichita, Kan., today reached the semi-finals of the eleventh annual Broadmoor Women's Invitational Golf Tournament.
One of the New York Public Library's most powerful magnets for the small fry of the city -- the story-telling hour -- moved outdoors yesterday for the rest of this month and August.

PITTSBURGH, July 10 (AP) -- Steve Nelson, former chairman of the Communist party in western Pennsylvania, was sentenced to twenty years in jail today for sedition. Judge Harry M. Montgomery, who presided at Nelson's trial, also fined him $10,000 and ordered him to pay court costs.

The Public Service Commission, which will begin a hearing at Albany July 23 on safety in the distribution of natural gas, was urged anew yesterday to conduct a thoroughgoing inquiry into all aspects of use of the fuel.
A little mature reflection could wipeout much of the bitterness which has been reported by Benjamin Fine from the nineteenth annual convention of the National Education Association in Detroit.

The stagehands of the theatre have a traditional pose. While the players are making guarded love before the first-act setting the stagehands stand in the wings, waiting to put in place the setting for the second. As they wait to make this change, they stand motionless, with heads down, arms relaxed, resting, seemingly asleep.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, Friday, July 11 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower seemed to be moving steadily today toward an early ballot nomination as the Republican Presidential candidate, while backers of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio sought to form a "Stop Eisenhower" coalition.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 10 -- Delegates from New Jersey were ready tonight to vote 33 to 5 for the nomination of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower as the Republican candidate for President. The Connectticut delegation stood 21 to 1 in favor of the general at the same time.

An irate housewife argued yesterday forenoon in Central Park Station that slapping a policeman was not striking him, above all when he only got what he deserved for attempting to serve a summons on her because the family collie dog romped free in a forbidden area.
Three persons were injured and ten apartments were damaged at 11:05 A. M. yesterday by a gas explosion in a six-story apartment house at 221 Sherman Avenue, in the Inwood section of Manhattan.
TOKYO, Friday, July 11 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,307 for the twenty-four hours ended at 6 A. M. Friday, Korea time:

Estimates of the losses incurred by the Staten Island Rapid Transit Railway in maintaining passenger service were given yesterday by witnesses for the railroad at a hearing before the Public Service Commission at 233 Broadway. The carrier, a subsidiary of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, seeks to discontinue its passenger service.

HONESDALE, Pa., July 10 -- Flash floods resulting from heavy rain stopped trains, cut roads, marooned people in houses and caused an estimated $750,000 worth of damage today in Wayne County, site of at least thirty private summer camps for New York children.

TOKYO, July 10 (UP) -- The new United Nations Command set-up for Korea, with Gen. James A. Van Fleet's Eighth Army freed of rear-area anxieties, will enable the Allied forces to deal with the increasing Communist pressure along much of the battle front.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 10 (AP) -- F. J. Mollica's favored Musician set all the pace tonight in winning the feature race at Roosevelt Raceway. With Stanley Dancer handling the reins, the 5-year-old paced the mile in 2:04 1-5 to finish a length in front of Sparkle Hanover.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Political activity was at a low ebb in the Capital today as Democrats and Republicans alike stayed close to their television sets, waiting to see who would win the Republican Presidential nomination.

A rise of 30 per cent in polio-myelitis incidence as compared with the first six months of 1951 was disclosed yesterday in the mid-year report of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis. There were 500 more cases reported than in comparable periods of the severest epidemic years of 1949 and 1950, but they were not so widespread.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 10 -- Members of the Economic and Social Council adopted today a number of recommendations to governments designed to promote international economic stability and full employment, with particular reference to possible future recessions.

Melbourne, Australia, has no intention of relinquishing its claim on the 1956 Olympic Games, Mayor Impellitteri was notified yesterday. The Mayor immediately "retreated to a previously prepared position" of setting his sights on getting the 1960 international competition for New York.
TOKYO, July 10 (Reuters) -- Japan is planning to approach the United States about a joint Japanese-American project to produce pulp wood in Alaska.

Another step in the city's expanding program of sewage disposal and its plan to eradicate pollution in waters around the city was taken yesterday when Public Works Commissioner Frederick H. Zurmuhlen accepted the new Sludge vessel, Owl's Head, the fourth and largest, for use in the department.
BONN, Germany, July 10 -- The rearmament of West Germany and its integration in the European community received a smashing endorsement in the Bundestag tonight

Two exceptions to television's generally good record for impartial presentation of political issues have come to the fore. One is the new half-hour video program of Vivien Kellems, who for some years has been conducting a one-woman campaign against the Administration's tax policies.

A picture of just where New York State stands in child care facilities and services and a clear outline of how much further it still has to go are contained in a report titled "Child Welfare in New York State," just issued by the State Department of Social Welfare.
Taxicab drivers received no more abuse than usual yesterday as the new higher fares that will add $32,000,000 a year to gross bookings went into effect here.
CHICAGO, July 10 (AP) -- The Republican convention endorsed today the Texas Eisenhower faction, but the action merely intensified the struggle for party control in the state.

CHICAGO, July 10 -- Rivals for the Republican Presidential nomination, or their emissaries, beat a path to the door of Gov. Earl Warren today, while Senator William F. Knowland, the Californian's floor leader at the convention, claimed new and unexpected first ballot strength for his candidate.

Suede was the favored fabric in the fall collection of millinery presented yesterday at Beatrice-Martin, 16 West Fifty-seventh Street. Cutouts of brightly colored suede were appliqued on a number of town tweed felt cloches and turbans.
PHILADELPHIA, July 10 (UP) -- Alex Kellner spun a four-hitter and was supported with a ten-hit attack tonight as the Athletics beat the Indians, 11 -- 1.
ST. LOUIS, July 10 (UP) -- The Cardinals routed Curt Simmons in the first inning tonight and then coasted to their tenth straight victory as they whipped the Phillies, 10 -- 3.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 10 -- The first ballot division of the New York State delegation of ninety-six to the Republican National Convention was set definitely tonight as ninety-two for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and four for Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio.

Shareholders of American Potash and Chemical Corporation yesterday approved by a 79 per cent favorable vote purchase of 120,000 shares of the company's stock from Mathieson Chemical Corporation at $40 a share. Peter Colefax, president, announced that the deal had been completed.
Bill Veeck's highly sensitive Browns made the Yankees' home coming at the Stadium a thumping success last night.

LONDON, July 10 -- An analysis of the 1951 census results published today showed that since the 1931 census the people of Britain, especially the women, have been marrying younger, getting divorced much more often and living longer.
CHICAGO, July 10 (AP) -- Following is the text of the Republican campaign platform, of adopted by the convention today:

The machine tool industry in Germany is supplying this country with tools and other products to fill gaps in defense plants, it was asserted yesterday by Kurt Orban, president of the Kurt Orban Company, Inc., a major importing concern.

The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) is not involved in any illegal arrangements anywhere of any kind, including those that would fix prices, allocate markets or control or restrict oil production, Eugene Holman, president, said yesterday in a letter to stockholders and employes.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 10 -- Senator Harry P. Cain of Washington invited the young people of America today to join the Republican party because it was the "only political organization on the face of the earth that still adheres to the belief that the individual himself comes first."

MIAMI, Fla., July 10 (AP) -- A young Illinois laborer, a California salesman, a Washington State College student and a Florida airline pilot captured semi-final berths today in the national public links tournament.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 10 -- Dr. Ary Torres, the principal Brazilian collaborator in Point Four economic development work, has been named president of the newly created National Bank for Economic Development. The bank is intended to finance Brazil's part of projects in which the United States is aiding. The decree was signed last night by President Getulio Vargas.
WASHINGTON, July 10 -- President Truman signed an appropriations bill today giving the military services $46,610,938,912 for their operations during the next twelve months.
LONDON, July 10 (Reuters) -British silversmiths protested today that American companies are faking ancient British hallmarks on silver plate.
LONDON, July 10 -- News of a record June steel output, following a more optimistic forecast for the coal industry, helped industrial shares to maintain their advance in the London stock market today.

BOSTON, July 10 -- Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee paid a flying visit to Boston today in the interests of his Presidential candidacy and apparently made a favorable impression on at least one important delegate to the Democratic National Convention, Mayor John B. Hynes.

The long statement of the Republican party on foreign policy sounds as if twenty or more people had had a look at the first draft, come up with a favorite phrase or idea of their own, and insisted upon, and achieved, its incorporation. Nine-tenths of the statement is introductory, taking the form of a sharp attack upon the foreign policies of the Democratic party.

FAIRMONT, W. Va., July 10 -Judge J. Harper Meredith today denied a motion to direct a verdict in favor of the defendant in the $100,000 slander suit by Dr. Luella Raab Mundel, former head of the Art Department at Fairmont State College, against Thelma Brand Loudin, vice president of the State Board of Education.

The Authors League of America, parent body of the Radio Writers Guild, voted yesterday to ask its members over the country to contribute funds to help sixty-seven radio writers who have been on strike since July 2 against NBC, CBS and ABC networks.

BOSTON, July 10 (AP) -- General Manager Joe Cronin of the Red Sox said tonight that the status of Jim Piersall was unchanged as that young outfielder flew back to Birmingham to rejoin his Southern Association Club.

CHICAGO, July 10 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, fighting tenaciously for the Republican Presidential nomination, initiated today a movement intended at minimum to prevent any first-ballot designation of his chief rival. General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- The forecast of the Department of Agriculture for grains and other crops compared with last year and the ten-year average follow:

The handbag industry will realize a 10 to 15 per cent increase in dollar and unit volume over last fall, according to Mitchel Bienen, president of Ronay, Inc., manufacturer of bags in the $7.50 to $25 range. A 10 per cent increase next fall, he said yesterday, would bring the industry back to a "normal" period while a greater rise would mean a good season.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- William S. Cox had his commission in the Navy taken away from him 139 years ago. President Truman signed a bin today that gives him the authority to return Lieutenant Cox' commission to him.

LONDON, July 10 -- A new synthetic male hormone called DHA (dehydro-- iso -- androsterone) has been used with considerable success on difficult cases of schizophrenia, a form of psychosis, according to two papers on the subject in the current issue of the British Medical Journal.
HELSINKI, July 10 (AP) -- Two Russian women who set world records in recent years have failed to make the Soviet track and field team for the Olympic Games.

ST. PAUL, July 10 (AP) -- A 42-year-old player of twenty-one years' campaigning and a 28-year-old pro in his third year on the tourney circuit blasted out 64's to tie for the lead at the end of the first round in the $15,000 St. Paul open golf tournament today.

YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N. Y., July 10 -- A freakish accident on the Taconic State Parkway at 3 A. M. today caused $100,000 damage to a bridge that had been under construction for six months and completely blocked the important parkway. The motorist involved suffered only minor injuries.

Two representatives of local 649 of the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., were arrested yesterday on charges of conspiracy and attempted extortion. They are Anthony Topazio, 38 years old, of 33 De Martino Avenue, Yonkers, secretary-treasurer of the local, and Joseph Cohen, 43 of 358 South Second Street, Brooklyn, an organizer.

The nation recently concluded a holiday week-end in which more than 300 persons lost their lives in traffic accidents. This is a familiar story and one asks again: Can something be done to reduce this needless loss of life?

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The United States, Britain and France agreed today to a four-power meeting with the Soviet Union but insisted that the talks be limited to the selection of an impartial commission for studying the possibility of free elections throughout Germany.

Considerable new construction of both tankers and dry cargo vessels is expected to result from rule changes governing the transfer of American-flag ships to foreign ownership or registry announced yesterday by the Federal Maritime Administration.

Back seat drivers at least in New Jersey will have competition from a concrete road strip that will hiss an audible warning to the erring motorist. The New Jersey State Highway Depart ment announced yesterday that it would install "talking" lane dividers as part of a widening of Route 6 to end a traffic bottleneck at Netcong and Roxbury Township.

THE word from Gloucester is that an outstanding season for tuna may be in the making for Ipswich Bay, perhaps as good as the one of 1949. No bluefin have been taken on rod and reel so far, but keg line and harpoon have produced upwards of fifty, all over 400 pounds.

PITTSBURGH, July 10 -- With victory beckoning and with it a chance to pick up a game on the beaten Dodgers, the Giants went into a nose-dive tonight that stunned even the 15,226 partisan fans in Forbes Field.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 10 -- A plea for political activity at the coffee-drinking and baby-sitting level was made at the Republican convention today by the National Committeewoman from Montana.

It is a specialized collection that is being shown at the house of Braagaard where the two designers, Braagaard and Sardinas, his associate, fashion millinery with merit as its understatement. The trends of the day are followed in an individualized but never exaggerated manner.

The appointment of William W. Golub as counsel to the Long Island Transit Authority to replace Edward W. Bourne, who has resigned, was announced yesterday by George E. Roosevelt, authority chairman. Mr. Roosevelt said that the extent and complexity of the legal work required in the reorganization of the Long Island Rail Road might necessitate the appointment of additional counsel later.

CHICAGO, July 10 -- Home runs by Jackie Robinson and Duke Snider, as well as a pair of triples by Pee Wee Reese and another by Robinson, couldn't offset the shabby fielding of the Dodgers at Wrigley Field today as the Cubs won, 7 -- 6.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- During the week ended July 9, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, member bank reserves increased $260,000,000. The principal changes supplying reserves were an increase of $310,000,000 in Reserve bank credit and decreases of $52,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve banks, $32,000,000 in money in circulation, and $13,000,000 in Treasury cash holdings.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The outcome of a fourteen-year fight by coastal states for title to submerged oil resources off their shores may hinge on the identity of the next President. Advocates of state ownership consequently have a very special interest in the Chicago conventions.

Shirley Blocki of Long Beach, Calif., was declared the winner of the recent all-woman transcontinental air race at a dinner in the Park Sheraton Hotel last night. She had made the more than 2,000-mile flight from Santa Ana, Calif., to Teterboro Airport, N. J., in twenty-two hours and thirty-eight minutes.
CHICAGO, July 10 (AP) -- Dick Savitt of Orange, N. J., seeded first, continued his saunter through the national clay courts tennis tournament today.

Four traffic officers of the Port of New York Authority received yesterday the agency's Commendation Medal for "unusually efficient service characterized by specific good conduct, judgment or initiative."
Three Staten Island boys adrift on a Army raft in the Lower Bay for an hour yesterday were rescued by an unidentified launch as they were being carried by wind and tide toward Sandy Hook.

Charles Schiff, 25-year-old New York conductor, will make his first appearances with the Stadium Symphony Orchestra next Tuesday and Wednesday evenings, as a highlight of the fourth week of concerts at Lewisohn Stadium.

Merger of E. R. Squibb Sons, a leading ethical pharmaceutical concern, into the Mathieson Chemical Corporation, major producer of industrial, agricultural chemicals and petrochemicals, was proposed yesterday by directors of both companies.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, Friday, July 11 -- The names of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio were placed formally before the Republican National Convention last night and early today in nominating speeches indicative of the fighting election campaign to which both were pledged.

Yehudi Menuhin, violinist, was soloist for the Stadium Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Pierre Monteux, at Lewisohn Stadium last evening, playing the Beethoven D Major Violin Concerto as part of an all-Beethoven program. The concert attracted an audience of 17,500, second largest of the stadium season.
CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, Friday, July 11 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from the speeches nominating aspirants for the Republican President candidacy here last night and early today:

Sixty-six squads of juvenile safety deputies were sworn in yesterday at Police Athletic League play streets in the city. And from the zeal with which they took up the first day's program, wild horse power alone should tempt motorists into zones where driving is forbidden.

F. Ambrose Clark's The Creek gave a fine exhibition in winning the Aqueduct Spring Maiden Steeplechase yesterday. While a crowd of 19,608 looked on at the Aqueduct track, The Creek led the procession all the way over the course of about two miles to defeat Mrs. Esther du Pont Weir's Master Mariner by a half length.

SPRING LAKE, N. J., July 10 (UP) -- Billy Talbert of New York and Gardnar Mulloy of Coral Gables, Fla., moved into the semi-final of the Bathing and Tennis Club invitation tournament today without loss of a set.

As part of the state-wide campaign for 70,000 additional volunteers to make a total of 100,000 aircraft spotters, the New York City Office of Civil Defense on behalf of Director Arthur W. Wallander yesterday appealed for 900 recruits.

GLEN HEAD, L. I., July 10 -- Peggy Mackie of Inwood and Mrs. Mortimer May of Willow Brook, won the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association best-ball championship today. Playing at the North Shore Country Club course, they defeated Roslyn (Cookie) Swift of Glen Oaks and Mrs. Samuel Weinsier of Fresh Meadow, 2 and 1.

CHICAGO, July 10 -- Donald W. E. Eastvold, the young state of Washington lawyer credited with a major portion of the success of the Eisenhower forces in the fight over Southern delegates at the Republican National Convention, has two big reasons to count Nov. 4, 1952, as an important date in his life.
