David Ffolkes, scenic designer who will turn producer this season with "The Thracian Horses," has reached an agreement with John Burrell for the latter to handle the direction of the Maurice Valency play. Since Mr. Burrell already is committed to stage Stanley Young's play, "Mr. Pickwick," there will be a delay of a month in the production plans for the Valency project.

CHICAGO, July 10 -- The sale of three cargoes of corn to Austria, together with extremely light receipts at Western points stimulated active buying of July and September corn today. Activity of other grains on the Board of Trade was without special significance, the general disposition being to mark time pending the Government's July crop estimates, which were due after the close today.

Capt. Giovanni Gladioli, who last sailed from New York in command of Italy's largest liner, the Vulcania, has made good his vow not to be "legislated from the seas" and is on his way back to America on the bridge of an Israeli freighter.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- Following is the text of a United States note to the Soviet Union on unification and peace for Germany, similar to communications handed to the Kremlin by Britain and France:

City and state fiscal experts held their third meeting yesterday in the office of Budget Director Abraham D. Beame to discuss a long-range program to finance the city's budget needs for 1953-54 and succeeding years.

A six-block area in South Ozone Park, Queens, adjoining Idlewild Airport, has been purchased by Wildwood Gardens, Inc., from the estate of J. Milton Bergen in a transaction negotiated by Butterly Green as brokers. The property. is bounded on the north by South Conduit Avenue and on the east by 130th Place.

Happy was sad yesterday. Neither whines nor whimpers saved the 4-year-old Belgian shepherd from being bathed at a dog-washing demonstration in the Jones Center of the Children's Aid Society, 405 East Seventy-third Street.

HONG KONG, July 10 -- A "patriotic health campaign" is now unfolding throughout China in the form of mass inoculations, urban refuse clean-ups and a systematic drive against flies, rodents, mosquitoes, fleas and bedbugs. The campaign has been accompanied in rural areas by a war on locusts, spiders and other crop-destroying insects.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 10 -Greet Garson and June Allyson today were cast in starring roles in different pictures at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer. Miss Garson, who already has three films on her schedule for the immediate future, has been chosen by the studio to appear as Marjorie Lawrence, former Metropolitan Opera star, in "Interrupted Melody," a drama with music based on the life story of the singer, who resumed her career briefly following a crippling attack of polio.

LONDON, July 10 -- William Martin Marshall, 24-year-old Foreign Office radio operator, was found guilty today and sentenced to five years imprisonment for having passed secret information about the diplomatic radio service to a Soviet official and for having recorded information. He was acquitted on a further charge of obtaining information.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 10 -- Overriding protests from the women and the South, the Republican Convention voted today to give a National Committee seat to state chairmen whose states voted predominantly Republican.

PORTLAND, Ore., July 10 (AP) -- The United States and the United Nations should work anew to gain the freedom of William Oatis, imprisoned in Czechoslovakia, a resolution adopted by the American Newspaper Guild, C. I. O., said today.

Two works of non-fiction are the only books published today. Harvard University Press is issuing at $5 C. L. Cline's "Byron, Shelley and Their Pisan Circle," a retelling of the lives of the poets and their friends. Coward-McCann has for $3 Kataryn Loughlin's "Miss Abby Fitch-Martin," an account of small-town life in upstate New York.

ST. ANNE'S-ON-SEA, England, July 10 -- Five thousand golf lovers packed around the home green of the Royal Lytham St. Anne's Club let go a roaring cheer late this afternoon as Fred Daly of Belfast, Ireland, completed a second superlative round in the seventy-two hole British open championship to establish a four-stroke lead.

Arlington County. Va., sold yesterday $3,500,000 of school bonds due from 1953 to 1972 to Estabrook Co. and associates at a bid of 100.43 for interest of 2.35 per cent. The bonds were reoffered at yields of 1.1 per cent to 2.5 per cent.

GENEVA, July 10 -- The president of Switzerland's largest industrial enterprise, Dr. Waiter Boveri of the Brown Boveri Company, bluntly warned the United States today that unless its international trade policy was revised toward larger imports the free world would be plunged into an economic crisis greater than that of 1931.

PARIS, July 10 -- The Eisenhower victory in the contest over the Georgia delegation at the Republican National Convention in Chicago led several Paris newspapers today to predict the general's nomination. The news from Chicago took precedence over all other topics in the French press.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, Friday, July 11 -- An uproarious forty-six-minute ovation for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, and one of only lightly less exuberance for Senator Robert A. Taft, marked the quadrennial enactment of the greatest spectacle in American politics, the nomination of aspirants to the highest office in the land.

CHICAGO, July 10 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower has achieved a signal victory in the drafting of an agreed foreign policy and national defense program for the Republican party by securing approval of a platform entirely excluding reference to the specific theory of "retaliation" in connection with American security guarantees abroad.

Puerto Rican woven grass reed fabric is combined with mahogany wood, in a mellow brown finish, for a new correlated collection of furniture designed by Farkas-Baermann. It will be on view Monday at Modernage, 16 East Thirty-fourth Street. The display marks the twenty-fifth anniversary of the founding of Modernage and the fiftieth of the manufacturer of the furniture group. Unagusta of Hazelwood, N. C.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 10 -- Eighty-eight more Negroes were arrested at Port Elizabeth today for disobeying the racial segregation laws.
Secret negotiations to end the thirty-nine-day-old steel strike got under way yesterday in Pittsburgh.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 10 -- Eugene Roth of Fenway and Mal Galletta of North Hills, L. I., posted 31, 35--66 for a one-stroke triumph in the annual Seymour Mittlemark Memorial best-ball tournament at the Fenway Golf Club today.

The three factory buildings at 47-55 Rodhey Street and 662 Wythe Avenue, Brooklyn, formerly occupied for the manufacture of paints and varnishes, have been sold by the American Waterproofing Corporation and the 47-55 Rodney Street Corporation to an investing client of the Kalmon Dolgin Company, broker in the transaction.

TOKYO, Friday, July 11 -- The Chinese Government's official radio told the United Nations today to "stop bargaining with the lives of prisoners of war" and agree to the Communist plan for the exchange of all captives in Korea, by force if necessary.

Formation of a citizens' committee to support efforts of the tenants of Parkway Village, Queens, to obtain a rent settlement and continue as a "world community," was announced yesterday by Nelson Seitel, executive manager for Robert F. Wagner Jr., Borough President of Manhattan.
Mayor Impellitteri began yesterday a campaign to obtain the cooperation of city, state and Federal authorities in a program to eliminate unsafe and insanitary slum housing conditions.

Double parking is "a public nuisance" and a motorist whose car has been blocked is entitled to collect damages, the Appellate Term of Supreme Court ruled yesterday in affirming an award made in Municipal Court.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended July 5, 1952, totaled 447,396 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 201,776 cars, or 31.1 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 140,763, or 23.9 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year and 106,514, or 19.2 per cent fewer than in the corresponding week two years ago.
HELSINKI, July 10 (AP) -- Finland proclaimed an Olympic truce in the style of ancient Greece today with the hope that the biggest athletic festival will go off smoothly.

The debut yesterday of the first two jaguars born in the Central Park zoo was halted abruptly in its third hour because, as it seemed to one of the keepers, "children just don't know how to behave any more."

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The international materials conference today announced the allocations of copper for the third quarter of this year, allotting metal for United States' defense needs as well as for the country's stockpiling purposes. The organization allocated 368,100 tons to this country of a total supply of 744,290 tons.

PATERSON, N. J., July 10 -- Plans for a $10,000,000 building project here, which will include a seven-story office building and a thirteen-story 1,200-car garage, were disclosed today by Joseph R. Lambert of Joseph R. Lambert Son, real estate brokers.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 10 -- Dr. Mohammed Mossadegh agreed today, after a two-hour discussion with eighteen delegates representing the Iranian Chamber of Deputies, to form a new government and present a definite program.

HONK KONG, July 10 -- The British-owned Ewo cotton mills, one of the companies affected by the decision of British concerns to withdraw from Red China, announced in a public notice here today that a stockholders meeting would be held in Shanghai August 7 to change the concern's articles of association.

LONDON, July 10 -- James B. Figgins, leader of the 400,000-strong National Union of Railwaymen threatened today that the union might use strike action to fight the Conservative Government's bill to restore nationalized trucking to private ownership.
Prices of July futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 16 points higher yesterday and other months ended 4 points higher to 4 points lower than on Wednesday.
ALBANY, July 10 (UP) -- Billy Shields, the defending champion, today eliminated Joe May of Buffalo, 6 and 5, in the fourth round of the State amateur golf tournament.
CHICAGO, July 10 -- The official communique from General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's headquarters tonight was:

Top grade eggs, which are in very limited supply, have soared to 81 cants a dozen. Yesterday the large Grade A's shot up 8 cents a dozen, according to the City Department of Markets. Even higher prices were forecast for the week-end. In the last three weeks large eggs have advanced 18 cents a dozen.

JACKSON, Mich., July 10 (AP) -Warden Julian N. Frisbie, 60-year-old retired Marine brigadier general, was ousted today from his job as head of Southern Michigan Prison, scene of two riots in recent weeks.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (UP) -- A threatened strike that would have stopped production of Saber jet fighters for Korea was averted today when the United Automobile Workers of America, C. I. O., and North American Aviation, Inc., agreed to binding arbitration of their contract dispute.
There were two developments in sugar yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals today upheld the action of the Civil Aeronautics Board in revoking the operating permit of Air Transport Associates, Inc., of Seattle, Wash.

Currency exchange restrictions arising from dollar shortages again are stimulating barter and round-about trading to weird lengths. A sample is given in the current bulletin of the Brazilian Government Trade Bureau issued here. In an item attributed to Gileno de Carli, president of Brazil's Alcohol and Sugar Institute, it is reported that Germany may soon swap a fertilizer plant for 250,000 bags of sugar.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that department store sales in the United States during the week ended July 5, rose 4 per cent above those in the same period of last year.

CHICAGO, July 10 -- After witnessing the spectacle here this week, nobody can say that democracy lecks drama. Hitler's great demonstrations in the heyday of the Nazi party could not simulate the free play of real forces and raw emotions beating against the drab walls of the stockyard's amphitheatre last night.

THE trouble with Cinderella has always been that the pumpkin coach fell apart at midnight and the horses were turned back into mice. But the trouble with Artie Shaw, as he makes abundantly clear in this always sincere, if somewhat naively written book*, is that he did not enjoy the pumpkin coach even when he was in it.

PARIS, July 10 -- To an audience of French physicians, officials, war veterans and others Dr. Howard Rusk, Director of the Institute for Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation in New York and associate editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, explained today the achievements in the United States in restoring to active life disabled persons who until recently were considered hopeless invalids.

Professor Steere of Haverford has, in a letter to THE TIMES on June 24, taken exception to a piece of mine published on June 1 about the Schweitzer Hospital. He complains of disparaging remarks and challenges a conclusion which was, in fact, not there at all.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (UP) -The Department of Agriculture estimated today that farmers will harvest a 3,365,089,000-bushel corn crop this year, very nearly meeting Government goals for the key feed crop.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., July 10 (AP) -- Federal Judge Alfred V. Bryan today heard final evidence in the Government's suit to reclaim the tanker Meacham, which it sold as a surplus vessel in 1948. Judge Bryan set oral arguments for Sept. 15.

PARIS, July 10 -- The National Assembly approved late tonight a bill aimed at ending trusts or industrial agreements that seek to maintain prices at artificially high levels by stifling competition. The vote was 243 to 173, with most of the support coming from the Popular Republicans and Socialists.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 10 -- The United States, Britain and France outlined today the terms of reference under which they would be prepared to continue economic assistance to Yugoslavia for the fiscal year 1952-53.
DETROIT, July 10 -- A confident Averell Harriman resumed today his courtship of Michigan's forty-vote delegation to the Democratic National Convention opening in Chicago July 21.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, July 10 (AP) -- The liner United States sailed today for Le Havre and then for home with the nonchalance of a champion, her skipper uncertain whether he would attempt to set a new westbound Atlantic speed record.
ALBANY, July 10 (AP) -- Drenching rains that flooded portions of New York State and chased families from their homes in the Catskill Mountains tapered off tonight.

The five-story apartment building and two-story rear studio building on lot 25 by 100 feet at 539 East Thirteenth Street have been sold by Diana Frankel to Anthony Rugolo for investment in a deal negotiated by Arnold T. Milton, broker, and Joseph Cohen, co-broker.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 10 (AP) -- The Brookmeade Stable, not very fortunate in the Monmouth Park meeting, snapped out of its doldrums in the featured High Quest Purse today as Safety carried the white and blue cross sashes to victory.
CHICAGO, July 10 -- Officials in Eisenhower headquarters here have been embarrassed all week by the repercussions to General Eisenhower's critical remarks early this week about Frenchmen.
In your issue of Sunday, June 15, I read two articles with deep interest. One, "Point 4 Will Build Ethiopian College"; another, "Conference Sifts Tribal Problems."

The final contingent of United States Olympic athletes took off from Idlewild International Airport yesterday at 1:50 P. M. Its arrival in Helsinki some twenty hours later will mark the completion of what Pan American World Airways System officials describe as the "biggest non-military airlift in history."

In the intense excitement of the Eisenhower-Taft race relatively little public attention has been given to the selection of a nominee for the Vice Presidency. Neglect of the country's second highest elective office is unfortunately typical of national conventions, but it is none the less dangerous to the welfare of the United States.
LONDON, July 10 -- Britain's economic planners have lately begun to have visions of a new kind of big dollar earning export for this country: not whisky, pottery or automobiles, but weapons of war.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 10 -- The Republican party pledged itself today to restore the dollar to "a fully convertible gold basis," generally lower taxes, an independent central banking system and an end of deficit financing by the Federal Government and of favoritism in tax administration.

CHICAGO, July 10 -- In taking control of the Republican party from the pro-Taft group that dominated its machinery when this convention began the younger and progressive delegations and their leaders were obliged to use tough methods. They repudiated the principal recommendations of the majority of the Committee on Credentials for the first time in party history.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 10 -- The Republican party pledged itself today to restore the dollar to "a fully convertible gold basis," generally lower taxes, an independent central banking system and an end of deficit financing by the Federal Government and of favoritism in tax administration.

CHICAGO, July 10 -- In taking control of the Republican party from the pro-Taft group that dominated its machinery when this convention began the younger and progressive delegations and their leaders were obliged to use tough methods. They repudiated the principal recommendations of the majority of the Committee on Credentials for the first time in party history.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The State Department began a study today of a Federal court's reversal of the department's refusal to renew the passport of Miss Anne Bauer, a United States citizen now living in Paris.

BERLIN, July 10 -- A mass meeting of an estimated total of 25,000 West Berliners to protest against the abduction of one of Berlin's anti-Communist leaders into the Soviet zone of Germany turned into a riot today after pro-Communist hecklers had tried to interrupt the proceedings.

A forty-hour week for 55,000 city employes will be instituted gradually beginning at once, according to a plan submitted yesterday to Abraham D. Beame, Budget Director, by Mayor Impellitteri. The plan, however, will not become fully effective until the 1953-54 fiscal year.

CHICAGO, July 10 -- Fashion, both high style and faddish, is an important part of the Republican Convention for the women. They are interested, of course, in who is nominated for President but they are also interested in what the other women are wearing as they wait for the decision.
The Department of Health yesterday requested doctors and nurses in the city's eighty child health centers to warn parents on the high rate of drownings among youngsters under 5 years old.

THE main trouble with every collegiate sanity code and reform movement in the past was that each was built on lip service and never on genuine desire. It was like a bank robber piously telling the parole board that he'd learned his lesson and would go straight while plotting another Brink's job as soon as he was free.

The conspiracy trial of fifteen secondary Communist party leaders was interrupted several times yesterday when the prosecution objected to cross-examination procedures of counsel for the defense. The trial is being held in Federal court.

A ten-acre tract at the northeast corner of Hillside Avenue and Herricks Road in East Williston has been leased by Irving Berger and Gilbert Tilles, builders, for another shopping center on Long Island. The property was leased through their Herricks Shopping Center, Inc., for sixty years from William Stoothoff.

Seasonal influences continued in the last week to lessen the demands of business and industry for bank funds in the New York area. A further net drop of $11,000,000 in loans by reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in this city reduced the outstanding total to $7,497,000,000 in the classification of commercial, industrial and agricultural borrowings.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (UP) -- The White Sox defeated the Senators, 2 -- 0 and 4 -- 2, behind the brilliant pitching of Billy Pierce and Saul Rogovin tonight and moved to within two and a half games of the first-place Yankees in the American League.

Help is on the way for the housewife and the janitor plagued by the modern corrugated board cartons in which the groceries come nowadays, instead of the old shook box that could be hacked up for kindling in the no longer existent kitchen coal range or used by father for whittlin'. The help is called the Constructo-Board Corporation.

CHICAGO, July 10 -- Representative Walter H. Judd of Minnesota and Gov. Dan Thornton of Colorado were added today to the list of candidates for the Republican Vice Presidential nomination considered by strategists in the Presidential campaign headquarters of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower.

Martin G. Olsen, 36-year-old former bank teller, who was accused of embezzling $38,224 from the Chemical Bank and Trust Company branch, 50 Court Street, Brooklyn, was returned from Los Angeles yesterday to face an indictment today in the Brooklyn Federal court.

The stock market dipped yesterday into lower ground despite some stiffening of prices among the industrial issues. There was no indication of either concentrated demand or selling and the retreat proved orderly. Final hour pressure again accounted for a further upset to the share list and carried the composite rate of THE NEW YORK TIMES index back 0.31 point, a more moderate recession than occurred on Wednesday.

Two new films arrived today. "We're Not Married," a Twentieth Century-Fox omnibus comedy-drama directed by Edmund Goulding and produced by Nunnally Johnson from his own script and a story by Gina Kaus and Jay Dratler, at the Roxy. Ginger Rogers, Fred Allen, Victor Moore, Marilyn Monroe, David Wayne, Paul Douglas, Eve Arden, Eddie Bracken, Mitzi Gaynor, Louis Calhern and Zsa Zsa Gabor are among the principals.

CHICAGO, July 10 -- Representative Walter H. Judd of Minnesota and Gov. Dan Thornton of Colorado were added today to the list of candidates for the Republican Vice Presidential nomination considered by strategists in the Presidential campaign headquarters of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower.

Martin G. Olsen, 36-year-old former bank teller, who was accused of embezzling $38,224 from the Chemical Bank and Trust Company branch, 50 Court Street, Brooklyn, was returned from Los Angeles yesterday to face an indictment today in the Brooklyn Federal court.

YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N. Y., July 11 -- Because of the emergency closing of one mile of the Taconic State Parkway near here yesterday by a bridge accident, the State Police and the Taconic State Parkway Commission advised motorists today to use detours around the area.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., July 11 (AP) -- Good Time, 6-year-old pacer, tonight became harness racing's top money winner by taking the $6,000 Albany Pace at Saratoga Raceway.

CHICAGO, July 11 (UP) -- Senator Richard M. Nixon, Republican of California, said tonight that he and General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower agreed that the Vice Presidency should be a job of more responsibility than ever.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, July 11 -- Senior Allied military experts at Supreme Headquarters, Allied Powers, Europe, turned aside from their international defense planning briefly today for a look at another experiment in international cooperation: The headquarters' children's school which was holding its first commencement ceremony.

The prospect of having a new $22,000,000 housing project, to be known as Governor George Clinton Houses, rise near Times Square is a pleasant one, for it will transform a definitely dingy and substandard neighborhood into desirable living space for hundreds of persons employed in a busy industrial and commercial area.

FAIRMONT, W. Va., July 11 -- Members of the State Board of Education testified today in defense of Mrs. Thelma Brand Loudin, vice president, who is being sued in Marion County circuit court for $100,000 slander damages by Dr. Luella Raab Mundel ousted Art Department chairman at Fairmont State College.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., July 11 -- Roslyn (Cookie) Swift of Glen Oaks and her partner, Mrs. Samuel Trepner of Glen Head, carried off the principal honors in the Women's Cross-County Golf Association tourney at the Rockville Country Club today.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 11 -- The proceedings that culminated in the nomination of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower were distinctly anti-climactic after the tense political jockeying and hoopla that had filled the four preceeding days and nights.

ST. LOUIS, July 11 (AP) -- The Phillies tonight threw out three Cardinals trying to score on doubles and then tallied in the tenth inning to gain a 4-3 victory, breaking the Redbirds' ten-game winning streak.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., July 11 -- Mrs. Nellie Sheer Kagan of Rockaway, Queens, led the way into the singles semi-final of the New York State women's tennis championships today after play resumed at the New Rochelle Tennis Club following a two-day suspension because of rain.

James A. Farley, former Democratic National Chairman, warned last night that the election in November would be "no pink tea party" for the Democrats and urged party leaders to subordinate personal preferences for candidates and to unite on a nominee qualified to perform the duties of the Presidency.

LISBON, Portugal, July 6 -- Development of Portugal's vast resources of strategic raw materials and basic foodstuffs in her African territories of Angola and Mozambique is one of the objectives in which the United States is deeply interested today.
DETROIT, July 11 (AP) -- Ward's Automotive Reports asserted today that "95 per cent of the automotive production in the United States may be 'blacked out' by July 25."
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- A comprehensive exhibition of textiles from all parts of Sweden is a feature here this month at the Natural History Building of the Smithsonian Institution.

The District Attorney's office charged yesterday in Felony Court that a local union of the United Automobile Workers, A. F. L., existed for the sole purpose of forcing "extorsive actions" upon the public.

BONN, Germany, July 11 -- Like a small boy swallowing castor oil but refusing to say he likes it, the West German Government and the coalition parties supporting it are "satisfied" with the latest Western notes to the Soviet Union.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 11 -- A sudden shift of nineteen delegate votes and the snowballing effect of an ancient political dictum were the chief contributing factors to the first ballot nomination today of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower as the Republican candidate for President.

PARIS, July 11 -- In Western Europe tonight the nomination of General Eisenhower was received generally with a sense of relief as auguring -- whatever the outcome of the election -- the continuance of the United States foreign policy developed in the last four years.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, as the Presidential nominee of the Republican party, will not be entitled to Secret Service guards unless he wins the election.

PARIS, July 11 -- With the cooperation of the French tourist industry Texas will add one more distinction to its many others starting tomorrow night when the entire French Riviera will begin a week of festivities in honor of the Lone Star state.
NORTH LONG BEACH, L. I., July 11 -- An 11-year-old boy sacrificed his life here this morning to save his 5-year-old brother from drowning.
MEXICO CITY, July 11 -- Ambassador William O'Dwyer is seriously considering taking up permanent residence in Mexico when his job comes to an end.

Liebmann Breweries, Inc., has announced that it increasing its already large newspaper expenditures in New York City's' dailies to make if the largest current national account in the market. Against large national advertisers in the general field, Such as soaps and toiletries and food, the account stood forty-third in rank before the new schedules were announced.
ALBANY, July 11 (AP) -- Ray Billows of Poughkeepsie beat Tommy Goodwin of Rye, 3 and 2, today in a battle of birdies to move into the semi-finals of the New York state amateur golf championship.

The appropriate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade state, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers: July I1.
Two sleek gray Navy destroyer-escorts carrying 163 reservists tied up at Pier 26, North River, here yesterday afternoon at 3 o'clock, to complete a twenty-eight-day training cruise to Europe.

MADRID, July 8 -- Juan Aparicio, director general of the Spanish Ministry of Information, today denied a statement published in the June 30 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES that his department had issued instructions to the Barcelona newspapers not to mention the words "Catalonia" or "Catalan" during the International Eucharistic Congress held in that city last May.

Combined sales volume of major stores this week showed a loss of 20 per cent from 1951 levels, little of which appeared attributable to the lure of convention broadcasts. Virtually all of the decline was statistical, and sales basically continued to show a return to normal seasonal patterns.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 11 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower accepted the Republican Presidential nomination tonight and summoned his party to a "great crusade" for "total victory" over the Democrats in November.

SHAWNEE - ON - DELAWARE, Pa., July 11 (AP) -- Favorites, headed by Frank Allan of West Pittston, Pa., medal winner, survived the first round of match play in the twenty-ninth annual Shawnee invitation golf tournament today.

Democratic party leaders in various parts of the country reacted yesterday to the Presidential nomination of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower on the Republican ticket by emphasizing the need for a liberal nominee to oppose the general.

OCEANPORT, H. J., July 11 (AP) -- Kinsman, racing in the colors of Mrs. James Carson of Perryville, Md., measured strides with Phantom Farm's Nullify, the favorite, and Joe Gavegnano's Go Between, and won by a head in the $5,000 Johren Purse at Monmouth Park today.

Communist party officials concealed the party membership of persons who felt open memberships would cause them trouble in employment, John Lautner, second Government witness in the conspiracy trial of fifteen secondary Communist leaders, testified yesterday.
The Metcalf-Hatch bill was pressured through Albany by the American Medical Association, whose head -- ironically enough -- will be the first to fall when socialism is more firmly entrenched!

HONG KONG, July 11 -- Robert T. Bryan, China-born American lawyer who was held incomunicado for sixteen and a half months as a political prisoner in a Shanghai jail, said today that his Communist captors had drugged him with two injections of "truth medicine" to extract an acceptable "confession" and a separate statement denouncing the United States State Department.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) -- United States exports increased $126,600,000 in May to reach a record high of $1,461,000,000, the Bureau of the Census reported today. The previous record was $1,455,200,000, set in May, 1944.

Actual production of steel by the nation's mills in June declined to 1,639,000 tons with the results that output for the first six months of this year totaled 45,028,660 tons, off 7,275,000, or 14 per cent, from a year ago.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 11 -- Jennifer Jones will co-star with Humphrey Bogart in "Beat the Devil," it was announced today by Santana Productions, which will make the picture in England and Europe, with John Huston directing. Miss Jones goes to Santana on loan from David O. Selznick. Interiors for the film will be shot in a London studio yet to be selected, while outdoor scenes will be photographed in southern France and Greece.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 11 -- On the crucial first call of the states, which gave to General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower the 595 votes that made his nomination for the Presidency inevitable, New York and its neighbors, New Jersey and Connecticut, gave 146 votes to the general against only ten for Senator Robert A. Taft.

Essential maintenance work on Anchorage Channel, main channel of the port in Upper New York Bay, will swing into high gear next month, it was announced yesterday by Col. Benjamin B. Talley, head of the North Atlantic Division of the Army Corps of Engineers.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 12 to 28 points yesterday after showing considerable strength early in the session. The market opened 3 points higher to 1 point lower than on Thursday. It then held steady, led by the strength in July contracts, which at one time sold at 40.42, representing an advance of 20 points.

CHICAGO, July 11 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower won the Republican nomination for President because the members of his board of strategy completely outmaneuvered the supposedly adroit group of politicians who managed the campaign of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio.

Most biographers of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, who won the Republican Presidential nomination yesterday, agree that his political outlook was influenced by his early years in Abilene, Ken., and his family heritage.

A syndicate headed by Goldman, Sachs Co. was awarded an issue of $1,985,000 of Lower Bucks County, Pa., School Authority bonds yesterday. It named a net interest cost of 2.7316 per cent for a combination of 3s, 2 5/8 s and 2 3/4 s. The bonds are due from Aug. 1, 1955 to 1992.

PELHAM, N. Y., July 11 -- More than a dozen windjammers left tonight and a score or more of power cruisers will depart tomorrow morning in the race to Block Island conducted annually by the New York Athletic Club from Travers Island.

The headline way to say it is: "Eisenhower Wins." That is true, of course, but it is only a small part of a larger truth. "Eisenhower" wins only because "Eisenhower" is a compact symbol for a group of ideas more important than any individual. Victory at Chicago is victory for these ideas and concepts, and Dwight D. Eisenhower is their distinguished and happy representative.
PITTSBURGH, July 11 -- The Giants took another one on the chin today from the Pirates. The count was 6 to 2 and as a result Leo Durocher's band is trailing the Dodgers by five and one-half games.

SPRING LAKE, N. J., July 11 (UP) -- Vic Seixas, America's top-ranking player, gained the semi-final round of the Spring Lake Bathing and Tennis Club's invitation tennis tournament today as fourth-seeded Sid Schwartz fell by the wayside.

The stock market apparently anticipated and then later applauded yesterday the nomination by the Republicans of General Eisenhower as the party standard bearer for president. Price-wise, the share list made the best showing of the week with advances of fractions to 2 points.

Political developments yesterday appeared to have no effect whatever on commodity prices. Trading floors followed the contest for the Republican nomination by radio and news ticker but market action assigned no significance to the result.

John H. Griffin, manager of the top department of Macy's, New York, has added bulk toys and wheel goods to his line. Josiah Schneider has been appointed department manager for infants' and juvenile furniture and Miss Audrey Hodupp has been named department manager of infants wear.
Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, recommended yesterday that all public employes, including school teachers, be required to take a loyalty oath at the time they start employment.

ROBERT H. STANIFORD Jr., president of the Long Island Waterfowlers Association, has been continuing his efforts to obtain a duck season for Long Island separate from the remainder of New York State. This month they took the form of correspondence with Representative Ernest Greenwood of Bay Shore, L. I. Copies of the correspondence sent to this department did not reflect progress.

GLEN COVE, L. I., July 11 -- Public sale of the fifty-seven-room mansion built by the late J. P. Morgan at a cost of more than $1,000,000 nearly forty-three years ago and which, it is believed, agents for the Russian delegation to the United Nations are seeking to buy, was deferred tonight until Aug. 16 at a brief meeting of the Glen Cove City Council.
ST. ANNE'S - ON - THE - SEA, England, July 11 -- Bobby Locke won the British open golf championship for the third time in four years today.
A four-figure daily double, the largest of the local racing season, was returned at Aqueduct yesterday.

A mysterious swindle by a thief or thieves wise in the ways of electronics, who defrauded the Aqueduct Race Track in Ozone Park, Queens, of $4,420 by cashing unauthorized pari-mutuel tickets, was investigated yesterday by Queens detectives.

MIAMI, Fla., July 11 (AP) -- Bob Scherer, a young Illinois laborer driving toward a professional golfing career, and Omer (Pete) Bogan of South Gate, Calif., a furniture salesman, smashed into the final of the national public links tournament today.

CHICAGO, July 11 (AP) -- The nation's first major test for top-flight 2-year-olds, the $108,985 Arlington Futurity, will be presented at Arlington Park tomorrow with fifteen horses named to start in the six-furlong race.

NEW DELHI, India, July 11 -- Communist protests against sarcastic references by Prime Minister Jawarharlal Nehru to the intellectual quality of his parliamentary opposition, which is chiefly leftist, caused the Prime Minister to pour on a little more of the same today.

ROME, July 11 -- The nomination of General Eisenhower was received here with relief and undisguised satisfaction, both by Italian Government circles and by most of the general public. The news dispelled fears of a resurgent American isolationism, and particularly pleased those Italians who considered that the only hope for the future was in collective security and a unified Europe.

A complaint charging illegal use of the largest quantity of carbon steel by a single company since the inception of the Controlled Materials Plan has been filed by the National Production Authority against the Art Metal Construction Company of Jamestown, N. Y., manufacturer of metal office furniture.

Rather than let his wife serve thirty days in jail, which she wanted to do, Alexander Rubi, a bank employe of 101 West Fifty-fifth Street, paid a $50 fine on her behalf in Mid-Manhattan Court yesterday. Mrs. Rubi was charged with slapping Patrolman Carmine De Franco in an altercation over a dog in Central Park on Thursday.

CHICAGO, July 11 -- The Government's official wheat estimates for July were less bearish than expected, especially the 201,000,000 bushel crop forecast for the Northwest spring wheat farms. As a result the market had a strong early tone.

BERLIN, July 11 -- John J. McCloy, retiring United States High Commissioner, said in a final broadcast from Berlin today that the Kremlin could not indefinitely resist the "peaceful pressure" of the European-Atlantic community.

UNITED NATIONS, N, Y., July 11 -- United Nations delegates are relieved that General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, and not Senator Robert A. Taft, has been chosen as the Republican candidate for President.
CHICAGO, July 11 (UP) -- Mrs. Martha Taft, who has shared her husband's defeats and victories throughout his long political career, was both a winner and a loser today.
CINCINNATI, July 11 (UP) -- The Braves hammered out sixteen hits, including Earl Torgeson's second home run of the season, to beat the Reds by 6 -- 1 today behind Warren Spahn's seven-hit pitching.
CHICAGO, July 11 (AP) -- Tears welled in General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's eyes at the moment he won the Republican Presidential nomination today.

Following are the texts of the addresses by General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Richard M. Nixon accepting the Republican nominations for President and Vice President, respectively, at the National Convention in Chicago last night, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Casey Stengel was both talking and fretting before yesterday's game between the Yankees and Browns at the Stadium. While it is not unusual for the New York manager to be doing the former, he seldom has been seen worrying. He's not the type. It developed, however, that Stengel had reason to fret, for his league-leaders proceeded to drop a 6-3 decision to a club that had been shackled with a nine-game losing streak.

When the news came to General Eisenhower yesterday that he had been nominated he went without delay to Senator Taft's headquarters. The cheering crowds, the newspaper reporters, the radio and television experts had to wait until Eisenhower had had his chat with Taft.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 11 -- Westchester County's air defense day, organized to call attention to the beginning next Monday of the Air Force's thirty-eight-state Operation Skywatch, was observed so effectively today that some persons feared that jet planes would fly through roofs of their homes.

SILVER MINE, Conn., July 11 -- A large collection of prize-winning craft objects will be placed on view here tomorrow in the Silver Mine Guild of Artists Galleries. Composed of crafts, architectural models and industrial designs, the display was arranged under the auspices of the Society of Connecticut Craftsmen and the guild. The exhibit will continue through Aug. 1.

Martin G. Olsen, whose take-home pay as a bank teller was $47 a week, appeared yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court to answer to a charge that he embezzled $38,224 of the bank's funds, disappearing with it in his lunch hour.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 11 -- Delegates prominent in the Asian bloc expressed fear today that heavy United Nations air attacks against enemy targets in North Korea might wipe out hopes for an armistice soon.

William Powers, registrar of the Graduate School of Banking of the American Bankers Association, has been appointed by Dr. Harold Sonier, director of the school and executive manager of the association, to represent the school at the International Banking Summer School at Oxford University, Oxford, England, July 19 through Aug. 1.

WILTON, Conn., July 11 -- A four-day observance of the sesquicentennial of the founding of this town and the parish of St. Matthew's Protestant Episcopal Church was marked tonight by the presentation of a historical pageant in Town Hall.
PITTSBURGH, July 11 -- Because his team obviously is playing sub-par baseball, Leo Durocher tonight revealed that the Giants face one of the most thorough shake-ups in the history of the club.
BOSTON, July 11 (AP) -- The Red Sox made the first taste of defeat for Freddy Hutchinson, new Detroit manager, doubly bitter today by taking two games from the last-place Tigers, 16 -- 6 and 5 -- 3.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 11 -- Squeezing between two rivals ten yards from the wire, Ferman Hanover, 5-year-old gelding owned by Cleo A. Young of Timmonsville, S. C., captured the $6,000 Wantagh free-for-all pace before 21,730 persons at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. At 20 to 1, he was the longest-priced racer in a field of six.

LONDON, July 11 -- The rabbit population of Australia has been reduced by "some tens of millions" by the deliberate introduction of a virus disease called myxomatosis. This estimate was made in a report published in the scientific magazine Nature this week by members of the Commonwealth Scientific Organization, who have conducted the experiment.
CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 11 -- Senator Richard Milhous Nixon of California was nominated without opposition today as the Republican candidate for Vice President of the United States.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 11 -- The mysterious barrel that United Nations officials refused to allow Israelis to transport to Mount Scopus on June 4 has been rejected for transportation to Mount Scopus by Lieut. Gen. William E. Riley, chief United Nations truce supervisor, and returned to Israeli authorities.
PITTSBURGH, July 11 -- Negotiations to end the crippling national steel strike waited on a new industry offer today.
Customs collections at this port in June dropped more than $2,750,000 below the figure for the same period last year, despite an increase of 273,529 tons in the amount of shipping using the harbor.

CHICAGO, July 11 -- It was Warren Burger, St. Paul attorney and assistant floor leader for Harold E. Stassen, who carried the message to Garcia -- to get recognition for the Minnesota switch at the Republican National Convention.

Distillers in this area are looking upon fall prospects with optimism. Reports received here yesterday indicated that improved economic conditions, more war production spending and the seasonal change in weather would add up to increased sales of liquor.

OTTAWA, July 11 (Canadian Press) -- Barriers blocking trade in livestock within Canada are being cleared away as authorities gain slowly the upper hand over Saskatchewan's foot - and - mouth disease outbreak.
TOKYO, Saturday, July 12 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,308, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Saturday, Korea time:

LONDON, July 11 -- The Stock Exchange ended a cheerful week today with prices of domestic issues continuing to rise. British Government securities took the lead, quotations advancing in busy trading conditions as much as ten shillings ($1.40).
CHICAGO, July 11 (AP) -- Dick Savitt and Art Larsen reached the semi-finals of the National clay courts tennis tournament with brisk victories today.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The small rearguard of professional politicians left in Washington was impressed today with the assurances of help given by Senator Robert A. Taft to General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower.

Two men and a woman were arrested yesterday on a charge of plotting to dig their way from the cellar of a Bronx building to a first floor office housing a check cashing service where $16,000 in cash was said to be held.

CHICAGO, July 11 -- The real die-hards in the Republican ranks in Chicago today were the supporters of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur, despite the fact that the general got only ten votes from the convention they had hoped he would stampede.

, police search for a masked bandit in a twenty-story office building off Times Square proved fruitless yesterday afternoon after an alarm was raised by a man and a girl who asserted a man wearing a bandanna about his face had made an unsuccessful attempt to rob an office at gunpoint.

PARIS, July 11 -- The split in the ranks of Gen. Charles de Gaulle's Reunion of the French People was formalized today with the formation of the Independent Group of Republican and Social Action by twenty-eight rebel Gaullist Deputies in the National Assembly.

TOKYO, Saturday, July 12 -- The United Nations and Communist delegates met for twenty-six minutes yesterday at Panmunjom with no indication that the secret sessions for discussion of the crucial question of prisoner exchange during an armistice in the Korean war yet had yielded any progress.

The First National Bank of Ardsley, N. Y., reported as of June 30, 1952, total deposits of $2,058,249 and total assets of $2,273,102, compared, respectively, with $2,000451 and $2,210,452 on Dec. 31, 1951. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $457,516 against $458,077; holdings of United States Government securities to $585,803 against $586,484; and loans and discounts to $1,184,659 against $1,124,256.

The report of the Superior Oil Company of California, issued to stockholders yesterday, showed a sharp increase in gross operating income, but a decline in net income to $10,355,711 for the nine months ended with last May from $11,275,613 earned in the similar period of the year before.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 11 -- An imperial decree was issued today charging Premier Mohammed Mossadegh with the task of forming a new cabinet to replace his Government, which resigned last Saturday in accord with constitutional practice, after the organization of a newly elected Parliament. Few changes in the ministerial posts are expected.
In the winter, it's snow, ice and extreme cold that delay the Long Island Rail Road. In the summer, it turned out yesterday, it's rain, wind and extreme heat.

TOKYO, Saturday, July 12 -- Allied aircraft of many nations smashed yesterday at the North Korean capital at Pyongyang and the Communists' military build-up in western Korea in one of the largest and most devastating raids of the war.
The following is a round-up of new booklets that might be of use to the homemaker.
MARSEILLE, France, July 11 (Reuters) -- The first tenants were moving today into Marseille's Cite Radieuse (Radiant City), the architect Le Corbusier's huge modernistic apartment block set on stilts.
CHICAGO, July 11 -- Arthur E. Summerfield of Michigan and Sinclair Weeks of Massachusetts were regarded as leading contenders for chairman of the new and enlarged Republican National Committee today.
CHICAGO, July 11 -- "Today is Ike's day," was all Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower would say when the general returned for his first triumphant march after the end of World War II.

CHICAGO, July 11 -- The Dodgers made no miscues afield today, but the Cubs committed five, with the result that the Brooks won, 6 -- 5, before 16,742 Wrigley Field fans, and took their longest lead of the season over the second-place Giants -- five and a half games.

Taking account of European public opinion, the United States, Britain and France have now agreed to a Soviet request for another Big Four conference on the key issue of Germany, but under conditions which should test Moscow's real intentions without abrogating or greatly delaying the new political and military pacts for European unification.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- James P. McGranery, the Attorney General, announced today the appointment of Charles B. Murray as a special assistant to evaluate reports asked from all United States Attorneys on the amount of time they were giving to private practice and on the backlog of cases pending in their offices.

KIEL, Germany, July 11 (AP) -- A roller-skating company from New York decided today to give a benefit performance -- without their skates. The skates and other equipment valued at $300,000 are behind the Iron Curtain, held by Russian authorities.
CHICAGO, July 11 (UP) -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower has two home states, which any politician will tell you is no disadvantage.

CHICAGO, July 11 -- Many of those associated with the Presidential campaign of Senator Robert A. Taft appeared to be headed for political eclipse today as a result of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's nomination. Had the convention's choice been otherwise, these persons would have been in charge of Republican policy making for the next four years.

More than 1,000 chaplains representing all branches of the armed forces and every major faith are expected to attend the annual convention of the Military Chaplains Association of the United States at Fort Slocum, New Rochelle N. Y., July 22-24.

MOSCOW, July 11 -- Diplomatic observers in Moscow believed tonight that prospects were good that the Soviet Union would agree to an early four-power meeting to establish a commission for an investigation of the possilibity of holding free all-German elections.

Lumber production for the week ended on July 5 was 44 per cent above the comparabale 1951 week, according to reports received by THE NEW YORK TIMES from regional associations. Shipments were up 45.5 per cent and orders, 36.7 per cent. Following are the weekly statistics in thousands of board feet:

CHICAGO, July 11 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Robert A. Taft today had their first face-to-face meeting since the Republican convention opened and exchanged mutual professions of esteem and respect in an obvious effort to allay factional bitterness within the Republican party.

PHILADELPHIA, July 11 (UP) -- Al Rosen's sixteenth home run of the season tied the game for the Indians in the ninth inning tonight and Larry Doby's fourteenth homer won it as Cleveland gained an 8-7 victory over the Athletics.

" KING SOLOMON'S RING,"* by Konrad Z. Lorenz, is presented as a book about "the human side of birds and animals delightfully described by a world-famous naturalist." Now this genial recommendation is a friendly sort of gesture toward rapprochement among birds, beasts and men. And the volume bears it out with energetic amiability.

Gayelord Hauser, author of "Look Younger, Live Longer," has a new work on Farrar, Straus Young's list scheduled for early Noveember publication. "Be Happier, Be Healthier" discusses not only diets and eating habits, but also the relation of sun, earth, air and water to every aspeect of living, showing how to use these natural forces to create healthy bodies and happy minds.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 11 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, frequently mentioned as a possible candidate for the Democratic party's Presidential nomination, today declared he had "no comment" on the nomination of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower as the Republica party's standard bearer in November.
The local summer home furnishings market in the New York Furniture Exchange went into closing stages yesterday with buying generally satisfactory.

RYE, N. Y., July 11 -- Gus Salerno and Mrs. Madelene Walinsky of Hampshire won the pro-women's best-all tournament of the Westchester P. G. A. with an eight-under-par 32, 30 -- 62 over the Ryewood Country Club course today. A total of eighty-eight teams competed.

LONDON, July 11 -- The news of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's victory at the Republican convention drew cautious expressons of approval and relief today in this city that has known him as a friend and often a neighbor during ten anxious years.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 11 (AP) -- An eccentric spinster won her last wish today -- to go back 5,000 years in death and be buried like the Pharaohs of ancient Egypt.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Grants for fourteen new television stations in nine communities were announced today by the Federal Communications Commission.

The Board of Transportation authorized yesterday, subject to approval of the Board of Estimate, eight subway construction projects in Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx with a total estimated cost of $445,650,000.
ST. PAUL, July 11 (AP) -- A couple of old hands -- Henry Ransom and Sam Snead -- shot six-under-par 66's today to stand one, two at the halfway mark in the $15,000 St. Paul open golf tournament.

This season must be the one most beloved by cooks. They must love it very much, indeed, for in it they get away with sheer murder. Using the tawdry excuse that the hot weather is no time for eating hot meals, they manage to keep away from their stoves for days at a time.

ABILENE, Kan., July 11 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's home town welcomed his nomination for President with spontaneous demonstrations minutes after word of his victory at Chicago was received here.

The undersigned, who are acquainted with German history and political realities, look with misgivings at the current unrealistic policy of the United States toward Germany. We believe that rearming of Germany, in any form, will harm the interests of this country.

RANGOON, Burma, July 11 -- The 3,000 Chinese Nationalist troops of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek who a month ago launched an attack from their base in Burma against Chnese Communists in Yunnan Province have been beaten back.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 11 -- Four of every five men students who imbibe began the practice before entering college, it was reported here today at Yale University.

The election of Bertram A. Gabriel, formerly vice president of Samuel Gabriel Sons Co. as president to succeed Arthur Gabriel, president since 1920, was announced yesterday. Arthur Gabriel becomes chairman of the board of the American Colortype Company, parent concern.

CHICAGO, July 11 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower ended his "victory day" at 10 o'clock tonight by telling a rally of 10,000 cheering persons that for the moment he was "a little bewildered, upset and uncertain."

RIO DE JANEIR0, July 11 -- The Military Assistance Agreement between Brazil and the United States which is now before the National Security Committee of Brazil's lower house has aroused the Communist press to a final effort to block its ratification.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified today 109 additional casualties in Korea, including 17 killed, 78 wounded, 10 missing and 4 injured. The following were from New York and Connecticut (none from New Jersey.)

The four aircraft that disturbed Thursday night's concert at Lewisohn Stadium have been identified, the National Air Transport Coordinating Committee announced yesterday. The four operators -- three nonscheduled and one scheduled line lines -- have been informed of the incident and each has promised immediate corrective action.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) -- Eddie Yost's single with one out in the tenth inning scored Hal Keller from second base and gave Washington a 2-1 victory over the White Sox tonight.

CHICAGO, July 11 -- Gov. Earl Warren, whose seventy-vote California delegation stuck with him, as pledged, despite heavy pressure for a first-ballot switch, described the nomination of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower today on one ballot as "a dramatic victory."
HELSINKI, July 11 (AP) -- The dispute over whether Red China or Nationalist China can compete in the Olympic Games was placed squarely before the International Olympic Committee today.

LAPEER, Mich., July 11 (AP) -- Graying, 60-year-old Mrs. Elizabeth Stevens was evicted today from the eighty-acre Lapeer County farm she had defended through years of legal warfare and two abortive eviction raids.

News of current attempts to settle the long-standing controversy between the United Scenic Artists and the League of New York Theatres involving the importation of foreign-made scenery came to light yesterday.

OSLO, July 11 (UP) -- E. A. Kongshaug of Norway became the first double individual winner at the world shooting championships today when he captured the small bore rifle event, standing position, and the match title during the second day's competition.
Richard M. Nixon, who was nominated last evening for Vice President, is a California Quaker.
CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 11 -- Through an unusual set of circumstances it fell to the lot of Harold E. Stassen today to seem to realize one of the most cherished dreams of a politician.
PORTLAND, Ore., July 11 -- A stronger bargaining policy was approved today in the closing session of the five-day national convention of the American Newspaper Guild, C. I. O.
Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr., joined with his brother Elks yesterday in setting up a focal point in Times Square for their eighty-eighth national convention opening here tomorrow.

Parents who think that children's "art experience" is limited to modeling figures from clay or creating pictures with crayons or paints are out of step with the thinking expressed in "Art in the Elementary School," a manual for teachers -- but with a message for parents -- just published by the New York City Board of Education.

The Republican choice of Senator Richard M. Nixon of California for the Vice Presidential nomination underlines the necessity and desire of the party to make a special appeal to youth. Not yet 40 years old, Senator Nixon is alert, vigorous and serious-minded.

The Veterans Administration announced yesterday that 120,000 blind, crippled and tuberculous veterans of all wars and peacetime service would receive increased monthly payments beginning with compensation checks due Sept. 1 under a bill signed by President Truman on June 30.

The Italian Line, reduced by the war to one 300-ton vessel, has built up its passenger fleet to twelve ships, with two more scheduled to enter service this year and in 1954, Carlo Linch, president of the line, announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 11 -- The Eisenhower victory is one of the most remarkable phenomena in American history. A newcomer in American politics, a man who has spent little time in his own country in the last twelve years, returns a month before the convention routs the Republican organization and its picked candidate and wins the Presidential nomination in a sweep on the first ballot.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 11 (AP) -- Calumet Farm's Two Lea and Wistful headed a field of twelve candidates named today to run in the $100,000 added Hollywood Gold Cup tomorrow, and the Kentucky stable is favored to win the rich event for the second straight year.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Politicians and television announcers, on whom the cameras bear down mercilessly at convention time, may be grateful for an invention patented this week. It is a "hair cap for bald or sparsely haired head," devised by George Frederick Hull of Yallourn, Victoria, Australia.
Following are excerpts from editorial comment in newspapers gathered by THE NEW YORK TIMES and The Associated Press on the nomination of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for President:

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 11 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower won a hard-fought first-ballot nomination today as the Republican candidate for President and Senator Richard M. Nixon of California was chosen by acclamation as his running mate for the Vice Presidency.

In your issue of July 1 Hanson W. Baldwin mentions the disparity in Korea of British Commonwealth troops vis-a-vis United States troops. He points out that the American casualties amount to 110,000 against less than 10,000 for the Commonwealth.

PARIS, July 12 -- The numerically strongest French party, that of Gen. Charles de Gaulle, underwent a split this week which may reduce its voting strength in National Assembly by about one-fourth. Yesterday, thirty dissident Gaullists formed a new group in the Assembly calling itself the "Independent Group for Republican and Social Action."

NOT nearly so restrained as Theodore Maynard's recreation of the saint of Assisi published some years ago, this narrative more closely resembles a prose lyrical poem than a novel. It will thus appeal more to readers of devotional books than to those who seek entertainment in their fiction.

THE United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization's program to stimulate development of productive and disease-resistant plant species has been responsible for more and better food crops all over the world.
DETROIT, July 12 (AP) -- There may be a new-car dealer somewhere with more cars than orders but if there is he isn't complaining as he was a few weeks ago.

LONDON. "HEPBURN PLAYS SHAW -- AND WINS," said the headline in The Brighton Standard the morning after Katharine Hepburn opened there on her pre-London tour of George Bernard Shaw's "The Millionairess." And when the production reached the West End a week later, nobody could think of anything better to sum it all up.

CHAUTAUQUA, N. Y., July 12 -- The Chautauqua Symphony Orchestra opened its twenty-fourth summer season tonight as its conductor, Franco Autori, directed works by Beethoven, Brahms and Sibelius before a capacity audience in the Chautauqua open-air amphitheatre.

GOOD gardening practices and regular maintenance through spring and early summer are the vacationing gardener's insurance against disappointment. Postponement of too much work until just before leaving can be as discouraging as returning home to flower borders engulfed in weeds, plants lying prostrate, unprotected against wind and weather, and riddled foliage that tells a story of holiday high living for every insect within range of the vacationer's garden.

Re Theodore H. White's "Victor Hugo Again Is a Storm Center" (June 22), the story goes that when the famous literary hero returned to France after Napoleon III's downfall in 1871, the City Council wanted to do something worthy of him.

LUCIDLY if conventionally, and with strong and true observations, "The Early Frost" tells the story of an unloved adolescent. Lann Saunders is the 17-year-old daughter of divorced parents, a student in a fashionable California boarding school.

THE daylily is a long-lived perennial which likes to settle down in a congenial location. Given the right conditions, one plant will develop into a large clump that produces more numerous and more beautiful flowers every year for a long time.
NEW DELHI, India, July 12 -- The appointment of Gaganvihari L. Mehta as India's new Ambassador to the United States was announced today.

PAWTUCKET, R. I., July 12 (UP) -- Top-weighted Jampol, the "Cinderella horse" of the year, surpassed the $100,000 earnings mark today with a front-running victory over a seven-horse field of 3-year-olds in the $25,000 Providence Stakes.

TWENTY-FIVE years ago this summer, there appeared at suitable intervals along United States Highway 65, just south of Minneapolis, several sets of four homemade signs each, upon which were printed the pregnant legend:

INDONESIAN nationalism and modern ways have begun to make their inroads on the green, lovely and other-worldly island of Bali -- for many years a daydream to millions of landlocked Westerners and a dream come true to a few adventurers and lotus-eaters.
TOKYO, Sunday, July 13 -- The Peiping radio charged this morning that eight United States Sabre jets strafed Antung, on the Manchurian side of the Yalu River, Friday, killing forty-nine persons.
WSAHINGTON, July 12 (UP) -- The keel of the aircraft carrier Forrestal, expected to be the largest warship in the world, will be laid at Newport News, Va., Monday afternoon.

The ocean-going tug Kevin Moran set out for Boston early yesterday, carrying nine Columbia University geologists who plan to study the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. After picking up supplies and explosives in Boston today, the 498-ton tug will rendezvous off New England with the Atlantis of the Woods Hole (Mass.) Oceanographic Institute.
Grants for research in the United Kingdom are now open to qualified American social workers under the Fulbright Program, the Institute of International Education has announced.

POSTMASTER General Jesse M. Donaldson made available last week a photograph of the 3-cent stamp to be issued on Sept. 30 for the "500th Anniversary of the printing of the first book, The Holy Bible, from movable type, by Johann Gutenberg" -- the inscription in dark Old English, which occupies the right half of an unfurled scroll that is the design.

The wife and father of a prisoner accused of robbery were arrested in Brooklyn Felony Court yesterday morning on charges of attempted bribery after a reported offer of $50 to a complaining witness to "forget" her identification.

DUBLIN, Ireland, July 12 -- Maureen (Little Mo) Connolly, the 17-year-old girl from San Diego, Calif., wound up her first international tennis tour with a perfect record and in an appropriate spot today by winning the women's Irish lawn tennis championship with a 6 -- 1, 6 -- 1 triumph over Jean Walker-Smith of Britain.

Cotton prices tended to back and fill last week, but closed the period mostly in lower ground. At the close on Friday active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were 12 points higher to 34 points lower on the week, with the only net improvement being recorded by the July delivery.

A few of Mr. Markel's suggestions are especially worthy of further thought and application. We must realize that most Europeans are not idlers. This country was built by immigrants. A sea voyage alone did not transform them from alleged drones into American pioneers and performers of hard physical labor.

CINCINNATI, July 12 -- Leo Durocher gave his Giants a dressing down in the clubhouse today and made some drastic changes in the line-up. The revamped champions then went out and downed the Reds, 5 to 3. But they didn't exactly set Crosley Field on fire.
Despite renewed dollar and exchange problems abroad, plans are now being initiated to increase sales to department stores in foreign countries of a wide line of American consumer goods.

The Navy transport Gen. Nelson M. Walker made her maiden appearance here last week when she arrived on Monday from Bremerhaven, Germany, after completing the first 14,000-mile leg of a globe-circling voyage that started on the West Coast on May 31.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia, declared tonight that it was "a curious commentary on Republican thinking" for the party to nominate a military man for the Presidency "in this time of world tension."

ALTHOUGH Faulkner seems at last to have come into his own, Irving Howe's book, the latest of several recent critical studies, makes one wonder how much of Faulkner's new prestige is due to the lack of competition rather than to our own clear and positive realization of his originality.

NOW that week-end farmers have received official recognition from the U. S. Government, they can no longer be brushed aside with a grin. Of course, it's still tough sledding to convince some country people that week-end farmers aren't slightly "teched in the head."

Faced with a shortage of volunteer aircraft spotters to man the state's 605 ground observation posts, the state Civil Defense Commission called upon civil defense personnel yesterday to contribute still more of their time until replacements are found.

THE clearest danger signal in slam bidding is a long weak suit. It doesn't help a side to hold twelve or thirteen cards that would win tricks if the opponents can start off by taking two tricks; and even when the long weak suit is controlled, as in a suit like A-x-x-x-x, it should be viewed with suspicion.

PITTSBURGH, July 12 -- The steel industry made a new proposal tonight to settle the forty-one-day-old national strike, but it failed to end immediately the walkout that had cut off seven-eighths of the country's steel supply and forced scores of large industrial plants to shut down.

ANOTHER "first" for the British-built de Havilland Comet jet airliner was written into the record last week when it flew from London to Tokyo in twenty-seven hours and twenty-two minutes' flying time. The plane made the 10,404-mile hop at an average speed of 350 miles an hour.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 12 -- None of the $23,000,000 in the Iranian Point Four Program of technical aid for this year has been allocated to the Shah of Iran's immense land reform program, although the Shah's representatives have sought help.
Pete, the hippopotamus at the Bronx Zoo, will be 49 years old today. He will spend the day quietly with his five elephant friends and two rhinoceros chums in the pachyderm house in Bronx Park.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- A White House meeting this afternoon attended by three officials of the United States Steel Corporation led to speculation that a break in the month-old strike might be imminent.
ST. LOUIS, July 12 (AP) -- Harry (The Cat) Brecheen defeated Russ Meyer in a thrilling pitching duel today as the Cardinals downed the Phillies, 3 to 2, to take the series, two games to one.

MUNSAN, Korea, Sunday, July 13 (AP) -- Communist truce negotiators said today that thirteen Allied prisoners of war were killed and seventy-two injured when Allied warplanes staged a night air attack on a Communist prison camp.
" THE CLOSEST KIN THERE IS" by Clara Winston * * * has all the earmarks of being written by a woman who combines a flawless and poetic style with great psychological insight and integrity.

SINGAPORE, July 12 -- Jean Letourneau, French Resident Minister for the Associated States of Indo- China, said today that United States military aid to the French Union forces in Indo-China now amounted to 40 per cent of the total material supplies in the Indo- China war against the Vietminh forces.

NEW ZEALAND'S Director General of Posts, P. N. Cryer, has supplied photographs of the designs of the "Health" semi-postals to be issued on Oct. 1. Seated figures of Britain's royal children are respective designs -- on 1 1/2-pence plus 1/2P chocolate, Princess Anne Elizabeth Alice Louise; on 2p plus 1p pale claret, Prince Charles Philip Arthur George, heir to the throne.

WHEN Harry Stack Sullivan suffered a fatal heart attack at the untimely age of 57, while attending the World Health Conference in Paris two years ago, we lost one of the most fertile and creative minds in modern psychiatry.

FOR travelers planning to visit Europe in the early fall, Ireland offers a number of motor coach tours at a time when hotels are less crowded than during midsummer and when most of the country can be covered in a fortnight.
CHICAGO, July 12 (AP) -- Hedge selling against purchases of cash grain depressed wheat futures prices today.

Instruction in most classrooms in the United States today is "woefully inadequate" for developing international-minded citizens needed for this century, according to a study made public last week at Teachers College, Columbia University. The study -- "World Horizons for Teachers" -- was directed by Dr. Leonard S. Kenworthy.

SHAWNEE - ON - DELAWARE, Pa., July 12 (AP) -- Ellis Taylor of Wilmington, Del.; Rudy Ozol of Union, N. J.; Lionel Noah of New Canaan, Conn., and Olin Cerrochi of Bayside, Queens, today reached the semi-finals of the Twenty-ninth Annual Shawnee Invitation Golf Tournament at the Shawnee Inn and Country Club.

The stock market made two decisive moves last week -- a retreat in the final hour of trading on Wednesday and a firm upturn in Friday's late dealings, coincident with the Republican convention's nomination of General Eisenhower for President -- but otherwise held to a narrow course in only moderately active dealings.

SPRING LAKE, N. J., July 12 -- Vic Seixas of Philadelphia and Billy Talbert of New York gained the final of the Bathing and Tennis Club's invitation tennis tournament today for the second straight year.

SLOATSBURG, N. Y., July 12 -- Northbound motorists on Route 17 today spent several hours of their vacation time in what was described as the heaviest traffic congestion of the year in the noted bottleneck created by parking on the east side of the main highway here.
WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- Three different programs are emerging from the election year debate on foreign policy.
Chicago's political slugfest had its counterpart in Brooklyn yesterday. Six Eisenhower supporters were arraigned on charges of felonious assault charges after a battle with Taftites from Greenpoint.

ALTHOUGH Simon Schuster has adopted an official "no comment" attitude, it is reliably reported that the Ickes diary mentioned in these columns two weeks ago has gone to S. S., with the probability that editor Joseph Barnes will do the blue-penciling and that Mrs. Ickes will be retained as technical adviser.

WILMINGTON, Del., July 12 (AP) -- The 40-year-old Collector of Internal Revenue for Delaware said today he resigned because he did not meet requirements for the reorganization plan for the bureau, particularly the requirement that be give up his private business.

THE term "Indian literature," strictly speaking, is approximate, inasmuch as there are eight major languages in the country, each of which has its own literature. However, all these languages, being derivations of Sanskrit, are related -- consequently, the literature of one readily influences the literature of the other.

On reading MacGregor Burns' article, "The Case for the Smoke-Filled Room" (June 15). I was left with the impression that the author, with some exceptions, fundamentally tolerates our primary system. * * *

IN the popular mind the Lewisohn Stadium concerts seem primarily events that provide fine outdoor music for the people of the city. But throughout the years they have also provided young artists with opportunities for fame.
MONTAUK, L. I., July 12 -- "Tent City" again has mushroomed on the sandy beach at Hither Hills State Park, a few miles from Montauk Point.

BOSLEY CROWTHER, in his interesting article in last Sunday's TIMES on Eidophor, the new large-screen theatre television system, either wrote off or omitted many of the system's factors which I feel are unique.

BERLIN, July 12 -- The East Germany Socialist Unity (Communist) party ended its second party congress tonight by voting an extensive program that called for the strengthening of state power and the building of armed forces.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 12 -- The Communist germ warfare charges, which a few months ago were a cloud no bigger than a man's hand, by sheer force of repetition have now assumed a position of fundamental importance in relations between the Soviet Union and the free world.

PARIS, July 12 -- Although the Republican platform adopted at Chicago said the Democrats had no foreign policy, Europeans labor under the contrary impression; and the praise of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower published here today was based mainly upon the assumption that he would follow the main lines of the Truman foreign policy.

THE first of Carlo Coccioli's novels to be published here, "Heaven and Earth" very obviously will not be the last. Mr. Coccioli is a writer already mature, with cunning in his craftsmanship and an artistic eye able to follow reality in its progress not only from the physical to the mental but through that misty, confusing transition from the mental to the spiritual.

THE Canadian playwright Robertson Davies manages to include in his first novel all the possible ingredients of a dull amateur theatrical -- the jollying, the fussing, the chatter and a suicide which is a miss.
