But many of Shakespeare's fundamental ideas and attitudes have lost their validity; some of the conventions and techniques he employed are now strange or obsolete; and the platform stage for which he wrote has been superseded by the picture stage.

In your editorial of July 5 you rightly stress the urgent need to expose and counteract the perversity of the Soviet hate campaign spreading deliberately fabricated accusations of bacterial warfare. This action is clearly intended to foster a warlike atmosphere behind the Iron Curtain and to create suspicion and resentment against the United States in Asia and inside the Western camp.

THE late Bela Bartok, according to those who knew him well, looked upon his researches in the field of Hungarian folk music as hardly less important than his composing. An avid collector, he had toured the remote towns and villages of his native land before World War I, recording authentic music of the people on old-fashioned Ediphone cylinders, and at his death was probably the world's foremost authority on the music of Hungary.

The fact that virtually all the free world should hail with satisfaction the nomination of General Eisenhower is not in itself surprising. He is admired by all with whom he has come into contact, and he has inspired a high degree of confidence. To still others he stands as a symbol of American cooperation, friendship and leadership.
Terry Young, lightweight boxer, was one of two men arrested on Friday on charges of having stolen a $472 payroll of the National Committee for Labor Israel, the police disclosed yesterday.

IN many publications which deal with the problem of religion and psychiatry one is never quite sure what the author means by religion. The term religion may connote anything from some vague feeling of brotherhood to "our common higher values."

Discovery of the smallest known star -- only about one-third as large as the earth -- is announced jointly by Dr. Willem J. Luyten, Professor of Astronomy at the University of Minnesota, and Dr. E. F. Carpenter, director of the Steward Observatory at the University of Arizona.
A crowd of 32,612 winner-seekers at Aqueduct yesterday saw the richest and fastest mile-and-a-quarter running of the Brooklyn Handicap.

CHICAGO, July 12 -- For the first time since he returned from Europe six weeks ago, General Eisenhower now will have time to rest and take command of the extraordinary political adventure that has been launched in his name.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 12 -- The devil red silks of Kentucky's Calumet Farm were carried to victory for the second straight year in the $137,100 Hollywood Gold Cup today when Two Lea, the stable's distinguished mare, won the thirteenth running of the mid-summer event at Hollywood Park.

Business skills can now be learned in a fraction of the time formerly required. This is the conclusion of a report issued at City College, describing the five-year program of Intensive Business Training carried on by the institution in cooperation with business.

GENEVA, July 12 -- Denmark's decision to risk stoppage of American military and economic aid by living up to her four-year-old contract to deliver a tanker to Russia is only one in a long series of unpleasant incidents between the United States and its Allies arising out of the problem of East-West trade.
QUEBEC, July 12 -- Newsprint production in Quebec Province has increased from 1,624,332 tons in 1935 to 2,875,000 in 1951, an increase of 1,251,000 in sixteen years.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 12 -- Connecticut Democrats are planning to press Senator Brien McMahon's candidacy for President at the Democratic National Convention, opening in Chicago July 21, despite his continued illness in Washington.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 12 -- The twentieth Riverside to Stratford Shoal yacht race, a 50-mile overnight run to the mid-Sound light at the shoal and return, drew thirty-one auxiliary cruising craft tonight.

The current exchanges between the Soviet Union and the West about a four-power meeting on Germany, though politically and psychologically necessary, inevitably will act as deterrents to the building of effective military strength in Western Europe.

CHICAGO, July 12 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower resigned today from the Army and charted a "total victory" campaign aimed first at reuniting warring Republican factions that fought his nomination, and then expanding the party's growth in the "Solid South" in the hope of capturing the electoral votes of several normally Democratic states.
WITH the eyes of most of the nation fixed upon the political scene at Chicago last week, business and industrial developments were more or less forced to take second place.

Members of the Bill Orchard Alumni Association were reassured last week. At 66, William I., as he is officially named, had announced his retirement from the classes in advertising he has been teaching at Columbia's post-graduate school of business for thirty years, along with other classes at Washington Irving High School and Pace Institute.

On a large grassy mound on the west bank of the Brandywine River, near Wilmington, Del., the great chemical manufacturing company of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., will mark its 150th birthday on Friday.

BERLIN, July 11 -- Maj. Gen. Lemuel Mathewson, United States commandant in Berlin, turned down today a Soviet request that he curtail the movements of his troops to prevent them from wandering over the city line into the Soviet zone of Germany.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 12 (AP) -- President Truman's vote at the Democratic National Convention will be cast by an amiable little Irishman who was a party worker years before he could vote.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 12 -- The International Olympic Committee reecived another hot issue in sport's cold war today when it was asked to decide whether both East and West Germany should be admitted to the 1952 games.

Fall activity continued to look good to shirt manufacturers as orders from stores rolled in last week. While early orders were said to be running more than 25 per cent ahead of last year's, now that most lines are out two or more months, reports show gains averaging 20 per cent above 1951.
CREDITED with introducing "repeat performance" programming to the local scene with its "Broadway TV Theatre" showings five nights a week, WOR-TV is planning to expand on its idea.
ALBANY, July 12 -- Billy Shields, defending his title, and Ray Billows carded easy triumphs in the semi-final round of the New York State amateur golf championship today.

WHEN Henry Dreyer won the American weight - throwing championship almost two decades ago, Pat McDonald rubbed a huge pew across his jaw in sheer disbelief. "This beyond understandin'," he said in his soft County Clare brogue. "A foine lad is Henry but --" His voice rose to almost a plaintive wail as he added despairingly, "He's not Irish."

CHICAGO, July 12 -- In terms of ultimate implications to friends of the United States abroad, the candidacy of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower is infinitely more important than the phrasing of any specific foreign policy pledges contained in the Republican platform.

Your editorial "The Raw Materials Problem in 1975" in discussing some aspects of the Materials Policy Commission's report to the President summed up the problem as "essentially one of technology." The commission shares your belief in the importance of technology to do many materials jobs, and devoted an entire volume of the report to "The Promise of Technology."

LONDON, July 12 -- Emanuel Shinwell, who belongs to the moderate wing of the Labor party, warned Britain's Allies today that the country was bearing a burden of defense "far in excess of what we can afford and far greater than that of any other European country."

In honor of Bastille Day, the New York Public Library will devote its recorded concert in Bryant Park tomorrow to works of French composers, among them Ravel's "Le Tombeau de Ceuperin" in the original piano version played by Robert Casadesus.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., July 12 (AP) -- Bea McWane of Birmingham, Ala., played a steady, sure short game today to beat Mrs. Harlan Riedel of Dallas. 5 and 3, for the championship of the Broadmoor women's invitation golf tournament.

CHICAGO, July 12 -- Business conditions in the Chicago area showed some improvement in June compared with the month before the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago reported. There were slight gains in the number of employes, production and larger backlogs of orders compared with the May period.

SOUTHAMPTON -- Commodore Harry Manning has completed the first run of the United States, a voyage that has undoubtedly made history in more ways than by bringing to our country for the first time in 101 years the blue ribbon of trans-Atlantic supremacy in speed.

JOHN ADAMS, writing to the Abbe de Mably in 1782, noted four New England institutions as the key to the history of the American Revolution -- the towns or districts, the congregations, the schools and the militia. In "Meetinghouse Hill" Miss Winslow -- the author of the 1941 Pulitzer Prize biography of Jonathan Edwards -- expounds with clarity and wit the influence of the second of these institutions upon the first.

CHICAGO, July 12 -- Taking his defeat for the Republican Presidential nomination philosophically, Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio told his campaign managers and headquarters staff today that they had no reason to blame themselves for what happened, because "we did the best we could."

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- A minor thing like the travel record of Secretary of State Dean Acheson, who returned this week from a European mission by way of Brazil, has begun to reflect the pace of world events and the extent of United States participation in them.
Research is proving the savior of the men's clothing industry and, in the instance of companies in New England, providing the stimulant needed to keep alive some tottering industrial units.

HER first novel, "The Grass Is Singing," marked Doris Lessing as one of the most talented younger British writers of the last decade. This first collection of short stories reaffirms her talent; if seriousness of purpose and exceptional literary ability determined commercial success, "This Was the Old Chief's Country" would be a best seller for a long, long time.

A new city Department of Air Pollution Control would cost the city ten times as much to operate as the present $200,119-a-year Bureau of Smoke Control and should not be established, Rear Admiral William S. Maxwell, retired, deputy director of the bureau, has told the Board of Estimate.
LAPEER, Mich., July 12 (AP) -- Sheriff Clark Gregory withdrew his armed deputies today from the eighty-acre Stevens farm, scene of Lapeer County's latest and roughest eviction battle.

As soon as the Republican convention was over preparations were begun for the Democratic convention. Republican signs came down. Democratic signs began to go up. Democratic experts, studying the way in which television revealed the Republican convention, made plans for improvement.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 12 (AP) -- Capt. Robert G. Burke, a Navy officer from New York City, was elected president of the Reserve Officers Association at the closing convention session here today. Philadelphia was picked as the convention city for next year.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 12 -- Hal Senator, the 4-year-old bay horse owned by K. D. Owen of Houston, Tex., tonight proved he is still in top form. Driven by Harry Fitzpatrick, the son of Hal Dale scampered to his third straight victory in the Lawrence Junior free-for-all pace at Roosevelt Raceway.

MIAMI, Fla., July 12 (AP) -- Pete Bogan, a 35-year-old South Gate, Calif., furniture salesman, rallied today to win the national public links golf tournament with a 4-and-3 upset victory over Bob Scherer, Decatur, Ill., laborer.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 12 -- The Iranian Senate, which showed in a vote of inclination taken a few days ago that it could not muster more than 14 votes in Premier Mohammed Mossadegh's favor, voted today to go into recess until Oct. 4.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- The Defense Department today identified 215 battle casualties in Korea. A new list reported 28 killed, 156 wounded, 3 missing and 28 injured. The following casualties were listed for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut:

The immediate response to the nomination of General Eisenhower is one of deep satisfaction and gratification. The Republican party has, we believe, expressed the will not only of a majority of its convention delegates but also of a majority of Americans. The nomination came in response to a great public demand.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The Senators collected only three hits off Chuck Stobbs today but capitalized on two defensive lapses by Chicago's shortstop, Sam Dente, to beat the White Sox, 2 -- 1.
BIRMINGHAM, England, July 12 (AP) -- Doris Hart of Coral Gables, Fla., retained the women's singles title in the Midlands Counties lawn tennis championships to-

BOSTON, July 12 (UP) -- Archie Wilson, rookie outfielder, drove in the winning run with a pinch hit and made a game-saving catch today to spark the Red Sox to a 5-4 victory over the Tigers before 11,394 Fenway Park fans.

New Steel Talks Ever since the steel strike began six weeks ago manifold pressures for settlement have been building up. There is economic pressure. Labor has lost an estimated $300 million in wages. Some steel fabricators are beginning to run short of steel. There is public pressure because the strike impairs defense production.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., July 12 -- Edward Brodstein, postmaster of this city for eighteen years, who was under fire on the floor of Congress some weeks ago, has resigned and applied for a disability retirement pension.

MARK down as one of the more intriguing situations to be watched during the coming months the race between producers Irving L. Jacobs and Arthur Lesser to get to Broadway first with a play about the celebrated French artist Toulouse-Lautrec.

This year's vanguard of daylily introductions indicates the trend toward fine pastels and improved form with broader, overlapping petals and sepals. Of course, better substance and finish, more lasting blooms, sunfast colors and plants of generally good habits are characteristics which hybridists strive to fulfill annually.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- As 150,000 civilian volunteers prepared to begin Monday a twenty-four hour plane-spotting service in twenty-seven states, President Truman described the operation today as a "common sense precaution" that would serve to prevent war.

TELEVISION'S coverage of the Republican National Convention has afforded an unusual opportunity to study both the remarkable advantages and the very real limitations of the video medium as the newest arm of journalism.

PERHAPS his qualifications for the job were illusory in the first place. Robert Abial Rolfe had been a great third baseman on a great Yankee team under a great manager, Joe McCarthy. His baseball background hardly could be matched. Nor were there any flaws to be found in his personal background.

THE disgrace of Ana Pauker and other leading lights of the Rumanian Communist party seems to have surprised a great many people in the West. Madame Pauker is one of the most formidable women in the world; she has more blood on her hands than any other woman in the world -- all shed for the greater glory of Stalin -- and she was regarded, rightly, as one of the Kremlin's most reliable trusties.

BALBOA, C. Z., July 12 -- Although, in the fiscal year that ended on June 30, a new high record of 6,524 merchant vessels passed through the Panama Canal, tolls were $188,000 less than the peak for such revenue in 1929, according to the annual report of the Panama Canal Company.

IT matters title to the boasting class of Americans, as one of their own censors has said, whether a thing be good or bad, provided it surpass all others. If an Arkansas man cannot boast of the education of a Boston man, at any rate he can chew more tobacco, and spit more and farther and straighter than any other man.

An American roller skating troupe whose equipment has been seized by East German Communist autorities pending payment of a smuggling fine appealed yesterday to President Truman to authorize United States officials to pay $17,000 to $25,000 as a "fine or ransom."

In a world of tension in which the order of the day is a jockeying for position, a meeting of particular importance was held in Paris on Thursday. It was a demonstration on rehabilitation under the joint auspices of the World Veterans Federation and French organizations and was conducted by French and American physicians before representatives of more than fifteen countries.

The Republican Party has had many extraordinary conventions in its ninety-six years. There was the historic Chicago Convention in 1860 which nominated Abraham Lincoln. There was the victory-flushed convention of 1868 which nominated the triumphant Union General, Ulysses S. Grant. There was the interminable convention in Chicago in 1880 which, after thirty-six ballots, nominated James A. Garfield.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 12 -- Dixie Flyer of the Duntreath Farm calculated the distance perfectly to win the $20,000 added Molly Pitcher Handicap at Monmouth Park today. With Porter Roberts in the saddle, the 5-year-old daughter of Blue Flyer gained the lead at the quarter pole and went on to take the event by a full length.

CHICAGO, July 12 -- A dramatization of man's progress through his utilization of the science of engineering and other technical helps was portrayed here today at the opening of "Adam to Atom," an extravaganza in twenty-six scenes.

BOSTON, July 12 -- Two fishing vessels chartered by the Fish and Wildlife Service of the Department of the Interior, cruised off the New England coast today on separate research projects aimed at bolstering the region's economy.

Your editorial of July 6, "Who Owns Our Corporations?" has as its main new bit of evidence for the argument about the widespread nature of ownership of corporations in America the recent Brookings Institution's survey.

THE discussion on this page last Sunday of the effort by the American Federation of Musicians and its president, James C. Petrillo, to cut down competition from abroad has evoked a good deal of comment from readers.
Lawyers for Frank Costello, convicted of contempt of the United States Senate, will make their first move tomorrow in an effort to get the United States Supreme Court to review the gambler's case.

WHEN Goethe spoke to the Germans about Shakespeare he used the title: "Shakespeare Forever." The unending stream of Beethoven publications which has flowed through America and England for the last fifty years suggests that it is also, "Beethoven forever."

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- Never before has Florida's West Coast experienced -- and enjoyed -- such a summer tourist season as this year. Reports from Homosassa in the north down to Fort Myers in the south range from 10 to 30 per cent better than last year and there is every indication that the influx of Northern and Midwestern visitors will continue through August.

STONY BROOK, L. I., July 12 -- This little harbor village sixty miles from Times Square on Long Island's North Shore turned back the pages of history today to pre-Revolutionary times as its "Colonial" residents, celebrating the second annual Stony Brook Festival played host to 4,000 visitors.

Markets here last week were almost cleared of summer goods because both manufacturers and retailers fought to keep stocks down, according to Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office. With a tight supply of goods for close-outs reducing mark-ups, retailers concentrated on fall lines.
Two National Guard units that were among the first to be called into Federal service in the summer of 1950 were returned to state duty yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 12 -- Dodger hits were a dime a dozen at Wrigley Field today as the Brooks collected twenty-two assorted blows and buried the Cubs beneath a 12-2 score. This was the Dodgers' highest hit total since 1950, when twenty-three hits were made in the two parts of a suspended game with the Pirates.

A District Court decree awarding $2,100,000 to the De La Rama Line for the wartime loss of the cargo ship Dona Aurora has been reversed by the United States Court of Appeals on the ground that the lower court lacked jurisdiction, it became known yesterday.

CHICAGO. WE are at midpoint of the quadrennial political marathon for the biggest prize and the biggest headache on earth -- the Presidency of the United States. Last week the Republicans swarmed into Chicago's bunting-draped Amphitheatre and in a blaze of noise, heat, light and worked-up excitement abandoned themselves to the prodigious game of picking their torchbearer in the great race.

WHAT is happening in the curious world of science fiction is patly illustrated by the practically simultaneous appearance of these four volumes. They contain a total of ninety-eight stories, which should hold the most avid fan for a while.
CHICAGO, July 12 (AP) -- Art Larsen and Dick Savitt smashed through rugged semi-final opposition today and into the final of the national clay courts tennis tournament at suburban River Forest.

PARIS -- Someone once wrote a poem which Miss MacMillan, who taught the fourth grade fractions and poetry with equal vehemence, made us all learn, with the proper emphasis on the dimly remembered fact that "Paris is a woman's town with flowers in her hair."

AS every Argentine schoolboy, and nearly every Latin-American schoolboy, once knew, Gainza Paz is the man who was most instrumental in making La Prensa the foremost Latin-American newspaper. In the recently published "Defense of Freedom," Senor Gainza, along with his co-editors, tells the story of the paper's struggles and triumphs up through that fatal day early in 1951, when a dictator ordered its presses stopped.

THE Forty-Eighters were a group of German liberals and radicals who in 1848 fought for a unified republican Germany. At the end of the abortive revolution, some died before a firing squad or landed in prison, some conformed to the re-established reactionary regimes, some fled the country. Most of this last group found their way to the United States.

Ownership of the $4,249,000,000 of new public debt which the Treasury sold less than a month ago mostly to non-bank investors is gradually passing into the hands of the nation's commercial banks, but the effect on investment markets is singularly different from what took place during the wartime period, when the Treasury's budget deficits were financed in a pegged market supported rigidly by the Federal Reserve System.

MOSCOW, July 12 -- The Young Bolshevik, the magazine of the youth organization, Komsomols, to which most Soviet Olympic athletes belong, called on athletes everywhere to transform the Helsinki games into a vast demonstration for peace and friendship of peoples.
Plans to seek an immediate appropriation of $507,000 for construction of the long-contemplated Harlem Retail Market were announced yesterday by Frederick H. Zurmuhlen, Commissioner of Public Works.

For months, perhaps years, to come Wall Street will be using the Brookings Institution's census of shareholders as a guide to future action. Already it is being cited as demonstrating that the New York Stock Exchange should have a longer day -- perhaps running from 10 A. M. to 4 P. M. -- because it shows that a much higher proportion of the nation's stocks are held in the West than anybody had suspected.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., July 12 -- Bus Mosbacher skated around Long Island Sound today in what was scheduled as a yacht race. At least it looked like skating.

FOR a few days last week, Palazzo Brancaccio, the rich and formidable edifice on Rome's Colle Oppio, was dusted off to something resembling its former splendor, and temporarily returned to its ancient and glorious function as a playground for Roman nobility.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 12 (AP) -- There is no night in Helsinki at this time of the year.

The Empire City Racing Association will take over the promotion of the thoroughbred sport in New York this week. Starting tomorrow and continuing through Saturday the Empire City meeting will be conducted at the Jamaica track.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- With Virginia choosing the last twenty-eight-vote delegation next Thursday, the latest Associated Press tabulation of delegates to the Democratic National Convention, starting July 21, based on pledges and known first-ballot preferences stood today as follows:
TOKYO, Sunday, July 13 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,309, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Sunday, Korea time:

MINEOLA, L. I., July 12 -- Plans for the establishment of a Nassau County Academy of Medicine and the construction of an academy building this year are slated to be made at a meeting of the Nassau County Medical Society's executive board here next Tuesday.
ST. PAUL, July 12 (AP) -- Cary Middlecoff, the golfing dentist from Memphis, took the fifty-four-hole lead in the $15,000 St. Paul open golf tournament today with a 16-under-par 200.
HELSINKI, July 12 (AP) -- Old Glory was unfurled at the top of the thirteenth flag pole at the entrance to the neat, new Olympic Village of Kaepylae today.

A good portion of the nation's legitimate theatre has begun to fold its tents and steal across the countryside in search of the special audience that supports the citronella, or summer, circuit. This year will see literally hundreds of playhouses weighted with all grades of professional and amateur talent.

The letter by Nelson M. Fuller, Superintendent of the Department of Water, Batavia, N. Y., published in THE TIMES of July 6, asserts that significant climatological changes exist in the Midwest and on the Eastern seaboard as a consequence of cloud-seeding activities carried out in the western part of the United States.
MILWAUKEE, July 12 (AP) -- Eight Methodist Bishops, three of them just elected, received four-year assignments at the North Central Jurisdictional Conference today.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- The Secretary of Agriculture, Charles F. Brannan, today accused Senator James P. Kem, Republican of Missouri, of voting "against the farmers" whenever there was a conflict between the farmers and the private power industry.

OF all the competing exhibitions of modern art, the Biennale of Venice takes an easy first place. For comprehensiveness, for international variety, and for the sheer number of paintings and sculpture on view this years, the twenty-sixth in its history, housed in pavilions throughout the cool and sparkling Public Gardens, is Europe's principal art attraction of the summer. It was launched with customary pomp and circumstance.

Beer sales in New York and the surrounding areas have been good in the last few weeks, there is no question about that. The hot weather, of course, always helps beer sales and the Republican convention was a big inducement last week for families to sit around the television set with glasses in their hands.

American colleges and universities are constantly seeking ways to take the curse of bigness from the campus. Soon after World War II, when the veterans flooded the colleges, many institutions had classes ranging as large as 500 students. But administrators and educational leaders objected to this "mass" schooling.

THE man of the hour in this election will be the independent voter, an amorphous, inscrutable and undependable sort of fellow, who may or may not take the trouble to go to the polls at all, and who, if he does, may not decide for whom he is going to vote until he gets inside the voting booth.

A police detail was assigned last night to guard St. Patrick's Cathedral after a telephone call threatening that the Roman Catholic edifice would be bombed before midnight had been received at the parish house. The guard was posted after police emergency and bomb squad crews had searched the cathedral and had found no explosive.

The directors of the American Kennel Club have approved a new standard for the Shetland sheepdog. It is that submitted by the American Shetland Sheepdog Association and is more detailed than the one it supplants. The standard was completely rewritten.
WOODBRIDGE, N. J., July 12 -- A convict's escape plan that was frustrated when death intervened was under investigation today at the New Jersey State Prison Farm in Woodbridge Township.

SOMETHING really new in discussion material for parents' groups will be made available this week when Outlook Productions, Inc., and the National Association for Mental Health release three film strips adapted from the book.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Now it is the turn of the Democratic party. Its pilgrims already heading for Chicago are in a sober mood, realizing that the Republicans have raised the most serious challenge to their rule in two decades.
VACATIONISTS heading northward at this time might look in on one of two tours that are planned by garden groups for this week. One is in Vermont, the other in upstate New York.

Although some 2,000,000 fewer acres of cotton were in cultivation on July 1, than a year earlier, prospects are that the final yield may approximate the 15,057,926 running bales, or 15,130,243 of 500 pounds each, from the 1951 crop.

DAYLILIES may be selected to provide a succession of bloom from May to October. Not only are there varieties that flower at different dates but there are those that bloom twice and even three times. They range in price from inexpensive varieties for the modest budget to high-priced novelties for the hobbyist.

OLEUM, Calif., July 12 -- One man died, two were believed drowned and at least thirty were injured today when an explosion of crude oil set fire to two tankers unloading here on the eastern shore of San Francisco Bay.

THE world that Bil and Cora Baird have on a string is a universe of imagination peopled by a vast assortment of short individuals, about two feet tall, made of wood. It would be a mistake, however, to consider the delightful characters who populate C. B. S.-TV's "The Whistling Wizard" (Saturday, 11-11:30 A. M.) as merely puppets or marionettes or anything less than human.

THIS is the time of year, what with week-ends and holidays, when the weather is a vital concern to everybody. Recent lamentable Saturday-Sunday deluges have made universal misery; also there's been a lot of heat. Whatever happens, people accuse the weather man. It's his fault.

IT'S impossible to arrive at a rave review of this vivid excursion into verbal portraiture pillorying the upper-crust society of small town life in central Georgia. At the same time, it's equally impossible to dismiss it as an inconsequential distortion of the basic realities.

ROAMING at large over the New York State highways are more than 1,000,000 unsafe drivers who leave a trail of accidents which cost 2,101 lives, $83,000,000 property damage in 159,090 mishaps last year. This group is composed of careless, irresponsible and vicious motorists who flout traffic laws, create highway hazards, send insurance rates upward and refuse to curb their reckless habits.
CHICAGO, July 12 -- When the Democrats come to town next week -- there'll be some changes made.

CHICAGO, July 12 -- The Middle West is the home of the Republican party, but again, as in these twelve years past, the Republican party in this Presidential year finds no really congenial home in the Middle West. The long estrangement persists, and widens.
FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., July 12 -- A $12,000,000 Signal Corps training center, modeled after a modern technological college rather than the traditional Army-type school, is under construction here.

The $10,000,000,000-a-year home furnishings industry is muddling through to a solid recovery. Unlike the false starts of a few months ago, the current upsurge will continue for some time, industry leaders asserted last week.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 12 -- United States atomic scientists are helping Brazil to take the lead in Latin-American atomic energy development, Admiral Alvaro Alberto, head of the Brazilian National Council of Research, said today.

MAHWAH, N. J., July 12 -- A threat to "secede" from this township has been made by property owners in Mahwah's western section. The threat was voiced by Michael Martis, a builder, after a proposal to issue $505,000 in bonds to finance repairs and alterations to public schools had been approved in a special election by five votes.

THE publication of this novel is an act of justice long delayed. It is also a major contribution to American literature. For all our sweet talk about the necessity of inter-American understanding, we have done precious little at the intellectual level -- a scattering of anthologies of poetry and prose; a few translations of (usually) mediocre novels.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 12 (AP) -- American and Russian oarsmen rowed together today and swapped friendly chatter, breaking the ice of United States-Soviet relationship in the Olympic Games.

GROTON, Conn., July 12 (AP) -- A displaced person tossed his fiancee into the Thames River before plunging to his own death early today from the giant vehicular bridge here in the climax to a lovers' quarrel.

When a fan goes to see the Yankees these days he's not sure whether it is to see them play or to see Billy Martin fight. At the Stadium yesterday a ladies' day turnout of 22,327 was treated to both. The Yankees, once trailing by 4 -- 0, came on for an eleven-inning 5-4 victory on Allie Reynolds' single with two out and the bases loaded.

The Affiliated Young Democrats of New York State, holding its tenth biennial convention at the Piccadilly Hotel, approved a platform yesterday urging the rooting out of "the Communist cancer in our blood stream at home," a strong program of civil rights, Federal aid for school construction and the stockpiling of atomic and hydrogen bombs.

" TELL me about when you were little," says the child. It is his first, unconscious expedition into biography. When he has overcome the first shock of realization that time, people and places have existed before he was born, he develops a lively curiosity about the past.

CANBERRA, Australia, July 12 -- An atomic accelerating machine that may help to reveal what holds together the particles of an atomic nucleus is to be installed at the Research School of Physical Sciences at Acton, a Canberra suburb.

Continuing the trend of the first three months, earnings of most of the leading New York City banks and trust companies increased slightly in the second quarter over a year ago, condition statements for June 30 recently published, indicated.

The Elks will begin their national convention in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel tonight. Mayor Impellitteri, former Postmaster General James A. Farley and Thomas J. Curran, New York Secretary of State, all members of the order, will welcome the delegates.

Now comes the height of summer when, although the sun is already inclining toward autumn by celestial measurement, our latitude has weather fit for the tropics and vegetation almost to match. The trees stand lush and listless, their great canopies of chlorophyll working magic with sun and air and moisture, their April growth solidifying itself, their roots a-tingle with life in the warm earth.

OTTAWA, July 12 -- Voters in Quebec Province will go to the polls Wednesday to decide whether they wish the National Union party of Maurice Duplessis to continue in office for another four years or to return to a Liberal administration.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, by tendering his resignation from the Army today, took the decisive step toward becoming just plain "mister" after thirty-seven years as an officer.

CONSIDERING the fact that few heroes that have ever fared forth upon the screen have been more popular or persistent than the swashbuckling Robin Hood, it is not surprising to find this gentleman -- or reasonable facsimiles -- in what must be frankly acknowledged as abundant supply these days.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Cutting fresh flowers for arrangements may be more fun, but cutting off faded ones is also a satisfaction. The removal of flowers in any state prevents seed formation, thus prolonging bloom on annuals and perhaps bringing second bloom on perennials. Snipping off the dead flowers makes a border look much more tidy, too.

AS a member of both oganizations, I will venture the rash guess that there are, per capita, more first-rate cooks in Mystery Writers of America than in the Societe des Gentils-hommes Chefs de Cuisine.

ALMOST every day throughout the three and one-half months from mid-July to late October this year at least one fair will be going full tilt somewhere in the northeastern states from Maine to Maryland.

An innocent-looking automobile was singled out from 100 others lined up in front of Pier 90 Hudson River recently, then it was stripped of its gasoline tank, and Uncle Sam was $140,000 richer. The tank contained 250-odd pounds of pure gold about to be smuggled from the country to the European black market.

RICHMOND, Va., July 12 -- Issues of Federal economy and "Trumanism" have stirred heated arguments in a round of Virginia politics that will culminate Tuesday in the state's first mid-July Senatorial primary election.

In his fine article, "Dynamic Capital of Conventioneers" (June 29), Albert Halper achieved an enormous feat by moving the International Amphitheatre from Forty-second Street and Halsted Street to West Madison Street, a distance of about seven miles.

CHICAGO, July 12 -- Arthur E. Summerfield, an automobile dealer from Flint, Mich., was elected unanimously today to be chairman of the Republican National Committee for the next four years. The selection was no surprise. General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Presidential nominee, was reported to have given Mr. Summerfield immediate approval.

FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., July 12 -- The Army Signal Corps announced today the development of a new type telephone and telegraph cable, already in use in Korea, that is expected to save $18,000,000 in production costs in the next year.

The first automobile death in the United States occurred in 1899. In December, 1951, this country's millionth automobile death was recorded. In 1950 more than 1,000 persons lost their lives in aircraft accidents in the United States, 109 of them in regularly scheduled commercial airliners.

A FRIENDLY smile was the international language that kept Ruth Orkin functioning as a photographer during a recent six-weeks' sojourn in Israel when ignorance of the country's language threatened to cut short her picture-taking activities.
Two Brooklyn youths who, the police said, tried out a new wrinkle in car theft, were arrested on charges of assault, robbery and grand larceny yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 12 (AP) -- Carl (Bobo) Olson of Honolulu outboxed and outpunched Robert Villemain of Paris tonight to win a split decision in a ten-round bout billed as an elimination round for the middleweight title contenders.

There have been several thoughtful and obviously sincere expressions of anxiety lest the increased tempo of United Nations air activity in Korea, such as the massive raid on Pyongyang, should upset the truce negotiations at Panmunjom. This anxiety, we believe, arises from a mistaken appraisal of the character of the Communist "negotiation."

THIS first novel is very nearly as simple as lovers' initials carved on a tree. An aging man from the West returns to a small Ohio town to "search out beginnings." He finds the old places in shambles. Among the wreckage, he dreams out the life he had for a year on his grandmother's farm and the love he shared at the age of 13 with Hallie, aged 11, and Madie, aged 11.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 12 -- The African National Congress, which represents Negroes in the Cape province, held a mass meeting in Port Elizabeth's city hall last night to honor the volunteers who are defying "unjust laws.

WHEN more than 8,206 people appear at the battery of box offices, the new Marine Stadium on Zachs Bay, Jones Beach, begins to feel pinched for space. For this is one of those mammoth projects that make architects and engineers feel like Superman.

THE largest fish the writer has seen on his trips to the Battenkill swims in melancholy and slightly dusty glory over a wooden plaque on Roy Brown's wall. At 12 pounds 4 ounces and measuring 31 1/2 inches, it is said to be the biggest brown trout ever taken from the stream that flows from Vermont and across New York's Washington County.

THIS romance of strolling Jewish theatrical folk in Europe who eventually come to America was composed for serial publication in a New York Yiddish newspaper during the years of World War I, when Sholom Aleichem, the great Yiddish humorist, came to this country.

NEW YORK will get its first glimpse of a new ballet company in the making when Mia Slavenska and Frederic Franklin and their colleagues give a program at the Stadium on Saturday evening, with Alexandra Danilova as guest artist.

LONDON, July 12 -- The British Government has ordered the expulsion from this country within one week of Pavel Kuznetsov, the Soviet diplomat to whom a Foreign Office radio operator betrayed secret information.
PITTSBURGH, July 12 (AP) -- Ed Mathews doubled home two runs in a four-run fifth-inning for Boston today to pace the Braves to a 5-2 victory over the Pirates.

The eyes of a tourist returning from a midsummer vacation with a Mediterranean sky-sweep are full of visions and scenes from ancient civilizations. A good place for a first stop at journey's start is at an airport flanked by the green fields of England.

One prospective grandmother has already, signed up to brush up on her baby-sitting technique in the free mother-and-baby-care home nursing classes given at the Central Chapter of Queens American Red Cross. Mrs. Lewis Kohn of Forest Hills, home nursing chairman, predicts good attendance for the classes, which will begin Tuesday at 1:30 P. M. at 92-32 Union Hall Street, Jamaica.

PARIS, July 12 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, conferred at length today at Supreme Headquarters near Paris with Gen. Thomas T. Handy, who will shortly begin functioning as General Ridgway's deputy in the newly reorganized European military theatre.

READERS who like tales about very human Americans served up in small parcels must not let the forbidding title (or titles) of this book keep them away from the witty and informing profiles of former Harvard men all too modestly launched by Clifford Shipton every four years.

At Panmunjom on the first anniversary of the Korean truce talks last Thursday, a U. N. soldier stacked the foolscap size volumes containing the record of the negotiations one on top of the other. The pile was seven feet high.

MEXICO CITY, July 12 -- Mexico's new President-elect is a man who has been in politics for nearly thirty years without having enriched himself and without having made an enemy, even among his bitterest political opponents. This is defying a political tradition here on the grand scale.

MINNEAPOLIS -- The Aquatennial, which opens here next Friday and will continue to July 27, will be the thirteenth of its kind, but no citizen is superstitious enough to believe that the big civic celebration will suffer any setback on that account.
CHICAGO, July 12 -- A national convention provides a kind of barometer of the political mood of the nation -- or at least that part of the nation it is supposed to represent.

TODAY'S most serious phonographic gap is none of the relatively insignificant lacunae in the bursting LP catalogues, most of which are being filled as promptly as they are spotted. Nor is it even that aching void in one's budget, symptomatic of the avocational disease of record-buyers, whose financial digestive powers lag far behind their review- and advertisement-stimulated musical appetites.
The metropolitan district's sectional qualifying round for the United States Golf Association's junior championship will be held on Tuesday at the Rockville Country Club, Rockville Centre, L. I.

Allie Reynolds gained his eleventh victory by driving in the winning run in the eleventh inning yesterday as the Yanks beat the Browns, 5 -- 4. After benching Alvin Dark and Davey Williams, the Giants defeated the Reds, 5 -- 3. The Dodgers got twenty-two hits in crushing the Cubs, 12 -- 2.

IN your June 22 issue you published a letter by Herman F. Reissig which contained the following sentence: "But Barth in Germany and the Rev. Premier Malan in South Africa to the contrary notwithstanding, the basic beliefs of the Judeo-Christian religion and not compatible with Stalin's communism, Hitler's nazism, Malan's racism, or with some current interpretations of individualism."

CHICAGO, July 12 -- Two Knoxville, Tenn., attorneys today were enriched by $81,575 by the surprise victory of their Mr. Good in the $108,985 Arlington Futurity before a crowd of 24,716. Douglas Dodson brought the 2-year-old son of Easy Mon and Grim and Gay across the finish line three lengths ahead of Mr. Paradise, owned by Mrs. Ada Rice, Chicago, and ridden by Eddie Arcaro.
OSLO, July 12 (UP) -- Arthur Charles Jackson of Flushing, L. I., won the "English match" title today at the world shooting championships with a new international record of 596 points.
CHICAGO, July 12 -- The Republican convention took no chances on not having candidates if something unforeseen should happen to its nominee for President and Vice President.

Summer workshops in elementary school supervisory and administrative problems, home economics education, education of the mentally handicapped and agricultural education will be offered at the University of Illinois summer session. Supervisors of elementary teachers will participate in a workshop covering supervision, curriculum, public relations, administration and in-service training.

NEWARK, July 12 -- With the nomination of the Republican Presidential ticket an accomplishd fact, political interest in New Jersey focused today on the Democratic delegates to the convention in Chicago.

AMERICAN big business began by being overarticulate. The crudities and gaucheries of its symbolic figures have become landmarks in our history. From Commodore Vanderbilt's "the public be damned," to J. P. Morgan's "I owe the public nothing," to Mr. Dooley's famous lampoon of the magnate "who says th' Lord an' him is partners in a coal mine," American business would have served itself better by saying less.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The Democrats take over the political center stage next week in a wide-open scramble to pick a man to beat General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower.

THE Florence May Festival begins in May and lasts through June. In certain respects it stands apart from other great European music festivals. For it is not fundamentally a tourist festival, planned to attract the traveling trade.
SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 12 -- A Southampton resident, Neil MacNeil, has been selected to preside at the annual Gaelic Mod at St. Ann, Cape Breton Island, N. S., Aug. 7-10.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 12 -- The prosecutor in charge of cases against officers accused of Communist activity in the Brazilian armed forces has been relieved of his post on suspicion of Communist sympathies and on the specific ground of attempting to see one of the prisoners outside the line of his duties.

A change for the better in United States foreign aid and trade policies could be expected under an Eisenhower administration, it was agreed last week by a substantial portion of the foreign trade community.

LOTS and lots of Mozart, nearly all of it available for the first time on long-play, has recently been issued by Period. To begin with, there is a disk concerned with the first two Violin Concertos -- in B flat (K. 207) and D (K. 211), both played by Aida Stucki and the Tonstudio Orchestra of Stuttgart conducted by Gustav Lund.

A CRIPPLED half-wit French boy, in one of these stories by a Philadelphia newspaper man and writer, risks his life to give the American soldiers information leading to the capture of a town during World War II.

MADRID, July 11 -- Pedro Cardinal Segura y Saenz, Archbishop of Seville, published today a "pastoral warning" replying to critics who had taken exception to some of his recent pronouncements on the question of Protestantism in Spain. He announced that he would issue a series of instructions to explain the attitude of the Roman Catholic Church on controversial subjects because of widespread ignorance.

THE serious lyric poet who ventures into humor runs a double jeopardy. His detractors say he has sunk to his proper level. Some of his more somber friends reproach him for "betraying his art." I speak from my experience with "The Suburb by the Sea."

But to do so ls misleading in that It overlooks the balically dlfferont ozfentatlon of the two men, and it is this ,reLy difference in orientation that has made it ]xstblo 1c Sullivan to eomin ne !dem to ps.boanalysh.

Over-all dollar sales of major New York City department stores last week fell 20 per cent below those of the corresponding week of last year. However, the statistical comparison was heavily weighted against a better showing. More than half of the deficit could be attributed to the added volume achieved last year by a Manhattan store's large-scale and successful special promotion not repeated this year.

ABOARD THE LINER UNITED STATES, at Sea, July 12 -- The liner United States was racing into fog wisps tonight, with a forecast of thickening weather ahead, but the ship's officers were confident that they had built up a sufficient margin to assure her of a new record on the westbound run.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission has announced the filing of proposed natural gas rate increases by Texas Gas Transmission Corporation, Owensboro, Ky., and United Gas Pipe Line Company, Shreveport, La., totaling $18,955,000 a year.

LONDON. ANEURIN BEVAN, the M. P. whose mounting attacks on the Conservative Government and whose leadership of the Left in the Labor party schism currently make him a most important figure in British politics, lives in a pleasant house in Chelsea with his wife, Miss Jennie Lee (who is also in Parliament), and her parents.

TOKYO, July 12 -- The marathon negotiations at Panmunjom for a truce in the Korean war went into their second year this week, snagged on a single major issue but with little indication that a quick way out of the impasse could be found.

A 35MM miniature camera with Compur Rapid shutter mounted behind the lens instead of the conventional between-the-lens placement, and selling for $197.25 equipped with a 50mm f/1.5 lens, is announced by Futura Camera Corporation of America, 153 West Nineteenth Street.

A LITTLE-KNOWN phase of the work currently being carried on by botanical gardens and arboretums is the exchange of seed that annually takes place between many of these institutions. To a large extent this activity has replaced the expeditions into remote parts of the world, which resulted in the introduction to American gardens of countless valuable ornamentas.
When an industry reaches the $70,000,000,000 mark it's the tops in big business. That is where the nation's life insurance industry stands today.

TOKYO, Sunday, July 13 -- The United Nations and Communist delegates held another twenty-six-minute meeting at Panmunjom yesterday without apparent progress in the negotiations for the exchange of prisoners of the Korean war, the last major issue standing in the path of an armistice.
CHICAGO, July 12 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's painting is good, but his wife can't find the right word to describe the first picture he made of her.
WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations said today an economic recession was likely in 1953 and 1954.

RAHWAY, N. J., July 12 -- A strike of 1,600 production workers at the huge plant of Merck Co., manufacturing chemist here, was called at 2 A. M. today when negotiations over a wage increase and working conditions broke down.

A TROUPE of thirty, including director Gregory Ratoff; his stars, Dan Dailey and Constance Smith; producer Samuel G. Engel and some seventy local actors of Twentieth Century - Fox's "Taxi," will make our town the scene of another film production any day now.

BONN, July 12 -- The position of the Western Allies in any conference with the Soviet Union on Germany was signally strengthened this week when with consummate political craft Chancellor Adenauer guided the bills embodying the Bonn convention and European Defense Community treaty through their first reading in the Bundestag.

Motorists who believe too implicitly in highway signs in this state are likely to come to a sorry end, according to the Association of Casualty and Surety Companies. Lack of uniformity in traffic signs was reported an outstanding cause of acidents and travel congestion.

CHICAGO, July 12 -- Traditionally the platforms issued by the national parties every four years at convention time feature adroit compromises designed to win a majority of the voters rather than sheer principles designed to attract extremists.

ON New Year's Day in the year 1800, Eleuthere Irenee du Pont arrived in America, a refugee from troubled France. Two years later, he laid the foundation of what has since become the chemical and industrial empire of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 12 -- One aspect of the strain in relations between the United States and France over North Africa reaches the International Court of Justice here Tuesday, when hearings begin to determine whether the United States can still exercise extraterritorial rights in French Morocco.

CONCORD, N. C., July 12 (UP) -- The retiring dean of Congress, 88-year-old Representative Robert L. Doughton, accepted the plaudits of the nation's leaders with tears tonight, then denounced the new Republican Presidential nominee, General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower.

The only way to find out how an atom is constructed is to pound it to pieces. The physicists have been doing this for over a generation with pounders of ever-increasing power. In this way and in other ways it was discovered that the nucleus of an atom, in which nearly all its mass is concentrated, consists of protons and neutrons.

Stan Sayres' record feat the other day at Seattle has turned the speed-boat racing fraternity of pilots, mechanics, hangers-on and even bulkhead birds and riverbank experts into dreamers about the predictable future. What is next, they are asking.

New York City, which bade the United States Olympic team farewell in festive fashion last Monday with a ticker-tape parade up lower Broadway, a City Hall reception and a luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria, has special reason to feel warm-hearted toward this 1952 Olympic squad.
LONDON. THEY'RE bagging fewer pedestrians in Britain now. Motorcars, that is. A good part of this cheerful intelligence can be attributed, in the opinion of the Ministry of Transport, to the Zebra.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., July 12 -- Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., national chairman of the campaign of Averell Harriman for the Democratic Presidential nomination, in a speech prepared for delivery tonight called upon General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Republican nominee, to repudiate Senator William E. Jenner.
PHILADELPHIA, July 12 (UP) -- Behind the six-hit pitching of sob Lemon, the Indians won the rubber match of their three-game series with the Athletics today, 5 -- 1.

A Chinese consultant to the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, now living in New Rochelle, N. Y., who fled from Shanghai, China, shortly before the Communists took over that city, expressed his joy yesterday on learning that President Truman had signed legislation granting to him and his family permanent residence in this country.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 13 -The flag of the Soviet Union was raised on an Olympic site for the first time ever today and its athletes and newspaper men exchanged visits with Americans and competitors from other nations.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 13 -Ed Raymond's ketch Chanteyman, only thirty-three feet overall, representing the host club, and Richard B. Nye's forty-six-foot yawl Carina from Indian Harbor were declared the victors today in their divisions of the Riverside-Stratford Shoal overnight race.

The eighty-eighth Grand Lodge convention of the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks opened in the flag-draped ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night with a program of speeches and patriotic music attended by 3,000 members and their families here for the five-day reunion.

HONG KONG, July l3 -- According to the Peiping radio, Red China's National Import and Export Corporation signed a 150,000000 ruble barter agreement with a group of West German business men in Berlin on June 25. The radio broadcast identified the West German group as Ostagan Ltd., of Bonn.

CHICAGO, July 13 (AP) -- Art Larsen of San Leandro, Calif., today defeated Richard Savitt of Orange, N. J., 4 -- 6, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 4, to win the national clay courts singles championship at the suburban River Forest Tennis Club.

A hot and unremitting sun beat down on New York all through yesterday, searing the city's pavements and the relatively few inhabitants who remained within its precincts. By 4:50 P. M. the mercury had reached 95 degrees, just a shade under the record high for the year.

BOSTON, July 13 (UP) -- The Red Sox equaled their long-distance winning streak of the year today by capturing a double-header from the Browns, 8 -- 5 and 4 -- 0, for Boston's fourth and fifth consecutive victories before 22,770 Fenway Park fans.
CINCINNATI, July 13 -- Dusty Rhodes made his debut as a Giant on Crosley Field today in time to help salvage one game of a twin bill with the Reds before 16,135 onlookers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 13 -David O. Selznick, who has made no motion pictures since he did "Portrait of Jennie" in 1948, told THE NEW YORK TIMES today that he had virtually completed arrangements for co-production with an Italian film company of "Mary Magdalene," a screen project in which he has been interested for the last eight years.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 13 -- The new economic plan initiated by Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion five months ago has brought on a paradoxical situation. Never since the state was established has the purchasing power of the Israeli pound been so low. Never has the pound been so precious.

It is regrettable to find THE NEW YORK TIMES relaxing its high standards of objectivity to publish two heavily biased reports concerning the use of United Nations material in schools. I refer to the articles in the issues of June 29 and 30 last, and mention should also be made of Anne O'Hare McCormick's column on the latter date, entitled "The Charge Against UNESCO Is 'Internationalism'."

ST. LOUIS, July 13 -- A downpour halted today's game between the Dodgers and Cards in the lower half of the first inning. The resulting postponement bitterly disappointed the largest Sportsman's Park crowd in five years.

PHILADELPHIA, July 13 (UP) -- Bobby Shantz pitched his fifteenth victory of the season as Gus Zernial drove in six runs with two homers to give the Athletics a 6-0 triumph over the White Sox today. Chicago bounced back to win, 7-4, in the second game of their doubleheader.
Six new films, including an importation from England, are scheduled to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

HUNTER, N. Y., July 13 -- Two new dormitories at Camp Loyaltown in this Catskill Mountain resort area were dedicated today. The exercises were under the auspices of the Loyal League Philanthropies and the Town Club of New York City.
CHICAGO, July 13 (AP) -- The fifth-place Phillies moved two steps nearer the National League's first division today by sweeping a double-header, 7 -- 3 and 9 -- 2, from the Cubs before 29,065 fans.

" Spy-Catcher," by Col. Oreste Pinto, a Dutch officer who served with the British counter-espionage authorities in World War II, will be published on Aug. 6 by Harper. In his account, Colonel Pinto, whose specialty was screening refugees, describes the art of examination and his work behind the advancing Allied armies on the Continent.

CHICAGO, July 13 (AP) -- Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat of Illinois, declared tonight that Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee "has the best chance of any Democrat to beat General (of the Army Dwight D.) Eisenhower."

Music returns to tiny Bowling Green Park this week when the Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., opens what company officials described as another "ten-year series" of weekly band concerts. The steamship company started this weekly musicale shortly after this country entered World War II.

A model house, displaying new electrical equipment, opened yesterday on Route 17, near Paramus, N. J. Designed to be used later as an office of the Electriglas Company, formerly located in Bogota, N. J., the house contains some of the radiant electric heating units made by that company. The kitchen and laundry are outfitted with General Electric equipment.
DENVER, July 13 -- A latecomer to the higher echelon of Republican politics looms as a key figure in the Eisenhower-for-President campaign.

FREEPORT, L. I., July 13 -- Riding in the best traditions of western bronco-busters, twelve youngsters churned their six-foot soapbox sea sleds through choppy Great South Bay waters here this afternoon in a trophy race held under the auspices of the Freeport Police Boys Club.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The International Materials Conference announced today the distribution among member countries of 36,580 metric tons of nickel for the July-September quarter of this year. This compares with 35,195 tons for the preceding three months.

The return to Reserve Fleet status of forty-two Governmentowned merchant vessels in the last two weeks increased the number of such laid-up ships to 454 since March, when the demand for this emergency tonnage to meet Mutual Security Agency cargo demands declined sharply.

Dwight D. Eisenhower's military career began in June, 1911, when he entered West Point. It ended last Saturday, when he telegraphed his resignation to the Secretary of the Army. If this were also to be the end of his career as a man in the public eye he would still have his place in history.
Rumor had all to do with the erratic movement last week of the Canadian dollar and British sterling, two currencies which have been the center of speculative interest for sometime.

SPRING LAKE, N. J., July 13 (UP) -- Vic Seixas of Philadelphia, America's top-ranking tennis player, rebounded today from his poor showing in the recent Wimbledon tournament to win the men's singles title in the Spring Lake invitation tournament by beating Billy Talbert of New York, 10 -- 8, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 2.
LONDON, July 13 -- The United States Air Force is here to stay -- for a while anyway. That is the distinct impression one gets from a tour of the United States Air Force bases in the United Kingdom.

TOKYO, Monday, July 14--The Communists this morning asked for a two-day recess in the negotiations at Panmunjom for an armistice in the Korean war and the United Nations delegation agreed to the delay.

The Broadway opening in September of Stanley Young's play, based on the "Pickwick Papers" and sometimes referred to as "The Trial of Mr. Pickwick" (London saw it under that title in May) or just "Mr. Pickwick," has struck a snag.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 13 -- The Jewish Cultural and Social Association of Iran has addressed a petition to Premier Mohammed Mossadegh asking him to put a stop to the anti-Semitic agitation of semi-Fascist organizations in the country. The Jews in Iran have a Deputy in Parliament and full equality with other Iranian subjects under the constitution and the laws of the land.

PITTSBURGH, July 13 -- Less than three months ago some observers were predicting that steel output in the last quarter of this year might drop to 85 per cent of capacity. Many steel items appeared to be easier and some steel plants were looking for business.

LONDON, July 13 -- A young United States scholar who spent five years studying the workings of Britain's largest labor union from within startled Britain, right left and center, last week with his book, a factual report on the state of the union.

BLOCK ISLAND, R. I., July 13 -- Some night next October when the New York Athletic Club yachtsmen gather at their Fifty-ninth Street clubhouse to award the season's honors and prizes, the main one will go to Dr. Allen B. Du Mont of Cedar Grove and Clifton, N. J. He was declared cruiser champion of Long Island Sound today for winning the 107-mile predicted log race from Execution Light off Travers Island last night.

Walter I. Berger and Leo A. Bercow, operators, bought the five-story building containing twenty-two apartments and three stores at 2340 Belmont Avenue, corner of Crescent Avenue, the Bronx, from clients of Margolin, Feldman Blinkoff, attorneys.

BERLIN, July 13 -- East Germany's official Communist newspaper sought today to justify last Tuesday's abduction of an anti-Communist leader from West Berlin and implied that more such disappearances were to be expected.

ST. PAUL, Minn., July 13 (AP)--Cary Middlecoff of Memphis won the $2,400 first prize in the $15,000 St. Paul open golf tournament today with a record-tying 72-hole score of 266, twenty-two strokes under par.

The steel strike is slowly strangling industry throughout the nation. Unemployment is mounting as steel stockpiles are exhausted. The six-week period for which some manufacturers said they had enough stocks to continue operations has now expired. Laid-off workers, now exceeding half a million, are lining up for unemployment benefit checks.
The men's clothing industry operated at 71 per cent of capacity in the first five months of 1952, compared with 89 per cent in the same period of last year, using men's suits as the index.

GSTAAD, Switzerland, July 13 (UP) -- Herbie Flam of Beverly Hills, Calif., won the men's singles title, and Dorothy Head of Alameda, Calif., gained the women's singles crown today in the international lawn tennis championships of Switzerland.
NEWPORT, R. I., July 13 (AP) -A combined Princeton-Cornell lawn tennis team completed an 11-4 victory today over a touring Oxford-Cambridge group in a round-robin match at the Newport Casino.

At a time when the Christian Church "should shine like a great beacon" it has been "stricken with impotence, has little power of initiative, little grasp of essentials and little directness of decision," the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken, minister of the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street, said in his sermon yesterday.

The National Association of Manufacturers attacked the Federal Trade Commission in stinging language yesterday as having turned in "a consistent record of factual misrepresentation" in its studies on concentration in industry.
LONDON, July 13 -- The gradual recovery of the stock markets, under way since the last week in June, last week turned into something more definite and substantial.

A fund of $80,000 to provide grants-in-aid to educational institutions for instructive radio and television programs is to be administered by the National Association of Radio Broadcasters, Seymour N. Siegel, president of the association, announced today.

ABOARD THE LINER UNITED STATES, at Sea, July 13 -- The world's fastest ocean liner was slipping through calm seas at about 36 knots at dinnertime tonight, less than a day's run from New York and with the westbound trans-Atlantic record in her grasp. We are less than 800 miles from New York.

The delivery of two completed vessels and the addition of a single new contract in June left the shipbuilding industry with 102 commitments for new tonnage, a point very near the peak of peacetime activity.

The Soviet Union has used its veto power for the fiftieth time to block the passage of a Security Council resolution dealing with the charge that the United Nations was using bacterial warfare. The forty-ninth veto had been used to prevent adoption of a resolution that would have called upon the International Red Cross for an investigation of the germ warfare charges.

CHICAGO, July 13 -- Investment buying of wheat futures cushioned the impact of hedge selling last week, but as a matter of fact both the buying and the sales against marketings of new crop grain were not especially heavy. However, such buying served to make for a generally steady market.

When Vic Raschi refused to "waste" a pitch to Joe Ginsberg, the big righthander of the Yankees missed a no-hit, no-run achievement against the Tigers in the first game at the Stadium yesterday. With two out, none aboard and a two-strike, one-ball count against the Detroit catcher in the eighth inning, Raschi grooved a fast ball, which Ginsberg drove into the right-field seats.

PARIS, July 13 -- The French wine industry is undergoing one of the gravest crises it has ever known as a result of its inability to sell a large quantity of its production on the home market while competition abroad hinders exports.

NEWARK, July 13 -- Charged with criminal abortion, Dr. Frank L. Costello, 45 years old, an osteopathic physician, of 621 Mount Prospect Avenue, was released today in $25,000 bail for a hearing in Family Court tomorrow.

One of the more interesting if little-noticed consequences of the Republican National Convention is that the man who had appeared on television the most went down to defeat and the man who had appeared the least won the nomination.

CHICAGO, July 13 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower today stressed the necessity of the Republicans' winning control of the United States Senate and House of Representatives in November as "vital to the success of our crusade."
PITTSBURGH, July 13 -- Negotiations to end the six-week-old steel strike bogged down again today as unemployment in industries dependent on steel passed the half-million mark.

AMSTERDAM, July 13 -- The main interest last week was in Royal Dutch shares which, being quoted ex-dividend, went further ahead on considerable foreign buying, especially for American account. It is estimated that of late between 3,000,000 and 6,000,000 guilders nominal of Royal Dutch shares weekly have passed into foreign ownership.
Volunteer aircraft spotters in twenty-seven states will begin this morning a twenty-four-hour watch for hostile planes.

Major changes in the price-control program have made the role of the thrifty shopper more important than ever in the fight against inflation, James G. Lyons, regional Office of Price Stabilization Director said yesterday.

Some theorists hold that consumption of fish can be increased only if the product is enhanced by glamorous packaging. But Alphonse Tocco, who acquired appreciation for this food from his Sicilian parents, does not believe in such subterfuge.

The Fairchild Engine and Aircraft Corporation of Hagerstown, MD., has been licensed to produce a training plane built in the Netherlands. This is believed to be the first time an American company has undertaken the manufacture of a trainer developed by a foreign country.

MADRID, July 13 -- Despite the disappointment caused by the failure of Senator Taft -- Spain's favorite son -- to win the Republican nomination as Presidential candidate, the Spanish ruling class indicated today that it still preferred General Eisenhower to Mr. Truman as the future President of the United States.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, July 13 -- In the struggle against the Communist insurrection in Malaya, the British authorities here are building up to a peak effort that will not be reached until some time next year. Meanwhile, things are going better, but it is still too early to say whether ultimate success is assured.

PARIS, July 13 (AP) -- France took a 2-1 lead over Belgium in the European Zone Davis Cup semi-finals today as Paul Remy and Marcel Bernard defeated Jacques Brichant and Philippe Washer, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 2, 1 -- 6, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 1, in doubles.
WASHINGTON, July 13 (UP) -President Truman's Materials Policy Commission said some things in its recent report that gave a big fillip to the oil industry but left some Administration leaders unhappy.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 13 -- Peg's Pride, the aged gray gelding, gained another open jumping championship today. Competing in the twenty-seventh Harrison Horse Show, the Hutchinson Stables' star captured his seventh straight title in as many week-ends and the sixty-third of his career.

THOMAS E. DEWEY'S "Journey to the Far Pacific,"* published this morning, completes an interesting trilogy. The other two books are Wendell Willkie's "One World" and Dwight D. Eisenhower's "Crusade in Europe."

The problems of youngsters suffering from rheumatic fever, one of the most dangerous diseases of childhood, are psychological as well as physical, a report in the current Journal of Pediatrics points out. Preventing and overcoming the psychological problems will require thoughtful cooperation of both parents and medical men, it adds.
WILMINGTON, Del., July 13 (UP) -- A vacationing New York sales manager and his wife were killed today when their private plane crashed after a take-off at the du Pont Airport here.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The World Monetary Fund today held out prospects of financial aid to member countries moving toward freer trade through removal of restrictions on currency exchange.

Recent issues of the Soviet press have made it clear that the Kremlin is again seriously troubled about the situation on the collective farms. As in 1939 and 1946, extensive field investigations are turning up numerous cases of theft, embezzlement and misappropriation of collective farm property, as well as diversion of collective farm land to private use.
INDIANAPOLIS, July 13 -Agreement has been reached in Indianapolis Federal Court on a reorganization plan for the French Lick Spring Hotel in Indiana.

The United States must correctly evaluate the financial risks ahead of it and refrain from overextending itself in "doing good at home or in foreign lands," according to John S. Sinclair, president of the National Industrial Conference Board.

Averell Harriman, New York's favorite son candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, refused yesterday to cross a picket line to appear on the National Broadcasting Company's program, "Hats in the Ring," until he had been assured by one of his aides that permission to cross the line had been granted by the striking union, the Radio Writers Guild, independent.

Averell Harriman, candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, asserted yesterday that a Republican victory in November would lead to a depression if the Republicans "carried out the policies for which they have been famous."

CHICAGO, July 13 -- No big price changes were made in lard prices the past week, the range being rather narrow, with few outstanding trade features. There was a little buying due to the possibility of higher ceiling levels being established for vegetable oils, and the fairly firm tone in the latter commodities influenced some buying at times.

Yesterday morning, in the course of what might be regarded as almost a routine dispatch, THE NEW YORK TIMES correspondent in South Africa said: "Race relations in South Africa are worse than they have ever been in the Union's forty-two years."

France serves as "the balance wheel of Western Europe because its people abhor the tryanny of the right and the tyranny of the left," the Rev. Dr. Rene E. G. Vaillant declared yesterday at a religious Service commemorating Bastille Day, France's national holiday.

DOUARNENEZ, France, July 13 (UP) -- Martime quarters feared today that Ann Davidson, 38, British writer who set out from this Breton port June 10 in an attempt to become the first woman to sail the Atlantic alone, might have perished in stormy weather over the Gascogne Bay.
Rich in the traditions of early New York as a port and city, Battery Park will be reopened to the public with civic ceremonies at 12:30 P. M. tomorrow, Park Commissioner Robert Moses said yesterday.

Rent increases were approved in June for 27,710 residential tenants, or slightly more than 1 per cent of the 2,324,759 whose rents are controlled by the Temoprary State Housing Rent Commission in the city and Nassau, Suffolk and Westchester Counties.

BERLIN, July 13 -- The official East German news agency A. D. N. tonight attacked the most recent Western note to the Soviet Union on the German problem, charging that its aim was in effect to prevent German unity and gain time for ratification of the Bonn peace contract and the European Defense Treaty. In the past, A. D. N. commentaries have often foreshadowed official Soviet reaction.

Mayor Impellitteri's new drive to wipe out firetraps and disease-breeding tenements follows a report turned in by a committee headed by Robert Moses, which in turn followed a Brooklyn fire in which seven lives were lost. It is tragic that martyrs seem so often to be required before we get simple and obvious reforms, but this is the case.

CHICAGO, July 13 -- No quiet ever seemed so profound as the ordinary sounds of a noisy city when the tumult and shouting of a convention die. The racket ended as automatically as it began and left in its wake a curious emptiness in the morning-after lull. The big question is no longer who but how -- and where do we go from here?
LOS ANGELES, July 13 -- The mystery of the week-old disappearance of Albert Clark Reed, 45 years old, aeronautical research scientist, deepened today with the authorities unable to find any clue.

The largest audience of the season, 19,000, crowded Lewisohn Stadium Saturday evening for the Kern-Hammerstein concert. The audience heard a condensed version of "Show Boat" and also participated in an impromptu greeting for Mr. Hammerstein on his fifty-seventh birthday.

The Affiliated Young Democrats of New York State, winding up their three-day biennial convention yesterday, declined to go along with the Democratic State Committee with an endorsement of Averell Harriman, director for Mutual Security, for President.

MOSCOW, July 13 -- Pravda and other Soviet newspapers today concluded their reports of the Republican National Convention with a dispatch saying that an "extreme reactionary," Senator Richard M. Nixon, had been selected at a secret meeting of party bosses as General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's running mate.
Attractive, easy-to-make, summer house coats are brought to you today by Patterns of The Times. Anyone who likes to sew easily can complete one of these garments in next to no time at all.

When a soldier from Boston sailed for overseas duty ten years ago as a bachelor he probably did not anticipate the type of homecoming he had here yesterday. When he arrived on the Queen Elizabeth he was accompanied by his Austrian-born wife and seven children -- three by his marriage, three by a previous marriage of his wife, and an adopted Eurasian orphan.

CHICAGO, July 13 -- Trade activity was at a slower pace the past week on the Chicago Board of Trade, with wheat futures still retaining a lead in point of volume.
