Average daily purchases of futures of grain and soybeans were about 31,000,000 bushels compared with 44,000,000 bushels the previous week and 40,000,000 bushels a year ago.

BONN, Germany, July 13 -- Although the Soviet Government has used every weapon in a well-stocked armory of vilification and abuse, there are signs in Russia that the "hate America" campaign and a good deal of other Government propaganda are failing to impress the Russian people.

A fellow sent back home from Korea the other day a cigarette lighter battered and bent by a bullet which, had it not been for the pocket lighter, perhaps would have ended this chap's military career then and there.
Recipients of the Thurman H. Bane Award and the Octave Chanute Award for 1952 were announced yesterday by the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences.

MEXICO CITY, July 13 -- As the counting of votes in last Sunday's election neared an end, Gen. Miguel Henriquez Guzman served notice on the Government today that he would continue to struggle to have himself installed as President whatever official result was announced.

The Government has approved the construction of a 24-inch, 953-mile-long crude oil pipeline between Wink, Tex., and Norwalk, Calif., and construction is scheduled to begin in the fourth quarter this year, West Coast Pipe Line Company announced yesterday.

Considerable public interest in the merits or demerits of company-wide and industry-wide bargaining units has focused attention on the National Labor Relations Board's role in deciding the proper unit, whether it be by employer, craft, plant or other unit.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 13 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh, appearing in Parliament today for the first time in seven months, presented a single-article bill under which he would receive dictatorial powers for six months. He sought these powers "to formulate and implement plans for financial, economic, judicial, banking and personnel reforms," he explained.

The steadily increasing population of New York's penal institutions has made it imperative for the city to expand substantially its present capacity to house convicted criminals and persons being held for court action, according to a five-year report by Commissioner of Correction Albert Williams.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Senator Richard M. Nixon, Republican nominee for Vice President, returned to Washington today confident that his party had weathered a "hard fight" and would unite for victory in the coming battle with the Democrats.

LAPEER, Michigan, July 13 -- Arnold W. Lenz, general manager of the Pontiac Division of the General Motors Corporation and vice president of General Motors, was killed and his wife, Amelia, was injured fatally when their automobile collided with a train near here this afternoon.

CHICAGO, July 13 -- The Democrats began today an eager descent on weary Chicago and backers of Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia opened a push here for his Presidential aspirations a full week ahead of the Democratic National Convention.
ALBANY, July 13 (AP) -- Billy Shields successfully defended his state amateur golf title today by defeating Ray Billows, 6 and 5, in the thirty-six-hole final at Wolferts Roost.

The news that G. L. Mehta has been named as the next Ambassador from India to the United States will be well received in this country. Mr. Mehta is a business man and a close student of economic affairs. Dispatches speak of his wit and humor, and they are right. He is witty and humorous. But India is not sending an after-dinner speaker to the United States.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., July 13 -Morristown Memoral Hospital will begin a new stage in its career next Saturday. It is going to move -- patients, beds and baggage -- to its new home in once-exclusive Madison Avenue.

BOSTON, July 13 -- An agreement was reached today that cleared the way for termination of the strike of 1,800 drivers and mechanics of the Eastern Massachusetts Street Railway Company. The strike is now in its 126th day.
Restoration of the "lost virtue of compassion" was called for yesterday by the Rev. Edwin B. Broderick, director of radio and television for the Roman Catholic archdiocese of New York.

The attacks upon Democratic policies contained in the Republican foreign-policy plank are barefaced lies inspired by the hope that the people are ignorant and will be fooled and that at long last President Roosevelt will be defeated.

There are three schools of thought about investment. There is the Lock-It-Up-and-Forget-It School. There is the Highest-Yield-Compatible-With-Prudence School. And there is the Why-Not-Admit-You're-a-Speculator School. Gerald M. Loeb of E. F. Hutton Co. belongs to the last.

MARTINEZ, Calif., July 13 (AP) -- The damage was set today at more than $3,000,000 in the raging fire that ruined one ocean-going oil tanker, damaged another, destroyed a refinery pier and took one life and probably two more yesterday.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation, the nation's second largest producer of electrical equipment, disclosed yesterday plans for a $32,000,000 expansion of its South Philadelphia Works near Lester, Pa.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 13 -- A new gold field, where nuggets are said to lie virtually on the surface of the ground, has drawn thousands of adventurers into one of the wildest corners of Brazil in the past month.

Despite enormous progress in the diagnosis, prevention and treatment of tuberculosis, which has been reflected in a reduced death rate, the incidence has not changed materially in the last twenty years.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- President Truman ordered today a broad investigation of United States foreign trade policies.

The public could be made receptive to many more and larger life insurance policies through well-planned advertising, the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association declared yesterday. Officials of the association believe that the number of policies written during recent years has not kept up with the increase in national income and higher standards of living.

PHILADELPHIA, July 13 (UP) -- Harold E. Stassen said today that General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower would be "a great President who would contribute much to the future peace and well-being of this nation and of the world."

THERE aren't many left but Jack Hurley positively belongs to that fast vanishing breed of men, the genuine fight manager. Most fight managers are merely guys with an aversion for work. They contribute no more to their sweaty charges than to slap them in the kissers with wet sponges and to slice up the gate receipts.

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, July 14 (AP) -- Allied infantry today beat off a savage Red attack on a key hill position at the eastern end of the Korean battle front. The United Nations troops captured the hill late last night after a fierce three-day assault.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat of Illinois, told home state constituents today that the Eighty-second Congress was "an utter flop" in the field of domestic affairs.
BATON ROUGE, La., July 13 (AP) -- Louisiana has passed laws to open the state's $100,000,000 welfare rolls and to ban public bodies from taking final action in closed meetings.

BLED, Yugoslavia. July 13 -- The United States informed Marshal Tito tonight that Washington had decided to equip the Yugoslav armed forces with tanks, heavy artillery and jet aircraft during the fiscal year 1952-53.
TOKYO, Monday, July 14 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,310, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Monday, Korea time:
OSLO, July 13 (AP) -- Swiss and Scandinavian marksmen dominated today's events in the world shooting championships.

PITTSBURGH, July 13 (UP) -- The seventh-place Braves reached a season's peak of four straight victories today when they whipped the last-place Pirates, 4 -- 2 and 2 -- 1, behind the steady pitching of Max Surkont and Virgil Jester.
The rise in temperature yesterday was matched by a sudden increase in the activity of pickpockets.

Racial bigotry was condemned by the Rev. Dr. William Lloyd Imes, director of field service of the New York State Council of Churches, in a sermon yesterday at St. Augustine Presbyterian Church, Prospect Avenue and East 165th Street, the Bronx.

There was a time, a few years back, when it was the fashion to observe that there were categories of young sports writers -- those who decided to be second Grantland Rices and those who, faced with the same momentous decision, had passed up the purple patches and the Whistlerian chromatic values of Mr. Rice for the sophisticated approach that was the hallmark of Mr. W. O. McGeehan.

Gov. Earl Warren of California, accompanied by Mrs. Warren and their three daughters, Virginia, 23 years old, Dorothy, 21, and Nina, 18, arrived at La Guardia Airport at 3:35 P. M. yesterday for a four-or five-day vacation in New York.

The Rev. Dr. Samuel Henry Prince of the faculty of King's University, Halifax, N. S., opened his thirty-third series of summer sermons yesterday at St. Stephen's Protestant Episcopal Church, 122 West Sixty-ninth Street. The rector, the Rev. Dr. J. Wilson Sutton, will depart on vacation this week.

James Reardon, a former plainclothes man in the New York Police Department, will go on trial today before Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz on a charge of committing perjury before the Brooklyn rackets grand jury.

Automobiles are among the products of our American scene which we all take for granted. Few of us, however, have an adequate conception of the varied uses to which they are put. The Automobile Manufacturers Association has issued the results of a cross-section survey of our national population conducted by an independent research organization.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (UP) -- Mike Garcia pitched his fourth shut-out in the opener and Al Rosen knocked in both runs with his seventeenth homer in the finale today as the Indians defeated the Senators, 1 -- 0 and 2 -- 1, running their winning streak to four games.
Francis J. Sinnott, Brooklyn Democratic leader, named Aaron L. Jacoby yesterday as chairman of the Kings County delegation to the Democratic National Convention in Chicago next week.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 14 -- Connecticut Democratic leaders said tonight they did not expect Senator Brien McMahon, this state's "favorite son" for the Democratic Presidential nomination, to attend the National Convention next week in Chicago.

CINCINNATI, July 14 -- The Giants started belting the left-handed Ken Raffensberger at modest tempo on Crosley Field today, gradually adding momentum to their blasting. Before they laid their clubs aside, the champions had subdued Manager Luke Sewell's Reds, 6 to 2, and Jim Hearn had his tenth victory of the campaign.

The Philippine Senate has been called into special session today to take up again the question of ratification of the San Francisco peace treaty with Japan. The regular session could not come to agreement on this issue and President Quirino is pushing for ratification and has insisted that action, be taken. Meanwhile, parallel action on the mu tual security pact with the United States has also been held up.

That dreadful combination of high temperature and soaring humidity settled on an uncomfortable city yesterday, breaking a record for the date and causing many city departments and business offices to close shop early in the afternoon.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- Items specifically exempted from controls by the Office of Price Stabilization today were: canned asparagus, lima beans, green and wax snap beans, carrots, sweet corn, beets, all varieties of fresh field peas and fresh shell beans, fresh green peas, tomatoes, succotash, mushrooms, okra, onions, peppers, pimentoes, canned sweet potatoes, canned white potatoes, pumpkin, squash, spinach, turnip greens, canned mixtures of vegetables, canned vegetable juices and mixtures of vegetable juices.

GENEVA, July 14 -- As a result of sound economic diplomacy, aided by some luck, the United States Government has avoided, at least temporarily, an embarrassing showdown with some of its best trading partners over the United States restrictions on imports of cheese and other milk products.

NEW LONDON, Conn., July 14 -- No question was raised as to the need for a Government laboratory for the study of foot and mouth disease, but more than fifty persons attending a public hearing here today found themselves in two camps.
DALLAS, Tex., .July 14 (AP) -- Spokesmen for both Taft and Eisenhower factions of the Texas Republican party will meet here Saturday in a harmony move.

An exhibition showing the economic development of Israel will be dedicated at 10:30 A. M. today in Rockefeller Plaza, 22 West Forty-eighth Street, in memory of Eliezer Kaplan, Israel Deputy Prime Minister, who died Sunday. The exposition will be opened to the public on Thursday.

BOSTON, July 14 (AP) -- The Browns snapped the Red Sox' five-game winning streak today, 7 -- 5, but Dave Madison, rookie right-hander, tired in the 90-plus degree heat, and lost a shut-out in the ninth as Dick Gernert walloped a two-out, three-run homer.

CHICAGO, July 14 -- Tom Fool, Greentree Stable's 2-year-old champion of 1951 and one of the leading contenders for the $150,000 Arlington Classic next Saturday, took a beating today in his first appearance on a Chicago race track, finishing fourth in a $6,000 allowance race at Arlington Park.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (UP) -- Helped by five errors and nine walks, the Senators crushed the Indians, 15 to 4, today, on thirteen hits off four pitchers.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., July 14 -- Two steel plates weighing thirteen tons each clicked together with the precision of a watch case here today and so was laid the keel of what will be the world's largest airplane carrier when she is completed two and a half years hence.

A 20-year-old secretary was shot dead yesterday at 9:20 A. M. by an unidentified man in a room on the ninth floor of the Pupin Building of Columbia University at Broadway and 120th Street. The victim was Eileen Fahey of 161 West 108th Street, who for two years had worked as a secretary and bookkeeper for the American Physical Society.

Governor Dewey returned to his home in the Roosevelt Hotel at 9:40 o'clock last night with the prediction that substantial Democratic and independent support would aid the Republicans in electing General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower in November.
Three-dimensional warfare -- by land, sea and air -- was opened yesterday by the Bureau of Smoke Control.

BALTIMORE, July 14 (AP) -- A Baltimore doctor and his nurse were convicted today of conspiring with a Brooklyn, N. Y., lawyer in selling babies for adoption. Judge Herman Moser deferred sentence on Dr. Charles J. Tommassello and the nurse, Mary Margaret Roper, pending motions for a new trial.
Jersey Joe Walcott, heavyweight boxing champion of the world, will defend his title in September against the winner of the Rocky Marciano-Harry (Kid) Matthews fight at Yankee Stadium on July 28.

BOSTON, July 14 -- Union leaders officially accepted today a settlement of the four-month strike against the Eastern Massachusetts Street Railway Company. Buses will start rolling again at 5 A. M. tomorrow, according to John H. Moran, president of the company.

PHILADELPHIA, July 14 (AP) -- Fresh from his second straight victory in the Spring Lake invitation tourney, Vic Seixas of Philadelphia polished off Tim Coss, Washington collegian, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 1, in his first- round match of the Pennsylvania State tennis championship at the Merion Cricket Club today.

BINGHAMTON, N. Y., July 14 (AP) -- Mrs. Ruth Torgerson, five-time State champion from Garden City, L. I., took the medal today with a 1-over-par 77 in qualifying play for New York State Women's amateur golf tournament.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 14 (AP) -- Harry Lundeberg, head of the Sailors Union of the Pacific, A. F. L., today announced union acceptance of an agreement with the Alaska Steamship Company, the first break in the forty-seven-day-old Pacific coast maritime strike.

The trick for 6,611 fans in the Stadium yesterday was to recognize which team was in first place and which was last. Certainly, the Yankees did not look nor perform like champions as they succumbed to the eighth-place Tigers, 8 -- 2.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 14 (AP) -- The Philippines, Canada, Cuba, Hungary and Bulgaria were the winners today in the opening series of basketball eliminations preceding the July 24 opening of the Olympic basketball tournament.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The Treasury announced tonight that tenders for $1,400,000,000 of ninety-one-day Treasury bills to be dated July 17 and to mature Oct. 16 were opened to the Federal Reserve Banks today.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- President Truman today signed an act opening the way for the Government to boost its operations in financing home mortgages.

AMARILLO, Tex., July 14 (AP) -- C. M. Henderson, 61-year-old former mayor of Farwell, Tex., was found guilty in Federal court here today on forty-seven counts of a fifty-three-count indictment charging misuse of Government-owned grain.

THE sun was just getting over the horizon at Montauk Point yesterday for its regular business of blistering the waterfront when those up and about saw gulls plunging with excited screeching the flat waters near the docks.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 14 (AP) -- A decision in the struggle for control of the 103-year-old, $10,000,000 United States Finishing Company of Norwich rested in Superior Court today as counsel for management and a stockholders' committee argued on an injunction motion for an hour and a half before Judge Thomas J. Molloy.

CHICAGO, July 14 -- As incoming Democrats tried tonight to match or better the party platform of claimed deeds of the past and promises for the future built by the Republicans last week, it appeared that the sharpest contests would be on the planks of civil rights and agriculture.

LONDON, July 14 -- In the face of sharp criticism in the House of Commons, the Conservative Government agreed tonight to reconsider economy measures that have restricted the public's access to British museums and art galleries.

Public offering will be made of a new issue of $100,000,000 of convertible subordinated debentures of the Dow Chemical Company. A syndicate of 233 underwriting houses headed by Smith, Barney Co. is making the distribution. The debentures, which will come due July 1, 1982, will bear 3 per cent interest and are priced at 101 1/2 to yield 2.925 per cent.

For those who are fortunate enough to have summer homes at the mountains or seashore and have the need of wool coverings, some hints on washing blankets may be of interest. Also, since the ideal weather for drying heavy pieces is a sunny day that is also dry and breezy, some homemakers may have saved tackling the laundering of blankets until this season of the year.

Real Brother, owned by Mrs. George F. Spear, was the winner of the Wakefield Stakes, the $10,000 added event that served as the feature of the opening program of the Empire City Racing Association's meeting at Jamaica yesterday.

Last week's events at Chicago showed that a major party's Presidential nominating convention could escape from the leash of its nominal leadership and respond to the pressure of public opinion. At the same time the contests in some Southern states, notably Georgia, Louisiana and Texas, raised serious doubts as to whether the present system -- or the present confusion of systems -- in selecting convention delegates ought not to be changed.

BINGHAMTON, N. Y., July 14 -- As the result of the suffocation of a College Point, L. I., child, the superintendent of Chenango Valley State Park, Edward Strong, said today he had banned the use of underwater swimming masks there.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 14 (UP) -- Whiffenpoof, a 12-1 shot from the Carolyn K. Stable, made it two in a row at Monmouth Park today when he led all the way to beat Tocoli by half a length in the $6,000 Twenty Grand Purse.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 14 -- An easement for a natural gas pipeline was sold today by the Westchester County Board of Supervisors for $75,000 to the Algonquin Gas Transmission Company.

President Truman's new study of the effects of United States foreign trade restrictions on its program for building economic and military strength of the free world met mixed praise and criticism from foreign traders yesterday.

Commodity markets had a day of light volume yesterday, with only minor changes except for zinc and hides. Hides gained 35 to 48 points on the Commodity Exchange, but volume was only thirty-five lots. Zinc gained 30 to 35 points on twenty lots.

A trend toward toys dealing with space travel and atomic energy is discernible in the items being prepared for Christmas, the Toy Guidance Council, Inc., announced yesterday. Television has always influenced the demand for toys and now, with many science fiction programs on the air, the western types arc waning slightly, according to Melvin Freud, president.

" The Big Stick," volumes V and VI of "The Letters of Theodore Roosevelt," will be issued Aug. 15 by Harvard University Press. The volumes cover 1905 to 1909, the years in which the fleet cruised around the world, of trustbusting, railroad regulation and the Panic of 1907, the choice of a successor and the conflict between President and Congress in the closing days of the Administration.
LONDON, July 14 -- Small investment buying in markets short of stock brought a further general price improvement on the Stock Exchange here today.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 14 -- Connie Neher, representing the Indian Harbor Yacht Club, led the qualifiers in the Long Island Sound junior girls' sailing championship for the Gregory Taylor Cup as the three-race preliminary series was completed off the Riverside Y. C. tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- The Justice Department is going to check the authenticity of a series of cablegrams allegedly showing how Chinese Nationalist officials here tried to influence United States policy in the Far East.

In announcing the schedules under which the forty-hour work week will be put into effect gradually for some 55,000 of the city's 165,000 employes who do not now have it Mayor Impellitteri is living up to a promise made to the city workers when the current budget was being made up last spring.

William H. Cochrane has been appointed to the new position of industrial sales manager of Lever Brothers Corporation. He will have responsibility for the bulk edible and glycerine sales departments as well as the industrial detergent sales department, a new unit.

A so-called new Magna Carta for the Reserve components of the armed forces was passed in the closing hours of the last session of Congress in an attempt to codify and modernize disparate legislation, some of it decades old, to rectify discrimination and to vitalize the Reserve forces.

The Board of Health added a new section to the city's Sanitary Code yesterday requiring manufacturers of cleaning fluids containing carbon tetrachloride to label their products with special warning against misuse.
ST. LOUIS, July 14 -- Carl Erskine, the Dodgers' no-hit right-hander, hurled his third shut-out of the season tonight as the Brooks beat the Cardinals, 6 -- 0, before 28,985 fans at Sportsman's Park.

JACKSON, Mich., July 14 (AP) -- Thirteen leaders of the April mutiny at Southern Michigan Prison were shifted to the Geneses County jail at Flint today as Frank Millard, State Attorney General, prepared to ask warrants against a score or more who participated in the rioting.
CHICAGO, July 14 (AP) -- The order of Railway Conductors today called a strike for 6 A. M. Central standard time July 29 against the Pullman Company.
Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 10 to 19 points lower than on Friday, on a moderate volume of business.
JERSEY CITY, July 14 -- Former Mayor Frank Hague will record next week his first absence in thirty-two years from a Democratic national convention, it was said here today.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- President Truman, who has suffered nothing worse than sniffles for as long as White House attaches can remember, was laid up today with "a mild virus infection."

Two new films will arrive in first-run theatres this morning. At the Sixtieth Street Trans-Lux the attraction will be "White Corridors," a British-made medical drama with Googie Withers, James Donald and Godfrey Tearle. Pat Jackson directed and Joseph Janni and John Croydon produced from a screen play by Mr. Jackson and Jan Read and the novel, "Yeoman's Hospital," by Helen Ashton.

RICHMOND, Va., July 14 (AP) -- Virginians will vote tomorrow on whether to return Harry F. Byrd to the United States Senate or send in his stead, Col. Frances Pickens Miler, anti-organization stalwart.

A window-shopping policeman who was off duty in plain clothes captured an alleged robber at 1 P. M. yesterday after a chase of roughly two blocks on Fifth Avenue and East Fifty-sixth Street. The captive was identified by Miss Barbara Lauter, 29-year-old cashier at the Rosemarie de Paris candy shop, 697 Fifth Avenue, south of East Fifty-fifth Street, as the man who had puncher her eye there and run off with $77, the police said.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 14 -- Eighty-five teams took part in the weekly one-day Westchester Professional Golfers Association pro-amateur best-ball tournament over the Fenway Country Club course today. When it was over there was a three-way tie at 65.

LONDON, July 14 (Reuters) -- Peter May, England and Cambridge University batsman, hit a century off Kent bowling today in his first match of the season for Surrey, county cricket leader. During his four-and-a-half hour innings of 124, May had eleven fours.

MELBOURNE, Australia, July 14 -- Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies has returned from his conferences in Washington and London to find that electors in three states -- New South Wales, Queens-land and Victoria -- had cast decisive votes for the Labor party during his absence.

CHICAGO, July 14 -- Senator Robert S. Kerr of Oklahoma predicted today that, barring interference from President Truman, the Democratic National Convention, which opens here next Monday, will decide upon a candidate for President after "five or six ballots."

Canned stewed tomatoes are exceedingly plentiful because of heavy carry-overs from last season's record pack. A No. 2 can yielding four portions ranges from 10 to 16 cents, and should be compared with 61 cents, the cost of the equivalent in stewed fresh tomatoes.

As a Republican who is willing to recognize the degree to which this nation is indebted to the New Deal for the rebirth of confidence and hope given the people in 1932 I believe that the campaign to elect a Republican Administration in November must be conducted on a basis of wise promise: for the future, not on repudiation of the New Deal.

CHICAGO, July 14 -- Although the two labor federations as such profess adherence to neither major political party, labor leaders will figure significantly in the Democratic convention that opens Monday in contrast to their conspicuous absence from the Republican conclave last week.
ROME, July 14 -- The United States Embassy said today that Alberto Moravia, Italian novelist whose works are best-sellers in America, had been refused a visa to visit the United States.

A plot of vacant land covering the blockfront on the north side of Forty-eighth Avenue from Thirty-seventh to Thirty-eighth Street, Long Island City, was sold by the Thomson Hill Land and Improvement Company to the Franshir Realty Company in a deal negotiated by the Cross Brown Company, broker.

" LAMENT FOR FOUR VIRGINS," by Lael Tucker, is a novel of realistic nostalgia for the Georgian South of the Scott Fitzgerald, rather than the Faulkner, era. It is the story of four lost ladies, told in a murmurous, cadenced prose that flashes, at intervals, with exuberant wit and is animated with some of the sharpest observation I've seen in a first novel in a long time

Limited progress was made by some sections in the stock market yesterday but it was offset by late selling. Although the composite rate of THE NEW YORK TIMES index showed a slight edge of 0.02 point, much wider gains appeared in the favored divisions.

PHILADELPHIA, July 14 (AP) -- Dave Philley's fourth hit, a tenth inning single to center, scored Eddie Joost and gave the Athletics a 2-1 triumph tonight over the White Sox. Philley also batted in the A's first run with a triple in the first.

The Sunray Oil Corporation increased its gross income from operations in the first six months this year to $34,641,000 from $31,734,000 in the initial half of 1951, but higher operating costs reduced the net income by $2,383,000, according to the semi-annual report issued yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 14 -- Dr. Walter M. Kotschnig of the United States told the United Nations Economic and Social Council today that the Soviet Union and its satellites had furnished no data for the first preliminary survey of world social conditions prepared by the Council.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 14 (UP) -- The two top-ranking foreign entries in the Western tennis championships scored easy victories today. Don Candy of Australia and Francisco Contreras of Mexico, seeded one, two, respectively, among the non-U. S. players, lost only three games between them.
CHICAGO, July 14 -- The Democrats decided today to have more red, white and blue bunting and more American flags for their national convention than the Republicans used.

LOS ANGELES, July 14 -- John Anson Ford, Los Angeles County supervisor and head of the California delegation for Senator Estes Kefauver, said today that "a certain party" had bought eight tickets on the Kefauver special train to the Democratic National Convention in Chicago and had offered them as bribes to delegates to switch their votes after the first ballot.

The Herbert Jacques Morris Corporation was co-broker with Milton Levin of Max Gruber Associates, the Clark Wilcox Company and the J. Clarence Davies Realty Company in the recent sale of store properties in Levittown, L. I., by Levitt Sons to Webb Knapp, Inc.

Do you have good eyesight? Is your hearing sound? That, together with a sense of duty, is about all you need to do the country and your city a service. Yesterday 150,000 volunteer aircraft spotters went on a round-the-clock watch in twenty-seven states to scan the skies for possible enemy airplanes. Maybe we'll never see any enemy planet We hope not. But until that is certain we must be on the lookout.
Mrs. Walter J. Monaghan, wife of a form plainclothes man, continued yesterday her defiance of Brooklyn's law agencies.

Traffic congestion, deteriorated roads and fear of accidents have reduced the annual average mileage in individual use of passenger cars to below the peak pre-war rate. Lack of parking facilities also has contributed to the decrease, even though over-all motor travel volume and car registrations have mounted steadily.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- Government officials today explored a new plan to bring an independent aluminum producer into the industry now dominated by Alcoa, Reynolds and Kaiser.

ALBANY, N. Y., July 14 (AP) -- A Greenport lawyer today urged the Court of Appeals to uphold a ruling that the Long Island State Park Commission had no power to set a forty-mile-an-hour speed limit on its parkways.

TOKYO, Tuesday, July 15 -- The headquarters of the United Nations commander, Gen. Mark W. Clark, yesterday denied that United States planes had bombed a prisoner-of-war camp during the big raid on the North Korean capital of Pyongyang last week as the Chinese and North Korean truce delegation had charged.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 14 -- The American track and field team had one of its liveliest workouts at the Olympic Village training ground as the weather turned cool, after the sun's warmth of the past few days, following a heavy rain this morning.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 14 (AP) -- Vincent Farrell, an American sports official, delighted European fans with his colorful officiating today as he made his debut in the Olympic basketball tournament.

HONG KONG, July 14 -- With its third anniversary ten weeks away, the Peiping Government has announced a "new tide of construction," apparently destined to follow an initial three-year program aimed at rehabilitating China's war-damaged economy.

SEA GIRT, N. J., July 14 -- Averell Harriman, Director for Mutual Security and a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, declared tonight that the Democrats faced a "tough" campaign this fall because of the constant "smear campaign" that had been waged against the Truman Administration since 1948, on both domestic and foreign issues.

DENVER, July 14 (AP) -- Two North Texas State collegians and a Denver favorite turned in one-under-par 69's to lead the first round of qualifying play in the forty-ninth Trans-Mississippi golf tournament.

PARIS, July 14 -- Frenchmen around the world celebrated Bastille Day today -- the 163d anniversary of the beginning of the French Revolution, when the capitals citizenry stormed the Paris prison that symbolized royal despotism.
Some time ago there appeared an item headed "Job Bias Pact Is Reached." May I add one other phase of discrimination -- age.

PALO ALTO, Calif., July 14 -- Stanford University scientists are building a low-cost microwave machine that promises to put high energy X-ray treatment of deep-rooted cancer within reach of virtually every hospital in the country.

NEW DELHI, India, July 14 -- The controversial and delicate matter of future relations between India and the strategic princely state of Jammu and Kashmir is expected to be threshed out at conferences here this week in which Sheikh Mohammad Abdullah, the Prime Minister of the Indian-held part of the state, will participate. Other Kashmir officials are already in the capital and were to see Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru this evening.

BERLIN, July 12 -- The Executive Board of the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions has sent to its seventy-one affiliates a recommendation against the admission of the Yugoslav trade unions.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, July 14 -- The development of a multiracial Malayan National Army, authorized in legislation recently passed by the Legislative Council of the Federation of Malaya, will be a long, slow process. Officials here say a lack of officers, the shortage of training facilities and personnel and limited financial resources will restrict the rate at which an army can be expanded.
TOKYO, Tuesday, July 15 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,311, for twenty-four hours time:

Bruce Gustafson, unseeded Washington player, upset David Harum of Coral Gables, Fla., seeded No. 5, by 6 -- , 6 -- 2 in the Eastern junior tennis championship at the West Side Club, Forest Hills, yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Fifty-three Democratic members of Congress called on their party today to pledge itself in its platform to a fight for enactment of a nation-wide Presidential primary law. The signers of the petition represented every section of the country.
The use of color as an aid in creating an uncrowded atmosphere is demonstrated in seven model rooms that will go on view today at Bloomingdale's.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif, July 14 -- Warwick Productions and Columbia will be associated in the production two Alan Ladd pictures, "The Red Beret" and "The White South," according to word from Columbia today.
When the liner United States enters New York Harbor this morning as speed queen, she will get a greeting reserved for ocean royalty.

If your child enjoys going to school, don't send for a psychiatrist -- it's just that times and schools have changed. This word of advice to parents was given yesterday by Prof. Howard F. Fehr of Teachers College, Columbia University, who asserted that, "believe it or not," most youngsters liked school and enjoyed learning.
ATLANTA, July 14 (AP) -- The Georgia Supreme Court questioned today whether it had jurisdiction in an appeal of two Atlanta Constitution editors from fines and jail terms for contempt of court.
BERLIN, July 14 -- East Germany's Communists promised Premier Stalin today that they would begin to convert that region into a socialistic state.
DETROIT, July 14 -- General Motors has perfected an air conditioning unit for automobiles, it was announced here today by C. E. Wilson, president.

CHICAGO, July 14 -- Reports of extremely heavy flour sales over the week-end were largely nullified by the huge shipments of wheat to terminal markets. However, the flour business temporarily stemmed the tide of selling of wheat futures.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 14 -- The International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, Local 35, was found guilty today of racial discrimination in refusing to admit two Negroes to the union. The finding was made in a decision by Superior Court Judge A. S. Bordon.

A group of employes who have been with James McCreery Co., Thirty-fourth Street department store, for more than twenty-five years, were honored last night at a reception given by William Holmes, president. Among the employes honored, fifty-four have been with the company for more than twentyfive years, seventeen more than forty years, and three more than fifty years.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., July 14 -- Three American Federation of Labor international unions are being investigated by a committee of top A. F. L. leaders, the latter said today. The inquiry is the result of charges that these unions have issued charters for locals in Chicago, New York and Jersey City to individuals with questionable characters.
Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia declared here yesterday that he was "the man to beat Eisenhower."

CHAUTAUQUA, N. Y., July 14 -- A bronze portrait bust of the late Georges Barrere, regarded as one of the greatest flutists in musical history, was presented to the Chautauqua Institution this afternoon by an anonymous friend of the musician.
The Society for Seamen's Children cared for 123 children in 1951 both in its Marshall Cottage on Staten Island and in foster homes on the island, the group's annual report said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- Savings bond buying has picked up since the Government put its higher-interest bond on sale on May 1. But new purchases haven't yet caught up with total cash-ins.

GENEVA, July 14 -- The Association of Swiss Labor Unions, representing almost all organized labor in Switzerland, appealed to the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions today for support in a protest against a threatened increase in the United States' traiffs on Swiss watches.

CHICAGO, July 14 -- With six avowed candidates, one "favorite son" and two "dark horse" possibilities listed for the Presidential nomination, the Democratic National Convention, which will convene next Monday, is confronted with the prospect of a prolonged battle before the party's nominee is selected.

Having brought his country to the verge of bankruptcy, Premier Mossadegh is now trying to take it further along the road to ruin by demanding dictatorial powers for six months, on the plea that he needs these powers to pull Iran out of the crisis into which he has plunged it. What he proposes is in effect a legalized coup d'etat that smacks of Hitler's technique.

LOS ANGELES, July 14 -- The calamitous effect of the steel strike on the nation's economy is graphically indicated in the business of the railroads, it was pointed out today by William T. Faricy, president of the Association of American Railroads.

THE transaction had gone through proper channels without a hitch. First, Bob Carpenter, the owner of the Phillies, phoned Joe Cronin, the boss of the Red Sox, and asked for permission to offer the Phillies' managerial job to a Red Sox scout by the name of Steve O'Neill. Cronin was so tickled by the news that he even phoned O'Neill by way of expediting matters.

One of the founders of the Czechoslovak Communist party, Dr. Sigmund Stein, who for several years had been the chief legal adviser to the Czechoslovak Government, has been arrested in Prague, according to information received in New York yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- A $94,000,000 loan, the largest sum advanced for a mining enterprise in the twenty-year history of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, was made to the San Manuel Copper Corporation, of Pinal County, Arizona, today.
Tonnage-poor Trieste shipowners are seeking the enactment of a special bill in the United States Congress that would permit them to buy ten Government-owned Liberty ships here.

DAMASCUS, July 14 (AP) -- Syria is expected to produce a record wheat crop of 850,000 tons this year, according to an estimate by the Government Wheat Office. This, Government officials say, will permit the export of around 250,000 tons of wheat in 1952.
Twenty - two thousand Elks roamed the hot streets of Manhattan yesterday, viewing the city from the heights of its skyscrapers and probing the depths of its subway system.
LONDON, July 14 -- A suggestion that Dr. Hewlett Johnson, Dean of Canterbury, might be indicted for treason was rejected in the House of Commons today.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., July 17 -- The labor plank in the Republican party platform was castigated today by a top American Federation of Labor official who called it an "insult" to the labor movement.
THE NEW YORK TIMES has performed a good service in publishing in your issue of July 12 the letter of Charles Stuart-Linton discussing the British military effort in the First and Second World Wars.

PARIS, July 14 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower is noted in Europe for his repeated appeals for European unity, and it is assumed that an Administration headed by him would press as hard as the present one has done for a union of the Western European states.

Methods of infant care that are considered up-to-date and scientific in one country may be looked upon as thoroughly outmoded in another. This creates difficulty when public health workers trained in one part of the world set about organizing child health programs in another.
ABOARD THE LINER UNITED STATES, in Quarantine Station, July 14 -- The liner United States has swept the seas of speed competition and stands as the fastest vessel in the world.

Despite its brave name and vital purpose, "Operation Skywatch" proved a spotty, half effective affair yesterday. Preliminary reports indicated that about half of the 6,000 posts in the operation's twenty - seven - state area were manned, as round-the-clock operation began at 8 A. M. for Civilian Defense volunteer aircraft spotters.

CHICAGO, July 14 -- Frank E. McKinney, the Democratic National Chairman, said today that he took both President Truman and Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois at their word that they were not receptive to the Democratic Presidential nomination and that he looked for a wide-open race principally among four men for the right to oppose General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., July 14 -- Senator Estes Kefauver today attacked General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Republican Presidential nominee, as "the unwitting tool of the few greedy men who have long sought to control this country's economy."

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, July 14 (AP) -- Flames flashed through this inland Alaska city's second largest hotel early today, leaving one person known dead, five listed by the police as missing and eight hospitalized.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 14 -- In A last-minute rush, thousands of residents of this country today queued up from 7 A. M. to declare that they did not want to be citizens of Israel and did want to retain their foreign citizenship and passports.

HEADQUARTERS, Eighth Army, in Korea, July 14 -- Gen. J. Lawton Collins, United States Army Chief of Staff, wound up a two-day tour of the Korean front tonight with a warning to the Chinese Communists that they would not have a "ghost of a show" if they tried now to launch a new offensive.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- In a formal order today the Office of Price Stabilization removed from price control almost all fresh and processed fruits and vegetables.

BOSTON, July 14 -- While Massachusetts Republican leaders enjoyed a post-convention rest today, political interest in New England centered upon reports that Gov. Frederick G. Fayne of Maine seemed assured of victory in his campaign for the Senate there. Burton M. Cross, president of the State Senate, was expected to become the next Governor of the Pine Tree State.
The Lehigh Navigation Coal Company, Inc., controlled by the Lehigh Coal and Navigation Company, announced yesterday a plan for financing the sale of coal to dealers as well as consumers.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Ellis G. Arnall, head of the Office of Price Stabilization, presented a problem tonight to the White House by insisting again that steel companies were not entitled to an increase of more than about $3 a ton under present wage, price and economic controls laws.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- President Truman today signed the "Fair Trade" Act, restoring the price-fixing authority of the Fair Trade laws of forty-five states. This authority had been wiped out on May 21, 1951, by a United States Supreme Court decision that precipitated price-cutting wars, notably the one between Macy's add Gimbels in New York last summer.
Textile prices, in a slump for the last two years, gave indication yesterday of reversing the trend and starting upward again.

The Messrs. Shubert and Maurice Evans have agreed to join in presenting on Broadway this season "Dial 'M' for Murder," a melodrama by Frederick Knott that received a favorable reception when it was presented in London last month.

Erica Morini is a superb violinist and last night she provided one of the high points of the Lewisohn Stadium season when she played the Tchaikovsky Violin Concerto, the climax of the all-Tchaikovsky program led by Alexander Smallens.
The Government and the defense in the conspiracy trial of fifteen secondary Communist leaders in Federal Court here continued to spar yesterday.
DENVER, July 14 -- Formation of Columbine Pulp and Paper, Inc., to produce newsprint in western Colorado was announced today.

Air conditioning and ice water coolers placed at strategic spots throughout the fourth annual national China, Glass and Pottery Show may have proved yesterday to be an attraction equal to the quantity of "hot" merchandise displayed.

Mayor Impellitteri will turn a valve at 10 A. M. tomorrow to admit Hudson River water to the emptied twenty-six acre lake near Grassy Point, north of Haverstraw, and begin the process of floating the three huge pontoon-like structures that will form the base of the city's new revolutionary type pier.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 10 -- Although census figures show the Union of South Africa as having 1,100,000 persons of mixed blood, Dr. I. D. duPlessis, Commissioner for Colored Affairs, has asked the public to help in the search for a comprehensive definition of "colored person."
WASHINGTON, July 14 (UP) -- Americans earned money at the rate of $263,500,000,000 a year during May, the Department of Commerce reported today. That is an average of $1,678 a person a year.

BAY PARK, L. I., July 14 -- The efficiency of Nassau County's new treatment plant here, handling 300,000,000 gallons of sewage a month, reduces bacterial count in its efficient enough for "good" ratings in both shellfishing and bathing beach water categories.

Sales in June of leading man order and chain store companies showed an increase of 4.8 per cent over the same month of 1951, according to a compilation covering forty-two companies made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. In May, a gain of 9.3 per cent was reported.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 14 -- The start of a test of Ohio's right to censor newsreels has been arranged here for Wednesday night by the Motion Picture Association of America and the Independent Theatre Owners of Ohio.

The steel strike, now in its seventh week, holds the nation's economy in a vise. Some 1,500,000 workers are partially or wholly idle. Ten per cent of the nation's 1,300,000 railroad employes have been furloughed; 300,000 automobile workers have been laid off; 50,000 coal miners are idle.

Thousands of television viewers have been irritated at commercials interrupting moments of high drama or low comedy in the recent Republican convention. But a number of watchers appear to have been captivated by glowing descriptions of refrigerators and television sets.

BONN, Germany, July 14 -- A committee of the West German Bundestag recommended today that Chancellor Konrad Adenauer dismiss two former Nazis from his Foreign Ministry and take action against five others.

ATLANTIC CLTY, July 14 - Financial aid through direct Federal subsidies or private philanthropy is essential if present high standards of the nation's colleges of healing arts are to be maintained and more doctors are to be educated, the president of the American Osteopathic Association said here tonight.

HIGHLAND FALLS, N. Y., July 14 -- Maj. John S. D. Eisenhower and his wife, Barbara, completed today a week-long house-hunting expedition here, then went to Chicago, where Major Eisenhower said good-by to his parents, General of the Army and Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower, before leaving for Korea Friday.
PITTSBURGH, July 14 -- The White House forced resumption of steel peace talks today after leaders of 600,000 striking steel workers had turned down a new industry settlement proposal.

LOS ANGELES, July 14 -- Six Japanese financial experts arrived here today en route to a New York meeting with American, British and French representatives of the Japanese Bondholders' Organization. Their problem is Japans $400,000,000 default on it indebtedness.

TEHERAN,. Iran, July 14 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh told the Iranian Parliament yesterday in its close session, according to the generally respected newspaper Ettelaat, that Hjalmar Schacht, key financial figure of the Nazi regime in Germany, had agreed to come to Iran to try to correct present financial and economic situation.
SEOUL, Korea, July 14 (UP) -- Fighter-bombers of the Fifth Air Force raked the 155-mile Korean battle front today in one of the heaviest close-support attacks of the year.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 14 (AP) -- Gov. Gordon Browning of Tennessee who will nominate Senator Estes Kefauver for the Presidency next week, has proposed that all Democratic Governors join in urging the party"s National Chairman to work for a "free, untrammeled convention."

A young mother gave birth to a healthy child yesterday morning after the ambulance in which she was being rushed to a hospital collided at First Avenue and Eighteenth Street, with a station wagon containing five children.
SEOUL, Korea, July 14 (UP) -- Fighter-bombers of the Fifth Air Force raked the 155-mile Korean battle front today in one of the heaviest close-support attacks of the year.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 14 (AP) -- Gov. Gordon Browning of Tennessee who will nominate Senator Estes Kefauver for the Presidency next week, has proposed that all Democratic Governors join in urging the party"s National Chairman to work for a "free, untrammeled convention."

President Truman is entirely right in suggesting that there is a contradiction between Congressional approval of the Mutual Security Program and Congressional approval of various devices for restricting international trade. In asking the Public Advisory Board for Mutual Security to look into the whole question of American foreign trade policy the President focuses attention on a "very real dilemma."
MEMPHIS, Tenn., July 14 (AP) -- The most richly ornamented church in Memphis was left wide open last night in the hope that a thief would return, but he did not.

A young mother gave birth to a healthy child yesterday morning after the ambulance in which she was being rushed to a hospital collided at First Avenue and Eighteenth Street, with a station wagon containing five children.

ALBANY, July 15 -- The Court of Appeals unanimously upheld today New York's right to levy its weight-distance tax on trucks traveling the state's highways. The court approved the constitutionality of the year-old law without opinion.

Those who read in this space last summer of the adventures of Capt. J. W. Menke and his showboat, the Goldenrod, at St. Louis, where the company has been riding at anchor since 1937, may have felt that the age of river entertainment had been preserved although there was little likelihood that it would be expanded.

The giant ore carrier Joseph H. Thompson, product of three shipyards separated by hundreds of miles, is expected to be ready for service in mid-October for an effort to replenish sorely depleted ore supplies before the winter freeze closes up the Great Lakes.

HONG KONG, July 15 -- A "triple squeeze and double opposition" movement has been launched by Chinese Communist authorities in Kwangtung Province to curb opposition elements accused of "rumor-mongering arson, poison-spreading, sabotage and assassination."
WASHINGTON, July 15 (UP) -- The Civil Service Commission accused the National Production Authority today of hiring more than 100 employes "irregularly" last year.
Battery Park was returned officially by the city yesterday to the citizens of New York as 8,000 persons gathered there under a noon sun to take it back.

Twenty-seven contests for major party nominations in the Aug. 19 primary were indicated yesterday as the time passed for the filing of designating petitions for the 121 offices to be filled by voters of this city in November.

ALBANY, July 15 -- The Long Island State Park Commission has the power to establish and enforce a forty-mile-an-hour speed limit on the parkways under its jurisdiction, the Court of Appeals ruled today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 15 (AP) -- A young Californian, Ellis Slack of San Francisco, scored the first major upset of the Pennsylvania State tennis championships today. In a match that went as expected, the nation's No. 1 male player, Vic Seixas of Philadelphia, moved into the third round.

TOKYO, Wednesday, July 16 -- The Communist delegation at Panmunjom obtained today another two-day recess in the Korean armistice negotiations. The talks had been in adjournment since Monday, when the Chinese and North Korean representatives first asked for a halt, giving no reason but arousing speculation that important developments might be under way.

LONDON, July 15 -- British diplomatic officials were disturbed today to see newspaper reports that the United States was putting pressure on Britain to resolve her dispute with Egypt and to recognize King Farouk's title as "King of the Sudan."

ELIZABETH, N. J., July 15 -- Without a precedent here -- thirty years without an accident -- Sgt. Ray Apgar quit his motorcycle today as a member of the Elizabeth Police Department traffic division for his first desk job as head of the department's license bureau.

The fair-haired world traveler regarded the giant trans-atlantic plane with a slightly bored expression. He was frankly not elated at the prospect of spending six weeks in Finland or of viewing the Olympic Games in Helsinki.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The plea by Frank Costello that his bail of $5,000 be continued pending an appeal to the Supreme Court, was denied today by Associate Justice Robert H. Jackson. Officials of the high court said they could not tell when Costello's bond would expire and he would have to go to prison.

LONDON, July 15 -- If he did not know already, Dr. Hewlett Johnson, the Dean of Canterbury, learned today what it means to live in a land where a man can speak his mind, no matter how mistaken or mischievous the ruling authorities may think him to be.

CINCINNATI, July 15 -- Roy Campanella was prepared to go behind the bat for the Dodgers again tonight despite his injured hand, but the Brooklyn catcher received an unexpected rest when the scheduled game with the Reds was postponed because of rain.

CHICAGO, July 15 -- Frank E. McKinney, Chairman of the Democratic National Committee, today announced the following program for the convention that opens Monday. All times are Central daylight, which is one hour behind New York time.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Presidents of the American Federation of Labor's nineteen building trades unions moved today to stamp out jurisdictional strikes by their 12,500 local unions.
OTTAWA, July 15 (AP) -- The railways today applied for a new series of freight rate increases that would amount to more than $80,000,000 a year.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- "Where's Gavin?"
New issues of corporate securities valued at more than $74,000,000 are included in offerings which underwriters placed on the market yesterday or will do so today.

Three professional handlers and five judges have been suspended for undisclosed periods from participating in their customary capacities at dog shows. This action was made known yesterday by the American Kennel Club through its executive vice president, John C. Neff.

The letter from Theresa Joyce in the July 12 edition contains several misstatements and inaccuracies which should be corrected. First, the Metcalf-Hatch law does not involve seizure of private property. An unlicensed, unclaimed, unwanted dog belongs to the state and is not private property, as has been decided in the courts.

MOFFETT FIELD, Calif., July 15 -- An apparently inadvertent disclosure that the Skyrocket research airplane had flown more than 1,300 miles an hour, twice the speed of sound, was confirmed here today.

CHICAGO, July 15 -- Frank E. McKinney, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said today he would feel it his duty to discourage any movement that might develop at the Democratic National Convention to draft President Truman as the nominee.

Although there may be any number of good reasons that the Indians are not dominating the American League flag race, neither the Yankees nor 43,673 spectators could detect any in the sweltering heat at the Stadium last night.

Few elements in the "fair trade" camp are missing an opportunity to sing the praises of the new national "fair trade" law signed on Monday by President Truman to the surprise of almost everybody. Yesterday Harry P. Herrfeldt, vice president of Park Tilford Distillers Corporation, pole=vaulted onto the bandwagon.
Charles Schiff, 25-year-old New York conductor, made his debut at Lewisohn Stadium last evening conducting a program by the Stadium Symphony Orchestra.
Maybe it was the heat. Perhaps he was hungry. Or maybe he wasn't impressed with the Rotarian version of "Carry Me Back to Ole Virginny."

CHICAGO, July 15 -- Hedge pressure on the Board of Trade was not at all heavy in wheat after early sales, while there continued to be enough commission absorption to create a rather strong undertone. Some reports from the Northwest indicated that improvement had been disappointing in spite of the rains, and this induced some buying.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 15 -- Ninety-four outstanding physicists from the Americas and Europe met here today in a symposium under the auspices of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization and the Brazilian Academy of Sciences to discuss new developments in the technique of advanced research in physics.

Eighty young wives, who for several years have freed their husbands from the after-dinner dishes and other domestic duties so they could attend evening classes, found last night that virtue does not go unrewarded.

MANILA, Wednesday, July 16 -- The Philippine Congress adjourned at midnight last night its thrice-extended special session, called by President Elpidio Quirino three weeks ago to ratify the Japanese peace treaty and approve the budget.

Aggregate market value of all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose $3,799,347,242 in June, the Exchange reported yesterday, Average market price of a share rose $1.16, from $41.14 on May 31 to $42.30 on June 30. This was the highest average since March 31, when the figure was $42.78.

The astronomical clock now used to turn the city's street lights on and off automatically each day may give way eventually to a radio control device developed by the Broadway Maintenance Corporation at the suggestion of Dominick F. Paduano, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 15 -- Norman C. Armitage of New York, a member of the fencing team, was chosen today as the American color-bearer for the opening ceremony on Saturday of the games of the fifteenth Olympiad.

The failure yesterday of the city, the New York City Omnibus Corporation and the Transport Workers Union to get together on pension privileges indicated the complete breakdown of negotiations leading to the sale of the five city-owned Manhattan bus lines to the company.

Though summer did not begin officially until a few days ago, today actually marks the halfway point on the march through the three summer months of June, July and August. We can scarcely regard as unseasonable, therefore, the ninety-plus heat that has covered the city like an immense, damp, woolly blanket this week. The weather is here, and with it come all the familiar cliches.

The American Federation of Labor has a committee at work investigating the issuance of local union charters by affiliates to former convicts. It seeks to learn why A. F. L. international unions grant charters to men who have never worked in the particular craft where they were named as officials of the locals created by the charters.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The State Department has granted a "limited passport" to Dr. Linus Pauling, chairman of the Department of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering at California Institute of Technology, after having rejected his passport application three times in the last few months.

PRESQUE ISLE, Me., July 15 (AP) -- Two big helicopters, which flew so low the crewmen said they could see women on bathing beaches en route, today completed the initial leg of the first attempted helicopter flight to Europe.

DENVER, July 15 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower made a strong appeal today for support from the adherents of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, whom he defeated at Chicago last week for the Republican Presidential nomination.

Averell Harriman, Director for Mutual Security and a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, asserted last night that the Republican platform was made up of "rotten planks" and that no Republican was "qualified" to lead the nation.

The Phil Cook and Margaret Arlen morning radio programs will be discontinued by WCBS early inext month. Beginning Aug. 11 they .will be replaced by Bob Haymes, singer and disk jockey, who will be heard from 8:15 to 9 A. M., Mondays through Saturdays.

If the railroad men at Syracuse say they saw a long and menacing crocodile early Monday, then that is what they saw. But there are strong indications that nobody ever will see the reptile again. Word came from Syracuse of how, in the still hours of Monday morning, the railroad men opened the door of a mail car, and a four-foot crocodile burst out.

A two-year contract succeeding one that expired June 30 was signed yesterday between the Liggett Drug Company and Local 1199, Retail Drug Employes Union, unaffiliated. The contract, covering 500 employes in twenty-two New York stores and three in Westchester, provides for a five-day, forty-hour week by next April 1.

PARIS, July 15 -- The creation of a Greek-Turkish army group headquarters under the command of a high ranking United States Army officer has now been agreed upon in principle by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization as part of a wide reorganization of the Southern Command under Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe.

TANGIER, July 7 -- Improvement in port facilities, estimated to cost $4,500,000, have been voted by the Tangier Legislative Assembly. The work is to be financed by the Tangier Port Company through a bond issue guaranteed by the Moroccan government.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, N. Y., July 15 -- A son of a golfing professional, 17-year-old Donald McDougall, led the quartet of Metropolitan qualifiers for the United States Golf Association's junior championship in the eighteen-hole test at the Rockville Country Club today.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 15 (AP) -- The Russians tricked Maj. Sammy Lee into wearing Pablo Picasso's Communist peace dove for a while today and the little Olympic diving champion is sizzling about it.

LONDON, July 15 -- Miss Angela Dowding, daughter of. Lady Fox, was married today in St. Margaret's Church, Westminster, to the Hon. Gerald Lascelles, younger son of the Princess Royal, the Dowager Countess of Harewood, only sister of the late King George VI.

The undersigned, representing millions of Americans of Eastern European and Chinese descent, protest the failure of the Republican convention to include in its platform a pledge for the ratification of the genocide convention, despite the forceful presentation of the genocide case at the Republican convention by Lev Dobriansky, president of the Ukrainian-American Congress Committee.

IT appeared yesterday that friction was developing between United States sportsmen and government authorities in Canada. This newspaper's correspondent at Watertown, N. Y., wired that Canadian customs officers along the St. Lawrence River have been instructed to charge duty and regular taxes on American boats and angling equipment taken into Canadian waters.

Abbott Laboratories, Inc., which recently acquired a plant in Teterboro, N. J., has sold the four-story commercial building at 209-11 West Fourteenth Street, near Seventh Avenue, to an investing client of Douglas L. Elliman Co., brokers. The Manhattan building was erected originally for the Home Insurance Company and was bought by Abbott Laboratories, manufacturer of pharmaceuticals, vitamins and germicides in June, 1944.
BONN, Germany, July 15 -- A pervasive, unorganized and largely passive resistance to the Communist regime exists in the Soviet Union, a Russian engineer asserted today.
The board of trustees of the North Side Savings Bank elected yesterday as vice presidents Isabella M. Davidson, George L. Kelley and Arthur J. Martel.

PHILADELPHIA, July 15 (AP) -- Aging Bobo Newsom of the Athletics went the distance to chalk up an 11-to-3 victory tonight over the Browns in the second game of a twilight-night twin bill. Newsom allowed ten hits but was in serious trouble only in the ninth when Jim Dyck clouted a two-run homer.

The events that culminated on July 11 call for the end of old Democratic and Republican party alignments. We have come to the climax of another convulsive period in the shifting sands of our political history.

The collapse of the steel peace negotiations had no effect yesterday on the stock market. In fact, despite the breakdown in talks aimed at getting the mills back into production, the steel issues rallied smartly. This gave further support to the feeling in financial circles that a settlement was imminent -- one behind the scenes and not yet apparent.

The world's largest corporate enterprise paid its 125th consecutive quarterly dividend yesterday. More than 1,116,000 stockholders of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company received $78,500,000. This was at the quarterly rate of $2.25 a capital share.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 15 -- The United States Government, appearing before the International Court of Justice as a litigant for the first time today, heard itself denounced by France on a charge of seeking to misuse ancient treaty rights to obtain immunity for American business men engaged in alleged currency manipulations in French Morocco.

GENEVA, July 15 -- Cancer as a cause of death has increased throughout the twentieth century in virtually all the countries of the world, the United Nations World Health Organization reported today in the first comprehensive survey of the incidence of cancerous diseases.

A hot spell on Main Street used to mean setting up the ice-cream freezer on the back porch. The sound of the crank being turned was so suggestive that the youngsters next door got out their freezers, too. There never was better ice cream -- smoother, more flavorful. The thought of it yesterday, while the mercury soared, set us to wondering whether people ever "crank up" ice cream any more.

All domestic seeded players reached the fourth round of the junior competition in the eastern junior championship yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, but three of the favorites were eliminated in the boys' title tournament.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, July 15 -- A legal controversy over how Communist rebels in Malaya who surrender should be treated is being resolved in practice by a policy of leniency. The result is an increasing number of surrenders and fat dossiers of information helpful to security forces in eliminating Red insurgents.

Cook County, Ill., sold yesterday $15,000,000 of superhighway bonds due July 1, 1972, and callable from 1953 to 1971 to a syndicate headed by Chase National Bank at a bid of 100,809 for interest of 2 1/4 per cent. The bonds were reoffered at yields ranging from 1.10 per cent to 2.25 per cent.

Purple-capped delegates to the Grand Lodge convention of the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks took over much of the city's sight-seeing facilities yesterday, then gathered in the evening for a dance at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in honor of the order's new Grand Exalted Ruler, Sam Stern of Fargo, N. D.
New fur fashions at Arnold Constable were presented in the store's Mink Room yesterday afternoon.

After trying for nearly twenty years to establish normal relations with Soviet Russia, the American Government has been compelled to resort to a new policy in dealing with that country and its satellites -- the policy of selective retaliation and punitive reciprocity.

Unless the dwindling supply of tin plate used in manufacture of cans for food is replenished millions of dollars worth of perishable food will be lost, the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., warned yesterday. The statement was made after a further spot check on the impact of the steel strike on industries in this city.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- William D. Hassett, secretary and literary companion to President Truman, resigned today, ending his long service of blending fact and tact, literary phrase and biblical allusion in the thousands of letters and other documents he had drafted for Presidents Roosevelt and Truman.

The two-story taxpayer at 330-40 East 204th Street, the Bronx, has been sold by a client of E. Osborne Smith, Inc., broker, to the Corner Hull Corporation, Henry Sachs Jr., treasurer, for cash above mortgages of $143,000. Part of the building is occupied by a Grand Union super market.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture, said today that the farm plank in the platform that would be written at the Democratic National Convention in Chicago next week would be a better one than was included in the platform adopted by the Republicans at their convention last week.

Directors of Universal Pictures Company, Inc., elected Milton R. Rackmil president and voted yesterday to place the common stock on a semi-annual rate of 50 cents a share. This marks the first time the dividend on the common has been put on a definite basis since reorganization of the company on April 2, 1936.
The Mayor's Committee Investigating Housing in its recent report has failed to put its finger on the underlying cause of the matter -- the present inequitable and unfair state rent regulations.

VIENNA, July 15 -- The Soviet broad gauge railroad, according to reliable witnesses, has now been laid from Russia through Czechoslovakia to Miskolc, 120 miles farther west into the Hungarian plain than it was two years ago.

ST. LOUIS, July 15 -- Because Jim (Dusty) Rhodes, the rookie just up from Nashville, hit a variety of Cardinal pitching tonight, the Giants cut half a gems off the margin separating them from the Dodgers and widened by a game the gap between themselves and Eddie Stanky's club.

Television's endless pursuit of parlor games with a different twist goes on apace. The warm weather, with its inevitable emphasis on inexpensive programming, has brought forth a record batch of quizzes and assorted panels of experts.

Sudden summer breezes, blowing through open windows, may cause a scattering of papers on the desk -- a temporary state of chaos -- that can be offset by a paper weight. Rough pieces of semi-precious minerals, and cool looking chunks of glass are among some of the serviceable and pleasant looking varieties offered in the shops today.

CHICAGO, July 15 -- The Democratic Convention promises to be as unusual in its way as the Republican. The G. O. P. delegates came to Chicago last week divided in their allegiance, divided in their views, but queued up almost solidly behind two candidates and pretty certain that one of the two would be nominated.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 15 -- Recent reports from trustworthy diplomatic sources on the manner in which Communist regimes in the Iron Curtain countries are treating Jews are forcing Israeli Government officials, much against their will, to the conclusion that there has been a radical change in the application of over-all Communist policy toward Zionism and Israel, and that the time may be ripe for a change in Israeli policy.

New wrought iron furniture in a traditional, classic style, somewhat French in feeling, will be introduced today at the opening of the Blackamoor showroom, 17 East Sixty-fourth Street. All the pieces are light in weight and decorated with ormolu. They were designed by the owners of the shop, Charles Meyer and Randall Kenney, and are available through decorators.

The New York Stock Exchange has embarked upon a new phase of its program to acquaint the public with its services. A new mobile exhibit, embodying data from the recently completed national census of shareholders of the Brookings Institution, is being displayed daily through Friday, from 10 A. M. to 5 P. M., in the main gymnasium of University Hall, Broadway at 119th Street, as part of Columbia University's twentyeighth annual educational exhibit.

OSLO, July 15 (AP) -- Huelet Leo Benner of Fort Kobbe, Panama Canal Zone, made one world record himself and led the United States team to another in the silhouette pistol shooting competition in the world championship shooting matches today.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The Government said today the air conditioning system in the Chicago Convention Building and International Amphitheatre was illegal.

PITTSBURGH, July 15 (AP) -- Sparked by Rookie Mel Clark's grand-slam homer in the third inning -- his first circuit clout of the year -- the Phillies trounced Pittsburgh's last place Pirates, 10 -- 3, tonight.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 15 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois has halted all communication with newspapers or radio until the start of the Democratic National Convention next Monday.

Rubber gained 90 to 110 points on the Commodity Exchange yesterday on volume of 530 tons, but most other commodities moved little or were mixed. Hides slipped 10 to 25 points on forty-four lots, lead gained 5 to 10 points on two contracts, and zinc lost 10 to 20 points on eight lots.

Confident that no other liner afloat today can approach the amazing speed of the superliner United States, John M. Franklin, president of the United States Lines, announced yesterday that the company would not attempt soon to better the ship's two record-breaking performances.
CAIRO, July 15 (Reuters) -- Abd el Krim, a living legend to millions of North Africans for three decades, announced today his movement to "liberate" Tunisia, Algeria and Morocco had failed.

Low-fare trans-Atlantic tourist-class service in June gave Pan American World Airways a 35 per cent increase in revenue passenger miles over the same month of last year, Juan T. Trippe, president, told the annual meeting yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Accelerated tax amortization certificates totaling $190,627,156 were granted by the Defense Production Administration from June 27 through July 2, the Agency announced today. The certificates, which permit a company to amortize its investment by tax write-offs in five years instead of the twenty to twenty-five years normally allowed covered 217 new or expanded defense facilities.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 15 -- Perspiring members of the Town Board of Hempstead fanned down a request today to prohibit the wearing of shorts on the streets of Atlantic Beach, seaside resort.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 15 -- A steering committee to form a private adoption organization in Westchester was appointed today by Mrs. Earle D. McBride of Scarsdale, chairman of the County Council of Social Agencies. The organization will be a nonsectarian clearing house for babies and foster parents.

GENEVA, July 15 -- The Swiss Government announced today that it considered any attack on the neutrality of the International Committee of the Red Cross as an attack on the neutrality of Switzerland herself.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's statement on signing a special appropriations bill today:

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The Defense Department today identified 164 battle casualties in Korea in a new list that reported 39 dead, 104 wounded, 8 missing and 13 injured. The following were listed from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut:

BOSTON, July 15 (UP) -- Dick Gernert, scoring five runs with two successive homers, paced the Red Sex to a 7-to-5 victory over the White Sex tonight and moved Boston into third place by two percentage points in the American League pennant race.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The United States closed down today its Russian - language magazine Amerika, which has been distributed in the Soviet Union, and simultaneously ordered Moscow to cease publication in this country of the U. S. S. R. Information Bulletin and other pamphlets and periodicals.

CHICAGO, July 15 -- River barge line companies are losing thousands of dollars a week because many cargoes of steel products have been almost completely cut off by the protracted steel strike, a survey indicated today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 15 -- Ben Hecht's recent film, "Actors and Sin," which opened at the Park Avenue Theatre, New York, on May 29, has precipitated a legal battle here in Superior Court between United Artists and Sid Kuller Productions as plaintiffs and the A. B. C. Theatres Company as defendants.

LONDON, July 15 -- Domestic issues strengthened on the stock markets here today. British Government securities, again influenced by firmness of the sterling exchange rate, gained up to 10s ($1.40). Industrial shares generally finished firmly after having overcome some profit taking.
TRENTON, July 15 -- A Jersey City taxpayer's suit has been filed in State Superior Court to set aside purchase by the city of the former International League ball park for $97,000.
The new Atlantic speed-record holder, the liner United States, was escorted in triumph yesterday morning from Quarantine to her home berth at West Forty-sixth Street, Hudson River.

PITTSBURGH, July 15 -- Government-sponsored talks to settle the national steel strike collapsed almost as soon as they began here today, leaving White House officials with no weapon they felt could force an end of the crippling tie-up.
Fewer than half of the voluntary aircraft spotting posts in the East were manned yesterday, the second day of "Operation Skywatch."
