WASHINGTON, July 15 (UP) -- Walt Dropo of the Tigers tied a major league record by collecting his twelfth consecutive hit tonight but his efforts went for naught as the Senators swept a doubleheader with Detroit, 8 -- 2 and 9 -- 8.

BOSTON, July 15 -- Bus schedules were officially restored for commuters in seventy-four cities and towns along routes of the Eastern Massachusetts Street Railway Company today with the settlement of a drivers' and mechanics' strike that began March 10.

The 1,920-bed Bird S. Coler Memorial Hospital and Home on Welfare Island, which city officials maintain will assure "the finest possible care to those no longer able to make their own way," was opened yesterday for the treatment of aged and chronic disease patients.

CHICAGO, July 15 -- In recognition of the fact there are almost 2,000,000 more women of voting age in the nation than men, the Democratic National Convention will accord women a considerably larger role in the proceedings starting next Monday than their Republican sisters received.

The American Smelting and Refining Company announced yesterday that it was closing its Bolivian copper-mining subsidiary which operates the Coro Coro mine. It blamed serious labor disorders and the "poor economic outlook" for the decision.

CHICAGO, July 15 -- A new type boxcar unloader for sand, gravel-grain, slack coal, gypsum and other materials which its manufacturers claim will cut unloader time as much as 80 per cent to demonstrated today to a group of railroad officials and other material handlers in the Illinois Century Railroad's yards.

TAMPA, Fla., July 15 -- All favorites were victorious after two sessions of the first round of the annual open championship tournament of the United States Chess Federation at the Hotel Floridan today.

ALBANY, July 15 (UP) -- The Court of Appeals ruled today that the unsanctioned use of a person's name or picture on a television program immediately before or after a "commercial" did not violate his civil right to privacy.
TOKYO, Wednesday, July 16 (AP) -- United Nations Command headquarters communique 1312 for the twenty-four hours ended at 6 A. M. today:

YONKERS, July 15 -- Three Yonkers policemen rescued two teenage boys today after they had tried to ride the waves of the Hudson River on an inflated inner tube, but instead drifted a mile and a half downstream.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 15 (AP) -- Dick Savitt, top seeded, and Art Larsen, national clay courts champion, breezed through the first two rounds of the Western tennis tournament today. Reporting a day late, both caught up with the field.

Defense attorneys for fifteen secondary Communist leaders on trial for conspiracy in Federal Court here ended their cross-examination yesterday of John Lautner, an expelled Communist party official, who has been on the witness stand since May 19 as a Government witness.

MOSCOW, July 15 -- The English-language magazine News insisted today that the possibilities for peaceful co-existence of the capitalist and Socialist systems had increased rather than decreased since the end of World War II and would continue to increase with the development of the Socialist system in the Soviet Union.
Two industrial properties in Long Island City, Queens, passed to new control in a trade deal reported yesterday by Queens Industrials, the broker.

The resignation of Philip B. Perlman as Solicitor General of the United States deprives the Government of an able attorney who for five years has filled the second most important post in the Justice Department with notable success. The Solicitor General has charge of all federal litigation in the Supreme Court and has the responsibility of deciding whether the Government should appeal cases from the lower courts.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 15 -- United States Point Four aid is starting to be used on a serious scale this month in Iran, at a moment when a sudden concentration on internal financial and economic affairs, the financial paralysis of the Government and the dragging economy give it a value out of all proportion to the sums being expended.
BINGHAMTON, N. Y., July 15 (AP) -- Mrs. Virginia Allen of Syracuse, 1941 State women's amateur golf champion, turned in the best card today in the tourney's opening round.

BRISBANE, Australia, July 15 (UP) -- Prime Minister Robert G. Menzies told the nation tonight about his recent Washington and London talks in a radio broadcast repeatedly interrupted by Communist heckling and fist fights among his audience in Brisbane's City Hall.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- An offer to steel mills of a price increase of $5.60 a ton provided they make peace with striking workers, is understood to have been sent to Pittsburgh today by Dr. John R. Steelman, Presidential negotiator in the present strike situation.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 15 -- A disparging appraisal of social progress in the United States was given today by the Czech member of the United Nations Economic and Social Council, who contended that Givernment forces had stifled civil liberties and neglected the economic needs of citizens to pay for a costly armaments program.

The Douglas Aircraft Company increased sales almost $100,000,000 in the six months ended with last May to a total of $196,000,000 from the $97,000,000 volume for the corresponding half year of 1951, Donald W. Douglas, president, reported yesterday in the midyear operating statement.
PARIS, July 15 -- Simone Cange's opening introduces millinery that envelops the head, especially in comparison to this summer's half hats that left the entire back uncovered.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 15 (AP) -- Mrs. Alfred Roberts' Eatontown came back to the races at Monmouth Park today in the featured Neptune Township purse to win the fastest six furlongs of the meeting in 1:10 4/5.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was steady all day yesterday and active months closed 28 to 33 points higher.
TEHERAN, Iran, July 15 -- The Chamber of Deputies today debated Premier Mohammed Mossadegh's request for full powers for a period of six months without result. The issue was hotly disputed.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 15 (UP) -- Russia, launching its first Olympic competition since the days of the Czar, beat Bulgaria in an overtime soccer game and Canada's basketball team won the first clash of the East and West by downing Rumania today.

Perhaps it was inflation or maybe the boys and girls were working harder, but in the last school year the 3,000 pupils who were enrolled in the Board of Education's cooperative courses earned $2,199,457, or nearly $1,000,000 over the previous high of the year before, it was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 15 (AP) -- The Braves blended two singles with five walks, a sacrifice and two of three errors by Shortstop Roy Smalley for a six-run fifth inning in routing the Cubs, 10-3, for their fifth straight victory today.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., July 15 (AP) -- A Florida Ku Klux Klan leader today announced establishment of a new organization -- "the American Confederate Army" -- ready to bear arms if necessary to "uphold our Constitutional right," and he declared a Supreme Court ban on segregation would be considered a violation of such rights.

The appointment of Warren Moscow, for twenty-two years a political reporter for THE NEW YORK TIMES, as Manhattan Commissioner of Borough Works was announced yesterday by Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. Mr. Moscow, whose salary will be $15,000 a year, succeeds the late Charles S. Hand.

LINCOLNTON, N. C., July 15 (UP) -- Six rebellious convicts seized a guard and threatened to kill him today but released the hostage after Walter Anderson, state prison director, gave in to the prisoners' demand for a conference.

RICHMOND, Va., Wednesday, July 16 -- Senator Harry Flood Byrd won nomination early today for his fourth six-year term in the Senate in Virginia's Democratic primary. The conservative foe of Federal spending piled up a commanding margin over Col. Francis Pickens Miller.

Middle Eastern countries offer real potentialities for increased trade opportunities in other than the oil industry, members of the Export Managers Club were told yesterday at a luncheon in the Statler Hotel. The guest speaker was Maj. George Haig, economic and trade consultant on the Arab countries, who is engaged in the advertising business.

Mystery yesterday continued to conceal the identity and motive of the tall, dark-haired young man who shot and killed 18-year-old Eileen Fahey Monday morning at her desk in the American Physical Society office at Columbia University.
Bedspreads and draperies, which form part of a new group designed to complete a color coordination plan by Cannon Mills, are at Macy's.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee predicted today that he would win the Democratic Presidential nomination on the fifth or sixth ballot.

CHICAGO, July 15 (AP) -- A spokesman for the wool industry said today that proponents of wool and synthetic fibres should study how to expand potential textile markets. The spokesman was F. Eugene Ackerman, president of the wool bureau in New York.
COPENHAGEN, July 15 (AP) -- Hungary won the women's foil fencing world championship today by defeating France in the final match.

Today's new film is "Carrie," Paramount's adaptation of the Theodore Dreiser novel, "Sister Carrie," produced and directed by William Wyler, at the Capitol. Laurence Olivier, Jennifer Jones, Eddie Albert and Miriam Hopkins head the cast of the drama, which was written for the screen by Ruth and Augustus Goetz.

BERLIN, July 15 -- The West Berlin police took steps today to prevent threatened Communist disorders tomorrow when Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor, arrives for a one-day visit. The Chancellor will speak at various points in West Berlin in an effort to strengthen the city's morale.

ALBANY, July 15 -- The Court of Appeals cleared the way today for the special grand jury investigation of gambling and political corruption in Saratoga County by upholding as constitutional the manner in which the grand jury was selected more than a year ago.

MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 15 (AP) -- Paul Smiley's 65-foot cutter Orient won the over-all fleet honors as well as laurels in her own Cruising A Class today in the twenty-eighth annual Port Huron-to-Mackinac yacht race.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Down payment restrictions on new homes will be lifted by the Federal Reserve Board and the Housing and Home Finance Agency beginning Oct. 1, if new "starts" at that time are running at an annual rate of less than 1,200,000.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- Ford Motor Company today lost a battle to get a bigger share of auto industry materials.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 15 -- John Foster Dulles said tonight that regional security agreements "have undermined the United Nations to a certain extent." Mr. Dulles, who drafted the foreign affairs plank of the Republican platform, added that "we must reverse that trend."

MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 15 (AP) -- Paul Smiley's 65-foot cutter Orient won the over-all fleet honors as well as laurels in her own Cruising A Class today in the twenty-eighth annual Port Huron-to-Mackinac yacht race.

BUENOS AIRES, July 15 (AP) -- The business magazine Review of the River Plate predicted today that the proposed United States law limiting Defense Department purchases of foreign wool would "further depress" the international wool market if enacted.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 15 -- Overexposure to the sun is a definite factor in the development of skin cancer, Dr. Edwin H. Cressman, Philadelphia dermatologist, told the fifty-sixth annual convention of the American Osteopathic Association here today.

CHICAGO, July 15 -- Democrats seeking a strong civil rights plank in their party platform for 1952 -- a plank constituting one of the biggest issues of both national conventions meeting here -were looking today to Senator Herbert H. Lehman of New York to lead an attack against civil rights legislation's greatest obstacle, the Senate filibuster.

LANSING, Mich., July 15 -- The Michigan delegation to the Democratic National Convention agreed by unanimous vote in a caucus here today to oppose any watering down of the party's 1948 campaign plank on civil rights.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., July 15 -- The very existence of trade unions in New York is being threatened by a growing trend of anti-labor rulings of state courts and actions by the Legislature, Harold C. Hanover, secretary-treasurer of the State Federation of Labor, warned today in his report to delegates attending the federation's eighty-ninth annual convention.

TOKYO, July 15 (AP) -- Gen. J. Lawton Collins, United States Army Chief of Staff, said today even tougher bombing of North Korean military targets was in store for the Communists if they "insist on prolonging the war."

Exchange of goods with the United States now accounts for the largest share of India's growing foreign trade, according to a report just issued by India News, an official Government of India information service. For the eleven months ending with February, 1952, Indo-United States trade-aggregated $754,026,000, the report states.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Contracts for the production in Europe of military equipment to arm the forces of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization countries amounted to $684,000,000 in the fiscal year ended June 30, Ambassador William H. Draper Jr., United States special representative in Europe, announced today.

CHICAGO, July 15 -- The pre-convention maneuvering among supporters of candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination was enlivened today by the charge of Gael Sullivan, campaign manager for Senator Estes Kefauver, that backers of other candidates were "ganging up" on the Tennessean in an attempt to block his nomination.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 15 -- Meade Alcorn, Connecticut chairman of the forces of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, declared today that some "awful boners" helped to defeat Senator Robert A. Taft at the Republican National Convention in Chicago last week.

ROME, July 15 -- The Vatican newspaper, L'Osservatore Romano, charged today that Protestant propaganda was carrying out an intense campaign of disparagement against the Roman Catholic hierarchy and laity of Colombia.

TRENTON, July 15 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, active supporter of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower at the Republican National Convention, today expressed confidence in a Republican victory in November, regardless of the Democratic nominees.

True Pattern of the Woolford Farm made things look easy as he took the feature race of the Empire City Racing Association's program at Jamaica yesterday. Competing in a six-furlong event that was entitled the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks Handicap, True Pattern never relinquished the lead as he moved to victory by a length and a quarter over his nearest rival.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- Four Negro leaders today asked the Federal Security Administrator, Oscar R. Ewing, to seek the Democratic Presidential nomination.

A former plainclothes man testified yesterday in Kings County Court that he was one of several members of the Eighteenth Division in Brooklyn who were Harry Gross' guests on a trip to Chicago in 1947 to attend a prize fight.
NASHVILLE, July 15 (AP) -- Nine of the nation's Democratic Governors have promised to back Gov. Gordon Browning in working for a "free, untrammeled" national convention in Chicago next week.

YOKOTA, Japan, Wednesday, July 16 -- Fifty-one F-84G Thunderjets of the Thirty-first Fighter Escort Wing roared over Yokota Air Force Base near Tokyo this afternoon completing a historic transpacific mass flight.

Cheese importers are finding new quota controls highly complicated but have started to bring in new shipments pending determination of individual quotas by the Department of Agriculture, a check of trade sources showed yesterday.

Three major manufacturers of men's clothing will produce suits of 100 per cent Dacron (a Du Pont polyester fiber) for next spring, invading a field formerly limited to Witty Brothers. The companies that will start producing the suits are B. Kuppenheimer Co., Chicago; Hart, Schaffner Marx, Chicago, and Timely Clothes, Inc., it was announced yesterday by Princeton Worsted Mills, producer of the cloth.

TAIPEI, Formosa, July 15 -- Premier Chen Cheng of Nationalist China appealed to the free world today to take "joint action" against those who 'seek to dominate the world and enslave mankind by the employment of force."

LONDON, July 15 (Reuters) -- Syd O'Linn, 25-year-old Capetown-born left-hander, scored his first century in English cricket today and turned the Kent-Surrey match at the Oval into one of the most thrilling in cricket history.

The city has collected $2,230,715 in receipts from the new tax on state retail liquor permits to date, City Treasurer Spencer C. Young said yesterday. Yesterday was the deadline for meeting the liquor tax payments without incurring penalties. Since June 25 the city has collected an interest chareg of one-half of 1 per cent added to the impost.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- President Truman severely criticized Congress today as he signed the $11,793,776,339 omnibus supplemental appropriations act. He assailed the lawmakers for slashing foreign aid funds and, he said, thereby weakening the military strength of this country and its allies.

Housewives and youngsters who used to answer conservation appeals and earn tidy pin money by selling waste paper to junk dealers for as much as $1.25 a hundred pounds only a year ago were being told yesterday that times have changed.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 15 -- The Screen Writers Guild, by a vote of 176 to 143, has defeated a proposed plan of the Motion Picture Industry Council to establish a special committee through which any person in the film industry here who has been attacked for alleged pro-Communist sympathies or affiliations could clear himself.

A "popular biography" of Philippine Ambassador Carlos P. Romulo is being completed by Cornelia Spencer. The book traces the general's life from his boyhood in the Philippines through his experiences with General MacArthur during the war to his presiding over the General Assembly of the United Nations. It is planned for January publication by John Day.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., July 15 -- A "get tough" policy was placed in effect today for ten convicts transferred to Middlesex County jail last night from the New Jersey State Prison at Trenton.

Ideal Mutual Insurance Co, in 60 Hudson St; S. M. Grosner, insurance agent, in 60 E 42d St; Palmer Olive, printers, in 215 W 34th St; AEB Machine Tools, Inc, French Lathes, Inc, machine tools, in 475 5th Ave -- Cushman Wakefield, Inc, brokers.

TOKYO, Thursday, July 17 -- The Communists announced today a large-scale redistribution of prisoner-of-war stockades in Korea, in which about 12,000 United Nations captives are being held and the establishment of four new stockades in or near the North Korean capital at Pyongyang.
TAMPERE, Finland, July 16 (AP) -- Italy's soccer team eliminated the United States squad today from the Olympic Games.

CHICAGO, July 16 -- Wearing a Paris outfit, two jeweled pins that she said were not emeralds although she "wished they were," and a 1948 Truman button, Mrs. Perle Mesta, United States Minister to Luxembourg, arrived today for the Democratic National Convention and provided thirty minutes of sprightly comment about parties -- social and political.

HELENA, Mont., July 16 (AP) -- Montana primary election voters apparently gave Lieut. Gov. Paul Cannon the nod over Justice Lee Metcalf of the State Supreme Court for the Democratic nomination as United States Representative from Montana's First District.

FAIRMONT, W. Va., July 16 -- A $100,000 slander suit against Mrs. Thelma Brand Loudin, vice president of the State Board of Education, was lost in Marion County Circuit Court here today by Dr. Luella Raab Mundel, former Art Department chairman at Fairmont State College.

TOKYO, Thursday, July 17 (AP) -- Admiral William M. Fechteler, the United States Navy Chief of Operations, said today the United States Navy had two or more carrier jets in production that were equal to or better than the Soviet-built MIG-15 plane.

CHICAGO, July 16 (UP) -- Southpaw Chuck Davey piled up a big point advantage in the first six rounds tonight, but he had to hold on during the last two rounds to gain a unanimous decision over Carmen Basilio in a ten-round fight in the Chicago Stadium.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The Army's strategic or general Reserve units in this country, and even the United States divisions in Germany, will have to be cut materially in strength during the present fiscal year, according to present Army calculations.
ALBANY, July 16 (AP) -- The New York State residential rent control is not affected by recent legislation continuing the Federal price and wage control law.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 16 -- A very Brundage of Chicago, head of the United States Olympic Committee since 1929, was elected president of the International Olympic Committee today, to take office Sept. 1. He succeeds J. Sigfrid Edstrom of Sweden, who has occupied the chair since 1946 and becomes the first American to hold the post.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 16 (UP) -- Second-Seeded Straight Clark, Pasadena, Calif., and Third-Seeded Lorne Main of Montreal advanced into the quarter-finals of the men's Pennsylvania State tennis championships today as rains cut heavily into play at the Merion Cricket Club.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 16 -- Complaints of Southern California film exhibitors regarding industry trade practices affecting the distribution of motion pictures probably will be heard at open hearings here to be conducted by the United States Senate's Small Business Committee, according to William D. Amis, an investigator for the committee now in Los Angeles.

CHICAGO, July 16 -- Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia today made an open bid for labor support in his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination by declaring that the Taft-Hartley Law must be replaced.

BUENOS AIRES, July 16 -- Albert F. Nufer, a 58-year-old career diplomat, arrived here today and in response to questions posed by Argentine reporters expressed the hope that he represented an end to the quick turnover of United States Ambassadors to this country.

PARIS, July 16 -- A major reorganization of Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway's Southern Command, which embraces Italy, Greece, Turkey and the Western half of the Mediterranean, was announced jointly here today by Supreme Headquarters of the Allied Powers in Europe and by the North Atlantic Council, supreme directing committee of the alliance.

THE Nobel Prize changed many a person's ideas of what William Faulkner had been doing. But it did not change what he had done. This is demonstrated in Irving Howe's rather stuffy, but usefully informing, new book, "William Faulkner: A Critical Study."*

The combined net earnings of thirty leading United States oil companies increased from $1,739,000,000 in 1950 to $2,090,000,000 last year, a rise of 20.2 per cent, according to a compilation prepared by Frederick G. Coqueron of the petroleum department of the Chase National Bank of the City of New York.

NEWARK, July 16--Federal District Judge Frederick Follmer of Lewisburg, Pa., sitting here as a visiting judge, approved settlement today for $225,000 of two civil suits brought by the Federal Government against forty-eight North Jersey road contractors and individuals.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 11 to 17 points net yesterday.
LONDON, July 16 -- For what was possibly the first time in musical history, a symphony conductor issued a communique to his audience here last night.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 16 -- The Swedish Navy has begun annual summer maneuvers in the Baltic unmindful of the Soviet Union's growing tendency to regard that sea as its own, as the Russians have forcefully demonstrated on several recent occasions.
ATLANTIC CITY, July 16 -- Gen. Carl A. Spaatz (retired), former Air Force chief, said here today that America was no longer the No. 1 air power in the world and had fallen "somewhat below" Russia.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 16 -- Observers report a marked improvement in the relations between the independent peasants and the regime of Marshal Tito as a result of the Government's new agrarian policy. The independent peasants, who made a determined effort to slow down agricultural production last year, are today making a maximum effort on their small farms, according to spot checks in various parts of the country.

First-seeded Ed Rubinoff of Miami Beach, Fla., national interscholastic champion, defeated unseeded Frank Pisciotta of St. Albans, Queens, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, yesterday to pace the juniors into the quarter-final round of the Eastern junior and boys' tennis championships at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation announced today that it made a total of thirty-nine loans involving some $3,453,722 in the week ended July 9. Of these, twenty-two were business loans granted by R. F. C. either under the Defense Production Act or the R. F. C. Act.
PITTSBURGH, July 16 -- An air of hopelessness settled over efforts to end the national steel strike today as union and industry leaders dug in for a showdown battle on the sole remaining issue.

Operations of the New York Stock Exchange and its subsidiaries for the quarter ended June 30 resulted in consolidated net income of $145,694, against $72,775 in the preceding three months, Keith Funston, president, reported yesterday.

An investment banking syndicate headed by Paine, Webber, Jackson, Curtis is offering to investors today an issue of $3,000,000 of new convertible subordinated debentures of General Acceptance Corporation, a finance company active in the small loan field, in retail and wholesale financing and in insurance underwriting.

MONTREAL, July 16 (Canadian Press) -- The germ warfare charges of Communist China and North Korea's refusal to supply complete prisoner of war lists will "most certainly come up" at the International Red Cross convention starting in Toronto next Wednesday, although they are not on the agenda, an official said today.

Parker H. Ericksen, sales director for the Bendix Home Appliances division of Avco Manufacturing Corporation, addressing news men at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday, predicted a sharp rise in sales of automatic driers and washers next year. Mr. Ericksen said he expects Bendix to sell 10 per cent more automatic washers and 20 per cent more automatic driers in 1953 than this year.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended July 9:

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Senaator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin, called on the Truman Administration today to establish liaison on foreign policy with General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for the period between now and Inauguration Day, Jan. 20.
S. C. Williams has been appointed general field sales manager of the Pyrene Manufacturing Company.
Sales by manufacturers of airframes have boomed under the defense program, but their profits have slumped.

OTTAWA, July 16 -- For the third time in succession and the fourth time since he formed his National Union party in 1936 Prime Minister Maurice Duplessis and his party were today returned to power in the Province of Quebec.

Fans at Yankee Stadium enjoyed a "triple header" yesterday when lodge bands and drill teams here for the convention of the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks took over the period between games of a double bill to celebrate Elks Day at the ball park.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 16 -- The Soviet Union, extolling its own scientific achievements and claiming the invention of such contributions to civilization as the radio and airplane, said today that the United States was entitled to credit only for such items as the first waffle iron, the hot-dog machine and the electric chair.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- As Democratic Presidential hopefuls headed for Chicago, Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, whose own high hopes were dashed last week, returned to the Capitol today predicting that the Democrats would renominate President Truman.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Senator Thomas C. Hennings Jr., Democrat of Missouri, proposed a full-scale Congressional investigation today of what he called the control of the world's oil market by a seven-company cartel.

To refute testimony offered by the defendants in the Communist conspiracy trial in Federal Court here, the Government offered in evidence a note instructing a Communist party state official who had been stabbed that "we want it to be serious."

CHICAGO, July 16 (AP) -- The Cubs, beaten twenty-one times in the past thirty games over a month's span, snapped a five-game losing streak when Manager Phil Cavarretta smashed a single with one out in the thirteenth inning for a 3-2 victory over the Braves before 6,899 today.

LOS ANGELES, July 16 (AP) -- A speed of 1,238 miles an hour and an altitude of 79,494 feet, both records, were officially credited to the Navy D-558-2 Skyrocket by Secretary of the Navy Dan A. Kimball tonight.

An exposition of hundreds of products made or assembled in Israel will be opened to the public today at 22 West Forty-eighth Street under the sponsorship of the Greater New York Committee for State of Israel Bonds. The exhibit was opened yesterday for the press, when products ranging from canned foods to toy-room furniture and apparel were surveyed.

KINGSTON, N. Y., July 16 -- An exhibit of seventy-seven paintings representative of the Hudson River School, scenes of the Hudson Valley and work of Hudson Valley artists, opened tonight at the New George Washington School.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- President Truman, still suffering a slight fever as the result of a virus infection, was in the Army's Walter Reed Hospital here tonight for a "check-up." Mrs. Truman left her home in Independence, Mo., to be with the President.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- Trans World Airlines said today it would resume direct weekly service from Philadelphia to Europe, Aug. 27. Spokesmen for Pan American World Airways here and in New York declined to say whether Pan American had similar plans.
Two hundred children began a six-week fishing contest in Prospect Park Lake, Brooklyn, yesterday under the auspices of the Park Department and the Abraham Straus department stores.

Rear Admiral William S. Maxwell, retired, deputy director of the Bureau of Smoke Control, flew over the city yesterday in a Police Department helicopter, sighting smoke through his binoculars. After a two-hour flight he expressed the opinion that smoke conditions were "50 per cent better'' than a year ago.

PARIS, July 16 -- General Charles de Gaulle today pronounced an official "good riddance" to the thirty deputies of his Reunion of the French People who recently deserted his standard to support the domestic policies of Premier Antione Pinay.

We are glad to note that the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions has now barred the way to admitting the Yugoslav Federation of Labor, a project with which some European labor leaders have been flirting under the guise of "cooperation." A definite pronouncement against such admission has been sent by the Confederation's executive board to its affiliates.

PITTSBURGH, July 16 (UP) -- The Phils defeated the Pirates, 8 -- 7, in a free-hitting battle today to send the Bucs down to their fifth straight defeat. Ralph Kiner, Gus Bell and George Metkovich of the losers hit homers off Robin Roberts.
BALTIMORE, July 16 (AP) -- Dr. Carol Gordon, 47-year-old specialist in delivering babies, was put on probation today for switching one to the wrong parents.

The Maritime Administration has agreed to lease its valuable Hoboken, N. J., waterfront property to that city at the rate of $1 a year provided Hoboken authorities, in turn, sublease the property for fifty years to the Port of New York Authority for development.

A commentary on ballet, ballet companies, choreographers and ballet movements by John Martin, dance critic of THE NEW YORK TIMES, is one of two books published today. "World Book of Modern Ballet" is issued by World Publisher at $6 and it is illustrated with 160 photographs.

LONDON, July 16 -- Dr. Hewlett Johnson, "Red Dean" of Canterbury Cathedral, whose right of free speech was defended yesterday by Prime Minister Churchill in the House of Commons and the Archbishop of Canterbury in the House of Lords, renewed his charge that the United States waged germ warfare against China at a public meeting here tonight.

The new American liner United States will be open to the public for inspection tomorrow from 10 A. M. to 4 P. M., with the admission proceeds going to the Merchant Marine Academy, Kings Point, L. I The last public inspection, before the liner took Atlantic speed honors, was held for the benefit of the Travelers Aid Society.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, July 16 -- Leaders of the Communist insurrection in Malaya are now operating under conditions of special jeopardy. The British chiefs of the Malayan security forces have recently decided to concentrate on hunting down and eliminating the high ranking Reds.

PARIS, July 16 -- A bomb blast today shattered the Paris apartment of the magistrate who presided over the Appeals tribunal that quashed Government charges against the French Communist chieftain Jacques Duclos and ordered his release from prison on July 1.

In your issue of July 9, in a dispatch from Geneva, you report on the defeat of a Swiss tax bill on beverages. Revenue was to have been used to finance the increased armaments' cost. Your dispatch comments that the only propaganda against the measure came from the Communists.

A record high in total assets of the mutual fund, or open-end investment company industry, was attained in the first half of 1952. Combined with the closed-end, or specialized type of investment companies, over-all assets of the investing company business reached $4,512,332,000 on June 30, the National Association of Investment Companies announced yesterday.
CHICAGO, July 16 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois can be drafted for the nomination for President by the Democratic National Convention, which opens here Monday.

A gradual increase in production, reduction of producers stocks and price increases portend a strong market for textiles this fall, a survey of the market showed yesterday. Wool goods, cottons, rayons and other synthetic cloths continue to show strength in the primary markets, and the fibers themselves are up in price.
ROME, July 16 -- A high Italian police source indicated today that Charles (Lucky) Luciano's Italian passport, obtained in 1950, had been withdrawn.

The consolidated net profit of the Caterpillar Tractor Company for the six months ended on June 30 was $11,926,102, compared with $10,398,969 in the first half of 1951, L. B. Neumiller, president, reported yesterday.

The Coast Guard vessel Courier will sail today from Hoboken for the Mediterranean. Her "cargo," unlisted on the manifest, will continue to the Black Sea and, disdaining customs or immigration barriers, to different parts of the Soviet Union and its satellite nations.

WEEHAWKEN, N. J., July 16 -- Puffing steam locomotives, which, since 1883, have delighted countless small fry along the right-of-way of the West Shore division of the New York Central Railroad, will puff no more for their admirers.
The police intensified their efforts yesterday to find the murderer of Eileen Fahey, who was shot and killed Monday morning at her desk in a Columbia University building.

An armed man and a woman companion held up three women in the tenth floor apartment of a sportswear manufacturer at 450 West End Avenue at Eighty-second Street yesterday morning and escaped with two diamond rings valued at $10,000.

RICHMOND, Va., July 16 (AP) -- United States Senator Harry F. Byrd will be a key figure at the Democratic State Convention in Roanoke tomorrow as a result of his record triumph over Col. Francis Pickens Miller in yesterday's Senatorial primary.
VIENNA, July 16 (AP) -- Two top international Jewish leaders today charged the Austrian Government with "re-establishing the Hitler regime" by a series of seven laws now before Parliament.
THE news that developed through a call to Jerry Sylvester's place at Narragansett, R. I., yesterday was fairy disheartening to a man interested in plying the surf for striped bass.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 16 -- The showing of an uncensored newsreel, scheduled for a local theatre tonight to start a test of Ohio's right to censor newsreels, was called off because of a disagreement over who was to be arrested.

CHICAGO, July 16 -- The proposal for the nomination of Presidents of the United States in the future by the direct primary election votes of the people, rather than by the existing party convention tactics, ran into storms today. It was put before the preliminary platform drafting committee of the Democratic National Convention.

In the presence of thirty friends and attaches of the Manhattan Borough President's office, Warren Moscow, former political reporter for THE NEW YORK TIMES, was sworn in yesterday as Manhattan Commissioner of Borough Works. The oath was administered by Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. in his office in the Municipal Building.

PURCHASE, N. Y., July 16 -- Rivals a week ago for the New York State championship, Joe Risoli Jr. and Mike Volpe of the Willows Country Club teamed to win the British Victory tourney today at the Century Country Club.

LONDON, July 16 -- There was still another clash between the rival factions in the British Labor party today and once again Clement R. Attlee, the party leader and former Prime Minister, emerged victorious over Aneurin Bevan, but by the smallest margin yet.

CHICAGO, July 16 -- Representatives of five candidates for the Democratic nomination for President agreed today at a meeting with Frank E. McKinney, Democratic National Chairman, to support his recommendation that demonstrations for Presidential candidates be limited to delegates and alternates.

CHICAGO, July 15 -- The bitter fight for control of the Air Lines Pilots Association, A. F. L., threatened today to cause a strike of members of the union who refuse to recognize David L. Behncke as president of the 6,000-member organization.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., July 16 -- Milton (Babe) Lichardus of Baltusrol took a 3-stroke lead as the thirty-second annual New Jersey open golf championship started at the Plainfield Country Club today. Lichardus, recently made assistant to pro Johnny Farrell at Baltusrol, posted a 4-under-par 34, 34 -- 68.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (UP) -- The Air Force, which does not believe in "Flying Saucers" but is always willing to investigate stories of them, disclosed today that it was looking over a new report on them.

An added woe has been heaped upon the caving back of the New York City car owner. This is the refusal of certain insurance companies to furnish complete comprehensive automobile coverage to car owners in the city who do not customarily garage their cars.
PARIS, JULY 16 -- Rose Valois introduces hats that envelop the back of the head right down to the nape of the neck but leave the top uncovered to far beyond the hairline.

In reference to your editorial of July 14 entitled "A Sensible N. L. R. B. Policy," covering determination of appropriateness of nation-wide bargaining units by the N. L. R. B., I would like to bring some facts to your attention which are not too well known.

NEW DELHI, India, July 16 -- Decisive talks on the political relationship of the state of Jammu and Kashmir to the Indian Union began this morning with the arrival of Sheikh Mohammed Abdullah, Prime Minister of the Indian-held part of the state.

BERLIN, July 16 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor, joined today the procession of leading Western statesmen who visited West Berlin in the last two months as a symbol of their support to the city on the eve of what must be its most critical period.

ST. LOUIS, Thursday, July 17 -- The Giants blew a five-run lead in an alarming ninth-inning collapse of Old Reliable, Hoyt Wilhelm, against the Cards early today before 15,326 spectators at Sportsman's Park, but the champions righted themselves and pulled out an 8-7 victory in the tenth inning.

WINNIPEG, July 16 (Canadian Press) -- Stan Leonard of Vancouver, Skee Riegel of Tulsa, Okla., and Johnny Palmer of Bodin, N. C., shot 6-under-par 66's to finish the first 18-hole round of the 72-hole Canadian Open golf tournament in a tie for the lead.

A teacher of fine cookery whose pupils include professional cooks confided to us the other day that she wanted "to get away from the tag of cooking only glamour food." She is Mrs. Matilda Erikzen, who, aware of the "great need of making the most inexpensive food delicious," recently directed her artistry to the development of several economical dishes.
GRASSY POINT, N. Y., July 16 -- An age-old force was turned loose here today, to lift three great concrete structures that at a glance would seem as immovable as the pyramids.
CINCINNATI, July 15 -- Brooklyn's mastery of the Reds at Crosley Field remained unblemished as the Dodgers won here tonight for the sixth straight time, 5 -- 3, before 10,652 fans.

CHICAGO, JULY 16 (UP) -- The Calumet Farm's Real Delight gave away plenty of weight to her rivals and gave Arlington Park's racegoers another exhibition of her blinding speed today as she drove to a thrilling victory in the $40,000 Modesty Handicap.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The Senate Preparedness subcommittee today commended the Government for winning an "economic victory" over an international tin cartel that had sought "exorbitant profits" from this country.

SALIX, Iowa, July 16 (AP) -- Although a sheriff and two deputies stood by, all was quiet today when twelve children departed for free swimming lessons at near-by Sioux City aboard a public school bus on which Roman Catholic school children had been forbidden to ride.

The First National Bank of Boston, Mass., reported as of June 30, 1952, total deposits of $1,504,903,160 and total assets of $1,684,355,044, compared, respectively, with $1,495,148,775 and $1,676,027,869 on Dec. 31, 1951. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $442,646,853 against $463,130,250; holdings of United States Government securities to $454,149,988 against $455,298,867; and loans and discounts to $660,662,248 against $652,733,766.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 16 -- Adopting a personnel management program like those of large corporations, this suburban city of 45,000 appointed James E. Heap Jr. of Moorestown, N. J., today as its first Director of Personnel. Mayor Edwin G. Michaelian said Whiite Plains was the first city in the state and among the first in the nation to establish a comprehensive personnel department.

Management and cutting rights on a 47,500 acre tract of long leaf and slash pine in Madison and Hamilton Counties, Florida, have been acquired by the St. Regis Paper Company, it was announced by its New York office yesterday. The rights were acquired for a period of sixty years from the J. W. Gibson Company, Madison, Fla.

This may yet become known in American history as the year of the revolution -- if Senator McCarthy will permit the phrase. The revolution, if it comes off, will be within the two great political parties. Within the Republican ranks, in fact, a very considerable revolution has already taken place.

CHICAGO, July 16 -- Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee flew to Chicago today for the Democratic National Convention, confident he would win the nomination for President and that General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Republican candidate, would be easy to defeat because "he will not have the vigorous backing of the rank and file of the Republican party."
WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- The Government today allocated $67,000,000 for school construction in federally affected defense areas.

F. Ambrose Clark's Tea-Make, who is one of the most remarkable race horses in the land, scored his third stakes victory of the year in the main event of the Empire City-at-Jamaica proceedings yesterday. He hustled six furlongs in a brisk 1:10 1/5 and won the $21,825 Fleetwing Handicap.

CHICAGO, July 16 -- The Republican elephant has given way to the Democratic donkey on the Chicago convention scene, and there has been a transition from the weighty and belligerent tension of a World Series clash to the genteel rivalry of an intercollegiate track meet.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 16 -- The American debut of the French trotting mare Cancanniere, owned by Mme. Pierre Barcllhon of Paris, at Roosevelt Raceway tonight proved a failure when the 1952 Grand Prix winner broke on the final turn of the mile and one-half race and finished seventh. She was driven by Jonel Chyriacos, her Greek trainer-driver.

BONN, Germany, July 16--Reviewing the state of West Germany in his final press conference today, John J. McCloy, retiring United States High Commissioner, found a firm basis for optimism over the future but warned of those persons who would "like to restore the old aberrations of the Nazis."

The Fund for the Advancement of Education, a subsidiary of the Ford Foundation, has set aside $2,000,000 to provide fellowships for about 400 high school teachers throughout the United States this fall, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Clarence H. Faust, president of the fund.

TOKYO, Thursday, July 17 (AP) -- History's biggest transoceanic jet plane flight was completed at nearby Yokota Air Base Wednesday when the last of fifty-eight F-84G Thunderjets landed from the United States.
LONDON, July 16 -- The stock markets began a new three-week bookkeeping account in a cheerful mood today. Business expanded a little and prices rose in almost every section.

The operating deficits that have been charged to the passenger service of the Staten Island Rapid Transit Railway would disappear if the operations were included with the freight profits of the Baltime Ohio Railroad in that area, it was contended yesterday by counsel for the Public Service Commission.
HARRISON, N. J., July 16 -- A general-alarm fire here early today destroyed the six-story main building of the Camden Brewery at 504 Harrison Avenue, causing damage estimated at $150,000.
Wood alone made notable gain in futures trading here yesterday. Lead gained 5 points on a single Commodity Exchange transaction but all other commodities were mixed or lower.

The city experienced yesterday its fifth successive day of temperatures above 90 degrees, which, combined with a relative humidity ranging above 50 per cent, made things exceptionally oppressive. The Turkish bath atmosphere was relieved briefly here and there by thunder showers, but these were so widely scattered and localized that the Weather Bureau could record them only as "centering about thirty miles to the southwest."
To whatever powers that already have been attributed to music, the Goldman Band added yesterday the power to root pedestrians in Bowling Green Park for an hour's concert under a broiling sun.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- Announced United States battle casualties in Korea reached 112,843 today, an increase of 715 since last week.

Juichi Tsushima, former Finance Minister of Japan, arrived in New York yesterday with five aides to reach an agreement on means to restore his country's international credit. "That," he said, "is our No. 1 need of the moment."

CHICAGO, July 16 -- President Truman tonight warned delegates to the Thirty-first Democratic National Convention, which opens here on Monday, that "there must be no betrayal of the New Deal and the Fair Deal."
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The Aluminum Company of America applied to the Office of Price Stabilization today for the right to increase prices by at least 10 per cent.

CHICAGO, July 16 -- Some of the country's major farm organizations attacked today the keystone of the Democratic Administration's agricultural policy -- rigid high price supports -- and called upon the Democratic National Convention to return the party to its platform pledge of 1948 that advocated a flexible system of price props.

New York City is playing host this week to the Eighty-eighth Grand Lodge convention of the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks. Some 32,000 delegates and their families are attending meetings and seeing the sights in so orderly a manner that many New Yorkers are not aware that so large a convention is in town.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson described in glowing terms today the "tremendous confidence" and "tremendous friendship" with which the United States is regarded by the peoples of West Germany and Austria and those of Brazil.

Today's new film is "The Story of Will Rogers," Warner Brothers' biography of the humorist, starring Will Rogers Jr. in the title role, and Jane Wyman, at the Astor. Michael Curtiz directed and Robert Arthur produced the Technicolor offering from a script by Frank Davis and Stanley Roberts, an adaptation by John C. Moffitt, and the story, "Uncle Clem's Boy," by Mrs. Will Rogers.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., July 16 (UP) -- Officers at Ent Air Force Base, headquarters of the Air Defense Command, said today 430,000 more civilian volunteers were needed for Operation Sky- watch to protect this country from possible attack by enemy planes.

HAVANA, Cuba, July 16 (AP) -- The Cuban Sugar Institute announced today the sale of a minimum of 7,500,000 gallons of molasses to Publicker Industries of Philadelphia, at 12 cents a gallon. The Institute's molasses sales committee announced at the same time it would welcome offers from other concerns at the same price, at least for the next fifteen days. The figure is f. o. b. Cuba.
The financial records of 300 persons are being investigated by Special Prosecutor William B. Herlands, who is conducting a grand jury inquiry into crime and corruption on Staten Island.

Kal Segrist and Tom Gorman, a couple of farm hands fresh from Kansas City, were prominent figures as the Yankees swept the double-header with the Indians yesterday at the Stadium. Segrist started a tenth-inning rally with a single and subsequently scored the winning run on a single by Hank Bauer, giving the home side an 8-7 decision in the opener.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 16 -- West Coast shipowners offered the striking Sailors Union of the Pacific, A. F. L., today monthly wage increases allowable under regulations of the Wage Stabilization Board. The sailors countered with new demands, reportedly including a wage increase of 11 per cent.
TRENTON, July 16 -- New Jersey-New York waterfront crime will be the first field into which the New Jersey Law Enforcement Council will inquire.
The Metropolitan Opera Association and the Associated Guild of Musical Artists have signed a two-year contract that will extend through the 1953-54 season, it was learned yesterday.

COME Monday evening at the Stadium, the Yankees and Dodgers will clash in a game which, barring another little miracle under the lee of Coogan's Bluff, could well be, according to the respective publicity directors of the two clubs, a preview of the 1952 world series.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 16--The creation of a standard bar examination, to be administered on a national basis, was advocated today as one of the greatest needs of the legal profession in the United States. The bar examining processes as now administered in most of the states were termed "woefully inadequate."

The nation's gasoline stocks declined 1,201,000 barrels last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end they were 118,332,000 barrels, compared with 119,533,000 a week earlier and 133,482,000 a year ago.

The Malthusian specter of an increasingly overpopulated and eventually starving world, while it may never be entirely exorcised from anxious professorial minds, has been taking something of a beating lately from agricultural science.

The stock market was unable to hold its ground yesterday as prices backed or filled with each new development in the steel strike situation. When the steel issues failed to push ahead, the remainder of the list took this as a warning that hopes for a settlement of the stalemate were premature.

The Long Island Lighting Company, serving one of the fastest growing areas in the country reported yesterday a net income of $5,864,357 for the twelve months to June 30, 1952, or 40.4 per cent over the net of $4,176,035 in the preceding fiscal year.
VICKSBURG, Miss., July 16 (UP) -- A converted World War II landing ship will leave here Saturday on a mission to carry Christianity to Liberia through mechanized farming.

The Navy and the Coast Guard demonstrated yesterday morning at Floyd Bennett Field a new air-borne rubber lifeboat that inflates in thirty seconds to provide protection for fifteen survivors in either sub-zero or blistering tropical weather.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (UP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan asked farmers today to reduce their 1953 wheat crop by about 170,000,000 bushels by cutting their fall planting.

LANSING, Mich., July 16 -- Attorney General Frank G. Millard issued today a report charging that interference by the State Corrections Commissioner in the administration of Southern Michigan Prison near Jackson had helped to precipitate the convicts' mutiny there last April.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- A three-day session of the seventh annual National Conference on Citizenship will open here on Sept. 17, Attorney General James P. McGranery and Mrs. Sarah C. Caldwell, president of the National Education Association, announced today.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today that cotton consumption for the period June 1 to June 28 averaged 34,798 bales for each working day. This compared with an average of 40,858 bales for the corresponding period a year ago, and with 35,215 for the May period this year.

Students and colleagues gave a dinner last night in the Brevoort Hotel to Prof. Charles J. Pieper, chairman of the department of science education at New York University, who will retire with the close of the summer session after twenty- four years of service with the university.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 16 -- France asserted before the International Court of Justice today that the refusal of the United States to give up extraterritorial rights in French Morocco was harming the interests of the North African Protectorate's inhabitants.

BOSTON, July 16 (AP) -- The Red Sox tightened their grip on third place in the American League today by battering a former teammate, Joe Dobson of the White Sox, for a 7-3 victory. Hoot Evers contributed a two-run homer and Billy Goodman a two-run double to the thirteen-hit Boston attack.

United States Attorney Frank J. Parker of Brooklyn yesterday advised Henry L. Hoffman, Director of Internal Revenue for the First New York District, not to produce a copy of the income tax returns of Harry Gross, convicted bookmaker, at the Police Department trial scheduled to start next Tuesday in the Criminal Courts Building, 100 Center Street.

Toy sales this year will top the 1951 record figure of $720,000,000 by about 10 per cent, bringing the total close to $800,000,000, Melvin Freud, president of the Toy Guidance Council, Inc., said yesterday at the opening of the group's exhibit for 1952. The estimate of sales in toy departments includes children's records, books and furniture as well as the conventional games, toys and wheel goods.

The office of director of the New York Zoological Park, vacant for twelve years, has been revived by the New York Zoological Society, which administers the park, and filled by the appointment of John Tee-Van, former executive secretary of the zoo and the Aquarium.

A new synthetic rubber has been developed that can be made without the costly refrigeration equipment now used to produce "cold" rubber for tire treads. This was announced yesterday in Akron, Ohio, by Raymond C. Firestone, vice president in charge of research and development of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company.

Officers of the Eastern Air Defense Force's headquarters at Stewart Base, Newburgh, N. Y., said yesterday they frankly were worried about the poor response for appeals for voluntary air watchers as "Operation Skywatch" went into its third day with fewer than half the spotting stations in seventeen Eastern states even partially manned.
CHICAGO, July 16 -- Pronounced weakness in new crop deliveries of corn and soybeans unsettled the markets on the Board of Trade today, causing considerable long liquidation in wheat and oats also.

Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee, a leading aspirant for the Democratic Presidential nomination, was placed on record yesterday as favoring a liberal foreign trade policy, including a reduction of trade restrictions and an increase of imports.

Functional modern furniture pieces are currently on display in settings at Hearn's. Especially considering the young budget-minded homemaker, the settings suggest color schemes and suitable accessories as well as contemporary furniture that often serves several purposes.

The New York Central Railroad borrowed $8,475,000 in the public market yesterday to help finance the purchase of sixty-four new Diesel freight locomotives and other new equipment estimated to cost $11,363,380.

The man and woman who were reported fleeing from a seaplane stranded at 1 A. M. yesterday in the Hudson River at 110th Street have not been found, nor have the pants that Patrick O'Brien doffed as he aided them ashore.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., July 16 -- Prison labor in competition with free workers was condemned today by the State Federation of Labor as delegates at the closing session of the federation's eighty-ninth convention voted to seek elimination of this direct competition.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 16 -- High temperatures and humidity caused adjournment at 3 P. M. today of the one-man grand jury investigation here by State Referee Alfred C. Baldwin of possible corruption in Norwalk and Stamford. The closed hearing will resume at 10 A. M. Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson said today that the forthcoming meeting of the tripartite Pacific Council would give the United States, Australia and New Zealand an opportunity to review "matters affecting their common relationships in the Pacific area."

BONN, Germany, July 16 -- The West German Parliament unanimously called on the Western Powers today to "protect all Germans entrusted to them as if they were their own citizens" after Jacob Kaiser, Minister for All-German Affairs, reported that more than 100 West Germans had been abducted by East German and Soviet agents since 1948.
The removal of "No Parking" signs at schools and other buildings closed for the summer was suggested yesterday to accommodate at least 8,000 automobiles during the tourist season.
Actors' Equity Association announced yesterday a set of regulations containing new restrictions on the employment of alien actors in this country.

Now that a Federal "fair trade" law has become effective, manufacturers using this minimum-price protective system are somewhat perturbed over the question of whether new price-maintenance agreements have to be drawn to gain the benefits of the new law in interstate commerce.

The concept of the Atlantic Community is acquiring new vitality as a result of the American program for "offshore procurement" of military equipment for our own forces and those of our allies. Under this program, which is part of the Mutual Security program, the United States has placed a total of $684,000,000 worth of defense contracts in Europe, chiefly in nine NATO countries, during the last fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- President Truman signed today a bill designed to increase safety in coal mines, but he described what he regarded as five deficiencies in it and warned that the public should not be "misled" into believing it was a broad accident-prevention measure.

Gross revenues of American Airlines, Inc., for the first half of this year rose to a new peak of $86,957,000 from the previous record of $75,115,000 established in the initial six months last year, according to the semi-annual operating statement issued for publication today.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (UP) -- President Truman today signed a new billion-dollar G. I. Bill of Rights extending most of the World War II benefits to veterans of the Korean war.

More than 100 riders in two northbound B. M. T. subway trains suffered minor injuries at 5:33 P. M. yesterday when one train rolled back on the other in the Fulton Street station under Nassau Street. Service on the track was held up for one hour and twenty-seven minutes.

ALBANY, July 16 -- Governor Dewey's office, which has been confined to pretty routine information of late, came up with something out of the ordinary today -- an announcement that the Chief of State of Vietnam would be able to fish for small-mouth bass in the streams of his native land.

The German Parliament has appealed to the United Nations and to the Council of Europe for aid in a matter which has become a world-wide scandal -- the Soviet kidnapping of anti-Communist opponents from free territories. According to German Government figures, the Soviets and their East German puppets have kidnapped no fewer than 169 persons from West Berlin and many more from West Germany, both of which areas are under Allied protection.

BERLIN, July 16 (AP) -- All the Russian-seized equipment of the American roller-skating show "Skating Vanities" is back in West Germany, Harold Steinman, the show's producer, said tonight. However, he cannot move the equipment until he has paid the West German Federal Railways 110,000 Deutsche marks (about $26,000) -- including a Soviet fine of 80,000 marks (about $19,000). He does not have the money, he said.
PITTSBURGH, July 16 (AP) Averell Harriman, here seeking support of his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination, made an appeal today to organized labor.

TAMPA, Fla., July 16 -- Larry Evans of New York, the defending champion; Herman Steiner of Los Angeles, Arturito Pomar of Madrid, James T. Sherwin, New York State champion, and Donald Byrne of Yale University were successful again today in the second round of the United States open chess tournament.
Plans of the City Housing Authority to build 39,093 low-rent apartments with Federal aid face a five-year slowdown to 1960, instead of 1955, under the latest Congressional schedule.

Yesterday's news brought word of the astounding performance of Bill Bridgeman in flying the Navy's D-558-II, otherwise known as the Skyrocket, at an altitude of 79,000 feet (the previous record was made in a balloon by Anderson and Stevens in 1935) and in attaining a speed of over 1,300 miles an hour.

More drama and newness from season to season in hat designs as a means of improving business were requested by Joseph Rabinovich, president of the millinery syndicate of Ogus, Rabinovich Ogus, at yesterday's meeting of the Fashion Group at the Astor Hotel.

While Republicans congratulate themselves on nominating one of the world's truly great men to lead their campaign this fall they should not for get that their Chicago convention has to its credit another achievement of almost equal importance.

WASSENAAR, the Netherlands, July 16 -- West Germany offered world Jewish organizations today 450,000,000 marks (about $107,000,000) for the relief and rehabilitation of Jews persecuted by the Nazi regime, and stated that a further 50,000,000 marks would be made available for aid to non-professing Jews who had been oppressed.

The Park Association of New York City will conduct another of its "Know Your City Parks" sightseeing yacht tours on Wednesday. The boat will leave from West Forty-second Street at 2 P. M. and sail down the Hudson River. After circling Manhattan Island, the touring group will return at 5:30 P. M.
Both sides rested yesterday in the perjury trial in Kings County Court of James E. Reardon, former plainclothes man and admitted associate of Harry Gross, the bookmaker.
The Long Beach, Calif., Unified School District announced yesterday that it will receive bids on July 29 on an issue of $8,500,000 of bonds.
OTTAWA, July 16 (Canadian Press) -- Canada, once the third largest among the trading countries of the world, has slipped to fourth position although her business is booming.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 16 (UP) -- The Brazilian Government acted today to halt a reported contraband flow of gold from the newly discovered fields in northern Brazil into the French and Dutch Guianas.
Common stock financing intended to raise about $5,600,000 for Bailey Selburn Oil and Gas, Ltd., is in effect today in both the American and the Canadian market.

The New York State Racing Commission yesterday revoked the owners' license of Louis Tufano on charges that the New York contractor instructed his jockeys not to try and win with the horse Gondolier at Belmont Park on May 12 and again on May 29.

Efforts to have the Mexican Government modify a recent regulation that has caused delay in overland shipments from this country are being pressed by the United States Embassy in Mexico City, it was reported yesterday by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York. Notice of this action was received in a letter from Harry T. Benson, commercial attache of the embassy.
CHICAGO, July 16 (UP) -- Frank E. McKinney, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, announced today that hearings had been scheduled for Friday on delegate contests from Texas and Mississippi.

GENEVA, July 16 -- The establishment of a huge international fund for financing the construction of trans-European highways has been proposed by the International Road Federation and has received a provisional go-ahead signal from the six European Governments participating in the Schuman plan, the project that would co-ordinate Western Europe's coal and steel industries.

PARIS, July 16 -- Janette Colombier's hats are the smallest ever. In their briefest expression they are mere coifs about four inches wide that pass around the back of the head to clamp the temples, symmetrically or with one end higher on one temple than the other if desired.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP)--American government officials look for Japan soon to settle, probably at par, with the holders of Japanese pre-war dollar bonds. It may be done with a new issue of securities, spreading the cost to Japan over a period of years.

A 38-year-old import and export dealer was sent to the workhouse for fifty-eight days and fined $1,025 after he was denounced yesterday as "a menace" and "the worst traffic chiseler ever to appear in Traffic Court."

A tax muddle, for which everyone disclaims responsibility, is costing buyers of new automobiles millions of dollars a year. The situation stems from the generally standard industry practice of figuring sales taxes on the overall price of a car, including $150 to $500 in Federal excise taxes.

DENVER, July 16 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower will start on a week's fishing trip tomorrow, but first he will say farewell to his son, Maj. John S. D. Eisenhower, who is going to Korea. To do so the general will postpone his departure for the mountain-trout country from the morning to the afternoon.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 16 -- A fight for a Republican Congressional nomination will be the only contest in the Aug. 19 primary election in Westchester County, petition of candidates showed today. The petitions were due at the board of elections last night.

Mrs. Harry Price, the wife of a business executive and mother of three children, disappeared from her home, 680 West End Avenue, at 9 A. M. on March 21 and has not been heard from since. The Police Department has sent out an eight-state teletype alarm and notified the Federal Bureau of Investigation to watch for her in other parts of the country.
TOKYO, Thursday, July 17 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,313, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Thursday, Korea time:

For twelve years Battery Park, torn into ugly trenches and unsightly piles of earth, has been closed to the public while the $80,000,000 Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel and the $10,000,000 West Street-South Street Underpass were being built underneath. Now the entire area has been surfaced over and refurbished.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 17 -- A need for greater coordination of military and civilian activities was seen by state officials today when the state's most extensive test of controls and communications in civil defense was conducted at the state control center field headquarters in a secret place near here.

This is the start of another week-end, but the car will not leave the garage. This is Friday and, after the close of the working hours today, there will be many rewarding hours unsupervised by the time clock or the foreman.

TAMPA, Fla., July 17 -- Contests for chess supremacy increased in intensity today, as results of the third round of the national open championship tournament were posted on the bulletin board at the Hotel Floridan. United States champion Larry Evans of New York, with three straight to his credit, shared first place with Arturito Pomar of Spain, Donald Byrne and Carl Burger, both of New York, and Philip LeCornu of Detroit.

A colony of 40,000 worker army ants from Barro Colorado Island in the Panama Canal Zone will be placed on public exhibition today in the Seventy-second Street foyer of the American Museum of Natural History.

Egg prices, which rose sharply again, are now higher than in any corresponding week since 1949. Top grade large and medium sizes are up 6 cents a dozen since last week. The large size are now 4 cents a dozen higher than a year ago, while the medium have caught up to last year's level.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The Army is establishing a combat development unit to foster the tactical and technical development of new weapons and to integrate them into the "fighting team" of the ground forces.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- A firmer tone in wheat futures, with cash prices also gaining a little, sharp price recessions in corn, especially the July and September, and a broad price drop in rye futures featured the operations on the Board of Trade today.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- The Government today authorized sellers in states having minimum-price laws to apply for higher ceilings to meet state-fixed price levels.

The American Fair Trade Council will fight for legislation curbing mail-order price cutters of "fair traded" products when Congress reconvenes, John W. Anderson, president, announced yesterday. The decision to go after mail order houses was taken after an executive conference of the council in Gary, Ind.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- State Department officials declined today to comment formally on either the resignation of Dr. Mossadegh as Iranian Premier or the selection of Mr. Ghavam as his successor. Informally, however, they made it clear that the first was not a surprise.

The American Car and Foundry Company reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on April 30 a consolidated net income of $7,202,165, equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $8.63 a share on the outstanding common stock. This compares with $2,675,914, or $1.08 a common share, in the previous fiscal year.

RIDGEWOOD, N. J., July 17 -- One hundred and ninety-six young foreign students who have been on a tour of principal American cities arrived today at the Ridgewood Young Men's Christian Association and then were escorted by more than 100 American students to private homes where they will spend the next four days.
BALBOA, C. Z., July 17 -- Merchant ships of twenty-nine nations used the Panama Canal in the fiscal year ended June 30, 1951, according to the annual report.

PHILADELPHIA, July 17 (AP) -- Little Bobby Shantz of the Athletics turned in a six-hit 3-to-1 triumph over the Browns in the second game of a twilight-night twin bille tonight to chalk up his sixteenth victory against three losses.

The Western Union Telegraph Company announced yesterday that as a result of the rapid recovery of revenues after the ending of the telegraph strike last May 26, operations in June produced a substantial profit, as indicated in preliminary estimates, but no figures were given. In June, 1951, the company had a net income of $791,213.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 17 -- The Nassau Country Club team of Franklin Burke and Franklin Burke 3d, mixed their shots superbly in the alternate-shot competition to card 84 -- 17 -- 67 for low net and the championship honors during the Long Island Golf Association father-and-son tournament at the Hempstead Club today.

ROANOKE, Va., July 17 -- Virginia Democrats, stanch supporters of Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia for the Democratic Presidential nomination before Senator Russell announced that he favored the repeal of the Taft-Hartley Act, voted today to send an uninstructed delegation to the National Convention, opening Monday in Chicago.
Roberta Peters, coloratura soprano, and Robert Merrill, baritone, will be soloists with Alexander Smallens and the Stadium Symphony Orchestra at Lewisohn Stadium Monday evening.

ROME, July 17 -- The Italian Ambassador to Washington, Alberto Tarchiani, has been instructed to call the attention of the United States State Department to the adverse effect that the American decision to supply the Yugoslav armed forces with tanks, heavy artillery and jet aircraft is likely to have on Italian-Yugoslav relations, especially on the problem of Trieste.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- Democrats will stage their own battle of contested Southern delegates tomorrow, but indications are that the row will not be so bitter or so decisive as it was in the Republican National Convention, when the outcome of the fight spelled defeat for Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio in his fight for the Presidential nomination.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission reported today that individual savings in the first three months of the year totaled $2,700,000,000 -- the highest amount for the first quarter of any year since World War II.
Columbia University announced yesterday the solution of a basic problem that has confronted scientists for more than sixty years and could not have been solved by any human mathematician.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (UP) -- Jim Busby singled home the only run of the game in the ninth inning tonight as Frank Shea recorded his sixth straight victory by pitching the Senators to a 1-0 decision over the last-place Tigers.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 17 -- The team of Nationalist China was withdrawn today from the games of the fifteenth Oympiad in protest against the action of the International Olympic Committee in voting to permit the participation of the Chinese Communists.
CHICAGO, July 17 (UP) -- Vern Bickford won his own game today, singling in the seventh to drive home Ed Mathews with the only score and sink the Cubs, 1 to 0, before 5,963 fans.
Net assets of the National Investors Corporation on June 30 were $29,321,128, against $24,581,227 a year earlier. The latest report was equivalent to $12.50 a share against $12.36 on Dec. 31, 1951.

WHILE crossing the main street of four in an upstate village the other day, the writer was hailed by Al Prindle with a purposeful gesture that indicated something important was afoot. Prindle, whose main occupation is fishing, used to be a purist, but he has changed.

Softening became more pronounced yesterday on the stock market as selling developed in the steel and automotive sections. The new decline did not, however, produce an increase in volume. In fact, business was the smallest in a week. More stocks lost ground than advanced and the composite rate dipped 0.52 point.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 17 -- Betty Hutton will leave Paramount on Saturday after twelve years on the lot to go into independent film production with her husband, Charles O'Curran, and also to enter television.

James E. Reardon, former plainclothes policeman and admitted associate in Harry Gross' $20,000,000-a-year bookmaking combine, was found guilty yesterday in Kings County Court of perjury in the first degree.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., July 17 (UP) -- Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman Donald C. Cook disclosed plans today for an efficiency survey of the nation's public utilities systems.
While idleness from work stoppages dropped by 40 per cent in the nation in 1951 as against 1950, in New York State it rose in 1951 to 2,500,000 man-days of work lost compared to 2,190,000 in 1950.

Now that the worst part of the potato shortage is over, harvesting of the first of the Long Island potato crop has begun. The crop is reported to be of fair size and quality. The acreage devoted to growing potatoes on Long Island has been increased about 10 per cent this year over that of 1951 to about 53,000 acres.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (Science Service) -- Poliomyelitis cases sharply increased in the week ending July 12, state reports to the Federal Public Health Service here show.

NEW DELHI, India, July 17 -- By approving an amendment to the Indian Companies Act the House of the People, the lower house of Parliament, gave powers to the Central Government today to permit, under special conditions, any foreign company starting a new industry in India to retain "full control" over the management of the undertaking.

UNION CITY, N. J., July 17 -- An 18-month-old girl and her 7-month-old twin brothers were burned to death here early today when a two-alarm fire swept their third-floor apartment at 517 Twenty-second Street. Firemen recovered the bodies of the three children forty-five minutes after the blaze was discovered.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 17 -- A special investigating committee of the Brazilian Congress left today for the Argentine frontier to investigate charges of border violations by Argentine gendarmes that are endangering good relations between the two countries along that boundary.

GENEVA, July 17 -- If Communist China fully ratifies the Geneva Conventions of 1949 relating to prisoners of war and other matters involving the protection of non-combatants in wartime, as Foreign Minister Chou En-lai has announced it will, it would by that act go a long way toward repudiating the Communists' own denunciations of various Red Cross groups as agents of the United States and of Western "imperialism."
After seventy-nine years, less one day, the New York Stock Exchange is about to change its traditional 10-to-3 trading hours.
Marking the second occurrence of its kind in recent days, a slim young matron slapped a policeman at 6:20 P. M. yesterday and was arrested on a charge of simple assault, the police reported.

Allergies may form the basis for allegedly humorous after-dinner conversation but anyone who is wracked by hay fever does not find the subject funny. Another allergy -- to wool -- can torture its possessors more thoroughly than politicians orating at a national convention. But steps are being taken to end the wool allergy nightmare once and for all.
GENEVA, July 17 -- There is a new kind of American tourist in Europe this summer.
