Loans for industrial and business purposes declined the third time in a row in the New York City area during the week ended on Wednesday, with smaller seasonal needs the main cause of the $18,000,000 drop. In the last three weeks the decline has aggregated $191,000,000 and brought the total for the year to date down $454,000,000 in contrast to an increase up to this time a year ago of $473,000,000.

Actors Equity has put its foot down against the importation by the Playwrights Company of a London cast for "The Trial of Mr. Pickwick," it was learned yesterday. Consequently, Stanley Young's dramatization of a segment from Charles Dickens' "Pickwick Papers" is the first to feel the drastic effect of Equity's newly adopted regulations, stringently curtailing the appearance of foreign performers in this country.

PARIS, July 17 -- A proposal to create "a supranational political authority" to link together the nations taking part in the Schuman plan, the European army and any similar "communities," will be made by the French Government next week to the foreign ministers of the six Schuman plan countries who will meet here.

TAIPEI, Formosa, July 17 -- George Yeh, Chinese Nationalist Foreign Minister, in a statement obviously aimed at Secretary of State Dean Acheson's challenge to Communist China to live up to its professed adherence to Geneva Conventions, flatly rejected tonight Communist China's right to accede to the Conventions.

Mayor Impellitteri, with the approval of the Board of Estimate, deferred yesterday for two weeks final action on the proposed sale of five municipal bus lines in Manhattan to the New York City Omnibus Corporation.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 17 -- For more than two years, American Quakers have been sponsoring a series of meetings between United Nations officials and United States labor specialists, aimed at pooling information about an "art" that the world organization regards as one of its most useful tools -- mediation.

CINCINNATI, July l7 -- Jackie Robinson and Billy Cox blew their tops today and Roy Campanella blew a chance to win in nine innings because of bad base running, but the Dodgers won the final game of their series with the Reds, 2 -- 1, in eleven innings and more than three hours.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange lost 13 to 21 points yesterday in quiet trading.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 17 -- Top-seeded Dick Savitt of Orange, N. J., and fourth-place Gardner Mulloy of Miami, Fla., swept their matches with ease today to gain the semi-finals of the sixty-fifth annual Western tennis championships.
Israel put its products on display yesterday, and an estimated 400 persons an hour visited a showroom in Rockefeller Center to see what the infant nation could make.
S. Jay Gardiner has been elected president of Olympic Appliances, Inc., distributor in the New York area for Olympic Radio and Televison, Inc.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified 66 casualties in a new Korean battle list that reported 14 killed, 39 wounded, 2 missing and 11 injured. The following were listed from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut:

Five of the policemen who were ousted from the force for taking bribes from Harry Gross, convicted bookmaker, applied in Supreme Court yesterday for reinstatement and obtained a show-cause order from Justice Thomas L. J. Corcoran which is returnable next Wednesday.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., July 17 -- A protest over "misinformation" given by employes of the New Jersey Turnpike concerning the shortest route to Asbury Park from New York and points north was sent today to Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll and Paul Troast, chairman of the Turnpike Authority, by the Asbury Park Chamber of Commerce.
LONDON, July 17 -- In the fifty years since the present Queen Elizabeth's great-great-grandmother Queen Victoria died in 1901, the nation's health has improved greatly.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Dwight D. Eisenhower is now a civilian.

MADRID, July 17 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco announced today plans for an extensive reorganization of the Spanish armed forces designed to increase their efficiency by improving the present cadres. The text of the law setting forth the details of the military reform was published in the Official Bulletin.

There are 10,000,000 "overseas Chinese" in the Pacific who constitute the balance of power between communism in the Far East and democratic ideals in the West, Governor Dewey declared last night on a television program, "Author Meets the Critics," over the DuMont network.

DENVER, July 17 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower left today for a log cabin and a week's fishing in the Colorado Rockies after saying another farewell to his son John, an Army major, who stopped here on his way by air from Chicago to Seattle and Korea.

The pattern of the master wage stabilization agreement in the construction industry here was broken yesterday with the announcement that union bricklayers in the city had been granted an increase of 30 cents to bring their pay up to $3.55 an hour.

Two hundred students -- all under sixteen and a half years old -- will attend four universities this fall to participate in the second year of an experimental program financed by the Ford Foundation's Fund for the Advancement of Education.
CHICAGO, July 17 (AP) -- Gov. Allan Shivers of Texas said today he would take a pledge of party loyalty if the majority of the Democratic National Convention required that of all delegates.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 17 -- Lieut. Col. Adam Kornecki, Polish military attache to Sweden who returned to Poland ten days ago after the Swedish Foreign Ministry had notified the Polish legation here that his presence in Sweden was no longer desirable, was caught in the act of photographing military installations and particularly top - secret Swedish Air Force fields, according to the police.

PITTSBURGH, July 17 (UP) -- Ralph Kiner's seventeenth home run with one aboard and none out in the ninth inning brought the Pirates a 4-2 victory over the Phils in the nightcap of a twin bill today. The Bucs also took the opener, 2 -- 1.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., July 17 -- Milton (Babe) Lichardus continued his sub-par golf as he added a 71 to his first-round 68 for a total of 139 to keep the lead in the New Jersey open golf championship at the Plainfield Country Club today.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The Malayan Tin Bureau denied today charges of the Senate Preparedness subcommittee that an international tin cartel had sought "exorbitant" prices from the United States.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 17 -- Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi tonight charged Ahmad Ghavam es Sultaneh, aged Iranian statesman, who was Premier during the successful struggle to force the Soviet Army out of the country after World War II, with the task of forming a new Government to succeed that of Premier Mohammed Mossadegh.

Preliminary reports on the size of the video audience that watched the Republican National Convention indicate rather clearly that despite all the fanfare over television and politics no new viewing records were set. While the Chicago sessions easily outdrew all other current attractions on the video channels, they fell appreciably short of the tallies regularly recorded by the top wintertime programs.

Sheikh Abdullah, Prime Minister of Indian-occupied Kashmir, and Prime Minister Nehru are in a series of conferences that can have a decisive bearing on the future status of Kashmir. Sheikh Abdullah is making his bid for strong leadership and for a high degree of autonomy for the state.

Since the story appeared in THE TIMES about The Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind, decrying the contributions to blind beggars who are sometimes making more money than the givers, there has been a lively controversy about this subject throughout the country.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- A Democratic platform for 1952 pledged to the civil rights programs that Presidents Roosevelt and Truman tried and failed to get through Congress in a generation was demanded today by fifty-four fraternal, church, labor and professional organizations that asserted their membreship ran into millions of voters.

DESPITE popular belief, backed by the opinion of men who have become expert in calculating odds, that history does not repeat, there seems to be a pronounced feeling abroad that our Giants are getting ready to slip their old pals, the Dodgers, another flat tire as the pair moves along in the second half of the National League flag race.

The Public Service Commission ruled yesterday that virtually all of the 10 per cent reduction in electric rates of the Consolidated Edison Company ordered in 1948 as a temporary measure would now become permanent. It was estimated that this would continue an annual saving of $20,000,000. to 2,200,000 customers in the metropolitan area.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- Averell Harriman arrived here this afternoon for the final stages of his drive for the Democratic Presidential nomination voicing confidence that he would be selected at next week's convention to carry the New Deal-Fair Deal standard into the fall campaign.
CHICAGO, July 17 (AP) -- A field of twelve today shaped up for the $150,000 Arlington Classic, the nation's richest race for 3-year-olds, to be run at Arlington Park Saturday.

A third man was suspended yesterday by the Board of Transportation as a result of the Wednesday evening rush-hour collision of two B. M. T. subway train in the financial district station at Fulton and Nassau Streets. The motormen of the trains were suspended four hours after the crash.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Public utilities, transportation and storage facilities made up almost 50 per cent of the value of projects for which rapid tax amortization certificates were granted by the Defense Production Administration between April 15 and June 20, the D. P. A. announced today.

The Stanley Works, Inc., of New Britain, Conn., manufacturer of hardware, sold the eight-story showroom building on plot 87 by 25 feet at 100 Lafayette Street, southwest corner of Walker Street, to the 100 Lafayette Street Corporation, which leased the entire property to Avildsen Tools and Machines, Inc.

A 39-year-old war veteran fatally wounded his wife and stepdaughter with German 8-millimeter rifle while they slept in their second-floor apartment at 551 Cauldwell Avenue, the Bronx, at 5:15 A. M. yesterday after a vain attempt at reconciliation with his wife, the police reported.

Two new films will open at first-run theatres this morning. "Don't Bother To Knock," a Twentieth Century-Fox melodrama starring Richard Widmark and Marilyn Monroe, is at the Globe. Roy Baker directed and Julian Blaustein produced from a script by Daniel Taradash and a novel by Charlotte Armstrong.

Kenneth M. Spence, attorney for Frank Costello, the gambler, who faces imprisonment for contempt of the United States Senate, told reporters yesterday that he had not decided whether he would apply to the United States Court of Appeals for a rehearing of an appeal from Costello's conviction.

BERLIN, July 17 -- West Berlin's Parliament asked the three Western powers today to undertake the patrolling of the city's outer borders. A resolution to this effect was adopted after one of West Berlin's anti-Communist leaders was abducted over the border into the Soviet zone last week.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 17 -- Arthur E. Palmer Jr. of New York City has been elected chairman of the board of directors for the Yale University Alumni Fund, Charles Watson 3d, managing director of the fund, announced today.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- When Senator Russell of Georgia, at the outset of his campaign for the Democratic nomination for President, said that, regardless of whether the party platform contained a so-called "civil rights" program he could and would not approve, he nevertheless would support the candidates of next week's Democratic convention, many of his Southern colleagues were chagrined.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 17 -- Howard Hughes, head of R. K. O., and Stewart Granger and his wife, Jean Simmons, British film stars, today reached an agreement that ended a suit filed by Mr. Granger and Miss Simmons against Mr. Hughes and R. K. O. in the United States District Court here for $250,000 damages.

The proceeding brought by the Staten Island Rapid Transit Railway to discontinue its passenger service by Sept. 12 was adjourned for sixty days yesterday by the Public Service Commission at the request of the city to permit further discussion by a special committee of city officials to solve the problems affecting the railroad and its passengers.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- Averell Harriman, New York's candidate for the Democratic nomination for President, arrived this afternoon to find the convention city filled with rumors and supporters of opposing candidates seeking to line up delegates for what promised to be a long battle in the Democratic National Convention opening here Monday.

Ahmad Ghavam es Sultaneh, new Iranian Premier, has been Premier four times previously and each of his terms was marked by bitter disputes over domestic or foreign policies. The 77-year-old statesman, born of landed gentry, has been imprisoned on at least one occasion and forced into exile on another.
ALBANY, July 17 (AP) -- Governor Dewey today appointed a committee to help Federal and international agencies find a solution to the high-water level of Lake Ontario.

HONG KONG, July 17 -- Famine has gripped a number of districts in Hunan Province, one of China's leading rice production areas, according to a Chinese Communist dispatch reaching here today. The Hankow Yangtze Daily, a Communist party organ, said the Hunan provincial government had ordered immediate distribution of grain confiscated from landlords to cope with the "crisis."

Rae's Reward, owned by Walter S. Horne, improved his position steadily through the mile and a sixteenth to win the Bronxville Handicap, the classified race that occupied the feature spot at the Empire City meeting at Jamaica yesterday.

If it is true that a hot day calls for a cold drink, then we can expect to quaff many cold drinks in the days to come. The bad news yesterday from the Weather Bureau in Washington was that most of the East and South might expect above-normal temperatures for the next month.

LONDON, July 17 -- The rise in the stock markets was checked today by Prime Minister Churchill's warning yesterday that further economic measures "grave and far reaching" would be taken to deal with the economic situation.

On the basis of recent laboratory tests of water samples, the Health Department warned yesterday that shellfish obtained from Jamaica Bay "are contaminated and dangerous to health." The bay has a shoreline of twenty-five miles in Brooklyn and Queens.

BONN, Germany, July 27 -- A resolution recommending a deeper study of the problem of communism in order that a Christian approach may be found was adopted at the fifth conference of the International Missionary Council.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, July 17 -- A third field trial to determine if children can be protected against paralytic poliomyelitis by innoculation with a serum will be conducted next week in the Sioux City area, ravaged by one of the most serious polio epidemics in the country.

The only book published today is "Lost Hill," a novel by Dorothy Evelyn Smith that Dutton is selling at $3. The story's setting is the English moors. Mrs. Smith is the author of "O, The Brave Music" and "My Lamp is Bright."

Daily newspapers reporting to the American Newspaper Publishers Association consumed 379,943 tons of newsprint in June, compared with 365,324 tons a year before and 376,482 tons in June, 1950, the association reported yesterday. This year's consumption was an increase over June, 1951, of 4 per cent and an increase over June, 1950, of 0.9 per cent.

WINNIPEG, July 17 (AP) -- Johnny Palmer, 34-year-old professional from North Carolina, today led a par-smashing attack in the $15,000 Canadian open golf championship and wound up with a four-stroke lead at the half-way stage of the seventy-two-hole competition.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (UP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today that public utility holding companies have released control of 753 affiliates with assets of $10,311,000,000 since passage of the utility holding company law in 1935.

As the Western Powers prepare to enter into a new conference with Soviet Russia on the key issue of Germany, the Soviets themselves continue to step up a propaganda campaign which is causing increasing concern in all Western capitals. This campaign, camouflaged by propaganda for "peace" and "co-existence," is directed against the United States, now the object of Soviet vilification without precedent in history.
PARIS, July 17 -- A democratic equivalent of the Communist-led Partisans of Peace movement was launched today by Leon Jouhaux, French labor leader and winner of the Nobel prize for peace last year.

The Consolidated Edison Company, which for about a year has been pressing legal tests of the power of the Magistrates Courts to issue summonses for smoke violations, was found guilty of creating a smoke nuisance yesterday and fined $100, the maximum penalty.

The honors are pretty evenly divided in the annual midsummer furniture show opening Monday at Macy's. Not only are contemporary and traditional styles equally well represented but Macy's own designs vie with those of well-known designers and furniture makers.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 17 -- Jacob A. Malik, Soviet representative on the United Nations Security Council, today canceled his passage on the liner Nieuw Amsterdam, on which he had planned to sail Tuesday for an extended home leave. Although there was no explanation from the Soviet delegation, other delegates believed the cancellation reflected the Kremlin's feeling that an armistice in Korea might be near.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- The Wage Stabilization Board said today the Aluminum Company of America and the United Steelworkers, C. I. O., had accepted an invitation to renew negotiations Tuesday looking toward a settlement of their long contract dispute.

NEW DELHI, India, July 17 -- Despite what are regarded here as "setbacks" provoked by the United States in the Panmunjom negotiations, India is hopeful that a settlement in Korea will be reached. With that end in view, the Indian Foreign Office appears to have cast itself in the role of communications channel between Peiping, where India has unique diplomatic contacts, and London, which in turn relays Chinese proposals to Washington.

Peter Pressinger of Washington, seeded eighth, eliminated defending-champion Richard MacAtee of Flushing, seeded third, from the junior competition of the Eastern junior aid boys' tennis championships yesterday, 6 -- 4, 3 -- 6, 8 -- 6, at the West Side Club, Forest Hills, Queens.

Assets of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States increased $200,000,000, to $6,300,000,000, as of June 30, Thomas I. Parkinson, president, reported yesterday in the semi-annual statement.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 17 -- An international ring trying to beat the strategic materials blockade of Iron Curtain countries by large-scale forgery of documents has been under investigation for the past eight months, Dutch authorities disclosed today.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- If you are above average in intelligence, endowed with extraordinary eyesight, and keenly alert, Northwestern University Traffic Institute researchers would like to warn you that you are probably not a first-rate driver.

This congested city greatly needs the eight subway construction projects in Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx that the Board of Transportation has approved at a total estimated cost of $445,650,000. Present rapid-transit facilities are manifestly unable to serve even under tolerable conditions the millions of straphangers who twice daily must jam and squeeze their way into subway trains during rush hours.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 27 (UP) -- The United States and Wimbledon champion, Maureen (Little Mo) Connolly, crowding three days' play into one, swept into the semi-finals of the Women's Pennsylvania and Eastern states tennis championship today by winning three matches and taking another by default.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., July 17 (AP) -- An arbitrator-ordered 8 1/2-cent pay cut for 15,000 New Bedford-Fall River C. I. O. cotton textile workers, which is expected to set the pay pattern in Northeastern mills, also will affect A. F. L. organized plants here, a union official said today.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (UP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today authorized two railroads to construct lines to share in the huge traffic in coal that will result from the new atomic energy plant at Paducah, Ky. The I. C. C. granted the construction applications of the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad and the New York Central Railroad over the objection of the Chicago Eastern Railroad.
ST. LOUIS, July 17 -- The Giants' four-game winning streak ended tonight at Sporstman's Park as a leaderless flock of Cardinals salvaged the final contest of the three-game set, 3 to 2.

The Government's second witness stepped down from the stand in Federal court yesterday, more than eight weeks after his first testimony at the trial of fifteen Communist party leaders charged with conspiracy to advocate the violent overthrow of the Government and to organize the party for that purpose. A third witness is expected to appear today.

LONDON, July 17 -- If any of those Members of Parliament who have been saying that the British royal family should get closer to the people attended this afternoon's garden party at Buckingham Palace they must have witnessed an interesting demonstration of propinquity. They also would have gotten wet.

The world sulphur emergency is at an end, Langbourne M. Williams Jr., president of Freeport Sulphur Company, a major producer of the essential raw material, said yesterday. He reported that the needs of nearly all consumers in this country were being met and that the outlook for the future was "extremely encouraging."

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The Federal Maritime Board said today that it would conduct in the Netherlands an investigation of the cost of constructing ships there as compared with the cost of building them in American yards. The result of the inquiry may be a redetermination of the Government's share of the cost of the Independence and the Constitution, new passenger liners being operated by the American Export Lines.

CINCINNATI, July 17 -- The General Tire and Rubber Company of Akron, Ohio, has bought Crosley Motors, of Cincinnati, for an exchange of stock which would give a value of about 20 cents a share to the Crosley shares, it was announced here today.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The State Department disclosed today that it had received reports of talks between India and Communist China on a possible settlement of the Korean war, but that the United States found nothing in the discussions to give hope.

MOSCOW, July 17 -- Pravda's foreign news page, which is usually devoted entirely to the state of international affairs beyond the borders of the Soviet Union, today carried in bold, black type this headline: "Big defeat of U. S. A. footballers."
BOSTON, July 17 (UP) -- The transcript of a statement made by Bayard Peakes at Police Headquarters today follows:
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- During the week ended July 16 member bank reserves increased $9,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Two Brooklyn boys were believed to have drowned at 3 P. M. yesterday, when they slipped off a log that was carried out forty feet by a strong current in the inlet of Jamaica Bay near Paerdegat Basin, the police of the Brooklyn Avenue station reported.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- The American Zionist Council urged the Democratic convention's platform committee today to pledge the party's continued support of Israel in providing a sanctuary for homeless Jews.

Under a spread of canvas rarely seen in the port and with a liberal application of "Norwegian steam" -- the sailor's term for sweat and muscle -- the three-masted barque Statsraad Lehmkuhl sailed grandly into New York yesterday and tied up at Pier 75 Hudson River.

LONDON, July 17 (Reuters) -- Australia has so far made advance sales of 368,000 metric tons of wheat because of the new International Wheat Agreement year starting Aug. 1. Canada's advance sales total 225,090 tons, those of the United States 184,000 tons.

The intent of the money plank of the Republican party's 1952 platform was praised yesterday by Dr. Walter E. Spahr, executive vice president of the Economists' National Committee on Monetary Policy. But he criticized some of the language in the final phrasing of the plank as having "outstanding defects."

PORTLAND, Me., July 17 (AP) -- Federal Judge John D. Clifford Jr. approved a plan today for distribution of Washington Water Power Company common stock to American Power and Light Company stockholders on a share-for-share basis. Distribution will be made Aug. 21 to stockholders of record July 31.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, July 17 -- The Senate Preparedness subcommittee's report, renewing charges of cartel activity and "price gouging" by Malaya's tin producers, stirred a new wave of resentment and indignation in business and Government quarters here today. The charges were described as "completely untrue" by tin mine executives.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia held a series of strategy meetings today with the leaders in his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination and later announced that "at this moment, I would not exchange my chances with those of any other candidate."

LONDON, July 17 -- One of the most interesting personalities to be seen at the forthcoming autumn show of the Incorporated Society of London Fashion Designers here will be Lady Clark, the society's new president.

The Campbell and Kenton Counties Sanitation District No. 1 of Kentucky rescheduled yesterday the sale of $7,600,000 of revenue bonds to be held on July 28. The district rejected the only bid submitted on Wednesday.

An anniversary of considerable importance to this nation is taking place this afternoon on a grassy mound on the banks of the Brandywine Creek, near Wilmington, Del. There, in a small structure of stone, 150 years ago tomorrow, one Eleuthere Irenee du Pont de Nemours, using equipment imported from France, began making black powder.

PARIS, July 17 -- The French Communist party works for the "certain defeat" of the French Army in Indo-China, Korea and Tunisia, according to a written statement attributed to Jacques Duclos, acting leader of the French Reds, published here today.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 17 -- Misfortune piled up on the French trotting champion, Cancanniere, a 6-year-old chestnut mare owned by Mme. Pierre Bancilhon of Paris, when Trainer Jonel Chyriacos announced tonight that the racer had suffered a bowed tendon in the left front leg last night at Roosevelt Raceway.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee found only one rival for the Democratic Presidential nomination in today as he dropped by their headquarters to say hello in a continuation of his handshaking campaign that won him primary votes on the Main Streets of the country.

A fifteen-month investigation into the issuance of fraudulent licenses to unqualified drivers has resulted in the indictment of six men on charges of bribery and forgery, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan announced yesterday.
A meeting of the Democratic party's platform committee in the Conrad Hilton Hotel in Chicago this morning will be televised over Channel 4 beginning at 11 o'clock.

On his return from his recent tour Secretary Acheson was able to report that he had found tremendous friendship for and tremendous confidence in the United States in all three countries he had visited -- namely, Germany, Austria and Brazil. Such friendship and confidence, all self-serving propaganda statements to the contrary notwithstanding, can be found in most other countries as well.

After a two-month battle against the snow-bound wastes of southeastern Alaska, an expedition of eight American scientists yesterday scaled Taku Glacier, a formidable ice world that soars 6,500 feet above sea level The announcement was made here by the American Geographical Society.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- James P. McGranery, the Attorney General, authorized today a grand jury investigation of charges that an international cartel had been formed to control the world's oil market.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 17 -- With more than 100 ships tied up by a prolonged strike of the Sailors Union of the Pacific, A. F. L., West Coast shipowners were pictured today as determined to forego operating under "the rule of expediency, based on the idea that whatever happens the ships must sail."
DAYTON, Ohio, July 17 -- An Air Force spokesman said today some sixty reports of flying saucers had been received during the last two weeks. He could give no reason for the sudden increase.

EL SEGUNDO, Calif., July 17 (UP) -- A test pilot confirmed today that he had flown the Navy's new Skyrocket plane 1,238 miles an hour -- almost twice the speed of sound -- and said "we don't think this is the fastest we can go."

The annual Stadium Concerts "Italian Night" was held at Lewisohn Stadium last evening, with Alfredo Antonini conducting the Stadium Symphony Orchestra. Soloists were Jan Peerce, tenor; Herva Nelli, soprano, and Salvatore Baccaloni, bass.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 17 -- The State Department's new "clinicar," which will be shipped to Libya in ten days for the treatment of medically underprivileged persons in the desert, rolled into a municipal parking lot here today in the rear of the manufacturer's offices at 19 South Broadway and gave a demonstration of how it will work.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- An effort was made today to persuade the Democratic Governors of the nation to take the lead in drafting Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

The events which transpired at the Republican convention together with its final outcome may prove of deep significance toward shaping future world history as well as our domestic political scene. The radio and television audiences could easily perceive that the Old Guard had stacked the cards thoroughly before the convention opened.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- A shift of United States diplomatic officials got under way today with the selection of Llewellyn E. Thompson Jr., a veteran Foreign Service officer, to be Ambassador to Austria.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., July 17 -- The University of Michigan made public today the text of a letter in which six of its faculty members urged Czechoslovak educators to join in making possible an objective, scientific investigation of Communist allegations that United Nations forces were waging germ warfare in Korea.

BINGHAMTON, N. Y., July 17 (AP) -- The defending champion, Barbara Bruning, and a five-time winner, Mrs. Ruth Torgerson, advanced today to the semi-finals of the New York State women's amateur golf tourney -- but only after 1-up victories.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., July 17 -- Maj. Gen. Arthur A. Thomas, commanding officer of the Eastern Air Procurement District, awarded today the third contract for the William A. Betterly, Inc., plant from the United States Air Force. His visit recognized the achievements of the company workers -- all disabled veterans.

Grants by the New York State Association for Crippled Children to twenty treatment and training centers were announced yesterday by Dr. J. Emerson Noll, president of the association. The funds were raised through its annual Easter Seal Appeal.
American cities are beginning to solve the financial problems encountered in meeting the urgent demand for more adequate off-street parking facilities.

WESTPORT, Conn., July 17 -- A "Yankee Doodle Fair," held last week-end by the Westport Woman's Club to raise money for community projects, had its aftermath today when a warrant was served charging the club with operating a lottery and obtaining money under false pretenses.

The resignation of Premier Mossadegh of Iran at this stage will be no loss to his country. He is reported to have stepped out because the Shah refused to give him the concurrent posts of War Minister and Premier and at the same time confirm his demand for six months of dictatorial powers.

A 29-year-old mentally twisted author of an electronic theory that nobody would take seriously was arrested yesterday as the admitted killer of 18-year-old Eileen Fahey. The young man, Bayard Peakes, had been picked up in Boston by New York detectives who had been on his trail since Tuesday, the day after the girl was shot in her ninth-floor office at Columbia University.

New York's landlubbers will get their chance today to honor the officers and crew of the liner United States, which entered the harbor last Tuesday with the Atlantic speed record, made on her maiden round-trip voyage.

Officials of three up-state communities offered land and facilities yesterday for a new home for Champlain College, a four-year co-educational liberal arts institution if the Air Force takes over the college's quarters at Plattsburg, N. Y.

A pair of rapid-fire ninth-inning home runs gave New York's largest baseball gathering of the year, a crowd of 51,114, a couple of last-minute thrills last night as the Yankees and Indians brought their marathon series to a close with an even split of the twilight-night double-headers.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- President Truman was without fever today for the first time since he became ill of a "slight virus infection" last Sunday. He had spent a restful first night in the Presidential suite at the Army's Walter Reed Hospital and did considerable work today.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- The Political Action Committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations takes a skeptical view of the statement of Senator Richard B. Russell, Democrat of Georgia, that he favors repeal of the Taft-Hartley Law.
Moderate to low volume and generally mixed price movements characterized commodity futures markets here yesterday.
William W. Howard, a vice president of R. K. O. Theatres Company, has been appointed head of the company's operations.
LONDON, July 17 -- The nomination of Mr. Ghavam as Premier of Iran was considered a hopeful though by no means conclusive omen in London diplomatic circles.

Hearings were started yesterday in Surrogate's Court to determine the heirs to the estates of the recluse Collyer brothers who were found dead after a search of their refuse - cluttered brownstone home at 2078 Fifth Avenue, in March, 1947.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- Amid a cacophony of sound and an array of heroic-size photographs, Senator Estes Kefauver unfurled himself to Democratic conventioneers today in a dozen manifestations ranging from music to match books.
TOKYO, Friday, July 18 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,314, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Friday, Korea time:

TOKYO, Friday, July 18 -- The United Nations and Communist armistice delegations met for forty-one minutes in their tent at Panmunjom today and then adjourned until tomorrow without an announcement of developments in what, according to some speculation, might have proved a crucial session in the long-drawn-out truce negotiations.
Most delegates from Greater New York will leave Sunday for the Democratic National Convention, which begins Monday in Chicago, pledged to support Averell Harriman, Director for Mutual Security.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- President Truman today signed two bills calling for the creation of a Delaware River Port Authority to provide for the development of he Philadelphia-Camden port area.
Three players equaled par to tie for medal honors in the Metropolitan Golf Association's junior championship yesterday at the North Hills Golf Club, Douglaston.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- A study of potential markets for goods and services to keep the American economy at high levels after defense goals have been reached was ordered today by Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The Office of Price Stabilization has won the largest share of funds in a division of the reduced appropriations voted by Congress for the economic stabilization agencies.

The Board of Education will start construction this year on the city's first new high school in ten years -- a building that will be shaped like a giant banjo and, according to school officials and architects, will mark a radical departure from traditional school design.

THE quarterlies that bloom, often unseen, on our college and university campuses give us consistently some of our best and some of our worst prose and poetry. Many esteemed writers have been nourished and encouraged by publication in the pages of these reviews. At the same time, often in the same issue, they have cheerfully given space to awkwardly written articles of little interest, stories of no merit and foolish non-poetry.
PARIS, July 17 -- European diplomats and foreign affairs specialists, who have now studied the foreign policy plank in the Republican platform, are puzzled by it.

TRENTON, July 17 -- The New Jersey Highway Authority made an exclusive offering of $10,000,000 of parkway revenue notes today to state banks and trust companies as an initial step in constructing the Garden State Parkway as a toll route.

Thirty thousand delegates and their families scattered yesterday for their homes throughout the country as the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks closed its five-day convention with a colorful ceremony installing new officers.

BOSTON, July 17 (AP) -- An effective ninth-inning relief performance by Ray Scarborough plus Sammy White's seventh homer and George Kell's run-producing two-bagger today enabled the Red Sox to sweep a three-game series from the White Sox with a 2-1 victory.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 18 -- Foreign Minister Moshe Sharett said today that Israel was seeking military aid from the United States within the framework of the Mutual Security Act but Washington had not yet replied.
NEWARK, July 18 -- An 8-year-old safecracker was among four boys responsible for at least nine burglaries in the last month, Deputy Chief Hugh A. O'Gorman announced today.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- President Truman is planning to leave Walter Reed Hospital tomorrow morning and return to the White House. For the second day he was without fever and the virus infection that struck him last Sunday apparently had cleared up.

Plans for the erection of a one-story industrial building in Astoria, Queens, were announced in connection with the sale by H. Weissner of a vacant plot containing 16,500 square feet between Twentieth and Twenty-first Streets, near Steinway Street, to A. Winig.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (UP) -- President Truman has signed a bill granting permanent United States residence to a Yugoslavian physician who discovered the controversial drug "krebiozen."

The autobiography of .ugustu John, the portrait lainter, will be published Sept. S by Pellegf-ini Cudahy, entitled "Chiaroscuro." The painter, in answer to his publisher's author questionnaire wrote, I"I decided to write my own life, rather than leave it to some ignorant, prejudiced, or irresponmble iperson."

Twelve policemen, scheduled for departmental trial Tuesday on charges of accepting gifts from bookmaker Harry Gross, obtained in Supreme Court yesterday an order requiring Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan to show cause Monday why their trial should not be halted and they be restored to duty.

The Questionnaire Handicap at $25,000 added will occupy the feature spot on the racing program of the Empire City Raving Association today. The card will be presented at the Jamaica track, and will be the final one of the six-day meeting of the Empire City organization.

After General Dwight D. Eisenhower's announcement yesterday that he would address the American Legion's thirty-fourth national convention here next month, Legion officials disclosed further details on speakers and activities.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- More than a quarter of a million persons and almost 2,000 planes will commence tomorrow the first continental air defense exercise in history.
SAIGON, Indo-China, July 18 (UP) -- Violent fighting flared tonight at several points along the French-Vietnamese defense perimeter in south Vietnam.
MOSCOW, July 18 (AP) -- The Soviet press announced today that Premier Joseph Stalin had met with Pietro Nenni, leader of Italy's left-wing Socialists who are closely linked with the Communist party.

Bayard Pfundtner Peakes, admitted slayer of 18-year-old Eileen Fahey, lost his air of remorseless detachment for the first time yesterday when Magistrate Thomas H. Cullen Jr. ordered him to Bellevue Hospital for psychiatric examination.

Parents who hold the point of view that children's toys should be attractive, safe, sturdy, educational and, at the same time, fun to play with, will be able -- starting Monday -- to find a vast array of just what they are looking for at the new headquarters of the Childcraft Equipment Company at 155 East Twenty-third Street.

CHICAGO, Saturday, July 19 -- Averell Harriman, who seeks the Democratic nomination for President as a "four-square" supporter of the New and Fair Deals, today sought to form a Northern coalition, probably with help of supporters of Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee, also a candidate for the nomination.

CHICAGO, July 18 -- More frequent political conventions to enable mid-term Democratic candidates for Congress to campaign on a "current national platform" were proposed today in a draft resolution prepared for submission to the Democratic National Convention that opens here Monday.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 18 -- Premier Ahmad Ghavam, chosen yesterday evening to form a new Iranian Government to succeed that of Dr. Mohammed Mossadegh, held out, in a long declaration today hope for a settlement of the conflict that has paralyzed the Iranian oil industry for more than a year.

I don't know why you made so much in your editorial page of the opening of the new Battery Park. It is twelve years since the old park was closed. People who knew it as of old may have moved away or forgotten what the old one was like: the pleasant walks, shady trees and air of conviviality.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 18 -- A former chief censor of the Eighth Army in Korea was charged today with having submitted a book manuscript about military subjects to a publisher without having obtained clearance required by the Department of the Army.
CHICAGO, July 15 (AP) -- Democratic National Convention headquarters said today that what it had announced as the tentative program for the convention would be the official program.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 18 -- After two years of field tests and exhaustive studies, six traffic experts from five continents today unanimously approved a draft convention designed to increase the safety and convenience of road traffic throughout the world.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- The National Production Authority today accused the Wooldridge Manufacturing Company of Sunnyvale, Calif., of selling steel in the black market. A hearing will be held in California on the charges.
DENVER, July 18 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower will address the American Legion national convention at Madison Square Garden in New York on Aug. 25.

Settlement of a strike against the National Broadcasting Company and the Columbia Broadcasting System by the Radio Writers Guild, an affiliate of the Authors League of America, was announced last night by representatives of the strikers and officials of the two networks.

CHICAGO, July 18 -- Vice President Alben W. Barkley arrived in Chicago today in a gathering Barkley-for-President movement of genuine proportions that was being strongly pressed by old and powerful Democratic politicians.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 18 (AP) -- The International Olympic Committee today postponed until July 28 action on recognizing East Germany. West Germany will take part in the games which open here tomorrow. Since the games end Aug. 3, East Germany would have little chance to compete.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, July 19 (AP) -- Allied infantrymen today launched an attack across the muddy slopes of "Old Baldy" in a renewed effort to drive a Chinese Communist battalion from its foothold on the strategic western front position, just west of Chorwon.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 18 -- Dr. Nathan P. Feinsinger, in what was described here as his final address as chairman of the Wage Stabilization Board, told the Commonwealth Club today that except for the steel strike no continuing agency ever had had so successful a record in settling labor disputes as the board possessed.

After an ownership of three years, the Theilest Realty Corporation has resold to Max Feinblum and Marion Grodsky for investment the six-story apartment house at 875 West 181st Street occupying the blockfront from Haven Avenue to Riverside Drive.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 18 (UP) -- Maureen Connolly, United States and Wimbledon champion from San Diego, Calif., gained the final round of the women's Pennsylvania and Eastern States tennis championship today in defense of a title she has won here the past two years.
PHILADELPHIA, July 18 (UP) -- Art Houtteman, a thirteen-game loser, scored his first victory since May 14 tonight as the Tigers defeated the Athletics, 2 -- 1, with the help of Walt Dropo's home run.

The Alcoa Steamship Company, Inc. added yesterday another link to its chain of steamship services between the United States and the Caribbean area with the departure of the Alcoa Roamer to San Juan Puerto Rico.

LONDON, July 18 -- Uncertainty created by Prime Minister Churchill's reference to "grave and far-reaching" economic measures to be taken by the Government continued to hold the stock markets in check today. Prices fell further, and although week-end leveling of the books produced a mild temporary rally most of the markets closed dull.

BERLIN, July 18 -- The line between the East and the West in this divided city was sharpened today as the three Western Allies announced they were increasing their roving jeep patrols in the Western sectors.

TAMPA, Fla., July 18 -- The close of the fourth round of the open championship of the United States Chess Federation at the Hotel Floridan today found the United States champion, Larry Evans of New York, alone in first place. The undefeated City College student attained a score of 4 -- 0 by beating Carl Burger of Columbia University in fifty-two moves.

To the Barbecue Bill in the family, whose week-ends are devoted to cutting culinary capers outdoors, the thought of preparing a young turkey may not have occurred. Traditionally, that bird has been considered too large for a family barbecue.

Eight years ago both parties also held their conventions in Chicago. In this brief period they bring new evidence of the contrast between the speed, vision and boldness in the technical, scientific field and the snailishness with which political leadership is meeting the international dangers to peace and freedom this involves.

The Liberal party put up M. Maldwin Fertig, a lifelong Democrat, yesterday as its candidate for Surrogate in Bronx County in an attempt to "crack" the Bronx County Democratic organization that has been under the undis uted leadership of Edward J. Flynn, Democratic National Committeeman, since 1922.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- President Truman is expected to act early next week to seize certain steel mills capable of producing combat materials needed in Korea.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, July 12 -- Across Western Europe, in a broad arc ranging from north Norway 1,500 miles to the heel of Italy, nearly 50,000 engineers and workmen in the North Atlantic Treaty countries are hurrying to finish an imposing network of airbases for the defense of the free world.

How antiques collectors are made -- their beginnings, their growth and the outcome of their devotion to their special interests -- is a favorite topic for those in the field, particularly dealers who, in many instances, play an important role in the making of a collector.
ALEXANDRIA, La., July 18 (UP) -- Louisiana followed the lead of Virginia today and cooled toward the candidacy of Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., July 18 -- Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer shot a 39, 37--76 to win low gross honors in the July tournament of the Tri-County Golf Association at Quaker Ridge today. It was the second triumph for the Century player, who had won the June event at Greenwich, Conn.

BOSTON, July 18 (UP) -- The Red Sox, pounding out eight doubles in thirteen hits, pummeled the Indians 9 to 2, before 34,477 Fenway Park fans tonight to take a firmer grip on second place in the American League pennant race.

LONDON, July 18 -- A simple but entirely novel explanation of the significance and layout of the pyramids and tombs of ancient Egypt has been put before the Egypt Exporation Society here by Dr. Herbert Ricke, the scientific director of the Swiss Institute for Egyptian Archaeology at Cairo.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., July 18 (UP) -- State health officers said today that 3,000 gallons of cyanide dumped by mistake into the Wabash River have now become harmless through dilution. The only casualties, apparently, were thousands of fish killed by the poison.

Distributors of new securities made further progress this week in moving unsold merchandise into the hands of investors. The prospects at the moment are for underwriters to head into the traditionally inactive weeks of mid-summer with only a nominal amount of undistributed securities on hand, and with a calendar of new investment supply sizably smaller than that of the spring and early summer.
CHICAGO, July 18 -- Leo Durocher faced a moderate-sized casualty list today as his Giants neared the end of their third swing through the West.

The Third World Conference on Faith and Order, an interdenominational gathering scheduled to be held in Lund, Sweden, Aug. 15-28, will be "previewed" tomorrow in a special service at Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway and Wall Street.

Six traffic accidents occurred within a three-mile stretch on Grand Central Parkway, Jamaica, Queens, during a twenty-minute downpour yesterday afternoon, and a hitchhiker was killed on Cross Island Parkway in near-by Bayside an hour later.
HOLLYWOOD, July 18 (UP) -- Mary Astor's so-called "purple" diary, the key to a court trial sixteen years ago, has been destroyed on court orders.

The claim in your editorial "The Old Guards," on July 17, that the only course that can insure General Eisenhower's victory is to follow the course indicated by his success at Chicago, i. e., the internationalist, liberal line, is at sharp variance with a preponderant weight of evidence.

A claim for $1,000,000 was filed against the city yesterday charging responsibility for conditions that allegedly led to the "wrongful death" of a mother and her three children in a fire June 18 in a tenement at 1101 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The problem of how to eat spaghetti has been solved by a Canadian inventor. Up to now, there have been several schools of spaghetti-eating in this country: adherents of one roll it around a fork held in the bowl of a large spoon; others roll it freehand, now and then soiling a cuff, and some just give up and cut the spaghetti into short bundles.

BINGHAMTON, N. Y., July 18 (AP) -- The defending champion, Barbara Bruning, today played the best golf of the women's state amateur golf tournament to defeat Mrs. Virginia Allen of Syracuse, 5 and 4, and move into the final round.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Difficulties encountered in finding persons willing to serve on the new Wage Stabilization Board threatened today to force the Administration to reduce the board's size from its present number of eighteen to nine.

TAIPEI, Formosa, July 18 (AP) -- President Chiang Kai-shek of Nationalist China said today he did not think a positive step against Communist China such as a blockade of the Chinese coast would provoke another world war.

WINNIPEG, Man., July 18 (AP) -- Johnny Palmer of Badin, N. C., shooting the three keenest consecutive rounds in the forty-three-year history of the Canadian open golf championship, took a commanding eight-stroke lead today in the $15,000 tournament.

ONE of the places in the metropolitan area that is sure to have no surf whatever will be the locale of a surfcasting tournament on Sunday, July 27. It is Flushing Meadow Park. The event will be the annual New York State distance casting championships.

Fatigued by their consecutive double-headers against the Indians, the Yankees took the shortest way home against the White Sox yesterday. Hank Bauer slammed a three-run homer in the third and Gene Woodling solved Southpaw Chuck Stobbs for a two-run blast in the fourth as Rookie Tom Gorman and Johnny Sain pitched the league-leaders to a 6-3 victory before 7,618 fans at the Stadium.

Qualification records of 150 civil service-exempt city jobholders have been made available to the Citizens Budget Commission in response to a court order, Michael A. Castaldi, acting corporation counsel, disclosed yesterday.
BUENOS AIRES, Saturday, July 19 (UP) -- A moderate, "slight improvement" in the condition of Eva Peron, Argentina's ailing first lady, was announced early today.

Today the Olympic Stadium near Helsinki will witness a dramatic and poignant scene. Finland should have had the Olympic Games twelve years ago. She did not, for reasons painful to remember. As has too often been the case since the modern revival of the games, war intervened.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- President Truman approved today the Social Security bill increasing old age and survivor insurance payments to more than 4,500,000 persons and widening other benefits of the Federal Social Security System. In doing so he derided the Republicans in Congress and the American Medical Association.

Long Island Sound from shore to shore is expected to be the scene today of the largest yachting gathering of the summer. It will be the opening of the fifty-fourth Race Week at the Larchmont Yacht Club.
There can be no serious disagreement with most of the points made in your editorial on inter-American relations.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 18 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer today announced the purchase of two original stories for filming, "George" and "Trooper Hook." The former, which is by John Shelton and Paul C. Ross, is a comedy with a New York background, which will bring to the screen another remarkable animal, a singing dog.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- The Bureau of Mines issued a preliminary report today on a proposed hundred-mile-long tunnel for the drainage of anthracite mine water in Pennsylvania.
The State Department's right to withhold reasons for refusing passports was condemned yesterday as a violation of the Bill of Rights and the Constitution.
LONDON, July 18 -- In this town a Member of Parliament earns about the same as a messenger or typist in Washington -- that is 1,000 or $2,800 a year.

HONG KONG, July 18 -- A new forced labor decree giving China's public security bureaus administrative power to put "historical counter-revolutionaries" under control for "ideological education" and "reform by labor" was promulgated yesterday by the Peiping Government.

Heavy construction contract awards reported in the week ended Monday amounted to $295,779,000 or 12 per cent above the average week to date this year, Engineering News-Record and The Construction Daily report.
VIENNA, July 18 (AP) -- Over the protests of international Jewish leaders, the Austrian parliament tonight adopted three laws restoring property and civil rights to 34,000 former Nazis.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday, with active months 11 to 17 points higher than on Thursday.

The Montreal Stock Exchange and Curb Market has followed the lead of the New York Stock Exchange in eliminating Saturday sessions throughout the year and extending trading hours to 3:30 o'clock daily Monday through Friday starting Sept. 29.

Leon Jouhaux, veteran French labor leader, is one of those who won't let the Communists drag a magnificent old word in the mire without a protest. The word is peace. For his devotion to that cause M. Jouhaux last year received a Nobel Prize. He resents the more the so-called Partisans of Peace movement, by which Moscow works for disarmament in all countries except Russia and those already dominated by Russia.

PARIS, July 18 -- As a result of the reported failure of negotiators to reach an agreement on the number of "dubbed in" American films France would allow in for the fiscal year beginning July 1, the Cabinet decided unilaterally today to set the total of foreign films that may be shown with French voices "dubbed in" at 138.

CHICAGO, July 18 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, arrived today to start off the work of the C. I. O. Political Action Committee at the Democratic convention but refused to name his favorite candidate.
CHICAGO, July 18 -- Two women who, at the moment, have some prospect of achieving unofficial positions in the White House engaged in brief public speculation on the matter at news conferences today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 18 (AP) -- Robert C. (Bobby) Shantz was on the official records today as the smallest player in major league baseball. The little pitcher for the Athletics was placed on the scales before tonight's game with the Tigers to satisfy once and for all the mystery of his height and weight.

PARIS, July 18 -- United States officials have already agreed upon defense production orders to be placed in France in the fiscal year that began July 1. The cost is between $140,000,000 and $170,000,000. This represents only a part of the "offshore purchase" program for France for the current fiscal year.

CHICAGO, July 18 -- The Secretary of Agriculture, Charles F. Brannan, target of the country's major farm organizations, drew high praise today from Representative Harold D. Cooley, chairman of the House Agriculture Committee, and James G. Patton, president of the national farmers union.

UNION, N. J., July 18 -- Permits for nearly 150 more one-family dwellings than were issued during the same period last year were recorded here during the first six months of 1952, Building Inspector Robert F. Williams revealed today. The total value of the homes was nearly $1,000,000 more than the figure for 1951, he said.

CHICAGO, July 18 (AP) -- Eleven of the nation's top 3-year-olds will charge from the starting gate in the $151,450 Arlington Classic tomorrow to scramble for $106,375, richest first prize in racing history for 3-year-olds.

Frank Costello, the gambler, staved off yesterday the beginning of a jail sentence of eighteen months. He filed a motion for reargument of an appeal from the contempt conviction incurred in his refusal to answer questions before the Senate Crime Investigating Committee in March, 1951.

The cumulative effects of the steel strike struck the stock market yesterday and produced the widest losses since early June and dropped the price average to the lowest level in a week. Despite the severe losses in some key issues in relation to volume, pressure never attained major proportions. It was more the lack of buying than selling that gave the list such a heavy appearance.

Two teen-age boys who thought it would be cowardly to shoot a man sitting on a bench, but who agreed that a stroller with his back to them was fair game, were charged with homicide yesterday in the slaying of Samuel Bernard London, Brooklyn graduate rabbinical student, in McCarren Park on the night of June 26.

The Montana Power Company, in its report yesterday for the twelve months ended with May, showed its net income at $7,068,074, equal to $2.46 a common share, against $7,093,604 or $2.47 a share earned in the preceding twelve months.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- Manager Marty Marion of St. Louis used twenty-two players in a losing cause tonight as the Senators defeated the Browns, 6 -- 5, on a fifteen-hit attack.
Pollution control and the degree of treatment afforded sewage from Westchester County is unsatisfactory and must be improved, the Interstate Sanitation Commission said yesterday.

Two unemployed hoodlums were captured feigning sleep in a double bed yesterday a few minutes after they had held up a Brooklyn jewelry store, the police reported. They were pulled out from under a large sheet fully clothed and the few hundred dollars' worth of loot they allegedly had stolen lay under the bed.
Charles Adler Jr., aviation safety expert who has given the rights of many of his patented devices to the Government for public use, announced several new inventions yesterday.

QUEBEC, July 18 -- American visitors to Quebec Province had their cars damaged during a post-election melee in Levis, opposite this city. Crowds on Wednesday night defied firemen with hoses and heaved eggs and tomatoes at the mayor and hurled stones and bricks through windshields and plate-glass windows.

Picketing an employer in an economic dispute is legal and defensible as a pressure tactic. But it is illegal for a union to picket in order to compel an employer to bargain with it if another labor organization has been certified as the representative of the employes. Despite this, however, some local unions engaged in jurisdictional disputes have continued the picketing practice, to the discomfiture of their rivals, to say nothing of the employers.

YONKERS, July 18 -- The new Westchester Citizens Transportation Company is slated to take over the Yonkers Railroad, a trolley system with nine routes, from the Third Avenue Transit Corporation on Aug. 1. The new operator gradually will substitute buses for trolley cars.
Directors of Colonial Airlines, Inc., accepted yesterday the terms of a merger proposed by Eastern Airlines, Inc. The offer is subject to approval by stockholders of both companies.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 18 -- The little nation that paid its debt and stood unafraid once again commands the applause of the world. In Finland's capital city of 400,000 persons will be held the biggest of all Olympic Games, opening tomorrow with a record entry of 5,870 athletes gathered from seventy nations and with Soviet Russia a participant for the first time.
NEWPORT NEWS, Va., July 18 (AP) -- A Government employe and two New York shipping companies were indicted in Federal Court here today on thirty-one counts of bribery and conspiracy.

The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., announced yesterday that its directors are considering a plan for raising additional funds for expansion and improvement through the sale of capital stock to present shareholders. The company says it is contemplated to offer one new share for each ten held.

The Kings County Rackets Grand Jury asked Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz yesterday whether it could consider the indictment of Mrs. Walter J. Monaghan, wife of a former policeman, for criminal contempt because she had not appeared before that body as a witness Judge Leibowitz said he would have a decision ready Monday morning.

CHICAGO, Saturday, July 19 -- A Democratic National Committee Subcommittee on Credentials voted early today to seat two contested anti-Administration delegations from Texas and Mississippi after party leaders in those states had made qualified party loyalty pledges.

LITTLE SILVER, N. J., July 18 (AP) -- A boiler exploded in the locomotive of a Pennsylvania Railroad commuter train tonight, injuring two trainmen and causing delays of about forty-five minutes on shore lines.

The American Automobile Association has come up with what looks like the unlikeliest conclusion of the year -- that the average American is driving his car less and less every year. They have the statistics though -- 9,020 miles per average car in 1951, 9,030 in 1950 and so on steadily upward to 9,942 in 1946.

The Atlantic Division, Army Corps of Engineers, has received a Government appropriation of $410,000 to continue its participation in a survey of the natural resources of the New England States and New York as a member of the New England-New York Interagency Committee.
WILMINGTON, Del., July 18 -- E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. observed its 150th anniversary today with ceremonies at the site of the company's first mill on the west bank of Brandywine Creek near here.

Commodity futures on the local exchanges were mostly lower in quiet trading yesterday. Generally, the near positions held firm, with widest declines in the distant months. Cocoa futures were in heavy supply and dropped 65 to 75 points on transactions of 191 lots.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of interest to homemakers.

CINCINNATI, July 18 (AP) -- The Phillies blew a four-run first-inning lead, but rallied with three in the ninth to deal the Reds their fifth straight setback, 7 -- 5. Both starters, Harry Perkowski of the Reds and Howie Fox of the Phils, failed to survive the free-swinging first frame.

As a cure for the recurring fits of nostalgia to which old inhabitants of this island are subject in the midst of our modern metropolis a chronic sufferer from that malady recommends a ride on a Third Avenue bus.

TOKYO, Saturday, July 19 -- United Nations and Communist negotiators met again at Panmunjom today for twenty-nine minutes and adjourned without announcement, but leaving little apparent hope for a quick settlement of the prisoner-of-war exchange issue, the last major barrier in the path of an armistice in Korea.

OSSINING, N. Y., July 18 -- Two Maryknoll Fathers who were forced by the Communists to leave China have been assigned to posts in New York, the Catholic Foreign Mission Society of American announced here today.

Establishment of a Brazilian subsidiary by Charles Pfizer Co., Brooklyn, chemical and pharmaceutical house, was announced yesterday. The new organization is known as Pfizer Inter-American, S. A. It will be a manufacturing subsidiary with a plant in Sao Paulo and headquarters in Rio de Janeiro, and will process and distribute antibiotics and other pharmaceuticals.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., July 18 -- The New York State Federation of Labor made public here today a resolution putting the federation on record as favoring the Panther Mountain reservoir project and declaring it to be in the best interests of the public and of specific benefit to workers and employers of the Black River Valley in upstate New York.

BONN, Germany, July 18 -- John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner, and Chancellor Konrad Adenauer signed today an agreement under the Fulbright Act of 1946 providing for the extension of the mutual exchange program to West Germany and the United States.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 18 -- United Nations members will be called on to contribute $25,000,000 toward the world organization's technical assistance program for 1953 under a resolution adopted today. The 1952 budget is $20,000,000.

As the bulk of delegates from New York and New Jersey prepared to leave today and tomorrow for the Democratic National Convention at Chicago, Averell Harriman, New York's favorite son candidate for the party's Presidential nomination, and Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee appeared to be their favorites.
TOKYO, Saturday, July 19 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,315, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Saturday, Korea time:

A flash fire swept the 4,929-ton freighter Black Gull sixty-five miles southeast of Montauk Point, L. I., last night, forcing nine passengers and forty-two crewmen to abandon the vessel without lifeboats.
CHICAGO, July 18 -- Choppy fluctuations were the rule in the grain trade today. An easy turn in all pits early was followed by a rally that ran into free selling, with prices reacting later.

Trading in German dollar bonds in the United States is still at least six months off, according to a conference which United States Government officials have just held with representatives of the financial community.

It is to be hoped that the decision of Magistrate Ohringer finding the Consolidated Edison Company and Hotel Pierre guilty of violating smoke-control regulations and levying fines of $100 and $50, respectively, will definitely establish the obligation of large corporations as well as owners of incinerators to live up to the city's smoke-abatement laws.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The United States has decided to send only non-voting observers to the forthcoming Toronto meeting of the International Red Cross in expectation of a major political and propaganda onslaught by the Soviet Union and its Communist satellites.

Gross sales and operating revenues of Loew's, Inc., for the twelve and forty weeks ended on June 5 showed increases over the corresponding periods of last year, but earnings declined, according to the report to be issued to stockholders today.

Women from 18 to 35 years old are superior to men in learning how to drive an automobile, but after that age the men take the lead. Aptitude on the distaff side then declines for a quarter of a century, but after passing the age of 60 the women perk up again. They outpace men for five years, then go into a final slump.

PITTSBURGH, July 18 -- The Pirates, pugnacious against the Phils yesterday, were the same soft touch for the Dodgers tonight. The Brooks beat them, 6 -- 2, for the eleventh straight time this season without a loss and attained their longest lead over the second-place Giants, six and a half games.
CHICAGO, July 18 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois arrived in Chicago today and immediately took one more long step toward eliminating himself from the Democratic Presidential nomination race.

NEW DELHI, India, July 18 -- The Communist Chinese Government, using India as a sounding board, had broached a new basis for a Korean truce at Panmunjom a few days before United Nations planes bombed the Yalu River power plants, according to informed sources here.

Demand for work clothing and dungarees has outstripped the industry's ability to produce them in time for the fall season, it was learned yesterday. A late start in laying down orders for fabrics has shortened the manufacturing period, with the result that production has fallen behind that of a year ago.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- President Truman today signed a bill passed by the Eighty-second Congress to continue the present price support program for six basic agricultural commodities through 1954. Final action on the measure was taken by the Senate and the House on July 5.

CHICAGO, July 18 -- News that European politicians are puzzled by the contradiction between the denunciation of the Truman foreign policy in the Republican platform and General Eisenhower's frequently expressed support of that policy falls pleasantly on the ears of the committee engaged in drafting the Democratic party platform.

Undeterred by Soviet provocations, neutral but independent and self-respecting Sweden is now holding the usual summer maneuvers with naval, air and coast guard forces in and over the international waters of the Baltic Sea. These are the waters over which the Soviets have recently shot down two Swedish planes and one American and in which they have pursued and seized Swedish, Danish and Finnish fishing vessels.

" Glory Alley," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer drama with Ralph Meeker, Leslie Caron, Kurt Kasznar, Gilbert Roland and John McIntire, has been scheduled to have its local premiere on Tuesday, July 29, at Loew's State Theatre, according to an announcement yesterday by the company.
CHICAGO, July 18 -- The Democratic Presidential sweepstakes was thrown into an overnight furor by the appearance of a new mystery candidate. His name was Jones.

TOLEDO, Ohio, July 18 -- Martin G. Smith, co-owner of a group of Toledo theatres and past president for twenty-five years of the Independent Theatre Owners of Ohio, submitted to voluntary arrest today as the first step toward a friendly court test of Ohio's movie censorship laws.

LONDON, July 18 -- Mayors throughout Britain have been asked to organize house-to-house canvassing teams to recruit volunteers for civil defense against atomic air raids, the Home Secretary, Sir David Maxwell-Fyfe, disclosed in the House of Commons today.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- Major bondholders of the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company agreed today to a public hearing on the validity of the 1951 balloting on a Missouri Pacific reorganization plan.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., July 18 -- Milton (Babe) Lichardus became the new open champion of New Jersey by winning the thirty-second annual tournament over then rugged Plainfield Country Club course with a score of 294 today.

ST. LOUIS, July 18 (AP) -- Billy Johnson's first 1952 home run, a grand slam smash in the fifth inning, enabled Harry (The Cat) Brecheen to coast to his fifth straight victory tonight as the Cardinals trimmed the Braves, 7 to 2.

LONDON, July 18 -- Following its gains in local elections in the spring, the Labor party won a significant victory yesterday in a by-election for Parliament at Dundee, Scotland. The ballots were counted today.

The case of Mrs. Helen A. Judge, 35-year-old real estate saleswoman, who was arrested Thursday night in Queens on a charge of simple assault for slapping a motorcycle patrolman, was put over yesterday to Aug. 19, after she had criticized the Police Department in Flushing Magistrate's Court.

HEWLETT HARBOR, L. I., July 18 -- Mrs. G. F. Boyle and Mrs. W. C. Huebner of Wykagyl carded 36, 35 -- 71 with the help of an 85 per cent handicap allowance to win the low net prize in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tournament at the Seawane Harbor Club today.
" Paint Your Wagon," the musical play at the Shubert Theatre, will end its run tonight after 289 performances.

TOKYO, July 18 (AP) -- The Foreign Office said today the United States, Britain, Canada, France and Japan would confer late this month in Washington on Far Eastern export controls -- policies affecting mainly Red China.

CHICAGO, July 18 -- The civil rights plank of the Democratic platform for 1952, with its emphasis on fighting discrimination in employment, appeared tonight to be taking a place ahead of such matters as foreign policy, national defense, inflation and the farm vote that played a vital role in the party victroy of 1948.

Self-regulation on the part of American business irks the Kremlin state worshippers no end because it so often works. The latest group to organize itself to end excursions down the primrose path of unethical practices is travel agents.

A summer shower turned lower Broadway into a stifling steam bath yesterday as the master and some of the crew of the record-breaking liner United States bravely weathered a storm of sodden ticker tape and wet paper streamers, public accolade for their setting a new Atlantic speed mark.

HAVANA, July 18 -- The Cuban Cabinet, after a night-long session, announced today its decision to publish a call for bids for the purchase of the British-owned United Railways of Havana. A committee of Cabinet members headed by the Minister of Communications, Pablo Carrera Justiz, has been appointed to draft and publish a call in London, Paris, New York and in Cuban newspapers.

PARIS, July 18 -- Burglars who knew exactly what they wanted and exactly where to find it early this morning stole two paintings -- a Rubens and a Raphael -- valued at about $140,000 from the historic Chateau de Dampierre of the Duke de Luynes, twenty miles outside Paris.

An unusual aftermath to a deadlocked jury trial in General Sessions was revealed yesterday when a juror, accused of "willfully and deliberately violating the admonitions of the court," was ruled guilty of contempt and sentenced to ten days.

A group of new room settings displaying some well selected groups of furniture, ranging in style from simple early American to examples of the more sophisticated modern, will go on view Monday at Bamberger's Newark.
CHICAGO, July 18 -- Senator Robert S. Kerr of Oklahoma said today he could not be bound by any Democratic convention mandate impinging on Senate prerogatives.

A four-story building with thirty-eight apartments at 546 Bergen Avenue, Jersey City, N. J., has been sold by the Elite Realty Company to Bergen Associates. The George J. Wolf Realty Company was the broker. Burke, Sheridan Hourigan, lawyers, acted for the sellers, and Clifford I. Odwak and Harry Cooper represented the buyers.
Three New Jersey representatives and one from Westchester gained the semi-finals of the Metropolitan Golf Association's junior championship at the North Hills Golf Club, Douglaston, yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- President Truman signed today the so-called long-range shipping bill setting up a broader system of ship construction subsidies and containing other provisions designed to strengthen this country's merchant marine.

NEW DELHI, India, July 18 -- Parliament was thrown into an uproar today when Communists repeatedly interrupted a debate on the extension of the preventive detention bill under which hundreds of their members have been imprisoned.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, July 18 -- Legislation that will provide an opportunity for a majority of the 2,000,000 Chinese inhabitants of the Malayan Federation to become citizens is in the process of being approved by the states and territories that comprise the Federation.

Miss Jean Liedloff, a tall, tanned, green-eyed blonde who spent seven months digging diamonds out of Venezuelan river beds, is back in New York with a pet monkey, the skin of a leopard she shot, and an Indian canoe paddle among her souvenirs -- but wearing no diamonds. Yesterday, in fact, she was wearing rhinestone buttons on her dress.

CHICAGO, July 18 -- A group of airline pilots who are acting, they reported, for thousands of fellow airmen, filed a petition today for a stay of execution and a superceding order from the ruling last week of Federal Judge Walter J. LaBuy, who restored David L. Behncke as president of the A. F. L. Air Line Pilots Association.
A professional check casher and a truck driver were robbed yesterday of a total of $6,500 in two separate hold-ups in Brooklyn. Both said that the armed thugs were in their twenties.

MADRID, July 18 -- The Spanish ruling group commemorated today the sixteenth anniversary of the day when Generalissimo Francisco Franco and other military leaders revolted against the Republican Government of Spain and unleashed a civil war that led to the establishment of the present totalitarian regime.

A DISCUSSION of point-control bidding appeared in this column not many weeks ago, and no doubt it was possible for readers to infer that this writer approves that method of valuing one's hand. For whatever reason, some readers made that column an occasion for writing letters expressing aversion to any point-count method of valuation.

LONDON. WHEN an American was told he had inherited some money on condition that he live m England, he is reported to have said: "What would I be doing over there, hanging around all day eating crumpets?" To an Englishman, this sounds as misleading a reductio ad minimum of his habits and customs as to say a Frenchman pinches girls or a Spaniard fights bulls.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- A little confusion on the defense at water-logged Wrigley Field today helped send the Giants down to defeat at the hands of the Cubs.
