Unearned runs led to the Polo Grounders' setback. A gathering of 8,953 saw Captain Alvin Dark of the visitors boot a slow-rolling grounder as the Cubs batted in the eighth.

Paul R. Beall, scientific consultant of the Air Research and Development Command, Baltimore, Md., reports that since 1941 the Federal Government has spent about $10 billion for scientific research and development. This is more than three times as much as the Napoleonic Wars, which lasted twenty-five years, cost in money.

MICHAEL BRETT is one of America's flamboyant robber barons -- a millionaire gold miner in the time of the Spanish-American War. He loves his gentle, aristocratic wife and has built Keepsake to surround her with beauty and elegance.

WOULD you like to organize a symphony orchestra in your own community? Not necessarily a major, professional ensemble with a large budget, but one that draws largely on home talent that plays for fun?

Eileen Fahey, 18-year-old secretary murdered last Monday by Bayard P. Peakes on the campus of Columbia University, was buried yesterday after funeral services attended by 3,000 friends and neighbors. Her fiance, Pfc. Ronald Leo of the Marine Corps, failed to arrive in time from Korea.

ICE is nice -- nice almost anywhere and at any time during an American summer. Nice tinkling in a glass of tea, nice floating in a punch, nice in a block on a buffet as a "bed" for radishes, shrimps and other hors d'oeuvre, nice crushed free surrounding a big bowl of sherbet or ice cream.

THE single-ticket sales for the New York Philharmonic-Symphony have been holding up well, but in the last three seasons there has been a progressive decline in the subscriptions. In 1949, 1950 and 1951, when officials examined the subscription figures, they found they had been stepping down, with a drop of about 3 per cent for each season.

MONTREAL -- For the past two weeks, American tourists have encountered, as general policy rather than sporadic practice, the discounting of their dollars in Canadian hotels and stores, but complaints have been far fewer than apprehensive travel authorities here had expected.

WASHINGTON. AT noon tomorrow in a huge, barn-like auditorium flanking the Chicago stockyards, Chairman Frank E. McKinney of the Democratic National Committee will pound three times with his gavel to call to order the thirty-first quadrennial convention of the Democratic party.

Aeronautic engineers were not astonished to learn last week that test pilot Bill Bridgeman on one occasion had made a world record of 1,238 miles an hour in the Navy's D558-II Skyrocket and on another occasion had reached a height of 79,494 feet, thereby also beating the record of 72,394 feet made in a balloon by Orville Anderson and Albert Stevens in 1935.

HOUSTON, Tex., July 19 (UP) -A local oil operator today offered to provide transportation from any place in the United States for nurses who would come here to help hospital staffs as the city fought its worst polio epidemic.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- Southern Governors and Senators today settled their differences with Senator Richard B. Russell. The differences arose when the Georgia Senator announced he favored passage by Congress of a substitute for the Taft-Hartley Act.

THE long-play situation in France begins to be overwhelming, says Armand Panigel in Disques, the fine magazine devoted to recorded music published in Paris. It is certain, according to M. Panigel, that in a few years the "33 tours" catalogue in France will equal that in America, even though right now this country is turning out LP's in a ratio of four or five disks to France's one.

THE vegetable plot is already providing its quota of early crops for the table. The qquality and quantity of future harvests depend on a maintenance program that should include thinning out recently seeded crops, keeping down weeds and spraying or dusting to control the insects and diseases.
The American Kennel Club is engaged in a study of the spread of disease at dog shows in order to determine whether present rules should be enforced more strictly or revised.

As an old infantryman who saw much action in the first World War, when anyone rises as Herbert Hoover did at the Republican convention to announce confidently that there will be no future need for American land armies, I cannot help saying: "Amen! Amen! I hope what you say is true."

ONE of the best rail trips of the year in this area will take place next Sunday when the New York Central will operate a special Rip Van Winkle Flyer over its Catskill Mountain branch between Kingston and Stamford, the old Ulster and Delaware route.

FOR most of his life Coleridge believed in much of the quackery, especially that of German philosophy, which was part and parcel of Romanticism. In spite of this it could be argued quite plausibly that of all the English writers in the Romantic Movement he was the greatest genius.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 19 -- Political rapprochement between Yugoslavia and Greece and Turkey has developed to a point where it is believed the ground has been well prepared for eventual military discussions among the three countries that hold key positions in the Balkans and the Middle East against Soviet imperialism.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -Following are excerpts from President Truman's message to Congress on the Midyear Economic Report:

CHICAGO, July 19 -- Mark-Ye-Well, the Calumet Farm's substitute for the Kentucky Derby winner, Hill Gail, turned on full power in the stretch of a muddy track today and won the twentyfourth running of the Arlington Classic. It was the richest race ever run for 3-year-olds, and it grossed $150,450 after the Greentree Stable's Tom Fool and J. H. Dunn's Oh Leo had been scratched because of the condition of the track.
BOSTON, July 19 -- Joe Cronin, general manager of the Red Sox, today announced Jim Piersall, rookie outfielder, would take an indefinite rest on advice of physicians.
BINGHAMTON, N. Y., July 19 (AP) -- Barbara Bruning retained her New York State women's amateur golf crown today by defeating Mrs. Ruth Torgerson, 2 and 1.

The decision of the Department of Justice, announced on Thursday, to start anti-trust proceedings against five American oil companies and two foreign concerns stems from a report prepared several months ago by the Federal Trade Commission alleging that these companies were members of "a giant international oil cartel."

General expectations of an economic upturn in this country in the latter half of the year add to the prospects for new gains in British exports to this market, according to views expressed last week by Duncan M. S. Mowat, chief executive of the British Trade Promotion Center in New York.
WINNIPEG, July 19 -- Johnny Palmer of Badin, N. C., won the Canadian open golf championship today by shooting a 6-under-par 66 for a record score of 263 in the 72-hole tournament.

PARIS, July 19 -- A report of an international group of experts contending that some European currencies must be devalued -- which meant, above all, the French franc -- was made public today by the European Marshall Plan Council.
MOUNT HOLLY, N. J., July 19 -- Township officials were confronted today with the problem of what to do with a $66,000 "white elephant" incinerator plant.

MANY British authors still prefer to send their protagonists to Paris for a deep analysis. The self-revealing escapade of the Englishman abroad is a national tradition and the convention persists that a Britisher will face the truth about himself more frankly on a boulevard than in a psychiatrist's office.

ROME, July 19 (AP) -- Piracy of pharmaceutical formulas and tricky patent laws that fail to protect medicinal products are causing major difficulties for United States and foreign pharmaceutical houses in Italy.

A 22-year-old Indiana University Negro honor graduate who has been blind since birth has been named one of the twenty winners of New York University's $6,300 Root-Tilden Scholarships for 1952-53, it was announced yesterday by Dean Russell D. Niles of the N. Y. U. School of Law.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Dr. John R. Steelman, acting Director of Defense Mobilization, announced today that industry-union negotiations to settle the forty-eight-day-old steel strike would be resumed in Pittsburgh tomorrow morning.

THE title-page drawing sounds the key -- F minor, as it turns out -- in which this reedy parable is written. The author's delicate lines portray a Rossetti-type young woman holding a statuette of Hathor, "Goddess of Social Joy."
TAMPA, Fla., July 19 -- The United States chess champion, Larry Evans of New York, gained his fifth consecutive point today to lead the annual open tournament by 5 -- 0.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., campaign manager for Averell Harriman, said tonight that, with the knowledge of the White House, Harriman supporters had decided to press next week to require all Democrats attending the National Convention to pledge loyalty to the party and its national candidates.

The National Audubon Society has purchased the Harrison Williams house at 1130 Fifth Avenue, at East Ninety-fourth Street, for its new headquarters and will move into the building later this year, it was announced yesterday by John H. Baker, president of the society.

ACCORDING to your temperament, the past half century in music has been the most interesting and progressive or the most discouraging and degenerative period in the history of the art. Even if you try to take a judicious stand midway between these two positions, as Norman Demuth does in this book, certain events of enormous historical import make the period look very different from any that preceded it.

In this department on April 6, 1951, something was said of the attempts that Australia made in 1950 to stamp out the rabbit pest. The reports received at that time stated that the inoculation of rabbits with the fatal tumor-raising infection known as myxomatosis was a failure.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: A hot and dry July means watering some plants in spite of a rainy spring. Trees and shrubs set out during the last year head the list; ground around them should be soaked deeply once a week. Dahlias and gladiolus need regular watering for good flowers. Availability governs watering of other plants and lawns. A deep soaking once a week is better than light sprinkling every day.

The initial message to the Iranians of the newly named Premier, Abroad Ghavam, may have sounded bellicose to some of his fellow countrymen. Elsewhere it will be received as showing a large measure of good sense and a willingness to come to grips with the distressing situation into which the violent and sometimes blind nationalism of his predecessor had led the nation.

Taking a hint from the recent survey by the Brookings Institution of stock ownership in the United States, the New York Stock Exchange last week eliminated Saturday as a half-session trading day not only for the summer, but all year round.

TWO one-day fairs, both only a short drive from New York, are among the popular events of the month. Both are being held to raise money for the benefit of their respective communities. One is East Hampton's fair, which dates from 1895. The other is the quarter-century-old Library Fair of Woodstock, N. Y.

THAT unique art festival, the Biennale of Venice, spreading wide its net over the contemporary field and including some good catches from painting and sculpture of the past, will remain open until Oct. 19. It is proving a great success and, as the dog days approach and the Adriatic looks more inviting than the Champs Elysees, it should reach the peak of its popularity.

THE artist as critic and -however incidentally and innocently -- advance agent for his own unmade film is a new role in which to find John Gielgud. On top of the announcement that he had accepted Joseph L. Mankiewicz's invitation to play Cassius in a forthcoming Hollywood "Julius Caesar," his third film in fifteen years, came the Shakespearean stage star's surprise essay in print, standing in for a holiday-making critic.

Rogue, an Irish setter handicapped by a dreamy disposition, lost his chance for some extra-fine steak bones yesterday by sleeping soundly while his slightly built master struggled with a 6-foot-2-inch burglar who invaded their Brooklyn home.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee tonight proposed a Democratic "fair play" amendment to the convention rules so that contested delegations would not vote until the officially seated delegation to the convention had been agreed upon.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 19 -- A Brazilian Congressional committee has begun an investigation of the Argentine border area, where Argentine gendarmes recently were accused of killing a Brazilian and, on other occasions of firing into Brazilian territory.

GLADIOLUS fans from coast to coast are currently attending annual shows featuring their favorite flower. Hundreds of such exhibits are being held all over the country. Of particular interest to the fancier, as well as to the home gardener, are the newer varieties and the 1952 introductions.
CAMDEN, N. J., July 19 -- The 20-year-old dream of a port authority for the Camden-Philadelphia area today is a reality.

Lewis C. Daniel of Fort Lee, N. J., Associate National Academician and winner of the Philadelphia Water Color Prize in 1944, was killed Friday near Brookville, Ill., when the automobile he was driving ran off the road in a heavy rainstorm and hit a bridge abutment, according to word received here.
CHICAGO, July 19 -- More than 500 American women have been named as delegates, alternates, advisers and technical assistants to international conferences since 1946.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 19 -- Connecticut's lone hold-out for Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio at the Republican National Convention, State Representative Nelson Carpenter, fears that his district in Eastern Connecticut faces reprisals by Eisenhower leaders in the state because of his convention stand.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The Navy announced today that the sister ship of the Forrestal, world's largest aircraft carrier, would be built at the New York Naval Shipyard at Brooklyn.

Another effort is being made to give investors information about new securities that Congress intended they should get when it passed the Securities Act of 1933. Whether they will get it will depend largely on the outcome of proposals recently made by the Securities and Exchange Commission to make it available to them.

THE Handel Society, which already has complete versions of "Acis and Galatea" and "Israel in Egypt" to its credit, has rendered another significant service. It has made a good recording of Judas Maccabaeus. What is more, it has made it in this country, having the enterprise to round up excellent, if not yet famous, forces with which to perform the oratorio.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (UP) -Representative Kenneth B. Keating, Republican of New York, said tonight that corruption hunters of the House of Representatives would soon reveal new "connections" between Democratic "bigwigs" and handling of Department of Justice cases.

NEW YORK CITY has been a photographer's paradise since the days of the daguerreotype. Seventy-five examples of how photographers in various decades during the past century have treated the New York theme went on display last week at the Museum of the City of New York.

THE author of "William Faulkner: A Critical Study" is a strikingly casual fellow. Irving Howe is his name, and if you haven't heard of him by now it means you haven't strayed off the best-seller pastures.

How public utility companies have raised more than 400,000,000 this year by the sale of common stock is shown by the following tabulations. The first is related to standby offerings, showing the discount from market price accorded to subscribing stockholders, the extent of subscriptions, and the market standing of the stock before and after the transaction. The second, tabulation summarizes similarly the outcome of flotations offered to the public:

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -The Defense Department reported today another 292 casualties in the Korean war, including 67 dead, 212 wounded, 6 missing in action and 7 injured in battle zone accidents. The following were from New York and New Jersey (none from Connecticut):

THE kinds of plant diseases and their severity vary according to the season and the weather. During this past wet spring, for example, tree diseases were prevalent. Five consecutive days of rain when sycamores were leafing out caused spectacular blighting and leaf drop from anthracnose, a fungus disease that turns young foliage as brown and crisp as if hit by late frost.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- After taking a preliminary census of the densely populated Democratic Presidential ballot, President Truman has apparently reached at least one conclusion. This is that a Democratic victory over General Eisenhower in November is likely to depend more on a program than on a man.

High temperatures and humidity kept stores' potential customers away last week, and merchants estimated that the drop from the 1951 week was about 12 per cent, with half of it ascribed to the weather. Other causes were indirect effects of the steel strike and the fact that one Brooklyn store, included in the 1951 week, has since been closed.

BOSTON, July 19 -- Democratic king makers seeking to do business among New England delegates to the national convention at Cihcago, starting Monday, will find some of them reluctant to being pinned in any particular corner. The region is sending 150 delegates, whose eighty-eight total votes represent a wide range of opinion.

A FEW weeks ago my husband and I arrived in the United States from the British West Indies for the express purpose of touring the country by car. We hope, before the tour is over, to reach the West Coast, visit Mexico and explore the Pan American Highway down through Central America.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 19 (UP) -- Great Circle, who hadn't won a race since capturing the $205,000 Maturity at Santa Anita a year ago, came back today to score a surprise neck victory today in the $54,750 Sunset Handicap, closing feature of the highly successful fifty-day Hollywood Park meeting.

NO American now resident in Moscow remembers who first put those words to the music of Yale's "Whiffenpoof Song" and set the chorus ringing in one of those high vaulted apartments in the seven-story tan building at No. 13 Mokhovaya Street.

ALTHOUGH better than three-fourths of the world's supply of flower seed is grown in southern California, vegetable seed is produced over a much wider area. There is vegetable seed production along the West Coast from the Mexican border to the Canadian line, and east to Colorado.

FIVE animals were caught by the flood for six weeks on a mound of dirt, and a stranger five could hardly have been put together. There was a wise old raccoon, a gloomy bullfrog, a rabbit, a long black snake and a red fox.

BOSTON, July 19 (UP) -- Bill Glynn, rookie first baseman making his third start in the major leagues, put on a sparkling show today as the Indians shut out the Red Sox, 4 -- 0, and moved to within one percentage point of a second-place tie with Boston in the American League.

James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, called yesterday on American recording companies and union instrumentalists abroad to halt the making of cut-rate records.

UTRECHT, the Netherlands, July 19 -- The International Federation of Christian Trade Unions, which is overwhelmingly Catholic, has sharply rebuffed an approach from the Government-controlled Spanish labor organization. The Christian federation is following the same policy as the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions, which, opposing Yugoslav affiliation, is refusing any connection with nondemocratic labor organizations.

LONDON, July 19 -- The Foreign Office confirmed today that a "politely worded" note from the Chinese Government on trade with Britain had been delivered to the British Embassy in Peiping. A summary has been received in London, but the text is not yet available for careful study, a Foreign Office spokesman said.

The first woman to hold the post of Controller of Customs for the New York Controller District, Mrs. Margaret Daly Campbell, is expected to be sworn in within the next ten days by Harry M. Durning, Collector of Customs.

Two leaders of the Patriarchal Russian Orthodox Church in America have left here by plane for Moscow, according to Religious News Service. They are Archbishop Adam of Philadelphia, Vice-Exarch of the Moscow Patriarchate, and Bishop Anthony of San Francisco.

Many a housewife too busy to pay much attention to trade marks and brand names uses the word "Bendix" as a generic term for automatic electric washing machine. A good deal of the responsibility for this error, almost as common as the notion that all refrigerators are Frigidaires, car be laid at the doorstep of a quiet but promotionally powerful little man of Danish extraction who likes monkeys.
DETROIT, July 19 (AP) -- The future will bring increasing use of diesel power and possibly gas turbine engines in motor vehicles, but probably in trucks and buses rather than passenger automobiles.
CHICAGO, July 19 -- Long planned Democratic efforts to avoid this year a party split over the civil-rights issue such as occurred in 1948 went out the window here today.

Harry Truman has always been exceptionally healthy. As a boy, he had the usual accidents and ailments -- fell off a chair and broke his collarbone; swallowed a peach pit and, as he has told it, "almost choked to death, but Mama pushed the seed down my throat with her finger and I lived to tell about it"; had diphtheria -"They gave us ipecac and whisky, and I've hated the smell of both ever since."

WHAT could be a more satisfying antidote for today's literary malaise than a lovingly executed Victorian novel of the London theatrical world in the Eighteen Eighties? A distant, gas-lit, perfect period it was, more antique and fustian for most of us than the Elizabethan.

An experimental pilot program in work-and-study curriculums for special students which began at Boston University in 1949 will become a full-fledged junior college and join the fifteen other colleges of the university. To its classrooms will go students with good potential ability, but who may have struggled with studies because of unique social or personal situations.

WHETHER he is a gardener or not, every home owner has a dooryard. Since its appearance is apt to be the criterion by which his outdoor housekeeping is judged, this conspicuous part of the property takes precedence in planting and maintenance.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- Although differences in policy exist within the national Democratic party, they have not degenerated into name-calling, "which has disgraced the Republican party," Senator Paul H. Douglas of Illinois said today before the National Committee of the Young Democrats.

DENVER, July 19 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower expects to make a swing through the South when his Presidential campaign gets under way in earnest. This will be the first time any Republican Presidential nominee has conducted a full-scale campaign in the South, as distinct from a speech or two.

SALT LAKE CITY, July 19 -The entry of Marriner S. Eccles, former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, into a four-cornered contest for the Republican nomination for United States Senator this week focused regional attention on the Utah political scene.

ROME, July 19 -- The Vatican's Sacred Congregation of the Holy Office in instructions for the guidance of bishops throughout the world has condemned "corrupt and errant forms of sacred art" that have been finding their way into churches.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- The typical 1952 Democratic convention delegate would appear to be a far more well-heeled individual than his predecessor of recent decades. He can, in an impressive number of instances, peel $100 bills off his bank roll without batting an eye, and not quibble about the change.

An almost endless variety of fabrics, styles and color combinations has been instrumental in keeping retailers interested in the offerings of the New York garment industry. Manufacturers in this area said last week they are looking forward to extended buying for fall and are anticipating a substantial increase in both unit and dollar volume.

Within recent years the nation has witnessed a remarkable educational development in the growth and expansion of the junior college system in the United States. These two-year institutions are now a significant factor in higher education. As of this spring, there were 586 junior colleges with a total enrollment of 576,453.

The Democratic National Convention that begins tomorrow in Chicago will be, for the first time in twenty years, a wide-open one. Even when they are under the political domination of a single powerful figure the Democrats are noted for the vehemence of their intra-party scraps.

THE bell tolled last week for the controversial services-committee plan recently recommended by the Motion Picture Industry Council to its member organizations as a likely means of helping certain deserving Hollywood individuals to wipe the red stain of communism from their reputations.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- An effort to promote a bloc of 264 delegates behind a single Presidential candidate will be made by several Democratic leaders of fifteen states, Jake More, chairman of the Iowa State Central Committee, said tonight.

Plans were announced yesterday by the Lefrak Organization, .builders of four aparhnent centers in New York, for a -Lfth development at Wallace and Holland: rAvenues, in the Pelham section of Abe Bronx. The latest group will ',consist of four seven-story eleva?tor buildings with a total of 200 :partments.

SEVERAL months ago I was asked by the P. E. N. Club to participate in a panel discussion of the subject, "Psychoanalysis in Writing." Jean Stafford spoke from the novelist's point of view; Father William F. Lynch of Fordham University gave the churchman's outlook and Dr. Theodore Reik spoke for the analysts.

An oil tanker carrying a crew of four burst into flame at 2:30 P. M. yesterday as she was making her way downstream in the East River, off Seventy-third Street. Three explosions racked the 115-foot vessel in quick suc cession after the crew had leaped overboard.

THIS is the second novel published in this country by a young French writer with considerable literary gifts. Herve Bazin's previous novel, "Viper in the Fist," described the relentless warfare between an ogreish mother and her three small sons; and out of this dismal subject M. Bazin wrested a highly entertaining little tale, glowing with ferocious humor.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 19 -- Revival of the Maritime Federation of the Pacific, an organization of maritime union disbanded in 1940, has been proposed by a caucus of the longshore, ships clerks and walking bosses of the unaffiliated International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union.

Works of Mozart, which are among those most often requested at the free recorded concerts of the New York Public Library, will be heard tomorrow in a program entirely devoted to his music from noon to 2 P. M. in Bryant Park.

AT the office of producers James Russo and Michael Ellis word came over the long-distance phone last week that Bette Davis, held up by a new picture assignment, is hoping to arrive here the first week in September to begin work on that revue, "Two's Company."

BRIGHTON, Utah -- Meeting here last week, members of of the National Association of State Aviation Officials -- about fifty air-age enthusiasts heading aeronautics commissions in thirty states -- have been gloomily mulling over the reasons private fliers have failed to get off the ground en masse.

A GARDEN looks as neat as its edges. No matter how meticulous the rest of the grooming may be, unclipped grass and ragged lines along the margins of borders and paths destroy much of their beauty. A great aid to tidiness is a permanent edge of brick, stone, metal or wood.

BONN, Germany, July 19 -- In the teeth of bitter Socialist opposition including veiled threats of a general strike the Government pushed the co-determination bill through its final reading in the Bundestag this afternoon. The vote was 195 to 140 with seven abstentions.

PORTLAND, Ore., July 19 -- Justice William O. Douglas of the United States Supreme Court, who is hunting and fishing on and off in the Pacific Northwest before setting out on a tour of the Far East, has been giving little thought to the political maneuvers preceding the Democratic National Convention, he said today.

A reduction last week in cotton textile wages in Northern areas -the result of an arbitrator's decision -- has injected a new factor in the competitive fight between Northern and Southern mills, The reduction, amounting to 8 1/2 cents an hour, affects 15,000 workers belonging to the Textile Workers Union of America, C. I. O., and 2,000 members of the United Textile Workers, A. F. L., in the New Bedford-Fall River areas.

There appears to be little public sympathy toward Philip Murray's demand for a union shop for his C. I. O. steelworkers' union. Many people feel that union membership as a condition of employment seriously abridges fundamental freedoms. Enforced tribute to earn a living is an abhorrent idea to many.
ARECORD of music by Hollywood composers has just been released by Lyrichord and recorded by the Frankenland State Symphony under the direction of Erich Kloss.

Carmine G. DeSapio, New York County Democratic leader, announced last night the selection of substitute candidates for the Seventeenth Congressional District and the Twentieth Senatorial District, both of which are now represented by Republicans.

For three hours last night West Ninety-fourth Street between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues formed the backdrop for an age-old Buddhist holiday as gaily garbed followers of the Gautama Buddha celebrated "O-Bon" and lanced the traditional "Bon-Odori."

Little Conn McCreary played a waiting game in Empire City-at-Jamaica's $28,800 Questionnaire Handicap yesterday, and then went to work on the second turn and in the stretch to win first money of $19,750 with the Hampton Stable's 4-year-old colt, Alerted.

PITTSBURGH, July 19 -- The ball is on the one-inch line in efforts to settle the paralyzing national steel strike, but no one has been able to carry it across for the touchdown that will win for the national economy and allow 1,500,000 workers in steel and industries dependent on steel to go back to their jobs.

Some answers to the question why department stores have lost some of their volume to chain stores, specialty shops and mail-order houses are contained in a bulletin of the University of Illinois Business Management Service, just released.

Edward Baldwin, younger of the two teen-agers charged with homicide in the park shooting of Samuel Bernard London, Brooklyn graduate rabbinical student, was a fatherless child, deserted by his mother years ago, and the address he gave the police turned out yesterday to be that of a temporary foster home where he had lived only from June 6 to June 19.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The tallest political fable of 1952 is to the effect that the Democratic National Convention will be wide open. It is a tale that has been carefully nurtured ever since President Truman started to spin it in Key West in March.

FACTION is so violent in the world of jazz nowadays that it behooves any commentator on the subject to declare himself at the outset, I seem to be fairly catholic, responding to masters in several schools, from New Orleans pioneering to bebop, from Jelly Roll Morton on the right to Lennie Tristano on the left.

BOSTON, July 19 -- Court action involving the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Chauffeurs, Warehousemen and Helpers, A. F. L., in Boston next Thursday may turn out to be an important skirmish in the cold war between the nation's railroads and the trucking industry.

THE Twenty-sixth Festival of the International Society for Contemporary Music took place this year at Salzburg, the city where the first international festival was given thirty years ago. The festival included in its programs those of the Third International Assembly of the Twelve Tone Congress -- cacophonists all.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 19 (AP) -- Russia took an early lead today as seven nations opened their quest for the Olympic team gymnastic championship a few hours before the official opening of the games.

For some time I have intended writing you concerning the letter from a group of individuals affiliated with local and national associations which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES for Sunday, June 15, under the title "Subversive Education."

AN illumination control device for the Stereo-Realist viewer will be placed on the market this month by Haber Fink, Inc., 12 Warren Street. The unit is the H. F. Variable Transformer, which will permit the stereo observer to increase or decrease the light intensity of the stereo pair.

Americans have been keeping an unusually large amount of cash on hand ever since the end of the last World War, with the total of currency now outside the banking system equivalent to approximately $400 for every member of the working population, including the armed forces.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- In the name of small business President Truman signed the "fair trade" law this week freely acknowledging he was not sure whether it would be a boon or a bane to the national economy.

The Ford Foundation Board on Overseas Training and Research has established a new foreign fellowship program designed to stimulate increased knowledge about Asia and the Near and Middle East. The funds appropriated for this program are adequate to provide 100 fellowships of from one to three years.

FLOWER arrangers often regret that their creations are so short-lived. Perhaps the ephemeral quality of flowers is their greatest charm, but when considerable time has gone into planning and executing an arrangement it is somewhat disheartening to see its beauty soon gone. Actually, a certain type of arrangement can be preserved, and even framed and hung on a wall.

Cotton prices in the domestic market fluctuated narrowly last week. At the close of trading on Friday changes in active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange ranged from a six point advance to a seven point decline. The current July delivery, in which trading expired at noon on Tuesday, went off the board at an average price of 40.03, a decline of nine points from the previous week's close.

ASCOT, England, July 19 -Tulyar, the stretch-running thoroughbred owned by the Aga Kahn, came from behind again today to win the $77,420 King George VI and Queen Elizabeth Stakes and become the greatest money winner in British racing history.

DENVER, July 19 -- Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican nominee for President, is spending the week of the Democratic National Convention fishing in the Colorado Rockies, but his campaign team remains here putting the organizational plan into effect.
CHAUTAUQUA, N. Y., July 19 -- Dimitri Mitropoulos, musical director of the New York Philharmonic - Symphony, made his Chautauqua debut tonight as piano soloist with the Chautauqua Symphony Orchestra.

A POLICE officer walked toward the stage, his eyes fixed on the large movie screen; he stopped at a microphone and, looking directly at the three men facing him from the screen, said, "This is what Chicago wants to know, Washington...?"

The Swedish American liner Gripsholm, which rescued forty-five persons early yesterday from the flame-ravaged freighter Black Gull, has a distinguished record for her "mercy ship" duty in World War II.

In a letter in your columns June 22, James B. Simonson wrote of "a wind which seems to spring up in the mountainous interior [of Jamaica, B. W. I.] every day at approximately 4 P. M." and is called "The Doctor."

President Juho Paasikivi of Finland opened the fifteenth modern Olympic Games before 70,000 persons in the rain at Helsinki yesterday. More than 5,800 men and women athletes from sixty-seven countries, a record entry, took part. A West German girl, described as a "peace fanatic," marred the ceremony by attempting to speak from the podium.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 19 -The President of Finland declared the games of the Fifteenth Olympaid open today before a hushed gathering of 70,000 persons under dripping skies, and the dream of a people brave of heart had come true.

Miss Biruta Sneiders, 21-year-old coloratura soprano, whose voice so annoyed her Flatbush neighbors that she was ordered to make a drastic reduction in practice hours, will appear in Magistrate's Court tomorrow with a plea for more singing time.

Security markets, responding closely to developments in the seven-weeks-old steel strike, registered modest gains during the first half of last week on the expectation that steel settlement was imminent, but then sustained an equally moderate reversal when hopes for peace in the basic industry faded.

AUBURN -- Vacationists interested in history can see the Finger Lakes of New York by following the route of Sullivan's March, a punitive expedition against the Iroquois Indians led by Maj. Gen. John Sullivan in the summer of 1779.
Thousands of New Yorkers got into their cars early yesterday morning and crowded the highways leading from the city in all directions to escape the continuing heat and high humidity.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- Following is vote by which the Democratic National Committee today rejected 64 to 23 a motion to bar from the Democratic Convention both the pro- and anti-Administration representatives of Mississippi and Texas until party loyalty questions and the contesting rights of rival delegations had been settled finally:

ALTHOUGH it handles a vast volume of traffic, the New Jersey Turnpike is gaining rank among the safest routes in this country. Comparative data show that for the first six months of the year accidents totaled 311, which, using the standard formula of Federal and state governments, makes 90.7 per 100,000,000 miles of travel.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, July 19 -- In the first six months of this year Bermuda took in $16,596,985 in United States and Canadian currency and spent $9,168,314, according to a report sent to the Assembly by the Currency Board. The Assembly recently deplored official secrecy concerning the dollar position of the colony and asked the Governor to insure the issuance of periodic statements.

Don Thompson of Jackson Heights, seeded second, scored an upset victory in straight sets over Ed Rubinoff of Miami Beach, seeded first, to win the junior division title of the Eastern junior and boys' tennis championships yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills. The scores were 6 -- 4, 10 -- 8, 6 -- 3.

GENEVA, July 20 -- Sometimes when a piece of paper is laid on an official's desk, among all those that governments receive every day, the effect in foreign ministries around the world is like that of a cat let loose among nervous pigeons.

WHEN the Eighty-second Congress adjourned on July 7 seventy-five bills requesting special postage stamps had been presented. They had not been enacted into law but Postmaster General Jesse M. Donaldson knew their import and had acted favorably on seven which contained the following suggestions:

Thirty-three foreclosure actions to satisfy liens amounting to $1,442,940 were taken in Manhattan during the first half of this year, the Real Estate Board of New York reported yesterday. While noting that the figures represent a continuance of the recent low level of forced conveyances, the board called attention to comparable data for the first six months of 1951, when there were thirty-one foreclosures involving a lien total of $838,220.

Your interesting history of the pocket lighter in Topics of The Times recently omits one significant point in the development of that exasperating, indispensable device. What was different about the original Dunhill lighter and made it the first successful model was the close-fitting cap over the wick.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- Though the setting will look much the same, the Democratic National Convention, which opens here tomorrow, will offer a different sort of drama from that of the Republican National Convention, which left town a week ago.

THOSE who were present at the June 1952 Pantheon ceremonies, when Paris gave homage to Victor Hugo 150 years after his birth, were able to measure the fervor and unanimity of the crowd. The time has passed when to the question "Who is the greatest French poet?" Gide replied, "Victor Hugo, alas!" Gide himself, toward the end of his life tried, by various remarks, to take the sting from this unjust comment.

TOMORROW'S opening of the Democratic National Convention is scheduled to provide the first test of what video already may have done to the political convention as an institution. The Republicans had not even left Chicago before the Democrats announced that they intended to give a more showmanly and streamlined appearance to their quadrennial conclave.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (UP) -Lieut. Col. Joseph O. Fletcher, an Air Force Arctic expert, said today that United States airplanes now landed observers "with relative ease" on floating ice islands near the North Pole.

A 44-year-old New Hampshire business woman was sent to Bellevue Hospital last night for observation by Magistrate Charles E. Ramsgate in Night Court. She had been booked on a disorderly conduct charge for allegedly slapping a foot patrolman after he had seized her automobile ignition keys at Fifty-fourth Street and Seventh Avenue because of traffic violations.

Sixty-five acres comprising a farm-estate in the AspetuckMerryall section of New Milford, Conn., have been sold by Mrs. Victor C. Bell to Maj. Herbert L. Miskend of New Milford and New York through the Housatonic Valley Agency of New Milford.

BONN, Germany, July 19 -- Three sleek, fast freighters, symbolizing the challenge of a resurgent Germany for equality on the sea lanes and in international shipbuilding, have been completed at North German ports in the last week.
RANGOON, Burma, July 19 -Non-Communist Burma will ask the Soviet Union and Communist China for economic aid.

BORN of missionary parents on the Kansu-Tibetan border, and a missionary by profession, Robert Ekvall has produced a fascinating book that is unique in many ways. His is not a missionary story, nor is it in the slightest an attempt to show himself and family "in bold relief against the Tibetan scene."
EARLIER this month, July 6 to be exact, "The Drunkard" began its twentieth year of continuous nightly performances here at the Theatre Mart.

PITTSBURGH. UNIONISM is as much a part of Philip Murray's heritage as his Irish wit and the Scottish burr that mellows his speech. His father and his father's father were mine union leaders, and the chief spokesman today for 5,000,000 American trade unionists in the C.I.O. is as proud of his heritage as the most proper Bostonian.
CHICAGO, July 19 -- The second hat for the Vice Presidential nomination of the National Democratic Convention was tossed into the ring today and, like the first one, it belonged to a woman.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 19 -- The collapse of the Mossadegh regime in Iran is the result of an almost fantastic incompetence rather than of any serious opposition to Dr. Mohammed Mossadegh's ultra-nationalist policies.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 19 -- The Olympic flame had just been lighted by Paavo Nurmi and everybody in that vast stadium was waiting for Finland's Archibshop Ilmari Salomies to take his place on the rostrum to say an invocation in Latin.
WHILE checking with Joe Friedman of White Plains last week on the local season for black bass, the writer learned of some striped bass fishing in Long Island Sound that interested him more.

BEGINNING this week, the best seller chart gets its face lifted ever so slightly. Perhaps it would be more accurate to say that the chart gets its memory improved. Those who follow the fortunes of best sellers will have noticed that although the list accurately reflected the relative sales of books during a given week, and three preceding weeks, it did not supply any kind of cumulative record.

THE training and ultimate triumph in a field trial of an Ozark coon hound, is the main subject of Col. S. P. Meek's latest story. Running parallel to this theme is the regeneration of Greg Oliphant, Boy's master, who reaches the Ozark's suffering from acute battle fatigue.

WE stand in the presence of an excited, perhaps of an awakened, nation. Every four years the Presidency becomes the operative symbol of our whole American system. It is not of course the whole of even our political system, much less of our American system. It is indeed only one of three political parts, as our politics is only one aspect of our multi-dimensional cultural system.

HERMISTON, Ore. -- The wayfarer from the effete East, in search this summer of the typical Westerner, is likely not to recognize the object of his quest. This is because the average inhabitant of Oregon or Wyoming probably will turn out to be a person very much like himself.
We do not yet know whether the Communists really desire peace in Korea.

LONDON, July 19 -- Last Tuesday evening, as usual, the Very Rev. Dr. Hewlett Johnson, Dean of Christ Church Cathedral -- the seat of the Archbishop of Canterbury, Primate of all England -- officiated at evensong.

AS one who, years ago when a student planning a musical career, was impressed with the survey of the status of the musician presented by Howard Taubman in his "Music as a Profession," I should like to take exception to his prophecy, in his otherwise perceptive column of Sunday, July 6, that "Americans will turn away from a future in music if they cannot make a decent living out of it."

TOKYO, Sunday, July 20 -- The Communists' propaganda sources continued yesterday to pour out charges that United Nations planes had violated the Manchurian border on five consecutive days this month, warned the Allies that "intimidation'' would produce no results at the conference table and reported there was "no sign the Americans intended to settle" the prisoner question -- the last major barrier to an armistice.

The Norwegian training barque Statsraad Lehmkuhl played host to several hundred visitors yesterday. Many were Norwegian-Americans who came from Brooklyn and Staten Island to seek news of former townsmen and to stand on a Norwegian deck beneath Norwegian rigging.

Ground action in Korea again centered around hills in the western sector of the front. The battle continues in progress at the close of this period. In another action in this sector a friendly, raiding party seized limited objectives without contact but received an attack from an unknown number of enemy and withdrew upon orders.

Literary criticism has taken a dim view of contemporary letter writing. To write a letter is said to be virtually a lost art; no longer does a muse of fire breathe warmth and life into our present-day epistles. Whatever the merits of this criticism, the suspicion grows that the art of letter writing has reached a very low ebb indeed.

The fifteenth Olympic Games will be opened within a few days in Helsinki, capital of the valiant Finn nation, related to us Hungarians. While free peoples all over the world will follow with keen interest the performances of their compatriots, a small but important group of sportsmen -- many of them former world and Olympic champions -- must endure the bitter disappointment of being barred from the games.

TOLD in the first person, this story revolves around love love offered and denied, love given and betrayed and love that is beyond earthly ties. It has all the telling touches by an author well versed in writing romantic fiction for a feminine audience.

THREE generations in the history of a prolific Swedish-American working-class family in western Pennsylvania are put on display in Eunice McCloskey's first novel. The story begins in 1893 when Karen Swanson, age 10, is living with her mild-mannered coal-mining father, her beautiful tubercular mother and her brothers and sisters.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -The National Boxing Association today scored titleholders for giving Archie Moore the "cold shoulder" and named him as the No. 3 challenger in the heavyweight division.
CINCINNATI, July 19 (AP) -- For the second straight day, the Phils today broke up a tie ball game in the ninth inning as they scored two runs for a 7-to-5 victory over the Reds. The box score:
THAT imitation is the sincerest form of flattery and that parlor games are a "natural" for television seem to be the two guiding principles for summer video programming.

I read Brother Cormac Philip's letter in your issue of July 6, dealing with the 1952 College English Association Institute, with surprise and puzzlement. 1, too, attended the institute sessions at the University of Massachusetts, but I failed to gather the impression which Brother Cormac Philip did -- that the business representatives in attendance were anxious to see a watered-down, narrowly vocationalized type of English Major established in our colleges.

For a nation that started out strongly averse to political parties and suspicious of political conventions the United States is doing very well with both this summer. Political parties, once considered dangerous factionalism, have rent the air but have not shaken the foundations of the Government.

Col. W. W. Dick Jr., division artillery executive of the Twenty-fifth Infantry Division, who returned from duty in Korea a few months ago, was elected president of the veteran's association of the division yesterday at the third annual reunion in the New Yorker Hotel.

A receptive market responding to prudent pricing has enabled the nation's public utility capital plant to expand its equity base more than $400,000,000 this year. More than forty of the nation's private gas and electric enterprises have shared in this formidable requisition on the market, a proffer of new utility common stock exceeding in volume that of any full year of the post-war expansion period.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- The Democrats were headed tonight for more of their traditional North-South trouble as, in this restless week-end before the opening of their thirty-first National Convention, five Presidential aspirants worked feverishly to win favor.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., July 19 -- The new $3,500,000 Morristown Memorial Hospital was dedicated this afternoon. Officials from Morris and Somerset Counties, the New Jersey Medical Association and various surrounding municipalities attended.

In his article "Multi-Party System" (June 15) Leonard J. Cromie mentions "the syndicalist Socialist Labor party." The Socialist Labor party is positively not "syndicalist." "Syndicalism," according to Webster and as the term is generally understood, means "the theory, plan or practice of trade union action which aims by the general strike and direct action to establish control by organizations of workers over the means and processes of production."
SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, July 20 (AP) -- Chinese Reds yesterday hurled back three Allied attacks on the crest line of "Old Baldy," a strategic hill position on Korea's western front.

AT the turn of the century (if we are to believe this novel), St. Louis was a wide-open town operated by politicians who turned their heads, for a "fee," and failed to notice the gambling, prostitution and profiteering on municipal contracts which went on all about them.
Two modest and unidentified stewardesses were lauded last night by passengers of the Black Gull as heroines of the disaster off Montauk Point in which the Norwegian ship was burned.

BONN, July 19 -- The hullabaloo in Chicago about the great decisions facing the United States has obscured the fact that the Soviet Union, our unrelenting adversary in the world struggle, is facing a very serious decision of its own. This is whether Russian policy is to abandon the seven-year-old attempt to bring Western Germany within the Soviet sphere of influence.

WESTPORT, Conn., July 19 -Two conflicting stories were told today in connection with the complaint against the Westport Woman's Club that alleged obtaining money under false pretenses and operating a lottery at a fair held by the club here last week-end to raise money for community projects.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- The Democrats will open their thirty-first National Convention in the Chicago Convention Building and International Amphitheatre here tomorrow. They elected their first nominee, Andrew Jackson, in 1832, their latest one, Harry S. Truman, in 1948, and seven other Presidents between.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- The forty-eight states and six territorial possessions of the United States have elected 1,652 delegates with 1,230 votes to participate in the Democratic National Convention, which opens here Monday. Following is the state and territory listing of the number of delegates and votes, with 616 needed to nominate:

MARSHALL FIELD always strode into his famed Chicago store a half hour before it opened and kept a sharp eye on the tiniest details of its operations. One morning he confronted a male clerk who was arguing hotly with a customer.

Forty-four survivors of the American-chartered Norwegian freighter Black Gull, which was swept by a naphthalene-fed fire late Friday night sixty-five miles southeast of Montauk Point, L. I., reached St. George, S. I., at 8:30 o'clock last night aboard the Coast Guard cutter Mackinac.

THE salt tide is flooding our literary marshes with cleansing waters. "The Caine Mutiny," "Kon-Tiki," and '"The Sea Around Us" are excellent. Now comes George Millar's "White Boat From England," a wonderful book that deserves to become a favorite with landlubbers and seamen alike.
CHICAGO, July 19 -- Leaders of rival labor federations met today and talked about pooling all the strength the unions can muster in the Democratic convention that opens on Monday.

The first dogs requisitioned under New York State's recently enacted Metcalf-Hatch law were obtained last week by the Sloan-Kettering Institute for use in cancer research, the New York State Society for Medical Research announced. The dogs, unlicensed and unclaimed, had been held in the pound for five days.

EAST WILLISTON, L. I., July 19 -- George Uhe and Fred Lazard, Cherry Valley, the medal winners, led the way into the second round of the Casey Memorial member-guest golf tournament at the Wheatley Hills Club today with a 3-and-2 victory over Robert Odom and Matty Mardozza of the Garden City Country Club.

CHICAGO, July 19 (AP) -- Sails were soggy from a mid-day down-pour as a flotilla of fifty-six yachts took off today in the forty-fifth annual Chicago-to-Mackinac race -- a 333-mile sweep up Lake Michigan to the Straits.
ONE question not answered by the recent Republican National Convention was how much a television commentator should talk while proceedings from the convention floor are on view.

SAN JUAN, P. R. -- For ten frenetic days next month this dance - conscious island will be jumping even more than usual to the rhythms of the conga, rhumba, mamba, meringue and the native dance patterns of the Caribbean.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- President Truman returned to the White House from a three-day hospital session today, looking fit and feeling fine.

THE world at large, even that small portion that reads the Bible regularly, knows little of Joachim of Babylon. In Daniel's version, he is the husband of virtuous, maligned Susanna who refused those lecherous elders watching her at the bath.

The nineteenth annual women's open golf championship of the Fairfield and Westchester Counties will begin tomorrow with one of the largest and most talented fields that has participated in a long time. This event, three days of medal play for the Elizabeth Wheeler Trophy, again will be held over the hilly and rugged Whippoorwill Country Club course in Armonk, New York.
HAVERFORD, Pa., July 19 -Maureen Connolly of San Diego, Calif., the United States and Wimbledon champion, won her third straight Pennsylvania and Eastern States tennis title today.
The chance sighting of a 4-yearold boy on a Harlem street corner yesterday ended a police search of nearly nine months and led to the arrest of a man and woman on kidnapping charges.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 19 (AP) -Top-seeded Dick Savitt of Orange, N. J., and third-ranked Art Larsen of San Leandro, Calif., outlasted older opponents to win semi-final victories in the Western tennis tournament today.

WITH these three books, Henry Schuman launches a new science series for children of junior high school age. The aim of the series is to present meaningful and exciting material by authors qualified in their fields arid carefully checked by experts.

COLORADO SPRINGS, July 19 (AP) -- Air Defense Command headquarters here announced that a controlled training exercise began today placing Air Defense Commands of the United States and Canada on an all-out operational basis for one week.
BERLIN, July 19 -- A Communist-sponsored mass meeting of Berlin youth was called today to take place Sunday, Aug. 3 in the heart of West Berlin.

A NEW book by Martin Buber is always an event, especially when, as in the present case, he deals with a highly controversial subject gently and with great learning. The author is by all odds the outstanding Jewish philosopher of the present day.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 19 -Flaunt, owned by Arnold Skjeveland and ridden by Keith Stuart, took the $20,000 added race that served as the feature at Monmouth Park today. Flaunt's triumph, which was worth $41.80 for $2, was in keeping with earlier developments that saw a record local daily double of $3,962.60.

The Democratic party, like all American parties, has always been a coalition of regional groups and diverse economic interests. In the days of Jefferson and Jackson the party found its strength among Tidewater planters, frontiersmen of the Allegheny foothills, poorer working classes in the cities, all of whom combined against the Federalist and Whig mercantile and banking interests.

Since 1950, the Census Bureau has just estimated, the population of the United States has increased by 5,672,000. It is now increasing at the rate of a little over 200,000 a month. Thus in a little over three years the nation would add the equivalent of New York City to its numbers and every month it would add about the equivalent of Worcester, Mass.

TODAY there is a wide measure of agreement, which on the physical side of science approaches almost to unanimity, that the stream of knowledge is heading toward a non-mechanical reality; the universe begins to look more like a great thought than like a great machine.

Ambassador Romulo from the Philippines made a significant statement in his eloquent support of a progressive increase in the Expanded Program of the Technical Assistance Committee of the Economic and Social Council of the United Nations. After showing what was being done by various agencies in different parts of the world, he declared:

CHARLIE DELL. By Anderson Wayne. 247 pp. New York: Coward-McCann. $3. THE trouble began when Charlie Dell's 17-year-old sister-in-law, Lois, arrived in Denver to hve with him and Irma. Lois was sweet and wholesome, an unspoiled adolescent. It was not her fault that she was mature physically, or that -- as novelists interminably put it -- she was as beautiful as Irma was plain.

The pulse of international affairs has throbbed sluggishly these days between the conclusion of the Republican party convention, which nominated General Eisenhower for the Presidency, and the opening of the Democratic meeting tomorrow. From Asia across the Middle East to Europe moods shifted, Governments fell, hopes, attitudes and speculation were formulated.
It's a game that never will appear in the official records. Nor will the victory help either party should both get into next October's world series.

Prices have firmed in all wholesale markets here last week and retailers and manufacturers appeared more confident, according to Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office. Excellent values were available, encouraging buyers to spend their full budgets.

The Brooklyn delegation to the Democratic National Convention left for Chicago aboard a special New York Central train at 3:45 P. M. yesterday, with the delegation chairman expressing the view that "a Harriman-Kefauver ticket would be a very good one."

PITTSBURGH, July 19 -- If it is true, as Branch Rickey has has said, that this Pirate team is a challenge to him, it is equally true that the Bucs are no challenge to the Dodgers, who trounced them today for the twelfth straight time by a 9-1 score.
PHILADELPHIA, July 19 (UP) -- Ray Murray's single to left field scored Allie Clark from second base with two out in the ninth inning today and enabled the Athletics to beat the Tigers, 5 -- 4.
WITH the six-week season of the Connecticut College School of the Dance well under way, plans for the annual American Dance Festival which is to bring it to a close are swinging into shape.

Hanson W. Baldwin's article "Two Generals: The Climax of the Drama" (July 6) is very interesting. Although I have read of this situation more than once before, his is the clearest and most convincing account which has come to my attention.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 19 -Under fair skies and a tailor-made breeze, 256 sailing craft were out on Long Island Sound today for the opening session of the Larchmont Yacht Club's fifty-fourth annual Race Week.

The Chicago Convention Building and International Amphitheatre, four miles from the city's business center, will show signs of only minor renovation since the Republican convention vacated the arena a week ago last Friday when the Democratic National Convention meets tomorrow.

FROM "Abbey Theatre (Dublin, Ireland)" to "Zog, Ex-King of Albania," from "A P Stores" to "Zysman, (Maj.) Shalom. See Israel." "THE NEW YORK TIMES Index" again records the events and personages of a year, the great and the small.
DENVER, July 19 (AP) -- Charley Coe, the two-time winner from Oklahoma City, and Buster Reed of Sanger, Tex., scored victories today in the semi-finals of the Trans-Mississippi golf tournament.

FROM an incident "told by the people" in Pennsylvania, the author creates a wilderness thriller such as any lucky child might hear from his great-grandparents. Eight - year - old Jonathan lived on the opposite side of Hemlock Mountain from his Aunt Emma and had never crossed it alone.

A 19-year-old Newark factory worker, Jimmy DePiro, became the new Metropolitan junior golf champion yesterday when he won the final at the North Hills Golf Club, Douglaston, Queens, from Murray Vernon of Greenwich, Conn., 2 up.

Most of the important administrative jobs in American colleges and universities are held by men. Such positions as those of college presidents, provosts, deans or business managers go to men, while the women get the relatively minor posts dealing with food, dormitories or libraries.
KANSAS CITY, July 19 -- A Kansas City ward politician sipped beer at a brewery picnic today and sat on the best-kept political secret of the day.

A detective was stabbed, a prisoner was shot and his wife jumped out of a second-floor window in a raid by police of the Narcotics Squad on a Harlem rooming house at 5 A. M. yesterday. Seventeen detectives, including four women, took fourteen prisoners and seized fifteen decks of heroin.

HOME-GROWN bamboo may be the answer to the problem of providing stakes to support weak-stemmed flowers. At best a necessary nuisance, such stakes should be as inconspicuous as possible. Bamboo, in its natural green state, or painted green after it is cured, answers the purpose about as well as anything I have found.

AMONG career stories, some of the most popular have been about nurses. The present pair of books suffers from the usual difficulty of fiction concerned with vocational guidance -- a heavy load of facts. "Linda Kent" deserves most serious consideration, for it makes an honest effort to provide professional information, and to keep Linda's story within the realm of practice.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 19 -- Violence flared in this capital city today, and most shops and business houses closed as the Army moved in to deal with rioting groups of supporters of former Premier Mohammed Mossadegh. The demonstrators hurled stones at buildings and shouted against the new Premier, Ahmad Ghavam.

Leaders in the fields of physical medicine and rehabilitation met in London last week at the first International Congress of Physical Medicine since World War II. They had much to discuss, for there is probably no other aspect of medicine that has increased in scope to such a degree in the last decade.

In a revolutionary move entirely foreign to the food trade, a central buying office has been opened here for supermarkets. The resident buying office will be known as the Super Market Buying and Merchandising Company and will concentrate entirely on purchases of non-food lines for distribution through large chain and independent retail grocery stores.

EARLY this year the commercial airlines cautiously predicted that 1952 might be the best year in the history of air travel. The prediction has been borne out by the business of the first six months of the year, and if the second half remains even near the level of the January-June period, then the airlines will have had their biggest year.

THE summer of 1947 was an uneasy one in Berlin. The great powers had failed at Moscow to settle Germany's future and it was becoming apparent to the citizens of the city that in the struggle between the two Germanys, then slowly taking shape, Berlin would be both a prize and a pawn.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- President Truman predicted today that this country's expanding economy would achieve a total annual output of nearly $440,000,000,000 by 1960, a gain of $100,000,000,000 over current output.

AS naturally as Melba follows peche, so did the cogent proposal to pleasure horseplayers by letting them get down legal bets in Times Square, Wall Street and similar concourses invite an inquiry into the veiled nature of the horse-coper.

Pleasure boating, now at the zenith of the season, is keeping thousands of skippers agog and astir. Folks used to sympathize with golfing widows. Now the yachting wives are left at home while husbands tear hither and yon for the regatta excitements.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 19 -- The acquittal yesterday by a Port Elizabeth magistrate of nineteen non-whites, arrested in the "whites only" section of a post office at Port Elizabeth July 5, has given a sharp jolt to South Africa's system of apartheid (separation of races) and corresponding encouragement to the non-white campaign to resist what are called "unjust laws:"

IN this day and age when the mortality rate among major league managers keeps rising at an alarming rate it comes as something of a jolt to note that there is still one old gaffer on the rolls who, incredible as it may sound, appears to be doing a better job with each succeeding season.

IN his review of "Changing the Attitude of Christian Toward Jew" by Henry Enoch Kagan, Prof. Paul Ramsey makes a serious charge that should not go unchallenged. He state, "For a long time it has been known that the teaching of anthropological or cultural information has no effect on prejudice."

Residents of Parkway Village, the Queens community where hundreds of United Natioons delegation and secretariat personnel are fighting a proposed rent increase averaging 24 per cent, asserted yesterday that the project's owners, a group of fifteen savings banks, sought profits "on $3,500,000 that was wasted in construction."

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 19 -Israel took another big step toward consolidating her status as a state this week by conferring Israeli citizenship on all Jews residing in the country unless they signed a form specifically declaring that they did not want to become Israeli citizens and produced valid papers as citizens of foreign countries.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 19 (AP) -- Three great athletes -- Walt Davis of the United States, Emil Zatopek of Czechoslovakia and Nina Dumbadze of Russia -- will take the center of the Olympic stage tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The State Department made public today a heretofore secret memorandum to the late President Roosevelt, in which Dr. Hjalmer Schacht, Adolf Hitler's "financial wizard," admitted Nazi Germany's readiness for war and world conquest in 1935.

THE big news from the merchant's standpoint last week was the disclosure by the Office of Price Stabilization that it plans to suspend retail price ceilings on a large variety of consumer goods soon. It was indicated that the sharp cut in O. P. S. funds by Congress was the reason for the curtailment in the price control program.

STRAWFLOWERS and cocks-combs are the usual candidates for dried or "everlasting" bouquets. Less well known, the helipterums, with graceful form and pastel colors, supply a much needed contrast to the stiffness of those larger, better-known flowers.
A WEEK or so ago we were strolling in Riverside Park behind a mother and two small boys when the younger of the pair -- he looked about 2 1/2 -- dropped a penny he had been fondling.

THERE is no official explanation of why the "Sister" part has been dropped from the title of Theodore Dreiser's "Sister Carrie," now that this famous novel has been translated to the screen. But if the reason is the film's distributors feared that the full title might mislead somebody into thinking it about a very good girl (which could ruin it at the box office), they need not have troubled themselves.

" OF all the definitions mouthed by a certain branch of the critical fraternity that which has to do with creation in literary fields is the most completely bogus." Charles Angoff quotes George Jean Nathan as saying in a recently published biographical appraisal of that iconoclast.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -The New York State Electric and Gas Corporation of Ithaca, N. Y., seeks Federal permission to construct about fifty-nine miles of natural gas transmission lines and to install an additional 2,200 horsepower at a compressor station in Auburn.

FONTAINEBLEAU, France, July 19 -- In a sunlit clearing in pinewoods of the former royal forests here, Gen. Lauris Norstad formally inaugurated today a new $10,000,000 headquarters for the Allied Air Forces Central Europe, which he commands.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Senator Richard Milhous Nixon, the 39-year-old Californian whom the Republicans have named to the Vice Presidential spot on their national ticket this year, is counted on to attract millions of younger voters to the G. O. P. banner.

GENEVA, Switzerland, July 19 (Reuters) -- A French-German system for pooling freight cars is to be extended to other European countries in the hope that by next year the participating countries will be able to speed the movement of goods and lower transportation costs.

FOR a man who never set foot inside U. S. A., Robert Browning did tolerably well in placing his name and fame before the American public. Miss Greer's excellent scholarly history of Browning's American reputation during the poet's lifetime shows how the trick was turned.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 19 (AP) -- Paavo Nurmi, Finland's great running star of three Olympics, disclosed today his predictions for the distance races in the 1952 games.

SIMPLY and with much human sympathy, this novel tells of a young English widow, left helpless and alone on a Devonshire farm called Lost Hill The story is provided by a Welsh tinker who comes along the village road with a sick child in his cart.

Seven members of the University of Pennsylvania's light weight crew returned from England yesterday aboard the Georgic, triumphantly displaying the Thames Challenge Cup that they won for the second straight time.

SCONE rings -- today's pretty dish -- are a richer edition of the shortcake that, teamed with berries and topped lusciously with whipped cream, has been standard for summer in this country as long as clam-bakes and fish fries.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- James A. Farley, former Democratic national chairman and now a delegate at large from New York to next week's national convention, arrived here today and immediately undertook the role of peacemaker in the delegate disputes and civil rights issue that threaten to split the party.
CHICAGO, July 19 -- Mrs. Alben W. Barkley, wife of the Vice President, said today that he was so active that she could hardly keep up with him.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- The Democratic National Committee approved a new party loyalty affirmation today and then voted temporary credentials for the anti-Administration delegations from Texas and Mississippi. It made the latter action subject to a further questioning of the so-called "regular" party leaders from those two states as to whether they would pledge themselves in advance to support the national party ticket in 1952.
CHICAGO, July 19 (AP) --Wheat futures were firm today on buying attributed to milling and export interests. Soybeans featured the market, however, climbing more than 5 cents a bushel at times.

LONDON, July 19 -- Clement Attlee, leader of the Labor Opposition, declared today that his party would not run away from difficult problems, such as rearmament and the balance of payments "just because we are now in opposition."

PAWTUCKET, R. I., July 19 -- Hal (Red) Keene, the 28-year-old Lowell, Mass., jockey wso is battling Howard Craig for the national riding lead, capped a four-victory splurge at Narragansett today by guiding White Cliff to a four-length triumph in the $9,900 Nursery Stakes.
Soaring to their longest lead of the campaign, the Yankees turned back the White Sox by 4 -- 2 yesterday at the Stadium and now boast a five-and-a-half-length margin over the Red Sox and the Indians.

Morris Bogdanoff and his son, David, who built Tarrytown Crest Homes and the Crossroads in Briarcliff Manor and Briarcliff Manor and River Pines Apartments at Hastings in Westchester County, announced plans yesterday to start work soon on a 215family cooperative apartment project in Irvington-on-Hudson.

NO one knows more about Thomas Hardy's life and publications than Carl Weber, curator of rare books at Colby College. In his several hundred articles, introductions and books he has carefully explored everything anyone now can know about Hardy's American reputation, Hardy music, Hardy editions and Hardy gossip.
The Holland-America Line has decided to build a luxury liner for the New York-Rotterdam route to operate as a running mate for its flagship Nieuw Amsterdam.

The birds begin to sing well before sun-up, the orioles and the robins particularly from their elm-top perches, and soon after that the crows begin to caw. The night's coolness is a benison, persistent on the hills but already flowing with the mists toward the valleys where it will settle and subside by midmorning.
TOKYO, Sunday, July 20 -- The Communists accused the United Nations today of parachuting Red prisoners of war into North Korea to act as spies.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- James A. Farley, former Democratic national chairman, announced today that he would vote for Vice President Alben W. Barkley of Kentucky for the Democratic nomination for President.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The stunning blow struck on June 21 against Communist opposition to voluntary repatriation of prisoners of war in Korea was based on evidence produced by the historians of the American Federation of Labor, it was learned today.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- Except in corn there was a general pick up in the trade volume in Board of Trade grain and commodity futures last week. Average daily sales of grain and soy bean futures were 36,000,000 bushels compared with about 31,000,000 bushels a week earlier and 30,000,000 bushels a year ago.

SARANAC LAKE, N. Y., July 20 -- Property owners along Lower Saranac Lake have become increasingly concerned over the prospect that high water levels sought by boat operators will flood their beaches and seriously affect their summer homes.
PITTSBURGH, July 20 -- White House-sponsored efforts to settle the seven-week-old steel strike broke down again tonight.

When it became apparent that in the atomic bomb we had a weapon that would profoundly change the method of waging war uranium became as important as steel or gold. Ever since, we have been drawing heavily on rich foreign deposits of uranium ore because our own were of a lower grade.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- The Democratic party, which opens its thirty-first National Convention here tomorrow, likes to be known as the "party of the common man." Historians generally agree on the accuracy of this billing. But in explaining how it got that way, they portray a series of glaring contradictions.

The news dispatches on land reform in Iran by Albion Ross appearing under Teheran datelines in your issues of July 13 and July 16 convey the impression that Point Four has done and is proposing to do very little to support Iran's forward-looking ruler in his move to better the economic and social conditions of the peasants upon his royal estate.

DENVER, July 20 -- Aksel Nielsen, a business man of Denver, who is General Dwight D. Eisenhower's host at a ranch in the Colorado Rockies, was asked today what he and the General planned to do during the Democratic National Convention, which begins tomorrow in Chicago.

Methods in use by American steel mills will be of assistance in furthering the objectives of the British steel industry's five-year development plan, according to the findings of a British technical team which recently completed a tour of United States steel plants. The findings are summarized in a report just issued by the British Iron and Steel Federation.
AMSTERDAM, July 20 -- American and other foreign investors continued a buying spree in Royal Dutch and other "international" securities in the first half of last week.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 20 -- Brazilian authorities are increasingly worried about the gold rush in the far northern territory of Amapa, fearing that the disruption of normal activities will more than offset any benefit from the gold that is found.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- A formula for a 1952 Democratic platform that might avoid a party split, such as occurred in 1948 when Southern delegates bolted on the civil rights issue, appeared to have been found here tonight.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., July 20 -- Current intelligence reports, which reflect an increasing Russian capability for air attack upon the United States, provide the sombre background for the first United States-Canadian air defense exercise, which started yesterday and will last for one week.
CAIRO, July 20 -- Premier Hussein Sirry Pasha submitted his resignation to King Farouk at Alexandria today, precipitating Egypt's second Cabinet crisis in less than a month.
YORK, Me., July 20 -- The reenactment of a Puritan church service marked the opening day of the 300th anniversary of the town of York today.

George C. Hanold, retired police lieutenant, died at 8:45 A. M. yesterday after an illness of nine months at his home at 82-81 166th Street, Jamaica, Queens. Death was attributed to heart decease. His age was 46.
