SEOUL, Korea, Monday, July 21 (AP) -- Allied soldiers early today recaptured "Old Baldy," a key hill on the western Korean front and the scene of bloody fighting in recent weeks.

One, the 1953 Fleischman International Carpet Design Competition, held under the auspices of the Detroit Institute of Arts and the Arthur Fleischman Carpet Company, offers awards totaling $2,100 for the best new carpet patterns.

More people are smoking and people are smoking more than ever before, according to a survey of the cigarette industry in the forthcoming issue of Trusts and Estates. Despite this, 40 per cent of the men and 60 per cent of the women in the United States do not smoke.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (UP) -- The Federal Trade Commission dismissed a complaint today against Bond Stores, Inc., and its vice president after the clothing concern agreed to do away with challenged debt-collecting practices.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- More than 6,000,000 families face a steep increase in rents unless their local governments act soon to preserve controls, Tighe E. Woods, Director of Rent Stabilization, said today.

TAMPERE, Finland, July 20 -- Yugoslavia and the Soviet Union both managed to remain in the Olympic soccer football tournament today because the teams of the two rival Communist countries drew, 5 -- all, after a hectic match.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- If the Democrats split this year as a result of decisions taken at their National Convention, the aim of a determined group that unreservedly supports the Administration and the New-Fair Deal is officially to excommunicate some of the most powerful and distinguished leaders of the party.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- Vice President Alben W. Barkley bolstered his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination today with a grueling sixteen hours of radio and television appearances, visits with state delegations and private conversations designed as much as anything to prove that "a man is only as old as he feels."
BERLIN, July 20 -- The German officers who died in the futile attempt to overthrow Hitler in July, 1944, were honored today by their families and by members of Germany's faded military aristocracy.
CHICAGO, July 20 -- Michigan's delegation to the Democratic National Convention lost its fight tonight to overthrow the unit rule imposed by the state convention.
CAIRO, July 20 (Reuters) -- The resignation of Premier Sirry Pasha was reported at first to have been accepted by King Farouk, but Afifi Pasha later issued the following statement:

PITTSBURGH, July 20 -- For the third time this season the Dodgers ran their winning streak to eight games as they beat the Pirates, 8 -- 5, today for a sweep of the three-game series before 14,490 Forbes Field fans.

HAMBURG, July 20 (Reuters) -- Barbara Rotraut Pleyer, the German "girl in white" who interrupted the opening ceremony of the Olympic Games at Helsinki yesterday by trying to make a speech to the crowd, arrived today by plane from Finland.
CHICAGO, July 20 (AP) -- Senator Robert S. Kerr of Oklahoma said today he had "a fighting chance" to win the Democratic Presidential nomination.

CENTRAL ISLIP, L. I., July 20 -- Seven relatives were killed at 5:20 P. M. today when the automobile in which they were riding was struck by a Long Island Rail Road train at a grade crossing a half mile east of the Central Islip station.

The American Geographical Society will confer medals on five of the world's best known geographers on Aug. 5, Dr. George H. T. Kimble, the society's president, announced yesterday. A majority of the 157 companies surveyed by the National Industrial Conference Board have begun programs in the last few months to increase the effectiveness of their sales activities. The board released over the week-end a summary of its findings.

Mia Slavenska and Frederic Franklin brought their new little ballet company into New York for its first local appearance on Saturday night, with Alexandra Danilova as guest artist, and drew some 15,000 persons to the Lewisohn Stadium.

We dropped in the other day at the Israel Exposition that had just opened at 22 West Forty-eighth Street under the auspices of the State of Israel Bond Drive. There were some fine candies on display, a sound brandy, several sweet wines and olive oil.

BONN, Germany, July 20 -- Federal Chancellor Konrad Adenauer announced today that he would propose to the foreign ministers of the Schuman plan nations the establishment of an over-all European political organization, under which the Schuman plan for a six-nation coal-steel pool and the European Defense Community would operate.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (UP) -The Petroleum Administration for Defense recommended today that a rapid tax write-off certificate be granted to a Texas concern for construction of a new aviation gasoline refinery at Florence, Ariz.

Margaret Halsey, author of "With Malice Toward Some," has a new work on Simon Schuster's list for September publication. "The Folks at Home" presents her answers to such questions as why we smoke too much, eat too much, take too many sleeping pills, buy too much, marry too much and drive too fast.
CHICAGO, July 20 -- One of the most practiced and professional groups in political history makes up the official leadership of the Democratic National Convention that opens here tomorrow.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- Trade in lard on the Board of Trade was moderately active last week, with rather continuous pressure of selling by packing interests and also by vegetable oil people. In spite of the fact that considerable lard is being exported the domestic cash trade appears to be a little slack. Consequently processors are finding the provisions pit on the exchange the best market for their excess production.

MOSCOW, July 20 -- The Soviet press today published an extensive analysis of the Democratic National Convention issues, which concluded with a suggestion that some powerful Democratic leaders were prepared to lose the 1952 elections in order to place General Dwight D. Eisenhower in the White House.
CHAUTAUQUA, N. Y., July 20 -- A blind violinist who served as a messenger in the Hungarian underground in the second World War made his American professional orchestral debut here this afternoon.

Time, Inc., magazine publishers, earned $4,215,600 after taxes and all charges, equal to $2.16 a share in the first half of 1952, Roy E. Larsen, president, reported in his statement issued for publication today. In the corresponding six months of last year the net profit was $3,263,100, or $1.67 a share.
CHICAGO, July 20 -- There is one candidate out here who refuses to insist that she and only she is the best qualified for the job.

A small group of department stores is making an attack on rising costs of operations through use of a scientific accounting technique similar to one employed in manufacturing, but new in the retail field.

Agreement has been reached between local communities and Connecticut highway officials on the general alignment of more than 80 per cent of the route of the controversial New England Thruway, according to a study made public yesterday by the Regional Plan Association.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 20 (AP) -- Foreign Office spokesman tonight denied categorically a charge by the Peiping radio that the Allied commander in Korea had admitted to a Belgian diplomat the use of germ warfare.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- Labor leaders at the Democratic National Convention came to the reluctant conclusion today that they could not support Vice President Alben W. Barkley for the nomination for President. They said his age was against him, and his backing from the conservative wing of the party also influenced their decision.

TOKYO, Monday, July 21 -- Armistice delegates of both sides met for twenty minutes at Panmunjom today and adjourned until tomorrow with no indication that progress had been made toward a cease-fire in the Korean war. It was the second successive day in which the United Nations, Chinese and North Korean delegations had met just long enough to permit them to exchange a minimum of remarks before a new recess.
CHICAGO, July 20 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey said today that Democratic National Chairman Frank E. McKinney was "a political traitor" to President Truman's program.

LONDON, July 20 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Claire L. Chennault will begin a last-ditch legal fight tomorrow before Britain's highest court to win back forty transport planes that were handed over to the Chinese Communists last year by the Hong Kong Supreme Court.

The Democrats meet in their nominating convention in Chicago today in a peculiar group of circumstances. In most of their previous meetings the question was solely one of choosing a candidate. Sometimes the choice was so obvious that it took place by unanimous first ballot.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 20 -- Clashes with soldiers and police, demonstrations and agitation continued today in Teheran and many other Iranian cities and towns as large numbers of partisans of the uncompromising anti-British policy of Mohammed Mossadegh demanded that he be made Premier again in place of Ahmad Ghavam, whom the agitators called a "servant of the British."

CHICAGO, July 20 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois was thrown back into the fight for the Democratic Presidential nomination tonight when the Illinois delegation to the Democratic National Convention refused to abide by his personal appeal to it not to vote for him.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 20 (AP) -- America's undefeated eight-oared crew from the United States Naval Academy easily defeated Great Britain's Leander crew today in a preliminary heat of the Olympic rowing competition.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- Democratic leaders speculated today that President Truman might intervene twice and for two men before the party's convention finally picks its Presidential candidate.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The Secretary of the Army, Frank Pace Jr., has written to General Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican nominee for President, that his resignation from the Army has been accepted "with great regret."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 20 -- Three pictures a year for the next two years were added by R. K. O. today with the signing of a contract with Aubrey Schenck Productions, an independent unit organized recently by a former New York lawyer who has been making films here for the last seven years.

In certain areas of India improvement in farming methods has increased wheat crops 63 per cent, potato crops 112 per cent. In Mexico, introduction of the quick-freeze has made possible big markets for shrimp in this country.

Truck drivers and helpers employed by the Railway Express Agency agreed yesterday to accept an offer of a 12-cents-an-hour increase and retroactive pay averaging $225 a man.

The mercury climbed yesterday to 94 degrees at 5:45 P. M., only one-tenth of a point below the July 20 record established in 1894, when Grover Cleveland was President.

Before John C. Wilson left for London recently to double-check with Robert Morley on the star's Broadway appearance in "The Little Hut," he agreed upon terms to book the Coronet for a late September opening of the Nancy Mitford-Andre Roussin play, a popular entertainment of long standing in the British capital.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The nation's active cargo and passenger carrrying fleet decreased 28 per cent between January and July of this year, the National Federation of American Shipping reported today.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 20 -- One thing was demonstrated conclusively again today on Long Island Sound. It was that yacht racing cannot be held without wind -- any more than a political convention can.

The public will finally have law-enforced protection in the purchase of fur products when the Fur Products Labeling Act, which President Truman signed in August of 1951, becomes effective on Aug. 9 of this year.

Last week's foreign exchange market opened with much of the forward swing in British sterling and the Canadian dollar which sparked each to new highs in the preceding week, but on Wednesday a London dispatch that Britain had called a fall meeting of her Commonwealth Ministers to discuss a save-sterling program introduced an easy undertone and reaction from foreweek highs.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- Leaders of the Harriman-Kefauver coalition announced tonight plans for a showdown on the pasty loyalty issue on the floor of the Democratic National Convention. The test may come tomorrow night or possibly Tuesday.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- It was a question today at Wrigley Field whether gusty winds would sweep the game with the Cubs out of reach of the Giants, whether they would kick it away or whether they would run Larry Jansen into a state of utter helplessness and close this third swing through the West on a depressing note.

PHILADELPHIA, July 20 (UP) -- The American League's repeal of the suspended game rule at the recent All-Star meetings brought its first reaction today as the Athletics gained a 3-3 tie by going into slow motion in the tenth inning of the second game after scoring an 8-7 victory over the Tigers in the opener of a double-header.

It is an unpleasant commentary on our life and times that the population of New York's penal institutions is on the increase; so much so that the city must make plans to expand substantially its present capacity to house convicted criminals and persons being held for court action.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 20 (AP) -- Vic Seixas, America's top ranked amateur tennis player, successfully defended his Pennsylvania and Eastern States court title today with an 8-6, 6-4, 6-1 victory over Straight Clark of Pasadena.

MOSCOW, July 20 -- Pravda, Izvestia and other Soviet newspapers today marked the opening of the Olympic competition at Helsinki with a call to Soviet athletes to win world championships and demonstrate the superiority of Soviet sport over that of bourgeois countries.

MEXICO CITY, July 19 (AP) -- Mexico reducecd its export tariffs on a long list of products today to increase sales abroad by lowering prices.

LONDON, July 20 -- Many overseas visitors mingled today with the thousands of Britons who inspected the home of the first Duke of Wellington, admiring the trophies and honors won by Britain's greatest and best-loved soldier, who smashed Napoleon's power at Waterloo.

BOSTON, July 20 (AP) -- Johnny Lipon slashed a bases-loaded single off Mike Garcia in the twelfth inning today to gain an 8-7 victory for the Red Sox over the Indians. The triumph moved second-place Boston to within 4 1/2 games of the league-leading Yankees.

LONDON, July 20 -- Before Parliament goes on vacation at the beginning of August, R. A. Butler, Chancellor of the Exchequer, will make a comprehensive assessment of the effects of the first nine months of the Conservatives' economic policy and announce measures to strengthen or alter it.

CAIRO, July 19 -- After long and arduous negotiations a treaty of friendship, economic development and commerce between Egypt and the United States is now virtually in its final draft. It was scheduled to be scrutinized tomorrow by a special interministerial committee headed by Abdel Rahman Hakky Pasha, Under Secretary for Foreign Affairs.
LONDON, July 20 -- Dr. Hewlett Johnson, the "Red Dean" of Canterbury, repeated Communist charges of germ warfare against the United States from the pulpit of Canterbury Cathedral tonight.

Upward of 70,000 fans are expected to invade the Stadium tonight to see what could be a preview of next October's world series. At any rate, it will bring together the two currently front-running pennant contenders, the Yankees and Dodgers, who will clash in the annual Mayor's Trophy game staged for the benefit of the city's sandlot baseball organizations.

PARIS, July 20 -- According to official figures on France's foreign trade in the first six months of this year, exports to the principal monetary zones dropped considerably from those of the same period last year. These statistics explain the Government's preoccupation with foreign trade problems and the measures taken to increase sales abroad by tax and other relief measures for producers of export goods.

The Commission on Teacher Education and Professional Standards of the National Education Association in its fifth annual report points again to the urgency of the elementary-teacher shortage in the United States. ST. LOUIS, July 20 (UP) -- Three home runs sparked the Cardinals' 8 -- 4 victory over the Braves today as the Redbirds pounded Warren Spahn and Lew Burdette for thirteen hits.

PITTSBURGH, July 20 -- Some metal-working people have been wondering how the steel strike could be really serious when no apparent crisis had appeared after a loss of 15,200,000 tons of steel up to yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- Wheat futures held well last week, while there were substantial price recessions in other grains and in soy beans, except for July soy beans. The action in wheat was regarded as proof that with the huge receipts and rapid accumulation of visible stocks to contend with, bearish factors have been well discounted by the price shrinkage of the last few months.

HONG KONG, July 20 -- Deputy Foreign Minister Chang Han-fu declared in a statement broadcast from Peiping today that Red China wanted to trade with all countries on terms of "equality and mutual benefit" as a means of developing her economy.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- The Federal National Mortgage Association is ready to start using its new authority to buy an additional $900,000,000 worth of Government-backed mortgages for defense, military and disaster housing.

THE ladies in lawn tennis have taken a back seat to the men for many years but a 17-year-old girl from California has wrested the play away from the stronger sex. The Appian Way, constructed by the Romans 2,200 years ago, is in better condition today than many of this country's streets and highways, according to William N. Carey, executive secretary of the American Society of Civil Engineers.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 21 -- Following is the text of the keynote address by Gov. Paul Dever of Massachusetts at the Democratic National Convention here tonight as transcribed by the THE NEW YORK TIMES:
LONDON, July 21 -- Most sections of the London Stock Exchange closed steady today at around Friday's prices after a dull tendency had been thrown off by a modest demand for stock.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 21 -- By ten votes to five, with three abstentions, the United Nations Economic and Social Council indicated today its intention of recommending to the General Assembly the adoption of Spanish as a working language for the Council, in addition to English and French.

ARMONK, N. Y., July 21 -- Despite two heavy downpours that delayed the start for several hours, the nineteenth annual women's open golf championship of Fairfield and Westchester Counties got under way over the hilly Whipporwill Country Club course today.

GENEVA, July 21 -- Swiss authorities have rejected applications by the Communist-organized committee for the encouragement of East-West trade to establish permanent headquarters in this strategically situated neutral country.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- The first dispute among the Democratic Convention factions arose over two Southern delegations, as it did among the Republicans after they assembled here to nominate their national ticket a couple of weeks ago. Then the issue -- which developed into the test by which Eisenhower won and Taft lost -- was joined over the credentials of the Georgia and Texas delegations; now it is the delegations from Texas and Mississippi.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 21 -American athletes all but swept the boards today as little New York-born Lindy Remigino won the closest 100-meter race in Olympic history in a photo finish with Herbert McKenley of Jamaica, B. W. L, for the United States' fourth gold medal of the day.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- Gen. Mark W. Clark has revealed that the Communists have doubled their air-ground strength in Korea during the truce talks but could not sustain a major offensive for more than two or three weeks.
FALLS VILLAGE, Conn., July 21 -- Three persons were injured fatally today in a head-on crash of two automobiles on Route 7 in front of the Housatonic Valley Regional High School.

While there is no question of the fact that a case can be made for "off-shore procurement" of military equipment, your editorial of July 17 weakens the real case by concentrating on some points of doubtful validity.
MOSCOW, July 21 -- The biggest Olympic news for Soviet sports fans today was the account of Sunday's epic 5-to-5 soccer football tie played by the Soviet and Yugoslav teams at Tampere, Finland.

JERUSALEM, July 21 -- Government estimates for a development budget 115,000,000, Israeli (the official rate of exchange is $2.81 for one Israeli pound), were circulated in Knesset (Parliament) today. The estimates cover mainly projects for the expansion of industry, agriculture, communications and housing.

TORONTO, July 21 (Canadian Press) -- A new company to be known as Simpsons-Sears, Ltd., will be formed to buy the mail order agency and order office business of Simpsons, Ltd., it was announced today.
Following is a digest of the address by Senator Paul H. Douglas of Illinois before the Democratic National Convention in Chicago yesterday, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

J. Lauritzen of Copenhagen, Denmark, shipowners and operators, much of whose tonnage is run by the West Coast Line between eastern United States ports and South America's west coast, has announced delivery of the Kista, a vessel designed specifically for navigation in Arctic and Antarctic waters.
Those "gnats" that have been observed in various parts of the city in the last several days concentrated in Bryant Park yesterday afternoon before the storm.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- President Truman today enlisted Allium sativum, a non-secret weapon of psychological warfare, in the conflict against international communism.
TOKYO, Tuesday, July 22 -- Secret sessions for discussion of an armistice in the Korean war, hopefully begun a fortnight ago, apparently reached a complete deadlock today.

Negotiations aiming at resumption of service on Japan's foreign debt -- now something more than $400,000,000, including interest payments in default -- opened yesterday afternoon at the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

CHICAGO, July 21 (AP) -- A New Jersey delegate to the Democratic National Convention said today he was not bound by the state delegation's decision to keep its thirty- two votes uncommitted and declared himself publicly for Senator Kefauver for President.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 21 (AP) -- Comanche, skippered by John Reid of Miami, Fla., slipped into second place today in the Star class Olympic yatching competition.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., July 21 -- Oliver K. Palm of Jamestown was elected president of the New York State Credit Union League, Inc., last night at the Grand Union Hotel at the final session of the three-day annual convention. He succeeds Jack J. Jackman of New York.

Twenty-two detectives and policemen were commended yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri for "outstanding" work in two recent homicides. A 29-year-old pseudo-physicist was arrested for the slaying of Eileen Fahey a week ago yesterday and two teen-agers were seized in the killing of a young rabbinical student in Brooklyn on June 26.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 21 (AP) -- Two 22-year-old students -- Russia's Turij Tjukalov and Britain's Tony Fox -- dominated the long Olympic rowing program today with surprisingly easy triumphs over two of sculling's greats, Jack Kelly Jr. of Philadelphia and Mervyn Wood of Australia.
CHICAGO, Tuesday, July 22 -- Vice President Alben W. Barkley withdrew early today as a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination in a statement in which he accused cer

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 21 -- The biggest United Nations technical assistance program devised for any one country will start Wednesday night with the departure of twenty-four Yugoslav workers for Switzerland, where they will undergo six months' training in the field of public works and construction.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 21 -- The United States accused France today of trying to establish a protected market in French Morocco for her own high-priced goods by import restrictions masked as currency conservation measures, in violation of treaties with Washington and against the interests of the inhabitants of the North African protectorate.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- Sentiment among New York delegates in favor of an early switch from Averell Harriman to another candidate, possibly Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, became so pronounced today that Mr. Harriman and Senator Herbert H. Lehman made special appeals to the delegation to defer second choice commitments.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 21 -- Six nationalist Parliament members, including three Cabinet ministers, sat today as a court of law at Pretoria. They were members of the judicial committee on the High Court of Parliament meeting to hear a request by Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan for the review of an Appeal Court judgment of March 20 invalidating his Government's act to place colored voters on separate electoral lists.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- The Connecticut delegation to the Democratic National Convention caucused at the Conrad Hilton Hotel today and nominated John Golden, New Haven County party leader, as the new National Committeeman. He wil succeed Paul R. Connery of Norwalk, a lawyer, who has held the post for the last four years.

BUENOS AIRES, July 21 -- In attempt to get this country's large stocks of wool moving the Argentine government last night announced a new foreign exchange rate for greasy and scoured wool. As a result of this action by the Ministry Of Foreign Trade, wool exporters may receive up to 33 per cent increase in their prices while allowing Argentine exports to compete with International prices.
CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 21 (AP) -- Texas Democrats attended their national convention all right today.

RANGOON, Rangoon, July 8 -- Burmese Government quarters are becoming increasingly optimistic about the possibility of suppressing the rebel Communist movement. The growing confidence stems from the marked success achieved during the last year in campaigns against the Reds.
TRENTON, July 21 -- A proposal to conduct a twenty-four-day harness racing meet from next July 4 to Aug. 1 at Garden State Park was received today by the New Jersey Racing Commission.

CHICAGO, July 21 (UP) -- Senator Robert S. Kerr of Oklahoma said tonight his Presidential campaign gained no strength today but he still expected to receive about 150 votes when delegates to the Democratic convention start choosing a nominee.

Two new bans have struck "The Miracle," the controversial Italian film that won a United States Supreme Court decision on May 26 upholding constitutional guarantees of free speech and free press for motion pictures.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- Jacob M. Arvey, Cook County Democratic chairman, promised a group of perspiring fellow passengers in a crowded hotel elevator tonight that would ask the Democratic National Committee four years hence to hold its convention "any place but Chicago."
ROCHESTER, N. Y., July 21 (AP) -- The chairman of the United States section of the International Joint Commission predicted today that the level of Lake Ontario could be lowered twelve inches.
CHICAGO, July 21 -- Labor leaders told the Democratic party's platform writers today that if they stood for "people against privileges" the party would be continued in power.

HAVERSTRAW, N. Y., July 21 -- While hundreds of residents looked on early today, the first of the 360-foot concrete and steel boxes that will form the substructure and deck of Pier 57 at the foot of Fifteenth Street and North River was floated in its natural drydock at Grassy Point just north of here.
ALBANY, July 21 -- The State Department of Public Works announced today plans for an informal public hearing on the controversial question of the rising water level in Lower Saranac Lake.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Senator Everett M. Dirksen of Illinois, chairman of the Republican National Senatorial Committee, today named Harold E. Rainville of Chicago and Victor A. Johnston of Washington to direct the drive to elect Republican Senators.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 21 (AP) -- The schedule of events tomorrow in the Olympic Games. (Time is local, followed by New York time):

Under the Employment Act of 1946 it was contemplated that the periodic Economic Reports of the President would be just what that term implies -- economic reports. They have, however, become increasingly political in tone and coloration with each succeeding year.

Abrahom N. Geller, a lawyer for thirty-two years and prominent in Jewish philanthropic affairs, has been chosen by the executive committee of Tammany Hall as the Democratic candidate for General Sessions judge.

The Democratic National Convention had at least two keynote speeches yesterday -- one described as such and delivered by Gov. Paul A. Dever of Massachusetts; the other an address of welcome from the Governor of Illinois, a gentleman going under the name of Adlai E. Stevenson.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 21 -- Frank E. McKinney, Chairman of the Democratic National Committee, declared tonight that the issue of the 1952 political campaign was the people against privilege.

The Saratoga Association inaugurated its "down-state" meeting at Jamaica yesterday, and conditions were generally satisfactory all afternoon except during the feature race. This was the $10,000 added Schuylerville, in which nine 2-year-old fillies were asked to run five and a half furlongs.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 21 -- Omar Hoskins, Federal Conciliation Commissioner, strove doggedly today to effect a truce in the 54-day West Coast maritime strike.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., July 21 -- "Enemy" bombers ranged over Canada today in the opening phases of the first joint United States-Canadian air defense exercise.

The Board of Transportation filed formal charges of neglect yesterday against the motorman and conductor of the B.M.T. Culver Line express train that rolled back and struck a Fourth Avenue express train in the Nassau Street tube at Fulton Street last Wednesday night.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 21 (AP) -- Henry Wittenberg, New York policeman, led a four-match American second-round sweep in the Olympic free-style wrestling competition tonight.

CHICAGO, July 21 (UP) -- Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia accused some of his opponents today of a "deliberate effort to divide the party" because they are "more interested in their own local politics" than in a Democratic national victory.

CANTON, N. Y., July 21 -- Paintings by both professionals and amateurs of the St. Lawrence Valley Art Exhibition group went on display here today on the campus of St. Lawrence University. Backed for the first time by the university, the organization's exhibit included the work of about 150 artists, which will be shown in the Men's Residence through Aug. 22.
MEDFORD, Ore., July 21 (UP) -- The bodies of two executives of a General Motors subsidiary were found today in Crater Lake National Park, each shot once through the head.

Directors of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) at a meeting yesterday in Chicago declared an extra dividend of one share of Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) stock for each fifty shares of Standard of Indiana in addition to the regular quarterly cash distribution of 62 1/2 cents a share.

NORFOLK, Va., July 21 (AP) -- Rumblings of a revival of the Ku Klux Klan in Tidewater, Va., were reported today in the wake of two mass rapings of the wives of service men in Norfolk County yesterday and Saturday.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 21 -- While all Western nations have made it a point of honor to refrain from political propaganda in connection with the Olympics, the camp run here concurrently with the games by the "World League of Democratic Youth" appears to be a deliberate Red attempt to spread Communist propaganda among the Olympic crowds, thereby infringing the time-honored world truce always observed in the past during the games.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The United States has cautioned the Government of Israel against moving its foreign office from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem until the international status of the latter city is determined, the State Department confirmed today.

Michael Krutchoff of Dumont, N. J., who inherits from his father the trait of always being for the underdog, presented $61 yesterday to the National Multiple Sclerosis Society in its offices at 270 Park Avenue. The 12-year-old youngster on vacation from grammar school explained from his home in Dumont that a television appeal by the society three years ago had made him decide that the cause "was worth looking into."

GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 21 -- Frank Sherry, a 17-year-old Fordham sophomore from the Glen Oaks club, shot a 1-over-par shot, 36, 37 -- 73, to win the medal in the thirty-first Long Island Golf Association junior championship at the Cherry Valley Club today.

CAIRO, July 21 -- King Farouk has accepted the resignation of Premier Hussein Sirry Pasha's eighteen-day-old Cabinet and has asked Ahmed Naguib El Hilaly Pasha, Sirry Pasha's predecessor, to form a new Cabinet.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- President Truman, back at work today after a week's illness, watched the opening of the Democratc National Convention on television but did not disclose his reaction. His aides, however, were highly pleased with the speech delivered by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 21 -- Carrying on even with bulging spinnakers while the wandering mid-afternoon thunder squall no more than threatened them, 211 sailing craft were out on Long Island Sound today in the third regatta of Race Week at the Larchmont Yacht Club.
CHICAGO, July 21 -- A variety of careers is represented by the women attending the Democratic National Convention as delegates and alternates.

Advertising gets tied into the political scene whether it wants to or not. President Truman gave the Democrats a powerful political handle to pull in votes of small business men by signing the McGuire bill to re-establish the validity of fair trade pricing, which in effect bolsters brand names and brand advertising.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 21 -- The Democrats registered an indisputable victory over the Republicans on the score of punctuality today, getting their national convention started only a half hour after its scheduled time -- less than half the delay in which the G. O. P. indulged a fortnight ago.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 21 -- The Arab-Asian bloc has failed to obtain enough votes for a special session of the United Nations General Assembly on the Tunisian question. Secretary General Trygve Lie's office announced today that twenty-three countries -- eight fewer than the required number -- had voted for the special session.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, Tuesday, July 22 -- The reluctant Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois appeared headed early today toward ultimate nomination for President in a Democratic National Convention torn by a sectional fight over party loyalty.

TAMPA, Fla., July 21 -- Although held to a draw by Donald Byrne of Yale in the open championship of the United States Chess Federation, Larry Evans of New York, the defender, retained a full-point lead today.
Following is the text of the welcoming address by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois before the Democratic National Convention in Chicago yesterday, as transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- The Defense Department today identified 145 battle casualties in a new Korean war list (No. 610) that reported 24 killed, 113 wounded, 6 missing and 2 injured.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 21 (AP) -- Versatile Hanover, owned by Walter T. Candler of Decatur, Ga., and driven by John Simpson, won the $6,000 His Excellency Trot for 2-year-old fillies tonight at Roosevelt Raceway as the Grand Circuit opened a two-week stand.

PURCHASE, N. Y., July 21 -- New flight patterns at the Westchester County Airport here to reduce the hazard of planes crashing on homes and estates were in prospect today. Complaints had been filed with the Civil Aeronautics Administration by Connecticut and New York State neighbors of the field, which adjoins the state boundary.

THE NEW YORK TIMES is to be complimented on taking public notice through its editorial of July 14 of the inexplicable action of the Board of Education in recommending to the City Planning Commission diversion for other purposes of $200,000, of funds now set aside for the acquisition of public school sites.
A move-to take the nation's 6,000 airline pilots from their American Federation of Labor union into a new independent union was disclosed last night.

MEXICO CITY, July 21 -- A campaign to halt the flow into Mexico of Spanish language periodical published in the United States has been launched by a group of publishers and editors of the leading Mexican newspapers and magazines.
CHICAGO, July 21 -- The first sign of overture from the South for a compromise on a civil rights plank in the Democratic platform for 1952 came today.
The burning hulk of the Norwegian freighter Black Gull, her buckled hull plates glowing cherry red from the fires in her four holds, was towed into the Lower Bay late last night.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, Tuesday, July 22 -- The Democratic National Convention early today told rebellious Southern Democratic delegates that they must take a party loyalty pledge or give up their seats and go home.
Cotton will enjoy popularity this fall and winter such as never before. The style world has watched with interest as this fiber has inched its way into high-fashion position.

On the return of the Giants from their third western trip yesterday, Secretary Eddie Brannick said that outfielder Monte Irvin had been restored to the active list. It is proposed to use Irvin in pinch-hitting roles during the home stand beginning with tonight's clash with the Cardinals.

A uniform price of $4.28 a hundredweight (46.5 quarts) will be paid to dairy farmers for their July deliveries to pool-approved plants in the six-state New York milkshed, according to a forecast issued yesterday by Dr. C. J. Blanford, market administrator of the New York Metropolitan milk marketing area.

HOBOKEN, N. J., July 21 -- Copies of, the proposed $22,000,000 plan to rehabilitate Hoboken's waterfront under auspices of the Port of New York Authority were presented today to members of the City Commission, the municipal legal department and the chairman of a citizens advisory committee.

WHITEVILLE, N. C., July 21 -- Thomas L. Hamilton, Imperial Wizard of the Ku Klux Klan in North and South Carolina, today pleaded not guilty in Columbus County Superior Court here to charges of conspiracy to kidnap and assault.
CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, Tuesday, July 22 -- Following is the text of the "loyalty" resolution introduced at the Democratic National Convention by Senator Blair Moody of Michigan early today:
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced today award of nearly a billion dollars worth of contracts to expand atomic plants at Oak Ridge, Tenn., and Paducah, Ky.

LONDON, July 21 -- Prime Minister Churchill and his Cabinet will hold an extraordinary series of three meetings tomorrow, Wednesday and Thursday to decide upon serious additional measures needed to relieve Britain's economic crisis. The measures will be announced in Parliament next week.
SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, July 22 (AP) -- Chinese troops stormed back up the shell-blasted slopes of "Old Baldy" today and rewon it from Allied soldiers.

The stock market merely went through the motions of operation yesterday as prices ended about on dead center. Traders snied away from doing anything more than carrying out a minimum of business as a new breakdown developed in the negotiations to end the long steel strike, and evidence mounted of industrial strangulation if production was not soon resumed.

Despite handicaps of restricted production quotas and shortages of steel as a result of the steel strike, the Studebaker Corporation and its Canadian subsidiary achieved higher sales and earnings in the three and six months ended with June than during the similar periods a year ago.

Arthur H. Schwartz chairman of the law committee of the state Republican committee, is being considered by Governor Dewey for appointment to the vacancy on the Supreme Court bench created by the death on May 23 of Justice Bernard L. Sheintag.

Applications by the West Coast Trans-Oceanic Steamship Company and the Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., for permission to operate in the intercoastal trade were attacked last week as adding to the "excessive number of operators in the trade."
MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 21 (AP) -- The Fleetwood, a 34-foot Yawl, breezed to victory on corrected time today in the 333-mile Chicago to Mackinac yacht race.

" Indian Tales," by the late Jaime De Angulo, who spent nearly forty years with Indian tribes on the Pacific Coast, will be issued by A. A. Wyn on Oct. 15. It is a book of American Indian folklore, legends and songs, told from the Indian's point of view and in his own earthy idiom.

Novelties and new ideas were well received in the fall lines exhibited at the semi-annual New York Curtain and Drapery Show and the Domestics and Linen Show, which opened Sunday and will run concurrently at the New Yorker Hotel through Thursday.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 21 -- Premier Ahmad Ghavam resigned today after a general strike and riots involving thousands of partisans of Dr. Mohammed Mossadegh, former Premier, and members of the Tudeh (Communist) party. The death toll in Teheran alone was estimated at eleven to twenty, with more than 100 wounded or injured.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 21 -- Betty Hutton, who bowed out as a Paramount star on Saturday, is considering an offer from J. Arthur Rank, British film producer, to play a top role in "Matthew, the Matador," a comedy in Technicolor to be filmed next year in Spain.

A new record in earnings was established by the Atlantic Refining Company and its subsidiaries in the first half of this year with a net of $21,934,000 after taxes and all charges, according to the mid-year statement issued to stockholders yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee labeled Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower a "pseudocrat" today. "He speaks liberal one day and reactionary the next in an effort to impress the electorate," the Tennessean said.

California has been stricken by another earthquake, her worst in intensity since 1906, but fortunately one that has not been followed by heavy loss of life. In a sense, this latest catastrophe of its kind is the price that is paid for some of the most beautiful scenery in the world; for when Nature molded the Pacific Coast she also created the conditions that are best for seismic disturbances.
Scenic artists representing stage and television productions, who have been involved in a dispute with employers, will return to work this week while negotiations for a new contract are continuing.

Mrs. Walter J. Monaghan, wife of a former plainclothes policeman, faces possible prosecution on criminal contempt charges arising from her refusal to appear before the Brooklyn rackets grand jury which has been investigating her husband's financial affairs.

Tightness continues to characterize the New York money market. Federal funds throughout last week held the line at 1 11/16 with the rate carried over to yesterday. Federal Reserve member banks in New York which, on Wednesday showed a deficiency of $30,000,000 in excess reserves, widened this deficit to $160,000,000 on Thursday due to an outflow of funds and repayments of borrowings to the Federal Reserve Bank.

DENVER, July 21 -- The Eisenhower campaign headquarters here characterized the attack today by Senator Paul Douglas, Democrat of Illinois, on Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower as "propaganda." It was indicated that the general himself would not reply to any Democrat, except the Presidential nominee yet to be named.

THE view expressed by Al Prindle last week that the New York State Conservation Department experiment of restricting parts of some trout streams to fly fishing smacked of "class legislation" has drawn the fire of Arthur Gerry of New York and Homer Peters of Albany.

PARIS, July 21 -- In talks begun here today, to be followed by negotiations in Washington this week, the French Government brought new pressure on the United States for early and precise commitments regarding the amount of aid that will be accorded to France in the fiscal year that began July 1.

PARIS, July 21 -- Albouy continues half-hats, the front half, but brings them into line with the head-enveloping trend by making a very deep bandeau in back that is heart-shaped on its upper edge. In fact, so wide is this bandeau molding the back of the head that the opening above it rather suggests a cutout in a hat of one piece.

COOPERSTOWN, N. Y., July 21 (AP) -- Lefty Dick Rozek struck out six men in three hitless relief innings today after Johnny Berardino hit a tie-breaking home run as the Indians topped the Cubs, 4 -- 2, in a major league exhibition game at Doubleday Field.

Reminiscent in design of furniture received in the last few years from Denmark and Italy are two groups that will go on view today in the midsummer furniture opening at Gimbels. As was noted in reports from the furniture market in Chicago in June, such details as a mixture of woods, recessed bases to give a suspended appearance and the sculptured look are being applied to American-made pieces in the lower-priced brackets.

NEW DELHI, India, July 21 -- Prime Minister Jawaharial Nehru and Sheikh Mohammed Abdullah, the Prime Miinster of Jammu and Kashmir, are reported to have reached an agreement whereby that northern state will retain a special position in the Indian Union giving it considerably more autonomy than other states.
A mother and her seven children were evicted yesterday morning from their six-room apartment at 62 Fourth Avenue, near Bergen Street in Brooklyn.
Heavy thundershowers in mid-afternoon brought a temporary respite from the excessive heat yesterday, the mercury dropping sixteen degrees in an hour.
COOPERSTOWN, N. Y., July 21 (AP) -- Paul Waner and the late Harry Heilmann were admitted to baseball's Hall of Fame today in ceremonies conducted in front of the museum.
The Dodgers may win the spring exhibitions, but when it's a world series or something important, the Yankees still seem to hold the winning hand.

The steel strike is now in its eighth week. The union's policy committee voted yesterday to continue the walk-out, although virtually all economic issues relating to wages have apparently yielded to settlement. The sole obstacle now has to do with the union shop.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- The opening session of the Democratic Convention was unusual in two respects. Seldom, if ever, has circumstance granted the favorite candidate the opportunity to make the first speech to the delegates.

The much-publicized plans of the Democrats to improve on the technical aspects of television's coverage of their convention proved something of a boomerang at yesterday's opening session in Chicago. The distractions on the screen during speeches were at least as bad, if not worse, than during the Republican conclave.

The decision of the Department of Agriculture, announced after the close of the market on Friday, to reallocate 200,000 tons of deficit in American beet sugar production to four other producing areas hit the market yesterday.

Small residential properties figure in the most of the Manhattan realty transactions announced yesterday. Several houses on the West Side changed hands, and a home on East Eighty-third Street was taken for a combination residence and place of business.

The Foreign Bondholders Protective Council announced here yesterday that it was prepared to rejoin the London conferences related to the settlement of the Young and Dawes Loans claims against pre-war Germany. The agency said that "a new basis for discussion appears to present a reasonable prospect of an equitable settlement."

Six hundred small-mouth bass fingerlings, the gift of Governor Dewey to Emperor Bao Dai of Vietnam, Indo-China, left the New York International Airport, Idle-wild, Queens, yesterday. They are scheduled to arrive in Saigon on Friday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 21 -- An air letter sheet of 10-cent denomination, which will carry messages to all parts of the world, will be issued by the United Nations Postal Administration on Ang. 29, coincident with the opening of the annual convention of the American Air Mail Society in Norfolk, Va.
COESFELD, Germany, July 17 -- In a rundown castle with plaster flaking, off the walls, thirty-two men, living on a meager German dole, are observing two somber anniversaries.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, July 19 -- Economically one of the wealthiest and most advanced colonial territories in the British Commonwealth, the Federation of Malaya politically is still relatively backward. Representative government and political parties still are in the early stages of development.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 21 -- American Red Cross units from widely separated California cities, operating under direction of the organization's Pacific Area Headquarters here, sent doctors, nurses and canteen workers into Tehachapi today after an earthquake had virtually leveled the town's business district.

Carpet industry leaders predicted yesterday that overcautious retailers would face a shortage of desirable carpet grades this fall. They said the industry was all but out of the swollen inventory goods at all levels and that several mills were already oversold several weeks on wanted goods.

LONDON, July 21 -- Prime Minister Churchill was taken to task in the House of Commons today because two United States Air Forces teams played a baseball game for "The Winston Churchill Trophy" at a Saturday afternoon fete given by the Iver Heath Conservative Association.

Sales of two dwellings in Flushing, Queens were reported by John D. Connaughton, broker. Modesto L. Cordero sold the house at 59-12 160th Street to James Mules and Angelina Faro, and Arthur Sternberg bought the dwelling at 67-32 169th Street from Frank Caramazza. Richard Albert was co-broker in Caramazza sale.
CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 21 -- The "draft Stevenson" boom at the Democratic convention gained solid support today from an unexpected source -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois himself.
The cotton futures market on that New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday, and closing prices were nine to fourteen points net higher.
CHICAGO, July 21 -- Song, scrambled eggs and Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson started the official convention week for women Democratic leaders today.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Treasury announced tonight that tenders for $1,400,000,000 of 91-day Treasury Bills to be dated July 24 and to mature Oct. 23 were opened to the Federal Reserve Banks today.
CHICAGO, July 21 -- Thomas J. Gavin, President Truman's half-vote proxy at the Democratic National Convention, keeps one step ahead of reporters and others seeking him.
TOKYO, July 21 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,317, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Monday, Korea time:

A bulky, olive-drab tractor-trailer, equipped for delicate scientific work, was on display yesterday at First Army Headquarters on Governors Island. The vehicle is a mobile crime laboratory, devised by the Army's Provost Marshal General for use in the field.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- Wheat futures developed a strong tone today, advancing sharply before meeting any heavy selling. Strength in the bread grain tended to stimulate buying in other grains, but in all pits the upturns encountered increased selling.
STAMFORD, Conn., July 21 -- Almost 200 foreign students reached here today to be guests in homes in this area until Thursday morning, when they will board ship in New York for their home lands.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 21 -- The United Nations, which ordinarily conducts its meeting in five languages, listened today to a sixth -- Swahili, the tongue of the Wa-Meru tribe of Tanganyika.

Another installment in the Harry Gross police graft story will be started at 10 A. M. today when thirty-four former plainclothes men go on departmental trial before Third Deputy Police Commissioner James A. Delehanty in the Criminal Courts Building, 100 Centre Street.

A program of research studies to stimulate manufacture of improved machinery and equipment needed by the engraved printing industry will be among the subjects to be taken up at the annual convention of the Engraved Stationery Manufacturers Association, it was made known yesterday.
PARIS, July 21 -- Outsize bathing caps, soft, a little puffy and suggestive of those worn on the beach in the early part of the century, are Gilbert Orcel's exciting contribution to fall millinery.

LOS ANGELES, July 21 -- Fabrics and fashions vie for top honors in the coat and suit collections shown today in the first of the Annual Fall Press Week events sponsored by California fashion creators. A world of new faces appears on domestic and imported woolens, while various blends of synthetic fibers with wool find expression in the more popular-priced suits.
CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 21 -- Following is the program for tomorrow at the Debocratic National Convention. All times are Central daylight time, which is one hour behind New York time:

Placing the problem of the country's juvenile delinquents squarely on the shrugging shoulders of an apathetic public and on inadequate public and child service agencies, the Children's Bureau of the Federal Security Agency rallied representatives of thirty national organizations yesterday to discuss a national program to combat the condition.

The fifth week of the Lewisohn Stadium concerts began last night, and an audience of 9,000 turned out to hear Robert Merrill and Roberta Peters in a program that consisted mostly of individual display pieces for the talents of the two singers.

From now until Labor Day falls like a shroud the summer bachelor will be having the time of his life. Do not think he won't, you who have gone away to the mountains or the shore. Do not pity him, you who have gone away and have taken with you all the noises and nuisances made by children.

The building with forty-eight apartments and eight stores at 2265 Davidson Avenue, in the Bronx, has been sold by Jack Resnick to clients of Morris Mohr, lawyer, for cash over a first mortgage of $130,000. Louis Landsman was the broker.

As the convention gets down to business the Great Democratic Mystery of 1952 remains unfathomed. It is a double-barreled mystery. It involves two fascinating questions, closely related and yet quite distinct: (1) Who will be the nominee? and (2) How will the North-South conflict be resolved?

Chairman McKinney of the Democratic National Committee in his comment, July 15, as to the possibility of drafting Mr. Truman as a Presidential candidate is not convincing. As reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES, he said: "In view of what (the President) told me and his repeated statements, and unless he instructs me otherwise, I feel it my duty to discourage such a (draft) movement."

Production of steel by the nation's steelmaking industry is scheduled to increase slightly this week, but will remain well below the pre-strike level. The operating rate of the industry is scheduled for this week at 15.3 per cent of capacity, equivalent to 318,000 tons of ingots and steel for castings, the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday.

A new single, over-all regulation covering sales to the Federal Government has been issued by the Office of Price Stabilization. The agency revised yesterday its special overriding regulations governing sales to the United States, its agents and suppliers, and re-issued them in a single regulation.
The newest cargo ship of the oldest steamship line in the world was being unloaded yesterday at her Brooklyn pier at Congress Street, before departing on the last leg of a five-month maiden voyage.

PITTSBURGH, July 21 -- Four top industry executives made a dramatic personal appearance before 175 steel union leaders here today, but failed to sway the union from a decision to scrap all the compromise wage and union shop proposals on which tentative agreement had been reached in weeks of efforts to settle the fiftyday-old steel strike.

SAN FRANCISCO, JULY 21 (UP) -- A Federal Grand Jury today Cleared the San Francisco press of allegedly obstructing justice in newspaper articles published during the investigation of last winter's Internal Revenue Bureau scandal.

A Government witness at the trial in Federal Court of fifteen secondary Communist leaders outlined yesterday the "industrial concentration policy" through which the Communists hoped to slow down this nation's war program in the event of hostilities with the Soviet Union.

Most appreciated during the hot months of summer, crisp and refreshing cucumbers are, fortunately, in best supply at this season. This year excessive heat in southern growing areas in June led to shortages and high prices. But the cost has gone down, and from now till well into September the cooling vegetable will be arriving in abundance from New Jersey, upstate and Long Island.

WASHINGTON July 21 (UP) -- The Federal Trade Commission said today three companies had agreed to discontinue certain advertising claims for hearing aids they sell. They will stop using such phrases as "invisible hearing" and "revolutionary invention." The concerns are Maico Company, Inc., Minneapolis; Otarion, Inc., Chicago, and American Sound Products, Inc., Chicago.

TEHACHAPI, Calif., July 21 -California's second greatest earthquake of the twentieth century in intensity rocked a West Coast area of more than 100,000 square miles today, frightening millions and causing at least eleven deaths.
THERE is little likelihood that Joe Gagliardi, who starts the defense of his metropolitan amateur golf title tomorrow at the Ridgewood Country Club, Paramus, N. J., will be ordered off the course.

The Rev. Dr. Leland P. Cary of Stamford, Conn., superintendent of the New York District of the New York East Conference of the Methodist Church since 1951, has been named executive secretary of the New York City Society of the Methodist Church, it was learned yesterday.

Substitutions filed with the Board of Elections up to 5 o'clock yesterday included a Liberal party substitution of Elmer F. Quinn for State Senator from the Sixteenth Manhattan District in place of David J. Graubard. Mr. Quinn is Democratic minority leader of the State Senate.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- President Truman was highly pleased today with the speech delivered before the Democratic national convention yesterday by Gov. Adlai Stevenson of Illinois and was reported to be supporting the movement to nominate him for the Presidency.
PITTSBURGH, July 22 -- Steel shortages forced the Army to shut down its largest shell-making plant today as efforts to end the fifty-one-day-old steel strike slipped back into the do-nothing stage.
CHICAGO, July 22 -- Expressions of delegate sentiment on this second day of the Democratic National Convention more than doubled the known strength of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois.

TAMPA, Fla., July 22 -- Larry Evans of New York, defending the United States Chess Federation open championship, played a routine draw with Arturito Pomar of Madrid in the eighth round today, reducing the titleholder's lead to a half-point.

The titles of "King and Queen of Freckledom" were captured yesterday for the second consecutive year by the same boy and girl at a Children's Aid Society contest at Jones Center, 407 East Seventy-third Street. The winners were Martin O'Connell, 14 years old, of 142 Alden Place, and Irene McClaughry, 9, of 7 High-view Avenue, both in Staten Island's New Brighton section.

CHICAGO, July 22 -- Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia refused today to withdraw his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination and, as chairman of the embattled states' rights Southern delegations, defied the Democratic National Convention to drive him out.

Twenty-five pickets accused State Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman and Knickerbocker Village, a lower East Side limited-dividend corporate housing project, of discrimination against Negroes yesterday at a two-hour demonstration in front of the State Office Building, 270 Broadway at Chambers Street.

There was a good deal of heat in the city's ice business yesterday, and one chilling fact -- a price rise. But ice manufacturers generally insisted that there was plenty of their product to invigorate the city's food and drink, even while some dealers hotly complained of shortages.

The situation in Iran, the key to the Middle East, has taken a grave turn for the worse that must cause rejoicing in the Kremlin. Mohammed Mossadegh, the man who has already brought his country to the brink of ruin, is back as Premier under circumstances and with a program which, should they continue to prevail, can only lead to national suicide, with the Soviets as the heirs to what remains.

Our State Department announced recently that it was discontinuing publication of its Russian-language magazine, Amerika, and, in reprisal for Soviet suppression of its distribution, was ordering that the Soviet Embassy here halt its own magazine.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Defense Production Administration called today for a total outlay of $125,000,000 to expand capacity for production of machine tools by Jan. 1, 1954.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., July 22 (AP) -- J. Raymond McGovern, State Controller, said tonight that the mounting highway accident toll "shouts for tough law enforcement and tough penalties" for traffic violators.

PARIS, July 22 -- In Legroux's handsome collection the new head-enveloping lines are well represented by deep-tilted cloches with soft crowns, by snug little bonnets gathered into a tab at the nape of the neck, by looser puffy bonnets deep in back and by close-fitting Jersey turbans.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The average physician last year earned $12,518, or $980 more than in 1950.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Following is the voting record on key Fair Deal issues in the last eight years of the four avowed candidates from Congress for the Democratic Presidential nomination -- Senators Estes Kefauver of Tennessee, Robert S. Kerr of Oklahoma, Brien McMahon of Connecticut and Richard B. Russell of Georgia.

CHICAGO, July 22 -- With Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, generally regarded as assured of the Democratic nomination for President, speculation turned today to possibilities for the nomination for Vice President. It was agreed that the Illinois Governor, if nominated, would be able to name his running mate, but speculation was based on the theory that he probably would seek advice before picking the Vice Presidential candidate.
Legal efforts by defense lawyers to halt or postpone the departmental trial of thirty-four suspended policemen accused of taking bookmaking graft from Harry Gross proved unsuccessful yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- The Defense Production Administration posted today expansion goals for iron ore, ore transport and alloying metals to support the 20,000,000 - ton steel industry expansion now in progress.

Sales and earnings of the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation for the quarter and six months ended with June declined from last year, according to the semi-annual report issued yesterday by Morse G. Dial, president.
FORT SLOCUM, N. Y., July 22 -- A blending of the religious faith and military power of this country is symbolized in a relatively small gathering of men here on an island garrison post.

TOKYO, Wednesday, July 23 -- Peiping warned the United Nations Command today against attempts to apply "military pressure" to force the conclusion of an armistice in Korea and told the Allies "they will have their heads broken" if the fighting should be extended.

July 23 is a historically significant day for the peoples of Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia. On July 23, 1940, Under Secretary of State Sumner Welles released a declaration of the United States Government which repudiated the devious processes of Soviet Russia aimed at the annexation of the three Baltic Republics.

TEHACHAPI, Calif., July 22 -- After-shocks recorded at the rate of forty to fifty for a twenty-four-hour period kept Southern California on the alert today as hard-hit communities launched rehabilitation programs in the wake of yesterday's earthquake, which took a toll of eleven deaths here.

HONG KONG, July 22 -- Admiral William M. Fechteler, Chief of United States Naval Operations, declared today he thought there would be a truce in Korea even though neither side had yet retreated from its basic stand on the knotty prisoners' exchange issue.

The stock market regained some of its composure yesterday and, without the benefit of any great amount of buying, managed to move higher. Traders again appeared to prefer the sidelines to major moves and this was reflected in the small volume of business.

Dave Koslo, with the aid of a two-run homer by Hank Thompson, continued his mastery over the Cardinals last night, hurling the Giants to a 3-2 triumph over the Redbirds. Not since June 11, 1950, has the St. Louis club beaten the New York southpaw, who now claims thirteen in a row, five this season, over his "cousins."
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- Requests for the return to Mexico of "braceros" employed in Texas and New Mexico cotton fields ran into United States Government opposition today.

ST. LOUIS, July 22 (AP) -- Bobby Shantz, the little man with a big chance of winning thirty games this season, added his seventeenth victory tonight as the Athletics scored a tie-breaking run in the ninth inning to defeat the Browns, 3 -- 2.
Mahogany furniture, dark brown in color and graceful in line, is silhouetted against contemporary pale-colored backgrounds in a group of five model living rooms that go on view today at Stern's.
Although the circumstances of Vice President Barkley's withdrawal as candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination constitute a personal tragedy, its significance has broader implications.

PARIS, July 22 -- Encouraging results in the treatment of cancerous tissue by direct injection of radioactive rare earth isotopes furnished by the United States Atomic Energy Commission from its plant in Oak Ridge, Tenn., were reported here today at the second session of the Congress of Biochemistry.

DETROIT, July 22 (UP) -- Virgil Trucks, who tossed a no-hitter against Washington on May 15, stopped the Senators with one hit tonight as Detroit squeezed out a 1-0 victory before 18,706 fans at Briggs Stadium.

Mr. and Mrs. Matthew A. Kerwin gave a dinner last night at another in the series of South American fetes being held this month in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. The event was in honor of Honduras.
J. K. Buckwalter has been named general sales manager of the Wooster (Ohio) Rubber Company.

Details of Brazil's plan to raise development capital internally by a compulsory loan to be raised tax-wise from individuals and businesses with large income-tax liabilities, were made known yesterday by Licurgo Costa, director of the Brazilian Government Trade Bureau here.

Desperate efforts to arrive at some sort of compromise between the Northern and Southern wings of the Democratic party seemed to be making headway yesterday. The tug-of-war between the two factions had threatened to split the organization again, as it did in 1948; and the danger is not yet past.

PHILADELPHIA, July 22 (AP) -- Karl Drews, who became a father early today for the third time, racked up his seventh victory of the season tonight as the Phillies trounced the Pirates, 8 -- 1, to sweep both ends of a twilight-night twin bill.
Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard denied a motion in United States District Court yesterday for a new trial for Alger Hiss on the perjury charges that resulted in his conviction on Jan. 21, 1950.

Financing of automobile installment sales, perhaps more than any other single factor, has been responsible for the American industrial revolution. Yet forty years ago, it was practically unknown, according to an interesting booklet just issued by the Commercial Credit Company to mark its fortieth anniversary.
PADUCAH, Ky., July 22 (AP) -- Hometown friends of Vice President Barkley greeted his withdrawal from the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination with a mixture of indignation and sadness.
BUENOS AIRES, July 22 (AP) -- Argentina, with one of the world's biggest unsold stocks of wool on its hands, acted today to put it on the market.

Members of the 320th General Hospital, the first reserve medical unit recalled into the Army from New York after the outbreak of hostilities in Korea, will move into a new 1,000-bed hospital this fall at Landstuhl, Germany, where the unit has been stationed since last November.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 22 (AP) -- Only an upset loss by the defending Olympic light-heavyweight champion, Henry Wittenberg, marred an American slam in this evening's Olympic free-style wrestling.

PARIS, July 22 -- Consider the frustrating plight of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas MacArthur 2d -with a triple entry of candidates in the Presidential sweepstakes, two of which since have been scratched, but barred by diplomatic protocol from discussing the race except in private.

LONDON, July 22 -- British hopes for an eventual settlement of the protracted oil dispute with Iran took two setbacks today with the return of Dr. Mohammed Mossadegh to office in Teheran and the decision of the International Court of Justice in the Hague, the Netherlands, that it was not competent to hear the oil dispute.

CHICAGO, July 22 -- Rust reports from the Northwest and also from north of the line in Saskatchewan and Manitoba stimulated buying of wheat today, and it also was noted that primary receipts were dropping sharply while cash wheat was firm, especially the hard winter varieties.

" I Am A Camera" isn't going to reopen at the Empire after all. The John van Druten play, last season's winner of the Critics award, had shut up shop for a vacation on July 12 after a successful run of 262 performances and was supposed to resume around Aug. 18.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, July 22 (UP) -- The new Government of Premeir Ahmed Naguib El Hilaly Pasha was sworn into office today and an official source said it would push Egypt's demands that Britain evacuate the Suez Canal zone and recognize King Farouk as ruler of the Sudan.

Gideon of the Phantom Farm scored his second straight victory by taking the Athol at Jamaica yesterday. A long-priced winner exactly a week previous, Gideon gave a duplicate performance at more reasonable figures in this allowance event, returning $9 for $2 straight.
Police Commissioner George Monaghan named two new unit chiefs yesterday, both to take over next month.

Smoke inspectors assigned to once-a-week marine duty were disclosed yesterday to have tagged with a smoke violation notice a ferryboat operated by the Department of Marine and Aviation -- the department that lends the launch used by the inspectors each Monday for over-the-water operations.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 22 -- A master of tactics and trained to a fine point of perfection, Mal Whitfield repeated his 800-meter victory of London as the United States won three more gold medals today in track and field to raise its total to eight in the games of the Fifteenth Olympiad.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 22 -- This nation's basic foreign policy must continue to be made by civilians and "not be molded by generals -- in or out of uniform," Mrs. Eugenie Anderson, Ambassador to Denmark, told the National Democratic Convention today.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 22 -- They used to talk for years about "Larchmont luck" in the competition at the Larchmont Yacht Club. It came back this afternoon in the fourth session of Race Week.
If Luke Sewell feels like the most frustrated manager in major league this morning nobody can blame him after what happened under the Ebbets Field lights last night.

Under the influence of many pressures our meals are losing their seasonal character. Generally this has been thought to be good. Isn't it wonderful, most of us have exclaimed, that thanks to quick transportation, Northerners can eat in January the strawberries they used to savor only in June.

DENVER, July 22 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower as "supreme commander" of his Presidential campaign today named Gov. Sherman Adams of New Hampshire as his "chief of staff" and "liaison officer" with the Republican National Committee.

TOKYO, July 22 -- In a bold move to expand textile sales in southeast Asia, Japanese industrialists are seeking a merger with Indonesian interests to establish a 1,000,000 ($2,800,000) textile plant in Java.

CHICAGO, July 22 -- Averell Harriman and Senator Estes Kefauver met tonight to discuss a possible pooling of their combined strength in the Democratic National Convention to block the nomination of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson for President and an agreement on a possible compromise candidate.

MARIANNA, Fla., July 22 (UP) -- A six-engined Stratojet bomber burst into flames 7,500 feet over Marianna today, killing its four crewmen and showering a residential section with flaming wreckage that fatally burned two children.

HOWARD M. ERNST of New York thinks that much of the discussion deriving from the State Conservation Department's action in closing parts of a few trout streams to all but fly fishing has "missed the forest because of the trees."
The Institutional Investors Mutual Fund, Inc., announced yesterday that the following had been appointed organizing directors:

ROCQUENCOURT, France, July 22 -- Under the direction of Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway staff officers at Supreme Allied Headquarters here are putting finishing touches on a wide program of autumn maneuvers that will involve the ground, air and sea forces assigned by the various Allied countries to the Supreme Command.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 22 -- The Democratic convention already is showing some of the reverse-English aspects that characterized its Republican counterpart, "the convention that was over before it got started."
CONCORD, N. H., July 22 -- Governor Adam said today that he had accepted an invitation from General Eisenhower to serve in an "important capacity" in the campaign.

ARMONK, N. Y., July 22 -- Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of Century played better than par golf for the second day in a row as she toured the Whipporwill Country Club course in a 2 under 38, 36 -- 74 today. Added to her first round 76, the score put Mrs. Untermyer ahead with 150 after thirty-six holes in the Nineteenth Annual Women's Westchester and Fairfield County open championship for the Weeler Trophy.

Manufacturers who make financial or other contributions to a retailer's catalogue will involve both parties in a violation of the Robinson-Patman Act, Sidney S. Korzenik, executive director and counsel of the National Knitted Outerwear Association, said yesterday.

TAMPERE, Finland, July 22 -- Yugoslavia knocked the Soviet Union out of the Olympic soccer tournament, 3 -- 1, in a rough-and- tumble match here tonight that, but for the resolute intervention of a British referee, would have degenerated into a brawl between the teams from the two rival Communist countries.

ROME, July 22 -- The problem of wealth and poverty can be solved only by increasing the available supply of goods through the expansion of production and by reaching a more equitable division of the income produced by the common efforts of management and labor, according to Pope Pius XII.

LOS ANGELES, July 22 -- Smartly cut jumper dresses, high-rise waistlines on skirts slim as a wand or deceptively full with a slender look, jackets boxy, cutaway or with a modified middy line, sweater blouses of novelty knits or jerseys, fitted-below-the-knee "short pants" for study and play hours -- these highlight the back to college and career girl fashions shown today by California fashion creators.

BOSTON, July 22 (AP) -- The Braves spotted the Cubs a grand-slam homer by Dee Fondy and battled from behind to give Vern Bickford a 6-4 victory tonight as they opened a twenty-one-game home stand. The Braves beat Lefty Paul Minner, seeking his tenth victory, for the third time this season.

When Frank J. Sensenbrenner started out as a 15-year-old postal clerk in the little town of Menasha his home state of Wisconsin was not very far removed either in time or distance from the American frontier. During the long span of his life he devoted himself with conspicuous success to building up one of the great private enterprises of state and nation.

BALTIMORE, July 22 (AP) -- Fred Kovaleski of Hamtramck, Mich., pulled the first big upset of the Middle Atlantic grass courts tennis tournament today by downing third-seeded Hal Burrows of Charlottesville, Va., 6 -- 2, 6 -- 2, in the second day of first-round play.

Harry Grossman, lawyer and former deputy collector of internal revenue in the third district, Manhattan, was endorsed yesterday by the Liberal party as a candidate for Congress in the Seventeenth Congressional District, Manhattan.
Development of three new types of tires was announced yesterday.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 22 (UP) -- France tonight won the team foil event of the Olympic fencing tournament by beating Italy, 8 victories and 42 hits against 6 victories and 62 hits, after the final match was interrupted for 40 minutes while an international jury judged a disputed decision.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., July 22 (AP) -- Property owners along the New York State shore of Lake Ontario said today that their land was being ruined by high water level. They asserted that the Gut Dam and the Ogoki River diversion were the principal causes.

New issues of securities valued at more than $57,000,000 will be offered to investors today. The flotations consist of debentures of a manufacturer of agricultural machinery, public utility preferred stock, and common stock of a phonograph record enterprise. The offerings are as follows:

FLORENCE, Italy, July 22 -- Roberto Capucci, 21-year-old vest-pocket genius, steals the spotlight from his elders today as the fourth Italian high fashion show opens in Florence. Despite the concensus that experience could improve his tailoring skill, buyers and press alike cheer the vigor, imagination and uninhibited originality of the young designer's work.

Coffee futures trading in recent days has failed notably to respond to persistent reports that the Brazilian Government has devised a new plan to buy strictly soft No. 4 Santos and Parana coffees when prices fall below 52 or 52.20 cents a pound f.o.b. Brazilian ports.

Fifty per cent of the dollar value of contract awards made in June by the New York Quartermaster Procurement Agency went to small business, while 10.3 per cent went to manufacturers in surplus labor areas in Massachusetts, New Hampshire, New York, Pennsylvania and Rhode Island.
