CHICAGO, July 22 -- Having driven a steam roller at headlong speed to the brink of the deepest split that has confronted the Democratic party since 1896, the crew of the Harriman-Kefauver Fair Deal machine shrank back today after a good look at the steep and perilous terrain ahead.

KARACHI, Pakistan, July 22 -- For the last four days it has been raining here. The more than three and a half inches that has fallen would make little difference in New York, but to Karachi it is a near-disaster.

ALBANY, July 22 -- A World War I veteran, who finally won a thirty-two-year battle to convince the Government he was totally disabled in service, has received the largest retroactive insurance benefits payment ever made by the Veterans Administration.
Joseph Curran, who has headed the National Maritime Union, C. I. O., since its formation in 1937, has been re-elected president in the union's national elections just closed.
CHICAGO, July 22 -- John L. Lewis issued a strong condemnation tonight of other labor leaders who rejected the Presidential candidacy of Vice President Alben W. Barkley.

The Police Department's Division of Civil Defense obtained forty recruits last night after a simulated air attack in Fifty-seventh Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues. During the demonstration, held from 8:15 to 9:15 P. M., the block was closed to all traffic except buses and mail trucks, which were escorted by motorcycle units of the auxiliary police.

BOSTON, July 22 -- Some fifty rioting convicts, led by two life term killers, broke out of their cells at the Charlestown State Prison today, seized three hostages and set a series of fires in trying vainly to escape from the 147-year-old institution.

AND the Lord God planted a garden eastward in Eden. And the Lord God took the man and put him into the garden to dress it and to keep it." So wrote, among other things, the author of the Book of Genesis. Most authorities think the Garden of Eden was somewhere in the Middle East. But the Middle East is no garden today.

A 19-year-old City College student who, the police said, admitted making bomb-scare telephone calls for the last eleven months to theatres, schools, railroad terminals and public utilities for the "thrill" they gave him, was sent to Bellevue Hospital for observation yesterday after he was arraigned on a disorderly conduct charge in Bronx Magistrates Court.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 22 -- Bill Dodd, 6-foot 5-inch Colgate senior, eliminated Alan Cook of Brooklyn, the defending titleholder, 1 up and then halted Joe Cardemone, N. Y. U., 1 up; to gain the semi-finals in the thirty-first Long Island golf association's junior tournament today.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 22 -- With a warning that California farmers face a loss of $200,000,000 or more unless prompt shipments of tin plate are made available, six agricultural groups today issued an urgent appeal for tin cans in which to pack the state's summer fruit and tomato crops.

CHICAGO, July 22 -- Gov. Henry F. Schricker of Indiana said today that he would place Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois in nomination for the Presidency and he had Governor Steven son's personal assurance that he would accept if nominated.
CHICAGO, July 22 -- Following is the declaration of the Congress of Industrial Organizations on the statement of Vice President Alben W. Barkley:
CHICAGO, July 22 -- A new technique in giving women practical help for the political campaigns ahead was tried today by the Women's Division of the Democratic National Convention.

PARIS, July 22 (AP) -- A group of Texas students last night opened the first Paris production of Lynn Riggs' "Green Grow the Lilacs," upon which the musical "Oklahoma!" is based. The students were unperturbed by Communists who tore down their advance posters:

A four-alarm blaze of undetermined origin swept the basement of an Elmhurst, Queens, furniture store last night and it took firemen almost four hours to bring it under control. Thousands of motorists moving a slow speed along Queens Boulevard watched the fire.

The Gulf Oil Corporation and its consolidated subsidiaries reported yesterday for the first six months this year net earnings of $66,981,000, equal to $2.95 a share. This was exceeded only by the six-month earnings reported in the peak year of 1948.

One hundred and fifty members of the Women's National Republican Club, Inc., met yesterday at luncheon to voice their stanch support of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and promised to "close ranks, forget differences and devote ourselves to one purpose -- winning in November."

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 22 -- The United States declared before the International Court of Justice today that France, in restricting United States imports into Morocco, was exceeding her function as protector and acting in her own interests.

CLEVELAND, Wednesday, July 23 -- A twilight-night double-header that began at 6 o'clock last night and ended a few minutes past midnight this morning left this town plunged in gloom thicker than the night that enveloped the nearby lake.

CHICAGO, July 22 -- President Truman sent word to Missouri delegates to the Democratic National Convention today that overnight developments had cancelled a letter to his alternate that named his choice for the party's Presidential nomination.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., July 22 -- Exercise Signpost, the first joint United States-Canadian air defense exercise, continued today over the North American Continent as the Air Defense Command marked the end of its second year of "on guard with hot guns."

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 22 -- Senator William L. Benton of Connecticut tonight told the Democratic National Convention that control of the United States Senate after the November election "far transcends the personalities" of the Presidential candidates.
HAMEENLINNA, Finland, July 22 (UP) -- Istvan Szondi of Hungary took the lead after the second event of the Olympic modern pentathlon today with 7 points.

A small hotel property in the block south of the Pennsylvania Railroad Station passed to new control yesterday when Buford Realty Corporation sold the three-story building containing stores and rooms at 402 Eighth Avenue, northeast corner of West Thirtieth Street, in a deal negotiated by Brett; Wyckoff, Potter, Hamilton, Inc., brokers. The lot is 25 by 67 feet.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (UP) -- The Government today started a two-year research program designed to lessen the chance of airplane accidents during bad weather instrument landings.
CHICAGO, July 22 (UP) -- Senator Robert S. Kerr of Oklahoma said today he could unite the forces of the Democratic party better than Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois.
A check for $100,425,000, representing the proceeds of a security issue, was turned over yesterday to the Dow Chemical Company to finance expansion over the next few years.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 22 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt received the greatest ovation of the Democratic National Convention tonight when she strode to the platform for a speech attacking critics of the United Nations and defending it as having prevented war in many parts of the world.

At a time when the Democratic Convention in Chicago is providing more important political developments every hour than are produced during a month in normal times, competition in political news from other fronts is bound to be negligible by comparison. It is not, however, nonexistent.

An account of the ascent of Yerupaja, 21,769-foot mountain in the Peruvian Andes, by six college students will be published tomorrow by Rinehart, entitled "The Butcher." The author is John Sack, who accompanied the expedition as Harvard correspondent for The Boston Globe and The United Press.

CHICAGO, July 22 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois was assured of at least twenty-four and possibly as many as twenty-nine of New Jersey's thirty-two convention votes on the first ballot for the Presidential nomination. Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee will get a minimum of three votes from New Jersey.

A family of five Canadian hitch-hikers, including one only 6 months old, began its journey home to Toronto, Ont., yesterday afternoon. The group had hitch-hiked to New York from Toronto in two days. The family left home with $32. The return hitch-hiking was begun with only $4.

LONDON, July 21 -- British shipbuilding has declined this summer after a spring quarter during which an unusually high number of sixty-eight vessels totaling 405,600 tons were completed, Lloyd's Register announced today. Work was begun on only fifty-seven ships during April, May and June but the Register said "such periodic fluctuations are to be expected."

A research scientist in New York is among those who have learned that parking in a restricted area can be expensive, particularly when it involves trips to the Department of Sanitation pounds where seized cars are stored pending recovery or auction.

CHICAGO, Wednesday, July 23 -- Most of the South assented early today to a new compromise pledge of party loyalty after the Democratic National Convention's Credentials Committee had voted permanent seats for anti-Administration delegations from Texas and Mississippi with a total of seventy votes.

WHITEVILLE, N. C, July 22 -- Thomas L. Hamilton, Imperial Wizard of the Ku Klux Klan in North and South Carolina, pleaded guilty today to charges that he had conspired to flog a Negro woman last year.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 22 (AP) -- The United States' heavily favored basketball team will meet Hungary while Russia will oppose Bulgaria in the opening round of the Olympic basketball tournament, it was announced today.

CHICAGO, Wednesday, July 23 (AP) -- Dick Gernert's two-run homer in the thirteenth gave the second-place Red Sox a 4-2 victory over the White Sox tonight before 40,786, the largest night crowd of the season at Comiskey Park.
LONDON, July 22 -- The stock markets improved today although business generally remained restricted by the approach of the parliamentary debate on economic affairs next week.

A civil service board in this area has ordered the reinstatement of Dominic Vita, discharged on Dec. 17 as head of the Inspetcion Division of the Alcohol Tax Unit of the Internal Revenue Bureau in Newark.

Champlain College, situated on the former military reservation at Plattsburg, N. Y., and scheduled for conversion by the Air Force into a bomber base, will continue to function as a college until June, 1953, Dr. William S. Carlson, president of the State University of New York, announced here yesterday.
TOKYO, Wednesday, July 23 (AP) -- United Nations Command headquarters communique 1,319, for twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M. Wednesday, Korea time:

Some disquietude has been reported as a result of Japan's application for admission to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Japanese low-cost competition is feared by some of the signatories, and there is therefore apprehension over the possibility that each country would be required to extend the "most favored nation" treatment to Japan.
Following is the text of the address by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt before the Democratic National Convention in Chicago last night, as transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:...

The scorched and twisted hull of the Norwegian freighter Black Gull rested on the bottom in about twenty-two feet of water near West Bank Light off New Dorp Beach, S. I., late yesterday afternoon with fires that had destroyed her apparently under control.
CHICAGO, July 22 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement by John L. Lewis on the withdrawal of Vice President Alben W. Barkley from the Presidential race:

Jacob Stiber, 44 years old, of 2755 Holland Avenue, the Bronx, a disabled war veteran and civil service employe for twenty-five years, moved in Supreme Court yesterday to oust Deton J. Brooks Jr., administrative assistant in the Department of Welfare, from his $5,400-a-year job.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 22 (AP) -- Philadelphia's Jack Kelly Jr. failed again today to match his father's Olympic sculling championship as a large part of America's rowing hopes foundered in the choppy waters at Meilahti.

CHICAGO, Wednesday, July 23 -- FoUowing are the votes by which the Credetials Comittee seated the "regular;, or anti-Truman, delegatiw from Texas and Mississippi. Each state, district or territory ha tz single vote in swh cotmittee aetiot; the first column i these tables gives the tota votes each delegation will have later o the conventiw floor.

LONDON, July 22 -- Reports reaching here today suggested that King Farouk had restored Ahmed Naguib El Hilaly Pasha to office as Premier because he had reason to fear the disfavor of the Egyptian Army and the possibility of a military coup.

CLEVELAND, July 22 -- As one enters this steaming metropolis, one becomes aware of a rumbling sound that isn't caused by the lapping waters on the near-by lake front. It's the local citizenry and it's asking a lot of questions to which it is not getting the sort of answers it had been led to expect.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 22 -- Herbert J. Yates, president of Republic Pictures, announced today that he was doubling the studio's production budget for the 1952-53 season. Republic's program calls for twenty pictures, which have been reported at being budgeted from $800,000 to $1,600,000 each.
CHICAGO, July 22 (AP) -- At least twenty-eight state and territorial delegations -- including Missouri -- will let members vote as they choose at the Democratic National Convention.

Two pianists, Stell Andersen and Gordon Manley, were soloists with Alexander Smallens and the Stadium Symphony Orchestra at Lewisohn Stadium last evening. It was a Stadium debut for Mr. Manley, and a first appearance this season for Miss Andersen, whose earlier scheduled appearance on July 9 was postponed on account of rain.

SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, July 23 (AP) -- Sixty Allied planes firebombed and strafed Chinese troops who were dug in again on the crest of "Old Baldy," shell-stripped goal of a see-saw battle on the western Korean front.

Today's new film is "Jumping Jacks," a service comedy produced by Hal Wallis for Paramount release and starring the team of Dean Martin and Jerry Lewis, at the Paramount. Norman Taurog directed from a script by Robert Lees, Fred Rinaldo and Herbert Baker.

LONDON, July 22 -- As the British Cabinet met today to consider urgent measures to increase the sales of British goods abroad, a Government spokesman made a plea for "a fair deal" for British exports in the United States.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, July 22 -- British policy is giving increasing attention to the welfare and the aspirations of Chinese inhabitants of the Federation of Malaya. The new attitude is a departure from the traditional approach which put the emphasis on safeguarding the rights and interests of the indigenous Malay population.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 22 -- Dr. Mohammed Mossadegh was charged again today with forming a Cabinet after the downfall of Ahmad Ghavam yesterday and after he had received an overwhelming vote of support in Parliament.

Commodity markets fluctuated widely and irregularly yesterday. Rubber dropped as much as 85 points, cocoa as much as 40. The Spot delivery of wool tops soared 6 1/2 cents a pound. Lead, coffee, sugar and vegetable oils moved in both directions.

The maritime segment of the American Federation of Labor turned out yesterday to honor Joseph P. Ryan upon the occasion of his twenty-fifth anniversary as president of the International Longshoremen's Association.
The election of H. W. Pierce as executive vice president and a director of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation was announced yesterday. T. H. Bosert has resigned as president and director.

Two shafts of the Osceola Lode, in the heart of the Michigan copper country will be rehabilitated and equipped for production at a cost of about $6,000,000, E. R. Lovell, president of the Calumet and Hecla Consolidated Copper Company, announced yesterday in Boston.

CHICAGO, July 22 -- The suspense in this convention is about over. For the Democrats, like the Republicans, the decisive day was the first day. In the opening session the Republicans plunged at once into the crucial question of the contested delegates, and the poll showed that the Eisenhower forces had the votes to defeat Taft.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday, and closing prices were 2 to 7 points net lower than on Monday.

Peggy Mackie of Inwood shot a 1-over-par 37, 37 -- 74 to win low gross honors in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tournament for Class A competitors at the North Hills Golf Club, Douglaston, Queens, yesterday. The Inwood golfer had a net 73, but was ineligible for a net award under the association rules.
CHICAGO, July 22 (AP) -- Out of the running for the Democratic Presdiential nomination, Vice President Alben W. Barkley spent a quiet day at the Blackstone Hotel today.

Cigarette consumption in this country continues to rise and the end is not in sight. The Department of Agriculture's latest forecast, based on the assumption that employment and incomes of consumers will remain at high levels, is that during the 1952-53 marketing year more cigarettes will be smoked than the record -- in round numbers -- 421,000,000,000 purchased in 1951-52. At

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 22 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson's nomination for President on an early ballot seemed likely tonight in a Democratic National Convention restored to comparative serenity.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 22 -- A civil suit was begun in the United States District Court in Los Angeles today by the Anti-Trust Division of the Department of Justice against twelve motion-picture producing and distributing companies and their television-film subsidiaries to break up an alleged conspiracy in restraint of trade affecting the distribution of 16-millimeter prints of their feature pictures to TV stations.

PARIS, July 22 -- The foreign ministers of the six countries forming a pool through the Schuman plan will meet here tomorrow to set the plan in motion and to discuss a proposal to draw a charter for a European parliament to represent the six nations.

CHICAGO, July 22 -- With a declaration that "peace with honor is the greatest of our goals," the nineteen-member Democratic National Convention's subcommittee assigned to draft the party's platform for 1952 recommended tonight a foreign policy plank that called for:

Statements by Andrei Y. Vishinsky, deputy Foreign Minister of the Soviet Union, were introduced in evidence yesterday at the trial of fifteen Communist party leaders on charges of conspiring to teach and advocate the overthrow of the Government of the United States by force and violence.

No prospect of a break in the enervating twelve-day heat wave was in sight last night. It was the longest continuous hot spell with daily temperatures of 85 or higher in the eighty-one-year history of the local Weather Bureau.
CONVENTION HALL in Chicago, July 22 (UP) -- Mrs. Roosevelt also gave the convention a "last message" from the late President Roosevelt, pleading for mankind to work together for permanent peace.

TORONTO, July 22 -- While both the extent and degree of the Soviet bloc's expected attack on the United States constitute the chief enigma on the eve on the eighteenth International Red Cross Conference, opening tomorrow, the Russians have indicated at least that they intend to continue active participation in the League of Red Cross Societies.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 22 -- With forty-two nations out of sixty-four delinquent in fulfillment of pledges to the expanded program of technical assistance to underdeveloped countries, members of the United Nations Economic and Social Council today urged laggard parliaments to expedite passage of the necessary appropriations, lest the lack of operating funds necessitate suspension of major projects.
A preview of fall fashion accessories was offered yesterday by members of the Accessories Committee at the Fashion Group's luncheon meeting at the Astor Hotel.

LONDON, July 22 -- Katharine Hepburn, Mary Martin, Maurice Evans, Boris Karloff and most of the other United States actors presently in London sent a message today to the Actors Equity Association in New York protesting the new restrictions on foreign actors in the United States, announced on Friday without warning.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation told the Government today that it would be forced to curtail expansion of aluminum production facilities unless it received a price increase for the metal.

A four-family house with store at 2008 Bergenline Avenue, Union City, N. J., was sold by Clara von Waldheim to Helen M. Dunn through J. I. Kislak, Inc, brokers, who also sold the two-family dwelling at 140 Forty-ninth Street, Union City, for William Wisk to Thomas P. O'Donnell and the home at 1512 Palisade Avenue, Union City, for Earl Meenachan to Wallace F. Britsch.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 22 -- West Coast shipowners were accused today by Harry Lundberg, secretary-treasurer of the Sailors Union of the Pacific, A. F. L., of blocking settlement of the sailors' strike, now in its fifty-eighth day. Despite Mr. Lundberg's charge negotiations for a settlement continued under auspices of Omar Hoskins, Federal Conciliation Commissioner.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- An indefinite extension of the period in which the nation can complete its defense program will be necessary as a result of the steel strike.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 22 (AP) -- Two American boats won their Olympic yachting races today but trailed European entires in points at the end of the third day's racing. The seven-day regatta ends Monday.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The following table compares the delegates and voting strength of the Democratic and Republican National Conventions:

If television has done nothing else, it certainly has pointed up the drab state of the art of oratory in contemporary political life. The endless stream of rhetoric that has flowed first from the Republican meeting and now the Democratc convention suggests unmistakably that the technique of speech-making is going to need re-examination.
RANGOON, Burma, July 22 -- Prime Minister U Nu in his weekend speech reaffirmed the Government's wholehearted opposition to Communists and announced a new welfare state policy.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, July 22 -- The West German Trade Union Federation after two days of anxious deliberation proclaimed today open conflict between labor and the coalition government of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, July 22 -- The International Court of Justice ruled today by a vote of 9 to 5 that it had no jurisdiction in the British-Iranian dispute over oil nationalization. As a consequence, the court canceled its unheeded year-old injunction calling for a temporary restoration of the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company to control of its property.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce reported tonight that the gross national product had spurted $45,000,000,000 in 1951 to a new record high of $329,232,000,O00 -- but jumping prices accounted for half the rise.

President Truman's rejection of Tariff Commission recommendations for restricting imports of garlic raised hopes among importers yesterday that similar action would be taken on commission-recommended import curbs for Swiss watches and watch movements.

Blood donations to the Red Cross were asked yesterday to fulfill a request from the Defense Department for whole blood to be flown to the fighting men in Korea as an emergency shipment not later than Friday afternoon. The amount of blood required was withheld for military reasons.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 22 (AP) -- Bonnie Widow and Lonway took top honors in the King's Counsel pace for 2-year-old fillies tonight at Roosevelt Raceway as the Grand Circuit meeting swung into the second night of its two-week session. The King's Counsel was raced in two divisions.

LONDON, July 23 -- The fact that the widely used antibiotic drug chloramphenicol, formerly known as chloromycetin, may cause fatal degeneration of the bone marrow has been widely publicized here by the British Medical Journal this week following reports of some deaths from this cause in the United States.

DALLAS, July 23 -- D. W. Conway, Clint, Tex., won the National .20-gauge championship at the fifteenth annual National Skeet Shooting Association meet today with a perfect score of 100/100 and 49x50 in the shoot-off.

What the Army calls its "new "glamorized and steramlined" model of the hard-riding jeep was put on display yesterday at Governors Island. Developed by Army Ordnance, it costs less, rides better, uses less gasoline and has more power and cruising range than previous models.

EAST LONDON, South Africa, July 23 (Reuters). Africans prayed and sang outside the courthouse here today when eighty-five fellow Africans were tried for disobeying pass regulations as part of the passive resistance campaign against racial segregation laws.

CHICAGO, July 23 -- The wind-up today of operations in July, 1952, grain futures was featured by irregular fluctuations, but with a generally easier tendency most of the session. Long liquidation of July wheat was quite heavy at times and there also was pressure on July corn, while the deferred futures of both wheat and corn showed relative strength.
CHICAGO, July 23 (UP) -- Confused California delegates failed to vote today when the Democratic convention decided to seat "regular" delegations from Texas and Mississippi.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, Thursday, July 24 -- South Carolina delegates voted last night to boycott the Democratic National Convention, but quickly changed their minds when delegates from Virginia and Louisiana refused to follow suit.

Current attacks on education are symptoms of a deep-seated feeling that the schools can and should do more than they are doing to help a troubled world, Dr. William H. Bristow, director of the Board of Education's bureau of curriculum research, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (UP) -- American corporations increased their assets by $700,000,000 and cut their debts by $800,000,000 in the first three months of this year, giving them a record $84,100,000,000 of capital for their operations, the Government reported today.

CAIRO, July 23 -- A thrice-wounded Egyptian war hero who is an avowed foe of corruption in the Government and the armed forces seized control of the Army in a coup today and forced a man of his choice into the Premiership.

The nation's second largest manufacturer of electrical equipment, the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, reported yesterday a net income of $31,507,000 in the first six months of this year on net sales of $681,378,000. This compares with a net income of $31,564,000 on net sales of $590,562,000 in the first half of 1951. Increased Federal income taxes took the lion's share of improved sales.
CHICAGO, July 23 -- There is nothing new or surprising in the foreign policy plank of the Democratic platform.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 23 -- In an effort to win the good will of collectivized peasants, the Government has issued instructions that rent and interest on rent be paid to them on the land they brought into collective farms. The Government's attempt to win the cooperation of collectivized peasants follows the successes achieved in pacifying independent peasants with a series of measures aimed at consolidating their positions in farm districts lying outside the great plains.

MRS. KAY TOWNSEND of Shrewsbury, Mass., 26-yearold housewife, has submitted a claim of a world striped bass record (women's version) to the International Game Fish Association. One recent night she caught a striper that weighed 40 pounds 10 ounces from the surf at Cape Cod. An eel was the bait.

Member of the Park Association of New York City took an offshore look at Manhattan yesterday and a view of as many of the parks and parkways as are visible from its encircling waters. For the waterborne inspection tour, more than 100 members boarded the Sightseer of the Circle Line at West Forty-second Street and spent the afternoon looking for traces of greenery in the tangle of the city's skyscrapers and dockside activities.

Projecting a "goal in the foreseeable future" of $1,000,000,000 of sales for the General Foods Corporation, Clarence Francis, chairman of the board, told shareholders attending the annual meeting yesterday in the Park Lane Hotel that he was "talking in terms of volume and not inflation."
TOKYO, Thursday, July 24 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,320 for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Thursday, Korea time:

CHICAGO, July 23 -- Averell Harriman's top campaign advisers, striving to keep the Mutual Security Administrator's bid for the Democratic Presidential nomination alive, were pinning their hopes tonight on a last-minute endorsement from President Truman that, they conceded, might never come.

The sale of the bankrupt New York, Ontario and Western Railroad to Lincoln Epworth, a New York broker, remained incompleted yesterday after a hearing held by Federal Judge Edward A. Conger at which opposition to the plan was expressed by a group of bondholders.

Punch Opera last night offered the second production of its current summer season at the Metropolitan-Duane, 201 West Thirteenth Street, a double bill of "The Devil and Daniel Webster" by Douglas Moore, and Offenbach's curtain-raiser, "La Nuite Blanche," retitled in English "The Smuggler."

PORT DALHOUSIE, Ont., July 23 (Canadian Press) -- Joe Angyal lifted the New York Athletic Club into the lead at the opening of the four-day seventieth Royal Canadian Henley regatta today when he won the 145-pound quarter-mile singles dash, the lone point final on the fifteen-race program in 1 minute 25 seconds.
LOS ANGELES, July 23 -- The sweater look is the popular look in fall separates shown here yesterday by California designers as a feature of California fashion creators' annual Fall Press Week.

The City Planning Commission moved yesterday to help builders of new houses, particularly in Queens, as it set Aug. 13 for a public hearing on a zoning amendment that would liberalize "setback" requirements for two-family houses on corner lots in residential areas.

Posing as reporters for a non-partisan poll on Presidential candidates, three detectives, one a woman, obtained information in a three-week survey in Harlem that led to the arrests yesterday of seven persons in a narcotic ring accused of peddling to teen-agers.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- United States battle casualties in Korea reached 113,363 today, an increase of 520 since last week. The Defense Department's weekly summary, based on notifications to families through last Friday, reported:

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 23 -- A roaring Democratic National Convention that was not allowed to vote for him as a candidate gave its heart to Alben W. Barkley here tonight and all but tore the hall apart in a spontaneous demonstration that guaranteed him a permanent seat in the Democratic hall of fame.

A recent editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES stated very cogently the importance of choosing with care the nominee for Vice President at the conventions. To be sure, the office of Vice President has not been in itself of major significance historically -- who remembers, as a random example, the achievements of Levi P. Morton?

CHICAGO, July 23 -- Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia and Senator Robert S. Kerr of Oklahoma, both candidates for the Democratic nomination for President, said today that they had no intention of withdrawing from the race despite the seemingly mounting strength of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- An agreement aimed at increasing small businesses' share in Navy contracts was discolsed today in a joint statement by Telford Taylor, administrator of the Small Defense Plants Administration, and Herbert R. Askins, Assistant Secretary of the Navy.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, Thursday, July 24 -- The thirty-first Democratic National Convention, expecting to nominate its candidate for President before this day ends, was astir with "stop Stevenson" movements early today and scarred a bit from its North-South troubles on the party loyalty issue.

FRASER, Colo, July 23 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican nominee for President, discussed campaign organization and strategy today with four visitors to his vacation ranch near here in the Colorado Rockies. They were Senator James Duff of Pennsylvania, Ralph Cake, of Oregon, National Committeeman; Gov. Dan Thornton of Colorado and Palmer Hoyt, publisher of The Denver Post.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 23 -- Two more gold medals in men's track and field, making a total of ten, and victories for the Navy eight-oared crew and the Rutgers pair without coxswain in the rowing finals, marked another afternoon of conspicuous success for the United States in the Games of the Fifteenth Olympiad today.
CHICAGO, July 23 (AP) -- Scoring seven runs in the ninth inning, the Red Sox downed the White Sox, 10 to 4 before 8,321 fans in Comisky Park today.

The ads for Saratoga-at-Jamaica programs refer to "eight big races." Yesterday there were eight little races. Six were claimers; the other two were for 2-year-old fillies that had nary a victory to their credit.
The Federal Maritime Board, headed by its chairman, Vice Admiral Edward L. Cochrane, departed for Holland yesterday on a shipping subsidy inquiry mission believed to be without precedent.
CAMDEN, N. J., July 23 -- Frank L. Suplee Jr. was named today to the new post of superintendent of the Delaware River Bridge at the first meeting of the Delaware River Port Authority.
CHICAGO, July 23 -- Senator Estes Kefauver and Gov. Allan Shivers of Texas exchanged angry words outside the Democratic convention building today, but ended shaking hands.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- While the White House announced this evening that the President would go to the Democratic National Convention Friday afternoon, Mr. Truman was busy writing a speech in which he will urge the Democratic party to carry the Fair Deal program forward unmodified.
LONDON, July 23 -- Egypt's new strong man was so little known that on the day he seized power in Cairo news dispatches called him Naguib Mohammed instead of Mohammed Naguib for several hours.
ST. LOTUS, July (AP) -- The Athletics rallied for the second straight time tonight to defeat the Browns, 3 -- 2. St. Louis suffered its seventh consecutive defeat.

BOSTON, July 23 -- Forty-three rioting prisoners, led by two life-term killers, surrendered unconditionally at 5:15 A. M. today and released two hostages after a fifteen-hour siege at the 147-year-old Charlestown State Prison.

As the new law governing charges that can be made by towing companies for hauling away broken-down automobiles from the highways takes effect with the signature of Mayor Impellitteri we have the word of individual City Councilmen that amendments will be introduced for modifying the measure if, in actual administration, it proves to be unduly restrictive.

Lack of steel has compelled the Army to close its largest shell-making plant. * * * Unless tin cans are available soon, farm groups fear that most of the August crop of fruits and vegetables will be lost. * * * These are but two items plucked from one day's grist of news that illuminates some of the disastrous effects of the eight-week-old steel strike.

A 4-year-old girl had a narrow escape from serious injury or death at 7 o'clock last night when she fell from the window ledge of a fourth-floor tenement at 204 Navy Street, Brooklyn. She landed in the waiting arms of a muscular construction worker, Rosario Gugliero, 35, of 36 Bolivar Street, Brooklyn, and came out of the incident unharmed.

CHICAGO, July 23 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois was assured of three additional votes from New Jersey today, raising his total in the state from twenty-four to twenty-seven, when delegates absent from yesterday's caucus recorded their preference.

" The Youthful Queen Victoria," a new work by Dormer Creston, will be published Sept. 19 by Putnam. The biography focuses on Victoria's childhod and education and her first two-and-a-half years on the throne of England. It concludes with her marriage to Prince Albert.

United Nations delegates and civic-minded citizens moved yesterday to prevent the possible disintegration of an international settlement whose continued existence is threatened by a proposed rent increase.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- President Truman, advised by his defense counselors that the nation's arms program was "grinding to a halt," made a new move today to settle the fifty-two-day-old steel strike.
Following is the text of the address by Vice President Alben W. Barkley before the Democratic National Convention in Chicago last night, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Today's new film is "High Noon," a Western drama produced by Stanley Kramer, released by United Artists and starring Gary Cooper, at the Mayfair. Fred Zinnemann directed from a script by Carl Foreman and a story, "The Tin Star," by John W. Cunningham. Thomas Mitchell, Grace Kelly, Lloyd Bridges, Katy Jurado and Otto Kruger are among the featured players.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- An official of the Bituminous Coal Institute disclosed here today that John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America, had served notice that the union was terminating its soft coal contract in sixty days. The official declined to be identified.
In reading of the two vicious killings committed in New York City, both appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES this last week, I am moved to make a few observations and suggestions.
CHICAGO, July 23 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois isolated himself from the general commotion of the Democratic National Convention but his bandwagon kept rolling on.
Average market value of bonds listed on the New York Stock Exchange dropped 21 cents, and aggregate market value fell $1,347,250,179 in June, according to figures just released by the Exchange.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 23 -- The Democratic National Convention gave a rousing demonstration this afternoon for Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee, who earlier in the day had lashed out against a "synthetic draft" for Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois as the party's Presidential nominee.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 23 -- Speaker Sam Rayburn of the House of Representatives called Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower a front for shrewd campaign managers tonight and charged "they wanted him because they want the same old Republican party "changed in nothing but the clothes it wears.

SOUTH RIVER, N. J., July 23 -- The 11,500 residents of this Middlesex County community have had ample time to reflect on modern man's dependence on electricity since a mishap crippled the municipal power plant last Friday.

LONDON, July 23 -- All reports of the military coup in Egypt today left two major questions unanswered: What is the position of King Farouk and what are the chances for future stability and security in the country?
Lewis G. Barber has been appointed merchandise manager for the vacuum cleaner department of the appliance division of Westinghouse Electric Corporation.
WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- Grain futures trading increased 5.7 per cent in the year ending June 30, the Commodity Exchange Authority reported today.

Directors of the Chicago Board of Trade -- the last important hold-out against Saturday holidays in the summer -- voted yesterday to dispense with Saturday sessions after Aug. 2. At the same time, the directors announced that members will be asked soon to vote on extending trading sessions one-half hour to 1:45 P. M. Mondays through Fridays.
PEARL RIVER, N. Y., July 28 -- Development of new solvent recovery techniques that will eliminate the use of sewage outlets from the Lederle Laboratories into the Hudson River, were announced today.
A group of this city's most influential business, industrial and labor leaders has set up an organization to spur action to solve the "sadly neglected" traffic situation.

Once again yesterday domestic sugar worked higher and world sugar eased in trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The No. 6 domestic contract advanced 3 to 4 points on a turnover of 23,150 tons, influenced apparently by renewed strength in the market for actual sugar.
Deputy Mayor Charles Horowitz appointed a three-man committee yesterday with instructions to seek a settlement of a strike of demolition workers that began three weeks ago.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 23 -- India and Pakistan are studying a set of new proposals aimed at clearing the way for a plebiscite to determine the future of the princely state of Kashmir.

THE casual caller on Freddie Capossela -- if casual can be applied to anyone climbing the endless flights of steps leading to the cupola atop Jamaica race track -- will at first regret having gone to all that trouble once he gets there. He'll find himself alone, just outside a small room, from which there will be emanating a string of disconnected phrases, delivered in a firm, clear voice.
LONDON, July 23 (UP) -- Yugoslavia's 3 -- 1 defeat of a favored Russian team in the Olympic soccer play-offs was reported in Soviet newspapers today without comment.
CHICAGO, Thursday, July 24 -- Following is the text of the party platform adopted by the Democratic National Convention early today.

TAMPA, Fla., July 23 -- Larry Evans of New York downed Carl Pilnick of New York in thirty-four moves of a ninth-round match to regain a one-point lead in the annual tournament for the open championship of the United States Chess Federation today.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 22 -William H. Cane's Good Time scored his ninth straight victory as the 2-5 favorite added the fourth annual United States Harness Writers' Trophy to his collection with a 3:08 3/5 pacing performance for one mile and a half at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

Twelve hundred employes will receive wage and other benefits costing 9 cents an hour under an agreement to settle a strike that had shut the American Safety Razor Corporation plant at Jay and Johnson Streets, Brooklyn, since June 5, the company announced yesterday.
FORT SLOCUM, N. Y., July 23 -- Clergymen serving with the armed forces as chaplains were rebuked here today by their own leaders for failure to adopt a dynamic program in a time of national need.
The Reds, of all people, stopped the Dodgers' winning streak at nine yesterday at Ebbets Field.

The departure yesterday afternoon of the Italian liner Saturnia closed out a forty-two-year sea career for the vessel's chief purser, Emilio Empoldi, who will go ashore under the line's compulsory retirement age limt of 60 upon reaching Naples.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 23 (AP) -- Tommy Jacobs of Montebello, Calif., the defending champion, and Don Bisplinghoff of Orlando, Fla., a top challenger, set a fast pace under a torrid sun today in the opening round of the national junior golf championship at the Yale course.

A maladroit attempt by the Soviet bloc in the United Nations to convert the Economic and Social Council into a sounding board for propaganda on alleged infringement of trade union rights in nations other than their own has rightly been rejected by the council.
SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, July 24 (AP) -- Two hundred Allied warplanes blasted a well-stocked Communist supply depot into an exploding inferno yesterday, the Far East Air Forces reported today.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 23 -- This was Junior Day in Race Week at the Larchmont Yacht Club, the time that boys and girls under 18 years old, but well versed in hard knots and hard knocks, take over as captains and crews.
Greens and flowers, which add cool or colorful accents to rooms in summer, might be displayed in some of the new decorative vases now available.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 23 -- Citing Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt's address to the Democratic convention at Chicago as proof of his statements, Mauro Mendez of the Philippines charged today that the United States press had shown hostility to the ideas and ideals of the United Nations.

Collections outstanding against Brazil rose in value by $12,300,000 last month to a new high of $185,500,000, according to a report on Latin-American export credit issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- A recommendation that the nation quit producing some of its major airplane types and concentrate on a few that are considered superior has been made to the Aircraft Production Board.
The Federal Government does not "give a damn whether steel mills are opened to produce defense steel" in the opinion of Charles M. White, president of Republic Steel Corporation.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday its intention to call $45,474,000 of convertible debentures of two issues for redemption on Oct. 29.

It is at this season there is heard in the land not so much the voice of the turtle as the voice of the backseat driver. It is a sound known to all of those who sit at the wheel, trying desperately to apportion attention between steering, watching the road in front and the cars approaching from behind, watching, too, for any sudden emergency.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today an amended plan for the liquidation of the North American Utilities Securities Corporation, investment subsidiary of the North American Company.

Record-breaking revenues and traffic in the quarter and six months ended with June lifted earnings of United Air Lines to the highest in its history despite increased taxes, according to the midyear report yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The amount of money paid for admissions to motion picture theatres in the United States in 1951 was $69,000,000 less than in 1950, the Department of Commerce reported in its July survey of current business. This represented a decline of 5.5 per cent.

Eleven hundred shop chairmen and stewards roared approval last night for an "organizational strike against the open-shoppers and law-defying elements" that they estimated have built up the nonunion women's coat and suit business here to $45,000,000 a year, as compared with a unionized $600,000,000.

TORONTO, July 23 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian Government today made a formal application to the International Joint Commission for a hydroelectric power development on the St. Lawrence River. The project would produce 2,200,000 horsepower for Ontario and New York state.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 23 -- James Stewart has been signed by Universal-International for two pictures, according to word from that Studio today. First of these films will be "Thunder Bay" while the second has not been decided upon.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (UP) -- Glenn McCarthy, oil and hotel operator, told the Government today that speculators would be running "a considerable risk" if they went in with him in a proposed multi-million-dollar "wildcat" oil venture.
Following is the text of the address by Representative Sam Rayburn of Texas before the Democratic National Convention in Chicago last night, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Administrators appointed by the Textile Workers Union of America, C. I. O., have placed funds and property held by forty rebellious local unions and joint boards in trust accounts pending the settlement of a secession movement to the rival United Textile Workers Union, A. F. L., Emil Rieve, president of the C. I. O. union announced yesterday.
Gold medals of the Roman Catholic Order of St. Sebastian were bestowed yesterday upon three members of the clergy and laity of the archdiocese for "outstanding service to church and country."

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations asked President Truman today to reject recommendations of the Tariff Commission for restricting imports of Swiss watches and watch movements.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 23 -- The United States concluded its three-day argument befor the International Court of Justice on its treaty rights in French Morocco today by declaring that the real issue was whether the territory would be integrated into the French economy or would develop freely as contemplated by the 1906 Act of Algeciras.

The liner United States will not attempt another speed run across the Atlantic this year, her operators said yesterday as the 53,000-ton vessel sailed from West Forty-sixth Street for her second voyage to Le Havre and Southampton.

One hundred tanned boys returning from a three-week vacation at the Police Athletic League summer camp, Fox Lair, in the Adirondack Mountains, arrived at 6:10 P. M. yesterday at Grand Central Terminal.

For the second night in a row the Lewisohn Stadium concerts presented two soloists in two concertos. The artists of this double-header were Aldo Parisot, Brazilian 'cellist, who returned after a successful Stadium debut last summer, and Aurora Mauro-Cottone, New York pianist, who played at the Outdoor amphitheatre for the first time.
BOSTON, July 23 (UP) -- Bob Rush notched his tenth victory tonight as the Cubs pounded four Braves' pitchers for thirteen hits to score a 6-2 triumph before 4,308 fans.

CHICAGO, July 23 -- Senator Olin D. Johnston of South Carolina, who has been one of the leading fighters against the party loyalty pledge in the Democratic Convention, collapsed this afternoon on the convention floor. Other South Carolina delegates helped the Senator from the hall and he was rushed to Columbus Hospital in a Fire Department ambulance.

Harvey Matusow, Government witness in the trial in Federal Court of fifteen secondary Communist leaders, was cross-examined at length yesterday by the defense, which touched on almost everything from the witness' ethics to the "violent" melting of ice in a highball.
CHICAGO, July 23 (AP) --Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
An issue of tax-exempt-interest revenue bonds to finance underground parking facilities for the Chicago Park District is being marketed here by a banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.

The Protestant Council of the City of New York was host yesterday at its annual assembly to 2,000 children from 106 daily vacation church schools in Manhattan, who have to spend the summer in the city.

UTICA, N. Y., July 23 -- If all the automobiles and trucks in the state were lined up bumper to bumper they would stretch 14,676 miles, or more than the length of the state highway system of 13,757 miles, according to James R. MacDuff, Motor Vehicle Commissioner, who today addressed the conference of the State Association of Chiefs of Police.
DETROIT, July 23 (UP) -- The Senators pushed across three runs in the sixteenth inning today to beat the last-place Tigers, 5 to 2.

Rear Admiral William S. Maxwell, retired, acting director of the Bureau of Smoke Control, charged yesterday that many property owners recently were concealing the bad smoking conditions of their incinerators by burning only in the night hours.

NEWBURGH, N. Y., July 23 -- New radar controlled fully automatic 75mm "Skysweeper" guns, and anti-aircraft guided missiles will be added to the defense of cities in the United States within twelve to eighteen months, it was learned today.

Practicality and prettiness are combined in several food products that have just arrived at Bloomingdale's from California. Like many of the new, attractively packaged delicacies in other local shops, they suggest themselves as possible gifts for the week-end hostess or perhaps as purchases to brighten up the home table in the summer doldrums.

An elderly woman was run down and killed yesterday by a bus that she apparently had been hurrying to catch. The accident occurred at Fiftieth Street and Seventh Avenue at 11:30 A. M. and slowed traffic through the intersection for nearly an hour.
CHICAGO, July 23 (AP) -- Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia, candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, asserted tonight that "radical schemers" had turned their fire on him.

" LAXDALE HALL,"* Eric Linklater's new novel, is a comedy set to the measure of a Highland fling. As you know if you remember some of Mr. Linklater's earlier books -- "Juan in America," "Ripeness Is All," "Mr. Byculla" -- he has a fine gift for making the preposterous seem plausible, and an even finer gift for making the weighty seem light.

PARIS, July 23 -- The foreign ministers of six Western European nations met today to create a single free market for their coal and steel industries and to explore an even bolder project for a common political authority based on a supranational European parliament.

PHILADELPHIA, July 23 (AP) -- fifth-inning homer by Del Ennis with one on base helped the Phillies grab a 4-to-1 victory over the Pirates tonight. Steve Ridzik, making his second start, held Pittsburgh to five hits in seven innings before Robin Roberts relieved the tiring rookie.

CONVENTION BUILDING, in Chicago, July 23 -- Regardless of what the official program said, this was most notably rumor day at the Democratic National Convention, with candidates and delegates alike plodding around in a great thicket of "I understand -----" bushes and "They tell me -----" trees.

A drop last Week of 952,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end they amounted to 117,380,000 barrels, compared with 118,332,000 a week earlier and 131,483,000 a year ago.

PARAMUS, N. J., July 23 -- After twelve hours of competition in the fiftieth Metropolitan amateur golf championship, two of the 158 starters at the Ridgewood Country Club tied for qualifying honors with 72's.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 23 -- The United States Steel Corporation in a telegram received here today accepted a proposal from six California farm groups to resume the emergency production of tin plate, which would be converted into tin cans to save the state's big crops of peaches, pears and tomatoes.

Eight youngsters, whose ages range from 2 1/2 to 3 1/2 years, are shown at New York's International Airport yesterday after flight from Brussels. In front from left are Mrs. Burnham Sherwood of Chardon, Ohio, holding Sigman Knobel; Hans Winter, who will be adopted by Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Blumenthal of Tulelake, Calif.;

When three years ago Ellen McCloy came to Germany she was received by the German women with the respect that we owe to the wife of the American High Commissioner. Within a short time there grew out of this respect for the personality of Ellen McCloy herself.
WASHINGTON, July 23 (UP) -- Senator Harry P. Cain accused the State Department today of "open hostility" toward efforts to help the West Coast fishermen meet competition from low-paid foreign labor.

Efforts to salvage the burned and sunk Norwegian freighter Black Gull were begun yesterday by the Merritt, Chapman Scott Corporation following a preliminary examination of the hull by Capt. Cornelius Petersen, operating manager of the company's marine-salvage department.

FORT MEADE, Md., July 23 (UP) -- Court martial hearings for Maj. Gen. Robert W. Grow, involved in the "stolen diary" incident, opened here today in surroundings so secret an Army spokesman would not admit at first that the trial had started.

PARIS, July 23 -- Small, narrow at the sides Claude Saint Cyr's hats extend to the nape of the neck in a simple point or into a short supple volant. In velvet, furry felts and nylon plush, the few neutral smoke grays and fur shades are overshadowed by the many brilliant color combinations: emerald and flag blue, yellow and violet, green and red.

Harry Winston, Inc., New York, one of the world's largest diamond dealers, is negotiating with the Portuguese Government for the purchase of the rough diamonds from mines in Angola, Portuguese West Africa, which produce about 8 per cent of the world's supply.
In the realization that new products can make a vital contribution to the growth of a company, industrial management is showing sharply increased interest in research and development procedures.
Your editorial on the Kashmir parley in THE NEW YORK TIMES of July 18 prompts me to make the following observations:

SAN FRANCISCO, July 23 -- Negotiators seeking to settle the strike of the Sailors Union of the Pacific, A. F. L., temporarily shelved jurisdictional issues today in favor of economic questions, but failed to make any real progress, Omar Hoskins, Federal Conciliation Commissioner, said.
CHICAGO, July 23 (AP) -- Fulvous, a daughter of Dixiana Stable's famed Spy Song, today won the twenty-fourth running of the $68,175 Lassie Stakes at Arlington Park.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, July 23 -- Most of Denmark listened tonight to a broadcast by Danny Kaye. With Danish artists, the American comedian gave a one-hour charity program that was relayed also by the British Broadcasting Corporation. His program included one song in Danish.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Arthur E. Summerfield, new Republican National Chairman, took over at national headquarters today, but was silent on his plans.
TORONTO, July 23 -- The eighteenth International Red Cross Conference, the first to be held in the Western Hemisphere in forty years opened today.

LONDON, July 23 -- The stock markets were dull today with the news from Egypt providing an additional restraint to business. British Government securities and leading industrial shares were reasonably firm in the morning, but they reacted later and closed on a dull note.
CHICAGO, July 23 -- The Democratic Convention Platform Committee rejected tonight a Kefauver-backed proposal to set up a permanent Congressional crime committee.

TORONTO, July 23 (AP) -- Ontario representatives told the International Joint Commission today that the high water level on Lake Ontario and the proposed St. Lawrence River hydro-electric development were urgent problems.

GENEVA, July 23 -- The fear of an American depression, which for so long has dominated Europe's thinking about its own and the world's economic future, has largely been replaced by another type of concern and one that is probably easier to deal with.
CLEVELAND, July 23 -- The Indians, it develops, are still breathing, and it wasn't exactly a pulmotor that pumped life into the Tribe, to the delight of 29,697 onlookers tonight.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 23 (AP) -- The United States was forced to settle for one Olympic free-style wrestling gold medal tonight as Russia, Turkey and Sweden each carried off two titles and Japan won the other.
CHICAGO, July 23 (AP) -- Where does Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, who appears to have the Democratic Presidential nomination within his grasp, stand on key public issues of the day?

It is the uniform contention of the Southern states'-rights Democrats that they are as much "for" civil rights as any other group of Democrats but they are "against" F.E.P.C. and other civil rights legislation with teeth in it.

PARIS, July 23 -- Final figures for his gold loan, announced today, showed that Premier Antoine Pinay had achieved a large measure of success in this part of his experiment in stabilizing France's currency.

The International Business Machines Corporation and its subsidiaries had a net income of $13,937,142 in the six months ended on June 30, which is $752,401, ahead of the $13,184,741 earned in the corresponding period last year.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 23 -- A crowd of 20,000 to 30,000 Iranians, voicing anti-United States sentiments and demanding death to former Premier Ahmad Ghavam, gathered today in the bazaar area of the capital in a demonstration of mourning for the dead in the rioting Monday that led to Mr. Ghavam's resignation.

LONDON, July 23 -- With the policy of wage restraint under increasing pressure from organized labor, Prime Minister Churchill undertook today to present the Government's case in person tomorrow to the economic committee of the General Council of the Trades Union Congress.

Seven bids were received yesterday for Leitz, Inc., American distributor for the Leica camera, which was seized by the Government in World War II. Three bids were disqualified, including the high bid of $1,000,000 by Samuel Elison of New York and $818,799 from Robert R. Hammond of New York, because they did not provide for immediate cash payment.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 23 -- It is a particularly sober crowd that is attending the Olympics, in the opinion of the Helsinki police. They stated that last night only 135 drunks were locked up in this capital of 400,000. This is much below the usual figures.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 23 (AP) -- Navy's undefeated eight and a surprising twosome from Rutgers swept to championships in the Olympic rowing finals today. Russia's astonishing Jurij Tjukalov breezed to an upset triumph in the single sculls.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 23 -- The feminine delegates of twenty-one American nations met here today for the formal opening of the eighth assembly of the Inter-American Committee of Women. The meeting this afternoon at the Brazilian Ministry of Foreign Affairs marked the beginning of eighteen days of discussion of questions affecting the rights of women in all the countries of North, Central and South America.

BERLIN, July 23 -- East Germany took the first step today in its planned conversion into a "people's democracy" when its Parliament approved a law revamping the entire internal administration of the country. The five traditional provinces of East Germany were abolished as administrative units in favor of fourteen districts.

CONVENTION BUILDING, in Chicago, Thursday, July 24 -- A Democratic platform for the 1952 campaign that found the party united generally on international and most domestic ques tions but in sharp disharmony on civil rights was approved early today in a voice vote by the national convention.

In another of the continuing series of jewel robberies in apartments on the upper East Side of Manhattan, burglars got away yesterday afternoon with more than $25,000 worth of diamonds from the apartment of Arthur Weiser, an architect, in the elaborate building at 60 Sutton Place South, which he had designed.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended July 16, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

SAIGON, Indo-China, July 23 (AP) -- The French announced today that Communist-led Vietminh forces, in hit-and-run attack on the seaside resort of Cap St. Jacques, killed twenty persons, including ten children and two women.

ARMONK, N. Y., July 23 -- Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of Century regained the women's open golf campionship of Westchester and Fairfield Counties when she added a third-round 78 to her thirty-six-hole total of 150 for 228 over the hilly and rugged Whippoorwill Country Club today.

The thirteenth day of the record-breaking heat wave here spelled bad luck yesterday, causing at least one death, slowing up business, emptying offices, thinning traffic and bringing more misery to the city's heat-weary millions.

ALBANY, July 23 (AP) -- A State Senator and a New York City Assistant Corporation Counsel today urged the Public Service Commission to investigate "fast meters," which they said were cheating illuminating gas customers.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 23 (UP) -- Following is the text of the majority report of the Democratic National Convention Credentials Committee today recommending the seating of all delegations that had been temporarily seated:
Edward Ludlum has signed to direct the revival of Edwin Justus Mayer's play, "Children of Darkness," scheduled for production here in November under the sponsorship of Howard Gottfried.

ROME, July 23 -- In an appeal that was held in the Vatican to be without parallel in the history of the Roman Catholic Church, Pope Pius XII urged the people of the Soviet Union today to resist, "if necessary unto death," the atheistic and materialistic features of communism.
HELSINKI, July 23 (AP) -- The two big early point scorers in the Olympic fencing foils -- the United States and Russia -- suffered heavy casualties tonight.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange experienced another quiet session yesterday and final prices on active months were 3 to 9 points net higher than on Tuesday.
CHICAGO, July 23 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, assured Vice President Alben W. Barkley tonight of undying affection and esteem.

Lack of white lines defining crosswalks on New York streets was cited yesterday as an outstanding factor in the increasing plague of "inchworm" drivers who are creating added perils for the citizenry afoot and awheel. These motorists let their front bumpers protrude over the normally accepted but often unmarked crosswalks, thereby forcing pedestrians into the paths of oncoming vehicles.

MEXICO CITY, July 23 -- Persistent complaints about the exportation of "braceros" -- Mexicans legally admitted to the United States as laborers -- have developed into open pressure on the Mexican Government to re-examine the situation.

TOKYO, Thursday, July 24 -- The official Peiping radio declared today without qualification that the Chinese and North Korean peoples "absolutely cannot" accept the retention of any of their captured troops after an armistice in Korea and "are determined to fight to the end to get all their prisoners returned to their homes to live in peace."

FLORENCE, July 23 -- Fabrics -- such stuff as fashion dreams are made of -- inspired 300 heat-weary American and European buyers to drop their fans and applaud this afternoon and evening at the fourth Italian high-fashion show in Florence's Pitti Palace.

MOSCOW, July 23 (AP) -- Twenty-two Soviet Ministers fulfilled their plans for the second quarter of 1952 but six -- including the heavy machine building industry -- did not, the Central Statistical Board announced today.
OCEANPORT, N. J., July 23 (AP) -- Mrs. Gerard S. Smith's Nilufer made her first stakes appearance a winning one in the Miss Woodford Stakes at Monmouth Park today.

Two rare medieval Hebrew manuscripts of the Mohzorim -- liturgical texts used in synagogue worship -- were presented yesterday to the New York Public Library, the gift of Louis M. Rabinowitz, a New York manufacturer and for many years a friend and donor of the library.

" Oblivious of the obvious," is a disease which plagues the advertising profession. Warren S. Kraft, Seattle advertising agency executive, commenting favorably on the advertising campaign of Lewyt vacuum cleaners says: "Copywriters, artists, clients -- all nurture the ambition for self-expression.

Amazing vigor was shown yesterday by the stock market in spite of further disquieting labor-management news in the steel industry. Interest continued in a group of stocks not ordinarily in heavy favor and fresh strength in the petroleums pushed the general price structure close to the highest levels of the year.

Earl Bryant, 56-year-old house-mover who for a time faced a possible life sentence in prison, was freed yesterday and immediately rejoined his wife and the 8-year-old son he was accused of having beaten.

The Democratic party in convention assembled went through an exciting, exasperating and inconclusive day yesterday. The only thing that was proved by the succession of confused events inside and outside the auditorium at Chicago was that the party is bitterly, profoundly and perhaps irreconcilably divided -- and this has been known all along.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., July 23 -- The touring Oxford-Cambridge tennis team of England scored its second victory on Long Island today, beating Piping Rock, 5 -- 4, at the Piping Rock Club. Earlier, the visitors defeated the Rockaway Hunt Club.

It is hard for persons who try to be rational to understand the extent of personal and group irresponsibility that has engulfed Iran in disaster. Vigorous nationalism is a familiar factor in the political world and it can be constructive. But when nationalism is turned into a sort of mass-suicide complex it leaves the world of political health and gets into the field of morbid psychology.
PARIS, July 24 -- Paulette, endorsing the trend toward hats that envelop the head, designs cloches, toques, wool jersey bonnets and caps deep in back though they reveal the hairline in front.
There is no better test to prove whether two persons can get along together than a 25,000-mile voyage in a forty-five foot ketch.

Of the three works conducted last night at Lewisohn Stadium by Alexander Smallens, one had somehow missed connections up to now. That was Schoenberg's "Verklaerte Nacht," which received its first Stadium performance. Copland's "Rodeo" Suite, a somewhat more familiar work to Stadium audiences, also was played, as was the most familiar piece of all -- Beethoven's "Emperor" Concerto.

Prices of United States Government securities firmed somewhat yesterday despite the continued tightness of the money market. The better tone, most noticeable among the longer-term issues, followed upon a three-day shakeout of speculative holders of the new 2 3/8 per cent bond issue.

PARIS, July 24 -- The Bey of Tunis, nominal ruler of the French protectorate of Tunisia, has dimmed French hopes for quick approval of the French proposed reform program with a message to President Vincent Auriol stating that approval of the program by the Tunisian Cabinet did not commit the throne.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned steadier and slightly more active yesterday, and closing prices were 22 to 31 points net higher.

AMSTERDAM, N. Y., July 24 (AP) -- The Carpet Workers Union, C. I. O., announced tonight that employes of the Mohawk Carpet Company here had rejected a new proposal for ending their seven-week-old strike.
PORT DALHOUSIE, Ont., July 24 (AP) -- The host St. Catharines Rowing Club took the lead today in the seventieth Royal Canadian Henley regatta.

The American Tariff League charged yesterday that President Truman, in his rejection of recommended quotas on imports of garlic, had "gone out of his way to impugn the integrity of the United States Tariff Commission," which made the recommendation.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 24 -- George B. Begole's Silver Riddle from Oakfield, N. Y., with Clint Hodgins driving, scored a smashing half-length victory over favored Pronto Don in world record time of 2:37 2/5 in the seventh annual $25,000 American trotting championship at the Roosevelt Raceway tonight. Silver Riddle paid $12.50.

" Donut Week," "Honey for Breakfast Week," "National Kraut and Frankfurter Week" are all funny, but even funnier is the fact they apparently succeed as promotional schemes. At least they keep coming, which, we judge, is a mark of success. Latest "push" of the kind is "National Sandwich Month," which starts Aug. 1, under the auspices of the Wheat Flour Institute, American Bakers Association and the National Restaurant Association.

A syndicate represented by T. Victor Searing has purchased the seven-story residence club containing 200 rooms and eleven stores at the southwest corner of Broadway and Ninety-ninth Street in a deal negotiated by J. P. and L. A. Kissling, brokers.

CHICAGO, July 24 -- Averell Harriman is being urged by many delegates and influential party leaders in New York to seek the Democratic nomination for United States Senator from New York this fall if he fails to win the nomination for President.

The three-week old strike of 900 demolition workers that has tied-up work on nine public housing projects and affected an estimated 100,000 construction workers, may be settled today if union and management groups accept proposals made yesterday by a three-man citizens committee and Daniel Kornblum, city labor relations division director.

HAVANA, July 24 -- President Fulgencio Batista has granted the Havana Philharmonic Orchestra a subsidv of $150,000 for the 1952-53 season according to Dr. Salvador Bonilla Sosa, who was recently elected president of the organization. One-third of this amount has been delivered, Dr. Bonilla said, and the balance is expected within a few days.

An industrial site comprising 120,000 square feet of land at the northeast corner of Fifty-eighth Street and Fifty-fifth Drive in Maspeth, Queens, has been purchased by the Manufacturers Corrugated Box Company for a new plant. The C. Grant Keck Organization was the broker in the sale.

We now have the platforms of both major parties. And while it is the vogue nowadays (unfortunately, with increasingly good reason) to dismiss party platforms as so much political verbiage, it is nevertheless useful to examine these documents at least for the light they throw on the present state of mind of the two parties and their declared intentions for the future.
CHICAGO, July 24 -- The Democratic convention cheered news of the settlement of the steel strike today and speakers hailed it as a victory for collective bargaining.

CONVENTION BUILDING, in Chicago, Friday, July 25 -- Uncompromising Dixie Democratic leaders from Virginia, South Carolina and Louisiana early today were given full voting rights in the Democratic National Convention, which capitulated completely on the requirement imposed upon all other delegations for a signed party regularity pledge.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- A three-man panel of the Bureau of Finance of the Interstate Commerce Commission today told that agency that changed conditions and enhanced earnings of roads making up the Missouri Pacific System made necessary another look at the 1949 plan of reorganization approved by the commission.

LONDON, July 24 -- Prime Minister Churchill promised British trade union leaders today that his Government would give careful consideration to their complaints against Government action to delay wage increases pending for 1,000,000 workers in the distributive trades.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 24 -- Several angry arguments within the New York delegation and among leaders of the New York and other state delegations preceded Senator Herbert H. Lehman's announcement today of the corrected vote of the Empire State delegation on the seating of the Virginia delegates.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -Following is a chronology of events in the steel dispute that was settled today at the White House:
LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 24 -- A breeze at last! That was the keynote when 194 trim sailing craft convened out on Long Island Sound today for another session of the Larchmont Yacht Club's Race Week.
TOKYO, Friday, July 15 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,321, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Friday, Korea time:
HELSINKI, July 24 (AP) -- America's eight-oar Olympic rowing champions were wined and dined by the Russians today at the Soviet's camp at Otaniemi.

The nation will breathe a sigh of relief that the longest and costliest and most disastrous steel strike in American history is over. This unnecessarily prolonged strike inflicted greater damage on defense production than the worst possible enemy bombing raid could have done.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 24 (UP) -- Mrs. Fanny Blankers-Koen ran her last Olympic race today -- and lost. She should not have run it at all.

THE dramatic triumph of Lindy Remigino in the Olympic 100-meter dash should help to silence unreasoning critics of the method used to select this country's Olympic teams. When the pre-Olympic campaign opened, a dollar bet would have netted a hundred-dollar pay-off for anyone brash enough to back Remigino's chances of qualifying for the trip to Helsinki. That Lindy should be a winner there was totally inconceivable.

PARIS, July 24 -- The so-called off shore purchases that the United States will make in France have assumed a dominant importance for the French Government and aroused deep feelings in the breasts of some of its members.
The appointment of Dr. Henry W. Kolbe as a general medical superintendent of the Department of Hospitals was announced yesterday by Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, Commissioner.
SAN JUAN, P. R., July 24 (AP) -- Puerto Rico will cease tomorrow to be a colonial possession and become a self-governing "Free Commonwealth" closely associated with the United States.

IN 1910, workmen digging a well near Antioch in the Middle East unearthed an ancient silver chalice of early Christian design and workmanship. On it were carved Christian symbols and figures of Christ and the Apostles. It was obviously a sacred vessel and an important one. Some thought the chalice might actually be the cup used at the Last Supper, the Holy Grail of so much song and story.

CHICAGO, July 24 -- Grain futures developed marked strength on the Board of Trade today, and there was also a sharp upturn in soy beans, which helped along the markets in cereals. Wheat buying was active and prices advanced to the highest levels in several weeks, following a little early dip due to moderate hedge sales.

Simplified methods of calculating ceiling prices on new consumer durable goods products were announced in Washington yesterday by the Office of Price Stabilization. Affected are household wares and electrical appliances, radio-TV sets, hardware, notions, jewelry, farm tools, luggage, toys and sporting goods.

MEXICO CITY, July 24 -- After four days and nights of steady rain, Downtown Mexico City was a virtual lake today with parts of it under as much as three feet of water. Commercial life was semi-paralyzed.

BOSTON, July 24 -- The New Hampshire State Planning and Development Commission, one of several departments forced to retrench under the Legislature's latest "austerity" budget, managed to earmark $1 to protect it's scenery by copyright from "theft" by other states.

An eventual compromise agreement seemed likely yesterday in the rent dispute between United Nations personnel living in Parkway Village, Queens, and owner-bankers who have scheduled an average 24 per cent increase effective Oct. 1.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, underwent a major operation today that will prevent him from doing any active campaigning for two months even though he is standing for renomination in the Sept. 9 Wisconsin primary.
CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, Friday, July 25 -- A small fire broke out in some paper on the Democratic National Convention floor early today but quickly was put out.
A full review of the dual rate systems used by ocean shipping conferences is being conducted by the Federal Maritime Board.

Long Island Rail Road patrons will get a chance, beginning tomorrow, to express themselves on the subject of decorating and equipping twenty new passenger cars -but there's a catch. William Wyer, trustee of the bankrupt line, was asked yesterday if plans for improving the road's appearance and riding comfort would necessitate another rise in fares.

Increases will be made in the stakes distribution at Belmont Park in the three weeks of racing from Sept. 15 to Oct. 4, with a total of $425,000 in added money. The daily program calls for an average of $55,000 in overnight races and stakes.

LONDON, July 24 -- Oliver Lyttelton, the Colonial Secretary, disclosed in the House of Commons today that a conference in Central Africa to discuss the federation of Northern and Southern Rhodesia and Nyasaland had been postponed from October to next January.
