HANOVER, Germany, July 24 (Reuters) -- Hanover's Protestant churches rang today to the steps of 5,000 delegates to the second assembly of the Lutheran World Federation which opens tomorrow.

Reflecting the record sales achieved by the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company in the first six months this year, earnings of this major tractor and farm equipment maker increased 8 per cent to $11,510,307 from $10,672,694 in the 1951 half year, despite substantially larger taxes.

BOSTON, July 24 -- A spokesman for the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad testified today that the road had lost approximately $5,000 in three days as a result of "secondary boycott of its trailer-truck haulage by the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Chauffeurs, Warehousemen and Helpers, A. F. of L., Local 250.

WEST POINT, N. Y., July 24 -- Brig. Gen. John H. Michaelis, who won the Distinguished Service Cross and a battlefield promotion in Korea, arrived at the United States Military Academy today where he will serve as commandant of the Corps of Cadets. General Michaelis succeeds Brig. Gen. John K. Waters, who has left for duty in the Far East.

The General Education Board, founded fifty years ago by the late John D. Rockefeller to promote education regardless of race, sex or creed, appropriated $14,352,666 in 1951 to support its program in the Southern states. Total appropriations since its establishment amount to $310,947,000.
BUENOS, AIRES, July 24 (UP) -Owing to unprecedented Government support, Argentine industrial production in 1951 reached the highest level in history, official reports said today.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 24 -- The hearing of the International Court of Justice on American treaty rights in French Morocco reached an unexpectedly sharp climax today when France accused the United States of threatening to impose its own "quasi protectorate" on the territory.

The four-story loft building at 46-48 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by Garry M. Ketcham to the Bassons Picture Framing Company, which insured title with the Title Guarantee and Trust Company. It is assessed at $32,000.

High Dive of the King Ranch registered an easy triumph in the feature race at Jamaica yesterday. Engaging five others in the mile and a furlong test called the Yellow Hand classified handicap, High Dive responded to the commands of jockey Willie Boland to gain the victory by two and a half lengths.

Two new films will arrive at first-run theatres this morning. "Dream Boat," a Twentieth Century-Fox romantic comedy starring Clifton Webb and Ginger Rogers, is at the Roxy. Sol C. Siegel produced and Claude Binyon directed and wrote the screen play from a story by John D. Weaver.
PARAMUS, N. J., July 24 -- The defending champion, Joe Gagliardi of Winged Foot, moved through two rounds in the Metropolitan amateur golf championship today at the Ridgewood Country Club.

Apparently it is a tossup whether adults or children are getting more from the Museum of Modern Art's televised art instruction series, but judging further from letters submitted by viewers, it is obvious each group is deriving plenty.
CHICAGO, July 24 (AP) -- A threatened strike against the Pullman Company, which had been called for next Tuesday and would have affected the country's major railroads, was canceled today.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on July 19 totaled 608,957 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 36,570 cars or 6.4 per cent more than for the preceding week, 196,421 cars or 24.4 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 221,119 cars or 26.6 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, Friday, July 25 -- The thirty-first Democratic National Convention, apparently well on the way to nominating Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson for President, quit for nine hours of rest early today with the whole of the South back home in the party.

CAIRO, July 24 -- The military coup that put the destinies of Egypt yesterday into the hands of Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib Bey and his "free officers" yielded its first fruits today with formation of a civilian, non-party Government headed by Ali Maher Pasha, new Premier.

CHICAGO, July 24 (AP) -- Senator Guy M. Gillette, Democrat of Iowa, disclosed today that the Senate Campaign Investigating Committee is inquiring into charges of excessive spending and "unfair and illegal practices" in the Missouri Democratic Senatorial contest.

TORONTO, July 24 -- The first East-West test in the International Red Cross conference here today resulted in the defeat of a Russian proposal to block the admission of West Germany to the League of Red Cross Societies.

TAMPA, Fla., July 24 -- Accepting the Queen's Gambit offered by the United States chess champion, Larry Evans of New York, in the tenth round, Edgar T. McCormick of East Orange, N. J., played a twenty-five-move draw today in the annual tournament for the open championship of the United States Chess Federation.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The Consumers' Price Index, which measures the cost of living for moderate - income urban families, reached a record-breaking peak in the May 15-June 15 period, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

Robert K. Christenberry, chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, yesterday refused to permit the ten-round heavyweight fight between Rocky Marciano and Harry (Kid) Matthews at the Yankee Stadium Monday night to be held under championship rules.

The trend to more formal attire for brides was indicated again yesterday in the first showing of fall bridal designs by three stores -- Bonwit Teller, Gimbels and Oppenheim Collins. Bonwit Teller and Gimbels devoted almost all their collections of floor-length gowns the majority with sweeping trains, while Oppenheim Collins showed both ballerina and longer length styles.

ENGLEWOOD, N. J., July 24 -- The Board of Education here ended today a three-month controversy over methods governing the selection of textbooks and other teaching materials by adopting policies set forth by the State Board of Education and the State Commissioner of Education.

LONDON, July 24 -- An improvement was reflected in slightly higher prices in most parts of the stock exchange today. However, business remained restricted pending the Government's statement next week on economic affairs.

Fruits are generally more expensive this week-end than a year ago. Plums, for example, cost 12 cents a pound more, cantaloupe and peaches are a nickel a pound higher, and lemons, Thomson seedless grapes and apricots are 4 cents a pound more.
CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 24 -- The Democratic nomination has become more valuable and more coveted as this assembly nears its decisive moment.

In an effort to offset the serious summer slump in Red Cross blood collections, New York Military, District 1242 of the Organized Reserve Corps will hold a block rally at noon today in a roped-off section of East Tenth Street between Broadway and Fourth Avenue.

Max Lanier posted his first triumph over his old St. Louis teammates yesterday. Going the route, Lanier hurled a six-hitter as the Giants hammered four Cardinal pitchers for eleven hits in romping to a 9 -- 5 decision before a Ladies' Day gathering of 9,538 at the Polo Grounds.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 24 -- Hal Roach, president of Hal Roach Studios and veteran film producer, today announced that his company soon would resume making pictures for theatres after having been inactive in the field since 1946.

The final volume in Salvador de Madariaga's trilogy, "The Rise and Fall of the Spanish American Empire," will be published Sept. 12 by Pellegrini Cudahy. Following "Christopher Columbus the Discoverer" and "Hernan Cortes: Conqueror of Mexico," the founder of the empire, the forthcoming biography, "Bolivar," spans the dissolution of the old order and the birth pangs of the new. The book, which will contain more than 800 pages, will sell for $10.

An increase of $26,262,399 in new business written in the first six months this year over the 1951 period and a rise of $123,456,247 in insurance in force since the first of the year was reported yesterday by Leland J. Kalmbach, president of the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company.

LOS ANGELES, July 24 -- Tissue weight fabrics made fashion news in today's Fall Fashion showings. "Husbandry and home decoration" was the title California fashion creators, under whose a auspices the showings are held, selected for this group of flattering daytime, cocktail and evening costumes.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (UP) -- Dr. John R. Steelman, acting Defense Mobilizer, set up a new advisory committee on critical defense housing areas today, headed by Roger L. Putnam, Economic Stabilizer.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 24 -- A short two-stroke run for goal in the final thirty seconds of play enabled the Bostwick Field poloists to defeat Brandywine, 8 -- 7, for the Hempstead 12-goal cup on Hitchcock Field at the Meadow Brook Club today.
A program of music by Gian-Carlo Menotti will be presented at Lewisohn Stadium Thursday evening as a highlight of the final week of the 1952 stadium concert season.
W. E. Kimbrough has been appointed manager of the truck sales department in the general sales office of the Ford division of Ford Motor Company.

CHICAGO, July 24 -- Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee and Averell Harriman, Director for Mutual Security, huddled in a hotel-room for thirty minutes today in a final effort to halt a draft of Gov. Adlai Stevenson of Illinois as the Democratic Presidential nominee.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 24 -- The vice chairman of the New York State Democratic Committee Stepped into the convention building this afternoon and found herself caught in a roaring, cheering crowd.

With the hiring of twenty new inspectors and the prospective hiring of several more within the next few days the Department of Housing and Buildings began yesterday carrying out one of the major recommendations made recently by Mayor Impellitteri's six-man committee on improvement of slum conditions.
Small wonder that the Swiss industry is rather uneasy about and aggravated by the tariff increase planned on the import of Swiss watches and movements.

CHICAGO, July 24 -- The "little man who wasn't there" except at the right time lectured his fellow delegates from Missouri today about their poor attendance at the Democratic National Convention before he told them of President Truman's vote.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 24 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh's new director of police for Iran went on the radio today to warn the nation against the efforts of the Tudeh party (Communists) to realize their aims under the guise of nationalism following the strong Communist bid in Monday's riots for a united front with nationalist groups.
CLEVELAND, July 24 -- There were two good reasons why the Yankees were set to go all out today to win their series finale with the Indians.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., July 24 -- Maureen Orcutt of Ridgewood won the low gross honors in a Women's Metropolitan Golf Association Class A and B one-day tournament today by carding a 4 over par 36, 42 -- 78 over the Essex County course.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Oscar Collazo, the Blair House assassin, was spared by President Truman today.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 24 (AP) -- The schedule of events tomorrow in the Olympic Games (Time is local, followed by New York time):

PHILADELPHIA, July 24 -- The New York shipbuilding company of Ira S. Bushey Sons abandoned today its efforts to salvage the tanker F. L. Hayes, which has partly blocked the Chesapeake and Delaware Canal since it exploded and sank in flames near St. Georges, Del., May 15.

ST. LOUIS, July 24 (AP) -- Bobby Young's sixth-inning home run, his third of the season, was the decisive blow as the Browns snapped a seven-game losing streak with a 4-to-3 triumph over the Athletics tonight. Ned Garver hurled the victory. The box score:
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The effects of the steel strike on small business were shown in a spot check made throughout the country last Saturday by the Small Defense Plants Administration.

Although sales of the General Electric Company for tile first six months this year were only 1 per cent less than the record volume attained in the corresponding period a year ago, the company's earnings declined 19 per cent.

Further investigation by the police of the East Fifty-first Street station of a robbery on Wednesday at 60 Sutton Place South revealed yesterday that five other apartments in the fashionable air-conditioned building had been entered. The thieves attempted to get into two more.

Futures prices on the local commodity exchanges generally worked higher yesterday in relatively quiet trading. Rubber, lead, zinc, cocoa, coffee and vegetable oils finished higher, while sugar was lower and hides and wool were mixed.
CHICAGO, July 24 (UP) -- Bob Hope, the comedian who is here as a television convention commentator, made a command appearance today before an official of the Superior Court.
ALBANY, July 24 -- More new polio cases were reported upstate during the week ended last Saturday than during the comparable weeks of 1951 or 1950, the State Health Department announced today.

CHICAGO, July 24 (UP) -- Senator Russell B. Long of Louisiana and the son of another Louisiana delegate heatedly debated the Southern revolt issue today on the floor of the Democratic National Convention.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 24 --The first "free and open" National Convention of the Democratic party since 1932, if it manages to put the best potential Democratic vote-getter at the head of its ticket in 1952, can trace that good fortune to a stroke of destiny four years before it assembled.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The State Department today attributed the massive anti-United States demonsration in Teheran yesterday to the participation of the Iranian Communists.

CHICAGO, July 24 (UP) -- Lou Kretlow won his first victory of 1952 today. He hurled his first complete game and limited the Red Sox to two hits as the White Sox Won, 3 to 0. It was the tenth shut-out for the White Sox.

Duke Snider saved the Dodgers wear, tear, time and effort, along with a length in the National League race, when he blasted his twelfth homer of the year in the eleventh inning of the second game against the Reds yesterday at Ebbets Field.

NEW DELHI, India, July 24 -- A special position for the State of Jammu and Kashmir within the Indian Union was conceded today by Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru. In explaining the situation to Parliament he declared that the Indian Government intended to abide by its commitments to the United Nations Security Council which is to determine by plebiscite whether this strategic northern territory shall belong to this country or to Pakistan.

HAMEENLINA, Finland, July 24 (AP) -- An eleven-man board of appeal tonight rejected a Russian protest against a United States competitor in the swimming event of the Olympic modern pentathlon competition.

The season for parental bewilderment now is at hand. It began not too long ago when those heavy trains began staggering from Grand Central, weighted down and all but bursting at the rivets with hordes of youthful campers.

GRASSY POINT, N. Y., July 24 --A thirty-foot clay wall between the world's largest natural drydock and the Hudson River was broken here today, thus completing the last major local portion of New York City's Pier 57 project. The wall-breaking followed the flotation of the three 360-foot concrete boxes that will be towed early next week to the North River at Fifteenth Street to form the substructure and deck of Pier 57.
PLYMOUTH, England, July 24 (AP) -- The American yacht Caribee, owned by W. Carlton Mitchell of New York, finished first today in a 2,780-mile race from Bermuda to Plymouth.
The National Production Authority accused the Warner Manufacturing Company of Jersey City yesterday of using 1,394,267 pounds of aluminum illegally.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 24 -- Officials of the British-controlled Palestine Potash, Ltd., which held a concession from Palestine under the former Mandate Government to exploit Dead Sea minerals and chemicals, have agreed to exchange its plant, patents and goodwill for a minority interest in a new company to be controlled by the Israeli Government.

CHICAGO, July 24 -- President Truman gave the Stevenson bandwagon a tremendous -- and probably decisive -- shove tonight when he instructed his alternate on the Missouri delegation to vote for the Presidential nomination of Gov. Adlai E. Steveson of Illinois.

TOKYO, Friday, July 25 -- The United Nations ended today the secret sessions called at Panmunjom, July 4, in the hope executive meetings would give the Communists an opportunity to modify their insistence that all prisoners of the Korean war must be returned, by force if necessary, after the conclusion of an armistice.

The worst of the slump in "soft goods" is over and the consumer goods industries are reviving, business men in this city believe. As a result they expect employment in these lines to rise 5 per cent by October. Companies with defense contracts anticipate a 7 per cent rise in jobs.

CHICAGO, July 24 -- The Democrats set out today to maintain their hold on the farm vote with a platform pledge to keep price supports on basic agricultural products at a mandatory level of not less than 90 per cent of parity.
A program for alleviating the present shortage of engineering and technical personnel was presented yesterday at a meeting in the City Council chamber to 100 engineering executives.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., July 24 -- A wildcat strike today of 150 marine warehousemen at the Claremont terminal, shipping depot of the Army Corps of Engineers, the second in the last month, is being investigated by Federal security and intelligence agencies to determine whether or not the so-called "rank-and-file" group is being agitated by Communists.

The Phillips Petroleum Company set a record in earnings for the first half of this year with a net of $38,933,442, or 22 per cent higher than the $32,002,597 cleared in the first half of 1951, the semi-annual statement disclosed yesterday.

FONTAINEBLEAU, France, July 24 -- North Atlantic Treaty air forces in Europe are now being linked more efficiently by a new and expanding network of radar, radio and telecommunications. The nerve center of this far-flung system is in a new cream-colored building that has been in operation for a month in the forests here.

Because of the lack of volunteers, the city's ten-day-old "skywatch" soon may be forced to operate on a part-time basis, despite a warning by the Air Force that Russian bombers might bore in under the 5,000-foot floor of effective radar screening for a sneak attack.

New York Secretary of State Thomas J. Curran, the New York County Republican leader, made it clear to party district leaders in the Twenty-second State Senatorial District yesterday that he expected them to work vigorously for the defeat of Senator William J. Bianchi in the Republican primary Aug. 22.

PARIS, Friday, July 25 -- The Schuman plan treaty took effect today with the deposit of formal ratifications, and when the foreign ministers of the six Schuman plan countries adjourned at 5 o'clock this morning, it had been agreed that France and the Bonn republic would try to settle the Saar question by immediate negotiations.

Although fires will be lighted today at some of the nation's huge steel mills it will take up to three weeks before production of the basic metal will be in full swing and it will take four weeks longer for many allied industries dependent upon steel to resume full-scale operations.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., July 24 (AP) -- The American Locomotive Company said today that a Wage Stabilization Board panel had suggested that the company and the United Steelworkers Union, C. I. O., resume direct negotiations on the union's bid for higher wages.
SIOUX CITY, Iowa, July 24 (AP) -- Al Besselink took the eighteen-hole lead in the Sioux City open golf tournament today with a 7-under-par 65 for the windswept Elmwood course.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 24 (AP) -- Members of the United States track and field team at the Olympic games will participate in meets in six nations before returning home, Dan Ferris, chairman of the post-Olympic competition committee, said today.

Bristol-Myers Products division of the Bristol-Myers Company has completed its program of national distribution of a chlorophyll toothpaste. Considering that sectional distribution began in Miami, Fla., in April, the spread to all markets has been accomplished in a comparatively short time.

LENOX, Mass., July 24 -- Returning from its phenomenally successful spring tour of Europe, the Boston Symphony Orchestra, Charles Munch, conductor, gave the opening concert of its Annual Berkshire Symphonic Festival tonight in the Music Shed at Tanglewood.

ALBANY, July 24 -- More than 1,000 representatives of 358 Knights of Pythias lodges in the state may arrive in Saratoga Springs Sunday for their eighty-fourth annual convention to find that the meeting has been banned by the courts.

The Public Housing Administration announced yesterday that forty-seven local housing authorities planned to borrow $259,428,500 on temporary loan notes. Twenty-three authorities will take bids next Thursday and twenty-four agencies on Aug. 21.

FORT SLOCUM, N. Y., July 24 -- President Truman, in a message to the twenty-first annual convention of the Military Chaplains Association, warmly complimented these men today for a "patriotic and spiritual unity" fundamental to the nation's life and to be found nowhere else in it.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The United States has asked the Soviet Union to urge North Korean and Chinese Communist compliance with the Geneva rules for the treatment of prisoners of war in the Korean campaign.

The regional office of the Wage Stabilization Board has refused permission to the National Transportation Company, which operates 1,600 taxicabs in the city, to raise its commission rate to drivers beyond 44 per cent. The company, which asked for the right to raise driver's rates to 45 per cent from the present 42.5 per cent, said it would appeal the decision to a higher body.
BOSTON, July 24 (UP) -- A ninth-inning double play with the bases loaded ended a Cub threat today and enabled the Braves to gain a 3-1 victory in the rubber game of their three-game series.

The Bloomfield Steamship Company of Houston, Tex., which is seeking a Government operating subsidy for two routes out of Gulf of Mexico ports, has negotiated successfully the initial steps toward obtaining this aid and now is preparing its case for presentation at a public hearing.

Cross-examination of the Government's third witness continued yesterday the Communist conspiracy trial in Federal Court. Harvey Matusow, 26-year-old former Communist youth leader, was questioned by John T. McTernan, defense counsel.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 24 -- Harrison (Bones) Dillard got his gold medal as a hurdler today to stand unique among all athletes who have competed in the modern Olympic Games and Emil Zatopek staged one of the most stirring sprints credited to a mortal to win the 5-000-meter run.

The first company of Balinese dancers and musicians ever to appear in the Western Hemisphere will be brought to this country in the fall by the Columbia Artists Management, Inc., in cooperation with the Government of Indonesia. Under the title of Island of Bali Dancers, they will open a four-week engagement at the Fulton Theatre on Sept. 16, and for twelve weeks will travel to other cities.
The Goldman Band presented last evening the first New York performance of Morton Gould's Symphony for Band at Prospect Park, Brooklyn, with the composer conducting.
DETROIT, July 24 (AP) -- Walt Dropo paced the Tigers to a 4-to-2 victory over the Senators today. The triumph enabled the last-place Bengals to take the series, two games to one.

Supreme Court Justice Eugene L. Brisach dismissed yesterday a suit brought against State Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman by a white lessee and a Negro occupant to prevent the latter from being evicted from an apartment in Knickerbocker Village on the East Side.

In show business, if it isn't one thing it's generally another. On Tuesday Actors Equity gracefully modified its stand against the employment of alien players to permit the Playwrights Company to import the actors required from London for "The Trial of Mr. Pickwick."

BONN, Germany, July 24 -- In the opinion of Lieut. Gen. Adolf Von Heusinger and Lieut. Gen. Hans Speidel, military advisers to the Federal Government, it will be impossible to recruit desirable officers for West German military contingents unless a substantial number of war criminals are released from Allied jails.

CHICAGO, July 24 -- Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama was mentioned today as the most likely choice of the Democratic convention for Vice President if top honors go to Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -Americans put a record amount of money last year into things that could be converted quickly into cash.

The antiquated I. R. T. subway entrance and exit kiosks at Broadway and Fiftieth Street were described yesterday as menaces to pedestrian and motor travel. These structures, termed relics of the horse and buggy days, also were cited as dangerous factors in the pattern of modern traffic, which includes the scheduled widening of Fiftieth Street.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (UP) -- The Air Force will soon test a new rocket ship, expected to smash the Navy skyrocket's 1,238-mile-an- hour speed record.
BERLIN, July 24 -- East Germany announced tonight the formation of a labor corps into which youths more than 17 years old could, in some cases, be drafted for six months' service.

THE offshore boats sailing from Freeport, Hampton Bays and Montauk Point on Long Island have been faring well with bluefish. Those from Freeport have been concentrating on the blues to the exclusion of school tuna, while the boats farther to the eastward have been getting action from the small tuna as well.

MEXICO CITY, July 24 -- The Bank of Mexico today announced new exchange rates for the purchase of dollars. Dollar bills will be bought for 8.61 pesos and dollar checks for 8.63. The old rate was 8.65 for buying and selling and it remains unchanged as the selling rate.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Making his first overt move in the Democratic National Convention tonight, President Truman directed his alternate, Thomas J. Gavin of Kansas City, to cast his vote for Gov. Adlai Stevenson of Illinois.

Your reports on the negotiations at Wassenaar concerning Jewish and Israeli claims against Germany, which may be concluded in the near future, cause me to attempt an appraisal of the degree to which the German people endorse restitution to the Jews. I have just returned from a two months' stay in Germany.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The steel strike that has been choking the national economy for fifty-three days was settled at the White House today. The settlement came less than seven hours after President Truman had warned union and industry leaders to end the tie-up within twenty-four hours, "or else."

MINEOLA, L. I., July 24 -- A 46-year-old former bookmaker was sentenced to Sing Sing Prison here today as a forger despite his protest that the crime was committed by another man who closely resembled him.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (UP) -The Federal Trade Commission today ordered the Florida Citrus Canners Cooperative, Lake Wales, Fla., to stop "unlawfully discriminating in price" between competing buyers of its canned citrus fruit juice products.

CONCORD, N. H., July 24 -- Four New Hampshire Republicans and two Democrats filed papers today as candidates for the nominations for Governor in the state primaries, Sept. 9, to succeed Gov. Sherman Adams, who will not be a candidate for re-election.
CHICAGO, July 24 -- Organized labor spokesmen praised the Democratic platform today.

Tight money conditions were reflected during the last week in New York and especially by the combined statements of the reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System. Business and industry continued to call less on the banking system for ready cash with a further drop of $10,000,000 in borrowings for commercial, industrial and agricultural purposes.

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, July 25 (AP) -- Chinese Communist forces shifted their main blows from "Old Baldy" to nearby "T-Bone Hill" on the western front in Korea today, but dug-in French troops drove off an attack by about 500 of the enemy.

CHICAGO, July 24 -- True to the predominating form of national political conventions, the 8,000-word Democratic platform 1952 -- the contract of pledges under which all the party's candidates are supposed to run -- was read and approved amid noisy confusion early this morning at the stock yards. amphitheatre here to delegates whose minds appeared to be occupied largely with other matters.

In the understandable preoccupation with television's coverage of the national conventions, the job done by radio has been all but ignored. In fact, according to emissaries returning from Chicago, the radio broadcaster has been the forgotten man during the last three weeks in the Windy City.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 24 -- A man from Mars -- and if there wasn't one present it was purely an oversight -- would have gotten a very simple impression from the nomination proceedings at the Democratic National Convention today: everybody was for everybody.
CONVENTION HALL, in Chicago, July 24 (AP) -- Ohio's "favorite son" candidate for the Presidential nomination became a casualty of the Stevenson boom at the Democratic convention today.
CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 24 (AP) -- Following are digests of the speeches nominating Democratic candidates for the Presidency:

ALBANY, July 24 -- The Brooklyn Union Gas Company will reduce its rates on Aug. 1 to 55,000 customers using natural gas for space-heating or air-conditioning and to 4,000 commercial consumers in an effort to attract more consumers to those services.

BROWNSVILLE, Tex., July 24 (UP) -- A flight of ten small crop-dusting planes was scattered over a 200-mile area today by a violent thunderstorm, with six missing for a time, but all ten were accounted for six hours after the storm.

Paris, July 24 -- Svend interprets the new depth at the back by designing close fitting caps with a dramatically flaring volant at the nape of the neck. This silhouette of Egyptian inspiration he calls the "Sphinx." Sometimes it is severe, of untrimmed black, garnet or white beaver felt.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, Friday, July 25 -- Eleven candidates for the Presidential nomination were placed formally before the Democratic National Convention yesterday and early today to the accompaniment of florid oratory about "the man who" and calculated bedlam on his behalf.

MONTREAL, Friday, July 25 (Canadian Press) -- The bomb-maker in Quebec's bizarre airlines crash of Sept. 9, 1949, died at 1:12 A. M., Eastern daylight time today on the gallows in Montreal's Bordeaux jail.
The thirteen-day heat wave -the worst New Yorkers have suffered in the eighty-one-year memory of the local Weather Bureau -was broken yesterday.

In your issue of July 17, under the heading "U. S. Inventiveness on Soviet Griddle," you carry an account of a United Nations debate wherein Georgi P. Arkadyev, Soviet Union delegate, lays claim to the invention of radio for Russian physicist Alexander Popov, who, prior to Marconi, conducted some experiments with electromagnetic waves.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified today 171 additional battle casualties in Korea. A new list included 21 killed, 146 wounded, one missing in action and three injured. The following casualties were reported for New York and New Jersey (none for Connecticut):

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that department store sales in the United States during the week ended July 19 were 1 per cent above sales in the same period of 1951. Figures from the board's weekly report on sales by districts follow in terms of percentage changes from corresponding periods of last year:

OGDENSBURG, N. Y., July 24 (AP) -- Thirty-two witnesses from northern New York today urged the International Joint Commission to give New York State and the Canadian province of Ontario permission to build a big power plant on the St. Lawrence River.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- During the week ended July 23 member bank reserves decreased $96,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
DENVER, July 24 -- Arthur E. Summerfield of Michigan, new chairman of the Republican National Committee, will function as Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's campaign manager in the Presidential race.
A jury before Federal Judge T. Hoyt Davis acquitted yesterday two attorneys, who are father and son, of perjury charges arising from the alleged bribe of an Internal Revenue collector.

During these days of abnormal heat the urgent need to improve the running of the city's subway system becomes increasingly apparent. The violent noise and the pushing crowds who rush to board the jammed trains are, I believe, a major source for creating bad tempers and ill manners.

TORONTO, July 25 -- War and politics dominated today's session of the board of governors of the League of Red Cross Societies, made up of the heads of national Red Cross organizations around the world.

PORT DALHOUSIE, Ont., July 25 (Canadian Press) -- The Buffalo West Sides today took over the leadership in the seventieth Royal Canadian Henley regatta with a display of strength which included four firsts, two seconds and one third.
BOSTON, July 25 (UP) -- Murry Dickson pitched Pittsburgh to a 3-2 victory over the Braves tonight to break a six-game losing streak for the Pirates before 4,126 fans.

During one of the recent and prolonged heat waves which New Yorkers were fending off ineffectively with ice cubes and electric fans we fell to wondering just where in the whole wide world is the hottest place.

With brokers and operators watching the Democratic National Convention in Chicago with more interest than market movements here, commodity futures trading eased yesterday. Only in hides and coffee was the day's volume above subnormal levels.

JERSEY CITY, July 25 -- A spectacular pre-dawn two-alarm fire that could easily be seen from lower Manhattan, destroyed today the ferryboat Catskill of the New York Central Railroad's West Shore Division in the Morris Basin at Henderson Street, here.

The example set by the Republicans two weeks ago at Chicago has now been followed by the Democrats. Each party has had the great good judgment to nominate its strongest available candidate for the Presidency.

HIGHTSTOWN, N. J., July 25 -- A private plane owner was killed and his passenger, a radio entertainer, was injured when the small aircraft crashed and burned on pasture land in near-by Applegarth early tonight.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 25 (AP) -- America's men lead their Russian rivals by 249 points to 224 1/2 thus far in the Olympic Games, but the Soviet women have put the U. S. S. R. far in front in the team standings.

Ethical use of testimonials in advertising is again reviewed by the National Better Business Bureau in a supplement to "Do's and Don'ts in Advertising Copy." Seven basic principles are set forth and these provide a set of standards for advertisers to follow.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, July 25 -- Though the secret armistice meetings that ended today failed to produce a formula to end the Korean war, they served to give the Chinese complete control of the Communists' delegation. Nominally, North Korean Lieut. Gen. Nam II continues as senior delegate, but actually Chinese Maj. Gen. Hsieh Fang is the chief Communist spokesman in the conference tent.

MONPELIER, Vt., July 25 -- Gov. Lee E. Emerson of Vermont asserted today that the state had "scenery enough for the whole country," which made it easy to see why New Hampshire was worried about losing its supply. He voiced this reply to a charge from the neighboring state that Vermont had "stolen" New Hampshire scenes to illustrate its promotional magazine.

LOS ANGELES, July 25 -- This was ladies' day at California Fashion Creators' last press week showing for this season, because extremely feminine fashions prevailed, designed by the Affiliated Fashionists, California's famous "designing women."
HELSINKI, Finland, July 25 (AP) -- An American master sergeant won a gold medal, and a young Canadian ranked close up in another event as the Olympic shooting competitions opened today on two fronts.

Sally Benson is expected to turn over to Leonard Key on Monday the completed script of her comedy "Josephine," based on five short stories by F. Scott Fitzgerald. Mr. Key, who, in partnership with Fred Finklehoffe, has scheduled "Josephine" for production this season, would like to get rehearsals started by Aug. 15.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, July 25 -- Independence is not a burning issue with the inhabitants of Malaya. This is evident from the reaction that has followed last week's declaration on the question of independence for Malaya that was made in the House of Commons by the Colonial Secretary, Oliver Lyttelton.

VANCOUVER, July 25 -- (Canadian Press) -- The 700-mile Trans Mountain Ltd. oil pipeline from Edmonton to Vancouver will carry 120,000 barrels a day instead of the 75,000 originally intended, it was announced here today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 25 (AP) -- Three Californians, including the defending champion, Tommy Jacobs, moved into the semi-final round of the national junior golf championship today, along with Don Bisplinghoff, a Floridian, who has been playing better than any of them.
CHICAGO, Saturday, July 26 -- The strategy used by supporters of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson to get him the Democratic nomination for President, like the horns of a dilemma, had two prongs.

BERLIN, July 25 -- In an ironic, and perhaps not accidental, coincidence seven alleged agents of the West Berlin Investigation Committee of Free Jurists went on trial in East Berlin today almost at the same moment that the committee opened an international congress on the other side of the city designed to expose injustice under communism.
PARIS, July 25 -- French fashion designer Christian Dior announced today that he would shortly enter the British market with ready-to-wear models manufactured in England.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 25 -Where to put the Chinese Communist Olympic team, due to arrive here during the week-end, is giving the local housing committee some headaches. The Iron Curtain camp at Otaniemi is filled so the only chance for the Peiping team is to accept quarters at the Western non-Communist camp at Kaepylae.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The zipper has simplified many questions of feminine dress, but created a problem of its own: how a woman can operate one up and down her own spine. Roxann Shakarian Vahan of North Hollywood, Calif., has presented a solution in a tackle arrangement to be installed on a wall. Patent 2,604,242 was issued for it this week.
CHICAGO, July 25 -- If Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson should become President of the United States, his first lady probably would be his sister, Mrs. Ernest L. Ives.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 25 (AP) -- Horace Ashenfelter, the F. B. I. man who is the new Olympic steeplechase champion, admitted today he was an opportunist who saw a chance and took it.

Jim Hearn pitched and batted the Giants to a 3-1 triumph over the Reds at the Polo Grounds yesterday. The powerful Georgian, now the belwether of Leo Durocher's staff, yielded only four singles and belted a two-run homer in posting his eleventh victory against three defeats.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 25 (AP) -- The United States and Russia gained easy victories today in the opening round of the Olympic basketball tournament but the Russians were more impressive.
Following is the text of President Truman's address to the Democratic National Convention, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

PARAMUS, N. J., July 25 -- Bobby Jacobsen of the Hollywood Golf Club, Deal. N. J., finalist in 1950, eliminated Joe Gagliardi of Winged Foot, defending titleholder, in the quarter-final round of the metropolitan amateur golf championship at the Ridgewood Country Club today.

KARACHI, Pakistan, July 25 -- It is reported here that a move will be made in the next session of the Pakistani Parliament to move the capital of Pakistan away from Karachi. The new capital, according to supporters of the move, should be situated somewhere in the north of the western half of the nation.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 25 -Peter Abbey, owned by Wales T. Flynt of Crawfordsville, Ga., won the $11,800 Meadow Brook Trot, feature of the grand circuit harness-racing program tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, Saturday, July 26 -- President Truman told a cheering Democratic National Convention early this morning that it had nominated a winner in Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois.
CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 25 (AP) -- Following is the text of a resolution of appreciation to President Truman adopted by acclamation today at the Democratic National Convention:
POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., July 25 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt declared here tonight that America needed moral and spiritual backbone to make democracy work.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 25 -- A number of United Nations delegates were suffering today from election headaches and their troubles had nothing to do with the Chicago convention.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- The Wage Stabilization Board ruled today that seven New York breweries could not grant their employes a wage increase and also reduce their work week by two and one-half hours.

MADRAS, India, July 11 -- Nearly four tons of food donated for the Madras famine area by readers of THE NEW YORK TIMES through the Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe were handed out personally today in three stricken villages of the Chittoor District by E. T. Greaves, CARE representative for India.
FRANKFURT, Germany, July 25 (AP) -- A United States Army spokesman tonight denied a Russian charge that Soviet military mission members in West Germany were shadowed by German police.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- Today' was the deadline for the great majority of World Way II veterans to receive unemployment and self-employment readjustment allowances in a program which has cost almost $4,000,000,000.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- The Federal Security Agency today issued a considerably watered-down set of regulations for enforcing the nation's first prescription law --omitting certain proposed "interpretations" that had drawn fire from trade and professional organizations in the drug field.
CAIRO, July 25 -- Gen. Mohammed Naguib Bey's Army-backed governmental house-cleaning reached to King Farouk's own palace today. Six of the monarch's top aides resigned.

There are only two books published today. The Philosophical Library is issuing at $2.75 Ben F. Kimpel's "Religious Faith, Language and Knowledge: A Philosophical Preface to Theology." Funk Wagnalls has at $10 "The New International Year Book: A Compendium of the World's Progress for the Year 1951," edited by Henry E. Vizetelly.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- President Truman ordered today that military, economic and financial aid be continued to Denmark despite the delivery of a new Danish tanker to the Soviet Union on July 7 in contravention of United States aid legislation.

PARIS, July 25 -- A French-German discussion of the future of the Saar began here today as a result of a French effort to link the Saar question with the Schuman plan and thus with the move for West European integration.

MINEOLA, L. I., July 25 -- Cyril C. Ryan, Nassau County Civil Defense director, said today that the immediate need was for more men and women, singly or in pairs, to bring the personnel of the Ground Observer Corps up to required strength.

In a recent editorial in your paper notice was taken of the latest improvements in agriculture -- including such things as hybrid corn, new soil conditions and the prospects of being able to convert sea water to fresh for use in irrigation.

DENVER, July 25 -- At his fishing camp in the Colorado Rockies, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower listened on the radio to the Presidential balloting at the Democratic National Convention today and then cooked lunch of pancakes, mountain trout, and steak for his executive assistant, Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 25 -- The next to last regatta of Larchmont Race Week broke some kind of record as well as many hearts, especially those of the youngsters who took their best girls out to crew with them, and to show them how fast they could sail.

The appointment of Dr. Wilhelm Pauck as Professor of Church History at Union Theological Seminary was announced yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Henry P. Van Dusen, president. Dr. Pauck will assume his post next July, succeeding Dr. John T. McNeill, retired.
LONDON, July 25 -- Evening dresses in the grand manner formed the greater part of today's opening collections of London's "top eleven." This is in preparation for the coronation next year.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., July 25 -- Increases in the maximum rent levels for two low-rent housing developments here and for two others in near-by Long Branch were sought today by the housing authorities in both cities.
More Roman Catholic magazines and newspapers are being sold in this country and Canada than ever before, according to a statistical report prepared by the Catholic Press Association.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 25 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh told the nation in a radio broadcast tonight that the tangled oil problem had taken a turn for the better and that therefore he was resolved to initiate and carry out reform measures and to take fundamental speedy steps he believed the country direly needed now.
Capt. David H. Swinson, commodore of the Panama Line's three-ship fleet and master of the Ancon, retired yesterday after thirty-six years' service.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 25 -- Within the space, of a few hours Wednesday morning the internal balance of power in Egypt was so profoundly and abruptly altered that the rules for the exercise of authority there may never be the same again.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Employes of The Cincinnati Enquirer, who purchased the 111-year-old daily to keep it from being sold to its competitor, The Cincinnati Times-Star, turned to the securities markets today to finance their project on a permanent basis.

An observant Englishman's appraisal of 80 per cent of drivers in New York City is divided into three categories -- pushers, poachers and pouters. Another 10 per cent are termed "timid blighters who turn the other cheek so often that they get cricks in their necks and wits." The remainder are checked off as tolerably good.

Litigants who gamble with the law must take the consequences, Supreme Court Justice Matthew M. Levy warned yesterday in a decision refusing to set aside a jury award of $15,000 in a negligence case. The plaintiffs had turned down an out-of-court settlement of $22,500 and had demanded a jury trial.

BRAINTREE, Mass., July 25 -- Ian Smith, 16 years old, a Boy Scout from Braintree, England, arrived here today to begin a month's goodwill visit. His welcoming committee found that he already had taken care of his daily good turn.

NORWALK, Conn., July 25 -- Members of the family of Senator Brien McMahon were called from their homes here yesterday to his bedside in Georgetown University Hospital in Washington, D. C. The relatives were summoned because his condition was now grave, according to Dr. John D. McMahon, physician here and brother of the Senator.

Directors of the Crown Cork and Seal Company, Inc., have deferred action on a dividend on the common stock, formerly on a 25-cent quarterly basis. John J. Nagle, chairman and president, announced yesterday that the action was taken after a full review of conditions brought about by the steel strike which has resulted in a curtailment of operations of the company and its subsidiaries.

Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan announced yesterday that an investigation of an alleged assault at the Club Lilac, 56 East Fifty-sixth Street, on June 17 in which a police inspector was involved and two persons were reported injured had failed to disclose evidence that would warrant action against the inspector.

ALBERTO MORAVIA'S novel, "The Fancy Dress Party,"* is a lively satire on fortitude, servitude and turpitude. It is the story of an enamored dictator called Don Tereso and the traitors, strategists and spoilsmen who seethe around him in a mythical country with a vague Spanish accent but pointedly Italian ways.
Steel workers were preparing for work yesterday, but their return was held up by a hitch in the settlement agreement. Only a handful of maintenance men had re-entered any of the mills.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 25 -- Horace Ashenfelter won today the fastest 3,000-meter steeplechase race ever run for the United States' twelfth gold medal in track and field and its first Olympic victory ever in this event.

A consecutive double by C. V. Whitney's color-bearers lent a truly Saratogan touch to the horse-racing proceedings at Jamaica yesterday. The victories came with dramatic sequence, too, one occuring in the fifth race, and the other in the feature, a mile-and-a-sixteenth affair called the Checkmate.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, Saturday, July 26 -- A sudden switch of more than 300 votes gave Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois a third-ballot victory and the Democratic Presidential nomination here early today after Averell Harriman had announced his withdrawal from the contest and New York, Pennsylvania, Massachusetts, Michigan and Arkansas had swung in behind the choice of President Truman.

The Shell Oil Company and its wholly owned subsidiaries had a consolidated net income in the first half of this year of $42,554,913, equal to $3.16 a share, against $45,220,846 or $3.36 a share earned in the corresponding six months of 1951, the report of H. S. M. Burns, president, disclosed yesterday.

In an effort to offset a summer slump in donations to the Red Cross blood bank program, a rally was held yesterday noon by the New York Military District. Several hundred persons attended the rally held on East Tenth Street between Broadway and Fourth Avenue.

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., Saturday, July 26 (UP) -- Everybody from the grocer to the taxi man rejoiced early today that Bloomington's native son, Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, had become the Democratic Presidential nominee.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 25 -- Alexis Smith and Stephen McNally today were cast by Universal-International as co-stars with Jeff Chandler in "Sioux Uprising," a Technicolor film of the West in Civil War days. Albert J. Cohen has been named by the studio as producer.
HANOVER, Germany, July 25 (AP) -- The second Lutheran World Federation Assembly opened tonight.

Physicians assigned by New York State law to the ringside in boxing matches should have authority to protect injured young boxers from the between-rounds ministrations of greedy, ignorant or unscrupulous handlers, it was suggested here yesterday.

JERSEY CITY, July 25 -- Rank-and-file leaders of a wildcat strike, in its second day at the Claremont Terminal Shipping Depot of the Army Corps of Engineers, served this afternoon a three-point ultimatum on officials of the Marine Warehousemen's Local 1478, International Longshoremen's Association.

ALL the records are not being broken in Helsinki. Those who find their pleasure on salt water have been doing a fair job of revising the standards kept by the International Game Fish Association at the American Museum of Natural History.
CINCINNATI, July 25 (AP) -- The United States Davis Cup tennis team today got a good start on the way to a victory over Japan in the first round of the North American zone eliminations.

TOTNES, England, July 25 (Reuters) -- The future of handicrafts in the modern world is the big question before the International Conference of Craftsmen in Pottery and Textiles, now taking place at Dartington Hall, near here.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The longest and most costly steel strike in the country's history was officially called off today, but an unexpected snag over wage rates for 23,000 iron ore miners blocked the sending of union back-to-work orders to 600,000 striking steel workers.
CHICAGO, July 25 (AP) -- The $157,350 Arlington Handicap, richest race of its kind this year, will cap Arlington Park's 36-day meeting tomorrow with a probable field of thirteen starters.
CLEVELAND, July 25 (UP) -Early Wynn outpitched Bob Porterfield tonight and the Indians grabbed the opener of a four-game series with the Senators, 4 to 2, before 19,906.

LONDON, July 25 (Reuters) -- The directors of Grosvenor House, luxury hotel in the heart of London's Mayfair, have opposed an offer by the Hilton Syndicate of America for control of the hotel, it was learned tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The Small Defense Plants Administration has called upon the National Production Authority to see to it that small business is not "short-changed" in the distribution of available steel supplies in the weeks immediately following the resumption of steel production.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The National Production Authority today came to the aid of machine tool builders hit by cutbacks and the cancellation of defense orders for their products. The Defense Agency revised its machine tool regulations to permit producers to accept orders for civilian sources provided the work does not interfere with defense orders which they may have on hand.

Demolition workers who have been on strike for three weeks rejected yesterday a plan proposed by a three-man Mayor's committee to settle the walkout that is seriously affecting major construction work in the city.

Brushing back a batter with a tight pitch may be regarded as a legitimate tactical maneuver in baseball, but what happened last night at Ebbets Field, where the Cardinals downed the Dodgers, 8 -- 4, was out of order. Among the 24,122 fans, those who believe in good sportsmanship were sickened by the knock-him-down pitches delivered by both sides.

Parts of a report made by Harvey Matusow, Government witness at the Communist conspiracy trial in Federal Court, to the Federal Bureau of Investigation were obtained yesterday from the Government by direction of Federal Judge Edward J. Dimock.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 25 (AP) -- The schedule of events tomorrow in the Olympic Games (Time is local, followed by New York time):

GUATEMALA, July 25 -- The First Labor Court denied today the request of Pan American Airways to have a strike of local ground employes here declared illegal on the ground the company had no advance notice of the workers' decision to strike.

THE TIMES editorial of July 21, "Russian Recordings," misstates some important facts. As agent in this country for Mezhkniga, the Soviet export organization which your editorial mentions, I am in a position to correct the false impression which these errors give.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 25 -- With a sailors' peace proposal before them, negotiators for the Pacific Maritime Association and the Sailors Union of the Pacific, A. F. L., met again today in an attempt to settle the union's strike that has kept much West Coast shipping tied up one day short of two months.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The American Federation of Soroptimist Clubs outlined today proposals to aid illegitimate and handicapped children and juvenile delinquents.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, Saturday, July 26 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois was nominated early today on the third ballot for President of the United States by the thirty-first Democratic National Convention.
ST. LOUIS, July 25 (AP) -- Getting two of their three hits with two walks in the seventh inning, the Browns tonight scored three runs to defeat the Red Sox, 3 -- 2.

A one-story garage and repair shop on plot 50 by 100 feet at the northeast corner of Myrtle Avenue and Steuben Street, Brooklyn, was sold by Gussie Kantor to the Harmosa Oil Corporation, which insured title with the Title Guarantee and Trust Company. Pearce, Mayer Greer were the brokers in the sale of the property, which is assessed at $22,000.

Long-term prospects for developing a greater volume of exports from Ireland to the dollar market are promising, provided some basic technical improvements are undertaken, it was indicated yesterday in an outline of a three-month survey completed recently by two American counseling organizations.
Mention of mustard is opportune, the American Spice Trade Association reminds us, because of its natural affinity to, frankfurters, favorite summer snack at beach, ball park and picnic.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 25 (AP) -- Apprentice Fred Ryan booted the Blue Valley Stable's Rollicking Lad to victory in the featured Monmouth County Purse at Monmouth Park today. He Survived a photo finish over the favored Charley Foy, with Albmarle third in the field of ten sophomores.
BALTIMORE, July 25 (AP) -- Favorites in the Middle Atlantic grass courts tennis tournament cleared another hurdle today and entered the semi-finals, with only one match decided in extended sets.
CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 25 -- Averell Harriman decided to drop out of the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination as the second ballot neared its end this afternoon.

The Democratic platform adopted this week at Chicago points with admiration to the alertness of the Administration in perceiving the threat of inflation after Korea, and to the vigor with which it has conducted a successful resistance through allocations, fiscal policy and direct price-wage controls.

Directors of the Chicago Board of Trade have set the coming Monday for a ballot on their proposal to extend the market's closing time from 1:15 to 1:45 P. M., Central daylight saving time. Their move follows a decision earlier this week to dispense with trading on Saturdays, effective on Aug. 2.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, July 25 (AP) -- Jimmy Clark, a former marine, blistered the Elmwood course with a record ten-under-par 62 today to move in front of the pack at the halfway mark in the Sioux City open golf tournament with a 130 total.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., July 25 -- Re-enactment of the reading of the Declaration of Independence at Williamsburg 176 years ago took place here this afternoon with members of the cast of the "Common Glory" providing the pageantry for the occasion. It was on July 25, 1776, that the Declaration of Independence was proclaimed in public places here on orders of the Virginia Council.

BERNARDSVILLE, N. J., July 25 -- Mrs. William Hockenjos of Baltusrol won low gross honors with a 39, 38 -- 77 today in a women's New Jersey Golf Association one-day tournament at the Somerset Hills Country Club.

ALBANY, July 25 (AP) -- A State Supreme Court Justice refused today to issue an injunction that would have prevented the state lodge of the Knights of Pythias from holding its annual convention. A spokesman for the grand lodge announced immediately that the six-day convention would open Sunday in Saratoga Springs, as scheduled.

Federal Judge John F. X. McGohey has rejected a motion by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its manufacturing subsidiary, the Western Electric Company, for dismissal of an anti-trust unit brought by Joseph A. Petnel of Troy, N. Y., it became known yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (UP) -- The Wage Stabilization Board approved a contract today that grants wage increases to 9,500 employes in six plants of the Aluminum Company of America.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, Saturday, July 26 -- Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee almost missed the bandwagon last night as he and Averell Harriman, Mutual Security Director, fought furiously down to the wire to block the nomination of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois for President at the Democratic National Convention.

LONDON, July 25 -- The stock market continued idle today apart from South African gold mining shares, which rose on renewed continental buying, prices were barely tested. British Government securities closed virtually without change, as did Japanese stocks in the foreign bond market.

Plans for the erection of four one-family homes were announced in connection with the purchase by Fina Homes, Inc., of a vacant plot of land measuring 200 by 100 feet on the south side of Shipherd Avenue, 220 feet east of Denton Avenue, Lynbrook, L. I.

FLORENCE, Italy, July 25 -- Perhaps because Italians are experts at relaxing and enjoying life, the madcap fantasy of their boutique and sports clothes is, in the opinion of many, a more original contribution to the world of fashion than is their haute couture.
LOS ANGELES, July 25 (AP) -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson's birthplace here now is a rooming house, in contrast to the mansion it was when the Illinois Governor was born in it fifty-two years ago.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., July 25 (AP) -- Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican of New York, said today that what he called military "spendthrift habits" and "inefficiency" were hurting the nation's defense effort.

TOKYO, Saturday, July 26 -- The United Nations delegates walked out of the new plenary sessions at Panmunjom today and told the Communists they would return in a week for further discussion of an armistice in the Korean war.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., July 25 -- A small forest of yellow-pine pilings has been driven into the muck of Long Island Sound off Hudson Park here, forming an under water platform extending almost two miles toward the shores of Long Island.

SAN JUAN, P. R., July 25 -- The new flag of Puerto Rico was raised beside the Stars and Stripes at the Capitol here today to symbolize the establishment of this Caribbean island as the first overseas commonwealth of the United States.
CONVENTION HALL in Chicago, July 25 (UP) -- Cheers and booes greeted President Truman's vote for Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson at the Democratic National Convention today.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of use to homemakers.
Nobody can minimize the importance of the steel strike settlement, but to hail it, as did some of the Democrats at Chicago, as a triumph of collective bargaining is more than an exaggeration.

OTTAWA, July 25 (CP) -- Canadians invested nearly $1,000,000,000 in new housing in 1951. Despite higher costs, higher interest rates and increased difficulties in obtaining mortgages, housing investments totaled $844,000,000 compared with $836,000,000 in 1950.

Gov. Adlai Ewing Stevenson, the Democratic nominee for President, is, like the late Franklin D. Roosevelt, a member of a family whose roots go to the pre-Revolutionary period. And, like two other Democratic Presidents, Grover Cleveland of New York, and Woodrow Wilson of New Jersey, he was chosen to lead the party after a brief but spectacular career as a reform Governor.

Harry Weinberg's letter in THE TIMES of July 23 commenting on one of your editorials regarding the "Red Dean" raises a point which has been argued again and again in the history of our nation. His point is well taken, with yours, that freedom of speech and of the press demands the right of dissension with current popular and political thought and action.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (UP) -- The Air Force disclosed today that it was going to stop building the B-36 heavy intercontinental bombers that caused a serious Air Force-Navy controversy in 1949.
CHICAGO, July 25 -- Grain futures generally showed a firm undertone early, but rallies met increased selling resistance and there was considerable long profit taking.
BALLSTON SPA, N. Y., July 25 (AP) -- James A. Leary, Saratoga County Republican leader, was indicted today on charges of first-and second-degree perjury.

DETROIT, July 25 -- Casey Stengel's carefully calculated plans to start his Yankee steamroller going again struck an unexpected snag tonight as Freddy Hutchinson's last-place Tigers tripped the Bombers, 2 to 1, before a crowd of 41,538.
Henry Clews Co., one of the oldest and, for many years, one of the most colorful member firms of the New York Stock Exchange, celebrated its seventy-fifth birthday yesterday.

As the city's first move toward deciding whether it will comply with recommendations of consultants of the Mayor's committee on Management Survey for abolition of fifty-two firehouses, Fire Commissioner Jacob Grumet will inspect next Tuesday the fourteen Manhattan stations proposed for elimination.

A four-alarm fire of undetermined origin that rushed through the two upper stories of a five-story brick commercial building in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn early today was watched by thousands of passersby, motorists and riders on the B.M.T. elevated line.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 25 (UP) -- Arthur Bliss Lane, former United States Ambassador to Poland, will substitute for Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, who is recovering from a major operation, in the Wisconsin Republican's campaign for re-election.
Crime in Brooklyn dipped to a new low yesterday afternoon when five noisy teen-agers, with handkerchiefs as masks, beat up the woman owner of a launderette, stole $10 and escaped on bicycles.

Joseph Eisenstein has purchased for investment from Webster Affiliates, Inc., the apartment house for fifty-six families at 1150 Vyse Avenue, the Bronx, in a deal negotiated by Farber-Wittman, Inc., brokers. James J. Leibman was the attorney for the seller and Joseph V. Farinella for the buyer.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 4 to 10 points lower yesterday than on Thursday.

BONN, Germany, July 25 -- The failure of Robert Schuman, French Foreign Minister, to give Chancellor Konrad Adenauer a pledge of free elections in the Saar or even of unrestricted political campaigning by pro-German parties has produced a mood of gloomy pessimism in the German Government about a settlement of the Saar issue.

CHICAGO, July 25 (AP) -- Pete Suder's bases-clearing triple capped a five-run third inning that led to a 5-4 victory for the Athletics in a second game of a twi-night double-header with the White Sox. The Sox won the opener, 5 -- 0, registering their second straight shutout behind Billy Pierce's seven-hit pitching.
In his "Education in Review" of July 13 Benjamin Fine had a tantalizing article titled "World Point of View, Teachers Are Wanted Who Can Lead the Modern Movement."

TAMPA, Fla., July 25 -- Larry Evans of New York, chess champion of the United States, tonight successfully defended his national open title by winning in the twelfth and final round from Herman Steiner of Los Angeles, his predecessor as United States champion, in forty-seven moves.

NEWPORT, R. I., July 25 -- An attempt to commercialize Newport's most exclusive summer colony section was thwarted last night when the Board of Review denied the petition of Miss Edith Newlin of Palm Beach to convert Seaverge at the southerly end of Bellevue Avenue into an apartment hotel with dining privileges.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce announced today how it will split up the 232,500 long tons of crude sulphur which the United States will export between July 1 and Sept. 30.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Construction permits for the first four educational television stations were approved by the Federal Communications Commission today.

GLEN HEAD, L. I., July 25 -- Mr. and Mrs. Donald O'Brien of Winged Foot became the new husband-and-wife champions of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association by playing alternate shots to score a 40, 38 over the Glen Head course today.

There are some aspects of the India-Kashmir agreement, as announced by Prime Minister Nehru in New Delhi, that are anything but reassuring. Foremost of these is the matter of timing. Dr. Frank Graham, acting as mediator on behalf of the United Nations, has just suggested raising the discussions of the India-Pakistan impasse from the delegate to the Cabinet level.
Negotiations between shipyard workers' representatives and the Bethlehem Steel Company were resumed yesterday, free of the cloud of a steel strike for the first time in nearly two months.

Whether Tassel, a 5-year-old French poodle worth $450, is in Washington, at the Democratic convention in Chicago or somewhere else was only one of the bewildering problems that faced Magistrate Benjamin Brenner yesterday in Felony Court.

WITH COMMONWEALTH DIVISION in Korea, July 25 (AP) -- Gen. James A. Van Fleet saluted the British Commonwealth division in Korea today as "great and gallant." The six-nation unit, first of its kind, will celebrate its first anniversary Monday.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 25 -- Members of the African National Congress, representing the Negroes, have sent a letter to Secretary General Trygve Lie of the United Nations asking for an opportunity to put their grievances before the General Assembly.
PHILADELPHIA, July 25 (AP) -Curt Simmons was blasted from the mound by the Cubs tonight as they scored four runs in the second inning and three in the third to defeat the Phillies, 8 to 3.
CHICAGO, July 25 -- The Democratic national committee today gave out a corrected version of one of the platform planks adopted by the convention last night.
Following are the texts of the two addresses in Chicago early today by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois accepting the Democratic Presidential nomination, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture forecast today "a rather sharp reduction" in United States cotton exports in the 1952-53 crop year.

Expanded defense production enabled the General Motors Corporation to achieve an outstanding employment record before it began to feel the effects of the steel strike, the company disclosed yesterday in a statement preliminary to its second-quarter operating report.

Private placement corporate financing in the first six months of 1952 totaled 470 transactions aggregating $2,484,447,937, compared with 400 placements totaling $2,090,231,442 in the first half of 1951, according to a mid-year survey of the new-issue market by the Investment Dealers' Digest.

Emil R. Capita's Hi-Q from the Port Washington Yacht Club was the first boat to start, at 6:03 last night, in the golden jubilee Bayside-to-Block Island auxiliary handicap race off the Bayside Yacht Club. Thirteen boats are entered.
TRENTON, July 25 -- The New Jersey Highway Authority, preparing to build the 165-mile Garden State Parkway, announced today it was changing the form of its initial temporary financing.
TOKYO, Saturday, July 26 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,322 for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Saturday, Korea time:

CHICAGO, July 25 -- The draft of Adlai Stevenson as the Democratic standard bearer represents a desire for a change in party leadership almost as insistent as the Republican choice of Dwight Eisenhower. In both cases the candidates did not seek the nomination.

Sales of beer, mostly for home consumption, have reached record levels here this month, brewers reported yesterday. They attributed the boom in sales to hot weather and the interest in the political conventions that has kept many families home watching television.

Morris Warschauer, who began his school career in 1907 as a $300-a-year office boy, plans to retire next year from his $14,000-a-year post of secretary of the Board of Education, it was disclosed yesterday.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, Saturday, July 26 -- Democratic party leaders went into a huddle early today immediately following the Presidential nomination of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson for talks on the Vice Presidency.

" Taras Shevchenko," a Russian-made biographical drama in color width Sergei Bondarchuk in the title role, is today's new film at the Stanley. Igor Savchenko wrote the scenario and directed the import, which was produced at the Kiev Film Studio.
THE HAGUE, July 25 -- World tin ore production in May has been estimated at 14,300 tons compared with 13,100 in April, an increase of 1,200 tons.

WITH U. S. FIRST MARINE DIVISION, Korea, July 25 -- A sharp-shooting sergeant using a fellow Marine as a decoy has claimed a perfect but highly unofficial record -- nine Chinese snipers killed with nine bullets.

Net income of the Consumers Power Company for the twelve months ended June 30 amounted to $19,946,709, according to the report released yesterday. This was equal to $2.68 a share on 6,176,693 common shares.
ATLANTIC CITY, July 25 (AP) -- The Glass Bottle Blowers Association, A. F. L., declared a strike today against the Hazel-Atlas Company, the nation's second largest glass container manufacturer.

Both the backlog of new security issues and the float of undistributed merchandise continues to shrink as the summer advances. Only a nominal amount of unsold corporate bonds and stocks are around, and even the float of railroad equipment certificates, which swelled last week to $34,000,000, has since declined to $27,400,000.

SAN JOSE, Calif., July 25 -- Sale of The San Jose News and The San Jose Mercury to Northwest Publications, Inc., owned by the Ridder publishing family, was announced today by Elystus Hayes, publisher of the morning and evening and combined sunday papers. The price was not disclosed.

The bullish bloom wore off slightly yesterday as profit-taking followed in the wake of the enthusiasm over the settlement of the steel strike. While the news of peace in the steel industry did not come until after the close of trading on Thursday, the share list, during business hours, anticipated that a truce was at hand.
BIRMINGHAM, July 25 (AP) -- Kentucky's athletic future was placed in the hands of the Southeastern Conference executive committee tonight.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 25 -The United States made an unlucky appearance in the Olympic water polo tournament today, losing to Sweden, 5 -- 1. The score at half-time was 2 -- 1.
CHICAGO, July 25 -- Organized labor, which looked like a powerhouse when the Democratic convention began, ended up as a trailer on the Stevenson bandwagon today.

Following are the texts of the statement of Averell Harriman of New York throwing his support to Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, and the convention addresses by Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee and Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia supporting the nomination of Governor Stevenson:

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, Saturday, July 26 -- The triumph of Governor Adlai E. Stevenson early today in the vehemently contested voting for the Democratic Presidential nomination evoked probably the greatest tribute conceivable from the National Convention -- a brief period of respectful silence.

Oak Ridge will be expanded at a cost of $464,000,000, and at Paducah, Ky., there is to be a $459,000,000 addition to the uranium-235 separation plant now under construction. Carbide and Carbon Chemicals Company, a division of Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation, will operate both.

A NOVEL that should have been written, "Strangers and Afraid" is concerned with what it is within some human beings that makes them become do-gooders, yet warps that urge into something so personal that such individuals become unable to see the trees for the forest.

When you see a crow or a hawk being pursued and pestered by a much smaller bird which attacks like a miniature jet fighter you are undoubtedly watching a kingbird in action. Ounce for ounce the kingbird is probably the most courageous of all our birds, and he sometimes seems the most truculent. Crows and hawks are his particular targets; birds of his own size seldom challenge him.

GROSSINGER, N. Y., July 26 -- Barbara Cunningham of Mamaroneck, N. Y., a member of the Women's Swimming Association, won the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union 300-meter individual medley championship at the Grossinger Country Club today. The W. S. A. swimmer was timed in 5:07.3.

The demand continued for fillin seasonal stocks in the wholesale market here last week but cutters were unwilling to prolong summer operations, causing a tightening of the supply, according to McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office.
DELMAR, Calif., July 26 (AP) -- The winner by two lengths in today's $7,500 Oceanside Handicap, Del Mar's first stake race of the season, was Danae -- only filly in the field of seven 3-year-olds.

Rockford College's experimental program of assistance to young women who want college training but may not be able to afford it now is in its second year of operation. College administrators, employers and students are satisfied with the past year's project.

The danger of a crisis in the machine tool industry, basic to all production, has all but disappeared. The Government, recognizing that the situation has reversed itself in the last month, last week eased its regulation requiring buyers of tools to have a priority rating.

LINDEN, N. J., July 26 -- The Esso Standard Oil Company has applied to the Army Corps of Engineers for permission to install a pipeline across the Arthur Kill between Staten Island and Elizabeth near the Goethals Bridge.

THE two catchers who won the "Most Valuable Player" awards in their respective leagues in 1951 are, unlike may ball players, interesting both as athletes and personalities. Roy Campanella, the Brooklyn Dodger backstop, is one of the warmest, most likable men to reach the big leagues since Lou Gehrig.

Former Vice President Henry A. Wallace, who bolted the Democratic party four years ago, said yesterday he had not decided whether to support Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson or Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Presidency.

Samuel Hardy, captain of the United States Davis Cup team in 1920 and 1931, recently received the second annual Professional Lawn Tennis Association award. George L. Seewagen, president of the P. L. T. A., presented an inscribed wrist watch to Hardy.
Canada, the third largest country in the world, is rapidly developing her natural storehouse of raw materials and industrializing her economy at the same time.
HANOVER, Germany, July 26 (AP) -- A delegation of five Hungarians crossed the Iron Curtain into West Germany today to take part in the second Lutheran World Federation assembly.
