Since Governor Stevenson was first advanced as a candidate for President, there have been references to his connection with the trial of Alger Hiss. What follows is a statement by the Governor of his part in that trial. It is an excerpt from a "Meet the Press" television program in Washington last March 30:

LONDON, July 26 -- Britain is making preparations to manufacture a guided antiaircraft rocket that can pursue its objective at more than 2,000 miles an hour, Duncan Sandys, the Minister of Supply, disclosed today.

CHICAGO, July 26 -- Steel warehouses and steel fabricators in the Chicago area are coming close to the "sold out" point on many types of steel, while a number of steel shapes have already disappeared from stocks. Production of 196,000 net tons in June was the lowest since August, 1949.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 26 -- The nomination of Gov. Adlai Stevenson of Illinois was generally welcomed today by United Nations delegates, a number of whom became friends of the Democratic Presidential candidate while he was a member of the United States delegation at the San Francisco conference and at the 1946 and 1947 sessions of the General Assembly.
TRUE enough, this book is funny, as the publisher claims. But to this reviewer it is, above all, a report on the strange and specifically American tragedy of being 40 plus.

Arthur Daley in "We Sprint, French Cycle, Japanese Swim" (July 13), writing about Russia's great basketball team, attributes this greatness to the absorption of Estonia. Although it is true that Estonia has produced some fine basketball players, the credit nevertheless belongs to Lithuania.
Dietary experts of the Department of Health whiled away a summer afternoon yesterday by estimating that New Yorkers lost at least 3,200,000 pounds in weight during the recent two-week heat wave.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 26 (AP) -- The American yacht Comanche, skippered by Jack Price of Miami, Fla., lost its lead in the Olympic Star Class competition today.

The world has spun a long course since Thomas Jefferson wrote to Baron von Humboldt: "The insulated state in which nature has placed the American continent should so far avail it that no spark of war kindled in the other quarters of the globe should be wafted across the wide oceans which separate us from them."

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- It was too much to expect that the steel strike, which had touched off some of the weirdest and most disastrous developments in American labor history, would pass quietly from the national scene when a settlement formula had been battered out.

BRILLIANT thought and logic are here contained within the framework of a pretty bad novel. As extrapolation of known fact the narrative is superb, exploring the probable development of extrasensory perception, psycho-kinesis and similar psychic potentials now dimly guessed at.
LONDON, July 26 -- King Farouk of Egypt got his come-uppance today. The price of his follies proved to be the loss of his throne.

UNDER the guise of camera importers' promotional quarterlies, two magazines have been appearing for some time which attempt to do more than merely publicize their stock in trade. One is Leica Photography, publication of E. Leitz, Inc., importers of the Leica camera, recently revived after a wartime suspension, and Exakta Magazine, a postwar journal distributed by the Exakta Camera Company, which imports the Exakta camera.

A BLIND may be fine for some bird photographers but give Stephen Foster Briggs a telephoto lens any time. Mr. Briggs, a business executive whose pictures of birds went on exhibition last week at the Kodak Information Center in Grand Central Terminal, where they will hang through Aug. 11, uses a 35mm camera and a 26-inch focal length telephoto lens.

THE subject of this biography Rear Admiral Daniel Judson Callaghan, was killed during the Battle of Guadalcanal on Nov. 13, 1942, when an enemy shell exploded on the bridge of his flagship, the San Francisco. Minutes earlier the same battle had claimed the life of Rear Admiral Norman Scott on the Atlanta.
The crisis of a few days ago in Iran is now being repeated with some variation in Egypt.

MONROE, N. Y., -- One mile from this pleasant Orange County town on Route 17 in the Ramapo Mountains and a two-hour drive from New York City is the museum village of Smith's Clove, a unique tourist attraction because within its eighteen buildings is housed probably one of the most diversified collections of Americana in the state.

DENVER, July 26 -- Commenting on the Democratic ticket nominated at Chicago, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower today struck the keynote of the Republican Presidential campaign. It com bined a promise of lasting peace and expanding progress for the United States with an implied attack on the record of the Democratic Administration.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J. July 26 -- An experiment is being conducted at the New Jersey Agricultural Experiment Station here on the use of a "stericooler" for chilling peaches before they are shipped to markets.

In his article "Peace May Be in Moslem Hands" (April 6) Rom Landau was inviting the Americans to try to consolidate their relationship with the Moslems. For this, I am sincerely grateful, for I am one of those who advocate a harmonious relationship between Moslems and Americans.

WESTFIELD -- Chautauqua County, 1,100 square miles of wooded hills and rich valleys at New York's southwestern corner, equally famous for its agriculture, industry, vacationlands, cultural centers and as the home of an American institution, today begins a week-long 150th birthday party.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., July 26 -- The Middlesex County Sewerage Authority voted this week to defer final action on plans for building a multimillion - dollar trunk sewer in the Raritan Valley pending a conference proposed by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll.

AFTER months of frantic search during which hundreds of candidates, Negro and white, had been heard by producer Robert Joseph and his associates, it now can be disclosed that what may turn out to be one of the choicest assignments of the season has fallen to a young soprano named Elaine Malbin.

At the Democratic Convention just ended, and at the Republican Convention which preceded it, a striking victory has been won by the people of the United States. Through all the mumbo-jumbo in Chicago, despite all the ritual dances of frenzied politicians before the usual political images, American democracy has proved itself strong and vigorous enough to force the selection of the two best possible candidates in the field.

FOR a quarter of a century a distinguished naturalist and scientist, Konrad Lorenz, has been making careful studies of animal, bird and fish behavior, mostly at his home in Altenberg, Austria. In so far as possible birds and beasts have been given the run of his home, as Mr. Lorenz believes, quite rightly, that only under conditions of freedom can valid observations be made of the habits of wild creatures.

CHICAGO, July 26 -- It is not the South that has really won here. It is not the North that has really won here. It is the Democratic party that has won here -- won a unity that it had not known since the Nineteen Thirties and the second Administration of Franklin D. Roosevelt.

After seven years of furnishing medical service to occupation troops, the United States Army and Air Force medical services in Europe are now quietly and effectively realigning themselves to their new mission of medical support to the American combat troops and airmen assigned to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization mission.

IT would require about $750,000,000 just to supply the population of Egypt with non-polluted drinking water. And the consequent drop in the death rate would not be entirely a blessing: increased demand on the meager national food supply would provoke other deadly ailments from malnutrition.

SINCE "The Marrying Kind" and "Pat and Mike" now are pictures to which moviemakers point with pride, it should be noted that Ruth Gordon and Garson Kanin, the husband and wife writing team responsible for these works, are laboring on another film project.

BAYSHORE, L. I., July 26 -- It will be the ninetieth birthday tomorrow for George Petit Le Brun, the man who drafted New York State's Sullivan Law against illegal possession of dangerous weapons. Today Mr. Le Brun, tall, able, alert and still an earnest student of the times, took the opportunity in a birthday interview to call for similar laws in other states.

The Joint Distribution Committee last year aided one of every eight Jews living in eighteen countries of Europe and the Moslem world, the committee's sixth annual Statistical Abstract, published yesterday, said.

MANY plants can be increased in summer, as long as the gardener is prepared to give them more than just ordinary attention. Summer cuttings will add to the collection of shrubs, hedge plants, evergreens, groundcovers and roses.

FLORENCE -- The drought and heat wave that have been dehydrating Italy and cutting into her water supply have reduced the Arno River to a slow-moving trickle, but there has been no drought of tourists here. Even before the international fashion show that made the hotel situation tighter than it has been in Chicago, the city was overflowing with visitors in search of beauty, culture and Florentine bargains.

THE travail of platform writing has pervaded Chicago for weeks now, first with the efforts of the Republicans and then with the exertions of the Democrats, and above the mounds of used scrap paper rises the inescapable question: What does it all mean?

A Federal Bureau of Investigation agent was wounded fatally in the lobby of the Congress Hotel, 19 West Sixty-ninth Street, at 1:15 P. M. yesterday in a pistol battle that resulted in the capture of a Kansas bank robber sought as one of the nation's ten most-wanted criminals.

The steel strike may have been a hammer blow to some industries but it was far from disastrous to appliance manufacturers. Reports last week indicated that the last uncomfortable inventories in factories were wiped clean and the industry appears to be in the strongest position it has held for a long time.
THE Dramatists Forum, which continues to draw novice playwrights to its weekly sessions the way honey draws bears, celebrated its fifth birthday this month by moving into larger quarters.

TOKYO, Sunday, July 27 -- Full-scale negotiations at Panmunjon for an armistice in the Korean war were in abeyance for a week today after an angry squabble yesterday when United Nations delegates walked from the conference tent, forcing a new adjournment.

FACED with what might be called at best an indifferent attitude on the part of prospective sponsors toward the proposed Worthington Miner dramatic series to be spotted in the 8 to 9 P. M. time on Wednesdays, the National Broadcasting Company TV network is hedging on its gamble to sell the series by setting a time limit for the sale.

MOST mountaineering expeditions, meticulous about all other details, overlook the advisability of including a writer trained to see the human interest aspects of the adventure. The result is a ponderous alpine literature. There are, of course, notable exceptions.

DALLAS, July 26 (UP) -- Major Harry Trimble, a 32-year-old air force pilot from Hickam Air Field Base in Hawaii, captured the national all-gauge skeet championship today, but only after a Marine captain extended him 225 extra targets in a shoot-off.

IN 1949 Thomas Costain temporarily turned aside from a successful series of historical novels to commence a long history of England in which it was his intention to apply his persuasive imagination to the sober realm of fact.

BALTIMORE, July 26 (AP) -- Top-seeded Dick Savitt outlasted Fred Kovaleski in a bitterly contested match today to move into the final of the Middle Atlantic grass courts tennis championships. The score was 6 -- 2, 12 -- 10, 6 -- 2.

ONE of the greatest problems that the television industry has had to face is the overwhelming demand for adequate storage space and the continually soaring production costs that far exceed anything ever imagined in the areas of entertainment or communications.

ASTENOGRAPHIC record is no real substitute for interpretative exposition. That is the basic weakness of this factual account of the murder trial of three hoodlums who were convicted in 1950 for killing a man in a hold-up.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, observed quietly today his thirty-fifth anniversary as a member of the Department of Justice. He came to the department as an attorney on July 26, 1917, after his graduation from George Washington University here.
EARLY this month, an organization known as the American Hobby Federation released the results of a year-long survey just completed among young members of 8,414 hobby clubs throughout the country.

Charles E. Wilson, who resigned as Director of Defense Mobilization March 30 in a sharp dispute on how the steel issue should be settled, predicted yesterday that the agreement that ended the fifty-five-day strike would bring great inflationary pressures on the nation.

PITTSBURGH, July 26 (UP) -- The United Steelworkers C. I. O., began disbanding picket lines at the nation's steel plants today and the industry immediately took the first steps toward the resumption of steel production.
A ring match that is weighted with significance with respect to the world heavyweight title, and carries traditional box-office appeal is scheduled for tomorrow night in the Yankee Stadium.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., July 26 -- A fleet of eighteen ambulances from surrounding communities transferred sixty-three patients, including two incubator babies and an infant three hours old, from the old Morristown Memorial Hospital to its new building this morning. The transfer was completed in two hours.
LENOX, Mass., July 26 --Ceremonies were held today in Sedgwick Hall of the Lenox Library in memory of Dr. Serge Koussevitzky, whose seventy-eighth birthday this would have been.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 26 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh presented his Cabinet to Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi today in which he, himself, will be Minister of War and responsible for the armed forces. At the same time, the National Front organ Bakhtar Emruz disclosed the proposals that the Premier has made to the British Embassy for settlement of the British-Iranian oil issue.

WHY do we take it for granted that we shall be forcibly retired from work at the age of 65 -- or, as is actually done in some organizations, at 60? The origin of this idea in modern society is not entirely clear, but in any case it is a totalitarian, undemocratic, "statist" concept, best fitted to the rigid social structure of the Incas, who thousands of years ago established a fixed age-scheme.
One of the most intriguing things to reach the American home since radio and television has been the home deep freeze.

May I, as the wife of a musician, say that George D. Griffin is absolutely right in taking exception to Mr. Taubman's prophecy that Americans will turn away from a future in music if they cannot make a decent living out of it. The musicians I know will not.

HOW the real St. Louis Browns could use the hero Mr. Webster's book this season! The Brownies -- the fictional team of the story -- are a slack and demoralized bunch when Wilbur Hatfield signs up as rookie left - fielder.

PERHAPS only in the novel can a Japanese author make his own people really understandable to Western readers. In speech and deed the Japanese are not given to self-revelation. There is a code of behavior which circumscribes almost any act a Japanese might contemplate or speech he wished to utter.

ANYONE who fears that New York City fosters moral wickedness will be further dismayed by the unhealthy, unlovely souls who flit through this alleged novel. Action begins when Geraldine Lowell, a high-priced prostitute, generously helps a girl friend to retain an expensive car, given by a now insolvent male companion, by strangling the donor.

LONDON, July 26 -- The first all-Egyptian military coup since the British moved into the country seventy years ago removed King Farouk from his throne this week and launched a drive against the corruption that has so long gone unpunished in Egypt, that land of vast wealth and mass poverty.

PARAMUS, N. J., July 26 -- A golfer who learned to play the game in Texas and another who started as a caddie in Westchester reached the final of the Metropolitan amateur championship at the Ridgewood Country Club today.

Following is the text of President Truman's address early Saturday to the Democratic National Convention in Chicago, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES. This text is reprinted from the latest edition of Saturday's TIMES.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 26 -- Louis M. Rabinowitz of New York City, has presented an original copy of "The Dictes and Sayings of the Philosophers" to the Yale University Library.

The Democratic National Convention leaves one, as did the Republican National Convention, still uncertain as to whether the national convention is an institution worth preserving. There are many arguments against it, but when a dramatic moment arrives and one is made aware of that moment by television or even by plain old-fashioned radio, none of the arguments seem to be any good.

THERE is little on Marshal Tito in "The Truth About Yugoslavia." This is a historical survey mainly concerned with the internal weaknesses of royalist Yugoslavia and the influences responsible for the climactic debacle of army and state under Axis attack in April, 1941.

SETTLEMENT of the steel strike last week gave a badly needed lift to business and industrial Sentiment. The stoppage, longest and most expensive in the history of the industry, cost the economy of the country about $4,000,000,000 in production and some 17,000,000 tons of ingot steel.

TO the eye, the ancient city of Dublin seems unchanged. The sea gulls still swoop overhead in endless cry and the River Liffey still churns murkily through the city. In O'Connell Street the post office still stands -- still a shrine to the Irish patriot -- and it still bears the bullet scars of the uprising against the English in 1916.

NONE of Moravia's novels so far published in America ("The Woman of Rome," "Two Adolescents," "Conjugal Love," "The Conformist"), with their intense illumination of psychological Sturm und Drang, could lead one to expect "The Fancy Dress Part."

BEHIND James C. Petrillo's latest ultimatum to record-makers is a simple but powerful motivation. The American Federation of Musicians head wants additional contributions to the Music Industry Performance Trust Fund, the organization through which recording companies indirectly make payments to the Musicians Union on records sold.

A GOOD cook, like any other creative artist, can have temperamental moments. Pot roast and apple pie may suit one mood, but for another nothing will do except Quiche Lorraine, Foie de Veau Nicoise, a green salad and Strawberries Romanoff.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 26 -- Laffango and South Point shared the honors in the Tyro Stakes at Monmouth Park today. The event was divided into two sections, and the crowd of 30,044 was pleased with the way things turned out because each half was won by the favorite.

IT looks very much as if New York would be having an opportunity to see Alicia Markova in action next fall after much too long an absence. If present negotiations turn out as they should, she will be appearing as guest artist with Ballet Theatre in its season at the Metropolitan Opera House late in September, and possibly also in Chicago and elsewhere later.

The adjustments a player to make and the problems he meets in shifting from one position on the diamond to another is excitingly set down in Addison Rand's story, "Southpaw Fly Hawk." Pitching had always been Eddie Hadley's strong point.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., July 26 -- Training scientists in tracking down disease carriers by blood identification is the latest service of Rutgers University's Serological Museum, directed by Dr. Alan A. Boyden.

THE "sadistic" novel has been under attack again in The Sunday Times of London, the paper which tried to get Norman Mailer's "The Naked and the Dead" banned some years ago. This protest against sadism was made by C. P. Snow, an eminent novelist and regular reviewer, and the question has now been debated by Walter Allen, Joyce Cary, J. L. Hodson, Storm Jameson, Rose Macaulay, Rebecca West and others in The Author.

DURING summer and early autumn, florist shops all over the country give prominence to the beautiful, velvety, bell-shaped gloxinia. At a time when many other house plants have finished bloom and are resting, they are in their prime. Yet the flowers on gloxinia were not always so large and frilly. Their present size and form is the result of more than a century of hybridizing.

CHICAGO, July 26 -- Sure, there was a lot of hoopla, hullabaloo and hooey. Sure, there were times when the patron saints seemed to be, not Lincoln and Jefferson, but Barnum and Bailey. Sure this isn't the way the rest of the world does it, especially Russia.

EACH United States soldier on the front line in World War II was backed up by about seven in the training and service echelons. In baseball the rear areas seem to be much more populous -- a dozen men backing up every player in the big league line-up.

FAIR HAVEN, N. J., July 26 -- Fred C. Glasier of Springfield, N. J., a home club former commodore, today won the 46-mile offshore predicted log cruiser race of the Shrewsbury River Yacht Club with an unusually accurate score of an error percentage of only 2,243 in his black hulled yacht Spindrift.

Senator John Jackson Sparkman, the Democratic nominee for Vice President, has been an unwavering supporter of the Administration's foreign policy and, with some exceptions, has backed the New Deal and Fair Deal domestic programs since his election to the House of Representatives in 1936.

CHICAGO, July 26 -- Somebody is going to have to write a new book of political rules, for the Chicago stockyards never saw a slaughter to compare with what happened to the old political maxims, assumptions and cliches here this month.

PARIS, July 26 -- Salaheddine Baccouche, Premier of the French Protectorate of Tunisia, declared today that his Cabinet was incompetent to accept the French-sponsored home-rule program and that only his sovereign, the Bey of Tunis; could approve or reject the proposals.
ST. LOUIS, July 26 (UP) -- The Browns scored their second straight victory over the Red Sox, 7 -- 2, today, giving them a three-game streak, their longest in more than two months.

YOU don't hear much about gun dog activities during the summer, but whether it's freezing or frying, the field trial folk keep going. During the hot weather the clubs maintain a semblance of competition by holding "picnic trials."
LONDON, July 26 -- The British Government has warned the Egyptian Government that it will take any necessary action to defend British lives and has alerted its forces in the Mediterranean.

For years Egypt has been the center of the turmoil and stress set up by the forces that are turning the whole Middle East against the West. The flames of nationalism have found brushwood in Egypt. Hatred of imperialism has been intense in a land where 20 million impoverished peasants are ruled by a handful of Pashas.
CHICAGO, July 26 (AP) -- Grains generally moved upward throughout the session on the Board of Trade today. The advance set in shortly after a mixed opening.

CLEVELAND, July 26 (UP) --The Senators regained third place and scored their twenty-second one-run victory of the season today when they defeated the Indians. 11 -- 10. Late rallies by Cleveland almost overcame a nine-run Washington lead.

Fortunately California's second strongest earthquake of the century was not so destructive of life and property as the famous quake of 1906 that San Francisco euphemistically refers to as "the fire." The little town of Tehachapi (population 2,500) suffered the most damage, but the shock was felt from San Francisco south to San Diego and inland from Sacramento to Las Vegas, Nev.

HUMOR, that rarest of all qualities in science fiction, is at once the most rewarding. This volume contains five adventures of Gallagher, the drunken inventive genius, and his narcissistic robot, Joe (designed to serve as a super beer-can opener).

DOCUMENTATION of a Communist party can never be an easy task; for communism itself is a flower of the darkness and the workings of its party machines usually are carefully guarded from the inquiring outsider.

WOMEN are the lost sex; women are not the lost sex. Women should be allowed to do the same work as men; women should have special tasks. Women are being victimized by a man dominated society; the American man is the victim of his mother, sister, school teacher and wife.

ELKO, Nev. -- Since they usually encounter Nevada when the thermometer is touching the 100-degree mark, and since they are given to spending considerable time and coin of the realm within the pleasure domes of Reno or Las Vegas, many summer motorists look upon the Silver State with rather jaundiced eyes.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 26 -- The widespread explosion of public wrath against the aged statesman, Ahmad Ghavam, which drove him out of the Premiership after only four days, following sanguinary rioting, was essentially nationalistic.

CHICAGO, July 26 -- King Ranch's To Market, a sensation on Chicago race tracks as a juvenile two years ago, returned to the scene of his earlier triumphs today, winning the $152,350 Arlington Handicap by ten lengths. Oil Capitol was second and Ruhe third on the slow track.

THE statement that growing perennials require little or no care is an exaggeration. True, they will take much abuse and live, but they do not thrive on neglect. During a hot summer, particularly, they need regular care to continue well through the season and produce their best effects next year.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 26 (AP) -- Don Bisplinghoff of Orlando, Fla., today won the national junior golf title. He beat Eddie Meyerson of Los Angeles, 2 up, in a stirring eighteen-hole final.

CHICAGO, July 26 -- Frank E. McKinney of Indianapolis was retained as chairman of the reorganized Democratic National Committee today on a temporary basis at the request of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, the party's Presidential nominee.

WE owed to Claude Delvincourt, director of the Paris Conservatoire, the privilege of a place on the jury for the "Concours de fin d'annee 1952" of the conducting class of that famous institution. We had said that we wanted to hear the Conservatoire's student orchestra.
ATLANTA, July 26 -- Georgia farmers continued today to look for general rain to break a drought that has already pushed crop damage estimates past the $50,000,000 mark.

THE housing shortage has hatched several books about rooming houses, but none of them has the freshness of this heart-warming story. Helen Sherkanowski, a former jeep driver of the Navy and her sister, Mary, have had such an exciting time leasing a filthy, abandoned house of shady reputation, and transforming it into a clean, shining home for wartime strays that they had to write about it.
MANY gardeners are familiar with the early - flowering spring primulas. Few realize that early summer, too, finds its full share of these beautiful flowers in bloom.

ELIZABETH, N. J., July 26 -- The Union County Park Commission Police Department's "lone ranger," Patrolman Charles S. Hoag, the county's only mounted policeman, covers a beat that includes about thirty miles of wooded trails and open fields in the rolling hills of the Watchung Reservation.

ROME, July 26 -- The news of Governor Stevenson's nomination reached Italy too late for publication this morning, but was prominently displayed by all newspapers this afternoon. It aroused only mild interest, since Mr. Stevenson is almost unknown to most people.

Dr. George W. Kisker, associate professor of psychology in the University of Cincinnati, is recording on tape the voices of the world's leading minds as they expound their theories. He calls his collection of tapes "Recorded University.'' Originally he intended to make a few recordings for classroom use. The possibilities were so obvious and alluring that he thought of saving as many words of wisdom as he could for the benefit of the world.

The amount of legal liquor consumed in this country each year is declining steadily, Walter F. Terry, vice president of the Calvert Distillers Corporation, declared in an interview yesterday. Bootleg liquor is being bought instead because of high prices caused by taxes on the legal product, he explained.

MANES SPERBER suggests in his article, "The Autobiographer's Hidden World," that all those who wish to write confessional literature should do so in fiction rather than non-fiction. The reason: it is impossible to give a scientifically subjective account, and therefore it is antithetical to non-fiction writing.

CHICAGO, July 26 -- Technically it was Utah, with only twelve convention votes, that nailed down Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson's nomination as the Democratic candidate for President but only because Sam Rayburn, the permanent convention chairman, apparently wanted it that way.

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., July 26 (AP) -- The Daily Pantagraph played the Democratic Presidential nomination of one of its stockholders, Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, Illinois, with traditional lack of fanfare today.

HONG KONG, July 26 -- Reports from Macao tonight said that three persons had been killed and five wounded there in a series of gunfire exchanges between border guards on the short land frontier separating the tiny Portuguese colony from Communist China.

IN an industry where standards shift in competitive scrambling and the new and the different constantly face eclipse by mass production, the experimental corner quietly occupied by Norman McLaren remains a small but verdant oasis.

HEMINGWAY will be an outstanding target of opportunity in the autumn lit'ry maneuvers. His new book, "The Old Man and the Sea," due in September from Scribners, is already being called one of the three or four best things he ever wrote.

This is a short comment on Wildon Lloyd's letter regarding a French translation of the Chinese phrase, "to have a tiger by the tail." The letter ends: "The expression is perfectly translatable into French: 'Qui chevauehe un tigre ne doit pas demonter.'

MINNEAPOLIS, July 26 -- Building and construction activity in the Ninth Federal Reserve District held close to 1951 levels during the first six months of this year, the Minneapolis Reserve Bank reported. A survey of building permits in eighty-three of the district's cities showed a total dollar value of $101,774,960 for the period, a decline of 1 per cent.

BUENOS AIRES, July 26 -- Argentine-Chilean relations appeared to be suffering new strains today as Santiago accused the Argentine Foreign Ministry of having engaged in an "excessively offensive" propaganda campaign against Chile.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Senator Brien McMahon, Democrat of Connecticut and chairman of the important Joint Coumittee on Atomic Energy, is "seriously ill" of a spinal ailment his personal physician, Dr. Philip Caulfield, said in a formal statement today.
TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., July 26 -- Mrs. John Hill McKinney has been named chairman of the Tuxedo Autumn Ball, which will be held on Oct. 25 in the Tuxedo Club.

THE lapse of time between the printing of the Book Review and its arrival in Spain may make this comment untopical, but I am forced to protest over a statement by' Mr. Joseph Wood Krutch in the June 29 "Speaking of Books" column.

IMPORTANT projects to eliminate highway hazards are being delayed through lack of personnel to carry out the plans of the State Traffic Commission. Already this work, which extends throughout the state, is about 600 projects behind schedule.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 26 (UP) -- "I didn't think yesterday I could do it. But I did and now I'm finished."

DALLAS, Tex., July 26 (UP) -- Gov. Allan Shivers took a wide lead tonight in his bid for re-election after earlier opposition strength. Attorney General Price Daniel appeared headed for Tom Connally's United States Senate seat without a run-off.

King Farouk abdicated after sixteen years, or just half his lifetime, on the throne of Egypt. He was 16 years old when his father, King Fuad, died, and he had to interrupt his formal education in England to become monarch of the land of the pharaohs.
ALTHOUGH it sounds like an impossible statement to make, many trees slowly but surely die of strangulation. Horticulturally this condition is known as "root girdling."
LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 26 -- At the end of a perfect day for sailing, if not a perfect week, the fifty-fourth Race Week at the Larchmont Yacht Club came to a close today.

THIS handsome book, a further embellishment for the imaginary museum, is nothing less than a complete photographic record of the paintings by the brothers Van Eyck and is introduced with a long and learned introduction by one of the most respected scholars of Flemish painting.
TULARE, Calif., July 26 (UP) -- Jubilant Tulare residents held their wildest celebration since 1948 today after the No. 1 citizen, Bob Mathias, had set a new world decathlon record at the Olympics.
BOSTON, July 26 (UP) -- George (Cat) Metkovich broke up a pitching duel today with a double that scored two runs in the ninth inning and gave the Pirates a 6-4 triumph over the Braves.

FOR a month our attention has been focused on our national conventions. As the delegates go home from Chicago, the whole nation, in a manner of speaking, goes home from Chicago too, away from its watching and back to normal.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 26 -- Pleadings before the International Court of Justice on United States treaty rights in French Morocco concluded today with the United States' assertion that it desired freedom of imports not only for itself but for all nations, and that this would be "of inestimable value" to the protectorate.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 26 (AP) -- These Finns are fabulous. The way they stage and handle these mammoth Olympic games is a show as spectacular and amazing as the games.

CHICAGO, July 26 -- The sound and fury of the nominating process ended this week with the Presidential issue joined between Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Republicans and Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois for the Democrats.

BY the time this column appears both national convention should, God willing, be over; and the public can at last unglue itself from its TV sets and resume the more soothing summer practice of reading about murder.
MARGATE CITY, N. J., July 26 (AP) -- Jerry South and Claiborne Coupland, both of Norfolk, Va., today won preliminary heats in the International Moth Class open championship races.

FROM that corner of the R. K. O. lot where Jerry Wald conducts a production operation in association with Howard Hughes and company, comes word of a development or two affecting Mr. Wald's future filming plans, of which he is never without an abundance.

Beaten on the head with a heavy toy pistol in an attempted hold-up, an I. R. T. change booth attendant in Brooklyn died at 6:30 A. M. yesterday at Kings County Hospital after his wounds had been treated at Unity Hospital forty minutes earlier.

THE subject of "Are you air conditioned?" has by no means displaced politics, baseball and Russia as something to talk about, but it is certainly running up. The reasons are: (1) this summer seems intent on setting the nastiest records for heat and humidity; (2) air conditioning is striding off in all directions in eightleague boots.

CINCINNATI, July 26 -- The doubles combination of Billy Talbert of New York and Gardnar Mulloy of Miami, Fla., today steered the United States into the second round of 1952 Davis Cup tennis competition.

A comprehensive three-year study of the Jewish-sponsored educational institutions in New York City and the metropolitan area was begun last week. The more than six hundred schools in this city, Westchester, Nassau and Suffolk Counties under Jewish auspices will be studied.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Official Washington tried to decide today who was more surprised at the continuing steel strike, the Congress of Industrial Organizations or the steel industry.

CHICAGO, July 26 (AP) -- Two women were placed in nomination today for Vice President on the Democratic ticket. They said "Thanks, very much" and withdrew, so that Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama might be selected unanimously.

ON Tuesday, the new S. S. Flandre of the French Line will arrive in New York from Le Havre on her maiden voyage. The 20,500-ton liner, first ship built by the French Line for trans-Atlantic service since the Normandie, will join the Ile de France and the Liberte on regular service between England, France and New York, stopping at Plymouth eastbound, and Southampton westbound. She departs for Plymouth Friday.

IF this collection of short stories, parts of novels, poetry, documentaries and sketches is any index of the young American writer, then it can be said at once that he is a poor poet and a good short story writer; he has a knowledge of his craft, he believes in Mansfield, Joyce and Kafka but he writes like Farrell, Dos Passos, and Steinbeck without their bewilderment.

MITCHEL AIR FORCE BASE, L. I., July 2 -- An all-girl team from Colorado was the sentimental favorite, but a male contingent from Puerto Rico won first honors today in the annual national drill competition held by the Civil Air Patrol of the Air Force at Mitchel Air Force Base.

BY way of London comes information that India plans a series of stamps with portraits of famous Indian poets. The first six who will thus be honored are Ghalib, Kabir, Mira Bai, Sur Das, Tagore and Tulsi Das.

CANNES -- Only a fleet mountain goat, and some American tourists, would attempt to journey in one day from Florence via Pisa and up through the Italian and French Rivieras through Genoa, Monte Carlo and Nice to Cannes.

WALLY COX, who does "odd comedian jobs" and recently became the star of a television program, entered show business three and a half years ago as a monologist and mimic. He is a dead-pan comic, except when effecting a doltish grin, and speaks always in a soft, conversational tone with a peculiar, quizzical pitch in his voice.
CHICAGO, July 26 (AP) -- The White Sox, paced by Minnie Minoso's four straight hits, defeated the Athletics, 9 -- 3, today.
A 23-year-old expectant mother who had started out on a shopping trip for maternity clothes was found strangled yesterday morning on a sidewalk in Kingston Place, Jamaica Estates, Queens.

CHICAGO, July 26 -- Again President Truman has sent up a ringing cry to his party to carry on the Fair Deal, but it is obvious now that the Roosevelt-Truman philosophy of government is nearing the end of an era.

Following are excerpts from editorial comment in newspapers on the Democratic nomination of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois for the Presidency, as gathered by THE NEW YORK TIMES, The Associated Press and The United Press:

An all-Bach program tomorrow will open the week's recorded concerts of the New York Public Library in Bryant Park. The concerts, held Mondays through Fridays from noon to 2 P. M., will wind up the week with a program exclusively devoted to recordings by Enrico Caruso, from the earliest made by the famous tenor in 1903 to those of 1920, the year before his death.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The final obstacle to ending the steel strike was removed late this afternoon and union back-to-work telegrams started 600,000 strikers streaming into the steel mills after an absence of fifty-five days.

In a hotel ballroom in Pittsburgh nine months ago two groups of men gathered around a long table. On one side were spokesmen for the American steel industry. On the other were spokesmen for the United Steelworkers, C. I. O. The men were gathered to negotiate a new contract.

For the Republican -- Dwight David Eisenhower, 61, born in Texas, reared in Kansas; forty years a soldier; Supreme Commander in the Allied victory in the West in World War II and in the founding of the NATO's military forces; now president-on-leave of Columbia University.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., July 26 -- Miss Janet Wilkins, an upstate farm girl who lives at Homer, N. Y., will be crowned as New York State and National Vegetable Queen at the summer meeting of the New York State Vegetable Growers Association.

A vital decision in the thirty - five - year - old dispute over the Government-owned Hoboken piers is expected Wednesday when Government and city officials, civic leaders and representatives of the Port of New York Authority meet in the Hoboken City Hall.

In selecting Senator John Sparkman of Alabama for the Vice-Presidential nomination, the Democratic National Convention made a gesture to the Southern branch of the party without capitulating to its extreme right-wing element. Senator Sparkman has a reputation as one of the relatively liberal Democratic leaders of the South, and he is highly regarded in the Congress, where he has ably served for fifteen years.

The 52 Association of New York, Inc., will give a series of parties for wounded service men and veterans this week. Beginning tonight, the group will be host to twenty-five patients of Valley Forge Army Hospital on a three-day visit.

I agree with Gian-Carlo Menotti's article "A Plea for the Creative Artist" (June 29) wholeheartedly. But may I suggest that not only the parents should be educated to a more idealistic attitude toward the arts.
LONDON, July 26 -- This week in three meetings the British Cabinet was pondering a problem that confronts most of us at one time or another how to make ends meet.

Have the Giants launched their big push? That question was buzzing around the Polo Grounds yesterday after a grand slam homer by Henry Thompson and a solid pitching job by Larry Jansen defeated the Reds, 7 -- 2, for the New Yorkers' fifth consecutive victory.

With Sunny Jim Fitzsimmons peering at the proceedings from his favorite spot under a tree on the clubhouse turn, the Fitzsimmons trained Golden Gloves, bred and owned by William Woodward's Belair Stud, won the $23,850 Saranac Handicap for 3-year-olds at the Saratoga-at-Jamaica session yesterday.
TWENTY years ago this month Franklin D. Roosevelt shattered tradition by flying from Albany to Chicago to accept the Democratic nomination for the Presidency of the United States.

DETROIT, July 26 -- Mickey Mantle, who, the Tigers are convinced, must be twins, because he belts them from the left as well as the right, hit the first grand-slam homer of his major league career today. But even that didn't win for the Bombers, for after blowing two leads, they had to carry the battle into extra innings and went crashing down to defeat.

THE bright and shining colors of gladiolus are already seen in gardens here in the Northeast. The parade of shows for this spectacular summer-flowering bulb, which started in Texas last May, has now reached this part of the country.

In an article which he contributed to the French monthly Science et Vie, Jules Romains of the Academie Francaise says that "discoveries of the first magnitude -- like stars similarly designated -- seem to be limited in number," and that in the future there will be few. The energetic Henri Corbiere asked scientists to comment. He presents the results in Les Nouvelles Litteraires.
There are more than 4,000 shallow-draft vessels plying the forty different channels of New York Harbor, according to a report of the American Waterways Operators.

THE Olympic Games, like Presidential campaigns, take place once every four years and the pair of attractions have frequently produced rival displays of acrimony. Olympic competition, despite an occasional fly in the liniment, has been none the less keen, colorful and, on the record, consistently dramatic.

CAIRO, July 26 -- King Farouk I abdicated the ancient Egyptian throne today at the climax of a tank-supported Army clean-up campaign and sailed away in the Mediterranean aboard his Royal yacht, the Mahroussa. The Army said his family went with him for exile in Italy.

In a thoughtful letter appearing on this page today an American who has been on a Fulbright grant in the Philippines points to a possible connection between Manila's ratification of the Japanese peace treaty and further Philippine trade talks with the United States. This connection is inevitable, of course, but it should not be regarded as purposeful.
ARE concert-goers music-lovers or are they only dismal copy-cats who respond to the call of box-office names and publicity hullaballoo?

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 26 -- Senator Herbert H. Lehman of New York today urged Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama, following his nomination for Vice President, to embrace without reservation the civil rights plank written into the Democratic platform earlier in the week.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., July 26 (UP) -- Jon (Jackie) Douglas, fifth-seeded Santa Monica, Calif., player and Tom Freiberg of Beverly Hills, Calif., were upset victors today, capturing singles championships of the Western junior and boys tennis tourney.

IN no department of fine French cooking, with the possible exception of desserts, is there more chance for show than in the cold buffet of hot summer. Because the dishes are usually decorated and often glazed, as the examples on this page indicate, they look striking.

Savings banks of New York will use a wholly owned investment company to make their stock investments, now that such investments are permitted under a recently enacted law, it was disclosed last week. The company start operating within a few months after completion of legal arrangements.

Stock prices scored moderate gains and moved to new highs for twenty-two years last week in a steady four-day advance prior to announcement of the steel wage-price settlement after the close of trading on Thursday. Having already discounted the steel agreement the market then retreated slightly on Friday under light profit-taking, but the bulk of the earlier gains was retained.

DETROIT, July 26 -- Barring the customary fine performance the eminent Professor Casey Stengel continues to give in a bid to manipulate the Yankees into their fourth straight pennant, it would seem from this corner that two of the finest managerial jobs of the year are those now being achieved by Lou Boudreau of the Red Sox and Bucky Harris of the Senators.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 26 -Beirut and other Arab capitals were stunned tonight by the news of the unexpected abdication and banishment of King Farouk of Egypt and the formation of a Regency Council to exercise what was left of the royal prerogatives during the minority of the infant Crown Prince, Ahmed Fuad.

Officials in Washington last week resumed conversations on the purchase of Bolivian tin. If successfully concluded, they promise to strike a severe blow to a group of British companies which jointly control more than 50 per cent of world tin production.

ORIANA ATKINSON, in the opening lines of her review last week, hit it right on the head when she described the author of "Postmarked Moscow" as a "member of the American diplomatic set, but not a diplomatic lady."

BUENOS AIRES, July 26 -- Senora Dona Maria Eva Duarte de Peron, wife of President Juan D. Peron, who had made herself one of the most powerful women in the history of Argentina and of the New World, died tonight at 8:25 o'clock. She had long been ill.

THERE are many explorers, and a good many of them enjoy life up North, but few truly write about the Arctic, and very few can write as well as Constance and Harmon Helmericks. The Helmericks were born brave and full of joie de vivre.
RUMSON, N. J., July 26 (AP) -- The Oxford-Cambridge tennis team won the Prentice Cup for the second straight time today by taking five out of seven matches from the Harvard-Yale squad.

A starting field that may be as large as thirteen of the world's fastest speed boats and classed as Unlimited Hydroplanes is indicated for the annual Gold Cup race on Lake Washington, Seattle, on Saturday, Aug. 9, according to Carl Johnson of Detroit, executive secretary of the American Power Boat Association.

Bob Mathias broke his own world record with 7,887 points as the United States swept the first three places in the decathlon yesterday. It was the Tulare (Calif.) star's second victory in that event. Milton Campbell of Plainfield, N. J., was second and Floyd Simmons of Los Angeles third.

THE citizens of Frankfort on the Main, Germany, are in the midst of a gala celebration these days because one of their proudest accomplishments, the frankfurter, is 100 years old. According to historians on the subject, the glorified sausage was developed in 1852 by members of a German butchers' guild in Frankfort.

GUATEMALA, July 26 -- Chicle, the base of chewing gum, once one of the most important products of the vast Peten jungles, is now without a market, according to the newspaper La Hora. This means the loss of at least $2,000,000 annually to the Government and will leave a great many workers without employment.

Consumer spending is influenced by what people know of price trends, how they feel about prevailing prices and what course they expect prices to take.

PARIS, July 26 -- The only notable published comment tonight on the nomination of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois as the Democratic Presidential candidate was that of the afternoon newspaper Le Monde. That newspaper said nothing about Governor Stevenson except that he had the "conquering smile" of President Roosevelt, but it spoke caustically of the "lack of substance and imagination" in the Democratic platform.

PHILADELPHIA, July 26 -- In wholesale and retail lines, seasonal conditions plus prolongation of the steel strike reduced July turnover to below the dollar-volume for June. Large retailers, however, sold more units of merchandise this month than a year ago.

TODAY the biggest American bridge tournament of the year begins in Cincinnati, and unless the expectations of the American Contract Bridge League are widely askew, some 4,000 of the best bridge players in the country will have entered the competition for national championships by the time the last round is completed on Aug. 6.

Milton Solomon, candidate for the Democratic nomination for Municipal Court justice in the Sixth District of Brooklyn, announced yesterday that a show cause action had been brought in Supreme Court seeking to invalidate the petitions of Justice Murray H. Pearlman, his rival for the nomination.

The Dodgers' lead over the second-place Giants was cut to four and a half games after they dropped their second straight to the Cardinals, 5 -- 3, at Ebbets Field yesterday. Only five days ago the Brooks were riding high on the strength of a seven-and-a-half length spread over the runners-up.

BERLIN, July 26 -- All of the seven alleged agents of West Berlin's Investigation Committee of Free Jurists who were put on trial in East Berlin yesterday were found guilty today of having spied for the United States.
Republican Platform: "The Republican party stands confident that it expresses * * * the decent aspirations of our people for peace, for solvency and for the fulfillment of our best welfare * * *."

CHICAGO, July 20 (AP) -- Two Negro leaders joined today in criticizing the choice of Senator John J. Sparkman for the Vice Presidential nomination on the Democratic ticket, citing his voting record and public statements on the issue of civil rights.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 26 (AP) -- Tommy Kono, 22-year-old soldier from Sacramento, Calif., and Pete George, 23-year-old student from Akron, Ohio, gave to the United States its first 1952 Olympic weightlifting championships today with record-smashing performances.

PHILADELPHIA, July 26 -- Dr. A. S. W. Rosenbach, the noted bibliographer, has left his personal collection of rare books and manuscripts and the bulk of his estate to the Philip H. and A. S. W. Rosenbach Foundation.

TULLIO SERAFIN, one of the major figures in the operatic world, is coming to New York next fall to conduct the New York City Opera Company at the City Center. It is expected that he will open the season on Sept. 18 with Puccini's "Tosca."

Intelligent and equitable rate adjustments based on the best interests of both the consuming publice and private investors, are essential in order to maintain the high standards of service that are provided by the nation's $33,000,000,000 electric power and gas utility industry.

HAMILTON, N. Y., July 26 -- Hume Wrong, Canadian Ambassador to the United States, charged tonight that this country's restrictive tariff policies were hindering the collective economic strength of the free world upon which the principal hope for global peace depended.

Arturo Toscanini yesterday resumed command of the N. B. C. Symphony for a two-week summer stint. His broadcast program, which emanated from Carnegie Hall, was announced as a light one. But "light" in this case is relative. Any program that contains Wagner's "Siegfried Idyll" automatically has a certain amount of sinew in it.

TORONTO, July 26 -- After the Chinese political question had virtually disrupted the first plenary session of the International Red Cross conference here today and necessitated a special session on Monday to resolve it, the expected Communist Chinese allegation of germ warfare materialized in a report by the Chinese Red Cross Society to the conference.

When the summer sun is at its hottest it is, paradoxically, the time for considering winter furs -- the time when new styles are decreed. This season sees them emerging in several exciting interpretations. They follow the trend for the slightly lifted waist, the back that is full and belted, the hip that rounds ever so slightly.

SECOND-GUESSING on the long-range implications of television's coverage of the Republican and Democratic National Conventions undoubtedly will prove a popular pastime for a long time to come. With two such inherently volatile and unpredictable topics for debate as video and politics there is bound to be an almost unlimited number of opinions on what their future relationship will be.

IN a preface to the volcanic outburst of his "Generation of Vipers," Philip Wylie made passing reference to the fact that, during most of his literary career, he had "written largely for entertainment." He added that this was merely "a euphemism for saying I have written for money."

BERLIN, July 26 -- The Soviet command in East Germany sent two protests to the Western Alies last Thursday, it was announced tonight. One charged that United States and French planes on July 15 strayed from the air corridors leading to Berlin.

The railroads are expected to have difficulty meeting the pent-up demand for freight haulage now that the steel strike has ended and the transporation industry and others dependent upon it for supplies return to the high rate of operations which preceded the strike.

PHILADELPHIA, July 26 (UP) -- Robin Roberts today became the first National League pitcher to win fifteen games this season as he hurled the Phillies to a 7-2 victory over the Cubs before 4,312 fans at Shibe Park.

The nomination of General Eisenhower should relieve the Republican party of its position as the "scrub team" of the Democrats and put it back into the running as a serious contender in the framework of a revitalized two-party system. Specifically, it should soften the solidity of the "Solid South," making the Republican party a national party in fact as well as in aspiration.

It is heartening to read in THE NEW YORK TIMES continued objective reporting and writing about the Philippine Republic. The latest manifestation is your editorial concerning the difficulties of the Quirino Administration in obtaining ratification of the Japanese peace treaty.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 26 -- Clarke Scholes of the United States churned out a new Olympic swimming record today in the 100-meter free-style semi-finals.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Since any little wind or rain storm can damage plants, staking of many annuals is in order. Scabiosa and sometimes even snapdragon need individual props. Forked sticks hold heavy double-flowered petunias above dust and mud. Stakes at either end of a row anchor string to keep cosmos upright. Marigolds may need support.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 26 -- Bob Mathias paced an American sweep of the gruelling Olympic decathlon event tonight, shattering his own world record and raising to thirteen the number of gold medals taken by the United States in these games.

THE aim of "Education and American Civilization," according to its author, George S. Counts, is "to develop a conception of American education which will support the values of free society in the present troubled age."

SLIGHTLY embarrassed engineers cheerfully acknowledged last week that traffic on the New Jersey Turnpike, which was opened to the public throughout its entire length only six months ago, on Jan. 15, was 80 per cent ahead of the pre-opening estimates and that revenues were 67 per cent higher than originally predicted.
PITTSBURGH, July 26 -- Rank-and-file workers of the Pennsylvania Railroad launched a move today to send the union shop the way of the closed shop -- into oblivion.

TOKYO, July 26 -- The negotiations for an armistice in Korea dragged on this week in the steaming tent beside the road at Pannunjom, and, at least for the moment, the sickening impression grew that after more than a year of talks no one was going anywhere in the direction of an immediate truce.

With instructions "not to wear stiff-brimmed campaign hats rolled up in Paul Revere or cowboy fashion" -- at least not until they reach the wild and woolly Southwest -- thirty-four Explorer Scouts from the five boroughs and four adult leaders will leave the city by bus early tomorrow morning for a month of hiking and camping at the 130,000-acre Philmont Boy Scout Ranch near Cimarron, N. M.

CHICAGO, July 26 -- Weary, disappointed and a mite disheveled, the unsuccessful contestants for the Democratic party's Presidential nomination left here today, each still holding his political chin high and predicting victory for the party's ticket in November.

Ambitious, ruthless, untiring, clever and strikingly beautiful, Maria Eva Duarte de Peron had in large measure many of the qualities needed to lift her in a dozen short years from obscurity to fame, wealth and power on the unpredictable currents of Argentine political life.

BECAUSE iron was so costly in the pioneer era, the first wooden rails of the Walla Walla and Columbia River Railroad were covered with rawhide, to which the faint smell of flesh still clung. Came a winter of famine with no game.

THE TIMES of July 12 reports that the rabbit population of Australia has been reduced by "some tens of millions" by the introduction of the virus of myxomatosis. Prior to the field experiment three members of the team, including the director of the investigation, "infected themselves to make sure the virus was harmless to human beings. It was."

NO great shakes as an athlete, Larry Scott, 10, tenacious and chunky, proves he's a leader when Old Man Smithers moves secretly to abolish Elmburst's popular Annual Field Day. Larry prods his friends to meet this threat and he finally wins out.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 26 -- Flashing a return to the form that had made him one of the top 3-year-old pacers of 1951, the Hanover Shoe Farm's Solicitor from Hanover, Pa., with Johnny Simpson driving, scored a smart victory in the Mattituck Junior Free-for-All Pace for $4,500 at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 26 (AP) -- The United States Olympic water polo team, composed mainly of El Segundo, Calif., players, remained in the tournament today with a 6-to-3 triumph over Rumania in a second-elimination game for teams beaten in the first round yesterday.

TOKYO, Sunday, July 27 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,323, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Sunday, Korea time:

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 26 -- Having transferred the future leadership role of the Democratic party to Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, early this morning, President, Truman retraced today to his native Missouri for a quiet sojourn. He hailed the Stevenson-Sparkman team as 'a winning ticket."

PORT DALHOUSIE, Ont., July 26 (Canadian Press) -- Joe Angyal of the New York Athletic Club won the championship singles and the Canadian sculling championship this afternoon, driving across the finish line ahead of Gabby Beaudry of the Lachine Rowing Club and Bob Platt of the Toronto Dons, in that order.

A plea to the churches of the country to protest the "political exploitation of religion" as evidenced in the recent political conventions was voiced in a lead editorial in the current issue of The Christian Century, nondenominational Protestant weekly published in Chicago.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 26 -- Thousands of cheering Finns crowded the dock here and lined the streets to welcome the Duke of Edinburgh, who sailed in today for the Olympic Games.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 26 -- America served up a mixed grill in the Olympic basketball arena today and the result was a tasty victory that sent the United States squad into the semi-finals of the sixteen-team tournament.

TWO recording firsts have just been scored by Vox Records, it is reported by George Mendelssohn, president of the company, in a letter from Paris. They are a full-length recording of Gluck's "Iphigenia in Tauris," made at the Aix-en-Provence Musical Festival, with the American soprano Patricia Neway in the title role; and the Rubinstein D Minor Piano Concerto, with Friedrich Wuehrer, pianist, and the Vienna State Philharmonic Orchestra conducted by Rudolf Moralt.

PARIS is never stingy with the pleasures it has to offer, and this year's visitors who have art uppermost in their minds should have few complaints. Exhibitions spring up all over the place, and, among these, there are a number of major events headed, perhaps, by "L'Oeuvre du Vingtieme Siecle," which was at the Museum of Modern Art and is now at the Tate Gallery in London.

My ROOFTOP terrace in the middle of Manhattan has a southern exposure. This means it is wide open to burning sun from late morning until early evening, when Old Sol finally sets behind a tall apartment building in the west.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 26 (AP) -- The schedule of events tomorrow in the Olympic Games (Time is local, followed by New York time) :

The Selective Service System reported recently that 57 per cent of the 54,755 college students who took its last two college-qualification tests made passing grades of 70 or better. These were the sixth and seventh tests given. In the first through the fifth, larger percentages -- in the 60's -- passed.

NEWS PICTURES OF THE YEAR 1952" (Chicago: Louis Mariano, Publisher. $1) is the second issue of this annual report on the News Pictures of the Year Competition jointly sponsored by Encyclopaedia Britannica Book of the Year and the University of Missouri School of Journalism.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 26 (AP) -- The Southeastern Conference executive committee reported tonight it was unable to reach a decision in the sports over-emphasis case against the University of Kentuccky.
SIOUX CITY, Iowa, July 26 (UP) -- Jimmy Clark of Laguna Beach, Calif., battered par for the third straight round today to retain his lead in the $15,000 Sioux City open by three strokes.

WOODBRIDGE, N. J., July 26 -- Applications are being prepared for steel and critical-materials priorities to build a $4,500,000 sewage disposal plant for this township, Louis P. Booz, consulting township engineer for the project, announced today.
TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., July 26 -- A 4-year-old golden retriever, Ch. Lorelei's Golden Rockbottom, went to best in show today in the thirtieth annual event of the Tuxedo Kennel Club.
CHICAGO, July 26 (AP) -- Democratic leaders made it clear today they believed they had blocked Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower off from the South by their choice of the Stevenson-Sparkman ticket.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -The forced abdication of King Farouk after a week of crisis in Egypt was interpreted here today as the consequence both of the King's laxness in observing the proprieties and responsibilities of his office and of a drive for power that overshot its objectives.

VANCOUVER, B. C. -- Like Banff National Park, its neighbor, Jasper National Park is confident of having one of its best summers in spite of the fire that damaged the Jasper Lodge less than a fortnight ago.

The recent installation of a new type harbor radar device aboard the Jersey Central Lines' ferryboat Elizabeth was the first of seven Radiomarine radar sets that will be put into use on that railroad's ferry fleet, Thomas P. Wynkoop, president of the Radiomarine Corporation of America, said yesterday.

MOSCOW, July 26 (AP) -- The United States Ambassador, George F. Kennan, has declined an invitation to attend tomorrow's Soviet Aviation Day celebration because of his objections to a poster appearing on Moscow's streets in connection with the event, the Embassy disclosed today.

AFTER a decade or two of ranging the world for his uniquely amusing stories, Eric Linklater has turned to his native Scotland for as entrancing and hilarious a yarn as he has ever written. With his usual lightly handled erudition, he sets out to demonstrate convincingly that the primal emotions are the most unalterable and that they change least in remote places where "the silver cord of tradition" is unbroken.

Lester Markel's "More Than Hands Across the Sea" (June 29) poses the question: "Isn't America depending on the past to bluff her way through the present?" Only a few years ago Britain was in the uncomfortable position in which America finds herself today in the eyes of the world.
BONN, Germany, July 26 -- Late next week Walter J. Donnelly will take over one of the most difficult, responsible and fluid jobs that the United States can give to any of its servants.

CONVENTION BUILDING in Chicago, July 26 -- The thirty-first Democratic National Convention nominated Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama today for Vice President on the ticket headed by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, and wound up its long, weary meeting in general party harmony.
CHICAGO, July 26 (AP) -- Jonathan Daniels, Democratic National Committeeman from North Carolina, urged Governor Stevenson today to open his Presidential campaign in the South.

Warm weather held sales down in New York and Brooklyn department stores in the week, with volume staying well below the 1951 figures. The easing of the weather came too late to help volume, and trade observers estimated that the decline from 1951 was about 11 per cent.

One of the most unwieldy, if not the most difficult, tows ever seen in the Hudson River will get under way at 12:45 P. M. Tuesday when the Moran Towing and Transportation Company begins the task of moving the first of three great caissons from Grassy Point to West Fifteenth Street, Manhattan.

TAMPA, Fla., July 26 -- Herman Steiner of Los Angeles said today that he would not go to Helsinki, Finland, as a member of the United States squad chosen to play in the international team tournament. Steiner made his announcement at the conclusion of the United States open championship in which he bowed to Larry Evans, who successfully defended his title, in the final round.

MONTREAL, July 26 (UP) -- The Canadian Broadcasting Corporation made its television debut last night with a telecast of an International League baseball game between the Montreal Royals and the Springfield Cubs.

Fall bookings in the men's clothing industry have been extremely good this year, manufacturers reported last week, and most producers are running considerably ahead of 1951. Most companies have completed three-quarters of their fall season.

Measures designed to protect young boxers from mutilation and to promote the exchange of medical information on the effects of athletics were discused yesterday at the closing session of a two-day medical symposium at the Astor Hotel under the sponsorship of the State Athletic Commission.

LOS ANGELES -- The motorist driving through Solvang, Calif., next week-end may well wonder whether he has suddenly been transplanted from the Pacific Coast to a village in Denmark. In effect he will have been, for from Friday through Sunday the people of this unique Danish settlement will dress in the costumes of the old land for their annual festival, Danish Days.

EIGHT centuries ago, the Counts of Toulouse fathered the Albigensian Heresy and suffered a bloody punishment which taught them a lesson in orthodoxy not forgotten until Henri, the only son of the Count of Toulouse-Lautrec, was born at the Chateau of Albi in 1864.
On the cover of THE TIMES Magazine for July 13 occurs the phrase "* * * Roosevelt dictating his 'day of infamy' speech a few hours after Pearl Harbor. * * *"
WASHINGTON, July 26 (UP) -- No matter which party wins there is a good chance the November election will bring more new faces into Congress than at any time since 1932.

The day dawned pleasantly yesterday, the kind of a day when a man likes to look around and see how the good world is going. Three times a team of detectives from the Brooklyn burglary squad looked around. As a result, four men wound up under arrest.

In effect he will have been, for from Friday through Sunday the people of this unique Danish settlement will dress in the costumes of the old land for their annual festival, Danish Days.
