WASHINGTON, July 26 (UP) -- No matter which party wins there is a good chance the November election will bring more new faces into Congress than at any time since 1932.

The day dawned pleasantly yesterday, the kind of a day when a man likes to look around and see how the good world is going. Three times a team of detectives from the Brooklyn burglary squad looked around. As a result, four men wound up under arrest.

ALONG and growing shadow is being cast on all Government workers these days as a result of public readiness to draw sweeping conclusions from isolated cases. When one Government wrongdoer turns up, people have a tendency to say, "See? That proves Washington is corrupt."

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- In the next couple of weeks strategy boards for both the Republican and Democratic Presidential candidates will be engaging in some concentrated skull practice to map out the plays in their respective campaigns, which will get under way on or about Labor Day.
CHICAGO, July 26 (AP) -- Jonathan Daniels, Democratic National Committeeman from North Carolina, urged Governor Stevenson today to open his Presidential campaign in the South.

Warm weather held sales down in New York and Brooklyn department stores in the week, with volume staying well below the 1951 figures. The easing of the weather came too late to help volume, and trade observers estimated that the decline from 1951 was about 11 per cent.

One of the most unwieldy, if not the most difficult, tows ever seen in the Hudson River will get under way at 12:45 P. M. Tuesday when the Moran Towing and Transportation Company begins the task of moving the first of three great caissons from Grassy Point to West Fifteenth Street, Manhattan.

MOSCOW, July 27 -- The annual Soviet air show was presented today in the presence of Premier Stalin, members of the Politburo and several hundred thousand spectators, including foreign military attaches and other diplomats. Nearly 500 military and civilian aircraft took part in the program.

Take-off procedures on two runways at La Guardia Airport and New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, will be changed today in the hope of bringing "substantial relief" from aircraft noise to six Long Island communities.

Every pedestrian has at one time or another had the experience of bypassing cars standing in crosswalks to get to the other side of the street. Sometimes the cars are standing still, but at other times they are moving forward slowly to gain the edge on other cars at the light change.

The departmental trial of thirty-four suspended policemen accused of accepting bookmaking graft from Harry Gross will be resumed as 10 o'clock this morning in the Criminal Courts Building, 100 Centre Street.

CLEVELAND, July 27 (UP) -- The Indians vaulted from fourth into second place in the American League race today. They swept a double-header from the Senators, 3 -- 1 and 3 -- 2, before a crowd of 31,494.

OLD WESTBURY, L. I., July 27 -- Philip Iglehart, absent from the game for fifteen years prior to this season, stroked eight goals in leading Meadow Brook to a 17-4 polo victory over the Bostwick Field team at Bostwick Field today. Philip, a five-goaler, is a brother of Stewart Iglehart, ten-goal ace, now passing up polo play.

In reporting sales of $468,864,838, highest in the history of General Mills, Inc., but reduced earnings of $9,549,466 for the fiscal year ended on May 31, Harry A. Bullis, chairman, and Charles H. Bell, president, announced negotiations for a $15,000,000 long-term loan to finance product development and expansion of facilities.

PARIS, July 27 -- Premier Antoine Pinay's announcement last week that the 3.5 per cent bond issue had brought 195,000,000,000 francs ($557,000,000) of new money into the treasury was coupled with the following statement:

WASHINGTON, July 27 (UP) -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation announced today it will spend $6,500,000 during the next eleven months on a synthetic rubber research program, with emphasis on producing rubber for large-sized tires and "assisting national defense."

ATLANTIC CITY, July 27 -- The police are seeking a man for questioning in the murder of an attractive 24-year-old Pennsylvania ste nographer whose body, beaten about the head and face, was found yesterday in a field near the Atlantic City Race Track, fourteen miles from here.
The Rev. Dr. E. Stanley Jones, evangelist and missionary, summarized his philosophy in a guest sermon yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- It took 28,000,000 words to express everything that the Eightysecond Congress wanted said before it adjourned early this month.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 27 -- Emil Zatopek stood as the wonder runner of the ages today as the track and field competition of the Olympic Games came to a close with the United States supreme by an overwhelming margin after eight days of record-breaking performances such as the world has never beheld before.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- The Defense Department Saturday identified 125 battle casualties in a new Korean war list (No. 613). It reported ten killed, 103 wounded, one missing and eleven injured. The following were from New York and Connecticut:
CHICAGO, July 27 -- News stories sent over the Western Union wires from the Democratic National Convention last week totaled 8,403,392 words.

PARIS, July 27 -- In the intense negotiations between the French and United States Governments over the highly controversial question of offshore purchases for defense, the new element is a desire by the French to produce equipment not only for their own or for other European forces but for United States forces also.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 27 -- About 6,000 sailors at ports from Seattle to Los Angeles will meet at 1 P. M. tomorrow to vote on an agreement reached near midnight last night to end the protracted West Coast maritime strike. The walkout, which began May 23, reached its sixty-second day today.

CHICAGO, July 27 -- Drastic streamlining of future Democratic national conventions appeared likely today in the wake of loud and long complaints that some "crackpot" delegates, long-winded speakers and outmoded rules made the Democrats look bad on television and slowed up convention deliberations.
ST. LOUIS, July 27 (AP) -- The Red Sox snapped their four-game losing streak today with a 9-3 decision over the Browns in the finale of a double-header after dropping the opener, 8 to 1.

The importance to mental health of family unity, a sharing of experiences by parents and children is the theme of "Roots of Happiness," a twenty-five-minute film made in Puerto Rico and now available to parent and community groups in this area.

LONDON, July 27 -- It would appear at first sight that the absence of any noticeable reaction in the stock markets here to current events in the Middle East last week indicates indifference to developments in that troubled part of the world.
DETROIT, July 27 -- The Yankees dropped the first game of a doubleheader today and with this startling achievement set a record toward which Casey Stengel is not likely to point with pride.
IOWA CITY, Iowa, July 27 (AP) -- An astronomer at the State University of Iowa reported today that a spark-shooting object seen in the sky by southeast Iowans "most likely was the planet Jupiter."

WASSENAAR, the Netherlands, July 27 -- Iran's new Foreign Minister, Hussein Navab, declared in an interview tonight that he was willing to meet Britain in the International Court of Justice to test her case against oil nationalization.

AMSTERDAM, July 27 -- Last week's topic was the further substantial rise of Dutch foreign exchange and gold reserves by 93,000,000 to 2,932,000,000 guilders, including a rise of gold stocks by 22,000,000 guilders to 1,324,000,000, while note circulation decreased 15,000,000 to 2,882,000,000.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The nation's privately owned ocean-going tanker fleet decreased in size by a net of six vessels from January to July but remains the world's largest under a single flag, the National Federation of American Shipping reported today.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 27 (AP) Officials of the United States Olympic team decided today no attempt would be made to reciprocate the hospitality extended by the Russian team last night.

European unification took a long stride forward when the Foreign Ministers of six Continental nations agreed on the first concrete measures to put the Schuman Plan for a European Coal and Steel Community into immediate operation. The most important achievements of the Ministers are the creation of the actual machinery for the administration of the Schuman Plan and the decision to start operations under it on Aug. 10.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., July 27 -- Cornelius (Corny) Shields scored his second victory of the Long Island Sound Yacht Racing Association season today in the regatta sponsored by the yachting department of the New York Athletic Club.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (UP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Administration announced today that New York State would spend $1,300,000 and New Jersey $400,000 for airport improvement projects in the 1953 fiscal year that began July 1.

The Political Party Platform belongs, it seems obvious, in that category of American institutions of which it has been said that institutional status was achieved by the simple and negative process of remaining alive and avoiding innovation.

The television receiver industry has settled down to production in line with normal demand and the "wild" output following the Korean war will not be repeated, Arthur L. Chapman, vice president in charge of the radio and television division of Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., asserted yesterday.

LONDON, Monday, July 28 (Reuters) -- Two of Britain's biggest trade unions will plead for more trade between Britain and Communist countries when the 8,000,000-strong Trades Union Congress holds its annual meeting in September.

Institutions of what we hopefully call higher learning have been adding the subject of public relations to their curricula. Students who have never worked as newspaper men or magazine writers are being turned out on the world with a knowledge of the subject that probably compares pretty favorably with this reviewer's recollections of the rule of the Hyksos Kings and the equatorial armillary sphere of Tycho Brahe.

CINCINNATI, July 27 -- A record field of twenty-nine contract bridge teams started play this afternoon in a two-session nonmasters-team-of-four championship, first scheduled event in the present summer session of the twentysixth annual National Contract Bridge Championships.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- The Defense Production Administration approved a major new West Coast steel expansion today -- an $81,250,000 project of Yolo Steel and Metal Company, Sacramento, Calif. The certification entitles the Yolo Company, to write-off in five years, in depreciation for Federal tax purposes 55 per cent of the anticipated outlay.

BUTLER, Pa., July 27 -- Two Air National Guard fighter planes collided at 14,000 feet over near-by West Sunbury today but both pilots escaped unhurt. One pilot bailed out and the other rode his crippled plane to a belly-landing in a field.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 27 -- The United States-born wife of a Rome banker was dragged to her death from her seat beside her husband today when the door behind her opened and allowed the air to rush out of the pressurized plane in which they were flying at 12,000 feet near here.

TORONTO, July 27 -- Former leaders of Eastern European Red Cross societies pressed their fight tonight to have the political character of the present Red Cross groups in the Iron Curtain countries denounced at the international conference of the humanitarian organization here.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- Arthur E. Summerfield, Republican National Chairman, said today President Truman "hand-picked" the Democratic national ticket but that the American people would not be fooled by it.

BOSTON, July 27 (AP) -- Darkness halted the second game of a double-header between the Pirates and the Braves at the end of eleven innings with the score tied 3 -- 3 today. Vern Bickford, Braves right-hander, won his fifth straight game, 5 -- 2, in the opener although he gave way to Lew Burdette in the eighth.

The Right Rev. John T. Dallas, retired Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New Hampshire, said yesterday that it "takes money made by the labor of our hands, our sweat, our blood and our tears" to maintain the United States.

Citation for meritorious service were awarded yesterday to 175 members of the Police Department. Two patrolmen were cited for exceptional merit, forty-one received commendations, seventy earned meritorious police duty and sixty-two excellent police duty.
SEOUL, Korea, Monday, July 28 (AP) -- Torrential rains drenched the Korean battle front for the third straight day today, bringing ground and air fighting to a virtual halt.
Brazil is about to set in motion an ambitious and drastic effort to raise development capital internally.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- The United Steelworkers, C. I. O., threatened tonight to strike nine plants of the Aluminum Company of America (Alcoa) Tuesday evening, a management announcement said.
CANTERBURY, England, July 27 (AP) -- Dr. Hewlett Johnson, "Red Dean" of Canterbury, was involved in two incidents today.

BUDD LAKE, N. J., July 27 (AP) -- A young mother, trying desperately to release her parachute, fell 2,500 feet to her death today trying to become a member of a parachuting-for-fun club organized by her husband, a former paratrooper.
TEHERAN, Iran, July 27 -- Iran's armed forces will undergo a fundamental reorganization now that Premier Mohammed Mossadegh is also Minister of War, National Front sources said today.

Now that the nominations have been made and the 1952 Presidential race has officially begun, the American Heritage Foundation is putting pressure on the public to set a record at the polls in November. The goal is 65,000,000 voters. Last week hundreds of telegrams, letters and campaign kits telling why voters should vote were sent to 120 advertising clubs throughout the country.
CHICAGO, July 27 (AP) -- Bobby Shantz hurled his eighteenth victory today as the Athletics swept a doubleheader with the White Sox, 3 -- 1, 9 -- 3.

The Radio Corporation of America and its subsidiaries established a new high record for sales of products and services with its six months' volume totaling $305,837,825, exceeding the previous peak of $302,332,933 by $3,505,000, Frank M. Folsom, president, reported in the mid-year statement to be mailed to stockholders today.
Six good jackets for early fall-into-winter wear are offered today by Patterns of The Times. Each embodies significant style notes drawn from a round-up of reports on fall and winter trends.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 27 (AP) -- Clarke Scholes of Highland Park, Mich., captured the first gold medal awarded in the Olympic swimming meet today by winning the 100-meter free-style race.

Joseph J. Brock, the 44-year-old agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who was shot fatally on Saturday in the capture of Gerhard A. Puff, Kansas bank robber, was struck by five bullets from Puff's automatic pistol, an autopsy disclosed yesterday.

Nothing is lacking in America for a good Turkish meal except the time to prepare it. Mrs. Nuri Eren, young wife of the director of the Turkish Information Office, has been in New York long enough to find that commodity much scarcer than the olive oil, lemons, eggplant, rice, lamb, mint, dill and yogurt that go to make up her native cooking.

The demand for men's summer-weight suits, particularly those of blends of wool and man-made fabrics, will increase next spring, according to a survey by the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the United States of America. Gabardine suits will fall off in popularity and regular-weight suits will ease slightly, according to the survey of 439 retailers throughout the country prepared by the research council of the men's and boys' clothing industry.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 27 (AP) -- Norwegian yachts led the United States' boats tonight in the two big events of the Olympic sailing tournament that ends tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- Georgetown Hospital reported shortly before midnight that Senator Brien McMahon, Democrat of Connecticut, was in "very, very critical" condition. His family was keeping vigil. Previously, his condition had been listed as critical.

HAMILTON, N. Y., July 27 -The Rev Edmund A. Walsh, regent of Georgetown University's School of Foreign Service, charged today that George F. Kennan, United States Ambassador to Russia, had publicly advocated a "dangerous" philosophy of freeing nations from moral responsibility for their actions.
DETROIT, July 27 (AP) -- Controls on materials and output volume have hampered the auto industry's operations to no small degree, but planning for the future is going ahead unrestricted.

QUANTICO, Va., July 27 -- Pvt. Adlai E. Stevenson 3d said yesterday that the nomination of his father as Democratic Presidential candidate surprised him. Referring to his father, he added that "it probably surprised him, too."
LENOX, Mass., July 27 -- The Boston Symphony Orchestra's first Sunday afternoon concert of the Berkshire Festival was devoted principally to works of long proved popularity.

Too late to do the Giants any good in the first game, but in time to save them from further embarrassment, it rained yesterday at the Polo Grounds and Leo Durocher's club, despite an 11-4 setback by the Reds, lost no ground to the Dodgers.

An 18-year-old girl was pulled to her death at 3 P. M. yesterday while trying to save the life of a 17-year-old boy who had fallen through a skylight window on the roof of the Marie Antoinette Hotel at Broadway and Sixty-sixth Street.

TUCSON, Ariz., July 27 -- Southern Arizona is jubilant at the news of a vast new addition to its copper mining industry. The San Manuel Copper Company has announced that it will invest $101,000,000 in what will be the largest underground copper mine in North America, forty-six miles from Tucson.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 27 -- John Wayne has been signed by Warner Brothers to star in "Alma Mater," a college football story. The actor, who played the game at the University of Southern California, before entering pictures, will appear as a coach.

Directors of the General Foods Corporation have elected as vice-presidents G. O. Bailey, R. M. Schmitz and Wayne Marks, it was announced over the week-end. They will be on the staff of Charles G. Mortimer Jr., executive vice president and chief operating officer of the corporation.

From the head of the Great Lakes to the foot of the Rockies extends the great Canadian "wheatbasket" -- the prairie provinces of Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Alberta; flat as a billiard table and just as green during the growing season.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., July 27 -- The question of civil rights and the elimination of a restrictive white-membership clause highlighted the annual convention of the New York State Knights of Pythias, which opened here tonight with a reception.
MARGATE CITY, N. J., July 27 (AP) -- Claiborne Coupland, 17-year-old Norfolk, Va., high school student, today won the international moth boat championship for the second time.

Domestic cotton market prices fluctuated within a relatively narrow trading range last week, with slightly more losses than gains. At the close of trading on Friday active futures contracts were up twenty-eight to thirty-five points from the previous week.

Severed is the Damo and Pythias collaboration of Elia Kazan, a topnotch Broadway-Hollywood director, and Arthur Miller, an outstanding, playwright. Consequently, Mr. Kazan will not supervise Mr. Miller's next play (untitled at the moment), which is to be produced in the fall by Kermit Bloomgarden, co-sponsor of the author's memorable "Death of a Salesman."
WASHINGTON, July 27 (UP) -- Civilian mobilizers have asked the military whether plane production could be speeded by streamlining procurement and production technique.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 27 (AP) -- The proposed increase in United States import duty on Swiss watches has raised a storm of protest in Switzerland in which all political parties, nearly the entire press, the labor unions, the watch manufacturers and the Government itself have joined.

SHELTER ISLAND, L. I., July 27 -- Virtually the entire population of this "green isle in the sea," a small fishing, farming and resort town ninety-seven miles east of New York, began yesterday a week's celebration of the 300th anniversary of the first white settlement here.

The free world will greet the forced abdication of King Farouk in Egypt with a certain mixture of feelings. All those who subscribe profoundly to democratic government by consent are hostile to military coups as such. The use of tanks and machine guns to force a change in regime is in itself evidence that the proper processes of government have failed.
Teachers College. Columbia University, received gifts, grants and bequests totaling $1,111,167 for the academic year ending June 30 -- the largest total since 1936.

She wanted to be known only as Eva Peron and not by the more formal and correct Eva Duarte de Peron. But to the world she was simply Evita. The romancers of the future will call her that, for she was a figure of romance. To historians she will unquestionably be the most remarkable woman in Latin-American chronicles -- at least until our time.

BONN, Germany, July 27 -- The Soviet satellite states in Eastern Europe appear to be well into the period in which increased industrial production, including armaments programs, is being emphasized to the point where it has replaced the Communist indoctrination of the peoples as the prime objective of the Kremlin's policy.

NEW DELHI, India, July 27 -India and the United States, working together, "can give the world its first real assurance of peace," Ambassador Chester Bowles declared in a signed article published prominently today in a special "United States number" of the Bombay Free Press Journal.

SALEM, Mass., July 27 -- Four persons were dead and three were listed as missing tonight after a sudden squall that struck Salem harbor with hurricane force this morning and swamped more than 100 small craft before roaring out to sea.
CHICAGO, July 27 -- Trading on the Chicago Board of Trade showed a moderate improvement last week as compared with a week before, and was materially better than a year ago.

HONG KONG, July 27 -- Three out of six provincial Governors and four Mayors in Manchuria have been removed in a shake-up that appears to represent a general tightening of discipline and stronger direct control by the Communist party over local administration in Red China's strategic northeast provinces.

CHICAGO, July 27 (AP) -- Following is the Democratic National Committee, announced last night by Frank E. McKinney, National Chairman, after conferring with Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, Presidential nominee:
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -The United States has protested strongly to the Soviet Union against Soviet posters picturing Russian planes chasing United States aircraft.
It was a quiet and uneventful week in the foreign exchanges. British sterling and the Canadian dollar moved narrowly on light dealings.

RICHMOND, Va., July 27 (AP) -- Gov. John S. Battle, who led Virginia's successful fight against signing a "loyalty pledge" at the Democratic National Convention, received a rousing welcome today as he returned to the state capital.

PARIS, July 27 -- The selection of Governor Stevenson by the Democrats to oppose General Eisenhower for the Presidency was greeted this morning by French editorialists as guarantee that the United States foreign policy and its vital European manifestations would be removed from the partisan political arena.

Religion is "the very center of human life, not merely penicillin to be used when fever runs high," Bishop Paul B. Kern of the Nashville, Tenn., Area of the Methodist Church declared yesterday at the Marble Collegiate Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.

Persons who suffer injustices in this life and accept them without rancor or grumbling because they identify them with Christ's sufferings and elect to suffer with Him, should look forward to the Day of Judgment with confidence and trust that "the just Judge will straighten the injustices that shaped your cross," the Rev. Charles J. McManus declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The Appropriations committee of the House of Representatives has undertaken reluctantly a long-sought overhaul of its budget-cutting machinery that, if successful, may lead to significant reductions in the cost of Government without continued resort to meat-axe techniques.
ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., July 27 (UP) -- The next stage in rocket development may send men aloft into the dead, airless space of the upper atmosphere, thirty - five scientists reported today.

A thirteen-week radio study of the life, times, principles and philosophy of Thomas Jefferson, third President of the United States, has been produced and recorded under a $300,000 grant from the Fund for Adult Education established by the Ford Foundation and soon will be heard by the public.

Charges by the Communist-backed Women's International Democratic Federation that the United Nations forces in Korea were engaging in germ warfare were denounced by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and two other prominent American women in a letter sent to women's organizations throughout the world.

Television viewers who can't wait for the start of the political conventions of 1956 will be glad to hear that they have a new way of keeping in trim during the next four years. Thanks to WOR-TV, they can stay up all night indefinitely.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Roger L. Putnam, the Economic Stabilization Administrator, disclosed tonight that President Truman would back him in an effort to "isolate" the $5.20-a-ton price increase granted on Thursday to settle the steel strike.

Summer students enrolled in the city's four municipal colleges this year total 13,875, the Board of Higher Education announced yesterday. Registration at City College totals 6,176; at Hunter College, 2,341; at Brooklyn College, 4,054, and at Queens College, 1,304.

A sudden thunderstorm soon after 6 P. M. yesterday cut city temperatures from 84 degrees to 70 degrees in less than an hour, but the relief will be only temporary. A Weather Bureau meterologist forecast that today's heat would be well up in the 80's with the humidity as high as yesterday's before the storm.

PHILADELPHIA, July 27 (UP) -- The surging Phillies celebrated the completion of their first month under Manager Steve O'Neill today by defeating the Cubs, 12 -- 8 and 3 -- 0. The Phils replaced Chicago in fourth place.

CHICAGO, July 27 -- Price improvement in grain futures was impressive last week inasmuch as the moderate recoveries were registered in the race of bearish statistics on wheat, and in spite of generally flattering crop prospects in corn and soybeans.
ZURICH, July 27 -- The midnight broadcast last Wednesday by France's Premier Pinay, announcing success for the French 3 1/2 per cent gold guaranteed state loan, has aroused widespread misgiving here.

KINGSTON, N. Y., July 27 -- For the first time since before World War II a Sunday passenger train rolled over the single-track Ulster and Delaware Railroad -- the old "Up and Down" -- today as the New York Central's birthday gift to the 300th anniversary celebration of the City of Kingston.

CHICAGO, July 27 -- The Democratic high command decided today on a "short, hard-hitting campaign" featuring the coordinated efforts of the new and old leaders of the party -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois; Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama, his running mate; President Truman and Vice President Alben W. Barkley.
LENINGRAD, July 27 -- The annual Soviet fur auction opens here tomorrow with more than sixty buyers from foreign countries in attendance.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 27 (UP) -- The first East-West friction of a remarkably peaceful Olympics flared today in an auditorium where the weight-lifting competition was in progress.

The continuance of existing charters on some thirty Government-owned vessels is the subject of a strong fight by American-flag tramp ship operators, who assert the use of the Government ships is forcing the lay-up of privately owned vessels.

ALBANY, July 27 -- The Public Service Commission, in its annual report, today, stated that the introduction of natural gas in New York City and other areas of the state had saved consumers $3,391,400 during 1951.

"The Heir of Douglas," a new work by Lillian de la Torre. will be published on Aug. 18 by Knopf. It is a compilation of fact and conjecture about the case of Archibald Douglas -- whether he was really the son of Lady Jane Douglas and Col. John Steuart and therefore the legal heir to the vast fortune of the Duke of Douglas.

Since hate and fear are psychological ailments, man is in sound mental health to the degree that he relates himself "affirmatively" to his fellow men, the Rev. Joseph D. Huntley, associate pastor of the Broadway Tabernacle Church (Congregational), Broadway and Fifty-sixth Street, said yesterday in his sermon.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The Air Force said today that jet fighter planes had made an effort to intercept unknown objects in the sky over Washington last night after the objects had been spotted by radar, but that no direct contact had been made.
CINCINNATI, July 27 (UP) -- The United States completed a 5-0 sweep over Japan today in the first round of Davis Cup elimination play by winning the final two singles matches.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 27 (AP) -- The United States carried off two more gold medals in the Olympic weightlifting competition tonight as Norbert Schemansky of Detroit and John Davis, the Brooklyn strong man, posted record performances.

People abroad did not enjoy the opportunity afforded to millions of Americans of "looking in" on the Chicago conventions through the eagle eye of television. But by means of the short-wave radio and the American Forces network in Germany, which is relayed to many European countries, many foreigners were able to get an earful of the unimaginable din and commotion -- human and mechanical -- that almost beat down the walls of the arena.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 27 -- The semi-official news agency Yugopress reported today that Yugoslavia would face a serious crisis unless this summer's drought was broken by rains within the next few days.

TOKYO, Monday, July 28 -- The Communists have indicated that they may seek changes in Item 5 of the draft agreement for an armistice in the Korean war. The article provides for an international conference on Korean affairs three months after a ceasefire starts.

BALTIMORE, July 27 (AP) -- Dick Savitt proved too strong for Straight Clark today as he scored a 9-7, 6-2, 6-3 victory over the 145-pounder from Pasadena, Calif., to take the Middle Atlantic grass courts tennis championship.
TOKYO, Monday, July 28 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,324, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Monday, Korea time:

Rocky Marciano, unbeaten heavyweight of Brockton, Mass., and Harry (Kid) Matthews, seasoned campaigner from Seattle, yesterday were reported ready and waiting for their ten-round bout tonight in the Yankee Stadium.
SALEM, Mass., July 27 -- The desire to catch "just one more fish" resulted in death for two of those caught offshore by today's sudden squall, according to Roland J. Chute, 46 years old, a survivor.

Opportunity pounded in vain at the Dodgers' door yesterday and at the end of three hours of a rhubarby contest they had dropped their third straight to the Cardinals, 4 -- 3, for their fifth loss in the last six games.
UNIONTOWN, Pa., July 27 (AP) -- A heavily loaded truck ran wild down near-by Summit Mountain and crashed into a carload of picnickers today killing six persons.

WHEN I drove through a blizzard a year and a half ago to speak at the Lake Erie College for Women, in Painesville, Ohio, I did not realize that I was approaching the small and tranquil alma mater of one of the most coldly clever and glossily sophisticated of all our modern literary chroniclers of the New York scene.
The city is preparing a warm harbor welcome for the new 20,264-ton French Line passenger ship Flandre on Tuesday afternoon.
LAKE MOHAWK, N. J., July 27 -- A 5-year-old Afghan hound, Ch. Majara Mahabat, was adjudged best in show in the ninth annual exhibition of the Lake Mohawk Club today.
SIOUX CITY, Iowa, July 27 (AP) -- Al Besselink set a terrific stretch pace today to win the seventy-two hole Sioux City open golf tournament with a 22-under-par 266.

The United Nations international community in Queens, which has been threatened with rent increases up to 32 per cent, has appealed to President Truman and the Republican and Democratic Presidential candidates to prevent what it believes would be the disintegration of the model community.

PITTSBURGH, July 27 -- By the time full operations are attained in the steel industry, over the next two weeks, close to 19,000,000 tons of steel will have been lost due to the fifty-three-day strike. Up to yesterday steel loss was approximately 17,100,000 tons -- the biggest loss in steel-mill history as a result of a single strike.
IPOH, Malaya, July 27 -- Ipoh, capital of the big and rich state of Perak, has for the last four years been the center of one of the toughest fights against Communist insurrection in Malaya.

CAIRO, July 27 -- Gen. Mohammed Naguib Bey, leader of the military group that took control of Egypt last Wednesday, returned to Cairo by air from Alexandria today less than twenty-four hours after he had sent King Farouk into exile aboard the royal yacht Mahrussa.

BILOXI, Miss., July 27 (UP) -- An independent slate of electors pledged to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and affiliated with neither the Republican nor Democratic parties is expected to be offered for the Mississippi general election ballot.
It was with great interest that I read your recent news item which pointed out the accidents emanating from poor signposts. We would do well to use the practical type employed in France.

MADRID, July 27 -- The statecontrolled Spanish press today welcomed with undisguised pleasure the nomination of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois and Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama, as the Democratic party's Presidential and Vice Presidential candidates.

No lead toward solving the murder of Mrs. Russell Brown, 23-year-old expectant mother of Mineola, L. I., was believed to have been uncovered yesterday by police. The young woman was found strangled in Jamaica Estates, Queens, early Saturday, several hours after she had started on a shopping trip for maternity clothes.

According to a dispatch from Moscow which THE NEW YORK TIMES printed on July 16, the English-language magazine News of July 15 insisted that the possibilities for peaceful coexistence of the capitalist and socialist systems had increased rather than decreased since the end of the second World War.
SIOUX CITY, Iowa, July 27 (AP) -- Al Besselink set a terrific stretch pace today to win the seventy-two hole Sioux City open golf tournament with a 22-under-par 266.

BOSTON, July 27 -- Selection of Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama rather than Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee as the running mate for Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois on the Democratic Presidential ticket prompted today reassessment of the party's chances in New England.

The Australian complaint at the Red Cross meeting in Toronto that the United Nations Command in Korea has slowed down Red Cross aid by needless red tape should be listened to with appreciative attention. Things are getting better there, as Mortimer Cooke, coordinator for civilian relief in Korea, pointed out, but there is still room for much improvement.

DALLAS, Tex., July 27 (UP) -Conservative Democrats, led by Gov. Allan Shivers, swept yesterday's Texas primary of the party and observers said today that the results reduced the chances of General Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican Presidential nominee, to carry the state in November.
CHICAGO, July 27 (AP) -- A successor to Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson as the Democratic nominee for Governor of Illinois probably will be named in about a week.
Six new films, including importations from France and England, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

HELSINKI, Finland, July 27 -- A sharp controvery has arisen between the International Amateur Athletic Federation and the Nationalist China A. A. F. over the Nationalists' membership. The question will be discussed at a congress of international groups here tomorrow, with delegates of both the Nationalists and Peiping barred.

LONG BRANCH, N. J., July 27 -- In two slam-bang five-mile heats for the national championship of the Jersey speed skiff class in speed boating, Ray Morris of Red Bank emerged as the winner with a perfect tally of 800 points today.

MANILA, Monday, July 28 - President Elpidio Quirino returned yesterday from a ten-day state visit to the neighboring Republic of Indonesia, bringing with him a strong impression that he had helped dispel the mistrust of foreigners that seems to have characterized the East Indies Government and people since their separation from Dutch rule.

The American Society of Civil Engineers announced yesterday the winners of eight annual awards for technical papers. The awards will be presented Sept. 10 at the Centennial Day luncheon of the convocation of engineers in Chicago. The recipients follow:

Less than one-third of the 17,284 offenders constituting the average population of the penal institutions under the United States Bureau of Prisons in 1951 were confined in maximum security prisons. This means that two-thirds of them were serving their sentences in medium or minimum custody institutions.
NEW DELHI, July 27 -- Leading Indian newspapers today expressed satisfaction over the Democrats' nomination of Governor Stevenson.

FRASER, Colo., July 27 -- Senator Richard M. Nixon of California, Republican Vice Presidential nominee, visited Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Presidential nominee, today at the ranch where the General has been vacationing. They had midday dinner with friends and members of the General's personal campaign staff, and discussed campaign organization and strategy.

PARAMUS, N. J., July 27 -- Playing through rain and a thunderstorm that marred the last part of the final, 39-year-old Joe Marra of White Plains, N. Y., won the Metropolitan amateur golf championship at the Ridgewood Country Club today.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 27 (AP) -- The United States basketball team won its third straight game in Olympic competition tonight, easily breezing past Uruguay, 57 -- 44, and will meet Russia in the first game of the next round starting tomorrow.
LONDON, July 27 -- All reports reaching London today indicated that Gen. Mohammed Naguib Bey was maintaining order and according full protection to foreigners in Egypt.

LONDON, July 27 -- British newspaper comment on Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson's nomination for President by the Democrats was uniformly friendly to the Illinois Governor whose name was virtually unknown here before the party's convention in Chicago.

NEWBURGH, N. Y., July 27 -- Intensive simulated bombing raids by "aggressor" aircraft against military and industrial targets across the country today brought into action a large part of the Canadian and American air defense forces as part of the joint air maneuvers, "Exercise Signpost."

A lot of people are wondering where television is going, not electronically but economically. They are asking what effect it will have on radio, newspapers, books, movie theatres, moviemaking, sports attendance.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., July 28 -- Paul S. Drane of 3 Hampton Road, retired director of the library of The New York Sun and brother-in-law of the late Carr V. Van Anda, managing editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES from 1904 to 1932, died today at the White Plains hospital, where he had been a patient for two months.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., July 28 (UP) -- Five hundred Congress of Industrial Organizations and American Federation of Labor workers clashed with fists and knives today in front of the Allis-Chalmers jet engine plant and six men were injured.

CHICAGO, July 28 (AP) -- Will Harridge, American League President, today ruled that Bill Veeck, owner of the Browns, had erred in protesting the eligibility of Manager Lou Boudreau as a Red Sox player at St. Louis yesterday.

BATON ROUGE, La., July 28 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois will have to court the Louisiana Democrats if he wants their support in November, it was indicated here today through the generally noncommittal stand taken by Gov. Robert F. Kennon. Governor Kennon was leader fo the Louisiana delegation to the Democratic National Convention which refused to take the "loyalty oath."
R. R. Roberts has been named finance manager of the Carboloy department of the General Electric Company, manufacturer of specialized metals and cemented carbide tools for the metalworking industry.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -The Bureau of Mines reported today that crude oil production in May -- while a strike affected a third of the industry -- averaged 1,322,000 barrels a day less than during April. However, in May demand dropped by 1,576,000 barrels daily.

ROME, July 28 -- The neo-Fascist Italian Social Movement, whose large gains were the feature of the provincial and municipal elections in Southern Italy May 25, came out in favor of a planned economy and of a "revision" of Italy's defense commitments in its first public party congress, which came to an end in the city of L'Aquila this evening.

BERLIN, July 28 -- The Investigating Committee of Free Jurists, an anti-Communist organization in West Berlin, today announced that one of the two members of its staff who knew the names of groups of informants in East Germany had defected to the Communists.

ROME, July 28 -- The Giornale d'Italia, in a copyrighted story splashed across its front page today reported that an Italian scientist named Ubaldo Loschi had discovered the secret of the hydrogen bomb and that the first bomb of this kind had been exploded at an artillery proving ground in central Italy Saturday night.

Eisenhower cooks better than she. And just the other day came that report of a breakfast "Ike" prepared at his vacation ranch in Colorado at which one guest was said to have eaten eleven of his flapjacks.

A concentrated effort by all the appropriate agencies, public and private alike, has been called for by Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy to meet the problem of a steadily increasing number of disabled persons requiring assistance from the city.

CHICAGO, July 28 -- Wheat and corn futures reacted sharply today from early prices that had shown moderate gains. Failure of export business to develop was a bearish phase of the wheat situation, while predictions for cooler weather with showers over the corn belt caused pressure on the yellow cereal.

In his three previous appearances at the Lewisohn Stadium Eugene Istomin has been paired with another guest artist, but when the 26-year-old pianist played there last night he was the only soloist of the evening. His selection for solitary eminence is a token of how he has come up in the musical world.

Increased costs and some reduction in June sales as a result of the steel strike were largely responsible for the decline in the six months' net earnings of the Armco Steel Corporation to $14,565,386 from $20,644,703 earned in the first half of 1951.

Three thousand inmates at the Willowbrook State School for Mental Defectives, at Willowbrook, S. L. were evacuated from Seventeen fireproof brick buildings, shortly before 2 P. M. yesterday because of a small fire started inside the steam pipes connecting building No. 7 with the power house.

He sped along the wide open spaces of White Plains Plains Avenue, stopping at a store window filled with salami.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, July 28 -- Hussein Navab, Iranian Foreign Minister stated today he had been "misunderstood" in an interview with THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday that represented him as willing to test the oil nationalization dispute with Brtain before the International Court of Justice.

BONN, Germany, July 28 -- West Germany is prepared to ask for a greater share in the making of major strategic decisions governing the defense of Western Europe against Soviet aggression when rearmament begins in this country.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- The Air Force said tonight the current series of "flying saucer" reports had brought no change in its twenty-four-hour-a-day program to challenge any unidentified and potentially hostile object in the skies over the United States.
Thirty-four Explorer Scouts from the city's five boroughs hit the trail yesterday on a streamlined "covered wagon" to scout the haunts of Kit Carson and Buffalo Bill.

Two conclusions seem to be self-evident.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 28 -- With track and field completed, basketball and swimming attracted the major interest today in the games of the Fifteenth Olympiad and the United States scored notable victories in both.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, July 28 (Reuters) -- Malaya's rapidly worsening financial position is causing widespread concern.

Congressional action in the closing days of the last session cut Army appropriations for the current fiscal year by 14.9 per cent, compared with budget requests; Navy by 8 per cent, and the Air Force by 6.4 per cent.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 28 (AP) -- An American weight-lifting official said today that the Russians used a secret weapon in the barbell competition -- a vial of potent stuff that they sniffed between lifts.
A minimum weekly wage of $45, recommended yesterday by union officials, was $13 higher than shop owners have asked the New York Beauty Service Minimum Wage Board to establish for hairdressers.

MUNICH, Germany, July 28 (AP) -- The teen-age American mother of two infant daughters said in a written statement today she had accidentally shot and killed her soldier husband during an argument over "other women."

United Corporation announced yesterday a net income of $1,642,784, equal to 12 cents a share, for the six months ended June 30. This represents an increase of 9 per cent above the $1,501,837, or 10 cents a share, cleared in the corresponding six months of 1951.

LONDON, July 28 -- Andrei A. Gromyko, former Deputy Soviet Foreign Minister who has become Ambassador to Britain, arrived here tonight with an appeal for a better understanding between Britain and the Soviet Union.

BONN, Germany, July 28 -- All Allied restrictions on West German steel production and capacity have been lifted and the first steps taken to liquidate the International Authority for the Ruhr, which was created three years ago as a security measure against German military and economic dominance in Europe.

HAMILTON, N. Y., July 28 -- India's Ambassador to the United States charged tonight that this country's mounting defense preparation "can lead only" to a war that would bring "utter and complete destruction of the human civilization that has grown through the centuries."
The hulk of the fire-swept Norwegian freighter Black Gull was refloated yesterday on the shoals near West Bank Light off New Dorp, S. I.

McMINNVILLE, Tenn., July 28 (UP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, said today his bid for the Democratic Presidential nomination had put him "in the red" but, he added, "I'm not worrying about it."

A Red Cross bloodmobile unit under the sponsorship of the New York Military District, 90 Church Street, will receive blood from military and civilian volunteers at the Wanamaker Building, 70 East Tenth Street, from 9:30 A. M. to 4 P. M. today.
MONTREAL, July 28 (AP) -Johnny Bratton, Chicago welterweight, scored a third-round technical knockout over Laurent Dauthuille, French middleweight, in their ten-round main bout tonight.

Steel Comeback Production of steel, following one of the nation's most serious clashes between management and labor in the history of the industry, is on the long path back to normal. Steel workers are not happy over their loss in pay and stockholders of the nation's steel-making concerns are equally apprehensive over uncertain returns on their investments.
BANGKOK, Thailand, July 28 -- Queen Sirikit gave birth to a son here this afternoon at 5:45 o'clock.

The following story by James A. Michener, author of "Tales of the South Pacific" and "Return to Paradise," was released yesterday by the United State Navy. Mr. Michener is in Korea as a magazine correspondent.

TOKYO, Tuesday, July 29 -- Chinese official circles charged today that United States naval maneuvers in the Strait of Formosa this month were a "direct provocation against China" aimed at influencing the talks at Panmunjom for an armistice in the Korean war.

ROME, July 28 -- The most spirited clothes of the season so far presented in Italy were shown this week-end by Simonetta Visconti. Full of color and movement they are both gay and elegant, always beautiful and in most scrupulous taste.

You are to be congratulated for another public service. In your editorial columns of July 24 you called attention to the ominous fact that juvenile delinquency is on the rise -- a sad commentary on society as a whole. But more, it also is an indictment of parents who fail to meet the awesome responsibilities of guiding youth along paths that lead to good citizenship. A better youth means a better America.
Dr. Victor Corse Thorne, a retired surgeon and medical philanthropist, left a net estate of $6,383,707 when he died in 1948, an estate tax appraisal filed yesterday with the state showed.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama, Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee, as he returned to the capital today, pledged that he would wage "an aggressive campaign that will take the Democratic doctrine to all parts of the country and to all the people everywhere."

The high cost of covering political conventions by television and radio, particularly until 4 o'clock in the morning with hundreds of engineers and commentators standing by, may cost the networks several million dollars this year for gambling on politics.
TEHERAN, Iran, July 28 -- The social ostracism of Americans here, which began with the pro-Mossadegh disorders last Monday, has become more marked.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission will hear arguments on Sept. 10 on exceptions to an F. P. C. examiner's ruling on gas service applications made by Colorado Interstate Gas Company and the Kansas-Colorado Utilities, Inc. The examiner, Francis I. Hall, held that Colorado Interstate should be authorized to supply natural gas for resale in the towns of Eads, Fowler and Ordway, Colo.

CHICAGO, July 28 -- Federal District Judge Walter J. La Buy granted permission to the Federal Government today to amend its anti-trust suit against the du Pont industrial empire, so as to add 115 individuals and one corporate defendant to the original three individual and five corporate defendants.

SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, July 29 (AP) -- A Chinese Communist probing force stabbed at Allied positions on "Old Baldy" on the western front in a driving rain and early morning darkness today in an apparent attempt to drive United Nations infantrymen completely from the height.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was fairly active yesterday and closed 36 to 72 points net higher than Friday on active months.

The men's straw hat industry has reached a record yearly sales volume of $30,000,000 at retail and can increase this at least 20 per cent in 1953 if stores stop treating the merchandise as a between seasons item and start an intensified merchandising and promotion campaign, according to James B. Lee, president of Frank H. Lee Company.

Prices of intermediate and longer-term Treasury securities suffered a sizable relapse yesterday. Another shake-out took place in the new 2 3/8s of 1958, with par being bid at the close. With no respite visible in the long-sustained stringency in the money market, dealers trimmed down their positions and their bids.

LONDON, July 28 -- The stock markets were quiet today as investors pondered the possible crisis measures that might be announced in tomorrow's House of Commons debate on the country's economic situation.
AN effort yesterday to establish what fishing in fresh and salt water had been like during the hot weather proved only that fish were where you found them.

RIVERSIDE,' Conn., July 28 -- Representatives of nine clubs today started competition for the Long Island Sound women's sailing championship and possession of the Syce Cup in a series staged by Riverside Yacht Club, where the trophy has rested the past year.

In THE TIMES of July 19 Clarence Streit expressed his regret that the Republican party foreign-policy plank calls for "ending the political and economic divisions" between European nations only. Much as we agree with his arguments in favor of calling a federal convention of the Atlantic democracies, we regret his lack of enthusiasm for a European regional federation.
LONDON, July 28 -- The most revolutionary silhouette at the London collections is the "gaucho" suit, which was shown yesterday by Michael of Lachasse.

A banking syndicate headed by the First Boston Corporation and Drexel Co. will offer to investors today a new issue of $10,000,000 of preferred stock of the Pennsylvania Power and Light Company. The offering consists of 100,000 shares of $100 par value 4.4 per cent dividend stock at $100 a share.

A five-and-a-half furlong dash for maiden 2-year-old fillies of such mediocre talent that the feature was nameless, headlined yesterday's Saratoga-at-Jamaica racing. Despite this and seven other so-so tests, 20,900 fans turned out, and, as one sore loser summed it up. "it served them right."

Your recent dispatch from Rome dealing with Pope Pius' message to the Russian people erroneously refers to St. Cyril, one of the apostles of the Slavs, as "the inventor of the Russian Cyrillic alphabet." The alphabet which Cyril (and his brother Methodius) created was the so-called glagolitic alphabet, which was derived from Greek minuscules.

MEXICO CITY, July 27 -- A mass of complaints by the opposition the conduct of the July election has held up the official announcement of the result. But it has already become clear that the ruling Party of Revolutionary Institutions will be accorded a sweep of both the Presidency and the Congress.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., July 28 -- An overwhelming vote in favor of eliminating a restrictive white membership clause was reported today to the annual convention of the New York State Grand Lodge of the Knights of Pythias. A resolution, urging enactment of legislation barring racial or color discrimination in fraternal organizations, then was presented to the delegates.

LONDON, July 28 -- Britain is still prepared to negotiate a fair settlement of her dispute with Iran over the ownership and operation of the Iranian oil industry, Selwyn Lloyd, Minister of State, informed the House of Commons today.

The release from mental institutions of potential killers and felons, as in the case of Bayard P. Peakes, confessed slayer of a girl office worker at Columbia University two weeks ago, was censured yesterday by General Sessions Judge Saul S. Streit.

The Celanese Corporation of America, largest producer of acetate filament yarn, has raised its price from 1 to 4 cents a pound. The rise followed an increase by three other producers of the yarn in the last two weeks and was announced almost simultaneously with an increase made by American Viscose Corporation of 1 to 12 cents a pound.
A 19-year-old Bronx girl was wounded critically yesterday, apparently as the result of a game of "reverse Russian roulette."
Unbeaten Rocky Marciano, the ring's block-buster from Brockton, Mass., is the man who will battle Jersey Joe Walcott for the world heavyweight title in September.

Philippine President Elpidio Quirino has returned to Manila after an official visit to Indonesia. He was well received in the neighboring archipelago and believes that he has done something to dispel Indonesian mistrust of foreign influences. This was possible because of his emphasis on the ethnic kinship between the Malay Filipinos and the Indonesians.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 28 (AP) -- The Congress of the International Amateur Athletic Federation today voted down a Russian proposal that the rules be altered to provide for official team scoring of men's and women's events at future Olympic Games and the European championships.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 28 (AP) -- The schedule of events tomorrow in the Olympic Games (time is local, followed by New York time ):

While the service wholesale drug industry was able to maintain a net profit before taxes in 1951 of 4.1 per cent, increased income taxes reduced the actual net to less than 2 cents a dollar of sales, according to an operations survey for 1951 released yesterday by the National Wholesale Druggists Association.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 28 (AP) -- America's hopes for Olympic boxing gold medals soared tonight when seven United States athletes advanced to the second round.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- A United States veto of Austrian Nazi amnesty legislation and of recently adopted modifications of the national restitution laws was forecast today by the State Department. A spokesman said the United States Government was "greatly disturbed" by the legislation and had communicated its views to the Austrian Government.
ST. LOUIS, July 28 -- Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, the Democratic Presidential nominee, blames Mark Twain "for the confusion that exists as to how to pronounce my first name."

One of the country's most important music store executives warned television manufacturers yesterday that music merchants might drop television receivers as stock items if their profit margins were not increased. The warning was delivered at the fifty-first annual convention of the National Association of Music Merchants and trade show of the music industry in the New Yorker Hotel.
The new take-off procedures at La Guardia Airport and New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, designed to reduce the noise factor over several Queens communities, are now in effect.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- Staff counsel for the Federal Power Commission urged today the dismissal of the Texas Eastern Transmission Company application for a $41,600,000 annual increase in wholesale natural gas rates.

Commodity futures on local exchanges generally were higher yesterday in slightly more active trading. Hides, rubber, coffee and vegetable oils advanced while zinc and wool declined. Sugar contracts were mixed.

The packaging industry, in spite of a slow start in the early part of 1952, should as a whole find conditions favorable for the balance of the year, the National Production Authority concluded in its quarterly report on containers and packaging.

THE art of reading has been extolled and explained in many a book and the art of reading particular authors from Shakespeare to William Faulkner in many more. But there is one aspect of the art of reading which each reader must learn for himself from personal experience and that is to suspend judgment while waiting to see what an author is up to.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture, announced today the selection of Plum Island, in Long Island Sound, N. Y., as the site for a $10,000,00 laboratory to study hoof-and-mouth and other animal diseases.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- Admiral William M. Fechteler, Chief of Naval Operations, said today he thought there would be an armistice in Korea -- "principally because the Communists want it."

The glamour resources of Canada at present are oil and iron ore. Dominion economy for years has been based to a large extent on non-ferrous metals. Aluminum, nickel, gold, lead, zinc, copper and uranium have been contributing factors, although new metals such as titanium are opening up future possibilities broadening the base of the economy.

CHICAGO, July 28 -- No one seemed to have the right time today in the Conrad Hilton Hotel Exhibition Hall, but a visitor would suspect it was Christmas in July. Even Santa Claus was there, along with thousands of jewelers who were exhibiting precious stones, watches, silverware and related items at the opening of the National Jewelry Fair, which will continue through Friday.

Once again the floundering Dodgers put on a ninth inning rally that fell one run short and they were beaten for the fourth straight time by the Cards at Ebbets Field last night, 3 -- 2. This is the Brooks' longest-losing streak of the year and the loss of the entire series cut their first-place margin over the Giants to four games.
The election of G. Kenneth Crowell as a director of International Cellucotton Products Company was announced yesterday. Mr. Crowell is a partner of the Chicago law firm of Crowell Leibman.

LONDON, July 28 -- Britain and all free nations hope that a stable and orderly administration will emerge from the present crisis in Egypt, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden said in the House of Commons today.

The garment section from Thirty-fourth Street to Fortieth and from Seventh to Eighth Avenues will be spotted today with pickets as the Cloak Joint Board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A. F. L., declares war against nonunion shops in the women's coat and suit industry.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- A threatened strike of 15,000 workers in nine plants of the Aluminum Company of America was averted today, ending the only outstanding labor dispute in the vast aluminum industry.

Under the United Mine Workers' contract with the coal industry John L. Lewis has given the required sixty days' notice of the union's desire to terminate the agreement with the Bituminous Coal Operators Association, headed by Harry Moses. In serving this notice solely on the Association representing Northern producers predominantly, and ignoring the Southern Coal Producers Association, Mr. Lewis may be pursuing a significant tactic, though we do not pretend to read his mind.

DETROIT, July 28 -- The Yankees, having just snapped a five-game losing streak, are still cutting up some weird capers at the top of the American League scramble. They went off the deep end again today as the Tigers, behind their refurbished southpaw, Hal Newhouser, made off with the series finale, 12 to 2.

European industry should be given the opportunity to apply directly to American management engineers for productivity assistance, according to Herbert L. Werner, industrial consultant. The aid given by the Mutual Security Agency and its predecessor, the Economic Cooperation Administration, has been an important factor in European recovery, he said, but if industry abroad is to stand on its own feet, the individual manufacturer must obtain management assistance tailored to his specific requirements.

Brien McMahon did a lot, in a brief political career, to make the word politician a term of honor. He well knew how to get elected. In 1950, when Chester Bowles lost the Connecticut Governorship to John Lodge by 17,000 votes, McMahon won re-election to the Senate by 44,593 votes. But once elect-I led 3/fclViahon turned naturally to jobs and causes that he believed would benI efit his fellow-citizens.

This is not only the season for cliches about the heat, as was pointed out the other day in the columns at the left, but, what is even more trying, it is one of those years in which political cliches assail the ear in unusual volume and persistence.

LONDON, July 28 -- Announcing its plans for the denationalization of the British iron and steel industry, the Conservative Government conceded today that it "may well take some years" to restore the industry to private ownership.

Gerhard A. Puff, the Kansas bank robber who on Saturday fatally wounded Joseph J. Brock, 44-year-old agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, was arraigned on a murder charge yesterday as he lay in bed in the Bellevue Hospital prison ward United States Commissioner Edward W. McDonald held Puff without bail for a hearing on Aug. 11.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department today apportioned $65,875,000 for operation of the school-lunch program during the 1952-53 school year.

SOUTH SALEM, N. Y., July 28 -- Twenty-three men and four New York models pleaded guilty here early today to disorderly conduct for participating yesterday in a woodland "photography class" that Westchester County officials said outraged public decency. Four other defendants were booked on a charge of arranging the event and will be tried Aug. 9.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 28 -- President Otilio Ulate Blanco today officially inaugurated the start of construction work on Costa Rica's new airport at El Coco near Alajuela, fifteen miles' from the capital. This $4,000,000 project, scheduled to be completed in a year, will have a paved runway 6,600 feet with a total landing surface, including an additional area levelled and compacted, of 8,000 feet, enabling the largest commercial airliners and bombers to take-off.

Spokesmen for R. H. Macy Co, held yesterday at arbitration hearings, where the question of wage increases for Macy's 8,000 employes will be decided, that the company was not doing as well as other department stores in this area.

The romanticists who are willing to believe that Mars and Venus are inhabited by people so intelligent and advanced that they have been visiting us for centuries and giving us a periodic "once over" must be highly pleased with the reported failure of jet fighter planes to intercept what, a few months ago, were called "flying saucers" but are now called "objects."

There are only three books published today, of which "Dance and Skylark" by John Moore (Macmillan), is reviewed in Books of The Times. The others are "Silent Friends, Animals I Have Known," by Gene Hoopes (Exposition, $2.50); and "Bolshevism: An Introduction to Soviet Communism'' by Waldemar Gurian (University of Notre Dame, $3.25).

ST. LOUIS, July 28 (AP) -- Although needing help from Bob Cain toward the end, Satchel Paige celebrated his "night" with his first starting-role victory of the year as the Browns defeated the Senators, 6 to 3, tonight.

BUENOS AIRES, July 28 -- After more than 100,000 Argentines had filed past the coffin in which the body of Senora Eva Peron was lying in state and it was evident that hundreds of thousands still wished to pay their last respects to the "Spiritual Chief of the Nation," the Subsecretariat of Information announced tonight that the final funeral rites would be postponed for at least twenty-four hours.

LONDON, July 28 (Reuters) -- Cable and Wireless, Ltd., Britain's nationalized communications system, today recommended that annual dividends be slashed from 4 to 2 1/2 per cent because of decreased earnings.
LOS ANGELES, July 28 (AP) -- Senator Richard M. Nixon received a rousing reception today on his return to California as the Republican Vice-Presidential nominee.

ST. LOUIS, July 28 (AP) -- Senator James P. Kem, Republican of Missouri, tonight charged that "Attorney General James P. McGranery apparently desires to further whitewash the notorious theft of the 1946 Kansas City vote fraud ballots."

" In Any Language," the comedy by Edmund Beloin and Henry Garson, which will star Uta Hagen, has been booked to open at the Cort Theatre on Oct. 8. Sponsored by Jule Styne and George Abbott, the attraction will go into rehearsal on Aug. 25 under Mr. Abbot's direction and will play engagements in New Haven and Boston before arriving in New York.

TRENTON, July 28 -- New Jersey Democratic leaders, just returned from their national convention, began plans today for a campaign with the hope that Adlai E. Stevenson, Presidential nominee, would attend an opening rally Aug. 21. Before the convention, he had accepted an invitation to come to New Jersey in the course of the campaign and the Democrats had tentatively arranged a rally at Jumping Brook County Club, near Red Bank, for Aug. 21.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Thousands of industrial plants now operating will be forced to shut down and an untold number of workers will become wholly or partly unemployed before the steel supply gets back to where it was on June 2, when the steel strike began, Henry H. Fowler, Defense Production Administrator, said today.

Three balky witnesses featured yesterday's proceedings at the departmental trial in the Criminal Courts Building of thirty-four suspended policemen charged with accepting graft from Harry Gross, the convicted bookmaker.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 28 -- Brazilian Government experts are redrafting their bill to liberalize foreign exchange rules in the hope of solving a question that has been hurting Brazilian - United States relations since January: the export of profits and repatriation of capital by foreign investors.
CHICAGO, July 28 (AP) -- Tuonine, a filly running as part of a four-horse field, won the $18,375 George Woolf Memorial Stakes in today's opening program of Washington Park's thirty-one-day meeting.

HARTFORD, July 28 -- The death of Senator Brien McMahon, Connecticut's senior Senator and leader of the Democratic party in the state, brought expressions of regret and mourning today from leaders of both major parties here.
A TRIPLE crown that has graced the heads of only five other pitchers in baseball history is moving into the short-armed reach of Bobby Shantz.

" I can lick anybody I get in there with," shouted an exultant Rocky Marciano in his dressing room after last night's fight with Harry (Kid) Matthews. The undefeated Brockton heavyweight made that positive utterance in response to the question, "do you think you can beat Joe Walcott?"

The principle upon which the hydrogen bomb is based involves the fusion of the nuclei (cores) of hydrogen atoms into helium, the element next to hydrogen on the periodic table. This fusion process is believed to take place in the interior of the sun, where the temperature is estimated to reach about 20,000,000 degrees Centigrade.
YAKIMA, Wash., July 28 (AP) -- The Yakima Indian Nation, once proud ruler of the vast Central Washington region, has lost a 100-year battle to the white man.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 28 (UP) -- An expected forty-man Olympic delegation from Communist China failed to arrive from Moscow as scheduled today, and the best guess among their fellow Communists was that they "might come tomorrow."

Thomas Le Roux, a 37-year-old assistant engineer on the S. S. La Guardia, died yesterday morning in the Israel Zion Hospital, Brooklyn as a result of injuries received in a fist fight last Thursday with Gerald Hagg, a 35-year-old junior engineer aboard the ship.

Harold C. Burton, Negro delegate to the Republican National Convention, told a Harlem luncheon gathering yesterday that he had switched his support from Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower only after the latter had assured him that an enforceable Federal Fair Employment Practices bill "could be" enacted if the general were elected President.

GREAT NECK, L. I., July 28 -Phil Weinsier and Fred Wampler of the Fresh Meadow Golf Club scored 33, 31 -- 64, six under par, to win the weekly amateur-pro tourney of the Long Island P.G.A. at the Deepdale course today.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 28 (AP) -- The United States won two Olympic yachting championships today, and Norway, Denmark and Italy captured one each.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 28 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson returned to his home capital today still protesting that he would like to stay.

RYE, N. Y., July 28 -- Fred Moore and Foster Nichols of Hudson River, with an 8-under-par 32, 32 -- 64, won the top price in pro-amateur best-ball tournament of the Westchester County Golf Association at the Apawamis Club today.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 28 (AP) -- Red China's application for membership in the International Amateur Athletic Federation was shelved for two years today until the I. A. A. F. meets again in Zurich in 1954.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 28 (AP) -- Emil Zatopek, Czechoslovakia's wonder distance runner, was invited today to run in the United States.

Francis X. Gomila, a soft drink and sugar dealer, was named yesterday by the Federal rackets grand jury in an indictment charging him with evading payment of more than $900,000 in income taxes. The case was described by United States Attorney Myles J. Lane as one of the largest of its kind ever filed in the Southern District of New York.
OCEANPORT, N. J., July 28 (AP) -- Alan T. Clarke's Senator Joe, a 1-2 shot, galloped to a convincing victory in today's featured Cherry Pie Purse at Monmouth Park.
MEXICO CITY, July 28 (UP) -- Ambassador William O'Dwyer told friends tonight he was considering becoming a Mexican citizen after his resignation from the diplomatic corps.

There was little news yesterday to inspire on-the-spot trading in either direction on the stock market where prices operated over an irregular course, with alterations in quotations so small that the final result meant little. The difference between stocks to advance or decline was thinly drawn, while the composite rate showed an increase of 0.10 point.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES of July 17, C. P. Trussell, your correspondent at the Democratic National Convention covering the meetings of the Platform Committee, reported that three of the possible nominees -- Senator Richard Russell of Georgia, Senator Robert S. Kerr of Oklahoma and Representative Sam Rayburn of Texas -- were "not acceptable" as Presidential candidates to the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights.

RICHMOND, Va., July 28 -- Vir ginia's Democrats are not bound to support the national party platform, according to Gov. John S. Battle, but they are not yet ready to determine their official view on the Stevenson-Sparkman ticket.
TOKYO, Tuesday, July 29 (AP) -- United Nations Headquarters communique 1,325, for twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M. Tuesday, Korean time:

A consistent decline in exports as well as in coastal and inter-coastal waterborne trade over the last eight months has reached serious proportions and is causing considerable concern to a large, segment of the maritime industry. Those who are affected are noticeably pessimistic, and they see little chance of halting the downward trend before the fan -- if then.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 28 -- President Truman expressed his sorrow today at the death of Senator Brien McMahon, for whom he had a high regard as a friend and as one of his most loyal supporters in Congress. The President issued this statement from his office in the Hotel Muehlebach:

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor voted today to accept the appointment of federation officials to the new Wage Stabilization Board, which is to be created on Wednesday.

LOS ANGELES, July 28 (AP) -Polly Riley of Fort Worth, a member of the United States Curtis Cup team, knocked two strokes off par today to lead the qualifiers for the annual women's Western amateur golf championship.
Rogers Hornsby, one of the finest hitters in the game during his active career, last night was named manager of the Cincinnati Reds.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The Government increased the retail ceiling prices on hams, chops and other lean pork cuts tonight from 1 to 8 cents a pound.

It is well known that a substantial part of the Chinese Communist propaganda has been directed at India. Because of some positions that India has taken it has also been supposed that the Indians, by and large, were receptive to this propaganda. If they are, and that is doubtful, there are some strong exceptions.

HONOLULU, July 28 -- Christian Endeavor friendship crusade will come out of the current Pacific area conference of the World Christian Endeavor Union in Honolulu, the Rev. Dr. Daniel A. Poling of Philadelphia, president of the organization and editor of The Christian Century, declared here today.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 28 -- Striking sailors affiliated with the American Federation of Labor voted without dissent this afternoon to end a walkout that had kept more than 100 ships tied up for sixty-three days.

Earnings of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) broke all records for an initial half-year with its estimated consolidated earnings of $265,000,000 reported yesterday for the six months ended June 30.
ST. LOUIS, July 28 (AP) -- Seventy-nine companies filed suit in Federal Court today asking $10,000,000 in damages from the Teamsters Union, A. F. L., for a twenty-seven-day truck drivers' strike.

LENINGRAD, July 26 -- One of the biggest restoration and rehabilitation programs in the Soviet Union has been launched in Leningrad to improve the appearance of the city's hundreds of historic buildings. Almost every building along the famous Neva embankment from the Summer Gardens to the Winter Palace is now criss-crossed with builders' scaffolding.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 28 -Karoly Takacs, a Hungarian who taught himself to shoot with his left hand after losing his right one in an accident, today won the Olympic silhouette shooting championship for the second straight time.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., July 28 (UP) -- Three survivors were picked up today amidst the explosion-torn debris of a 35-foot cabin cruiser that carried a party of twelve men on a deep-sea fishing trip yesterday.

New York shipping men frankly admitted concern yesterday over the terms of the settlement that ended the two-month West Coast ship strike. They expressed the fear that the agreement might be used by other maritime unions as a pattern in future negotiations.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Enquirer, Inc., the employe-formed company that purchased The Cincinnati Enquirer, has listed total assets of $8,967,467 with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

An amusement park, fruits and flowers are some of the motifs that give a summer-like air to prints in a new collection of domestic and imported materials, available through decorators at Hambro House, Inc., 17 East Fifty-fourth Street. The group includes both patterned and textured fabrics, suitable for draperies and upholstery.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 28 -- President Truman accepts the seasons as they were ordained and said today a good conscience enables him to sleep well despite the oppressive heat.
TORONTO, July 28 -- The International Red Cross conference, by a vote of 58 to 25, with five absentions, decided tonight to seat the delegates of both Communists and Nationalist China.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Brien McMahon, senior United States Senator from Connecticut, chairman of the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy and a leader in the movement for world peace, died today at Georgetown University Hospital.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 28 -- Three known casualties and numerous unrecorded ones resulted from a full-fledged blitz war started by the Uruguay team in the Trade Fair Hall Arena this afternoon after its 68-66 basketball defeat there at the hands of France.
