LONDON, July 28 -- Reporting on the progress of the war in Korea, Field Marshal Earl Alexander, British Minister of Defense, announced today that a British officer, Maj. Gen. Stephen N. Shoosmith, would be appointed Deputy Chief of Staff to Gen. Mark W. Clark, the United Nations commander in chief.
The Office of Price Stabilization acted yesterday to speed the flow of metal scrap to steel mills.

MADRID, July 28 -- The United States Government has been informed that Spain must receive enough economic and military aid to defend herself if attacked by the Soviet Union before the Franco regime will consider Washington's request for the use of Spanish air and naval bases in wartime, well informed Spanish circles said today.

Federal Judge Edward J. Dimock announced yesterday at the Communist conspiracy trial that when the Government rested its case he would expect "very detailed statements of how each defendant is connected with the conspiracy." He advised the prosecution that he also would expect "a very complete exposition" of group connection with the conspiracy if the prosecution has such proof.

Charles H. Kerrigan, regional director of the United Automobile, Aircraft and Agricultural Implement Workers of America, C. I. O., and two other union men were arrested yesterday on a charge of disorderly conduct in mass picketing before a struck Brooklyn manufacturing plant.

Your calmly dispassionate and searching appraisal of the two chief contenders for the Presidency was deeply appreciated. It is heartening, too, that THE NEW YORK TIMES has seen fit to reaffirm its original support of Dwight D. Eisenhower, even though it is fully cognizant of the high caliber of the Democratic nominee, Adlai E. Stevenson.

LONDON, July 28 (UP) -- Britain's highest court reversed today a Hong Kong Supreme Court decision awarding forty former Chinese Nationalist transport planes to Communist China and ordered that they be turned over to a United States airline.

ROME, July 28 -- A collar that springs full blown from the shoulders, backless and draped into a bandana or shawl effect in front is one of the new neckline and sleeve treatments introduced today by Fabiani, master tailor of Rome, in a special couturier showing for buyers from the United States and the press.

" Glory Alley," which arrives at Loew's State, is this morning's lone film newcomer. The Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer romantic melodrama, which features Leslie Caron, Ralph Meeker, Gilbert Roland, Kurt Kasznar, Louis Armstrong, John McIntire and Jack Teagarden, was directed by Raoul Walsh and produced by Nicholas Nayfack from story and screen play by Art Cohn.

The national Presidential nominating convention has been a feature of American life for more than a century. Many of its characteristics have grown by long habit into traditions. If there has been any change it may be that the convention is a little less hysterical than it was a generation or so back.
The Rockefeller Foundation and General Education Board announced yesterday they had made grants of about $10,000,000 in the second quarter of 1952 for educational and scientific research programs.
WESTBURY, L. I., July 28 (AP) -- Lively Lady won the $12,250 Dean Hanover Trot at Roosevelt Raceway tonight, leading a field of thirteen 2-year-olds with ease in a Grand Circuit race.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (UP) -- Other tributes to Senator McMahon included the following:

WHITEVILLE, N. C., July 28 -- Thomas L. Hamilton, Imperial Wizard of the North and South Carolina Ku Klux Klan, is scheduled to be sentenced in Superior Court here tomorrow for his role in a Columbus County flogging case.

GENEVA, July 27 -- The first serious international effort to develop a fundamentally new approach to the problem of reducing tariff barriers to world trade has ended here with what might be called modest progress.
DENVER, July 28 -- Back at summer headquarters here after a vacation in the Colorado Rockies, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower began a series of meetings today to complete his campaign organization.

CINCINNATI, July 28 -- The nation's leading bridge experts, gathered here at the Sheraton Gibson Hotel for the summer session of the twenty-sixth annual National Contract Bridge Championships, settled down today to a week-long pursuit of the American Contract Bridge League's most coveted titles.
El Borracho, a night club at 51 East Fifty-fifth Street, was cited in Federal Court yesterday for alleged violation of Office of Price Stabilization ceiling prices.

After driving almost 52,000 miles on an international motor tour, Dr. Franco Nacci of Palermo, Sicily, described traffic arrangements in New York as "chuckleheaded." There are too many "No Parking" signs, too much horn blowing by taxi operators and a widespread lack of order, he said yesterday.

The Board of Elections threw out yesterday the designating petitions of Richard Neville, who was seeking to capture the Republican nomination for Representative in the Seventeenth Congressional district from the incumbent, Frederic R. Coudert Jr., who has the backing of the New York County Republican organization.

CAIRO, July 28 -- Interest here today focused on the internment of a number of prominent Egyptians by order of Gen. Mohammed Naguib Bey, Commander in Chief of the armed forces and leader of the military group that took power Wednesday and forced King Farouk to abdicate three days later.

I should like to enter a mild protest against THE TIMES' support of General Eisenhower before the Democratic nominee was known and its immediate reiterated support of him before it truly knew the man Stevenson.

BONN, Germany, July 29 -- The West German Government regards the discussions on the future of the Saar, which begin in Paris Friday, as the acid test of French willingness to cooperate with Germany in the building of a united Europe.

Explaining that the company needs cash for its expanding business, directors of the Foster-Wheeler Corporation took no dividend action yesterday on the common shares. The company designs and builds steam plants, refineries and natural gas plants.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 29 -- A route for the entire Westchester County segment of the New England Thruway was recommended to county officials here today by engineers of the New York State Thruway Authority. It is fifteen miles long and would entail construction that James C. Harding, Westchester Commissioner of Public Works, said would cost the Authority $40,000,000.

Four buildings with seventy-two apartments at 403-21 Avenue C, the north blockfront between East Fourth and Fifth Streets in Flatbush, Brooklyn, have been sold by Rubin Glickman to an investing client of Lane Realty, Forest Hills, brokers. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

The railroads continued yesterday to assume the leadership among the pivotal units of the stock market and general strength in this division enabled prices to improve selectively. While the steels and motors lagged further and attracted slim followings, trading in the carriers, some of the aviations and an assortment of specialties kept business above the 1,000,000-share mark.

LONDON, July 29 -- Representatives of the United States, Britain, France and Belgium met here today to give further consideration to the replies their Governments have been asked to make to the recent report by a committee of experts from the Organization for European Economic Cooperation.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (UP) -- The Defense Department announced today that discharged Korean war veterans and others who left the armed forces since the Korean fighting began may apply immediately for mustering out pay ranging from $100 to $300.

If proof is needed that beer is among the favorite summer beverages, industry statistics provide it. A representative of the United States Brewers Foundation said yesterday that from the first hot day of June until the last of September sales are almost double those of winter.

Many insomniacs when they are afflicted with a sleepless night, turn to counting sheep. But not Arthur A. Merrill, a General Electric Company engineer. He began counting days. The result is a new and simpler solution to the perpetual calendar problem, long the idle moments' delight of mathematicians.

LONDON, July 29 -- Because of the dollar shortage British tobacco imports from United States this year will be less than half what they were in 1951, Peter Thorneycroft, President of the Board of Trade, announced in the House of Commons today.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 29 (AP) -- Three of the United States Olympic champions opened Sweden's post-Olympic track and field meet tonight with victories.

The problem of how to get attention for the advertiser with a small or moderate budget has intrigued John Goodwillie, vice president in charge of advertising of Alexander Smith, Inc., carpet manufacturer. He has come to the conclusion that coordinated promotions, in which a group of noncompetitive manufacturers could be persuaded to combine their selling efforts for their related products, would carry an impact far in excess of individual efforts.

A defendant in the departmental trial of thirty-four suspended policemen charged with accepting graft from Harry Gross, the convicted bookmaker, persisted yesterday in his refusal to take the stand as a prosecution witness. He was told by Third Deputy Commissioner James A. Delehanty that disciplinary action would be taken against him.

PARIS, July 29 -- Premier Antoine Pinay gave James C. Dunn, the United States Ambassador, a memorandum yesterday reviewing the French military obligations and financial resources and emphasizing the urgency of decisions regarding United States aid.
The nation is fortunate in having as the nominees of the two great parties men of integrity and exceptional intellectual honesty.

An apartment house site comprising 70,000 square feet of land at the junction of Kappock Street and Johnson Avenue in the Riverdale section of the Bronx has been sold by the Estate of Isaac G. Johnson to the M. J. Laurel Corporation, a subsidiary of Jacob Mark Sons, who are building the Knolls cooperative apartments near by.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 29 -- The United Nations Korean Reconstruction Agency announced today that a three-man medical team, recruited by the World Health Organization from Britain and Ceylon would leave here tomorrow for Korea to gather data for a long-range program to rebuild the country and make it self-supporting.

MIAMI, Fla., July 29 (UP) -- A $475,000 program of stake races at Hialeah, headed by the $100,000 Widener and the $100,000 Flamingo, which are both doubled in value, was released today for next winter by President John C. Clark.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Overthrow of the United States Government by force and violence and not by peaceful methods is now Premier Joseph Stalin's key to Communist ascendancy in this country, a Federal Bureau of Investigation report released today declared.

Ten persons were injured, one critically, at 6:02 A. M. yesterday when an inbound subway train struck a stationary train on the east track of the 241st Street terminal of the I. R. T. White Plains Road line in the Bronx, the police reported.

LONDON, July 29 -- R. A. Butler, Chancellor of the Exchequer, told the House of Commons today that with aid from the United States and a further readjustment of her rearmament program, Britain should be able to live within her income for the rest of this year after having overspent for the last two years.
Mirages on the radarscope, which have started the latest mass delusion about the "flying saucers," are phenomena that became well known to the Navy in World War II.

The whole idea of international "cultural interchange" has received an important stimulus in the announcement that a group of Balinese dancers and musicians will come to the United States early in September. The Balinese dance and musical form is a vital part of the world's cultural heritage.
Of the four oil companies that reported operating results for the 1952 half-year period yesterday, only one showed an improvement in earnings over the six months of last year.

DETROIT, July 29 (AP) -- The resignation of Leroy Spencer as executive vice president of Packard Motor Car Company and his appointment as West Coast manager was announced at the company offices today.

CHAMBERSBURG, Pa., July 29 -- Dr. Frank Aydelotte, for thirty-five years American Secretary to the Rhodes Scholarships, will retire next Jan. 1, The American Oxonian, magazine for the Association of American Rhodes Scholars, announced here today.

Unification of East and West Germany was predicted yesterday by John J. McCloy, retiring United States High Commissioner for Germany. "I can't speculate as to when and how it will come about," he said, "but powerful moral forces are working toward that end."

The duo-pianists, June and Iris Yaysnoff, made their Lewisohn Stadium debut last evening. The Stadium Symphony Orchestra was under the direction of Alexander Smallens. The London-born pianists have toured widely in Europe but as yet are not familiar to American audiences.

The Government's fourth witness in the four-month-old Communist conspiracy trial, Mrs. Bereniece Baldwin of Detroit, took the stand yesterday in Federal Court and tolid how she joined the Communist party to gather information for the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
The steel industry's blast furnaces and open hearths, cool for fifty-five days, were roaring into production yesterday at a more rapid rate than anyone had expected.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Maj. Gen. Robert W. Grow was convicted by an Army court-martial today of improper use of secret official information in a private record, and of having failed to safeguard such information. He was reprimanded and suspended from command for six months.

Although the radio air waves abound with commentators on both the international and domestic political fronts, there never have been many programs devoted to a critical appraisal of the arts and allied fields. Gilbert Seldes had a go at the idea some time back on WNEW, but unfortunately got caught up in his own ponderousness.

Dixie Flyer of the Duntreath Farm soared to victory in the Judith Hunter Handicap, the $10,000 added race for fillies and mares that served as the feature attraction at the Jamaica Track yesterday. Opposing nine others in the six-furlong test, Dixie Flyer closed fast to take the victory by three-quarters of a length over the favored Jacodema of the Apheim Stable.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., July 29 -- The State Legislature was asked today by the New York State Knights of Pythias to enact legislation making it illegal for any fraternal or benevolent organization to reject applications for membership on the basis of race or color.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 29 -- The Netherlands is caught in a dilemma between tempting Russian offers of shipbuilding contracts and United States objections. The situation that has arisen here epitomizes anew the difficulties that the West European countries face in finding an acceptable level of trade with the Communist world.

The Public Service Commission denied yesterday a request by the Westchester Electric Railroad Company, which operates a bus route between the North Bronx and New Rochelle, N. Y., by way of Mount Vernon, for a five-cent fare increase for each zone.

HANOVER, Germany, July 29 (AP) -- Dr. Petrus Bersell of Minneapolis told a Hungarian churchman today that the Lutherans regretted that Bishop Lajos Ordass could not represent the Hungarian Church at the Lutheran World Assembly here.

It is strange to emerge from the din of the conventions into a quiet in which other voices can be heard. In Chicago there was a sense that nothing was happening except the struggle within each of the great political parties to find a candidate who could win the election.
TOKYO, July 29 (AP) -- United Nations Headquarters communique 1,325, for twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M. Tuesday, Korean time:

Henry D. Ecker has been appointed vice president in charge of operations of the Smoke Rise Company, developers of the Smoke Rise housing colony in Kinnelon Borough, N. J. Mr. Ecker, formerly assistant to J. Alden Talbot, president of the concern, will be in charge of land development and construction.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The deadlocked negotiations between the United States and France, involving that country's entire rearmament effort, were brought into the open today with a statement by the French Ambassador, Henri Bonnet, that the "two Governments did not see the question with the same eye."

TORONTO, July 29 -- While the Soviet and satellite delegations pressed an attack against the International Committee of the Red Cross, the general commission of the world conference here refused today to "approve" reports by Chinese Communist and North Korean delegations charging the use of germ warfare by the United Nations.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 29 (AP) -- C. V. Whitney's Counterpoint, "horse of the year in 1951," galloped to a four-length victory over a small band of contenders in the featured Lakewood Purse at Monmouth Park today.

BERLIN, July 29 -- Refugees have been pouring into West Berlin in the last few days, taking advantage of what they believe to be their last chance to leave the Soviet zone of Germany. The total of such persons in the city is now estimated at 200,000.

The huge requirements for equipment to bring the nation's Air Force to a point of readiness to meet all eventualities were reflected in the reports issued yesterday by Boeing Airplane Company and Republic Aviation Corporation. Sales of Boeing and Republic for the six months ended June 30, last, increased 84 per cent and 157, respectively, above the volumes attained in the corresponding six months of 1951.

Stockholders of the nation's largest steel enterprise received good news yesterday. Despite the most devastating strike in the history of the steel industry, the Unit-United States Steel Corporation declared a quarterly dividend of 75 cents a share on its outstanding common stock and $1.75 a share on the preferred stock.
ROME, July 29 -- The graceful morning-glory is the inspiration for silhouettes in Fontana's new collection.

Various historical, ethnographic and anthropological works have divided Homo Sapiens into Homo Pictor, Homo Faber and various other classifications. It has remained for the Union and New Haven Trust Company to isolate and describe a new grouping: Homo Stockbuyer.
KANSAS CITY, July 29 (AP) -- Stockholders of the Mid-Continent Airlines and Braniff International Airways voted overwhelming approval today of a proposal to merge the two systems.

LONDON, July 29 -- The stock markets here were quietly steady today while waiting for Chancellor R. A. Butler's statement on economic affairs, the details of which were not known until after the exchange had closed.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 29 -- Senator Richard M. Nixon, Republican Vice-Presidential nominee, said tonight that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, head of the party's ticket, had agreed that one of them should start at one end of the country and one at the other and conduct the most vigorous possible type of campaign drive. It was expected to get under way sometime after Labor Day.

A hesitant hold-up man, who changed his mind several times as to whether he would rob the place or not, finally made off with $30 from Loft's candy store at 152 East Forty-second Street yesterday. He promised to repay the sum in a month.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 28 -- Indonesian opinion at the completion of the eleven-day state visit of President Elpidio Quirino of the Philippines is that his tour will have a salutary effect on Southeast Asia.

An expanding agenda confronts Joshua Logan. Newly added to it is "Kind Sir," a romantic comedy by Norman Krasna, which is to be presented and staged by Mr. Logan. Look for its arrival on Broadway in the late spring. Equipped with a New York locale, the plot touches upon three different sets of people -- diplomatic, theatrical and suburban.
PARIS, July 29 -- Phrygian Bonnets, pastry cook coifs and supple cloches are Jean Barthet's contribution to autumn millinery.
DALLAS, Tex., July 29 (AP) -- The Kirby Petroleum Company of Houston will be absorbed by the Taylor Oil and Gas Company of McAllen, Tex., according to an announcement here.

IPOH, Malaya, July 28 -- Protection for the tin rich Kinta Valley from Communist terrorism and extortion will soon be bolstered by the first British-led anti-Communist Chinese military force so far created in Malaya. The special 1,500-man army, now being recruited and trained, is scheduled to be ready for action by the end of the year.

BUENOS AIRES, July 29 -- The Argentine Government today announced an indefinite postponement of funeral services for Eva Peron as several scores of thousands continued to wait in long queues to get a glimpse of the wife of the President lying in state in the Ministry of Labor Building where she worked unofficially and acquired almost unlimited power for herself and for her husband.

Capt. John W. Anderson, master of the United States liner America and a popular figure with all the licensed seamen in the line, is slated to become captain of the 53,000-ton superliner United States as soon as Commodore Harry Manning, present master of the vessel, retires.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 29 -- Ninety-six racing craft were out on Long Island Sound today in the New York Yacht Club regatta for junior sailors, or those under 18 years old. The turnout was the largest in any of the seven such annual events the New York club has held.

Today's new film is "Affair in Trinidad," a Columbia romantic drama in which Rita Hayworth returns to the screen, at the Victoria. Glenn Ford is co-starred with Miss Hayworth, and Valerie Bettis, Alexander Scourby and Torin Thatcher are among the supporting players.
MOSCOW, July 28 -- The Soviet press today declared that on the basis of experience at the Olympic Games, "the language of friendship" is one which Americans and Soviet athletes can speak freely.

THE reason many discriminating readers do not enjoy detective stories is that they are only about murder and violence. And murder and violence can be dull stuff indeed. To make them interesting something more must be added, successful characterization of victim and criminal and the ability to make their emotions seem real. A murderer hiding from the police is not in himself very interesting.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 29 -- By a vote of 9 to 5, with three abstentions, the Economic and Social Council of the United Nations accepted today a French proposal that the Human Rights Commission hold its 1953 session at Geneva, beginning April 6.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 29 -- Pat Hinman, 19-year-old representative of the Manhasset Bay Club, clung to her point lead for the Syce Cup, emblematic of the women's sailing championship of Long Island Sound, as four more events in the nine-race series were completed in a good northwest breeze today off the Riverside Yacht Club.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- Roger L. Putnam, Economic Stabilization Director, issued an order today putting nine categories of small business enterprises under wage controls.

The formation of the New York U. S. O. (United Service Organizations) Defense Fund, with Artemus L. Gates, banker and industrialist, as president, was announced yesterday. The fund will conduct an appeal in Manhattan, Brooklyn, the Bronx and Queens on behalf of the U. S. O., United Community Defense Service, American Social Hygiene Committee, American Relief for Korea and the National Recreation Association.

Missing a grand opportunity to gain additional ground on the slumping Dodgers, the Giants bowed to the Cubs, 4 -- 2, before 15,657 spectators at the Polo Grounds last night. Two-run homers off Max Lanier by Tommy Brown and Bill Serena and strong pitching by Warren Hacker and Dutch Leonard did in the New Yorkers.

The Allied Chemical Dye Corporation reported yesterday a net income of $20,633,771 for the first half of this year, after deducting $23,358,745 for taxes. In the corresponding six months last year the concern had a net of $20,442,758 after a $37,616,326 tax bill.

Rocky Marciano, Brockton, Mass., heavyweight, who is undefeated in forty-two ring engagements, encountered more difficulty in preliminary negotiations yesterday for a proposed September heavyweight title match against Jersey Joe Walcott, the champion, than he did in knocking out Harry (Kid) Matthews Monday night at Yankee Stadium.

Martin G. Olsen, the 36-year-old Brooklyn bank teller who stole $38,224 of his employer's funds when he was going out to lunch, was sentenced yesterday to two and one-half years in a Federal Penitentiary by Chief Judge Robert A. Inch in the Brooklyn Federal Court.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (UP) -- Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama, Democratic candidate for Vice President, said today his party's civil rights plank was "basically correct" even though it might not satisfy "either extreme" completely.

IDAHO FALLS, Idaho, July 29 (UP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced today that facilities to test an atomic-powered airplane engine would be built at the sprawling national reactor testing station in eastern Idaho.
SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 29 (UP) -- Two seeded players were eliminated today as the Meadow Club invitation tennis tournament opened with two rounds of singles.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- Prices received by farmers rose 1 per cent between June 15 and July 15, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Air Force headquarters skimmed away into the broken dishware bin today the latest wave of "flying saucers." It called them "natural phenomena" and announced through high-ranking general officers that henceforth the Air Force would treat reports of the disks with "adequate but not frantic" attention.
The cotton market closed steady on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, with final prices on active months up 12 to 22 points net.

The Seaboard Air Line Railroad announced yesterday that it has called for redemption at par and accrued interest on Aug. 29, its $26,931,800 of general mortgage 4 1/2 per cent income bonds, series A, due on Jan. 1, 2016. The bonds are convertible at the rate of ten shares of common stock for each $1,000 bond and this privilege will expire at the close of business on the redemption date.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The existing Wage Stabilization Board, ordered out of office by a Congress irked by the manner in which it handled the steel wage dispute, held its last meeting today and disbanded. A new board, which it is reported will be headed by Archibald Cox, Harvard University professor and co-chairman of the Construction Industry Stabilization Commission, will start functioning tomorrow but with much more limited powers than the original board enjoyed.

DETROIT, July 29 (AP) -- The Tigers scored six runs in a fifth inning rally to edge the Athletics, 10 to 8, in the second game of a twilight-night double-header tonight. The Athletics won the first game, 5 -- 0.

Through the suburbs these days, through towns and villages the country over, commercial partnerships are flourishing. They are composed of two or more of the young, and they are engaged in that most pleasing and profitable form of agriculture, cutting grass.

LOS ANGELES, July 29 (AP) -- Berridge (Berri) Long, a 15-year-old high school girl from Huntington, W. Va., produced the biggest upset of the first round of the annual women's Western amateur golf tournament today by defeating the defending champion, Marjorie Lindsay, of Decatur, Ill.
The Veterans Administration was advised yesterday by Judge Saul S. Streit "not to put its head in the sand and hide behind a quirk in the law."

The Brewing Corporation of America, which has had a sales increase of 140 per cent since 1949, is planning an expansion program that is likely to increase competition, already at a high level, in this area.

CHICAGO, July 29 (UP) --A broadcasting company cannot be held liable for extemporaneous defamatory remarks made over the air by guest artists unless the person allegedly libeled can prove malice or negligence on the part of the station, a Federal judge ruled today.
Shipping in the North Atlantic and Pacific Oceans has been warned not to follow too closely on radio beacon signals transmitted by weather patrol ships because of the danger of collision.

CINCINNATI, July 29 -- The contract bridge team of Mrs. Olive Peterson, John R. Crawford, and Sidney Silodor, all of Philadelphia, with Mrs. Emma Jean Hawes of Forth Worth, and George Rapee of New York, this afternoon continued to lead a ninety-one-team field in the 1952 mixed team of four championship, first of five scheduled championship events in the twenty-sixth annual National Contract Bridge Championships.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 29 (AP) -- The United States boxing team won five of six bouts and sent three men into the third round of the Olympic competition tonight.

Three thousand pickets patrolled the garment district yesterday as the Cloak Joint Board of the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union, A. F. L., began its "war of extermination" against nonunion manufacturers in the women's coat and suit industry.

ST. LOUIS, July 29 (AP) -- The Browns won their sixth decision in seven games tonight as Starter Ned Garver and Earl Harrist pitched a 7-3 victory over the Senators. Garver, turning wild, left the game in the seventh.

TOKYO, Wednesday, July 30 -- The United Nations staff officers yesterday accused the Communists of willfully delaying the conference of colonels under way at Panmunjom to examine the text of a proposed armistice in the Korean war while the plenary sessions continued in adjournment after the Allied walkout last week.

HONG KONG, July 29 -- About 100 Chinese Communist civilian guards went on sitdown strikes at two police stations in Kowloon today in a protest against the Hong Kong Government's seizure of seventy-one disputed aircraft they were protecting for the Peiping regime at Kai Tak Airfield here.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- A list of nine persons it has proposed as members of the initial board of directors of the Washington Water Power Company, of Spokane, Wash., was filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today by the American Power and Light Company.

Private financing of the 241-mile Ohio Turnpike was consummated here yesterday as a nationwide investment banking syndicate turned over a check for $319,882,972 to the Ohio Turnpike Commission and got back, in return, an issue of $326,000,000 of serial bonds.
There's a real bit of news in children's fashions these days with the advent into this field of three well known designers of misses fashions, Sally Victor, Vera Maxwell and Philip Hulitar.

CHICAGO, July 29 -- Two full months still to go and the major league campaign already has seen five managerial shake-ups since opening day. If that isn't a record somebody has been tinkering with the book. Soon we'll be hearing venders at the ball parks shouting: "Scorecard, scorecard, can't tell who's the manager without a scorecard."
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The Government will support the price of this year's cotton crop at an average of 30.91 cents a pound, the Department of Agriculture announced today.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., July 29 -- Paul Kelly and Tucker Campbell of Sleepy Hollow turned in a 6-under-par 33, 31 -- 64 to win the Metropolitan Golf Association's best-ball one-day tournament at the Briar Hall Country Club course today.

This year has proved to be the year of great ships, the climax of a recent trend toward the planning of larger and larger vessels, particularly in the field of tankers and bulk-ore carriers, Walter L. Green, chairman of the board and president of the American Bureau of Shipping, said yesterday.

NEW CITY, N. Y., July 29 -- Permission to construct a 5,600,000,000-gallon reservoir in Clarkstown, N. Y., along the Hackensack River, has been granted by the New York State Water Power and Control Commission to the Spring Valley Waterworks and Supply Company.
TOKYO, Wednesday, July -- 30 (UP) -- Allied. infantrymen killed thirty Communists and wounded at least thirty more in two skirmishes on the sodden Korean battlefront yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 29 -- West Coast shipowners reached an agreement today, after a negotiating session of two and one-half hours, with representatives of the National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, A. F. L., calling for a wage increase of 5 per cent and for increased employer contributions to the union's welfare fund.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today ordered complete reargument of the long-pending Ogden (Utah) gateway freight rate case.
SANTIAGO, Chile, July 29 (UP) -- President Gabriel Gonzalez Videla named a new non-political Cabinet today in preparation for the Sept. 4 Presidential election.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Robert Humphreys, former political writer and magazine editor, has been appointed publicity director of the Republican National Committee, Arthur E. Summerfield, committee chairman, announced today.

Lee S. Crandall, who retires tomorrow as general curator of the New York Zoological Park in the Bronx, will come to the zoo on Friday morning with hopes that he can look at the animals and enjoy them just like anyone else.

Eastman Kodak Company announced yesterday that it will issue new "fair trade" agreements on much of its photographic supplies to dealers in forty-five states that permit "fair trading." The company had caused a minor sensation in the trade earlier in the year when it abandoned "fair trade."

In THE TIMES of July 24 Leslie Peat of the Society of Automotive Engineers and Thomas W. Ryan, New York State Director of Safety, denounced "inchworm" drivers for creating added perils of automobile accidents and also increasing traffic congestion. "Inchworm" drivers are motorists who creep up or sneak up into crosswalk areas while red lights are against them.

During the course of a four-week vacation, in which we indulged in only a moderate amount of shooting or fishing, we took a busman's holiday with two allegedly "long-range" varmint shooters, and after two days on the hill pastures we arrived at the conclusion that our previous convictions were sound.
The State of Delaware announced yesterday that it would receive bids Aug. 13 on issues of bonds totaling $15,987,000. The bonds will come due on Sept. 1 from 1953 to 1972.

The announcement by the city's Department of Public Works that the new $6,000,000 Rockaway Pollution Control Project will go into operation, with appropriate civic ceremonies, on Aug. 7 means that the last important step has been taken in long-range plans for purifying the waters of Jamaica Bay to make them available for recreational use.

Shareholders of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation were notified yesterday that it proposes to proceed with reorganization under the plan adopted Oct. 4, 1951, and complete it on or about Sept. 27, 1952.

JERUSALEM, July 29 -- Finance Minister Levi Eshkol today told the Knesset (Parliament) his proposed budget of 115,000,000 for development would combat both inflation and a threatened disastrous deflation.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 29 -- The arrest of 133 Negroes in East London and twenty-five in Boksburg yesterday raised the total arrested since the defiance campaign started June 26 to 1,452.

MEXICO CITY, July 29 -- Ambassador William O'Dwyer declared today that his United States citizenship was the "most precious thing in the world to me." In sulphuric language, he denounced an American reporter who had written that the Ambassador was considering assuming Mexican citizenship.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today barred interstate shipment of hogs and their meat products from California and parts of fifteen other states. The action was aimed at control and eventual eradication of vesicular exanthema, a relatively new disease of hogs.

Stockholders of Remington Rand, Inc., at their meeting in Buffalo yesterday approved a 4,000,000-share increase in the authorized common stock to 10,000,000 from 6,000,000 shares at 50 cents par value. There are outstanding 5,041,774 common shares. The company said that directors had no present intention, of issuing any additional shares.

The General Motors Corporation earned $269,048,085, or $3.01 a common share, in the first half of this year. This represented a drop of $11,535,049 from the $280,583,134 net profit, or $3.13 a share, recorded for the corresponding six months of 1951.

It has been shown again and again that, upon the whole, strikes have cost vastly more than the benefits gained. Wage-earners should demand a more reasonable, constructive method of settling labor disputes. The millions who unavoidably are vitally injured demand release from the devastating effect of strikes.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 29 -- Col. Francis Gabreski, 33-year-old Army Air Force hero of two wars, will soon be a hero also on the screen. After conferences during the past week between the flying ace, who recently returned from Korea, and President Herbert J. Yates of Republic Productions, Inc., it was announced today at the studio that Republic will make a film under the title of "The Gabreski Story."

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- An Interstate Commerce Commission Examiner, Burton Fuller, recommended today slightly higher rates on interstate commuter trips of from five to twelve miles in the metropolitan areas of New York, Philadelphia, Harrisburg, Pittsburgh and Chicago.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- A split developed today on the method of bringing Japan into the program of the Western powers to control shipments of strategic materials to countries under Soviet domination.
Expert advice from Sanitation Commissioner Andrew W. Mulrain on how to combat street littering apparently is as much in demand in the British House of Commons as in New York's City Council.

The governing body of the American Federation of Labor has made a wise decision in voting to accept appointment on the new Wage Stabilization Board, even though Congress has stripped the Board of its authority to handle disputes and limited it to administering wage-stabilization policy.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., July 29 -- Shooting a one-over-par 38, 36 -- 74, Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of Century led home a field of forty-eight players to win low gross honors in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association tournament for Class A competitors at the Pelham Country Club today.

BOSTON, July 29 -- Paul A. Dever, the incumbent Democrat, and Representative Christian A. Herter, Republican, were unopposed as rival candidates for Governor at the deadline for filing for the state primaries on Sept. 16. Governor Dever is seeking a third term.

HAMILTON, N. Y., July 29 -- Alexander Kerensky, former Prime Minister of the 1917 Russian provisional government, today attacked the Yugoslav regime of Marshal Tito as just as dangerous to free democratic institutions as Stalinist communism.

Uncertainty as to what action will be taken on Tariff Commission recommendations for higher import duties on Swiss watches and watch movements, now awaiting a decision by President Truman, is beginning to disrupt plans of manufacturers, wholesalers and retailers for production and sales later this year.
RICHMOND, Va., July 29 (AP) -- The independent Richmond News Leader today endorsed the Eisenhower-Nixon ticket.

LONDON, July 29 -- The waistline was the chief concern at yesterday's autumn dress shows in London. High in front and curved down to its natural place at the back, the waistline's effect is a dual silhouette.

Fire Commissioner Jacob Grumet began yesterday a personal inspection of the city's firehouses that will embrace ultimately all of the fifty - two companies throughout the city recommended for elimination by consultants to the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Interstate commerce in alcoholic beverages is being seriously hindered by a network of trade barriers set up under the guise of alcoholic beverage control measures, it was charged in a report today by the Joint Committee of the States to Study Alcoholic Beverage Laws.

Britain's Conservative Government, which made a campaign pledge to denationalize the steel industry, hopes to introduce a bill for that purpose during the autumn session of Parliament and to enact it before Easter. However, it now concedes that "it may well take some years" to carry out the program of restoring to the industry the status of private enterprise.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 29 (AP) -- The United States and Argentina emerged tonight as the class of the Olympic basketball tournament and almost certain contenders in the gold medal game scheduled for Saturday afternoon.

CHICAGO, July 29 -- With campaign time running out the Illinois Democratic organization appeared tonight on the verge of an intra-party battle over its choice for a successor to Adlai E. Stevenson as the party's candidate for Governor in November.

The fourteen-month-old private American organization seeking to help Asians of eleven free countries from Japan to Pakistan protect their freedom and keep out Communist imperialism has rallied a staff of 180 persons. Planned costs have gone into "seven figures," Alan Valentine, president of the group, the Committee for a Free Asia, said yesterday.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 29 -- In a debate in which Premier Mohammed Mossadegh received a unanimous vote of confidence from Parliament, Deputies and galleries applauded today as demand by Mohammed Damavandi, National Front Deputy, that all United States military advisers leave Iran.

GRASSY POINT, N. Y., July 29 -- The first of three huge concrete caissons that will form the foundation of a new Pier 57 in Manhattan started a thirty-eight-mile journey down the Hudson River today as six ocean-going tugboats eased it into the channel from a natural drydock in an abandoned clay quarry here.

Now that his well-earned vacation is behind him General Eisenhower is plunging into the heavy work of drafting the detailed plans for his Presidential campaign. Although there will be little speechmaking during the dog-days there will be a great deal of thought devoted to the strategy and tactics to be followed during the crucial weeks of September and October.

CAIRO, July 29 -- Gen. Mohammed Naguib Bey, Commander in Chief of the Egyptian armed forces, and Premier Aly Maher Pasha conferred for more than three hours tonight, but apparently did not reach any definite decisions about how to get on with Egypt's renovation.

A pledge to wage a "broad, aggressive attack" on the twin evils of traffic accidents and traffic congestion was made yesterday at a meeting that marked the formal organization of the Citizens Traffic Safety Board.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 29 -- The supposition that the return of Japan to the Olympics constituted a serious threat to the United States' swimming supremacy seemed hardly tenable tonight after the Americans had won their third gold medal and qualified all three 400-meter men for the final.

TRENTON, July 29 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll agreed today with thousands of motorists who use the New Jersey Turnpike that the pigs of Secaucus are a poor advertisement for the state. The smell causes many motorists to hold their noses as they drive out of the Midtown Tunnel from New York and cross the New Jersey Meadows near Secaucus.
Mrs. Walter J. Monaghan's month-long challenge to the authority of Brooklyn's legal agencies came to an end yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Diplomatic observers here were about resigned today to a long, unpleasant siege of anti-Americanism in Iran.

CLEVELAND, July 29 (AP) -- Early Wynn struck out a dozen Red Sox batters tonight, a season high for Cleveland pitchers, as he hurled the Tribe to a 4-1 victory that increased the Indians' hold on second place to a game and a half. Luke Easter clubbed a game-tying homer and Dale Mitchell a two-run single to pace the winners' attack.
A 40-year-old merchant seaman stabbed his 8-year-old niece fatally, slashed her sister, 12, and then killed himself as he fled the police last night from the family grocery store in the Bronx.

The American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corporation achieved the second highest sales for any first half year period, but earnings for the initial six months this year dropped $7,013,680 from the corresponding period of 1951.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., July 29 -- Peggy Mackie of the Inwood Club fired a 38, 39 -- 77 to win the low gross prize during the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association Class A one-day tournament at the Creek Club today.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- An Army program to reclaim billions of dollars' worth of abandoned World War II equipment in the Pacific area is paying extra dividends in the Korean conflict.

BERLIN, July 29 -- Frank L. Howley, former United States commandant in Berlin, said today that the United States should abandon its "containment" policy toward Communism and "think of liberating the people of Eastern Europe."

Consolidated net income and operating revenues of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended June 30, last, increased 4 1/2 per cent and 4 per cent, respectively, above the volume attained in the preceding twelve months.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 29 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois started working on his Presidential campaign today from scratch- -- minus.

Activity on the second day of the annual music industry trade show under the auspices of the National Association of Music Merchants in the New Yorker Hotel indicated strongly yesterday that musical instrument manufacturers and retailers would have clear sailing for the rest of the year.

BOSTON, July 29 (AP) -- The Cardinals continued their blistering National League pace by topping the Braves, 6 -- 5, tonight in a thirteen-inning game. The Cards bunched two hits with a sacrifice, a base on balls and a Boston error for their winning marker against Lew Burdette, relief pitcher.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- One-fourth of the non-whites in the United States live in fourteen big cities, the Census Bureau reported today.
William A. Bittel Jr. has been appointed vice president and general sales manager of the Charles B. Knox Gelatine Company, Johnstown, N. J.
CHICAGO, July 29 -- The Yankees seemed to be heading full-tilt into serious trouble tonight when they touched off an explosion that floored the White Sox and stunned a gathering of 38,967.

An underwriting syndicate headed by Granbery, Marache Co. and Burnham Co. will place on the market today a new issue of $1,500,000 of 5 per cent sinking fund debentures of Toklan Royalty Corporation, an oil and natural gas enterprise with leasehold and royalty interests in the Southwest and Middle West.

PHILADELPHIA, July 29 (AP) -- A ninth-inning single by Johnny Wyrostek with the bases filled and two out enabled the Phillies to gain a 4-to-3 victory tonight over the Reds in the second game of a twilight-night double-header. The Phillies won the opener, 6 to 1, behind the seven-hit pitching of southpaw Curt Simmons.

CHICAGO, July 29 -- The general tone of all grains was easy early in today's session but there was a good recovery in corn futures on reports of dry conditions and high temperatures in various areas, especially in the Southwest. There were reports of rust spread in southern Saskatchewan and southern Manitoba and of rather severe frosts in northeastern Saskatchewan, but these developments failed to increase buying much here.

BAKERSFIELD, Calif., July 29 (AP) -- Sharp jolts continued to rock this quake-weary city today after early-hour tremors caused considerable minor damage and drove hundreds of families from their homes.

CAPRI, Italy, July 29 -- Former King Farouk of Egypt, who abdicated Saturday after a military uprising, landed shortly before 7 o'clock this evening on this island, which he and his wife, Narriman, had visited under happier circumstances on their honeymoon last year.

B. G. Gokhale has surely missed the main point of your editorial of July 18 on Kashmir. India, Pakistan and the United Nations are parties to an international agreement according to which "the question of the accession of the State of Jammu and Kashmir will be decided through the democratic methods of a free and impartial plebiscite."
For making contributions to a Red Cross bloodmobile unit, 122 inmates of Queens City Prison in Long Island City were treated yesterday to ice cream, milk and soda. Later they had

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Halsey Stuart Co., investment banking house of Chicago, and the Federation for Railway Progress are before the Interstate Commerce Commission with statements opposing requests by two railroads for two exemptions from the I. C. C. requirement that competitive bids be taken on railroad security issues.
CHICAGO, July 29 -- The Yankees seemed to be heading full-tilt into serious trouble tonight when they touched off an explosion that floored the White Sox and stunned a gathering of 38,967.

An underwriting syndicate headed by Granbery, Marache Co. and Burnham Co. will place on the market today a new issue of $1,500,000 of 5 per cent sinking fund debentures of Toklan Royalty Corporation, an oil and natural gas enterprise with leasehold and royalty interests in the Southwest and Middle West.

PHILADELPHIA, July 29 (AP) -- A ninth-inning single by Johnny Wyrostek with the bases filled and two out enabled the Phillies to gain a 4-to-3 victory tonight over the Reds in the second game of a twilight-night double-header. The Phillies won the opener, 6 to 1, behind the seven-hit pitching of southpaw Curt Simmons.

CHICAGO, July 29 -- The general tone of all grains was easy early in today's session but there was a good recovery in corn futures on reports of dry conditions and high temperatures in various areas, especially in the Southwest. There were reports of rust spread in southern Saskatchewan and southern Manitoba and of rather severe frosts in northeastern Saskatchewan, but these developments failed to increase buying much here.

BAKERSFIELD, Calif., July 29 (AP) -- Sharp jolts continued to rock this quake-weary city today after early-hour tremors caused considerable minor damage and drove hundreds of families from their homes.

CAPRI, Italy, July 29 -- Former King Farouk of Egypt, who abdicated Saturday after a military uprising, landed shortly before 7 o'clock this evening on this island, which he and his wife, Narriman, had visited under happier circumstances on their honeymoon last year.

DENVER, July 29 -- Senator Hugh Butler of Nebraska, a leading backer of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio in the Republican pre-convention campaign, assured Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower today of 100 per cent backing in Nebraska's Republican ranks. He said the state would strive in November to continue its claim as "the most Republican state in the Union."

TOKYO, Thursday, July 31 -- United States Superforts from Japan and Okinawa last night and early today blasted a big aluminum plant of the Communists at Yangsi in North Korea on the Yalu River estuary. The B-29's flew within a few miles of the Manchurian border in the greatest air strike of the Korean war against a single military target.

A modern marine precedent was established here yesterday as the new French luxury liner Flandre made her debut in tow. Anchored, and almost helpless after a power failure, the gallant ship was forced to remain off Staten Island for six hours before sufficient power could be restored to raise her big anchor chain.

LONDON, July 30 -- A sharp increase in telegraph and cable rates from Britain to all other countries because of rising costs was announced today in the House of Commons by L. D. Gammans, Assistant Postmaster General. The new rates will go into effect Sept. 1 and will be the first general rise in charges in twenty-five years.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Senator Burnet P. Maybank hinted tonight there might be an all-out fight at the South Carolina Democratic Convention next Wednesday over whether to make Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower or Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson the official Democratic Presidential candidate in South Carolina.

SOME minor changes, most of them involving season dates, were apparent in the 1952 hunting regulations for rails, gallinules and sea ducks. The rules have been announced by the Department of Interior, but no hint was forthcoming as to the waterfowl and woodcock regulations, which will be issued late in August.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 30 -- Patricia (Pat) Hinman, 19-year-old daughter of Commodore George Hinman, past president of the Yacht Racing Association and an international skipper of note, won the women's sailing championship of Long Island Sound today.

In the sketch of the life and background of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson in your issue of July 26 it is stated that Mr. Stevenson is a Presbyterian. This is an error. Although Mr. Stevenson's father was a Democrat and Presbyterian, his mother was a Republican and Unitarian, and the Governor has stated that he took his father's politics and his mother's religion.

It is a sad commentary on the present state of public feeling that the New York State Bar Association deemed it necessary to declare by formal resolution that since it is the right of every person accused of crime to counsel of his own choosing such counsel should not be subject to adverse and hostile criticism for accepting the retainer.
The violation of the safety of Crosswalks at street intersections by impatient and irresponsible motorists is a peril and an affront to pedestrians.

A plan for the diagnosis and treatment of mild and nonparalytic forms of poliomyelitis patients at home was advanced yesterday at a symposium for 150 physicians and nurses arranged at the New York Academy of Medicine by the New York chapter of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis

OTTAWA, July 30 (Canadian Press) -- Canada rolled up a $109,800,000 foreign-trade surplus in the first five months of the year, a sharp reversal of the trend toward a heavy deficit a year ago, according to the Bureau of Statistics.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Arthur E. Summerfield, new chairman of the Republican National Committee, carried through today on the shake-up at Republican National Headquarters that had been expected since the nomination of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Presidency.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., July 30 -- The $45,000,000 Chesapeake Bay Bridge, which links Maryland's isolated Eastern Shore with the "mainland" was dedicated today in a four-hour ceremony in sweltering heat.

OAKLAND, Calif., July 30 -- A de luxe private plane, with revolving throne and an oversized bed, is being prepared for King Ibn Saud of Saudi Arabia by Transocean Airport Lines at Oakland's Municipal Airport.
Most commodities drifted a little lower yesterday in a day of light trading.

The One Four Six Horace Harding Corporation bought for improvement with a taxpayer a plot of 26,000 square feet at the northeast corner of Horace Harding Boulevard and 146th Street, Flushing, Queens, from Ely Maran. John D. Connaughton was the broker.
The steel shortage left by the nation's worst steel strike will keep the Army's biggest shell-making plant shut for three more weeks, defense officials reported yesterday.

BERLIN, July 30 -- The West Berlin Government and the Federal Republic today moved to speed the airlift to West Germany of refugees streaming into this city from East Germany at a daily increasing rate. The total for this month has already reached a record of almost 12,000.

The Public Housing Administration announced yesterday that 1.05 per cent would be the maximum interest cost permitted at today's sale of $165,865,000 of temporary loan notes of thirty local housing authorities. No bid exceeding an interest cost of 1.05 per cent will be accepted, it was said.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 30 -- America's county prosecutors gathered here today to map lines of attack on organized crime. More than 100 met for the annual convention of the National Association of County and Prosecuting Attorneys.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The heads of various coal industry associations expressed certainty today that John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America, and Harry M. Moses, head of the Bituminous Coal Operators Association, had begun conversations on negotiations over a new contract.

CHICAGO, July 30 -- Reports indicating serious deterioration in corn and oats prospects in many parts of the country started a brisk upturn in new crop corn deliveries after an easy turn in the market early. Current advices show a splendid outlook for corn in the heart of the belt, but in the Southwest, through Tennessee and Kentucky and in the Southeast, the prospect for all cereal crops is poor.
LONDON, July 30 (Reuters) -- Surrey lost three wickets for 28 runs today against Derbyshire. Surrey opened its innings confidently after dismissing the opposing team for 214 runs.

Surrounded by a detective acting as a blind musician and carrying a mandolin under his right arm, another detective acting a drunkard and a third detective playing the role of an innocent working man, an alleged narcotics peddler was arrested at 10:30 o'clock last night under dramatic circumstances on the Triborough Bridge near First Avenue.

UNITED NATIONS; N. Y., July 30 -- United Nations staff experts are working on a report outlining possible ways of forming a United Nations legion, an idea that is not being met with much enthusiasm by most powers.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 30 -- Sir Gladwyn Jebb of Britain served notice today one the Economic and Social Council of the United Nations that, so far as the non-self-governing peoples for which London is responsible are concerned, his Government would ignore any General Assembly recommendation that plebiscites on independence be held among such peoples on demand.

CINCINNATI, July 30 -- The 1952 mixed team of four championship went this afternoon to the contract bridge team of Mrs. Robert Burnstein and Harry Harkavy, Miami Beach; Mrs. Edith Seligman, New York, and Alvin Roth, Washington.

As a psychiatrist who has been working for more than thirty years in different psychiatric hospitals in Europe and in this country, I want to reply to the statement of Judge Saul S. Streit. The Judge holds the negligence of officials responsible for the murder of Eileen Fahey, a secretary, on the Columbia University campus.

Real Brother was admired by a comparative handful of the 19,429 fans at the Jamaica race track yesterday, but those who liked the colt enjoyed the thrill of seeing him take the $10,000 added Albany, the six-furlong event that occupied the feature spot

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 30 (AP) -- A United States District Court judge today acquitted two conscientious objectors on the ground that their constitutional rights were violated by reports of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

WHITEVILLE, N. C., July 30 -- Thomas L. Hamilton, Imperial Wizard of the Carolinas' Ku Klux Klan, received today the maximum sentence of four years in prison for conspiring to flog a Columbus County Negro woman.
DETROIT, July 30 -- The Republican party has mapped a campaign to raise $4,800,000 for the campaign, Arthur E. Summerfield, National Republican Chairman announced tonight.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, July 30 -- The appointment of Admiral Earl Mountbatten of Burma, former Viceroy of India and the present Commander in Chief of the British Mediterranean Fleet, as commander of all Allied naval forces in the Mediterranean -- including the mighty United States Sixth Fleet -- would be acceptable to the United States Government, according to a high authority.
DENVER, July 30--Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower has decided to "run scared" for the Presidency, relying upon regular Republican party organizations to back up his personal popularity with...

Giving notice that the Winnipeg Grain Exchange will be closed on Saturday, Aug. 2, and on Monday, Aug. 4, which is a civic holiday in Ontario, the governors of the organization announced yesterday that they will take up the question of year-round Saturday closings at their next meeting, Aug. 6.

A new edition of "Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, a Portrait," by Noel F. Busch, is being rushed to press by Farrar, Straus Young, who originally published the book on June 20. It is the only biography of the Governor of Illinois. With his nomination as the Democratic candidate for President, the publisher's first edition was completely sold out and as of noon Monday there still were orders for 1,300 copies.
MUNSAN, Korea, Thursday, July 31 (AP) -- Gen. James A. Van Fleet says there is "less chance for an armistice than ever before."
Miriam Hopkins and Peter Lorre will be co-starred in "A Night at Mme. Tussaud's," a new thriller by Edwin Justus Mayer, to be presented here this season by Ben Kranz.

TOKYO, Thursday, July 31 (UP) -- Hironoshin Furuhashi's failure to score in the 400-meter free-style swim at the Olympic Games today was blamed by his father upon "too much iron" in the family drinking water.

The sensible man would be hard put to take exception to the general tenor of the editorial of July 23 on Japan's trade position. However, one sentence is subject to an interpretation which is at odds with sound economics. It reads: "What is required is to assure that [Japanese] competition will be based on skills and qualities and not merely on differentials in the standard of living."

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 30 -- Brazil's complicated import restrictions, designed to protect home industries and conserve the scanty supply of dollars, have completely upset the workings of the international parcels post system, as far as Brazil is concerned. More than 30,000 parcels are estimated to be piled up here awaiting return to the senders.
LEXINGTON, Ky., July 30 (AP) -- A dark bay yearling son of Alibhai and Miss Dogwood was sold today for $58,000 at the thoroughbred auction at Keeneland.

With practically no advance fanfare a new French ship, the Flandre, docked in New York yesterday at the end of her maiden voyage. The debutantes of the seas are always sure of a noisy greeting in this port, and this sleek and graceful liner was especially welcome as another proof that France is rapidly regaining her old eminence in luxury transport.

The nation's stocks of gasoline increased 905,000 barrels last week, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. At the week-end they amounted to 118,285,000 barrels, compared with 117,380,000 a week earlier and 130,518,000 a year ago.

LAUREL, Md., July 30 (UP) -- Laurel race track officials announced today that thoroughbreds from at least six countries will take part in a $50,000 international race on Oct. 18 during the Laurel fall meeting.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- The United States is preparing to tell the Government of Generalissimo Francisco Franco in Spain that its price for American use of air and naval bases on Spanish territory must be drastically reduced if agreement is to be reached.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 30 -- The players of the New Jersey Women's Golf Association maintained their record of superiority over those of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield County Golf Association in the annual team matches for the Mrs. J. J. Thomason Trophy today at the Bonnie Briar Country Club.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- Nine types of small business enterprises have been put under wage controls by Economic Stabilizer Roger L. Putnam.

LOS ANGELES, July 30 (AP) -- Four down with four holes to play in a scheduled eighteen-hole match, 15-year-old Berri Long of Huntington, W. Va., today rallied to defeat Mrs. Lyle Bowman of Richmond, Calif., on the twenty-first hole in the second round of the women's Western amateur golf tournament.

PARIS, July 30 -- Subtly and with great elegance, Jacques Fath frees the silhouette of constraint, abandoning cinched waistlines and molded midriffs. He expresses this new ease principally in sweater bodices cut on the bias, in costumes for all hours.

PARIS, July 30 -- France will make every effort to apply a home rule reform program in its protectorate of Tunisia before the opening of the next United Nations General Assembly in October despite the demand of the country's ruler for a two or three months' delay, a French spokesman said today.

Jackie Robinson was right all along. It had been his contention that the Dodgers needed most of all the return of Roy Campanella. "Never mind me, Billy Cox or any of the other cripples," the star second-baseman said. "When Campy gets back the club will straighten out."

LONDON, July 30 -- Prime Minister Churchill announced in the House of Commons today that the Conservative Government was once more "reshaping" the rearmament program that it inherited from its Labor predecessors.

Dr. Harold Lenz said yesterday that he had appealed his transfer from the post of Dean of Students at Queens College to a teaching position in its German Department. The appeal was submitted to Dr. John Theobald, president of the college. Dr. Lenz said Dr. Theobald had referred the appeal to the college administrative committee.

A 200-ton stator, the stationary part of an electric generator, arrived in Jersey City on schedule yesterday, largely because the founder of the Erie Railroad insisted 100 years ago on a six-foot gauge for his tracks (later converted to the standard gauge of four feet, eight and one-half inches) and cut his tunnels to fit.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended July 23, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:
HOUSTON, Tex., July 30 (UP) -- Glenn H. McCarthy, Texas oil and hotel multimillionaire, was sued for $1,000,000 today by Dresser Industries, Inc., of Dallas.

CHICAGO, July 30 -- Vincent Hallinan of San Francisco, Presidential candidate of the left wing Progressive party, is scheduled to make his first Chicago campaign speech Sept. 6, the party's state director, James Wishart, said today.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- Top price officials asserted today that even though living costs were at a record high, there was every indication that prices in many fields would be heading upward soon.

The United States Rubber Company increased its net sales by 3.7 per cent to a record $443,491,316 in the first six months of 1952, but its earnings declined 21 per cent, H. E. Humphreys Jr., board chairman, reported yesterday.

RYE, N. Y., July 30 -- Two New York business executives and the wife of one were watching television in a large home in Greenhaven here just before last midnight when two armed burglars entered the house and took from the two men and the woman $12,000 in jewelry, $210 in cash and an automobile.

Production of paperboard in Canada in the first half of 1952 was 346,297 tons ,or 9 per cent, below the 1951 half, and 1 per cent below the 1950 period, it was announced in Montreal yesterday by the Canadian Pulp and Paper Association.

JERSEY CITY, July 30 -- Henry Krajewski, Secaucus pig farmer and self-styled "poor man's" candidate for President of the United States told Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll today to stop picking on hardworking pig farmers.

MOSCOW, July 30 -- Under the headline "Inglorious End of Magazine Amerika," the Soviet press revealed to its readers today that the United States had suspended its Russian - language periodical prepared for distribution in the Soviet Union and had simultaneously ended the circulation of information bulletins by the Soviet Embassy in Washington.

BONN, Germany, July 30 -- The Federal Constitutional Court checked today the Socialist campaign to delay through court action the ratification of the treaty system binding a rearmed Germany to Western Europe.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson announced today that the United States delegation would leave Friday morning for a five-day conference in Honolulu with Australia and New Zealand on the creation of an organization to unify the political and military efforts of the three countries in the Pacific area.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The steel strike, which ended last Saturday, drove industrial production in the country to the lowest level since the outbreak of the Korean war, the Federal Reserve Board reported today in its monthly summary of business conditions.

Today's new film is "Ivanhoe," Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer's Technicolor adaptation of the Sir Walter Scott novel, filmed in England with Robert Taylor, in the title role, Elizabeth Taylor, Joan Fontaine and George Sanders heading the cast, at the Radio City Music Hall.

The Aluminum Company of America, the nation's largest producer of aluminum, reported yesterday for the first half of this year consolidated net income of $22,688,570 after providing $33,665,000 for income and excess profits taxes.
ROME, July 30 -- Aurora Battilocchi, whose first showing for American buyers last spring was a marked success, is now presenting her first original fall and winter collection for the foreign market.

ALBANY, N. Y., July 30 -- The distribution of the first monthly payments under a $3,000,000 emergency fund authorized by the 1952 Legislature to provide cost-of-living increases for retired state and municipal employes and public school teachers was announced today by J. Raymond McGovern, State Comptroller.

Youngsters between 6 and 8 years old are almost forgotten so far as day-care plans are concerned, a study released yesterday by the New York Jewish Child Care Council indicates. Although facilities for wholesome supervision for children of working mothers are inadequate throughout the city for all age groups, according to Herbert Polskin, assistant executive director, the situation of the 6-to-8 group is especially difficult.

WIESBADEN, Germany, July 30 (AP) -- A United States Air Force colonel's wife, once the social leader of this military community, was convicted today on five charges of dealing in currency, coffee and gasoline coupons on the German black market and was fined $3,982.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 30 -- The Malan Government struck at the non-white campaign of passive resistance against "unjust laws" today with police raids on the offices of the African National Congress, which represents the Negroes, the Indian Congress and the National Action Committee, and of non-white trade unions, and on the homes of officials of these organizations throughout the Union.
WASHINGTON, July 30--The Radio - Television Manufacturers Association asked the Office of Price Stabilization today to lift all price ceilings on televison and radio sets and parts.

HONG KONG, July 30 -- Portuguese Macao, which lies fifty miles west-southwest of here as a tiny colonial knob on one of Communist China's southern doors, was bloodied again last night and today in a new series of border clashes between its outnumbered garrison and Chinese Communist troops.

CHICAGO, July 30 -- Mindful of the fact that a lot of folks missed last night's fireworks because they left the park before the ninth inning seven-run explosion, the Yankees made a noble effort to repeat the performance today for the edification of a gathering of 15,103, who this time stuck to the end.

LONDON, July 30 -- The stock markets expressed today their relief at the moderate tone of Chancellor R. A. Butler's statement on economic affairs with an early rise of prices. However, business remained well below the levels that prevailed just before Prime Minister Winston Churchill announced two weeks ago that grave economic measures would have to be taken.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- Announced United States battle casualties in Korea reached 113,688 today, an increase of 305 since last week.

BOSTON, July 30 (AP)--New England is in the grip of a month-long, multi-million-dollar drought that is killing crops and parching pastures and has caused Massachusetts to seek to be declared a disaster area.

CAIRO, July 30 -- Premier Aly Maher, a Pasha, announced after tonight's Cabinet meeting that the Egyptian Government had decided to abolish all civil ranks, notably those of Pasha and Bey, but that it would retain other distinctions, such as decorations and medals.
Current and pending developments in atomic weapons, jet aircraft and guided missiles are forcing a reassessment of future defense programs.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 30 -- George Jessel, who recently ended his association as a producer with Twentieth Century-Fox with plans make pictures on his own, will begin his career as an independent film maker with a musical extravaganza starring Jimmy Durante, according to word from his office here today.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- An expansion program calling for $300,000,000 worth of new terminal and road facilities for American railroads by January, 1954, has been drawn up and approved by the Defense Production Administration.
KALAMAZOO, Mich., July 30 (AP) --Francisco Contreras, the top-seeded foreign entry, came up against his strongest opposition yet in the national junior tennis tournament today and survived.
SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 30 (UP) -- The foreign seeded list was reduced further today as quarter-final brackets were filled in the Meadow Club invitation tennis tournament.

The Cloak Joint Board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A. F. L., reported its first gains yesterday in its effort to sign up nonunion manufacturers in the women's coat and suit industry.

NEW ORLEANS, July 30 (AP) -- The Times-Picayune Publishing Company appealed to the United States Supreme Court today a Federal District Court decision holding that the newspaper organization had violated the antitrust laws.

Taking his defeat for the Democratic nomination for President philosophically, Averell Harriman is back at his summer home at Sands Point, L. I., with no hard feelings against anybody and ready to campaign for Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, the party's nominee.

TOKYO, Thursday, July 31 -- Communist staff officers at Panmunjom yesterday proposed a change in the conditions for the international conference on Korean questions that the armistice delegations tentatively had agreed to recommend to their Governments after a cease-fire on the warring peninsula.

MANILA, July 30 -- Secretary of Defense Ramon Magsaysay will be flown to Jolo Island tomorrow to launch a campaign against Moro bandits and pirates who have become the Philippines' latest threat to peace and order, second only to Communist-inspired Hukbalahaps.

BOSTON, July 30 (AP) -- Rookie Ed Mathews' seventeenth homer of the season, with Johnny Logan on base in the fourth inning, tonight enabled the Braves to snap the Cardinals' five-game winning streak with a 2-1 decision. One of the seven St. Louis hits against Lefty Warren Spahn was Stan Musial's fourteenth homer in the sixth inning.

After rallying for four runs to defeat the Cubs, 10 -- 6, the Giants bowed to the Chicagoans, 6 -- 2, in the afterpiece of a twilight-night double-header that attracted 15,425 fans to the Polo Grounds last night. As a result of the split the New Yorkers fell four and a half games behind the league-leading Dodgers.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 30 (AP) -- The United States sent four more boxers into the quarter-finals of the Olympic tournament tonight but lost two others to end a long, double-barrelled session all even with the power-punching Russian squad.

The Bankers Securities Corporation has been notified by the Securities and Exchange Commission that it has ceased to be considered an investment company but one engaged in the mercantile and real estate business. The company had applied for reclassification.
Eighty-six-year-old James Pollack does not like dimes. That's why he appeared in Bronx Magistrate's Court yesterday.

A number of times during the past year or more the State Department has withheld passports from American citizens in what has seemed to be an arbitrary manner. No thoughtful person would deny that under certain circumstances the department has the right to refuse the grant of a passport, which is a formal guaranty of the protection of the United States Government in foreign lands.
NEW ORLEANS, July 30 (AP) -- Five United States Representatives with opposition were renominated for new terms by Louisiana Democrats, but one may face a squabble.

HAMILTON, N. Y., July 30 -- Yugoslavia's representative at the fourth annual Colgate University Conference on American Foreign Policy charged today that Alexander Kerensky had used the meeting "to mislead the American public" and destroy relations between the Tito Government and the United States.

A fancy night club in a tent planned for the thousand members of the Breezy Point Surf Club, exclusive cabana and beach resort at the western end of the Rockaway Peninsula, has been put out of business abruptly by the Police and Fire Departments as in violation of too many city ordinances.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 30 (AP) -- Gov. Sid McMath, who is seeking a third term, and Chancellor Francis Cherry, a country judge who stirred Arkansas with his unique political tactics squared off today for the Democratic Gubernatorial nomination.

CHICAGO, July 30 (UP) -- Johnny Saxton, stunned when he was knocked down for the first time as a pro fighter, got off the canvas in the first round tonight and neatly punched out a unanimous ten-round decision over Virgil Akins in a Chicago Stadium bout.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 30 (AP) -- The United States pulled another Olympic surprise today by upsetting Belgium, 4 -- 2, in the semi-final round of the water polo competition.
ALBANY, July 30 -- The State Health Department reported today that new cases of poliomyelitis outside New York City dropped slightly last week, but are still somewhat ahead of the 1951 figures.

A new, white, wallet-sized library card is being introduced to the 1,000,000 members of the New York Public Library. It will replace the beige card that has been used by readers for more than forty years.
TOKYO, Thursday, July 31 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,327 for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Thursday, Korea time:

WESTBURY, L. I., July 30 (AP) -- Good Time, the biggest money winner in harness racing history, has another golden, opportunity to boost his earnings closer to the $300,000 mark tomorrow night in the $50,000 Nassau two-mile pace at Roosevelt Raceway.

Wamsutta Mills will use its trademark in a new range of products in the textile field, it was announced yesterday. The company, which makes high-count, nationally advertised sheets and other combed cotton goods, has established a new custom products division to carry out the expansion program.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 30 -- The United States suffered its first swimming defeat in two Olympics today in the men's 400-meter free-style, but gained its thirtieth gold medal of the games on the victory of Mrs. Pat Keller McCormick of Long Beach, Calif., in springboard diving.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- Reports of disastrous drought conditions in many parts of the country, coupled with appeals for aid, poured into Washington today.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 30 (AP) -- The schedule of events tomorrow in the Olympic Games (time is local, followed by New York time):

PHILADELPHIA, July 30 (UP) -- Willie Jones hit successive home runs in the seventh and eighth innings to lead the Phils to a 7-3 victory over the Reds tonight as Robin Roberts gained his sixteenth victory of the year.
