CLEVELAND, July 30 (AP) -- Bob Feller lost his fourth straight tonight as the Indians bowed to the Red Sox, 5 -- 4, but remained three games behind the league-leading Yankees.
An agent for the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals discovered last night that trouble, like charity, often begins at home.

TORONTO, July 30 -- After the International Red Cross Conference had been shocked this morning by a bitter and prolonged Communist denunciation of alleged germ warfare and mistreatment of prisoners in Korea, James T. Nicholson, executive Vice president of the American National Red Cross, warned that the Eastern bloc's conference tactics threatened to destroy the Red Cross.

" THEODORA and the Emperor,"* by Harold Lamb, is the spirited chronicle of a spectacularly difficult marriage. It is the story of Justinian and his Empress -- those Byzantine harbingers of the Middle Ages. The origins of Justinian were rough; the origins of Theodora were rougher. When you see what gaudy material Mr. Lamb had to work with, you may well wonder at the moderation with which he has cut his passages of imperial purple.

Grayson-Robinson Stores, Inc., approved at a special meeting yesterday a profit sharing and stock bonus plan for employes. Under it, contributions of the company and of employes will be paid into a trust fund for investment in property of all kinds, including the shares of the company, which operates a national chain of apparel stores.
The State Congress of Industrial Organizations set up a seventeen-man campaign committee yesterday to try to get out the labor vote in the November elections.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 30--Following are excerpts from the transcript of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson's press conference today:

Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane and associates will place on the market today an issue of $2,750,000 of 5 1/2 per cent fifteen-year subordinated convertible debentures of the Flying Tiger Line, Inc., air freight carrier.
Now that the steel strike has been settled, why not face up to the real issues involved?
HELSINKI, Finland, July 30 (AP) -- America marched undefeated into the final series of the Olympic basketball tournament today but it was a close squeak.

Seven life insurance companies have bought $37,500,000 of subordinated notes from the Associates Investment Company of South Bend, Ind., an automobile installment finance company, it announced yesterday. The transaction will add $15,000,000 to the company's capital and permit retirement of $22,500,000 of subordinated notes due this year.
In connection with that old saw about the French having many sauces and one religion and Americans many religions and one sauce, we have this to observe:
A group of American seamen will compete today to see who can go fastest and farthest with the most pull.

A 29-year-old private citizen's move for conciliation between Roman Catholics and Protestants in Colombia is receiving serious consideration by the Bogota Government, Dr. W. Stanley Rycroft, secretary for Latin America of the Board of Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A., said here yesterday.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 30 (AP) -- In one of the most stirring finishes of the Monmouth Park season. Mrs. M. W. O'Connor's La Corredora, moving rapidly on the outside in the stretch, scored her most important victory today by annexing the $20,000 added Monmouth Oaks before a crowd of 19,623.

BROWNSVILLE, Tex., July 30 (UP) -- Border patrolmen rounded up thousands of Mexican wetbacks today for shipment back across the Rio Grande, and immigration chiefs said charges might be filed against the Texas Cotton planters who hired them.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 30 -- Gen. Achmad Vossough, head of the Iranian Ministry of Defense under Premier Mohammed Mossadegh who holds the Defense portfolio, announced today that the Iranian defense budget would be cut.

STOCKHOLM, July 30 (AP) -- Four Olympic champions, three of them from the United States, won their specialties in the completion of Sweden's two-day track and field meet tonight before a capacity crowd of 20,000.

THE temporary tenant in this space has nothing more than a stray idea about who's going to win the sixth at Saratoga-on-the-L. I. R. R. today, but he does have a firm opinion about the identity of the most extraordinary first-class race horse in the land. The name is Tea-Maker. No arguments about this, please.

Alvin (Cliff) Steward, the Queens tavern owner who had testified in the departmental trial of thirty-four policemen accused of taking graft from Harry Gross, the bookmaker, was arraigned yesterday in Kings County Court as a material witness in Brooklyn's gambling inquiry.
HANOVER, Germany, July 30 (UP) -- A Hungarian Lutheran Bishop told a press conference here today that church representatives have complete freedom of speech in that satellite country.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 30 -- At precisely 2:43 New York time this afternoon Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois buried "Reluctant Adlai, the Humble Candidate," under an ash tree on the east lawn of the Governor's Mansion.

Shipping executives and public relations men were hosts yesterday at a luncheon for Walter H. Jones, advertising and publicity director of the United States Lines, in recognition of his part in promoting the superliner United States. The luncheon was held on the liner America at Pier 86, West Forty-sixth Street.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The Army released on request today parts of the diary of Maj. Gen. Robert W. Grow that appeared to show the Communist propagandists had deliberately distorted his writings to put the United States in the role of warmongering.

BOSTON, July 30 -- Judge Jesse W. Morton of the Massachusetts Superior Court declined today to dissolve a temporary injunction restraining members of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Chauffeurs, Warehousemen and Helpers, A. F. L., from interfering with the haulage of trailer trucks by the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad.

That big concrete caisson turned out to be a speedier craft than had been expected. The 13,550-ton structure arrived at West Fifteenth Street, where it will form the foundation for a new pierhead, at 2:30 A. M. yesterday, having covered thirty-eight miles down the Hudson River in thirteen and one-half hours instead of the estimated minimum of thirty hours.

Three hundred fifty shouting youngsters jammed a section of Corlears Hook Park at Delancey Street and the East River for two hours yesterday to participate in the annual "county fair day" of the East River Day Camp.

Outside of its celebration of the return of Rita Hayworth to the screen -- an occurrence almost as momentous as the birth of a new camel at the zoo -- there is little to endow with distinction that lady's and Columbia's new film, "Affair in Trinidad," which took its shoes off and settled down at the Victoria yesterday.
CHICAGO, July 30 (AP) -- Harry Dee of New City, N. Y., fired a 4-under-par 68 to lead twenty-six qualifiers from a field of 192 into tomorrow's $30,000 All-American golf tourney.

The defense in the conspiracy trial of fifteen secondary Communist leaders moved yesterday for a mistrial as a result of the release in Washington on Tuesday of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's summary of Communist party aims in the United States.

TRENTON, July 30 (UP) -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll said today he had no political plans but indicated that he would accept a call to higher duty if Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower won the Presidential election and his services were sought.

Restraints on the manufacture and sale of a plastic material used in making dentures have been removed nationally under an anti-trust consent judgment entered yesterday in Federal Court against Luxene, Ine. This was announced by C. Worth Rowley, head of the New York office of the anti-trust division of the Department of Justice.

PARIS, July 30 -- High officials indicated tonight that the French Government would place before the North Atlantic Council the problem facing France as a result of her failure to obtain a United States promise to provide $500,000,000 to $600,000,000 to finance French armament production over the next three years.

A Brooklyn Federal grand jury indicted six individuals and two corporations yesterday as participants in an alleged conspiracy to defraud the Government of thousands of dollars in the preparation of technical manuals used by military trainees. Pleading was set for Aug. 11.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- The Pullman Company today notified the Interstate Commerce Commission that its proposed higher minimum charges for sleeping-car accommodations would be made effective Friday. The change will be made without I. C. C. approval, which raises a possibility of refunds later if the increase is rejected by the commission.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- For the first time in more than twenty years the Treasury will pay 2 per cent interest in an exchange offering on two issues of one-year certificates totaling $2,415,648,000.
Animal lovers will be happy to learn that in case of an atomic attack on this city a branch of the Civil Defense organization is ready to rescue and care for their pets.

A former New York Telephone Company executive testified yesterday at the departmental trial of thirty-four suspended policemen that he had helped Harry Gross obtain "hundreds" of phones for himself and other bookmakers between 1942 and 1945 when business men had priority.

CEDARHURST, L. I., July 30 -- Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence H. Dixon of the Rockaway Hunt Club shot 31, 34 -- 65 to tie Mrs. J. B. Balding, Creek, and F. R. Ryan, Wheatley Hills, 32, 33 -- 65, in the Women's Long Island Golf Association best-ball tournament at Rockaway Hunt Club today.

The apple, in addition to supplying content and flavor for the community cupboard's pies and assisting in influencing teacher, is responsible for a good deal of advertising. Plans for the promotion of this year's harvest will be discussed at the annual convention of the International Apple Association, which begins in St. Louis on Monday.

John S. Jacox has been appointed manager of purchasing for the aviation gas turbine division of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, coordinating all purchasing activities. Wilbur C. Wilson has been named purchasing agent for the South Philadelphia plant and George A. Fadler purchasing agent at Kansas City.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and closed 18 points higher to 18 points lower than on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The possibility that France may be compelled by public opinion at home to abandon Indo-China to the Communists has been raised in negotiations with the United States Government for an extra $625,000,000 in defense contracts to help finance the French rearmament effort.

Marine operations conducted by the Bureau of Smoke Control during the last four weeks began to pay off yesterday as Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh, sitting in Municipal Term Court, Manhattan, assessed a total of $100 in fines against smoke violators spotted by the harbor patrol

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 30 -- Costly revisions in the New York-Buffalo Thruway route that the Yonkers Common Council and Planning Board - had advocated were rejected today in a 5,000-word report to the Westchester County Board of Supervisors by its Committee on Thruways. Minor changes were approved.

The eleven-story and penthouse apartment building at 740 Park Avenue, northwest corner of Seventy-first Street, has been purchased by Webb Knapp, Inc., from the 740 Park Avenue Corporation, it was announced yesterday.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development had a net income of $15,872,883 for the year ended June 30, compared with $15,156,947 for the preceding year. The net income was placed in the bank's general reserve fund, increasing the reserve to $58,028,100.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 30 -- President Truman today appointed fourteen of the eighteen members of the new Wage Stabilization Board, whose authority to intervene in wage disputes was curtailed by Congress as a result of the recently-settled steel dispute.
A pick-up in the steel division gave the stock market a new lease on life yesterday and, supported by the railroads, prices snapped back to the best levels since 1930.
CAMDEN, N. J., July 30 -- It has been established that you can't take it with you and 68-year-old Harry Ambruster of this city is not the man to challenge this doctrine.
OSLO, July 30 (UP) -- Missing 15 feet by an eyelash, Don Laz of Champaign, Ill., achieved the highest pole vault of the 1952 outdoor season in a special post-Olympic track and field meet tonight.
DETROIT, July 30 (UP)--Allie Clark hit a pair of two-run doubles to lift the Athletics to a 4-to-3 victory over the last-place Tigers today.

The long-awaited final decision on the leasing of the Government-owned piers in Hoboken, N. J., was delayed further yesterday when several objections were entered by civic leaders at a meeting in the office of Mayor Fred M. DeSapio.

It would appear to this lay observer that the Democratic party has maneuvered itself out of one dilemma only to create for itself another of no less magnitude. The party, as a political organization, may have achieved a kind of equilibrium -- albeit an uneasy one -- by the nomination of Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama for Vice President.

A vacant plot on the east side of Netherland Avenue, about 300 feet south of West 235th Street in the Riverdale section of the Bronx has been sold by Brakarsh Nussbaum to Harry and Samuel Lefrak, builders, who will erect a six-story apartment house on the site.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 30 (UP) -- For the first time since the Olympic Games opened. Russian officials today predicted that the Soviet would win the team championship.

A number of examples of a decorator's ingenuity are displayed, along with the new furniture and color schemes, in the series of model rooms that opened in several of the large department stores here in the last two weeks. Such decorator "tricks" might be imitated to some degree by homemakers who are their own decorators.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Max Conrad flew in from Europe today in the lightest plane ever to cross the Atlantic and promptly ran afoul of the Customs Office.

MEXICO CITY, July 30 -- Ambassador William O'Dwyer's angry denunciation of a correspondent from the United States, for sending a dispatch to the effect that Mr. O'Dwyer was considering taking Mexican citizenship, was outstanding news in the Mexican press today.

The much discussed early curtain on Monday nights, the pro and con of which has filled the air with considerable palaver, isn't a moot point any longer. Beginning Sept. 8, nearly all the current attractions and presumably the impending ones, will start their Monday night performances at 7 P.M., thus conforming to a general practise -- more or less.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The Atomic Energy Commission, in its twelfth semi-annual report, disclosed today new sources of raw materials that will support its accelerated expansion and development program. Congress has authorized more than $4,000,000,000 to cover the program in the current fiscal year.

The Standard Oil Company of California reported yesterday that for the six months ended June 30 it had a consolidated net income of $87,159,717, equal to $3.04 a share on the outstanding capital stock. This compares with $84,918,170, or $2.96 a share in the corresponding period of 1951.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- The Court of Military Appeals today ordered a new trial for a 20-year-old New Jersey soldier who was sentenced to ten years at hard labor for allegedly sleeping on sentry duty at the Korean war front.

Advising restaurateurs and hotel men on summer menus recently, Philippe of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel mentioned "assiettes anglaises," a term the French use to describe the dishes traditional in an English cold supper. His comments, although directed to professionals, include suggestions on foods for warm-weather dining, which may prove helpful to the home cook.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -The Air Force said today that it was getting so many "flying saucer" queries that regular intelligence work had been affected.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., July 31 -- Five young persons, three of them teen-agers, were arrested here early today on narcotics charges. Prosecutor's detectives and local police seized Alan Moore, 19 years old, of Clarence Street, Long Branch; Cora Maddox, 19, of 204 Eighth Avenue, West Belmar; Mary Napalitano, 18, of 410 Langford Street, Asbury Park; William R. Shropshire, 21, same address, and Joseph Sucarato, 26, of 348 East 110th Street, New York.

In a memorandum to Bernard J. Gillroy, Housing and Buildings Commissioner, an ex-officio member of the administrative Smoke Control Board, Rear Admiral William S. Maxwell, retired, acting director of the Bureau of Smoke Control, stressed yesterday the importance of enacting a pending City Council measure limiting incineration to daylight hours.

DETROIT, July 31 (AP) -- The sixth-place Athletics swept a double-header from the last-place Tigers today, taking the second game by 3 -- 2, after Bobby Shantz had recorded his nineteenth victory, 2 -- 1.

The "organization strike" against nonunion women's coat and suit manufacturers which was begun on Tuesday by the Cloak Joint Board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A. F. L., continued unabated yesterday as Rudolph Halley, President of the City Council, indicated he might try to help settle the dispute.

Sherry's Restaurant at 300 Park Avenue, which with its predecessor restaurants founded by the late Louis Sherry has conducted fashionable parties for several generations of New Yorkers, closed its doors yesterday.

BABYLON, L. I., July 31 -- When two contestants in the school election here took their dispute about which one should be seated on the Board of Education to the New York State Department of Education, the state group resolved the question -- it declared a third man the winner.

PRESTWICK, Scotland, July 31 -- Aviation history was made here today with the arrival of two United States military helicopters at the end of the first crossing of the Atlantic by rotary wing aircraft. Out of the S-55 Sikorsky helicopters stepped four young airmen, veterans of air-rescue operations in Korea, who had sat cramped in a confined space on the last stage of their Atlantic flight.

In a booklet just released jointly by the American Association of Advertising Agencies and the Association of National Advertisers, critics of the industry were attacked by the author, Otto Kleppner, head of the agency bearing his name.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, said today there was no schism between him and Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, the Democratic Presidential candidate, on the subject of national health insurance.

John Robilotto, a Greenwich Village undertaker, was turned over to New Jersey authorities yesterday to face a murder indictment after he had sought unsuccessfully to stay his extradition in a Brooklyn Supreme Court proceeding.

Robert Moses, City Construction Coordinator, appeared almost content yesterday while checking the results stemming from his insistent requests for steel allotments to meet the needs of critical arterial projects here.

LONDON, July 31 -- Government acoustic engineers have been spending a busy week in London checking the sound effects of the helicopters now hovering between the Houses of Parliament and the south bank of the Thames on trial flights for a projected municipal "gyro run" between the Thames Embankment and the principal airports on London's outskirts.

The International Red Cross is officially "guided by the basic principles of impartiality, neutrality and independence; it acts in the service of all who suffer, regardless of race, religion, nationality or political convictions; it remains neutral both in general policy and methods of giving relief." The quoted words are taken from material issued by the International Committee of the Red Cross, whose seat is at Geneva.

NORWALK, Conn., July 31 -- United States Senator Brien McMahon of Connecticut, who became intentionally known for his work as chairman of the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy, was buried at St. Mary's Cemetery this afternoon beside the grave of his father, William H. McMahon.

Commonwealth Edison Company and subsidiary companies cleared a consolidated net income of $30,225,526, equal to $2.10 a common share for the twelve months ended June 30, according to the report released yesterday by Charles Y. Freeman, president.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 31 -- Syed Amjad Ali, president of the United Nations Economic and Social Council, suggested today that plans be started now for accelerating aid to underdeveloped countries as promptly as the peak of the rearmament program is reached in the western world.
New financing in July showed a sharp contraction from the offerings here in recent months, but the total was the largest for any July in several years.
CINCINNATI, July 31 -- The 1952 men's pairs contract bridge championship was won early this morning by William Rosen, young Chicago University student and Art Grau of Ormond Beach, Fla.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Three youngsters from the sidewalks and tenements of East Harlem should be able to talk with authority to their schoolmates about freedom and democracy when they return home five weeks from now.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 31 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois started working today on his farm policy in the hope of carrying some of the Prairie States into the Democratic column in the November election.
BAKERSFIELD, Calif., July 31 (AP) -- Enduring two more damaging jolts today, residents of this quake-stricken area were heartened by the possibility of state financial aid to repair the damage.

Factory sweatshops where workers are compelled to toil long hours at starvation pay are almost a thing of the past. The chances are that your car, radio, television set and wearing apparel were made by men and women whose wages have advanced quite steadily in recent years and whose standards and living conditions have improved measurably.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 31 -- Mexico and Yugoslavia protested strongly today against a decision of a United Nations committee to ask the Franco Government of Spain what it might be able to do to strengthen the collective security machinery of the world organization.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 31 -- Senator Richard M. Nixon of California, Republican nominee for the Vice Presidency, opened fire tonight on Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, describing the Democratic party's candidate for President as a captive of President Truman, big city bosses and the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

AUSTIN, Tex., July 31 (AP) -- A large section of plaster ceiling collapsed in the old Queen Theatre today, injuring thirteen of an audience composed mostly of children who had come to see a Tarzan thriller.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- During the week ended July 30, member bank reserves increased $83,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Austria appealed to the United States today for support of a move to end the occupation of Austrian territory by the troops of the Big Four powers.

Net income of the nation's second largest steel producer, the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, slumped sharply in the second quarter of this year as a result of the steel strike. Directors, however, at their meeting yesterday declared the usual quarterly dividends of $1.75 a share on the preferred stock and $1 on the common stock, payable on Oct. 1 and Sept. 2, respectively.
A prolonged drought is causing serious damage to crops, golf courses and lawns in New Jersey, Long Island, Southern New York and Connecticut.

Knits -- in trim, sweaters and dresses -- starred yesterday as one of the strongest trends in Lord Taylor's collection for the college girl's wardrobe this fall. Other highlights were the Empire and middy look, the tweed dress, popularity of jersey and handsome coats of camel's hair or alpaca pile.

Statisticians of the New York Stock Exchange and the Brookings Institution have discovered that two-thirds of the non-share owners of the country do not own stocks because they feel they haven't enough money to do so.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Price increases on aluminum, a key metal in the nation's economy, will be authorized over the week-end by the Office of Price Stabilization, officials of the agency said today.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 31 -- Russia will participate in the 1956 Olympics at Melbourne with a full team, Arthur Coles, chairman of the organizing committee for the Sixteenth Olympiad, said tonight.
The television viewer who would to see new Hollywood films on his home screen -- and who wouldn't ? -- certainly can't complain that official Washington hasn't tried to be helpful.

LONDON, July 31 -- More than 2,000,000 workers in British industries using iron and steel had their claim to higher wages rejected today by their employers. This brought to nearly 5,000,000 the number of British workers for whom rises have been refused or suspended in recent weeks.

Today's new film is "The Duel at Silver Creek," a Universal-International Western in Technicolor, with Audie Murphy, Faith Domerque and Stephen McNally, at the Palace. Don Siegel directed and Leonard Goldstein produced from a script by Gerald Drayson Adams and Joseph Hoffman and story by Mr. Adams Susan Cabot, Gerald Mohr, Eugene Iglesias, James Anderson and George Eldredge appear in supporting roles.

The R. C. A. Victor division of the Radio Corporation of America announced yesterday that it would market soon a new, longer-playing and otherwise improved 45-R. P. M. record. The new records will permit the recording of long selections on a single side and will reduce by half the number of records now required in an album.

PITTSBURGH, July 31 (UP) -- The drive to increase steel production in the wake of the long strike of the United Steelworkers, C. I. O., suffered a serious setback today when negotiations between the Wheeling Steel Corporation and the union broke up without settlement.

The Stadium Symphony Orchestra last evening played a program of music by Gian-Carlo Menotti at Lewisohn Stadium, under the direction of Thomas Schippers. Soloists were Byron Janis, playing the Piano Concerto in F, and Eileen Farrell and Rosemary Kuhlmann, sopranos; Richard Mincer, boy soprano, and Wesley Dalton, tenor, in excerpts from Mr. Menotti's operas.

BERLIN, July 31 -- The International Congress of Jurists ended its week-long session here tonight by approving a series of resolutions that characterized the administration of justice in East Germany as a virtual tyranny. Before adjourning, the congress established a permanent organ to continue its work.

An electronic brain with features designed to make its mathematical abilities available for business generally was demonstrated by the Electronic Computer Corporation at its plant in Brooklyn yesterday.

Mayor Impellitteri announced yesterday the collapse of the city's plan to sell its five deficit-ridden bus lines in Manhattan to the New York City Omnibus Corporation. The Mayor immediately sent word to the Board of Estimate that he was withholding his approval of the resolution adopted by the board on June 30 granting the company a franchise to operate the five lines.
LONDON, July 31 -- Belief that no new crisis measures were announced in yesterday's House of Commons economic debate was reflected today in the all-round higher prices on the London Stock Market.

Herman T. Stitchman, New York Commissioner of Housing, replied yesterday to criticism by the Commerce and Industry Association, 233 Broadway, that the proposed West Side midtown Governor George Clinton Houses, a major development, would involve annual tax losses to the city amounting to $150,000.

LONDON, July 31 -- Former Prime Minister Clement Attlee, leader of the Labor party, rebuked Aneurin Bevan in the House of Commons today for his "inadvertance" in disclosing proceedings that had taken place in the Cabinet when they were both members.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 31 (AP) -- Nineteen-year-old Bob Perry of Los Angeles, a newcomer on the Eastern grass court circuit, scored the biggest upset of the Meadow Club invitation tennis tournament today when he eliminated top-seeded Straight Clark of Pasadena in the quarter-final round.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- A press-radio group reported today that it had wound up a three-year investigation of the murder of George Polk, Columbia Broadcasting System correspondent who was shot in May, 1948, in Salonika, Greece.

A half-length portrait of Theodore Roosevelt as a colonel in the Spanish-American War was presented to the Theodore Club yesterday by Dean Carpenter, vice president of Hilton Hotels International, Inc., at a brief ceremony in the club's new headquarters in the Roosevelt Hotel.

NEW BRUNSWICK N. J., July 31 -- The civil rights issue, with which Republican and Democratic politicians dealt warily at the Chicago conventions, dominated the discussion in today's opening sessions of the second annual Institute on Teamwork in Industry.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif, July 31 -- Negotiations concerning a basic contract between the Screen Writers Guild and the Alliance of Television Film Producers, which represents ten Hollywood companies, were broken off today after five months. The guild immediately notified its members not to sign deals with producers in the alliance that would conflict with the calling of a strike. It also sent similar notice to all writers' agents here.

CLEVELAND, July 31 (AP) -- A six-run rally in the eighth inning, marked by Joe Tipton's two-run homer, gave the Indians an 8-2 victory over the Red Sox in the rubber game of a series today before a crowd of 11,634.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 31 -- The United Nations Economic and Social Council this afternoon completed one of the most spirited debates during its three-month session, and sent to the General Assembly, without comment, a series of resolutions submitted by the Commission on Human Rights concerning the future independence of nonself-governing peoples.

The Federal Government intensified its drive yesterday against New York's night club and restaurant salient and demanded approximately $1,000,000 in treble damages from a dozen alleged violators of price regulations.

TORONTO, July 31 -- India officially suggested today that all Communist charges about germ warfare and prisoner treatment in Korea be fully aired here under Red Cross auspices, with both sides participating.

Prices of United States Government securities reacted adversely yesterday to the Treasury's decision to refund two issues of certificates of indebtedness totaling $2,415,648,000 into a single issue of one-year paper bearing interest of 2 per cent.

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Allied troops, in a bloody bayonet attack early today, drove the Chinese Communists off the crest of "Old Baldy," on the western Korean front. The Chinese had seized the strategic hill ten days ago.

BRIELLE, N. J., July 31 -- Most of the off-shore anglers, from Brielle to the Highlands, seem to be concentrating on bluefish, although a few are trolling for school tuna and some are making a nbt too successful effort to pick up a wandering striped bass along the edge of the surf.
Plans for international participation in the nation-wide celebration in 1954-55 of the 300th anniversary of the first Jewish settlement in the United States were announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 31--Senator A. Willis Robertson of Virginia moved to stem defections from Democratic ranks in the South by announcing today, just as he did four years ago, that he would "vote the straight Democratic ticket next November"
PARIS, July 31 -- A large part of the Lanvin-Castillo collection confirms an easy fit, soft lines developed in supple fabrics.

The retail costs of pork already are partially reflecting the higher wholesale price ceilings authorized earlier this week by the Office of Price Stabilization. Pork loin roasts, center-cut chops and smoked hams averaged 4 cents a pound more than they were a week ago, the City Department of Markets reported yesterday.

Long Island police pressed a widening search yesterday for a man whe beat two teen-age girls in separate assaults on Wednesday. One of the victims was a 15-year-old Massapequa girl who was attacked in South Farmingdale and beaten into unconsciousness.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Drought and high temperatures have resulted in such widespread damage to crops throughout the South that a conference was called today by Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture, to meet tomorrow in Nashville, Tenn., to discuss the situation.

General of the Army Douglas MacArthur accepted appointment yesterday as chairman of the board of Remington Rand, Inc., a manufacturer of business machines and electronic equipment. At the same time he said he would take no part in the political campaign now getting under way.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 31 (AP) -- Two Communists who confessed selling vital Swedish defense secrets to Russia were sentenced today to life imprisonment at hard labor. Four of their accomplices, including a woman, received lesser sentences and one defendant was acquitted.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 31 -- Parliament today pushed through the two main readings of Premier Mohammed Mossadegh's single article bill giving him power to legislate by decree for six months or what amounts to dictatorial powers.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- Installment credit, freed from Government controls May 7, jumped $593,000,000 in June on top of a $447,000,000 rise in May, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
NEW DELHI, India, July 31 -- The Indian Government firmly repudiated today a Communist allegation that New Delhi had rejected favorable trade offers made by the Soviet Union.
CHICAGO, July 31 (UP) -- A force of more than 125 police today arrested defiant sitdown strikers in the twine mill of International Harvester Company and removed them from the plant in patrol wagons.
A fresh approach to the young homemaker's problem of arranging a small apartment in a comfortable and efficient way may be studied in a series of model rooms opening today at Altman's.

TOKYO, Friday, Aug. 1 -- The United Nations and Communist staff officers, in a sixty-five-minute meeting at Panmunjom today, made "some progress" in the revision of the sixty-four-paragraph draft text of the armistice agreement, used as a basis for negotiations in the Korean truce talks.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 31 -- A compromise agreement between individual steamship operators and the American Radio Association, C. I O., today ended the threat of a new shipping tie-up on the West Coast that followed a two-month strike of the Sailors Union of the Pacific, A. F. L.

More than 425 New York furriers received their first briefing on the new Fur Products Label Act yesterday at a meeting in the Governor Clinton Hotel. The regulation, which will be supervised by the Federal Trade Commission, becomes effective on Aug. 9.

Supreme Court Justice Thomas J. Brady reserved decision late yesterday afternoon on a motion by State Senator William J. Bianchi of the Twenty-second District to invalidate the designating petition of Dr. Charles Muzzicato, his organization opponent for the Republican nomination for Senator, on the ground that Dr. Muzzicato does not live in the district.

Gerhard A. Puff, the 37-year-old Kansas bank robber, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on a charge of first-degree murder in the fatal shooting last Saturday of Joseph J. Brock, an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
BEAUMONT, Tex., July 31 -- A giant barge bearing a 167-foot insulated tank was launched here today to mark an innovation in shipping molten sulphur.

ALBANY, July 31 -- Governor Dewey said that "I am delighted to receive news today from Washington which indicates that after twenty-two years we are at last making real progress with New York's great program of developing the St. Lawrence River for cheap water power."

SAN FRANCISCO, July 31 -- Sir Percy Spender, Australian Ambassador, said today that Australia and New Zealand were ready to contribute 1,000,000 fighting men to aid in the defense of the United States, Japan or the Philippines, should the Soviet Union attack in the Pacific.

RICHMOND, Va., July 31 -- Five alleged Communists and a party lawyer failed today to upset a verdict of the Baltimore District Court convicting them of conspiring to advocate overthrow of the Government.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 31 --The Yugoslav Government has replied to the aide-memoire of the United States, British and French Governments outlining the terms of reference within which the three powers stated that they would be prepared to underwrite Yugoslavia's current trade deficit for the fiscal year of 1952-53.

GENEVA, July 31 -- The Inter governmental Migration Committee will assist in the resettlement in Israel of 2,000 European Jews, officials announced today. An agreement with the Israeli Government provides that the committee will handle the transport of these immigrants, while Jewish organizations, possibly the Jewish Agency for Palestine, will make the pre-embarkation arrangements.

CHICAGO, July 31 -- If it is true that the first hundred games are the hardest, it could be that the Yankees could find the rest of the trail to their fourth straight pennant a trifle less difficult than it has been of late.
A power plant on wheels, designed for emergency use, was shown yesterday to several hundred civil defense and utility officials in a parking lot on Forty- first Street east of Lexington Avenue.

The stock market found it a bit difficult yesterday to advance prices further. But, under the sponsorship of the railroads, the list continued to rise selectively into the best ground since October, 1930. Contrary movements in the steels and motors hampered the advance and there was some backwardness among the petroleums. However, on balance, the composite rate registered an increase of 0.78 point.
BOSTON, July 31 (AP) -- The Cardinals teed off against Vern Bickford for six runs in the fifth inning today to gain an 8-3 victory over the Braves.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended July 26 totaled 607,271 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 1,686 cars or 0.3 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 213,205 cars or 26 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year and 237,740 cars or 28.1 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.
The City of New York was likened to Simon Legree by city sanitation workers as their union dramatized demands yesterday for a five-day, forty-hour work week in a demonstration outside City Hall Park.

Sales of the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company for the first six months this year were down 7.3 per cent from the record volume for the 1951 half and earnings fell 9 per cent, according to the report yesterday of Harry B. Higgins, president.
DETROIT, July 31 (AP) -- The auto industry's big three producers, General Motors, Chrysler and Ford, announced plans today for stepping up lagging production after the costly steel strike.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 31 -A discordant note in the chorus of high praise bestowed upon the games of the Fifteenth Olympiad as struck today by Gun Sun Hoh, head delegate from Nationalist China.

CHICAGO, July 31 (AP) -- Dick Mayer, who is seventeenth on the pros' money winning list, fired a 7-under-par 65 today for a stroke lead over Jim Turnesa, national professional golfers association champion, in the first round of the $30,000 All-American golf tourney at Tam O'Shanter.
DETROIT, July 31 -- Arthur Weinfeld, 23-year-old Wayne University student, today became the one-millionth American to be drafted for military service since the Start of the Korean War.
Profound changes of thinking and doing by the American people will be brought about if Gov. Adlai Stevenson is elected President of the United States.
ST. LOUIS, July 31 (AP) -- The Senators pushed across five runs in the first inning before a man was out, then went on to gain a 10-to-5 victory over the Browns tonight. The box score:

CHICAGO, July 31 -- Coarse grains again paced the futures market on the Board of Trade today, oats following the lead of corn in registering sharp upturns. Traders appeared to have become suddenly aware that the drought conditions that have caused serious deterioration in coarse grains, as well as in hay crops, balance to a great extent the fine outlook in most of Illinois, Iowa, Indiana and Ohio.

WAYNE, N. J., July 31 -- Charlotte De Cozen of Montclair won low gross honors in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's one-day Class A and B tournament by scoring a 4-over-par 40, 39 -- 79 over the Preakness Hills course today.

Issues of $165,865,000 of public housing notes of twenty-three local housing authorities were sold at public bidding yesterday at interest rates ranging from 0.97 per cent to 1.03 per cent. Excepting certain notes of the New York City Authority maturing in nine months, the note issues will come due in from three months to six and one-half months.
Federal Judge Edward J. Dimock denied yesterday a defense motion for a mistrial in the Communist conspiracy case, ruling that the Government had "a duty to advise the citizens of a danger."

Two candidates supported by Robert B. Blaikie, Democratic leader of the Seventh Manhattan Assembly District, drew first-place positions on the primary election ballot in drawings conducted yesterday by the Board of Elections at its office, 400 Broome, Street.
HANOVER, Germany, July 31 (UP) -- Delegates to the first Assembly of the Luthern World Federation drew up plans today for a "Lutheran World Service" to aid millions of homeless refugees.

The sailing of the new French luxury liner Flandre, which arrived here Wednesday on her maiden voyage, has been postponed from noon Friday to the same hour on Sunday. The delay was ordered by the French Line when it was ascertained that necessary repairs could not be completed until tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (UP) -- The sixteen-month ban on private imports of tin ended today.

A short time ago I read an article that cited instances of prevailing untidiness in our National Forest recreation areas -- particularly in the Western forests. The article indicated, moreover, that this situation was the result of grossly undermanned forest districts, coupled with large crowds of tourists.

A mass meeting of members of the Associated Actors and Artistes of America, the parent body of all American Federation of Labor entertainer unions, has been called for 1 P. M. next Thursday at the Park Sheraton Hotel.
A convicted bookmaker with an aching molar who sought treatment beyond prison bars was informed yesterday that the Bronx Supreme Court should not be expected to sanction "unneeded" outside jaunts.

LONDON, July 31 -- The price of domestic newsprint for the second half of 1952 has been reduced from 66 ($184.80) to 56 ($156.80) a ton, Viscount Swinton, Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster, announced in the House of Lords today.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (UP) -The Public Health Service reported today that 7,090 Americans had been stricken with infantile paralysis thus far this year. This total was only 3 1/2 per cent below the figure for the same period in the "epidemic" year of 1949.

Charitable, medical and community organizations share in more than $400,000, while ninety relatives, friends and employes receive legacies of cash, trusts, residuary interests or personal property under the will of Mrs. Sophie L. Goodhart, filed for probate yesterday.

It was with a comfortable albeit tired feeling that the Dodgers left Ebbets Field yesterday after having struggled through more than five hours with the Pirates. For, by beating the Bucs, 7 -- 6 in overtime and 4 -- 1, Chuck Dressen's pace-setters gained a game and a half and now lead the second-place Giants by six lengths.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 31 -- The string of successes that Good Time had been enjoying came to an end tonight when the famed 6-year-old, favorite at 1-to-4, was defeated by Dudley Hanover in the $50,000 Nassau two-mile pace at Roosevelt Raceway. It was a tingling finish with the winner overtaking his rival in a brilliant stretch drive to win by a length and a quarter.
TOKYO, Friday, July 31 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,328, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Friday, Korea time:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 31 -- A sharp cut in operations of the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund is threatened as a result of a recent decision by Congress that American contributions to international organizations must not exceed one-third of their total annual budgets.

In a converted tenement room in east midtown yesterday a husky youth smacked the face of a thin, dark girl in the best Jimmy Cagney movie style. She beat fiercely at his head, using her high-heeled slipper as a club, and tore the shirt from his chest. Meanwhile, both were screaming insults at each other.

DENVER, July 31 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower was warned today that he needed the support of 10,000,000 independents, dissident Democrats and non-regular Republicans to win in November. He was urged to rely on "amateur" organizations that appealed to these groups where the regular Republican set-up did not.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 31 (AP) -- The United States sent five men into the semi-finals of the Olympic boxing tournament tonight but the greatest cheer from the United States rooting section went to a gangling South African heavyweight.

Sugar refiners in the New York area held out of the market yesterday because of a report that two 10,000-ton cargoes, bought by California and Hawaiian Sugar Refining Corporation on the West Coast at the time of the maritime strike, had been re-directed here upon its settlement.
The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was active yesterday and active months closed steady 18 to 32 points higher than on Wednesday.

OSLO, Norway, July 31 (AP) -Lindy Remigino, United States sprint ace from Manhattan College, equaled the world 100-meter dash record of 10.2 seconds during a post-Olympic track and field meet that ended tonight.

MANILA, Friday, Aug. 1 -- The unconditional surrender, reported early today, of the Moro outlaw leader, Hadji Kamlon, prepared the way for the launching of Defense Secretary Ramon Magsaysay's military campaign against the bandit forces on Jolo Island, the Philippines' No. 2 threat to peace and order.

HONG KONG, July 31 -- Civil Air Transport, Inc., an American company, took possession at noon today of the forty former Chinese Nationalist planes it had been awarded in an appeal proceedings before the Judicial committee of the Privy Council in London.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., July 31 -- The Long Island team of Mal Galletta and Gordon Stott of North Hills led the qualifiers in the sixteenth annual John G. Anderson Memorial tourney at the Winged foot Golf Club today.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 31 -- Finland has entered the homestretch in her payment of war reparations to the Soviet Union.
Swelled by the retirement of a large issue of bonds for a steel company, bond redemptions in July rose to the highest total since March and the largest amount for any July since 1950.

BONN, Germany, July 31 -- The Social Democratic party, preparing for its convention in September and next year's general election, presented today a program calling for Germany's reunification now through negotiations with the Soviet Union and special efforts to regain this country's lost markets in Eastern Europe.

FALMOUTH, Mass., July 31 -- Slightly more than a jet plane roar from this gateway to Cape Cod, veteran fighter pilots of the 4707th Defense Wing lounge in ready rooms of the Otis Air Force Base on an around-the-clock alert for "unidentified" aircraft.

Will you please help me and the thousands of families like my own that have sons and relatives in Korea. These are the forgotten citizens of this country. They have been taken from their homes and after brief training now daily face the risk of death and mutilation in Korea.

Treatment that breaks down self-confidence in a child and makes him overly fearful of rebuke can seriously retard his educational and emotional growth, Prof. Laurance F. Shaffer of Teachers College, Columbia University, said yesterday.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 31 (UP) -- Mohammed Ramzan of Pakistan got the biggest cheer of all from 5,000 spectators present at the Olympic swimming pool this morning for his performance in the 1,500 meters heat, though he finished last.
The United States Weather Bureau offered a batch of figures yesterday confirming that July was the hottest calendar-month in New York's recorded weather history, which dates from 1871.
WALLINGFORD, Conn., July 31 (AP) -- An Old Greenwich man under indictment in New York on a charge of swindling a wealthy Brazilian out of $100,000 was found dead here today in a rented automobile.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- A Harvard law professor took charge of the Administration's wage stabilization program today, determined to "make it work" despite Congress' fiat that stripped this agency of all authority to settle labor disputes.

FLORENCE, Italy, July 27 -Under the red tile roofs of Florence, in yellow farmhouses in the provincial sun-drenched hills, the artisans of Italy patiently ply their ancient trades. From the mountains to the sea hundreds of them, at primitive hand looms and potter's wheels turn out steadily the handcrafts for which their country is so justly famed.
LOS ANGELES, July 13 (AP) -- Berri Long of Huntington, W. Va., the 15-year-old golfer who refuses to accept defeat, won again today in the quarter-finals of the women's Western amateur tournament.

Conty Bay of the Warbern Stables came through with a thrilling victory in the feature race at Jamaica yesterday. The son of Lochinvar, benefiting from an excellent ride by Hedley Woodhouse, held up in the stretch to beat off the obstinate challenge of Mrs. Robert H. Heighe's Sate.
KALAMAZOO, Mich., July 31 (UP) -- The national junior and boys tennis championships developed today into a battle among the favorites.

Brookly Aquarium, Inc., bought the four-story apartment house for six families at 339 Ninth Street, Brooklyn, from Michael Delyam and insured title with the City Title Insurance Company. The tax valuation is $24,500.

Demands on the New York banks for commercial loans continued to contract during the last week. It was the fifth consecutive decline in business borrowings and, while it represented somewhat a usual summer lull, it also reflected the lack of buying power due to the long strike in the steel industry and the absence of demand for sales financing.

TRENTON, July 31 -- Completion of state negotiations for the purchase of Island Beach, ten-mile stretch of untouched seacoast off Ocean County, was announced today by State Treasurer Walter T. Margetts. New Jersey has been seeking possession of the island as a wildlife and plant reserve.

Immediate suspension of Ceiling Price Regulation 7, which affects department and specialty stores, was urged yesterday by Malcolm P. McNair, chairman of the National Retail Dry Goods Association committee on emergency Government controls.

LONDON, July 31 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden called on the Labor party in the House of Commons today to acknowledge the paternity of one of the policies that it left on his doorstep -- the policy of rearming Germany.

The Welfare and Health Council of New York City has completed the organization of its health division, the first of six units being planned for advisory work in specialized areas. The health division has begun to function as the coordinating body for 100 public and private health agencies here.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The Atomic Energy Commission, in its report today, expressed pride in the safety record at its installations. It described in detail the third radiation accident in its history. The first two occurred during the weapons tests at Eniwetok in 1948, with five men re burns.
The Breezy Point Surf Club's fancy night club in a tent folded yesterday under the weight of city ordinances.

Revenue from world-wide operations of the Burroughs Adding Machine Company during the first six months this year were the highest for any similar period in the history of the company, totaling $73,174,460 or 18 per cent above the $62,236,032 total for the 1951 period.

Armand (Al) Weill of New York will cease being matchmaker for the International Boxing Club on Sept. 1. His resignation will take effect on that date so that Weill may resume managing Rocky Marciano, who is almost certain to be the next opponent for Joe Walcott, the heavyweight champion.

CAPRI, Italy, July 31 -- Insisting that he was no longer a rich man and that his children were "the only kingdom that is left to me," former King Farouk, now officially known as H. R. H. Prince Farouk Fuad of Egypt, made an appeal today to be allowed to live "a quiet, normal life" in exile with his family.
Motorola, Inc., announced yesterday it had perfected complete mechanization of mass production of conventional home radio sets for the first time in the history of the electronics industry.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Department store sales in the week ended July 26 were 2 per cent under sales of the corresponding week of last year. This was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board, which listed the following percentage changes from like periods of 1951:

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- Secretary of the Interior Oscar L. Chapman said today the outlook for profitable production of synthetic liquid fuels was so promising that private industry should begin building experimental plants. He also emphasized the importance of synthetic fuels for national defense and said their production should be developed as soon as possible.
MOSCOW, July 31 (UP) -- The Government - controlled Russian newspapers, for the second time since the start of the 1952 Olympics, charged today that the umpires were unfair.

New joint efforts by the United States and the Latin-American republics for solving serious fiscal problems and combining further economic development with hemisphere defense have been recommended by the National Association of Manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The Federal Power Commission and the New York Power Authority joined today to clear the way for reconsideration of a proposal by New York State to develop jointly with Ontario a power project on the St. Lawrence River.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 31 -- Progress in shaping Israel's armed forces into a smooth fighting machine was noted by observers who witnessed the first phase of the annual maneuvers now in progress in the hills of Galilee.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in July was slightly below that of the month before and the dullest for a corresponding month since 1949. Sales, however, exceeded the million-share mark in every session except three, the largest being 1,453,880 shares on July 1.

The admittance of Soviet Russian sportsmen to the present Olympic Games, or, more precisely, to the summer competitions of the XV Olympics -- as the Soviet representatives did not participate in the winter contest -- has apparently brought quite some confusion into matters which hitherto seemed clear.

CAIRO, July 31 -- Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, commander in chief of the Egyptian armed forces and leader of last week's coup, said tonight that the army was relinquishing all control of civil affairs to the Government and henceforth would concentrate on military affairs and on the "purge."

TRENTON, July 31 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey and Gov. John S. Fine of Pennsylvania announced today their preference for a new Delaware River toll bridge, rather than a tunnel, to link Camden and Philadelphia.

Sales of British motor cars in the United States increased 21 per cent during the first four months of this year in comparison with the same period a year ago, according to the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders, British automotive trade association. A total of 6,610 was sold during the period, against 5,292 in 1951.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The first step toward the development of an atomic-powered aircraft carrier was taken today with the award of a contract to the Westinghouse Electric Corporation for work on a large-sized nuclear power plant.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 31 -The United States reached the final of the basketball tournament with Russia, and American swimmers and divers were among the top qualifiers with record-breaking performances today as the games of the Fifteenth Olympiad drew near the close of competition.

Samuel Blumenthal, 32-year-old confessed perjurer and bookmaker, testified yesterday that he had given protection money to Capt. James W. Flynn, one of thirty-four suspended policemen on departmental trial charged with accepting graft from Harry Gross.

Coming apart at the seams in the seventh inning, when the visitors piled up nine runs, the Giants bowed to the Cubs, 11 -- 8, yesterday. Their triumph gave the Bruins the series, three games to one, and effectively silenced the pennant murmurs that were beginning to be heard around the Polo Grounds just a few days ago.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Maine, Massachusetts and South Carolina were added today by the Department of Agriculture to the list of states eligible for disaster loans because of drought. Seven more counties in Arkansas also were so designated.

THIS is the shooters month, for August will not only bring the national rifle and pistol matches, but will find hundreds heading for the Camp Perry championship meet, with even the bench rest shooters able to participate in events in New York and Pennsylvania.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decline of 9.5 per cent during July in comparison with those of the same month a year ago, according to the monthly survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Mothers of young graduates of the Madison Square Boys Club sewing classes, which have been conducted since January, have been more than pleasantly surprised by their sons' new interest in the care of their clothes, Mrs. Martin L. Charles, instructor, said yesterday.
LONDON, Aug. 1 (UP) -- Britain today announced that she had concluded a new estimated $20,000,000 trade agreement with Communist Czechoslovakia.

With Monte Irvin starting for the first time, Bobby Thomson in center field and Henry Thompson at third base, the Giants last night snapped out of their slump to defeat the Pirates, 7 -- 3, before 10,458 spectators at the Polo Grounds.
CLEVELND, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Interlake Steamship Company announced today that it had granted 10 per cent wage increases to the 1,200 sailors manning its Great Lakes fleet of ore carriers.
HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 1 (UP) -- The Fourth Congress of the Pan-American sports committee voted today to hold the 1955 Pan-American games in Mexico City in March.

HAVANA, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Bernard Bartzen and Hugh Stewart coasted to easy straight set victories today as the United States took a 2-0 lead in its second round North American zone Davis Cup battle with Cuba.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 1 -- Frank E. McKinney, Democratic National Chairman, had dinner with President Truman tonight but said they had abstained from discussing politics.
JERSEY CITY, Aug. 1 -- The attempts to get a truck loaded with lumber past the picket lines of striking warehousemen at the Army-leased Claremont Terminal Pier here failed today.

While trying to scare off would-be automobile thieves, William Hopkins, 22 years old, of 295 Troy Avenue, Brooklyn, was killed at 12:45 o'clock this morning near the corner of Creston Avenue and 197th Street, the Bronx. His father-in-law, Alfred McCullough, 50, of 2,805 Creston Avenue, was shot in the head and was taken to Fordham Hospital.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 1 -- Fifty seven per cent of the merchant fleet of the United States, available for auxiliary duty in the event of a world emergency, consists of vessels slower than 14 knots in speed, a special committee of the Veterans of Foreign Wars warned here today.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 1 (AP) -- Many Florida Democrats will vote the Republican ticket in November, the Democratic National Committee was advised today by Richard D. Barker, Florida's Democratic National Committeeman.
GOODWOOD, England, Aug. 1 (Reuters) -- For the first time since her accession to the throne, Queen Elizabeth today watched her purple, scarlet and gold horse racing colors carried to victory.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 1 -- Gen. Vassily I. Chuikov, head of the Soviet Control Commission in East Germany, has told the Western powers they must restore freedom of trade between West and East Germany or face the consequences. These might take the form of a new blockade of Berlin, Western observers agree.

CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, Aug. 1 -- The Harlem Globetrotters, professional Negro basketball team, introduced basketball to Pope Plus XII today in a demonstration that left the Pontiff pleased and smiling.

Sam Goody, phonograph-record dealer, sought yesterday a ruling on whether the new minimum retail prices set by the Raxor Corporation for its records are legally binding as far as he is concerned. He contended that the new prices, established by Raxor as a result of the recently enacted Maguire Fair Trade Act, could not be observed because they were higher than ceilings fixed for his concern by the Office of Price Stabilization.

The 1949 murder of William Lurye, garment union organizer, was dramatically introduced yesterday into the departmental trial of thirty-four suspended policemen charged with taking graft from Harry Gross for protecting his bookmaking empire.

After an ownersship of six weeks, a client of Harry G. Silverstein, broker, resold the five-story loft building on plot 50 by 134 feet at 419-21 Broome Street, seventy-five feet west of the corner of Lafayette Street, to Ernest Maihack of Newark, N. J.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 1 -- Promising normal diplomatic relations between the United States and West Germany as soon as possible, Walter J. Donnelly arrived at Mehlem, site of the office of the United States High Commissioner, today and took over that post.

BOSTON, Aug. 1 (UP) -- Violent thunderstorms broke a month-long New England drought today but caused damage that may total $1,000,000 and failed to ease the danger of forest fires or help wilted crops.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 1 -- Iran now is watching 80-year-old Ayatollah Kashani, the greatest of the political Islamic Mullahs, to see what is going to come of his decision to stand in the middle between the firmly anti-Communist National Front that is supporting Premier Mohammed Mossadegh, and the Tudeh Communists, who were considerably strengthened by their alliance with the National Front in the overthrow of former Premier Ahmad Ghavam.

Plans by boys apparel manufacturers and buyers to hold joint market weeks in spring and fall were termed unfeasible in a statement issued yesterday by the Boys' Apparel and Accessories Manufacturing Association and the Boys' Apparel Buyers Association.

TOLEDO, Aug. 1 (UP) -- Danny Menendez will not appear next Monday to testify before a local Grand Jury investigating his purchase of the Toledo Mud Hen franchise from the Detroit Tigers, his attorney, Franklin Hayward, said tonight.

TOKYO, Saturday, Aug. 2 -- United Nations and Communist colonels completed today a series of staff meetings on the phrasing of the draft agreement for an armistice in Korea with "some progress" on technical points, but without an approach to a solution of the basic issue of an exchange of war prisoners.
LONDON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Moscow Radio's Helsinki correspondent tonight gave Russian home service listeners a "we wuz robbed" version of the Olympic boxing semifinals.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1 (UP) -- The third-place Cardinals smashed through with five extra-base hits for six runs in the final two innings tonight to defeat the Phillies, 10 -- 5, and crown a five-inning one-hit relief chore by Eddie Yuhas with success.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Sammy Snead unleashed a tremendous long game to offset an erratic putter for a 7-under-par 65 and a 5-stroke 36-hole lead in the second round today of the $30,000 all-American tourney.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 1 -- A score of Kansas housewives exercised their constitutional right of petition before President Truman himself today. They protested against the construction of the Turtle Creek Dam and pleaded for their nine towns and villages and the homes of 6,000 persons that would be inundated if the dam was built.

People who have lost their sight know that they have lost something precious. At first they feel completely lost, but with proper counseling and guidance over a period of time most are soon brought to a state of mind that calls for them to enter upon some constructive activity that will earn a livelihood.
Your recent editorial "Creed of Conquest," although it brings out interesting and important points, needs clarification and amplification.

HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Medical scientists claim that they helped set all those records in the 1952 Olympic games. But not, they insist, with any secret formulas, stimulating shots in the arms, or invigorating inhalations.
Wilson W. Wyatt, who was named yesterday as campaign manager for Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, came to national prominence as Federal Housing Expediter on Dec. 12, 1945.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Aug. 1 -- Mrs. Andrew Steidinger of the Cherry Valley Club fashioned a 44, 45 -- 89 to win the low gross prize during the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association class B tournament at the Nassau country Club today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 1 -- The Brazilian National Union of Students voted early today, after a stormy all-night session of its annual congress, to withdraw from the International Union of Students, which it decided was dominated by Communists.

ALBANY, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Eddie Myerson of Los Angeles won the seventh Hearst national junior golf tournament today with a seventy-two-hole total of 286 -- two under par and thirteen under the previous tournament record.

LONDON, Aug. 1 -- Aneurin Bevan complained in the House of Commons today that the leader of his party, Clement Attlee, had accused him of "constitutional impropriety" and cast reflection upon his personal honor.

Violence broke out in the garment area and threats against the lives of non-union dress manufacturers were reported yesterday as the "organizational strike" against the non-union group, staged by the Cloak Joint Board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A. F. L., moved into its fourth day.
The only book published today is Elio Vittorini's "The Red Carnation," translated by Anthony Bower. Reviewed today.
A special radio broadcast of the Rodgers and Hammerstein concert at Lewisohn Stadium tonight has been canceled by the National Broadcasting, Company.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The chiefs of four big operating rail unions received word tonight of a strike vote authorizing a walkout Sunday morning of all operating employes on the New York Central Railroad's lines east of Buffalo.

An overabundance of liquor stocks and declining sales are forcing distillers to reappraise their advertising copy, officials of Frankfort Distillers Corporation declared yesterday. All over the country new brands are appearing on the market in an effort to move large stocks and the company officials estimated that nearly 1,000 different brand may be offered to the American public at this time.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UP) -- Charles Patrick Clark was convicted of assault today for punching Drew Pearson, columnist, on the jaw in a hotel lobby melee. Mr. Clark, an attorney, had told the jurors that when he saw Mr. Pearson it was just like "the red flag in front of the bull."

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 -- Attorneys representing what is recognized as the majority of the country's airline pilots said today that they were prepared to seek a contempt citation against David L. Behncke for his refusal to recognize an order issued late yesterday by Judge Walter C. Lindley of the United States Court of Appeals.
BOSTON, Aug. 1 (UP) -- Max Surkont, after eight well hurled innings, blew up tonight and let in one run with two successive wild pitches as the Reds shut out the Braves, 2 to 0, before 4,081 fans.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- A mystery photograph of four blazes of light in the sky, plus a report from jet pilots on a night flight that an object they sighted was not a reflection, added new twist today to the "flying saucers" puzzle.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Tournament-wise Polly Riley of Texas dashed the title aspirations of Berri Long, the 15-year-old upset kid from Huntington, W. Va., today in the semi-finals of the Women's Western Amateur Golf Tournament.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway enlarged the chain of command over 400,000 United States fighting men on the Iron Curtain front today in seeking to strengthen the defense of Europe.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Pimlico today hired John D. Jackson of Chicago to direct the job of rebuilding the 82-year-old horse racing track.

HELSINKI, Finland, Saturday, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Clyde Littlefield, assistant United States Olympic track coach, was reported "slightly better" early today after receiving two more transfusions to combat a bleeding stomach ulcer.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Aug. 1 -- The Governors of Maine and of New Jersey, both Republicans, agree that the Governor of Illinois is the "best available candidate" the Democrats could have nominated for the Presidency.

HUIZEN, The Netherlands, Aug. 1 -- Delegates from thirty-four countries to the first International Conference of the Educators of Blind Youths -- some of them sightless themselves -- urged today the improvement of facilities to integrate blind young persons into the national and international community.

The stock market lost further momentum yesterday as the effort to continue advancing became more labored. There were some maximum price changes of 1 to 2 points in both directions but the composite rate of THE NEW YORK TIMES index rose only 0.07 point.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Differing views of the Democratic party's platform plank on civil rights marked discussions among politicians in the Capital today.

High-flying commuting has been recommended for the metropolitan area. The commuting, however, is not to be done by suburbanites, but by airliners being ferried between La Guardia Airport and New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.
LONDON, Aug. 1 (Reuters) -- Surrey moved a step nearer the English county cricket championship today with a six-wicket triumph over Derbyshire. The victory was the sixteenth in twenty matches.

Beginning tomorrow, mass will be said for Catholics on Sundays and Holy Days at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens. Permission was obtained from the Very Rev. Thomas E. Molloy, Archbishop of Brooklyn.

The country faces an increasing demand for piano tuner-technicians, with fewer young men entering the trade each year, delegates to the American Society of Piano Technicians were told yesterday. Two hundred of them opened a five-day convention at the New Yorker Hotel.

The agreement negotiated in 1946 between E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., and Imperial Chemical Industries, Ltd., of Great Britain, for the manufacture of nylon has been cancelled by a final judgment entered yesterday in Federal Court by Judge Sylvester J. Ryan.

JONES BEACH, L. I., Aug. 1 -- Lifeguards launched and beached lifeboats and plowed into the surf with pontoons, lifelines and surfboards here this morning before an attentive group of twenty-eight boys and two girls.

An impressive report on the work of the Sidney Hillman Health Center of New York in the year since it was founded is issued by the New York Joint Board of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, C. I. O. The report, entitled "Health Security by Union Action," describes how forty thousand workers in the men's clothing industry in New York acted to meet their health problems when mounting costs of medical care moved beyond their means.

Alvin (Cliff) Steward, 35-year-old Queens tavern owner, was held in $2,500 bail yesterday as a material witness when he was arraigned before Judge Clarence H. Brisco. The request for the bail was made by Assistant District Attorney Aaron Koota.

DENVER, Aug. 1 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower announced plans today for an intensive sixty-day stumping tour into every "nook and cranny" of the United States beginning about Sept. 1, and said that on policy matters affecting that campaign he and he alone would be the boss.

In an appeal for increased public support, Dr. William M. Markel, director of the Red Cross Regional Blood Program, reported yesterday that blood donations here during July fell to the lowest point in the last year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The Government report today indicating that the over-all cost of living was almost certain to reach a new peak later this month, was interpreted by price officials as showing that new inflationary pressures were brewing.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The Air Force is considering the production of two supersonic pilotless interceptor planes and a supersonic jet bomber.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 1 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson announced today that Wilson W. Wyatt of Louisville, Ky., former Federal Housing Expediter, would manage his campaign for the Presidency on the Democratic ticket.

HAVANA, Aug. 1 -- A "plot" allegedly fomented by former President Carlos Prio Socarras and his adherents to overthrow the Government of Gen. Fulgencio Batista has been broken up with the arrest of a group of civilians and policemen, Police Headquarters announced today.

TORONTO, Aug. 1 -- The Soviet bloc at the International Red Cross Conference suffered a tactical defeat today when its resolution on control of atomic weapons was adopted with two British amendments. The amendments tied such control to the work of the United Nations Disarmament Commission.

HONG KONG, Aug 1 -- Communist China's People's Liberation Army, which traces its origin back to a 1927 insurrection at Nanchang in Kiangsi Province, celebrated its twenty-fifth anniversary today. The event was marked by political meetings, the opening of an eight-day athletic festival in Peiping and publication of a series of congratulatory telegrams from Communist leaders abroad.

Only three possible legal moves remained yesterday between Frank Costello and the beginning of his eighteen-month jail term when the United States Court of Appeals denied his petition for reargument of his appeal from conviction on April 4 for contempt of the Senate.
GENEVA, Aug. 1 -- The grim march of events is once again forcing the hand of Western statesmen in international economic affairs.

Norton Rothchild, a subway train dispatcher, gave the Fire Department stiff competition yesterday. Armed with only a carbon dioxide extinguisher, he single-handedly put out two blazes at different underground locations within thirty minutes.

BUTLER, N. J., Aug. 1 -- One man was killed and twenty-three persons were injured, four of them critically, in an explosion that wrecked part of the American Hard Rubber Company's plant here this afternoon.

Steps were taken by the Dodgers yesterday to tighten the club for the late pennant drive. Johnny Schmitz, a southpaw relief pitcher, was sold to the Yankees for $10,000 and a player, and Clem Labine was optioned to St. Paul of the American Association.

CORNWALL, N. Y., Aug. 1 -- The Stanton Preparatory Academy that once prepared candidates for entrance examinations at the United States Military Academy at West Point and the United States Naval Academy at Annapolis soon will become the town hall in this township of 6,000 persons in the Hudson highlands.

Two four-story buildings containing furnished apartments at 5 and 7 East Sixty-second Street have been sold by Adolph Levitt to an investing client of Hyman I. Luster, attorney, in a deal negotiated by Brett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hamilton, Inc., brokers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- A clock that talks is among the inventions patented this week. In addition to the usual time mechanism, it contains a moving film strip on which are recorded the lines it is to speak. A photo-electric cell picks up each message and sends it at the proper moment through an amplifier.

HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 1 -- Major Sammy Lee of the Army Medical Corps and Yoshinobu Oyakawa, 18-year-old Hawaiian from Ohio State University, won two more Olympic gold medals for the United States in diving and swimming today to raise the total to six thus far.

Major grain exchanges throughout the nation will be closed today and on future Saturdays until further notice. Whether the Saturday shut-down will be permanent has not yet been determined. Directors of the various exchanges, including the Chicago Board of Trade, Minneapolis and Kansas City have not yet adopted a definite policy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson left by plane today to meet in Honolulu with the Australian and New Zealand Foreign Ministers for the creation of machinery for strengthening the defenses of the three countries in the Pacific area.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Four American visitors today quoted Roman Catholic Archbishop Aloysius Stepinac as saying Communist practices were driving toward the elimination of religion in Yugoslavia.
DAYTON, Ohio, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Reports by jet interceptor pilots today marked the first time pilots checking on flying saucer reports here had made such a positive statement.
TOKYO, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The Japanese Government Security Board began to function today as a unified command of Japan's two defense services -- the National Police Reserve and the Maritime Safety Board.

When King Haakon VII reaches the age of 80 years, on Aug. 3, the warm gratitude and affection of the Norwegian people will go out to him. Rarely in history has a king been so universally respected and beloved by all his people, regardless of parties, regardless of social position.

KALAMAZOO, Mich., Aug. 1 (AP) -- Top-seeded Bill Quillian powered his way through the quarter-finals of the national junior tennis tournament today with a 75, 6-1 victory over Edward Rubinoff of Miami Beach.

LONDON, Aug. 1 -- A return to a normal arrangement under which the United States private buyers of tin may purchase the metal directly from producers in Malaya was announced today in the House of Commons by H. R. Mackeson, Secretary for Overseas Trade.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 1 -- Before taking off for Hawaii today, Sir Percy Spender, Australian Ambassador, issued a statement to "clarify" what he said was a misunderstanding of his remarks before the Commonwealth Club yesterday.

Facing a mandatory sentence of life imprisonment if convicted, Edward Leo Madigan, 56 years old, of 510 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, who was out of prison on parole after serving a fourth term on felony charges, was arrested in Brooklyn just after 5 P. M. yesterday on charges of attempted burglary and possession of burglar's tools.
DETROIT, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Mel Parnell, blazing along on a comeback since recovering from bursitis scattered eight hits tonight as the Red Sox whipped the Tigers, 3 -- 1.
