In a new effort to end Soviet sabotage of the Austrian treaty negotiations, which have now lasted for five years, Austria has determined to appeal to the decent opinion of mankind and to submit her cause to the United Nations in the hope of ending the foreign occupation regime and regaining "the freedom that is her due."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The Army adopted today a new system of granting promotions to enlisted personnel and made them more difficult to obtain.
Two Frenchmen will set out from here today to see 30,000 miles of the world from the seats of their red scooters.

HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Five Americans swept into the final round of the Olympic boxing championships for the first time in history today as the Russian forces suffered four crushing defeats.

A 200-ton stator, the stationary part of an electric generator, was hauled through the East Side streets at dawn yesterday and delivered to the Consolidated Edison power plant on the East River at Fourteenth Street. When the generator goes into operation next year it will produce 175,000 kilowatts of electricity.
TRAVERSE CITY, Mich., Aug. 1 (AP) -- A Government official said today some shortage of petroleum products was possible this winter, particularly on the East Coast and in the Pacific Northwest.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 1 (UP) -- The United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., announced today that it had signed a final contract with Inland Steel Company -- the first in the industry in the 1952 dispute.

The current scarcity of frogs' legs probably is a matter of concern only to gourmets with a liking for this delicacy and to those restaurateurs who usually include it on their menus. But for them, the situation is acute. With the drastic curtailment in shipments from Japan, source of most of our frozen frogs' legs, wholesale prices have shot up from $1.35 a pound to the present average of $1.85.

Jockey Nick Wall completed a triple in the main event, but for those in the crowd of 20,457 who had made across-the-board bets on a 3-year-old named George W. W., and for an apprentice rider named William Lester, the highlight of the Saratoga-at-Jamaica proceedings yesterday was a claiming race that was run in the fourth spot.
Ten persons lost their lives yesterday in three automobile accidents -- two of them in New Jersey and one in Bethlehem, Pa.
Carolyn Schuster's letter of July 19 protests against the availability of firearms.

The semi-annual report of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. and its wholly owned subsidiaries, released today, shows for the first six months this year a net income of $101,708,123, a drop of $16,693,832 from the record $118,401,955 earned a year ago.

Net income of the Richfield Oil Corporation for the first half of 1952 declined to $11,731,195, equal to $2.93 a share, from $14,997,075, or $3.75 a share, earned in the initial six months of 1951, the mid-year statement reported yesterday.

Staten Island is about to mobilize the horse for civil defense against atomic warfare. New York's most rural borough has plans for turning hay wagons into emergency ambulances and supply trucks. With a horse population of 500 or more, it hopes to recruit its own cavalry--local equestrians who would gallop into action with walkie-talkies and first-aid kits at the drop of a tether.
WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 1 -- G. Albert Hill, State Highway Commissioner, served notice on this town today that it would have to accept the state's route for the proposed New England Thruway.

MONTREAL, Saturday, Aug. 2 (Canadian Press) -- One prisoner was shot and killed and another was wounded last night in a battle between the police and 700 prisoners, who rioted in a protest against food conditions in Bordeaux Jail, on the outskirts of Montreal.

HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 1 (UP) -- The United States, thanks to its swimmers and boxers in the stretch drive, appeared certain tonight to win the unofficial team championship of the 1952 Olympic Games.

When the President, addressing the convention, stated, "These men have been opposing everything that the people have wanted in the last twenty years," he implied that the electorate voted Democratic against Republican as a matter of choice.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 1 -- Gene Bearden, mound wizard of 1948, and Satchel Paige, who was a wizard before most of those on the field were born, combined their pitching skills tonight to upset the Yankees as Marty Marion's Browns made off with the opener of a four-game series, 2 to 1.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 1 -- Twentieth Century-Fox today reported that Fredric March tentatively had agreed to play the top role in "Man On a Tightrope," a story with anti-Communist overtones. Mr. March, now in New York, was expected to sign a contract for the picture over the week-end.

PARIS, Aug. 1 -- The descriptive term "jut-outs" is applied by Schiaparelli to collars projecting in front, to peplums out in back, to wings folded in many ways -- all giving motion to her clothes, whether slender or of bell fullness. Because of these details the cricket is the mascot of her collection.
HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Hungary's saber fencers captured all three medals in the individual Olympic competition today.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of interest to the homemaker:

The three basic pieces of household furniture fashioned to receive the resting human from are the chair, bed and intermediary chaise longue. Considering the variations on these standard articles that furniture makers are frenetically devising today it is a wonder they have not turned their ingenuity to the making of entirely new objects of repose.
SINGAPORE, Aug. 1 -- The announcement that the United States Government has lifted restrictions on the purchase of overseas tin by private importers was applauded in Malaya today.
The need for adequate tariff protection for the American watch industry was linked yesterday to its role as a vital component of this country's defense goods producing facilities.

MOSCOW, Aug. 1 -- Pravda, replying today to the protest made by George F. Kennan, United States Ambassador, against a Soviet Aviation Day poster, contended that the poster had presented true facts, that it was liked by the Soviet people and that persons who disliked it were enemies of the "peace and security of the people."

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Aug. 1 -- Substantial agreement on the controversial civil rights issue was reached by the conferees attending the second annual Institute of Teamwork in Industry, which closed here today.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Aug. 1 (UP) -- The Florida Supreme Court dismissed today the pleas of five Negroes who sought to be admitted to the University of Florida.
ATLANTA, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Among Southern newspaper editors, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower is believed to be the most popular candidate the Republicans ever have nominated for President.

Fitz H. Alleyne bought the three-story brownstone dwelling at 81 Lefferts Place, Brooklyn, from Isaac A. Alleyne and insured title with the Lawyers Mortgage and Title Company. The parcel is assessed at $7,000 and was sold for cash over a mortgage of $2,150.

Two taxpayer buildings at 242-52 Central Avenue, Valley Stream, L. I., were sold by Miriam Levinson to the Valstream Building Corporation for investment. The property is assessed at $30,500 and was sold subject to two mortgages amounting to $72,000.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Retail food prices lose to a new record high level during the two weeks that ended on July 15, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.
WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 1 (AP) -- Adio Abe toured the Roosevelt Raceway oval in 2:01 4-5 tonight to win the $11,500 Adios Pace, a preview of the Little Brown Jug for 3-year-old pacers.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 1 -- The Women s Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association defeated the Connecticut State links women, 24 1/2 to 20 1/2, in their annual inter-association team match today at Brooklawn Country Club, reversing the outcome of last year.

Preacher Roe finally lost a game. It happened under the Ebbets Field light last night when the Cubs, riding on the momentum of two straight triumphs over the Giants, beat the Dodgers, 6 -- 1, and reduced their league lead over the Giants to five games.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 1 -- An eleven-week sessions of the United Nations Economic and Social Council ended today with many of the council members expressing satisfaction with the accomplishments, particularly in the economic field, but also noting that they had hoped for greater progress.

BOONTON, N. J., Aug. 1 -- Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood won low gross honors from a field of Seventy-five in a Women's New Jersey Golf Association one-day tournament at the Knoll Country Club course today. Mrs. Mason, metropolitan champion, had nines of 37, 39 -- 76. Jean Carlson of Manasquan River took second low gross with 40, 37 -- 77.
MAMARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 1 -- Mal Galletta and Gordon Stott of North Hills, the medalists, won two matches in the John G. Anderson Memorial tourney at the Winged Foot Golf Club today.

CAIRO, Aug. 1 -- The Council of State, Egypt's highest judicial body, issued today a fatwa, or official opinion, in which it concluded that the Government could set up a temporary regency council without summoning the dissolved Chamber of Deputies back into session.
The American contribution to the U. N. Children's Fund is proportionately a far smaller sum than most Congressmen probably realized or intended when they voted for it shortly before adjournment.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The Bureau of Mines today revised downward its forecast of total demand for crude petroleum and its products for 1952.

" Ivanhoe," Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's Technicolor version of the Sir Walter Scott novel, drew the largest opening day audience for a non-holiday offering in the history of Radio City Music Hall, according to the management of that showcase, with Thursday's total attendance of 23,259 surpassing the record previously set by "Sunset Boulevard" on Aug. 22, 1950.

Ellis Arnall, Chief of the Office of Price Stabilization, told a radio audience this week that when he signed the order granting the rise of $5.20 a ton in steel he did so "reluctantly" because he was convinced that "another round of inflation would be set off."

BOSTON, Aug. 1 -- Maine and Massachusetts sources through which disasters usually are declared were somewhat surprised today when the two states were declared crop disaster areas by the United States Department of Agriculture.
CHICAGO, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Walter Masterson of the Senators, facing the White Sox the second time this season, achieved a 3-1 victory in the first of a four-game series tonight.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UP) -- Military and aircraft industry officials asserted today that combat airplane production was on schedule despite the fifty-five-day steel strike.
LONDON, Aug. 1 -- Britain's bipartisan foreign policy was rent asunder today on the issue of rearming Germany.

A noon-time ceremony yesterday at the Custom House marked the induction of the first woman Controller of Customs at the Port of New York, as the oath of office was administered to Mrs. Margaret Daly Campbell. About 150 persons watched while the 57-year-old native of New Brunswick, N. J., was sworn in by Harry M. Durning, Collector of the Port, in a ceremony recorded for world-wide broadcast by the Voice of America.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 1 (AP) -- Sidney Schwartz of Long Beach, L. I., former national junior champion, and Grant Golden, a 22-year-old Chicagoan, today advanced to the semi-final round of the Meadow Club's annual invitation tennis tournament.

It looks as if Beatrice Lillie will be opening on Broadway in late September or early October -- probably at the Booth Theatre -- in the program of songs and sketches in which she is successfully touring summer playhouses.

LONDON, Aug. 1 -- The stock markets ended the week today in a cheerful mood. Generally the tone was firm and although the approach of the week-end bank holiday restricted business in British Government securities and leading industrials the turnover in other sections was higher than usual for a Friday. Engineering and copper shares were particularly active.
TRENTON, Aug. 1 -- The membership of the Metropolitan Rapid Transit Commission was appointed today by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll before his departure on a Maine vacation.

France's desperate concern over possible changes in the pattern of United States financial aid has led to the suggestion that France may be obliged to abandon Indo-China to the Communists unless the original aid pattern is restored. This suggestion and its implications may be misleading.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- A state of emergency to help Federal authorities stamp out vesicular exanthema, a disease that has afflicted hogs in sixteen states, was proclaimed today by Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture.

YONKERS, N. Y., Aug. 1 -- The nine-week-old strike of 4,200 employes of Alexander Smith, Inc., carpet manufacturers, ended tonight when members of Local 122 of the Textile Workers Union, C. I. O., voted overwhelmingly to accept a wage increase offered by management.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Top civilian and military officials of the Air Force announced today a program of strict budget enforcement in order to bring into being as soon as possible an increased number of combat-ready air wings.

Two men who escaped last Monday from the Matteawan State Hospital for the Criminal Insane at Beacon, N. Y., were identified yesterday, through photographs, by a young Filipino physician as the pair who had held him up a few hours before.
TOKYO, Saturday, Aug. 2 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,329, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Saturday, Korea time:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UP) -- Radio Moscow, which is doing an "inside" series on American politics, has broadcast two more episodes -- one on Tennessee and the other on the Democratic National Convention.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Larry Doby hit a home run in the tenth inning tonight to give the Indians a 6-5 victory over the Athletics. The Athletics had tied up the game in the ninth on Gus Zernial's grand slam homer, which capped a five-run frame.
BOSTON, Aug. 1 (UP) -- A $400,000 offer was made Jersey Joe Walcott, the world champion, today to defend his heavyweight title against Rocky Marciano of Brockton, Mass., at Braves Field on Sept. 29.
With a moderately heavy volume of business, cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday 4 points lower to 22 points higher than on Thursday.
United States Government obligations sagged again in the dealers' market yesterday, with markdowns generally exceeding those of the day before.
A frail 81-year-old widow was beaten and robbed of $8,600 in jewelry and cash early yesterday morning by a bandit who barricaded her in a clothes closet, where she remained for six hours.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UP) -- The wheels of the country's multi-billion dollar illegal gambling businesses are beginning to turn again after being stalled by the new Federal gambling tax, Internal Revenue officials asserted today.

Cab drivers get all sorts of passengers, all kinds of requests. So Gregory Rosado, 29 years old, of 314 East 143d Street, the Bronx, didn't lift an eyebrow when his six male fares asked. him, early yesterday morning, to stop on the Third Avenue bridge connecting Manhattan and the Bronx.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 1 -- The steel strike has so depleted the country's stock of tinplate that some will be rushed here from Hawaii for the manufacture of cans for the West Coast's perishable fruits and vegetables.
OTTAWA, Aug. 1 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian official price for gold sagged to an eighteen-year low today, bringing further gloom to Canada's hard-pressed gold-mining industry.
Five prominent clergymen from Switzerland, England and Scotland will preach in New York pulpits tomorrow at the regular 11 A. M. services.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 1 -- Knox T. Hutchinson, Assistant Secretary of Agriculture, said today that crop damage caused by drought and higher temperatures throughout the South made it certain that national production goals in agriculture would not be reached this year.

Operating revenues and net income of the Central and South West Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended June 30, increased 11 per cent above the results attained in the twelve months ended June 30, 1951, according to the report released yesterday.
HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Sweden won third place in the Olympic soccer tournament tonight by defeating Germany, 2 -- 0, in the consolation game.

Federal Judge Edward J. Dimock suggested yesterday to the jury in the Communist conspiracy case that they forego reading the Federal Bureau of Investigation's monograph on communism, which was released Wednesday by Senator Pat McCarran of Nevada, chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Aug. 1 (Reuters) -- The Bey of Tunis, Sidi Mohammed el Amin Pasha, today formed a twelve-man commission of political, religious and industrial leaders to examine France's proposals for giving greater internal autonomy to the protectorate of Tunisia.

If the world had stood still after the expiration of Marshall Plan aid the recovery of Western Europe might have reached a point where the beneficiaries could manage without further outside assistance. A moonlight "show boat" excursion on the Hudson River, arranged by a Greek-letter, non-college Harlem fraternity was preceded last night by an on-shore fracas that brought thirty policemen and numerous apparatus, including a police launch, to the Hudson River Dayline pier at 125th Street.

The Soviet Union protested to the United States April 11, 1950, that Russian planes had exchanged fire with a B-29 Flying Fortress over Latvian territory. The Defense Department described the plane as an unarmed Navy Privateer that had been on training flight between Wiesbaden, Germany, and Copenhagen, Denmark. It later disappeared.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 1 -- Seventy-two contract bridge teams of four played here last night through the first knockout round in the masters' team of four championship, final and most important event in this twenty-sixth annual National Contract Bridge Championships.
OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 1 (AP) -- Mrs. G. H. Bostwick's Hyvania outgamed Mrs. E. duPont Weir's Clive of India in the S10,000 added Midsummer Hurdle Handicap at Monmouth Park today.
Ethiopian young persons are "just wild for education," and Emperor Haile Selassie has a yen for lemon pie.

Four officials of the Ryukyu Islands, who are in this country as guests of the United States Army, urged yesterday that the United States return control of the islands' civil administration to the Japanese Government.

HANOVER, Germany, Aug. 1 (UP) -- Bishop Hanns Lilje of Germany, who was arrested by the Nazis in connection with the assassination plot against Adolf Hitler, was elected today president of the Lutheran World Federation.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 1 -- The Berkshire Music Center, an integral part of the Berkshire festival development, is in its tenth year this summer, and the annual "Tanglewood on Parade," which is a long, informal show put on by and for the forces of the center, had the character of a retrospect today.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, Aug. 2 (AP) -- United States jet pilots, after having listed a record 32 to 2 score in air combat last month, opened the August tally by shooting down three MIG-15's and damaging two others yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Moscow has accused the State Department of lying about the reasons for suspending the magazine Amerika and ordering the Soviet information bulletin to cease publication in this country.

LONDON, Aug. 1 -- David Eccles, Minister of Works, announced today some of the box office arrangements for what he called "the most glorious and moving pageant in the world" -- the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II on June 2, 1953.

Two New York commodity futures markets marked time yesterday awaiting developments from abroad. Coffee traders continued uncertain over new Brazilian price support regulations, to take effect today. Rubber operators followed with no great hope the conversations in London on price stabilization measures.

To see what lies at the bottom of the sea and to view the plants and mobile creatures that live there, William Beebe and Otis Barton descended in a diving bell called a "bathysphere" to a depth of 3,000 feet in 1934. Barton outdid this performance in 1949 by going down to 4,500 feet in his "benthoscope." That still remains the record.

AT some crisis in each of the previously published volumes of Beverley Nichols' continuing autobiography, Life has rapped him lightly over the knuckles and whispered that it was much later than he seemed to think. This time Life waits until he has reached page 97 before it warns him again.

Agreements made with Soviet Russia at the wartime Big Three Conference at Yalta more than seven years ago have been the cause of continuing controversy in the Western world and, in this Presidential election year, have raised a sharp political issue in the United States. A FIVE-DAY program of talks, demonstrations, discussions technical clinics and picture shows with marked emphasis on practical photography in many fields will be held Aug. 12-16 at the Hotel New Yorker and Manhattan Center when the Photographic Society of America meets there for its 1952 convention.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 2 -- The Yugoslav Government has decided to introduce and enforce a considerable number of fundamental Yugoslav laws in Zone B of the Free Territory of Trieste, which it controls. This was another move to counteract a Western Allied decision to associate the Italian Government more closely in the administration of Zone A, which is controlled by British-American forces.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Officials who head Federal agencies responsible for the care and treatment of those who are mentally ill took sharp issue this week with Judge Maul S. Streit of New York, who censured state and Federal authorities for releasing from mental institutions potential killers and felons.

United States exports and imports of the normal commercial variety will tend to decline in the second half of 1952 and will close the year below the peak levels reached in 1951, it was agreed last week by Government and private foreign trade observers.

CAIRO, Aug. 2 -- "If Ismail Pasha's rule had been bad, his fall at least was dignified. His worst enemies must have pitied a man in the hour of his distress who had stood so high and who had fallen so low. HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Sweden's riders captured two gold medals today -- team and individual -- in the Olympic three-day event, one of the toughest equestrian tests in the world.

BALBOA HEIGHTS, C. Z., Aug. 2 -- A total of 30,073,022 tons or cargo passed through the Panama Canal in the fiscal year ended Jue 30, 1952, according to the report of the Governor. This was the second highest amount in the history of the canal, exceeded only in 1929 with 30,647,768 tons. All cargo statistics are given in long tons of 2,240 pounds.

MONTREAL, Aug, 2 (Canadian Press) -- Canada today won the first-round North American Zone Davis Cup tennis matches with Mexico by winning the doubles, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 4. Yesterday the Canadians defeated Mexico in two singles matches.

DALLAS, Aug. 2 -- The Federal Reserve Bank's monthly business summary reflected booming summer business on Thursday in the Southwest. Department store sales in June, the bank reported, were the highest for any June on record, although down seasonally from May.

NEW CITY, N. Y., Aug. 2 -- Rockland County, where considerable landscape changes will be effected soon by the New York State Thruway and the Palisades Interstate Parkway, also will get a new lake, four and a half miles long and a half-mile wide, along the Hackensack River in Clarkstown.

IN 1929 Reginald Reynolds spent several months at Gandhi's ashram (a spiritual and philosophic retreat) and met him once again at the 1931 Round Table Conference in London. The Brown Palace Hotel in Denver, Colo., the temporary headquarters of Republican nominee Dwight D. Eisenhower, is a plush, old-fashioned, comfortable hostelry. It was built in 1891 and is a reminder of that brief and gaudy silver age when Colorado was ruled by the Bonanza Kings.

Fall merchandise met with favorable consumer acceptance last week wherever it was offered despite the unusually hot weather, Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office, reported. Many buyers are expected in the wholesale market here after the middle of August to fill stocks and place reorders.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug 2 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois took his first direct slap at Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower today for promising to try to elect Republican members of Congress even though he could not endorse entirely their individual stands on foreign or domestic policies.

TEX McCRARY will not be co-featured with his wife, Jinx Falkenburg, next season on the "New York Close-Up" television series, which will resume over Channel 4 on Sept. 8 in a new time period, 2 to 12:30 P. M., Mondays through Fridays.

A simple radar has appeared to detect cars or anything else that approaches the main entrance of the General Electric Company's research laboratory in Schenectady, N. Y. The system was developed by William C. White, C. Luther Andrews and Hiram S. Lasher, who conduct research in electronic physics.

Hugh Massingham's article "Nye Bevan's One Rule -- 'Fight'" (July 13) was of interest to me. Mr. Bevan is, certainly, a dynamic man and, potentially, a tremendous force in British politics. In the author's treatment of Mr. Bevan, however, it seems to me that he neglected a very important observation.

LEADERS of motion picture studio unions that recently began a concerted effort to halt what they term the "runaway" production of films by Hollywood companies and individuals in foreign countries will carry their campaign to the biennial national convention of the International Alliance of Theatrical and Stage Employes and Motion Picture Operators of the United States and Canada, which will open in Minneapolis, Minn., tomorrow.

YALTA means many things. It is an historical event, it is a symbol, it is, already, a myth. To the historian it is, quite simply, a conference that took place on the bleak shores of the Crimea early in February, 1945, a conference designed to settle many practical details of war and peacemaking.
BONN, Aug. 2 -- The strains and stresses which affect any free confederation to resist tyranny pulled and hauled at the structure of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization this week.
KANSAS CITY, Aug. 2 -- President Truman told friends today that he had been demoted to the rear ranks of politics but was ready to serve in the Presidential campaign with old vigor.
PARIS, Aug. 2 -- Some important French officials expressed regret today that the argument over the United States defense aid by offshore purchases had become emotional and unrealistic.

GREAT BRITAIN'S long-range program for the capture of a part of the world market for commercial airliners with its de Havilland Comet, the world's first jet airliner to be put in operation, inched forward again last week.

THE greatness of Leonardo da Vinci is one of the least disputed points in art history and, this year, Europe celebrates the 500th anniversary of his birth with a series of exhibitions of unsurpassable richness and variety.

A GREAT debate on the effects of the new McGuire Fair Trade Law is raging drowsily this summer throughout the book world. Familiars of the measure, signed by President Truman on July 14, are referring to it as the Bastille Bill.
A strike against the New York Central Railroad east of Buffalo by the four railroad brotherhoods has been averted at least temporarily.

A FEW Mondays ago, on July 14, President Truman signed H R. 5767, a bill named the McGuire-Keogh Fair Trade Act. This act will have an effect upon a major portion of the retail trade of the United States, with attendant repercussions in the record industry, What happens in the record industry depends on the stand taken by the manufacturers.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 2 -- Plans to go forward with construction of a $45,000,000 brewery on a 65-acre site in the San Fernando Valley were announced yesterday by Anheuser-Busch, Inc., after receiving assurance from the City Council that adequate sewer facilities will be provided.

Ambrose Lightship, the chunky, 132 foot, bright red vessel that for a quarter of a century stood sentinel duty twenty miles off the Battery at the seaward entrance to Ambrose Channel, is scheduled to be relieved by a newer craft now being prepared at Curtis Bay, Md.

ALTHOUGH based on the author's television program, "The Johns Hopkins Science Review," this book stands on its own merits, and is complete in itself. In a step-by- step manner Lynn Poole discusses many aspects of science today and points out problems involved in modern invention and discovery.
BOSTON, Aug. 2 (UP) -- The Farmers Home Administration announced today that it would begin processing drought-caused disaster loans for Maine and Massachusetts farmers Monday.

RESERVATIONS for accommodations in London for the coronation of Queen Elizabeth on June 2, 1953, are already mounting and just how many grandstand seats will be available is at present worrying planners.

SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Fighting slackened on "Old Baldy" hill in western Korea yesterday after Allied infantrymen had beaten off three Chinese Communist assaults on the shell-blasted crest.

PLANTS that will grow in crevices between stones are rather scarce, yet there is a definite need for them in landscape design. Between stepping stones of garden paths, steps or terraces, creeping plants break the monotony of the thoroughfare.
Western nations tackled a ticklish problem last week. It concerned the method of bringing Japan into the organization that is trying to keep strategic materials from going beyond the Iron Curtain.
HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 2 -- Forrest (Phog) Allen of Kansas University, assistant coach of the United States basketball team, said today "the Russians played the smartest game they could have."
RATZEBURG, Germany, Aug. 2 (UP) -- Armed Russian troops and Communist police, ignoring British protests, seized a sliver of Western Germany today and declared it part of the Soviet zone.

KALAMAZOO, Mich., Aug. 2 (AP) -- Jack Frost of Monterey and James Read of Santa Monica won their semi-finals matches today for an all-California final tomorrow in the national junior tennis championships.

It is not usual for a book to maligned by its blurb writer, but that is what has happened to Madeline Babcock Smith's charming novel "The Lemon Jelly Cake." It is made to sound like one more folksy book in which everyone's face is firmly turned toward the sunny side.

This country is short approximately 20,000 skilled tool and die makers, and the prospect of getting them is dim. Even if 20,000 apprentices were to start training tomorrow it would take four to seven years before they could take up their jobs as skilled workers. In New York alone there is a shortage of 1,500 workers.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 2 (AP) -- New York won the thirty-eighth annual Union Printers baseball tournament today, drubbing the defending Washington nine, 7 -- 1, in the final game.

Monmouth Park, at Oceanport, N. J., will have no competition from the Long Island tracks this week in its bid for the metropolitan running-horse trade. New York racing, after a 107-day run at Jamaica, Belmont and Aqueduct since April 1, switches tomorrow to Saratoga Springs.
The concept of sustained productivity is gradually making headway in the cycle-ridden textile industry.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 2 -- Although a week has passed since Senora Eva Peron's death, there appeared to be no end to the long queues of people still waiting to pay their last respects to the former First Lady. The press continued to publish oversized newspaper devoted chiefly to the nation's mourning.

Skidmore College, in cooperation with New York University Hospital and affiliated agencies, is offering a new course to prepare young women as dietitians in a shorter time than that usually required. It includes three years of study at Skidmore, two summers and an entire year at New York University Hospital, two months in the out-patient department of the hospital and two months with a public health bureau.

" IL faut etre absolument moderne," wrote Rimbaud; and this was the order of the day given by a general to an army of writers, artists and composers for perhaps fifty years. There were the poems of Apollinaire about a Paris of slums, bars, the Eiffel Tower and airplanes, and journeys to other cities.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 2 -- The strategy of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson's campaign for the Presidency is based upon and symbolized by this historic Illinois capital.

A NEW French luxury liner -- the fastest and largest to emerge from a French shipyard since World War II -- arrived here Wednesday on her maiden voyage. Despite an ignominious debut which saw her towed to her pier after a power failure in the lower harbor, she is truly a beautiful ship.

Grave crises have struck almost simultaneously at the northern and southern borders of the Middle East, the predominantly Moslem belt which links the Eastern and Western worlds. One ruler, Farouk of Egypt, has been deposed by a military coup. Another, Shah Mohammed Reza of Iran, finds his throne tottering.

HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 2 -- A twenty - year Olympic victory drought ended in a cascade of first-place medals tonight as America's boxers swept five championships, defeated Russia in the only face-to-face meeting of the two nations in the sport and won the unofficial team title for the first time.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 2 -- The Belgian Socialist Federation of Labor today ordered a twenty-four hour strike and a demonstration for next Saturday in protest against the two-year compulsory military service period in force in Belgium.

HONOLULU, Aug. 2 -- Around a green baize table near the spot where a World War II aggressor struck first in the Pacific, the foreign ministers of Australia, New Zealand and the United States are to sit down Monday for what in a sense is a historic meeting.
A tale of an industrial Golconda where diamonds glitter in profusion was brought back from Detroit yesterday by Harvey Turnure, who deals in automobiles, not gems.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 2 -- A runner-up in his two previous starts, Titanic, the 4-year-old bay horse owned by Mrs. William C. Harris of Massapequa, L. I., stepped out briskly in the stretch tonight to capture the Brookhaven Class A pace in a blanket finish that featured the harness racing program at Roosevelt Raceway.

WITH a record number of Americans vacationing in Europe this summer (somewhere around 400,000), interest in shipboard cookery is greater than ever. Both those who go and those who stay want to know what is being served, how it is presented, the general quality and style of the cuisine.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Two events of this week reminded the capital of the great, continuing problems of atomic energy and of the considerable advance that has been made in the seven years since the bomb was exploded over Hiroshima.
BOSTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- A Coast Guardsman's photograph probably will not help solve the riddle of "flying saucers," one of the nation's ranking astro-physicists said today.

In a hold-up of the Persian Curio Shop at 534 Madison Avenue, near Fifty-fourth Street, shortly after 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon, an armed thug escaped with $200 in cash and jewelry valued at $4,000.

AS the early rays of the sun rising out of Lake Michigan began to penetrate the sultry canyons of downtown Chicago on the morning following the nomination of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson for the Presidency last week-end, a small man with a bald head and a sly grin observed: "Never in history was there such a campaign. Not a nickel was spent by us."

JAMES Thurber's article, "Dark Suspicions," which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES, July 27, proves, if it needed proving, that he is an incomparable humorist. His message is studded with incongruities that only an artist of his caliber could effectively exploit.

PARIS, Aug 2 -- By an adroit maneuver, the aging Bey of Tunis has transformed the political situation in his French-protected country and diverted French pressure for action on an unpopular reform program from himself to representatives of the Tunisian people.

A DRY - BATTERY portable electric flash unit that uses two 225-volt dry batteries in series and offers a film guide number of 220 with fast panchromatic film, 35 - 45 with color, has been announced by Strobo Research, 4351 North Thirty-fifth Street, Milwaukee 16, Wis.
Speaking for a few of us who watched the TV screen, we did not find the recent convention as confusing as did the commentators and columnists.
HOUSTON, Tex., Aug. 2 -- The $28,643,532 Gulf Freeway, stretching 50.75 miles from here to Galveston, was opened to through traffic today after brief ceremonies held about midway of the route.

IT was indeed encouraging to read "A Literary Letter from India" by Suresh Vaidya. Although the classical Sanskrit literature of India has a small -- but enthusiastic -- following in this country, the literature of the modern languages of India is unfortunately unknown to most Americans, and even to those who profess interest in the current social and political problems of that Feat nation.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 2 -- India is involved today in a great debate, in which the fundamental concepts of civil rights generally cherished here appear to be pitted with the practicalities of safeguarding the orderly functioning of democratic government against tentative threats of violent overthrow by the Communists and others.

FOR a so-called "nation of shooters," this country made a sad showing, both at the World Shooting Championships at Oslo and in the Olympics, and were it not for a few individuals this country would now be completely obscured in the powder smoke of Norwegian, Swiss, Russian and Swedish shooters.

THE tugboat Betty Ann swayed with the tide, the waves slapping her hull, waiting for word that she was needed. Finally a megaphoned voice summoned: "Betty Ann Ahoy. Assist tug Nancy O with barges in the bay."

Rain, varying from showers to a steady downpour, brought some relief to parched crops in several states along the Atlantic seaboard yesterday and farmers took hope that Weather Bureau forecasts for more rain during the week-end would be accurate.

Visitors at the 1952 Pittsburgh International Exhibition of contemporary world painting may expect to be disturbed by what they see. Gordon Washburn, director of fine arts of the Carnegie Institute, who has just returned from a seven-month inspection tour, selecting 160 European canvases for the show, says the exhibit will represent "somewhat advanced material."

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 -- Sam Snead dropped to a 74 today while Tommy Bolt slammed a 68 to gain the 54-hole lead in the $30,000 All-American golf tournament at Tam o'Shanter by one stroke with a 205, eleven under par.

Arturo Toscanini led the N. B. C. Symphony late yesterday afternoon in the second of his two mid-summer programs of "concert favorites on the lighter side." An audience filled Carnegie Hall to hear it, and it was broadcast on a coast-to-coast network.

BOSTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The reason girls in the United States are getting married younger and younger, says a Boston University Professor, Lowell S. Trowbridge, is that they are too lazy to go to work.
RARITAN TOWNSHIP, N. J., Aug. 2 -- A 12-year-old Raritan Township girl faces arraignment on homicide charges, after the death by beating of a boy, 5, who boarded at her Park Place home.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2 -- With the ending of the strike the steel industry finds itself with reduced inventories, stronger prices and broader demand. Wolfgang Borchert, a young German poet, died in 1947, consumed by a strange illness he contracted at the Russian front and in the Nazi prisons to which he was confined for speaking his mind.

In "A Briton Explains British Views of Us" (July 20), the eminent cartoonist David Low argues that because all political parties in Britain accept the welfare state it is completely justified. BECAUSE American music cannot be copyrighted for more than fifty-six years, most of Edward MacDowell's music is now in the public domain. Nevertheless, the A. P. Schmidt Company of Philadelphia has continued to pay royalties to Mrs. MacDowell, the composer's 94-year-old widow.

LONDON, Aug. 2 -- An audience of several thousand Londoners overflowed onto the lawns surrounding the bandstand on Victoria Embankment tonight when word got around that seventy kilted lassies from the highlands of Iowa were scheduled to give a guest performance in place of the band of the Coldstream Guards.

A nick-of-time homer by Jim Rhodes gave the Giants a 4-3 triumph over the Pirates at the rain-drenched Polo Grounds yesterday. The slugging rookie outfielder connected off Murry Dickson with Alvin Dark on base and two out in the bottom of the sixth inning, just before an increasingly heavy shower made it necessary to call the contest.

TORONTO, Aug. 2 -- After Red China had announced that it would reject any on-the-spot inquiry of germ warfare charges in Korea that was tied to the Red Cross, the international conference of that organization, by 62 to 0, approved today a watered-down resolution on the germ issue. There were thirteen abstentions by the Soviet bloc.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2 -- The Frontiers of America, National Negro service club, pledged itself today to continue its fight for civil rights "on Federal and state levels."

DALLAS, Aug. 2 -- The Federal Reserve Bank's monthly business summary reflected booming summer business on Thursday in the Southwest. Department store sales in June, the bank reported, were the highest for any June on record, although down seasonally from May.
ATLANTA, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower has a brighter chance to win Southern electoral votes in November than any Republican Presidential nominee since Herbert Hoover in 1928.

Rocco Cirigliano, 19-year-old Ohio State freshman competing unattached, retained two championships in the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union senior title swimming meet at the Sunset Park pool in Brooklyn yesterday.

COOKSBURG, Pa. -- The largest stand of virgin white pine in the eastern United States, where one may see woodlands looking just as they did before the white man came to America, lies only about 400 miles from New York City.

THERE is not an expert bridge player in the United States, and perhaps there is none in the world, who would hesitate to counsel against dangerous overcalls. The United States yesterday clinched the unofficial team championship of the 1952 Olympic Games with a next-to-last-day surge that brought eight gold medals, 111 points and a total point tally of 610 to Russia's 553 1/2.

He had the mount on Charfran Stable's favored Crafty Admiral, and the 4-year-old colt did another of his all-the-way-in-front jobs to collect $19,450 and set up a $5.30 mutuel.

Y., Aug. 2 -- A fleet of 62 racing yachts drew miserable sailing weather this afternoon as Echo Bay Yacht Club conducted the first section of its two-day regatta on Long Island Sound. Trade observers estimated volume for the week at 6 per cent below 1951, which compares with a drop of 12 per cent recorded the previous week.

Five American-flag steamship companies canceled their charters last month on twelve Government-owned Victory-type vessels because of declining business in what operators describe as a serious shipping slump.

YOUNG AUDIENCES, INC., organized last February, is primed for extensive activity starting this fall. If it requires some assistance in the way of money to launch a full-scale program, as it would like to do, it deserves to receive whatever funds it asks for.

ROME -- It was with a mingling of remorse and glee that we left in Rome the most frustrated guide in all Europe. He was an eager and a challenging cicerone, his English the result of years in a British prisoner-of-war camp in Africa, his guiding the result of a bullet in his left arm so he could no longer work as an automobile mechanic.

WHEN this symposium first appeared in the pages of The Saturday Review of Literature it made a very exciting number, and now, reprinted as a book, it is a must for all those readers who want to understand how and why Russia has a head start over the United States in the struggle for the mind of Europe.

IT is the Englishman's martyrdom to the bazaar, the garden party which keeps the "fete worse than death" theme perennially funny. John Moore in his latest novel has captured precisely the mood of despairing bewilderment with which a Britisher prepares to Do Something Helpful about local public festivities.
TOKYO, Sunday, Aug. 3 -- The United Nations and Communist delegates negotiating at Panmunjom for an armistice in Korea resumed plenary sessions today in a thirty-two-minute meeting.

ONE of our most popular play reviewers, closing his most recent report of a new production, spoke of its direction as "fast, ingenious, and altogether admirable." The first part of the same review pointed out that the production failed to catch the spirit of the play, or to convey the author's intention.

Fans of the New York Yankees are in for another memorable treat when the club holds its sixth annual Yankee Stadium Oldtimers' Day, Saturday, Aug. 30, to commemorate the golden anniversary of the Yankees in the American League.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Political predictions of any kind are an extremely risky business, but if one may be ventured here with full disclaimers for either omniscience or proximity to the horse's mouth, it is that the campaign of 1952 will be notable for its concentration upon issues and the absence of personal bitterness between the two principal candidates.

SARATOGA SPRINGS -- They're off at Saratoga tomorrow, and to those who circle the calendar with horseshoes Aug. 4 in this Adirondack city marks the unofficial first day of summer. The Saratoga trunk-lines have been humming with calls for reservations and the hotels and paddocks are filling up.

A $300,000 grant from an agency of the Ford Foundation has enabled the National Association of Educational Broadcasters to do some pathfinding in the radio field by producing and planning to produce four broadcast series of historical and contemporary significance.

Queens area chairmen for the fan canister campaign of the Queens Council of the Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind, were announced yesterday by Mrs. William B. Comerford, Queens chairman. The drive will begin Sept. 17.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 2 -- Playing through a heavy downpour and finishing their match in fog, Mal Galletta and Gordon Stott of North Hills won a prolonged semi-final in the John G. Anderson Memorial today at the twenty-first hole from the Kuntz brothers, Bob and Bill of Bonnie Briar.
CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (UP) -- Eddie Robinson drove in four runs to lead the White Sox to a 6 to 1 victory over the Senators before a ladies day crowd of 14,439 today.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 2 -- The trade agreement signed last night by East and West Germany, providing for a total exchange of goods valued at 400,000,000 marks, is not likely to halt Soviet protests against Western "discriminating trade practices" and "illegal restrictions on trade."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Four Western Governments and Japan agreed today to bring Japanese trade with the Soviet Union and its Communist satellites under the supervision of a semi-secret export control committee established in Paris.

As blackberries ripen, the fence rows and briar patches are full of dark, sun-warmed, juicy sweetness. This is the time to eat blackberries, since many say with reason that blackberries should be eaten as you pick them, still warm and dead-ripe; certainly they do lose flavor when iced, though they keep better that way.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 2 -- President Truman signed today the Bonn peace contract with the West German Republic and a protocol to the North Atlantic Treaty embodying the European Defense Community arrangement.

I HAD hoped to find them both, when I went to No. 27 Goose Street in Rome: Alberto Moravia and his wife Elsa Morante. I only found him. "My wife is not here; she says she can't work here. So she got herself a small flat where she does all her writing.

PERTH AMBOY, N. J., Aug. 2 --Named as the man who robbed a Bound Brook loan company and four of its employes of $1,237 on July 25, Russell Ford, 30 years old, an escaped convict from the Connecticut State Prison, was lodged today in Somerset County jail after having been shot and captured in Perth Amboy's business district last night.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The United States Steel Corporation is building a huge iron ore dock -- more than one-fifth of a mile long -- in Texas and floating it in parts to Venezuela.

FOR 11-year-old Judith, the best part of moving to the country is that she can learn to ride a horse. The horse that takes her heart is a beautiful and spirited young filly, Freelance, which the owner agrees to sell.
In an apparent attempt to evade being fingerprinted, an alleged bookmaker jumped to the street yesterday afternoon from the second floor of the Criminal Courts Building, 100 Centre Street.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 2 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson and his advisers, delayed nearly twenty-four hours in Denver by aircraft trouble, arrived at San Francisco Airport at 6:41 P. M. Pacific daylight time (9:41 P. M., Eastern daylight time) today, en route to the Pacific Mutual Security Conference in Hawaii.

Eight teen-age youths were arrested in Queens yesterday on charges varying from the theft of lawn furniture to burglary. Two 15-year-old boys were accused of accepting a $5 note from another youth whom they are alleged to have threatened with bodily harm. A detective of the Jamaica station made the arrests after allegedly watching the transaction in St. Albans Park, St. Albans.

HANOVER, Germany, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Dr. O. Frederick Nolde of Philadelphia told the World Lutheran Federation today the United States and Russia were especially to blame for a situation that he described as "dangerously near to the beginning of a new world catastrophe."

BODY armor has returned to the battlefield. Our combat troops -- G I.'s and marines -- in Korea are now wearing armored jackets made of nylon and fibrous glass. These "vests" have proved their effectiveness and are credited with saving many lives.

THE folk tales in earlier collections by Frances Carpenter came from a single country. In this fine book of stories about horses she has ranged far afield in time as well as place. Many of these tales have been translated for the first time from unfamiliar sources and will be new to our boys and girls; others are famous legends retold.

BARBER: Symphony No. 1; Nils Lehmann and Stockholm Symphony; Dover Beach; Songs from Chamber Music; Paul King, baritone; Sam Quincy, pianist, and Hartt String Quartet (Classic). Barber's early symphony is energetically played, but the recording is thin in sound, noisy in surfaces.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Aug. 2 -- The radar station of the Illinois State Water Survey at the University of Illinois Airport here detected a river in the sky the other night, Glenn E. Stout, meteorologist, reported today.

OF LONDON'S twenty-eight boroughs perhaps a dozen have names which are well known beyond the metropolitan boundaries; only one has a firmly established connotation with a specific brand of entertainment, and even art.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Some confusion has developed in the Democratic National Committee here over the precise part it is expected to play in the forthcoming Presidential campaign and who will directly supervise its activities.

THIS study, concerned with finding ways to prevent human maladjustments that make children delinquent, should be read by responsible citizens in general, and educators and parents in particular. It presents the fundamentals of a ten-year survey by Sheldon Glueck, Professor of Law at Harvard, and Eleanor Glueck, assisted by a staff of specialists.

NEW LONDON, Aug. 2 -- The Northern New Jersey Division won the Commodore's Cup at the seventh annual rendezvous of the Northern Area, United States Coast Guard Auxiliary, which started at the Coast Guard Academy here yesterday and will end tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The Army and Air Force are completing plans to offer commissions of indefinite length to reserve officers and to release those who decline.

HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 2 (UP) -- An unpleasant Olympic incident was narrowly averted today when two suspended Uruguayan basketball players received their third place bronze medals with the rest of their team-mates and then had to give them back.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- More than nine million persons may begin receiving an increase of from $2.50 to $8.60 a month in social security benefits with their October payments.

PARIS, Aug. 2 -- France's efforts to apply a series of moderate home-rule reforms in her North African protectorate of Tunisia before the Arab Nationalists can bring their demands for complete internal autonomy before the United Nations were stalled this week by a royal roadblock.

TRENTON, Aug. 2 -- Harold G. Hoffman, director of the division of employment security, Department of Labor and Industry, said today 46,000 New Jersey employers had received notices of unemployment insurance tax rates -- most of them higher -- for the fiscal year 1952-53.
The American Bureau of Shipping, technical classification society, has reached the peacetime high point of its long career with a total of 8,494 vessels, aggregating more than 37,000,000 gross tons.
In a recent issue of THE TIMES Dr. Howard Rusk pointed out that in 1951 in the United States $181,000,000 was spent for medical research. This sum is pitifully small.

OTTAWA, Aug. 2 (Canadian Press) -- Canada recorded a purchase balance of $9,300,000 -- first in six months -- in international security transactions during May, the Bureau of Statistics reported today.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 2 (UP) -- The Athletics rallied for four runs in the ninth inning today and defeated the Indians, 6 to 4. Allie Clark's third pinch homer of the year ignited the rally.

RIDGEWOOD, N. J., Aug. 2 -- The New York Public Library, which for months has been seeking to acquire costumes, records and scenery from the property of R. H. Burnside, for many years manager of the Hippodrome in New York, is racing against time and vandalism.

THE turnabout in demand for consumer durable goods that is now taking place may well prove a significant development in retail trade. It suggests a change from the cautious attitude which the public has maintained with respect to prices.

WASHINGTON -- Residents, both year - round and summer variety, of the resort towns along the Atlantic shore of the Delaware-Maryland-Virginia peninsula are of several minds about the value and effect of the opening last week of the new bridge across Chesapeake Bay.

Within the last year, outmoded city regulations and ordinances that threatened the unhampered operations of the television industry here have been revised, with the result that the City of New York is expected to retain its position of commanding importance in television.

MANY historians -- Bancroft, Prescott, Motley, Parkman, Parton, Mahan, for example -- have been more widely read than Henry Adams; none other has been as painstakingly studied, as voluminously interpreted.
HARTFORD, Aug. 2 -- The death of Senator Brien McMahon has left both major political parties in Connecticut uncertain and confused over a successor.

At Lisbon in February the North Atlantic Council set a goal of fifty divisions in Western Europe by the end of 1952. The NATO Ministers realized that the goal was ambitious and might have to be revised if the arms program put unbearable strains on our Allies' economy.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 2 -- A former chief of staff of the German U-boat service thinks that the submarine arm of the Soviet Navy has been overrated by the West. The improvement of detection devices, the shortage of competent Soviet crews and the absence of initiative among Soviet commanders would, in his opinion, be barriers to Russian success.

MADRID, Aug. 2 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco indicated today that what he regarded as Washington's failure to treat Spain on a par with the other Western European nations was the basic reason for the virtual deadlock in the current United States-Spanish negotiations to Conclude agreements on military and economic collaboration designed to strengthen the defense system of Western Europe.

FOR twenty-five years John Martin has occupied, in the name of THE NEW YORK TIMES, an aisle seat in dance recital halls, opera houses, theatres, movie houses. He has ventured into off-the-beaten-track studios, into tufted night clubs.

A new curriculum, which will offer greater flexibility for four-year liberal arts education, has been approved by the faculty at Hollins College, a small woman's liberal arts college in Virginia. The newly devised plan of study is constructed to give the student an opportunity to spread her degree requirements through all four years.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 2 -- Some of the best-informed observers of Middle Eastern affairs here see in the coup in Egypt of Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib an opportunity for the United States to exert its influence and begin a new era in the Middle East.

If it were not for the tragic implications of what has been happening in the International Red Cross Conference at Toronto there would be a temptation to laugh at the magnitude of Communist effrontery. When an observer from Malta referred to the Katyn Massacre and the refusal of North Korea to admit Red Cross observers the Polish delegate accused the speaker of "injecting propaganda."

All types of building projects, started in New York in the first six months of 1952 were valued at $155,000,000, about 21 per cent below the same period last year, according to a preliminary report released by Robert R. Behlow, regional director of the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 2 (UP) -- The International Basketball Federation took steps today to control European referees who penalized fast-shooting, hard-passing teams such as the United States.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Aug. 2 -- A new method of compacting road materials, designed to reduce costs and provide better driving conditions, has been tested successfully in a joint project of Rutgers University and the State Highway Department.

This afternoon at Travers Island, following the Harry A. Jackson Memorial Race, the New York Athletic Club's Yachting Department will have its clam bake, preceded by a cocktail hour. Commodore Eugene J. Hynes and Chairman Ray Georgi have scheduled some entertainment.
WASHINGTON Aug. 2 -- The bright prospects for the economic future that President Truman described in his recent mid-year economic report have now become clouded with uncertainty.

YPSILANTI, Mich., Aug. 2 -- Doak Walker, who gashed his pass-throwing right arm in an accident last June, was in the starting backfield today as the Detroit Lions went through their first scrimmage of the Season at their training camp.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Polly Riley of Texas, a Curtis Cup star, captured the fifty-second annual women's Western golf championship today for the second time, defeating Mary Ann Downey of Baltimore, 2 and 1.

ST. ANN'S, N. S. -- Scotch-Canadians of Cape Breton Island will gather at the Gaelic College in St. Ann's for the fourteenth annual Mod or meeting of the clans, from next Thursday through Saturday, and Cape Breton Scots will be joined by descendants of Scotsmen from all parts of the province of Nova Scotia, the very name of which means New Scotland.

NO phase of the second World War has been so gravely misinterpreted and misjudged as the Yalta conference and the agreements it produced. On one hand, these are denounced as a betrayal of democratic principles and of Anglo-American interests and as the source of our post-war difficulties with the Soviet Union.

The appointment by the Secretary of Defense of a predominantly civilian commission to study the utilization of manpower in the armed services was strongly recommended by a Senate subcommittee in a recent report.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 2 -- At the finish of the semi-final round in the Masters Pairs championship, conducted at the Sheraton Gibson Hotel by the American Contract Bridge League, Frank Weisbach and Allan P. Harvey, both of Cincinnati, forged ahead of a seventy-two- pair finalist field with a three-session score of 323 points.

AMERICAN readers know Father Bruckberger only as the author of two brief parables, as sensitive as hares and as finely wrought as Florentine leather. "The Seven Miracles of Gubbio" and "The Stork and the Jewels" gave glimpses of a Hans Christian Andersen with a deeper dimension of compassion, of a Swift without the bitterness of that uncommon scold.

CURRENT happenings in three widely separated parts of the world -- a death, a birth and a royal abdication -- serve to illustrate once more how philately ties in with news developments of universal interest.

I read your editorial of July 30 entitled "Criminal Insanity" with particular interest and approbation, since the terrible tragedy that struck down Miss Eileen Fahey has moved all public officials to consider what measures are needed to protect the community in a problem so vexatious and difficult of solution.

TOKYO, Aug. 2 -- South Korea will vote Tuesday to elect a President for the next four years. It is virtually certain that there can be just one outcome of the republic's first election by popular vote: the return of Dr. Syngman Rhee to the post.

HAVANA, Aug. 2 -- The United States swept into the final round of the North American Zone Davis Cup tennis eliminations today when Gardnar Mulloy of Miami and Hugh Stewart of Los Angeles defeated Pope Aguero and Juan Weiss of Cuba in doubles, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 2.

The largest number of American visitors ever recorded for a single month--26,467 persons -- arrived in Great Britain in June, James T. Turbayne, United States manager of the British Travel Association, announced yesterday. Mr. Turbayne said the figure represented a 46 per cent increase over the same period in 1951.

OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 2 -- Count Flame, owned by E. B. Bixer and ridden by Hedley Woodhouse, raced confidently through the entire mile and a quarter to win the $25,000-added Choice Stakes at Monmouth Park today. A crowd estimated at 33,625 -- the largest gathering of the year -- cheered the performance of Count Flame, for he was the heavily played favorite and his mutuel return was $4.60.
DETROIT, Aug. 2 (UP) -- Dom DiMaggio drove home five runs with a grand-slam homer and a single today to lead the Red Sox to a 10-to-5 victory over the Detroit Tigers.

IN today's column I should like to pursue a little further some of the issues raised in Edith Hamilton's essay on Faulkner, to which I referred last week. She approached consideration of our ablest romantic writer in the light of her knowledge and understanding of the art of ancient Greece.

The problem of Germany's debts to the outside world is on the verge of settlement on terms assuring holders of the defaulted dollar bonds that their claims against the defunct Reich and its local governments and corporate enterprises will have a substantial value in the public market when trading in the German external securities is resumed in the United States, probably next Spring.

Flying saucers -- or "objects," as the Air Force prefers to call them -- are back in the news, largely because they have been reported in the night sky near Washington, D. C. Last week they were detected by radar. Two Army jet planes were sent after them.

BOSTON, Aug. 2 (UP) -- The seventh-place Reds continued their bid to go home to their new manager, Rogers Hornsby, in sixth place in the league standings by belting the Braves for the second consecutive game, 8 to 3, today before 1,567 fans.

THE clothing salesman who "won't let you wear it unless it fits" now has a commercial counterpart in, believe it or not, the field of gardening. He's the dealer who won't sell garden equipment "unless it fits."

Two fugitives from Matteawan State Hospital suspected of kidnapping and robbing two Brooklyn men last Friday were arrested by the police of the West Thirtieth Street station at 7:23 o'clock last night, just eight minutes after they had been reported in that precinct.

HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 2 (UP) -- The Olympic flame flickers out and dies for another four years tomorrow night, the closing day of competition -- always exciting and sometimes tumultuous -- of the fifteenth Olympiad.

An ex-convict was arrested yesterday in Harlem and charged with the robbery and brutal beating on early Friday morning of 81-year-old Mrs. Alice M. Lowenstein in her apartment at 929 Park Avenue. The widow is in critical condition at Lenox Hill Hospital.

FIVE years ago, at Bremerhaven, Germany, a United States transport, the Marine Perch, took on a strange human cargo. It was composed of DP's of all ages and faiths, relics of Hitler's ghettos and concentration camps and of the post-war DP camps.

Out on Lake Washington, Seattle, where speed boat history of world consequence has been made repeatedly for three seasons, another of the classic regattas for the Gold Cup will be held Saturday. Although no East Coast boats are entered, Detroit will be making another desperate challenge to bring the internationally famous trophy back to the automotive city.

LONDON. THOUGHT about public affairs in recent years has been so completely absorbed by the problem of relations between Russia and the West that various other problems, which would remain even if that one were solved, have not received as much attention as they deserve.

Women active in behalf of the Girls Service League have taken over the first benefit performance of Terence Rattigan's new play, "The Deep Blue Sea," with Margaret Sullavan in the leading role, on the night of Nov. 10 at the Morosco Theatre.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Whenever weather and rainfall permit, certain planting may be started. Bulbs of colchicum, sternbergia and autumn crocus are set out to bloom this fall, madonna lilies for next June. Iris may be divided and transplanted and new ones set out. Oriental poppy is another perennial for late summer planting. In the South, sow vegetables for fall.

Eastern management has not been making enough of an effort to do business in the Western states, according to a survey released last week by John D. Louth of McKinsey Co., management consultant. Mr. Louth said he had collected a bill of particulars against the "home office back East."
RYE, N. Y., Aug. 2 -- The American Yacht Club's annual five-day cruise started shortly before noon today with a fleet of thirty-three in three divisions.

DENVER, Aug. 2 -- A spokesman for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower disavowed tonight any suggestion that the Republican nominee war considering any deals with Mississippi Dixiecrats for electoral support from that state.
Men's sports shirts will have the feminine touch -- to make them appear ruggedly masculine.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Members of the National Association of the Sixth Infanry Division at their annual reunion here today adopted a resolution bidding the Government either wage an "aggressive" war in Korea or withdraw our forces entirely.
HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Andre Noyelle, a determined 20-year-old Belgian, won the grueling 120-mile cycling road race in the Olympic Games today as the United States' team was eliminated.

WHEN a popular Broadway actress goes to work in the summer theatre, she generally does so in the interest of about $2,000 a week plus 50 per cent of the gross over the theatre's break-even point, thereby nicely serving both art and commerce in a rustic setting and laying up a little something against the beginning of the fall television season.
