Oriental poppy is another perennial for late summer planting. In the South, sow vegetables for fall.

Eastern management has not been making enough of an effort to do business in the Western states, according to a survey released last week by John D. Louth of McKinsey Co., management consultant. Mr. Louth said he had collected a bill of particulars against the "home office back East."
RYE, N. Y., Aug. 2 -- The American Yacht Club's annual five-day cruise started shortly before noon today with a fleet of thirty-three in three divisions.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UP) -- A staff report of a Senate subcommittee proposed tonight that them requirement for non-Communist affidavits from labor union officials be eliminated from the Taft-Hartley law.

The Port of New York Authority will sell thirty-six dwellings and thirty-nine other buildings in Moonachie, N. J., at public auction Aug. 26, beginning at noon, in the First Presbyterian Church there.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 3 -- Paul G. Hoffman, director of the Ford Foundation, announced today a grant of $2,900,000 by the foundation to the United Nations Refugee Emergency Fund. The money is to be expended in an attempt to find g permanent solution of the problem of more than 10,000,000 expelled persons and political exiles in western Europe.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 3 -- The largest fleet listed in years for an annuel cruise of the New York Yacht Club was gathered in the mouth of the Thames River this afternoon. The first of seven racing runs and special events will be held tomorrow.

The work of resurfacing Tenth Avenue between Forty-fourth and Sixtieth Street will begin this morning, Manhattan Borough President Robert F. Wagner announced last night. The job will consist largely of laying a "skin" of asphalt over the old trolley tracks and over all other portions of the avenue where the surface is not in prime condition.
READING, Pa., Aug. 3 -- Any time anyone wants to start a scramble among the pilots of the 107th Fighter Wing of the New York Air National Guard, all he has to do is touch off the "scramble" alarm.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Sixteen prominent Republicans, most of them officeholders, declared today that a Republican victory in November would speed enactment of a Fair Employment Practices law with adequate enforcement powers.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., Aug. 3 -- The Riverside Yacht Club drew an entry of thirty-seven to its championship series regatta for the combined Indian Harbor, Greenwich Cove and Riverside fleets today. The class winners were Sam Pryor Jr.'s Luders-16 Invictus; Carl Schoeller's Lightning, Jester; John Muhlfeld's Ajax among the Quincy Adams-17's and Tom Nelson with Two Bits in the Hurricane Class.

HONOLULU, Aug. 3 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson arrived here at 3:40 P. M. (9:40 P. M., Eastern daylight time) today, declaring that during the next three or four days he and the foreign ministers of Australia and New Zealand would discuss "every single Pacific problem, every last one of them."

MANILA, Aug. 3 -- Observers who watched the Moro surrender ceremonies at Jolo Island last week returned here with the strong impression that the bandit leader Hadji Kamlon had put one over on the Philippine Government and had not really yielded either himself, his men or his arms.

Chuck Dressen is goin' fishin' today. Unconcerned with the big series against the Giants starting tomorrow night at the Polo Grounds, the manager of the Dodgers, who are idle today, will be trying to hook trout in an upstate stream. Nor will anyone deny Dressen's right to a day of relaxation after yesterday's events had catapulted the Brooks to a six-and-a-half-length lead over the second-place Giants.

" Facing Life's Incompleteness" was the subject of the sermon delivered yesterday at the Riverside Church by the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo, president of the New Brunswick Theological Seminary, New Brunswick, N. J.

A dark woman in a sleeveless pink dress, a snowy stole across her tanned shoulders, recently sat in her husband's New York office and told how she recreated the flavor of Austria in her Manhasset kitchen.

NEWARK, Aug. 3 -- Albert B. Hermann of Milltown announced today that he would return from Washington to direct the re-election campaign of Senator H. Alexander Smith and that headquarters for his candidate would be set up shortly in Newark or Trenton.

PARIS, Aug. 3 -- Hubert de Givenchy has launched winter prints inspired by furs. As if painted by an artist, the general impression and coloring of silver fox, beaver, silver blue and pastel mink is printed on supple ottoman, taffeta or flat crepe.

WALTHAM, Mass., Aug. 3 -- The Navy Bureau of Aeronautics unveiled today at the Raytheon Manufacturing Company laboratories a new type of electronic digital computing machine that also worries. The device, capable of carrying on between 3,000 and 5,000 mathematical operations per second, stops its entire operation when an error creeps in.

Four prisoners charged with offenses ranging from homicide and kidnapping to narcotics possession were held without bail yesterday. Two were arraigned in Brooklyn Felony Court, two appeared in Bronx Magistrates' Court. A fifth, held in $5,000, will have a hearing today.

Reports of pre-campaign activities in Denver and Springfield reveal that both candidates for the Presidency have to wrestle with the common problem of unifying their divided parties. Both are new leaders of old political organizations with split personalities.
Two mountain tapirs -- rarities in the animal world -- were placed on exhibition as a couple in the Bronx Zoo yesterday.

A steadying influence was imparted to British sterling last mid-week on the statement of Chancellor of the Exchequer Butler that with aid from the United States and readjustment of her armament program, Britain can expect to balance her trade with the world in the second half of 1952, after having overspent for the last two years.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 -- Futures purchases on the Board of Trade averaged about the same for the five-day week as for the preceding six-day week, and were considerably larger than a year Ego. Average daily purchases were 40,000,000 bushels, compared with 40,000,000 the week before and about 32,000,000 a year ago.
ZURICH, Aug. 3 -- The Zurich Stock Exchange showed interest in the changes last week in German iron and steel industries caused by the decision to put the Schuman plan into operation on Aug. 10.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 3 -- Those plant which did not feel the full effects of the steel strike last week will feel them keenly in weeks to come and long after operations have reached the level that prevailed before the strike began early in June.

AMSTERDAM, Aug. 3 -- The Netherlands Bank lowered the bank rate to 3 per cent last Thursday due to the excellent development of foreign exchange and gold reserves, which again rose 59,000,000 to 2,992,000,000 guilders. Note circulation increased 50,000,000 to 2,932,000,000. while the Treasury's balance fell 55,000,000 to 700,000,000.

Vanadium Corporation of America has called all its 3 1/2 per cent convertible debentures due on Oct. 1, 1965 for redemption on Sept. 3 at 102. Of $5,000,000 marketed in October of 1950, only $2,465,000 of the debentures are now outstanding.

Declaring that the Negro voter had been "sold down the river" by "Uncle Toms" at the Democratic and Republican National Conventions, Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. called yesterday on Negroes to "boycott" the national election unless Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, Democratic nominee for President, and his running mate, Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama, took a forthright stand on civil rights.

Still cool toward Mayor Impellitteri's proposal for an unsalaried Transit Advisory Commission, the Board of Estimate is now willing to set up and finance an official city staff of experts to supervise and coordinate public and private transit operation, including taxicabs.

BONN, Germany, Aug, 3 -- The scheduled invasion of West Berlin today by Communist youths, heralded by triumphant exhortation in the Soviet-licensed press, sputtered out in a handful of minor tussles between the police and blue-shirred members ou the Free German Youth.

While great strides have been made in cutting infant mortality in the 1-to-12-month age group in New York City, only limited reduction has been achieved in the death rate of infants under one month, it is disclosed in a study carried out by the New York Academy of Medicine.

I was rather surprised to see the editorial on India and Kashmir in your issue of July 26, particularly when you have built up a reputation both here and in India for an objective and sympathetic presentation of the Indian scene.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 3 -- For the last eight days, twenty-two members of the Israeli Productivity Institute -- representatives of Histadrut, the labor organization; of the Government, of the manufacturers' association and the engineers' association -- have been listening to and exchanging ideas with an American professor.
TOKYO, Monday, Aug. 4 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,331, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Monday, Korea time:

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Rain washed out a scheduled doubleheader between the White Sox and the Senators today, erasing fine pitching performances by Billy Pierce and Connie Marrero who had dueled to a 0-0 stand-off in eight innings of the opener.

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, Aug. 4 (AP) -- American infantrymen entrenched on the crest of "Old Baldy" hill beat back today attacking Chinese who stormed up the slopes of the strategic height in western Korea.

TOKYO, Monday, Aug. 4 -- The deadlocked conferences for an armistice in the Korean war were in adjournment again today after a thirty-two-minute session of the two delegations at Panmunjom yesterday showed that neither side had altered its attitude on the bitterly disputed issue of a prisoner exchange.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Curt Simmons hurled a four-hitter for his tenth victory and fifth shut-out of the season today as the Phillies defeated the Cardinals, 6 -- 0 at Shibe Park.

URANIUM CITY, Sask., Aug. 3 -- Hundreds of prospectors and geologists were ready in deep bush and jack pine in this Canadian north country wilderness tonight for the first uranium claim-staking rush of the atomic age.

The Civil Defense Building Control program, which includes the organization of safety procedures for office buildings, hotels, factories and multiple dwellings in the city, has made "encouraging progress," Thomas J. P. McVeigh, commandant of the Air Warden Service, reported to Civil Defense Director Arthur W. Wallander yesterday.

Addresses on retailers' and suppliers' problems, a sports shirt identification clinic and awards to' the supplier who best serves the shirt industry and to the retailer who does the best job in the country for men's wear will be among the features of the Annual Market Buying Week and Suppliers Exhibit sponsored by the National Association of Shirt, Pajama and Sportswear Manufacturers at the New Yorker Hotel, Sept. 8 to 10.

The new French luxury liner Flandre, which set a modern marine precedent by suffering a series of mishaps on her initial Atlantic crossing and by arriving here in tow, continued to be a hapless ship yesterday as her departure was delayed a second time by mechanical "difficulties."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The State Department today published an intelligence report on a Soviet refugee's experiences and said it proved that the average soldier in the Russian army lived a life of futility and drudgery.

TORONTO, Aug. 3 -- The basic role of the Red Cross in the relief of human suffering has been obscured by the endless political controversy dominating the eighteenth international conference here. But it would be unfair to suggest that the humanitarian role has been forgotten.

The Hotel Irving, which occupies a plot 33 by 184 feet at 26 Gramercy Park South and is assessed at $210,000, has been sold by Hotel Irving, Inc., Charles H. Kelman, president, to the Bogardu Realty Corporation, which insured title with the City Title Insurance Company.

The true evidence of success is the return engagement. That is why we are proud to announce today that Adele Simpson has consented to give us a second contribution to our American Designer Series of Patterns of The Times.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 3 (UP) -- The Athletics completed their best western trip since 1948 when Carl Scheib pitched a three-hit, 9-2 victory that gave them an even split with Cleveland today. The Indians won the opener, 4 -- 1.

Experiments with a possible polio preventive serum were begun last year by the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, according to the annnal report made public yesterday by Basil O'Connor, foundation president.

In keeping with a study it is making of the depths of harbors and their entrances in the principal maritime countries, the Permanent International Association of Navigation Congresses has asked member nations to appoint national committees to study local port conditions.

As one step after another is taken to restore Germany to complete national sovereignty and to an equal role in the Western comity of nations, anxieties and tensions are bound to increase.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 3 (UP) -- Noel Brown, 26-year-old Los Angeles netman, captured the singles final in the sixty-second annual Meadow Club invitation tennis tournament today by scoring a straight-set victory over Sidney Schwartz of Long Beach, L. I., 8 -- 6, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 0.

OSLO, Norway, Aug. 3 -- Despite a pouring rain, King Haakon shared his eightieth birthday today with 250,000 persons who filled the city's streets to cheer their monarch on a 20-mile tour in a vintage open car. Dressed in an admiral's uniform, he sat alone in the back of the car.
Retail trade as a whole, for the first time since 1941, now shows, a relationship to the nation's overall economic activity comparable to that which prevailed before World War II.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 3 -- A relatively unheralded contract bridge pair, William Joseph of Paterson, N. J., and W. W. Jackson of Brockport, N. Y., this afternoon were declared winners of the 1952 Masters Pair Championship.
Four new films, including importations from Italy and Sweden, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

DALLAS, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Pro-Eisenhower Republicans and anti-Administration Democrats held firm control in Texas yesterday as both parties held their county conventions. Some county Democratic delegations asked that the Eisenhower-Nixon ticket be placed on the November ballot in Texas under a "Tex Democratic party" heading.

The Hospital for Joint Diseases, 123d Street and Madison Avenue, gave 116,566 hospital days' care to 5,802 bed patients last year, Raphael B. Malsin, its president, said in the annual report yesterday. To the out-patient department 22,372 patients made 147,695 visits.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 3 -- Following a succession of hardearned victories in earlier rounds, Mal Galletta and Gordon Stott of North Hills today became the first medalists in sixteen John G. Anderson Memorial tournaments to win the final.

DENVER, Aug. 3 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower announced a compromise settlement today of the organizational conflict between his "amateur" and "professional" supporters in a bid for the support of millions of non-Republican voters in November.

In an effort to curb widespread violations of its regulations by industrial executives, the Soviet Government has ordered a significant tightening of control over the day-to-day operations of its economy, Soviet publications indicate.

A. H. Truax, president of Truax-Traer Coal Company, has been elected chairman, succeeding G. W. Traer, who will remain chairman of the executive and finance committees, it has been announced. R. E. Snoberger, executive vice president, was elected president, and J. H. Price, vice president of a subsidiary sales company, was elected a vice president of Truax-Traer Coal Company.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 3 -- Making one of those miraculous recoveries for which his rivals never seem to be wholly prepared, Casey Stengel righted his Yankees in the nick of time today with the result the Bombers ended their Western trip by winning both ends of their double-header with the Browns.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 3 (UP) -- Farmers in drought areas of the South fought to save starving livestock today as Connecticut officials prepared to combat the month-long New England drought by making rain.

A full program for handling the needs of children with impaired hearing involves several definite steps and the coordinated services of many specialists in related fields, according to recommendations discussed in a new publication released recently by the United States Children's Bureau.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 3 -- The executive board of the Screen Writers Guild at a meeting tomorrow night is expected to decide whether to call a strike of its 1,200 members against the Alliance of Television Film Producers.
GOSHEN, N. Y., Aug. 3 (UP) -- Fifteen entries, with not a standout favorite among them, are expected to be named for the Hambletonian tomorrow, when the entry box officially opens at Good Time Park.

The Marshall Plan is the most historic single act of generosity ever performed by any nation, the Rev. Dr. Elfan Rees, adviser on refugee affairs to the World Council of Churches, declared in a ser-man yesterday morning. Even so, he warned, we must remember that silver and gold are false gods that will not solve the problems of the world.
DJAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 3 -- Semi-official sources here today flatly denied rumors that the Government intended to devalue the rupiah in view of a worsening economic situation.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 3 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois directed two more barrages at the Republicans today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Steel expansion for defense received further impetus today when the Defense Production Administration approved a major new project of the Delaware River Steel Corporation.
Prices were raised yesterday by an average of slightly more than 9 per cent on the entire line of television receivers of Muntz TV, Inc. Increases ranged from 4.3 per cent to 15.3 per cent.

The superliner United States, holder of the Atlantic blue ribbon for speed, has far outdistanced the British superliner Queen Elizabeth in their first simultaneous crossing. As a result, the former is expected to reach New York today, eight hours ahead of the Cunard Line flagship.

CENTER HARBOR, N. H., Aug. 3 -- Harvard defeated Yale today in an informal crew race, thus repeating its victory of 1852, as this town celebrated the 100th anniversary of the first intercollegiate crew race in America.

The first five volumes of a series of American biographies for young adults will be issued in September by McGraw-Hill under the general title "They Made America.'' They are: "George Rogers Clark," by Walter Havighurst; "Stephen F. Austin. Father of Texas," by Carlton Beals; "Alexander Hamilton, Nation Builder," by Nathan Schachner; "Charles Willson Peale, Artist and Patriot," by Berta N. Briggs, and "Red Jacket, Last of the Senecas," by Arthur C. Parker.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Aug. 3 -- Camp Kiwago on Upper Twin Lake, destroyed by fire last September, was re-dedicated today with 300 New York City boys and camp personnel looking on. Officials and guests of the Boys Athletic League of New York City, which maintains the camp, conducted a flag-raising ceremony.

Peter I. Feinberg, operator, bought a one-story garage-type building on lot 50 by 100 feet at 1661-63 Jerome Avenue, the Bronx, through Allan S. Feldman Co., brokers, who also sold the same buyer the four-story apartment house on site 50 by 100 feet at 584-86 Eagle Avenue.

Ernest R. LaPorte, chairman of the Bronx Independent Democrats, announced yesterday the formation of the Ideal party, indepenent, to support M. Maldwin Fertig for election as Surrogate of Bronx County.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 3 -- The second week-end of the main phase of the Berkshire Music Festival came to an end this afternoon, with the radiant summer weather bringing out huge crowds. Charles Munch conducted the Boston Symphony Orchestra in a program of Beethoven, Debussy and Honegger.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 3 -Sol Lesser, film producer, who returned recently after three months in Europe, has announced the formation of a new motion-picture company with headquarters in Stockholm, Sweden, to specialize in documentary adventure features.

TORONTO, Aug. 3 -- While Soviet bloc delegations to the International Red Cross conference have deluged it with political propaganda in every form, Toronto police assigned to the Royal York Hotel as security officers have barred and confiscated printed anti-Communist material that various groups have sought to distribute among the delegates.
Two projects to speed northbound traffic on the east and west edges of Manhattan will be started this month by Acting Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley. They are:

American voters, upon whom lies the responsibility of balloting in this year's Presidential election, should seek "divine guidance," Msgr. William T. Greene declared yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral. He is chairman of the music commission of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- A $500,000 project aimed at giving this country the nucleus of a permanent industry producing jewel bearings is expected to get under way at Rolla, N. D., within the next sixty days.

CAMBRIDGE, Md., Aug. 3 (AP) -- Twenty-five different classes of power-boats roared up and down the Choptank River today, setting nine world speed marks as the two-day American Power Boat Association regatta came to an end/

The Rev. Hamish C. MacKenzie, minister of the Orchardhill Parish Church in Glasgow, Scotland, delivered the first in a series of August sermons yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 3 -- Sunny Jim Fitzsimmons, the horse-trainer, should be elected to honorary membership in the Saratoga Springs Chamber of Commerce. He loves the place, and he loves to talk about it.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 3 -- A Republican party united behind its national ticket is offering to the nation "prosperity built on peace rather than prosperity built on war," Senator Richard M. Nixon of California declared today.

Joseph La Vopa of 1400 Shore Drive, the Bronx, who inflicted shotgun wounds on three youths who allegedly had tried to break into his home before dawn Saturday, was held in $500 bail yesterday by Magistrate Hyman Korn on charges of felonious assault and illegal possession of a firearm.

SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 3 -Utah Republicans and Democrats ended their state nominating conventions late yesterday after choosing contenders for Senate and Congress. The nominees of both parties face primary elections next month.
TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 3 -- The United States technical aid mission has worked out with the management of the Imperial estates a program for the implementation of the Shah of Iran's vast land reform.
MEXICO CITY, Aug. 3 -- A sad inquest into the state of Mexican bullfighting has been opened as a result of the latest round in the perennial feud between the matadors of Mexico and those of Spain.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 3 (AP) -- This famous Spa bustled today with last-minute preparations for what looked like a "boom year" at the nation's oldest active race track.

The New York United Service Organizations Defense Fund, Inc., 89 Broad Street, has named Admiral Oscar C. Badger, U.S.N., retired, its campaign chairman. He will head the city fund-raising appeal for U.S.O. and other defense-related health and welfare organizations.

With the untimely death of Senator Brien McMahon, chairman of the Joint Senate-House Committee on Atomic Energy, the nation has suffered a tragic and perhaps irreparable loss. Our bereavement is particularly unfortunate because he filled a unique place of leadership in a field so new and overwhelming that its portent for a troubled world is still not clear.

A semi-annual survey of employment on privately owned and operated American-flag merchant vessels, which was released yesterday by the National Federation of American Shipping, showed a decrease of 19,000 seamen in the first six months of this year.
The Shubert is to receive Bernard Shaw's play, "The Millionairess," in which Katharine Hepburn earned the approbation of the London critical brigade, for a visit of twelve weeks, starting Oct. 2.

A steady stream of small contributions and some large gifts from a few individuals, have paid off within five years more than one half of the $2,500,000 debt incurred for restoring the marble exterior of St. Patrick's Cathedral, it was learned yesterday.

Liquidation of the United States Leather Company is proceeding, C. Cameron, treasurer of the company, reported over the week-end. After adjustments for properties sold in the early part of 1952, he said, the Dec. 31, 1951, net asset value of the company was $15,016,000, equivalent to $13.16 a share.

KALAMAZOO, Mich., Aug. 3 (AP) -- Jack Frost of Monterey, Calif., won the national junior tennis title in an all-California final. Frost defeated James Read of Santa Monica, Calif., 1-- 6, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 3 (AP) -Six Kentucky Congressmen won renomination and one was defeated in yesterday's primary election.

Cotton prices in the domestic market moved steadily upward last week and closed the period with substantial net gains. At the close of trading on Friday, active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 68 to 140 points from the levels of the previous week.

In your editorial praising the nomination of Governor Stevenson you none the less state that your newspaper is already committed to Eisenhower's candidacy. Is it wise to close the mind before the selection of both candidates is made? The mind should remain open enough, as the campaign proceeds, to give Governor Stevenson the credit and confidence that are due to a leader of integrity, intelligence, vision and achievement.

Sherman Billingsley, proprietor of a world of his own, has terminated his absence from television. The bland boniface of the Stork Club, undeterred by the somewhat limited success of his previous fifteen-minute program, has turned the other profile in a new half-hour series at 7 P. M. Saturdays over Columbia Broadcasting System television.
Officials of the New York Central Railroad and four railroad unions will meet today in an effort to avert a strike by 6,000 workers on the road's lines east of Buffalo.

The United Nations negotiators at Panmunjom in Korea appear to have begun a new phase in the talks by adopting a tactic somewhat different from previous methods. The new tactic also seems on its face to be somewhat more forthright. A further adjournment of a week has been called, with the plain implication that the United Nations group is ready to meet the Communists whenever they have something germane to say, not otherwise.

Oscar Hammerstein 2d surely will go down in history as one of America's most popular lyricists. Three weeks ago the songs he wrote with Jerome Kern drew 19,000 to the Lewisohn Stadium, and last night his songs written with Richard Rodgers drew another 17,000 to the amphitheatre.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -Maj. Gen. Roger M. Ramey, the Air Force "saucer man," said today that six years of flying saucer reports had "reasonably well" convinced him that there was no such thing.

HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 3 -- A flame flickered out atop the lofty tower of Helsinki Stadium this evening and the games of the Fifteenth Modern Olympiad came to a close to the glory of Finland. Trumpets sounded the parting fanfare, massed choirs sang and cannons boomed a farewell salute as the Olympic emblem with five interlocking circles was lowered majestically from the arena flagpole.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 3 -- City authorities adjusting taxi rates here have hit on a system of zones and surcharges that taxes a mathematician.

DETROIT, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Young Art Houtteman of the Tigers, the American League pitcher with the most losses, shut out the Red Sox today with four hits and Matt Batts helped in the 6-0 victory with his first homer of the season.
The meeting today of the wage scale committee of the International Longshoremen's Association, A.F.L., to formulate wage demands, comes at one of the union's most critical periods.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The Communist party in the United States has, throughout its existence, adhered to the principles of Marxism-Leninism as interpreted and dictated by Lenin, Stalin and the Communist party of the Soviet Union, the United States Government has charged in its drive to force Communists to register under terms of the 1950 Internal Security Act.

The action of the Better Business Bureau of New York in calling a meeting for Aug. 13 of the combination storm-window industry to discuss a set of standards designed to eliminate deceptive advertising and selling practices underlines the danger that the average householder faces when he spends several hundred dollars for combination windows.

The Hickory Realty Corporation, Julian Marx, president, sold to a client of Reilly Curry, attorneys, for investment the gasoline and service station at Mamaroneck Avenue and Andrews Street, Mamaroneck, N. Y., in a deal negotiated by George E. Maran and Walter Samuels, Inc., brokers.
BOSTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Bubba Church's six-hit pitching gave the Reds a 4-0 shut-out today after they dropped the opener of a double-header to the Braves, 7 -- 4.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Sue Storer of the Lafayette, Ind., Swim Club cracked the old record by a half second as she won the Junior National Amateur Athletic Union 300-meter individual medley swimming championship today.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Aug. 3 -- A fresh southwest wind saved the day for the skippers in the finale of the Echo Bay Yacht Club's two-day Y. R. A. regatta today.

ROME, Aug. 3 -- Pietro Nenni, Left Wing Socialist leader, returned from one month's visit to Russia with an offer from Premier Stalin of an Italian-Russian nonaggression pact if Italy abandoned her present policy of friendship toward the western democracies and assumed a position of "neutrality" between East and West.

The eight millionth "character watch" for children -- made famous by such well-known personalities as Mickey Mouse, Cinderella and Hopalong Cassidy -- will come off the assembly line this week at the plant of the United States Time Corporation in Middlebury, Conn., it was announced yesterday by the company.

LONDON, Aug. 3 -- The smoke of battle -- a battle over journalistic ethics -- was still hanging today over Fleet Street, London's "Newspaper Row." Shots were still being fired by one Sunday newspaper.

DAKAR, West Africa, Aug. 3 (Reuters) -- Some 150 delegates from twenty two non-Communist countries, including the United States and Canada, today attended the opening of the third congress of the World Assembly of Youth.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UP) -- The Soviet Union has undergone a complete shift in its pattern of population growth since 1917 to the apparent dismay of Communist leaders, the Population Reference Bureau reported today.

A third of a century ago man made his first airplane flight across the Atlantic Ocean. A quarter of a century back he made his first non-stop solo flight over the route. Last week the Atlantic was spanned for the first time by helicopter -- the short-winded ugly duckling of the aeronautical family that was nothing more than a bright hope when the first flights were made.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Samuel Jackson Snead overwhelmed par, a torrential downpour and a Tam O'Shanter jinx today for a 7-under-par-65 and a winning 271 total, seventeen under standard for the seventy-two-hole route in the All-American pro tourney.
HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 3 (AP) -- What happened to the Japanese swimming team in the 1952 Olympics?

PUSAN, Korea, Aug. 3 -- The United Nations Commission for the Reunification and Rehabilitation of Korea has decided to keep a watchful eye on the South Korean elections for President Tuesday by conducting spot surveys at critical points throughout the country.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 3 -- Something new under the sun and different in speedboat regattas was attempted here this afternoon and it worked superbly as perfect weather came through with a big assist.

New Yorkers have heard every now and then stories of how Hollywood, Calif., already the focal point of the motion picture industry, would like to wean major television operations away from New York City. But it remained for Fire Commissioner Grumet, in summarizing the work of his first year in office, to take the wraps off the inside story on how our television leadership really nearly got away.
PRINCETON, N. J., Aug. 3 -- Two men were killed at 4:15 P. M. today when the Piper Cub in which they were flying crashed at Dutch Neck, six miles southeast of here.

The appointment of Henry Ford 2d, president of the Ford Motor Company, as national chairman of the Crusade for Freedom, 4 West Fifty-seventh Street, was announced yesterday by Rear Admiral H. B. Miller, U. S. N., retired, president of the group.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UP) -- The Federal Government faces its biggest mass turnover of top officials in twenty years next January regardless of the outcome of the November Presidential election.

Americans shared in spirit Norway's celebrations for the eightieth birthday of King Haakon VII. Sometimes it is enough for a public figure to reach the fine age of eighty to get automatic tributes. There was nothing automatic or artificial about the honors paid yesterday to Haakon and to his gallant little country.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -The Treasury announced tonight it will pass up a chance to call for redemption on Dec. 15 four bond issues totaling almost $16,500,000,000.

HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Clearing six towering obstacles without a fault, Pierre d'Oriola of France won the individual title in the Prix des Nations equestrian event after Great Britain took the team event today in the finale of the 1952 Olympic Games.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 3 -- Brazil has been caught in an acute dollar crisis that has seriously damaged her foreign credit. Word was received today that German banks had halted shipments to Brazil until something was done to reduce the arrears of $60,000,000 on current debts.

HAVANA, Aug. 3 (UP) -- Bernard Bartzen of San Angelo, Tex., and Hugh Stewart of Los Angeles each won a singles match today to complete a 5-0 sweep for the United States over Cuba in the second round of Davis Cup tennis eliminations.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 -- The increasing seriousness of drought conditions over a large area caused considerable revision in grain market Sentiment last week. Speculative interest shifted to corn and oats, both of which were active and sharply higher.

ALBANY, Aug 3 -- Gov. Dewey directed the State Mental Hygiene Council today to make a thorough review of the procedures prevailing in public and private mental hospitals of New York State and the statutory provisions governing the release of mental patients.

Marine Maj. John C. Riley, first naval airman to fly 100 missions over Korea, was recued yesterday from Rockaway Inlet after engine failure had forced him to crash-land his plane off Breezy Point, Queens. The accident happened at 2:15 P. M., two minutes after Major Riley had taken up a Grumman F-6-F from Floyd Bennett Air Base for an engineering test light.

PARIS, Aug. 3 -- Official quarters here have become uneasy over the Government's policy of price stabilization. The principal trouble they see involves food prices and notably the poor prospects with regard to meat, butter and milk.

Nicodemus of Dawson, Md., a machine operator, testified yesterday at the Communist conspiracy trial here that one of the defendants, Albert Lannon, told a meeting of Communists in 1945 that in the event of a war between the United States and the Soviet Union, party members would sabotage American industries.

Two issues of non-callable consolidated notes of Federal Home Loan Banks totaling $176,500,000 will be publicly offered today through Everett Smith, fiscal agent here. Harry Gross, who has listed his payments to police at $1,000,000 a year for protection of his gambling empire, was described yesterday by one of his former employes, who was not a policeman, as having strung him along on $25 a week expense money and an "if" promise of more substantial rewards that never materialized.

Carmine G. DeSapio, leader of Tammany Hall, declared yesterday that the Democratic national platform on civil rights went "further toward guaranteeing those rights than the platform of any political party this year, or any other year."
Joey Giardello of Philadelphia won a split ten-round decision last night over the welterweight challenger and 4-1 favorite, Billy Graham, before 3,000 in Brooklyn's Eastern Parkway Arena.
