Rain clouds moved toward parched Maine last night, but virtually no relief was in sight for the drought areas of the South, The Associated Press reported.

In accordance with recommendations made by a special committee appointed by Mayor Impellitteri after a tenement fire in Brooklyn June 18 cost seven lives, the Department of Housing and Buildings added twenty inspectors yesterday to its staff. Commissioner Bernard J. Gillroy said seventy-five more inspectors would be appointed as they became available and "as we can absorb them."

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 4 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois entered the mounting fight for the so-called Negro vote today by defending the New and Fair Deals in general and the Democratic party's civil rights policy in particular.
The Travelers Aid Society will be the beneficiary of an autumn dinner dance on the night of Sept. 23 in the Persian Room of the Plaza.
HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 4 -- Connecticut Democrats are holding four Congressional District nominating conventions this week to round out their slate of nominees for the House of Representatives.

SHREVEPORT, La., Aug. 4 (UP) -- N. B. Carstarphen, chairman of the Louisiana Democratic State Central Committee, said today it was his opinion that the Stevenson-Sparkman ticket should appear under the Democratic symbol on Louisiana ballots, but "with reservations."

Business harbingers for the latter half of 1952 are preponderantly favorable, declares Bathe Co. in the current issue of its semi-annual "Selected List." It warns, however, that changes in armament spending are possible and inject an element of risk.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The Government opened the way today to greatly increased use of copper and aluminum in building homes, shops, factories, schools and public buildings.

HONG KONG, Aug. 4 -- A committee headed by Dr. Han Lih-wu, the former Minister of Education, has been established in Nationalist Formosa to survey employment possibilities there with a view to resettling at least some of the thousands of Chinese intellectuals stranded in Hong Kong as refugees from the Communist-held mainland.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The campaign issues on which the voters will decide the Presidential contest may not be those the political analysts have listed since Mr. Truman made it clear that he would not accept renomination. And too little time has elapsed since the Republicans chose General Eisenhower over Senator Taft and the Democrats shanghaied Governor Stevenson of Illinois to disclose what changes if any will come in that list.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- Drought damage reports pouring in from the Southeast and New England brought tremendous buying of oats and corn today. These grains were the leaders in a market that began to show signs of being a full-fledged bullish affair.

The 13,550-ton concrete caisson that was floated down the Hudson River from Grassy Point, N. Y., was set in place at 7:20 o'clock last night at Fifteenth Street and the Hudson River. With two other caissons still being constructed at Grassy Point, the huge concrete box will serve as the substructure for a new Pier 57.
Why do juvenile delinquency cases decrease in the summer? Here are the figures for New York City:

Mayor Impellitteri and the Board of Estimate are moving into a period in which hard decisions will have to be made. These concern the transit deficit, transit construction, improvement and expansion, and the problem of balancing the city budget. Some exploratory sessions between city and state officials have studied the long-range financial program.

MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., Aug. 4 -- Dick De Mane, unattached pro of Port Chester, and Dave Hicks, St. Andrews amateur, posted 32, 33 -- 65 to head seventy-nine teams in the pro-amateur tournament of the Westchester P. G. A. at the Mount Kisco C. C. today.

Yesterday's bulletins on the prospects for a walkout by members of four railroad brotherhoods on the Eastern lines of the New York Central were more reassuring than any since this possibility became news last week. The first reports had it that the men might quit at midnight Saturday night.

A recommendation that the American meat industry take up an industry-wide public relations, advertising and promotion program to tell the public why meat is high in price was put before the Nation's meat retailers yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The Government went $3,426,000,000 into the red in July, first month of the 1953 fiscal year.

PRINCE ALBERT, Sask., Aug. 4 -- Two workers for the United States Field and Wild Life Service flew in from the Arctic yesterday with word that they had found the breeding ground of the almost extinct whooping crane. Other ornithologists had sought this hideaway in vain for more than a half century.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Vic Raschi, big wheel of the Yankee mound staff, came through with another stellar performance tonight as the Bombers shaded Bucky Harris' Senators, 1 to 0, in the opener of a five-game series before a crowd of 16,005.

IN order to take part in the sectional qualifying rounds of the United States Golf Association's amateur championship that are being held in thirty-two areas throughout the nation today, certain eligibility requirements have to be met. Fortunately for Joe Marra, recently crowned metropolitan amateur champion, he learned about one of them in time to have his entry accepted.
Your editorial of July 26 congratulating both major parties for having chosen such men as Stevenson and Eisenhower has disquieting implications despite its characteristically judicious tone.

URANIUM CITY, Sask., Aug. 4 -- The first uranium rush in history started at 8 o'clock this morning in this northern wilderness above the north shore of Lake Athabaska. It was remarkable for its contrast with the roaring days of the Yukon and of the California gold rash of 100 years ago.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The Defense Production Administration today called for a 640,000 mile expansion of the country's telegraph system by the end of 1954.
WACO, Tex., Aug. 4 -- At least twenty-eight persons were killed today when two buses collided and burst into flames in the worst such accident in the nation's history.
Jule Styne, composer and producer, plans to establish an organization of twenty of Broadway's leading managers to cooperate in presenting forty or fifty shows here each year, beginning next season.

The stock market adhered again yesterday to a fairly neutral course although final quotations leaned to the lower side by a slight margin. A mixed pattern persisted through most of the session in the major divisions as traders preferred to let prices seek their own level.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 4 -- The defeat of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio for the Republican nomination for President was emphasized today before the Ohio Democratic Convention here in an apparent prodding of "a divided opposition."

Capt. John W. Anderson, master of the luxury liner America for three years, will assume command of the superliner United States on Friday before the vessel departs on her third eastward crossing. Commodore Harry Manning, present skipper of the speed queen, will relinquish his post

BOSTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The Sheraton Corporation of America, owner of hotels in principal cities of the country, announced earnings of $2.71 today on each of 1,531,405 shares of common stock for the year ended April 30.
The Long Island and New Jersey teams triumphed in the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association's junior Davis Cup competition at the West Side Club, Forest Hills, yesterday.

Nonunion manufacturers in the garment industry combating a week-long "organizational strike" staged by the Cloak Joint Board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A. F. L., filed yesterday an anti-trust suit against the union, the industry's impartial chairman and three manufacturers' associations whose members have union contracts.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Aug. 5 -- The United Nations Command warned the Communists today that stepped-up air warfare would be used against North Korea, where the enemy was making increased use of towns and cities as military concentration points.

MANHASSET, L. I., Aug. 4 -- North Hempstead town officials were preparing today to move their offices, this being, they agreed, the quickest way to get the new $500,000 addition to the Town Hall here finished.

LONDON, Aug. 4 -- There is a good deal more poverty left in Britain than earlier surveys have indicated, according to Political and Economic Planning, a well-known unofficial and nonpartisan research group.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The Defense Department today identified 124 battle casualties in Korea. A new list (No. 619) reported 11 killed, 96 wounded, one missing and 16 injured. The following were listed from New York and New Jersey.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug 4 (UP) -- The Budd Company announced today that the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad had ordered twenty-six more streamlined, air conditioned self-propelled diesel cars.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The Army ordered "strict austerity" rationing of training ammunition today to insure that combat troops in Korea would have all the shells they needed.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Aug. 4 -- The 107,000 sandy acres of pine and brush on this military reservation reverberated with the sound of heavy guns and grinding tanks today as 12,000 reservists and National Guardsmen here for two weeks of summer field maneuvers went through their paces under the scrutiny of Lieut. Gen. Willis D. Crittenberger, First Army commander.

The Manton House, a six-story apartment building for forty-eight families, at 139-05 Manton Street in Kew Gardens, Queens, has been sold by the builders, Kessler, Pirozzi Rosen, to Bernard Shaw of Forest Hills. Joseph R. Paretta was the broker.

SEATTLE, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Lou Fageol, never driving slower than 100 miles per hour, qualified the Slo-Mo-Shun V at 102 1/2 m. p. h. today for her defense Saturday of the Gold Cup, premier trophy of American speedboat racing.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UP) -- John B. Dunlap, Federal Tax Commissioner, said today that reorganization of the Bureau of Internal Revenue's Washington headquarters would be completed next Monday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UP) -- Almost all of the coal industry was brought into negotiations with the United Mine Workers today when John L. Lewis, union president, served contract termination notices on the anthracite and Southern coal producers. He is seeking a new contract for the 475,000 U. M. W. members.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Aug. 4 -- Vice Admiral C. Turner Joy, former commander of naval forces in the Far East and chief United Nations spokesman at the Korean truce negotiations, today took over the superintendency of the Naval Academy from Vice Admiral Harry W. Hill, who is retiring with the rank of admiral.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- Government transfers of military and civilian personnel have sharply increased interstate moving of household goods, officials of the van companies said today. Meeting at the movers' annual assembly, they said the United States Government had become their No. 1 customer.

Grants totaling $1,226,537 have been authorized for distribution to the nation's accredited medical schools by the executive committee of the National Fund for Medical Education, S. Sloan Colt, president of the fund, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Vocational education was presented as perhaps the most important key to technical progress at today's opening session of the Inter-American seminar on vocational education held at the Pan American Union.

TORONTO, Aug. 4 -- Insisting that it had been denied conference facilities, the Communist Chinese delegation to the International Red Cross conference today "shot the works" in its charges that the United States was waging germ warfare in Korea and China.

The Ford Foundation has come up with another humanitarian grant in its series of financial contributions to worth-while causes. The Foundation has given $2,900,000 to the United Nations Refugee Emergency Fund for an attempt to find a solution to the problem of 10,000,000 displaced persons and political refugees in Western Europe.
LONDON, Aug. 4 (Reuters) -- Twenty-thre wickets fell for 234 runs today in the Yorkshire-Lancashire cricket match.

The disappearance of an 18-year-old girl from the Holland-American liner Veendam last Thursday night was reported to officials of the company by the vessel's commander, it was learned yesterday. The New York-bound liner was in mid-Atlantic when the young passenger was missed, Capt. Harm Oldenburger said in a brief radio message.

NIAGARA FALLS, Ont., Aug. 4 -- Announcement has been made by Eunice Lady Oakes of the engagement of her daughter, Nancy, to Baron Ernest Lyssard von Hoyningen Huene, younger son of Baron and Baroness Herrmann von Hoyningen Huene of Oberammergau, Germany.

Chicopee Mills, Inc., a division of Johnson Johnson, has acquired for occupancy in a consolidation move the five-story building at 47-49 Worth Street. The property, on a plot 50 by 100 feet and assessed at $205,000, was purchased from Mrs. Bertha L. Wolf, Mrs. Madeline T. Blumoehr and Mrs. Mildred P. Salomon.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The Secretary of Defense, Robert A. Lovett, today gave full authority to the chairman of the Munitions Board, John D. Small, to make decisions for the panel regardless of the views of its members.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 4 -- The California State branch of AMVETS, national organization of veterans of World War II, has called on the heads of motion-picture studios to sign a pledge that they will not employ any persons who refuse to respond to the House Un-American Activities Committee or any other duly constituted Government agency investigating charges of alleged subversive activities involving Hollywood personalities.
PARIS, Aug. 4 -- Lengthening to about 12 inches from the floor, Jean Desses abandons the rigid cinched look for softness, for fluid lines in crepe georgette and chiffon.

The drought that has caused crop losses in the millions of dollars has cut fresh produce shipments to this city. As a result, housewives who already are struggling with the highest food prices in history are paying much more for certain vegetables than a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Mrs. India Edwards, vice chairman of the Democratic National Committee and director of the Women's Division, canceled a California speaking trip today in order to confer in Springfield, Ill., with Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democratic nominee, and his campaign manager, Wilson W. Wyatt.
The likelihood of a strike on the lines of the New York Central Railroad east of Buffalo virtually disappeared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- An attempt to have the incoming Congress write a Federal statute to protect so far as possible the right of Presidential and Vice Presidential nominees to appear on the general election ballot in each state is under consideration.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Procedural details for hastening disaster loans to farmers in drought areas of ten Southern states will be discussed at a conference of Farmers Home Administration officials in Atlanta Wednesday and Thursday, the Department of Agriculture announced today.

Recent revisions of the charter of the European Payments Union raise the prospect that extreme debtor and creditor positions may be avoided during the coming year, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Analyzing the union's operation, the bank says in its monthly review that the revisions have "strengthened the E. P. U.'s capacity to deal with future strains arising out of imbalances in intra-E. P. U. payments."

PEOPLE who write books, in the opinion of the vast majority of mankind who do not write them, are ipso facto eccentric characters. They work odd hours in queer places, alone and sitting down. They don't truckle to bosses or punch time clocks. They wear odd clothes, ignore social conventions and look often upon the wine when it is red.

Increases of more than $90,000,000 in sales, of $1,500,000 in earnings before taxes and of $367,729 in earnings after tax deductions were reported yesterday by Pillsbury Mills, Inc., in its eighty-third annual report.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Aug. 5 -- The Chinese Communists angrily charged today that American negotiators at Panmunjom had "no intention of reaching an armistice in Korea."

ATLANTA, Aug. 4 -- Georgia's Democratic Executive Committee today pledged the state's twelve electoral votes to the regular Democratic nominees -- Gov. Adlai Stevenson and Senator John Sparkman. Their session was harmonious and it lasted only nine minutes.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Aug. 4 -- New concepts for better family and community living are being studied by professionals and laymen at the Vassar College Summer Institute, now nearing the conclusion of its twenty-seventh annual session.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 4 -- To Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's gray 2-year-old colt Native Dancer, in his first bit of under-silks exercise since April, went first money of $8,000 in the seventy-eighth running of the Flash Stakes as the Saratoga Association's four-week meeting opened today.

The fifty-four-family house at 3215 Bainbridge Avenue, the Bronx, was sold by Morris Rudin to Jerome R. Jakubovitz, operator, for cash over a mortgage of $73,000. The Murrimac Realty Company and Langsam Schiffman were the brokers.

United States production may reach a new high level by 1960 even if the average work-week dips below forty hours, according to a study of long-range trends compiled by the business research department of the B. F. Goodrich Company, Akron, Ohio.
BLOCK ISLAND, R. I., Aug. 4 -- Their white sails ghost-like in a lingering haze, forty-six canvased creations from the New York Yacht Club came here today on the initial run of their racing cruise.
PARIS, Aug. 4 -- Stressing all black in a collection of great elegance, Christian Dior streamlines the figure for daytime, adding three or four inches to skirt lengths.
CHICAGO, Aug. 4 (UP) -- Theodore Roe, who ran a gambling empire on Chicago's southside in defiance of the law and rival mobsters, was killed tonight by a mysterious shotgun blast.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Aug. 4 -- Combining excellently for a 34, 30 -- 64, eight under par, Howard Morton, Sands Point, and Steve Legakis, Glen Head, captured top honors in the Long Island P. G. A. amateur-pro tournament at Cherry Valley today.

Bernard M. Baruch accused the Administration yesterday of fomenting inflation through "procrastination and inaction" although Congress passed what he called a workable controls law within sixty days after the start of the Korean war. The financier charged that inflation had been "legalized" by the Government itself.

NEWARK, Aug. 4 -- Edward J. Mueller of 86 Sunnyside Terrace. East Orange, having reached the age of 70, retired today as supervising cashier in the Newark commercial office of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company. Mr. Mueller was never tardy nor absent during his forty-four years and three months as an employe of the utility company, officials said.

An increase of $6,479,200, or 17 per cent, in the $44,586,701 consolidated net income of the Sinclair Oil Corporation and its subsidiaries was reported for the first half of this year in the midyear statement issued yesterday by P. C. Spencer, president. Net income for the initial six months of 1951 amounted to $38,107,501.

BOSTON, Aug. 4 (UP) -- Shortstop Johnny Lipon hammered out his first home run of the year tonight to lead the Red Sox to a 1 to 0 victory over the Giants in an exhibition game before 22,560 fans on hand for a veterans' benefit at Fenway Park.

DENVER, Aug. 4 -- A Negro delegation conferred with Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower today and a spokesman said later, that members of the group would support the general's candidacy because they believed his election would "greatly advance civil rights progress in America."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The North Atlantic regional office of the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations announced here today it was taking steps to convene an international conference to deal with the worsening shortage of rice in Southeast Asia.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 4 -- John B. Atkinson, Cambridge City Manager, was ousted today in favor of John J. Curry, a public schoolmaster, by a 5-to-4 vote of the City Council.
The cotton futures market turned strong and active closing at or near the best levels of the day and 60 to 102 points net higher on active months.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Aug. 4 -- Preoccupied with the summer holidays, the Netherlands looked on calmly today as another attempt to form a Cabinet failed and the crisis that has persisted since the June 25 election neared the end of its sixth week.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 4 (AP) -- A Federal judge has agreed that Robert Hirsch is entitled to a $1,005,000 profit on an airplane plant about which the United States Government changed its mind. District Judge J. Joseph Smith has ruled that the Government must pay $3,100,000 for the plant that it first sold for $2,010,000 and decided five months later to reacquire it by condemnation.

" The Problem of Power," seven essays by Lord Radcliffe of Werneth, will be published Aug. 26 by Macmillan. In the essays, originally the Reith Memorial Lectures delivered for the British Broadcasting Company in 1951, Lord Radcliffe discusses the problem of present-day power in the light of the writings and actions of thinkers, statesmen and administers of the past to the present, from Plato's "Republic" to the Four Freedoms.

ORLEANS, France, Aug. 14 -- The United States Government is forging quietly ahead with the construction of an imposing supply line, or line of communication, stretching nearly 1,000 miles from Bordeaux in southwest France to Kaiserlautern at the rear of United States forces in West Germany.

HALIFAX, N. S., Aug. 4 (UP) -- This usually busy port was in the midst of a slump today with shipping circles doubtful of any early improvement. Halifax normally handles more shipping than most world ports other than London and New York.

GREAT RIVER, L. I., Aug. 4 -- Great South Bay's annual race week got underway today under good sail as almost 125 craft assembled off Timber Point. Competition for the Corry Trophy emblematic of Great South Bay Star boat supremacy, starts tomorrow.
Three New York commodity markets boiled into sudden activity yesterday.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 4 -- Walter J. Donnelly, new United States High Commissioner in Germany, declared today that the United States was not going to allow the shipment of strategic materials to countries beyond the Iron Curtain, no matter how loudly Russian proconsuls abroad might holler.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 4 -- President Truman continued an easy routine of receiving guests and carrying on official business in his Hotel Muehlebach suite today. Tomorrow morning he will vote in the Missouri primary and then leave for Washington.

Benjamin Mekay, 55 years old, of 73-19 197th Street, Flushing, Queens, died yesterday in Bellevue Hospital's admitting room after he was found in the back of his car, parked at 648 East Eleventh Street, with a bullet wound in his head. The police reported that Mr. Mekay, president of the Stuyvesant Fuel and Oil Company, was an apparent suicide.
PARIS, Aug. 4 -- The French Government today dispatched a top Foreign Office official to Tunisia to seek a solution of the tangled political situation in the French North African protectorate.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 4 -- A new pay schedule that will add $254,914 a year to the salaries of Westchester County employes was adopted today by the Board of Supervisors. Democratic minority members of the board failed in a move to increase the amount to nearly $1,000,000.

HONOLULU, Aug. 4 -- The United States, in concert with Australia and New Zealand, took a step in this mid-Pacific American territory today that Dean Acheson, the Secretary of State, acclaimed as "one building block in the total structure of peace."

The wage scale conference committee of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., held its first meeting yesterday since the long dock strike of 1951. The group convened to formulate wage demands to be made on employing stevedores under a wage reopening provision of a two-year contract that does not expire until Sept. 30, 1953.

Net income of the Consolidated Vultee Aircraft Corporation for the six months ended on May 31 amounted to $4,012,196, equal to $1.69 a share, against $4,133,322 or $1.75 a share for the similar period a year ago, according to the report prepared for release today. Before taxes, earnings were $7,374,196 against $5,905,322.

The American Locomotive Company had a net income of $3,832,057 in the six months ended with last June, compared with $2,514,130 earned in the corresponding period a year ago, according to the mid-year statement prepared for publication today.

The United States and Canada will participate in their first simulated air raid exercise on Aug. 23, when a mock atomic explosion devastates a twelve-mile area radiating from the southern section of the city of Niagara Falls, N. Y. Lieut. Gen. Clarence R. Huebner, New York State Civil Defense Director, disclosed yesterday.

The Board of Transportation will try again today to be relieved of the responsibility of policing the municipal transit lines. Sidney H. Bingham, board chairman, is to confer with Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan at Police Headquarters at 2:30 P. M. on the problem, a vexing one ever since unification went into effect.

MANILA, Aug. 4 -- President Elipido Quirino views the Honolulu conference of the Pacific powers as a welcome step toward an eventual Pacific union for regional security, he said today. He said he did not join with Senator Jose P. Laurel and other Opposition political leaders in criticism of the conference for not including the Philippines.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UP) -- Carl R. Gray Jr., Veterans Administrator, said today he had asked state governors to set up machinery soon for approving schools and business establishments to train veterans under the Korean "G. I. Bill of Rights."

Julio Alvarez del Vayo, Foreign Minister of Spain in the Republican regime and now foreign editor of The Nation, was officially readmitted to the United States yesterday and released from parole by the Immigration and Naturalization Service of the Department of Justice. His wife also was readmitted.

The construction of 500 rental housing units programmed by the Housing and Home Finance Agency for defense workers in the area around Poughkeepsie, N. Y., has been allocated to six up-state and local building firms, it was announced here yesterday by Harold M. Clay, district director for the Federal Housing Administration.

Testimony by Harry Gross, the bookmaker, before the Brooklyn rackets grand jury linked Walter J. Monaghan, former plainclothes man, with a $25,000 fund raised for the widow of Chief Inspector Martin Brown, it was disclosed yesterday in Kings County Court.

On occasion humorists have been heard to comment on the subject of children's letters to parents, or to other adults, with particular reference to the difficulties encountered in persuading the young to take pen in hand, but the topic of parents' -- or other adults' -- letters to children is one that has been investigated too rarely.

A proposal that the Board of Transportation be stripped of all operating authority over the city's bus lines and be restricted to policy functions, if not abolished entirely, was made yesterday by Rudolph Halley, President of the City Council.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 4 -- A new effort by a member of the Chamber of Deputies to reveal to the public just what the Bank of Brazil has been doing in the last few years failed today, when a renewed request for publication of the findings of a Government inquiry was turned down by the Chamber of Deputies.

TANGIER, July 31 -- How one of the United States Navy's latest "hush-hush" planes was saved from disaster through the pilot's sang-froid and by brilliant organization on the ground was related here today by William Courtenay, a correspondent of The Daily Graphic of London.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The Navy announced today that one of its patrol planes, a slow-flying Martin Mariner flying boat, was attacked Thursday by Chinese Communist jet aircraft over the Yellow Sea. Two crew members were killed and two wounded but the plane, despite damage, was maneuvered to the Korean peninsula.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 4 -- Mrs. Allison Choate of Apawamis and Mrs. Harry Nevil Jr., of Hudson River tied at 79 for the qualifying medal in the twenty-seventh annual Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association's championship at the Woodway Country Club today.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 4 -- The largest all-rail movement of Lake Superior iron ore in history is being organized to erase part of the deficit in deliveries created by the long strike of steelworkers and ore miners.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 4 -- Indonesian Economics Minister Sumanang today denounced Senator Lyndon Johnson, chairman of the Armed Services Committee of the United States Senate, as a "master in distorting facts." The statement referred to the supplementary tin report issued by the preparedness subcommittee of the Armed Services Committee, which accused Southeast Asian tin producers of forming a cartel "with intent to gouge the United States."

A new issue of 380,000 shares of the capital stock of Washington Mutual Investors Fund is being offered by Johnston, Lemon Co., principal underwriter, at $10.72 a share. The fund, an open-end diversified investment company, is required by its charter to hold only common stocks eligible for trust fund investment in the District of Columbia and to maintain a fully invested portfolio of such issues.

AUGUSTA, Me., Aug. 4 (AP) -- New York and Canada's Province of New Brunswick rushed firefighting equipment to Maine today as state officials invoked the Northeastern Forest Fire Protection Compact for the first time.
BALLSTON SPA, N. Y., Aug. 4 (AP) -- The trial of Dr. Arthur J. Leonard, Saratoga Democratic chief charged with taking bribes from gamblers, was postponed today until Sept. 8.
MONTREAL, Aug. 4 (UP) -- A $1,000,000 cargo of Russian fur was under guard in a waterfront warehouse today while shippers sought a way to move it to New York, where longshoremen refused to handle it.

In keeping with their practice in all international organizations, including the United Nations, the Soviets and their satellites have done their best to convert the Toronto conference of the Red Cross into a political arena for their propaganda warfare. Despite international agreements to which they have subscribed, recognizing the Red Cross and its all-Swiss International Committee as an impartial humanitarian agency entrusted with certain functions and prerogatives, they vilify that agency as an "imperialist tool."

Police Capt. Otto A. Kafka Jr., a member of the force since 1926 and one of the first pilots in the department's Aviation Bureau, has filed his retirement application, it was announced yesterday at Police Headquarters.
CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- Strikers at the International Harvesters Company's twine mill fought with the police today to try to prevent a truck from hauling dismantled machinery out of the plant.

HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 4 -- The Soviet Union has veered away from battleships and instead is concentrating on the construction of heavy cruisers, which Soviet Navy planners consider more efficient, gun for gun, than the battleship, according to a naval observer who returned recently from a trip to Leningrad.

WASHINGTON Aug. 4 (UP) -- Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Selective Service Director, said today that it might be necessary ultimately to call draft-age fathers and others deferred for dependency to meet military manpower goals.

PUSAN, Korea, Aug. 4 -- The campaign for the presidency and vice presidency of South Korea wound up tonight on pre-election eve with all signs indicating that President Syngman Rhee would be re-elected.
WACO, Tex., Aug. 4 (UP) -- Greyhound representatives said they were not sure of the number aboard the buses because the ticket stubs were destroyed in the fire.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 4 -- Dr. Josue de Castro of Brazil, chairman of the council of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization, said today that he would see President Truman on Aug. 12 for a discussion of the problem of hunger throughout the world and methods of alleviating it.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 4 -- A production of a new English version of Mozart's "La Clemenza di Tito," the main effort this season of the Berkshire Music Center's opera department, was presented tonight in Tanglewood's theatre-concert hall. It was Tanglewood's claim that this was the American premiere of Mozart's opera, and no doubt the claim will stand up.

A twenty-five-story office building to replace the seventeen-story Sherry's at 300 Park Avenue was among plans filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings. The air - conditioned structure will contain 500,000 square feet of rentable space and will cost about $9,000,000.

A change in Federal Tariff Commission practices, by which it would officially announce the exact date it forwards to the President reports recommending quotas or higher duties on a particular import is being advocated by importers, key trade sources disclosed yesterday.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 4 (AP) -- Noel Brown, former professional from Los Angeles, and Keith Self of La Mesa, Calif., scored first-round upsets in the twenty-sixth Eastern grass courts championships today at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

The theft of jewelry valued at $10,000 to $15,000 from the Lombardy Hotel suite of Mr. and Mrs. Leopold Cecil was reported at 4 P. M. yesterday to the police of the East Fifty-first Street station. The robbery was believed to have taken place between 3 P. M. and midnight on Sunday.
CAIRO, Aug. 4 -- The Egyptian Cabinet approved tonight two decrees designed to give legislative teeth to its anti-corruption drive.

The long sweater bodice molding the torso and emphasizing the hipline is an outstanding theme of Jacques Griffes' collection. Worn with a slender skirt, it has long tight sleeves and a high close collar. It is most original as well as sporty in emerald green boucle with bushy wool fringe about the hips and a black skirt.
SEOUL, Tuesday, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Two waves of Allied fighter-bombers blasted a North Korean military headquarters yesterday in the latest concentrated raid on the Pyongyang area.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- A high Republican strategist today lined up Senators William E. Jenner of Indiana, Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin, James P. Kem of Missouri and John W. Bricker of Ohio to answer Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson's challenge to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's "great crusade."

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 4 -- The Iranian Senate rebelled today against the Chamber of Deputies' bill to confiscate the $8,000,000 to $9,000,000 fortune of Ahmad Ghavam, Premier for four days recently. The measure was sent to committee after only three of the twenty-seven Senators present had voted for it on the second reading. There are fifty-seven Senators, but most were absent.

PRINCETON, N. J., Aug. 4 -- The appointment of eleven persons to select the recipients of the Rockefeller Public Service Awards was announced here today by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University. The awards will permit outstanding Federal employes to take six months to a year's leave of absence for study of educational travel.

Perils incurred by pedestrians who wish to board and leave buses on Third Avenue were outlined yesterday by the Lexington-First Avenue Association. Accident data indicate that an average of one person a day is injured at the junction with East Forty-second Street.

Dr. Louis Finkelstein, chancellor of the Jewish Theological Seminary, outlined yesterday a program through which, he explained, scholars and men of affairs could contribute materially to the security and stability of the free world.
Timed to add a fresh note to the midsummer table setting are some new Italian bowls and plates. Fruits and vegetables are the inspiration for this collection, which is at Bloomingdale's.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Aug. 4 (AP) -- Two Californians, 18-year-old Julia Sampson of San Marino, seeded first, and 15-year-old Dennis Bradshaw of San Diego gained the quarter-final round of the Eastern grass court junior girls' tennis championship today at the Nassau Country Club.
WITH the first hay crop in and the dry weather slowing the new clover and alfafa, the woodchucks are finding the cover rather thin, and varmint shooters are turning in better scores than usual.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 4 -- Dr. Abraham L. Robinson, librarian and Professor of Chemistry of the University of Pittsburgh, where he had been a faculty member for twenty-six years, was found dead in his apartment here this afternoon, an apparent suicide. He was 49 years old.

A hunt for the 5,500 "missing" stockholders of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, once one of the nation's largest public utility holding companies, soon will be brought to a successful conclusion. The Tracers Company of America, which specializes in locating missing persons, reported yesterday that the search for "lost" C. S. shareholders extended to the forty-eight states, Canada and fifteen foreign countries.

MOSCOW, Aug. 4 -- The Russian newspaper Pravda today proclaimed the world superiority of Soviet athletes, asserting that the Soviet Union amassed a larger total point score than any other nation and also won more medals than anyone else in the 1952 Olympic Games that ended at Helsinki, Finland, yesterday.

Has anyone read a good book lately? The Magazine Advertising Bureau holds that people are reading more magazines, as shown by the increase in magazine circulation and the fact that in 1951 nearly 4,000,000,000 copies of magazines were sold in more than 108,000 retail outlets.

Eddie Gard, former Long Island University basketball player who served as an intermediary between gamblers and college players, has been released from Rikers Island Penitentiary after serving nine months of an indeterminate sentence up to three years.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -Senator John J,. Williams, Republican of Delaware, has asked President Truman to let him look over the personnel files and income tax records of some Internal Revenue Bureau employes who, Mr. Williams suspects, are involved in tax collection scandals.

Two men who escaped from the Matteawan State Hospital for the Criminal Insane were held without bail yesterday in Brooklyn Felony Court for a hearing next Wednesday on charges of kidnapping, robbery, assault, grand larceny and carrying a dangerous weapon.

LONDON, Aug. 5 -- Britain demanded of Japan today that she hand over two British sailors imprisoned earlier in the day by the Japanese civil court. The demand was put by Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden to Shunichi Matsumoto, Japanese Ambassador.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 5 (AP) -- Stockholders of the Southern Pacific Company at a special meeting today approved a proposal to double the number of authorized shares, paving the way for a 2-for-1 stock split. When this becomes effective, Southern Pacific will have a total of 11,889,036 authorized shares without par value.
STYLE, said Buffon, is the man himself (le style, c'est l'homme meme). By that he meant that the way a person expressed himself in writing reflected his character.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 5 (AP) -- The fourteen seeded players remaining in the twenty-sixth Eastern grass courts championships at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club moved into the round of sixteen today without disturbance although three of them were extended to the limit of three sets.
ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 5 -- The people of Ireland will not rest until all of the country is under one government, Frank Aiken, Minister for External Affairs for Ireland, declared today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Roger L. Putnam, head of the Economic Stabilization Agency, today discounted the view that the price rise granted recently to steel mills would touch off a round of inflationary consumer price advances.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 5 -- Intervention by the United States in settling the future of the Saar is being discussed here largely because hopes are waning that France and West Germany can reach a solution acceptable to public opinion in both countries.

MOUNT WASHINGTON, N. J., Aug. 5 -- Mrs. Ann G. Meeker, who has been missing since last Friday when she went berry picking, was believed to have been seen near here twice today in a wood about twenty miles from where she had disappeared.
Active cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 27 to 45 points yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 5 -- Peak demand for training in technologies was reported here tonight at the fourth annual commencement of the Institute of Applied Arts and Sciences that the University of the State of New York operates on a temporary basis in Battle Hill School.
William H. Old has been appointed director of purchasing for the Babcock Wilcox Company, manufacturer of boilers and heavy tubing.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 5 -- A group of striking warehousemen at the Army's Claremont Terminal who have been picketing intermittently since July 24 voted tonight to reinstate picket lines that had been called off yesterday and today.
CHICAGO, Aug. 5 -- The International Harvester Company closed its twine mill today to prevent new violence such as occurred yesterday when pickets fought policemen.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 5 -- After sixteen boards of play at the Sheraton-Gibson Hotel today, the contract bridge team of Howard Schenken, B. Jay Becker, Samuel Stayman and George Rapee, all of New York, together with John R. Crawford of Philadelphia, had amassed a lead of 1820 points over Alvin Landy and Sol Mogal of New York with Jeff Glick of Miami Shores and Arthur Goldsmith of Cleveland.

The United Defense Fund, formed less than two years ago, has performed outstanding work in coordinating the financing of health, recreation and welfare organizations serving the national defense effort. Its program of cooperation among these varied agencies has both avoided duplication and made sure that no needs have been overlooked.

Radioteletype service to the leading newspapers and radio stations of Latin America and the West Indies was started yesterday by The Associated Press to provide faster and more complete news reports to members in that region. They have been receiving the news by Morse wireless.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, branded as "a fraud on the American people" today the statement by sixteen Republicans Sunday that Presidential and Congressional victories for their party would accelerate enactment of a Fair Employment Practices Act with enforcement powers.
Your editorial page of Aug. 1 carried two delightful items of nostalgic rebellion against nature and civilization.

OXFORD, England, Aug. 5 (Reuters) -- Members of the large American contingent attending the Quakers World Conference here spoke up last night against unequal distribution of wealth and power, many criticizing the United States.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The Soviet Government has charged that the suspension by the State Department of the magazine U. S. S. R. Information Bulletin in the United States was an effort to prevent the dissemination here of "truthful information about the Soviet Union."

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Sweden sent two more strong protests to Russia today and said she would send to the United Nations a full account of her quarrel with the Soviet Union over the shooting down of two unarmed Swedish planes last June.

Drop-in guests are, on the whole, very pleasant things as well as being people, and, speaking generally, their visits should be encouraged. When the temperature is in the nineties, however, when the humidity forms a liquid in the saltcellar, it is permissible to set down an exception to this rule.

The aluminum industry in this country produced 17 per cent more of the vital metal in the first half of 1952 than it did in the first six months of 1943, when World War II production was at its peak, the Aluminum Association announced yesterday.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 5 -- When rain bucketed onto the Saratoga Association's old cavalry post shortly after 1 P. M. today, it appeared certain that Greentree Stable's Tom Fool, the champion 2-year-old of 1951, would be scratched from the twenty-third running of the Wilson Stakes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan today called upon state agriculture mobilization committees to report at once any "spot" shortages of tin cans in their areas that might endanger the packing of perishable foods.

On net sales of $83,015,391, the Admiral Corporation, makers of radio and television sets, refrigerators, ranges and related products, had net earnings of $2,523,355 equal to $1.31 a share in the first six months this year, according to the report issued yesterday by Ross D. Siragusa, president.
